title: Boris Yeltsin, Russian Reformer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Seagram Expands Grey Assignment
description: Seagram Americas has expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising in New York by naming the agency to handle creative and media assignments for Seagram's VO Canadian whisky, American media services for Seagram's 7 Crown whisky and electronic media buying for most of its spirits brands. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Wilde's Antics: Victorians Were Only Half-Amused
description: ''Wilde'' is the kind of film biography that finds Oscar Wilde in an art gallery, thoughtfully weighing the difference between an aging woman and her likeness as a beautiful young girl. His novel ''The Picture of Dorian Gray'' is a fait accompli in the very next scene. As written by Julian Mitchell (''Another Country'') and directed by Brian Gilbert (''Tom and Viv''), ''Wilde'' has a cursorily informative style that would be perfect for the classroom, if the film didn't also frankly depict Wilde's sexual affairs with fetching young men. As in ''Tom and Viv,'' there is the sense that a literary legend (T. S. Eliot) has come alive, however tenderly, to teach the audience a sort of lesson.

title: Calm Returns to Brawley Case, But Punished Lawyer Doesn't
description: A day after the judge in the Tawana Brawley defamation case sent a defense lawyer to jail overnight for contempt of court, calm returned to the courtroom and the trial resumed its glacial pace.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I want you to know that the office of Independent Counsel can indict my dog. They can indict my cat. But I'm not going to lie about the President, I'm not going to lie about the First Lady, or anyone else.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, NORMAN L.
description: SCHWARTZ-Norman L. On April 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Shirley. Adored father of Marjorie Steinmann, and Lynda and David Brokman. Grandfather of Darryl and Lauren Schaffer, Matthew, Andrew and Jonathan Brokman. Private services were held.

title: Frances Sonz, 84, Painter and Art Teacher
description: Frances B. Sonz, a retired painter and art teacher in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., died on April 12 at her home in Tiburon, Calif., where she had lived for 10 years. She was 84.

title: What's Wrong With Preparing for Adulthood?; The Diet Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Wrong With Preparing for Adulthood?
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Wrong With Preparing for Adulthood?
description: To the Editor:

title: District Thaws to School Superintendent
description: AT first, she was simply a curiosity. Children, fascinated by her green eyes, would demand to know whether she was masquerading behind contact lenses. Some called her ''Mrs. Clinton,'' as if any white woman walking through the neighborhood had to be on some kind of White House fact-finding tour.

title: Village Neighbors Welcome Noise Crackdown
description: To the Editor:

title: Before Celebrating a Nation, Remember the 20,000 Soldiers Who Died Defending It
description: The transition was purposefully awkward. Israel's Independence Day, the year's most joyous, follows directly on Memorial Day, its most painful. And since a day in the Jewish calendar starts the previous evening and ends at sundown, Israel's 50th birthday party -- the fireworks, the street music, the dancing -- took off at sundown on Wednesday after 24 hours of wrenching commemoration for the more than 20,000 soldiers who have fallen in battle.

title: BELCO TO GET 80% STAKE IN CANADIAN ENERGY COMPANY
description: The Belco Oil and Gas Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire an 80 percent interest in Big Bear Exploration Ltd., a Canadian oil and gas company, for $141 million. Belco, based in New York, is an independent energy company. Big Bear is based in Calgary, Alberta. Under the agreement, Belco is to buy $10.5 million of Big Bear preferred stock for 85 cents a share. If converted to common stock, the preferred shares would represent 24 percent of Big Bear. Belco will also buy up to $120 million of stock rights and will receive an option to buy an additional $10.5 million of Big Bear convertible preferred shares. If fully exercised, Belco's stock rights and convertible preferred shares would give it about 80 percent ownership of Big Bear.

title: White Youths Get Maximum In Beating Of Black Man
description: In the acrimonious conclusion of a trial that exposed underlying racial tensions between two Brooklyn neighborhoods, three Carroll Gardens teen-agers were sentenced yesterday to the maximum prison term of three and a half to seven years for the September assault of a 27-year-old black man from Red Hook.

title: Leslie Stevens, 74, Entertainment Producer, Director and Writer
description: Leslie Stevens, a writer, director and producer who achieved success on Broadway, in Hollywood and on television with plays like ''The Marriage-Go-Round,'' films like ''The Left-Handed Gun'' and television series like ''The Outer Limits,'' died on April 24 in Los Angeles. He was 74.

title: Last-Minute Change Imperils Auto Insurance Compromise
description: Only days after the State Senate and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman celebrated a hard-won compromise on an auto-insurance plan, the measure was at risk of unraveling over last-minute wording inserted in the bill that could make new legislation necessary.

title: U.S. Catholics and the Annulment Dilemma
description: The decision of a Roman Catholic school in Cortland Manor, N.Y., to dismiss Jeanne Hearty, a gifted and popular teacher, because of her marriage to a divorced Episcopalian is only the latest example of the problems surrounding remarriage in the American Catholic Church.

title: Kile Leaves The Mets Tumbling: 5 in a Row
description: As a free agent last winter, Darryl Kile made it quite clear that he did not want to pitch in New York. In one sense, considering the success the 29-year-old right-hander has had against the Mets, it is fairly easy to understand why.

title: Pas de Quatre: Hopes of Spring
description: Every ballet season has its triumphs and disappointments. But one thing is sure. In each new season, a few young dancers will blossom as artists.

title: City Takeover Looms for Gardens on Vacant Lots
description: In a city woefully short of both open space and affordable housing, Giuliani administration officials are taking steps to create more housing at the expense of some rare patches of greenery.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: Theater

title: Clinton Is 'Encouraged' by Iraqi Progress on Arms Inspections
description: President Clinton said today that he was encouraged by Iraqi cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors and that he expected to reduce the number of American troops who are now deployed in the Persian Gulf region to keep watch on Iraq.

title: Executive Changes
description: PAN AM CORP., Miami, said that David A. Banmiller had resigned as president and chief executive of the company and its Pan American World Airways unit. Robert Mencel was named general manager, with responsibility for day-to-day activities. Mr. Mencel joined Carnival Air Lines in April 1992 and remained director of operations after Pan Am acquired Carnival last September.

title: Sound of the Mainstream From Low-Profile Players
description: Emanuel Rueffler's set at Smalls on Tuesday night could be taken as a sign of the state of jazz, a sort of canary in jazz's mine shaft. Mr. Rueffler, a young German pianist, convened a group of some of the better second-level players in New York -- including E. J. Allen on trumpet, Eric Person on saxophone, Jerome Harris on bass and Gene Jackson on drums -- to play his compositions. It was mainstream music, without much pretension, played by people without much of a public image. It was the average; and the average, in this case, was being played at an extremely high level.

title: 'Springer' Producers To Reduce Violence
description: The producers of ''The Jerry Springer Show'' agreed yesterday to eliminate all physical violence from the raucous daytime talk show starting on June 8, taking a step toward toning down the very behavior that has made the show notorious and has sent its Nielsen ratings soaring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCUDDER, LOUISE FRY
description: SCUDDER-Louise Fry. Of Gulfstream, FL. and Lake Placid, New York. Died on April 28 at age 78 following a courageous battle with cancer. She was an enthusiastic volunteer for many charitable organizations. She was the beloved wife of Edward W. Scudder. Devoted mother of Katherine (Tiballi), Mary Gale, Edward and Robert. Survivors also include eight grandchildren. A memorial service in Lake Placid will be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering or the University of South Carolina.

title: U.S. Economy Grew at Brisk Pace This Winter Despite Crisis in Asia
description: The economy grew at a surprisingly strong pace this winter, and inflation remained unexpectedly subdued, the Government reported yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday about a campaign by California utility regulators to tell consumers about deregulation misspelled the name of the Mad magazine character whose slogan ''What, me worry?'' was invoked by a critic of the campaign. It is Alfred E. Neuman, not Newman.

title: Keeping Turkey Secular
description: To the Editor:

title: Boris Yeltsin, Russian Reformer?
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: 2 Companies in Deal With Prime Advisors
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation and the NAC Re Corporation said today that they had each agreed to purchase stakes in the privately held asset management firm Prime Advisors Inc.

title: Next Stop, Murals; Change Here for Uptown Sculpture
description: ''Blooming'' it is. Bloom it does.

title: Village Neighbors Welcome Noise Crackdown
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROH, EDWARD JR., DMD
description: STROH-Edward Jr., DMD. April 29, 1998. Age 89. Graduate of University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine. Formerly Chief of Dentistry and Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery at Metropolitan Hospital Center and St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center.

title: Metro Business; SPX Begins Echlin Offer
description: The SPX Corporation formally began yesterday its exchange offer to take over Echlin Inc., the auto parts maufacturer based in Branford, Conn.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'New Work, New Visions, Part II'

title: Randomness, Luck and Fate, but Whew, No Bears
description: A WIDOW FOR ONE YEAR

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: At the Movies; 'Be Prepared. This Film Bites.'
description: Sanity has never held much appeal for Terry Gilliam.

title: Widen Doors Into Public Housing; Assisted Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares of EMI Rise as It Says Talks May Lead to Merger
description: The shares of EMI Group P.L.C., the troubled British music company, soared yesterday after it confirmed recent speculation that it was in talks that might lead to an offer for the company.

title: At Last, Things Were Going Well; or So He Thought
description: When life starts going well for Nick Cameron early in ''Go Now,'' he looks grateful enough to suggest that this is the first time. Nick, played by Robert Carlyle of ''The Full Monty,'' is seen carousing fraternally with members of his soccer team (which happens to be called the Monts) and gratefully falling in love with a soul mate named Karen (Juliet Aubrey). The film emphasizes the physicality of both sex and soccer to show how robustly Nick enjoys his new-found happiness. And then it takes that happiness away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRALLE, JOSEPH B. 2ND
description: CRALLE-Joseph B. 2nd. Resident for 28 years of Upper Montclair, NJ, since 1980 of the Tides Lodge area of Virgina, died April 28 after a long illness. Betty Robb Cralle, his wife of 43 years, died in 1989, second wife Marguerite Houle Walton survives him, along with sons Jay, David & granddaughter Katharine. The family prefers that memorial contributions by friends be directed to charities of their own choosing or to Historic Christ Church Foundation, Irvington, Virginia 22480.

title: Cabbies Say Tougher Rules Are Unfair
description: The taxi drivers who stood around in the rain yesterday waiting for fares at La Guardia Airport greeted the news that the city plans to crack down on the taxi industry with the sort of reaction they usually reserve for flat tires, gridlock and passengers who stiff them.

title: CBS Reports Quarterly Profit On Strong Advertising Sales
description: The CBS Corporation said yesterday that it had a profit in the first quarter as the Winter Olympics and the strong economy lifted advertising sales at its television and radio stations.

title: Ferraro Restricts Routine Inspection of Tax Returns
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro made her 1997 tax returns available for public inspection yesterday afternoon, but imposed extraordinary restrictions on what has become a routine event for most politicians: Reporters were provided two sets of the returns to examine for precisely three hours before an aide who monitored the inspection retrieved the documents.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL ATLANTIC BUYS NINE PROPERTIES
description: Security Capital Atlantic Inc. said yesterday that it had bought nine apartment complexes in North and South Carolina for $161.5 million from the closely held Charter Properties Inc., increasing its holdings by about 9 percent. The properties contain about 2,384 apartments. Security Capital Atlantic, based in Atlanta, owns 22,181 apartments throughout the Southeast and has 5,567 more under development. Its shares rose 12.5 cents, to $22.0625. Earlier this month, Security Capital Atlantic agreed to merge with a sister company, Security Capital Pacific Trust, in a transaction valued at about $1.6 billion.

title: School Board Renews Contract Of Leader Crew Once Rejected
description: Nearly a year after Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew questioned her ability to run a Queens school district and agreed to only a provisional contract, Claire McIntee was unanimously approved last night as the Superintendent of Community School District 26 for another two years.

title: Unsettling Fantasies That Comment on Popular Culture
description: In ''Percussion for Jelly Beans and Gumdrops With Solo Broom,'' a 1975 performance piece by Sandy Skoglund, 50 pounds of jelly beans and gumdrops were kicked around a floor, then swept across it, using a broom as paintbrush in what Ms. Skoglund called ''a parody of Abstract Expressionism.''

title: U.S. SET TO BACK $1 BILLION OUTLAY TO AID INDONESIA
description: The United States is preparing to back a $1 billion payment in international emergency aid to Indonesia on Monday, despite evidence that President Suharto's family and friends are continuing to undermine efforts to break up the multibillion-dollar monopolies they control.

title: The Thrill of the Game
description: With ''He Got Game,'' Spike Lee returns full blast to what he does best. Basketball, bold urban landscapes, larger-than-life characters and red-hot visual pyrotechnics bring jolts to a film that also features DENZEL WASHINGTON (left) in a splendid performance and the N.B.A. star Ray Allen as his son. Stunningly photographed, it asks whether the father can hitch his future to his son's triumphant career, or whether the son must make sacrifices for his father. Yet again, Mr. Lee makes a film that might as well have been called ''Do the Right Thing.''

title: Shoppers Are Starting to See Lower Prices on Asian Goods
description: The signals may be small -- a pink T-shirt here, a baby's rattle there -- but shoppers are starting to see price savings in a number of goods as a result of the protracted financial crisis in Asia.

title: U.S. Report Calls Iran No. 1 Terror Sponsor, Despite New Leader
description: Iran remains ''the most active state sponsor of terrorism'' despite last year's election of a more moderate President, the State Department said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELLER, PETER, SR.
description: FELLER-Peter, Sr. Memorial at The Winter Garden Theatre, Broadway and 50 Street, New York City at 1 PM, Friday, May 1.

title: Provocative Arms Sales by Russia
description: No longer sustained by captive markets and client states, Russian arms designers and manufacturers are selling their wares to anyone willing to pay. Recent days have brought word that Russian enterprises are helping Iran, India and the Greek Cypriot Government develop or buy new missiles. In each case, the missiles could alter the balance of military power in a highly volatile region where armed conflict between neighbors has occurred in the past and could again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMPSON, HARVEY E.
description: SAMPSON-Harvey E. Cornell University mourns the loss of Trustee Emeritus and Presidential Councillor, Harvey E. Sampson, a member of the Class of '51, served the University in numerous capacities; as trustee for nineteen years, life member and chair of the University Council, chair of the Cornell Medical College Board of Overseers and of the New York Hospital-Cornell Joint Board and foremost benefactor to the University. He was a member of the nationally ranked football teams of 1948, 1949, and 1950, receiving United Press All-East honorable mention as an end in 1950. He served in the U.S. Army as a first lieutenant in the Korean conflict. A visionary entrepreneur & pioneer in the marketing and distribution of high technology electronic equipment and components to the broadcast industry, he placed his vast skills and knowledge at the service of Cornell and in support of interests as diverse as athletics, ornithology, medicine, art, and music. He served the larger community as director of the Cayuga Medical Center, and the Boyce Thompson Institute, director of Weiss, Peck and Greer Mutual Funds, and governor of the Audio Engineering Society. He was revered for his devotion, for his unflagging enthusiasm and keen insight, and for his good counsel. His charm, grace, intellect, and wit endeared him to all who knew him and made him an extraordinarily effective advocate for Cornell. We share with his wife, Carolyn, and their six children, a profound sense of loss at the passing of one of Cornell's most honored and respected alumni. He will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held May 11 at 4 P.M. in Sage chapel on the Cornell University campus, Ithaca, New York. Harold Tanner, Chairman Cornell University Bd of Trustees Hunter R. Rawlings, III President, Cornell University

title: A Spike Lee Explosion Roams All Over the Court
description: ''He Got Game'' is a Spike Lee Joint that deserves to be a Spike Lee hit, long overdue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIER, MILTON
description: BIER-Milton. On April 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Ted and Paula, Errol and Nancy and Laurie and Jerry Gelles. Cherished grandfather of Jeffrey, Craig and Holli, Robert, Jessica, Jordan, Alissa and Rebecca Mark. Fond brother of Abe and Charlie. Funeral services today at 2 PM at the Schwartz Brothers/ Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 76 Rd, Forest Hills. Interment Wellwood cemetery.

title: Degas, the Derby and Equestrian Motion
description: Mint juleps and millinery aside, tomorrow's Kentucky Derby should last a little longer than two minutes, a visual tangle of 3-year-old thoroughbreds careening around a mile-and-a-quarter track. Except in slow motion, the movement of the horses' legs -- the pattern in which the footfalls actually occur -- is almost impossible to decipher. No one depicted it accurately, in fact, until 1887, when Eadweard Muybridge published ''Animal Locomotion,'' a collection of stop-motion photographs that showed exactly how a horse places its hooves when it walks, trots, canters and gallops.

title: Man Arrested After Pipe Bomb and Guns Are Found in Manhattan Apartment
description: After an hourlong standoff with the police, a 23-year-old man was arrested at his apartment in upper Manhattan yesterday and a homemade pipe bomb, two machine guns and a rifle were recovered from a closet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, MAX (BORN BREJENSKY)
description: BARRETT-Max (Born Brejensky) in Brooklyn, NY age 75. Died April 27, 1998 in Cammarillo, CA. Interred at Beth David Cemetery.

title: British Aerospace to Buy A 35% Stake in Saab
description: The consolidation of Europe's military and aerospace industries continued yesterday with news that British Aerospace P.L.C. would acquire a 35 percent interest in Saab A.B., the aerospace unit of Investor A.B. British Aerospace said it would pay $450 million in cash to Investor for 35.1 percent of Saab's shares.

title: Yanks and Baseball Settle Suit
description: The Yankees and Adidas dropped their antitrust suit against Major League Baseball yesterday. As a major part of the agreement, baseball reinstated George Steinbrenner to its executive council.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in some copies yesterday about a suit by employees of the Trump Plaza casino in Atlantic City over secondhand smoke misidentified the defendant. Only tobacco companies are being sued, not the casino itself.

title: Widen Doors Into Public Housing; Bad Zoning Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoking Field Trips
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cat-and-Mouse Game Amid Epic Turbulence
description: Long before Jean Valjean ever sang a Broadway ballad, there was a tradition of serious literary adaptation to which the new film version of ''Les Miserables'' belongs. With a first-rate cast and a venerable storytelling style, it fluently condenses Victor Hugo's epic novel and retrieves some of its suspenseful momentum. As directed by Bille August with such sturdy, all-purpose erudition that Hugo occasionally plays like Dickens, it visits the familiar high points of a very famous story and bestows them with both classical and contemporary overtones. The tale remains fresh, headgear a la Bonaparte notwithstanding.

title: Earnings at MCI Fall 48 Percent
description: The profit of the MCI Communications Corporation fell 48 percent in the first quarter, but the decline was less than expected as the company sold more profitable data services and turned in its strongest growth in phone traffic in almost two years.

title: LYCOS BUYS A MAKER OF CUSTOMIZED SEARCH SOFTWARE
description: The Internet search directory Lycos Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the Wisewire Corporation, whose software allows Internet users to do customized searches, for $39.75 million in stock. Wisewire, a closely held company based in Pittsburgh, makes software that searches Web sites and picks out areas preferred by a user. That allows users to cut the time spent searching for information. Share of Lycos rose $6.125 each, or 11 percent, to $61.8125. Lycos, based in Framingham, Mass., ranked eighth in March among Internet users, according to Media Metrix, which tracks Internet use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAFFNEY, JOSEPH N.
description: GAFFNEY-Joseph N., 66, of Lavallette, NJ formerly of Medham, NJ died on Wednesday at his home. Beloved husband of Mary Elizabeth (nee Duffy). Father of Nicholas, Brian, Paul, Kathleen Thometz and Janna Gaffney. Grandfather of five grandchildren. Brother of Virginia Cooney, Joan Price and Barbara Gillman. Relatives and friends are respectively invited to attend the funeral on Saturday from The Timothy E. Ryan Home for Funerals, 706 Highway 35 North, Lavallette, NJ at 10:30am thence to St. Bonaventure RC Church, Lavallette, NJ at 11:30am where a Mass of Christian Burial will be offered. Burial to follow at St. Ann's Cemetery, Wall Township, NJ. Viewing Friday 2-4 & 7-9 pm at the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations to ''The Joseph Gaffney Memorial Scholarship Fund'' and make your check payable to St. Joseph's Church, 6 New Street, Mendham, NJ 07945.

title: A.B.L. Prepares For Its Draft
description: Of the 98 players eligible for the Women's National Basketball Association draft on Wednesday, only 40 were taken. Some of the bypassed players will be eligible for next Tuesday's draft of the rival American Basketball League.

title: CSX Sells a Rail Line
description: The CSX Corporation said today that it had sold a 51-mile rail line in Michigan to the Saginaw Valley Railway Company unit of Rail America Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Saginaw Valley will immediately start rail service on the line, which runs from just east of Saginaw to Brown City, Mich. Saginaw Valley expects to move several thousand carloads of commodities annually on the line. RailAmerica, based in Boca Raton, and CSX, based in Richmond, are railroad companies.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN WEAKENS. Japan's currency eased on increased demand for dollars as United States stock and bond markets rallied on news of a strong economy. In New York the dollar settled at 132.72 yen, up from 132.36.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: David Smith

title: Brain Risks For Athletes Are Detailed
description: At every level, from children's teams to professional leagues, athletes who suffer concussions are frequently allowed to resume playing too soon, doctors said today. Returning to sports too early leaves athletes vulnerable to devastating brain damage from a second blow, even a seemingly minor one, the doctors said.

title: City's Acting Drug Prosecutor To Take Over Top Post Today
description: Unlike a burglary committed in a single building, a drug felony can entail smuggling heroin or cocaine into Manhattan, distributing it in Queens or the Bronx and selling the drugs on the streets of Brooklyn or Staten Island, breaking the law in more than one borough.

title: Spicy Fare
description: Sometimes your mouth wants a jolt of heat, the kind that makes the lips burn. It's not easy to find. Even cuisines known for their spiciness are often tamed at restaurants trying to anticipate mainstream American tastes. While these 12 restaurants are known to unleash the power of hot peppers, it still helps to make clear your preferences. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATTI, NICHOLAS
description: GATTI-Nicholas. Of Staten Island, N.Y. Educator and Supervisor at P.S. 250K. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Father of Lucille Indik. Adored grandfather and great grandfather.

title: Yeltsin's New Outsider Team: Young, Reformist and Green
description: It was a month in the making, but President Boris N. Yeltsin has assembled a new team that is strikingly young, pro-reform and from outside Moscow.

title: Excerpts From Clinton's News Conference on Investigations and Middle East
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Emergency Aid Wins Approval From Congress
description: Congressional Republicans stared down the Clinton Administration today, passing a $6 billion emergency spending bill and winning President Clinton's promise to sign it, even though it failed to provide money he had sought to replenish the International Monetary Fund.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Kent Bellows

title: Coming Soon to a Mini-Van Near You
description: WHATEVER happened to license plate bingo? Now, children are entertained in cars by video games and compact disks. And as auto makers seek new ways to set their vehicles apart from competitors', they are offering more features to entertain children -- insuring a peaceful ride for parents.

title: Film in Review
description: 'Didn't Do It for Love'

title: Brodeur and Gilmour Drive the Devils
description: So how could the Devils change their luck, break out of a slump and avoid elimination from the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight against the Ottawa Senators?

title: Where Flag Is Green, And People Are Angry
description: At the end of an orchard-lined road leading to this Israeli Arab town northeast of Tel Aviv today, the sea of blue and white flags covering Israel on its 50th Independence Day abruptly receded.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Lost and Found'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, ALAN B., M.D.
description: LEVITT-Alan B., M.D., 66. Of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of Bronxville, NY, died April 28, 1998. Graduate of NYU, Class of 1952 and graduate of Univ. of Chicago Medical School, Class of 1956. Longtime surgeon at New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. Member of American Board of Surgery, American Board of Thoracic Surgery, Westchester County Medical Society, Florida Medical Association & Martin County (FL) Medical Society. Husband of Dorothy Levitt. Father of David Levitt, of NYC, Andrea (& husband Jim) Bonfils, of Darien, CT., and Wendy (and husband Andrew) Kagan, of Newport, RI. Stepfather of Ralph (& wife Robyn) Mazzoni, of New Rochelle. Grandfather of Zachary Kagan, Alexandra Bonfils & Mark Mazzoni. Graveside services at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY on Sunday, May 3 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice of Martin & St. Luci, Inc, 2030 S.E. Ocean Blvd, Stuart, FL 34996 preferred by the family.

title: U.S. Pressing European Union to Be More Friendly to Turkey
description: Senior diplomats from the United States are engaged in an intense effort to persuade the European Union to adopt a more conciliatory policy toward Turkey, diplomats involved in the effort say.

title: G.E. Hangar Plan Is Blocked in Court
description: A justice in State Supreme Court in White Plains yesterday blocked a proposal by General Electric to build a $20 million hangar for company jets at the Westchester County Airport, lawyers for both sides in the case said.

title: Kodak and Intel In Imaging Deal
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Intel Corporation said today that they would jointly develop and market digital imaging products in a move that may help Kodak cut losses in a business that caused its profits to fall in the last six quarters.

title: Favorable Government Data Spur a Treasury Securities Rally
description: After declining all week on fear of an overheating economy and higher interest rates, Treasury securities surged yesterday for their biggest rally in six months, reacting to Government data showing surprisingly low inflation.

title: TWO INSURANCE COMPANIES TO OFFER SOME CASH IN MERGER
description: Exel Ltd. and Mid Ocean Ltd., two insurers that were planning to merge in a stock swap, are now offering to pay some of their stockholders up to $300 million in cash for their shares. Exel, which owns 26.82 percent of Mid Ocean, is paying about $2.2 billion for the rest of the company. The latest move would give stockholders the option to receive cash for their shares instead of stock of the new company. If the $300 million limit is reached, Exel shareholders will get up to $204 million of the cash, and holders of Mid Ocean will be allowed $96 million. The amount shareholders will get for their stock will be calculated from the average price of Exel's shares in the 10 days before the merger. Both companies are based in Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Wednesday about fellowship awards by the Winston Churchill Foundation of the United States misstated the foundation's location. It is in New York, not in England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, BERNARD D.
description: BERNSTEIN-Bernard D. Beloved husband of Lorraine. Devoted father of Shari and Jon Meyer, Lisa, Craig, and the late Robert. Loving grandfather of Zachary and Ariella. Dear brother of Stanley and Charlotte, Corinne and Joe Glass. Services 10 A.M., Sunday at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: E. N. Hoffman, 79, Ad Executive And Avid Jazz Fan and Promoter
description: Edward N. Hoffman, an advertising executive for 50 years who never retired, died on April 23 in Chicago. He was 79 and had moved to Chicago last year from New Canaan, Conn.

title: On My Mind; Clinton's Fudge Factory
description: Now it is in print, and on tape. President Clinton says that when he judges it convenient his Administration deliberately evades carrying out an obligation at the heart of certain important Congressional laws. The question now is: What will Congress, courts or public opinion do about that?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEFFDING, HARALD O. (HOWDY)
description: HOEFFDING-Harald O. (Howdy) age 55, Clothing Designer. Mourned and loved by family and many friends whose lives were touched by his generosity of spirit and zest for life which he shared so freely and openly. Memorial service Monday, June 8, 4 P.M., Church of the Ascension, 5th Avenue and 10th Street.

title: Ex-Official Admits to Embezzlement and Payoffs to Assemblyman
description: A former official of what was once a powerful and politically connected social-services group pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing money from its government grants and using some of the money to make illegal payoffs to Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn.

title: Sports of The Times; Can Brodeur Survive Scorers' Slump?
description: THE Devils live. They go to Ottawa for tomorrow night's sixth game. But even with their 3-1 victory last night, their future remains in jeopardy because their four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup playoff series remains a mystery: The Case of the Missing Goals.

title: A Day at Sea: New Pals, and Fish That Don't Always Get Away
description: Charter fishing brings out camaraderie. Maybe it's the silliness of trying to drag in an unseen fish from unknown depths. Or maybe the sense of detachment from the worries of the land. At any rate, on a recent trip at the beginning of the charter season, it got to be giddy fun.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury Building Hopes to Lure Tenants to Bustling 57th Street
description: After a year and a half scouring Manhattan for a rental apartment, Jorge Schaulsohn recently found what he was looking for: a two-bedroom unit in the 34-story luxury building nearing completion at 150 East 57th Street. The building will have 145 apartments that rent for $2,550 to $30,000 a month, which rental brokers say sets a benchmark for apartments that are not in the most prime of residential locations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FRANCES (NEE MERSEL)
description: COHEN-Frances (nee Mersel). April 28. Beloved wife of the late Reuben. Loving mother of David (Janet), Arthur (Susan), Paul (Clare), Michael (Nancy). Cherished grandmother of Gary, Risa, Sharon, Cheryl, Gail, Marjorie, Ross, and Lindsey. Adored greatgrandmother of Nathaniel and Julia. sister of Michael, Ruth Rubin, Albert and Lily Brill.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Dalai Lama's visit to New York City misstated the day of his meeting with physicians at Beth Israel Medical Center about meditation. It is Tuesday, not Monday.

title: In About-Face, NBC Is Marketing Its Wares With Toll-Free Number
description: Adopting a practice that the networks have long disdained, NBC has taken the first steps toward establishing a regular business in direct marketing to television viewers through toll-free phone numbers, a segment of the industry previously relegated mainly to cable channels and public television.

title: TAX SCHEME CITED
description: Webster L. Hubbell, the longtime confidant of President Clinton and former law partner of Hillary Rodham Clinton, was indicted today on charges of tax evasion that included failure to pay taxes and penalties of more than $850,000 over the past four years.

title: Province Healthcare Deal
description: The Province Healthcare Corporation has agreed to buy an Arizona hospital for $105.5 million, adding to the eight hospitals in four states it now owns or leases. Province will buy Havasu Samaritan Regional Hospital in Lake Havasu City from the Phoenix-based Samaritan Health System. The hospital had about $55 million in revenue in its last fiscal year, while Province had 1997 revenue of $170.5 million.

title: Letter by Industry Executives Backs Microsoft
description: In the strongest show of support to date for the embattled Microsoft Corporation, 26 computer industry executives have written to the Justice Department saying that any delay in the introduction of Windows 98 will harm the computer industry.

title: U.S.-China Talks Make Little Progress on Summit Agenda
description: After two days of talks with Chinese leaders, American officials said today that there had been only limited progress on agreeing on key issues for President Clinton's summit meeting here in eight weeks.

title: Steinbrenner Delays Move On Stadium
description: Concerned about the intense political maneuvering over whether -- and where -- to build a new stadium for the New York Yankees, George M. Steinbrenner 3d will not make a decision about the ball club's future home until after the baseball season ends in the fall, his advisers say.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: New Video Releases
description: Alien Resurrection

title: Europe's Colossal Coin Toss
description: This weekend in Brussels, Europe will ratify its greatest gamble ever: a common money without a common government. Come next Jan. 1, the currencies of 11 European Union member states will be irrevocably chained to each other; come Jan. 1, 2002, marks, guilders and francs will be history. There will be only euros and cents.

title: Texas Utilities Wins Fight for Energy Group
description: Ending one of the longest and costliest takeover battles ever in the utility industry, the Texas Utilities Company won the Energy Group P.L.C. of Britain yesterday after another American utility company, Pacificorp, said that it would not try to exceed the $7.4 billion bid.

title: Euro Isn't Sovereign
description: To the Editor:

title: Tender Witness to the Togetherness of People in Want
description: Socially engaged, humanistic photography has a long and densely textured history in the United States, one marked by a constant tension between objectivity and empathy, idea and sentiment, the polemical urge and the personal touch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, JULIE
description: GOODMAN-Julie. Age 31, after her long and valiant fight, on April 29, 1998. Beloved daughter of Leni Goodman and Stuart Goodman. Loving sister of Cache. Dear niece of Joan L. Ellenbogen. Cherished granddaughter of Harriet Hecht Ellenbogen. Special friend of Lynette Gerald and her loving family of ''Patterners''. Services on Friday, 12 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Keep Young Nets Intact, Jordan Advises Owners
description: It was the early morning, not long after the Nets' season ended and Jayson Williams found himself in a restaurant with Michael Jordan.

title: Green at Derby Gate: Fewer Starts for the Starters
description: When Indian Charlie, the morning-line favorite, enters the starting gate for the 124th Kentucky Derby on Saturday, he will be attempting to become the first horse in 83 years to win with no more than four career starts.

title: Sports of The Times; Once Again, Force Will Meet Force
description: THE scene was out of Pat Riley's worst nightmare, if not the twilight zone. Alonzo Mourning, a volatile man hanging on to his cool as if it were dear life, lost it at the worst of all moments last night. In the final two seconds of a game already lost, he was baited into a fistfight by a former teammate he does not like. Mourning and Larry Johnson erupted in a flurry of punches. The next voice we will hear will be that of Rod Thorn's.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP., Portland, Ore., a maker of metal parts for aircraft engines and industrial applications, is closing two plants and consolidating operations to cut down on expenses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Strength Without Inflation, Latest Data Show

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRISTINA, ANTHONY GEORGE, M.D.
description: GRISTINA-Anthony George, M.D., on Thursday, April 30, 1998, in the company of his wife and sons in his home in Reston, Va. He is survived by his wife Susan, four sons, Anthony, Andrew, Thomas and Frank, brother Jerome, Friends, students, colleagues and patients.

title: Film in Review
description: 'Parallel Sons'

title: Computer Hustlers, Horses and Helium
description: The ghosts of Swinging England who scurry through the recent romantic comedy ''Sliding Doors'' do a frenzied frug in ''Shooting Fish,'' Stefan Schwartz's effervescent farce about a pair of likable con men and their charming Girl Friday. This aggressively whimsical fairy tale about a pair of grown-up orphans who rob from the rich to give to the poor (themselves!) and end up living happily ever after darts forward so quickly that several major plot turns are dispensed with in 10 or 15 seconds of babble. Although the movie isn't literally sped up, it often feels that way. It runs on an attitude of breathless zaniness that leaves you no time to ponder what it all means or if it means anything at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUGHAN, JOHN H.
description: MAUGHAN-John H., 69. Of Tenafly, NJ and Chincoteague Island, Va., after a short illness. Survived by wife Sydney of Tenafly and daughter Jennifer of Manhattan. Retired Assistant Managing Editor of Business Week Magazine. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Virginia Coast Reserve, The Nature Conservancy, Brownsville, Nassawaddox, Virginia 23413.

title: Small Schools as an Investment
description: On the long road to education reform, the movement toward the creation of smaller schools has gotten some important new affirmation. A study by New York University researchers has found that alternative New York City high schools with fewer than 600 students, long thought to be a luxury, are actually somewhat more cost-effective in terms of producing graduates than bigger, traditional schools. While earlier studies on school size have tended to relate size separately either to educational effectiveness or to per-student costs, this study is one of the first to link size to both cost and educational outcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, DINAH
description: FELDMAN-Dinah. Widow of Mike. Mother of Arthur and Eleanor. Grandmother of Ellen, Jessica, Amy and Joanne. Greatgrandmother of Megan, David, Leslie, Daniel, Benjamin & Sarah. Died peacefully in her sleep in her ninety-eighth year on April 29th. She will be lovingly remembered.

title: Investec of South Africa Plans to Buy Hambros
description: Hambros P.L.C., the British merchant bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Investec Group Ltd. of South Africa for $:428 million, or $715 million. Hambros, founded in 1839, has generated lackluster profits in recent years and has been under stockholder pressure to improve the bottom line.

title: Clinton's Wide Web
description: As President, Bill Clinton has often agonized over using force. But tonight he presided over one of the most dramatic expansions of the American military umbrella in 50 years, as the Senate voted to approve his plan to bring Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into the NATO alliance.

title: Findings on Holtzman Campaign Violations Are Upheld
description: New York State's highest court today upheld an investigative panel's findings that Elizabeth Holtzman, the former New York City Comptroller, had violated the city's conflict-of-interest laws when she took a campaign loan from a bank trying to obtain city business.

title: Allied Domecq Seeking Liquor Business Partner
description: Posting better-than-expected first-half earnings, Allied Domecq P.L.C. said yesterday that it was still searching for a partner for its spirits business to help it compete with Diageo P.L.C., the world's biggest liquor maker.

title: Widen Doors Into Public Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: I.R.S. Abuses Detailed

title: ELECTRONIC RETAILING CALLS OFF ACQUISITION OF A RIVAL
description: Electronic Retailing International Inc., a developer of electronic shelf-labeling systems, said yesterday that it had canceled plans to acquire a Canadian competitor, Telepanel Systems Inc. The deal, valued at $67.4 million when it was announced in October, was expected to close early this year. In March, Electronic Retailing, based in Norwalk, Conn., said the planned merger did not qualify as a pooling of interests, failing to satisfy one of the conditions of the merger. Under a pooling of interests, the assets and liabilities on two companies' balance sheets are added together, item by item. Reported earnings are higher under this method of accounting, so most companies prefer it.

title: Boeing Wins U.S. Contract For Missile-Defense Testing
description: Fifteen years after President Ronald Reagan envisioned a national missile defense system that came to be known as ''Star Wars,'' the Pentagon took a large step today toward actually building one -- or, at least, a scaled-down version.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMERO, MARY SMITH ALLEN
description: ROMERO-Mary Smith Allen. On April 29th, 1998. Beloved wife of Rudy and loving mother of Dolores. Born on September 10, 1940 in Cleveland, Ohio, Mary was a dedicated nurse and consummate artist and wonderful friend. She is survived by her husband and daughter, three brothers Archibald, Thomas and Samuel and her sister Susan. We all mourn her loss.

title: Fees From Friends Bring Fresh Woes for Hubbell
description: Webster L. Hubbell's memoir, published last year, was called ''Friends in High Places.''

title: On the Screen, Images of New York
description: Even New York's proudest citizens must feel it sometimes: the sneaking feeling that the city's real life is incomplete. So much of this city exists as fabulous celluloid figments of our imagination that the actual place is bound to pale by comparison.

title: Birth Rates for Teen-Agers Declined Sharply in the 90's
description: In a trend that some credit mostly to abstinence education and others to better use of contraception, teen-age birth rates nationwide declined substantially from 1991 to 1996.

title: Dalai Lama Notes Shifts in China; Backs Clinton's Softer Line
description: Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, distanced himself from militant Tibetans and some international human rights organizations yesterday by saying that the Clinton Administration was on the right track in muting public criticism of China.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Celebrating Tibet

title: McDonald's Executive Who Planned Overhaul Is Promoted to Chief
description: A month after the McDonald's Corporation said that it would overhaul the kitchen system in its United States restaurants and streamline its home office, the executive behind the reorganization got the nod to run the entire company.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: On Stage and Off; 'Equal Time' For Broadway
description: The movie and television industries have ''Entertainment Tonight,'' but what about poor old Broadway? Not to worry, ''Live Broadway, U.S.A.'' is on the way.

title: Nizar Qabbani, Sensual Arab Poet, Dies at 75
description: Nizar Qabbani, who left life as a Syrian diplomat to become one of the Arab world's greatest poets, died today in London, where he lived. He was 75.

title: Heller Financial Initial Offering
description: Heller Financial, a factoring company owned by Fuji Bank of Japan, sold a minority interest in itself yesterday for $1.04 billion, producing the largest initial public offering by a United States company in nearly two years.

title: Fugitive in Cuba Still Wounds Trenton; Chesimard Unrepentant at Trooper's '73 Killing; Whitman Is Irate
description: The case, for all its sensational elements, had begun to blur in the public's consciousness. Twenty-five years ago almost to the day, Joanne D. Chesimard, the leader of a black militant group, was involved in a bloody gunfight on the New Jersey Turnpike that left a state trooper dead, shot execution-style in the back of the head with his own weapon.

title: Village Neighbors Welcome Noise Crackdown
description: To the Editor:

title: Crumbling Wall Closes Disputed Middle School
description: The Albany Avenue School, a refurbished high school that reopened as a middle school last year despite the protests of state officials, will be closed today because of structural problems, Atlantic City school officials said yesterday.

title: Searching for a company's underlying value, often through the prism of the would-be acquirer.
description: FORGET about a company's fundamentals, its price-to-earnings ratio and its dividend yield. How much will it be worth to a potential acquirer? Can it use its expertise in data processing to create a new line of business?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, ARNOLD
description: ROSENZWEIG-Arnold at age 74. Beloved brother of the late Beverly and Sheldon Feinman. Loving uncle of Andrew, Joshua and Debra Feinman.

title: CLINTON PLEASED BY DECISION
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly tonight to expand the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which was born in 1949 as a bulwark against Communism, to include three of its former enemies: Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.

title: Torre Helps Williams Gain New Perspective
description: The impromptu meeting between Bernie Williams and Joe Torre occurred in the manager's office last Sunday when most of a soggy Yankee Stadium was already empty following a rainout with Detroit. Williams, who has often looked bewildered this season, was breezing out of the clubhouse when Torre invited him in to chat.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'View Three'

title: For Starks, No Gloves, Just Heart Amid Mother's Fight With Cancer
description: He came back on the team charter at 6 A.M., his heart still heavy from going home to be with his mother in Oklahoma after she underwent surgery for cancer. John Starks had left the team earlier this season to be with the grandmother who raised him, a woman dealing with the latter stages of the disease.

title: DDB Needham Gets Pep Boys Account
description: The Pep Boys -- Manny, Moe & Jack, the automotive retailer in Philadelphia, assigned its national advertising account yesterday to the DDB Needham Chicago unit of Omnicom Group.

title: Delta's Alliance With United Is On Again
description: United Airlines and Delta Air Lines said yesterday that they had agreed on a broad marketing alliance whose announcement had been delayed for a week by objections from Delta's pilots.

title: A Boy's School Project Aims to Revise History
description: It took the cruiser Indianapolis just 12 minutes to go down, pierced by three Japanese torpedoes in the Pacific on July 30, 1945. Hundreds of the ship's 1,169 crewmen managed to scurry overboard and spent four days and five nights fending off sharks and hallucinations.

title: Paying for Love and Death In the Desperation of Kiev
description: Reflecting on life in Ukraine since the fall of Communism and the breakup of the Soviet empire, Dima (Eugen Pachin), a cynical wheeler-dealer who owns a bar in Kiev, declares to his old army buddy Anatoli (Alexandre Lazarev) that friendship in the country has disappeared. Now it's ''only business relations,'' he observes drily, in Vyacheslav Krishtofovich's gloomy, symbolically weighted film, ''A Friend of the Deceased.'' Those relations include the casual hiring of contract killers who will do in anybody for 500 American dollars (paid in cash, of course), rampant prostitution and all sorts of black market operations.

title: Martinez's Single in 10th Ends a Night of Homers
description: The evening started with Ken Griffey Jr. silencing the rowdy Yankee fans in the right-field bleachers by smashing a home run right at them. It continued with Tino Martinez knocking a ball off the right-field foul pole and Darryl Strawberry clubbing a titanic shot into the bleachers. Then Alex Rodriguez went deep and Griffey drilled another one at the bleacher creatures. Five balls zoomed out of the field at Yankee Stadium and the game was only in the third inning.

title: Half a Century Of Sweetness And Sorrows
description: ONE of the world's most remarkable marriages was celebrated yesterday, a 50-year relationship nurtured by affection but also weakened by heartache, with a disappointment for every dream and a harsh word for every tender gesture. You need a calculator to count how many times a breakup was predicted.

title: Money Manager Guilty of Stealing Rebates
description: William Branston, the former president of Tandem Management Inc., a New York money management firm, has been convicted of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars in brokerage-commission rebates that were intended for the firm's clients.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Barbara Ess

title: Metro Business; Pfizer Training Site Is Set for Rye Brook
description: Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical company in Manhattan, has signed a contract with Doral Hotel and Resorts to move its worldwide training facilities to the Doral Arrowwood Conference Center in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Downshift, Download: Commuting as Work
description: CARS used to provide a refuge from the corporate office, a place to unwind on the way home. No one knew just where you were, and no one could reach you.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Chief Tells Panel of Faith in Deputy
description: John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., today offered his strongest defense of the federation's No. 2 official, Richard L. Trumka, who is under investigation over his possible role in siphoning teamster money into the campaign of Ron Carey, the teamster president.

title: China and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Louis Peterson, 76, Playwright Who Opened Doors for Blacks
description: Louis Peterson, the author of ''Take a Giant Step,'' a groundbreaking Broadway play of the early 1950's about a young black man growing up in a middle-class white neighborhood in New England, died on Monday at the Kateri Residence in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 76.

title: Inside Art; A Fresh Look For Houston
description: The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, is on a serious campaign to strengthen its holdings in contemporary art.

title: Major Indexes Soar in Response to Benign Inflation News
description: Major stock indexes soared yesterday, posting gains for the second consecutive day, after the latest economic data largely erased investor fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, HARRY DOUGLAS
description: GARBER-Harry Douglas. Of Garden City, New York, & Winter Park, FL died at home Tuesday, April 28 after a prolonged battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Diane, father of Deborah MacKelcan, Juliet, John and Buckley, grandfather of Douglas, Matthew, Emily Joy, Alexander and Harry, brother of Johanna Hoot, Donna Marie Schroeppel, and the late Rae Kuhn. Mr. Garber was Vice Chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society until his retirement in 1993. He joined the Equitable upon his graduation from Yale University in 1950. Mr. Garber was a noted Actuary, serving as President of the Academy of Actuaries for several years. A Memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, May 2nd, at 3 P.M., at the Garden City Community Church, Stewart Avenue at Whitehall Boulevard, Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to Memorial SloanKettering Hospital, Yale University, or The Metropolitan Opera.

title: A 2d Look Reveals Surprises
description: Alex Katz never exactly dropped from sight, but right now he's something of a comeback kid.

title: Olivetti's Profit Ends String of Annual Losses
description: Olivetti S.p.A., the Italian telecommunications and office equipment company, said yesterday that it posted its first annual profit in seven years as it sold off telephone assets to its new partner, Mannesmann A.G. Olivetti earned 16 billion lire, or $9 million, last year after losing 4.77 trillion lire, or $2.7 billion, over the six previous years, including a 1996 loss of 915 billion lire, or $515 million. Olivetti posted a gain of 972 billion lire from selling Mannesmann 25 percent of its telephone businesses.

title: Family Fare; Hoop Dreams And Hula, Too
description: Mixing ballet and basketball seems about as realistic as putting Michael Jordan in a tutu. Yet they're undeniably athletic activities, they demand fancy footwork, and Peter Pucci has been on his toes doing both for years. So it seemed only natural to combine them in ''Basketball Jones,'' which is about to have its world premiere in Manhattan.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Dennis Foy, the chef and owner of the new Restaurant EQ, comes dashing out of the kitchen just in time to catch a parting guest before she reaches the door. ''Are you Patricia Wells?'' he asks breathlessly.

title: Knicks Win in a Fight to the Finish
description: These two teams could not just go peacefully into the night. In an unsightly scene, there was Miami's Alonzo Mourning and the Knicks' Larry Johnson taking swings at each other like prizefighters, with Coach Jeff Van Gundy hanging onto Mourning's leg beneath the fray.

title: Observer; The Earthquake Look
description: It is midnight, maybe later, but time means nothing to me now. I am under the spell of an old-movie channel. It is showing ''San Francisco,'' a movie I have not seen since 1913, or whatever year that was when it first played the Capitol Theater on West Baltimore Street.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Home Video; One Less Film On Wish Lists
description: This week marked another of those milestones peculiar to video: the release of a major title that, to the puzzlement and consternation of film buffs, has never been available on tape.

title: New Program to Help AIDS Patients Get Jobs
description: A program intended to help AIDS patients in northern New Jersey find jobs was initiated yesterday in Jersey City.

title: GREAT-WEST LIFE AGREES TO ACQUIRE ANTHEM HEALTH
description: The Great-West Life and Annuity Insurance Company agreed yesterday to acquire the Anthem Health and Life Insurance Company of Piscataway, N.J. The purchase price will be based on the adjusted book value of Anthem upon closing, currently estimated at $100 million. In a statement, Great-West said the deal would provide it with an additional $975 million of equivalent premium income. Anthem Health, a subsidiary of Anthem Inc., provides life, medical, disability and dental products to small and medium-sized businesses. Great-West Life, based in Denver, provides group life, health and financial products. It is an indirect subsidiary of Great-West Lifeco Inc. of Canada, a member of the Power Financial Corporation.

title: Postal Service Is Blamed In Tax Processing Delays
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's office yesterday released a letter from the Postal Service that took the blame for a slowdown in the processing of state tax returns, a day after legislators accused the administration of causing the delay intentionally.

title: Hillary Clinton Is Star at a Rally for Kennelly
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton gave a talk here this morning, ''Women: Finding and Raising Your Voice,'' but later in the day she had another mission: finding and raising money.

title: Gang Rape of Three Girls Leaves Fresno Shaken, and Questioning
description: On the edge of this working-class city, along a highway not far from the vineyards and the strawberry and cotton fields on some of the richest farmland in the nation, as many as 20 men and boys crowded into a motel room three weeks ago for what the police said was a night of rape.

title: Mr. Clinton's Awkward Answers
description: In his first solo news conference since December, President Clinton gave his usual fluid performance, but it was obvious that he has paid a high price for his silence on the allegations about Monica Lewinsky. Most of Mr. Clinton's feelings came across through innuendo and body language. His repeated ducking of questions seemed defensive, argumentative and yet uncharacteristically passive. Asked whether his behavior should even matter to Americans, the President all but shrugged and said he was ''in some ways the last person who needs to be having a national conversation about this.'' For a man addicted to conversation, it was a revealing answer.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, DR. RAYMOND E.
description: STILLMAN-Dr. Raymond E. Devoted husband to Elsie. Loving and guiding father to Dr. Michael and Esther and Dr. Robert and Linda. Cherished grandfather to Lisa, John, David, Jessica and Joel. Beloved brother of Fred, Sylvia, Harry, Sylvia and Eva. The senior leader of the entire Stillman family. Your smile, charm, style and love will be with us all forever. Rest in peace sweet man. Services at 1 P.M. on Sunday, May 3 at Westchester Reform Synagogue, Scarsdale, New York.

title: National News Briefs; Agency Fines Company In Florida Valujet Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it was levying a record fine, $2.25 million, against the company that handled the oxygen generators that caused a Valujet DC-9 to crash nearly two years ago, killing all 110 people on board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEARES, CHARLES W. V.
description: MEARES-Charles W. V. The Board of Directors, Administration and Medical Staff of Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital mourn the passing of Charles W.V. Meares on April 29, 1998. Mr. Meares was a dedicated member of our Board of Directors for 42 years, including 12 years as Chairman & most recently as Honorary Chairman. He served as Chairman of the Budget Committee and as a member of the Executive, Planning, Building and Development Committees. His leadership helped guide our hospital, and his wisdom and wit inspired us all. To his daughter, Jennifer Meinert and all his family and friends, we extend our sincere condolences. Lindsay C. Herkness, III President George A. Sarkar, Ph.D., J.D. Executive Director David R. Edelstein, M.D. President, Board of Surgeon Directors

title: A Landscape Worshiper in Bali, Exploring the Mysterious Power of Light
description: ''Bali,'' an exhibition of Rena Bass Forman's photographs at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery on the Upper East Side, has nothing to do with the Indonesian island as tourist hot spot and everything to do with a place where the equatorial light is mysterious and sometimes surreal.

title: DISNEY BUYS REMAINING TWO-THIRDS OF STARWAVE
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it had bought the remaining two-thirds stake in the Starwave Corporation that it did not already own, as it seeks to bolster its Internet offerings. Terms were not disclosed. A year ago Disney made its initial investment in Starwave, an Internet site designer controlled by the billionaire Paul Allen, a one-third stake estimated at about $90 million. Mr. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, had been the largest shareholder, and employees also owned some shares. Gary Arlen, president of Arlen Communications Inc., a research company that studies interactive transactions, said Starwave had become one of the most prominent sports Internet providers. Disney had a five-year option to buy the remaining stake.

title: Film in Review
description: 'The Ugly'

title: Staff Says I.R.S. Concealed Improper Audits and Rogue Agent
description: Internal Revenue Service management covered up corrupt audits of major companies in New York and Los Angeles and protected a rogue agent who tried to frame former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. on bogus tax evasion charges nine years ago, the Senate Finance Committee was told today.

title: Fickle Finger of Fat; Nabisco Gives In as Consumers Shun Snackwell's, Demanding Taste
description: All right, American eaters, you win. Nabisco is throwing in the towel.

title: Treasury's No. 2 Rebuts Tobacco Arguments
description: A top Administration economist today rebutted the central arguments that cigarette makers had made against tobacco legislation before the Senate as President Clinton urged the companies to return to negotiations.

title: Clinton Scorns Starr, but Sees A Long Inquiry
description: President Clinton today dripped contempt for Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating his private and public conduct, but acknowledged that questions about his behavior would persist throughout his term in office.

title: Electronic Data's Profit Climbs by 8.9%
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit rose 8.9 percent because of higher revenue from contracts to manage other companies' computer systems.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CATTLE RISE. Cattle rose 1.6 percent on expectations that a recall of contaminated beef Wednesday would not lessen demand this summer. June contracts rose 1.1 cents, to 69.5 cents a pound.

title: Pepsi-Cola, with cola sales lagging, replaces its top marketer with a three-man committee.
description: STUNG by the lagging performance of its flagship Pepsi-Cola brand, the Pepsi-Cola Company is restructuring the leadership of its marketing for all soft-drink brands.

title: TV Weekend; Bloody Revenge, a Family Tradition
description: Kirstie Alley looks much better in ''Mario Puzo's 'The Last Don II.' '' In the original ''Last Don,'' last May's blockbuster mini-series, she wandered around the house in her nightgown like Lady Macbeth. This time she's still crazy (in the first scene she loses control in the confessional, and later she tosses her drink in a corpse's face), but her hair, makeup and wardrobe are perfect.

title: Mourning Apologizes For Losing His Cool
description: Right after the Knicks-Heat game last night at Madison Square Garden, Patrick Ewing, the injured Knicks' center, waited to enter the Miami locker room to see his longtime friend and fellow Georgetown alumnus, Alonzo Mourning, who was nursing not only some physical bruises, but also some mental hurts. This followed Mourning's fight on the court with 1.4 seconds left in the fourth quarter with Larry Johnson, the Knicks forward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIEVES, MARCELINO (MARC)
description: NIEVES-Marcelino (Marc). We join his beloved sisters, Janelle and Charisse, his devoted partner, Mel Heuman and his many friends in NYC, Ft. Lauderdale and Fire Island Pines, in mourning the loss of our dear Marc. He will always be remembered, with great affection. Congregation B'nai Olam, Fire Island Pines

title: Picnics and a Quarrel Mark Israel's 50th Anniversary
description: Israel marked its 50th birthday today with a uniquely Israeli blend of smoky barbecues, military fly-overs, fireworks and controversies.

title: $100 Million Donation Set For Cornell Medical School
description: Sanford I. Weill, Wall Street's larger-than-life deal maker who last month announced the merger of his company, Travelers Group, with Citicorp, said yesterday that he and his wife, Joan, had pledged $100 million to Cornell University's medical college.

title: Siderowf Tops Qualifying Round
description: Dick Siderowf has not won the Richardson Memorial since 1972, but his qualifying round yesterday made him one of the favorites to capture the 50th annual amateur invitational tournament.

title: A Hot-Blooded Groping While the Spirit Goes Cold
description: For the Pearl Theater Company's production of August Strindberg's ''Miss Julie,'' Christopher Martin -- who is the director, translator and scenic designer -- stretches an uninterrupted wall of cracked and broken white tile across the backstage wall and limits horizontal surfaces to the floor, a ledge and a butcher's block, creating what might be the kitchen in a nobleman's house that Strindberg indicated or, more likely, a room in a large abattoir.

title: Antiques; Ornaments That Set Off Nature's Art
description: Gardening may be America's favorite hobby, but it's no longer just about plants. Now you have to decorate your garden as well, preferably with an antique garden sculpture or architectural fragment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZOULLAS, LOUISA S.
description: ZOULLAS-Louisa S. Memorial service in memory of Mrs. Louisa S. Zoullas (who passed away March 23, 1998) at the Greek Orthodox Holy Trinity Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street, New York City, immediately following the Holy Mass at 10:45 AM, Sunday, May 3. All friends are invited.

title: Man Arrested in Rape Of 17-Year-Old Girl
description: The authorities have arrested one man and are searching for another in connection with the rape of a 17-year-old girl earlier this week in her bedroom, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPPIG, ANNETTE (NEE ANNE MARGARET BOHAN)
description: EPPIG-Annette (nee Anne Margaret Bohan) of West Islip, L.I. on April 30, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Edwin H. Eppig. Devoted mother of Sister Anne Eppig R.S.C.J., Mary ''Mimi'' Eppig and Aileen Eppig. Grandmother of John Eppig Muir. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Monday 9:45 A.M. St Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon, L.I. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y. Visiting Sunday 2-4:30 & 7-9:30 P.M. Donations may be made to Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center, 1000 Montauk Hwy, West Islip, New York 11795.

title: Change Ripples Through a Tiny Town
description: Could any American town, no matter how tiny and tucked away in the heartland, be as wholesomely Waltonesque as the itsy-bitsy West Texas village that gives the movie ''Dancer, Texas Pop. 81'' its title? The oil business that keeps the town afloat may be in trouble, but that doesn't seem to faze the happy residents who gather each Sunday at the town's picture-perfect little church to sing hymns and hear simple-minded sermons inveighing against lust. This is a place where every week, a phalanx of smiling widows blitz the one available man their age with yummy Jell-O molds and tuna casseroles topped with potato-chip crusts.

title: State Department Warns of 'Critical Levels' of Crime in Mexico
description: The State Department has toughened its advice for Americans traveling to Mexico, responding to a surge in violent crimes against tourists here and mounting complaints from Americans that they were not adequately warned by their Government about the dangers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALKENSTEIN, DAVID B., M.D.
description: FALKENSTEIN-David B., M.D. On April 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Jane Lowinger Falkenstein, M.D. Dear father of Amy Shein, Paul, Sara and Andrew. Adored son of Marta and the late Fritz Falkenstein. ''David, you are one in a million, and we will all miss you''. Services today, May 1, 12:30PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Rome Journal; Lunch With a Lesson: Pasta a la Linda McCartney
description: In school lunchrooms throughout the capital today, it was Linda McCartney Day -- a meatless homage to the former Beatle Paul McCartney's wife, a vegetarian, who died this month.

title: I.R.A. Says It Won't Yield on Weapons; Backs Accord
description: The Irish Republican Army today rejected calls contained in the Northern Ireland peace agreement for disarming its guerrillas and dismantling its underground arsenal, but expressed guarded support for the overall accord.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jason Dodge

title: Schrager Plucks St. Moritz Hotel From Trump's Grasp
description: A month before Donald J. Trump was set to rip apart the historic St. Moritz Hotel and rebuild it as condominiums, Ian Schrager -- the epitome of cool in hoteliers -- announced yesterday that he had snatched the building from Mr. Trump's grasp and would reopen it within 30 days.

title: Less Clutter on TV, But Ad Time Rises
description: Clutter on television -- defined as the time devoted to commercials and promotions -- dipped slightly last year while the amount of commercial time carried by the networks rose to new levels across most parts of the broadcast day, according to an annual report.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: APAC TO BUY ITI MARKETING FOR $155.2 MILLION
description: Apac Teleservices Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held ITI Marketing Services Inc. for $155.2 million. Apac, based in Deerfield, Ill., provides telephone sales, marketing and customer management services. The company, which currently operates 66 telemarketing centers, had revenue of $356 million in 1997. Shares of Apac rose 93.75 cents yesterday, to $10.4325. The Omaha-based ITI operates 24 telemarketing centers. The company, which is majority-owned by a Chicago private-equity firm, had sales of $135 million in 1997. After the acquisition, Apac will have 90 customer contact centers and 25,000 employees.

title: INSIDE
description: Campaign Counsel Sought

title: HUGHES IS RAISING STAKE IN PANAMSAT TO 81%
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation said yesterday that it would pay $846 million to raise its stake in the Panamsat Corporation by 9.5 percentage points, to 81 percent. Hughes is buying 14.1 million shares of the satellite company at $60 each, including 11.2 million shares from Grupo Televisa S.A. and 2.9 million from a group of Panamsat's founding shareholders. Owning more than 80 percent of Panamsat provides a tax advantage to Hughes, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, which bought 71.5 percent of Panamsat, of Greenwich, Conn., last year for $3 billion.

title: Suspensions, Again, Hit Knicks and Heat After N.B.A. Melee
description: For the second straight season the Knicks and the Miami Heat, two teams that cannot seem to share the same court without trading punches, will be missing key players for the deciding game of a contentious playoff series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, ROGER, M.D.
description: HYMAN-Roger, M.D. The faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine deeply mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague Roger A. Hyman, M.D., Professor of Radiology at the NYU School of Medicine and Chairman of Radiology at North Shore University Hospital. Dr. Hyman was a diligent teacher and a neuroradiologist who cared deeply about his patients as well as a leader in professional societies both locally and nationally. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife Susan, his sons Kevin and Douglas, and all the members of his loving family. Norman C. Chase, M.D., Chairman Department of Radiology Noel L. Cohen, M.D. Interim Provost, NYU Medical Center and Interim Dean, NYU School of Medicine

title: W. R. Grace Settles Wayne Pollution Case
description: W. R. Grace & Company and the United States Justice Department reached a settlement on Thursday under which the manufacturer would reimburse the Federal Government $32 million of the $60 million the Government has spent since 1984 to clean up an industrial site in Wayne that was contaminated with radioactive thorium.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Journal; Coming to You Dead From L.A.
description: All those politicians, clergymen and secular moralists who have made the defanging of Jerry Springer the No. 1 priority for purifying our culture were made to look like perfect fools this week.

title: Of Death and Memory of Things Lost
description: Death, loss, and remembrance were the theme of the program the conductor Leonard Slatkin presented with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night. Yet, though the program made sense thematically, it was oddly balanced musically, which can be the problem when works are grouped together to make a thematic point.

title: By Any Measure, Europe's New Monetary Union Is a Historic Exploit
description: WASHINGTON  Starting from the Declaration of Independence, it took the United States nearly 90 years to establish a fully fledged common currency, and a further 50 years to set up the Federal Reserve system in 1913.

title: Seoul Ready to Close Two Securities Firms
description: The South Korean Government is poised to shut the Dongsuh Securities Company and the Coryo Investment and Securities Company after a securities watchdog agency recommended their licenses be revoked. The closings would be a first in Korea's securities industry, underscoring the Government's determination to bolster foreign investors' confidence in the country's debt-ridden financial industry.

title: Queens Doctor Gets Prison Term for Shaking His Baby Girl to Death
description: His voice quavering as he described the killing of one's child as an act that ''not only shocks the conscience but sickens the heart,'' a judge sentenced a doctor yesterday to 2 to 6 years in prison for shaking his baby daughter so violently that she died.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline yesterday about pending American support for a resumption of international aid to Indonesia referred incorrectly to the extent of Indonesian compliance with conditions imposed by the International Monetary Fund. Both American and I.M.F. officials say Indonesia has failed to meet ''some'' conditions (chiefly those dealing with businesses controlled by President Suharto's family and friends), not ''most'' conditions.

title: Big Sludge Spill Poisons Land in Southern Spain
description: At daybreak on Sunday, as Jose Antonio Alvarez stood by in shock, a black tide rose from the riverbed and kept rolling onto his farm.

title: 3-Day Market Rally Erases Losses of Earlier in Week
description: After beginning the week with a tumble, stocks recovered to end with a gain for the week yesterday as they rose for the third straight session.

title: Mideast Nationalism Can Encourage Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rebellion Against History's Fuzzy Future
description: More than 200 historians, from the left and right alike, say a culture of conformity is stifling their field. They say their profession is riven by the politics of race and sex, a reliance on theory instead of evidence, rampant navel-gazing, obscurantism, and writing that reads like badly translated German.
