They are bolting from the American Historical Association and the Organization of American Historians, the National League and American League of professional history, to form their own group, the Historical Society. The founders held a news conference in Washington on Tuesday and spoke with Tim Weiner of The New York Times. Gary Nash, professor of history at U.C.L.A. and director of the National Center for History in the Schools, was asked to respond to their views. Here are excerpts from their comments.

title: $2.3 Billion in Housing Aid Is Cut From Spending Bill
description: Buried inside a $6 billion emergency spending bill signed by President Clinton today is a $2.3 billion cut to a Federal program that assists low-income tenants. New York City housing officials and advocates said the reduction could be devastating to big cities if Congress fails to restore the funds later this year.

title: War Crimes Horrors Revive As Croat Faces Possible Trial
description: In the fall of 1944, prisoners at the Jasenovac concentration camp in Croatia looked skyward as a lumbering American bomber, crippled and spewing smoke, plummeted and crashed near the Sava River after an air raid over Hungary.

title: Ease Off the Horn or Start Paying; For Safety, Take a Bus
description: To the Editor:

title: Euro Follows American Example; Logical Next Step
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Injured as Car and Taxi Collide on East Side
description: Six people were injured yesterday when a taxi collided with a car at an Upper East Side intersection and then veered onto the sidewalk, striking a pedestrian, the Fire Department said.

title: Ease Off the Horn or Start Paying; Those Blinding Lights
description: To the Editor:

title: Hellbent for the Rail: Six Stars in a Rush
description: Gary Stevens, who won the Kentucky Derby last year aboard Silver Charm, considered what would happen on Saturday in the 124th Kentucky Derby when 15 horses spring from the starting gate in America's premier race.

title: And in This Corner, the Play-by-Play
description: When Thursday night's fracas between the Knicks' Larry Johnson and Miami's Alonzo Mourning erupted, the MSG Network had the most complete coverage, TNT had the best camera angles and WFAN's Walt Frazier had the tartest commentary.

title: Prison Terms for Officers In Beatings of Immigrants
description: Two correction officers were sentenced to seven years in prison and a third received a five-year sentence yesterday after being convicted of beating illegal immigrants at the Union County Jail.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RISES 4.8 PERCENT. Crude oil surged on speculation that Saudi Arabia, Mexico and Venezuela would take new steps to cut production. June contracts rose 74 cents, to $16.13 a barrel, the highest since March 30.

title: About New York; At One Corner, 2 Perspectives On Cuba
description: WAVING a Cuban flag and a cigar to match, Benjamin Treuhaft leaned against a pole on Lexington Avenue at East 38th Street. He looked over to the Cuban Mission to the United Nations. As people walked home from work on Thursday evening, he serenaded them in Spanish. ''Cuba, how beautiful is Cuba,'' he sang. ''Who will defend her? Who loves her more?''

title: An Iconoclast Joins the Action
description: Jerry Brown is in the horse racing business, except he rarely goes to the races. Ten times a year, tops. Instead, Brown, dressed in dark clothing and working in a computer's glow, crunches numbers in a nondescript office in lower Manhattan. He is less interested in the glamour of the sport and mint juleps than he is in producing and selling his own brand of gambling wisdom.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in Weekend yesterday with a Critic's Notebook article about showings of films set in New York City misstated the address of Film Forum. It is at 209 West Houston Street in the South Village, not at 209 Varick Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, DAVID
description: SCHNEIDER-David. Age 77, died at home on Friday, May 1, 1998, of cancer. He was retired Chief Executive of El Al (North America) and prior to that Marketing Manager (USA) for British Airways. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Claire, three adoring daughters, Stephanie, Amy, and Tina, and seven grandchildren. Services will be held 11:15 AM, Sunday, May 3 at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76 Street, New York City. Donations may be made to the David Schneider Memorial Fund, Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, New York City 10022.

title: BROWN & SHARPE AGAIN REJECTS THERMO OPTEK OVERTURE
description: The Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Company said yesterday that it was not for sale, as the Thermo Optek Corporation contemplated a new bid for the company. ''We do not want to sell,'' Brown & Sharpe's chief financial officer, Charles A. Junkunc, said. Thermo Optek's parent, the Thermo Electron Corporation of Waltham, Mass., said yesterday that it remained interested in buying Brown & Sharpe despite its rejection last month of a $13.50-a-share cash offer. Brown & Sharpe shares rose $1.0625, to $14.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its market capitalization is more than $189 million. Thermo Optek makes industrial and laboratory equipment. Brown & Sharpe, of North Kingstown, R.I., makes precision measuring devices.

title: Flamenco Lite: New Steps
description: Too many people are trying to do too many things these days with the ancient and honorable art of flamenco. There was a refreshing straightforwardness to ''El Poder de lo Invisible'' (''The Power of the Invisible''), presented by the La Tania Flamenco Music and Dance company on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Yet La Tania, a San Francisco-based flamenco choreographer and performer who grew up in Spain and studied flamenco there, offered variations that were impressively intrinsic to the theme. What was largely missing was the rawness and authority that are also an inherent part of flamenco performing.

title: Now a Warm Welcome Instead of a Cold Bath
description: This time around, no cold water was dumped on Edward O. Wilson's head. Margaret Mead did not have to stand up in his defense and denounce a professional audience for having the equivalent of a ''book burning.'' And it is doubtful whether a dozen distinguished scholars like Richard C. Lewontin and Stephen Jay Gould will feel compelled to send a letter to The New York Review of Books, as they did 20 years ago, accusing Mr. Wilson of providing a ''genetic justification'' for racism and sexism.

title: Baptist Gets Visa to Return to Russia
description: Dan Pollard, an American missionary who was evicted from Russia in March under a new law that restricts minority religious groups, has been granted a visa for three months to return to his church in Vanino, a remote port town in the Far East. He received the visa on Thursday from the Russian Consulate in Seattle, and plans to leave for Russia today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLECHER, MILTON
description: BLECHER-Milton. May 2, 1914. Dear Daddy, Happy Birthday. I miss you. Love, Nanie

title: Foreign Affairs; Now a Word From X
description: His voice is a bit frail now, but the mind, even at age 94, is as sharp as ever. So when I reached George Kennan by phone to get his reaction to the Senate's ratification of NATO expansion it was no surprise to find that the man who was the architect of America's successful containment of the Soviet Union and one of the great American statesmen of the 20th century was ready with an answer.

title: F.B.I. Chief Still Sees Need for Campaign Finance Prosecutor
description: As the chief prosecutor of the Justice Department's campaign finance inquiry prepares to leave, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis J. Freeh, has told several Republican Senators that he still believes that the investigation should be turned over to an independent prosecutor.

title: Hal Laycoe, 75, N.H.L. Player Whose High Stick Led to Riot
description: Hal Laycoe, a National Hockey League defenseman, coach and general manager, died on Tuesday following surgery in Langley, British Columbia. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROH, EDWARD JR.
description: STROH-Edward Jr., DMD. The entire family of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of Edward Stroh, Jr., DMD. A distinguished Director of the Department of Dentistry and Oral Surgery from 1966 to 1974, he upheld our finest traditions of clinical excellence and will be sorely missed. To his family and friends, we extend our profoundest condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman of the Board Robert G. Newman, MD Acting President Richard P. Fried, MD President of the Medical Board

title: Mideast Nationalism Can Encourage Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: ORENSTEIN-Sylvia. On May 1, 1998. Beloved sister of Harold and Joseph. Devoted aunt of Donna Kerner, Debbie Magnusson and Grant Orenstein. Service Sunday, 12 noon, Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Unilever Profit Beats Analysts' Expectations
description: Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch consumer products company, said yesterday that its first-quarter pretax profit jumped by 56 percent, to $:754 million ($1.25 billion) from $:482 million a year earlier, as sales in Asia, Africa and Latin American all grew strongly. Unilever, whose major products include Lipton tea, Breyer's ice cream and Pond's cold cream, said the results also benefited from an accounting change, which meant the 1998 quarter was six days longer than the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Clinton Predicts a Safer and Richer Europe
description: President Clinton today hailed the Senate approval on Thursday night of a treaty admitting Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic into the NATO alliance, saying it would make Europe safer for its citizens and a more prosperous trading partner for the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, MARGARET
description: RUSSELL - Margaret. Literary Agent, of Livingston, NJ, on April 27, 1998. Daughter of Anna Russell & the late Charles Russell. Memorial service Sunday, May 3, 2PM in St. Andrew & Holy Communion Episcopal Church, corner South Orange Ave. & South Ridgewood Road, South Orange, New Jersey.

title: When Did Overbilling Become a Habit?
description: Suzanna Hubbell: You didn't actually do that, did you, mark up time for the client, did you?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSA, LOUISE (NEE MUDDARI)
description: BARSA-Louise (nee Muddari). On April 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Ronald, Odette, Patricia Grimes and George. Sister of Priscilla Moseley, Madeline Nackley, Alice Kotite and Mabel Morin. Grandmother of eight, and great-grandmother of five. Visitation Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 3rd Avenue at 97th St., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10AM, Church of the Virgin Mary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOY, HORACE ROBERT
description: TOY-Horace Robert. Of Bradenton, Fla. (formerly of NYC), on April 26, 1998, after a long illness. Retired President of Thos. D. Toy & Co., member of the Squadron ''A'' Assoc. Loving husband of the late Barbar Fish. Beloved father of Leontine (Bonnie) Audrain & sons Thomas, Peter and Christopher; also survived by seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Memorial gifts to The American Cancer Society would be greatly appreciated by his family.

title: Executive Succession Timetable Is Moved Up by Bell Atlantic
description: Ivan G. Seidenberg, president of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, took an unexpected step toward the company's brass ring yesterday as the big local telephone carrier announced that he would become its chief executive on June 1, more than two months earlier than the company had previously planned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, EDWARD
description: GOLDBERGER-Edward. Beloved husband of the late Eva. Dear father of Martha. Dear brother of Hilda Wieder and Florence Bisping, both of California. Services Monday 1 PM, Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial, Queens Boulevard & 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, JESSE J.
description: UNGER-Jesse J. On April 30, 1998 at age 101, of Briarcliff Manor, NY, formerly of Scarsdale, New York. Husband of the late Jane. Survived by two daughters, Mary Jane Florent and Frances Meade, one sister, four grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Reposing Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 1300 Pleasantville Rd., Briarcliff Manor, on Sunday evening from 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Theresa's Church, at Briarcliff Manor, on Monday, at 10 A.M. Interment Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: Indictment a Small Piece of a Bigger Puzzle
description: It is very unusual for someone to be prosecuted for the tax violations that President Clinton's old friend and former appointee, Webster L. Hubbell, was accused of on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUSKIN, SAMUEL A.
description: DUSKIN-Samuel A. On April 29 1998, at the age of 101. Born in Philadelphia, Oct. 17, 1896. Served in the Navy in World War I. Taught English in Havana afterwards. Enthusiastic world traveler. President of Estuary Council of Clubs while in his 80's. Active in his Connecticut Square Dance Club until the age of 96. He is survived by his sisters Ann Otis and Lillian Otis, his daughter Phyllis Hirschfeld, step-daughter Joan Blake, 10 grandchildren & 16 great-grandchildren. Loved, cherished and admired by all. Services on Sunday, May 3, 9:45 A.M., at ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Oxford Health Is Trying to Sell Bonds
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. has started making presentations to potential investors as it looks to sell high-yield bonds in a private placement as part of a $700 million financing package.

title: Trucking Along With Road Kill and Road Killers
description: Somewhere there surely exists a demographic group whose members thrill to the sight of the grilles of Peterbilt and White trucks filmed from such road-kill angles that they appear to possess the slablike architectural grandeur of the twin towers at the World Trade Center.

title: Hubbell Hope Of Pardon Seen By Investigators
description: As Webster L. Hubbell sat in prison six days before the last Presidential election, he and his lawyers worked frantically to amend old tax returns that had significantly understated his income, in part, investigators now suspect, to make him an attractive candidate for a Presidential pardon.

title: The Birthright of Beauty: Free and Easy
description: When Vanessa L. Williams insinuates her way down a flight of stairs, making her entrance in the sweet-and-sour Encores concert version of the 1946 musical ''St. Louis Woman,'' you don't doubt for a second that this is a gal who could provoke men to serious acts of violence. Not that there's anything brazenly provocative in her walk, which isn't so much a sashay or a strut as a cool, melting glide.

title: EX-PREMIER ADMITS HE LED MASSACRES IN RWANDA IN 1994
description: In a breakthrough for prosecutors, a former Prime Minister of Rwanda pleaded guilty today to genocide charges before a United Nations tribunal in Tanzania, and promised to testify against former colleagues in connection with the deaths of half a million people in 1994.

title: 16 Children Fall Ill After Party at School
description: The City Health Department is investigating what caused 16 Brooklyn schoolchildren to be stricken with food poisoning yesterday shortly after a party to celebrate their completion of citywide standardized reading tests taken earlier this week.

title: Hot Stock Gone Cold
description: Boston Chicken, once one of the hottest initial public offerings of the 1990's, but now a company whose ability to make money is questionable, said yesterday that its co-founders, Saad Nadhir and Scott Beck, were resigning as the company's top executives. J. Michael Jenkins, a restaurant industry veteran brought in from Vicorp, a competitor, will be chairman, president and chief executive.

title: Subpoena Paved Way For Tapes' Release
description: The public disclosure of some telephone calls made by Webster L. Hubbell when he was in prison was highly unusual and was possible only because they were subpoenaed last summer by Congress.

title: No Rest for the Deceased
description: Eternal rest isn't what it used to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTMAN, EILEEN
description: LITTMAN-Eileen. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Robert and Imke, Edward & Arleen. Loving grandmother & great grandmother of Cindy & Jack, Shari & Dan, Thomas, Kevin, Robert, Daniel, Joshua & Emily. Graveside services 1 P.M. Sunday at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island. For further information call ''Gutterman's Inc.'' (516) 764-9400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPPIG, ANNETTE (NEE ANNE MARGARET BOHAN)
description: EPPIG-Annette (nee Anne Margaret Bohan) of West Islip, L.I. on April 30, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Edwin H. Eppig. Devoted mother of Sister Anne Eppig R.S.C.J., Mary ''Mimi'' Eppig and Aileen Eppig. Grandmother of John Eppig Muir. Reposing at the Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Monday 9:45 A.M. St Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon, L.I. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y. Visiting Sunday 2-4:30 & 7-9:30 P.M. Donations may be made to Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center, 1000 Montauk Hwy, West Islip, New York 11795.

title: Knicks Become Nine Men on a Mission in Miami
description: The halogen haze that washed over Coach Jeff Van Gundy added to the surreal evening.

title: Chrysler Reports 8.2% Sales Jump, As Car Makers Push Big Rebates
description: In auto dealer showrooms nationwide, rebate skirmishes have given way to an all-out price war, with the Big Three American auto makers promising buyers ever-bigger discounts and even honoring competitors' $1,000-off coupons.

title: Programmers' Tax Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Be Your Own Brother's Keeper
description: JEFF VAN GUNDY emerged from the Knicks' two-hour practice session yesterday afternoon, composed, clean-shaven and most important, in one piece.

title: Augusta Chairman Says He'll Retire
description: Jack Stephens announced his retirement yesterday as chairman of Augusta National Golf Club and the Masters tournament. Stephens will be succeeded by William W. Johnson, who has served as the club's vice president since 1975.

title: Beliefs
description: For three decades, Daniel Callahan has been a leader in the field of biomedical ethics. One of the first philosophers to tackle topics that had begun to worry leading scientists, he joined with Dr. Willard Gaylin, a psychoanalyst, to found the Hastings Center in 1969. The institute brought together medical clinicians and researchers, legal scholars, ethicists, theologians, historians, social scientists and government officials to examine issues arising from human genetics, new reproductive technologies, organ transplantation and other developments in biomedicine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANN ROSENTHAL
description: MILLER-Ann Rosenthal. Age 63 on April 30, 1998, of Scarsdale, NY, after a long and courageous battle with ovarian cancer. Dear wife of William S. Miller. Loving mother of Elizabeth M. and Randolph Guggenheimer, III, Mark R. and Tonya Miller, Rachel L. Miller, and Steven W. Miller. Beloved grandma Ann to Laura Claire Guggenheimer, Brian James Guggnheimer and Samuel Yong Miller. Devoted sister, aunt, niece, colleague and friend. Service at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY at 10:00 AM on Monday, May 4, 1998. In Ann's memory a fund will be established at The Westchester Reform Temple to provide additional support for those in need of healing as well as comfort for the bereaved.

title: Devils Can See a Game 7 in Gilmour's Eyes
description: When Doug Gilmour arrived in New Jersey late last season, he was seen as the star center who would add flair and zest to a good, but mechanical, Devils team. With a championship ring and two final four appearances, he would provide New Jersey with the leadership it needed to win another Stanley Cup.

title: Japanese Auto Makers Tell U.S. What It Wants to Hear
description: Japan's trade surplus with the United States has climbed steadily over the last several months, increasing the likelihood of a protectionist backlash in Congress and industry.

title: NATO Is Inching Closer, But Russians Don't Blink
description: The traditional May Day holiday might seem to be the sort of occasion that would mobilize Russian opinion against NATO's decision to take in three of Moscow's former satellites.

title: Cigarette Makers' Strategy of '94 Is Echoed Today
description: In March 1994, the directors of the Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest cigarette maker, gathered to hear a warning that their industry faced tumultuous change. Just weeks before, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Dr. David A. Kessler, had announced that the agency might regulate nicotine as a drug.

title: Treasury Securities Rise in Price Again
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities closed higher yesterday after an unexpectedly weak manufacturing report added to optimism that inflation would remain benign.

title: Euro Follows American Example; Democracy Suffers
description: To the Editor:

title: ANCHOR FINANCIAL ACQUIRING ANOTHER SMALLER RIVAL
description: The Anchor Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the M&M Financial Corporation, parent of First National South, for $35.5 million in stock, as it expands its banking network in the Carolinas. The combination would bring the assets of Anchor, based in Myrtle Beach, S.C., to more than $1 billion and its number of bank offices in North Carolina and South Carolina to 28. Anchor would pay 0.87 share for each share of M&M, based in Marion, S.C., giving the transaction a value of $35.5 million based on Anchor's closing price of $40.50. Last month, Anchor bought a rival, ComSouth Bankshares Inc., for $74.2 million in stock. Shares of Anchor rose $1.25, to $40.50.

title: With the Euro en Route, Time to Pick a Manager
description: The foundation of the common currency that 11 European countries plan to adopt here this weekend, like the foundation of the 15-nation European Union itself, rests on a historic and often uneasy bargain between France and Germany.

title: Union City Officer Is Convicted in Sex Case
description: A Union City police officer was convicted of aggravated sexual assault and official misconduct yesterday for having sex with a 14-year-old boy whom he supervised in a mentor program run by the city Police Department, county prosecutors said.

title: Getting Biotechnology Set to Hatch; As Science Gathers Speed, Monsanto Leads Pack
description: As biotechnology pioneers like the Monsanto Company see it, the moment is arriving when science can give business the power to put the clock of evolution on fast forward.

title: Upsurge in Extremist Attacks After Lull Touches Off a Scramble to Find Causes : Germans Ponder Violence
description: MAGDEBURG, Germany  - At 7:25 P.M. on a recent Tuesday night, two young toughs broke into a Palestinian's apartment in a public housing project on the fringe of this city.

title: Favorite Wins Oaks by a Neck
description: A crowd of 94,415, a record for the day before the Kentucky Derby, jammed Churchill Downs today and saw the favored Keeper Hill win the 124th Kentucky Oaks by a neck over Banshee Breeze.

title: Water and Sewer Taxes Are Raised 4% by Board
description: The New York City Water Board voted yesterday to raise water and sewer taxes for the city's homes and businesses by 4 percent, and to extend two programs intended to soften the financial impact on residential landlords as they install water meters in their buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUDOW, SUNNY ''SPRINTZIE''
description: BUDOW-Sunny ''Sprintzie''. Hello, Love. 14 years without you. You're always in our hearts. Saul, Fern, Stephen and Family

title: U.S. Seeks Help for North Korea on Fuel
description: With increasing urgency, the United States is pressing Japan, South Korea and other countries for more money to supplement North Korea's energy supplies -- a key part of a deal that got North Korea to stop developing nuclear weapons. But Washington's efforts have had little success so far, American officials said today.

title: Cave Dweller In Bronx Park Is Arrested
description: The police said Everett Henriquez had gone to Van Cortlandt Park for the quietude, digging a pied-a-terre into the soft earth, stocking it with weapons and furnishing it with a mattress. There was a pond nearby. Everything was rosy, expect for the squawking birds.

title: Youngest Qualifier Sticks Around
description: Andreas Huber, at 18 the youngest golfer in the Richardson Memorial, gets to play with his elders for at least another round.

title: Deputy Arrested in Killing Of Wife at Buffalo School
description: As pupils and teachers cowered nearby, an Erie County deputy sheriff pursued his estranged wife into their children's elementary school in Buffalo yesterday and shot her dead in an office where she sought refuge, officials said. He also shot an aide, but no children were hurt and the suspect was caught blocks away.

title: FIRSTENERGY SERVICES PURCHASING COLONIAL MECHANICAL
description: The Firstenergy Services Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Colonial Mechanical Corporation, a provider of energy services, for an undisclosed sum. Firstenergy, based in Akron, Ohio, is an energy-services holding company that had sales of $3.4 billion in the year ended March 31. It is a unit of the Firstenergy Corporation, which was formed last year by the merger of Ohio Edison of Akron, Ohio, and the Centerior Energy Corporation of Independence, Ohio. Colonial, based in Richmond, provides heating, ventilating, air-conditioning, plumbing, and process piping construction and services. It had sales of $72 million last year.

title: Topics of The Times; Rebel at Rest
description: When Eldridge Cleaver's life ended yesterday in a California hospital, he died a man who had found fame as a violent black Marxist radical and writer, but who finished as a born-again Christian and a Republican. If that seems an anomaly, his end a repudiation of his beginning, it was simply the latest stage in a passionate, odd and driven life.

title: Countdown Starts for New Money : Adoption of Single Currency Marks Triumph of Political Will
description: BRUSSELS  A decades-long vision becomes reality Saturday with the formal nomination of 11 countries to join Europe's monetary union embracing 290 million Europeans in a single market with the same money, the euro.

title: Euro Follows American Example; Three Problems Solved
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockefeller Center Seeks City Approval for Flashier Facades
description: Facing competition from the oversized retail landscape that Fifth Avenue has become, the owners of Rockefeller Center have decided to enlarge their understated shopfronts into splashier, two-story facades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, ARNOLD
description: MARSHALL-Arnold. On May 1, 1998, after a courageous fight. Loving husband of Marcia. Beloved father of Alexandra. Dear brother of Johanna. Services Mon. May 4, 1:30 PM, Frank Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POTENZA, CONNIE
description: POTENZA-Connie. May 2, 1988. You are always in my heart and mind. The memory of your face will forever light my path. My love for you is eternal. Jack (Ronnie)

title: A Rainy Day Skirmish: Baylor Takes On Mets' Tatum
description: The Mets and Colorado Rockies were rained out yesterday at Shea Stadium. Nothing new there. The Mets have now had five scheduled games washed away.

title: Scientists and Their Political Passions
description: I received a note a few weeks ago, urging me to sign a petition card opposing the global climate change accord. So, it seems, did just about every scientist in the United States. The note was signed by Frederick Seitz, a physicist who once served as president of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Concern for the Most Vulnerable
description: As a young assistant prosecutor in Essex County, Patricia A. Hurt resisted being transferred from a trial team, which handled murder and narcotics cases, to the child abuse unit, where the caseload rarely reflected the action on the streets of New Jersey's most dangerous jurisdiction.

title: Inquiry Opened Into Shooting of 3 Black Men by New Jersey State Troopers
description: The prosecutor appointed by the New Jersey State Attorney General to investigate the case of three young men who were shot last week by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike interviewed one of the men at a Camden hospital yesterday, beginning the task of sorting out a chaotic scene of gunfire and bloodshed that followed a late-night traffic stop in Mercer County.

title: I.R.S. Commissioner Promises Full Inquiry
description: The Internal Revenue Commissioner, Charles O. Rossotti, promised today to ''investigate every allegation'' raised in the Senate Finance Committee's hearings on abuse of taxpayers.

title: Pataki Vetoes Money For Williamsburg Park
description: A proposal to build a public park along the waterfront in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, suffered a setback this week when Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed $10 million earmarked for the project by the State Legislature.

title: Temple-Inland Buyback
description: The paper-products maker Temple-Inland Inc. said today that it would buy back up to 2.5 million shares, or 4.4 percent, of its stock. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, will increase earnings per share by reducing the number of shares outstanding. Temple-Inland has 56.6 million shares outstanding. The shares rose $1.1875 each, to $65.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company has already repurchased 2.3 million shares under a previously announced 2.5-million-share buyback.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEKSELBLATT, BEVERLY
description: WEKSELBLATT-Beverly. Devoted wife of Raymond. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Abbe and Mitchell and Joseph and Maureen. Adored grandmother of Rachel, Beth, Sara, Shelby and Brooke. Former President of Shoshana Israel Group of Hadassah. Services Sunday, 10am at ''Parkside'' Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, near Avenue 'V' (opposite Kings Plaza), Brooklyn, NY.

title: Starr's Speech Invokes Days Of Watergate
description: At the same time he is battling the White House in a secret court proceeding over executive privilege, Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, delivered a televised speech on that issue today and compared himself to the prosecutor who helped topple President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, ROSLYN A.
description: WEINER-Roslyn A., 75. Of Aventura, Florida. formerly of NY passed away Friday, May 1, 1998. Beloved wife of Dr. Irwin, loving mother of Dr. Jonathan of Fresno, CA., Dr. Michael S. of Sanger, CA., Peter of Miami, FL., cherished grandmother of seven. Services and interment in Florida. For information Levitt-Weinstein Mem. Chapels, 18840 W. Dixie Highway, North Miami Beach, Florida.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article yesterday about a British fund set up to repay assets seized during World War II misstated the project's Internet address. It is www.enemyproperty.gov.uk.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZOULLAS, LOUISA S.
description: ZOULLAS-Louisa S. Memorial service in memory of Mrs. Louisa S. Zoullas (who passed away March 23, 1998) at the Greek Orthodox Holy Trinity Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street, New York City, immediately following the Holy Mass at 10:45 AM, Sunday, May 3. All friends are invited.

title: It's All in the Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Eldridge Cleaver, Black Panther Who Became G.O.P. Conservative, Is Dead at 62
description: Eldridge Cleaver, whose searing prison memoir ''Soul on Ice'' and leadership in the Black Panther Party made him a symbol of black rebellion in the turbulent 1960's, died yesterday in Pomona, Calif., at the age of 62.

title: After Massacre, Fact Meets Memory
description: In this era of tabloid television, it's not so difficult to understand the appeal of fashioning docudramas from recent events. As skillfully and tastefully realized as these movies might turn out to be, they represent an easy way out creatively: the quick appropriation of a story that doesn't have to be invented, a story that has already proved itself in bold headlines.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPAGHETTI WAREHOUSE INC., Dallas, said its board had unanimously rejected an offer by the closely held Conquest partnership to acquire the restaurant chain for as much as $58 million in cash and debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKOFF, CECILE
description: PARKOFF-Cecile. We regret to announce the death on April 29 of Cecile Parkoff, devoted wife of the late Meyer; mother of Stephen & Barbara, Gerald and Shulamet, and Rabbi Eliezer and Baracha of Jerusalem, loving grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: The Children of the Glum
description: In the back of every parent's mind, crowded in with worries about the job, the bills, the waistline and grandma, is a certain fear about the children -- that we haven't prepared them well enough, that their world won't be good enough, that we can't do anything about it. No wonder so many parents are glum.

title: Off the Streets, Into the Ring Is Boxing Program's Goal
description: Ray Mercer, Shannon Briggs, Larry Holmes and Michael Spinks joined with other boxers and city officials at the Stella Wright Homes here this afternoon to open a community boxing program that they hope will be a model for other programs in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DODGE, BRUCE M.
description: DODGE-Bruce M. Passed away peacefully at his home in Rancho Mirage, California, on April 28, 1998. He was born in New York City, on December 18, 1920. He is survived by his adored wife, Joan and loving sons, Mark (Vicki) Dodge, Andrew (Cindy) Aronson and grandchildren, Noah and Jesse Aronson. Funeral services will be private. Memorial contributions may be made in his memory to the American Cancer Society or the charity of your choice. For information Palm Springs Mortuary in Cathedral City, CA.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks End Volatile Week With Solid Advance

title: IRELAND'S CRH AGREES TO BUY SEGALE FOR $60 MILLION
description: The Irish building materials company CRH P.L.C. said yesterday that its Oldcastle Materials unit had agreed to acquire the privately owned M. A. Segale Inc. for $60 million. Segale, based in Tukwila, Wash., produces integrated aggregates and asphalt and provides paving and construction services. It had revenue of $50 million in 1997. CRH, based in Dublin, is Ireland's biggest building materials company, with 1997 sales of $4.5 billion. CRH said the acquisition was part of its effort to increase business in the Western United States.

title: CENDANT IN TALKS TO BUY BRITISH ROADSIDE SERVICES UNIT
description: The Cendant Corporation said yesterday that it was negotiating with the Royal Automobile Club Ltd. of Britain to acquire the club's RAC Motoring Services business for about $750 million in cash. Cendant, which completed the acquisition of Britain's National Parking Corporation for $1.3 billion on Monday, said the acquisition of RAC Motoring Services would make it the leading roadside assistance company in Britain. RAC Motoring Services includes RAC, Britain's second-largest roadside assistance company, and RAC Mechanical Breakdown Insurance, a provider of auto warranty products. RAC Motoring Services also owns Britain's largest driving school company.

title: Ease Off the Horn or Start Paying
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CIRKER, MINETTE
description: CIRKER-Minette. Lovingly remembered on your birthday. ''Rest my sweet darling''. Stanley

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Poles Say, 'Thank You, America,' and Czechs and Hungarians Voice Delight
description: Poland's leaders and people greeted the United States Senate's vote to approve their NATO membership with relief and delight today, praising the vote as the beginning of a promising new era that would overcome a century of dark history.

title: Being Ahead Is Where Senators Want to Be
description: The reasoning goes something like this: The pressure is on Ottawa Saturday night. If the Devils win, forcing a Game 7 at the Meadowlands, then the Senators can start booking tee times.

title: Rod Thrown From Window At P.S. 225 Hurts 4 Pupils
description: A metal rod used as part of scaffolding was thrown from a fourth-floor window of a Brooklyn elementary school yesterday morning and struck four pupils as children filed inside, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHER, THEODORE NICHOLAS
description: MAHER - Theodore Nicholas. ''Ted'' died of a long standing illness on his birthday, March 2, 1998. He is survived by 3 children: Candace, Michael and Nicole, as well as four grandchildren. Ted was raised in Greenwich, CT. He served in the South Pacific during W.W. II and later graduated from Princeton University. He was a professional writer and retired from the FAA in Washington, DC. He had many accomplishments including writing several unpublished novels. In his later years, he was especially proud of this thirty year chip.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We told them that it's a very hostile environment and that we're not welcome here and they don't want us here because they're not letting us in. We weren't pushing them to come to Cal.''

title: Studio Sues Over a 'Star Trek' Book
description: A ''Star Trek'' fan says that the Paramount Pictures Corporation, which owns the copyright to the series and spinoffs, is behaving more like the evil Borg than like the good-guy captains, Jean-Luc Picard and James Kirk.

title: Euro Follows American Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Takes Attendance
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying to Catch Up On Path to Success; Amid Debate, CUNY Students Grapple With Remedial Work
description: While politicians and educators debate the value of high school-level remedial classes at the City University of New York, the issue boils down to a simple question: Should students like Sergio Moya be in college?

title: BEACON CAPITAL MAKES FIRST PROPERTY ACQUISITION
description: Beacon Capital Partners Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired 11 suburban Boston commercial properties for $195 million, marking the first acquisition for the newly formed real estate investment trust. The properties, known as the Athenaeum Portfolio, are in East Cambridge, near the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. They include 10 office, laboratory and retail buildings, a nine-screen cinema and a 1,530-car parking garage. The acquisition comes a month after Boston Capital raised $400 million from pension funds and other institutions in a private stock sale. The company is headed by Alan Leventhal, who sold his Boston-based Beacon Properties Corporation last year to the financier Sam Zell for $4.4 billion.

title: O'Neill Helps Irabu Get a Victory for His Efforts
description: They passed out paychecks in the Yankee clubhouse on Thursday, prompting the recently slump-ridden Paul O'Neill to joke half-heartedly to a friend that he should not accept his.

title: Lawyers in the Outfield?
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill Contract Talks Begin
description: George Steinbrenner speaks of Paul O'Neill as Yankee royalty, referring to him as a warrior. Not surprisingly, the team has begun negotiations on a multiyear contract that would presumably allow O'Neill to finish his career in pinstripes.

title: Blacks at Berkeley Are Offering No Welcome Mat
description: In springs past, Dana Inman took pains to persuade black students who were offered admission to the University of California's most renowned, selective campus to join her here.

title: In Preparing for Euro, the Laggards Are Likely to Lose Market Share : Corporate Europe Is Running Behind
description: FRANKFURT  - Corporate Europe should be the first sector of society to learn what it means to have a shiny Trojan currency  a hopeful symbol of pan-European unity that many expect will sneak in with it a raft of painful economic and social changes.

title: Heat Has No Plans To Be All Hardaway
description: In digesting the loss of his starting center today, Miami Heat Coach Pat Riley had a message for his team -- and maybe for the world at large -- about Sunday's showdown against the Knicks.

title: When Resisting the Obvious Is How to Doom a Contract
description: There is little overlap between the public world of tournaments and the private world of rubber bridge, although a few players, like the globe-trotting Zia Mahmood, move confidently between the two. His partner in a high-stake game at the Regency Club, 15 East 67th Street, Manhattan, was Jack Dreyfus, a name to conjure with in financial circles. His opponents were Ronald Blau, sitting East, and Amos Kaminsky, West, both of whom had many tournament successes before retiring from that arena. They produced a tour de force in defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPLAN, BELLE
description: CAPLAN-Belle. Of Riverdale on May 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Lewis Caplan. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Morton and Joan Caplan and Murray and Caren Caplan. Cherished grandmother of eight. Funeral service Sunday 1 P.M., at Plaza Memorial, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Democrats Threaten to Oppose I.M.F. Bill
description: The House Democratic leader and five other senior Democrats threatened today to withdraw support for President Clinton's request for $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund, dealing a serious new setback to one of the Administration's top foreign policy goals.

title: Southwest Airlines Founder Chooses a New Top Deputy
description: Herbert D. Kelleher, who personifies Southwest Airlines, named a new second-in-command today and apparently narrowed the contest to succeed him.

title: Gandhi Off the Pedestal, All Too Human Parent As Well as Great Guru
description: For many Indians, Mohandas K. Gandhi, the Mahatma of India's freedom struggle, left a legacy that has never been easy. While venerating Gandhi for his role in ending colonialism, many in the post-independence era have found his ascetic insistence on self-reliance and self-denial too demanding, and too otherworldly, to have much relevance in the India he bequeathed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the actor Christopher Reeve and his new book, ''Still Me,'' referred incorrectly to his alma mater. It is Wesleyan University, not Wesleyan College.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about abuses by Internal Revenue Service agents misattributed a statement about a plot by a rogue agent against former Senator Howard Baker of Tennessee. It was Mr. Baker, not a tax investigator, Tony Deaton, who told reporters that the episode ''makes me wonder if there doesn't need to be a thorough inquiry'' by the I.R.S. commissioner.

title: Thought For Food: Cafes Offer Philosophy In France
description: It is 11 o'clock on a Sunday morning and more than 100 people have crammed into the small Cafe des Phares on the Place de la Bastille. This is an everyday bistro, ringed with busy traffic and a nearby street market. But inside there is a pious silence as the crowd hunkers down for an intensely French ritual: the practice of philosophy.

title: After a Suicide, Questions on Lurid TV News
description: Live local television coverage of a man in an armed standoff with the police here on Thursday was suddenly transformed into a horrific spectacle, and a debate over journalistic ethics, when the man set himself and his dog on fire and, minutes later, still smoldering and on camera, propped a shotgun under his chin and pulled the trigger.

title: B.A.T. Industries' Profit Fell in First Quarter
description: The profit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. fell 3.8 percent in the first quarter as profit growth at its financial services units was offset by the strength of the pound. Net income fell to $:333 million ($557 million) from $:346 million a year earlier. The company, the world's second-biggest cigarette maker after Philip Morris, sold fewer cigarettes in the United States because of health concerns and in Asia because of an economic slowdown. Its financial services arm, which will be spun off this year, had strong profit growth in life insurance and general insurance.

title: GIULIANI AND UNION POSTPONE LAYOFFS AT CITY HOSPITALS
description: On what 905 workers in city-owned hospitals thought was their last day on the job, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he would delay widespread layoffs for 30 days and try to avoid them altogether by seeking to place the workers in other city jobs.

title: Excerpts From the Tapes of Webster Hubbell's Prison Phone Conversations
description: Following are excerpts from telephone conversations of Webster L. Hubbell recorded in 1996, while he was in Federal prison for tax evasion stemming from the bilking of the Rose Law Firm of Little Rock, Ark. The discussions were transcribed by the House Government Reform and Oversight Committee, which had subpoenaed tapes of them from the Federal Bureau of Prisons. Those with whom Mr. Hubbell conversed in the excerpted passages were his wife, Suzanna, an Administration employee; Laura Shores and John Nields, his lawyers; Michael Schaufele, a financial consultant, and Marsha Scott, a White House aide.

title: Cuba's Imprisoned Dissidents
description: Given Canada's influence with Cuba, the wish list that Canada's Prime Minister, Jean Chretien, presented to Fidel Castro in Havana this week was disappointingly short. But at least he appealed to the Cuban leader to free four prominent dissidents held without trial since last July. One of them, Marta Beatriz Roque, has symptoms of breast cancer and other serious problems that have not been adequately diagnosed or treated. Mr. Castro gave Mr. Chretien the brushoff, as he did John Paul II when the Pope asked for their release earlier this year. Cuba's prisons hold about 350 political detainees in appalling conditions. None should be there.

title: Without Structural Changes, Experts Cautious on Economic Growth
description: ROME  The introduction of Europe's single currency in January 1999, despite much rhetoric about savings on cross-border transactions and other benefits, is unlikely to generate much new economic growth on its own. Nor, say many economists, will it have an immediate impact on the plight of the Continent's 18 million jobless.

title: Sports of The Times; Another Secretariat Not So Easy
description: THEY are waiting, still waiting, for the wonder horse who will rescue racing from the casinos and the lotteries and all the other sources of easy action. What they really want is another Secretariat. The count is now 25 years, and ticking. Other sports come up with new greatests, or reasonable facsimiles, a Woods or a Sampras, but racing is haunted by the late champion who cannot be replicated, not even by his own genes.

title: Bertelsmann Hits a Snag In Acquisition
description: Bertelsmann A.G.'s plan to purchase Random House and merge it with the media conglomerate's Bantam Doubleday Dell unit has temporarily stalled. Faced with an intensive new level of regulatory scrutiny, the German company decided this week to withdraw its application seeking approval from the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Students Sing To Aid Cause Of Road Safety
description: Last spring, shortly after a member of their a cappella singing group was killed in what the police are calling a drunken driving accident, Princeton University's Tigertones set about planning an event to commemorate a lost friend and to help prevent similar tragedies.

title: Leaders in Hartford Agree to Budget Deal With Rebates
description: Graced with a large surplus and a strong economy, Gov. John G. Rowland and Democratic legislative leaders have reached a mostly painless budget agreement in which both sides accomplished what they most wanted.

title: Rival May Day Throngs Disquiet Mexico's Elite
description: Mexico's ruling party once enjoyed undisputed control over most everything that was dramatically Mexican, from the colors of the national flag to the sweeping ranks of organized labor.

title: Mideast Nationalism Can Encourage Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeltsin Envoy To Chechnya Is Kidnapped Near Border
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's personal envoy to Chechnya was taken hostage by gunmen today in broad daylight on a well-traveled road near the Chechen border. The incident presented the President and his new, untested Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, with a harsh reminder of how little control they have over Russia's troubled southern rim.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about management changes at the McDonald's Corporation referred incorrectly to the outlook for job reductions in a reorganization of its headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill. While cuts are expected, the company says the specific number is unannounced, not 2,700.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK AT 3-MONTH HIGH. The mark rose sharply in advance of a weekend European Union meeting where approval of the Jan. 1 introduction of the euro is expected. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7799 marks from 1.7957.

title: After Fresh Kills, What?
description: Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island started 50 years ago as a temporary answer to the urgent question of where to put New York City's trash. Since then, the dump has assumed the proportions of a small mountain range -- 2,200 acres of garbage cresting in some places at 250 feet. Fresh Kills, the world's largest landfill, is scheduled to close on Dec. 31, 2001, which, as it happens, will also be Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's last day in office. That gives the Mayor a fairly clear idea of how much time he has left to bequeath the city a workable strategy for handling its gigantic stream of garbage.

title: Korean Trade Surplus Set Record in April
description: South Korea posted a record trade surplus of $3.93 billion in April, compared with the deficit of $1.41 billion a year ago, the Commerce, Industry and Energy Ministry said yesterday in a preliminary report. South Korea's trade surplus for the first four months of this year stands at $12.34 billion, compared with the deficit of $8.73 billion in the corresponding months of 1997, the ministry said.

title: Missing: One Banker and $66 Million; Trail Grows Cold as F.B.I. Hunts for Loan Officer With a Zest for Living
description: The $66 million man began his strategic descent into invisibility in late February, and by now it seems complete.

title: I Told You So
description: Writing in the most recent issue of The International Economy, William Greider used the occasion of Asia's economic crisis to settle some scores with conventional economists who scoffed at his 1997 book, ''One World, Ready or Not: The Manic Logic of Global Capitalism.'' ''They're not scoffing now,'' he declared. As it happens, he's wrong: they're still scoffing. Conventional economists never denied that crises happen; it was his explanation of why and how that they thought was silly.

title: Souvenirs
description: To the Editor: I too have a ''Storytelling Souvenir'' (April 5). While dining in a Parisian restaurant with a group of friends, I spied upon our table a pretty painted ashtray imprinted with the name of the restaurant, and, coveting it for my souvenir collection, I surreptitiously swooped it into my tote bag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNER, MAE
description: YOUNER-Mae. At age 89, in Florida, on April 30. Dear mother, proud grandmother and almost great-grandmother. Services on Sunday, May 3, 1:30PM, Parkside Chapels, Queens.

title: Stillness, and Then Farewell to a Firefighter
description: A long blue line of firefighters stretched along Jericho Turnpike today.

title: 'Empire by Default'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lives; Just Desserts
description: As a child I was content to have my time planned for me. School, piano lessons on Tuesday, dancing classes on Thursday, and Saturday mornings (a loony idea of my mother's) something called elocution lessons. I remember a lot of deep breathing and loud and embarrassing yodeling.

title: SOAPBOX; Shot
description: HEROIN has stolen the character of our neighborhoods. Andrea Kannapell's article about suburban heroin users in New Jersey (April 12) was timely and reported many of the important issues surrounding the newest resurgence of heroin. I was touched by the underlying story, the tragic loss of innocence and childhood ways, by the young people who become ensnared in the heroin culture.

title: Beautiful Schemers
description: Gary Cooper and Ingrid Bergman play period birds of prey in high-style plumage in Sam Wood's SARATOGA TRUNK (1945), based on Edna Ferber's novel of a New Orleans vixen and a cowboy bucaneering among railroad tycoons. The picture brims with so much color, from the French Quarter of Old New Orleans to the upstate New York resort hotel in Saratoga, that some viewers recall its black-and-white scenes in Technicolor. It is rarely shown on TV, or anywhere, so a taping might be in order to savor the glamorous adventurers whom Ferber fondly christened Clint Maroon and Clio Dulaine -- THURSDAY/EARLY FRIDAY at 2 A.M. on TURNER CLASSIC MOVIES. Howard Thompson

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: It was gratifying to see Lisa Belkin's article about a birth mother in your special issue (''Now Accepting Applications for My Baby''). Gina Bruystens is portrayed as going through her pregnancy and adoptive placement in a straightforward and determined manner. For many birth mothers, however, this is an emotional, sometimes mournful, time.

title: Viagra Wants to Be (Taken) Alone
description: Gay men in New York began circulating an important warning through social and on-line circles last week: Viagra, the much ballyhooed drug to treat impotence, doesn't mix with drugs commonly known as ''poppers,'' which are used to enhance sex.

title: Gingrich Sees Echo of Ancient Rome in America Today
description: Capping a week of strongly worded, intensely partisan jabs at President Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich used a weekend appearance in this Republican stronghold to invoke comparisons between Mr. Clinton's actions in office and the forces that led the Roman republic toward ruin.

title: Ms. Shapiro, Mr. Brookstone
description: Julie Anne Shapiro, a daughter of Iris and Floyd Shapiro of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Andrew Jay Brookstone, a son of Carol and Stephen Brookstone of Baldwin, N.Y. Rabbi Peter E. Kasdan officiated at the Green Brook Country Club in North Caldwell, N.J.

title: Ideas & Trends: Media Glamourfest; The Dinner, the Heartburn
description: EVERY year, Washington reporters congregate in droves at the White House Correspondents Dinner and compete for the best guests as they invite the famous and the notorious to dine. Then every year, they spend days afterward wondering out loud what possessed them.

title: Turning Timeless, Lilting Melodies Into Pop Stardom
description: PERHAPS the most incongruous hit in recent memory is ''The Mummers' Dance,'' a song that features exotic instruments like the oud and the hurdy-gurdy and was inspired by an ancient group of tree worshipers.

title: Katherine Wong, Robert Evans 3d
description: Katherine Robin Wong, a daughter of Liz F. Johnson and Jue Hoy Wong, both of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Robert Clements Evans 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans Jr. of New York. The Rev. Pamela Higgins, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the bride and bridegroom's home in San Francisco.

title: Spillers of Ink (And Blood) Join Rub-Out Editors
description: THE SETTING: New Mystery magazine's annual reception at the Lock Museum, on West 44th Street, where, it has been promised, ''locks, wine, cookies and celebrities will be served.'' The magazine publishes hard-edged stories by James Ellroy, Andrew Greeley and less-known writers. Its issues have lurid, pulp-style covers and themes like Bad Dogs and Bad Women.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, ETHEL
description: BERLINER-Ethel. On May 1, 1998. Age 91. Devoted sister of David Berliner. She will be sadly missed by family and friends. Service Sunday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Fear of Fun: Why Men Hate Dinner Parties
description: THE pink Cristal Champagne was flown in from France, and the rack of lamb was made to order by the chefs at Mortimer's. All so Ilyse Wilpon, whose family is an owner of the Mets, could entertain 113 friends at a private dinner recently.

title: EUROPEANS ACCEPT A SINGLE CURRENCY DESPITE LATE SNAG
description: A bold European Union plan to begin a common currency among 11 countries next year got underway this morning after temporarily running aground over a dispute between France and Germany about who should run the new European central bank.

title: Sheets, Towels And Prayers, In One Stop
description: Stand on the Avenue of the Americas between 38th and 39th Streets and watch the double takes as people walk past the little Millinery Center Synagogue. A man is selling sheets and towels just inside the front door.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHISOLM, LAWRENCE WASHINGTON
description: CHISOLM-Lawrence Washington. Died April 29 of cancer, at his home in Buffalo. Born February 7, 1929, New York City. Son of Ruth Anderton and William Garnett Chisolm. Graduated St. Mark's Academy and Princeton, class of 1950. Served as Lieutenant, U.S. Navy, 1950-53. Ph.D. 1957 Yale, where he taught until 1968. Established American Studies Department at the State University of New York at Buffalo, where he taught for 30 years. A warm and generous man and a gifted teacher, he is survived by his wife, Patricia Shelly; five daughters from a prior marriage to the late Elizabeth Richards Chisolm: Anne Huntington, Ruth Hamilton, Elizabeth Palmer, Susan Richards and Sarah Edings; and nine loving grandchildren.

title: Pencils and Phones Are Also Useful Tools
description: To the Editor:

title: Czars to Bolsheviks
description: RUSSIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, TERRY J.
description: MARTIN-Terry J. On April 27. Beloved husband of Janet, loving stepfather of Rodney. You will be missed very much.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A happy, spirited adventure about World War II? Not all that absurd. In fact, John Sturges's GREAT ESCAPE (1963), about a Nazi stalag, is a highlight of the films on television this week. Portraying Allied prisoners of war, fine actors compete for honors, starting with James Garner and Donald Pleasence (above), Steve McQueen, Richard Attenborough, Charles Bronson and James Coburn. This exciting melodrama, superbly scenic and depicting a true, mass escape plot, cuts from the flight to the pursuers for its tension and suspense. The location filming adds authenticity -- Saturday at Noon on TBS.

title: Lyme Testing
description: New York Medical College and the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla are seeking 300 children, 4 to 18, for a study of a Lyme disease vaccine, which has been successfully tested on adults.

title: Keeping Alive the Work of Maxwell Anderson
description: IT has been a tough time, a time for survival and a time of change, but the Maxwell Anderson Playwrights Series is still here. And to prove that an organization named for an old-style, once-celebrated playwright can be a life-enhancing model for a new generation, the torch is being passed from professional playwrights whose new plays in staged readings inspired the series, to youngsters for whom writing plays is an act of discovery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DR. LOUIS N.
description: KAPLAN-Dr. Louis N. 90, Hollywood, FL, April 29, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Dora Haiblum Kaplan, loving father of Dr. Marcia Rudy and Dr. Mark H. Kaplan, dear brother of Herman Kaplan and the late Frank Caplan and Alex H. Kaplan. Loving grandfather of Debra Rudy Reichman, Jennifer Rudy, Noah, Ethan and Daniel Kaplan, and father-in-law of Carol Dosik Kaplan. He was a dedicated physician for 40 years of practice in Brooklyn, and as a Captain in the US Army during WWII. We were blessed with his love and devotion to family, his love of culture and art, his value of hard work and his determination and optimism.

title: This Is a Simulation
description: The User Illusion

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: Let's see -- one adoption agency received $12,500; a second, $6,000; the adoptive parents got the child of their dreams. And Gina Bruystens, struggling to pay her bills, received $400 a month, had some medical bills paid during her pregnancy and got a box of new maternity clothes. Oh, I almost forgot. Her son got a stuffed animal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISSON, CARL LOUIS
description: BISSON-Carl Louis. Beloved life partner of John Lembo, departed this life on May 1, 1998, in New York City. A friend, confidant, and teacher to all who were blessed by his spirit, his ministry survives him. To have known this sweet man was to have experienced the true love and grace of God herself. Memorial service to be held on Friday, May 15, 1998 at 7 PM at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 W. 73rd St., New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGGINS, JACK H.
description: WIGGINS-Jack H. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Jack H. Wiggins, associated with The Times from 1948, until retiring in 1977.

title: Unions Worried
description: Union members, claiming they were betrayed by the County Executive they supported for election last fall, demonstrated in front of the Rye Town Hilton late last month to protest a lack of contracts for more than 9,000 county workers.

title: Could Israel Ever Be a 'Nation Like Others'?; Expelled by Arabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONES, HYMAN IRWIN
description: KONES-Hyman Irwin. Of Hollywood, Florida, formerly of Riverdale, New York. Passed away Wednesday, April 29, 1998. Loving husband of Marilyn, adored father of Sheryl Baker and Ilene (Dr. Peter) Wohlgemuth, cherished grandfather of Adam, Danielle, Ashley, Joshua, and Michelle.

title: Officer on Street Patrol Is Grazed by a Bullet
description: A plainclothes officer in Brooklyn was grazed by a bullet in the leg last night after a man who had been stopped for questioning turned and fired a revolver, the police said.

title: A Simpler Starr Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPY, BEATRICE K.
description: LIPPY-Beatrice K. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving aunt of Joan Bogart & Harriet and Robert Browner. Great aunt of Tara and Nelson Spiess, Russell Bogart, Craig Browner and Eric Browner. Graveside services Sunday 1PM at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALKOT, ANNE KARRIS
description: PALKOT-Anne Karris. Of Garden City, New York, on April 29, 1998. Wife of Edward J. Mother of Edward, Barbara Hymans, Patricia Abdellatif and Gregory. Grandmother of Donald Jr., Robert, Christine, Thomas, Stephen and Joseph. Visitation Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave., Garden City Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass St. Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City Monday 9:45 A.M. Interment following Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, N.Y. Donations to Mercy Medical Center, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: All-Female Show on Feminine Viewpoint
description: GIVEN the preponderance of female artists, it is no surprise to find nine of them exhibiting at the Candace Perich Gallery here. Numbering 62 prints, most of them black and whites, ''Close to Women, the Intimate Perspective'' would be a straightforward show were it not for its purpose.

title: POSTINGS: Consent Decree in Line-of-Sight Lawsuit on Sports Fans in Wheelchairs; Leveling the Playing Field
description: No matter when -- or where -- New York's new stadiums are built, it can be said about them with some certainty that fans in wheelchairs will have as good a view of the field as everyone else, even when the rest of the crowd is on its feet.

title: Relentlessly Nurturing the Odd Child Within
description: THE world's most popular adolescent is a 36-year-old Canadian with a 10-year-old daughter, two ex-wives and an enthusiasm for colonic therapy. ''It's a great way to find old jewelry,'' joked Jim Carrey, whose singing buttocks in ''Ace Ventura, Pet Detective'' helped make him Hollywood's most bankable star.

title: Dishing Darwinian Dirt
description: Although the instinct to gossip may have some evolutionary basis, this does not mean that we ought to embrace such behavior (Word & Image: ''Dishing Darwinian Dirt,'' by Max Frankel, April 12). Many of our greatest ideals emerge from a sense that we ought to transcend what may be the lesser angels of our nature. Interestingly, in addition to the wealth of philosophical and theological admonitions to refrain from speaking ill of others, there may be a more proximate, more compelling compass -- the human heart. Few of us can gossip about others without feeling ashamed that somehow we are doing wrong.

title: Robert Smink 3d, Tiffany West
description: Tiffany Berry West, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Togo D. West Jr. of Washington, was married there yesterday to Robert Daniel Smink 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Daniel Smink Jr. of Berwyn, Pa. The Rev. Luis Leon performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Jean Anne Swope, a Presbyterian minister and a cousin of the bridegroom, took part in the service.

title: Q and A
description: Finding Real Flamenco

title: A Renewed Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: Analysts Are Stars of This Investing Universe
description: GALILEO proved that the earth revolved around the sun. Now the new State Street Research Galileo fund wants to prove that stock-picking can revolve around analysts.

title: N.J. LAW; Law Tames Wanderlust Of Shopping Carts
description: Not long ago, Jersey City residents were nearly as likely to find a shopping cart on their street corner as in their supermarket.

title: Setting It Straight
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLOSTER, RICHARD S.
description: CLOSTER - Richard S. Dear Reuven, trying to live as you taught and you are beside us with every step. Love endures. Miren and Dad

title: Born to Be Wilde
description: Until recently, the British actor and writer Stephen Fry had an apartment on the Upper East Side, in the Carlyle House. Fry loves New York, and he liked his apartment, but he sold it to his upstairs neighbor, Jay McInerney, who plans to build a staircase between the two floors and spread himself out. Fry realized he was the only person in New York who could allow the McInerney family to expand into four bedrooms without terrible upheaval and expense. ''Nothing else would have worked,'' Fry says. ''It would have seemed churlish not to sell it to them.'' For fear of seeming churlish, Fry gave up one of his homes. He is an unusually polite man.

title: Civil Obedience
description: If Mayor Giuliani can introduce civility to New Yorkers, and Mayor Antanas Mockus of Bogota can teach manners to the citizens of his city, then perhaps schools can change inappropriate student behavior. For too long, we have essentially disregarded students' lack of respect for teachers and overlooked the bullying, the verbal harassment and the pushing, shoving and hitting that frequently take place on school grounds, in classrooms and in the halls.

title: It's Prime Time for Fertilizer
description: SPRING is probably the busiest time for gardeners -- cleanup, mowing, early planting, catalogues to study, nurseries to visit and perennials to stake. In between, gardeners should and do take time out to enjoy the glories of the season. Blossom after blossom bursts out and the land is aglow.

title: Lynn Chase, Richard Flintoft
description: Caroline Prentice Chase and Richard A. Flintoft were married last evening at the Racquet and Tennis Club in New York. Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye of the New York State Court of Appeals officiated.

title: Israel at 50: Drowning in History; Why Oslo Still Matters
description: If an Israeli Rip van Winkle had slept from 1948 to 1998, he probably would not recognize his country today. What was once a besieged wasteland inhabited by survivors of the Holocaust and refugees from Arab lands has become a vibrant democracy and a technological and military power that has absorbed Jews from every part of the world. It has won wars of survival and has engaged in a process of peacemaking with its neighbors. Israel is a revolution. Parallel to its rebirth and the building of a modern state, Israel has been engaged in a struggle to change fundamentally its relationship with the non-Jewish world, especially the Arabs. Central to this effort is the solution of the Palestinian issue.

title: Favorites Continue To Falter In Derby
description: The streak continues, inglorious, frustrating those caught in its vortex. Not since Spectacular Bid, in 1979, has the previous year's champion 2-year-old colt won the Kentucky Derby. Spectacular Bid also was the last favorite to win this race. Today, in the 124th Kentucky Derby, two horses were swallowed by that growing black hole that sits in the stretch at Churchill Downs.

title: Lydia Geddes, Matthew Jacobson
description: Lydia Lawrence Geddes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Maxwell Geddes Jr. of Oyster Bay, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew Kerr Jacobson, the son of Mrs. J. Francis Serr of Rochester and William S. Jacobson of Manetowoc, Wis. The Rev. Paul E. Gilbert officiated at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: Immigrant Children Thrive in English Immersion; Wired for Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: April 26-May 2; Cut! Let's Try That Again.
description: Stanley Kubrick has been compared to Greta Garbo and J. D. Salinger. Notoriously secretive, the Bronx-born director, who is one of the great filmmakers over the last 25 years, is a bit of an eccentric. He rarely travels outside his home near London, has various phobias and obsesses about every single detail in his movies.

title: Mental Patients in Shore Towns Are Moving to New Homes
description: Some Jersey Shore towns that have been inundated with former mental patients since the 1970's are experiencing some relief, thanks to a carefully planned program that closed five troubled boarding homes and found new, often better housing for about 200 residents.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you have cancer and you are a mouse, we can take good care of you.''

title: Yuiko Sato, Tsutomu Fujimoto
description: Yuiko Sato is to be married today to Tsutomu Fujimoto at the Fort Tryon Park Cafe in New York. The Rev. Benjamin Feller, an interfaith minister, will perform the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Q and A
description: Finding Real Flamenco

title: From TriBeCa to Inwood: Where the Meetings Are
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Battery Park, Civic Center, Financial District, South Street Seaport, TriBeCa; third Tuesday of month; next meeting May 19, 5:30 P.M.; Solomon Smith Barney, 388 Greenwich Street. Board Chairwoman: Anne Compoccia. District Manager: Paul Goldstein. (212) 442-5050.

title: The Wrong Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Albright Finds Unalloyed Love in a Newly Minted Democracy
description: After her difficult and often tendentious negotiations with Chinese leaders over everything from human rights and democratization to trade and Tibet, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright basked today in the attention of the plucky young democratic reformers of Mongolia.

title: For Six Million Lost, a Memorial in Music
description: WHEN Roger Ames, a composer whose operas, musicals, oratorios and liturgical music are performed throughout the United States and Europe, was asked to write a choral-orchestral piece about the Holocaust in the early 1990's, his immediate response was an unequivocal no.

title: Changing Lives Over the Summer
description: Growing up is difficult in neighborhoods where the streets are crowded and unsafe. For children in this stifling confinement, two weeks on a farm, in camp or in a rural community are more than a vacation. The new surroundings and friendships change how children see the world and themselves.

title: Everybody Out of the Pool
description: AT THE WATER'S EDGE

title: Getting Out the Message on Breast Cancer
description: WALK into the Shoprite Supermarket in West Haven on a Thursday afternoon and you'll see more than just groceries. Standing in the doorway right before the produce aisle are Gerry Anderson and Nilsa Cogdell, missionaries of sorts, whose calling is women's health.

title: Drawn to a Story Of Art and Rape
description: WHATEVER first attracted Agnes Merlet to the paintings of Artemisia Gentileschi, the subject of Ms. Merlet's film ''Artemisia,'' it wasn't the work's decorative quality. ''I was a student at the Fine Arts Academy in Orleans,'' she said in a telephone interview from Paris, where she lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCOLN, SOL
description: LINCOLN-Sol. Of Riverdale, NY, and Delray Beach, FL, died May 1, at the age of 93. Loving husband of Anne for 72 years. Devoted father of Rowena (Charles) and Bruce (Elaine). Cherished grandfather of Linda (Lynne) and David (Cassie), Melissa (Joseph) and Lori. Adored great-grandfather of Cory, Jennifer, Grant and Grace. Services will be held on Sunday May 3, at 1:30 PM, at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ.

title: PULSE; Flower Power
description: Six months ago, Eugenia Kim was an editorial assistant at Allure magazine. These days she is busy shipping her flamboyant hats to Elle, Women's Wear Daily and Mademoiselle. Last fall for fun, Ms. Kim, a 24-year-old Dartmouth graduate (major: psychology), took a class on millinery at Parsons School of Design, and her bright chapeaux caught the eye of SoHo store owners and shoppers like Cindy Sherman. Now her pastel straw cloches and cocktail hats, adorned with butterflies or shocking daisies (above), are $70 to $300 at Bond 07 (7 Bond Street at Lafayette Street) and Barneys New York. Her towering mohawk headband for $200 is a hit with clubgoers. For fall, Ms. Kim has crafted Erte-inspired hats, including one with purple guinea-hen feathers. ''Editors say it's the year of the bag, but I think it's the year of the hat,'' said Ms. Kim, stroking a pink marabou-and-Mylar creation. ''I like to make decadence an everyday thing.''

title: PULSE; Squishy Toes
description: As the temperature rises, a woman's thoughts turn to her feet -- specifically, how to make her callused soles, worn rough by winter footwear, ready for revealing sandals. This month, Borghese will introduce an alternative to the arsenal of files and razor blades. Its Spa Socks ($38.50 at Saks Fifth Avenue) may look like ordinary cotton socks, but slip one on and you will feel the difference. The cool, squishy lining is actually a patented gel polymer developed by the medical community to speed healing after surgery and burns. Working with the body's heat, the rubbery layer releases vitamin E, ceramides and grape-seed, jojoba and canola oils to soften callused skin while preventing moisture from escaping. Worn for 45 minutes twice a week, the socks last three months (longer than most summer flings). Martha McCully, Allure magazine's beauty director, tested them and said that although they ''felt like putting on wet tennis shoes,'' they did the trick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENDERS, CHARLES M.
description: ENDERS-Charles M. 87 years old. Died April 25, 1998 after a long battle with Alzheimers disease. Beloved husband of Miriam Russo, widowed of Alline Driscoll, loving father of Tim, beloved brother of Sue Winston and Katherine Flack. Born 1910 in Hershey, PA, Chuck graduated with a B.S. in Chemistry from Purdue in 1932 & received an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1933. During WWII, Chuck served as a Captain in the Signal Corps of the U.S. Army stationed in Philadelphia. After the War, he became a Senior Partner in the investment banking firm of F. Moseley & Co. and was instrumental in the organization of the Howard Johnson Corporation of which he became a Director. Private family services were held in Plant City, FL. Friends who knew and loved him may celebrate his memory by donating to the National Alzheimers Association.

title: Political Briefing; New Orleans Test Of Clean Government
description: For much of his political career, Mayor Marc Morial of New Orleans has been dogged by a rumor that he was once hospitalized for snorting cocaine. Time and again he has denied the rumor, calling it ''false, false, false, a thousand times false'' at one point when the local newspaper, The Times-Picayune, published a detailed article that pinpointed the date of the incident as Sept. 13, 1986, and the treatment site as Mercy Hospital.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: TGI Says Goodbye to Times Sq. As Rents Enter Tomorrowland
description: The booming real estate market in Times Square drove out a chain restaurant popular with after-hours office workers as TGI Friday's, at 1450 Broadway, on the corner of 41st Street, closed its doors at the end of March. It had been open about 10 years, according to the Riese Organization, the owner.

title: Credit Where It's Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Spires, Gargoyles and Bytes
description: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, considered the largest cathedral in the world, is one of New York's most magnificent sights. But until recently, visitors to the church at 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue had little to guide them. Now the cathedral has revamped its Web site, offering viewers an extensive virtual tour of St. John the Divine, begun in 1892 and said to be larger than the cathedrals of Chartres and Notre Dame combined.

title: After School in the Stacks
description: From the second-floor balcony at the Brooklyn Public Library, Jundallah Smith, 17, and Ricardo Leriche, 19, eyed a tete-a-tete in the lobby.

title: Trees, Traffic and a Street Fight
description: The greening of Greenwich, a plan to plant trees on Greenwich Street and narrow it to two lanes from six on the eight blocks between Hubert and Chambers Streets, is a relatively small project. But there is nothing small about the dust-up it is causing, involving a titan of commerce, well-known restaurant owners and a movie star.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about development in Ocean Shores, Wash., misidentified a developer of the area that went bankrupt.
