That developer was Wendel West & Associates, which had purchased the property from the original developer, MacPherson Realtors. The article also misidentified the seat of Grays Harbor County. It is Montesano, not Aberdeen.

title: Trucker Convicted
description: Glenn Stewart, a Port Chester truck driver, has been convicted of manslaughter in a hit-and-run accident that killed 3 1/2-month-old Arianna Schmidt two years ago, Steven Weiss, an Assistant State's Attorney for Connecticut, said.

title: Game, Set, Advice
description: Cue the spotlight: the tennis coaches are ready for their close-ups.

title: Bosom Foes Together Again
description: IT would have been an odd evening, that's for sure.

title: Announcing a Boycott (Drinks Provided)
description: Hoping to stir up interest in its news conference to ''launch a boycott of California,'' the National Licensed Beverage Association announced in bold letters at the bottom of the fax it sent to news offices: ''Cocktails and Beverages Provided.''

title: Steal This Burger
description: I was interested to read that ''two-thirds of the food purchased at Burger King is consumed off-premises.''

title: Philip Johnson's Glass House
description: To the Editor:

title: Winding Down on Whidbey
description: DAWN on Saturday, and the Little Leaguers have yet to stir. We are headed north, out of Seattle, then west to the shores of Puget Sound, zipping past the Boeing barns stuffed with half-built 747's. Downhill to the shore, and then -- the first shock of the weekend -- no line for the car ferry at the town of Mukilteo. The crossing on a pane of saltwater takes no more time than it does to finish a cup of coffee and realize that the most crucial bit of news in the morning papers is that the Seattle Mariners are in desperate need of pitching help.

title: Backtalk; It Takes Two: Ballroom Dancing Steps to Front
description: ''In the beginning, the man must be dominant,'' says Lee Wakefield, who sounds to me like Future Coach. ''The man leads. He creates the opportunities that the lady completes and enhances. But he has to give her the chance to fill the space. Then she becomes the more important one because she must produce the final result. In the end, it is an equal relationship.''

title: Form vs. Content
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volkswagen New Beetle; After Beetlemania Fades, Will the Beat Go On?
description: ENOUGH, already. Yes, the Volkswagen New Beetle is cute. It is adorable. It is unique. It is cool. It gets attention -- so far, at least -- everywhere it goes.

title: THE BOATING REPORT; Even at Starting Line, Adventure and Peril Arise
description: The nine boats in the Whitbread Round the World Race are at the end of a 10-day layover in Baltimore. The 31,600-nautical-mile odyssey restarts today for the eighth of nine legs, 3,390 nautical miles across the Atlantic from Annapolis, Md., to La Rochelle, France. The current standing places EF Language first over all, with Swedish Match in second. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women's crew of EF Education of Sweden, which stands eighth over all, will continue to file periodic updates of life at sea until the race's scheduled return to Southampton, England, later this month. This is her 17th report.

description: To the Editor:

title: Divorce and the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANKS, ELMER L.
description: BANKS-Elmer L. 72, Deacon of Abyssinian Baptist Church passed away on April 24, 1998. Survived by beloved wife and family. Remembrances to ALS Foundation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20

title: Pattern and Decoration, Abstract and Otherwise
description: ''GO west, young man'' may have been the catch phrase for 19th-century pioneers, but for artistic pioneers, then and now, a more appropriate slogan might be ''Look east.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOBADIN, STEPHEN
description: SLOBADIN-Stephen. The Board of Directors of the Prescott Fund for Children and Youth, Inc. express our profound sorrow on the death of Mr. Stephen Slobadin, our president and colleague. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Elizabeth Anne and family. For over a half century he dedicated his life on behalf of underprivileged children. The Prescott Neighborhood House, The Prescott Nursery School and The Prescott Fund thrived under his leadership. He set up summer camps and provided tuition assistance to those wished to attend college. He will be greatly missed. Memorial service to follow later. The Board of Directors

title: Habitats/281 Cumberland Street, Fort Greene; A Chance to Renovate And Own a Family Home
description: THE stairs leading to the rotted doorway at 281 Cumberland Street in Brooklyn were crumbling. The garden-level windows were boarded over, the cornice deteriorated. In a tidy block of renovated historic homes between Greene and Lafayette Avenues in Fort Greene, they caught the eye -- first because of the disarray, then because of the racket.

title: Hi-Tech Decor on the Hudson in Irvington
description: NICHES holding lovely colored light tubes punctuate the soaring walls of Bridge Street's spare cavernous spaces. In fact, this successful conversion from dusty warehouse to industrial chic has changed little since the restaurant's opening two years ago. When the weather cooperates, the outside area in front of the restaurant is a pleasant place for dining or having an aperitif. Only here is there a view of the Hudson River so glittery on one evening that the parking lot sharing the dock almost disappeared into the silvery air. Inside, as before, what windows there are face the railroad station.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEAVER, JOHN H.
description: WEAVER-John H. Former Sr. Vice President of Brown, Harris & Stevens. Memorial service May 4, Monday at 11 AM at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Ave. & 53rd Street.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: PRESCRIPTION FOR DISASTER

title: On Filming a Gonzo Vision: A Gonzo Dialogue
description: ON Sunday, April 5, the artist Ralph Steadman and the director Terry Gilliam, who are friends, met at Mr. Steadman's house in the English countryside to talk about Mr. Gilliam's new movie, ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,'' which opens on May 22. Based on the landmark 1971 document of American cultural disequilibrium that was written by Hunter S. Thompson and illustrated by Mr. Steadman, the film stars Johnny Depp as Mr. Thompson's alter ego, Raoul Duke, and Benicio Del Toro as his partner-in-lunacy, Dr. Gonzo, who go on a drug- and alchohol-fueled jaunt into the desert in a crimson convertible. To capture the 2 1/2-hour conversation, which careered from topic to topic -- the movie, the book, art, film, old times, drugs and the idiosyncrasies of Mr. Thompson -- Mr. Steadman set up four tape recorders and a video recorder. ''Appropriately, it is a work about paranoia,'' Mr. Steadman explained. Here are excerpts.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: In a Pair of Halls, Celebrating Seasons
description: ONE HUNDRED years of musical service are being observed today at 3 P.M., divided between the Waterbury Symphony, closing out its 60th anniversary season at the Armory, and the Danbury Community Orchestra, lighting 40 birthday candles in Ives Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHASE, REV. WILLIAM JAMES
description: CHASE-Rev. William James. A Memorial Service will be held at St. James Church, 71 and Madison Avenue, Friday, May 8, 11 A.M.

title: Shangri-La Without the Frills
description: GAZING at a village in northwestern Nepal, its stone houses glued to the slopes of a landscape more stark and tumultuous than the imagination could ever fashion, I wondered how and why people had ever penetrated these unforgiving canyons or built their village in such a spot. My husband, Phil, and I were trekking through Inner Dolpo, whose ethnic Tibetan villages may be the most remote in the world. What drove these people? Invading enemies, drought and hunger, or perhaps mystic visions?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZEKERES, JANOS
description: SZEKERES-Janos. Co-founder of the Savin Corporation died April 20th at his home in Stamford, CT. Born in Hungary, Mr. Szekeres attended the University of Vienna in Austria for his graduate studies and doctoral program in textile chemistry. During W.W. II he served as an aerial photographer in the US Army Air Corps and was awarded the Silver Star, Air Medal, American Defense Service Medal, Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Silver Service Star, Victory Medal, Philippine Liberation Ribbon and the Presidential Unit Citation with Silver Oak Leaf Cluster. Mr. Szekeres introduced the photo-copier diffusion process to the American market in 1951 and was granted a patent for the electrostatic copier using liquid toner in 1957. He went on to found the Savin Corporation. He was a member emeritus of the Chemist Club, the Oriental Ceramic Society, the Art Appraisers Association and the Gemological Institute. Mr. Szekeres also belonged to the Princeton Club, the Stamford Yacht Club and the Lighthouse Point Yacht & Racquet Club in Florida. He served on the Board of Directors of the International Chinese Snuff Bottle Society and on the Collections Committee of the Arthur W. Sackler Museum at Harvard University. He also had been on the the boards of the Everson Museum in Syracuse, NY and the Stamford Museum and Nature Center. Surviving are his wife Erna Szekeres, daughters Andrea Szekeres and Eva Levine, a sister Katalin Stapelfeldt and four grandchildren. Contributions in memory of Mr. Szekeres may be made to the Salvation Army, 1033 Washington Blvd., Stamford, CT. 06905 or the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Road, Stamford, CT 06903.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHTER, MARGARET RUTH
description: RICHTER-Margaret Ruth. On Saturday, April 25. In lieu of flowers, donations may be given to the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, MILDRED E.
description: BRAVERMAN-Mildred E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Mildred E. Braverman, associated with The Times from 1969, until retiring in 1991.

title: Opium Puts Myanmar In Crisis Over AIDS
description: At sidewalk tea stalls where Burmese men socialize over cups of fragrant black tea, proprietors in some towns have added a lucrative sideline -- heroin -- and use the same syringe to inject as many as 25 to 40 customers.

title: Bodies to Go
description: Life can be rough abroad. Interpol estimates that in major Russian cities, like Moscow and St. Petersburg, the homicide rate has ballooned to twice New York City's, and things aren't much better in countries like Taiwan and Mexico. Many countries are now importing freelance American medical experts to assist often overwhelmed pathologists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ALICE
description: SMITH-Alice, April 21, 1998. Services were private. Deeply devoted to the performing arts. Family and many friends mourn her passing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKLAR, HORTENSE
description: SKLAR-Hortense. On April 30, 1998. Loving wife of Ben for over sixty years. Devoted mother to Howard and Sharon Sklar and Adrienne and Gary Adelman. Adored grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Robyn Squeo and Glenn Gmyrek
description: Dr. Robyn Fannie Squeo, a daughter of Philip J. Squeo of Alpine, N.J., and the late Lillian Squeo, was married yesterday to Dr. Glenn Anthony Gmyrek, a son of Marie and Ferdinand Gmyrek of Garfield, N.J. The Rev. Boniface Ramsey officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Steal This Burger
description: Arthur Lubow's interesting article ''Steal This Burger'' (April 19), on the McDonald's-Burger King rivalry, didn't even touch on the key factor in my fast-food-decision process: the toy!

title: Pot Smokers' March Is Out of the Park
description: It was the pot smokers versus the baby toters in Greenwich Village yesterday, and the smokers lost. Nudged along by an imposing cadre of police officers, marchers at a pro-marijuana rally yielded Washington Square Park to mimes, face-painters and ponies at the first city-sponsored Family Day in the park.

title: Enjoying Cherry Blossoms' Moment of Glory
description: AT the Botanic

title: Report Says U.S. Is Lax in Screening Foreign Drug Ingredients
description: Nearly 80 percent of the chemical ingredients for prescription drugs sold in the United States are imported, but Federal investigators say in a new report that the Government has failed to police the safety and purity of the products shipped to this country.

title: Christina Auth, Laurent de Marval
description: Christina Elise Auth and Laurent Xavier de Marval were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. Canon Harry Krauss performed the ceremony.

title: Living Antiquity
description: As an Egyptologist specializing in mummies, Dr. Bob Brier likes to take a personal approach to ancient mysteries. A year ago he introduced viewers to his Tutankhamen murder theory; tonight, in THE GREAT EGYPTIANS II, he presents Ramses the Great, depicted in a 19th-century painting above, as the pharaoh who may have defied Moses. Then there's Tutankhamen's father, Akhenaten, a deformed rebel and monotheist, and Hatshepsut, the woman who would be king and still have an affair with a commoner. Dr. Brier gleans his theories from hieroglyphs, artifacts, mummies and monuments, including the obelisks at Karnak temple and the Rushmore-inspiring Abu Simbel, where Ramses the Great carved his image out of a mountain -- SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on THE LEARNING CHANNEL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, DAVID
description: SCHNEIDER-David. Age 77, died at home on Friday, May 1, 1998, of cancer. He was retired Chief Executive of El Al (North America) and prior to that Marketing Manager (USA) for British Airways. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Claire, three adoring daughters, Stephanie, Amy, and Tina, and seven grandchildren. Services will be held 11:15 AM, Sunday, May 3 at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76 Street, New York City. Donations may be made to the David Schneider Memorial Fund, Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, New York City 10022.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 19 with an article about the conductor Valery Gergiev misidentified the orchestra he led in January. It was the New York Philharmonic, not the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: A Woman's Crusade Results In Saving a Melville School
description: ALISSA SUE TAFF of Huntington sat down at her kitchen table and began leafing through three stacks of documents gleaned during her seven-year campaign to win the reopening of her neighborhood elementary school.

title: Bond Sale to Lower Electric Rates
description: In a matter of days, the first segment of the largest sale of municipal bonds ever undertaken in the United States will mark a milestone in Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to cut Long Island electric rates by 20 percent.

title: Classic Coke
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Salomon: A Smaller Fish in a Bigger Pond
description: JUST last summer, Salomon Brothers was an independent investment banking firm struggling to broaden its core bond-market franchise into equity markets and investment banking -- and to put memories of the Treasury scandal behind it.

title: Math, Math Everywhere
description: NEATLY dressed in a shirt and tie, Luis Andrade studied the computer in the reservations office of the Hyatt Regency in Greenwich. His job was to determine the total room rate for a family staying six days in a $224 room -- a snap, perhaps, for the hotel's regular staff, but Luis is only in the fourth grade.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Reflex Reaction: The Funny Bone of the 90's
description: Do you find the proliferation of cable stations funny? Do you smile at the idea of Julia Roberts seated at the same table as Norm Ornstein?

title: THEATER; The Erotic Story of Lulu Returns to Seduce Paris
description: THE theatrical and musical traffic across the Rhine has always been busy, although a lot of it seems to depend on misunderstanding and myth, especially when it comes to the erotic.

title: Once More to the Well of Hardy's Rural England
description: AS sure as there are lambs in spring -- a certainty of farming life that most of us were forced to take on faith even before the cloning of Dolly -- screen versions of Thomas Hardy's Victorian agricultural epics seem destined to proliferate. And no wonder. Hardy is perhaps the most cinematic of all 19th-century novelists. A writer best known for his panoramic vision of the English countryside, he is equally the master of highly charged close-ups, scenes so intensely visual that character and setting are emblazoned on a reader's consciousness.

title: Disappointment Follows Vetoes Of State Spending
description: IN Westchester, as in other parts of the state last week, bitter disappointment followed Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of $1.6 billion in proposed state spending. High hopes were dashed for new library services, improved school buildings, richer arts programs and other items included in the original fiscal proposal. And many state legislators who had been exulting about this year's almost on-time budget -- one that was hammered out in the open rather than behind closed doors -- were forced to deliver bad news to constituents in an election year.

title: A Queens Version of Gramercy Park, With Barbecues
description: With her feet propped on the edge of a sandbox, Catherine Doran lounged in a puddle of warm sun on a bench in Sunnyside Gardens Park on Tuesday. Every so often she glanced at her 18-month-old daughter playing on a sliding board with a motherly 10-year-old. Twenty feet away, where she could not even see it, Ms. Doran's handbag rested on a stroller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNICK, MINNIE
description: SKOLNICK-Minnie. On April 26, 1998, at ninety-nine years old. Dear Minnie, our treasured grandmother and great-grandmother, may you rest in peace. We thank you for all the love you brought into our lives. You leave a legacy of dignity, extraordinary grace, humor, wit, and a lifetime of fascinating stories. You leave a deep void in our lives. The wisdom that you imparted to us will be treasured forever. We will always cherish you and everything about you. Sheila, Jaime and Michael Gleicher

title: Could Israel Ever Be a 'Nation Like Others'?; Still Not Full Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Devils Simply Couldn't Score, and Ottawa Benefits
description: WITH the Devils trailing, 2-1, before the third period last night, Lou Lamoriello, their general manager, stood in a hallway high in the Corel Center.

title: Lisa Norwitz, David Stamm
description: Lisa Ann Norwitz and David Aron Stamm are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Max Hausen at the Pen Ryn Mansion in Bensalem, Pa.

title: Europe, Unified Against Itself
description: In Brussels, the leaders of the European Union make the historic decision to proceed with a monetary union of, initially, 11 nations. In Washington, the Senate votes for the enlargement of NATO to include Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Some Europeans will today be celebrating the former as the long-awaited birthday of a new European superpower, to rival the United States, while lamenting the latter as a premature American-led adventure.

title: In America; Pursuing the Children
description: The Times's Jack Curry had a story in last Sunday's sports section about Curt Schilling, a star pitcher with the Philadelphia Phillies who was first introduced to smokeless tobacco when he was 15.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Lives Not Quite Lived
description: Sudden death and early loss haunt the characters in Douglas Hobbie's sorrow-filled third novel, THIS TIME LAST YEAR (John Macrae/Holt, $23). Henry Ash, grieving for the loss of his daughter (a young woman who died from a lingering disease with slow and savage self-awareness), is spending the summer alone in Vermont. Henry's summer project is a study of Melville, Whitman and Dickinson entitled ''Loners.'' In his spare time, he reads James's novel of renunciation, ''The Ambassadors.'' His second wife, Elizabeth, while traveling in England, struggles to reconcile herself to the prospect of sharing Henry's grim new reality. In Vermont, Henry lives in a house once inhabited in body and now in spirit by Fitz, a man who was afraid to live his own life fully and who was felled before he could realize his best intentions. Also vacationing in Vermont is Helen, a book editor from New York who has recovered physically, but perhaps not emotionally, from breast cancer surgery. The lives not lived by the characters in this novel, like the lives not lived by the American eccentrics whose work Henry reads, call out for redress. While most of the narrative is told in Henry's constrained prose, some of it is reported in Fitz's confessional journal, in Elizabeth's detached postcards and in Helen's urgent telephone calls. Sadness, loneliness and loss have many voices. Yet all the voices in this carefully controlled and beautifully balanced novel fairly shout one message -- carpe diem. Barbara Fisher

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALKENSTEIN, DR. DAVID B.
description: FALKENSTEIN-Dr. David B. The Executive Council and Members of the New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy are deeply mournful for the loss of a beloved friend and colleague. One of the founders of the Society, he was consistenly active in the 24 years of the Society's existence. His dedication to the Society was unparalleled; he gave of his time & efforts unsparingly. David was a dedicated educator; an inspiration to a generation of gastroenterologists. He is beloved by his family, friends, colleagues, and patients. He will always be remembered for his generosity of spirit; his winning smile and quick wit; he is laughing with us now. We will never forget him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUILLERMO, ELLEN J. (NEE ASH)
description: GUILLERMO-Ellen J. (nee Ash). Beloved wife of Frederico. Wonderful daughter of Arthur Ash and the late Mildred (Silver) Ash. Sister of Kenneth N. Ash & sister-inlaw Terri Rojna Ash. Succumbed to a long, valiant battle of metastatic breast cancer on April 21, 1998. Donations in her memory may be made to Hospice of the North Country, Inc., Plattsburgh, N.Y. 12901. Services and burial were held in Plattsburg, N.Y.

title: Samantha Jones, Daniel O'Brien 2d
description: Samantha Findley Jones, a daughter of Ann F. Jones and Frederick E. Jones Jr. of Jupiter Island, Fla., was married there yesterday to Daniel Bryce O'Brien 2d, a son of Wendy W. O'Brien and Daniel B. O'Brien of Amenia, N.Y. The Rev. Seymour St. John performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel.

title: The Life and Times Of the Father of Ma Bell
description: THE mighty Bell telephone network began -- commercially, anyway -- on a February day in 1875, when Alexander Graham Bell signed an agreement with two partners (one his father-in-law) to start a company that would oversee his patents.

title: Leader of the Pack: Still at Large
description: Sunnyside Gardens residents are breathing a bit easier after one of a pack of wild dogs they think has been terrorizing their community was captured and killed a week ago, but they are also upset that the leader of the pack is still at large.

title: Horne's Accompanist, on Piano and at Movies
description: Ask the pianist Brian Zeger, 40, about his first encounter with Marilyn Horne, the world-famous mezzo-soprano, and he'll tell you that he was wearing his bathrobe at the time.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: GREETINGS FROM

title: Fleeting Intimacy
description: SPEAKING WITH STRANGERS

title: British Airways Locks Its Departure Gate on Fifth Avenue
description: For 41 years, employees at the British Airways ticket office on Fifth Avenue between 44th and 45th Streets have arranged travel plans for customers, but on Friday they prepared for a different kind of departure: their own.

title: Staying Alive: The Habit Of Working
description: ON a recent Tuesday, Charlie Pound, 78, rose at 5 A.M., showered and ate in his Armonk home and made it to New Jersey for his first appointment of the day by 7. Eleven hours later, he had not stopped working.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Recalling How We Got to the Moon
description: WITH the HBO special ''From the Earth to the Moon'' capturing viewers across the country, Tom Hanks, the actor, producer and director, may accomplish a feat that no American President has accomplished since John F. Kennedy: recommit this nation's resources to push farther into outer space.

title: On Language; The Return of Joe Six-Pack
description: ''If I were just a private citizen -- Joe Six-Pack,'' President Clinton told Time magazine after Paula Jones's lawsuit against him was dismissed by a judge in Little Rock, ''I would have mixed feelings about not getting a chance to disprove these allegations in court.''

title: April 26-May 2; Hello, Medicare? Hello?
description: For decades, Medicare officials have boasted about the tiny share of their budget spent on administrative costs. But now the people who care for millions of the elderly and disabled are suggesting that Congress may be penny-wise and pound-foolish.

title: Philippe Parola
description: Philippe Parola, a native of Paris, is the chef at the Bear Corners Restaurant in Jackson, La.

title: County Takes Up Idea Of Rights Commission
description: WOULD Westchester County have had a better way of dealing with the bias against black employees at Texaco that audio tapes revealed if the county had had a human rights commission? Would such a panel have been able to deal with -- maybe even educate enough to prevent -- anti-Semitic graffiti in Mamaroneck and elsewhere? Could such a commission help insure equality of life for residents?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRASNOW, ANNA
description: KRASNOW-Anna. May 3, 1898July 20, 1978. Today would have been your 100th birthday. A tribute from your children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. You are always in our thoughts. You have twelve great-grandchildren, three girls are named after you. Our love for you will live on as long as we live. Your loving family.

title: Irabu's Own Coach
description: Mel Stottlemyre strolled to the mound here in the eighth inning Friday night to discuss matters with his tiring pitcher, Hideki Irabu, who had just walked the leadoff hitter. The Yankee infielders gathered around.

title: Abbey Road
description: To the Editor: Re the Q & A ''Beatle Crossing'' (April 19). As a full-time recording engineer at Abbey Road Studios from 1958 to 1968, I must have used that zebra crossing at least 7,000 times but did not choose such a lengthy route as you describe. Coming out of St. John's Wood tube station, cross Wellington Road to Grove End Road and continue down this road until you reach Abbey Road. The crossing is to your right and you will have walked only half the distance of Joseph Siano's route!

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Hey! See You at the Next Concert.
description: I DON'T play sports, I don't belong to clubs, I don't have an after-school job, and I'm not an actress. I don't have any time for these activities. Instead, my life is simply one big concert. At last count, over 100 bands have strutted their stuff in front of me.

title: It's Prime Time for a Little Bit of Fertilizer
description: SPRING is probably the busiest time for gardeners -- cleanup, mowing, early planting, catalogues to study, nurseries to visit and perennials to stake. In between, gardeners should and do take time out to enjoy the glories of the season. Blossom after blossom bursts out and the land is aglow.

title: Could Israel Ever Be a 'Nation Like Others'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Industry Courts Congress
description: Facing huge legislative stakes and suffering from a battered public image, the tobacco industry has rained contributions on almost every incumbent in Congress, dispensing special largesse to proven allies while still giving generously to occasional adversaries, according to a study commissioned for The New York Times.

title: The Wrong Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: City Condo With Community on the Mind
description: DURING renovations at the Woodland House condominium in Hartford a few years ago, residents discovered a sculpture and learned that it had been created by the artist Sidney Simon. The mobile had been commissioned for the lobby of the 12-story apartment building, constructed in 1963 by Norman Zaubler, a developer. So, with the help of $15,000 from an anonymous donor, they found the artist (who repaired the work) and had the restored sculpture rehung.

title: Art Classes
description: To the Editor: I noticed a request for names of painting workshops taking place in Italy this summer (Q & A, March 1). As dean of professional studies at Pratt Institute, I would like to bring your attention to our programs in Italy.

title: April 26-May 2; Dodging Rubber Chickens
description: It's tough being a politician. They campaign and campaign, until they finally retire. But even then, like a perpetually wound-up toy, they are expected to keep on campaigning -- for their party's youngsters.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; A Cure For Instant Obsolescence
description: YOU'RE standing in the aisle of Micro Center, looking to jump beyond the sluggish performance of the Pentium 133 machine you bought in 1996. You notice that a new Compaq machine is marked down -- but that a newer I.B.M. looks awesome.

title: Ideas & Trends; Laying to Rest the Last of the Unknown Soldiers
description: PRESIDING over the ceremony adding the remains of a soldier killed in Vietnam to the Tomb of the Unknowns in 1984, President Reagan vowed that the nation would never abandon its efforts to account for all those still missing from that divisive war.

title: Q&A/Dr. Joseph Fashing; Race, From Perspective of a Sociologist
description: THE subject of race and what it means to one group as opposed to another is a subject that evokes passionate reactions. Such was the case last month when Purchase College sponsored a panel debate, ''Real Black/Real White,'' where the question of racial identity was explored.

title: For Newborns, Greeting Cards With Immunization Reminders
description: Along with the diapers and bottles, new parents in New Jersey will now also get a greeting card from Governor Whitman and her husband, John. In addition to ofing congratulations, the Governor will be remind the parents to have the child immunized against common childhood diseases.

title: Tchaikovsky's Opera of Dark Cravings
description: UKRAINIANS, beware! Despite what you may have read in these pages, Tchaikovsky's opera ''Mazeppa,'' which will receive its second performance by the Kirov Opera under the direction of Valery Gergiyev at the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow evening, is no paean to Ukrainian nationalism. True, its title character is venerated as a patriot in Ukraine today. But he is the opera's villain, not its hero. And that, of course, is how it had to be. To write a paean to Ukrainian nationalism in czarist Russia was a sure one-way ticket to Siberia.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Entertainment Showcase

title: Linda Kulman and Ralph Alswang
description: AMONG friends, Ralph Alswang is known for his ability to talk himself into or out of almost any situation. He's the kind of person, friends say, who will tell convincing sob stories and cry if necessary while begging the police officer not to ticket his car. An official White House photographer by profession, he is also known for giving giant bear hugs.

description: THE nation's hottest mutual fund companies have an important message for new investors: Go away.

description: Colette Jane Iacobellis, the daughter of Jane G. Iacobellis and Dr. Francis W. Iacobellis, both of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Allen Newton Jones 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones 3d of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Novak performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title: The Yarns of a Countess
description: The chat at Mortimer's has been about backgammon. Why? Maybe because Countess Sheila de Rochambeau, who makes needlepoint backgammon boards, was in town, staying with the Park Avenue socialite Nan Kempner, or because several of her elaborate boards have been in Bergdorf Goodman's 58th Street windows -- by the entrance used by chauffeur-driven shoppers.

title: The Welfare State Is Alive, if Besieged, in Uruguay
description: On the sprawling plains of Uruguay, where sheep and cattle far outnumber people, the milkman still makes home deliveries by horse and buggy. Elementary school children wear dour uniforms of the same style their grandparents wore. People still turn to radio more than television for the news, and a national hobby is collecting classic jalopies.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Patsy Kensit; A Child of Daisy Buchanan, Fashionably Rock 'n' Roll
description: FILMGOERS might remember Patsy Kensit from the cult favorite ''Twenty-One,'' in which she spoke directly to the camera in frank terms about her love affairs with a married man and a junkie. (''He's a junkie, but apart from that he's a clean-living guy.'') Or they might remember her as a voluptuous Victorian in ''Angels and Insects,'' adapted from an A. S. Byatt novella. But few probably retain an image of her very first role.

title: Group Tours, Pro and Con
description: ''FOR all its drawbacks,'' my brother-in-law said as we boarded a waiting bus at the airport in Catania, Sicily, ''group travel sure cuts down on the stress of arrival.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, SAMUEL S.
description: COHEN-Samuel S., M.D. Dearest Sam, May 1st, your 85th birthday. You are always with us. Love, Rhoda, Herbert, Mark and Alice

title: Strictly Extravagant
description: This was once a standard-issue Upper East Side apartment, with small, boxy rooms and traditional detailing -- but not anymore. The architectural firm of Gwathmey Siegel & Associates transformed this 2,300-square-foot dwelling into a more open, expansive space with an emphatically modern air. And the austerity of its design is balanced by sensual materials that were assembled with meticulous care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINGER, FREDERICK FURTH
description: BERLINGER - Frederick Furth. Died at his home in Palm Beach, FL on May 1, 1998. Beloved husband of Geraldine Q. Berlinger. Father of Robert G. Wilner and Virginia W. Newmyer. Also survived by six grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. Funeral services private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Alzheimers Association, 919 No. Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60611.

title: The Nation: Thanks a Bunch, Viagra; The Pill That Revived Sex, Or at Least Talking About It
description: IT is now well accepted that the diamond-shaped blue pill is a wonder of the modern age, a restorer of hope to the hopeless, the ultimate growth stock and, yes, in the blink of the CBS eye, already a tired joke at cocktail parties. But Viagra is now ascending to a yet loftier status, that of Topic One for America's would-be intellects, as seemingly everyone from subway to salon waxes ponderous or salacious or both in the rush to instant analysis.

title: Hilary Appelman, Will Yurman
description: Hilary Louise Appelman, a correspondent for The Associated Press based in Jerusalem, and Will Howard Yurman, a freelance photojournalist there, are to be married today by Rabbi Dan B. Isaac at the Hillside Inn in Wyoming, N.Y.

title: Ellis Island's Other Side
description: Since 1954, when Ellis Island was closed, its south side has lain untouched and neglected. The buildings have fallen into disrepair, including a hospital and confinement wards for immigrants who were too sick to pass directly through the main entrance on the north side. Water percolates through roofs and along walls. Corridors are lined with broken glass and upstart weeds. To the ghostliness of the empty rooms -- filled, it almost seems, with the memory of the sick and dying who once lay there -- nature has added its own ghostliness, compounding neglect with invasion. It can be hard to remember that just a few years ago the north side of Ellis Island -- now fully restored and America's third most popular national park -- looked just as forlorn.

title: You Too Can Be a Giga-Grifter
description: TO: THE CLASS OF 1998

title: April 26-May 2; Senate Approves NATO Expansion
description: A vestige of the cold war died when the Senate voted 80 to 19 to expand the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to include three former Soviet bloc foes, Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.

title: Real Quiet Gives Baffert Second Straight Derby
description: For the second year in a row, and nearly the third, a horse trained by Bob Baffert won the Kentucky Derby as Real Quiet drew clear in the homestretch of Churchill Downs today to win America's premier horse race by half a length over Victory Gallop. For good measure, Baffert took third place with his previously undefeated Indian Charlie.

title: Plane Crash Reviews Facing Long Delays
description: The National Transportation Safety Board is taking twice as long to investigate plane crashes as it did five years ago, primarily because of continuing inquiries into the crashes of T.W.A. Flight 800 in 1996 and a USAir flight near Pittsburgh in 1994. Experts question whether the delays mean a flaw in equipment, training or procedures could cause more than one crash before being corrected.

title: Cabo San Lucas
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, it was with great interest that I read Leslie Wayne's story, ''Where the Desert Meets the Sea'' (March 29). Ms. Wayne traced many of the same steps that I followed.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Sari of the Gods

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LOWER EAST SIDE/EDENWALD

title: HOPE IN THE LAB: A special report.; A Cautious Awe Greets Drugs That Eradicate Tumors in Mice
description: Within a year, if all goes well, the first cancer patient will be injected with two new drugs that can eradicate any type of cancer, with no obvious side effects and no drug resistance -- in mice.

title: Nuclear Fallout; A Whole New World of Arms Races to Contain
description: American officials who do daily battle against the spread of dangerous military technology must feel like a bunch of punch-drunk prize fighters.

title: A Fitting Destination for Francophiles
description: NEUILLY sur Seine is a mini-vacation in France. This attractive storefront in Port Washington has straight-from-Paris good looks. It is defined by French posters; impressionist paintings; traditional, multi-paned French doors; a pretty mahogany service bar and a trio of brass chandeliers. Sturdy chairs with silk brocade seats look as though they were plucked from a mansion's formal dining room.

title: Ideas & Trends: Chaos Theory; Unlearning the Lessons of Econ 101
description: THERE it goes again. Just when economists were wisely preparing a fat and happy America to face the inevitable unpleasant fallout from last summer's Asian financial crisis, the Government reported last week that things are going better than ever. Inflation is more or less gone. Jobs keep going up and growth continues.

title: Immigrant Children Thrive in English Immersion; Money Isn't the Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Rejecting Petitions, F.C.C. Supports TV News as Free Speech
description: Weighing the impact of violence on local television news against the First Amendment, the Federal Communications Commission has come down on the side of free speech, rejecting a petition to withdraw the licenses of Denver's four largest local television stations.

title: Don't Even Think About It. (The Cupid Cops Are Watching.)
description: ''Were you and sally making out in the back seat of a car at 11 last Friday night?''

title: In the Nation; Hollywood (the Other One) Gets a Makeover
description: FOUR years ago, Kitty Ryan took a drive through downtown Hollywood.

title: Marine Biology Class Offered to Youngsters
description: IF you have children in seventh, eighth or ninth grade, chances are they will be more knowledgeable than you this summer at the beach -- if they take the new marine biology course offered by the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLMAN, DANIEL
description: PERLMAN-Daniel. We will always remember Danny with lasting affection for his soft manner, sharp wit, bright intellect and compassion for the disadvantaged. The warmth of his friendship will be with us forever. The Shabbas Group

title: To Read The Omens in An Early Spring
description: ''NATURE'S first green is gold,'' said Robert Frost of early spring, and this year, Connecticut is cashing in with one of the earliest springs in memory. Everywhere, everything is bursting forth several weeks ahead of the normal schedule.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILSON, GOODWIN W.
description: GILSON-Goodwin W. May 3, 1991 Seven years today and ''not a day goes by ...''

title: Kaoriko Kuge, Frederick Katayama
description: Kaoriko Kuge and Frederick Hiroshi Katayama, news anchors in New York, are to be married today at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Emile E. Dumas will perform the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Pegram And Baffert Celebrate Friendship
description: They are closer than brothers. They are doppelgangers, sharing each other's pain, feeling each other's joy. Their bond seemingly reached its highest point at last year's Kentucky Derby, but the trainer Bob Baffert and the owner Mike Pegram went one better today.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: It's a bit confounding that you chose a stay-at-home mother to feature on your cover when most of us work, many out of necessity. It's even more perplexing that you chose a stay-at-home mother who is so financially comfortable that she can still take ''lots of vacations,'' including an annual family trip to Barbados.

title: CUTTINGS; A Gardener's Cornucopia on the China Road
description: OF all the world's flora, one-eighth grows within China's nearly four million square miles -- 30,000 species of plants, compared with 10,000 species for all of Canada and the United States. Many ornamental landscape plants in American gardens are native to China, including the ginkgo (Ginkgo biloba), weeping willows (Salix species), paperbark maple (Acer griseum), Kousa dogwood (Cornus kousa), Sargent crab apple (Malus sargentii), kiwi (Actinidia deliciousa), beauty bush (Kolkwitzia amabilis) and Korean stewartia (Stewartia koreana).

title: Frederic Gehring Dies at 95; Was 'Padre of Guadalcanal'
description: The Rev. Frederic Gehring, the World War II Navy chaplain who plunged into jungle combat with the First Marine Division in 1942 and came out with a battle-scarred little Chinese girl who became an inspiring symbol of hope at a time of national despair, died on April 26 at a hospital near his home in Orlando, Fla. He was 95 and known as the Padre of Guadalcanal.

title: There's a Comedian And a Sax in My Hair
description: A cafe and hair salon co-exist at Tonic, and the owners are dreaming of more. The cafe section opened at the end of March, following the hair salon by a month at 107 Norfolk Street between Delancey and Rivington Streets.

title: Where an Ancient Hero's Memory Lives On
description: IN his passion for history, Michael Wood likes to search out those corners of time that survive more as romantic myth than as reliable memory, that float in the past seemingly unconnected to the world as we know it. He usually starts his journeys in the pages of ancient manuscripts, a world he first explored as a history student at Oxford University three decades ago.

title: Trolling for 800 Lifeguards
description: The guy in the pool was flailing away at the water. He was trying to swim 50 yards in 35 seconds to qualify for training as a city lifeguard, but it wasn't going to happen.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on April 19 with an article comparing the hamburgers and marketing strategies of McDonald's and Burger King misstated the weight of a single patty in a McDonald's Big Mac sandwich. It is 1.6 ounces, not 3.2. There are two patties in the Big Mac.

title: Renters With Low Incomes Found to Be at Risk
description: More than 40 percent of low-income renters in northern New Jersey are spending at least half their incomes on housing, which means that many end up homeless if anything in their lives goes wrong, according to a Federal study released last week.

title: Still Singing, Still Dazzling, Still Here
description: NOT since Moses parted the Red Sea has anyone pulled off such a perfect division. Ann Miller, dressed in red from top to toe, stepped into the lobby of the Paper Mill Playhouse, splitting the box office line that stretched past the front entrance for tickets to the revival of ''Follies'' in which she co-stars. Her red knit pants clung to her famous long legs and her red jacket sported epaulets of gold braid. Her gold watch flashed, her gold earrings did, too. She had black pin curls at her temples, blue eye shadow clear up to her drawn-in eyebrows, false lashes, red lipstick and matching fingernails.

title: Switzerland's Lasting Demon
description: In ''Switzerland's Lasting Demon'' (April 12), Amos Elon writes that in 1938 the Swiss Government gave in to Germany's demand that passports of Swiss Jews be marked with a big J.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Active-Adult Communities Gaining in the North
description: SLOWLY but steadily, the construction of active-adult communities is pushing deeper into the northern part of the state, where developers say the demand for such housing outstrips the supply.

title: Linda Eder, Frank Wildhorn
description: Linda Eder, an actress and singer, and Frank Neal Wildhorn, a composer and record producer, are to be married this afternoon at their home in North Salem, N.Y. Justice J. Emmett Murphy of State Supreme Court in Goshen, N.Y., is to officiate.

title: Murdock Regrets a Gesture In Emotion of the Moment
description: While he was growing up in Bridgewater, N.J., sports gave Eric Murdock a chance to forget that his father abandoned him, sometimes even that his mother had died when he was 6 months old, killed by a car as she crossed a street.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: The photograph that accompanied Peggy Orenstein's article ''Almost Equal'' made me angry. Why is Doreen Lorenzo's husband, Michael Scully, sitting with his back to the camera? Is he ashamed that he is not the breadwinner and therefore did not want to be identified by the photo? Is he uncomfortable being identified as a man who is filling the role of caretaker?

title: London Weekend
description: To the Editor: All praise to Letty Cottin Pogrebin and her husband for their long London weekend in January in ''Packing (the Schedule) for the Weekend'' (March 29). A London theater blitz has been one of this past winter's great travel bargains.

title: Fruit, Cars and Now Funds: How a Portfolio Joins a Lemon List
description: FOR many busy investors, faced with the choices of nearly 9,000 mutual funds, it is tempting to look to simple rating systems instead of doing homework. Wouldn't it be great if, for example, someone could tell you when to dump a fund?

title: Don Petersen, 70, Playwright and Screenwriter
description: Don Petersen, a playwright and screenwriter who wrote ''Does a Tiger Wear a Necktie?'' -- in which Al Pacino made his electrifying Broadway debut in 1969 -- died on April 25 at the Senior Lodge in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 70 and lived in Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Jodi Blair, John Pfeiffer
description: Jodi Beth Blair, a daughter of Barbara Blair Kalmus and a stepdaughter of Leslie P. Kalmus of Manhattan, was married last evening to John Curran Pfeiffer, the son of MaryLou and John R. Pfeiffer of Garden City, N.Y. Justice Abraham Gerges of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated at the James Burden Mansion in Manhattan.

title: 'Assassins' Playing At Irvington Theater
description: WHO'S afraid of Stephen Sondheim? Anyone seeking instant gratification in musicals. That includes 100 million people, among them Westchester's producers of professional theater, such as it is.

title: Ideas & Trends; Sometimes, Fat Women Have Lives
description: FORGET about butter substitutes. The real breakthrough for fat people this year is Camryn Manheim.

title: The Very Rich Pay to Learn How to Give Money Away
description: For most Americans, the formula for giving money away is easy enough: Choose the charity and write the check.

title: Spiders and Diamonds and Dogs, Oh My!
description: WANTING a piece of the action on Wall Street but lacking the expertise to go it alone, millions of Americans began investing in mutual funds during the last decade. Then, as most equity funds failed to keep up with the bull market, investors embraced index funds as inexpensive shortcuts to owning the most-sought-after stocks.

title: Genetic Tests Gaining for Adult-Onset Ills
description: THE 42-year-old from Suffolk County had a strong family history of breast cancer. Her mother, a sister and two aunts had died of the disease.

title: Hollywood, Sex and a Sad Estrangement
description: ONE reason we go to the movies is to soak up a kind of erotic energy that only they can provide. There is nothing quite like the voyeuristic thrill of sitting in the dark and dreaming ourselves into the skins of beautiful, larger-than-life people rapt in a kiss. Movies have probably taught most of us more about what passes for romantic etiquette than any textbook or novel or trendy magazine. Hollywood's iconic princesses and vamps, playboys and action heroes have shown us how to flirt, how to kiss and -- without actually showing much of it, even as censorship barriers have crumbled in recent decades -- how to have sex.

title: Susan Littlefield And Martin Roper
description: Susan Liles Littlefield was married yesterday to Martin Francis Roper at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. William E. Wallace performed the ceremony.

title: Could Israel Ever Be a 'Nation Like Others'?; Intifada's Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDMAN, SAMUEL
description: SEIDMAN-Samuel, 98. Of Tequesta, Florida, formerly of Miami Beach, Florida, passed away on April 29, 1998. Mr. Seidman was the loving father of Libby Seidman of Tequesta, FL and Joseph (Ellen) Seidman of New Milford, CT; cherished grandfather of Joe Jr. & Wendy Williams. Graveside services are to be held at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, New Jersey, on Sunday, May 3, 1998.

title: A Place at the Table
description: DON SNYDER still wants in.

title: Red Cross Celebrates Centennial
description: AFTER one of its busiest stretches providing emergency relief in the county and in the state, the American Red Cross in Westchester celebrates 100 years of service at the Centennial Touch of Red Gala on Thursday at the Rye Town Hilton.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: BEYOND LONDON -- Virgin Atlantic Airways has extended its Virgin Values program through the summer, allowing its passengers to London to add one of three options for $69 when they buy a 21-day or 45-day advance purchase fare: round-trip flights on British Midland to 11 cities in Europe, including Dublin, Edinburgh, Glasgow, Paris, Amsterdam, Brussels and Cologne; a four-day rental of an intermediate-size Avis car with standard transmission and unlimited mileage, or round-trip travel on the Eurostar train to Paris or Brussels. In late April, the airline quoted a fare of $599 round trip plus about $70 tax for its 45-day advance purchase tickets from New York to London for weekday travel from mid-June to the end of September; weekend travel costs $50 more round trip. The reservations number is (800) 862-8621.

title: For $5, a Taste of Home
description: MOST people see him as a fruit vendor. And, most days, Esteban Zapata sees himself as just that, a man who stands near the corner of 135th Street and Alexander Avenue in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx and sells fruits from a table shaded by two umbrellas, from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. every day.

title: Elizabeth Darst, Henry Tenney Jr.
description: Elizabeth Standish Darst, a producer, and Henry Baird Tenney Jr., a writer, both at VH1, the cable television network in Manhattan, were married last evening at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens. Lisel Burns, a leader at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: . . . and the Whole Universe Is Outside a Bus Turned Space Shuttle
description: Eleven second-graders dressed in white space suits clutched helmets with blue visors under one arm and waved goodbye to the sea of cheering parents and classmates with the other. Their feet shuffled along the macadam. Then they each took a giant leap on to God's Force I, a school bus turned space shuttle.

title: Sports of The Times; Can-Do Cummings Will Heed the Call
description: IF Terry Cummings could sermonize the Knicks for a few reflective moments this first Sunday morning in May, he would talk about pride and repentance, courage and heart. These are subjects he is an expert on, given the fact that Cummings, an ordained Pentecostal minister, has for years needed a potent drug to allow his heart to beat regularly.

title: The Tao of a Scholar: How China's Literati Lived
description: WHEN museums recreate period rooms, they acquire an aura that lies somewhere between fact and fiction. The furnishings are real, but the setting evokes an imaginary scene the way a doll house does. The effect is amplified when museumgoers confront an entire house like the one created for the exhibition ''Beyond the Screen: Chinese Furniture of the 16th and 17th Centuries,'' on view here at the Museum of Fine Arts.

title: Sara Pozefsky and John Marks
description: Sara Ann Pozefsky, the daughter of Beth Amster Hess of Washington and Dr. Thomas Pozefsky of Baltimore, is to be married this morning to John Mitchell Marks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Marks of New York. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court, a cousin of the bride, is to officiate at the Mark Hotel in New York. Rabbi Miriam Ancis will take part in the ceremony.

title: The Nation; In Your Face, Pro Basketball
description: WHEN the decade began, the prevailing image of the National Basketball Association was the breathtaking vertical leap of Michael Jordan. As the 90's end, it's Latrell Sprewell's hands around his coach's throat -- or the sight of Jeff Van Gundy, coach of the New York Knicks, being dragged around the floor like a rodeo clown last week as he tried to restrain Alonzo Mourning of the Miami Heat in a playoff brawl.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A Place of My Own: The Education of an Amateur Builder

title: Classical Briefs
description: ORCHESTRAL PIECES AND EXCERPTS FOR OBOE

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; He Made the Whole World Listen
description: The invention of the telephone is one of the most celebrated events in American history, but rarely have inventor and invention been better served than in the 400 illustrations, many of them Bell family photos, assembled by Edwin S. Grosvenor and Morgan Wesson in ALEXANDER GRAHAM BELL: The Life and Times of the Man Who Invented the Telephone (Abrams, $45). Bell devoted his life to working with the deaf -- both his mother and his wife had hearing impairments -- and it was his knowledge of the shapes of sound waves, rather than any mechanical genius, that led him to the essential principle of telephony: that an undulating electrical current could mimic the subtle changes in amplitude and frequency that make up human speech. Patent No. 174,465 for ''improvements in telegraphy'' is often called the most valuable patent ever issued, but it opened Bell to more than 600 legal challenges -- the price of holding out against the communications giant of his day, Western Union. Bell went on to invent versions of the metal detector, Dictaphone, iron lung, and flat-disk phonograph record. He experimented in helicopter design and X-ray photography. In between, he edited the National Geographic, looked after the Smithsonian, mentored Helen Keller and very nearly scooped the Wright Brothers on the airplane -- but, characteristically, then generously conceded and praised their accomplishment. Watching Bell advance from childhood to old age in these photographs, one is struck by his openness and serenity, in public as much as in private, and even in glimpses of failed experiments. ''In scientific researches there are no unsuccessful experiments,'' Bell once wrote; Grosvenor, his great-grandson, and Wesson, a film producer, make plain not only the range of Bell's accomplishments, though that was amazing enough, but how consistently they depended upon qualities in his character: to watch, to listen, to understand.David Walton

title: Laura Bandler, Raymond Vollmer
description: Laura Danielle Bandler, the daughter of Sandra and James Bandler of New York, and Raymond Colin Vollmer, a son of Leonard P. Vollmer of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Jean E. Cribari, were married last evening at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Giles R. Spoonhour, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: Small Theaters Hit the Bigger Time
description: WHEN Sammi Gavich came to New York 20 years ago from San Francisco, she had the same dream of being discovered as many an aspiring actor before and since. She took odd jobs to pay the rent and auditioned for plays whenever she could. In the early 1980's, she got a part in an Off Broadway play and her union card from Actors' Equity. Then ''life intervened,'' she said, and she did other things, performing only now and again.

title: Beyond the Sugar Plum Fairy
description: BALLET 101

title: QUICK BITE/Closter; An Uncommon Bakery in Closter Commons
description: Bricks of air, rich dairy cream for mortar, a few crystals of sugar -- that's the delicate miracle called whipped cream. When it's blended for stability with rich egg custard and sandwiched into 17 layers of crepes, that's the immaculate, ethereal angelet layer cake concocted at Gateaux, a bakery so elegantly purposeful it actually gives meaning to the anonymous backside of the gray Closter Commons shopping center in northern Bergen County.

title: A Master From Germany
description: MARTIN HEIDEGGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUIS, TOBI
description: LOUIS-Tobi. Devoted sister of Helen Dilman and best friend of Beverly Zarling. Attended New York University and was a member of Pen, Dramatist Guild and New Dramatist. Graveside services were held-private.

title: Elegy for an Elegist
description: ONLY days before his death in 1996 -- of a heart attack, at 49 -- Larry Levis told his close friend and former teacher, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Philip Levine, that he had an ''all-but-completed manuscript'' of new work. Levis, as had been his habit with all of his books, planned to show his longtime mentor this new manuscript in order to ask his editorial counsel. Sadly, it would soon fall to Levine to edit the startling collection ''Elegy'' as a posthumous one.

title: A Painter's Warm Feelings for a Chilly Season
description: GEORGE BELLOWS: Love of Winter'' arrived at the Newark Art Museum at the same time as spring. A traveling exhibition, it was organized -- unlikely as the place of origin might seem -- by the Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, Fla. While the timing may be a little off, the exhibition offers much more than snow-filled scenery. Rather, it is a bounteous examination, with examples borrowed from far and wide, of a decisive phase in the career of a major American painter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, MAE
description: GOLDBERG-Mae. National Council of Jewish Women, Brooklyn section regrets the passing of Mae Goldberg, our devoted board member. Services 10 AM Monday, Kirschenbaum, Coney Island Avenue between Aves M and N. Anne Berger, Co-President Rita Berger, Co-President

title: Taking Another Look
description: To the Editor:

title: Frances McIntyre, Arnold Smith
description: Frances Elizabeth McIntyre and Arnold Jay Smith were married on Wednesday by the Rev. Dale Lind at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Venice Adriana

title: Style; Spectator Sportswear
description: Among fashion's most heroic themes in this century is the rise of sportswear, a story that opens in the 1930's. The early chapters are recounted in ''American Ingenuity,'' the current exhibition (through Aug. 16) at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum. The latest installment took place in Paris in March, when Marc Jacobs and Michael Kors, two American designers who are currently among sportswear's leading exponents, presented their debut collections for Louis Vuitton and Celine, respectively.

title: U.S. Lawyers May Go After More Leaders Of Teamsters
description: The indictment of the teamsters' former political director, William Hamilton, is part of an investigation in which prosecutors may seek indictments against more senior union officials and some Democratic Party officials, lawyers involved in the case say.

title: China Protests Tibet Movie At Festival in Washington
description: A movie about young Tibetans searching for fulfillment and success has angered the Government of China, which complained this week to organizers of a film festival that the movie was meant to smear Chinese policy.

title: The Ultimate House Call
description: ONE of the nicest things about his job, Joseph F. Corsetto says, is that he goes to a different office every day. It could be in a monumental mansion or a humble ranch, but for three hours someone's house becomes his office, the place where he exercises his expertise.

title: Art Classes
description: To the Editor: I noticed a request for names of painting workshops taking place in Italy this summer (Q & A, March 1). As dean of professional studies at Pratt Institute, I would like to bring your attention to our programs in Italy.

title: Rockies Unleash the Homers, Handing the Mets a Sixth Straight Loss
description: Bobby Valentine does not completely disdain the home run, but he suggests that it is not necessarily a sound formula for victory. ''You live by the home run, you'll die by the home run, too,'' he said yesterday.

title: WIRED UP
description: Along with bike trails and a country club, DC Ranch -- a new luxury-housing development in Scottsdale, Ariz. -- is offering its residents what's billed as the first private ''intranet,'' dubbed Ranch Net. An exclusive, members-only internal computer network, Ranch Net will assign its users E-mail accounts and allow for high-speed ''gateway'' access to the Internet. DC Ranchers can also participate in community forums or sign up for tennis games at the club -- all without leaving the computer. Eventually, Ranch Net will even plug community members into the hospital and soon-to-be-built school. For a new resident like Brad Berry, who intends to move in this summer, Ranch Net is just the thing: he plans to install five computers in his home, to maximize the family wonking. House prices start at $230,000, computers not included.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: In ''By the Numbers,'' Andrew J. Cherlin describes welfare reform as an accidental ally of feminists because it made most Americans accept the propriety of mothers working outside the home. But forcing poor mothers into the low-wage- labor market is not part of the feminist agenda. The feminist agenda is about giving all women the same choices that affluent women have. What choice does a welfare mother have when she does not have a high-school education but has to leave her children in inadequate child care, if she has any, to take a low-wage job without benefits?

title: The Gold Rush Becomes a Walk in San Francisco
description: The Barbary Coast Trail, a new self-guided walking tour of San Francisco, will be inaugurated with a celebration this Saturday at Union Square downtown. The two-hour festivities begin at 11 A.M. and include Chinese lion dancers and a Gold Rush musical revue.

title: Sport Utility Vehicles
description: Should there be a special driver's license required for sport utility vehicles, with their safety problems?

title: Pest Control That Considers Ecology
description: A WARM winter, a snowless February and an early spring. Put them all together and they spell trouble.

title: A Longed-For Musical From Times Gone By
description: AMONG New Jersey theaters' sudden embarrassment of musical riches -- genuine, bona fide and very hard to find -- it's not a bad idea to choose ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn'' at the Forum Theater. Why? Because it's there.

title: Tobacco's Contributions Reach Friend and Foe Alike
description: Gary A. Franks is the great-grandson of a slave who picked plantation tobacco and the grandson of a North Carolina tobacco sharecropper. His father grew tobacco on the same plot that his cousins still farm today. He has ''an affinity'' for the tobacco business, he says.

title: PULSE; Dry Times? Try Hemp
description: Hemp has grown on the public in recent years. Restaurants that cook with hemp byproducts, designers who weave the fiber into clothing and micro-breweries bottling hemp beer have tried to alter the image of the versatile crop, which is banned in the United States because of its association with marijuana. Now the Body Shop has entered the fray: it is offering to heal dry skin and foment a ''fiber revolution'' with a line of moisturizing products containing hemp-seed oil. It arrives in United States stores this month.

title: Immigrant Children Thrive in English Immersion; Let Educators Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Small and Daniel Oreskes
description: Elizabeth Small, a lawyer, and Daniel Robert Oreskes, an actor, were married on Monday at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York. Judge Richard Owen of the Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated.

title: Political Briefing; Penny Tax Increase Is a Big-Ticket Issue
description: The governorship, a United States Senate seat and many seats in the State Legislature are up for election in Ohio this year, but the issue that voters are talking about most in advance of Tuesday's primaries is a proposed penny increase in the sales tax. That issue is so hot that it has spilled over into the Senate race and into some Legislature contests and has flooded the state's airwaves with advertisements for and against.

title: The Rhythm Century: The Unstoppable Beat
description: GIANT ceremonial drums from Japan and humble hoe blades from the hardware store. Calabash rattles from Ghana and a traditional Italian tambourine. Two-headed Brazilian bells, bottlecaps attacked to sticks, even pairs of wooden clogs. If it could be beaten or shaken, tapped or scraped, it was probably on stage at Panorama Percussivo Mundial, the international percussion festival held here in the state capital of Bahia last month. As the final concert ended, all the performers gathered on stage -- carnival bands and pop musicians, virtuoso soloists and scholarly revivers of traditions -- to find their own interstices within a jubilant processional beat. With every subdivision, the rhythm grew stronger.

title: In the Region/Long Island; On the North Shore, Restoration's the Word
description: ZVIA GUTMAN's regular occupation is managing the apartment buildings she owns in Washington Heights, Harlem and the Bronx. But she also spends long hours at her future residence here on Terrace Lane, supervising the restoration of a playhouse that once belonged to Josephine Hartford Douglas, sister of Huntington Hartford, founder of the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company.

title: A View From the Dorm: Cute May Not Cut It
description: MY fleeting thoughts of getting a New Beetle vaporized when I heard that my 73-year-old grandmother had just bought one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, ARNOLD
description: MARSHALL-Arnold. On May 1, 1998, after a courageous fight. Loving husband of Marcia. Beloved father of Alexandra. Dear brother of Johanna. Services Mon. May 4, 1:30 PM, Frank Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue.

title: Telecommuting Will Help Reduce Demand for Roads
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert C. Kirkwood, 93, Former Woolworth Chief
description: Robert Campbell Kirkwood, a former chairman and chief executive of the F. W. Woolworth Company, died on Monday at the Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Mr. Kirkwood, who lived in North Palm Beach, Fla., was 93.

title: The Interview: Adding Insult to Indignity
description: Job seekers have long memories. Those who have run up against the rude and reckless among interviewers begin their letters with interesting headings, like ''Inhuman Resources'' and ''The Interviewer From Heck.'' Those who survive an interview sometimes wind up with a job. But as the E-mail and letters show, they sometimes wind up with psychic scars, or, if they're lucky, a good retrospective laugh.

title: Holy Orders
description: THE SEVILLE COMMUNION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIBACH, FREDA (NEE EBIN)
description: MEIBACH-Freda (nee Ebin). On May 1, 1998. Beloved wife of Aaron Meibach. Dear mother of Ina Lea Meibach, Doris Wallace and Judy Meibach. Mother-in-law of Martin Wallace. Cherished sister of Ida Ebin. An artistic, free-spirited and independent loving mother and wife. Service Sunday May 3, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Princeton Sweeps Two Regattas
description: Princeton swept two regattas at home on Lake Carnegie yesterday, winning the men's heavyweight Content Cup against Brown, and capturing the Goldthwait Cup for lightweight crews against Big 3 rivals Yale and Harvard.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARDNER, ELINOR W.
description: GARDNER-Elinor W. Forever loved, forever in our hearts, forever remembered. Love, Paul, Peter and Lisa, Ken and Jane

title: Yankees Keep A.L. in Balance as the Red Sox and the Orioles Flip-Flop
description: Thank goodness for the Yankees. Otherwise the American League East would be completely discombobulated. The Red Sox up and the Orioles down? That's like saying the Battery is up and the Bronx is down.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: Your issue helped to relieve some of the anxieties for middle-class, professional mothers. Surely, you are going to devote another entire issue to blue-collar and low-income mothers, transitioning from welfare to work.

title: Broker Fees, Too, Can Go Up or Down
description: OFFICIALS of Long & Foster Real Estate, the largest brokerage company in the Washington area, said last month that they were raising their standard sales commission from 6 percent to 7 percent and requiring an extra $149 documentation fee in listing agreements with sellers.

title: An Opera of Yesterday With the Cynicism of Today
description: GIVEN the story line of the virtually forgotten 1928 opera ''Transatlantic,'' by the American composer George Antheil, the self-described ''bad boy of music,'' one can readily understand why the Minnesota Opera put $1 million into an elaborate production of the work, which closed here last weekend, actually a co-production with the New York City Opera. This cynical satire is as up-to-date as the current headlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ANN ROSENTHAL
description: MILLER-Ann Rosenthal. Age 63 on April 30, 1998, of Scarsdale, NY, after a long and courageous battle with ovarian cancer. Dear wife of William S. Miller. Loving mother of Elizabeth M. and Randolph Guggenheimer, III, Mark R. and Tonya Miller, Rachel L. Miller, and Steven W. Miller. Beloved grandma Ann to Laura Claire Guggenheimer, Brian James Guggenheimer and Samuel Yong Miller. Devoted sister, aunt, niece, colleague and friend. Service at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY at 10:00 AM on Monday, May 4, 1998. In Ann's memory a fund will be established at Westchester Reform Temple to provide additional support for those in need of healing as well as comfort for the bereaved.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on April 12, about the Manhattan House apartment block, misstated the previous use of the land it occupies. The site was a car barn for Third Avenue streetcars, not for the elevated line. The article also referred incorrectly to the midblock buildings across 66th Street. They are not walkups; they have elevators.

title: Clinton Seeks To Overturn Land Mine Moratorium
description: With the Pentagon warning of serious threats to American troops around the world, the Administration is scrambling to repeal a law that imposed a moratorium on the use of antipersonnel land mines starting next February.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Summer Memories, to Make and to Treasure
description: Fifty-two years ago, when she was 8, Norma Pritchard traveled from Yonkers to Vermont for a summer as a Fresh Air Fund child. Today she is a 60-year-old diabetic, raising four grandchildren on less than $17,000 a year, but she remembers that summer vividly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEARES, CHARLES
description: MEARES-Charles. Honorary Life Director and past Senior Vice President, National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Mr. Meares was a driving force in the Society's battle to end the devastating effects of multiple sclerosis. As Chairman of the National Commission on Multiple Sclerosis, he led the successful struggle to increase the federal government's support of MS research. He was a mover in the establishment of the International Federation of Multiple Sclerosis Societies. The Society mourns his loss and sends condolences to his family. National Multiple Sclerosis Society Richard L. Snyder, Chairman of the Board Mike Dugan, General, USAF (Ret.), President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEACH, DAVID G.
description: LEACH-David G. The Board of Directors and staff of the Garden Conservancy acknowledge with sadness the passing of Dr. David G. Leach. A world-renowned horticulturist and plant breeder, Dr. Leach was a founding member of the Garden Conservancy board and a valued leader and supporter. His national and international stature added distinction and lustre to the Garden Conservancy and its board. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Francis H. Cabot, Chairman Thomas N. Armstrong III, Pres. Donald J. Bruckmann, Board of Directors

title: What Only-Child Syndrome?
description: Late in the 19th century, researchers at clark University in Worcester, Mass., undertook perhaps the largest study of children that had ever been tried. They sent a questionnaire to teachers around the country, asking them for accounts of ''peculiar and exceptional'' children they had seen in their classes, or remembered from their childhoods, or perhaps read about.

title: Stopping the Jumpers by Reinforcing Calm
description: EVERYBODY knows a jumper. Little jumpers and big jumpers. Wild, knock-over-the-furniture jumpers and muddy, paw-print-on-your-pants jumpers. The most popular excuse is, ''He's just so happy to see you.'' Happy, however, is an understatement. Out of control is a better description.

title: An Anniversary Brings Pride and Resentment
description: Swords of Toledo steel sparkled in the sun, the red and gold banner of King Philip II flapped in the breeze, helmeted pikemen stood at attention. Everything was in place for Manuel Gullon de Onate, a nattily dressed lawyer from Madrid, Spain.

title: April 26-May 2; Brittany Boop, Ashley Crocker
description: Try this: walk into a crowded Manhattan playground and call out, ''Betty, I've got your ice cream!'' The children would look at you as if you'd just stepped off the bus from a seriously weird planet. But call out for, say, Jennifer or Samantha or Brittany, and you'd better have a Good Humor wagon handy. A big one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEGHTE, MARY ALICE
description: VEGHTE-Mary Alice. Of New York City and Canajoharie, New York, died on April 28, 1998 at the age of 75 following a short illness. A graduate of Smith College, she was administrative officer of the tax department at Brown Brothers Harriman for forty-three years. She was an enthusiastic volunteer for many charitable organizations in the city. She was predeceased by her brother, Lewis Veghte Jr., and is survived by her niece, Elizabeth C. Veghte of Cardiff-bythe-Sea, California, and her nephew, William L. Veghte of Seattle, WA. A memorial service will be held in Canajoharie at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Smith College or the Reformed Church of Canajoharie.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Drink or Hold

title: Keeping Up With the Gateses?
description: HER car is a second-hand 1989 Acura, a bit of resistance on the part of Juliet B. Schor to the ''competitive consumption'' that she describes so vividly in her new book, ''The Overspent American.'' The television set is in the coldest, least inviting room of her house -- another bit of resistance. But the well-dressed Ms. Schor gives ground on clothing, participating despite herself in the new consumerism that has been reshaping behavior since the 1980's.

title: Subjective and Abstract Flow in Many Directions
description: International Group Show

title: Fallen Comrade
description: JUMPING THE LINE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRETT, ROBERT
description: GARRETT-Robert. Passed away on April 26, 1998. Beloved brother of Betty Werfel, cherished uncle of Diane Blake and Lauren Kolins. Best friend of Leo Langevin. We will all miss you.

title: DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Civil Obedience
description: I have to admit to feeling somewhat let down after reading John Tierney's ''Civil Obedience'' (The Big City, April 19). As a former New Yorker who will always be a New Yorker at heart, I find rudeness is one of the things I miss most. New Yorkers' tendency toward thoughtlessness is mostly about self- preservation. How I long to be shoved into a stench-filled subway car, surrounded by a sea of faces that dare not look at one another too closely or for too long. And the mad rush through the overpopulated streets, bodies bumping into one another, with no apologies.

title: Promise and Pitfalls of the Euro
description: Eleven of the fifteen members of the European Union are preparing to discard their marks, liras, francs and other national currencies by 2002 in favor of a new currency, called the euro. Their goal is to boost economic growth and political ties. But the euro could backfire, trapping unlucky regions in recession and triggering political resentment when no authority comes to the rescue. Americans can hope that the brash policy works because prosperity in Europe helps the United States grow, even if the rise of the euro diminishes the international clout of the dollar.

title: The Madison Tale
