description: I'M affectionate, loyal and a touch sentimental, but I have no flair for romance, which explains why I was a bit worried last spring as my 10th wedding anniversary approached. We had agreed to celebrate with an overnight getaway from Chicago and our three small children, but it was my job to choose the spot and I fretted that my wife, Michele, would be disappointed. My anxiety grew when I discovered that my first choice, the historic lodge at the scenic Starved Rock State Park on the Illinois River, was fully booked through winter.

title: The Talkies
description: ''You Ain't Heard Nothin' Yet''

title: Managers Hedge. Customers Don't.
description: An odd dichotomy is developing in American financial markets. The managers entrusted with investing cash are keeping their clients' money fully invested. But when it comes to their own investments, they are taking a slightly different course. They are selling.

title: Hartford Civic Center's Hard Times
description: THERE was an eerie, sinking feeling as Joseph Melendi walked the top level of the Hartford Civic Center Mall on a recent weekend.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Making History By Stephen Fry. Random House, $24.

title: In the Arts, Monmouth Theater And N.E.A. Grants Announced
description: It may not be an overnight success story, but in theater parlance, it's certainly a fast-moving one.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WILLIAM STYRON, A Life

title: POSTINGS: For Old Bank, Apartments and Theater; Village Condos And Playhouse
description: A landmark former bank building on the southwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 14th Street and a two-story building adjoining it, will be transformed into an 11-unit residential loft condominium and a 499-seat off-Broadway theater.

title: Empire, Nature And a Good Look At the Male Body
description: IN the world of movies, female pulchritude can flourish anywhere: in the city, the countryside, among Gypsies, salesclerks or chorus girls. Male pulchritude is confined within stricter limits. In general, to witness a semi- or nearly naked male body -- one meant to arouse awe or desire quite apart from the demands or pretend demands of the plot -- certain conventions are locked in place. Viewers must be taken beyond the boundaries of modern life (from ''Tarzan'' to ''Conan the Barbarian''); beyond the boundaries of believable modern life (from ''Tarzan'' to ''Rocky'' and ''Rambo''); into the realm of myth and religion (from ''Tarzan'' to ''The Robe'' and ''Ben-Hur''), or out of Western civilization into myths of other continents and galaxies (from ''Tarzan'' to ''Planet of the Apes'').

title: Food; Under Wraps
description: Naked food, like naked people, has a primal appeal, an elemental immediacy. Wrapped food, like clothed people, tantalizes in a different, more complex way. To wrap is to establish a barrier, and therefore a pause, between raw desire and its object. This pause -- which may be as quick as a gasp or as prolonged as a sigh -- gives time enough to season the instinctual response with reflection.

title: A Defiant Satellite, Georgia Finds Paternalistic Russia's Orbit Inescapable
description: As President Eduard A. Shevardnadze of Georgia was flying home last Sunday from a visit to Turkey, his pilot gave him alarming news. The two Georgian Air Force jets that normally escort the President's plane to guard him against airborne attack were nowhere to be seen.

title: Martinez Takes Yank Tally To 18 of 20
description: Watch the front foot of Tino Martinez when he is batting -- the right foot. Watch how he always strides forward, at the pitcher. A left-hander will throw inside and, where other hitters fall away, Martinez will move forward.

title: Once a Hero, but Now Accused of a Triple Murder in a Death Penalty Case
description: As Thomas Cinquemani sees it, it is impossible to believe that Darrel K. Harris killed three people in cold blood while robbing them, as prosecutors in Brooklyn charge.

title: Building Boats, Building Waterway Travel
description: A MARITIME tradition that has always included Indian peoples in the Northeast has been revived with the building of high-speed passenger boats and the effort to provide ferry service by the Mashantucket Pequots. And stalled so far.

title: Maria Torok, 72, Innovative Psychoanalyst
description: Maria Torok, a psychoanalyst in France whose rejection of Freud's ideas was welcomed in feminist circles and whose new methods for confronting pain and trauma drew many Holocaust survivors to her offices in Paris, died on March 25 at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 72 and had lived briefly in Madison, Wis.

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Screening Faulted

title: Thinking Globally, on the Menu and Off
description: NOTE carefully the definite article in the name of the Hartford restaurant: The Savannah. The reference is to the grassy plains of Africa, in honor of a Kenyan sojourn by the owner's sister.

title: New Jail Is for Youths, but Neighborhood Feels Punished
description: Like a boxer on the ropes in the last round, Reginald H. Bowman knows that he has lost the fight. ''What am I going to do?'' he wondered recently. ''Keep knocking my head against a brick wall?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, BEBE ROSE
description: HOFFMAN-Bebe Rose. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted daughter of the late Max and Esther Lerman. Loving mother of Paul, Dr. Douglas, Karen Mande and Nina Steen. Dear sister of Frances Redlich. Cherished grandmother of eight, great-grandmother of four. Services on Monday, at 1 P.M., Louis Suburban Chapel, Fair Lawn, New Jersey.

title: Vanessa Cutler, John McGarry 3d
description: Vanessa Davenport Cutler, the daughter of Alison Aldrich Fogge and Robert B. Cutler Jr., both of New York, was married yesterday to John Patrick McGarry 3d, the son of and Mr. and Mrs. McGarry Jr. of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Jane Rockman performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in New York.

title: Marvin Worth, Film Producer And Writer for TV, Dies at 72
description: Marvin Worth, a prolific writer and producer whose film credits ranged from black comedy (''Where's Poppa?'') to documentary biography (''Lenny'' and ''Malcolm X''), died on April 22 at U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 72.

title: Web Travel Shopping: The Surf Is Rising
description: TRAVELERS booked $827 million worth of reservations over the Internet last year, a mere pittance for the travel and tourism industries, which measure their size in the hundreds of billions of dollars.

title: Co-Op's Super-Sized Dream
description: The 5,500-member Park Slope Food Cooperative prides itself on being a democracy, so its recent decision to expand came only after a lengthy, sometimes contentious debate. But expand it will. Seventy-nine percent of the 3,500 members who voted favored the group's spending $860,000 to buy Cline's Rug and Upholstery Cleaners, which is next door to its headquarters on Union Street.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Hackensack, N.J.; After Long Decline, Downtown Rebounds
description: THERE is a saying in Hackensack that as goes Main Street, so goes the rest of the city.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: The Middle Passage

title: Queens Welcomes Big Eaters
description: ELIAS CORNER +

title: Immigrant Children Thrive in English Immersion; Schools Benefit All
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Best Sellers
description: HARD COVER

title: Why We Are So Healthy Now
description: THE GREATEST BENEFIT TO MANKIND

title: Homebuyers Spending for the Extras
description: AFTER living in six homes in the last 24 years, two of them newly built, Kevin E. McKenna, a marketing executive, and his wife, Susan, a registered nurse, are now building another. This time, Mr. McKenna said, they are putting in all the extras they never got around to before.

title: The Past Confronted, if Not Recaptured
description: ''FOLLIES'' isn't only a musical. It is a monument. The classic by Stephen Sondheim and James Goldman endures as a metaphor for the sudden examination of a frivolous life, of a sweet time of youth when ''everything was possible and nothing made sense.'' It is a eulogy for the conventions of a bygone musical theater era and a testament of faith in its rebirth.

title: Congresswoman's Story, on TV, Rankles G.O.P.
description: When the television movie that some Republicans are calling the ultimate campaign advertisement is broadcast Sunday night, Representative Carolyn McCarthy will be watching closely in the company of a few relatives and close friends.

title: Port Chester Offers Itself for a Car Show
description: STREET rods, muscle machines, antiques and customs -- they are all welcome at the Port Chester-Rye Brook Street Festival and Car Show to be held on and around Main Street in Port Chester on May 17. The event, from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., will feature bands, ethnic foods and merchants selling crafts, but mostly it will be about cars and more cars.

title: April 26-May 2; Hoffa Cleared to Run In Teamsters Election
description: Under President John F. Kennedy, Federal investigators spent years hounding James R. Hoffa, trying to drive the notorious union leader out of the teamsters' presidency. In an odd twist, Federal investigators paved the way last week for Mr. Hoffa's son to win the union's presidency.

title: Our Towns; Lost Crusader Inspires 'Jenna's Law'
description: BRUCE AND JANICE GRIESHABER never consciously tried to raise bleeding-heart liberals. They left a suburban tract of split levels and ranches for the wide-open countryside when their girls were 7 and 9 for an old-fashioned reason: They wanted a place where they could keep a firm handle on their daughters' lives.

title: Reno Aide Says He Had Urged Special Counsel
description: The Justice Department's top prosecutor for campaign-finance abuses privately told Republican Senators last week that he had urged Attorney General Janet Reno to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, but was rebuffed by Ms. Reno and other advisers, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about commercial property in Rockland County, N.Y., misidentified the owner of the Blue Hill Plaza office development. The owner is Glorious Sun Robert Martin L.L.C.; Mack-Cali Realty leases and manages the development.

title: Rule by Proposition
description: PARADISE LOST

title: Chappaqua Is Host To Cellist
description: THE 22-year-old, Moscow-born cellist Borislav Strulev should feel right at home today at 3 P.M. when he appears as soloist with the Chappaqua Chamber Orchestra at Temple Beth El in Chappaqua. He will play Tchaikovsky's ''Rococo Variations,'' and the rest of the program, arranged by the music director, James Sadewhite, is also Russian. It includes Arensky's ''Variations on a Theme by Tchaikovsky'' and two other Tchaikovsky works, the Suite No. 4, subtitled ''Mozartiana,'' and the ''Serenade for Strings.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, PEGGY L.
description: MOSES-Peggy L. Louise Wise Services for Children and Families mourns the passing of our esteemed Honorary Board Member and friend, Peggy L. Moses. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Charles and their entire family. Glenna R. Michaels, President

title: The World; In Scorching Kurds, Turkey Burns Itself
description: SHORTLY after dawn on a recent Monday morning, a military helicopter lifted off from its base in Turkey's war-torn southeast and crossed the border into northern Iraq. It is a border Turkey has ignored for the last few years, arguing that it has a moral right to strike against rebel guerrillas who operate from the Kurdish enclave on the other side.

title: Selling Peace Proves Difficult For Already Peaceful Dublin
description: At first glance, the agreement aimed at ending three decades of street warfare and other violence in Northern Ireland seems like a political winner here in the Republic of Ireland. In contrast to the North, where it is the subject of relentless and often vitriolic debate, in Ireland the accord has the support of every major political party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEBSTAEDT, ANDRE D.
description: GEBSTAEDT-Andre D., 78. Of Laurel Park, died Tuesday, April 28, 1998, after an extended illness. He was born in Germany and lived for many years in Port Washington, NY. He was Director of Advertising Services for ABC Television until his retirement in 1985. Survivors include his wife of 49 years, Virginia R. Gebstaedt; two daughters, Anne Hammond, of Greenville, S.C., and Kate Gebstaedt of Madison, N.J.; and two grandchildren, Timothy Hammond and Simone Pathe. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, P.O. Box 1066, Asheville, NC 28802. For information contact Thos. Shepherd & Son Funeral Directors and Cremation Memorial Center.

title: INVESTING WITH: James P. Barrow; Vanguard Windsor II Fund
description: ANY way you look at it, James P. Barrow, the manager of the vaunted Vanguard Windsor II fund, will always be skittish. He cheerfully acknowledges hand-wringing when the Dow Jones industrial average first hit 1,000, back in 1972. At the start of the decade, with the index pushing 3,000, he described himself as ''about as nervous as a long-tailed cat on a porch full of rocking chairs.''

title: Out of the Past, An Ur-Feminist Finds Stardom
description: POOR Artemisia Gentileschi. No one ever seems to get her right. Born in Rome in 1593, the daughter of a painter, she was celebrated in her lifetime for her pictures of biblical heroines. Yet she died in obscure circumstances, on an unknown date, and it wasn't until the 1970's that feminist art historians shook the dust from her reputation. They held her up as a shining example of neglected female genius, an honest-to-goodness Old Master (or is it Old Mistress?). It was just a matter of time before she moved from the grad-school classroom to the Miramax screening room.

title: American Empire
description: FROM WEALTH TO POWER

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CISYK, KACEY
description: CISYK-Kacey. April 4, 1953-March 29, 1998. The family and friends of our beloved Kacey would like to invite you to a memorial service to be held on Sunday, May 17, 1998 at 4:30 P.M., at St. Bartholomew's Church, 50 Street & Park Avenue. Please join in a celebration of Kacey's life, her unique spirit, and the joy she gave to each of us.

title: One Year Later, a Second Chance for Houston
description: Allan Houston glanced up and the tears pooled in his eyes. One blink, and they would have rolled right down his cheek. But he managed to gulp and gather himself and express his devastation over what had just happened last May 18 at the Miami Arena.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: I was moved and encouraged by Jane Smiley's sensitive article ''Mothers Should.'' When I gave birth 10 months ago, I never imagined that I'd be judged so harshly for choosing to breast-feed my son. It's O.K. to whip out a bottle in public, but when I nurse him discreetly, in ladies' rooms or in dark corners of restaurants, I often get dirty looks.

title: April 26-May 2; To Some in the Village, Enough Already
description: Greenwich Village, the city's old bohemian heart, is beginning to look a lot like a police state to residents and visitors who say they have become overwhelmed by a spate of police checkpoints, sweeps and roadblocks as part of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's quality-of-life campaign.

title: Steal This Burger
description: Given the opprobrium that has been heaped upon Big Tobacco for deleterious health effects, does not Big Burger seem to be getting off a bit easy?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, DR. RAYMOND
description: STILLMAN-Dr. Raymond. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle records with sorrow the passing of the beloved brother of our treasured member Sylvia Halpern and brother-in-law of Honorary Trustee Harry Halpern. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Dorothy Fox, President

title: Immigrant Children Thrive in English Immersion
description: To the Editor:

title: A Place in Alaska For Man and Sea Lion
description: The northern Gulf of Alaska coast is the focus of the new Alaska Sea Life Center in Seward. The center, a 115,000-square-foot building that links research and rehabilitation with education, was set to open today.

title: Streetscapes/67th Street Between Lexington and Third Avenues; 19th-Century Buildings That Still Make Statements
description: TWENTY years ago, two of the four institutional buildings on 67th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues were headed toward demolition. But all four survived, and with the exterior restoration last year of the Park East Synagogue at 163 East 67th Street, both the fabric and the prospects of this unusual group of buildings have been renewed.

title: South Beach Cuisine Revs Up
description: BACK when Sonny Crockett and Ricardo Tubbs cruised Miami Beach, they had it all. The crime-fighting life, ''Miami Vice'' style, seemed to be a hedonist's cocktail of beautiful women, fast cars and Armani suits, served against a background of white beaches and turquoise water. There was something missing, though: good food.

title: Just Outside School, the Whole World Arrives Via Cargo Container . . .
description: ''There it is! There it is!'' came the cry, as the chartered school bus pulled into the South Kearny rail yard on Thursday morning. Craning their necks, the 21 fourth graders of Maryalice Palisano's class at the Wyoming School in Millburn Township pressed up to the bus windows to peer at the bright blue cargo container atop a truck in a loading bay.

title: Are Trusts' Stocks Poised for Revival?
description: SO far, 1998 has been a bust for real estate investment trusts. Indexes of REIT stocks are down for the year, while the broader market has soared. As speculation mounts that the Federal Reserve will soon raise interest rates to brake a speeding economy, are REIT's headed from bad to worse?

title: In Central Ward, Politics Are Past, Present and Tense
description: For some, the elections here on May 12 are a ho-hum affair in which strong and familiar incumbents are pitted against slightly less familiar challengers at a time when the city is seen as rebounding and reaping benefits from long-planned redevelopment efforts. If the oddsmakers are to be believed, the results in the mayoral race and the nine City Council races are not likely to alter the political landscape greatly nor inject any new stars into Newark's political firmament.

title: Spring Rite: The Search For Gobblers
description: Spring hunting for wild turkeys, the entire month of May in New York State, is not for slugabeds or the faint of heart, although it is a more comfortable endeavor than waterfowling, which also involves considerable stumbling about before sunup.

title: London Weekend
description: To the Editor: I had the pleasure of staying at Dukes Hotel in London in December. Ms. Pogrebin's account is definitely all true. Dukes has rooms of understated elegance and a genial welcoming staff.

title: April 26-May 2; Reducing Multiple Births
description: High-tech reproductive medicine has brought thousands of babies into the world, but at costs and health risks unappreciated by many participants when they first sought help.

title: Jennifer Osborne, C.B. Prescott
description: Jennifer Elisabeth Osborne and Christopher B. Prescott were married yesterday by the Rev. Shannon Leach at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: Lisbon
description: In honor of that intrepid seafarer Vasco da Gama and his journey to India 500 years ago, the Portuguese have organized celebrations the likes of which have never been seen in this onetime imperial capital. On May 22, Lisbon opens the gates to Expo '98, with a record participation of 154 countries and the theme ''The Oceans, a Heritage for the Future.'' During Expo's four-month run, visitors can discover the beauty, riches and challenges of the seas through scores of exhibits. There will also be nautical competitions, daily multimedia shows, live entertainment and food from around the world.

title: An American Nightmare
description: TROUBLE IN MIND Black Southerners in the Age of Jim Crow. By Leon F. Litwack. Illustrated. 599 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: Cabo San Lucas
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from Cabo San Lucas, Mexico, it was with great interest that I read Leslie Wayne's story, ''Where the Desert Meets the Sea'' (March 29). Ms. Wayne traced many of the same steps that I followed.

title: At Your Service
description: MY favorite place to eat when I'm not working is at home, and my second favorite is La Vigna. This small, meticulously managed restaurant serves homemade pastas and garlicky steak when you're famished and looking for dangerous excess, as well as salads when you wish to cut back, and these lighter suppers are equally satisfying.

title: Respect for a Teacher
description: To the Editor:

title: Preparing the Startling Tastes of Tuscany
description: WHY does food taste so much better in Italy? Perhaps it was the soft air and the beautiful Tuscan landscape, but on a recent trip, even the simplest dish -- a slice of bread dipped in olive oil and seasoned with a little sea salt, or a plate of wild boar salami -- seemed remarkable.

title: Word for Word / New York Gangs; The Dapper Don and Company Were a Bunch of Copycats
description: TO all but the most diehard ''Godfather'' buffs, La Cosa Nostra now sleeps with the fishes. Last week, this newspaper reported that the Mafia's ruling Commission, which adjudicated inter-family disputes (sometimes by issuing death sentences), has been defunct for two years. John Gotti, Vincent (Chin) Gigante and other infamous bosses are in prison or dead and their once fearsome crime families have dissipated into a disorganized collection of street thugs competing with other ethnic gangs for a piece of the action.

title: Political Briefing; Democrats Are Hurdle For Illinois Democrat
description: Republicans have held the Illinois governorship for the past 20 years. So if Representative Glenn Poshard, the Democratic nominee in this year's governor's race, is to have any chance of recapturing the job for his party, he must first of all solidify his base in the aftermath of a very divisive primary.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS; For Birders, the Longest Day is Next Saturday
description: THE game is simple. You have May 9, all 24 hours of it. You have the entire state to play in. You have approximately 270 different species of birds -- more than one-third of all the bird species to be found in North America. Your goal is to identify, by sight or sound, as many species as possible.

title: Melissa Abrams, Thomas Goosmann
description: Melissa Beth Abrams and Thomas Lawrence Goosmann were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Parker Meridien Hotel. The Rev. Louis L. Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Souvenirs
description: To the Editor: Our family of 15, ages 8 to 70, has been to Puerto Vallarta twice. Purchase of a real stuffed pig as well as a real stuffed snake has given my niece and nephew unique souvenirs as well as great family memoirs. We hoped Customs would confiscate them -- no such luck.

title: Something to Watch Over Me
description: I HAVE always secretly wanted a St. Christopher's medal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, EDWARD J.
description: FITZPATRICK-Edward J. Kramer, Levin, Naftalis & Frankel mourns the passing of our partner, colleague and friend. His humor, kindness, loyalty and individuality will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all members of his bereaved family. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in the name of the Edward J. FitzPatrick Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Fordham Preparatory School, Rose Hill, East Fordham, Bronx, New York, 10458-5175.

title: Reworked for the Stage, 'High Society' Isn't Very
description: ''HIGH SOCIETY,'' the adaptation of the 1956 Cole Porter movie musical now at the St. James Theater, suggests that there may be a new trend in turning movies into Broadway shows. Unlike the Disney Company, which is coining money by adapting feature-length cartoons into live-action musicals, the people responsible for ''High Society'' are fearlessly marching in the opposite direction. They have taken a breezy, intelligent live-action movie and turned it into the equivalent of a stage cartoon, something broad, flat and gross.

title: Ideas & Trends; Look Who's Talking. Don't Bother Listening.
description: SO ancestors of human beings might have had the capability to speak as early as 400,000 years ago, as anthropologists reported last week. But what did they have to say? Probably much more than an occasional yabba dabba doo.

title: Political Briefing; A Sneaky Candidate Is Caught in the Act
description: Tony Strickland, one of seven candidates seeking to represent Thousand Oaks in the California Assembly, was concerned. The campaign signs he had posted around the city, just northwest of Los Angeles, were beginning to disappear in the middle of the night.

title: Seek and Ye Shall Find
description: I'm enjoying a spring walk along the D&R Canal with the older daughter when I spot it: a flash of sun on metal, beckoning from the undergrowth. From a backpack I pull pen, paper and video camera, which I always carry for just such emergencies. Fate, I realize, has found me, the way it found John Martin of Trenton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, ELIZABETH M.
description: CALLAHAN-Elizabeth M. On May 1, 1998. Retired Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. Beloved wife of the late Michael, devoted daughter of John and Margaret Fitzgerald. Reposing Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Immaculate Conception Church, at 14th St., Monday, 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson St., NY, NY.

title: Election Fraud
description: The chairman of Westchester's Conservative Party, Vincent Natrella, and a former Yonkers City Councilman, Edward J. Fagan Jr., have pleaded guilty to forging signatures on nominating petitions, a violation of state election law and a criminal misdemeanor.

title: Questions for: Robert Dallek
description: In your Sunday feature ''Questions for: Robert Dallek'' (April 12), Dallek makes a flat assertion that President Johnson secretly backed Richard Nixon for President in 1968. I am the first to admit that Professor Dallek has many admirable qualities, but I am bound to say that accuracy is not among them.

title: Newfoundlanders
description: GAFF TOPSAILS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, BERNARD D.
description: BERNSTEIN-Bernard D. The Board of Governors of Middle Bay Country Club of Oceanside, NY, on behalf of its membership, wishes to express its sympathy and condolences to the family of its esteemed member, Bernard D. Bernstein. He will surely be missed.

title: On the Cutting Edge and in Cardboard
description: ART on the cutting edge and art made with a box cutter are currently paired at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield. Viewers will be challenged visually and conceptually by the first, and can simply bask in the latter. A museum that provides both experiences at the same time has its whole audience in mind.

title: Miss Schreiber And Mr. Schwarz
description: Whitney Paige Schreiber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Suydam Van Zandt Schreiber of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Patrick Jarrett Schwarz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Schwarz 3d of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Murphy performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Catholic Church in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: The Power of Self-Loathing
description: In the mid-1980's, while living in Massachusetts, I went to a comedy club in Boston to watch Jerry Seinfeld perform his stand-up routine (''The Power of Self-Loathing,'' by David Noonan, April 12). After the show I grabbed a cocktail napkin and rushed over to ask him for his autograph. He graciously responded, ''And whom shall I make this out to?'' I replied, ''It's really for my grandmother -- she's a huge fan of yours.'' He then asked, ''So what does she do?'' Puzzled for a moment, I blurted out, ''Nothing -- she's retired!'' He signed the napkin ''To Edie, It's good to do nothing! Best wishes, Jerry Seinfeld.''

title: Mary Maniaci and Rupert Fennelly
description: Mary Rosaria Maniaci and Rupert Fennelly were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Simon Sleeman, one of the bridegroom's former teachers at the Glenstall Abbey School in Murroe, Ireland, performed the ceremony.

title: They Made Him Great
description: To the Editor:

title: More Pupils Taking Prescribed Drugs To Relieve Distress
description: IT'S noon, and the bell signaling lunchtime at a North Shore elementary school has sounded. As the halls fill with children making their way to the cafeteria, a line forms in front of the nurse's office. Joining those temporarily taking allergy medication and finishing up their prescriptions for antibiotics are a number of children who visit the nurse each school day, throughout the year.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: Your issue on mothers brought me to tears, and I am 70. Why? Because you looked at mother-hood realistically, yet with optimism and appreciation. Even Spock gave us only logic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERLER, ANDREW
description: BERLER-Andrew. 1949-1994. You will always be remembered for your outstanding intellect, your appreciation of art and your unusual sense of humor plus your constant expression of love for family and friends. Mom, Dad and Ellen

title: Juliet McKenna, Douglas Kendall
description: Juliet JoAnn McKenna, a lawyer specializing in child abuse cases, and Douglas Townsend Kendall, an environmental lawyer, were married yesterday at the Sewall-Belmont House, a historic house in Washington. Judge Ellen S. Huvelle of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated.

title: The Piggy-Bank Chronicles
description: YOU know the type.

title: Q&A/Steve Kellogg; The Enchanted World of the Picture Book
description: IN Steve Kellogg's version of ''The Three Little Pigs,'' the mother sow saves the day with a scorchingly funny ending. Mr. Kellogg, author, illustrator and Connecticut native, is in the business of retelling traditional fairy and folk tales, as well as creating children's classics of his own -- ''The Christmas Witch'' and ''The Mysterious Tadpole.'' His storied illustrations accompany songs, tall tales and a variety of books by other authors.

title: Spring's Pleats Are Out All Over
description: A harbinger of spring, the return of the pleated skirt with its lively movement is an alternative to the static slim skirts and trousers of the last two decades. The below-the-knee length and the mostly gray flannel material echo the 1950's, when style was dictated. What's new is the variation in lengths. The most unusual silhouette is high waisted and ankle length, far left, from the Japanese designer Rei Kawakubo.

title: Creative Chinese for the Discerning Diner
description: DAVID'S China Garden Too in Seaford is more than it seems. Although the popular, 16-year-old David's China Garden in Massapequa, is a typical, old-line, suburban Chinese-American spot, its one-and-a-half-year-old offspring is that and more.

title: In Niagara Falls, Pataki's Vetoes Rouse Anger as Economy Slumps
description: Roger Spurback, a lifelong Republican in this city of Democrats, used to heap praise on Gov. George E. Pataki and his fiscal policies. But his feelings changed when Mr. Pataki cut $20,000 from the state budget for a neighborhood crime prevention program that Mr. Spurback supervises from his home here.

title: American Politics, Condition Dismal
description: IF you ask John M. Orman, professor of politics at Fairfield University, about politics in America today, better stand back from the heat of his response.

title: As Public School's Performance Lags, Parents Organize
description: Angered by three years of stagnant reading and math test scores at Community Elementary School 64, a group of parents is pressuring Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to remove the principal, Manuel Feliciano. But Mr. Feliciano's supporters say he is committed to improving the school's performance.

title: Twister in a Truck On a Whirlwind Tour
description: Few, if any, tornadoes have ever struck Queens. But on Thursday, something much like a tornado blew into the borough, in the back of a strange truck.

title: Pine Barrens on Edge
description: THE bungalows on the back roads of Pine Ridge South here are spanking new, and so is the life of the place. Tom Koehl, newly retired and resettled from Secaucus, says that although ''they roll up the sidewalks too early around here,'' regular bingo games are under way and the pool hall is open; shopping and restaurants are ''not bad.'' As he speaks, a gleaming silver bus pulls up at the clubhouse around the bend as residents return from an Atlantic City day-trip.

title: Deflation Isn't a Worry, Either
description: MORE than a year ago, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, warned about the danger of an ''irrational exuberance'' on Wall Street, prompting me to write an article for this space titled ''Deflating an Inflation Worry.''

title: Devils Get A Big Shock To System: An Early Exit
description: Dumped from the playoffs by the eighth-seeded Ottawa Senators tonight, the Devils were full of questions, self-doubts, false assurances, embarrassment. Even before the scoreboard lights were turned off on their 3-1 defeat, the sharp questions were fired first at Jacques Lemaire, the coach. After five seasons in the job -- and three consecutive seasons of post-season underachievement -- is he considering resignation?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, ARTHUR
description: KAYE - Arthur. 9/23/60 - 4/29/98. Passed away after a fierce, long and courageous battle with AIDS. Beloved son of Connie and Bob Kaye. Brother of Mary Wikowicz and John Kaye and uncle of many nieces and nephews who were so dear to him. Cherished friend of Jim Spera, Sandy Edelstein, Dean Taylor, Bob Andrews and many, many others. Arthur was respected and admired during a rich and rewarding career as an advertising industry executive. Strong and brave, loving and kind. He lived life more in 37 years than 10 men live in twice that time. Music lover, world traveler, chef and violinist are just a few of his varied interests and passions. Arthur lived this life with unfailing grace, unwavering dignity and unmatched style. He was a truly beautiful man, both inside and out. The lives of all who he touched-and there were many-have been immeasurably enriched by knowing him, and the light that he brought to all of our lives is sadly dimmed at his passing. He will be terribly, terribly missed. Though Arthur would have loved nothing more than to receive dozens of flowers, donations should be made to the AIDS charity of your choice. Mass to be held in West Palm Beach, Florida the week of May 4. Memorial service to take place in Los Angeles in June-exact date to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFFELD, HENRY G.
description: SCHAFFELD-Henry G., M.D. The entire family of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of Henry G. Schaffeld, MD. A 1941 graduate of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and a doctor in the U.S. Army during World War II, he founded the first chest clinic at Roosevelt Hospital in 1948. He was a beloved and revered Chief of our Division of Pulmonary and Critical Care who inspired generations of colleagues and students. He was a gifted and caring physician to countless patients who will be sorely missed. To his wife Florence, his family, and his friends, we offer our profoundest condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman of the Board Robert G. Newman, MD Acting President Richard P. Fried, MD President of the Medical Board

title: WEEKEND GETAWAYS; Newport's Great Indoors
description: NARRAGANSETT BAY glowed cornflower blue as I crossed the bridge to Newport, R.I., one windy April weekend. In summer, the city is a mecca for sailors and swimmers, but because it was too early to enjoy the beaches and ocean, I would be exploring Newport indoors before the crowds arrived.

title: WEEKEND GETAWAYS; Newport's Great Indoors
description: NARRAGANSETT BAY glowed cornflower blue as I crossed the bridge to Newport, R.I., one windy April weekend. In summer, the city is a mecca for sailors and swimmers, but because it was too early to enjoy the beaches and ocean, I would be exploring Newport indoors before the crowds arrived.

title: Do's and Don'ts on Exhaust Fans
description: EXCESSIVE amounts of humidity in the bathroom can cause mildew growth and also penetrate through the wallboard to condense in the insulation. A good way to prevent this is by installing an exhaust fan.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: 49 Pans, No Waiting But Plenty of Noshing
description: Northside Williamsburg got a new wholesale and retail bakery on April 12 when Richard Podedworny opened the Old Poland Bakery at 149 North Eighth Street between Bedford Avenue and Berry Street. Mr. Podedworny, who earned a master's degree in engineering in Poland, prides himself in using the highest quality of equipment, including a 49-pan revolving tray oven. He also owns the Old Poland Restaurant at 190 Nassau Avenue in Greenpoint. All breads and pastries are baked on premises and sold there or to delis. Cheesecakes are the specialty, including chocolate, honey chocolate, poppy seed and sour cream. There is also babka, a sweet bread, rye bread (staropolski) and three-grain bread.

title: Spring Fever In a Social Whirl
description: Fund-raisers for a medical center, the parks, schools of the arts and groups that help boys, teen-agers and families, and a reception for artists.

title: Run to Daylight
description: Goodnight, Nebraska

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLEAN, JANET G.
description: McLEAN-Janet G. Newspaper Librarian, 82, who retired in the late 1960s as a librarian with the Washington bureau of the New York Times, died of breast cancer April 26 at her home in the Lewisdale neighborhood of West Hyattsville. She was a native of Chicago who performed as a piano soloist there as a teenager. Her family moved to the Washington area in the early 1940s. Mrs. McLean graduated from the Eastman School of Music at the University of Rochester, where her orchestral and piano works were performed while she was a student. She went to work for United Press as a librarian in 1957 after her husband, journalist Hector F. McLean died. Mrs. McLean was organist & choir director at St. James Episcopal Church in Rockville. Survivors include two daughters, Nancy Suniewick of Kensington and Judith McLean of Lewisdale; a sister, Nancy Stephens of Ocean View, Delaware, and Key Largo, Florida; and three grandchildren.

title: Liberties; What, Me Scary?
description: Call me touchy. But didn't the President describe me as a castrating word-that-rhymes-with-rich?

title: Alzheimer's Gene Test: Facing the Answers
description: WHEN Janet Walsh was 14 her father began showing signs of dementia. Four years later, at 62, he was given a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease, considered a ''rare'' brain disorder in 1975.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, BERNARD W.
description: SCHWARTZ-Bernard W. 5/1/28-8/ 1/94. You will always be the most special Papa in all of our lives. Happy 70th birthday. We love you Sue-Ellen and Neil, Don, Jonathan and Gail, Jennifer, Samantha, Daniel, Natalie, Stephanie and Alison.

title: An On-Line Rush Is On
description: THE future of the mutual fund industry is wired, and that may be good news for Internet-wise investors. Their rewards could be a greater variety of funds and lower expenses, according to the authors of a Goldman Sachs & Company report on the money management business.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: I purchased your very timely special issue to commemorate the birth of my first child earlier that week. I especially loved what Mary Matalin had to say about ''crying hideously'' as she sang ''You are my sunshine'' to her baby. But I disagree with her that this is the sign of brain death. I would say it is more symptomatic of a newly enlarged heart.

title: Teachers Cheer as Democratic Candidates Denounce D'Amato
description: To an appreciative chorus of hisses and boos, the three Democrats seeking to unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato joined thousands of teachers yesterday in a rowdy morning of bashing the New York Republican, assailing Mr. D'Amato for his repeated attacks on public school teachers and depicting him as an enemy of public education.

title: Israel at 50: Drowning in History; Jerusalem Has No Past
description: Tip O'Neill liked to say that all politics is local. In Jerusalem, politics is local but also moral and cosmic. Of course, politicians everywhere employ an ethical diction, however ungrammatical. And the reality of power in every city has its source in a measure of combat. But nowhere is this as true as in Jerusalem. Millions of us, raised in three major faiths, grew up believing that even apparently trivial encounters in Jerusalem's narrow streets and within the shadows of its wall determine the human condition. Its sparrows were no mere sparrows. A broken promise in the Holy City, a night of lovemaking, an act of mercy, might be studied centuries to come as a guide to the will of the universe. The story of a nocturnal arrest and a felon's execution there might change eternally the notion of human responsibility.

title: Robert Wilson on Stage, In Word, if Not in Deed
description: THREE years ago, Robert Wilson, the avant-garde American director, designer, performer and visual artist, presented a deconstructed one-man ''Hamlet'' in which he starred. He took Shakespeare's speeches for the character (and several others in the play) and put them through his own verbal Cuisinart.

title: Shangri-La Without the Frills
description: GAZING at a village in northwestern Nepal, its stone houses glued to the slopes of a landscape more stark and tumultuous than the imagination could ever fashion, I wondered how and why people had ever penetrated these unforgiving canyons or built their village in such a spot. My husband, Phil, and I were trekking through Inner Dolpo, whose ethnic Tibetan villages may be the most remote in the world. What drove these people? Invading enemies, drought and hunger, or perhaps mystic visions?

title: London Weekend
description: To the Editor: All praise to Letty Cottin Pogrebin and her husband for their long London weekend in January in ''Packing (the Schedule) for the Weekend'' (March 29). A London theater blitz has been one of this past winter's great travel bargains.

title: There Is a Lot of Here Here
description: GERTRUDE STEIN

title: Dazzled or Dazed? The Wide Impact Of Special Effects
description: IT seems like a movie now, that day in March when mankind was forced to drop its puny temporal concerns for a moment and contemplate the unthinkable: a reliable report that the end might be nigh. And like a movie, this brush with destiny had a happy ending. Within 24 hours of hearing the dark news that an approaching asteroid as wide as the Mississippi had an outside chance of hitting Earth in 2028, the world got word that the initial projections on the big rock's path had been off by, oh, 500,000 miles. In short, never mind.

title: Wine Tasting Gala
description: THE Long Island Wine Council will hold its annual tasting in Manhattan on Tuesday at Windows on the World. The tasting will again be co-sponsored by the Partnership for the Homeless, a service agency in New York City.

title: Q & A
description: A Garage Sales Tax For a Co-op

title: Seething Riley Says Van Gundy Lost His Cool
description: Miami Heat Coach Pat Riley simmered on Friday when he heard about Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy's pointed criticism of Heat center Alonzo Mourning, and today Riley's anger spilled out.

title: The Dangers Of Dressing Down
description: As the weather improves, so does the climate for casual days, those corporately sanctioned breaches of formal office wear. Who wears what on casual day in your office, and does any of the attire make you pine for a bit less latitude in personal style? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKFIELD, PATRICIA ELLEN
description: MARKFIELD-Patricia Ellen. August 5th, 1947-May 5th, 1996. Precious Ellen. You blessed us with your beauty, grace, warmth, enthusiasm and intelligence. You left a legacy of caring unselfishly for others that will never be forgotten. You're loved beyond measure, missed beyond words. Lovingly, Mommy and Dale

title: A Violinist and Music's Healing Moments
description: TEN-year-old Philip Yeung didn't want to go to the concert. He had just begun chemotherapy. He was in pain and wanted to stay in his hospital bed and be left alone.

title: Touring Percussionists Who Aren't Really Offbeat
description: ONE might have thought that five percussionists who wanted to band together as a full-time touring ensemble were unrealistic, even slightly eccentric. The repertory for percussion quintets, after all, is slender. And although such a group is, strictly speaking, a chamber ensemble, its potential audience is likely to come not from the string quartet and piano trio circuit but from the more constricted world of new music.

title: Seeing Red
description: AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF RED

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the television pioneer Fred Coe reversed the identities of two men shown on the set of ''Playhouse 90.'' Mr. Coe was on the right, and the director John Frankenheimer on the left.

title: Domestic Air Fares Drop Sharply in Brazil
description: Brazilian airlines are radically reducing their fares on domestic flights as a result of the Brazilian Government's move to reduce its role in the air travel market. The airlines can now sell tickets with discounts of as much as 65 percent of the full economy fare, which is still set by the Government. In addition, charter flights can now be sold without links to a ground package.

title: Same Initials as Shakespeare
description: THE WORLD OF

title: Souvenirs
description: To the Editor: Our family of 15, ages 8 to 70, has been to Puerto Vallarta twice. Purchase of a real stuffed pig as well as a real stuffed snake has given my niece and nephew unique souvenirs as well as great family memoirs. We hoped Customs would confiscate them -- no such luck.

title: Rosie Speaks, and Broadway Ticket Sellers Cheer
description: It is a testament to the changing culture of Broadway that in the final weeks before the opening of ''The Lion King'' last fall, the show's producers and publicity agents turned their attention to winning the favor not of a theater critic but of a talk show host and comedian, Rosie O'Donnell.

title: Captive REIT's: A Tax Shelter Makes a Comeback
description: IT'S hard to keep a good tax shelter down.

title: A Pure Play for the Indians Depends on Their Play
description: BASEBALL fans fascinated by Jaret Wright's earned run average will be able to examine the price-to-earnings ratio of his team's stock after Richard E. Jacobs sells shares in the Cleveland Indians to the public in June.

title: Shari Lewis's Jazzy New Pals
description: BABY boomers may find a modicum of comfort in the enduring appeal of the ventriloquist Shari Lewis and her puppets, who appeared on ''Captain Kangaroo'' and ''The Shari Lewis Show'' in the 1950's and 60's.

title: Policing the Avant-Garde: Parallels Out of the Past
description: GOEBBELS is long and thin; Hitler closely resembles a Charlie Chaplin impersonator. Dressed in clown ruffs, they nudge each other onto the stage in the Irondale Ensemble Project's musical theater-cabaret caper ''Degenerate Art,'' which opened last night at Theater for a New City on First Avenue and 10th Street. Hitler and Goebbels have come to seek the help of a fear-of-art counselor.

title: Democrats Come In Last After Pataki's Display of Veto Power
description: Sheldon Silver's top priority this year was to add $500 million to the state budget to build and repair schools. Joseph L. Bruno's was to cut business taxes.

title: Swimming Upstream
Sinking Feelings About My Pond
description: PUTTING in a garden pond, like starting the Vietnam War, seemed like a good idea at the time. There was a perfect space in the bottom right-hand corner, and I was all in favor of anything that would reduce the total area of lawn requiring my attention. In the planning stage, I allowed my imagination to run riot with visions of tinkling fountains, crystal-clear water, beautiful lilies, dragonflies and exotic, well-mannered fish.

title: Checking on the Nuts and Bolts Before the Thrills
description: WITH the warm-weather season and its crowds of thrill-seekers fast approaching, amusement parks have been preparing for business and awaiting the state inspectors who must certify the safety of their rides. Each of the more than 1,300 rides with permits in the state must be inspected before they open.

title: Go With the Flow Chart
description: Lloyd: What Happened

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITMAN, ADRIANE KLEBAN
description: PITMAN-Adriane Kleban. On April 26, 1998 in San Antonio, TX. Daughter of the late Francis and Helaine Kleban. She leaves her husband, Michael Pitman of San Antonio, two sons, and four grandchildren. A free spirit with a zest for life, she will be missed.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: A Fallen King In Search of a Lesser Throne
description: THE crowd of writers and public relations people just would not stop chattering one evening not long ago at Tavern on the Green. Over the clinking glasses and crockery in the glittery restaurant, the guest speaker, John H. Gutfreund -- looking every bit the Wall Street mandarin with his tailored business suit, shiny pate and Calvin Klein bifocals -- was having trouble making himself heard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, ANNE ORLIKOFF
description: SCHILLER-Anne Orlikoff. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY and Stratford, CT died May 1 in North Branford, CT at age 86. Born in Brooklyn and a graduate of Barnard College, she was for many years a beloved teacher and librarian in the NYC public schools. Her warmth, kindness and generosity won her innumerable friends everywhere. She is survived and missed by her husband, Dr. Israel A. Schiller; her sons and daughters-in-law, Daniel, Paula, Joel, and Helen; and her grandchildren, Johanna, Jennifer, Harry, and Cordelia. Funeral at ''Wien & Wien'' Englewood, NJ, today. For information call 1-800-322-0533.

title: Bankruptcy Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Rheingold Returns With a Family Link
description: WALTER H. LIEBMAN had let go of his dream by the time the phone rang last September. Mr. Liebman, head of public affairs at Purchase College, had long hoped to revive his family's beer company, Rheingold, but the idea grew dimmer each year. Then he heard Michael H. Mitaro's voice, and the dream blazed anew. Mr. Mitaro, a former executive with Labatt U.S.A., introduced himself as the new owner of Rheingold, which had languished since 1976. The beer that once filled more glasses in New York than any other could be No. 1 again, Mr. Mitaro said. The time was right. Nostalgia was in. Moreover, the microbrewery madness was over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULANSKY, GENE
description: ULANSKY-Gene. Graduate of Columbia University, Ph.D. Stanford University, writer, editor, teacher, counselor, advisor, mentor. Active in Crossroads Africa. Died Thursday, April 23, 1998 in his Berkeley, CA home at age sixty. Survived by loving wife Susan Clark, daughter Kate Ulansky, sister Nina Kohnstamm, brothers & sisters-in-law, nieces & nephews and thousands of beloved students. Donations in his memory to ''Kate's College Fund'', C/O Barbara Clark, 2928 Pine Street, Berkeley, CA. 94705.

title: Opera's 400th Birthday Is Celebrated in Vienna
description: One might call it the Woodstock of opera: 53 internationally known singers offering solo arias and duets outdoors over three nights in the 50,000-seat Prater stadium in Vienna. The event, Universe of Opera, July 3 to 5, will celebrate the 400th anniversary of the first Western opera, Jacopo Peri's ''Dafne,'' produced in Florence in 1598.

title: London Weekend
description: To the Editor: I had the pleasure of staying at Dukes Hotel in London in December. Ms. Pogrebin's account is definitely all true. Dukes has rooms of understated elegance and a genial welcoming staff.

title: Pharmacy Chic
description: Pills are Western medicine's most ubiquitous symbol, yet they were never a fashion statement until Louis Hohenstein, a San Francisco sound engineer, decided to bring them out of the cabinet and turn them into earrings.

title: April 26-May 2; Unabomber's Icy Precision
description: In hundreds of newly disclosed journal entries, Theodore J. Kaczynski, the confessed Unabomber, meticulously recorded his 17-year-long career as a serial bomber. The writings, made public by prosecutors in preparation for his sentencing on Monday, were culled from the huge haul of papers taken from his Montana shack in April, 1996, after his arrest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, SYLVIA
description: ORENSTEIN-Sylvia. On May 1, 1998. Beloved sister of Harold and Joseph. Devoted aunt of Donna Kerner, Debbie Magnusson and Grant Orenstein. Service Sunday, 12 noon, Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Last-Chance Season
description: BY the eighth inning of this season's opening game, in a muddy park in East New York, Brooklyn, Misael Quiroz's fingers were weak and numb with cold. The players on the benches were shivering in the icy drizzle, and about a dozen fans -- mostly their wives and girlfriends -- watched from the stands, hunched into parkas or blankets. A few players, trying to get warm, bounced up and down like children on Pogo sticks. But Misael, 21, did not suggest calling the game, and neither did anybody else, not even jokingly. On both teams, each player was intensely focused on the game, each as serious as if they had, after all, made it to the major leagues.

title: A Song-and-Dance Sendup of Beauty Pageants
description: THE resurrection of ''Smile,'' a failed 1986 musical about the bad and the unbeautiful part of beauty pageants, is being called ''a world premiere revival'' by the American Stage Company here.

title: Mary Collins, David Morales
description: Mary Elizabeth Collins and Dr. David L. S. Morales are to be married this afternoon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gabriel the Archangel in Saddle River, N.J. Bishop James J. Collins, the Bishop emeritus of the diocese of Esta Tocantins in Miracema do Tocantins, Brazil, and a great-uncle of the bride, will perform the ceremony.

title: Classical Briefs
description: BRAHMS, SIBELIUS, STENHAMMAR: SONGS

title: Calling the Tune, Raising the Money, Fixing the Plumbing
description: WHEN David Rivel assumed leadership of the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music in 1995, the Park Slope institution was withering on the vine. It had had six executive directors in the previous three years. Its enrollment was stagnating. And its fund-raising efforts were yielding just $59,000 a year toward a budget of $1 million.

title: PULSE; Big Sky City
description: For those times when you feel like a tourist in your own city, Tim Hussey has designed a clever line of T-shirts. His Huss-Ler shirts may say ''New York City,'' but the 1970's clip-art images -- bunnies, surfers, cowboys and cacti -- are several time zones to the west. ''People forget there's a world outside of New York,'' said Mr. Hussey, an illustrator who left his job at GQ magazine two weeks ago to move back to his hometown of Charleston, S.C. ''The shirts had a lot to do with it,'' he said of the move. ''I realized I wanted to go back to nature.'' The T-shirts, which he started making two months ago, cost $18 to $21 at Antique Boutique, 712-714 Broadway (Astor Place), and Screaming Mimi's, 382 Lafayette Street at West Fourth Street. Nelson Ryland, a New York film editor raised in Arizona, is partial to Mr. Hussey's Western-theme designs. ''It's from a time when life was easier,'' he sighed.

title: Beyond Personalities
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Urges Sudan to End Restrictions on Food Airlift to South
description: Warning of a ''human catastrophe'' in which hundreds of thousands of people face death by starvation, the Administration has agreed to provide tons of food for the southern Sudan and is trying to bring pressure on the Sudanese Government to lift its restrictions on the distribution of food and medicine.

title: Could Israel Ever Be a 'Nation Like Others'?; Apology Never Given
description: To the Editor:

title: In Aftermath of Fight, Van Gundy Becomes the Little Big Coach
description: Kim Van Gundy tuned in to talk radio on Friday, just to see what Greater New York was saying about her husband. Between suggestions that Alonzo Mourning might need a tetanus shot and someone wondering if Madison Square Garden had stooped to midget wrestling, callers to WFAN were merciless.

title: Inventor Makes a Dog Leash for Joggers
description: HARRIETT, a 4-year-old, 55-pound Australian shepherd, jumped on her dog bed and bit down on what looked like a seat belt with a leash attached. She played with it as she watched Joseph Perrulli lace up his sneakers for a run, ready to dash outside with him the second he stood up.

title: Deal With France Will Permit Dutchman to Manage the Euro
description: No European leader, not even President Jacques Chirac of France, has ever suggested that Wim F. Duisenberg lacks the credibility or the character to take on the enormous job of ushering in the euro.

title: Commercial Property/Connecticut; For Shelton, Fairfield's First Spec Building in Decade
description: GROUND is to be broken next month for Fairfield County's first speculative Class A office building in a decade -- not in Stamford, but at the northwestern edge of the county in Shelton. The construction is to start without the developer, the Davis Companies of Boston and Wilton, having a single lease in hand.

title: Onward and Upward, Gambling on Success
description: FROM high up on the Chrysler Building, a man surveys New York City. In an eye-catching 1991 photograph by Annie Leibovitz, this man, the choreographer-dancer David Parsons, is almost naked, stretched out belly down on a gleaming gargoyle, the sunset turning him rosy. Whatever Ms. Leibovitz's agenda was, her picture says a lot about Mr. Parsons. He's an athlete, an achiever, a hunk. His career has prospered. He's a risk taker.

title: HOT ITEMS
description: * The Department of Energy has enough cold-war junk on its hands to fill 2,255 Boeing 747's. Between 1998 and 2053, the D.O.E. is also decommissioning 123 nuclear reactors, adding to the pile. * The Government is ''recycling'' a lot of it to scrap dealers. * The Oak Ridge complex in Tennessee is selling office furniture from its uranium-enrichment facility, established for the Manhattan Project and now defunct. * Carbon steel from the demolished Weldon Spring Uranium Mill Plant in Missouri was sold to a metal recycler. * Los Alamos National Laboratory sells lead bricks, once used for radiation shielding, to be recycled into car batteries. * Is it safe? The D.O.E. says people get more radiation from drinking water. * But Diane D'Arrigo, a nuclear-waste watchdog, frets, ''Will mothers need Geiger counters when shopping for toys?''

title: Clinton Criticizes California Effort to Cut Bilingual Education
description: President Clinton denounced a California ballot initiative that would virtually eliminate bilingual education, saying that it would consign countless children of immigrants to a lifetime of ''intellectual purgatory.''

title: Albright Dubious on Closing Gaps at the Mideast Talks
description: With an important round of Middle East peace talks scheduled in London on Monday, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright ''has no reason to believe'' that she will be able to bridge the gaps between Israelis and Palestinians, her spokesman said here today.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Creation of the Night Sky

title: Displaced by Divorce, Getting On With Life
description: HER husband, her son, the house and all its attendant responsibilities, volunteer work, these were the sturdy spheres of Janice Wells's life. But in the instant her husband of 30 years walked through the door and told her he was divorcing her, they began to slip away.

title: Living to Be 100: Anger, Arthritis and Occasional Joy
description: Vera Peragine is waiting anxiously for Bar Beach to open, so she and her friends can go every Monday to listen to the bands and dance.

title: Backtalk; Former Olympian Defies Age and Challenges Time
description: Jeff Farrell refuses to go gentle into that good night. In fact, at the close of the 20th century, this gold medalist from the 1960 Rome Olympics might win the over-50 vote for athlete of the century. He has been an elite swimmer for the last five decades and this week at the United States Masters Short Course Swimming National Championships in Indianapolis, the 61-year-old Farrell could ultimately swim back in time and better his career personal best in the 50-yard freestyle.

title: Topics of The Times; Chewing It Kills You Too
description: Anyone who watches professional baseball has seen players with bulging wads of tobacco in their mouths, chewing and spitting all through the game. Chewing the substance once seemed an ideal way to escape the lung cancer that comes of smoking tobacco -- until a Surgeon General's report raised questions about the practice a decade ago and caused scientists to focus on Major League Baseball. A cancer scare in the late 1980's stopped the teams from handing out free samples of chewing tobacco and seemed to drive down its use dramatically. Hoping to discourage tobacco use in younger players, the major leagues banned chewing tobacco in 1994 from minor league clubhouses.

title: Nicole Ullrich and Mark Johnson
description: Dr. Nicole Ullrich, the daughter of Amy and George Ullrich of Hingham, Mass., was married yesterday to Mark Ronald Johnson, a son of the Rev. Ronald Johnson and Jennifer Johnson of Millburn, N.J. The bridegroom's father, who is the minister of the Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, performed the ceremony at Old Ship Church in Hingham.

title: Over the Moon About Cows
description: IN Texas, where I am from, I spent a lot of time driving around. After some years of traveling up and down U.S. Highway 77, which cuts through the vast King Ranch, on trips related mainly to watching birds, I developed a love for Santa Gertrudis cattle. Love is not exactly the right word, but something synonymous, like fondness, is even farther off the mark. There may not be a word to describe how I feel. I just know that Santa Gertrudis became important fixed points in my moving landscape.

title: John Bassett, 82; Controlled Canada TV Network
description: John White Hughes Bassett, a prominent figure in Canadian journalism, politics and sports for more than 40 years, died on Monday in Toronto. He was 82.

title: Delays Plague the Investigation of Air Crashes by Transportation Safety Board
description: The National Transportation Safety Board is taking twice as long to investigate plane crashes as it did five years ago, primarily because of the efforts it is still devoting to the daunting mysteries of the crashes of T.W.A. Flight 800 in 1996 and a USAir flight near Pittsburgh in 1994.

title: DNA Test for Lawyer
description: As a first step in establishing the paternity of a 15-year-old girl, Albert J. Pirro Jr., a lawyer and the husband of the county's District Attorney, Jeanine Pirro, has agreed to undergo genetic testing, in accordance with the ruling of an Indiana Court of Appeals.

title: Just in Case, Flea Markets Make Plans to . . . Flee
description: Though not as legendary as the Paris Flea Market, or as picturesque as Portobello Road in London, the weekend markets in the Flatiron District are very popular. But this being New York, real estate pressures may force them to search for a new home.

title: Q&A: Jayne Mayer; Distributing Grants to Nonprofit Groups
description: EVERY day, advances in communications technology are dramatically changing our lives. To deal with some of these changes, Bell Atlantic, the telecommunications giant, has created a foundation to finance nonprofit organizations so they can apply this technology to their programs and services, further their missions and improve the quality of life in their communities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, JACK
description: WASSERMAN-Jack. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jack Wasserman: devoted husband, beloved father, champion of Jewish causes. A longtime supporter of UJA-Federation, he dedicated himself to those who needed his help. All who knew him were touched by his love, caring, and good nature. To his son, Bert, and the entire family, we extend our deepest sympathies. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Edward Bleier, Marty Pompadur, and Martin Payson, Co-Chairs, Entertainment, Media & Communications Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: A Statue Fit for Queens?
description: Reported in newspapers from India to Germany, the furor over a planned statue of a 17th-century Queen Catherine returned last week to Hunters Point, the would-be waterfront home of the 50-foot bronze sculpture honoring the monarch who is widely considered to be the namesake of Queens County.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Smelly PATH Tubes

title: Officers as Bikers, but Training for Patrol
description: THE 17 bicyclists appeared in a misty rain, headed for the Yorktown Cycling Center here. Bent over their handlebars and undeterred by the wet spring weather, they might have been training for a cross-country race. A closer look at their jackets, however, told another story: they were police officers getting in shape for bicycle patrol.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOAPBOX; A Law That Repeats Past Missteps
description: SINCE the city enacted its current laws on lead paint, a new body of evidence on this paint and its hazards has evolved, one that forces us to rethink many accepted practices associated with lead paint abatement.

title: Anneke Wyman, Klaas de Boer
description: Anne Berrien Wyman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. M. Wyman of New York, was married yesterday to Klaas de Boer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholaas H. de Boer of St. Nicolaasga, the Netherlands. The Rev. Susannah R. Smith performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOX, IRMGARD
description: KNOX-Irmgard. Beloved mother of Ruth Knox Ruiz died April 27, 1998 in Miami, Florida. Born in Winsen-an-der-Luhe, Germany as Irmgard Sophie Minna Caroline Eckermann, she was affectionately known by her friends and family as Aimee. A life-long resident of Manhattan, Aimee moved to Bayside, New York in 1956. In 1995, Aimee moved to Miami after the death of her sister, Ruth. As a young woman, Aimee entered show business. She acquired the stage name, Irene Mann and with her two sisters Ruth and Ann, they traveled throughout the U.S. as showgirls in the Earl Carroll Vanities. Aimee also worked as a model and later in the insurance business. Aimee was active in the arts and was a founding employee of Queens Council on the Arts, sponsoring numerous operas and other artistic events throughout Queens, New York. Aimee married the late David Knox and they had one daughter, Ruth. Aimee has been the center of her family for a generation and will be greatly missed. Her memory will continue to bring great joy to her daughter Ruth of West Cape May, NJ; her grandchildren, Wallace Ruiz and his wife Gabriele of Miami, Jeffrey Ruiz of New Paltz, NY and Shannon Fitzgerald of Upper Saddle River, NJ; her four great grandchildren, Jens and Erik Ruiz, Gillian Fitzgerald and Hannah Ruiz; her niece Camille Loiacono of Edison, NJ; her nephew Nicholas Leone of Freehold, NJ; and her friend Elli Lehmann of Hamburg, Germany. The funeral service will be held on Monday, May 4 at 11:00AM, at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY; (914) 693-4700.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 3, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Let Them Lick-'Ems Roll
description: For the average American, transporting postage stamps is simple: a purse or pocket will do. The United States Postal Service can't be so cavalier. It frequently retains the services of Trism, a self-described ''premier carrier group'' for valuable and hazardous cargo based in Kennesaw, Ga. Among Trism's current projects is the transportation of 200,000 rounds of obsolete chemical weapons between Oregon and Nevada; it's also ready to handle napalm. Does high-security trucking seem like overkill for stamps? Not if they're being shipped in bulk. According to Steve Richardson, a Trism spokesman, a single truckload of stamps is worth up to $50 million. Untraceable dollars. Here's how they move.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption with the Art column last Sunday reversed the identification of two paintings. A detail from ''Masked Women'' by Peter Sarabella was on the left; ''Gulls at Gosman'' by Phyllis Hirschberg was on the right.

title: Sports of The Times; Winners Can Yell, Wherever They Are
description: He was sitting in the box with Indian Charlie's owners, but that was his other horse, Real Quiet, bursting to the lead of the greatest race in the land. Bob Baffert gave up any pretense of decorum, and he started yelling, ''The Fish! The Fish!'' -- his nickname for the slim, mercurial, unproved colt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPIN, MARIA A.
description: PAPPIN-Maria A. (Interrante). Retired J.P. Morgan, former Secretary to Chairman of Butler Aviation and partner at S.M.P. Corporate Travel, New York City. Wife of Roger L. Mother of Jeffrey. Sister of Theresa Cicero, Anthony, the late Carol and John. Survived by two grandchildren. Reposing Monday 2-4, 7-9 PM, at Hunt Stellato Funeral Home, 1601 Palisade Ave., Fort Lee, NJ. Religious services Tuesday 11 AM, at the funeral home. Cremation to follow.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: Despite the negative headline ''Mothers Can't Win'' (April 5), the articles in your special issue on motherhood indicate that we mothers (working, stay-at-home, single, widowed or any combination thereof) are winning. We are doing what needs to be done for our families, given our own set of circumstances. And we are doing it bravely, though not without struggle, and in a society that still believes that, by virtue of choosing to stay home with her children, a female attorney becomes an ''ex-lawyer.'' It's not always easy to recognize our victories -- but then we just have to look at our children.

title: The View From/Bedford; Voices on the Outside Benefit Jailed Mothers
description: THE women taking part in the benefit were the essence of genteel: soft-spoken, with sleek hair and expensive-looking printed silk skirts and interesting, hand-wrought jewelry. They looked as if they had never got so much as a speeding ticket, let alone spent time in jail.

title: Debating the Merit of a Social Security Cap
description: IN his early 60's, Alfred Armand set up a telecommunications consultancy in San Francisco. But in recent years, he turned down some jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KELLY, TRICIA A.
description: KELLY-Tricia A. Her friends will be saddened to hear that Tricia passed away at her home in Williamsburg, Virginia last October 21, 1997. She moved there three years ago from her East 73 Street home. She sang in both the Saint Bartholomew and the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Choirs. Her memorable Kentucky Derby and Christmas parties lifted our spirits with her infectious good cheer. She may be gone, but she will always be with us.

title: BENEFITS
description: Honoring the Mayor

title: Police Say Brooklyn Man Killed Wife and Himself
description: A 25-year-old man shot and killed his wife in their Brooklyn apartment as his children slept nearby, then fled down the street and fatally shot himself, the police said.

title: Gibstein Captures Richardson
description: When Ed Gibstein started his own investment partnership last year, his golf game suffered. Gibstein, 40, of Locust Valley, N.Y., vowed he would return to his form of 1994, when he reached the quarterfinals of the United States Amateur and the semifinals of the United States Mid-Amateur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEPLI, PHALON, NANCY L.
description: HOEPLI-PHALON-Nancy L. April 30, at home. Editor-in-chief Foreign Policy Association. Wife, Richard A. Phalon, Sr.; sister of Eleanore Hoepli Didriksen, Wellesley, MA. Interment, Saturday, May 9, at 11 AM, Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Sleepy Hollow, NY. Contributions can be made in Nancy's memory to St. Vincent's Hospital Cancer Care, 153 W. 11th St., NYC 10011.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLODNEY, ROSE
description: KOLODNEY-Rose. Passed away May 1, 1998 at age 99 after a short illness. Survived by daughter Beverly and grandchildren Dr. Ira Sutton, Dr. Jodi Sutton Gershel and Elizabeth Thompson and six great grandchildren. Services graveside.

title: With Holik Out Sick, Devils' Attack Is Weak
description: Bobby Holik knew he was having a run of buzzard's luck, but this was enough to make him sick.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Rich, the Gray and the Female
description: Lieut. Gov. Gray (''Experience Money Can't Buy'') Davis put his first commercials on the air recently, and instantly zoomed toward the top of the polls in the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Aides to one of Mr. Davis's adversaries, Al (''New Ideas'') Checchi, who has been running TV ads since last Thanksgiving, claimed the polls were just reflecting the voters' ephemeral interest in a new face. It is only in California that Mr. Davis, who has been a fixture in state government for 22 years, could be regarded as a fresh commodity. But political operatives here do not regard anything as real until it appears in a commercial. I air, therefore I am.

title: Sam Spade Throws a Pie
description: LIKE A HOLE

title: Souvenirs
description: To the Editor: I too have a ''Storytelling Souvenir'' (April 5). While dining in a Parisian restaurant with a group of friends, I spied upon our table a pretty painted ashtray imprinted with the name of the restaurant, and, coveting it for my souvenir collection, I surreptitiously swooped it into my tote bag.

title: SOAPBOX; A Lead-Paint Law the City Needs
description: TWO millennia ago, a Greek physician observed that ''Lead makes the mind give way.'' Before the next millennium, New York must act to protect its children from brain damage caused by lead poisoning.

title: Crime
description: THE BALLAD OF FRANKIE SILVER (Dutton, $23.95), the fifth book in Sharyn McCrumb's enthralling series of Appalachian mountain tales, invites us to pull up a quilt and turn our faces to the fire. ''We're not used to taletelling anymore, what with the TV and all,'' a woman from these parts says. But that doesn't stop McCrumb from adapting the folk art form for her own version of the story of Frankie Silver, an 18-year-old frontierswoman who was hanged in 1833 for killing her husband with an ax and disposing of the body in a cruel and disgusting manner.

title: The View From/Exeter; Postgraduate Programs -- of the High School Variety
description: DAVID CADELINA, football coach and math teacher, is introducing his students at Central High School in Bridgeport to another world, a world few of them even dream about. He is recommending his most academically promising players for a postgraduate year at Phillips Exeter Academy, one of the nation's most prestigious independent schools, which counts among its graduates Daniel Webster, John and David Rockefeller, George Plimpton and Pierre Dupont, former Governor of Delaware.

title: Onslaught From the Sky and From Decades Past
description: WILL the dangers never cease? Comets, giant lizards, maniacal toys and bands of Mafiosi are poised for attack during this summer movie season. Even the 70's are back to get us.

title: Generation of Firsts
description: Morris County, known as the home of affluent white suburbanites, has had black residents since early in the century, though never more than 3 percent of the population. The first generation of middle-class black professionals and entrepreneurs there is the subject of ''Chanceman's Brothers and Sisters,'' a documentary to be shown on the New Jersey Network today at 6 P.M. and Tuesday at 6:30 P.M. The name derives from James (Chanceman) Gregory (pictured), who in the 1920's became the first black police officer in Morristown. Much of the story is told by four lifelong Morris County residents: John Pinkman, a retired caterer whose father started one of the area's first black-owned business, a moving company; Gwendolyn Boyce Squire, a retired teacher who describes her childhood as a daughter of live-in servants; Jesse Evans, a war hero who left school at 13 to help support his family, and Robert Banks, the first black police chief in the county, in Boonton. The 27-minute tape is available for $10 by calling (973) 482-2988.

title: April 26-May 2; More Breathing Room For Social Security
description: Given the magnitude of the problem, the good news was relative, but it was good news nonetheless: Social Security will go bankrupt in 2032, not 2029. The program's trustees, in their annual report, attributed the improvement to the strong economy.

title: An Oyster Schooner From Bivalve Becomes the State Tall Ship
description: New Jersey has its state flower (the purple violet), tree (the red oak) and bird (the Eastern goldfinch). Now it also has a state tall ship: the A. J. Meerwald, an oyster schooner officially designated last month by Governor Whitman and the Legislature. Home port for the Meerwald is Bivalve, Cumberland County, a tiny town next to Shell Pile. The names come from the days when about 500 ships like the Meerwald worked the Delaware Bay dredging oysters from what seemed like limitless beds below.

title: The Startling Tastes Of Florentine Fare
description: WHY does food taste so much better in Italy? Perhaps it was the soft air and the beautiful Tuscan landscape, but on a recent trip, even the simplest dish -- a slice of bread dipped in olive oil and seasoned with a little sea salt, or a plate of wild boar salami -- seemed remarkable.

title: A Lost-Generation Romance for the Ages
