description: WHILE she was working on her new biography, ''Everybody Was So Young: Gerald and Sara Murphy and Their Circle -- A Lost Generation Love Story,'' Amanda Vaill kept hearing the sound of the same surf, walking the same beach, studying the same breathtaking view of trees and sky that she realized the Murphys had loved throughout their long lives in East Hampton.

title: The Classical Wynton Marsalis Turns Up Again
description: ''MAN, that's hard to play,'' the trumpet virtuoso Wynton Marsalis said recently. ''That's what goes through the minds of trumpet players when they hear it.''

title: April 26-May 2; Hubbell, Clinton Confidant, Indicted on Tax Charges
description: Webster L. Hubbell, President Clinton's longtime confidant, was indicted on charges that he failed to pay income taxes and penalties of more than $850,000 over the last four years.

title: Campus Alcohol and Drug Arrests Rose in '96, Survey Says
description: Alcohol arrests rose by 10 percent and drug arrests by 5 percent on college campuses in 1996, the fifth consecutive year that reported violations of substance abuse laws have increased, according to a survey being released on Monday by The Chronicle of Higher Education, an independent newspaper that covers higher education.

title: Abbey Road
description: To the Editor: Re the Q & A ''Beatle Crossing'' (April 19). As a full-time recording engineer at Abbey Road Studios from 1958 to 1968, I must have used that zebra crossing at least 7,000 times but did not choose such a lengthy route as you describe. Coming out of St. John's Wood tube station, cross Wellington Road to Grove End Road and continue down this road until you reach Abbey Road. The crossing is to your right and you will have walked only half the distance of Joseph Siano's route!

title: Tenant Advocate Puts Its Own Apartment House in Order
description: It's tricky being both a landlord and a tenant advocate. For more than a month, the tenants of a 20-unit South Bronx building have complained bitterly that their landlord seemed indifferent to their leaky roofs and shut-off gas. The landlord -- Banana Kelly, a 20-year-old grass-roots housing organization -- found itself facing the kind of accusations that it has long leveled at building owners.

title: Anne Heche Waits to Find Out if She's Still a Star
description: ANNE HECHE was one of the fastest-rising young actresses in Hollywood. Gifted and beautiful, increasingly sought after by A-list directors and studio executives, a comedian as well as a dramatic actress whose range and intensity had stirred Hollywood's attention, she seemed poised to be a big star.

title: As U.S. Spars With Microsoft, Federal Offices Use Its Systems
description: Even as it steps up its antitrust pursuit of the Microsoft Corporation, the Government is becoming increasingly dependent on the company's software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAR, MARIA
description: FELDMAR-Maria. Age 88. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Erno Feldmar. Died peacefully Sunday, May 3. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions in her memory to United Jewish Appeal.

title: TECHNOLOGY; An on-line grocer bets against bananas and meat, instead pushing low prices and national delivery.
description: THE problem with most on-line grocery delivery services is that they actually go to the trouble of delivering groceries.

title: Chocoholics Take Note: Beloved Bean in Peril
description: An unusual alliance of manufacturers and environmental groups has formed to try to prevent what for many people around the world would be a disaster of gigantic proportions: a shortage of chocolate.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARISON, WILLIS P.
description: LARISON-Willis P. Age 94, of Chester, NJ, Friday, May 1, 1998. Husband of the late Ruth Hildebrant Larison, uncle of Agnes Norstrand, Harry Emmons, Shirley Charters. Funeral service will be held on Wednesday, May 6, at 11 AM, at the Community Presbyterian Church of Chester. Friends may call at the Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., 8 Hilltop Rd, Mendham, NJ, on Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial gifts may be made to Chester Fire Department, Chester First Aid Squad or Community Presbyterian Church of Chester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, AARON
description: BROWN-Aaron. Of Aventura, FL. Passed away May 1, 1998. Survived by his loving wife Belle, children Donald, Stuart and Judith, grandchildren and great-grandchildren mourn his passing with fond memories and a smile.

title: Gore, in Mideast, Prods Sides Before Talks
description: On the eve of a new round of Middle East peace talks, Vice President Al Gore appealed to Israelis and Palestinians today to ''open your minds'' and use meetings on Monday in London to break their impasse.

title: INSIDE
description: Talks on Afghan Strife Fail

title: Boy Scout Is Wounded On a Camping Trip
description: A 13-year-old Boy Scout on a weekend camping trip was struck in the side by a stray bullet yesterday, the Nassau County police said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the Queen of a South African tribe misspelled its name. As the article noted, Modjadji, the Rain Queen, rules the Lobedu, not the Lodedu.

title: Gates to Sell 1 Million Shares of Microsoft
description: William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell a million shares of his software company's stock.

title: The Heat Barely Hears It From Riley
description: Pat Riley gave a very short speech to his team today after its 98-81 season-ending playoff loss at Miami Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKSNES, KARE
description: MOKSNES-Kare. On April 30, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Georgette. Dear father of Helen. Visitation 11 AM to 12 noon, Tuesday. Religious service 12 noon, Tuesday, at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave, New York, NY. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Norwegian Seaman's Church.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Offer More Data on Line
description: An Internet pioneer who put data from the Securities and Exchange Commission on line four years ago at no cost to computer users is now challenging the Federal Government to make the nation's patent and trademark data base freely available. He is threatening to undertake the project himself as a guerrilla effort to make the data publicly accessible if the Government fails to respond.

title: For Giuliani, Ties to Labor Turn Shaky With Layoffs
description: For a Republican mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani has maintained surprisingly good relations with labor, even gaining the endorsement of the citywide labor federation last year, but those relations have entered a rough patch in recent weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, ETHEL
description: ROBBINS-Ethel. Of Tamarac, FL, and Brooklyn, NY. On May 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harold W. Robbins. Devoted mother of Karyl Stile and Alisa Robbins. Cherished grandmother of Matthew and Jessica Lesher. Adored sister of Herbert and Bunni Applebaum. Loving aunt of Stefanie Ruben and Gary and Simon Applebaum. A woman of valor. Funeral service Tuesday, May 5 Parkside Memorial Chapel, Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY, 11:30 AM. Donations to the Grace Smith House, P.O. Box 5205, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

title: A Lift for After-School Programs
description: George Soros, the philanthropist, has announced that he will contribute up to $25 million annually for five years to create new after-school programs in the New York City schools. His one condition is that the grants are matched three to one by private and public contributions. The potential total, $100 million, could make an enormous difference to the city's children, but even a smaller sum would help a great deal. For years, educational leaders have lamented the lack of activities and adult supervision for children after school, particularly in impoverished areas. School buildings are available for use, but many stand empty after 3 o'clock because there is no money to pay for staff.

title: Bama's Governor Tells All
description: In a rare moment last week, Gov. Fob James of Alabama stepped up to a microphone and did something that would have been daring if he had known he was doing it. He spoke the truth. But it was a sad moment for the people of Alabama, because what he said, to another politician, was that what they were both doing was really a lie, an artifice. They knew it. It was just the people who didn't.

title: A Tribute to a Master Of the Bravura Moment
description: As Martin Scorsese is honored tonight with a gala tribute by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the event will mark a passing of the figurative baton. Mr. Scorsese, at 55, is the first of the 1970's youthquake directors to be thus recognized for a career of big risks and bravura moments, for a thrilling body of work that has consistently dazzled fellow filmmakers and audiences alike.

title: This Time, Martin Is Victorious
description: A year ago, Mark Martin saw his chance to win the inaugural California 500 in Fontana disappear when he had to make a late stop for gas. Yesterday, he had more than enough to put away the rest of the field for his third victory of the season.

title: Agencies Make Moves On Interactive Front
description: There were several developments last week involving interactive advertising.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about celebrations of Israel's 50th anniversary misstated the location of some festivities in Jerusalem. They were at Givat Ram stadium, not Ramat Gan stadium. The article also misspelled part of the name of a site in east Jerusalem and misspelled the Palestinian term for catastrophe. The site was Jabal Abu Ghneim, not Jamal Abu Ghneim, and the term is nakba, not nakva.

title: U.S. Pessimistic Before Middle East Talks
description: If the meetings here on Monday between Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Israeli and Palestinian leaders go as badly as American officials seem to expect, President Clinton will face some hard choices that could bring him into more open confrontation with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

title: Cable Industry Ready to Fight to Offer Internet Access
description: If you hear loud noise emanating from Atlanta today, it's the cable television industry clearing its throat saying, ''Ahem, remember us.''

title: Historical Accuracy Aside, True Psychological Battles
description: In interviews, when Valery Gergiyev speaks of why Americans should care about the work he does as the artistic director of the Kirov Opera in St. Petersburg, he emphasizes that there is an entire Russian repertory that is largely unknown and rich with masterpieces. It would be easy to assume this is overstatement, that by now all the truly significant pieces from every culture have won recognition.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Abroad at Home; Slime on the Right
description: If there has been a slimier political act in Washington in recent decades, I do not remember it. Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, reached depths of degradation in publishing transcripts of telephone conversations that Webster L. Hubbell had, from prison, with his wife, friends and lawyers.

title: Democrats Agree to a Tax Package Including Rebates
description: Four months ago, Democrats in the Connecticut House of Representatives dismissed as little more than an election-year ploy a proposal by Gov. John G. Rowland to send rebate checks of as much as $200 to thousands of taxpayers. On Saturday, many of those same Democrats swallowed hard and voted for a tax package with a rebate proposal strikingly similar to the one that Mr. Rowland, a Republican, had suggested in February.

title: Essay; Who's Squeezing Suzy?
description: Isn't it awful, spin the Clinton cover-uppers, that Webster Hubbell's wife is included in his indictment for tax fraud? How cruel to squeeze a potential witness by threatening his wife.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have to figure out how to grow it sustainably. Nobody wants to lose chocolate''

title: G.O.P. Leader Is Under Attack In Tape Release
description: The Republican leader of the House investigation into President Clinton's fund-raising came under sharp criticism today for releasing edited transcripts of the prison conversations of Webster L. Hubbell, which omitted one passage that appeared favorable to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Infertility Panel Missed on Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Bank Debacle May Shake Market Confidence, for Now
description: ROME   This weekend's unseemly battle over the presidency of the European Central Bank could rattle currency and bond markets temporarily and might even cause interest rates to rise sooner than expected in Germany and France this spring, several leading European economists said Sunday.

title: What Antitrust Is All About
description: Rarely does a prospective antitrust case roil public passion. But since it became known that I represent a company urging the Justice Department to challenge certain of Microsoft's business practices, my mail has certainly livened up. One letter writer complained that I had sold my ''sole.'' His spelling aside, that writer was at least kinder than the one who labeled me senile.

title: On NATO, How Will Russia React?
description: To the Editor:

title: School Where Bricks Fell Is Set to Reopen Today
description: A Queens elementary school that was shut down nearly two weeks ago after bricks slid from a fourth-floor corner of the building is scheduled to reopen today, school officials said.

title: Behind I.R.S. Hearings, a G.O.P. Plan to End Tax Code
description: The taxpayer abuse hearings that Senate Republicans held last week were designed to show that the Internal Revenue Service is out of control. And with tales of tax agents in flak jackets storming houses and forcing teen-age girls to change their clothes at gunpoint not leavened by any testimony from the accused I.R.S. agents, the case seemed overwhelming.

title: At Home With: GREGORY PECK; A Glamorous Movie Idol's Gracious Semi-Retirement
description: On an El Nino-soaked afternoon, Gregory Peck, white haired, bearded, still matinee-idol handsome, was strolling around his Bel-Air home, showing a reporter some of the art that he and his wife, Veronique, have collected during their 41 years of marriage.

title: Urban Oases Imperiled
description: To the Editor:

title: Lou Cioffi, 72, Dies; Veteran Journalist
description: Lou Cioffi, a broadcast journalist who covered the Korean War in the 1950's, the Vietnam War in the 1960's and the 1979-1981 hostage crisis in Iran, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He turned 72 last week.

title: Traveling Many Miles to Ask What Made Alexander Great
description: Michael Wood, tour guide, historian, legend spinner and Britain's gift to PBS, begins his latest trip tonight, an epic journey ''In the Footsteps of Alexander the Great.''

title: Immigrants Moving Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULVER, GEORGE MALCOM
description: CULVER-George Malcom. Of Charlotte, NC. Died May 1, 1998. Retired as Vice-President of Dime Savings Bank of N.Y. Survived by his wife, Edith P. Culver.

title: Staying Serene Under Pressure, the Knicks Oust Miami
description: Charlie Ward's world was twirling around him, again. There was an enemy crowd's roar hurtling through his ears and a season whistling by him.

title: Hearing on Death Row Inmate's Competency Bogs Down
description: Almost every workday for the last several weeks, Horace Edwards Kelly Jr., a San Quentin inmate sentenced to die, has sat shackled to his chair in Marin County Superior Court, observing a jury hearing that will determine whether he is mentally competent enough to be executed for fatally shooting two women and a boy in 1984.

title: The Old Guys Show That They Got Game
description: An hour before he, Buck Williams and Terry Cummings opened the classroom for Game 5, Charles Oakley was sitting by himself in the corner of the Knicks' locker room at Miami Arena. He tore the plastic off a new compact disk and popped it into his portable CD player. The title track from ''He Got Game'' blared through the earphones.

title: On NATO, How Will Russia React?; Kennan's Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELMAN, HOWARD
description: EDELMAN-Howard. Of Cliffside Park, NJ. Son of Leo and Mollie Edelman, father of Jack, Gary, Stacey Cambra and Jennifer Edelman, brother of Stuart and Jeffrey. Beloved grandfather of Aria Edelman and Nicholas Cambra. Services are 12 noon today, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W. 150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, JOSEPHINE
description: THOMPSON-Josephine. On May 2, 1998. Longtime resident of Larchmont, NY. One of two daughters of Harvey Mark Thomas of The Thomas Publishing Company. Beloved wife of the late Olaf Holst-Knudsen. Loving mother of Carl Thomas Holst-Knudsen. Caring sister of Felicia Townsend. Devoted grandmother of Heidi Cassola, Heather and Mark Thomas Holst-Knudsen. Great-grandmother of Alexis and Francesca Cassola. Later married and predeceased by John M. Thompson of Roanoke, VA. Stepmother of John B. Thompson of Roanoke, VA. Funeral Service at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY, on Tuesday, May 5, 1998 at 10 AM. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY. Memorial donations to The Westtown School, P.O. Box 1799, Westtown, PA 19395, would be appreciated.

title: The Stuff of Memories And Manic Wit; A Comic Revisits Queens, the Source Of Material for His Broadway Show
description: John Leguizamo was back home the other day, in what he once called ''the large intestine that was Queens.'' He cruised down Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, past the Mexican mango vendors and the hustler pitching the services of a storefront fortuneteller. He pointed to the pet shop where he had tried in vain to steal parakeets. ''They put locks on those suckers,'' he muttered resentfully. Up ahead, he stared, bewildered, at the man in the mangy chicken suit waving menus at the passers-by. ''Maybe it has Hong Kong bird flu,'' he ventured.

title: Brief Books for Busy Readers
description: Having trouble getting through that 700-page biography on your bedside table? The allure of books that can be read in a couple of hours has not been lost on publishers battling aggressive competition for consumers' leisure time.

title: Treasury Sale Is Limited to Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Metro Matters; A Charter For Doing Nothing Much
description: ALTHOUGH 1998 is barely five months old, it has already seen the formation of no less than three City Charter revision commissions. The first was a dubious affair, the second a mockery of that and the third, which is by some accounts a belated revival of the second, is straight out of Dario Fo.

title: Pollution Credits Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESENTHAL, MAXWELL L. (MICKY)
description: WIESENTHAL - Maxwell L. (Micky). Of Portland, Maine. On May 2, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Edith (Boguslav). Devoted father of Joan Beck of Denver, Colorado. Loving grandfather of Jonathan and Derika Brahmer of Augusta, Georgia and Joshua Brahmer of Denver, Colorado. Dearly loved brother of Bunny Barkin of Fairfield, Connecticut and the late Hilda W. Dannay and Harold. Services held in Portland, Maine.

title: New Congo, Old Politics
description: It was just under a year ago that Laurent Kabila drove the longtime Zairian ruler, Mobutu Sese Seko, from power. Promising to end 32 years of dictatorship, corruption and incompetence, Mr. Kabila restored the country's pre-Mobutu name of Congo. Eleven and a half months later, far too much of the Mobutu style remains.

title: 8th Leg Under Way
description: The eighth leg of the Whitbread Round the World race started yesterday from Annapolis, Md. The leg is, essentially, a dash across the Atlantic, ending 3,390 miles away in La Rochelle, France.

title: Banjo Tunes, Bombas and the Sounds of Tree Frogs in a Community Sing
description: Folkways Records celebrated 50 years of idiosyncratic survival at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, with a concert that assembled the label's longtime allies, including Pete Seeger and Ella Jenkins, along with younger admirers and traditionalists from across the United States. Together, they reveled in the ways musicians and listeners have redefined folk music.

title: Income Gap Widens
description: To the Editor:

title: When Ghost Town Dies, What of the Ghosts?
description: The calendar inside the ghost town's main residence has turned, April to May, but there is no indication what year it is. In perpetual defiance, its owner refuses to allow any hint of the modern age into town. Everything else is frozen, stuck in the tracks of time.

title: Ewing Unlikely for Game 1
description: Patrick Ewing continues to make progress toward a potential return from the wrist surgery he underwent in December, but the Knicks' president, Ernie Grunfeld, said today that in ''all likelihood'' their franchise center would not be in uniform for Game 1 of the Knicks' second-round series with the Indiana Pacers on Tuesday.

title: Ford is jettisoning its 17-year-old 'quality is job one' tagline for 'Better ideas. Driven by you.'
description: MOST cars and trucks built today by the Big Three American auto makers are of a high quality -- a big contrast to the 1980's when Japanese brands made Fords, Chryslers and Chevrolets look like junkers.

title: Legislation on On-Line Copyrights Advances
description: Hoping to take global leadership on the hotly disputed issue of protecting creative works in cyberspace, Congress is completing legislation that would expand copyright protections to on-line material.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DARRACH, BRAD
description: DARRACH-Brad. A memorial service honoring our friend and colleague will take place Tuesday, May 5, in the Ceremonial Hall of the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, at 5 PM.

title: Martins Finds Pleasure Amid the Ruins
description: The New York City Ballet presented four fine and familiar works by George Balanchine on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, but the program was of special interest because it included Peter Martins's ''Stabat Mater.'' Choreographed in February, this work to a poignant vocal score by Pergolesi is one of Mr. Martins's most unusual and imaginative creations.

title: O'Neill Ends Home-Run Drought, but No. 201 Is Elusive
description: Paul O'Neill, he of the helmet-bouncing and bat-flipping, will play his whole career thinking he could've or should've done more. He hit his first home run of the season today and was wondering why he didn't hit two.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bump in Road to Euro May Signal Trouble Ahead

title: A MOLE IN BLUE: A special report.; Detective's Loyalty Is Questioned As Mob Stays Step Ahead of Law
description: Disguised in a silk shirt, alligator shoes and the street name Vinnie Blue Eyes, the undercover police detective was closing in on the mobsters suspected of killing a New York City firefighter.

title: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro
description: If Europe gave out an award to politicians who shoot themselves in the foot, President Jacques Chirac of France might take the prize.

title: Rockies Hand Mets a Gift-Wrapped Victory
description: Rick Reed had pitched brilliantly for eight innings yesterday in silencing the formidable Colorado Rockies. He had also knocked in the starving Mets' only run, indicating how perilously close he was to enduring an aggravating afternoon. Then the Rockies presented the Mets with an unexpected batch of gifts in the bottom of the eighth and turned a close contest into an eruption of errors.

title: Waking Up Ears With Schubert
description: Gidon Kremer, with his inquiring mind and splendid skills at the violin, keeps making a case for living concerts in an increasingly moribund concert world. Mozart's Symphony No. 33 and Dvorak's seductive Serenade for Strings framed his visit to Orpheus and to Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, but it was the three pieces between them that woke up the ear and set the mind to working.

title: Why Today's News Is No Longer What Happened Yesterday
description: The 1970's may have been called the Me Decade, but in terms of news coverage, it is clearly the 1990's that have put a premium on the personal.

title: Sports of The Times; The Devils Need Some Playoff Scorers
description: FOR all the tributes to the Devils' trapping defense ever since they won the Stanley Cup in 1995, it turns out that they trapped themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINTON, JOEL J.
description: RUBINTON-Joel J., Esquire. Age 69. On April 29, 1998. Former attorney and teacher, Administrative Law Judge, culture vulture, avid traveler and community volunteer. He will be sorely missed by his loving wife of 46 years, Natalie; his children, Jeff, Eric, David and Ellen; their spouses Sharon, Miriam and Joshua; grandchildren Samantha, Sarah, Jillian, Daniel, Brian, Max, Evan and Gabrielle, and many dear and loving friends and relatives. He loved living and was well loved in return. Memorial gifts to the American Heart Association would be greatly appreciated by his family.

title: Baffert's Pair of Stars Will Head to Preakness
description: Four of the first five finishers in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, headed by Bob Baffert's triumphant pair of Real Quiet and Indian Charlie, were headed for the Preakness Stakes today. But only four other horses seemed certain to contest the race, leaving the second leg of the Triple Crown with a field of eight probable starters, with room for more.

title: A Plan to End Bankruptcy At Barneys Is Nearly Ready
description: The financial drama that has engulfed Barneys New York for two years may be coming to an end.

title: How Much Is a Euro? About$1.1
description: LONDON  Another struggle, another eleventh-hour compromise, and finally, after years of arduous effort, Europe has agreed to launch the euro. So what's it worth?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASH, CANTOR SAUL (BASHKOWITZ)
description: BASH-Cantor Saul (Bashkowitz). Beloved husband of the late Celia (Kumin) Bash; father of Rabbi Marvin, Paul, and Irwin; grandfather of nine and great-grandfather of five. Funeral services on Monday at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY, at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMA, MICHAEL A.
description: PALMA-Michael A. On May 1, 1998. Survived by his wife Kerstin, his sons Erik, James and Michael, family and friends. Family will receive Tuesday 2-5, 7-9 PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St. Mass of Christian Burial Church of Our Savior, Park Ave at 38th St, Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: A Cartoonist Who Mourns Bad Old Days; Oliphant Finds Political Satire Is Overtaken by Reality
description: Protecting his own subversiveness is the ultimate art for Pat Oliphant, the political cartoonist who is pernicious enough to vote for those politicians he most despises and so most needs to keep on drawing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, ETHEL
description: BERLINER-Ethel. On May 1, 1998. Age 91. Devoted sister of David Berliner. She will be sadly missed by family and friends. Service Monday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Fu Manchu Away From Pitching Success
description: The San Diego Padres were set up to be road kill by the time May arrived. A club that scared precious few last year faced a daunting task this spring: play 25 of its first 37 games on the road and survive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, ETHEL E.
description: HOWARD-Ethel E. Formerly of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, on May 2, 1998, age 92. Loving sister of the late James, Alice Paradine, Joseph, John and Margaret. Dear sister-in-law of Florence V. Howard and Florence Howard. Fond aunt of a niece and five nephews. Visting Wednesday morning, 1011:45 AM, at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave (corner 78th St), Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Angels, Wednesday, 12:15 PM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: A review of the musical ''High Society'' on April 28 misstated the critical reaction to an earlier production, in San Francisco. That show received several favorable reviews, and its run was extended for a week because of ticket demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSHACK, CYNTHIA
description: GRUSHACK-Cynthia. The Board, Staff and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, mourn the passing of Cynthia Gruschack, who served over the years as assistant to our founder, Jack Hausman. Both at Belding Heminway and since 1994 at UCP, she helped to assure support for our vital services. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband Louie, her son Ira and daughter-in-law Jo, her daughter Allison and son-in-law Leonard Isaacs, and to her grandchildren Sidney, Jesse, Sammy, Adam and Justin. Leo Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews Executive Director UCP of NYC, Inc.

title: Cloud Over the Emmys As Cable Surges Ahead
description: Will competition kill the Emmy Awards?

title: One Calendar or Another, Greek Orthodox Heal Rift
description: Amid the airs of a brass band, the pealing of church bells, sonorous Byzantine incantations and the jubilant cries of a thousand faithful, a 27-year-old rift that separated 30,000 Greek Orthodox from their 1.5 million brethren in the United States was healed over a couple of hours yesterday in a corner of Astoria, Queens.

title: Equity and Convertible Offerings Set This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Effort to Oust Gotti Lawyer Reopens Debate on Tactics
description: A Federal judge here is expected to rule soon on the request by prosecutors to bar Bruce Cutler, the boisterous defense lawyer, from the racketeering trial of John A. Gotti, the son of the imprisoned mob boss.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LELAND, ROBERT H.
description: LELAND-Robert H. On April 30, 1998. Formerly of NYC. Past District Deputy Grand Master, First Manhattan District of the Masons. Retired officer and legal counsel for Chase Bag Co. (Union Camp Corp.), Greenwich, CT. Devoted husband of Janine (nee Krupski). Loving father of James G. and Douglas R. Fond brother of Marilyn Kimmel. Cherished grandfather of three. Friends may call Tuesday, 12-2 PM, 6-9 PM, at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave (at City Line), New Hyde Park, NY. Masonic service Tuesday, 8 PM. Funeral service Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Interment Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: For Amber Waves of Data; After the Green Revolution Comes Farming's Geek Revolution
description: There is a haunting prescience to the ''Evolution of Agriculture,'' an old chemical company poster on the wall of Tom Dorr's farm office. It ends in 1981 with the invention of a mobile rig to measure electronically the nutritional value of animal feed -- the time line's first mention of a computer.

title: On NATO, How Will Russia React?; More Than Containment
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a threat by senior House Democrats to withdraw support for the Clinton Administration's request for $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund misstated the number of countries in the organization. It is 182, not 162.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, PEGGY
description: MOSES-Peggy. Westchester Jewish Community Services mourns the death of Peggy Moses, beloved, former Board President. Formerly of White Plains, Peggy will be sorely missed by all who were touched by her life.

title: Otto L. Bettmann, 94, Dies; Founded Archive of Photos
description: Otto L. Bettmann, who fled to New York from Nazi Germany in 1935 with two trunks of prints and photographs and founded the renowned Bettmann Archive, a commercial treasure house of pictorial material that percolated into American culture through newspapers, magazines, books and television, died on Friday at Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida. He was 94.

title: On NATO, How Will Russia React?; Lessons of History
description: To the Editor:

title: Magazine Marketing Raises Question of Editorial Independence
description: It is 9 A.M. in the conference room at Vogue magazine. Vogue's publisher, Ronald A. Galotti, is presenting the results of a research study to executives from Elizabeth Arden. Slides are projected. Coffee is served.

title: Three Agencies In Acquisitions
description: Three agencies are making acquisitions, the terms of which were not disclosed.

title: A Bargain Horse Wins for the Little Guys
description: In a sport where yearling horses often cost more than a four-bedroom house, Real Quiet was a fixer-upper in a rundown neighborhood. He had a crooked right front leg, a moderate pedigree, and was sold at auction in a cattle call that finds nearly 3,000 horses going through the sales ring in a week.

title: Reno Defends Her Decision About Inquiry on Finances
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today defended her decision not to appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign fund-raising by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, even as Republicans in Congress predicted that new evidence would soon force Ms. Reno to reconsider.

title: Is Incivility in Our Genes?
description: I have to confess that all my years of studying human evolution haven't helped me much in understanding our day-to-day behavior. But the latest New York City crises in civility and traffic make me think that, just as Homo sapiens is most neatly defined as the species that is impelled to take every good idea to its most ludicrous extreme, our city now bids fair to become the place where no sensible notion avoids being caricatured into its own antithesis.

title: Tough Decisions in Covering a Suicide
description: The questions raised by a public suicide in the car-pool lane of a Los Angeles freeway on Thursday are complicated and uncomfortable. The answers may be uncomfortable, too, but they are not all that complicated. Is live television coverage of a man bent on death ever permissible? Is it news or is it just a show? Is such coverage forgivable if the performer restrains himself until the afternoon children's programs have ended? Is live coverage, which reduces the control of news directors, too risky for public safety?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHTER, ROSA
description: SCHACHTER-Rosa. On May 1, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Enrique. Loving mother of Alicia and Sheldon Rich. Dear grandmother of Jenny Rich and Jenny Mayer. Great grandmother of Ethan Henry. Graveside service Tuesday 1 PM at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, New York.

title: The Privileges War
description: Properly construed, the doctrine of executive privilege exempts only a narrow band of Presidential activities from the reach of legal inquiry. To invoke that privilege in a broad and self-serving way, as the Clinton White House has done to shield itself from Kenneth Starr's inquiry, is to abuse it.

title: Lagos Journal; Nigeria Hangs Out a Banner: Ici On Parle Francais
description: Every school day begins with songs in the suburban Lagos elementary school classroom of Eniola Akinosho, who leads her tentative-sounding pupils through a collection of happy jingles to build their confidence before moving on to trickier matters like spelling and grammar.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 22 about a demonstration by strippers in City Hall Park referred incorrectly to one man at the scene The man seated on the bench was Robert Goodman, a Libertarian Party candidate for City Comptroller who was taking part in the demonstration; he was not an onlooker who decided to move from the bench because of the protests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGANELLI, ROGER T.
description: PAGANELLI-Roger T. Beloved husband of the late Carmela ''Babe''. Devoted father of Dolores Jurgens, Armand, Janet, Roger J., Helen Ray and Michael. Dearest brother of Dr. Dolores Paganelli. Reposing A. Ribustello & Son, 811 Morris Park Ave, Bronx. Funeral mass Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY Tuesday 11AM.

title: The On-Line Choice for People's Most Beautiful: Angry Hank
description: Even to those with only the slightest grip on the pulse of popular culture, it will come as little surprise that People magazine has chosen the teen-age idol Leonardo DiCaprio to grace the cover of its annual ''50 Most Beautiful People'' issue, which hit newsstands this last weekend.

title: A Chicago Options Trader Heads to the Cavendish Pairs
description: If one could arrange a team championship in which squads were organized by occupation, it is likely that the options traders would win: trading is a game in which the player must study patterns and make accurate decisions quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, ARNOLD
description: MARSHALL-Arnold. On May 1, 1998, after a courageous fight. Loving husband of Marcia. Beloved father of Alexandra. Dear brother of Johanna. Services Mon. May 4, 1:30 PM, Frank Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLANSKY, ARTHUR
description: SCHLANSKY-Arthur. Husband of Susan. Cherished son of Henrietta. Loving brother of Norman and Loretta Schlansky and Marilyn Sokolow. Dear uncle. Service today, 11:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (near Avenue V). Arthur was a very loving and caring individual who touched many people's lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLISH, ROSE C.
description: ENGLISH-Rose C. Age 90, of Interlaken, NJ (formerly Bronx, NY). On April 30, 1998. Wife of the late Howard L. Mother of Howard L. Jr., Rosemary English and Cathleen Flynn. Grandmother of Christopher M. Flynn and Mary C. English. Services were held in St. Anselm's Church, Wayside, NJ, on May 2, with burial following in Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-On-Hudson, NY. Buckley Funeral Home, Asbury Park, NJ, for more information.

title: A Tour de France, on Water
description: The Worrell 1000 tends to be unlike any other sailboat competition on the planet. That might explain why a road map of the route, complete with its cross-references to hotel locations along the way, helped Randy Smyth and Jason Sneed win the two-week catamaran race last year.

title: An Ordinary Life, Spiced With a Southern Flavor
description: ROXANNA SLADE

title: A look back at reporting in 1968 yields a mixed lesson.
description: THERE is something a bit disconcerting about seeing typewriter keys, old radio microphones and the like, the artifacts of the grittier days of journalism, arrayed on gift store shelves with price tags attached. Reporters are used to thinking of their work going to libraries, not to the tchotchke aisle.

title: Despite Countless Critics, Hashimoto Has No Rival
description: Norio Tanaka is not about to starve, but he was already nudged out of one longtime job and is worried he might lose the work he has now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKELLY, ALTMAN, FLORENCE
description: SKELLY - ALTMAN - Florence. The staff, clients and friends of DYG, Inc., express their profound sorrow on the passing of their cherished colleague, Florence Skelly. Her wit and brilliance will be deeply missed. A memorial service is planned for early June. Please call 203-744-9008 for further information.

title: WASHINGTON STATE IS STAGE FOR FIGHT OVER PREFERENCES
description: The State of Washington, until now known for its rain, software, caffeine and political independence, is about to become ground zero in the nation's continuing war over affirmative action.

title: With Euro Accord in Place, Next Question Is Credibility
description: In the wake of a messy political compromise that marred the agreement here this weekend among European leaders to adopt a new single currency, financial analysts predicted today that world markets were likely to be more suspicious than before about the fledgling euro.

title: For Yankees, Good Day, Sunshine
description: The sun rose in the East today and the Yankees won, naturally occurring events. The Yankees play, they win. Today it was a 10-1 destruction of the Kansas City Royals. The Yankees' Paul O'Neill laced his first home run of the season, the 200th of his career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNERNEY, JAMES J.
description: McNERNEY-James J. Died April 25, 1998, age 84. He was a retired Administrator of the Queens Public Library. Husband of Gladys (nee Pearce), father of James A., of Cortlandt, NY and Daniel of San Francisco, Ca. Grandfather of two. Interment at the St. George's Graveyard in Astoria at the family's convenience. In lieu of flowers contributions to your local Hospice

title: Reno Backs Stance In Denying Counsel Over Fund-Raising
description: Attorney General Janet Reno says she must have ''specific and credible evidence'' of wrongdoing before she will appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign fund-raising by President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore.

title: Circulation Of Papers Rises Slightly, Audit Says
description: Newspaper circulation, battered by a decade of declines, is showing limited improvement for the second time in a year, as increases at New York metropolitan area dailies and at USA Today, the Gannett Company Inc.'s national newspaper, helped push overall daily circulation up by seven-tenths of 1 percent.

title: On NATO, How Will Russia React?; Official Cynicism
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANSE, AGNES (NEE MCKENNA)
description: SANSE-Agnes (nee McKenna). On April 30, 1998. Of Heathrow, FL. Formerly of Manhasset, NY. Age 78. Retired in 1979 as Associate Director of Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn, NY, after 25 years of service. Beloved wife of Ray. Dear mother of William J. and Ann Mahoney and Sharon and Richard Berger. Loving stepmother of Anita Galan, Raymond Sanseverino and Raphael Sanseverino. Also survived by 16 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Reposing at Mangano Funeral Home Inc, 1701 Deer Park Ave, Deer Park, NY, Monday and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Ss. Cyril and Methodist RC Church. Entombment to follow.

title: Condominiums Consider Barring Some Paroled Sex Offenders
description: Villas at Eagle Ridge, an upper-income condominium complex sitting atop a cliff here, is one of about a dozen privately run communities in northern New Jersey that are considering barring some paroled sex offenders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSCHUTZ, GRETA
description: LIPSCHUTZ-Greta. On May 3, 1998. Wife of the late William. Beloved mother of Marion (Michael) Stahl. Grandmother of Andrew and a friend to many. We shall miss you. Services 1 PM, Tuesday, from Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Youthful Sprint Wears Out Houston
description: It was not exactly the kind of roundball lyric that Clyde Drexler wanted to lay down for the final movement of his Hall of Fame career: 1 for 13 from the field, 4 for 10 from the foul line, 6 points. But those were not the numbers that undid Drexler and the Houston Rockets today.

title: Patents; A restraint to hold, or sometimes free, riders when their horses come to a sudden stop.
description: THE actor Christopher Reeve was paralyzed in a horse-jumping accident three years ago when his mount stopped suddenly and he was thrown over the horse's head. Riders accumulate momentum just as do passengers in moving cars; if horses stop suddenly, their riders do not, momentum carries them forward, sometimes out of the saddle and onto the ground.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, HELEN
description: GOLDBERG-Helen. Age 92. Wife of the late Louis. Adored mother of Rhoda (Murray) Henick, Barbara (Herb) Gold and Gerald (Roxanne). Cherished grandmother of eight and sixteen great-grandchildren. Sister of Leo Bodner. Graveside services today.

title: National Guardsman Killed By Lightning at Fort Dix
description: A bolt of lightning that struck during a relatively mild storm killed a 22-year-old New Jersey National Guardsman and burned five other reservists, two of them critically, during a routine training exercise in the sprawling pinelands of the Fort Dix military base in Central New Jersey early yesterday morning, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTERST, STACY ANNE
description: LITTERST-Stacy Anne. Of Oakland, NJ, died March 29, 1998, at the home of her sister, Deborah Anne Litterst Barbara, in Alexandria, VA. Beloved daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Litterst, of Oakland, and the late Anne Stewart Litterst, sisters Mary Litterst, of Brookline, MA., Terry Litterst, of Newbury, MA., Sandra Brockman, of Kansas City, MO., Katherine McGarry, of Galesville, MD, and brothers, Arthur Congdon, of New Canaan, CT., Warren Congdon, of Vernon, NJ, and William McGarry, of Metuchen, NJ. Ms. Litterst was a graduate of Indian Hills H.S., in Oakland, Berkeley Secretarial School of Ridgewood, and Santa Rosa California Junior College. A Memorial Service will be at The Vernon Methodist Church, Vernon, Sat. May 9, 1998, 11 A.M.

title: On Local Level, at Least, Bosnians Try to Get Along
description: The political changes that have taken place in this town are signaled in the surprising new relationship between two men. From war-time enemies they have become the Mayor and Deputy Mayor and they are trying to learn something new for Bosnia: how to share political power.

title: Seeing Race as a Costume That Everyone Wears
description: When I was a child in the 1950's, you weren't supposed to use the word ''mulatto.'' You only heard or overheard adults using it with eyebrows raised and quotation marks implied. It was considered backward: meant to demean when used by whites and, when used by your own, a sign that you were just a little too proud of your white blood. It would have been rude to use it around mulatto playmates, and it wasn't always clear who was the child of a Negro and a Caucasian and who was the child of a brown-skinned and a fair-skinned Negro.

title: Infertility Panel Missed on Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Black and Hispanic Immigrants Lag in Housing Study
description: Black and Hispanic immigrants -- particularly those from the Dominican Republic -- continue to live in New York City's most dilapidated housing, pay among the highest percentages of income for rent and have the lowest rates of home ownership, according to a study commissioned by the Fannie Mae Foundation, an arm of the federally chartered home-mortgage provider.

title: Stunned Devils Are Left Searching for Answers
description: Just before the playoffs, goalie Martin Brodeur mused about all the attention that would soon come to his successful but often-overlooked Devils. With the Rangers and the Islanders failing to qualify for the tournament, the Devils were the New York area's only hockey team still playing. And with the Knicks and the Nets not expected to advance in the National Basketball Association tournament, the Devils would soon share the metropolitan spotlight with only the two baseball teams.

title: Yeltsin's Tax Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTOL, EUNICE SCHINE.
description: POSTOL-Eunice Schine. Of Fairfield, CT, on May 2, 1998. A special friend and a lady of grace and strength. Portal 15 will never be the same without you. Ellen and Austin Wolf

title: Restaurateur Accused of Driving Into Wife
description: Jimmy Rodriguez, a popular Bronx restaurateur who also made a name for himself in the rarefied circles of the Upper East Side, was arrested yesterday on charges that he hit his wife with his car early Friday, the police said.

title: Infertility Panel Missed on Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Van Gundy Shuns Mentor's Sad Lesson
description: THE young coach of the Knicks learned a few sobering things about his mentor in the heated hours leading into what would become the most gratifying 2 hours 20 minutes of his working life. Pat Riley, infuriated by events that had spun out of his control, desperate for an edge, made Jeff Van Gundy the target of his carefully scripted ire.

title: Child Killer Enrages Britain Again
description: Thirty years after 10-year-old Mary Bell strangled two little boys, becoming one of Britain's most notorious criminals, the revelation that she was paid to cooperate on a forthcoming book about her case has sent waves of revulsion around the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, HERMAN PETER
description: ROGERS-Herman Peter. Of Hackensack, NJ. On May 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Reita (nee Berlat). Devoted father of Beth A. Rogers and Toby Rogers. Loving grandfather of John Katz. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ, Monday May 4, 1998, at 11:30 AM.

title: Better Public Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Arenas and Records Keep a CityHawk in the Game
description: Battered from being tackled on a carpeted hockey rink, Mike Perez tells himself that every Arena Football League season will be his last. But pro football's fringe keeps calling him back.

title: Battle Likely Over Visits to Titanic Wreckage
description: Mike McDowell is a star of adventure tourism. For $19,000, he or one of his companies will sell you a berth on a Russian icebreaker that cuts its way to the North Pole. For $25,000, he will fly you to the South Pole.

title: Agreement Draws Scorn From Range Of Europeans
description: FRANKFURT   Critics across Europe's political spectrum poured scorn Sunday on a compromise over the leadership of the new EuropeanCentral Bank, charging that the weekend's overt deal-making violated the Maastrichttreaty and "deforms" the European Union's single currency at its birth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, PAULINE LILLIAN KLETTER
description: HOFFMAN-Pauline Lillian Kletter. Beloved sister of Clara Kletter Unterberg. Adored aunt of Adele and Roberta. Cherished grandaunt of Charles Joshua. Passed away Friday, May 1, 1998. She will be lovingly remembered and never forgotten.

title: Gay Priest Quits Notre Dame And a Debate on Sin Erupts
description: In Roman Catholicism, perhaps no symbol in America evokes a greater sense of pride than the University of Notre Dame. To be a Catholic on the campus of Our Lady under the golden dome is to be part of a family.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Software Fights Bring Former Foes Together
description: Forget politics. The Internet makes stranger bedfellows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEPLI, PHALON, NANCY L.
description: HOEPLI-PHALON-Nancy L. April 30, at home. Editor-in-chief Foreign Policy Association. Wife, Richard A. Phalon, Sr.; sister of Eleanore Hoepli Didriksen, Wellesley, MA. Interment, Saturday, May 9, at 11 AM, Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Sleepy Hollow, NY. Contributions can be made in Nancy's memory to St. Vincent's Hospital Cancer Care, 153 W. 11th St., NYC 10011.

title: Who Says What About a Tobacco Bill
description: Tobacco legislation is now at the stage where the various sides are staking out positions, and no consensus is in sight. DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

title: Schering Net Rose 8.5% in First Quarter
description: Schering A.G., the German pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 8.5 percent, to 165 million marks ($93 million), from 152 million a year earlier, in part because of strong sales of its multiple sclerosis treatment Betaferon. Schering said that revenue was up 10.7 percent in the quarter, to 1.62 billion marks ($913 million), from 1.47 billion a year earlier and that it expected the positive trends to continue the full year.

title: Threatened by Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Session That Led to the Indictment of Susan McDougal
description: Following are excerpts from the Whitewater grand jury session in Little Rock, Ark., on April 23, when Susan H. McDougal declined to answer most questions posed by Julie Myers and Mark J. Barrett, both of the independent counsel's office, and by grand jurors, whose names were not disclosed. A transcript of that session was included in Ms. McDougal's indictment today, which said that since her first grand jury appearance, in September 1996, the independent counsel had located a check in the amount of $5,081.82, dated Aug. 1, 1983, drawn on the James B. McDougal Trustee Account, payable to Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan, and signed by Susan H. McDougal. The words ''Payoff Clinton'' were written in the notation section of the check. There are no markings on the check that would indicate that President Clinton or Hillary Rodham Clinton knew anything about it.

title: In Growth of Body Parts, Darwinian Competition
description: THE natural world is a study in proportions: giraffes with outrageously long necks, Tyrannosaurus rex with its tiny arms, and supermodels with legs that go on and on. But despite all the fun-house-mirror changes wrought by evolution, a lot of imaginable creatures have never existed.

title: Piano Practice Alters Brain
description: PRACTICING the piano for long hours in childhood alters the anatomy of the brain, German scientists have reported. Brain areas that encode the sounds made by a piano are larger in skilled musicians than in people who have never played a musical instrument.

title: Gojko Susak, Defense Minister of Croatia, Is Dead at 53
description: Defense Minister Gojko Susak of Croatia, who went from running a pizzeria in Ottawa to playing a vital role in the Croatian war of independence from Yugoslavia in the 1990's, died on Sunday night in Dubrava Hospital in Zagreb. He was 53.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about a former Rwandan Prime Minister's plea of guilty to genocide charges before a United Nations tribunal in Tanzania included an erroneous reference, from a United Nations news release, to the history of war-crimes pleas in international courts. This was not the first guilty plea. (At least one man has tried to plead guilty to war-crimes charges before the United Nations tribunal investigating war crimes in the Balkans; the judges rejected his plea.)

title: Republicans And Whitman Reach Accord On Insurance
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Republican legislative leaders resolved a dispute today over last-minute changes that Mrs. Whitman had made in proposed auto insurance legislation that had threatened to scuttle it. The agreement cleared the way for final approval of the bill by the State Senate and the General Assembly in the next couple of weeks.

title: Patrick Hayes, 89, Impresario Who Enriched Washington
description: Patrick Hayes, one of the last of the American impresarios and virtually the only presenter of musicians, singers and dancers in Washington before the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts opened in 1971, died on Sunday at George Washington University Medical Center. He was 89.

title: Protecting Divers' Teeth
description: SCUBA diving can be, quite literally, a drag for the teeth, dentists warn.

title: 'Neighborhood' to Close
description: ''The Old Neighborhood,'' David Mamet's trilogy of one-act plays, is to close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The play, directed by Scott Ziegler and starring Peter Riegert and Patti LuPone, will have run for 197 regular performances and 10 previews.

title: Teen-Agers Plead Guilty In School Attack on Girl
description: Four teen-age boys pleaded guilty to a lesser charge yesterday in the gang rape of a 14-year-old girl in an empty classroom of a Queens high school last spring.

title: Red Sales In the Sunset Of the Left
description: THE young man looking around the Unity Book Center, on West 23d Street, could not find what he wanted. ''Don't you have any May Day cards?'' he asked.

title: Meet TNT's Harlan, The Velvet Foghorn
description: You have heard NBC's Bob Costas, Tom Hammond and Mike Breen call basketball and Turner's Verne Lundquist, Dick Stockton and Bob Neal, too. But you have not heard full-throated hoops until you have listened to Kevin Harlan on TNT.

title: Italy's Leader, Due on Visit, Praises U.S. for Backing Euro
description: Prime Minister Romano Prodi may well be the happiest man in Europe.

title: Falk Is Bought Out by SFX
description: David Falk, who helped create huge financial windfalls for his client Michael Jordan, reaped one on his own behalf yesterday when SFX Entertainment acquired FAME, Falk's agency, for $100 million, mostly in cash. Falk, whose client list also includes the basketball stars Patrick Ewing, Juwan Howard and Keith Van Horn, left ProServ in 1992 to found FAME. SFX, a concert promoter and producer, said it spent $125 million more yesterday to buy two concert promoters, a theater and an event merchandiser.

title: China's Leading University Celebrates and Ponders
description: Beijing University celebrated its 100th anniversary today in a scripted extravaganza featuring a speech by President Jiang Zemin, student singing contests, the unveiling of a vast new library and the gussying up of the campus's main gate with a digital countdown clock and a pair of fake potted palms.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Justices Reject Higher Standard for Lawsuits Against Officials
description: The Supreme Court today rejected new, restrictive rules for an important category of civil rights suits against public officials, spurning a lower court's effort to impose them and saying it was not the business of judges to change the law.

title: Clinton Agrees To G.O.P. Deal On Judgeships
description: President Clinton has struck an extraordinary bargain, agreeing to nominate a prominent conservative selected by a Republican senator to an important Federal appeals court post, in exchange for the confirmation of one of his nominees to the same court, Senate and Administration officials said today.

title: Takeover Talk Lifts Shares of Carbide
description: The shares of the Union Carbide Corporation shares rose today amid speculation that the maker of plastics and chemicals may be a takeover target.

title: Connecticut Is Now 49th State To Push Past 55 Speed Limit
description: Twenty years ago, mothers were driving Pintos. Now they are behind the wheels of Explorers or mini-vans. The long lines at gas pumps have gone the way of full-service stations, and ''55 saves lives'' is no longer the mantra of Federal highway officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSHKO, ALBERT
description: FOSHKO-Albert, 71. Of New York City, died April 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Jane Breault and Susan Wiener. Honoring his request, there will be no services.

title: Will the Euro Help Unite a Diverse Continent?; Many Allegiances
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Ragtime' Leads Tony Nominations
description: Ragtime -- 13

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, MURRAY. EUGENE M.
description: RESNICK-Murray. Eugene M. Grant & Company, deeply mourns the death of our beloved colleague & friend, Murray Resnick. A highly skilled Real Estate management professional, a loyal and devoted employee for over three decades, who was above all a gentleman of the old school. He was cherished by his co-workers, his staff members, numerous tenants and vendors, all of whom appreciated his superior qualities. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his loving sons and daughters-in-law, and all of his caring grandchildren. Eugene M. Grant, President

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Evening Hours page of Sunday Styles this week about the annual awards dinner of the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture misidentified a guest. She was Nan Goldin, not Cindy Sherman.

title: Pohang Is Cutting Prices For Korean Steel Users
description: The Pohang Iron and Steel Company said yesterday that it would cut prices for steel used by Korean exporters by as much as 15 percent, giving Korean auto makers and shipbuilders a competitive advantage. To offset the price cut, Pohang, the world's second-largest steel producer, will raise the domestic price of three of its biggest products -- hot-rolled coils, steel plate and wire rods -- by 7 percent each, effective tomorrow, the company said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEPLI, PHALON, NANCY L.
description: HOEPLI-PHALON-Nancy L. April 30, at home. Editor-in-chief Foreign Policy Association. Wife, Richard A. Phalon, Sr.; sister of Eleanore Hoepli Didriksen, Wellesley, MA. Interment, Saturday, May 9, at 11 AM, Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Sleepy Hollow, New York. Contributions can be made in Nancy's memory to St. Vincent's Hospital Cancer Care, 153 West 11th Street, NYC 10011.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, ROBERT S., MD.
description: SHERMAN-Robert S., MD. Age 88. Of Roxbury, CT. on May 3, 1998 in New Milford, CT. A former chairman & attending radiologist at Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in NY. Also a consultant in diagnostic radiology for IBM medical department. Survived by his wife, Dr. Ruth Snyder. Also survived by a daughter Ruth Ann Perkins of Finksburg, MD., two sons Robert Snyder Sherman of Pelham, N.H., and Roger Holmes Sherman of Northport, N.Y., and nine grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Wednesday 11 AM, St. John's Episcopal Church, Washington, CT. Burial in Roxbury Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to the Roxbury Scholarship Foundation, C/O Roxbury Townhall, Roxbury, CT. 06783.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks' Tale: Instincts And Elan
description: LAST December, when the assumed franchise, a k a Patrick Ewing, smashed his wrist, few expected the Knicks to be where they are today, in Market Square Arena in Indianapolis, slipping into their shorts to play the Larry Bird Pacers in the first game of the second round of the National Basketball Association playoffs. Two Knicks who have shocked and amazed more than any others, however, are Jeff Van Gundy and Allan Houston.

title: REPUBLIC TO ACQUIRE 4 AUTO DEALERSHIP GROUPS
description: Republic Industries, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has agreed to buy four groups of auto dealerships in four states for an undisclosed price, adding outlets with about $500 million in annual revenue to its nationwide sales network. Republic said the accord includes the B. J. McCombs Chevrolet, Pontiac/GMC/Jeep/Hyundai and Toyota and the Hendrix GMC and Isuzu Truck franchises in Austin, Tex.; Steve Rayman Pontiac-Buick-GMC Truck in Atlanta; Peyton Cramer Ford and Peyton Cramer Infiniti of Torrance, Calif., and Bob Townsend Ford of Cincinnati. Republic has bought or agreed to buy more than 270 dealerships in about 18 months.

title: Price Proving a Snag In South African Deal
description: Liberty Life Association of Africa Ltd. and the Standard Bank Investment Corporation said yesterday that they were far apart on a merger price, clouding the outlook for creating South Africa's biggest company by market value. Shares of Liberty, South Africa's largest publicly traded insurance company, fell 6 rand, to 165 rand ($32.65). Standard, the nation's biggest bank by assets, rose 1 rand, to 30.9 rand. Standard split its shares 10 for 1 yesterday.

title: Settlement Talks Move Ahead in Tobacco Trial
description: As the trial of Minnesota's lawsuit against the tobacco industry draws to a close, lawyers for the state, tobacco companies and an insurer have stepped up negotiations to reach a settlement, lawyers with direct knowledge of the talks said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGOR, HARRY P., PH.D.
description: GREGOR-Harry P., Ph.D. Age 81. Professor Emeritus of Columbia University and Distinguished Research Professor at Polytechnic University. Beloved husband of Elinor for 57 years. Loving father of Laurel Porter, John, Charles (Marjorie) and Polly (Brian Guillorn). Adored grandfather of Stephen Porter, Ephriam, Aryeh and Rachel Gregor, Martha, Gregory and Sally Guillorn and great grandson Daniel Porter. Also survived by his devoted sister Mary Molner other relatives and many nephews, cousins and loving friends. Memorial contributions may be made to The Polymer Research Institute, Polytechnic University, 6 Metrotech Center, Brooklyn, New York 11201. Shiva will be observed at 410 Riverside Drive, Apt 72A through May 10th.

title: From Science Fiction to Science: 'The Whole Body Transplant'
description: To lend credibility to his fraudulent account of an execution, the pretentious Pooh-Bah in Gilbert and Sullivan's ''The Mikado'' sings:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEE, ABRAHAMS NITA
description: LEE-Abrahams Nita. Our darling daughter. Although grief is our constant companion, we celebrate your glorious and remarkable life. Your loving family

title: They Fear Fewer Jobs, Lower Wages and Pressure for More Productivity : European Unions Warily Greet the Euro
description: FRANKFURT  It can come as a surprise to hear labor union spokesmen across the Continent expressing only guarded enthusiasm for the single European currency and the streamlined new Europe it is expected to bring.

title: Sign of Autumn: 'Watch for Falling Hemlines'
description: Last fall, designers were fixated on tough chic, as epitomized by the power suit with its square shoulders and short skinny skirt. The styles were barely in stores before designers switched their focus to soft romantic clothes for spring. Out of those came the emphasis on long skirts in the recent fall shows in Europe and New York.

title: Will the Euro Help Unite a Diverse Continent?; Future Political Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVELL, FRANK
description: LOVELL-Frank. Passed away peacefully at his home in New York City on April 30, 1998. He was born in Ipava, Illinois, 1913. Beloved husband of the late Sarah. He is survived by his adored daughter, Joan Lovell of Detroit, Michigan and sister-in-law Molly Kerchner of Florida. A memorial meeting will be announced at a future date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IHLO, FRED H., JR.
description: IHLO-Fred H., Jr., 78, Barryville, NY, May 2, 1998. Retired C.P.A.; WW II, 4th Armed Div. Assoc NYC. Survived by his wife, Frances Toaspern Ihlo; daughters, Barbara Sardone of Barryville, NY & Betty Morganstern of Annapolis, Maryland; sons William of New Milford, CT., and John of Brooklyn; a sister, Louise Fredin of Brooklyn; six grandchildren. Friends call at Gray-Rasmussen Funeral Home, Barryville, N.Y., Tuesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Wednesday 11 A.M., at funeral home. Burial Arlington National Cemetery. Contributions to Barryville United Methodist Church, Barryville, N.Y. 12719.

title: BANCORPSOUTH TO ACQUIRE MERCHANTS CAPITAL
description: Bancorpsouth Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Merchants Capital Corporation for $63.1 million in stock, expanding its business in two Mississippi counties. Bancorpsouth, with assets of $4.4 billion, will gain $222.2 million of assets and four branch offices in Vicksburg and two offices in Hinds County as well as a loan office in Jackson. Bancorpsouth, based in Tupelo, Miss., is the holding company of Bancorpsouth Bank, which in Mississippi does business as Bank of Mississippi, while the Vicksburg-based Merchants Capital owns Merchants Bank of Vicksburg. Bancorpsouth has 134 offices in 55 communities in Mississippi and Tennessee.

title: India's New Defense Chief Sees Chinese Military Threat
description: Defense Minister George Fernandes has breached a longstanding taboo by declaring publicly that China, not Pakistan, is India's ''potential threat No. 1.'' He also said India should move to declare itself a nuclear weapons state if a review of military policy by India's new Government supports his view.

title: A Cunning Kramnik Shows How to Make Tactical Magic
description: The grandmasters Vladimir Kramnik of Russia and Alexei Shirov of Spain tied for first place in the Seventh Melody Amber Tournament in Monaco, March 13 to 26. Each scored 15-7 in the 12-entrant, double-round robin tourney organized by the Dutch patron Joop van Osteroom.

title: Success Took 17 Years
description: For 17 years, the F.B.I. had been investigating a series of bombings in the case the agency called Unabom. Then, after a tip in 1996, agents converged on a shack in the mountains of Montana. Inside, a team of bomb experts found cans marked with the chemical names of explosives and 23 bomb igniters, and knew that the long search was over.

title: Topics of The Times; A New Political Pariah
description: Senator Lauch Faircloth, a Republican, has been running attack ads in his home state of North Carolina that castigate the leading candidate for the Democratic senatorial nomination, John Edwards, for being a lawyer. ''He makes millions suing people,'' the commercials contend.

title: Polish Bank Sweetens Its Bid for Competitor
description: Bank Rozwoju Eksportu S.A. raised its offer yesterday to buy another Polish bank. B.R.E., Poland's ninth-largest bank by assets, raised its bid for Polski Bank Rozwoju S.A., the nation's 16th-largest bank, to 28.50 zloty ($8.38) a share. That topped the 28-zloty offer by Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken A.B. of Sweden. B.R.E. is owned 49 percent by Commerzbank of Germany.

title: Knicks Aren't Counting On Ewing Yet
description: As the Knicks left practice and headed for the airport and a flight to Indianapolis this afternoon, Patrick Ewing pushed his way through a crowd of cameras. Refusing to issue any guarantees for the playoff series against the Pacers, resisting even a thumbs-up or thumbs-down, he simply ran his fingers across his lips, symbolically zipping them shut. If there was a positive omen to it, he completed the gesture without wincing.

title: Currency Markets Largely Discount Maneuvers Over Euro
description: World currency traders today largely disregarded embarrassing political squabbles among European leaders this past weekend over plans to introduce a common European currency on Jan. 1.

title: By Design; There's No Missing This Boat
description: After the turtlenecks and funnel necks of winter, the neck-baring boat neck is especially appealing. Saks Fifth Avenue has three-quarter-sleeve boat necks in navy by Philosophy di Alberta Ferretti ($135) and in baby blue by Calvin Klein ($330); sleeveless boat necks in blue by John Bartlett ($174) and in red by Mark Eisen ($150), and a long-sleeved white top by Donna Karan ($145).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEARNE, PAUL G.
description: HEARNE-Paul G. On May 3, 1998. The Board of Directors, staff and friends of Just One Break, Inc. (JOB) express their sincere sympathy to the family of Paul G. Hearne in appreciation of his leadership as its executive director from 1980-1988. He will be missed as a friend and advocate for people with disabilities. Mikki Lam, Executive Director

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING
description: LEVI STRAUSS & Company is beginning the first phase of a new campaign for its flagship jeans brand, in an effort to return the products to their iconic status, particularly among younger consumers.

title: Giuliani and Pataki Demand Apollo Theater Financial Data
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani are refusing to provide any more financial assistance to the Apollo Theater, the state-owned historic anchor of Harlem, until the private foundation that controls it answers questions about its financial affairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOV, BERTHA L.
description: SOKOLOV-Bertha L. on May 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Eugene Sokolov. Dear mother of Esther Fine (Adrian Adamson) and Joseph Sokolov (Dr. Leslie Arwin). Grandmother of Keira Fine. Stepgrandmother of Andrew Adamson and Gilliam Adamson. Sister of the late Rose Silverstein. Services 1PM, Tuesday afternoon at the Ira Kaufman Chapel, Southfield, MI. For further information call 1-800325-7105

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: If It's Tuesday, This Must Be . . .

title: The Shoulders Have It, by Way of Bournonville
description: Early in its spring season, the New York City Ballet has offered a change of pace in a delightful revival of ''Bournonville Divertissements.''

title: State Grand Jury to Hear Case of Three in Van Shot by Police
description: Promising a ''full and rigorous and honest'' investigation into the shooting of three men last month by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike, the State Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, announced today that the case would be presented to a state grand jury instead of a panel in Mercer County, where the shooting occurred.

title: Excite, a Web Directory Service, In a 2-Year Deal With Netscape
description: Underscoring how cutthroat the competition for Internet users has become, the on-line directory service Excite agreed yesterday to pay Netscape Communications $70 million for the right to provide just a fraction of the search services and other information that Netscape will make available to users of its browser software and home page on the World Wide Web.

title: Sale of Homer Seascape Sets Record
description: William H. Gates, the Microsoft Corporation chairman, has paid more than $30 million for the last major seascape by Winslow Homer left in private hands, setting what is by far the record price for an American painting, experts in the art world said yesterday.

title: Hearing Today for Back-Seat Crew of Jet in Cable-Car Crash
description: Two United States Marine Corps officers who sat in the rear seats of a jet that clipped ski-lift cables in Italy three months ago face a military hearing on Tuesday that will test the degree to which crew members can be punished for the actions of those around them.

title: Miscellany
description: * Greenfield Online Inc., Westport, Conn., a market research company, will offer a series of syndicated research studies about two markets: college students and homosexuals.

title: Under Pressure, Big Swiss Bank Yields to Daughter of Nazi Victim
description: The last time Estelle Sapir saw her father, in 1943, he reached through the barbed wire of a detention camp where the Nazis had imprisoned him in southern France and said: 'You have to survive. You'll be O.K. because there's money in the bank.''

title: Between Earth and Clouds
description: Douglas Dunn's ''Cocca Mocca'' started well on Friday night at St. Mark's Church. But Mr. Dunn didn't know how to stop this new work, which he presented for the City/ Dans series of the church's Danspace Project.

title: 2 Agencies In Seattle Merge
description: Two small Seattle agencies -- Hammerquist & Saffel and Matthaeus Halverson Advertising -- have merged to form Hammerquist Saffel & Halverson.

title: Norwegian Insurer Rejects Offer by Bank
description: Storebrand, a Norwegian insurer, rejected a merger proposal of 18.2 billion kroner ($2.5 billion) yesterday from Christiania Bank, saying the terms of the stock-swap offer were less attractive than a bid that its shareholders had rejected last year. Shares in both companies rose on optimism that they would continue to try to form Norway's largest financial-services company.

title: When Dance and Politics Both Dig Their Heels In
description: Dance is no stranger to controversy, but quarrels over meaning in a wordless art have rarely taken on the aura of a national crisis, which was the case last week in Israel when esthetics and politics clashed during a jubilee program celebrating the country's 50th anniversary.

title: Dramas Show a Surprising Strength in Tony Nominations
description: A battle for 42d Street pitted Disney's ''Lion King'' against Livent's ''Ragtime'' when the 52d annual Tony Award nominations were announced yesterday, but the musical rivalry was all but upstaged by the surprisingly strong showing of straight plays after a long Broadway eclipse.

title: 'Candy Bomber' Is to Buzz Berlin Again
description: Fifty years ago, a young Air Force lieutenant named Gail Halvorsen gave the Berlin airlift a personal twist. Between June 1948 and May 1949, the allied operation carried more than 2.3 million tons of coal, flour and food to Berlin, which was cut off by a Soviet land blockade. Over the same period, Mr. Halvorsen dropped candy and gum to the isolated sector's children.

title: After Farewell, It's Back to the Synthesizer
description: Gary Numan had his biggest international hit, ''Cars,'' in 1979, and he played farewell concerts in 1981. At the time, he was widely dismissed as a David Bowie and Roxy Music knockoff, an androgynous Englishman singing about alienation and dystopias. He was, however, an early convert to the use of synthesizers in pop, and he was skillful at writing terse, catchy melody lines that took odd turns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAR, MARIA
description: FELDMAR-Maria. We mourn the passing of Maria, widow of Dr. Ernest Feldmar. May her soul rest comfortably reunited with her beloved husband. The Allon and Kurz Families

title: Guilty Plea Made In Insider Case
description: An insider-trading defendant who was a fugitive in Europe for four years pleaded guilty last week to insider trading charges in New York.

title: Expressing the Caribbean's Rhythm and Whirl
description: For 36 years the National Dance Theater Company of Jamaica has been creating dancers and new works, pieces that seamlessly combine indigenous and other dance styles that express a vibrant, engaging culture. Company members have enriched American modern dance and ballet as dancers, choreographers and teachers.

title: Jolting Its Citizens, Indonesia Sharply Raises Energy Cost
description: Just hours before the International Monetary Fund unanimously approved restoring financial aid to Indonesia, President Suharto's Government announced plans today to raise the price of fuel and electricity by as much as 70 percent.

title: 'Showtime' Isn't Sport; Cagers on the Couch
description: To the Editor:

title: Assembly Introduces Bill To Aid in Literacy Fight
description: About 3.1 million New Jersey adults, or 51 percent, lack the literacy skills to write a business letter or read a bus schedule, a state task force reported in January. Yesterday, in response to a recommendation by the task force, Assembly leaders introduced a bipartisan bill to create a coordinating body to assist literacy programs run by school districts, community colleges and private organizations.

title: Born to Be Boss; Grooming the Next Generation To Take Over the Family Business
description: They are young, rich and restless.

title: Dow Sets Record, With Gains Mostly in a Few Companies
description: Investors propelled stocks further into record territory yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average posting a new high.

title: $22 Million Bowmar Deal
description: The Bowmar Instrument Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Electronic Designs Inc., a maker of computer memory products and flat-panel displays, for $22.4 million in stock. Bowmar, based in Phoenix, designs microelectronic components for the aerospace, electronic and computer industries. It had full-year sales of $22 million as of Sept. 30. Electronic Designs, based in Westborough, Mass., had 1997 revenue of $40 million.

title: Officer Sues City Over His Prosecution in a Bronx Corruption Case
