description: A New York City police officer who was dismissed amid charges of corruption and brutality in the Bronx but was reinstated after being acquitted in State Supreme Court filed a lawsuit yesterday against city officials for malicious prosecution.

title: Investigating a Guatemalan Murder
description: The recent murder of Bishop Juan Gerardi brought an unsettling sense of deja vu to everyone concerned with Latin America. Like many other victims in the region, Bishop Gerardi was a human rights activist, the head of the Guatemala City Roman Catholic Archdiocese's human rights office. Two days before he was bludgeoned to death, he presented a four-volume report on the human rights violations committed in Guatemala's 35-year war. The report attributed 80 percent of the killings to the military and its allies. The Guatemalan Government must show that things have truly changed in Guatemala by finding and prosecuting the killers in a nation accustomed to seeing powerful criminals go free.

title: Suit Filed by Woman Injured at Macy's Parade
description: A woman who was injured last November when a balloon was swept out of control by strong winds at the Macy's Thanksgiving Parade filed suit yesterday against the department store, New York City and the manufacturer of a lamppost that struck the woman after part of it was knocked down by the balloon.

title: Refusing to Discuss Clintons, Susan McDougal Is Indicted
description: As one of its final acts, a Federal grand jury in Arkansas indicted Susan H. McDougal today on charges of criminal contempt and obstruction of justice after she repeatedly declined to answer questions about Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, her former partners in the Whitewater land venture.

title: Rein In the I.R.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Cosmologists Ponder 'Missing Energy' of the Universe
description: CHALLENGED by recent unexpected, but compelling, evidence that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate, the theorists of cosmology are reacting as creative scientists should. They are stretching their minds in search of explanations, even to the point of risking comparison with the Queen in ''Alice Through the Looking-Glass,'' who practiced believing ''as many as six impossible things before breakfast.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, ALICE
description: BERMAN-Alice, 89. Of Hollywood, FL. Passed away May 3, 1998. She is survived by her loving daughter Virginia (Neil) Brandfon, devoted grandchildren, Mitchel Brandfon, Terri Maue and Gail Porto, ten cherished great grandchildren, sisters-in-law, Mildred (Phil) Nierenberg, Myra Berman, and brotherin-law Manny (Selma) Berman. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday (today) at 11AM in the chapel of: Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapel, 2230 Hollywood Boulevard, Hollywood, FL 33020 954-921-1776. Interment will follow at Temple Beth El Cemetery.

title: Whitman Vows to Veto Bill on Needle Exchange
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman vowed yesterday to veto a bill pending in the State Senate that would authorize a pilot needle exchange program intended to curb the spread of AIDS.

title: On My Mind; The New World Order
description: April 30 -- U.S. approves another $1 billion in aid to Indonesia as part of the international $40 billion economic bailout. President Suharto refuses to break up the multibillion-dollar monopolies controlled by himself, family and friends. He says no political reforms until 2003, at earliest. Police break up student protests.

title: For Combustibility, It's Knicks-Pacers
description: The day after the Knicks vanquished Pat Riley and the Miami Heat, along comes another group of natural-born villains: Reggie Miller and the Indiana Pacers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNDERBERG, ALAN J.
description: UNDERBERG-Alan J. Of Rochester, NY on May 3, 1998 at age 68. Lawyer and civic leader admired and loved by colleagues, friends and family in Rochester and throughout the country. Survived by his wife, Joyce Wisbaum Underberg of Rochester; his children, Mark A. Underberg (Diane Englander) of New York City, Amy Allen (Chris) of Newport Beach, CA, Lisa Hamburg (Glenn) of Denver, CO., Kathryn Zimmerman (Eric) of Arlington, VA; six grandsons; his mother, Anne Underberg of Rochester; his sister, Bernice Goodman (Mike) of St. Louis, MO. Funeral services will be held at Temple B'rith Kodesh, 2131 Elmwood Avenue, Rochester, N.Y., Thursday, May 7 at 11:30 AM. Burial will be private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alan J. Underberg Memorial Fund at the University of Rochester Cancer Center, 601 Elmwood Avenue, Rochester, N.Y. 14642, Genesee Hospital Foundation, 224 Alexander Street, Rochester, NY 14607, or the Memorial Art Gallery of Rochester, 500 University Ave, Rochester, N.Y. 14607. Reference: Parsky Funeral Home, Inc.

title: Extra Pounds in the Pews
description: Religious, church-going Americans apparently weigh more than their less religious neighbors, even though they follow many healthy routines, Prof. Kenneth Ferraro of Purdue University has found..

title: INSIDE
description: Suharto Sets Price Rises

title: A G.E.-Mexico Locomotive Deal
description: The General Electric Company said today that TFM, S.A. de C.V., a Mexican railroad operator, had ordered 75 locomotives with maintenance contracts in a transaction valued at several hundred million dollars as Mexico makes its railroads private.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: JAZZ
description: From the Spirit of Coltrane To Calypso Fever

title: Fans Show, but Cheers Are Few
description: The CityHawks drew a crowd of 8,271 last night as they lost their Arena Football opener to the New Jersey Red Dogs, 53-34, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sudan Foes Resume Talks As Famine Stalks South
description: A round of peace talks between the Islamic Government of the Sudan and the main rebel faction got under way here today against a backdrop of a looming famine in the south because of the protracted civil war.

title: Clinton Unveils Plan to Help Households in U.S. Use Less Fuel
description: President Clinton today announced a Government-industry initiative to reduce the gases that contribute to global warming by making homes in the United States more fuel-efficient.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I would have shed not a single tear had he been executed.''

title: Metro Business; Van Leer Chocolate Is Said to Be for Sale
description: Barry Callebaut S.A., one of the world's largest cocoa processors, said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire closely held Van Leer Chocolate Corporation, a Jersey City maker of chocolate and cocoa products.

title: OGDEN TO SELL AIRLINE-CATERING OPERATIONS TO ONEX
description: The Ogden Corporation of New York agreed yesterday to sell its airline-catering business to the Onex Corporation of Canada for $84.8 million to focus on renovating and servicing airports. The acquisition will add $139 million in annual revenue to Onex's SC International Services Inc. unit, one of the world's largest makers of in-flight meals. SC International operates as Sky Chefs Inc. and Caterair International Inc. Onex is a merchant bank based in Toronto. Ogden's catering business has 1,800 employees in cities including New York, Los Angeles, Newark, Honolulu, Washington and Las Vegas, Nev.

title: A Gadget for Listening to Books From the Web
description: IF you are willing to pay a premium up front and put up with plenty of annoyance in exchange for bargain prices on spoken-word programming, the digital world has a gadget for you. The Audible Player is a pocket-sized 3.5-ounce plastic device shaped like a child's mitten without the thumb. It costs about $200 and is designed to play audio books and other programs that you buy and download in digital form from the Web.

title: Black U.S. Marine Assaulted In Wave of Racism in Moscow
description: A black American marine has been severely beaten by a band of Russian skinheads in a new wave of assaults against foreigners of African and Asian descent.

title: Man Is Badly Hurt by Falling Pane of Glass
description: A pane of glass being installed at a midtown office building slipped and fell 12 stories yesterday morning, critically injuring a 52-year-old man on the street, the police said.

title: Topics of The Times; Not a Good Sign
description: A candidate's finances should be an open book. In the case of the United States Senate hopeful Geraldine Ferraro, however, the book was open only briefly last week. The candidate's relatively complex 1997 tax returns were made freely available to reporters for three hours, after which the price was $429 an hour, her accountant's standard fee.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Business; Delta Ferry Service Is Sold
description: New York Waterway, a commuter ferry service in Weehawken, N.J., said yesterday that it had bought Harbor Shuttle, the operator of the Delta Water Shuttle, which provides ferry service between Manhattan and the Marine Air Terminal at La Guardia Airport, where Delta Air Lines runs its shuttle service to Boston and Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURMAK, HYMAN
description: STURMAK-Hyman. Of Riverdale, New York. Passed away Monday, April 27. Loving husband of Rhoda, adored father of Douglas, Leonard and Marjorie, cherished grandfather of Jeremy, Julie, Lauren and Lindsay. We shall miss you. Services are at Riverside Memorial, May 7, at 12:30 P.M.

title: People
description: * Penny Erikson, executive vice president and client services manager at Young & Rubicam Advertising, New York, was promoted to the new position of executive vice president and director for partnership management services at the Y&R/ WCJ Partnership, New York, also part of Y.& R.

title: Q&A
description: Nitroglycerin and Chest Pain

title: Self-Image Is Suffering From Lack Of Esteem
description: SELF-ESTEEM had it all, once.

title: Red Foxes Thriving In Suburban Woods
description: One warm evening not long ago, two anglers were leaving the Connetquot River State Park Preserve on Long Island, after an almost trout-less day of fishing in the secluded nature reserve, when they spotted unusual movement in high grass at the edge of the woods.

title: Rescue Plan Advances For Credit Lyonnais
description: France and the European Commission edged toward agreement yesterday on a rescue plan for Credit Lyonnais, the troubled French state-owned bank. The movement came after France agreed over the weekend to make asset sales required by the commission. The European Competition Commissioner, Karel van Miert, said yesterday that substantial progress had been made with French officials as a result of new proposals put forward by the French side during weekend talks.

title: 'Showtime' Isn't Sport
description: To the Editor:

title: Concert of Thanks for an Airlift
description: While others were glorying in the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II, three years ago, Germany was, to put it mildly, in an awkward bind. Nothing served it so well as a dignified restraint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFARLAND, KATHRYN ELIZABETH (KATHY)
description: McFARLAND-Kathryn Elizabeth (Kathy). August 9, 1962-April 28, 1998. Kathy has gone home to God after an all too short stay on Earth. She will forever be alive in our hearts, our prayers, our thoughts. Funeral was held Friday, May 1, 1998. The McFarland Family

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER UP 1.5 PERCENT. Silver rose after Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor who owns a large amount of silver, repeated forecasts that prices are headed higher. July contracts rose 9.4 cents, to $6.247 an ounce.

title: The New Cancer Hope
description: It sounds too good to be true, and it may well be. But the data on mice look promising. Two drugs used in combination shrank huge tumors to the vanishing point, without causing side effects or causing mice to develop resistance to the treatment. No wonder investors yesterday bid up the price of a small company that is developing the drugs, and cancer doctors were besieged with inquiries from patients who hoped to benefit.

title: Old Moat at the Tower of London Yields Clues From Its Royal Past
description: When visitors came to the Tower of London early in Queen Victoria's reign, some 150 years ago, they found an ancient fortress surrounded by a wide moat dating almost to beginning of the millennium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, SARAH
description: BROOKS-Sarah. Age thirty-one. Passed away May 2, surrounded by family. Survived by her parents, sisters, brothers-in-law, nieces and nephews. Beloved first grade teacher at P.S. 175Q. Contributions in her memory to Sarah Brooks Memorial Fund/P.S. 175Q or Camp Simcha.

title: Albright Says She Will Add Day to Talks On Mideast
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright decided tonight to remain here an additional day to extend what she hopes will be decisive talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders that restore momentum to the search for peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, FRED
description: STONE-Fred. On May 2, 1998. Devoted father of Judith D. Stone and M. David Stone. Services were held May 4. Chaver L'olam Voed

title: For Jazz, Battle of Ages Before Battle With Spurs
description: How cranky are the members of the Utah Jazz? Coach Jerry Sloan consistently wears a snarl and dares anyone to ask how a team with the best record in the Western Conference allowed a valiant but all-nursing-home squad like the Houston Rockets to take them to a deciding game in a three-of-five-game series.

title: Will the Euro Help Unite a Diverse Continent?; Higher Living Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE FREITAS, ERIC M.
description: de FREITAS-Eric M. Of Manhattan. On May 2, 1998. (Member of the Park Avenue United Methodist Church, Manhattan) (American Bowling Congress Hall of Famer) Loving father of Althea White. Devoted grandfather of Karen Joyce Williams and William J. White, Jr. Great grandfather of Angus Lowery & Ethan Samuel Williams. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Howard E. Williams, Inc. Funeral Home, 181 Greenwich St, Hempstead, L.I. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM only. Religious service 11:30AM Thursday at the Congregational Church of South Hempstead. The Rev. Patrick Duggan officiating. Interment following at the Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: The Bad News Gets Worse: Alfonzo Is Out
description: The Mets, who have the second-worst offense in the National League, learned yesterday that they will be without their leading hitter from last season for at least the next two weeks, losing third baseman Edgardo Alfonzo because of a strained rotator cuff.

title: Will the Euro Help Unite a Diverse Continent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Neanderthals
description: To the Editor:

title: In Painting Eyes, Artists Go Halfway
description: A SCIENTIST who studies vision and the brain has made a curious discovery about portrait painting: Artists almost always place one eye of their subject at the horizontal center -- a point halfway between the left and right sides of the picture frame.

title: The Pain Continues as Mets Lose Spehr
description: It is, he said, the most frustrating feeling in the world. Todd Hundley can only sit and watch as the Mets futilely flail away at opposing pitching, as they did for most of last night's 4-2 loss to the lowly Arizona Diamondbacks in 11 innings at Shea Stadium.

title: Buddha and the Art Of Raising Chickens; Family Caters to Chinese Market With Farm-Fresh, Whole Pullets
description: When it comes to chicken, Doris Ma knows that bigger is not necessarily better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDER, WANDA D.
description: SEIDER-Wanda D. On May 4, 1998 of Garden City, N.Y. Beloved wife of Francis. Loving mother of Lois Till and Susan Morrison. Dear grandmother of James, Michele, Robert and John. Loving great grandmother of Christina and Elizabeth. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel Franklin Ave at 12th st. Garden City 3-5 & 7-9PM Tuesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City Wednesday 10AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury N.Y.

title: Arranging a World of Conspicuous Charity
description: TWO magazines threw parties for themselves recently.

title: In Excitement Over Cancer Drugs, A Caution Over Premature Hopes
description: Dr. Larry Norton, a prominent oncologist in New York City, received a telephone call at his home at 7:30 A.M. yesterday from a rich and very sick man.

title: Devils May Have Seen Last Of Lemaire and Gilmour
description: When the Devils' season ended in an embarrassing fashion Saturday night in Ottawa, Coach Jacques Lemaire did not know whether he would return next season.

title: A Plot on Castro Spotlights A Powerful Group of Exiles
description: When the Coast Guard approached the cabin cruiser La Esperanza near Puerto Rico last October, the four Cuban exiles aboard said they were on a fishing trip.

title: Bridling G.O.P. Leader Says Tapes Speak for Themselves
description: Insisting that a Democratic charge of selective editing ''does not hold water,'' the Republican chairman of a House committee released full tape recordings today of more than 10 hours of Webster L. Hubbell's telephone calls from a Federal prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ABE
description: WEINSTEIN-Abe. Devoted husband of Florence, loving father of Judith Dines (David), Caren Rosenbaum (Marc), Margery Frohlinger (Joseph). Much adored grandfather of Joshua and Alison Dines, Andrew and Caroline Rosenbaum, Matthew and Jonathan Frohlinger. Brother of Leona Feinstein and Philip Treston, brother-in-law to Shirley and Bernard Pullman, Gloria and Aaron Rosenblatt. Uncle to many special nieces and nephews. Services at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey, Wednesday, May 6, at 12 noon.

title: Tel Aviv Mayor Forming a Party to Fight 'Religious Extremists'
description: Pledging to neutralize the power of ''religious extremists,'' the Mayor of Tel Aviv announced today that he was forming a centrist party to challenge Benjamin Netanyahu for the Prime Minister's office in the next national elections in 2000.

title: Body Shop in Talks With Potential U.S. Ally
description: Body Shop International P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in an ''advanced stage'' of talks with a potential American partner about pooling its money-losing United States businesses into a joint venture. The company, a British cosmetics and health products chain, may disclose details of the talks at its annual meeting next Tuesday, a spokeswoman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, ANNE K.
description: WOLFF-Anne K. In loving memory of Anne K. Wolff. Anne was a wonderful grandmother and mother, cherished and treasured for her infinite wisdom & unending love, kindness and indomitable spirit. She will be dearly missed & remembered forever by Janine, Steven, Nancy and Bradford. Her caring nature brought joy to everyone. These memories of her will always remain in our hearts and souls from this day forward to eternity & beyond. We will always luminate this eternal light of Anne's love for us and for all who were touched by her life. May her memorial remain forever more.

title: Will the Euro Help Unite a Diverse Continent?; Luxembourg's Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Revolving Doors at Justice
description: Unsolved mysteries refuse to go away. That is why new wrinkles in the story of how President Clinton and the Democrats financed the 1996 election keep popping up. The latest news is that Charles LaBella, director of the Justice Department's campaign-money task force, urged Attorney General Janet Reno several months ago to appoint an independent counsel. He thereby joined Louis Freeh, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, in trying to instruct Ms. Reno in the requirements of this valuable law.

title: U.N. Chief Denies New Rwanda Charges
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan today dismissed renewed accusations that he was among those at United Nations headquarters who were warned in early 1994 that a campaign of genocide was coming in Rwanda and did nothing.

title: Once Again, the Veterans of Salsa
description: Thursday's benefit for Music Cares, an organization set up to help musicians in need, was amiable and even exciting occasionally, but it inadvertently pointed out how stagnant New York Latin music is in performance. The concert, at the Manhattan Center, brought out once again the last two big headliners in New York salsa, Celia Cruz and Tito Puente; the benefit opened with two younger acts with strong records, Dark Latin Groove and Lisette Melendez.

title: Gym Teacher Arrested In Assault of 2 Students
description: A veteran gym teacher was arrested yesterday on charges that he assaulted two students 10 days ago at a public intermediate school in Brooklyn, the police and school officials said.

title: Accounts
description: * Canandaigua Wine Co., Canandaigua, N.Y., to Trone Advertising, Greensboro, N.C., to handle advertising for a new division, Riverland Vineyards, and its initial product, Mystic Cliffs wine. Billings for the Mystic Cliffs marketing campaign were estimated at $35 million over the next 18 months. Trone handles other Canandaigua brands like Paul Masson brandy and Cook's champagne.

title: Mourning Emerges Contrite and Defensive
description: At today's post-mortem, long after his coach and most of his teammates had faced the glare of a failed playoff season, Alonzo Mourning eased out of the Miami Heat's training room and addressed his role in the demise.

title: Treaty Was Violated, He Asserts : Bundesbank Aide Derides 'Lazy' Deal
description: FRANKFURT  A senior Bundesbank official on Monday denounced as a "lazy compromise" the agreement over the leadership of Europe's central bank, saying it violated the European Union's Maastricht treaty.

title: 17-Year Search, an Emotional Discovery and Terror Ends
description: Patrick J. Webb cautiously entered Theodore J. Kaczynski's Montana shack, leading a team of bomb experts. In the gloom, he examined shelves crammed with baby-food jars and baking soda cans that were carefully marked with the chemical names of explosives. Then, in a Quaker Oats box, agents found what they had hoped for: 23 bomb igniters, each made from a piece of appliance cord pulled through a wooden plug. They were unique to the Unabomber.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 8 about Frank Lloyd, the owner of the Marlborough Gallery, who was convicted of illegal business dealings in the Mark Rothko art scandal of the 1970's, misstated the timing of the gallery's professional relationship with the painter Theodore Stamos, an executor of the Rothko estate. Marlborough started representing Mr. Stamos in 1972; it did not represent him in November 1971, when a suit was filed over the estate.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   L.A.P.
description: L.A.P. Feb. 4, 1944-May 5, 1991 ''whatever we were to each other that we are still.''

title: China Defies Forecasters With Strong Economic Numbers
description: Many economists assumed, just a few months ago, that the sharp currency devaluations rippling across Asia would sap China's fast-growing exports and foreign investment. Buyers and investors alike, it was widely argued, would turn from China and toward neighboring countries where, for buyers with stronger currencies, prices fell overnight.

title: Mercer Putting Trust in Ranking
description: Every punch that Ray Mercer drills into the air-filled heavy bag thunders through the House of Pain Gym in West Orange, N.J. Minutes earlier, Mercer was complaining to his trainer, Tommy Parks, that he didn't have any live sparring partners. Now, the bag is feeling Mercer's fury.

title: Police Testing Bullet That Wounded Boy Scout
description: The Nassau County police conducted ballistics tests yesterday on the bullet that struck a 13-year-old Boy Scout on a weekend camping trip at the Old Bethpage Restoration Village Park on Sunday.

title: Put Marriages to Test
description: To the Editor:

title: The Great Escape From Reality to Fantasy
description: THE KNIFE THROWER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERNANDEZ, VIVIAN
description: FERNANDEZ-Vivian. Of Middletown, N.J., on May 3, 1998. Wife of Anthony Fernandez. Mother of Michael Anthony Fernandez. Daughter of Flor Maldonado. Cousin of Debra Maldonado. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 & 79PM at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, New Jersey. Funeral Mass Thursday 9 A.M., at St. James RC Church, Red Bank, New Jersey. Interment to follow in Mount Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, N.J.

title: Roukema Again Has Conservative Challenger in Primary
description: ''Why are they doing this to me?'' Representative Marge Roukema asked with a laugh of mock despair. ''I can't explain it, and I am completely confounded.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Friendly $3.6 Billion Bid Could End Brawl for Echlin

title: On His Day for Pooh, Grown-Up Budget Questions for the Mayor
description: The setting for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's news conference yesterday was a public library, where plenty of dictionaries were available for those who felt the urge to look up the word ''irony.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMA, MICHAEL
description: PALMA-Michael. The family of Leonard Bernstein and the staff of Amberson cherish the memory of Mike Palma, our long-time friend and colleague. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife and children.

title: Bush Appointee Announces Plans to Quit Central Bank
description: Susan M. Phillips, a member of the Federal Reserve Board since December 1991, said today that she would resign from the central bank on June 30.

title: High Cost of Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: Smaller Biotechnology Stocks Stage a Spirited Catch-Up Rally
description: Some small biotechnology companies that have watched the big drug stocks soar over the last year had their turn yesterday as hopes grew for a new cancer treatment.

title: Fourth Democrat Joins Race To Unseat Attorney General
description: Saying the State Attorney General should be ''our Jimmy Stewart in Albany,'' Eliot L. Spitzer, a former prosecutor from Manhattan, officially added his name today to the list of Democratic candidates vying for the job.

title: Bus Service Is Criticized
description: Transit officials have not kept pace with a ridership increase on city buses following the free transfers and fare cuts introduced last year, the Straphangers Campaign, a riders' advocate, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, CATHERINE M. (NEE MURRAY)
description: RICHARDSON-Catherine M. (nee Murray) on May 4, 1998. Loving wife of the late Eugene P. Dear mother of John J. and the late Eugene F. Sister of Gloria Sager, Geraldine Keihm and the late Margaret Ryan. Also survived by eight grandchildren and 10 great grandchildren. Friends may call Tuesday, 7-9PM and Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9PM, Redden's Funeral Home Inc., 325 W. 14 Street, N.Y.C. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 10AM St. Bernards R.C. Church. Interment Calvery Cemetery.

title: For Beethoven, Modern as Ever
description: On Sunday afternoon at Tully Hall the Emerson Quartet got to the end of their seasonlong series devoted to Beethoven and the modern age, and if this final installment was anything to go by, people who stayed the course will have had a wonderful ride. The Emersons work tightly together: they jump and slide as one through Beethoven's most disrupted movements (like the first of Opus 135), and in his slow movements they seem to be breathing as one. Color and character are agreed upon and cleanly projected. Pianissimos can be extraordinary, as in the haunting note-by-note buildup of the chord that starts the slow movement of Opus 135.

title: Assistant Coaches Win N.C.A.A. Suit; $66 Million Award
description: A Federal jury in Kansas awarded more than $66 million yesterday to 1,900 assistant college coaches whose salaries were found to have been illegally restricted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The penalty, which included more than $22 million in back wages, penalties and legal fees that were tripled under Federal antitrust law, was by far the largest court assessment against the association, which regulates and administers major intercollegiate sports.

title: Gambling Ship Stops Operating Overnight Cruises
description: A company that began offering gambling cruises from Manhattan three months ago has ceased operating its overnight trips, saying not enough people were interested in the longer cruises.

title: Costco Expands in Korea
description: The Costco Companies agreed today to buy three membership warehouse clubs from the Shinsegae Department Store Company of South Korea for about $94 million, expanding the discount retailer into that country. Two of the stores operate under the Price Club Korea name in Seoul and Taegu, with the third expected to open in Taejon this month. Costco said there were another nine to 10 markets where it would like to add stores. Shinsegae, Korea's oldest department store, will keep a 6 percent stake through a joint venture with Costco.

title: Metro Business; Businesses Are Honored
description: The New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, the civic and business organization, is scheduled to present its annual small-business awards today to a Brooklyn contractor, a Manhattan printing company and a Queens manufacturer of medical equipment.

title: Argentina to Seek Extradition Of 2 Executives From U.S.
description: An Argentine federal judge investigating allegations that I.B.M. gave Government officials up to $21 million in bribes in exchange for a lucrative bank contract said tonight that he would seek the extradition of two current and two former I.B.M. executives if they refused to come to Buenos Aires to testify voluntarily.

title: Union Upholds Trusteeship For School Workers' Local
description: A union's appeals board has upheld a decision to put the local representing 22,000 New York City school cafeteria workers and crossing guards into trusteeship, finding that its president improperly took $1.1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DARRACH, BRAD
description: DARRACH-Brad. A memorial service honoring our friend and colleague will take place Tuesday, May 5, in the Ceremonial Hall of the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, at 5 PM.

title: Foreign Affairs; Booting Up Africa
description: Jim Lowenthal is wiring Timbuktu.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINN, SONIA
description: KINN-Sonia. The League Treatment Center Board and Staff express their deepest sympathy to the family of Sonia Kinn, Holocaust resistance fighter in the Abramov Group in White Russia, who died on Sunday, May 3rd. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and friend, Sonia will be deeply missed by all the people she loved and inspired with her bravery. She is survived by her husband Phillip, who also was a Jewish Resistance fighter, her children Gail and Mark, her daughter-in-law Hannah Achtenberg & her granddaughter Sarah Frieda, who gave her joy. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, May 5 at 12:15 P.M., at Brett Schneider Funeral Home, 2576 Flatbush Avenue (near Kings Plaza Shopping Center), Brooklyn, New York.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Drug Stock Joins List of Wall St.'s Wildest
description: Entremed Inc., a small biomedical company that might -- or might not -- have drugs that could lead to a cure for cancer, went wild yesterday in Nasdaq trading, rising $39.75, to $51.81, with volume reported at a level well above the number of shares outstanding.

title: Showalter Is Enduring Sacrifices
description: It's as if he spent 28 months designing and manufacturing a revolutionary new automobile and produced the Edsel. It's as if he spent 28 months devising a new formula for a soft drink and unveiled the new Coke. It's as if he spent 28 months writing a Broadway musical and produced ''Capeman.''

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Patterns
description: Kevan Hall's New Venture

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, EDWARD
description: GOLDBERGER-Edward. We sadly report the death of Edward Goldberger who was a loyal employee for over 50 years. Deepest sympathy to his family. West Mill Clothes, Inc. Lord West Formalwear

title: Democrats Use Direct Mail To Challenge Pataki's Cuts
description: Lacking the votes to override Gov. George E. Pataki's budget vetoes, Democrats in the Legislature have turned to a public-relations campaign -- mailing thousands of letters to constituents that decry cuts to schools, hospitals, nursing homes and other institutions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KELLY, MARTIN J.
description: KELLY-Martin J. May 5, 1997. In our hearts and thoughts today and always. We love you. Ede, Matt and Lexie

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: POP
description: Senegalese Roots

title: Germans to Mourn Mark, The Symbol of Revival
description: Half a century ago, from the ration lines and ruins of defeated Germany, a new German mark was born. Like many a child of postwar occupation, the mother was German, the father a foreigner. The date was June 20, 1948.

title: JUDGE SENTENCES CONFESSED BOMBER TO FOUR LIFE TERMS
description: A Federal judge sentenced Theodore J. Kaczynski today to four life sentences plus 30 years in prison at a hearing in which the widow of one of the confessed Unabomber's victims lashed out at him as a ''diabolical, evil, cunning murderer.''

title: Samuel Cummings, 71, Trader In Weapons on a Grand Scale
description: Samuel Cummings, the world's biggest small-arms dealer, died on April 29 in Monaco after a series of strokes. He was 71 and had long reigned as the undisputed philosopher-king of the arms trade.

title: Dana Offers $3.6 Billion in Stock for Echlin
description: The Dana Corporation, one of the largest domestic makers of automotive parts and supplies, made a friendly $3.6 billion acquisition offer yesterday for its competitor Echlin Inc., topping a hostile $3.1 billion bid from the SPX Corporation.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: JAZZ
description: Using a Rhythmic Freedom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEMING, JOSEPHINE
description: FLEMING-Josephine. Widow of John Fleming. Mother of Joan and Carol. Died March 20, 1998 in Phoenix, Arizona. Well known throughout the rare book community from her early days at the Rosenbach Company, to her many activities with her husband John, the legendary successor to Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, and lately as a Trustee of the Rosenbach Museum and Library, she was also a fierce competitor on the bowling alley, at the bridge table and on the tennis court. She leaves, as well, her grandchildren Holly Johnson, Heather Meyer and Alexander Cremin, six great grandchildren and her many friends in Larchmont. The Trustees and Staff of the Rosenbach Museum and Libary 2010 Delancey Place Philadelphia, PA 19103

title: ARCO to Acquire Union Texas Petroleum
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it would acquire Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc., an independent oil company based in Houston, for $29 a share, or $2.47 billion in cash, plus the assumption of debt and preferred stock.

title: Hollywood Under the Influence
description: High art has a special meaning in Hollywood, where some of the most meaningful work of recent years has been done in states of wildly altered consciousness. The mind-bending influence may have been drugs, money, sex or staggering hubris. (After winning an Oscar for ''The French Connection,'' a new book says, William Friedkin complained to a psychiatrist that he had not yet equaled Shostakovich's Seventh Symphony or Beethoven's Fifth.) But whatever the stimulant, it could magically prompt vast success and great, groundbreaking innovation.

title: Put Marriages to Test; Victims of Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: Studio's Bright Future
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EL PASO ENERGY CORP., Houston, a natural gas company, agreed to buy the Argentine electricity and gas company Capex S.A.'s 50 percent stake in Epic Energy Amazon Co., a Brazilian energy company, for $42.1 million.

title: Chief Guard Is Killed in Vatican Along With Wife and a 2d Man
description: In a jarring clash of the sacred and profane, the commander of the Pope's Swiss Guards, his wife and another Swiss Guard were found shot to death in the Vatican on Monday night, just hours after he was appointed to the post.

title: Executive Changes At 2 MacManus Units
description: Two agencies owned by the MacManus Group in New York announced a series of top executive changes yesterday.

title: 6 Arrests Are Said to Smash Theft Ring for Car Air Bags
description: A ring that stole thousands of car air bags in New York, New Jersey and the Northeast and netted $1.5 million by selling them to shady auto parts dealers across the nation was smashed yesterday with the indictment and arrest of five men and a woman, Federal and city law enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, MYRON (MICKEY)
description: WEINER-Myron (Mickey). On May 1, 72, a couragous fight against lung cancer. Loving brother of Arthur, uncle of Seth. He was loved and will be missed by family and friends.

title: In Death Penalty Case, Defense Says Killer of 3 Was Disturbed
description: In the first death-penalty trial under New York State's three-year-old law, a defense lawyer conceded yesterday that a former jail guard killed three people but argued that he should not be convicted of first-degree murder because he had acted while in a state of ''extreme emotional disturbance.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OECHLER, CHARLES
description: OECHLER-Charles. On April 29, 1998, after a short illness. He is survived by a brother, Willima F. Oechler of Cincinnati, a sister-inlaw Convere Oechler of New York City, two nephews, Hugh McA. Oechler of Cambridge, MA., and Henry J. Oechler, Jr. of Princeton, New Jersey, & a niece, Katherine O. Whitbeck of New York City. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church at 4P.M., on Friday, May 8.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary and an obituary headline yesterday about the founder of a historical photo archive misspelled his surname in some editions. He was Otto L. Bettmann, not Bettman.

title: Klinsmann Delivers A Message
description: GERMANY

title: Smoking Foes Battle the Industry's Specter of Smuggling
description: In fighting the anti-smoking legislation before the Senate, the tobacco industry argues that the current bill would lead to a black market in cigarettes and a crime wave that would rival the rum-running and gangsterism of Prohibition.

title: Fewer Teen-Age Mothers? Maybe
description: At 17, Juliene Daniels has had her share of handsome boys whispering in her ear about love and lust. And to be sure, some of them are hard to resist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, WERNER
description: SCHWARTZ - Werner. Passed away on May 3, 1998 at age 83. He will be greatly missed and always remembered by his loving wife of 54 years Gladys (Gretel), son Greg, daughter and son-in-law Evelyn and Eric Erenrich, and grandchildren Amy and Jordan. Graveside servces 2pm, Tuesday, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about newspaper circulation overstated the scope of some trends calculated by the Newspaper Association of America for the six-month period ended March 31 compared with the comparable period in 1997. Over all, daily circulation increased by seven-hundredths of 1 percent, not seven-tenths of 1 percent. Sunday circulation declined 0.172 percent, not 1.7 percent.

title: The Great Jewish Comics: So What's Not to Like?
description: If proof of the adage ''One good turn deserves another'' is needed, then the place to find it is at Playhouse 91.

title: Risks Are Cited In Bank-Broker Combinations
description: As Congress prepares to vote this week on a sweeping overhaul of the laws that have historically separated banks and brokerage firms, Federal regulators yesterday issued a pointed reminder of the risks these changes may pose for consumers.

title: Yankee Dominance Takes On a New Face
description: Generations of baseball fans are well acquainted with the dominance of the Yankees, teams led by sluggers such as Babe Ruth, Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and Reggie Jackson. But baseball fans are just beginning to recognize the latest Yankee juggernaut, modest in appearance but a team with subtle and overwhelming excellence.

title: RENTERS CHOICE TO BUY CENTRAL RENTS FOR $103 MILLION
description: Renters Choice Inc. has agreed to acquire Central Rents Inc., a privately held rent-to-own store chain, for $103 million, in a deal that was announced Friday night. Rent-to-own stores allow customers to take ownership of products if they rent for a certain period, usually a year or more. Central Rents, based in Commerce, Calif., has 176 stores and annual revenue of $104 million. The acquisition will give Renters Choice 956 rent-to-own stores in 43 states. The company, based in Dallas, currently has 780 stores in 42 states and full-year revenue of $331.5 million. Its stock rose $1.50 a share, to $29, in Nasdaq trading.

title: MAKING WELFARE WORK; Workfare's Misguided Critics
description: In 1935, in the middle of the Depression, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt ended a huge Federal program that gave cash welfare to the able-bodied poor, declaring it ''a narcotic, a subtle destroyer of the human spirit.'' Instead, he created a large public jobs program, the Works Progress Administration, which eventually employed more than three million Americans and built a lot of New York City's public works, including La Guardia Airport.

title: Man Is Hit and Killed By Train in Chatham
description: A man who was wandering on the train tracks in Morris County was struck and killed by a New Jersey Transit train last night, railroad officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNE, PATRICK J.
description: DUNNE-Patrick J. On May 3, 1998. Native of Portlaoise, Co. Laois, Ireland. Beloved husband of Catherine (nee Horan). Loving father of Frances, Margaret, the Reverend Patrick and the late Joseph and John. Fond brother of Christopher, John, Julia Feeney and the late Margaret Powell and Mollie Lalor. Cherished uncle of many nieces and nephews. Reposing Riverdale on Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx (West 261st Street). Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday 11 A.M., St. Margaret of Cortona R.C. Church. Interment in Saint Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: New Operators Likely for Rainbow Room at End of Year
description: Seeking to garner even more revenue from the Rainbow Room, which paid $3 million in rent last year, and to update its image, the landlord of the famous tourist destination said yesterday that it would be turned over to new owners when its lease expires at the end of the year.

title: Taking Stock of Mysteries of Medicine
description: MANY doctors continue to label alternative medicine ''quackery'' because proof of its effectiveness is lacking and the way the techniques work is often a mystery. Doctors are understandably turned off by seemingly irrational methods like reflexology (which treats the entire body through the foot) and by the mystical explanations offered for various techniques (''increases energy flow'' is a common one) that cannot be observed or measured.

title: TROPICAL SPORTSWEAR TO BUY APPAREL-MAKER FARAH
description: The Tropical Sportswear International Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Farah Inc., an apparel maker, for $9 a share, or $92.7 million. Farah shares surged 31 percent, gaining $2.0625 each, to $8.8125. Tropical Sportswear's shares rose $1.50, to $17.50. Farah, based in El Paso, makes men's and boy's pants, coats and shirts, and women's slacks. Tropical Sportswear, based in Tampa, Fla., makes men's and women's sportswear under private labels and brand names.

title: Excerpts From Prison Conversations With Hubbell
description: Following are excerpts from telephone conversations of Webster L. Hubbell with friends and family members when he was in Federal prison, as transcribed by the House Government Reform Committee. Additional material in bold type is taken from the tapes themselves, while material in the transcript but not on the tapes is in italic type. John Nields is a lawyer for Mr. Hubbell.

title: Communities To Receive $115 Billion, Citigroup Says
description: Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. announced yesterday that they would give $115 billion in loans to low- and moderate-income people over 10 years as part of their proposed $70 billion merger.

title: Two-Day Rally in Treasury Market Ends
description: The Treasury market ended its two-day rally yesterday, as investors grew cautious ahead of the report scheduled for Friday on employment payroll numbers for April.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He told some fellow soldiers that he felt he was not valued in the corps. It was a fit of madness in a person with very particular psychological characteristics.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, LYDIA
description: HERZ-Lydia, 98. On May 5, 1998, of Alzheimer's; widow of Alfred, devoted mother of Roger Herz and Carol Brull, loving grandmother of Howard and Jacalyn Brull; founder of Feinsod Herz Funds at Jewish Communal Fund and PEF Israel Endowment Funds. Graveside service Thursday, 11 AM, at Beth El Cemetery, NJ. Leaving at 10 AM from ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROFF, SANDRA
description: OSTROFF-Sandra. Died May 4, Plymouth Meeting, Pennsylvania. She will always live in the hearts of her survivors; daughters Alison and Debra Gottlieb, father Harold Ostroff, sister Maddy Braun and brother-in-law Philip Braun. Contributions may be made to The Scholarship Fund, Workmen's Circle Camp Kinder Ring, 45 East 33 Street, New York City 10016. Services today, 1:45PM, Riverside Chapel, 76 & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on April 27 about a lawsuit filed by workers at a Mademoiselle Knitwear factory in Brooklyn against their union, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, included an amenity erroneously among those that had previously been available at the factory. The factory did not have a day-care center. While space had been set aside for one, it was never established.

title: Parties and Contributors Exploit Many Loopholes
description: New York adopted most of its campaign finance laws in the Watergate era, and ever since, candidates and parties have become adept at getting around what were already relatively forgiving rules. Here are some common loopholes:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELTMAN, WILLIAM W.
description: WELTMAN-William W. Devoted husband of the late Janet. Loving father of George and Deborah, cherished grandfather of Rachel Beth. Services Wednesday 2:30PM Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, N.Y.

title: From Academic Weakling to Super Student
description: During his first three-and-a-half years at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, Eric Coyle found plenty of time for girls and golf. By his own admission, he was a mediocre student. Then Eric Coyle got motivated: he wanted, he said, to make the world a better place, to be a lawyer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELL, SARAH
description: MANDELL-Sarah. In her 105th year. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother to Gertrude Weitzner, Howard Mann and the late Charles Mandell. Adored grandmother of Dee Shapiro, Lee Wild, Eric Mann, Michael Mandell, Richard Mann, Randi Morantz and Robert Weitzner. Great grandmother of 18 and great, great grandmother of three. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name to the Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation, Old Westbury, New York 11568. Services today, 1 PM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETER, JOHN
description: PETER-John. Age 81, beloved father of Laurie Peter, Wendy Peter Abt, Sarah Peter and Molly Peter, and grandfather of Thomas, Emily, Rachel, Katy, Jacob, Lightning, Isaac, Noah and Lilly. Died on May 1 in transit to New York City, his home. Memorial services at the Art Directors Club, 250 Park Avenue South, on Tuesday, May 12th at 6 P.M.

title: Westchester Leader Is Left Some Surprises
description: On his first day heading Westchester County's government, Andrew J. Spano discovered that his predecessor, Andrew P. O'Rourke, had made off with most of the office furniture.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a deal struck by President Clinton to obtain some judicial confirmations referred incompletely to the figures cited for judicial vacancies. They applied only to the Federal appellate courts, not to Federal courts over all. Currently 23 judgeships are vacant on the appeals courts, for which Mr. Clinton has nominated 14 candidates.

title: Dowling College Is Buying La Salle Schools in a $16 Million Expansion Deal
description: Expanding a college is not unusual; expanding by buying a primary and secondary school is. But that is what Dowling College on eastern Long Island plans to do.

title: Donna Karan Shares Rise on News of Doubled Earnings
description: Shares of Donna Karan International rose 11.9 percent yesterday after the company announced that first-quarter earnings had more than doubled as it moves toward becoming a fashion concern that gets the biggest revenue boosts from licensing its name.

title: WHITE HOUSE'S BID TO CITE 'PRIVILEGE' FAILS, LAWYERS SAY
description: A Federal judge delivered a major setback today to President Clinton's efforts to limit the scope of the independent counsel's investigation by ruling that the President is not entitled to invoke executive privilege or attorney-client privilege to stop prosecutors from questioning his closest advisers, officials and lawyers involved in the inquiry said.

title: TV Notes; Vanishing Detective
description: On Friday night, fans of the NBC drama ''Homicide: Life on the Streets'' will get their last look at Frank Pembleton, the intense, difficult detective who is the show's soul and conscience. This week's season finale is also the series finale for Andre Braugher, who plays Pembleton. He is leaving to pursue film and stage opportunities.

title: Is It Getting Late Early for the Mets?
description: At last, a medicinal victory.

title: Europe's No. 2 Insurer Bids for Royale Belge
description: AXA S.A., Europe's second-biggest insurer, offered about $3.4 billion in cash and shares yesterday to buy the 52.2 percent of Royale Belge S.A. it does not own. The offer values Royale Belge at 14,792 Belgian francs a share, almost 5 percent below the company's closing price on Monday. For three shares in Royale, AXA offered five of its shares, 21,513 Belgian francs and a certificate allowing shareholders to be paid up to 200 francs on July 31, 2001, if AXA shares trade below 900 francs.

title: A Witness Tells of a Relentless Murder Spree
description: A Brooklyn man who witnessed the slayings of three people at a social club in 1996 testified in harrowing detail yesterday that a former New York City jail guard methodically killed his victims, including a woman who beseeched him to spare her life for the sake of her children.

title: Very Busy Chorus Keeps 'Cabaret' On the Move; Singing, Dancing, Changing Scenery and Playing in the Band
description: About 15 minutes before show time at the Roundabout Theater's hit revival of ''Cabaret,'' several young women wearing open kimonos with nothing much underneath drift onstage and begin to limber up. They move languorously, smoking or sipping a drink as they stretch and perform splits or run scales on their musical instruments -- a sax, a clarinet, a violin -- almost as if they are bored even before the show begins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNALLY, MARGARET M.
description: McNALLY-Margaret M. On May 4, 1998 of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Purchase, NY. Beloved wife of the late Harry J. McNally; loving mother of Bethanne Pouncey and Jaye Coldren, Barbara Lang and Nancy McNally. Also survived by three grandchildren. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, 11 AM at Our Lady of Sorrows R.C. Church, White Plains, N.Y. Interment to follow Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Connecticut Ties Early Release From Prison to Frequent Drug Testing
description: In an effort to trim its overcrowded prisons and stop drug-using felons from committing new crimes, Connecticut's Legislature passed a bill this week that will drastically cut prison time for nonviolent offenders on the condition that they undergo frequent testing for drug use.

title: By the Book; Dinner Party Revolutionary
description: BOBBY FLAY is one busy man. Between running his three Manhattan restaurants -- Bolo, Mesa Grill and Mesa City -- and taping ''The Main Ingredient With Bobby Flay'' for the Lifetime Network, he squeezed in enough time to turn out his second cookbook, ''Bobby Flay's From My Kitchen to Your Table'' (Clarkson Potter, $32.50).

title: TV Networks Pushed On Digital Standards
description: The chairman and chief executive of Tele-Communications Inc., John C. Malone, said today that his company would not carry CBS and NBC digital television signals if the networks kept the technical standards they were planning to use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOPIRO, CECELIA WAHNISH
description: SHOPIRO-Cecelia Wahnish. President Emeritus of Delta Phi Epsilon Sorority. Passed away Monday, May 5th in Miami Beach, FL.

title: Service for Norman Isaacs
description: A memorial service for Norman E. Isaacs, newspaper editor, journalism teacher and leader of national news organizations, has been scheduled by the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism for next Wednesday at 4 P.M. It will take place at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia campus. Mr. Isaacs, who died at 89 on March 7, taught at the school after serving as editor of The Courier-Journal in Louisville, Ky., as president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and as chairman of the National News Council, which has since disbanded.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LA PIDUS, MILTON N.
description: LA PIDUS-Milton N. Lovingly remembered today on your 92nd birthday. Joan and Michael

title: Court Rebuffs Press's Bid for Access to Hearings
description: A Federal appeals court today rejected a plea from news organizations that they be allowed to cover court hearings on the White House's executive privilege claim and other issues related to a grand jury's sex-and-perjury investigation of President Clinton.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Fall for Second Day
description: Treasury securities declined for a second day yesterday, as investors await Friday's jobs data and ponder the probability of an increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: INSIDE
description: Fugitive Linked to Bombings

title: As Gaullist Party Crumbles, Chirac Tries to Quell Factionalism
description: With the conservative Gaullist party he created crumbling around him under the weight of financing scandals, election losses and personal rivalries, President Jacques Chirac privately warned supporters today to stop bickering or face the loss of one of their last bastions, Paris City Hall.

title: April's Auto Sales Prove Unexpectedly Strong
description: The auto industry turned in unexpectedly strong April sales results today, the first month this year in which customers bought more cars and trucks than they did during the same period of last year.

title: Miller vs. Buckley Becomes Front-Office Problem
description: In February, the Giants' braintrust assembled to decide whom they valued more at linebacker, Marcus Buckley or Corey Miller.

title: No House Calls for Satan: Page Him at the Hospital
description: ''The Kingdom, Part 2'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 11. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Milbury Expected To Keep Both Jobs
description: The Islanders are close to announcing an agreement in which Mike Milbury is expected to return as coach and general manager, a team official said yesterday.

title: Reform Rabbis to Avoid Vote On Allowing Same-Sex Unions
description: In an effort to head off a potentially divisive debate at their annual convention, rabbis in Judaism's Reform movement will not vote on a resolution that would have stated that Jewish ritual allowed rabbis to perform same-sex unions, the rabbinical group's leaders said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAIFETZ, ROSE
description: CHAIFETZ-Rose. On May 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Al. Loving mother of Malcolm and Marilyn Chaifetz, Judith Chaifetz and the late Elaine Hurwitz. Adoring grandmother of Elyse, Jill, Lawrence and the later Jordan. Greatgrandmother of Erin, Caitlin, Amanda, Rachel, Sasha, Arielle, Milo, Isaac, and Leila. Service Wednesday, 9:45AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: New York Lags as Neighbors Toughen Campaign Fund Laws
description: In Connecticut, the limit on campaign donations to candidates for governor is $5,000. In New Jersey, the ceiling is $4,200. In New York, there is a vaulted ceiling of $41,400.

title: U.N. Chief Pays a Visit To Tribunal For Rwanda
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan, on his first visit to the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, got a sample today of the problems that have dogged the court since its creation more than three years ago.

title: Spicy Foods Struggle to Get a Little Respect
description: MAYBE it's time to get a few things straight about spices. Despite the increasing presence of fiery food on menus around the country, spiciness is still viewed with a certain condescension in our culture.

title: The Chef
description: THIS is a dish that sings out ''spring,'' marrying the mysterious, woodsy flavor of morels with the fresh, sweet flavors of the garden's early harvest. I'm partial to morels, and I put them on my menu the instant they're available. They have a very distinctive look -- conical, bulbous and honeycombed -- and their spongy texture makes them perfect for anything with broth.

title: Off the Menu
description: Dinner a la 'Seinfeld'

title: Notorious Welfare Hotel Given Landmark Status
description: As Manhattan buildings go, its decline was epic. Constructed in a French Renaissance-inspired Beaux-Arts style in 1897, the Hotel Martinique set a standard for luxury on Greeley Square and the stretch of Broadway then known around the world as the Great White Way. If not high fashion, its guests had a singular distinguishing quality -- wealth.

title: Witnesses Tell Of Lax Rules For Flights By Marines
description: The squadron whose plane struck a ski lift in Italy did not have strict rules on how to set the planes' low-altitude warning systems, and pilots regularly violated altitude restrictions, witnesses testified today in a hearing to determine whether two officers in the jet should be court-martialed .

title: ALLIED DIGITAL AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $68 MILLION
description: The Allied Digital Technologies Corporation agreed yesterday to be acquired by an investor group for $5 a share, or $68 million. The investor group consists of 399 Venture Partners Inc., an affiliate of Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd., and members of Allied management. Allied, based in Happauge, N.Y, duplicates compact disks, CD-ROM's, audio cassettes and videocassettes. It had revenue of $88.6 million in the six months that ended on Jan. 31. The shares of Allied Digital rose 37.5 cents, to $4.75.

title: Fugitive Sex Offender Is Arrested in Maine
description: A convicted sex offender who escaped from a New Jersey prison 19 years ago was captured late Monday in Maine after the authorities who had arrested him four days earlier on drug charges discovered that he was a fugitive.

title: TV Notes; Blaming Sameness
description: With much fanfare, Ellen DeGeneres and her character on the show ''Ellen'' both declared themselves to be lesbians last fall. This spring, when ABC canceled the sitcom for next season, Ms. DeGeneres accused the network of anti-gay discrimination. But Robert Iger, the network's president, says the show alienated audiences. His first public reply to Ms. DeGeneres appears tonight, on ABC's ''Prime Time Live.'' Diane Sawyer interviewed Mr. Iger, who is her boss, and Ms. DeGeneres.

title: TV Notes; 'Lolita' Reaches A U.S. Audience
description: Showtime announced yesterday that it had acquired the rights to Adrian Lyne's much-debated new film, ''Lolita,'' which means the $58 million movie, based on the Vladimir Nabokov novel, will be seen on American television without a prior release to theaters in this country. ''Lolita'' is the most expensive film ever to go directly to television.

title: Mlicki's Best Start Keeps Mets Over .500
description: As badly as the Mets needed a victory, Dave Mlicki might have needed one more.

title: Wine Talk; Beaujolais That Ages As Well as Burgundy
description: IT was in the dead of winter some 20 years ago, and the dining room at La Pyramide was half empty. The glory days of the famous restaurant in Vienne, 20 miles south of Lyons, where Fernand Point once reigned, were long past, but there was a feeling about the place -- that at one time great things had happened there.

title: True Love Is Good, Martyrdom Even Better
description: Donizetti, who died at 50, composed 65 operas. One doesn't work at that pace without resorting to formula. The best of Donizetti's operas triumph over convention, however, and at least half a dozen are masterpieces of the repertory.

title: The Bilingual Blunder
description: In less than a month Californians will vote on Proposition 227, an initiative that, if passed, will eliminate that state's bilingual education programs. George Louie, a parent in Oakland, doesn't need much convincing after his recent experience.

title: Italy Agrees to Sell 12% of Energy Company
description: Italy's Government said yesterday that it had approved selling about 12 percent of its shares in the energy company ENI S.p.A., which would lower its ownership stake to about 40 percent. The sale is valued at 11.9 trillion lire ($6.8 billion) at current market prices.

title: Sports of The Times; Pacers Know 'Big Fella' Is Coming
description: ALMOST hauntingly, the photo on the back cover of the Knicks' playoff media guide shows six players in a timeout huddle around Coach Jeff Van Gundy, but Patrick Ewing and Larry Johnson are nowhere in sight.

title: Irresponsible Athletes
description: Sports Illustrated has a remarkable investigative report this week about high-profile professional athletes, mainly basketball players, who have fathered out-of-wedlock children. It draws a depressing portrait of supremely talented and supremely indifferent men swaggering from city to city and leaving behind a trail of casual destruction, whose chief victims are the children.

title: Preservationists Criticize Rockefeller Center Renovation Plan
description: Rockefeller Center's plan to accommodate large-scale retailers by expanding its jewel-box Fifth Avenue shopfronts came under criticism yesterday from preservationists who worried that the commercial gain would come at the expense of mid-Manhattan's architectural soul.

title: No Monopoly on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Pharaonic Forensics: King Tut as Murder Victim
description: THE MURDER OF TUTANKHAMEN

title: They Say Life Is Hard Guarding The Pope
description: The requirements for a Swiss Guard are relatively simple and few: Recruitment brochures require candidates to be single Swiss males, practicing Catholics, over 18 and under 30 and more than 5 feet 8 inches tall and to have completed their Swiss military service. Their local parishes must vouch for their ''irreproachable character.''

title: Critic's Notebook; Standing and Staring, Yet Aiming for Empowerment
description: It's art; it's fashion. It's good; it's bad. It's sexist; it's not. It's Vanessa Beecroft's performance art. And one's mind can feel like Faye Dunaway's face in that famous slapping scene in ''Chinatown'' when confronted with it.

title: For Passionate Home Cooks, It's a Magnificent Obsession
description: WHEN dusk gathers and the dinner hour approaches, New Yorkers quietly divide into two tribes: the consumers and the creators. They look the same. By demographic, ethnic, religious and nearly every other measure, they are indistinguishable. But when it comes to food, they lead different lives.

title: Big Ratings Missing; Big Names Gone, Too
description: With television ratings sagging and a year remaining on its contracts with the Fox and ESPN networks, the National Hockey League could face a worrisome marketing challenge for the Stanley Cup finals: the Ottawa Senators might meet the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Out of Annulment Bind
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASH, HAZZAN SAUL
description: BASH-Hazzan Saul. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of a respected colleague of over four decades. Quietly and gently he served the spiritual needs of his congregants with great dignity, warmth, and care. We extend our sympathy to his children, and his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Henry Rosenblum, President Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENKEL, LILLIE
description: SCHENKEL-Lillie. On May 5, 1998. Loving mother of Myra and Michael, devoted grandmother of Walter. May she rest in peace. Services Thursday 9:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave., New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  A'HEARN, RUTH A. (NEE DONOVAN)
description: A'HEARN-Ruth A. (nee Donovan) On May 4, 1998 in her 98th year. Of Garden City, N.Y. Formerly of East Atlantic Beach, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Frank B. A'Hearn. Loving mother of Ruth Mallon, Jeanne Maloney and Francis A'Hearn. Cherished grandmother of 24 & great-greatgrandmother of 50. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Wednesday 7-9 P.M., and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial, 10 AM, Friday St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK AT 3-MONTH HIGH. Germany's currency rose after Denmark increased a key rate, which resurrected speculation that the Bundesbank would soon raise rates. In New York the dollar cost 1.7669 marks, down from 1.7803.

title: Gun That Looks Like Key Chain Fools Security X-Rays at Airports
description: A new weapon is available to airplane hijackers, terrorists and assassins, one that is as deceptive and as easy to conceal as it is deadly. It is only three inches long and an inch wide, and has a ring on the end. It looks as innocent as a key fob.

title: Liberties; Yentl vs. Moses
description: Washington had become so sulfurous, so full of scalding partisan rumbles and icky name-calling, I just had to get away for a few days. All those self-righteous Neanderthal bullies. All those self-righteous liberal divas.

title: INTUIT TO PRODUCE QUICKEN FOR MACINTOSH AFTER ALL
description: Intuit Inc. said yesterday that it would produce its popular Quicken personal-finance software for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh next year, reversing an earlier decision. Intuit, which makes personal-finance and tax-preparation software, said it would produce a packaged software version of Quicken for Macintosh in the second half of 1999. Intuit said last month that it would stop developing new versions of its flagship program for Macintosh, citing declining sales. Apple has had trouble persuading software developers to write new programs for Macintosh as its market share continues to slide. Yesterday, an Intuit spokesman, Adam Samuels said, ''We're excited about Apple's prospects and its upcoming consumer products,'' adding that the two companies had been in talks for the last two weeks. Intuit, based in Mountain View, Calif., also produces a version of its tax-preparation software, called Macintax, for Macintosh computers.

title: Human Rights in Congo
description: To the Editor:

title: Two's Company, Three's a Possibility
description: The only sure way to know that ''Dance With Me'' is set in the 1950's is to read it in the program. As Ray, an upstate New York doctor, Peter Michael Brouwer looks a little old-fashioned in his double-breasted suit and bow tie, but only a little. The simple, monochromatic dresses worn by Ray's wife, Ruth (Kara V. Sekuler), and his new mistress, Grace (Lillo Way), are not 50's silhouettes. The furniture (wicker chairs and a bar-car setup) can be found on patios and trains today. So it's easy to interpret the events as taking place in the present and to wonder why the audience is supposed to be so shocked.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHORR, RABBI SEYMOUR
description: SCHORR-Rabbi Seymour. 10 Iyar. Darling love, one year without your dear face-your infinite wisdom-our grief and desolation are unspeakable. Your adoring family Audrey, Ira, Nanette.

title: $25 and Under; Middle Eastern as Usual, Except the Appetizers
description: THE menu at most Middle Eastern restaurants is predictable, and Agora is no different. This Turkish and Middle Eastern restaurant, which goes by the trendier description ''Mediterranean cuisine,'' has one of those interchangeable menus, with the usual dips and appetizers, salads, kebabs and stews. No sweetbreads, lamb intestines or other exotica here. But many of the dishes are so good that you don't mind eating the same old thing, because the flavors are so fresh and inviting that even the old tastes new.

title: People
description: * Mark MacDonald was named to the new position of group publisher at Individual Investor Group, New York, overseeing Individual Investor and Ticker magazines as well as Individual Investor Online and Special Situation Reports. He had been president of the Association of Independent Business Owners, Westfield, N.J.; before that, he served as group publisher at Men's Journal, New York, owned by Wenner Media.

title: On Outside Looking In: Hofstra, Harvard, UMass
description: The North Carolina Tar Heels, who finished the regular season with a 7-7 record, were included in the field for the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's lacrosse tournament that was announced Sunday. Unexpected scores at the end of the season led to unexpected results in the selections for the tournament, which begins Saturday.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A deal reached in a Merrill case may change how the industry handles employees' bias complaints.
description: A PROPOSED settlement of a sex-discrimination suit against Merrill Lynch could lead to the end of Wall Street's mandatory arbitration system for dealing with employees' bias cases.

title: Lurid, Sure, but Is It Newsworthy?; A Prisoner's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: British Executives Forming a Shop
description: Three prominent British agency executives are forming a shop in London, to be named Spirit.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Bonnie Raitt; With A Cause In Her Heart
description: The scene looked like something out of a 1960's coffeehouse. Bonnie Raitt was standing onstage in a smoky room for an audience of not more than 150 people, playing guitar and singing folk songs with an American flag and campaign posters hanging behind her. The year, however, was 1998, and Ms. Raitt was performing at one of the many benefits she takes part in each year. This one was for Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, and Ms. Raitt meant it.

title: The Pop Life; Tweaking Beck With Piracy
description: It's not what you do, it's who you do it to. That's what a group of musical mischief-makers on the Internet are discovering.

title: Denmark Raises An Interest Rate
description: Denmark unexpectedly raised a key interest rate today by half a percentage point, causing concern that Germany's central bank was poised to increase rates there.

title: No Monopoly on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: TENNIS: Legendary Rivals And Close Friends; Evert and Navratilova Reunite on Court
description: First they competed for the bread basket, a skirmish that sent the nervous headwaiter at Lespinasse scurrying for hers-and-hers portions. Then, while keeping tabs on each other's generous use of butter, Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova explained where former champions and rivals go when early retirement becomes too much to bear: back to battle.

title: Sale of Agency Opens New Doors for Falk and Clients
description: The deal is so rich, you would think David Falk had negotiated it for Michael Jordan, Patrick Ewing or any one of his superstar pro basketball clients. Actually, Falk's big score was to sell his six-year-old agency on Monday for a sum that could exceed $150 million in cash and stock.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Decline on Fears Of Higher Interest Rates

title: Lose One, Win One: Ewing's Return Expected
description: Patrick Ewing sat on the bench, his surgically repaired wrist cupping his chin as he watched the Knicks surge and then seize up tonight in Game 1 against the Indiana Pacers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUCKNAM, DAVID C.
description: BUCKNAM-David C. Come celebrate David's life through his music on Sunday, May 10th, at 7 P.M., in the Anspacher at The Public Theatre.

title: 5 Arrested on Staten Island In Illegal Betting on Bingo
description: The gambling ring had been infiltrated. After casing the joint for more than a month, undercover investigators sidled up to the tables where the action was on Monday night and placed their bets. Suddenly, the doors burst open, more police officers streamed in, and five people were arrested.

title: Acquirer Likes Financial Arena
description: Thomas H. Lee, who runs a buyout firm by the same name, said today that he was interested in buying stakes in financial services companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLES, ETTA
description: GELLES-Etta. Of North Miami Beach, Florida, passed away on May 5, 1998. Widow of Irving, she is survived by children Charles (Brenda) Gelles of Manhattan and Diane (Bruce) Goldberg of Mamaroneck. A gracious and loving person, she will be missed. Services Thursday noon at Riverside 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: In the Vortex of 'Viagra Madness'; Long Days for Urologist as Men Clamor for Prescriptions
description: Beginning another day on the front lines of what he refers to as ''Viagra madness,'' Dr. Stanley Bloom, urologist and impotence specialist, flexed his hand to steel it against writing cramps. Men's redemption from sexual malfunction was exacting its physical toll on his already ragged penmanship. So many craved a prescription for the little blue Pfizer pill that was sweeping the country, but how much could a 60-year-old right hand take?

title: Metro Business; Staples Buys Leases Of Bankrupt Rickel
description: Staples Inc. said yesterday that it had bought 32 leases on stores formerly operated by bankrupt Rickel Home Centers of South Plainfield, N.J., for $32 million.

title: Taylor's Career Nearing End?
description: Time may be running out for the Yankee career of Brien Taylor, the former No. 1 draft pick from 1991 who signed for a $1.55 million bonus, then suffered a shoulder injury in a fight two years later and has never been the same.

title: Line Item Veto Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Lives; On Writing Well and Teaching Even Better
description: William Zinsser is the author of ''On Writing Well,'' a quiet how-to bible that has sold nearly a million copies in 22 years. At 75, he has come to see the teaching of writing as his ministry. Here are some things Mr. Zinsser has told his flock:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MICHAEL A.
description: BERNSTEIN-Michael A. Age 41. Resident of New York City and Saltaire, Fire Island. Suddenly in an automobile accident in Mississippi on Monday, May 4. Survived by his loving parents, George A. and Diane M. Bernstein, his beloved wife, Catherine Wolcott, his brothers Adam and Anthony and sister-in-law Janice. Memorial service to be announced.

title: On NATO Plan, 'X' Is Wrong Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators Criticize Public School's Repairs
description: The timetable had sounded reasonable enough: in April 1994, the Board of Education hired a small Brooklyn construction company to replace four windows on a rooftop bulkhead atop a Queens elementary school, a job that the board estimated would take 60 days to complete when combined with other minor masonry repairs.

title: Gray Eminence in U.S., Now Bright Star for Irish
description: When George J. Mitchell, the chairman of the Northern Ireland peace talks, showed up for a question-and-answer session at University College Dublin the other day, he attracted so many students that school officials had to move the event to a huge theater. Even then, hundreds were turned away.

title: Temptation; And Let Them Eat Pudding
description: IT'S comfort food where you would least expect to find it. At Lot 61, a new nightclub and lounge in Chelsea, a rich bittersweet chocolate pudding is served piping hot, almost bubbling, in a tall coffee mug. Beside it sits a tiny glass bowl containing a perfectly round scoop of coffee ice cream. The moment before it is eaten, the dollop of ice cream is plopped into the pudding, instantly forming an icy-hot concoction bathed in a rich mocha sauce. As if that were not decadent enough, there's a crunchy tuile to scoop it all up with (or a spoon, if you must).

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE UP 7.2 PERCENT. Orange juice reached the highest level in 19 months after Brazil exporters said bad weather and disease had done more damage than estimated. July contracts rose 7.7 cents, to $1.1535 a pound.

title: Foote, Cone Names Agency President
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide, a unit of True North Communications, said yesterday that it had promoted Ron Bess, president of its Chicago office, to the new position of president of the agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, PAMELA A.
description: ROBERTS-Pamela A. Passed away peacefully, surrounded by friends and family, May 4, 1998. She was a loving mother and a much loved daughter, sister and friend, and a very talented artist. Much admired in L.A.'s underground art community. She is survived, and greatly missed, by her loving companion Dave, her daughter Ava, her sister Cindy, her brother Derek, her mother Lorna and her father Arnold. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the American Cancer Society.

title: Accounts
description: * Adirondack Chair Co., Long Island City, Queens, to Bleecker & Sullivan, New York, as the first agency to handle retail advertising for its Adirondack Office Furniture. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million.

title: Republicans Seeking to Divert Fallout From Hubbell Tapes
description: Representative Dan Burton abruptly canceled a meeting of his House investigating committee today, as Republicans tried to turn attention away from Mr. Burton's release of tapes and transcripts of Webster L. Hubbell's conversations from prison.

title: Essex House Is the Latest Hotel For Sale on Central Park South
