description: With Manhattan hotels jammed and room rates soaring, a troubled Japanese airline has decided to sell the Essex House hotel on Central Park South in hopes of raising hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELMAN, NATASHA
description: GELMAN-Natasha. The trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Natasha Gelman, passionate collector and generous donor who bequeathed as the legacy of herself and her late husband Jacques an unparalleled collection of 20thcentury European masterworks. She graciously established an endowned curatorship of 20th-century art. She will be remembered at the Metropolitan Museum for her many important contributions-as honorary trustee, benefactor, donor, advisor, lender-as well as for her remarkable eye, generosity of spirit, her ebullience and wit and her joy in sharing with the public such an extraordinary collection. Arthur O. Sulzberger, Chairman William H. Luers, President Philippe de Montebello, Director

title: Metro Business; New Store on Madison Ave.
description: Paul & Shark, a luxury men's clothing retailer with 123 stores around the world, plans to open its first New York shop in October, the company announced yesterday.

title: An Acting Dynasty Recites Chekhov
description: Oh, those classically competitive Redgrave sisters. First, Lynn creates a one-woman Broadway show, ''Shakespeare for My Father.'' Now along comes Vanessa, performing Chekhov with their mother.

title: Disputed Lottery Winnings Awarded to Woman by Jury
description: Ending a six-year family battle over a lottery jackpot, a Manhattan jury awarded an $8.3 million prize to a 32-year-old Vietnamese refugee who had accused her husband's uncle of stealing her winning ticket.

title: Laurels for New York at Beard Awards
description: THIS year's James Beard Awards were an accolade to New York. Not that it was planned that way: it was just how 300 food professionals around the country voted.

title: A campaign for Forbes raises some internal hackles.
description: FORBES is running what it intends as a humorous new ad campaign. But some editors and writers at the magazine aren't laughing.

title: City Will Mark End of a Show About Nothing by Doing Nothing
description: First, there was the suggestion that the city might like to celebrate the May 14 finale of ''Seinfeld'' with a big outdoor party at Yankee Stadium. It was rejected. Then Times Square and Bryant Park were suggested. Again, rejected. And last week, Central Park came into the picture.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the Titanic referred incorrectly to one city in which artifacts recovered from the sunken ship are being shown. It is St. Petersburg, Fla., not Russia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARAIL, MARK, D.S.W.
description: TARAIL-Mark, D.S.W. On May 5, 1998. Devoted husband of Helen. Beloved father of Judith and Michael (Mary). Grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of five. Loving brother of Theodore (Pearl) & the late Robert. Director Emeritus of Maimonides Community Mental Health Center. Services are tomorrow, at 10 A.M., at Kehila Chapels, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: A Monet Leads a Modest Auction
description: Even in today's market, with buyers hungry for good material, few were tempted by the unsavory and in some cases overpriced offerings at Christie's sale of Impressionist and 19th-century art last night.

title: Provident Chooses Saatchi & Saatchi
description: The Provident Companies in Chattanooga, Tenn., the insurance concern that specializes in disability coverage, has named Saatchi & Saatchi in New York to handle its multimedia national advertising account, with billings estimated at $20 million. The account, which was previously limited primarily to trade advertising directed at insurance agents, had been handled by Brouillard Communications in New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, CATHERINE M. (NEE MURRAY)
description: RICHARDSON-Catherine M. (nee Murray) on May 4, 1998. Loving wife of the late Eugene P. Dear mother of John J. and the late Eugene F. Sister of Gloria Sager, Geraldine Keihm and the late Margaret Ryan. Also survived by eight grandchildren and 10 great grandchildren. Friends may call Tuesday, 7-9PM and Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9PM, Redden's Funeral Home Inc., 325 W. 14 Street, N.Y.C. Mass of Christian burial Thursday, 10AM St. Bernards R.C. Church. Interment Calvery Cemetery.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EQUITY OFFICE PROPERTIES TRUST, Chicago, a real estate investment trust run by the financier Sam Zell, acquired two downtown San Francisco buildings that were jointly owned by Rolaco Services Inc. and its Paladin U.S.A. Inc. subsidiary for $90 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 19 about the export of American-made weapons to Europe, and about Washington's concerns that it cannot monitor where they ultimately go, referred incorrectly to activities of a British company, Conjay Arms. According to Gordon Conway, an officer of the company, it has imported 72 firearms from the United States this year and has sought to import another 90. It did not purchase 1,600 handguns in the United States in February and apply for a license to export them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBBINS, EDITH H.
description: ROBBINS-Edith H. Beloved wife of Albert. Devoted mother of Karen and Mark Mariaschin, Edward and Lisa Robbins and Richard. Adored grandmother of Jennifer and Melissa Mariaschin, Lisa, Amy, Jacob & Amanda Robbins. Dear sister of Morton Manes. Services Wednesday, 9:45AM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 162nd Street, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTER, MAURICE G., OD
description: POSTER-Maurice G., OD. Beloved husband of Muriel. Father of James and William. Father-in-law to Sandi and Dianne. Grandfather to Simon, Alex, Harrison and Sofia. Decorated W.W. II Veteran. Bronze Star, Belgian Croix De Guerre, Medaille De La France Liberee. Practiced medicine in New York and Long Island for forty years. Professor Emeritus New York State University. President International Contact Lens Society. Past Chairman AOA Contact Lens Section. Funeral service today 1 PM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 516-921-5757.

title: Food Stuff
description: More Delicacies In Chelsea

title: Journal; The Rodent Rules
description: Who is more powerful -- Disney or God? It's a tough call, but no one, least of all Southern Baptist boycotters, has grappled with this spiritual question more hilariously than Carl Hiaasen does in his new paperback, ''Team Rodent: How Disney Devours the World.'' Mr. Hiaasen, the best-selling crime novelist and Miami Herald columnist, can't provide the definitive answer, but he has his fears. ''If anything is more irresistible than Jesus,'' he writes, ''it's Mickey.''

title: On NATO Plan, 'X' Is Wrong Again
description: To the Editor:

title: On Last Day, No Indictment of First Lady
description: The Federal grand jury in Arkansas that has been examining the Whitewater affair for the last two years completed its final working day today without bringing any charges against Hillary Rodham Clinton, a central target of the investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTER, DR. MAURICE G.
description: POSTER-Dr. Maurice G. A remarkable clinical specialist in contact lens therapy for more than 4 decades, he built a program at the SUNY College of Optometry and was renowned nationally & internationally, as a teacher and scholar, in an emerging field of visual function. He was an original staff professional in the Optometric Center of New York with a fervent devotion to his students, to his colleagues and to his institution that was unwavering in his commitments and unstinting in his professional and personal friendships. We will all mourn his loss, for it is a substantial one. Alden N. Haffner, O.D., Ph.D. President SUNY College of Optometry

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a $1 billion share repurchase misstated the name of the company making the offer. It is the U.S. Office Products Company, not the Office Products Company.

title: Natasha Gelman, Collector Of 20th-Century Fine Art, 86
description: Natasha Gelman, who with her husband, Jacques, amassed an outstandingly fine group of 20th-century European paintings and sculptures and who was a friend and patron of Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera and many other Mexican painters, died on Saturday at her home in Cuernavaca, Mexico, after a long illness. She was 86.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: U.S. Names Experienced World Cup Team
description: Coach Steve Sampson offered no surprises yesterday in naming 20 of the 22 players to the United States team for soccer's 1998 World Cup, beginning next month in France. He chose 12 members of the 1994 World Cup squad, which will lend maturity and experience to the American team, and paid close attention to the issue of chemistry on a team that has no real superstars.

title: A List Notable for Those Who Failed to Make It
description: Following are the direct and indirect results to date of Kenneth W. Starr's investigation into the Whitewater land deal.

title: U.S. GIVES ISRAEL MONDAY DEADLINE TO APPROVE PLAN
description: In an effort to keep the search for an Israeli-Palestinian peace from collapsing after two days of difficult talks here, the United States today set a deadline of early next week for Israel to agree to American proposals for a withdrawal from 13 percent of the West Bank.

title: A Huge Building Honors A Foe of Bigness: Reagan
description: They have short memories inside the Beltway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, MURRAY
description: RESNICK-Murray. Eugene M. Grant & Company deeply mourns the death of our beloved colleague & friend, Murray Resnick. A highly skilled Real Estate management professional, a loyal and devoted employee for over three decades, Murray was above all a gentleman of the old school. He was cherished by his co-workers, his staff members, numerous tenants and vendors, all of whom appreciated his superior qualities. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his loving sons and daughters-in-law, and all of his caring grandchildren. Eugene M. Grant, President

title: Gene Raymond, Stage and Screen Actor, 89
description: Gene Raymond, whose dashing blond looks led to a long career in theater, film and television, died on Sunday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: The Quilted Giraffe Cooks Again
description: FORTY-EIGHT chefs filed out of the kitchen on the 50th floor of the Equitable Center in midtown on Sunday night, each carrying two plates of beggar's purses, tiny crepes that were filled with caviar and creme fraiche, tied in a bundle with a strip of chive and topped with a shimmering wisp of gold leaf.

title: AUTODESK PAYS $68 MILLION IN CASH FOR ASSETS OF GENIUS
description: Autodesk Inc. said yesterday that it had bought most of the assets of the closely held Genius CAD-Software G.m.b.H. of Germany for $68 million in cash, to enhance its line of mechanical-design software products. Genius's mechanical-software design unit, which will remain in Germany, will be added to Autodesk's mechanical market group. Autodesk, which makes software to aid engineers and designers, will employ 70 workers from Genius, including software engineers and production-support personnel. The shares of Autodesk, which is based in San Rafael, Calif., fell 68.75 cents, to $47.9375.

title: Police Smash Piracy Ring For Videos, Arresting 43
description: It was a franchise of sorts, investigators said, a videotape and compact disk piracy operation that employed dozens of New Yorkers and offered dozens more the opportunity for profits through the sale of do-it-yourself duplicating kits.

title: Help Sex Shops Move
description: To the Editor:

title: Judicial Secrecy
description: Federal District Judge Norma Holloway Johnson has apparently rebuffed the White House's attempt to stretch beyond all recognition the doctrine of executive privilege to shield two Presidential associates from having to testify before the grand jury hearing evidence about President Clinton's relationship with the former White House intern Monica Lewinsky. She is absolutely right to do so. But her momentous ruling remains under seal, which makes it difficult to assess her legal reasoning. This is a direct result of her refusal to grant the press access to critical legal arguments and documents throughout the proceeding.

title: Lawyer Dissuaded Tobacco Researcher, Memorandum Suggests
description: The head of research for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company believed in the early 1980's that the Government should regulate cigarettes but changed his mind after lawyers told him that such a move would hamper Reynolds's ability to market products, according to a memorandum by a company lawyer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, HERMAN PETE
description: ROGERS-Herman Pete, age 88. Died on May 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Reita (nee Berlat). Loving father of daughter Beth and son Toby. Cherished grandfather of John Andrew Rogers Katz. Loving father-in-law to Jeffrey Katz and Francine Nayman. Your sense of humor and philosophy of life will sorely be missed. We all love you.

title: Calendar
description: Sake Tasting

title: Time Warner Cable Sale
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell three cable systems in southern Florida to the Adelphia Communications Corporation, a cable television operator. Terms were not disclosed. The three cable systems, which are in Lake Okeechobee, Belle Glade and Clewiston, have a total of 20,000 customers. Time Warner is based in New York, and Adelphia is based in Coudersport, Pa.

title: Report of an Anti-Gay Slur Prompts Chaplain to Retire
description: A police chaplain who spent 42 years counseling the rank and file of the New York City Police Department retired under fire yesterday as the department began investigating accusations that he used an anti-gay slur to refer to an assistant district attorney.

title: Euro Deal Adds to Kohl's Political Woes
description: Having dreamed for years about uniting Europe around a single currency, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany is now suffering acute heartburn as a result of last weekend's historic compromise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEDGES, CAMILLE F. (NEE FENN)
description: HEDGES-Camille F. (nee Fenn). 83, of Sag Harbor, New York, died May 4, 1998 at the Good Samaritan Nursing Home in Socorro, New Mexico. She was predeceased by husband, Thomas B. Hedges. She is survived by daughter, Kathleen, and her husband, Walter Jon Williams of Belen, NM; daughter, Alice H. Emigh, of Albany, New York, sister, Dolores Fenn of NYC and Sag Harbor, and brother Gene Fenn of Paris, France.

title: Hardball Tactics Appear to Fall Short Against a Defiant McDougal
description: If Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, harbored any hopes that his hardball tactics against Susan H. McDougal would force her to cooperate, he did not have to wait long to find out. One day after a Federal grand jury indicted her on criminal contempt and obstruction of justice charges, Ms. McDougal declared from a prison cell, ''I will not perjure myself for leniency.''

title: Restaurants; No Longer Just a Casual Spot for a Snack
description: IF you are a person who loves the serious Italian food at Felidia but wishes the restaurant were a little less formal and a lot less expensive, read on. If, on the other hand, you are a person who thinks the only Italian food worth eating comes from Tuscany, you might as well put the paper down right now, for you will surely have no interest in knowing about the mini-Felidia that has sprung up on Ninth Avenue.

title: Mayor Proclaims Arts Week To Showcase Student Talent
description: With schoolchildren at his side literally singing his praises for providing money to help restore arts education in some city schools, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday declared May 18-22 Arts Education Week.

title: Business Travel; Overseas airlines are following the lead of United States carriers in cutting fares for slow periods.
description: UNITED STATES airlines have become skillful at offering periodic low fares and special deals designed to fill seats during slow periods. Foreign airlines have wasted little time following this lead, and at the moment, carriers from three different continents are offering substantial reduced fares -- with the usual restrictions.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS PLANS ADDED BUYBACK OF UP TO $2 BILLION
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it would buy back up to $2 billion of its common stock in addition to an existing $6 billion buyback plan. The buyback, which will take place over an unspecified time, will increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. The company had 994.2 million shares outstanding as of Feb. 28. The company said it had repurchased about 79 million of its shares since 1994, at an aggregate cost of $4 billion. Bristol-Myers, based in New York, makes prescription drugs, over-the-counter products, medical devices and nutritional supplements. The company's stock dropped 81.25 cents, to $108.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, ETHEL S.
description: EPSTEIN-Ethel S., 83. Died at her home in Manhattan on May 4. Wife of the late Benjamin Epstein. Mother of Ellen Howe and David and Kate Epstein. Aunt of Thomas J. Schwarz. Grandmother of Benjamin, Caroline and Louis Howe and Lillian, Grace and Raphael Epstein. Service Friday, 12:30PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Contributions in her name may be sent to the Scholarship Funds of Deerfield Academy and the Groton School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: GOLDSTEIN-Abraham. On May 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Mildred. Loving father of Fredricka, Karen, Louis, David. Dear brother of Henriette Goldberg. Adoring grandfather of Samuel, Stephen, Brian, Ann, Susan, Anthony, Daniella, Amanda and Joseph. Great grandfather of Alexandra. Chairman and leader of Society of Jewish Science. Lover of the people and land of Israel where he lived for 20 years. A generous hand to those in need and those he loved. Service Thursday 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory to Society of Jewish Science, 109 East 39 Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: Old, for Rockers, But Still Shaking
description: After yelping his way through the recently written ''This Town Isn't Keepin' You Down'' at Tramps on Friday night, Jason Ringenberger flashed a wicked smile. ''We may be old, but we're still good,'' he declared.

title: The Minimalist; A Pork Stew For Spring
description: WE have entered the brief season during which fresh vegetables begin to flood the market while the weather stays cool enough to cook seriously, even in non-air-conditioned kitchens. Like early autumn, it is a time when you can include local produce in comforting, stew-like dishes.

title: Metro Business; A Secaucus Hilton Is Sold
description: Felcor Suite Hotels of Irving, Tex., said yesterday that it had acquired the Meadlowlands Hilton in Secaucus, N.J., from Metrostate Investment for $23.4 million.

title: From Boredom to Irritation To Humiliation (She's Dating)
description: Sandra Tsing Loh knows just how bad dating is in New York these days. (''Guys won't even cross the park to meet you for a drink anymore.'') She shares the news in her one-woman show ''Bad Sex With Bud Kemp,'' which is less about the title event than about the desperate measures she takes and abject humiliations she suffers afterward.

title: Debating History, And Winning Prize
description: Addressing such conversation-stoppers as ''What are the philosophical and historical foundations of the American political system?'' 50 high school teams from around the country competed last weekend in the national finals of the ''We the People . . . the Citizen and the Constitution'' program in Washington. After three days of simulated Congressional hearings in which students discussed Constitutional principles before a panel of judges, East Brunswick High School in New Jersey took home first prize. The nonprofit Center for Civic Education sponsors the event.

title: Political Memo; Race for California Governor Is Not Necessarily the News
description: California's closely contested race for governor took a significant turn the other day: a new poll showed that for the first time in months, Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, a phlegmatic 20-year veteran of state politics, had edged ahead of his richer, flashier rivals for the Democratic nomination.

title: Lurid, Sure, but Is It Newsworthy?; Video Wasn't Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: 4-Day Rally Comes to Halt On Fear of Rate Increases
description: A four-day rally in stocks fizzled yesterday amid renewed fears that strong economic growth may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David. January 9, 1931-May 6, 1997. Big D, we all miss you and love you more than ever. Time hasn't healed one bit. Love forever, The Kids

title: Moscow Journal; Olden Arts Mock the Newly Rich (and Their Toys)
description: Even in a nation of excesses, some things are excessive, as Grigory Baltser ought to know. He owns the World of New Russians, a trendy shop celebrating the life style of Russia's rich and famous.

title: Sales Tax Exemption Is Proposed for Film Work
description: In an effort to help New Jersey's growing movie industry, lawmakers plan to unveil legislation tomorrow that would exempt from the state's 6 percent sales tax purchases related to the production of films.

title: Public Lives
description: Eating Their Way To 'The Skinny'

title: Beach Fees to Rise At Gateway Park
description: Beach fees at the Gateway National Recreation Area at Sandy Hook will double this summer under a rate increase approved last week by the National Park Service.

title: PENTAIR SURPASSES APPLIED POWER'S BID FOR VERO GROUP
description: Pentair Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire the British electronics manufacturer Vero Group P.L.C. for $:102.2 million ($170.2 million), topping an earlier $:94.3 million bid by Applied Power. Two weeks ago, Applied Power, a maker of electronic and industrial products based in Butler, Wis., offered 157 pence a share for Vero. Pentair, a diversified manufacturer based in St. Paul, is offering 170 pence a share. Pentair's chairman and chief executive, Winslow H. Buxton, said the acquisition would strengthen the company's position in the fast-growing data networking and telecommunications equipment markets. The shares of Pentair dropped 93.75 cents, to $41.6875.

title: Killer Was Bitter Over Reprimand, Vatican Says
description: While the outside world pondered the astonishing murder mystery in the Vatican, officials at the Holy See moved quickly today to try to put the puzzling tragedy to rest. A disgruntled Swiss Guard, a Vatican spokesman said, lost control and killed his commanding officer and the officer's wife inside the Vatican on Monday night.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL AND BANCO FRANCES IN DEAL
description: American International Group Inc. plans to buy an Argentine consumer finance company from Banco Frances S.A. for $49 million. Banco Frances, controlled by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya S.A. of Spain, said American International had agreed buy its 70 percent stake in Compania Financiera Argentina S.A., which focuses on lending to low-income consumers. Banco Frances did not say what would happen to the remaining 30 percent of the company, though the daily newspaper Clarin reported that American International had agreed to buy out Compania Financiera's two other shareholders for another $21 million.

title: Auto Insurers Ordered To Return Some Profits
description: Citing a law intended to keep auto insurance affordable in New Jersey, the state yesterday ordered two companies to return $1.7 million in profits to nearly 60,000 policyholders.

title: Suspect in Clinic Explosion Is Sought in Olympics Blast
description: Federal authorities said today that Eric Robert Rudolph, the North Carolina fugitive charged with the deadly bombing of an Alabama abortion clinic, is also wanted for questioning in three bombings in the Atlanta area, including the 1996 explosion at Centennial Olympic Park.

title: Sovereign Vatican Can Investigate Its Own Crime
description: The Vatican is more than the headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church. Though it occupies a mere 108.7 acres and has only about 1,000 citizens, the Vatican is a sovereign city-state with the right to investigate and prosecute any crimes -- including the rare homicide -- that occur within its borders.

title: For Better or Worse, Here Comes Ewing
description: As the Knicks kept chipping paint off the rim in the second half last night, it was hard not to wonder whether Patrick Ewing could make a difference. It was easy to see him hitting five straight impossible fall-away shots from the baseline. No one who was actually on the floor could buy a basket, so an on-fire, imaginary big fella was the next best thing.

title: FOUNDATION HEALTH TO SELL UNIT FOR $290 MILLION
description: Foundation Health Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its workers' compensation unit to Superior National Insurance Group Inc., a unit of the Superior National Corporation, for about $290 million in cash so it can focus on its managed-care services and improve profit. Foundation Health said in February that it planned to sell the unit, which is called Business Insurance Group Inc. The unit, which reported a loss for 1997, writes workers' compensation insurance for businesses. Superior National, based in Calabasas, Calif., sells workers' compensation insurance in California and Arizona. The shares of Foundation rose $2.625, to $32.125, and Superior National's stock rose $1.50, at $22.

title: Too-High Hopes
description: I arrived at the office this week to find myself bombarded with telephone calls and E-mail about the new developments in cancer research, reported in Sunday's New York Times. Patients with advanced breast cancer, ovarian cancer, melanoma and a score of other malignancies were desperate for more information and for my opinion about the work of a Harvard colleague, Dr. Judah Folkman.

title: Lurid, Sure, but Is It Newsworthy?; Just Don't Watch
description: To the Editor:

title: Jumping On America's Hospitality Bandwagon; Foreign Students Choose U.S. for Studying Tourism
description: Nothing is fueling the world's economy quite like its inhabitants' wanderlust. Within the next decade, the global tourism industry is expected to triple in size, to almost two billion travelers spending $1.83 trillion a year, or $5 billion a day. All that growth could create as many as 100 million jobs.

title: Shhh, What Was That? A Pay Increase
description: It happened in a legislative nanosecond, a debate and vote so quick that anyone who stepped out for a cup of coffee would have missed it. It involved an issue that has been likened to political poison, and the sooner lawmakers got it onto the Governor's desk, the better.

title: Emily Mudd, 99, Dies; Early Family Expert
description: Dr. Emily Mudd, a onetime college dropout who trained to be a landscape architect before the trajectory of her life and her own inner fire led her to become a pioneering marriage and family counselor, died on Saturday at her home in Haverford, Pa. She was 99 and widely regarded as a giant of the field she helped create.

title: Frenchman Gets Big Stake In Christie's
description: A wealthy French takeover investor whose diverse empire includes France's biggest department store, Samsonite luggage and a Colorado ski resort, has bought 29.1 percent of Christie's, raising the prospect that ownership of the famed London auction house could pass from British hands for the first time in its 232 years.

title: On NATO Plan, 'X' Is Wrong Again
description: To the Editor:

title: House Again Delays Financial Services Bill
description: The House Republican leader, Representative Dick Armey, announced another delay today on an already troubled bill to revamp laws governing the financial services industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEARNE, PAUL G.
description: HEARNE-Paul G. On May 3, 1998. President of the Dole Foundation. Husband of Pamela S. Loving son of Patricia Hearne. Devoted brother of Jennifer Hughes and fond brother-in-law to Mark. Loving uncle of Aidan. Friends may call Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue (at R.R. Plaza), Floral Park. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, 9:30AM at Our Lady of Victory R.C. Church. Interment Saint Joseph's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to O.I. Foundation, A.A.P.D. or Henry Viscardi School of Albertson, N.Y. appreciated.

title: A Critical Moment in the Mideast
description: After more than a year of stagnation, the Middle East peace talks have entered a particularly delicate phase. Madeleine Albright managed to give the negotiations a nudge by shuttling between Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat in London this week. But if the Israeli Prime Minister and Palestinian leader cannot come to terms by Sunday on the dimensions of the next Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank, the entire peace effort could falter.

title: Lurid, Sure, but Is It Newsworthy?
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: TRANSACTIONS

title: Brawley Case Defendant Questions Officer's Death
description: The autopsy report of a part-time police officer who committed suicide was unsealed for the first time yesterday in the Tawana Brawley defamation suit, as one of the defendants sought to prove that the officer had been murdered to keep him quiet about the rape of Ms. Brawley.

title: Allstate Questioned Over Quake Claims
description: Federal investigators are looking into whether the Allstate Insurance Company altered documents to save on policyholders' claims from the 1994 earthquake in Northridge, Calif., the company said yesterday.

title: No Going Back in Albany
description: Ten days after Gov. George Pataki vetoed major parts of the State Legislature's budget, relations between Mr. Pataki and the lawmakers have sunk to new levels of name-calling. Unable or unwilling to override the vetoes, the Legislature has all but shut down. It now seems likely to adjourn soon without doing much more this year. The biggest loss resulting from the standoff is $500 million in borrowing rejected by the Governor for desperately needed school construction. But regrettable as that is, the open budget process this session has been an impressive accomplishment with potentially great benefits in the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROM, DONALD
description: STROM-Donald. Young Israel of Flatbush deeply mourns the passing of Donald Strom, beloved husband of Anne Strom. Beloved father of Barbara Korngold and Frank S. Strom. May the almighty console the mourners together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Sheldon J. David, President

title: Cone Maintains Focus for Hot Yanks
description: David Cone has a way of clearing his mind when he pitches, focusing unblinkingly on the glove of catcher Joe Girardi. But there was no way for him to pitch tonight without thinking of his mother, who will undergo an operation on Wednesday.

title: A Piece in Which Little and Much Happen
description: Sally Gross created a small, exquisite world shot through with faint foreboding in her new ''Suddenly Then She . . . ,'' performed on Sunday night at the Joyce SoHo. Very little and a great deal happened in the flowing quintet, danced to music by Robert Een.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ABE
description: WEINSTEIN-Abe. Devoted husband of Florence, loving father of Judith Dines (David), Caren Rosenbaum (Marc), Margery Frohlinger (Joseph). Much adored grandfather of Joshua and Alison Dines, Andrew and Caroline Rosenbaum, Matthew and Jonathan Frohlinger. Brother of Leona Feinstein and Philip Treston, brother-in-law to Shirley and Bernard Pullman, Gloria and Aaron Rosenblatt. Uncle to many special nieces and nephews. Services at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey, Wednesday, May 6, at 12 noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHREWSBURY, MATS G.E. NILSSON
description: SHREWSBURY-Mats G.E. Nilsson. Of 22 Prospect St., Shrewsbury, MA. Died Wednesday afternoon at the Whittier Rehabilitation Hospital in Westborough, MA. He leaves his wife of 52 years, Elsa E. Nilsson b. Falkengren; his son Dr. Claes Nilsson of Portland, Maine; his daughter Elsa N. Hill of Southborough; his grandchildren Carl, Matthew, Siri and John Nilsson and Kirstin Nilsson Hill. Mats Nilsson was born March 18, 1922 in Falkoping, Sweden. He graduated from the Skara Gymnasium and took his student exam in 1941. During World War II, he was a captain in the Swedish army. After the war he attended the Royal Swedish Pharmaceutical Institute in Stockholm, graduating in 1947. His interest in medical research led him to patenting medicines and an early career in the health care industry as president of Distra Distribution Co. in Sweden. He remained there until 1956 when he moved to ASTRA, U.S.A. Mr. Nilsson retired as President and CEO of ASTRA in 1981 and as Chairman of the Board in 1992. During his tenure at ASTRA, Mr. Nilsson served as Chairman of ASTRA Australia and Canada and served on many boards of affiliated companies. Mr. Nilsson was active in community affairs and had special interest in health care issues. He was instrumental in converting Fairlawn Hospital into a rehabilitation facility. For many years he was a member of the board of Guarantee Bank and Trust, Co. and its successors, The Bank of New England and Fleet Bank. He was a supporter of the Worcester Foundation, the Worcester Art Museum and Tower Hill. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM Saturday (May 9, 1998) in First Congregation Church, 19 Church Road, Shrewsbury, Massa chusetts. Burial will be private in Mountain View Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Shrewsbury Public Library, Library Memorial Gift Account, 609 Main Street, Shrewsbury, MA. 01545.

title: Commercial Real Estate; A Stretch of Fifth Avenue Is Turning Into a Corridor for Computers
description: Call it Gigabyte Gulch.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARMSTRONG, FRANK
description: ARMSTRONG-Frank Born Oct. 8, 1895, died May 6, 1959. Always remembered, never forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHANAN, SHIRLEY V.
description: BOHANAN-Shirley V. My secretary of many years. A kind, loving, compassionate woman who taught me much about friendship and what's truly important in life. I am so grateful. My deepest sympathies to her family and her many friends. Donald T. Fredrickson, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SULLIVAN, BENJAMIN C.
description: O'SULLIVAN-Benjamin C. On Saturday, May 2, 1998. Resident of Mamaroneck, NY & West Tisbury, Massachusetts. Husband for 56 years of Sonya, father of Chris of NYC and John of Washington, DC, grandfather of Sarah and Katie, brother-in-law and friend of Budd Schulberg. Retired partner, Holtzmann, Wise & Shepard. Director Association on American Indian Affairs. A lawyer's lawyer and a wit who loved music, Princeton & the Brooklyn Dodgers. Interment private in West Tisbury Cemetery. Gifts may be made to the Jazz Musicians' Emergency Fund, Jazz Foundation of America, 1200 Broadway, Suite 7D, NYC 10001.

title: From the French Marshes, a Salty Treasure
description: THE small waxy potatoes, browned in patches, skins glistening with butter, looked inviting, although I did not expect a lunch of them to be a transcendent experience. But that's just what it was.

description: In percent

title: About New York; Losing Chance To Give Help To Homeless
description: THE two toddlers tugged at their mother's shirt as she rooted through a makeshift pantry filled with boxes of macaroni and canned vegetables. She was in the social work office of a hotel where she was staying while city investigators determined if she qualified for emergency housing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNEY, ANN (COHEN)

Beloved wife of the late George, devoted mother of Stephanie (Marvin) Anzel, of Upper Makefield, PA, and Shelly Charney, of NYC. Dear sister of Sylvia Schulman and Dorothy Black, cherished grandmother of Scott and Joshua Anzel. Services Thursday 1 P.M. at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Saint Albans, NY. For information Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 609-883-1400.

description: LIPPMANN-Heinz I., MD, FACP, FACA, FRHS. On May 4, 1998. Of Chappaqua, NY. Formerly of Teaneck, NJ. Distinguished Emeritus Professor of Rehabilitation at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Yeshiva University, NY. Husband of Alisa (Moscato) Lippmann. Father of Coco Gordon, Robert F. and Lawrence A. Lippmann, MD. Brother of Barbara Friedlander. Grandfather of six. Great-grandfather of three. Funeral service Thursday, 12:30 PM at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, New York. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Toshiba Is New Leader in 8th Leg
description: Toshiba, with Paul Standbridge at the helm, took over the lead yesterday on Day 3 of the eighth leg of the Whitbread Round the World race from Annapolis, Md., to LaRochelle, France. Silk Cut of Britain, averaging 16.3 knots -- the fastest in the fleet -- moved up to second, followed by EF Language in third and EF Education in fourth. The nine-yacht fleet is expected to finish the 3,390-nautical-mile leg in France on May 18.

title: 20th-Century Art Treasures Left to Met
description: A renowned collection of 20th-century European art considered by many to be one of the strongest in private hands has been bequeathed to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Hoop Schemes, Dreams and Happy Feet
description: Adults giggled and children guffawed when Peter Pucci Plus Dancers appeared on Saturday afternoon at the New Victory Theater. Mr. Pucci's witty choreography made dances out of everything from human foibles to basketballs and Hula Hoops. The New Victory specializes in family entertainment, and Mr. Pucci had something for dancegoers of all ages.

title: To Go; How to Enjoy Food in Japanese
description: WHAT does the melodious name AH UMAKATTA mean? It's Japanese for ''yummy, yummy,'' and that's as good a way as any to sum up the little Japanese takeout shop of that name in SoHo.

title: Nancy Hoepli-Phalon, 67, Group's Editor
description: Nancy Hoepli-Phalon, the editor in chief of the Manhattan-based Foreign Policy Association, died last Thursday at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 67.

title: The Indonesian Tangle: How It Enmeshes the U.S.
description: In the last few days, President Suharto has ruled out any significant expansion of political freedom in Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation, until 2002, if not later. And his military chief has warned that protests could grow into anarchy, and promised ''stern action'' to quell student unrest.

title: Connecticut Links Parole to Drug Tests
description: In an effort to trim its overcrowded prisons and stop drug-using felons from committing new crimes, Connecticut's Legislature passed a bill this week that will drastically cut prison time for nonviolent offenders on the condition that they undergo frequent testing for drug use.

title: Sips; Spain's White Sweet Cool One
description: IT looks like a light, lovely milkshake. But horchata de chufa is nothing so familiar.

description: Nasdaq Considers Move

description: RESNICK-Murray. Eugene M. Grant & Company deeply mourns the death of our beloved colleague & friend, Murray Resnick. A highly skilled Real Estate management professional, a loyal and devoted employee for over three decades, Murray was above all a gentleman of the old school. He was cherished by his co-workers, his staff members, numerous tenants and vendors, all of whom appreciated his superior qualities. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his loving sons and daughters-in-law, and all of his caring grandchildren. Eugene M. Grant, President

title: Theater Zoning Plan Attracts Some High-Profile Supporters
description: It is not at every hearing of the New York City Planning Commission that the chairman intones: ''The next speaker is Stephen Sondheim.''

title: Sudanese And Rebels Call for Vote In the South
description: Peace talks between the Sudanese Government and southern rebels ended here today on a note of progress, as both sides agreed to accept an internationally supervised vote on self-determination for the southern half of the country.

title: Carmax and Nissan in Deal
description: Circuit City Stores Inc. said today that its Carmax Group, a retailer of used cars and light trucks, had agreed to become a franchisee of the Nissan Motor Corporation USA. Terms were not disclosed. Circuit City, based in Richmond, said the agreement would enable Carmax to acquire existing Nissan franchises, obtain new franchise points and integrate Nissan franchises into Carmax superstores or operate them as stand-alone sites.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERON, EVA DUARTE
description: PERON-Eva Duarte. May 7, 1919 Your 79th Birthday. We will love and adore you forever and you will never be forgotten. We will take up your name and wave it aloft like a victory flag, Mother Eva. Your Descamisados Children

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAAD, SAM, M.D.
description: SAAD-Sam, M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni record with sorrow the untimely death of Dr. Sam Saad, School of Medicine graduate of the Class of 1982. An outstanding young physician, he will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Avi Barbasch, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: 1968 Olympic Team To Hold Reunion
description: With athletes training out of trailer homes on a parking lot in Lake Tahoe, Calif., there was little indication that members of the 1968 United States Olympic track and field team were to carve their place at the Mexico City Games as perhaps the greatest assemblage of talent ever.

title: Chatichai Choonhavan, 76, Ex-Prime Minister of Thailand
description: Former Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan of Thailand, who personified the nation's old-school style of wheeler-dealer politics until he was ousted in a coup, died yesterday in a London hospital. He was 76.

title: Detective Faces Charges in Leaks to Mob
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that the department would soon file administrative charges against a detective accused of compromising the identity of two undercover officers and leaking information to mobsters that may have led to the murder of a street informer.

title: Leadership Plan for Citigroup Tilts in Favor of Travelers
description: Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc., which agreed last month to merge into Citigroup, designated the management team yesterday to run what would be the world's largest financial services concern, provided it wins regulatory approval.

title: COLD TRAIL: A special report.; Congo Not Alone in Ending Massacre Inquiry
description: Just days after a triumphant announcement last October by an American envoy that he had managed to rescue an investigation into the massacre of refugees that authorities here had blocked, a senior Congolese official bragged to aides that his Government had conceded nothing at all.

description: FRIEDMAN-Heidi Carol, 55. Suddenly. Loved by all for her kindness, elegance and spirit. Survived by mother Selma Price, Arthur Friedman, children Lewis & Julie (Alan Koffler) and grandson Max. Loving sister, niece and devoted aunt. Service on Thursday 10 A.M., Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Investors Cheer as Philips Considers Sale of Polygram
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V., said yesterday that it was exploring options for its 75 percent stake in Polygram N.V., the music company. The announcement aroused hopes on Wall Street that Philips, which has no other interests in the media business, would sell Polygram.

title: Facade Close to Collapse Prompts an Evacuation
description: Sixty-one people were evacuated from a five-story apartment building in the Bowery last night when officials discovered that part of the building's brick facade was bulging and in danger of collapse.

title: Stadiums Are Proposed, but Public Isn't Always Disposed to Pay Price
description: Seventy-five years ago, Jacob Ruppert and Tillinghast L. Huston built Yankee Stadium for $2.5 million, without debates over where to locate the stadium, how much money the city would chip in or how many luxury suites were needed to maximize their cash flow. It was their money, no arguments.

description: KAHN-Sheila (Albert). Beloved wife of Ezra Kahn, of Boca Raton, FL, daughter of the late Dewey and Adeline Albert, died Monday in Tamarac, FL., after a long illness. Loving mother of Howard and Meg, Kenneth and Amy, and Douglas, grandmother of Zachary and Danielle, sister of Jerome and Carol, aunt of Bradley and niece of Alvy West, and beloved cousin. title: Invasion of the Acronyms, Again
description: BRACE for impact. Once again, computer consumers -- from the self-assured whiz kids who delight in the latest technologies to those who occasionally wander blurry-eyed through computer emporiums, praying that megabytes won't mean megabucks -- are being drawn into The Next Big Thing in the computer universe of perpetual re-engineering.

title: LIBRARY/TEST PREPARATION; Score Builder Offers a Thorough Study Plan Minus Frills
description: SCORE BUILDER FOR THE SAT AND ACT(The Learning Company; $40; Windows 3.1, 95 or Macintosh)

title: Bridge; Seeking a Third Victory In a Match With a Quirk
description: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs is by far the strongest event of its kind in North America, and there is nothing quite like it anywhere in the world: before play starts, each pair is sold in a Calcutta auction, and the proceeds are eventually shared in accordance with the tournament results. It will be played in Las Vegas this weekend, and the 120 contestants include almost all the top American players and a sprinkling from other countries: Argentina, Australia, China, France, Germany, Israel, Italy, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Poland, Romania and Scotland.

title: Marine Plane Nearly Hit Ski Gondola
description: Traveling at nearly 600 miles an hour, the Marine warplane that hit a ski-lift cable in Italy in February came within about 130 feet of actually hitting the gondola that carried 20 doomed skiers, according to testimony here today to determine whether two of the crew members should be court-martialed.

title: Satellite Network Is Planned To Keep Car Radios Tuned In
description: Car radios may soon have far more reach than a full tank of gasoline and an open road. Lucent Technologies and CD Radio announced this week that Lucent would develop and supply communications chips for a planned satellite-to-car radio network that would beam programming coast to coast.

title: Intimate Story Is Told at Last, By the Survivor
description: At the end of Lillian Ross's memoir of her 40 years as the other ''wife'' of William Shawn, the longtime editor of The New Yorker, she tells how she learned of his death in December 1992. She dialed the number of the private telephone he had installed for her beside his bed in the apartment he shared with his wife.

title: Violinist Postpones
description: The violinist Maxim Vengerov has postponed his concert tomorrow night at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall because of a family illness. The concert has been rescheduled for June 5 at 8 P.M., and tickets for the Friday concert will be honored then. Information: (212) 875-5030.

title: Sports of The Times; Who Collects the Eggs Of the Golden Goose?
description: SINCE retiring as commissioner of the Atlantic Coast Conference, Gene Corrigan has led a satisfying, peaceful life in Charlottesville, Va. But Corrigan was jolted by the ghost of his administrative past Monday when a Federal judge in Kansas awarded more than $66 million to 1,900 collegiate assistant coaches whose salaries were found to have been illegally restricted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: In America; The 'A' Teams
description: It's getting to be a habit. Last month Jamaal Nelson was elected president of the Student Government Association at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tenn. Mr. Nelson is black, grew up in the Bronx and graduated from La Guardia High School in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the Tony Award nominations misstated the year of the most recent Off Broadway production of one of the nominated plays, ''The Chairs,'' by Eugene Ionesco. That production was in 1997, not 1952.

title: British Aerospace Soars on Hopes Company Might Buy Dasa
description: Shares of British Aerospace P.L.C. surged today after Daimler-Benz A.G. said it was in merger talks with the Chrysler Corporation, a deal that could lead to a sale of Daimler's military aerospace arm to British Aerospace.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Chinese Dissident Reaches Library

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Big Sales Gain for Sunbeam Proves Costly to Investors
description: When the Sunbeam Corporation posted an 18 percent sales gain last year, investors cheered. But they are now learning what price they paid for those results.

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSTER, WOLF, M.D.
description: FORSTER-Wolf, M.D., February 25, 1929-May 2, 1998, 7250 Klosters 02 May 1998, Davoserstrasse 22. You accepted your illness with great composure and you took it as part of your life till the end. Now you have gained eternal peace, where your spirit will transcend to superiority. You love shall guide us through this world you loved so dearly. All that exists we will caress with this love, thus no dreary thought may ever grieve us again. The memorial ceremony will take place on Friday, May 8, 1998, at 11:00 at the Marienkirche in Davos Platz followed by the funeral on the Waldfriedhof. We are in mourning for our best friend. Ulli, Peter & Marc Forster

title: Space Plan's Costs Increase Amid Delays
description: Both supporters and opponents of the planned international space station bombarded NASA representatives today with questions about the project's cost and slipping timetable, but agency officials said it would be several more weeks before they could provide answers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARLAN, GEORGE CUVIER
description: HARLAN-George Cuvier. Cherished husband of Mary C. Pratt (Toronto) died in his sleep on April 28, 1998, age 70 years. Memorial donations, if desired, to the Animal Welfare Institute, P.O. Box 3650, Washington, DC 20007

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROFF, SANDY
description: OSTROFF-Sandy. The Workmen's Circle extends its deepest condolences to our Past President and dear friend Harold Ostroff and his family. Sandy was a beautiful person who suffered much. She is at peace.

title: AUTOMOTIVE FASTENERS MAKER TO BE ADDED BY TEXTRON
description: Textron Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Ring Screw Works, a maker of threaded fasteners for the automotive industry. Terms were not disclosed. Ring, based in Madison Heights, Mich., has annual revenue of $200 million and employs 1,100 people. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., is a diversified company involved in auto parts, aircraft, industrial goods and consumer loans. Ring Screw will be merged with Textron's North American fastener operations. The fastener business, called Textron Fastening Systems, has revenue of more than $1.6 billion a year. Textron's shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $78.

title: For Giuliani, Hobbyist, A Different Big Picture
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani prides himself on being all Mayor, all the time. If there is a big fire, a building collapse or any of the other calamities that beset Gotham, it is a fairly good bet that the Mayor will be there.

title: Fed Report Indicates Growth Free of Inflation
description: The Federal Reserve's latest reading on the economy points to inflation-free growth as some manufacturers contend with weaker demand from Asia for electronics and other products.

title: Confusion Surrounds Mellon's Shares
description: The shares of the Mellon Bank Corporation spiked higher in chaotic after-market trading yesterday after the Pacific Exchange issued a trading halt on the stock and quoted a price as $85.875, which would have represented a jump of $12.625, from the New York Stock Exchange closing price.

title: Credit Lyonnais Accord Nearing
description: France and European competition authorities said today that agreement on terms for a Credit Lyonnais bailout worth more than 120 billion francs ($20 billion) could be reached within days, removing any threat of bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALEWSKI, KATHLEEN
description: MALEWSKI-Kathleen. On May 6, of Manhasset NY. Dear mother of Alexander Jr., Kathy Nihill, Karen Scaduto, Debbie and Robert. Mother-in-law of Renee, Chris & Bob. Loving grandmother of Kristen, Marissa, Matthew, Elizabeth, Krystyna, Katherine, Robert and Brian. In repose at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Nothern Boulevard, Manhasset on Thursday and Friday from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Saturday, May 9 at 8 A.M., in St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset, with interment to follow in Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York. Donations in her memory may be made to The American Cancer Society or Hospice Care of Long Island.

title: The American Way of Spam
description: THE life of a spammer is no bowl of cybercherries. Damien Melle, who makes a living sending huge amounts of E-mail advertising over the Internet, works out of his home in this hardscrabble Southern California suburb, in an office where the smell of fried food lingers like, say, unwanted E-mail in your In box.

title: Currents; WORKING FOR MIELE -- From Pitchman to Architect
description: ''We're all Willy Lomans,'' the architect Michael Graves said in Graphis magazine. If so, Mr. Graves deserves the most-dedicated-salesman-of-the-month prize for his efforts on behalf of Miele, the appliance maker. Little did he know when he posed with a Miele dishwasher for an ad campaign in 1994 that he would ultimately win the big prize, a commission to design the company's American headquarters in Princeton, N.J. Construction of the $8 million, 31,000-square-foot building (in Mr. Graves's palette of ochre, terra cotta and cobalt) is scheduled for completion by November.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NUEVO ENERGY CO., Houston, an oil and gas company, said it had retained Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities to evaluate the sale of its East Texas natural gas reserves.

title: Next Niche for a Chip Might Be on a Stamp
description: How should Americans remember the 1960's? The United States Postal Service is suggesting that a commemorative stamp might be nice, and that one featuring the ubiquitous computer chip might be dandy indeed.

title: America Online Posts Profit As Subscriber Base Surges
description: Propelled by strong growth in both subscribers and advertising, America Online Inc. reported quarterly profits yesterday that sharply exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Risky Task In Indonesia: Cleaning Up Banks' Mess
description: After riots and protests that erupted here for three days, the Government finds itself on an increasingly perilous course: It has little choice but to reform the economy, but with each step it risks alienating another segment of society.

title: KTI IN STOCK AND CASH DEAL FOR FCR, A WASTE HANDLER
description: KTI Inc., a waste processing company in Guttenberg, N.J., agreed yesterday to buy the privately held FCR Inc. for $63.9 million in cash and stock. KTI would pay 1.7 million shares, $30 million in cash and an earn-out provision of as much as $30 million in either cash or stock for FCR, a waste handler based in Charlotte, N.C. FCR operates 26 plants in 12 states. KTI, which earned $3.3 million on $37.6 million in revenue for the quarter ended March 31, said the acquisition would expand its geographic reach and add significant recycling assets. Its shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $20.50.

title: Strobes and Flags as More Than Gimmicks
description: David Parsons's dances meet the eye in more ways than one. ''Anthem,'' a premiere on Tuesday night at City Center, is typical: It is a colorful ode to flag waving, focused on fierce energy and design. Here is choreography that banks on the immediacy of the moment.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Accounts
description: * SMC Networks Inc., Hauppauge, N.Y., to Partners & Simons, Boston, to handle advertising for the computer networking company that was previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: What's a good word for updating one's competitive position? At Burnett, it's Vigilante.
description: A GIANT agency company that usually plays by the book is now trying to rewrite one: the dictionary, to redefine ''vigilante.''

title: Our Towns; Savoring Legal Success, an Ice Cream Vendor Calls the Tune
description: JEFFERY CABANISS, First Amendment hero, has changed his tune.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMANN, HEINZ, M.D.
description: LIPPMANN-Heinz, M.D. The President and the Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center mourn the passing of Dr. Heinz Lippmann, a distinguished professor and respected member of the Rehabilitation Medicine staff for more than forty years. A true renaissance man, Dr. Lippmann was a compassionate physician; inspiring teacher and scholar who published extensively on peripheral vascular disease; gifted pianist, and devoted husband, father and grandfather. Our sincere condolences are extended to his wife, Alisa; his children, and entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., Pres. Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, ELLEN B. (NEE PERRY)
description: COX-Ellen B. (nee Perry). On May 5, 1998. Beloved wife of Keneth B. Loving mother of Lauren Gabel and the late Mavis Elissa. Dear mother-in-law of Johannes. Visiting Thursday and Friday 24PM and 7-9PM. Religious service 8 PM on Friday. Funeral at 9 AM Saturday at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Interment Green-Wood Cemetery.

title: Rising Budget Surplus Spurs Changes in Treasury Note Sales
description: The growing Federal budget surplus -- which has been increasing faster than expected -- pushed the United States Treasury today to eliminate one benchmark note and to alter the issuing of another. They were the first major changes in Treasury auctions since the sale of 30-year bonds was cut back in 1993.

title: Chapel Hill Campus in Uproar Over Issue of Computer Choice
description: A small but determined group of students and staff members at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is organizing resistance to a university plan to require each student to own a personal computer by 2000.

title: HEALTHSOUTH TO ACQUIRE NATIONAL SURGERY
description: The Healthsouth Corporation agreed yesterday to buy National Surgery Centers Inc. for $30.50 a share, or about $590 million, in stock, in the latest move to bolster its position as the largest United States operator of outpatient surgery centers. The acquisition would add 40 such centers in 14 states to Healthsouth's chain of 1,850 centers. Healthsouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., provides diagnostic and rehabilitation services in addition to outpatient surgery. Shares of National Surgery, which is based in Chicago, rose $1.0625 yesterday, to $29.0625. Healthsouth's shares fell 37.5 cents, to $29.625.

title: Tripping Over Translations
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEALES, KENNETH W. SR.
description: SEALES-Kenneth W. Sr. In his 70th year. On May 4, 1998. Formerly of Long Beach, Long Island and North Babylon. At his home in Dungarvin, Ireland. Former President of Fischbach & Moore, Inc. and owner of Seal's Cove Restaurant. Mr. Seales leaves to cherish his memory many family and friends. Private services to be held in Dublin, Ireland. Memorial contributions may be sent to Internationnal Myeloma Foundation, 2120 Stanley Hill Drive, Los Angeles, California 90046.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHMAN, SEYMOUR
description: FISHMAN-Seymour. May 7, 1997. In our hearts and thoughts today and always. We love you and miss you. Your family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: GOLDSTEIN - Abraham. The Board of Directors and the staff of the Society of Jewish Science mourn the passing of their beloved leader and chairman, Abraham Goldstein. He will be greatly missed but his qualities of kindness, generosity and compassion will forever rest in our hearts. Bill Perlmutter, Board Member

title: Five Giants Running Backs All Figure in Fassel's Plan
description: It was running back by committee a year ago for the Giants, but this year's Giants should be different.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CRUICKSHANK, JILL GORHAM
description: CRUICKSHANK-Jill Gorham. Memorial service 10AM, Friday, May 8, St Marks Church in the Bowery, 131 East 10 Street, New York, NY.

title: Priest Is Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Financing New Stadiums
description: Even as New Yorkers debate whether to build new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets, voters in other jurisdictions this week rejected by overwhelming margins the notion of imposing taxes to finance new stadiums. In North Carolina, voters in two counties rejected a plan to tax restaurant meals and baseball tickets to finance a new stadium to lure a major league team to the Greensboro-Winston-Salem area. In the Toledo, Ohio, area, voters rejected a temporary sales tax increase to help build a new stadium for the Toledo Mud Hens, a minor league team that currently plays on a decrepit former race track.

title: Metro Business; Computer Problem Causes Phone Delays
description: A computer problem led to delays on the telephone yesterday for New Yorkers who wanted to request phone numbers and addresses from the Bell Atlantic Corporation's directory assistance operators.

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, J. MICHAEL
description: MURRAY-J. Michael, 43. A lifetime resident of Princeton, died at his home after a long battle with von Hippel-Lindau disease. Mr. Murray was a private investor and, a director of The Murray Foundation, devoted many years of his life to philanthropic causes related to his illness: Recording For The Blind & Dyslexic, Memorial Sloan-Kettering and Bascom Palmer Eye Institute of Miami and Palm Beach, FL., were among the many institutions which benefited from his tireless energy and the support of the foundation. Mr. Murray is survived by a devoted companion and friend, Barbara Henne. His parents, John and Mary of Princeton, NJ; sisters Ellen Kelsey of Greenwich, CT., and Libet Hosea of Princeton, NJ; and brothers John P. III of New York City, W. Stephen of Greens Farms, CT., M. Timothy of Stuart, FL., and R. Scott of Plymouth, New Hampshire. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Recording For the Blind & Dyslexic, Princeton Unit, 36-A Hibben Road, Princeton, New Jersey 08540. A private Mass will be celebrated for the family.

title: CONTINENTAL SHIFTS; Europe's New Challenge To America
description: Although the European Monetary Union will have only a very small effect on the United States economy, it will have major long-term consequences for Europe and for its relations with the United States. Indeed, the combination of European Monetary Union and the end of the cold war creates a significant new challenge for American foreign policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVNER, ELLEN (NEE ROSENBLATT)
description: AVNER-Ellen (nee Rosenblatt). Beloved wife of Kenneth. Devoted mother of Rachel, Julie, Shaya and Leah. Cherished daughter of Irving Obadiah and Frances Rosenblatt and daughter-in-law of Frances Avner. Dear sister of David (Bonnie) Rosenblatt. Services and interment were held Monday. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory to Arie Crown Hebrew Day School, 4600 West Main Street, Skokie, IL 60076 would be appreciated. For information: Weinstein Family Services, Wilmette Chapel, 847-256-5700.

title: Detective in Accident Is Given Modified Duty
description: A highly decorated New York City police detective was placed on modified assignment yesterday after a blood test that was taken after he was involved in a fatal car accident last month showed that his blood-alcohol content was above the legal limit, the police said.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES TO BUY 25 JETS FROM EMBRAER
description: Continental Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it would buy at least 25 new 37-seat jets from Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A., also known as Embraer, for $315 million, making Continental the largest customer of the Brazilian company's regional jets. Continental also took an option to buy an additional 50 aircraft. Part of the transaction will be financed by Brazil's national development bank, although the terms were not disclosed. The planned purchase is part of Continental's program to switch its entire Continental Express commuter fleet to regional jets and eliminate propeller planes.

title: A Tobacco Ban Stirs Charges of Unfairness
description: On the one hand, the effort to get smokeless tobacco out of baseball players' mouths is admirable. On the other, beating them with a stick to accomplish the goal is not.

title: Been There, Done That: Bird Can Relate to Ewing
description: Each time Larry Bird would win a rehabilitation battle, a larger foe remained: his ego. It was a fierce struggle between mind and body, almost like trying to break free for a jumper over James Worthy in Game 7 of the finals.

title: Pataki-Giuliani Plan Would Curb CUNY Colleges' Remedial Work
description: Negotiating what would be the biggest change in admissions standards at City University of New York in nearly 30 years, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have agreed on a plan to end all remedial classes at the system's 11 four-year colleges.

title: Mideast Turnabout
description: After so many false starts over the past 16 months, the lack of tangible progress at the latest round of American-Israeli-Palestinian talks in London raised few eyebrows. What may have been more significant was that the Clinton Administration was no longer a self-effacing ''facilitator,'' but a full-fledged negotiator -- sitting opposite Israel.

title: Jew Is Slain in Jerusalem And Palestinian in West Bank
description: A yeshiva student was stabbed to death today as he walked to morning prayers at the Western Wall in Jerusalem's Old City. Separately, an Israeli settler shot and killed a Palestinian who, the army said, had attacked him with a knife in the West Bank.

title: Tripping Over Translations
description: To the Editor:

title: Fans Flock to Vinyl In the Era of CD's
description: MIKE CIARAMELLA gently lowered the stylus, or needle, of his Grado Signature Jr. cartridge onto a mint British pressing of the Clash's ''London Calling'' LP that he had recently picked up at a garage sale for a dollar. As the title song's marchlike introduction exploded from his speakers, he smiled. ''Now that's what 'London Calling' is supposed to sound like, not what's on that tinny-sounding CD,'' he said, pointing to the digital version that he had been listening to but not enjoying since he became reacquainted with the sound of LP's.

title: Currents; MONUMENTS -- An Obelisk for Diana
description: Intellectuals may scoff at the idea of a monument to Diana, Princess of Wales, at the site of her car accident in Paris, the Italian architect Gaetano Pesce said. But he felt compelled to create one. ''I was in Brazil when the funeral came on television,'' he said from his Manhatttan studio. ''And when I realized that half the world was somehow participating in this event, it was a great sign to me.'' Mr. Pesce's design consists of a simple column -- very much in the tradition of Paris's historical obelisks. The concrete and resin column, costing between $300,000 and $500,000, would stand in a rose garden at Place de l'Alma, which is over the tunnel where the Mercedes S-280 crashed. It would be a visible extension of the 13th column in the tunnel, the exact site of the accident.

title: Metro Business; SPX Drops Offer for Echlin
description: The SPX Corporation yesterday withdrew its hostile takeover bid for rival auto-parts maker Echlin Inc. of Branford, Conn., two days after Echlin agreed to be bought by Dana Corporation in a friendly $4 billion acquisition.

title: Mets Come From Behind With a Vengeance
description: Things have become so bizarre for the Mets that even their injury replacements are getting hurt. Still, their knack for winning in their last time at bat remains unchanged.

title: Philip Morris Censored Data About Addiction
description: The world's largest cigarette maker stopped the publication of research in 1983 that found evidence that nicotine was addictive, days after outside lawyers warned the company that such research had ''undesirable and dangerous implications'' for smoking-related lawsuits.

title: Tradition, Tradition: Ross Society Strives to Stay the Courses
description: Michael Fay was walking off the 14th tee at Wampanoag Country Club, a golf course in West Hartford, Conn., designed by the architecture legend Donald Ross in 1926. He had just hit his tee shot on the 358-yard par 4 over a creek that crosses the fairway and faced an uphill approach to a small, sloping putting surface.

title: Shocking? Well, Shockingly Familiar
description: Fox News Channel's campaign to join the ranks of serious players in television news is not much advanced by tonight's debut of its Special News Unit. ''Washington Classified: Too Many Secrets'' begins with the plausible proposition that the Government, especially the military, stamps too much material ''Confidential'' and keeps it that way for much too long. If the charge seems familiar, well, it is.

title: Asian Faces in American Places
description: ''Mom and Dad were the Japanese version of Ozzie and Harriet,'' Renee Tajima-Pena says, recalling her all-American Chicago childhood in a Japanese-American family. Every summer the Tajima family would pile into the car for vacations, and eventually she noticed something odd. ''We'd drive clear across five states and never catch a glimpse of another Asian face,'' she says, as we see a photo of the young Renee in the 1960's posed with Mount Rushmore in the background.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHARTON, LACY DONNELL, JR. (DON)
description: WHARTON-Lacy Donnell, Jr. (Don). On May 6, 1998 in his 93rd year. Survived by two daughters Margaret W. Segalas and Julia W. Douglas; five grandchildren and three great-granddaughters. Services private.

title: Blair and Major Push Irish Pact
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and his old foe, former Prime Minister John Major, appeared here together today to press for a yes vote on May 22 for the Ulster peace settlement.

title: DAIMLER-BENZ WILL ACQUIRE CHRYSLER IN $36 BILLION DEAL THAT WILL RESHAPE INDUSTRY
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., the German industrial giant that makes Mercedes-Benz automobiles, will acquire the Chrysler Corporation in an estimated $36 billion merger expected to be announced as early as this morning.

title: Mosley Finally Steps Out of Legal Limbo and Back Into the Ring
description: Shane Mosley, the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion, has the kind of talent that should have him center stage among the elite boxers in his weight class. But for the last two years, his biggest fights have been in the legal arena.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, AUGUSTA H.
description: SIMMONS-Augusta H. Of Palm Beach, FL, passed away May 5, 1998. Widow of Herbert L. She is survived by her daughter Marjorie and son-in-law Rodney Fink. She is also survived by several nieces and nephews. Donations may be made to the charity of your choice. For information contact the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Events; Indian Art, Graphics And Quilts
description: Indian Artworks

title: Game Boy's Toy Camera: Serious Business
description: NINTENDO'S Game Boy camera is the Ginsu knife of digital imaging: an inexpensive mass-market device with a seemingly endless repertory of functions. For $45, you get a cartridge that snaps into your handheld gaming device and takes black-and-white pictures. It stores up to 30 images at a time and displays them on screen.

title: ESSAY; In a Life's Digital Flotsam, a Bittersweet Balm for Death's Sting
description: AN author, Lisa Goldstein, titled one of her short stories ''Death Is Different,'' an indisputable assertion I came to understand at the infinitely malleable age of 12, when my father died of cancer. My sense of the unwavering uniqueness of death was reinforced over the years by the passing of relatives and friends until it became a familiar, unwelcome stranger perched at the edge of my consciousness, as it is for most people who reach the age of 40. This lesson was recently driven home again and upgraded, if you will, because of a personal computer, of all mundane things.

title: Jailed Man Is Charged With Hiring a Killer
description: An inmate in the Bergen County Jail has been charged with two counts of attempted murder for hiring a man he thought was a professional killer to murder his former girlfriend and her ex-husband, county prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Making Books; No Rush to Ride Viagra Coattails
description: First the pill, then the book. Viagra, taking everyone through all the spheres of promise. For men the dream of erectile function. For a few book publishers, the hope of excitation of a different sort.

title: Arts Abroad; Reflections on African War, From a Haven in the U.S.
description: Emmanuel Dongala, a 57-year-old scientist, novelist and victim of an African war that never really caught the world's attention, walked through the budding woods of the Berkshire campus where he has come to teach and talked of the violence he has felt and witnessed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARAIL, MARK
description: TARAIL-Mark, D.S.W. We are deeply saddened at the passing of Mark Tarail, one of the founders of the Department of Psychiatry and the Community Mental Health Center at Maimonides. A dynamic leader and scholar, Mark always sought to speak for those who did not have a voice. He envisioned a world in which universal health care would become a reality, and he conveyed this dream to his students. We at Maimonides who worked with Mark and greatly admired him wish to express our deepest sympathy to his wife Helen, his brother Theodore, his children Judith and Michael, and to his seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Martin Payson, Chairman Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO, and the Staff of Maimonides Medical Center

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: People
description: * Keith M. Levitt, senior vice president for finance and administration at The New York Times Magazine Group, Trumbull, Conn., was promoted to the new position of chief operating officer, overseeing the advertising sales, marketing, circulation, human resources and production departments. Robert A. Sauerberg Jr., vice president and controller, was promoted to vice president for finance, assuming some responsibilities from Mr. Levitt. And Robert L. Maxon, vice president and group publisher of the Golf Co., New York, also part of The New York Times Magazine Group, was promoted to the new post of senior vice president.

title: Voice-Data Company's Shares Gain 38%
description: The shares of General Magic Inc. surged 38 percent today, to $12.9375 a share, amid hopes that a new voice and data service will buoy the once high-flying technology company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BETTMANN, OTTO
description: BETTMANN-Otto. You will be missed. Peter Rohowsky, Director Christie's Images

title: Calendar; Plant Sales, Exhibitions And Talks
description: Plant Sale

title: Sorting Out the Proposals for Improving Digital Sound
description: ALMOST from the moment the compact disk was introduced in 1983, engineers have searched for ways to improve its sound.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Cut Lilacs That Last

title: Head of AT&T's Overseas Operation Goes to Competitor
description: Adding to the turmoil in AT&T's international business, R. C. Mark Baker, head of the company's overseas operation, has decided to resign and become chief executive of one of AT&T's small competitors.

title: Irish Island Unites, in Commerce, Even Before an Accord
description: While Northern Ireland's politicians have been taking forced first steps to bring the two parts of the Irish island closer together, the province's business people have been virtually razing the long-disputed border.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANN, LEE I.
description: GANN-Lee I. On May 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Mitzi. Cherished father of Erik and Cory. Loving grandfather of Megan, Elliot, Caitlin and Alexander. Devoted uncle to Sean, Evan, Regan, Geoffrey, Wendy, David, Kevin, Madliene, Robin, Carla and Victor also Laura and Andrew. Dearest brother of Dr. Edith Gann. President of Cameron Craig Ltd. of Newark, New Jersey. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street Friday, 3 P.M.

title: 3-Doctor Rule Dropped In 'Right to Die' Cases
description: The New Jersey State Board of Medical Examiners said yesterday that it would drop its requirement that three doctors determine the competency of any terminally ill hospital patient refusing life-sustaining treatment or cardiopulmonary resuscitation if his or her heart later stopped.

title: After Half a Century, Still Writing, Still Questing
description: He is a courtly old gent, limping precariously on a bad knee across his top-floor apartment in Brooklyn Heights, a flat gray light sweeping in from the harbor. ''Oh, I have been using too many big words,'' he says, a little sheepishly, a shy smile breaking across his furrowed face.

title: How to Spell Fast: KKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKKK
description: At the Chicago Cubs' organizational meeting last November, club officials were discussing the timetable for Kerry Wood, a highly regarded pitcher in their minor league system. ''He's going to tell us when he's ready,'' said Lester Strode, the minor league pitching coordinator.

title: Hail, Wind and Rain Delay and Cancel Flights
description: Severe thunderstorms and isolated pockets of hail swept across the region yesterday, leading to flight delays, cancellations and maritime warnings of high winds.

title: Currents; FURNISHINGS -- Tibetan Treasures From Nepal
description: The Dalai Lama was not the only Tibetan import in town last week. ABC Carpet and Home (888 Broadway at 19th Street) received its first shipment of late-19th-century Tibetan trunks, chests and boxes ($1,095 to $3,195). They are in original condition and bear the lusciously colored illustrations typical of Buddhist monastery furnishings.

title: The Changing Face of the Beauty Makeover
