description: Perhaps to combat the sickly pallor that computer users are supposed to develop after long use, makeover software is now appearing on the market.

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOSSIN, KATHLEEN ANNE, NEE BROSNAHAN
description: CLOSSIN-Kathleen Anne, nee Brosnahan. Formerly of Lindenhurst, NY, died May 6, 1998. Funeral Mass Saturday at 11:00 AM at St. Patrick's Church, Gallitzin. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Kathleen Anne Clossin Memorial Reading Program, C/O Gallitzin Public Library, 702 Jackson Street, Gallitzin, PA. 16641.

title: 125 Years of Very Serious Amateur Singers
description: When it comes to illustrious pedigree, not many professional musical ensembles in the area surpass the Oratorio Society of New York, an amateur organization that will celebrate its 125th anniversary with a concert at Carnegie Hall tonight.

title: High Hopes on Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Accuse Clinton Of Blackmailing the Israelis
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that the White House was trying to blackmail Israel by pushing it toward the negotiating table, but President Clinton said he was only trying to bring about fruitful talks on Mideast peace.

title: Currents; LOFTS -- Where Romantic Triangles Happen
description: The plot of the new movie ''Two Girls and a Guy,'' a modern tale of romantic triage written and directed by James Toback, delves deep into the wherefores of lust, loyalty, betrayal and inexorable affection. But it never answers the question foremost on the mind of any sane New Yorker: Where did the guy get that spectacular apartment? The SoHo loft where two girlfriends come together to confront their boyfriend has majestic 14-foot ceilings with Corinthian cast iron columns, a shoji screen-enshrined bedroom and a Jacuzzi with a 10-foot window. Almost every review has cited the place: ''lavish'' (The New York Post), ''to die for'' (The New York Observer) or ''the colorful, fourth character'' (The New York Times). The film's main character, a hapless actor, would never have been able to buy the place, which is made clear when one woman insults him as ''loft inheriting.'' But the real-estate insatiable may want to know more. The Leonard Street loft was designed by its owner, Roberto Brambilla, an Italian architect. Movie scouts found the loft after inspecting more than 150 others. They added touches like a ''Jules et Jim'' movie poster and subtracted some personal effects (a huge screen of Lake Como is not visible, but the neo-classical sleigh bed that Mr. Brambilla slept in as a child is). Why did the architect allow a film crew into his home? ''They were very nice to me,'' he said, ''and frankly seemed so desperate. So I took pity and invited them over.'' That and a hefty location fee did the trick.

title: FONOROLA BOARD RECOMMENDS REJECTION OF CALL-NET BID
description: The Montreal-based Fonorola Inc. advised its shareholders yesterday to reject an offer by Call-Net Enterprises, another Canadian telecommunications company, to buy Fonorola at the equivalent of $41 (United States) a share. Fonorola's board said the offer, which was made directly to shareholders, did not reflect the value of the company. The offer of $41 a share or 2.4 Call-Net nonvoting shares for each Fonorola share is equal to $1.1 billion. Fonorola said Call-Net's business plan seemed to be focused on the Canadian market, which would deprive Fonorola shareholders of the potential in the United States market. In addition, it said Call-Net's offer of nonvoting shares disenfranchised Fonorola shareholders.

title: Friends of Suicide Victim Reject a Policy of Silence
description: A high school principal's refusal to allow the name of a student who committed suicide to be read during commencement in June has angered the boy's family and fellow students, who say that it would help put a terrible event to rest.

title: Invitation From an Illegal Donor Puts Gingrich on the Spot
description: Would the Speaker of the House like to be the main attraction at a big Republican picnic in Seattle on Aug. 22?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  A'HEARN, RUTH A. (NEE DONOVAN)
description: A'HEARN-Ruth A. (nee Donovan) On May 4, 1998 in her 98th year. Of Garden City, N.Y. Formerly of East Atlantic Beach, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Frank B. A'Hearn. Loving mother of Ruth Mallon, Jeanne Maloney and Francis A'Hearn. Cherished grandmother of 24 & great-grandmother of 50. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Wednesday 7-9 P.M., and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial, 10 AM, Friday St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York.

title: Clinton Faces Tough Choice
description: President Clinton faces a thorny decision on whether to appeal a ruling that he cannot block prosecutors from questioning aides. Page A20.

title: High Point Rejoices as Furniture Sales Climb
description: MODERNISM steamed into the International Home Furnishings Market, the world's largest wholesale furniture exposition, with all flags flying.

title: Cramer-Krasselt Wins Birds Eye
description: The Dean Foods Vegetable Company in Green Bay, Wis., said yesterday that it had named Cramer-Krasselt in Milwaukee to handle advertising and public relations for its Birds Eye frozen vegetables line, which had been handled by the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Inc. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. A three-month review of the account also included Y.& R. San Francisco and two other agencies: BBDO Minneapolis, part of Omnicom Group, and Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, part of Havas Advertising.

title: Fiat and Renault Set To Pool Bus Units
description: The Italian car, truck and bus maker Fiat S.p.A. said yesterday that it would pool its bus-making operations with Renault S.A. of France in a 50-50 joint venture that will become the second-largest bus maker in Europe, behind Daimler-Benz A.G.'s Mercedes-Benz. Fiat said the combined companies would have annual sales of about $1 billion and produce 4,500 buses and 1,500 mini-buses a year. The combination of the bus units of Fiat's Iveco division and Renault's RVI will lead to ''substantial savings,'' the statement said.

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: Compaq Said To Plan Cuts In Digital Jobs
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation will cut 15,000 jobs, or 28 percent, of the Digital Equipment Corporation's work force after the expected merger of the companies is completed later this year, an executive at one of the computer makers said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAISIER, RENE GEORGES
description: BAISIER-Rene Georges. On May 3, 1998 at the age of 90 of New York City. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Thalmann. Devoted stepfather of Catherine Cavanaugh of Morristown, N.J. Dear uncle of Jacques Baisier of Lille, France and two grand-nephews. Services at St. James Episcopal Church, 71 Street and Madison Avenue on Friday, May 8 at 2PM. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.

title: Mitsubishi Unit's Woes Hurt Affiliates' Shares
description: Shares in several Mitsubishi group companies tumbled yesterday in the wake of severe financial troubles at one affiliate, the Optec Dai-Ichi Denko Company. Last Friday, Optec Dai-Ichi, a wire maker, said it would post an extraordinary loss of 72.62 billion yen ($551 million) for the year that ended on March 31. Traditionally, stronger companies in Japanese business conglomerates come to the aid of struggling group members, and on Friday Optec announced that several Mitsubishi companies would help it restructure.

title: Bear, Stearns Vice Chairman Aids McCall in Fund-Raising
description: The vice chairman of Bear, Stearns & Company, one of the biggest sellers of government bonds in the nation, is helping to lead a fund-raising drive for the re-election campaign of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, whose office selects the firms that receive the lucrative job of selling New York State general obligation bonds.

title: Back From the Brink of Extinction
description: The Interior Department's proposal to remove more than two dozen rare plants and animals from the endangered species list is not only a triumph for the bald eagle, the peregrine falcon, the gray wolf and their fortunate companions but also a vindication of the Endangered Species Act, which made their survival possible. The act is the most controversial of all the landmark environmental statutes enacted in the early 1970's. Among the criticisms trotted out over the years is that it does not really work and causes more aggravation to developers and landowners than it is worth to the species. As yesterday's proposal makes clear, however, the act does indeed work. That should send an important message to those in Congress who would weaken it or cut the funds necessary to carry it out.

title: Growth of Budget Surplus Outstrips Plans for How to Spend It
description: The nation's fiscal condition continues to improve at a startling pace, so much so that Washington is having trouble keeping up.

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTLE, KATHERINE M. (NEE O'CONNOR)
description: LITTLE - Katherine M. (nee O'Connor). Of Bloomfield, New Jersey, on May 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Colin W. Little. Mother of Regina Little, Kathleen Marck, Patricia Little, Colin, Jr., and Brian Little, Elizabeth Libero, Pamela Tripsas. Grandmother of Peter and Lauren Libero, Mary and Colin Little, III, Jenna and Victoria Tripsas, Zachary, Caroline and Veronica Little.

title: Public Eye; Champions Of Breakfast
description: THE best first meal of the day might be a glass of juice, a bowl of cereal, maybe some fresh fruit. Reality for many people is racing to work or school with, at best, a yogurt or skim-milk latte.

title: Flowerpot Lands on 2 Officers As They Make Arrest in Bronx
description: Two police officers who were trying to arrest a man outside a Bronx apartment building yesterday were slightly injured when they were hit by a flowerpot that had been tossed from a sixth-story window, the police said.

title: House Proud; For Sale: This Old Show House
description: ROY AND ELSIE WILCOX, of Neath in southern Wales, are planning a trip to Boston next year. So far, they have no plans to see the Paul Revere House or the Old North Church. Instead, they are hoping for a glimpse of some of the houses in the area that have appeared on ''This Old House.''

title: Dow Slides by 92.92 as Uncertainty Surrounds Trading
description: The stock market fell sharply again yesterday, continuing a recent volatile trading pattern that reflects the uncertainty of the outlook after a rally that has pushed the market to repeated new highs this year.

title: Adding a Dimension to Web Art
description: THE abstract image on the yellow background of ''Repetition Patterns (detail)'' undulates slightly, disclosing new details as the viewer's head moves left and right, while the cursor hovers like a waterbug on the surface of the deep end of a pool. Rick Gibson of Vancouver, British Columbia, likes to think of the three-dimensional artwork on his Web site (www.express.ca/rigibson) as broadcast sculpture.

title: Priest Is Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENEN, AUSTIN
description: KOENEN-Austin. On May 2, 1998. Survived by his wife, Kathleen and three children - Karestan, Erin and Austin Junior. The viewing will be held on Friday, May 8th from 3:00 P.M. to 9 P.M. at the M. John Scanlan Funeral Home, 781 Newark Pompton Turnpike, Pompton Plains, New Jersey. Services will be held on Saturday, May 9, 10:00am at the Jacksonville Chapel located in Lincoln Park, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, the Koenen family has requested donations directed to Outward Bound in Rockland, Maine, the American Heart Association (800634-1242) or the Good Shepherd Mission (973-742-9244).

title: Seldon Pleads Guilty
description: Bruce Seldon, a former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts of child endangerment, admitting he engaged in sexual activity with a 15-year-old girl after taking sexually provocative photographs of her, prosecutors in New Jersey said.

title: Author's 'Zack' Is a Smash in Second Grade
description: DAN GREENBURG has signed his autograph several thousand times over a 35-year career as a writer, but lately he's had to draw the line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROTA, ANTHONY
description: PROTA-Anthony. On May 5, 1998. Respected Senior V.P. of Wolf Gordon, Inc. Tony was one of four founders of our firm, which became and remained one of the largest independent suppliers of commercial wall covering in the United States. Tony will be sorely missed by all of us at Wolf Gordon and by everyone dealing with our company as much for his warmth and upbeat personality, as for his expertise in our field. We personally have lost a special friend. Mel, Bernie, Rick, David, and Rob.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday comparing auto makers' United States sales in April reported outdated data. A corrected chart appears today on page D10.

title: Personal Shopper; So the Thought Can Linger On
description: ON Sunday, consider giving Mom something that will last longer than three days: fashionable fakes -- the silk variety, which hark back to the Art Deco 1930's. ''A little fake here and there is O.K.,'' said Mario Buatta, who shops at Arnie Weissman's Silk Gardens and Trees. Mr. Weissman, whose display is shown top right, calls his wares ''furniture accessories.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBBERS, WILLIAM HERMAN
description: LUBBERS-William Herman, 78. Died Saturday, April 25 in Savannah, GA. Memorial services will be held 11:00 AM, Saturday, May 9 at St. Michael's Catholic Church on North Street, Greenwich, CT.

title: National News Briefs; Rerun of Teamster Vote Is Proposed for September
description: The court-appointed official overseeing the teamsters' union election to fill out the term of its suspended president today proposed that the voting begin on Sept. 14.

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Dismisses Parallels to Nixon Case
description: President Clinton had a slight, and slightly annoyed, smile on his face today as he dismissed a question comparing his efforts to invoke executive privilege to the unsuccessful effort to do so by Richard M. Nixon.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: A QUAKE STILL FELT -- San Francisco's oldest art museum, the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum, is making an artful attempt to stave off the awful consequences of the 1989 earthquake that badly damaged the building, a depository of some of the nation's finest examples of American art.

title: The Surest Sign Of Spring: Tours
description: THE sounds of hammers banging, guidebooks rustling and choruses of ''Such exquisite woodwork!'' and ''Are those perennials?'' are in the air. This is the season for house and garden tours, most of them benefits for preservation groups, schools or social-service organizations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 28 about Martin E. P. Seligman, the new president of the American Psychological Association, misidentified one university that participated in a pivotal meeting of psychology department chairmen 65 years ago. It was the University of Pennsylvania, not Pennsylvania State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, LYDIA
description: HERZ-Lydia. P.E.F. Israel Endowment Funds, Inc. mourns the loss of one of our early supporters who established a fund for philanthropy in Israel, as a measure of her devotion to the Jewish people and the State of Israel. We offer our condolences to her family. Sydney Luria, B. Harrison Frankel, and the Board of P.E.F.

title: Sports of The Times; Reed's Return Not the Same As Ewing's
description: WHENEVER the Knicks played the Nets during the season, Willis Reed would stop to say hello to Patrick Ewing.

title: A Big Investor Stands to Get A Huge Payoff
description: Kirk Kerkorian is known as a reclusive billionaire who does not talk much to investors or the press. But if he did, he would certainly be entitled to say, ''I told you so.''

title: Tate & Lyle Agrees To Buy Bayer Food Unit
description: Tate & Lyle P.L.C. agreed yesterday to buy the food ingredients division of Bayer A.G.'s Haarmann & Reimer unit for $219 million to become the only global producer of citric acid. The British sugar maker already supplies molasses and dextrose used in making citric acid, and it says it will be able to cut production costs by combining the two businesses. The acquired units supply about 20 percent of the world's citric acid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, ETHEL S.
description: EPSTEIN-Ethel S., 83. Died at her home in Manhattan on May 4. Wife of the late Benjamin Epstein. Mother of Ellen Howe and David and Kate Epstein. Aunt of Thomas J. Schwarz. Grandmother of Benjamin, Caroline and Louis Howe and Lillian, Grace and Raphael Epstein. Service Friday, 12:30PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Contributions in her name may be sent to the Scholarship Funds of Deerfield Academy and the Groton School.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Defense Minister Gojko Susak of Croatia incorrectly located the University of Waterloo, for which he helped raise money during a period in which he lived in Canada. It is in Waterloo, Ontario, not London, Ontario.

title: Corrections
description: A profile in Public Lives on Tuesday about George Trescher, who organizes society parties and fund-raising galas, misstated the nickname of Kathleen Kennedy, who was a sister of John F. Kennedy. It was Kick, not Kit.

title: Subway Announcements Still Poor, a Study Finds
description: Despite promises to work on the problem, the Transit Authority has failed to improve its system of communicating with riders on trains, with many announcements either nonexistent or too garbled to understand, according to a study released yesterday by a riders' advocacy group.

title: Civility in the Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: J. Gordon Lippincott, 89, Dies; Pioneer Design Consultant
description: J. Gordon Lippincott, who helped design the Campbell soup label, the Tucker automobile and the interior of the Nautilus nuclear submarine before pioneering the new field of corporate identity, died on April 29 at his home in North Haven. Conn. He was 89.

title: Currents; GALLERIES -- Sipping Tea, Soaking Up Art
description: Chelsea may be chockablock with galleries, but it is short on soigne hangouts for those who need a break from esthetic overload. Sensing a vacuum, the gallery owner Max Protetch has leased 500 square feet of his space at 22d Street and 10th Avenue to Inez Sun for a tearoom furnished with artworks.

title: Rights Group Accuses Mexico's Security Forces in Disappearances
description: Policemen and soldiers are increasingly involved in the disappearance of detainees in Mexico, the human rights organization Amnesty International said in a report issued today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSACK, YVONNE
description: CUSACK-Yvonne. Died peacefully in New York at her home on Tuesday, May 5, in the company of her beloved husband of 46-1/2 years, Maurice. The members of the Board of The Spanish Institute express their deepest condolence. Yvonne, a dear friend of the Institute and of all things Spanish, travelled frequently with her husband to Spain and Iberoamerica. She will be very much missed by all her many friends.

title: A Pentagon Report Now Belittles the Menace Posed by Cuba
description: This just in from the Pentagon: Cuba is not, after all, much of a threat to national security.

title: Chances There, Goals Are Not
description: The MetroStars needed a finisher tonight. After failing to get a shot on goal in the first half against the Dallas Burn, the MetroStars took the offensive in the second, but having too many creators and too few scorers doomed them to a 1-0 defeat at Giants Stadium.

title: Essay; 'U.S. v. Clinton'
description: Thanks to a leak from ''lawyers familiar with the decision,'' we think that a judge has found President Clinton's attempt to place himself above the criminal law to be unconstitutional. Yet Federal Judge Norma Holloway Johnson will not let us hear the arguments, or see the briefs, or even read her decision.

title: N.A.S.D. Ponders Move to New York City
description: As part of its effort to challenge the New York Stock Exchange as the most important financial market in the world, the National Association of Securities Dealers is considering moving its headquarters and Nasdaq stock market to Manhattan from Washington, according to city officials and real estate executives.

title: HARCOURT GENERAL IN $415 MILLION DEAL FOR MOSBY
description: Harcourt General Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Mosby Inc., a publisher of professional health books and magazines, from the Times Mirror Company for $415 million. Mosby, based in St. Louis, publishes more than 3,000 books and 100 periodicals on nursing, health and medicine. It has annual revenue of about $225 million. Harcourt, based in Chestnut Hill, Mass., publishes educational and trade books, and has annual revenue of $3.7 billion. Times Mirror's holdings include Newsday and The Los Angeles Times. The Mosby acquisition is expected to raise the annual revenue of Harcourt's publishing unit to $700 million. Shares of Harcourt slipped 81.25 cents yesterday, to $52.3125, while Times Mirror rose 31.25 cents, to $62.1875.

title: Arrest of a Substitute Teacher Brings a Call for Improved Screening
description: School officials said yesterday that New York City's decentralized system for hiring substitute teachers has allowed people permanently barred from the system to return to classrooms. That practice, they said, allowed a substitute teacher -- excluded from the system after being accused of corporal punishment -- to be rehired Tuesday at a Queens school, where, by the end of the day, she was charged with assaulting children with a chair.

title: Keeping Track of Employees' On-Line Voyeurism
description: WHEN 100 companies secretly tested software designed to find out what employees were doing on the Internet, 68 of the companies found that at least some workers were logging on to peep at pornography.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERNER, EMANUEL M.
description: TERNER-Emanuel M., 89. On May 5th, 1998. Cherished and beloved husband of Mathilda (nee Weisenfeld). Loving father of Nancy Behrman, Elaine Cooper and Carol Lederman, father-in-law to Stanley and Mark. Devoted grandfather of Peter (Josephine) Grayson, Alan (Kim) Mnuchin, Steven Mnuchin, Amy (Jeff) Verschleiser & Judy Lederman. Adoring great grandfather of Bradley Louis Grayson. Dear brother of Selma Slater. Friends may call Thursday evening 6-8PM. Services Friday, May 8, at 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fashionable Place to Be: A Supermodel's Site On Line
description: If you are looking for style and fashion insights, but not necessarily on a style and fashion CD-ROM, the supermodel Niki Taylor is extending an invitation to visit her house, the Fashion House With Niki Taylor on line.

title: A Compromise Over Vetoes Proves Elusive
description: Despite signals that Gov. George E. Pataki is willing to talk about reversing some of his budget vetoes, Democrats in the Legislature have rebuffed his overtures, and a growing number of state officials worry that the two sides are so far apart that a compromise might not be reached.

title: Buddha and Chickens
description: To the Editor:

title: High Hopes on Cancer; Hype Hurts Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, PHILIP
description: ISRAEL-Philip. On May 1, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Lenore, devoted father of Daniel and Louis. Cherished brother of Marcia Brenner.

title: A Mayor's Empire and a Cabby's Turf
description: They don't know it yet, but Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Mayor of New York, and David Bradford, a taxi driver, have quite a lot in common: vaulting ambition, a personal interest in speeding cabs, cameras and captive audiences.

title: Liberty Life Ends Talks With Standard Bank
description: Liberty Life Association of Africa Ltd. and the Standard Bank Investment Corporation said yesterday that they had ended merger talks after failing to agree on a price. A merger would have created South Africa's biggest company, worth more than 100 billion rand ($20 billion). Liberty Life Association's shares fell 3.4 rand, to 160, while Standard Bank Investment's stock was unchanged at 30 rand.

title: Prince of the Citi; Reed Runs Citicorp With Brains and Pragmatic Skills
description: More than two decades ago, John S. Reed, then an executive vice president with Citicorp, spent and lost hundreds of millions of dollars on newfangled banking products like automated teller machines and credit cards. Eventually, both bets paid off handsomely.

title: Tough on the Bench, Private in Life
description: Back in high school in the late 1940's in Lake Charles, La., where there were only a couple of black lawyers and no female lawyers, Normalie Holloway told her friends at the drugstore where she dipped ice cream after class that she had no time for romance; she was headed to law school.

title: TOP INVESTIGATOR FOR HOUSE PANEL LEAVES UNDER FIRE
description: The top investigator for the House inquiry into President Clinton's 1996 campaign finance practices resigned under pressure today, amid growing bipartisan criticism of his role in releasing edited tapes of Webster L. Hubbell's jailhouse conversations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEXNER, BEATRICE HUDSON
description: FLEXNER-Beatrice Hudson. Age 79. Died at home on May 4, 1998. Beloved wife of James Thomas Flexner and mother of Nellie Flexner. A memorial gathering will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: Risking Labor Trouble and Clash Of Cultures, 2 Makers Opt for Size
description: A quarter of a century ago, most auto makers were convinced that the only way to thrive was to imitate a then-wealthy General Motors and become as big as possible, producing cars of every size and shape and selling them in every market around the globe.

title: SHAPING A GLOBAL GIANT: THE CORPORATE CULTURES -- Two Auto Makers With Long Histories Attempt a Trans-Atlantic Marriage; Survivor Chrysler Viewed as Folk Hero
description: So Chrysler, the corporate equivalent of the scrappy American, is forming an odd-couple partnership with a stodgy foreigner, Daimler-Benz.

title: Continuing Education Ordered For Teachers in New Jersey
description: The State Department of Education voted unanimously today to require teachers to take 100 hours of continuing education every five years to enhance their classroom skills. Until now, New Jersey had been one of the few states that had no requirement for continuing teacher education.

title: Ewing Works Out As the Knicks Wait and Wait
description: The rest of the Knicks were trickling out and heading to the team bus, but Patrick Ewing was still working out in his white practice jersey, draped in the color the starters wear.

title: Modernism's Secret Marriage
description: WHO would think that the feminist social causes of the women's movement and the male-dominated monument building of the modern movement in architecture would have much to say to each other?

title: Currents; HOME DESIGN -- Cooking in the Library
description: Winterthur, a museum of American decorative arts, has licensed 1,600 products, from furniture and rugs to needlepoint kits. Now, there's a kitchen, too. Capitalizing on the vogue for colonial posh, Winterthur, in northern Delaware, has joined forces with Heritage Custom Kitchens, (717) 354-4011, to offer carved paneling from more than 100 period rooms (circa 1640 to 1860) for kitchens that are up to the minute in function but old as the hills in looks. Price: $45,000 to $75,000. ''Kitchens today are looking more like libraries,'' Len Casey, the president of Heritage, said. One of the first Winterthur kitchens, modeled on a 1762 room, went into Mr. Casey's house.

title: Peacetime Police for Ulster
description: Hong Kong's last British Governor, Christopher Patten, who managed the colony's return to Chinese rule, is now taking on a job that could make dealing with Beijing look easy. Mr. Patten will run an independent commission proposed by last month's peace accords to overhaul Northern Ireland's police.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROKEACH, LEO
description: ROKEACH-Leo. December 13, 1912 to May 7, 1983. We will never forget the words of Rabbi Lehrman at your funeral May 10, 1983. ''In seventy years no person ever had a bad word to say about this human being.'' As Israel celebrates fifty years of statehood, we celebrate your life, dear father. Your Loving Children, Linda, Mickey and Stevie

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We know that the quality of life we hold so dear is weighed against progress of the country. But we're paying for that progress. People raise millions to save whales and walruses and birds, but the state doesn't lift a hand to save the most precious thing in the world, a person's way of life.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, DAVID W.
description: CARTER-David W. age 71. A former Vice President of TIAACREF, passed away May 5 in Riverside, CT. He is survived by his wife Patricia, children; David, Michael, Christopher and Alison and 11 grandchildren. Memorial service will be held Saturday May 16 at 11AM, at Saint Pauls Church, Riverside, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Saint Pauls Episcopal Church Building Fund.

title: Accord Signed to Name Tribunal On Holocaust Insurance Claims
description: The last major parties to a dispute over insurance claims by Holocaust survivors and the heirs of victims said yesterday that they had signed an agreement, reached last month, to create an international tribunal to resolve the claims.

title: Samsung in Talks to Sell Units and Consolidate
description: The Samsung Group, one of South Korea's biggest industrial conglomerates, said on Wednesday that it was in talks to sell some of its units to General Electric and Hewlett-Packard as part of a move to raise $13 billion to repay debt and reduce the sprawling organization to five main businesses.

title: Turf; Midtown Courtyard That Comes Complete
description: WHICH way to the French Quarter?

title: Embarrassing, But Yankees Hardly Mind This Victory
description: They discovered the missing link of all baseball games tonight. Neither the Yankees nor the Texas Rangers wish to accept any credit for their historical find.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS 1.3 PERCENT. Japan's currency fell in reaction to drops of Asian stocks and fear that rioting in Indonesia might help worsen the region's economic problems. In New York the dollar cost 133.18 yen, up from 131.44.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPHIR, JACOB (PSHERHOIFER)
description: OPHIR-Jacob (Psherhoifer). Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Men's Club, Sisterhood and Couple's Club mourn the passing of the beloved father of their Ritual Director, Chaim Ophir, and extend heartfelt condolences to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: Astronomers Detect Immense Explosion 2d Only to Big Bang
description: Astronomers have detected a titanic explosion in the outer reaches of the cosmos -- one so violent and bright that for about 40 seconds it apparently outshone all the rest of the universe. Except for the Big Bang that is generally believed to have created the universe, no other cosmic explosion of such magnitude has ever been discovered.

title: Battle of Conservatives In Nebraska's Primary
description: From the stockyards and railroads of Omaha to the cattle-roaming flat lands of western Nebraska, this state has grown far more conservative in the 100 years since its native son William Jennings Bryan ran for President as a radical populist.

title: Lawmakers End Their Session By Increasing State Spending
description: After three years of moderate fiscal austerity, the State Legislature today wrapped up its fourth session under Gov. John G. Rowland after enacting a series of budget revisions that will lead Connecticut to surpass its spending cap for the first time since it became law in 1991.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT RISES 2.3 PERCENT. Wheat rose for a third day on fear that persistent Midwest rain could reduce the summer harvest. July contracts for soft red winter wheat rose 7 cents, to $3.16 a bushel, the highest since April 2.

title: ANACOMP ACQUIRING THE ASSETS OF A FIRST DATA DIVISION
description: Anacomp Inc., a maker of microfilm and magnetic media equipment, agreed yesterday to acquire the assets of the First Image Management Company, a division of the First Data Corporation, in a deal valued at $150 million. First Image, based in Norcross, Ga., has three businesses: the transformation of computer-generated data and images to microfilm and CD, print mail services and data-entry image- scanning services. The businesses had revenue of $219.6 million in the 1997 fiscal year. First Data is a payment-services provider based in Hackensack, N.J. Anacomp is based in Poway, Calif.

title: Chairman of Eli Lilly Announces Retirement
description: Randall L. Tobias, the chairman and chief executive of Eli Lilly & Company, announced yesterday that he would retire from the giant drug maker at the end of this year.

title: Using Adrenaline To Fight Car Theft; High-Tech Task Force Pursues And Catches Newark Thieves on Run
description: Rain as fine as pine needles had just started to lay a watery coat over South Orange Avenue on a recent Sunday afternoon, when an officer's voice crackled across the police radio. ''Black Acura, Green Jeep,'' it said, reciting letters and numbers from the two license plates. Seconds later, a dispatcher responded: ''Confirmed, 10-15,'' the code for a stolen car. ''South 19th Street,'' the officer said, alerting other units from the Essex-Union Auto Theft Task Force. The chase was on.

title: Building Web Pages Is Child's Play
description: I WAS late to embrace personal home pages, a fad that I had previously viewed with the same disdain I had for pet rocks and mood rings.

title: Technical Art That Exalts Ideas
description: WITH his studio full of wires, cranks and sprockets, Arthur Ganson is the champion of contraptions and gadgets. His artworks, predominantly metal sculptures with practical names like ''Machine With Oil'' and ''Machine With Ball Chain,'' are a tribute to poetic precision and interlocking movement, an homage to mechanism.

title: Best Habitat For a Mouse
description: Q. I teach in a children's computer lab with 20 Macintoshes. Hard-surfaced mouse pads show lots of dirt and grease; with cloth-covered ones, it seems that the mice operate smoothly longer and collect less debris. Is the rougher surface better?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, DONALD S. JR.
description: LAWRENCE-Donald S. Jr., of Croton-on-Hudson, New York, died unexpectedly May 4th at home. He was 55. He is survived by his fiance Myriam Kessler and her son Bryan; his son Donald S. Lawrence III of Littleton, MA.; his grandsons Donald IV and Joseph Lawrence of Littleton; his daughter Jessica Lawrence of Dallas, TX; his sisters Holly Sears of Boston, MA., and Sally Reksten of Quincy, MA. Don was a Senior Warden at St. Augustine's Church. He was the president of The UPP River Coalition. Don was formerly the corporate vice president of human resources for The Equitable Life Assurance Society. A wake is to be held from 2-4 and 7-9 on Thursday at the Carter Funeral Home in Croton-on-Hudson. A funeral service will be held at 1PM, on Saturday at St. Augustine's in Croton-on-Hudson. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Augustine's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELASCO, RUDY G.
description: VELASCO-Rudy G. Formerly of New York, Zurich and Manila. Died in Los Angeles of a heart attack on May 2, 1998 at age 32. Beloved companion of Scott Silbiger of Woodland Hills, CA. Interment at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Daimler-Benz of Germany Plans to Acquire Chrysler

title: LIBRARY/TEST PREPARATION; Sugarcoated Practice for the SAT and ACT
description: IN June, thousands of high-school students will spend a Saturday chewing pencil ends rather than hanging out with friends. June is the last time this spring when the SAT and ACT Assessment examinations, those rites of passage, will take place in tension-filled auditoriums nationwide. Although college admissions offices have played down the significance of the tests in recent years, students and families still look upon the torturous multiple-choice tests as hurdles designed to sort high-schoolers who get into the colleges of their dreams from those who settle for second-best. Hope springs eternal that with a little help -- from test-preparation booklets or courses or, now, from test-prep CD-ROM's -- an underdog just might get a chance at a top college, or even the Ivy League.

title: LIBRARY/TEST PREPARATION; Princeton Review Takes a Sophisticated and Edgy Tone
description: PRINCETON REVIEW INSIDE THE SAT/ACT '98(Mindscape; $20 for standard edition after $5 rebate; $40 for deluxe version after $20 rebate; Windows 3.1, 95 and Macintosh.)

title: Man Pleads Not Guilty In Slaying On Shelter I.
description: A combination of deep depression, alcohol abuse and rage over the sexual assault of an 8-year-old girl may have caused a Shelter Island man to shoot and kill the man accused of molesting the girl, a defense lawyer said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEANEY, MARTIN H. JR.
description: MEANEY-Martin H. Jr., P.E. Of Garden City, New York, on May 5th, 1998. Devoted husband of Veronica, loving father of Mary Ann McKenna, M. Jay Meaney, Erin Brew, Peter Meaney, Gerard Raskopf, Paul Raskopf, Thomas Raskopf, Andrew Raskopf, Veronica Studt, and John Raskopf. Fond brother of Maureen Connelly, Eileen Kenney, Grace Brophy, and Frank Meaney. Cherished grandfather of twenty - two. Friends may call Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Avenue, New Hyde Park, New York. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:45 A.M. at Saint Anne's R.C. Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Currents; LAMINATES -- A Boomerang for the 90's
description: The Formica Corporation has a tradition of turning to heavyweight designers to give its laminates a lift. In 1957, Raymond Loewy created the ever-optimistic boomerang pattern. So what's the next boomerang? Formica asked Laurinda Spear, a founder of the architectural firm Arquitectonica in Miami. She designed Rainforest for Rent (above, $5 a square foot), with children's cutouts superimposed on rental ads in newspapers. For information, (800) 367-6422.

title: HORIZON BANCORP HIRES FIRM TO HELP IT WEIGH OPTIONS
description: Horizon Bancorp, a bank holding company in Beckley, W. Va., said yesterday that it had hired an investment bank and was looking at possible mergers. The company's shares rose $2.25, to $34.75, giving the company a market capitalization of $318 million. Horizon said it was reviewing strategic alternatives, including ''consideration of affiliation with other like-minded community organizations'' or staying independent. The bank said it had hired Baxter Fentriss & Company to help conduct the review.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SWANN, CHRISTINE S.
description: SWANN-Christine S. Happy birthday, my beautiful best friend. I love you. Lindy

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the actor Christopher Reeve and his new book, ''Still Me,'' misstated the name of a school with which he was associated, and a correction in this space on Saturday misstated the connection. The school is Wesleyan University, not Wesleyan College. His father, the writer F. D. Reeve, is a professor at Wesleyan; the actor is a graduate of Cornell University.

title: New Perspective Helps Seles Win
description: With her father's illness giving her a new perspective on tennis, Monica Seles briefly put aside her troubles yesterday and beat Silvia Farina of Italy, 6-2, 6-1, at the Italian Open in Rome.

title: Saguramo Journal; On the Tallest Pedestal, a Man for All Georgians
description: From the upstairs study in an imposing wooden house near this small farm village, a clarion voice boomed through the Georgian consciousness a century ago and has not stopped resonating.

title: Victorious on Privilege, What Next for Starr?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voice From Budapest
description: To the Editor:

title: As Hills Fill Hollows, Some West Virginia Residents Are Fighting King Coal
description: Sylvia Weekley's family has lived here, in Pigeon Roost hollow, for so many decades that the 84-year-old matriarch no longer recalls precisely when her ancestors first arrived.

title: Back Down the Yellow Brick Road
description: Big and colorful though it might be, a spectacle like the new ''Wizard of Oz'' cannot hold a Munchkin to either the L. Frank Baum novel or the 1939 film that are its inspirations.

title: Work Begins in Newark On a Baseball Stadium
description: Describing the project as a driving force in the revitalization of the city's economy, Newark and Essex County officials broke ground yesterday on a minor-league baseball stadium in Newark.

title: Economic Scene; The Fed is trapped between expectations and reality.
description: LOW unemployment, rapid economic growth, the lowest rate of inflation in decades: what more could a Federal Reserve chairman want?

title: House Approves Cheaper Loans to Help Students and Bankers
description: The House tonight overwhelmingly passed an education bill that would make loans cheaper for millions of students but would soften the blow for banks through a new Federal subsidy.

title: Clinton Asks For Sanctions Against Starr
description: Lawyers for the President and two senior White House aides filed a sealed motion asking Judge Norma Holloway Johnson of Federal District Court to hold the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr in contempt of court for violating grand jury secrecy rules with ''flagrant leaks'' to news organizations.

title: For Black Students, A Divided Berkeley
description: To the Editor:

title: Heavyweight Has A Pro in His Corner
description: Shannon Briggs believes he could be a heavyweight world champion right now if he had received better instruction from his corner during his March 28 bout against Lennox Lewis. So he has fired his trainer, Carlos Albuerne, and hired Emanuel Steward, who was working Lewis's corner that night.

title: Labor Officials See Little to Fear in a Combination
description: Labor unions often cringe at mergers because such combinations frequently portend large-scale layoffs. But the giant unions representing auto workers in the United States and Germany see little to fear in Daimler-Benz A.G.'s acquisition of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Starr Threatens to Counter Clinton's Bid for Sanctions
description: The office of the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, threatened today to seek legal sanctions against lawyers representing President Clinton and his aides unless they withdrew a motion seeking similar penalties against Mr. Starr's office by Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELMAN, STARR S.
description: MICHELMAN-Starr S., 93. Formerly of New Rochelle, NY and Long Boat Key, FL. In Lenox, MA, on May 7. Beloved mother of James H. Michelman and his wife Enid of New Marlboro, MA., and Frank I. Michelman and his wife Ellen of Lexington, MA. Motherin-law of Peggy Michelman of Armonk, NY. Grandmother of 11, great-grandmother of 17. Services Monday, May 11 at 10:30 AM in Temple Anshe Amunim, Pittsfield, MA. Donations to Hospice Care in the Berkshires, care of HickeyBirches Funeral Home, 33 South Street, Great Barrington, MA 01230

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERSMITH, RALPH
description: COOPERSMITH - Ralph. The Board of Directors of the Henry Kaufmann Camp Grounds mourns the passing of Ralph Coopersmith, the father of Jeffrey Coopersmith, our Executive Director. We offer our heartfelt condolence to his wife and his family.

title: Racial 'Profiling' at Crux of Inquiry Into Shooting by Troopers
description: The police, among themselves, call it ''profiling,'' making a traffic stop of someone they believe likely to be involved in the drug trade. African-Americans give it another another name, ''D.W.B.'' -- Driving While Black.

title: Sports of The Times; Looking More Rusty Than Ready
description: WEARING his Knicks uniform last night for the first time in nearly five months, Patrick Ewing had a blue wrap on his right wrist that might as well have been a target bull's-eye.

title: Productivity Grows at Slowest Pace Since '96
description: Worker productivity grew at the slowest pace in more than a year in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today, reflecting a surge in hours employees spent on the job and acute shortages of job applicants.

title: Select Communications Picks Up Jordache
description: Jordache Enterprises in New York said yesterday that it had named Select Communications in New York to handle advertising for its Jordache jeans account, which was previously handled in-house and by agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $10 million. The decision came after a six-month review that included two other New York agencies, Arnell Group Brand Consulting and Lipman, Richmond, Greene.

title: CHASE TO BUY CUSTODY UNIT FROM MORGAN STANLEY
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the custody unit of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company to help increase Chase's profits in the low-margin business of processing trades and keeping track of investors' holdings. Chase, the biggest United States bank, paid about $600 million for the unit, sources close to the negotiations said. Morgan Stanley, the largest United States securities firm by capital, said last month that it was in talks to sell the business. The Morgan Stanley unit has about 500 employees and is responsible for $400 billion in institutional assets. The stock of Chase Manhattan rose $1.1875 a share, to $136.25, and Morgan Stanley fell $1.0625, to $74.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, JEREMIAH J. JR.
description: O'DONNELL-Jeremiah J. Jr. On May 6, 1998. Of Hilton Head, S.C. Formerly of Bronxville, New York. Husband of the late Joan F. O'Donnell. Father of Patricia Ann Halliday, Jeremiah J. O'Donnell, III, Deirdre Anne Rajkowski, John M. O'Donnell, Joan Anne Buhrendorf, & Betsy Perry. Grandfather of 11. Brother of Mary P. Holden, Virginia DeLuca, Nancy Jennings and Barbara Quinn. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. Monday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Tuesday, May 12 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the local American Cancer Society.

title: Daimler and Chrysler Trade Vows Before Complex Union
description: ''Today, we are creating the world's leading automotive company for the 21st century,'' said Jurgen E. Schrempp, chairman of Daimler-Benz A.G. ''DaimlerChrysler Aktiengesellschaft.''

title: Remains of Vietnam Serviceman Ordered Exhumed From Tomb of Unknowns
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen ordered the reopening of the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia today so that the remains of a serviceman who died in Vietnam can be removed, tested and, very likely, identified.

title: For Black Students, A Divided Berkeley
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENEN, AUSTIN
description: KOENEN-Austin. On May 2, 1998. Survived by his wife, Kathleen and three children - Karestan, Erin and Austin Junior. The viewing will be held on Friday, May 8th from 3:00 P.M. to 9 P.M. at the M. John Scanlan Funeral Home, 781 Newark Pompton Turnpike, Pompton Plains, New Jersey. Services will be held on Saturday, May 9, 10:00am at the Jacksonville Chapel located in Lincoln Park, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, the Koenen family has requested donations directed to Outward Bound in Rockland, Maine, the American Heart Association (800634-1242) or the Good Shepherd Mission (973-742-9244).

title: Vickers Says It Will Now Accept VW Bid for Rolls
description: Switching suitors, Vickers P.L.C. of Britain announced yesterday that it had accepted a $710 million bid from Volkswagen A.G. for Rolls-Royce Motor Cars -- just eight days after it embraced a lower offer from the rival, BMW A.G.

title: Touring the Heart's Own Brooklyn
description: It has always seemed both exciting and practical to take a sightseeing bus tour through a strange city, as I have done many times. But a bus tour through my lost youth? Now there's a trip I wouldn't miss for the world, I thought, when New York Apple Tours announced its first foray into my native Brooklyn. Not that the red-and-yellow, double-decker, retired London buses would roll through Midwood, where I grew up, nor around Coney Island and Sheepshead Bay, where I spent summers. But there were more than enough landmarks of my childhood to make me want to hear them described with little jokes and factoids.

title: Sybil Connolly, 77, Irish Designer Who Dressed Jacqueline Kennedy
description: Sybil Connolly, who designed the linen dress that Jacqueline Kennedy wore in her White House portrait and who elevated Irish style to high fashion, died on Wednesday at her home in Dublin. She was 77.

title: Batted Balls Cause Rash Of Injuries To Pitchers
description: Larry Rothschild, former pitcher and pitching coach, has some advice for pitchers: ''Pitch inside and don't hang breaking balls.''

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; Retro Razzle-Dazzle: Chrome Comes Back
description: FOR a decade or more, bright trim has been in short supply in the auto showroom. Now, like platform shoes being liberated from the back of the closet, chrome is coming back.

title: Alan Simpson, 85, President Of Vassar in Transition, Dies
description: Alan Simpson, the president of Vassar College in the turbulent 1960's and 70's whose easygoing charm, wit and scholarship helped him weather not only a time of student protest but also the admission of men to the all-women school, died on Tuesday at Lake Forest Hospital in Lake Forest, Ill. He was 85.

title: Ewing Starts, but Pacers Have the Endgame
description: This was an awkward moment for the Knicks. They were watching Patrick Ewing make a grand, albeit graceless, entrance after five months of grueling rehabilitation.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Well, I guess this does away with all the 'Buy American' talk.''

title: What Two Big Auto Makers Bring to the Table
description: DaimlerChrysler would combine Daimler-Benz's force in research, advanced technology and rear-wheel drive cars with Chrysler's speedy product development, design expertise and front-wheel drive prowess. Here are some of the companies' individual strengths.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Business Digest yesterday with a summary of an article about a management change at Eli Lilly & Company was published in error. It showed Randall L. Tobias, the company's current chairman and chief executive, not Sidney Taurel, who will succeed him.

title: Airline Safety Improved
description: To the Editor:

title: ENVIROTEST HIRES INVESTMENT BANK TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
description: The Envirotest Systems Corporation said yesterday that it had hired the investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. to explore a possible sale or other alternatives. Envirotest, which makes equipment to evaluate car exhaust, wants to determine whether reorganizing its business or enlisting a buyer or partner with more financial resources will bring quicker gains in market share, a spokesman said. States use Envirotest systems to insure that cars meet pollution standards. Shares of Envirotest, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose $2, or 18.69 percent, to $12.75, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: What Killed Artificial Turf? A Mystery at Giants Stadium
description: No one knows what ate the brand-new $1.2 million artificial turf at Giants Stadium last year.

title: Six Set to Run In the Preakness
description: Only six horses were listed as definite starters in the $1 million Preakness Stakes on May 16, the second race in the Triple Crown series, but officials at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore said yesterday that they hoped four others would join the field.

title: Political Briefing; Their Place Is In the House (at 1600)
description: Under a headline that mused, ''A Female for President?'' The Harrisburg (Pa.) Patriot said the other day that ''it is becoming increasingly apparent that both major parties are going to have to confront the problem of the all-male Presidential club, sooner rather than later.'' Then, in the time-honored tradition of American politics, the paper took unto itself the role of ''the great mentioner'' and mentioned ''some interesting comers.''

title: Self-Portrait of an Artist With Customary Elan
description: THE TIME OF OUR TIME.

title: Senate Committee Rejects Plan for New Round of Base Closings
description: The Clinton Administration lost a pivotal Senate committee vote today in its effort to close more military bases, despite warnings from the Pentagon that keeping unneeded bases open was sapping resources for troops and weapons.

title: SALTON/MAXIM TO BUY BACK SHARES FROM WINDMERE
description: Salton/Maxim Housewares Inc. agreed yesterday to buy back the 6.5 million shares of its majority holder, Windmere-Durable Holdings Inc., for $93 million. Salton, based in Mount Prospect, Ill., will purchase the shares for $12 each in cash plus a $15 million promissory note, valuing the purchase at $14.27 a share. In July 1996, Windmere acquired 50 percent of the outstanding shares of Salton and controlled half its board. Salton, a maker of Farberware pots and pans and small kitchen and bath appliances, said that if it did not buy the shares, Windmere, based in Miami Lakes, Fla., would have the right to acquire the remaining Salton shares at $14.27 each. The stock slipped 75 cents yesterday, to $12.3125.

title: Europe Turning To U.S. to Fight Illicit Cigarettes
description: European governments, increasingly frustrated by the rising volume of American cigarettes smuggled into Europe, have decided to turn to Washington for help in investigating the suspected involvement of American tobacco companies, starting with the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, a senior European Union official said today.

title: Some Cross-Border Deals May Be Star-Crossed
description: They seem so smart and easy.

title: 2 Sentenced in Mexican Peddling Ring
description: A mother and daughter who helped lead a ring that forced deaf Mexicans to peddle trinkets in the subway and on the streets were sentenced to prison yesterday and ordered to pay $1.5 million in restitution to about 50 of the exploited workers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PG&E CORP., San Francisco, said its PG&E Energy Services unit had won a $120 million contract to sell electricity and energy consulting services to the Rite Aid Corp., of Camp Hill, Pa., a drugstore chain.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: In Free Markets, Just Who Is Free?; Price of Joblessness
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Television; Officer's Last Harangue
description: Taunting a suspect handcuffed to a desk in last week's ''Homicide: Life on the Streets,'' Detective Meldrick Lewis (Clark Johnson) tossed potato chips at the man's head and said his name three times. Maybe he just couldn't resist repeating one of the great names for a punk criminal: ''Junior Bunk, Junior Bunk, Junior Bunk.'' Such small touches are as carefully wrought as the murder plots on ''Homicide,'' and sometimes those small touches explode. Grabbing a gun from an officer's desk, Junior Bunk shot up the squad room in an act that led directly to tonight's gripping season finale (at 10 on NBC).

title: Contenders For the Tonys
description: The newly ended Broadway season had many twists and surprises, but the outcome is about what everyone thought it would be back when the season began last summer: the two big musicals fighting it out for the Tony appear to be Livent's ''Ragtime'' and Disney's ''Lion King.''

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Cecily Rose Brown

title: Auto Insurer Is Fined In Effort to Leave Market
description: The General Accident Insurance Company, the state's 10th largest auto insurer, must pay a fine of $550,500 to settle charges that it turned away eligible customers in an effort to leave New Jersey's insurance market illegally. It was the largest fine imposed on an auto insurer in New Jersey, state officials said yesterday.

title: Microsoft Created Its Own Problems, Justice Dept. Says
description: In a strongly worded court brief filed today, the Justice Department argued that the Microsoft Corporation had known for months that its legal problems with the Government might delay the release of its Windows 98 operating system, due to be released next week. But Microsoft deliberately waited until the last minute to ask a court for protection, Government lawyers charged, so the company could make ''a self-generated claim of hardship.''

title: Federal Judge Bars New York's Method of Classifying Sex Offenders
description: Concluding that New York State's system of classifying sex offenders under ''Megan's Law'' is unconstitutional, a Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the state cannot release detailed information on 6,400 offenders unless those offenders are given the chance to have new hearings.

title: In Demand: Fine-Art Photography
description: The New York City collector Gary Wolkowitz buys vintage modernist prints made between the wars. Sydney and Audrey Irmas restrict themselves to photographers' self-portraits. Dr. Stanley Burns buys early medical photography. Others buy landscapes, fashion spreads and works by Russian Revolutionaries. One connoisseur collects images of hands. A California developer buys pictures only of buildings he could own.

title: Democrats Fault Pataki on Education and the Economy
description: Speaking almost in unison, four of the Democratic candidates seeking to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki assailed his economic and education policies last night, belittling his first-term tax cuts as a waste of money and attacking him for vetoing spending that would have gone to rebuilding public schools.

title: Agency Orders Emergency Check of Wiring in Older 737's to End Spark Threat
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an urgent order to airlines yesterday to inspect the wiring of their older Boeing 737's after learning that sparks from a high-voltage power line in the wing tank of a Continental Airlines plane had burned holes in the surrounding conduit and allowed jet fuel to leak in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWSTUTER, DONALD E.
description: LOWSTUTER-Donald E. Died April 22, 1998 in New York City. His friends will miss that special style, wit and knowledge that made him unique. A memorial service and interment will be held at the Columbarium of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC on Thursday, May 28 at 5 P.M.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Disco Nights Of Studio 54 Studio 54 is back at least in the movies.

title: The Dan Burton Problem
description: By now even Representative Dan Burton ought to recognize that he has become an impediment to a serious investigation of the 1996 campaign finance scandals. He has dismissed David Bossie, the mischievous aide who helped issue inaccurate transcripts of Webster Hubbell's jailhouse conversations, and has apologized to his fellow Republicans. But that cannot compensate for inept behavior that has hobbled the inquiry and complicated Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr's criminal investigation of intriguing comments on the tapes. If the House inquiry is to be responsible, someone else on Mr. Burton's committee should run it.

title: Beware of Flaming Germans
description: There must be an unseen seventh member of the German techno-metal band Rammstein; he would be the full-time fire consultant. During the band's show at the Roxy on Wednesday night, the vocalist Til Lindemann sang with arms outstretched in a flaming chain-mail tunic; at other points, fire and sparks shot out from his boots, his microphone, his gloves, and his oversize flame-shooting machine gun.

title: The New Math Of Big Mergers Has a Number Of Solutions
description: Perhaps it is a reflection of the exuberant stock market, which places ever-higher valuations on anything that trades. Or maybe it demonstrates how many Americans -- even American journalists -- struggle with math. But once again, a big American company is being taken over and few people agree on how much the deal is worth.

title: A Federal Turf War Over Derivatives Control
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is seeking public comments as it re-evaluates its regulatory approach to the lucrative, and freewheeling, global derivatives market, in a move that promises to ignite a bitter turf war in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB SLUTZKY, BEATRICE GINS.
description: GOLDFARB SLUTZKY-Beatrice Gins. May 6. Beloved wife of Solomon Slutzky and Jerry Goldfarb, dear mother of Marilyn & Karen. Loving grandmother of Danny, Teddy, Julie, Sarah and Jake. Dear great grandmother of Joseph. Dear sister of Milton and Evelyn. Beloved aunt & friend. A joyous heart and generous spirit. Funeral at 11 AM, Sunday, May 9, Garlick Funeral Home, 186 Broadway, Monticello, New York.

title: Central Bank Deputy Assesses Japan Rate Cut
description: The deputy governor of the Bank of Japan and a member of its policy board, Yutaka Yamaguchi, said yesterday that a cut in the discount rate, which is now 0.5 percent, would have a positive effect on the economy, though the central bank would not consider any change in the rate before assessing the effect of Government measures for the economy. A central bank official who attended a meeting with lawmakers quoted Mr. Yamaguchi as saying, ''Over all, I think the positive effects would be larger than the negative effects.''

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with a front-page article about the planned merger between Daimler-Benz and the Chrysler Corporation referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of cars Chrysler sold in Europe last year. It was 19,244 (94,250 was the number of cars and light trucks sold).

title: Beguiled By the Past
description: ''I should have gone to an acting school, that seems clear,'' sings Ann Miller, without a flicker of apologetic cuteness, in the thrilling new revival of Stephen Sondheim's 1971 musical ''Follies'' at the Paper Mill Playhouse. ''Still, someone said, 'She's sincere,' so I'm here.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: David Scher

title: Hill & Knowlton and Sunbeam to Split
description: Hill & Knowlton, the public relations firm for the Sunbeam Corporation, has notified the company that it will no longer represent it, according to a person close to Sunbeam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HEIDI
description: FRIEDMAN-Heidi. On behalf of all cooperators, the Board of Directors of 975 Park Avenue wish to express our condolences on the passing of our beloved neighbor and friend to all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLLMAN, PHILLIP
description: STOLLMAN-Phillip. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn with great sorrow the passing of a founding father and guiding light of our University, Phillip Stollman. A visionary leader, he was a founding patron of Bar-Ilan in 1955 and, in the more than four decades since, has forged a cherished link between the Stollman Family and our University. Phillip, along with his brother and sister-in-law, Max and Frieda (z''l), and his family, has contributed immeasurably to the growth and development of BarIlan. The benefactor of several important campus facilities, including the Stollman Dormitory, Stollman Administration Building, Stollman Laboratory Floor in the Cancer Research Building, and the Stollman Garden, he and his family have supported Bar-Ilan's Exodus Scholarship program, the Slomovitz Program in Public Communication, and the University's Cancer, Aids and immunology Research (CAIR) Institute. Phillip Stollman was the first and longtime chairman of the University's Global Board of Trustees, an honorary chairman for several decades more, a Bar-llan Presidential Founder, and the recipient of an honorary doctorate degree from the University. His commitment to Israel and the Jewish people was reflected in his involvement with myriad Jewish causes and as a leader in his home community of Detroit, MI. His legacy of leadership, sterling philanthropic spirit, gentle speech and compassionate nature will inspire generations to come. We express heartfelt condolences to his son and daughter-in-law, Dr. Gerald and Leila Stollman, his daughters Shirley, Annette and Rochelle, his nephew and niece, Bernard and Barbara Stollman, as well as to his numerous grandchildren, greatgrandchildren and other beloved family members. May they draw solace from inspiring memories and may they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman Chancellor Bar-Ilan University Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President Bar-Ilan University Selik Wengrowsky, Chairman Bar-Ilan Global Bd of Trustees Charles Dimston, Chairman of the Board American Friends of Bar-Ilan Melvin Stein, President American Friends of Bar-Ilan Brig. Gen. (Res.) Yehuda Halevy Executive Vice President Bar-Ilan University

title: For Black Students, A Divided Berkeley
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUICKSHANK, JILL GORHAM.
description: CRUICKSHANK-Jill Gorham. On May 5, 1998. Loving aunt of Ilisa Barbash of Berkeley, CA., and Thomas Barbash of Menlo Park, California. Cherished sister of the late Heather Livingston Barbash, beloved daughter of the late Blanche Livingston Glickman and Ira Livingston. She is also survived by numerous loving cousins and friends. A composer and playwright, she also wrote music for Sesame Street.

title: Brawling, Humiliation And Theft, All on the First Date
description: With her blazing smile and insolent swivel, Jada Pinkett Smith radiates as much crackling charisma per centimeter as any young Hollywood star. But the energy and sass that have spiced up movies like ''The Nutty Professor'' and ''Set It Off'' are recklessly squandered in ''Woo,'' an incoherent romantic comedy whose sexy title character (played by Ms. Smith) is an unbearable, unfunny pain in the neck.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Netherlands Investment Group Seeks Weiss, Peck & Greer
description: The Robeco Group, a Netherlands investment group, is buying Weiss, Peck & Greer L.L.C. for about $400 million. It will also make further payments of up to $200 million over the next five years depending on the future profits of the New York investment firm.

title: Young Woman Is Found Slain In Queens Park
description: Police investigators are trying to find out who killed a young woman whose bullet-punctured body was discovered yesterday morning at the edge of Cunningham Park in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: SENATE VOTES 97-0 TO OVERHAUL I.R.S. AFTER COMPLAINTS
description: With horror stories from taxpayers and complaints about the tax code's ever-increasing complexity echoing through the chamber, the Senate voted 97 to 0 today for legislation to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service and make it more friendly to citizens.

title: Audit Time at the Apollo
description: The Apollo Theater was Harlem's golden stage, a place where ''stars are born and legends are made,'' including such musical Olympians as Ella Fitzgerald, Lionel Hampton, Nat (King) Cole and Diana Ross. Now the grand old establishment on 125th Street is suffering from an external shabbiness that apparently reflects deeper problems with the theater's politically prominent management.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Fun With Viagra

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LENORE
description: NEWMAN-Lenore. Died quietly at home on May 6 in her apartment in New York City. Family and friends join together in sorrow at the departure of this caring, loving person who carried her professional social work training as a way of life. She retired from Roosevelt-St. Luke's Hospital as supervising medical social worker. Lenore was proud of her volunteer work at the United Nations where after her retirement she dedicated increasing time as a representative of Economists Allied for Arms Reduction. Her surviving family include her nieces Sharon and Marla, her nephew Bernard, her grandnephews Frank and Jeremy, & her sister-in-law Janis Newman. The service will be at noon on Monday, May 11, at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, and the family will be receiving there on Sunday 6-8 P.M., and at the residence of L. Levi, 91 Central Park West (96th Street), Monday 6-8 P.M., and Tuesday 4-8 P.M. Interment will be at the Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: Detroit Is Optimistic, Despite Shock Over the Sale of One of the Big Three
description: Still stunned that his employer, Chrysler, would be acquired by Daimler-Benz, Darrell Thomas, a loyal union man, managed a brave-face smile.

title: Annan Given Cold Shoulder By Officials In Rwanda
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan came to Rwanda this evening on what he called ''a healing mission'' and admitted in a speech to Parliament that the United Nations had done too little to stop the 1994 massacres of Tutsi civilians.

title: US West Offers Service Option
description: US West Communications, sidestepping telecommunications law, will sell long-distance phone service provided by Qwest Communications International Inc.

title: Resort Is Ordered to Offer Jobs to Union Workers Let Go in '96
description: A Federal judge ruled on Wednesday that a private resort on Daufuskie Island, S.C., must offer jobs to 58 former union workers who were dismissed in 1996 when the resort changed ownership.

title: In Free Markets, Just Who Is Free?; Fed's Outdated Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, JEROME PERSHING (CONTI).
description: COHN-Jerome Pershing (Conti). Son of the late I. Dick and Mary Cohn. Survived by his loving sister Lynne Kasarsky and brother-inlaw and friend Irving, his niece Dana, nephew Steven, and great niece Rebecca. Service Sunday, 10AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapel,'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck.

title: A Booklet Tells the French to Be Nice
description: With about a month to get ready for the World Cup, the biggest event in the world's most popular spectator sport, soccer, France has spiffed up tens of thousands of hotel rooms, taught surly taxi drivers to say, ''Sank you, veri meutch,'' to English-speaking visitors, and built a futuristic $450 million stadium on the outskirts of Paris for the June 10 opening match.

title: Hearing Bach and Shostakovich in Conversation
description: If Bach was considered old-fashioned by some in his day, the contemporaries of Shostakovich must have thought even worse of him when, in 1951, he unveiled his Opus 87, 24 preludes and fugues for piano, obviously modeled on Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier.'' So obviously, in fact, that Olli Mustonen, a bright young Finnish pianist, will mix and match works from the Bach and Shostakovich collections on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, in the first and most provocative of his three programs exploring the connections between the composers.

title: New Video Releases
description: Tomorrow Never Dies

title: Minnesota, Tobacco and Insurer Reach Terms to Settle Suit
description: Negotiators for Minnesota, the tobacco industry and an insurer reached general agreement late last night on the terms of an out-of-court settlement of the state's landmark case and barring a last-minute hitch could announce a settlement today.

title: S.E.C. Chooses a New Chief Accountant
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission named Lynn Turner today as its new chief accountant, one of the most powerful and contentious positions in the accounting industry.

title: Mergers Help Fuel a Two-Tier Global Auto Hierarchy
description: The global auto industry is increasingly divided into two tiers, as a half-dozen giant companies prosper while many of their smaller rivals struggle to manage heavy debts or afford the ever-rising cost of designing new cars.

title: Calcavecchia Takes First-Round Lead
description: Mark Calcavecchia shot a seven-under-par 65 despite a three-and-a-half-hour rain delay to take the first-round lead at the Bell South Classic yesterday at Duluth, Ga.

title: For Black Students, A Divided Berkeley
description: To the Editor:

title: Portrait of an Imagist By a Like-Minded Artist
description: The avant-garde has found a new pastime. Whether it is Joanne Akalaitis creating a resume in sound and movement of the career of Jack Kerouac in ''Ti-Jean Blues'' at the Actors Theater of Louisville, Ky., or Robert Lepage taking stock of Frank Lloyd Wright in his ''Geometry of Miracles'' at the du Maurier festival in Toronto, stage directors who specialize in arresting images suddenly seem to have developed a passion for, of all things, biography.

title: Bronx Teacher Is Accused of Locking Teen-Agers in Room Near School Gym
description: A classmate tried to sexually assault a 13-year-old girl last week after a teacher at their Bronx school locked them with other students in a weight room for misbehaving, the police and school officials said.

title: Political Briefing; This Boxer Is Favored To Retain Her Title
description: Almost from the day she was elected back in 1992, Senator Barbara Boxer has had to contend with speculation that her rock-solid Democratic liberalism would ultimately turn out to be a bad political fit in California, with election to a second term an uphill struggle. But the hill doesn't seem so steep as it once did.

title: In Free Markets, Just Who Is Free?
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Restless New York eaters, hungry for the very latest thing, can't seem to get enough of Hiroshi Nakahara's inventive sushi. They sat like acolytes before him at the old T Salon in SoHo, and now they are flocking to the new Bond St., eager to taste his sashimi served on ice, his tuna sushi topped with edible gold leaf and his bamboo-wrapped fluke. ''Ahh,'' they cry, astonished, when he serves them sea bass sashimi topped with cod roe and set on a sorbet of fennel and oba leaf.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Anish Kapoor

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Edison Schools Are Unimpressive, A Union Maintains
description: When the Edison Project, the for-profit educational venture, took over the first of its 25 public schools in 1995, it enjoyed the guarded support of the nation's second-largest teachers union, the American Federation of Teachers. The two organizations pledged to share data and two of the union chapters, in Dade County, Fla., and Wichita, Kan., negotiated contractual waivers with Edison that smoothed its debut.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Tom Sachs

title: Shaping America's Self-Image
description: ''Masters of Color and Light: Homer, Sargent and the American Watercolor Movement,'' at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, is a springtime-heading-into-summer show. The pace is leisurely, the effects generally quiet. Occasional rumbles of thunder intrude, but on the whole skies are sunny, the esthetic atmosphere settled and calm.

title: Expressing Their Playful Inner Animal
description: The child in all of us will revel in ''Instinct,'' a mischievous new duet that David Parsons has choreographed for himself and Vladimir Malakhov, a guest from American Ballet Theater who is appearing with the Parsons Dance Company at City Center.

title: Hospital and Employee Are Cited in Death of Boy
description: State officials investigating the death of an 11-year-old boy who suffocated while being restrained at a private psychiatric hospital have concluded that the actions of a worker were abusive, and that the hospital itself was negligent in its staff training.

title: Investor Offers Saab Stake to Holders
description: Investor A.B. of Sweden said yesterday that it would offer shareholders 44.8 percent of the capital and 29 percent of the votes in its Saab A.B. warplane unit through warrants. Investor, the main financial vehicle of the Wallenberg empire, said earlier this year that it was considering a stock offering for the company, the unprofitable maker of the JAS 39 Gripen fighter. Last week, British Aerospace P.L.C. bought a 35 percent stake in Saab for 3.5 billion kronor ($450 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROFF, SANDRA
description: OSTROFF-Sandra. The Directors and Staff of YIVO are saddened by the loss of Sandra Ostroff, daughter of our esteemed Board Member Harold Ostroff. We extend our deepest condolences to the Ostroff family and mourn with you at this time of painful loss. May Sandra's memory be for a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Tom L. Freudenheim Executive Director YIVO Institute for Jewish Research

title: For Black Students, A Divided Berkeley
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFITH, BRUCE P.
description: GRIFFITH-Bruce P. Devoted husband of Antoinette (nee Moore). Beloved father of Kurt. Loving brother of Ramona Crosby. Cherished grandfather of Alexander and Nicholas. Funeral Saturday, at 11 A.M., from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Bklyn. Service Saturday, 10 AM. Cremation, Greenwood Cemetery. Visiting hours Friday 7-10 PM.

title: In Free Markets, Just Who Is Free?; The Other Unemployed
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Cindy Sherman

title: Dark Underside of Polish Family Life: Violence
description: In the beginning, Bozena L. felt flattered by the attention her new husband showered on her. He walked her to work, picked her up afterward and was always concerned about where she went. In the style of many Polish men who love to act like gallant knights, he bowed his head and kissed women on the hand.

title: Slight Increase in Rents Proposed
description: In a hearing marked by little of the chaos and ear-splitting acrimony of years past, the Rent Guidelines Board recommended last night that landlords in New York City be able to charge slightly more for rent-stabilized apartments and lofts beginning in October.

title: Not So Innocent After All: Works With a Sweetly Nasty Streak
