description: Call it the ''Applebroog effect'': a disquieting collision between something apparently innocent and something vaguely nasty.

title: Library of Congress to Buy Graham Dance Archive
description: The Library of Congress has agreed to an ambitious plan to preserve the artistry of the dancer and choreographer Martha Graham.

title: Life Lessons As Principal For a Day
description: ONE of the lessons quickly learned as Principal for a Day yesterday at Intermediate School 125 in Woodside, Queens, is that anyone can do it. What takes a brave heart, certainly braver than the one God gave a newspaper columnist, is to be Principal for a Second Day.

title: Police Say Man Killed Girl Who Rejected His Advances
description: A 19-year-old man from Long Beach has been charged with murdering a 16-year-old girl who rejected his advances, the police said today.

title: Critics Fear Role of Politics in CUNY Plan
description: As the battle lines formed Wednesday over the fate of remedial education at the City University of New York, it was becoming increasingly clear that the larger issues at stake were CUNY's tradition of open access and political control at a college system that has educated generations of New Yorkers.

title: The 'Madding Crowd' Is Getting Crowded
description: Sitting down to a ''Masterpiece Theater'' rendition of a Thomas Hardy novel can feel oddly like confronting an unwelcome exam. Reading the book was wonderful; you were captivated by the all-too-human characters and the sweep of great riddles of destiny set against the quaint scapes of 19th-century Dorset. But now, try as you might to sit back and enjoy, you find yourself having to dissect and compare, to judge what works and what doesn't in approximating brilliantly written prose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDEN, ASHER PAUL
description: EDEN-Asher Paul. On May 4, 1998. Memorial service Saturday May 16, 2-5PM at the Lesbian and Gay Community Center, 208 West 13th Street, New York City. Deeply loved, greatly missed, in our hearts forever.

title: Another Sister Showdown for Williamses
description: Oracene Williams wore her usual uniform, a warm-up suit and sneakers, to the Italian Open today, which was altogether appropriate.

title: Police Make an Arrest In 15-Year-Old Murder
description: When the police found Michael Chen's body in March 1983 in the lobby of a Chinatown savings and loan, they had no leads and no witnesses. They attributed his murder to a rival gang exacting revenge for the killing of three of its members.

title: Retail, 1990's Wallflower, Finally Dances
description: American retailers reported their best monthly sales gains in four years yesterday, capping one of the healthiest quarters of retail sales in almost a decade. Sales in retail stores open at least a year rose 10.2 percent in April, according to the Goldman Sachs Retail Composite Index.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALTBY, MYRNA
description: MALTBY-Myrna. On May 6, 1998. Loving wife of the late Charles. Past officer of the Ziegfield Club. Also member of the Catholic Actors Guild. Loving cousin of Anita & Tim Trammell. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street. Services Saturday, 10 AM. Interment Hillside Cemetery, Plainfield, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, ETHEL S.
description: EPSTEIN-Ethel S., 83. Died at her home in Manhattan on May 4. Wife of the late Benjamin Epstein. Mother of Ellen Howe and David and Kate Epstein. Aunt of Thomas J. Schwarz. Grandmother of Benjamin, Caroline and Louis Howe and Lillian, Grace and Raphael Epstein. Service Friday, 12:30PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Contributions in her name may be sent to the Scholarship Funds of Deerfield Academy and the Groton School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERNER, EMANUEL M.
description: TERNER-Emanuel M., 89. On May 5th, 1998. Cherished and beloved husband of Mathilda (nee Weisenfeld). Loving father of Nancy Behrman, Elaine Cooper and Carol Lederman, father-in-law to Stanley and Mark. Devoted grandfather of Peter (Josephine) Grayson, Alan (Kim) Mnuchin, Steven Mnuchin, Amy (Jeff) Verschleiser & Judy Lederman. Adoring great grandfather of Bradley Louis Grayson. Dear brother of Selma Slater. Friends may call Thursday evening 6-8PM. Services Friday, May 8, at 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Burial service private. Donations in his memory may be made to St. Mary's Hospital, 901 45th Street, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407.

title: 2 BIG DONORS JOIN FIGHT OVER FUNDS FOR CAMPAIGNING
description: Douglas Durst, one of New York City's biggest real estate developers, has noticed recently that candidates have been beseeching him for contributions at an exasperating pace, as if his business was not building skyscrapers but rather doling out money from some bottomless political piggy bank. Sometimes, when he is solicited by officials whose decisions can influence his properties, he wonders whether his refusal to give would lead to retribution.

title: Aides Disavow Mrs. Clinton on Mideast
description: White House aides today disowned comments by Hillary Rodham Clinton about the need for a Palestinian state and insisted that she was speaking only for herself.

title: INSIDE
description: Stores Catch Up to Economy

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WESTCARR, MARILYN
description: WESTCARR-Marilyn. May 8, 1932. Passed to God before we were born. In God always loving; in God forever loved. Sisters, Shirley and Lorraine

title: Tottenham Journal; The Cross They Carry Is the Red Cross's Blunder
description: For most people, a red cross is the symbol of the international relief agency that provides help to those in need.

title: Paul Seymour, 70, Part of 1955 N.B.A. Title Team
description: Paul Seymour, a guard for the old Syracuse Nationals known for his feisty style of play, the captain of their 1955 National Basketball Association championship team and a former coach, died on Wednesday at his winter home in Jensen Beach, Fla. He was 70.

title: Vatican Stirs Skepticism on Killings
description: Having moved swiftly to give a cut-and-dried motive for the shocking killing of the commander of the Swiss Guards and his wife by a young Swiss Guard inside the Vatican on Monday night, the Holy See is now under attack for having moved a little too swiftly.

title: Daimler-Benz Takes Over Chrysler as VW Acquires Rolls-Royce: Fast Lane for German Firms
description: LONDON  German automakers moved boldly Thursday to extend their global influence as Daimler-Benz AG said it would acquire Chrysler Corp., and as Volkswagen AG won a come-from-behind bidding contest to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd., the luxury British carmaker.

title: BANCFIRST OF OKLAHOMA TO BUY AMQUEST FINANCIAL
description: The Bancfirst Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the Amquest Financial Corporation for about $117 million in stock, issuing 2.6 million shares for the purchase. As of March 31, Bancfirst, based in Oklahoma City, reported $1.5 billion in total assets and $126.5 million in equity capital, while the closely held Amquest had $568 million in assets and $52 million in equity capital. Amquest has two subsidiary banks: Amquest Bank N.A. and the Exchange National Bank and Trust Company, with offices in six Oklahoma towns. Bancfirst is Oklahoma's largest state-chartered bank, serving 36 communities. Bancfirst's stock was unchanged yesterday, at $45, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Observer; For Whom the Chains Clank
description: Why Kenneth Starr had Susan McDougal shipped in chains to Little Rock is not clear. My first guess was that he wanted to show his utter indifference to the black arts of public relations.

title: Bermuda, facing a host of competitors, rolls out a campaign to revive its tourism industry.
description: HOPING to rejuvenate its slumping tourist industry, Bermuda is trying yet another advertising campaign, its third in recent years. Tagged ''Radio Bermuda,'' it differs from the ''Bermuda Shorts'' campaign of 1990 to 1996, which sought to convey the island's many charms through wordplay, and it is also a far cry from its immediate predecessor, ''Let Yourself Go.''

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, EDITH
description: WEINGARTEN - Edith. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Loving mother of Merri and Barry Grieff and Ira Weingarten. Cherished grandmother of Jordan and Benjamin. Devoted friend. Past chairperson of Kings Bay Construction Committee. A founder and past vice president of the Public Employees Federation, AFL-CIO. Services today, 10 AM, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Ave. J).

title: Ewing's Return Is No Cure-All
description: After being sidelined four and a half months by wrist surgery, Patrick Ewing, the star center, returned to the Knicks last night, but he looked rusty and couldn't rescue them in their second-round National Basketball Association playoff series with the Indiana Pacers.

title: Cancer-Drug News Puts a Focus on Reporters and Book Deals
description: A day after an article describing the medical world's optimism about a new drug therapy for cancer was published on the front page of The New York Times, agents for two reporters circulated book proposals among publishers.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions in Weekend last Friday with the continuation of an article about young dancers of the New York City Ballet misidentified two ballets shown. The large picture, with Benjamin Millepied, showed ''The Four Seasons,'' not ''A Midsummer Night's Dream''; the inset picture with Aesha Ash showed ''Jewels,'' not ''Ash.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Tina Barney

title: ONE VALLEY BANCORP TO PAY $68 MILLION FOR SUMMIT
description: One Valley Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Summit Bankshares Inc. for about $68 million in stock in the bank's fourth acquisition in Virginia in two years. One Valley, which has $5.5 billion in assets, is buying Summit's $199 million in assets. One Valley, based in Charleston, W. Va., does not plan to cut any jobs at Summit, which is the parent company of the Bank of Rockbridge. Shares of One Valley closed up 6.25 cents yesterday at $37.375.

title: Court Blocks Use of Embryos Without Ex-Husband's Consent
description: New York State's highest court stepped into the legal quagmire of biomedical ethics today, ruling that a woman could not use her frozen embryos to impregnate herself without the consent of her former husband.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: William N. Copley

title: WOOLWORTH IN STOCK DEAL FOR SPORTS AUTHORITY
description: The Woolworth Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Sports Authority Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $570 million. Woolworth will also assume about $179 million in debt. Woolworth said Sports Authority holders would receive eight-tenths of a share of Woolworth in exchange for each of their shares. Based upon Wednesday's closing price of $21.875 for Woolworth, the deal valued Sports Authority shares at $17.50 each. Woolworth's shares finished up $1.125 yesterday, at $23, and shares of Sports Authority closed at $18, up $1. Sports Authority, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has 202 sporting goods stores in the United States, Canada and Japan. Woolworth, based in New York, closed its five-and-dime stores last year and focused on its Foot Locker and Champs Sports stores.

title: Volvo and Samsung In $572 Million Deal
description: The Swedish car and truck maker Volvo A.B. said yesterday that it would buy 90 percent of the construction arm of the Samsung Heavy Industries Company in Korea for $572 million as it moves to expand its heavy equipment unit to No. 3 in the world. Samsung Group will keep the rest of the company, which makes excavators, earthmovers and cranes. Samsung, Korea's second-biggest industrial group, is selling assets to focus on five businesses and help repay $21 billion of debt.

title: Rolls Accepts VW Bid
description: The owner of Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, Vickers P.L.C., accepted a $710 million bid from Volkswagen, spurning an earlier deal with another German auto maker, BMW.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, RUTH. (NEE FRIEDMAN.)
description: GOLDSTEIN-Ruth. (nee Friedman.) Beloved wife of the late Morris F. Devoted mother of Howard Serwer. Dear sister of Natalie Cohen. Adored grandmother and cherished great-grandmother. Services Sunday 9:45AM at Gutterman's, 331 Amsterdam Avenue, corner West 76 Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Barnard College, C/O Colleges Development Office, 3009 Broadway, NYC 10027.

title: Ah, When Every Day Was Mother's Day
description: Honoring thy mother is not always easy to do (though you can conveniently send a card this Sunday). The poet Phyllis McGinley wrote that a mother was the hardest person to forgive: ''While you live,/Relentlessly she understands you.'' (Some mothers, like Jocasta and Joan Crawford and Bette Davis, went unforgiven for other reasons.) Society today seems to oscillate between honoring mothers and damning them, perhaps a reasonable enough reflection of the way things are. After all, the Bible would not have had to make honor a commandment if everyone already observed it.

title: As an Etcher, Whistler Did More Than Scratch the Surface
description: If James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) did not single-handedly revive the art of etching from its post-Rembrandt doldrums, he had much to do with repopularizing it. Convinced that prints could be as vital as paintings, he became a master of the medium, and there have been collectors so hooked on his etchings and lithographs that they scarcely acknowledge his talent at the easel.

title: On My Mind; Note for the Record
description: Bill Clinton has put the question to Americans and foreigners, answered it and provided the proof.

title: Political Briefing; The Public Humbling Of a Privacy Bill
description: It seemed to Ken Chlouber, a Republican member of the Colorado Senate, that the cyber age was closing in on all sides. Fast.

title: 'Titanic' Lifts Profit At News Corporation
description: The News Corporation said its third-quarter profit, better than expected, rose 10 percent, led by its hit movie ''Titanic'' and higher advertising revenue at its television stations and Fox TV network. Profit from operations rose to $319 million, or 32 cents for each American depository receipt, from $291 million, or 33 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 11 percent, to $3.22 billion.

title: Chrysler Takes On a Foreign Partner
description: The proposed merger between Daimler-Benz and Chrysler -- at more than $35 billion the largest industrial merger ever -- appears to be good for Chrysler's shareholders and workers. The merger could boost Chrysler's European sales, now tiny, yet pose little threat to factory jobs in the United States. The two companies are vastly different. Daimler focuses on its luxury cars, Chrysler on its sport-utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans. That means the companies cannot cut costs easily by consolidating production lines, sharing dealerships or restructuring business. But while the lack of overlap protects Chrysler workers, it also suggests that the merger, despite its size, might have little impact on the domestic or foreign auto industry.

title: Metro Business; Bridgeport Project Wins State Approval
description: The Connecticut General Assembly this week approved a $200 million plan to turn the depressed Steel Point area of Bridgeport into an entertainment and retail complex called Harbor Place.

title: A Joining of Opposites Could Help Customers
description: The Daimler-Benz-Chrysler deal is essentially a merger of opposites. But after Chrysler's turn-on-a-dime management is combined with the German company's research and engineering bloodlines, customers should notice improvements in the quality, performance, safety and perhaps price of DaimlerChrysler vehicles.

title: Joining a Move To DVD
description: Warner was the first one last year, and since then every major studio but Fox has committed itself to release movies on digital video disk, or DVD. Last week it was Paramount. Several months ago, a studio representative said Paramount was awaiting favorable developments in the marketplace. Now, in its judgment, the time has come.

title: Sometimes We Gain Much in Disturbing the Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: New Policy Center Seeks to Steer the Debate on Climate Change
description: With millions of dollars from a charitable foundation known for its environmentalism and with endorsements from some of the nation's biggest corporations, a former State Department official who helped negotiate the climate-change treaty is mounting a new campaign for action to head off global warming.

title: Teen-Ager Is Raped After On-Line Chat
description: After being charmed by a man in an Internet chat group, a Long Island teen-ager posted her home telephone number for him on line. The posting led to a meeting that ended in rape Wednesday night in a Queens motel, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about two promising new anti-cancer drugs included an imprecise paraphrase of a comment by Dr. Richard D. Klausner, director of the National Cancer Institute. As noted in the next paragraph, he said he was ''putting nothing on a higher priority'' than clinical trials of the new drugs with patients. He did not say the drugs were his highest priority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABSEVITZ, EMMA
description: SABSEVITZ-Emma. Of Miami Beach, formerly of New York City. Passed away May 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Irving Sabsevitz. She is survived by loving son, Arnold L. (Lite) Sabin. Cherished grandchildren Barbara (Stephen) Miller, Charles (Merril) Gottesman, Jill (Charles) Garner, Dr. James L. (Ellen) Meisel and Vicki Meisel and six adoring greatgrandchildren. Life member of Hadassah, a generous and giving person. She will be missed by many who loved her dearly. Graveside services May 8 in Florida. For more information call Riverside Gordon Funeral Home, 1-800-759-1151.

title: An 'Open' Admissions Policy Still Carried Restrictions
description: Although some critics of a plan to cut back remedial classes at the City University of New York are lamenting the end of open admissions, the university's 11 senior colleges have never truly been that open.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK RETREATS. Germany's currency fell for the first time in a week after Hans Tietmeyer, the Bundesbank's chief, suggested that rates there might not rise soon. In New York the dollar cost 1.7676 marks, up from 1.7665.

title: Playstation Sales Lift Sony Profits
description: The Sony Corporation's earnings jumped 50 percent in the latest half, lifted by sales of the Playstation home video-game player and software.

title: How Do You Reroute A Comet? Carefully
description: Apparently there is no better aid to family therapy than a murderously large meteor hurtling toward Earth. So the costly comet thriller ''Deep Impact,'' which is to summer movies what the first crocus is to springtime, explores the salutary effects of imminent doom. Lovers bond, family ties bind and old wounds heal as the planet prepares for its final hours, although the crisis proves not as dire as it could have been. We will survive to be hit by another comet picture (''Armageddon'') in July.

title: Hits Are Going, Not Gone, for Williams
description: Bernie Williams, the power-hitting center fielder for the Yankees, has splattered line drives against the outfield fences this season and hit triples between opposing outfielders. He is batting .311 and helping the team generate extraordinary run production in a variety of ways.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article in the Circuits section yesterday about test-preparation sofware misidentified the publisher of Kaplan's ''Higher Score on the SAT and ACT'' and misstated some prices. The publisher is Kaplan Educational Centers/Cendant Software, not Kaplan Educational Centers/CUC Software. The standard version is $20 (not $30) after a $10 rebate. The deluxe version is $30 (not $50) after a $20 rebate.

title: Pact on Israeli Pullback Hinges on Defining Army's Role
description: When President Clinton's special Middle East envoy arrives in Israel on Friday, he is expected to discuss new face-saving ideas for securing an Israeli pullout from 13 percent of the West Bank. The envoy, Dennis B. Ross, is to have last-minute talks with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu this weekend; Washington has set a Monday deadline for an accord.

title: Record Fees Paid Last Year For Lobbying City Hall
description: Lobbyists were paid a record $11.2 million last year to influence decisions by New York City government, an increase of 12 percent over the previous year, according to an annual report issued by the City Clerk's office.

title: Shares Decline on Concern Over Possible Rise in Rates
description: A couple of weeks ago, big bank mergers helped catapult the stock market to new highs. Yesterday, Daimler-Benz's proposed acquisition of Chrysler just helped prevent it from falling further.

title: Earle Palmer Brown In 2 Agency Deals
description: Earle Palmer Brown in Philadelphia said yesterday that it had acquired one agency outside Philadelphia and signed a letter of intent to acquire another one in Philadelphia. Terms were not disclosed.

title: So Gosh Darn Wholesome, Until a City Boy Comes Puffin' In
description: Things are pretty idyllic at Plumfield, the Massachusetts boarding school run by Jo March and her husband. The house is surrounded by lovely woods. Cows graze contentedly nearby. Big, hearty, family-style meals are preceded by grace. Plumfield students are so happy that they make jokes in arithmetic class. And to work off youthful energies, there's the Saturday night pillow fight.

title: Near 42d Street
description: While 42d Street has never been a destination for fine dining, the nearby restaurants have improved significantly in the last few years. Here are a dozen that are typical of the area today. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANN, LEE I.
description: GANN-Lee I. On May 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Mitzi. Cherished father of Erik and Cory. Loving grandfather of Megan, Elliot, Caitlin and Alexander. Devoted uncle to Sean, Evan, Regan, Geoffrey, Wendy, David, Kevin, Madliene, Robin, Carla and Victor also Laura and Andrew. Dearest brother of Dr. Edith Gann. President of Cameron Craig Ltd. of Newark, New Jersey. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street Friday, 3 P.M.

title: On a Serendipitous Stroll Among the Riches at a Fair
description: Though gullible by nature, I have trouble believing that, as its organizers claim, the International Fine Art Fair, now in its fifth year at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, is ''widely regarded as the premier fine art fair in the world.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Auto Giants Detail Deal, But Challenges Remain

title: Op-Art
Pataki's Veto of Day Care Spending Rallies Democrats and Labor Unions
description: Dismissing calls from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, union leaders and advocates for children for a substantial increase in spending on child care, Gov. George E. Pataki has vetoed more than $75 million from the budget that would have helped ease New York City's day care shortage.

title: Using Grit and Glitz to Bring Aid to Schools
description: SHE'S relentless,'' the author James McBride said yesterday about Lisa Belzberg, the woman who installed him as principal for the day at Public School 118 in Queens, and who was eight months pregnant when she asked him to do it. ''We had lunch at some tony restaurant near her office, and a lot of these East Side fat cats were coming up, shaking her hand, saying, 'Hi Lisa.' I thought it was interesting that these really arrogant folks would bow to a pregnant woman. And I just assumed that she had a very powerful personality, and that there was no point in resisting. And she was also really nice to my son.''

title: Businessman Admits Laundering Drug Money
description: A Margate businessman admitted in Federal court yesterday that he hid millions of dollars in drug proceeds for a convicted cocaine dealer who once tried to contribute to President Clinton's re-election campaign, prosecutors said.

title: S.A.T. as Democratizer
description: To the Editor:

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Lost in the Return, The Motion Offense
description: Option Nos. 1 through 5 was back on the blocks last night, bulling and bumping for position and calling for the ball. Patrick Ewing had returned, and with him the Three Steps and a Cloud of Uncertainty offense.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Catherine Murphy

title: FIDELITY NATIONAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE ALAMO TITLE
description: Fidelity National Financial Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Alamo Title Holding Company, a title insurance underwriter, for stock valued at $75 million to $85 million. Fidelity, based in Irvine, Calif., is a specialty-finance and real estate company. It had 1997 revenue of $746.7 million. Alamo Title, based in San Antonio, had 1997 title premiums and operating revenue of $100 million. It is the ninth-largest title-insurance underwriter in the nation. Fidelity will pay 2.1 million shares to Alamo Title. Fidelity's shares slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $37.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, HERBERT
description: WEIL-Herbert. Died quietly and with dignity Wednesday, May 6, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Jenny and late twin brother Sally. Companion of Rose Haas and the late Lieselotte Mayer. He left his indelible footprints on the sands of time. He will be best remembered as a very kind and most generous friend, a contributor to many charities, a past Nobel Grand of the Independent Order of the Odd Fellows Thomas Wildey Lodge No. 257. Funeral service Friday, May 8 10 A.M., at Hirsch & Sons, Bronx.

title: Goodby Takes Honors At One Club Awards
description: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco took top honors with the most awards at the One Show for creative excellence in advertising sponsored by the One Club for Art and Copy.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS 3 PERCENT. Copper fell to the lowest level in a month after the London Metal Exchange reported a large increase in international stockpiles. July contracts fell 2.45 cents a pound, to 79.55 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, ELLEN B. (NEE PERRY).
description: COX-Ellen B. (nee Perry). On May 5, 1998. Beloved wife of Keneth B. Loving mother of Lauren Gabel and the late Mavis Elissa. Dear mother-in-law of Johannes. Visiting Thursday and Friday 24PM and 7-9PM. Religious service 8 PM on Friday. Funeral at 9 AM Saturday at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Interment Green-Wood Cemetery.

title: Perhaps It Is All In Genes For Wilson
description: The stay will almost certainly be short. But so far it has been nothing but sweet.

title: Stock Exchange On Wall Street Offered a Home In New Jersey
description: The New York Stock Exchange said last night that it had abandoned plans to expand its historic headquarters in lower Manhattan and that it had received an offer from New Jersey officials to build a $1 billion trading floor for the exchange in Jersey City.

title: Indictment Outlines Huge Money-Laundering Scheme
description: A sophisticated criminal network operating mostly out of the United States has defrauded up to 400 people in at least 10 countries through a scam that collected more than $60 million in processing fees for nonexistent venture capital loans, Federal officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALYI, EMERY
description: VALYI-Emery. Of Katonah and Riverdale, on May 5, at age 86, husband of Elisabeth, father of Kathy and grandfather of Aran, Kieran and Clara. An inventor with over 200 U.S. and foreign patents who made original technical contributions to foundry technology, mass and heat transfer systems, packaging technology and automotive structures, Emery Valyi was active in his community and an early director of Wave Hill. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Elizabeth and Sandor Valyi Foundation. A memorial service is planned.

title: Mexico Says It Will Expel Italian Observers From a Rebel Area
description: The Government said today that it would expel most members of an Italian human rights delegation from the southern state of Chiapas after they disobeyed immigration authorities and caused a melee in an Indian village.

title: A Tale of Torture From an Indonesian Dissident
description: Pius Lustrilanang, a student activist, says he was kidnapped at gunpoint on Feb. 4 at a bus stop in Indonesia's capital, blindfolded, driven outside the city and placed in a cell, naked.

title: Pushing for Mideast Peace
description: Advancing the Middle East peace effort is difficult enough without a contrived political furor in Washington. Unfortunately, that is just what President Clinton faces as he tries to lead Israeli and Palestinian leaders over the negotiating roadblock that has immobilized the Oslo peace accords. Newt Gingrich has wrongly accused Mr. Clinton of selling out Israel, and Hillary Rodham Clinton's mistaken articulation of American policy has been inflated in importance. Israel's many friends in Congress ought to give the White House a chance to produce a diplomatic breakthrough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, HARRY
description: ROTH-Harry. On May 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary. Loving father of Stanley (Mimi) and the late Alan. Cherished grandfather of Eden. Services Friday 11AM, at Mount Lebanon Cemetery Myrtle Ave and Forest Park Drive Brooklyn NY. Donations to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Those Danes, So Melancholy

title: As the Great White Way Turns a Corner
description: Mother stood just beyond the rush of commuters spilling out of the Times Square subway station beneath the Reuters Building and looked west along 42d Street, which was bristling with lights and noise. She could make out a few small figures on one of the balconies overlooking the crowded street, smoking casually amid the clutter of signs. Father had taken Junior across the street to Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum after a hefty lunch at the new theme restaurant on the corner.

title: Stock Exchange Gets A New Jersey Offer
description: The New York Stock Exchange said last night that it had abandoned plans to expand its historic headquarters in lower Manhattan and that it had received an offer by New Jersey to build a $1 billion trading floor for the exchange in Jersey City.

title: Knee Injury Keeps Cone Off Mound
description: David Cone, the Yankees' pitcher who wrenched his left knee as he tried to field a bunt Tuesday night, has a mild sprain and will very likely miss his next scheduled start, Sunday against Minnesota.

title: Residential Real Estate; Equitably Sharing Water's Rising Cost
description: The hot water was running full blast when Jeffrey Katz, manager of an apartment building on 89th Avenue in Jamaica, Queens, entered the elderly woman's kitchen one recent Saturday morning -- just as it had for two years.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Mother's Day That's a Zoo

title: An Anxiety That Rules Out Romanticism
description: Haydn and Bartok are not easy for a pickup orchestra to play well. Not much music is. No doubt Robert Suter's viola concerto, ''Trois Nocturnes,'' has its problems, but a listener's lack of acquaintance will help conceal them, and this was much the most impressive item in the concert given by the Riverside Symphony under George Rothman at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEEL, ROBBY
description: STEEL-Robby. Dearest Robby you are forever in our hearts. We think of you always. Fare you well my honey Fare you well my only true one All the birds that were singing Have flown except you alone Love Mom, Charles and Eric

title: Pepsico Sues Coca-Cola on Distribution
description: In a major escalation of the cola wars, Pepsico Inc. sued the Coca-Cola Company yesterday, accusing its archrival of unfairly controlling the beverages served by restaurants and other businesses.

title: Investors Put an Estimated $24.5 Billion Into Stock Funds in April
description: United States investors put an estimated $24.5 billion into stock mutual funds in April, the highest inflow since September, raising the industry's assets to more than $5 trillion for the first time.

title: Underreporting Found On Male Teen-Ager Sex
description: Male teen-agers engage in risky behavior associated with H.I.V. infection more than previously thought, and they are also much more willing to report such behavior if the survey is administered by computer, rather than on paper, a new study suggests.

title: The Blah, Blah, Blah Campaign
description: Politicians and civic boosters are in a lather over how television news stations in California are ignoring the race for governor. It's true that these stories about the campaign, if they appear at all, surface late in the broadcast and last for all of a nanosecond. But the problem isn't just that television news programs are more interested in ratings than civic duty. The problem is that today's politicians, who have all the money in the world to spend on commercials, have nothing to say.

title: Student's Violent Prose Pits Free Speech Against Safety
description: By any measure, the two compositions that the 14-year-old boy wrote for his eighth-grade English class were not ordinary fare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, LENA
description: ROSEN-Lena. On May 6th, 1998. Beloved mother & grandmother. Services on Friday, 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Dead Boss With Drug Cargo: A Stooge's Stuff of Dreams
description: Question: What happens when you cross ''The Treasure of the Sierra Madre'' with the Three Stooges?

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Goldberg Moser O'Neill Wins Energy Account
description: Pacific Enterprises in Los Angeles and the Enova Corporation in San Diego -- which are merging this summer to form a new San Diego-based energy services and utility company, Sempra Energy -- named Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $35 million to $40 million. The decision came after a three-month review that included Bozell Worldwide in Costa Mesa, Calif., part of True North Communications, and Kovel Kresser & Partners in Venice, Calif.

title: Scared Family Says Police Raided the Wrong Home
description: Police officers last week broke down the door of a Brooklyn apartment, guns drawn, tossed a stun grenade into the front hall and handcuffed everyone inside, including a mentally retarded 18-year-old girl who was taking a shower. They were looking for guns and drugs. They found only a terrified family.

title: Advisers and Lawyers Stand To Get Richer in Auto Deal
description: Kirk Kerkorian, one of Chrysler's largest shareholders, won't be the only one walking away richer after the company merges with Daimler-Benz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSTER, DR. MAURICE.
description: POSTER-Dr. Maurice. We mourn with Muriel, Bill, Jim and their families. We are diminished by the loss of one of us who gave so much to so many. Table Number Seven

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Lutz Bacher

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, REVEREND WILLIAM J.
description: CHASE-Reverend William J. The members, staff and Board of Fountain House express deep sorrow at the loss of our Director and friend, who, since 1954, served on our Board. Bill was a guiding and considerate force through our early uncertain days, and in immeasurable ways helped Fountain House grow steadily and surely, to achieve national and international recognition in the field of psychiatric rehabilitation. His friendship and kindness will be missed by all of us.

title: Agony and Ecstasy, Especially Ecstasy
description: Movie biographies of artists tend to promote the romance-novel proposition that most great art has its inspiration in tormented love. In this simplistic view, art is essentially passion poured into pigment, and to ''feel'' what's happening on the canvas you have to ''feel'' the agony and the ecstasy that inspired the work.

title: Renault Says Sales Rose 24% in First Period
description: Renault S.A., France's second-largest car maker, said yesterday that its first-quarter sales jumped 24 percent as new models helped it win market share at home and abroad. Sales reached 58.63 billion French francs ($9.77 billion), up from 47.20 billion francs last year.

title: ALPHARMA BUYS GENERIC DRUG BUSINESS FROM HOECHST
description: Alpharma Inc. said yesterday that it had bought Hoechst A.G.'s generic drug business in Europe for about $200 million in cash. The business will allow Alpharma to expand in Britain, where 75 percent of prescriptions are expected to be generic by 2000. Alpharma, a drug manufacturer based in Fort Lee, N.J., said the Hoechst unit included Cox Pharmaceuticals in Britain and its marketing companies in the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Belgium. Cox had 1997 revenue of $88 million. Alpharma, which had 1997 revenue of $500 million, has its own operations in the Nordic countries, the Netherlands and Indonesia, with more than 170 prescription and over-the-counter products. Alpharma's stock fell 31.25 cents, to $21.25. Hoechst, based in Frankfurt, said it would focus on prescription drugs.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Political Briefing; In the Sunshine State, Clouds for Democrats
description: The last few years have not been good to Florida Democrats.

title: Jack F. Wilder, 72, Innovator in Psychiatry
description: Jack Frederick Wilder, a retired educator and administrator in psychiatry who was an innovator in the move toward community-based services for the mentally ill in the 1960's and 70's, died on April 28 at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, RUTH
description: MARCUS-Ruth. On May 6, 1998, in her 81st year. Beloved wife of Herman Marcus, devoted mother of Jo-Ann Kalb and Linda Marcus Sherry, dear sister of Shirley Saposnick, Milton Lampell, and the late Herman Lempel, cherished grandmother of Jonathan and Jamie Kalb, and Dana Sherry. Service Friday, 12 Noon, at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 312 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAISIER, RENE GEORGES.
description: BAISIER-Rene Georges. On May 3, 1998 at the age of 90 of New York City. Beloved husband of the late Margaret Thalmann. Devoted stepfather of Catherine Cavanaugh of Morristown, N.J. Dear uncle of Jacques Baisier of Lille, France and two grand-nephews. Services at St. James Episcopal Church, 71 Street and Madison Avenue on Friday, May 8 at 2PM. Interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx.

title: For the best of all possible markets, higher earnings coinciding with lower economic growth.
description: WITH the first-quarter earnings season winding down, investors need two things to help them reaffirm a positive outlook: a rebound in earnings from the anemic pace of the first quarter and a slowdown in the rapid pace of economic growth in the first three months of the year.

title: Metro Business; Jacuzzi to Buy Company
description: Jacuzzi Inc., a subsidiary of U.S. Industries of Iselin, N.J., agreed yesterday to buy Sundance Spas from Clark Manufacturing for $31.65 million.

title: Anxiety Persists For Doctor
description: There will be a moment when Patrick Ewing will come tumbling down on his surgically repaired wrist. And somewhere, perhaps in his seat behind the Knicks' bench, Dr. Norman Scott will forget to breathe.

title: For Black Students, A Divided Berkeley
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, SHEILA
description: KAHN-Sheila. Wife of Ezra Kahn of Boca Raton, FL., died Monday in Tamarac, Florida, after a long illness. Born in Brooklyn in 1935, she attended the University of Michigan & graduated Cum Laude from Adelphi University. She taught for several years at Mark Twain Junior High School. Surviving are their son Howard, daughter-in-law Meg, and their children Zachary and Danielle of Roslyn, NY. Also, son Kenneth and daughter-in-law Amy, of Seattle, WA., and another son Douglas, of Boca Raton, FL. Sheila was the daughter of Dewey and Adeline Albert of Brooklyn and Fort Lauderdale, deceased. She is also survived by her brother, Jerome, sister-in-law, Carol, Uncle Alvy West and many nephews and nieces. Services will be held at the Riverside Funeral Home, located at 180 W. 76th St., N.Y., NY on May 8th at 12 noon.

title: AT&T to Offer New Nationwide Cut-Rate Wireless Service
description: Flexing its financial, technological and marketing muscle, the AT&T Corporation moved yesterday to shake up the wireless telephone industry with a new service that offers calls from almost anywhere in the United States to anywhere in the nation for flat rates of as little as 11 cents a minute.

title: Sometimes We Gain Much in Disturbing the Dead
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGE, SARAH
description: PAGE-Sarah. On May 7th, 1998. Beloved wife of 61 years to Mack. Loving mother of Leonard and Richard. Devoted grandmother of Brian. She will be missed by all. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, May 10, 9:30AM, Garlick Memorial Chapel, 1700 Coney Island Ave, Bklyn, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Report Missed Chance to Put The Mantle File in Perspective
description: From the way Channel 2 hyped its three-part report about the Federal Bureau of Investigation's file on Mickey Mantle, I thought it would prove that the Mick had given batting tips to organized crime luminaries or had secretly played cribbage with Alger Hiss.

title: Boy Killed in Accident On Manhattan Subway
description: A boy died beneath the streets of Manhattan last night after he slipped between two subway cars, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEATTY, RYAN JAMES
description: BEATTY-Ryan James, 18, died peacefully on the 7th of May surrounded by his family. He brought love, laughter and joy to all. Son of Marion Usdan of Summit, N.J. and Martin Beatty of Washington, N.J. A Memorial service will be held on Saturday, May 9th, 1998 at 12:00pm at the Reeves-Reed Arboretum, Hobart Avenue, Summit, N.J. (1908-273-8787). In lieu of flowers, please direct all contributions in Ryan's memory to the Matheny School, Main Street, Peapack, New Jersey 07977.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGRAM, BERNICE
description: MAGRAM-Bernice. Age 84. Beloved mother of Richard Magram and Judith Ladd. Grandmother and great grandmother. Preceded in death by Louis Magram. Genuinely kind and generous and adored by all who knew her. We will miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HEIDI
description: FRIEDMAN - Heidi. Farewell, beautiful friend. You will enrich God's garden. Gail and Marc Goldberg

title: U.S. Dispatches Its Balkans Mediator With a Warning to the Serbs
description: Fearful that fighting along Yugoslavia's southern border is about to erupt into a full-scale war, the Clinton Administration has sent the architect of the Bosnian peace agreement to warn President Slobodan Milosevic of the consequences of the recent violence.

title: Giving Is Never Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Knoblauch Brushes the Boos Aside
description: Chuck Knoblauch said the boos would not bother him, and he produced convincing evidence tonight, getting two hits, stealing two bases and scoring two runs, including the tie-breaker, as the Yankees beat Minnesota, 5-1.

title: Cafe Philosophers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NARSIFF, PETER J.
description: NARSIFF-Peter J. On May 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Florence. Loving father of William. Dear brother of Josephine Brown, Mary Coury, Ethel Hansome & Whadia Ferris. Also survived by five grandchildren. Reposing Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Avenue, Richmond Hill, New York. Religious service Monday 10 AM. Interment to follow at Lutheran Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2:30-5 and 7-9:30 P.M.

title: Hillsdown to Spin Off Two Units and Sell One
description: The British conglomerate Hillsdown Holdings P.L.C. said yesterday that it would spin off its chilled-foods and housing businesses and sell its furniture operation. The moves will enable the company to return as much as $:600 million, or nearly $1 billion, to shareholders. Upon completion, Hillsdown will be left with its food business, which produces Typhoo Tea, Chivers Hartley jams and Maryland Cookies.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Rockefeller Center Is Class, Not Flash
description: To the Editor:

title: House Member Describes Snub At White House
description: Representative Cynthia McKinney, a black Democrat from Georgia, has complained to President Clinton that she received ''disparate treatment'' at a White House event because of the color of her skin, but said today that she was satisfied with the apology she received.

title: As Fishing Season Starts, a Surge in Striped Bass
description: The striped bass are running. That's the word at the bait shops around town. They are coming in from the ocean, and this year they are abundant. They are running into New York Harbor, some feeding in Jamaica Bay before swimming up the mouth of the Hudson and East Rivers to their home streams to spawn.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel to Miss Deadline

title: President Turns a Page: So Might History
description: If Bill Clinton's interest in germ warfare was intensified by having read ''The Cobra Event,'' a biological thriller, it is hardly the first time that history may have been nudged by what an American President read.

title: Eddie Rabbitt, 56, Whose Songs Zigzagged From Pop to Country
description: Eddie Rabbitt, a singer and songwriter who defined ''crossover'' in country and pop music of the 1970's and 80's and had 26 No. 1 country singles, died on Thursday at Baptist Hospital in Nashville. He was 56.

title: Lessons of Rome For Today's Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Backs Indonesian Loans But Cancels Military Exercise
description: The United States today gave Indonesia $1 billion in loan guarantees, free of any conditions concerning human rights abuses surrounding the protests against President Suharto's rule. Almost simultaneously the Pentagon, citing the unrest, canceled a joint training exercise with the Indonesian military.

title: New Jersey Plans Solid Fight to Keep Nets
description: Although the owners of the Islanders want to buy the Nets and move them from New Jersey to Long Island, the Nets' landlord is not ready to let them go.

title: Fretting Over Grip on House, G.O.P. Courts Conservatives
description: After months of confidence that the nation was heading into a serene, status-quo election, Republicans are suddenly worried that they could lose control of the House this November unless they energize their conservative base.

title: Arthur Miller Gets Award From PEN
description: The playwright Arthur Miller was named the winner yesterday of the first PEN/Laura Pels Foundation Award to a master American dramatist.

title: Border War As a Ploy: Companies Seldom Lose
description: Close the borders.

title: Judge Bars Reissue of '62 Beatles Recording
description: After four days of testimony that included a two-hour appearance by the usually reclusive George Harrison, a London judge ruled yesterday that a small English company could not reissue a recording of the Beatles performing in a Hamburg nightclub in late 1962, on the eve of their rise to international fame.

title: Democratic Candidates for Governor Struggle to Stir Interest
description: Peter F. Vallone rounded up a battery of police union leaders on the steps of City Hall the other morning to endorse his campaign for governor. When the speeches ended, Mr. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, invited questions about his candidacy. He was met with silence. ''Unrelated question?'' a radio reporter finally asked, as Mr. Vallone grimaced.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS PLANNING A HUGE ACQUISITION
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. plans to make a $1 billion to $2 billion acquisition in Western Europe or the United States in the next 12 to 18 months. ICN's chief executive, Milan Panic, said yesterday in an interview that the company was looking to buy a midsized pharmaceutical company with products that could be made and sold through ICN's rapidly growing Eastern European operations. ''It's very urgent for us,'' Mr. Panic said. ''We need to be somewhere between $3 billion and $5 billion in sales.'' Last week, ICN said it expected to lift sales to about $1 billion this year. Based in Costa Mesa, Calif., ICN makes and sells prescription and nonprescription drugs in over 90 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, JACK
description: MINTZ-Jack. On May 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Helen. Cherished father of Robyn, Brad and Cheryl. Loving grandfather of Sam Maxwell. Devoted to his sons in law George and Harris and daughter in law Lynn. Devoted brother to his sister Gerry Wodin. Services on Sunday, May 10, Gutterman's Funeral Home in Rockville Centre, New York at 9:45 AM. May his memory always be for a blessing. He will be missed.

title: Reno Still Undecided on Outside Counsel for Labor Secretary
description: Attorney General Janet Reno and her senior aides could not reach agreement today on whether she should seek an independent prosecutor to investigate accusations that Labor Secretary Alexis Herman accepted illegal payments while she was an official at the White House, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Credit Suisse First Boston May Make Korea Loan
description: Credit Suisse First Boston is considering whether to help the Dong-Ah Group raise $500 million, a decision that may determine whether South Korea's 10th-largest industrial group avoids bankruptcy. Dong-Ah is negotiating with the investment bank to borrow $250 million and sell $250 million of bonds, said Lee Seung Jae, a spokesman at the Dong-Ah Construction Company, the group's flagship construction business.

title: APARTMENT INVESTMENT OF DENVER ADDING TO HOLDINGS
description: The Apartment Investment and Management Company said that it had completed its purchase of Ambassador Apartments Inc. for $646 million, and said the transaction would add more to earnings than originally anticipated. The purchase increases the Denver-based Apartment Investment's holdings by 12 percent, to about 133,217 apartments across the country. It also manages 67,665 apartments for others. The planned purchase was disclosed last December, but the price was not reported. Apartment Investment said the purchase would increase earnings by 22 cents a share, 12 cents more than it expected.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Today the tobacco industry has surrendered, and they have surrendered on our terms.''

title: Child Abuse Centers Will Get $1.5 Million
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a law yesterday providing $1.5 million to improve services at four centers for abused and neglected children.

title: N.Y.'s Garbage Clout
description: To the Editor:

title: Songs Like Historical Novels, A Kind of Celtic Mood Music
description: Watching Loreena McKennitt plucking her harp at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday night, one could almost imagine what it must have felt like to watch Jenny Lind, America's first musical superstar. P. T. Barnum imported the so-called Swedish nightingale in 1850 as a messenger from an ancient northern Eden. She made him a fortune. Ladies swooned at her bell-clear voice; gentlemen rioted over tickets for her concerts. And so the marketing of the mystical feminine began.

title: Rugby in South Africa Scrums to a New Boycott
description: When South Africa roared back into rugby in 1995, winning the World Cup, it looked as if the helmetless, gore-spattered version of football beloved by white South Africans would be part of the glue binding the new nation. Nelson Mandela led the cheers, and the Springboks, the national team, got an African version of their name: Amabokoboko.

title: Bishop's Death Shakes Hopes for Guatemala Peace
description: Little by little, Guatemalans had come to believe over the last year and a half that their long civil war really was over and that they at last would be able to enjoy the fruits of peace. But the killing of a Roman Catholic bishop here late last month has shaken the country's confidence and plunged the civilian Government into crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEITMAN, DOROTHY
description: LEITMAN-Dorothy. May 8, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Risa (David). Fond sister of Shep Porter and the late Louis and Lester. Loving grandmother of Mallory and Alexander and dear aunt of Samantha. Services Sunday 9 A.M., Schwartz Bros Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard. For information, contact I.J. Morris Inc., 718-377-8610.

title: South African Court Ends Sodomy Laws
description: Gay sex was effectively declared legal today when a Johannesburg court overturned the nation's sodomy laws as unconstitutional.

title: Roy Eckardt, 79, a Pioneer In Christian-Jewish Relations
description: Roy Eckardt, a leading scholar of Christian-Jewish relations and chairman emeritus of religion studies at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., died on Tuesday at his home in Coopersburg, Pa. He was 79.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Public Lives column on Wednesday about renovations to the President's Room at City Hall in New York misstated the name of the organization raising money for the work. It is Friends of Vieilles Maisons Francaises.

title: Lawyers Prepare Stage for Lawsuit in Turnpike Shooting
description: Leading a team of lawyers known for winning O. J. Simpson's acquittal on murder charges, Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. invited a crowd of reporters and television cameramen to his offices in TriBeCa yesterday to draw attention to the civil rights suit they are planning to file on behalf of three young men involved in last month's shooting by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Giving Is Never Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Talk About a Fork in the Road; How and Why Did the French Make an Art of Cuisine While England Descended to Bangers and 'Chip Butty'?
description: Most Francophiles can vividly recall the moment when fascination turned to love. Inevitably, it revolves around a meal, usually a simple but indescribably perfect meal, served without fanfare in a humble small-town restaurant. The happy diner, desperate to express gratitude, showers incoherent praise upon the owner, who shrugs and gives a half smile, as if to say: ''Well, of course. What did you expect? This is France.''

title: Making Battery Park A Place to Linger
description: It is a fort that never saw battle, an immigrant way station that came and went before Ellis Island, and New York City's most heavily trafficked park, given over almost entirely to visitors from out of town.

title: Charles Meares, 91, Who Led Big Insurer
description: Charles W. V. Meares, a former chairman and chief executive of the New York Life Insurance Company, died on April 29 at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 91.

title: Big Tobacco's Loss in Minnesota
description: The multibillion-dollar settlement reached in the lawsuit brought against the tobacco industry by Minnesota and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Minnesota was achieved because the industry feared that a jury would render even harsher punishment. The plaintiffs presented evidence in a 16-week trial to prove that the industry had engaged in consumer fraud, conspired to manipulate nicotine in cigarettes and targeted minors in marketing. The settlement shows that the industry, despite its aggressive rhetoric, does not think it can win.

title: Lessons of Rome For Today's Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE PLUNGES TO 4.3%, LOWEST SINCE 1970
description: The nation's unemployment rate tumbled in April to 4.3 percent, the lowest level in nearly three decades, and employers added more than a quarter-million jobs to payrolls, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Sore Winner
description: Whether it's next week, next month or next year, as long as the U.S. stays firmly behind the proposal it put to Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, Mr. Netanyahu will say yes. He must say yes. Because there is no way you can look at this U.S. proposal, which the Palestinians have already accepted, and conclude that it isn't in Israel's long-term strategic interest.

title: French Pair Fetches Top Bid In Las Vegas Cavendish Pool
description: A group of 60 star bridge partnerships was on the auction block in Las Vegas, Nev., on Thursday night. The total Calcutta pool at the Cavendish Invitational Pairs was $1,112,000, slightly less than it had been a year earlier. When play ends tomorrow, this will be distributed to the buyers in accordance with the results.

title: The Mayor and CUNY
description: Deciding how to fix an educational life raft should be a matter for educators and trustees, not politicians. But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has made it clear over the last few months that punching the City University of New York makes a good political spectacle. At every opportunity he laments how CUNY's students take too long to graduate, with most needing some kind of help. Only recently, at a city budget hearing, the Mayor taunted CUNY administrators, saying he would not give them city funds if they did not do a better job of taking attendance. For the television cameras, he waved a grammar school attendance book and gave sarcastic instructions on how a teacher takes roll.

title: Officer Is Convicted In Shooting at Van
description: A Bayonne police officer was found guilty of aggravated assault yesterday for shooting out the windows of a van after getting into a minor traffic accident with its driver, county prosecutors said.

title: Why Scrap Bilingual Education?
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles (Bebe) Rebozo, 85; Longtime Nixon Confidant
description: Charles (Bebe) Rebozo, a self-made Florida millionaire who met Richard M. Nixon in 1950 and became his lifelong friend, died last night in Miami. He was 85 years old, born just three months before Mr. Nixon, the man who became the 37th President of the United States.

title: Coda for a Homeless Dancer; After Years in the Shadows, a Sudden Burst of Fame
description: Arthur Bell has a lawyer he has never met who is busy fielding movie and book proposals. He has held his own news conference, appeared on ''Good Morning America'' and endured a media blizzard usually reserved for A-list celebrities, or White House interns. When the telephone rang the other day, someone told him it was The Times of London.

title: Tobacco Companies Settle a Suit With Minnesota for $6.5 Billion
description: The first state lawsuit against tobacco companies to go to trial was settled today in Minnesota for $6.5 billion as jurors were hearing closing arguments. The agreement is likely to raise sharply the cost of future settlements between states and the tobacco industry, or of any tobacco bill in Congress.

title: That Love Stuff Again, but More So
description: When people fall in love in Erich Segal novels, they get it bad. Chances are, wherever the fictional Oliver Barrett 4th is today, he is still in therapy over Jenny Cavilleri's death, which, as ''Love Story'' fans know, was in 1970 or so.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Dowling College's purchase of the K-12 La Salle schools on Long Island missidentified the former estate that is their site. It was the Bourne estate, not the Vanderbilt estate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, MICHAEL
description: BERNSTEIN-Michael. The Mayor and Trustees of the Village of Saltaire share the grief of the Bernstein family at Michael's sudden and tragic passing. We extend our deepest sympathy to George and Diane, Adam, Tony and Cathy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LENORE
description: NEWMAN-Lenore. Died quietly at home on May 6 in her apartment in New York City. Family and friends join together in sorrow at the departure of this caring, loving person who carried her professional social work training as a way of life. She retired from Roosevelt-St. Luke's Hospital as supervising medical social worker. Lenore was proud of her volunteer work at the United Nations where after her retirement she dedicated increasing time as a representative of Economists Allied for Arms Reduction. Her surviving family include her nieces Sharon and Marla, her nephew Bernarr, her grandnephews Frank and Jeremy, & her sister-in-law Janis Newman. The service will be at noon on Monday, May 11, at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, and the family will be receiving there on Sunday 6-8 P.M., and at the residence of L. Levi, 91 Central Park West (69th Street), Monday 6-8 P.M., and Tuesday 4-8 P.M. Interment will be at the Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Middle East talks in London misspelled the surname of a spokesman for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He is David Bar-Illan, not Bar-Ilan.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 22 about a protest by strippers in City Hall Park referred incorrectly to a man at the scene, seated on a bench. He was Robert Goodman, a member of the Libertarian Party in New York. He was taking part in the protest; he was not just an onlooker. A correction in this space on Monday misstated the political office Mr. Goodman is seeking. It is State Comptroller, not City Comptroller.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about major league pitchers' being hit by batted balls misidentified the player shown. He was Eric Ludwick of Florida, not Darryl Kile of Houston.

title: Passionate Hippie Vestiges
description: Two eccentric Americanists, Sandy Bull and Eugene Chadbourne, coincidentally performed solo guitar concerts in Manhattan on Monday night. Despite an esthetic alliance, they have different dispositions. Mr. Bull, in his late 50's, seems a strong, silent, grandfatherly version of Peter Fonda's Captain America of ''Easy Rider.'' Mr. Chadbourne, a decade younger, plays a mixture of mad scientist and devious teen-ager with a radical political agenda. But they're both deeply dyed by the oppositional passions of the hippie movement, resulting in a resistance to all isms; they've never found any problem with mixing country, jazz, blues, rock and even classical etudes.

title: Amnesty Given Mandela Aides Is Struck Down
description: A South African court today struck down the blanket amnesties granted to top officials of President Nelson Mandela's governing party by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is investigating abuses committed in the apartheid era.

title: Von Otter, From Lieder to Blues
description: Anne Sofie von Otter, the remarkable Swedish mezzo-soprano, who turns 43 today, may now be in her vocal prime. She certainly could not be busier in the world's recital halls and opera houses. On Wednesday night, with her frequent partner, the elegant Swedish pianist Bengt Forsberg, she gave her Carnegie Hall debut recital, and the place was packed with attentive and enthusiastic admirers.

title: Why Scrap Bilingual Education?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ewing Promises to Do Better Today
description: Patrick Ewing moved around the court with the clumsy steps of a newborn colt in Game 2. It looked as if a stranger had slipped inside jersey No. 33.

title: Grand Finales, Pre-'Seinfeld'; The Family
description: I've always been a very superstitious person, so when we decided to end ''Happy Days'' after 11 seasons, we chose to shoot the final episode on the 11th day of the 11th month, Nov. 11, 1983. We figured three 11's had to be a lucky place to stop.

title: In Home City, Daimler's Deal Draws Skeptics
description: The marriage of Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation has been greeted here in Daimler's headquarters city not so much with joy as with resignation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, RUTH. (NEE FRIEDMAN.)
description: GOLDSTEIN-Ruth. (nee Friedman.) Beloved wife of the late Morris F. Devoted mother of Howard Serwer. Dear sister of Natalie Cohen. Adored grandmother and cherished great-grandmother. Services Sunday 9:45AM at Gutterman's, 331 Amsterdam Avenue, corner West 76 Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Barnard College, C/O Colleges Development Office, 3009 Broadway, New York City 10027.

title: Market Gains on Jobs Data In Spite of a Mixed Outlook
description: The stock market rose yesterday, but market analysts were uncertain about what data in the April employment report touched off the rally.

title: New York Struggles for Biomedical Grant Share
description: After generations as America's center of medical and biological research, New York State has lost its pre-eminence, and its medical schools and research institutes now find themselves struggling to take advantage of a national boom in biomedical discovery and Federal grant-giving largess.

title: Man Is Arrested in Fatal Shooting of His Ex-Girlfriend in Greenwich Village
description: A Greenwich Village woman who had weathered a series of hostile encounters with her ex-boyfriend during the last six months was shot and killed late Thursday, when the man approached her on a street corner, began arguing and shot her in the head, the police said.

title: Rockefeller Center Is Class, Not Flash
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Scrap Bilingual Education?
description: To the Editor:

title: 17 Manages To Maintain Edge on 16
description: The 17-year-olds got the better of the 16-year-olds in the quarterfinals of the Italian Open today.

title: Fences That Break Bonds
description: Jennifer Muller took a big risk by opening a week's engagement by her company, Jennifer Muller/The Works, with a program of four premieres. But these new pieces, presented on Tuesday night at the Joyce, were some of her most striking creations in recent seasons.

title: The Quicksilver of Love, but Rank and Kinky
description: With ''The Fastest Clock in the Universe,'' Philip Ridley's malevolent comedy of libidinous manners, Off Broadway's New Group once again demonstrates its seemingly infallible antennae for subversive drama with a British accent.

title: Why Scrap Bilingual Education?
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Eagles Have Parry Primed for PGA Victory
description: Craig Parry has been to many places, but in a PGA Tour event, Parry has never finished in first place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENDSEL, PETER DAVID.
description: BRENDSEL-Peter David. Age 27. On Wednesday, May 6, at his residence in McLean, VA. Beloved son of Leland C. & Diane Brendsel. Brother of Jon and Michael Brendsel. Grandson of Lars Brendsel & William and LaVerne Christensen. Services held at Vienna Presbyterian Church, 124 Park Street N.E., Vienna, Virginia, on Tuesday, May 12, 11 A.M. Valet parking provided. Interment private. No flowers, please. Contributions may be made to the Peter David Brendsel Fund for Children's Literacy, C/O Freddie Mac, 8200 Jones Branch Drive, McLean, Virginia 22102. Money & King Funeral Home, Vienna, Virginia.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORP AGREES TO ACQUIRE FIRST FINANCIAL
description: Mercantile Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire First Financial Bancorp, an Iowa bank-holding company, for $169 million in stock. The move will make Mercantile Iowa's No. 2 banking company. It will also allow Mercantile to enter the rapidly growing Iowa City-Cedar Rapids market. Under the agreement, expected to close in the summer, Mercantile will exchange eight-tenths of a share for each First Financial share. Mercantile's shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $53.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange, while First Financial jumped $6.9375, to $44.9375. Mercantile, based in St. Louis, is a bank-holding company with assets of $32 billion. First Financial, based in Iowa City, has assets of $550 million.

title: A Timely Key for Unlocking History
description: Despite the Clinton Administration's promise to open cold-war archives, Central American and Caribbean countries investigating recent abuses have found it difficult to get information they need. American intelligence and diplomatic officials serving in Honduras, Haiti, El Salvador and Guatemala collected information about human rights, and many had relationships with the abusers. But when investigators in trials or truth commissions have sought the documents, declassification has often been incomplete and tardy. An effort to change this, the subject of a Congressional hearing on Monday, deserves the Administration's full support.

title: Debate Spurs Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Proposes Legislation To Achieve Smaller Class Size
description: Decrying overcrowded classrooms where the students are barely known to teachers, President Clinton today proposed a $20.8 billion, 10-year program to hire 100,000 new teachers to reduce class sizes in the early primary grades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, EUGENE
description: ZIMMERMAN-Eugene. Beloved husband of the late Daisy. Devoted father of Robert, Barbara Sirotkin and Judy. Loving grandfather of Michael, Amy, Sharon and Susan; and Joanne and Michael. Adoring great-grandfather of Yehuda and Ryan. Service Sunday 1PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERNER, EMANUEL M.
description: TERNER - Emanuel M. The Trustees and Administration of the Manhattan School of Music note with sadness the death of Emanuel M. Terner, father of our esteemed trustee, Nancy T. Behrman. We extend our deepest sympathies to Nancy and all the members of the Terner family. David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees Marta Istomin, President

title: Rome Journal; Agony Lingers, 20 Years After the Moro Killing
description: On May 9, 1978, the bullet-riddled body of a former Prime Minister, Aldo Moro, was found in the trunk of a car in central Rome, 55 days after he was kidnapped by members of the Red Brigades. Twenty years later, the anniversary is being marked with an orgy of national brooding.

title: FIRST-QUARTER FILM SALES IN U.S. DOWN BY 24%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said late on Thursday that its first-quarter United States film sales fell 24 percent, more than previously disclosed, because the photography company changed the way it accounts for some promotional activities. The change does not mean that Kodak sold fewer rolls of film in the United States than it disclosed three weeks ago, a spokesman, Charles Smith, said. Instead, the lower number reflects the company's attempt to present investors with sales figures that were calculated in the same way as those from the first quarter of 1997, he said. Kodak said in its quarterly earnings statement on April 14 that United States film sales fell 18 percent. It did not mention the new accounting at that time but disclosed it this week in a regulatory filing.

title: Some on Wall St. See Buffett's Hand in Bond Sales
description: Is Warren E. Buffett selling part or all of his huge position in zero-coupon Treasury bonds? That is the question bond traders across Wall Street are asking, as huge sell orders pour in on the same long-term Treasury issues that Mr. Buffett owns.

title: G.O.P. Says Inquiry on China Is Blocked
description: The Republican leadership in Congress wrote to President Clinton today, complaining that the Administration had thrown a ''veil of secrecy'' in front of Congressional efforts to look into a case of space expertise provided to China in 1996 by experts for two leading satellite companies.

title: Of the Turmoil In Indonesia And Its Roots
description: When jetloads of pinstriped Western bankers descended on Indonesia last year to demand that President Suharto salvage his battered economy by shutting down the business monopolies held by his children, one of America's most influential anthropologists was not surprised that he balked.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japan's Auto Makers Go It Alone; Tradition Creates Resistance to Industry's Consolidation
description: Standing inside the dormitory he manages for the Nissan Motor Company, Mutsumi Goto looked a bit befuddled by the whirlwind on the other side of the world.

title: Riots Bare Ethnic Hatreds in Indonesia
description: The black-and-white banner hanging above a knot of student protesters at the University of North Sumatra had a blunt message for Indonesia's President: ''Fire Suharto and try him.''

title: Italians Have Video Found in Jet That Sliced Cable and Killed 20
description: Italian officials have a videotape taken from the cockpit of a Marine jet that brought down an Alpine cable car, prosecutors disclosed on the final day of a hearing to determine whether the jet's back-seat crew should be court-martialed.

title: Credit Suisse First Boston Settles Suit
description: Credit Suisse First Boston agreed today to pay $52.5 million to Orange County, becoming the first securities company to settle litigation stemming from the California county's 1994 bankruptcy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Indonesia's decision to raise prices for fuel and electricity referred incorrectly to the youngest son of President Suharto. His name is Hutomo Mandala Putra, not Tommy Suharto. (Tommy is his nickname.)

title: U.S. Settles Pollution Suit With Tyson Foods
description: In an effort to allay fears of pollution in the Chesapeake Bay, the Federal Government announced today that it had settled a lawsuit with a major food-processing company that imposes a record penalty and requires the company to reduce the runoff from its plants in four states.

title: Ex-Schoolboy Star Declares for Draft
description: The former New York high school basketball star Lamar Odom is declaring for the N.B.A. draft, although the University of Rhode Island said he still wants to play college basketball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTEN, RITA SUE.
description: GARTEN-Rita Sue. Suddenly on May 7. Daughter of the late Tina and Moses Garten, dear sister of Doris G. Bronson. Services Sunday, May 10, 12 noon, ''BoulevardRiverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Ave. at Prospect Park Circle, Brooklyn, New York. 718-633-0400.

title: Seagram Seen In Hot Pursuit Of Polygram
description: The Seagram Company is in intense talks to acquire Polygram, the music company, from Royal Philips Electronics N.V., the giant Dutch electronics company, several people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Journal; Tailgunner Dan vs. Tricky Bill
description: In a political war in which all sides insult our intelligence at every turn, there's no longer any hope of finding a hero. Our only choice is to pick our poison. This week's menu featured Presidential stonewalling and Congressional thuggery: Bill Clinton explicitly donned the mantle of Richard Nixon while his most noisy current antagonist, Dan Burton, expertly conjured the sleaze of Joe McCarthy and Roy Cohn. The race to the bottom doesn't get any lower than this.

title: Oxford Health Gets Financing Pledges
description: Oxford Health Plans Inc. has secured commitments to sell $350 million in debt, completing a part of the managed-care company's $700 million financing plan.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOBKER, JACK
description: BOBKER-Jack. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Jack Bobker. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President

title: Senator Jennings Randolph of West Virginia Dies at 96
description: Former Senator Jennings Randolph of West Virginia, a Democrat who was present at the creation of the New Deal and wrote the constitutional amendment that gave 18-year-olds the right to vote, died today at a nursing home in St. Louis. He was 96.

title: VW Is Set to Win Rolls-Royce as BMW Drops Out of Bidding
description: Volkswagen A.G. is poised to win the race to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd. after its German rival, BMW A.G., said today that it would not top VW's bid of $:430 million ($705 million) for the prestigious British auto maker.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MCN ENERGY GROUP INC., Detroit, an energy holding company, said the Internal Revenue Service had ruled the company qualified for tax credits on a coal-refining project. The company's stock rose $2.75, to $39.3125.

title: Grand Finales, Pre-'Seinfeld'; The Parting
description: It was my happy duty, a few months ago, to present the Screen Actors Guild Award to the cast of ''Seinfeld'' for their achievement as the outstanding comedy ensemble on television.

title: 'No Way' for Monday Talks, An Aide to Netanyahu Says
description: A spokesman for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said this evening that there was ''no way'' Mr. Netanyahu could meet Washington's deadline of Monday for deciding on withdrawing from 13.1 percent of the West Bank.

title: An Indelicate Question Doesn't Rattle This Dole
description: It is not often that City Hall reporters dare to ask visiting dignitaries about their sex lives. But these are the days of Viagra, when frank discussions of impotence can seem as natural as talking about fiscal conservatism.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN FALLS 1.7 PERCENT. Corn dropped on forecasts of mostly dry weekend weather for the rain-soaked Midwest, which has prevented some farmers from planting. July contracts fell 4.5 cents a bushel, to $2.5575.

title: Styles Changed, but Lemaire Did Not
