description: A few months ago, Colin Campbell coached the Rangers, Rick Bowness coached the Islanders and Jacques Lemaire coached the Devils. Now, all three are gone, the local hockey hat trick completed yesterday when Lemaire resigned from the New Jersey team.

title: Apparel Maker Sues Liz Claiborne and Union
description: Liz Claiborne Inc., the clothing manufacturer, and Unite, the principal garment industry union, have been accused in a lawsuit of conducting ''a massive fraudulent scheme'' to destroy one of Claiborne's sweater suppliers, Mademoiselle Knitwear Inc. of Brooklyn.

title: Writing Beyond the Self
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Journal; A Prelate and His Enduring Church
description: When one thinks of globe-trotting religious leaders, Pope John Paul II most likely comes first to mind. He has, after all, made 82 trips outside Italy since becoming spiritual leader of the world's Roman Catholics in 1978.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: POUND HITS 2-MONTH LOW. Sterling dropped on a London Business School forecast that Britain's economy would slow considerably this year. In New York the pound fell to $1.6393 from $1.6491, the lowest since March 8.

title: Get Tough With Japan (Phase 2)
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan was armed with charts and graphs when he visited the White House last year. He intended to rebut American fears that an increase in Japan's consumption tax, loaded onto an already fragile economy, would crush any chance for growth.

title: Slain Woman Was Daughter Of Diplomat
description: A young woman found shot to death in Cunningham Park in Queens on Thursday was identified yesterday as the 19-year-old daughter of the second-ranking diplomat in Yemen's Mission to the United Nations, officials said.

title: Grand Finales, Pre-'Seinfeld'; The Streets
description: ''M*A*S*H'' ended on the evening of Feb. 28, 1983, and it was a peculiar experience for all of us. The cast and production team gathered at the studio for a screening of the last episode, and then we went out to a restaurant to celebrate. The actual broadcast had already begun, and we realized as we drove to the restaurant that the streets of Los Angeles were nearly deserted. It suddenly struck us that an enormous number of people must be home watching. As we found out the next day, it had been well over 125 million. We were strangely quiet that night, sorry to be leaving one another and very aware of all those people out there. It was exciting to be playing to that many people, but I think we were a little stunned by it, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, EVE
description: WEINER-Eve, 92. On May 7, 1998. Beloved mother of Rhoda Pappenheimer and Michael Weiner. Loving grandmother of Andrea Segal, Vicki Criss and Julie Held. Dear great-grandmother of four. Cherished sister of Abraham Kirschenbaum and Helen Kopelov. Graveside service at Cedar Park Cemetery, on Monday 11 A.M.

title: Finding Joy and Sharing It
description: There is a sense, when hearing Etta Jones sing, of a self receding into tradition. Ms. Jones, who has spent the last 31 years of her career leading a group with the tenor saxophonist Houston Person, is one of the great singers working in jazz, and the oddest thing about her performances is their selflessness. She's there to take pleasure in the music, to be generous about the joy she so obviously feels and to share it.

title: CHS ELECTRONICS IN LATIN AMERICA COMPUTER DEAL
description: The computer distributor CHS Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire three computer-equipment distribution businesses in Latin America for cash and stock. The Miami-based CHS said the purchase price would be based on the acquired businesses' future performance. The companies to be acquired have estimated combined 1998 sales of $330 million. The largest of them is Intcomex, which has annual sales of more than $200 million and operations in Chile, Guatemala, Mexico, Panama, Peru, Uruguay and Miami. CHS will also acquire Acron S.A. of Argentina, with sales of $32 million, and Cornejo Informatica S.A. of Argentina, with sales of $21 million. CHS distributes computers, peripherals and software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABSEVITZ, EMMA
description: SABSEVITZ-Emma, 96. Of Miami Beach. Formerly of New York City, on May 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Irving Sabsevitz. Loving mother of Arnold L. & Lite Sabin, the late Natalie (Nibs) Sabin Gottesman and the late Judith Sabin Meisel. Cherished grandmother of Barbara and Stephen Miller, Charles and Merrill Gottesman, Jill and Charles Garner, Doctor James L. and Ellen Meisel and Vicki Meisel. Adored great-grandmother of Erin, Melinda, Caroline, Alison, Victoria and Carly. Life member of Hadassah. A generous and giving person. She will be missed by many who loved her dearly. Graveside services were held May 8th in Florida. For more information call Riverside Gordon Funeral Home, 1-800-759-1151.

title: 30 Suspects Are Arrested In Drug Sales to Youths
description: Thirty people were arrested yesterday in Gloucester and Camden Counties after a six-month undercover operation against a drug ring that sold thousands of dollars' worth of marijuana a week to teen-agers in southern New Jersey, prosecutors said.

title: MEXICAN CONGLOMERATE BUYS AUTHENTIC SPECIALTY FOODS
description: Authentic Specialty Foods Inc., a provider of Mexican food products, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Mexican conglomerate Desc S.A. for $17 a share, or $136.4 million. Authentic Specialty, based in Grand Prairie, Tex., makes tortillas, tortilla chips, salsa, cheeses and sauces under the brands Calidad, La Victoria, La Monita, Tortilla King and Alamo Street. It had first-quarter sales of $20.8 million. The company's stock rose 75 cents yesterday to $16.75 in Nasdaq trading. Desc had first-quarter sales of 4.43 billion pesos ($521.4 million).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, ANDREA
description: FARBER-Andrea. Beloved daughter of Murray and Audrey Farber. Dear sister of Sharlene Slutsky and Dodd Farber. Adored aunt. Services Sunday 11:30 A.M., at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Ex-Judge Gets Jail Term For Seeking Sex Favors
description: A former judge of Jersey City Municipal Court was sentenced yesterday to 30 months in Federal prison after admitting he offered to fix traffic tickets for women in exchange for sexual favors.

title: Tobacco Bill Supporters Buoyed by Minnesota Case
description: President Clinton, Senator John McCain and others in Congress who favor broad anti-smoking legislation said today that the settlement of the lawsuit against the tobacco industry in Minnesota improved the prospects for such a bill.

title: Hubbells Plead Not Guilty To Charges of Tax Evasion
description: Webster L. Hubbell, President Clinton's close friend and former Justice Department appointee, entered a plea of not guilty today to tax evasion charges brought by the independent counsel investigating the President's business and personal life.

title: Grand Finales, Pre-'Seinfeld'; The Island
description: ''Rescue me'' may be the phrase that best describes the 30-odd years since ''Gilligan's Island'' left prime time. That's because we never were rescued -- no final episode; no planning the final moment when all of us would return from paradise to the real world; no press, no anticipation, no farewells.

title: Chief U.N. Delegate May Get Energy Post
description: Though he holds a post that he seems to relish as chief delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson is likely to be President Clinton's nominee to be Energy Secretary, Administration officials are saying.

title: Editorial Observer; Ross Perot's Political Progeny Hit the Hustings
description: John Edwards's $3.2 million investment paid off this week when he handily won the North Carolina Democratic primary for U.S. Senate. Mr. Edwards's self-financed campaign drew little national attention. (The incumbent, Lauch Faircloth, did cause one brief flurry of excitement when he charged that Mr. Edwards, a lawyer, was responsible for rising health-care costs because he had won some malpractice cases.) But the national Democratic Party is now embracing its rich new nominee as the candidate most likely to topple a Republican Senator, in what a local paper called ''the battle between a self-made multimillionaire lawyer and a self-made multimillionaire hog farmer.''

title: TOUGHER LABELING FOR ORGANIC FOOD
description: Bowing to the wishes of consumers, the Government announced today that it would not allow food to be labeled ''organic'' if it was genetically engineered, irradiated or grown in soil fertilized with sewage sludge.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate Falls Sharply, More Americans Find Work

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWN, JAMES A.
description: BROWN-James A. Dearest daddy, during this last year I've reached for the phone 10,000 times, miss you dreadfully. Joyce

title: About New York; Giving Voice, And Meaning, To Old Age
description: YAFFA SCHLESINGER'S office at Hunter College commands a magnificent cityscape of soaring towers, graceful bridges and streets teeming with people. Life can appear dizzyingly random so far up, though Ms. Schlesinger knows better.

title: Allan Cormack, 74, Nobelist Who Helped Invent CAT Scan
description: Allan MacLeod Cormack, whose boyhood fascination with the vast canopy of stars above his South African home started him on a circuitous journey that led him to the accidental discovery of the underpinning of CAT scan X-ray technology and a share of the 1979 Nobel Prize for medicine, died on Thursday at his home in Winchester, Mass. He was 74 and had been a professor of physics at Tufts University.

title: Turkey Sells Its Stake In Bank for $651 Million
description: Turkey's Privatization Administration has sold its 12.3 percent stake in Turkiye Is Bankasi A.S., Turkey's largest nonstate bank, for $651 million, according to Salomon Smith Barney, which managed the sale.

title: U.N. Lifts Travel Ban on Iraqis Without Objection From U.S.
description: The Clinton Administration offered no objections in the Security Council today when a travel ban on Iraqi officials was ended, but the United States and Russia are still at an impasse over when and how to respond to a report last month that in effect declared Iraq free of nuclear weapons.

title: Lettuce Is Available, But Costing More Green
description: As a rule, Mary Keselowsky of Oakhurst, N.J., serves salad to her husband and three children at dinner. But when the price of romaine lettuce recently climbed to $1.99 a head, double what Ms. Keselowsky usually pays for it, she refused to add it to her shopping cart.

title: Shadowed By Upsets, Lemaire Says 'It's Time'
description: Jacques Lemaire, the man who brought a Stanley Cup to New Jersey in 1995 but then saw his team fall surprisingly short of expectations in the three seasons that followed, stepped down today as coach of the Devils after five years on the job.

title: The Georgia Republican Who Uses the I-Word
description: Representative Bob Barr complained that he had a plane to catch, but the young female security guard at the airport metal detector cursed and instructed her colleague to take her time looking through his bag. When Mr. Barr angrily demanded her name, she stuck her ID in his face, and he slapped her arms down forcefully. She came charging back at him, and he yelled, ''Nobody swears at me!'' The guards who quickly surrounded them led her away, and he walked on.

title: Papers Detail Identification Of Attacker By Louima
description: Three days after Abner Louima was reportedly brutalized at a Brooklyn police station house in August, he identified a photograph of Officer Justin A. Volpe as ''looking like'' the officer who he said had assaulted him with a stick in a bathroom, according to court papers filed by Federal prosecutors.

title: Sports of The Times; 30-Something Nears an End In the N.B.A.
description: EARLY yesterday morning, Clyde Drexler asked about his old buddy Patrick Ewing of the Knicks. Drexler, who is officially retired now that the Houston Rockets' season is over, said he hadn't closely followed the rest of the playoffs. Still, he said he was interested in the fraternity of players he spent battling during his 15 years in the National Basketball Association. Ewing most of all.

title: Bring on Garden Fans: The Pacers Feel Ready
description: They expect a video presentation Saturday before Game 3 at Madison Square Garden, followed by an ear-splitting roar, the chants cascading from the rafters, a pageantry befitting Patrick Ewing's homecoming.

title: U.N. Envoy Likely to Get Energy Post
description: Bill Richardson, the United States representative to the United Nations, is likely to be chosen as President Clinton's next energy secretary, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: McGwire Hits 400th, But Mets Win Again
description: Last night, Mark McGwire gave the weather-beaten fans at Shea Stadium something to remember when he supplanted Babe Ruth as the player to reach the 400-homer plateau in the fewest career at-bats.

title: A Delicate Medium, Less Easy Than It Looks
description: THE first works representing scenes of the New World by European explorer-artists were watercolors. Thus, the art of watercolor painting has a formidable history in America that goes back to the late 16th century. But not until the mid-1800's was the medium appreciated for its esthetic value and accepted as a means to create an independent work of art rather than to achieve documentation.

title: Counseling Sessions At High School Level
description: A COLLABORATION between the White Plains School District and the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's Westchester division has resulted in a new program for secondary school students 12 through 21, who are having difficulty in school because of emotional or psychiatric problems.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WANTING A CHILD

title: Into the Island Lair of a Currency-Trading Tiger
description: JOSEPH C. LEWIS is a private man. He lives regally, but quietly, in a low-slung, beachfront manse that abuts a golf course and a yacht-filled marina in this luxurious, palm-swept enclave. His neighbors include others who value their privacy, and the island's tax-haven status: the actor Sean Connery; the novelist Arthur Hailey; Fahad Al Sabah, a member of the Kuwaiti royal family; the mutual fund legend Sir John Templeton.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Finding Time

title: When Baseball Was Black and White
description: WHO Lawrence Hogan, 53, of Fanwood, a professor of history at Union County College in Cranford, with a Ph.D in American and Afro-American history from Indiana University. Mr. Hogan has acquired what is believed to be the most extensive private collection of black baseball memorabilia in the United States outside the Negro League Museum in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a street-widening plan in lower Manhattan misidentified the street. As the article said, it was Greenwich Street, not Greenwich Avenue.

title: Correction
description: The front-page index in this section last Sunday misspelled the given name of the trumpeter whose interpretation of Stravinsky was the subject of an article on the classical music page. He is Wynton Marsalis, not Winton.

title: Political Briefing; Feud Erupts Over Bills For Governor's Food
description: In South Carolina, they call it the ''food feud.''

title: POSTINGS: Apartments Above, Offices Below; Slicing Up Wedding Cake
description: The flow of rental apartments into Manhattan's financial district continues with the Renaissance, a 36-story office building at the corner of John and Gold Streets. The 23 upper floors of the 1931 wedding-cake-style structure are being converted to 221 apartments, 84 of which will have terraces.

title: True to Her Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOURKE, VERNON J.
description: BOURKE-Vernon J. On May 4, 1998. Retired Philosophy Professor, St. Louis University (45 years), author of twenty books, worldwide lecturer. 1988 Toronto University Distinguished Alumnus. President, American Catholic Philosophic Association, 1948. Phi Beta Kappa. Prominent ethics and medieval philosophy educator with special emphasis on St. Augustine and St. Thomas Aquinas. Honorary member of the Order of St. Augustine, 1982. Natural Law Board, University of Notre Dame.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on April 26 about plans to improve Sheffield Plaza, on Ninth Avenue at 56th Street, referred incorrectly to city regulation of such ''bonus'' plazas, installed by developers. The 1977 regulation that provided for the plazas allowed some of them, including Sheffield, to be closed at night. In 1996, the regulations were changed to require plaza improvements and Planning Commission approval if the areas were to be closed at night. No law was passed after 1989 prohibiting fences around the plazas.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article and a chart on the Backtalk page last Sunday about the Masters swimmer Jeff Farrell referred incorrectly to his training and accomplishments. His daily workout regimen in 1960 involved swimming 6,000 yards a day five to six days a week, not 2,000 yards. In the 1960 national championships, Farrell's double victory came in the 100-yard and 220-yard freestyle races, not the 100- and 50-yard races. In the chart, Farrell's freestyle times were for 50 yards, not 50 meters.

title: Single Mother's Helpers
description: THIS is not exactly your standard Hallmark Mother's Day story.

title: Husband and Wife Feature Sushi and Sashimi
description: Can a seasoned sushi chef succeed in a location that might seem to have had a restaurant jinx? The site, at 1350 Madison Avenue (between 94th and 95th Streets), has had much turnover in recent years. Once occupied by Saranac and then, only for a few months, by Bum Steer, it is now the home of Sachi.

title: A Wealth of Wildes, From Honest Oscar To Pensive Outcast
description: FOR most of the somber final scene of ''The Judas Kiss,'' David Hare's new play at the Broadhurst Theater, Oscar Wilde (Liam Neeson), recently released from prison and dressed in black, sits in noble, exhausted profile at the right of the stage. It is near dawn. The setting is the sparely furnished Mediterranean villa where he has been reunited with Lord Alfred Douglas (Tom Hollander), called Bosie, the beloved, madly unstable young muse for whom he has sacrificed his art, reputation, career, country and family.

title: 'Romeo and Juliet' at Prep School
description: SHE is a demure and obedient teen-ager until a star-crossed love transforms her into a defiant woman. Ever young, Juliet would not be so diminutive by any other name; hers means little Julia.

title: The Angry Urban Refugees
description: A CENTURY-OLD facade tumbles, tenants are roused from their beds, and reporters arrive to chronicle yet another faltering building in the city.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Jaguar XJ8; A V8 and an Exorcism Lift the Spirit of the Cat
description: IT was one of those uncommonly warm nights when you hardly needed a coat. I was returning home from a delightful dinner in a 1995 Jaguar sedan, only slightly used. The sunroof was open, the heated leather seat was easing the chill and Luciano Pavarotti's voice was wafting from the stereo into the heavens.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Liberalism Isn't Everything
description: CIVILITY

title: As Filipinos Vote, Movie Idol Has a Starring Role
description: Vice President Joseph P. Estrada hunched over a microphone in the stifling heat of the evening, a sagging, heavy-set man with a bouffant hairdo, a black smudge of a mustache and a bright orange vest, and reveled in his ignorance.

title: Williams Reaches Italian Final Only to Meet Hingis
description: The education of Venus Williams continues, and today's semifinal match at the Italian Open against Arantxa Sanchez Vicario confirmed that she is no innocent abroad.

title: A Fight Over September Games
description: Major league baseball and ESPN are in a standoff over September games that could land in court.

title: Interactive N.F.L. Is on Way
description: The National Football League is in the late stages of planning a possibly prosperous adventure. The league is working with the St. Joe Corporation, a real estate development company, to form several interactive entertainment centers that will include technology-based games, retail stores and restaurants, all located in an atmosphere similar to a football stadium.

title: Kayaking Among Dragons
description: OUR kayaks slice through the deep emerald seas of Halong Bay off Vietnam under the light of a full moon, with only the soft sound of our paddles dipping and sweeping the water.

title: Ideas & Trends; Is This Tomorrow? Nah. Yesterday.
description: THERE was a time when tomorrow seemed an enticing proposition. In the postwar years, a sort of World's Fair mentality prevailed, a sunny sense that the march of progress would inevitably transform the future into a cornucopia of solutions. Futuristic meant optimistic.

title: May 3-9; Killings in the Vatican
description: A disgruntled Swiss Guard killed his commanding officer and the officer's wife inside the Vatican, and then turned the gun on himself, a Vatican spokesman said.

title: The Queen Goes Green: Cars of H.R.M. Will Run on L.P.G.
description: QUEEN ELIZABETH II has had four of her cars including a gas-guzzling Rolls-Royce used for ceremonial occasions -- converted to run on cleaner-burning liquefied petroleum gas, or L.P.G., as well as on conventional gasoline.

title: FRESH AIR FUND; Going to 'the Country' for Summertime Fun and Waffles
description: On a beautiful day four years ago, Rita Jenkins of Ridgewood was driving home with her two young sons in the car when she started thinking about how lucky she was -- with healthy children and a lovely home -- and how she would like to reach out and help someone less fortunate.

title: Laurie Rosensweig, Jonathan Blank
description: Laurie Sue Rosensweig, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norton S. Rosensweig of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there last evening to Jonathan Steven Blank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Blank, also of Scarsdale. Rabbi Richard J. Jacobs performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: On Language; Great Moments In Moments
description: ''I 'm always afraid i'm going to have a senior moment,'' jokes Hildegarde Mahoney of Palm Beach, Fla. She is quoted using this locution in ''The Longevity Strategy: How to Live to 100 Using the Brain-Body Connection,'' by David Mahoney and Richard Restak, M.D., and her meaning is that she has forgotten something and figures that's evidence of growing older.

title: Playing the Name Game on West 23d
description: Maybe it's something about the block. For the second time in six months, a small business on West 23d Street has been forced to change its name because it was already claimed by a big business.

title: 3 in Florida Charged With Making Bombs
description: Two men and a woman who claim allegiance to a white supremacist group have been charged with manufacturing pipe bombs that investigators say were meant to divert attention from two bank robberies they planned to commit in the Orlando area last year.

title: For the Dying, Music Can Be More Than Just a Requiem
description: Q. I have read that music is being increasingly used to provide final comfort to the terminally ill. As a musician, I'd like to explore this area for full-time employment.

title: Rutgers's Mission
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dry Spell
description: For the modern bath, the understated towel.

title: Sonics' Tricky Puzzle: Lakers' Size and Youth
description: George Karl and Shaquille O'Neal have sheathed their sharp barbs. Seattle's Gary Payton is not saying why he chased the National Basketball Association official Danny Crawford off the floor at the final buzzer of Friday's 119-103 pasting with enough rage that his teammates had to collar him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMMER, THEODORE (TEDDY)
description: EMMER-Theodore (Teddy). Of Miami Beach, on Friday, May 8, 1998 in his 97th year. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Loving father of Herbert and cherished father-in-law of Carolee. Adored grandfather of Susan and Matthew, brother of Claire, Sylvia, Leon and the late Fay. Private family services at Beth David, Elmont Long Island. Contributions to you favorite charity please.

title: Some Diners' Pet Peeves About Restaurants
description: WHAT is wrong with Island restaurants? Not the food, according to most of the letters and comments I receive. Complaints from local diners center primarily on service and secondarily about annoying restaurant policies.

title: Sheila Cummings And Tod Macri
description: Sheila Mary Cummings, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin J. Cummings of Shelton, Conn., was married yesterday to Theodore William Macri Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Macri of New York. The Rev. Kenneth E. Jennings performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Catholic Church in Narragansett, R.I.

title: Elizabeth Darst and Henry Tenney Jr.
description: ELEVEN years ago, Elizabeth Standish Darst was working in New York as an editorial assistant at Snoopy, a children's magazine. It was there she met Henry Baird Tenney Jr., who was her office mate's serious boyfriend.

title: Seinfeld & Associates: A Portfolio
description: ACCORDING to conventional wisdom, ''Seinfeld,'' which will present its final episode on Thursday, has been the first sitcom about nothing. But in looking back on the series, a case could be made that ''Seinfeld'' has indeed been about something -- consumerism.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on April 19 about Irish cooking schools misstated the location of Miltown Malbay. It is west of Dublin, not south.

title: Shanghai
description: To the Editor: I have just returned from Shanghai and am delighted to read Seth Faison's ''What's Doing in Shanghai'' (April 19). Indeed, Shanghai is a wanderer's city, but recent changes have rendered it unrecognizable (I spent my childhood there half a century ago). I was most unsettled by the unruly bicycles.

title: Corrections
description: The cover article of The Times Magazine today, about Warren Beatty, includes an outdated reference to the opening of his new movie, ''Bulworth.'' After the magazine had gone to press, the opening was postponed, to next Friday, from last Friday.

title: Liberal Party Picks Democrat For Governor
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, the one-time Republican academic seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, received a political lift yesterday when the Liberal Party embraced her as its candidate, insuring her a spot on the ballot in November.

title: Putting It in Writing: Views of New Jersey -- FACT; Prepared to Push The Panic Buttons
description: As writers reach into their memories and imaginations, New Jersey turns up in a variety of guises. Here are excerpts from a variety of books that appealed to editors of this section.

title: Ugly Reality In Rwanda
description: The Secretary General of the United Nations walked into a political ambush this weekend, absorbing personal attacks from Rwandan leaders angry at the organization for failing to intervene in the 1994 genocide here. He even had to endure a humiliating diatribe from the Foreign Minister.

title: VIEWPOINT; How the Government Can Insure Fairer Fares
description: IN the early 1960's, a one-way, unrestricted, economy-class ticket from New York to Cleveland cost $28.61. Adjusted upward for inflation, but not downward for airline efficiencies of the last three decades, that ticket would now cost $148.

title: Hudson County Forming A Car-Theft Task Force
description: A month after a report said Hudson County had the nation's highest rate of auto thefts, county officials said Friday that they would form a task force to address the issue or join one shared by Essex and Union Counties.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Giving Children Another Summer at Play
description: SUMMERS were always bustling when Carol Rawlins was growing up on Cape Cod. In addition to her five siblings, the house was full of visitors -- cousins from Providence, R.I., neighbors, and always, always, children from New York City sent by the Fresh Air Fund. ''My Mom was so kid-oriented; she felt somebody had to do it,'' Mrs. Rawlins recalled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISK, KATHRYN APPEL
description: BISK-Kathryn Appel. In Princeton, MA, May 6, 1998. Treasured wife of Richard. Devoted mother of Megan, Brittany and Joshua. Loving daughter of Bunny and Jack. Cherished sister of Frederic. Beloved teacher of many. She will always live in our hearts.

title: Brian Milton
description: Milton and his friend Keith Reynolds, Englishmen both, are trying to accomplish an aviation first by circling the world in the GT Global Flyer, a ''microlight'' hang glider with a small engine and cockpit. He spoke by phone during a layover.

title: Literary Pilgrimages; George Orwell
description: Is there any form of travel less reliable than the literary pilgrimage? Based on a murky urge to honor some vanished authorial idol, such an expedition can spin out of control as soon as you've left your library.

title: Hard-Edged Imagery but Surprisingly Sensuous
description: Takayo Noda

title: Years of More Frequent Storms Predicted
description: IT was the big one, the storm everyone expected but hoped would never happen. A Category 3 hurricane, similar to the devastating one of 1938, was churning up the Atlantic coast, heading for Long Island.

title: Safer Riding For Children
description: HERE are some cautionary statistics to consider: Traffic injuries are the leading cause of death among children in the United States, killing 2,122 children 15 years of age or younger in 1996 and injuring 330,000, according to National Highway Traffic Safety Administration figures. And last summer, the Travel Industry Association of America says, 43 percent of adults who traveled took children with them, most of them in the family car.

title: Popular Neighborhood Spot in Scarsdale
description: A GLASS vat of grappa Italy's warming, knee-weakening liquor as potent as schnapps -- marks the center of the street-level dining room, and a few small pictures occupy the vast wall spaces. Excepting the gray-haired man behind the bar, who scowled as he plunked down menus on the table and was clearly annoyed that we were there, waiting staff proved friendly and efficient, and on all our other visits the welcome could not have been warmer.

title: Pennsylvania County Resumes Commercial Growth
description: WITH the recession of the early 90's ended, Chester County is once again the fastest-growing county in eastern Pennsylvania, with plans for five million square feet of new commercial space set in motion last year alone.

title: U.S. Envoy, Again in Israel, Sees Netanyahu and Arafat
description: Israeli and American officials acknowledged today that the Israeli-Palestinian summit meeting offered by President Clinton could not be held on Monday, but they indicated that it would still be held, perhaps late this month.

title: REPLANTING TIME
description: *''Dead bodies are uncommonly lively in the former Socialist bloc,'' says Katherine Verdery, an anthropologist, in her forthcoming book, ''The Political Lives of Dead Bodies in the Postsocialist Transformation.'' * Bodies get moved as political winds change. Bulgaria's Czar Boris died in 1943; in 1989 his widow brought his heart back to Bulgaria from Spain, where the couple lived in exile. * In 1987, 600 years after the Serbian Czar Lazar died in the Battle of Kosovo, his body was taken on a tour of monasteries. * In 1991, officials in Hungary brought home ashes of the country's 1918 Minister of Ethnic Affairs, Oszkar Jaszi, from a tomb in Oberlin, Ohio. * Inocentiu Micu Klein, an 18th-century Romanian hero, moved in style. Last August his remains traveled from a crypt in Rome back to Romania -- by limousine.

title: Payton Finally Finds His Way to the Mets
description: Jay Payton could not believe the news. The Mets were bringing him up to the major leagues.

title: Child Pornography
description: G. Donald White, 70, of Hastings-on-Hudson, a retired actor, was sentenced to 3 1/2 to 10 1/2 years in state prison for inducing a 14-year-old boy to engage in a sexual performance that was photographed.

title: At This Field, the Midville Team Is More Like Mudville
description: It was sunny, spring and a Saturday, but there was no joy in Midville.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASON, CALMAN
description: MASON-Calman, 85, on May 6. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Father of Ira and Gail, Marilyn and Bob. Grandfather of Bonnie, Michael, Cori, Seth, Jonathan and the late Marc. Great grandfather of Joshua and Zachary. His warmth and love and kindness personified the fullest expression of the goodness in man. We are far richer for having known him.

title: Aeolian Isles
description: To the Editor: Though I have never visited the Aeolian Islands, they are familiar. One of my favorite Italian directors, Nanni Moretti, travels the islands in his poignant comedy, ''Caro Diario'' (''Dear Diary'').

title: Providing Trained Liaisons in Health Care
description: ''WE HAVE all had personal experiences with doctors, hospitals, clinics and the like, and as more and more of us find ourselves in managed-care plans, it has become increasingly difficult to navigate the health care delivery minefield,'' said Joan Marks, director and founder of a graduate program in health advocacy at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. ''We all could use a friend at court.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, ANDREA
description: FARBER-Andrea. Beloved daughter of Murray and Audrey Farber. Dear sister of Sharlene Slutsky and Dodd Farber. Adored aunt. Services Sunday 11:30 A.M., at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills, New York.

title: Gayle Carter and David Meyers
description: Gayle Jo Carter is to be married today to David Christian Meyers at Meadowlark Gardens, a botanical garden in Vienna, Va. Rabbi Harold S. White is to officiate.

title: Sometimes, Casual Just Won't Do
description: As the weather improves, so does the climate for casual days, those corporately sanctioned breaches of formal office wear. Who wears what on casual day in your office, and does any of the attire make you pine for a bit less latitude in personal style? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Marriage That Feels a Bit Crowded
description: ''FANCIES'' is about a cultural clash that threatens the marriage of Michael and Elizabeth Crowther, an interracial couple married 18 years. They are played by Frankie R. Faison and Jane Mandel, an interracial couple married 20 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDELL, STEPHANIE
description: LIDELL-Stephanie. On May 7, 1998. Beloved life partner of Judy Hagen. Dear sister of James, Vivian, William, Robert and Nora. Also survived by numerous nieces & nephews & many, many friends. Reposing at the Walter B. CookeKennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd Street (between Columbus and Amsterdam), Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 and Monday 2-5. Funeral services Monday 7 P.M., at the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73rd Street (West of Broadway).

title: May 3-9; Phenom's Fastball
description: Kerry Wood is not one to waste time -- not when he throws a baseball, not when he blasts off on a career. When the Chicago Cubs rookie hurled pitches at the Houston Astros at up to 100 miles an hour, the Astro playerss could not figure out quite how to handle them. In the end, they didn't. In the Cubs' 2-0 victory, Wood had 20 strikeouts, tying a National League record -- and a number, as it happens, that matched his age. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Smits Struggles Again, And Pacers Do the Same
description: In one of Rik Smits's more recent visits to Madison Square Garden, he astonished this year's All-Star Game crowd by playing point guard. After Smits deftly executed a no-look, behind-the-back pass on a fast break, Michael Jordan smiled as the rest of Smits's Eastern Conference teammates rose in unison, slapping hands and laughing.

title: Dana Harper, Peter Turk
description: Dana Houghton Harper, the daughter of Georgena K. Grove of Vero Beach, Fla., and Kenneth B. Harper of Mount Dora, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Joshua Turk, the son of Joan and Robert B. Turk of Maplewood, N.J. William J. Stewart, a notary public, officiated at the Grand Harbor Golf Club in Vero Beach.

title: Cancer Victim to Walk in Fund-Raising Race
description: SHE has become a familiar figure to the early risers of this town. A petite woman in her 60's starting at the train station and walking briskly through Mount Kisco. Arms pumping, her short, dark hair matting as she proceeds, she walks with purpose, with determination, as if on a mission.

title: Bulletin: Yanks, Behind Pettitte, Actually Lose One
description: The Yankees returned sullenly to their clubhouse after losing tonight to the Minnesota Twins, with thick stares, the sound of their footsteps echoing above the silence of the cement hallway. A few stopped to pick at the post-game spread, but many quickly showered, dressed and fled the Metrodome, as if to purge themselves of defeat's scent.

title: Checking Medicine's Vital Signs
description: Your article failed to reveal whether this rating system would adjust for noncompliance among hypertensive patients who don't take their medication or diabetics who do not follow their therapeutic regimens. The reality is that health care teams now involve the patient as an active member in achieving high-quality care; this confers a responsibility upon the patient.

title: Word for Word/Historical 'What Ifs?'; Annie Could've Gotten Her Gun And Blown Away the Kaiser
description: HISTORIANS try to answer many questions, but the one they seem to have the most fun with is, ''What if?''

title: Windup Life
description: HOURMASTER By Christophe Bataille. Translated by Richard Howard. 108 pp. New York: New Directions. $17.95.

title: The World: Foreign Entanglements; Aid Dresses Up in a Uniform
description: CONGRESS is wrestling with the future of three great international institutions: NATO, the United Nations and the International Monetary Fund. One is wildly popular. The other two, to put it mildly, aren't.

title: Vietnam Memorial Service Remembers State's Women
description: Of the 1,553 New Jerseyans killed in action whose names are engraved on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel Township, only one is a woman. Eleanor Grace Alexander of River Vale was a 27-year-old Army nurse when she was killed in Vietnam in 1967.

title: Christina Prunier And David Doss
description: Christina Elizabeth Prunier, the senior vice president of Phoenix Pictures, a film production company in Culver City, Calif., was married yesterday to David Armster Doss, the executive producer of NBC's ''Nightly News with Tom Brokaw'' in New York. The Rev. Dr. Walter J. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Classical Briefs
description: BARBER, BARTOK, VAUGHAN WILLIAMS: CHORAL WORKS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMUTTER, JULES
description: PERLMUTTER-Jules, D.D.S. Of New Rochelle, on May 7, 1998. Devoted husband of Alice (nee Malerman). Loving step-father of Martin, Lowell and Glenn Bergman. A private cremation was conducted by the George T. Davis Funeral Home.

title: Q&A: William Flynn; Guiding the Knights of Malta in Charity
description: THE Sovereign Military Order of the Knights of Malta traces its origins to the time of the Crusades. This Roman Catholic charitable organization is currently dedicated to the relief of poverty and sickness around the world.

title: Gay Cruises Draw Hostility in the Caribbean
description: AFTER hundreds of demonstrators heckled some 800 lesbian passengers who arrived in Nassau, the Bahamas, last month aboard Premier Cruises's Seabreeze, a headline in Cruise Week, a trade publication, asked, ''Homophobic Protests on Rise in Ports?''

title: Essay on Sidewalk Cafes Was Restaurant-Bashing
description: To the Editor:

title: Meredith Maher, Michael Peterson
description: Meredith Loveday Maher, a daughter of Martha B. Deprez of Portland, Me., and Peter S. Maher of West Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Alexander Peterson, a son of Dr. Sally H. Peterson and Peter G. Peterson, both of New York. The Rev. John Madden performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOBKER, JACK RICHARD
description: BOBKER-Jack Richard. A very special person to all who knew him. On May 8, 1998 at the age of 69. Cherished and adored husband of Arlene, father of Ken, Jay, and Larry. Father-in-law of Wendy and grandfather of Zachary and Chloe. Brother of Lee and Kate and brother-in-law of Ira. Dearest friend of Bruce and Fern, David and Pearl and Buddy and John. Godfather of Evan and Brent. Funeral services will be held at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., 9:30 AM, Monday. May he always rest in peace.

title: Bali Hai, Now on Avenue A
description: AS I navigated through the suits and sex kittens packing the upstairs bar at Asia de Cuba on a recent Thursday night, a young woman in black boot-cut trousers and a white crocheted halter top spied my drink and asked the only logical question: ''What is that?!''

title: Childs Is a Keeper for Van Gundy
description: Less than five minutes into the third quarter, it became obvious why Jeff Van Gundy coaches the Knicks, and not Bruce from Flushing. Before thousands of disbelieving eyes inside Madison Square Garden, Oscar Robertson had come out of retirement, in the body of Mark Jackson, at the expense of Charlie Ward.

title: SOAPBOX; Low Turnout? No Turnout
description: DEMOCRACY may be messy, especially at the local level, but it's better than the alternative. In a textbook example of the electoral process at work, townsfolk in some 550 New Jersey districts had the opportunity to say yea or nay to their school budgets last month. Of those towns, 74.6 percent gave the thumbs up to proposed spending.

title: Animal Shelter Group Sues Volunteers for Libel
description: An organization that handles animal control for 29 municipalities has filed a libel suit against 15 former volunteers at an animal shelter in Monmouth County. The suit cites a news release the volunteers sent to state officials and regional newspapers in March, which said the Tinton Falls shelter of the the Associated Humane Societies of New Jersey treated dogs and cats inhumanely, advertised deceptively and banked its money instead of investing in improvements (''At This Animal Shelter, It's the Humans Who Are Fighting,'' March 29).

title: Errors Doom MetroStars To a Loss
description: Before tonight's game against the defending champion D.C. United, MetroStars Coach Alfonso Mondelo said his team could use the match as a measuring stick.

title: Pasta Magic, in Minutes, From the Pantry
description: PASTA'S popularity has to do not only with its versatility and taste appeal but also with its convenience. What else do you have on the pantry shelf that does not have a lot of additives, yet can be ready to serve, with minimal effort, in minutes?

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: WHAT SHE KNEW

title: New York Area Retirees Get More Housing Choices
description: AT 73, John Curran has made a decision about where he wants to live next. He will be moving when he turns 75 from his one-bedroom co-op on East 76th Street to a new retirement community in New Jersey called Seabrook Village, in the Monmouth County town of Tinton Falls.

title: FILM; In France, the Focus Shifts From Paris
description: ACROSS from the chalky cliffs of Dover, where the North Sea meets the English Channel and Flanders Fields run to the shore, the landscape is a rough mix of thickets and dunes. ''It's a view that gives me the shivers,'' says Bruno Dumont, director of the film ''La Vie de Jesus.'' ''It may not be beautiful to the naked eye, but it's beautiful to film.''

title: Witness Tampering Seen In Bronx Flowerpot Case
description: Detectives investigating an incident in which a flowerpot was thrown from a window and hit two police officers in the Bronx last week have arrested a teen-ager on a charge of witness tampering, apparently for trying to hinder their investigation, the police said yesterday.

title: EAT, ENJOY
description: It's a real-estate axiom that free buffets lure potential home buyers, so it probably makes sense to extend the gimmick to selling final resting places. In a recent innovation, Star of David, Beth David and Levitt-Weinstein memorial chapels, in south Florida, have been offering huge -- 140-foot! -- Chinese buffet brunches for the elderly. While potential clients heap their plates with moo shu chicken, the hosts discuss monuments, northern shipping rates and cremation options. This isn't just frivolous conversation, of course: according to one report, there's a funeral in Florida every 15 minutes, and the customers like to be courted. ''They come with napkins and big bags and take home leftovers,'' says Arthur Grossberg, a Beth David executive. ''But that's how you get people to listen. You offer them food.''

title: A Crime Victim's Comeback
description: Five months after awakening, dazed and caked in blood, in her car one misty December morning, Dr. Victoria Shoaf is no closer to knowing how and by whom she was attacked -- or even where. But those unanswered questions do not trouble Dr. Shoaf, a St. John's University professor.

title: A Caramoor Cabaret In Honor of Mothers
description: AT Caramoor in Katonah, Mother's Day is being observed today starting at 2 P.M. with the opening of an exhibition of costumes from the collection of Lucie and Walter Rosen, the original owners of the estate. Then at 3 P.M. the singer-pianist Larry Woodard offers a cabaret show of ''Songs for Mothers and Others.'' After the musicale, listeners are promised a lavish tea amid ''the regal splendor'' of the Italian Pavilion. Admission is fairly regal, too: $50, $25 for children under 16.

title: Correction
description: The ''Your Home'' column last Sunday misstated the name of a Manhattan real estate brokerage company. It is the Fox Residential Group, not Fox Realty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHTMAN, ELLIOTT
description: HECHTMAN-Elliott, D.D.S. of Great Neck. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Loving father of Barbara Rosenthal (Steven), James Hechtman and Joshua Prager. Dear brother of Beatrice Kaufman. Adored grandfather of Joshua (Julie) and great-grandfather of Alexi and Madeleine. Memorial service on Sunday, 2 PM at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Family Welcomes Girl's Return
description: MICHELLE RIVERA had been to Yankee Stadium before but never in $20 seats right behind home plate. That is where Michelle sat when she went to a ball game last summer with Gary and Kristin Friedman and their children, Sarah, 9, and Matthew, 6.

title: Literary Pilgrimages; Federico Garcia Lorca
description: Granada has produced many writers, but none can compare in fame and influence with Federico Garcia Lorca, a myth in his own lifetime and today the most translated Spanish poet and playwright in history. Which is another way of saying the most loved. Lorca, whose centenary is being celebrated this year, was born on June 5, 1898, in Fuente Vaqueros, a small village nestling among poplar groves in the center of the vega, Granada's fertile plain. His father was a prosperous landowner and his mother had been a primary school teacher. The future poet spent the first 11 years of his life in the vega. Later he was to say that, without that early immersion in the ways and speech habits of the Granadine countryside, he could never have written his rural tragedies. ''I have what psychoanalysts would call an agrarian complex,'' he once commented.

title: From Brando's Lips
description: To the Editor:

title: Theaters Alive With a New Sound of Music
description: THERE was a time when recordings acted like postcards. They reduced three dimensions to two, misapplied colors and told of places their addressees had little hope of visiting themselves. Whether these icons were round and revolving, or rectangular and lying in one's mailbox, certain things on them were recognizable. Distorted and incomplete perhaps, but here an original source and an ultimate beholder found a meeting place.

title: Rock of Ages
description: THE CRUCIBLE

title: Have Leopards and a Tiger, Will Travel
description: IT hasn't been an easy Suffolk County Fair for the folks who run the annual event, which is held by Exit 68 of the Long Island Expressway. First, this year's star attraction, Benny Boom-Boom, ''The Human Bomb,'' got injured. How, you might ask? ''He didn't blow himself up,'' said Bob DeStefano, the president of the fair. ''He was driving up from Florida and he got in an auto accident. He broke his leg.'' So Boom-Boom was out.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Aquebogue-on-the-Mosel

description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Express Expansion Delivers Controversy on Block
description: A plan by Federal Express to expand its operations in Greenwich Village has neighbors worried about increased congestion and pollution. But the company says the impact will be minimal.

title: Markevitch as Composer: An Icarus Who Flew Too High?
description: TALL, gauntly handsome, icily cultivated, the subject of many reverential memoirs and just as many backbiting or salacious rumors, Igor Markevitch was for more than five decades a spook of the first magnitude in the musical life of Europe and some of its North American artistic colonies like Cuba and French Canada. In the United States, however, he has been relatively little known, or known only as a conductor, a situation that may begin to change when the American Symphony Orchestra, directed by Leon Botstein, performs ''Icare,'' Markevitch's reputed masterpiece, on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 10, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEXLER, MELISSA ANN
description: WEXLER-Melissa Ann. May 9, 1958-September 12, 1981. Our dear Missy, this could have been such a special birthday if you were still with us. Love, Mommy, Eddie, Sheri & Larry Arline Joachim

title: May 3-9; A Belated Debt
description: It took 52 years, but Estelle Sapir finally got the attention of Switzerland's banks. The wispy Holocaust survivor, now 72 and living in a small apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens, went to Credit Suisse in 1946 to recover part of the fortune her father had placed there for safekeeping from the Nazis. He died in the camps -- but not before making his daughter memorize the whereabouts of all his deposits. Credit Suisse stonewalled for half a century, until Ms. Sapir appeared before a Senate committee in late 1996. Now, reeling from bad publicity for aiding the Nazis and refusing their victims, the giant bank announced it is convinced that her father deposited funds in their Geneva branch. The bank paid an undisclosed sum, rumored to be $500,000. DAVID E. SANGER

title: Land of the Conquerors
description: EXTREMADURA. It sounds as though it means ''extremely tough.'' All I knew when I began reading about this remote part of Spain was that the Spaniards who conquered the New World in the 16th century had come from there. They brought back Inca and Aztec gold and built palaces and castles that still dominate the region's walled medieval towns.

title: 'Lift Every Voice'

description: Anne Marie Fell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence T. Fell of New York, was married last evening to Jonathan Karis Coon, a son of Ann K. Coon of Arlington, Mass., and Keilah D. Coon of Scituate, Mass. The Rev. Patrick E. Brown performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: Francine Wiest, James Chattra
description: Francine Claire Wiest and James A. Chattra, medical students at Columbia University, were married yesterday in Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. Peter LeJacq, a medical missionary of the Maryknoll Fathers, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Augustine Church.

description: TIMES SQUARE

title: The View From/New Haven; Opening the Doors On Art Workspaces
description: NEXT weekend, artists all around New Haven will open their doors, display their work and talk -- or listen -- to anybody who drops by.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDEZA, CELESTIA M.
description: CARDEZA-Celestia M. March 20, 1927-April 15, 1998. Long-time Gramercy Park resident, born in Philadelphia. Loved books, dogs, orchids, horses, fine cuisine, travel, conversation. A keen mind, a sharp wit, the best of company. Much loved. Sorely missed.

title: Young Performers, Classical Works
description: Youthful energy is on display this afternoon at 3 when the three orchestras operating under the banner of the Norwalk Youth Symphony display their musical skills at the Norwalk Concert Hall. Ami Connoly, the winner of the symphony's concerto competition, collects her performing prize as soloist in Saint-Saens' Cello Concerto No. 1. The program also lists works by Bach, Beethoven, Holst and several American composers.

title: Girls Seek Equal Use Of All Fields For Softball
description: Ask the Heat softball team's utility player what there is to love about the sport, and the response could come from any starry-eyed Little Leaguer: ''I like the thrill of the game. I like knowing I can help out the team when we're losing. I can help bring in some runs. I could make a good play and get the third out.''

title: Along the Atlantic Coast, A New Schedule for Summer
description: The changing national weather patterns caused by El Nino are having an unexpected effect along the Atlantic Coast, warming the ocean just enough to bring an early start to the swimming season and attracting fish closer to shore so that fishermen should improve their luck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASLON, IRVING
description: KASLON-Irving. On May 9, 1998. Beloved husband, father, brother, grandfather, uncle and friend. He was an extraordinary man who will be remembered and missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his loving wife Marion, daughters and sons-in-law Karen and Aron Schlam, and Terri and Harvey Gilbert, his sister Dr. Sylvia Seidman, and cherished grandchildren Eli, Emily, Oliver and Tyler. Funeral service will be held on Monday, May 11, 11:30 AM, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY (corner Ave. V).

description: THE COAST OF GOOD INTENTIONS Stories. By Michael Byers. 163 pp. Boston: Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Company. Paper, $12.

title: Capitalism Victorious (Thanks, Everyone)
description: THE Daimler-Chrysler deal is the model for global capitalism, a marriage of champions of free enterprise whose success has been driven by their ability to deliver products that customers around the world want at prices they are willing to pay.

title: May 3-9; New to the Club
description: Eric Robert Rudolph, the North Carolina carpenter wanted in the Jan. 29 bombing of an abortion clinic in Birmingham, Ala., joined an exclusive club: the F.B.I. 10 most wanted list.

description: HERZ-Lydia, 98. On May 5, 1998, of Alzheimer's; widow of Alfred, devoted mother of Roger Herz and Carol Brull, loving grandmother of Howard and Jacalyn Brull; founder of Feinsod Herz Funds at Jewish Communal Fund and PEF Israel Endowment Funds.

title: Campaign Reform Falls Prey to Partisanship; Burton's 'Apology'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sense of the Spectacle And Its Place in Society
description: THE title ''Art as Spectacle'' has the impact of a drum roll, and the show it announces is almost as short in duration. In fact, there is less than a week in which to observe works by 93 artists, chosen by Thelma Golden for the exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art here.

title: Madeline Hardart, Kirk Saville
description: Mary Madeline Hardart was married yesterday to Kirk Dunbar Saville. The Rev. Thomas H. Stahel performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Op-Art; In Case You Forgot to Buy a Card
Evoking the Fitful Passage to Womanhood
description: THAT first teen-age kiss -- the butterflies in your stomach, the sweaty palms. Most people remember the experience all too vividly. Today, several women artists are turning to those unforgettable moments, grappling with the painful and perplexing experiences of puberty in their work. ''As you gain sexual knowledge, your understanding of your body changes,'' said one of the artists, Amy Jenkins. ''There is a turning point between what you thought would be gross and what you discover is pleasurable.''

title: Workfare Lacks the Vision of Roosevelt's W.P.A.; Remember Bread Lines?
description: To the Editor:

title: Seville, A Perpetual Fiesta
description: A LUSH oasis in the Ur-womb of Andalusia, alternately austere and sybaritic, Seville boasts a rich history of religious fervor rivaled only by its sensual self-indulgence. Christians, Jews and Muslims have all etched indelible marks on a city that seems to have been confected out of spun sugar and whipped cream.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; My Mom, Chief Executive Officer
description: UP two flights of stairs, in an old brick building in Mineola, sits my boss in her corner office. She chain smokes, remembers all the mistakes everyone else in the office would prefer to forget, calls out numbers for files and numbers for faxes, and has a voice so low that when people first call on the phone, they address her as 'Sir.' What else should I expect when my boss happens to be my mother?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPINCOTT, GORDON
description: LIPPINCOTT-Gordon. I note with sorrow Gordon Lippincott's passing. His vision, creativity and sense of humanity will continue to inspire and guide those who were privileged to know this truly remarkable man. Clive Chajet

title: Paul G. Hearne, 48, Affable Champion of Disabled, Dies
description: Paul G. Hearne, a high-spirited Washington lawyer who for more than two decades was one of the nation's most effective champions for people with disabilities, died on May 3 at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 48 and had been a founder or officer of virtually every national organization devoted to the disabled.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WAKIN, JEANETTE
description: WAKIN-Jeanette. A memorial service in honor of Jeanette Wakin, Professor of Arabic, will be held on Monday, May 11, 1998 at 4:00 P.M., at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

title: Commercial Property/SL Green Realty Corporation; This REIT's Favorite Lyric: 'We'll Have Manhattan'
description: IT is not so much that Steve Green breaks the rules. He just makes up his own.

title: Yankees Are Off to Remarkable Start, but They Can't Match '84 Tigers
description: Keeping the Yankees' torrid start in perspective, they could win their next 10 games and still not match the 35-5 start the Detroit Tigers staged in 1984. But they could come close.

title: Danish Resistance
description: To the Travel Editor: The Q & A on April 12 gave some fine information on what to do on a layover in Copenhagen. Another possibility is the Liberty Museum, Frihedsmuseet, a monument to the heroism of the Danish Resistance and to the suffering of the people, as well as their saving of thousands of Jews, smuggling them to Sweden. It is a must for anyone visiting Copenhagen, as is the Norwegian Resistance museum for anyone visiting Oslo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, HERMAN ''PETE''
description: ROGERS-Herman ''Pete''. Age 88. Died on May 3rd, 1998. Beloved husband of Reita (nee Berlat). Loving father of daughter Beth & son Toby. Cherished grandfather of John Andrew Rogers Katz. Loving father-in-law to Jeffrey S. Katz and Francine Nayman. Your strength and courage will be an inspiration forever. The most gentle man with a sense of humor who wrote beautiful poetic verse will be remembered in the hearts of all he touched. A Paterson, N.J. boy who never forgot his roots. We all love you.

title: Feminism's Third Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Bunny's Lesson in Pain
description: I felt the need to be abused.

title: May 3-9; Jury Verdict: Coaching Is Not A Charity Event
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association supervises low-budget amateur sports; it also negotiates billion-dollar deals with companies like CBS. Its two identities collided when a Federal jury in Kansas ordered the N.C.A.A. to pay $22 million to more than 1,900 assistant coaches who had been paid as though they worked for a charity. It tripled the award because the judge in the case ruled that the salaries had been capped in violation of Federal anti-trust law. N.C.A.A. officials said the salary policy was misunderstood and intended to provide an entry-level slot for beginning coaches. An appeal is likely. KIRK JOHNSON

title: Corrections
description: The contents page of The Sophisticated Traveler, Part 2 of The Times Magazine today, misspells the name of the cover illustrator. She is Tina Bela Limer, not Lima.

title: What's for Breakfast?; Hanoi
description: In Hanoi, before the cyclos creak or the motorbikes begin their morning's roar, groups of Vietnamese squat by roadsides or along sidewalks, chopsticks in one hand, soup bowl in the other. Oblivious to the rising sun, they are intent on the first order of any Vietnamese day: pho.

title: Jane Opperman, M. W. Moynihan
description: Jane Ann Opperman, a marketing director in New York for the RIA Group, a publishing company, and Michael Willard Moynihan Jr., an author and a senior adviser on electronic commerce to the Treasury Department in Washington, were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEET, GLEN
description: LEET-Glen. A memorial service will be held on Friday, May 15th, 12 Noon at United Nations Church Center Chapel, 777 UN Plaza, 44th Street and 1st Avenue.

title: Aeolian Isles
description: To the Editor: As an American born of Sicilian parents who hasn't been to Sicily since 1989, I can truly say that Artie Traum's article ''Heady Isles of Summer'' (April 12) not only managed to conjure up my own sweet memories but captured the very essence of Sicily.

title: Toshiba Leads in Whitbread
description: Toshiba, skippered by Britain's Paul Standbridge, had taken the lead from Merit Cup yesterday by less than a mile according to the last report from race headquarters as the nine-boat fleet in the Whitbread-Round-the-World Race streaked through the Grand Banks of Newfoundland. Toshiba had 1,981 nautical miles to go to the Leg 8 finish in La Rochelle, France, and the fleet was nearing the southeastern tip of the iceberg danger zone set at 46 degrees north.

title: Devoted Parents, a Doomed Child
description: AN infant in an incubator is the image that haunts ''Emma's Child,'' at 12 Miles West Theater Company. Positioned in the background of Kevin Allen's spare set design, it is the centerpiece of Kristine Thatcher's brave, humanizing new play, which teems with emotion yet is so generously even-handed that it denies none of its 11 characters the quality of mercy and the grace of forgiveness.

title: The History of 40 Fifth Avenue
description: To the Editor:

title: Strategies To Manage A Disorder
description: THE scenario sounds frustratingly typical: a college student postpones work on term papers until the last possible moment, finds the floor lounge or social center infinitely more attractive than the library or computer center and finds studing less compelling than partying.

title: Gala Wear To Go
description: For the mother-to-be who refuses to let her ballooning belly get in the way of a heavy social calendar, Mom's Night Out, a maternity formal wear rental store at 970 Lexington Avenue (70th Street) has been a mainstay since it opened four years ago. With business booming, the store is expanding to a new, larger location at 147 East 72d Street at the end of the month. ''Women want to look and feel their best when they're pregnant, and they don't always want to invest a lot of money,'' Patricia Shiland, the owner, said. ''I give them the option to rent or buy.''

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

description: WALD-Muriel L. Of Stamford and Palm Beach. Beloved wife of Joel. Loving mother of Stephen and Susan. Devoted sister of Peter and Eileen Lehrer. Grandmother of Daniel and Amy, and aunt of Debora and Suzanne Lehrer. Contributions may be made to American Lung Association.

title: Our Towns; Day Laborer Stakes Out His Own Patch
description: JOSE MARTINEZ fled the war in El Salvador in 1988 with an electrician's training, little English and no license. When he tried to land a job here in the trade, he was shooed away like a fly. After a year or so, he ended up like so many of his compadres, on a street corner, begging for lousy day jobs.

title: May 3-9; Close to Hell
description: Twenty years after the Unabomber first launched his crusade of terror, Theodore J. Kaczynski, the confessed serial bomber, was sentenced in a Sacramento Federal court to four life terms plus 30 years in prison. At the hearing, Mr. Kaczynski expressed no remorse for attacks that killed three people and wounded 22 others. Susan Mosser, the widow of a public relations executive killed at the family's home in New Jersey in 1994, said Mr. Kaczynski should be ''locked so far down that when he dies he'll be close to hell.'' DAVID JOHNSTON

Rabbi Devon Lerner is to officiate at the Southampton Princess Hotel in Bermuda. The Rev. Bob Couto, a Roman Catholic priest, is to take part in the ceremony.

description: NOW that cigarettes have been largely banished from the friendly skies, airlines have a new health threat to contend with: peanuts.

description: GROVE +

title: Visions by Rudy
description: Who knew? It turns out that New York's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, is an avid photographer, and he's currently sharing his work with the masses at Leica Gallery on lower Broadway. The photos themselves are predictably New York-centric and concrete -- buildings catch the Mayor's eye, not artsy interplays of light and shadow. Still, there's a purpose in mind, and some of the Mayor's pictures aren't half bad. ''While the Mayor is clearly an amateur photographer,'' says Julie Saul, owner of an eponymous downtown Manhattan gallery that handles cutting-edge photography, ''his photos are actually better than much of the stuff sent to me each day for consideration.'' Here, her further thoughts on the Rudy portfolio.

title: The Family Plan In Williamsburg
description: THERE can't be too many places in the world where you can spend the morning at the site of a decisive military victory, then pass the afternoon getting your guts churned up on one of the world's tallest roller coasters. Such a day is easily arranged in Virginia, however, on the jagged peninsula between the James and York Rivers, home to three of America's most important historic sites -- and one of its most popular amusement parks.

title: In a Modest Home, a Grand Vestige of Titanic's Sister
description: ''PEOPLE think we're mad for selling it, but I'm getting too old to do the polishing,'' said Joy Norton, who is 75, referring to the lustrous walnut paneling that has changed her life. ''All we want now is a cozy little bungalow.''

title: May 3-9; Something for Something
description: President Clinton recently struck an extraordinary -- and secretive -- bargain to get some of his judicial nominees confirmed by the Republican Senate: he agreed to let Senator Slade Gorton, a Washington Republican, pick someone to sit on United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit based in California. The President is expected to give a coveted seat on the court to Mr. Gorton's choice, Barbara Durham, a conservative Republican, who is the chief justice of the Washington State Supreme Court. NEIL A. LEWIS

title: Yankees Don't Have Even a Selfish Few
description: Every team, the Yankees' first baseman, Tino Martinez, was saying the other day, usually has two or three players who are too loud, too obnoxious, too selfish. Too something.

title: Susan Povich, Ralph Gorham
description: Susan Anne Povich and Ralph Winthrop Gorham were married last evening. Dr. Charles G. Agin, a rabbi, officiated in the Manhattan apartment of the bride's father, Maury Povich, the talk show host, and stepmother, Connie Chung, the ABC-TV news correspondent.

title: Charter Schools Unfair To Private Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Hot Directors: Rebellious to a Point
description: THE singers sit in front of a curtained stage, each at his own Formica table, as if waiting for a performance. Warming up, they produce fragments of arias that blend into a cacophony of half-heard sound.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. October 16, 1940 to October 20, 1990. Cherished mother. Needed always. . .especially now. Allison.

title: Basketball: Walk It, Wear It, Read It
description: GOT a serious basketball addiction? Or just want to walk the walk? If so, you may already be reading Slam, a glossy four-year-old magazine that covers ''basketball and its culture,'' in the words of its advertising promotion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OFSHE, IDA
description: OFSHE-Ida. On May 8, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Daniel. Loving mother of Pat and Fran. Adoring grandmother of Benjamin. Dear sister of Herman and the late Jerome Eisenman. A loving protector of all creatures great and small. She will be deeply missed. Memorial service Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Brief Delay Bedevils Enhanced 911 System
description: IN December 1979, Adam Berwid, a Mineola man confined to the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital, was released on a one-day pass, despite having told anyone who would listen that he intended to track down and kill his ex-wife, Ewa. Mr. Berwid made good on his promise, confronting his former wife at her home and stabbing her repeatedly as she frantically called 911. Since Mrs. Berwid could not give her name or location, the 911 operator listened helplessly as she was assaulted. By the time the police had traced the call, Mrs. Berwid had died of her wounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORTGANG, NETTIE
description: FORTGANG-Nettie. On May 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Louis, daughter of the late Israel and Rose Bendremer, sister of Sally Wideroff and the late Thomas J. Brandon. Loving mother of Iris Bashkin and Stephen. Devoted grandmother of Erika Fortgang.

title: Alice Faye, Hollywood Star Who Sang for Her Man, Is Dead
description: Alice Faye, one of the few movie stars to walk away from stardom at the peak of her career, died yesterday at Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif. She was in her mid-80's.

title: Tall Ships Festival In Savannah on July 4
description: Libertad, the largest sailing vessel in the Western Hemisphere, and at least 10 other tall ships will take part in the Americas' Sail Tall Ships Festival in Savannah, Ga., from July 3 to 5 before the start of the Americas' Sail '98 race from Savannah to Montauk, on Long Island. The vessels scheduled to take part include Libertad, representing Argentina; Barba Negra, Eagle, Rose, Meka II and Norseman, representing the United States, and Simon Bolivar, for Venezuela. Simon Bolivar will defend the Americas' Sail Trophy, which it has held since the first Americas' Sail race in 1995.

title: Knicks Keep Their Cool, and Keep the Series Up for Grabs
description: The vulnerable star center at Madison Square Garden yesterday was Rik Smits, as he stood there in the paint like the last slice of pizza in the box. Someone was bound to attack a guy who was all but baked with five fouls and six minutes left in the game.

title: Pure Plays Are Hard To Find
description: A CURE for cancer? An AIDS treatment? Invest big in a fledgling biotechnology company that has cooked up one of those and -- bang! -- you're on your way to tidy fortune.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOTTESMAN, ELIZABETH
description: GOTTESMAN-Elizabeth. 4/27/96. Our precious ''Libby'' loved and remembered forever. The Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, LIONEL C.
description: REED-Lionel C., 83. Resident of New City for 37 years, April 30, 1998. Having graduated as a chemical engineer from Worcester Polytechnic Institute with honors in 1936 he worked for the FDA, and then entered private industry, where he developed radio-labeled biochemicals used by major research centers to trace previously unknown pathways of human metabolism. His scholarly pursuits included music, arts, literature, and higher mathematics. His completed solution to the ''four color problem'' was presented to Princeton University. During the war he worked on classified projects. He was a loving husband, a concerned and charitable father, and a man of peculiar charm and wit, who charted courses energized by a strong sense of self-reliance. He was a keen observer of human nature and forgiving of human foibles. A home spun philosopher and master of the cleverly turned phrase, he will be greatly missed by family and friends. He was the loving father of Harold Reed, M.D., Lawrence (Arlene) Reed, M.D., Irving Reed, and Barry (Jill) Reed, M.D., dear brother of Lilly Rovno, Ida Gordon and cherished grandfather of Michael, Staci, Joshua, Dalia and Ilana.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 26 about the themes of corporate annual reports referred incompletely to the operations of Tenneco, one of the companies cited. Along with auto parts, the company focuses on packaging.

title: High Noon: Chicken Duels Bagels
description: The fight begins each day at high noon and Ben Maximov is caught in the crossfire. Mr. Maximov's shop, City Jeans, is all that divides Ranch 1 from Bruegger's Bagels on Avenue of the Americas between 42d and 43d Streets.

title: An Unconventional Communist
description: FALL OF THE NEW CLASS A History of Communism's Self-Destruction. By Milovan Djilas. Edited by Vasilije Kalezic. Translated by John Loud. 383 pp. New York:Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: A Vision of Betrayal And Forgiveness Whose Pull Is Deep
description: ROMANTIC ballets are meant to be exercises in enchantment. They transport their audience to a gloriously illogical domain where warriors are entranced by exquisite visions and princes are besotted by swans. Retrieving for adults the delight that children find in fairy tales, they provide return passage to the tender season of innocence. This spring, one of the greatest romantic ballets, ''Giselle,''is again in the repertory of American Ballet Theater after a two-year absence. In the eight-week season that starts tomorrow, it will be danced nine times, more than any other work.

title: With Ample Faith (and Funds) in the Future
description: THE karma is especially positive at American Ballet Theater these days. ''Energy begets energy,'' Kevin McKenzie, the company's artistic director, said before reeling off the names of choreographers he plans to commission in a troupe that increasingly attracts dancers from around the world. For Michael Kaiser, Ballet Theater's executive director, the focus is on innovative partnerships with tour sponsors, audience-development and new big-time donors. ''Any organization that makes good art can be saved,'' he said.

title: Debate Engulfs New Fire Island Superintendent
description: WHEN she was in the fourth grade 25 years ago, Anne-Marie Millen rode in a bus with her classmates 15 miles to the South Shore, where they took a 20-minute ferry ride across the Great South Bay to the Sunken Forest on Fire Island.

title: Brave New Post-Chocolate World
description: FROM our vantage point in the year 2098, an age of unparalleled peace and prosperity, it is easy to pick out the starting point for civilization's remarkable ascent. Yet looking back at that bittersweet year of 1998, when scientists first disclosed that cocoa farms, the source for the world's supply of chocolate, were under siege from fungal and viral diseases and insects, the future looked dark indeed. Visions of deprivation, rationing and the gradual disappearance of chocolate gave rise to a burst of dystopian fervor in film, literature, music and computer art. Global morale sank under the weight of chocolate substitutes. Even today, the memory of carob kisses and solid licorice Easter bunnies causes an involuntary shudder in all who lived through those bleak times.

title: Reality Punctures Entremed's Bubble
description: THUD.

title: SUMMER FESTIVALS; Where Shakespeare and Skateboards Meet
description: THIS summer at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, there will be regulars in the audience who have explored the complete canon several times in the years stretching back to the company's founding, in 1935. Cherishers of a grand tradition, they will delve into yet another presentation of ''Henry IV, Part One'' or ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' seeking fresh insights. Aiding them will be a repertory company of 70 actors, who practice their craft the old-fashioned way, spending most of the year together in Ashland, a small town nestled between two mountain ranges.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Thorns of Truth

title: The Sky's the Limit
description: THE SERVICE OF CLOUDS

title: Unleashing Opinions on Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Non-Artists' Housing Seen as Blot on Local Canvas
description: Most of the housing in SoHo consists of lofts, where only city-authenticated ''artists in residence'' are supposed to live. But the city has approved a developer's plan to build more than 100 conventional apartments in the neighborhood, which has some local residents up in arms.

title: Defending the Indefensible
description: It comes as no surprise that The Times and Tina Rosenberg continue to perpetuate distorted and false images of Dr. Milan Kovacevic and his defense. Rosenberg's failure to grasp the complexities involved in the onset of civil war in Bosnia, as well as Serb history, reveals fundamental flaws in the American journalistic system. Journalists should not make uninformed judgments. After five days in Prijedor (and with only the scant facts available to us at that time), Rosenberg became overwhelmed with emotion, looking at the ruins of war. Cicero remarked 2,000 years ago that everything is nauseating in a civil war.

title: Campaign Reform Falls Prey to Partisanship; Incumbent Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicholas Tsiolas, Nicole Petallides
