description: Nicole Anais Petallides, the daughter of Fannie Holliday and John C. Petallides, both of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Dr. Nicholas Tsiolas, a son of Helen and Eraklis Tsiolas of Bayside, Queens. Archbishop Spyridon, the Greek Orthodox primate of the United States, performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Shrine Church of St. Nicholas in Flushing, Queens.

title: Cafe Patrons Don't Rock, They Run
description: It was a sunny Sunday afternoon, and Mike O'Neal, who owns O'Neal's Restaurant on 64th Street opposite Lincoln Center, was looking forward to a second season of lingering sunsets, breezes off the Hudson and profits from the 79th Street Boat Basin Cafe, which he leases for $30,000 a year from the Parks Department.

title: The Mad, Mad Month of May
description: A baker's dozen of parties, uptown and down, from one of the busiest weeks in the busiest month of the spring social season. Whew!

title: Heather Platt, Thomas Gorin
description: Elizabeth Louise Platt and Thomas Bartley Gorin were married yesterday in Niantic, Conn. Judge Thomas Collier Platt, the bride's father and a judge of the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of New York, officiated at the home of Huntington Lyman, a cousin of the bride, and his wife, San.

title: Susan Miller, Richard Korchak
description: Susan Denise Miller, a vice president of public affairs for the American Express Company in New York, was married yesterday to Richard Alan Korchak, a district manager in New York for AT&T. The Rev. David Jefferson Sr., a Baptist minister, officiated at the Burden Mansion in New York.

title: Putting It in Writing: Views of New Jersey -- FICTION; An Education In Democracy?
description: As writers reach into their memories and imaginations, New Jersey turns up in a variety of guises. Here are excerpts from a variety of books that appealed to editors of this section.

title: Habitats/218 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn; One Historic District Swapped for Another
description: FOR years, Drew Kramer, who heads a not-for-profit agency on the Lower East Side, and Yarrott Benz, a teacher, confined themselves to renting, unable to see themselves as homeowners.

title: Unleashing Opinions on Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats To Gather in Rye for State Convention
description: DEMOCRATS from throughout the state will gather at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook later this month to put together a slate of candidates it hopes will recapture the offices of governor and attorney general and oust the three-term Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: DANCE
description: California

title: May 3-9; A Top Aide Resigns
description: The chairman of the House inquiry into President Clinton's 1996 campaign finance practices ousted his top investigator amid a furor over the aide's role in releasing edited tapes of Webster L. Hubbell's jailhouse conversations. Under pressure from Speaker Newt Gingrich, Representative Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican who heads the House Government and Reform Committee, accepted the resignation of the aide, David N. Bossie, a dogged anti-Clinton sleuth. ERIC SCHMITT

title: Prurient Plainsong
description: Just when you thought sales of medieval church music were as dead as, say, Pope Gregory XI, along come the Mediaeval Baebes. A group that includes a former Lloyd's of London underwriter and a former stripper, the Baebes have earned a place on Britain's classical charts by singing, of all things, early music from the 1300's.

title: Capitol Becomes a House United
description: The legislative session here ended on Wednesday at midnight, and in this and other state capitals around the country, a strange thing has happened. While Republicans and Democrats in Washington continue to do battle, a spirit of bipartisan cooperation has dominated the politics of many state governments.

title: Skip Away' Streak Stretches to 5
description: Skip Away won his fifth straight Grade I stakes yesterday when he swept to victory in the $750,000 Pimlico Special at Pimlico Race Course by three lengths over Precocity, and ran his career earnings to $7.8 million.

title: Q and A
description: Cooperstown Without a Car

title: What's for Breakfast?; Sicily
description: As the early morn- ing sun floods the piazzas of Sicily it illuminates a scurry of young boys, dressed in white from cap to apron strings with an overall dusting of white cake flour. Each balances on his head a large tray of pastries that vary from season to season: fig-filled bucellati cakes celebrate Christmas; at Easter marzipan lambs appear.

title: Nurses' Give-Backs at Issue
description: The regional director of the National Labor Relations Board said he may file a civil complaint against Long Island College Hospital for allegedly failing to provide a nurses' union with cost-cutting information during contract talks.

title: What's for Breakfast?; New York City
description: Now that Doughnut Man has acquired two assistants, doughnut production has risen to 312 hand-crafted beauties every day, up from 144. This is not insignificant news to certain Manhattanites who will do the almost unthinkable -- stand in a long line early in the morning, on the way to work, to get one of Mark Isreal's deep-fried, yeast-raised, all-natural, $2 doughnuts.

title: What Florida Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMS, SHIRLEY
description: SIMS-Shirley, 94. Of Tamarac, FL. Formerly of Brooklyn & Englishtown, NJ., died May 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Louis; Dear mother of Judith Silverman & Marion Fox; Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Interment FL.

title: Bricks Fall From Building
description: Bricks and a parapet rattled loose from the facade of a Harlem building late last night, injuring no one, but slowing commuter train traffic after 10:20 P.M., the police said.

title: Painter's Picks: Painting, Works on Paper
description: THE national competition run by Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven specifies a theme and names a well-known judge associated with that theme, which all entries must fit. When the judge is also an artist with a reputation, it's amazing how the resulting exhibition looks like so many variations on the judge's own style -- as though the show was hand-picked, instead of the result of random submissions on slides.

title: Janice Worobec, Cliff Abromats
description: Janice Jennifer Worobec and G. Clifford Abromats were married last evening by Justice Penny M. Wolfgang of State Supreme Court in Buffalo, at the Saturn Club there.

title: On to the Next Round
description: ON a clear day, the view from Atlantic City Country Club's fourth hole is almost sublime. Casino hotel towers stand clean and proud against the horizon. The noise and hustle of the gambling mecca about five miles northeast, across Lakes Bay, seem a safe distance from this 177-acre paradise in Northfield.

title: Chandler's Frustration
description: To the Editor:

title: A Monument With a View Is Opening Again
description: A WINDING staircase of 103 steps takes visitors to the top of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Memorial Arch, the triumphal entrance to Prospect Park. The stairs are considered easy to climb, and at the top, the payoff is grand: picture-postcard views of Brooklyn and the Manhattan skyline. The arch, part of Grand Army Plaza, is reopening for the summer on Saturday, and the Prospect Park Alliance, with the Urban Park Rangers, will sponsor tours of the arch every weekend through July 5.

title: People With Feelings
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Q&A/Timothy S. Carey; Demystifying Electric Company Choices
description: THE bad news is that you may soon be getting a lot of dinner-hour telephone solicitations trying to get you to change your electric company. The good news is that it could pay you to listen to what they are saying, said Timothy S. Carey, chairman and executive director of the state's Consumer Protection Board.

title: Mother Arrested After Her Son, 5, Is Found Wandering the Streets
description: A 30-year-old mother of three was arrested yesterday after her 5-year-old son was found wandering the streets of Flushing, Queens, in a cold rain in the early morning darkness.

title: Monet's Lilies Bloom in Baltimore and Boston
description: Monet was hardly a late bloomer -- he had started his painting career by age 18 -- but his later years are the focus of two exhibitions in the United States this year. Between 1900 and his death in 1926 at 86, Monet mainly painted at his home in Giverny, about 40 miles northwest of Paris. There, he started to broaden his brush strokes, rendering images of his garden that eventually grew abstract and trading in easel-sized canvases for ones stretching more than 18 feet. His monumental water lilies were an eventual result.

title: The New Jersey Chronicles
description: FUNNY how things work out, John T. Cunningham thinks even now, nearing 83 years of age, looking back at his journeys with the acuity of the writer and historian that he became.

title: Political Briefing; Primary in Nebraska Is Called a Dead Heat
description: On the eve of Tuesday's primaries in Nebraska, the Governor's race there has taken a new turn.

title: Lives; Why I Really Learned to Ride
description: I lean against the fence, my heart aching, watching 7-year-old Ruby on a small, shaggy pony, trotting circles around a muddy ring. In the middle of the ring stands her mentor, 12-year-old Amanda.

title: Pacers' Jackson Shakes Off Old Familiar Boos
description: When the game was over and the questions had finally ended, Mark Jackson walked out of the visitors' locker room under the stands at Madison Square Garden. He picked up his daughter, Heavyn, as he left the tunnel. He stopped to speak to Patrick Ewing, then got a warm greeting from the few family members who were still waiting for him.

title: What's for Breakfast?; London
description: Greasy, salty and among the fishiest of fish, smoked kippers are very much an acquired taste, particularly first thing in the morning. But kippers -- once a staple of British breakfasts and now more likely to be an occasional treat on weekends or special occasions -- yield unexpected pleasures for those adventurous enough to try them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GETTINGER, ANNA J.
description: GETTINGER-Anna J. Dearest and most wonderful Mother. Our loving thoughts are of you today and every day. Martin and Gloria

title: Embowered In Britain
description: What would it be like to watch dusk darkening over faintly ominous shapes of sculptured yew? Or to walk among row after row of perfumed white roses on a moonlit June night? Or to stroll alone in the early morning along clipped grassy paths past peonies drooping with heavy red blossoms?

title: Pauline Aguilera, Nicholas Longano
description: Pauline Elena Aguilera, the daughter of Jill Isles Blanchard of New York and Guillermo B. Aguilera of Seattle, was married yesterday to Nicholas Francis Longano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donato A. Longano of Melbourne, Australia. The Rev. James Burns performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Vacation Planner
description: INSTRUCTIONS: Mount disk and arrow on cardboard. Cut out arrow and attach with pin (see diagram below). Spin for destination and start packing.

title: Myres Smith McDougal, 91, Expert on International Law at Yale
description: Myres Smith McDougal, an authority on international law and co-founder of the New Haven school of jurisprudence, died on Thursday at the Evergreen Woods Health Center in North Branford, Conn. A longtime resident of New Haven, he was 91.

title: Liberals' Candidate Is McCaughey Ross
description: The New York Liberal Party selected Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, a former Republican whose ideological credentials are suspect among many Democratic leaders, as its gubernatorial candidate, insuring her a place on the November ballot.

title: Dance Souvenir
description: To the Editor: Reading Sarah Ferrell's article ''The Storytelling Souvenir'' (April 5), I am reminded of my favorite travel souvenir.

title: Golden Boy?; He's Dazzled Wall Street, but the Ghosts Of His Company May Haunt His Future
description: EVEN by Wall Street standards, Jeffrey A. Citron is enormously successful. He has a multimillion-dollar mansion on the Jersey Shore, often commutes to work by helicopter and likes to fly to Florida in his private Gulfstream jet. Now just 27 years old, he puts his net worth at $100 million.

title: POLLUTION POLICY IS UNFAIR BURDEN, STATES TELL E.P.A.
description: State governments and major industrial groups are challenging a new Environmental Protection Agency policy intended to insure that minority neighborhoods are not saddled with an unfair share of incinerators, dumps and other sources of pollution.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Into the Heart of Haiti
description: Although it was the first black nation to free itself from the shackles of European colonialism, Haiti has yet to come to terms with itself as a nation. In the course of Lilas Desquiron's strange yet insistently powerful novel, REFLECTIONS OF LOKO MIWA (University Press of Virginia, cloth, $55; paper, $16.95), the storms of repression, betrayal and prejudice that have buffeted this country virtually since its independence are memorably drawn -- and just as memorably left unresolved. The story is told through the lives of two women, raised together as ''sisters,'' who become 20th-century representatives of the pervasive oppositions that have tormented their homeland since it was liberated from France in 1804. Cocotte, a black woman from the countryside, is separated from her impoverished family as a child and spends her youth trying to establish her identity. Violaine, a light-skinned mulatto of privilege and station whose violent passions become the novel's focus, feels that her ''African soul suffers in a body that's too pale for it,'' even though she belongs to a family determined ''to repress all traces of its African heritage.'' Translated into conversational English by Robin Orr Bodkin, ''Reflections of Loko Miwa'' (the title refers to a spirit that protects healers and twins) is an intense social, political and magical voyage into the heart of Haiti. At the end of that journey lie death and transcendence as the warring saints of voodoo and Christianity intermingle to determine Violaine's destiny. Ironically, despite their best efforts, her fate is finally decided by a whim -- and a slingshot. James Polk

title: Smashing Windows 98
description: The accelerating confrontation between Microsoft and the Justice Department seems likely to become one of the most bitter antitrust cases ever and perhaps one of the most important. The department may try to delay the debut of Windows 98, the next generation of Microsoft's operating system, while it looks for any predatory practices by Microsoft. The department is clearly right to try to promote competition in a fast-changing business. The question is whether it is being unfair to Microsoft, stifling innovation or demanding ''remedies'' that create more problems than they solve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE BARBIERI, EVELYN NEE ROBERTS
description: DE BARBIERI - Evelyn nee Roberts. At Montreal on May 3, 1998 at the age of 75 years, Evelyn born in Montreal, Quebec passed away in the presence of her children. Daughter of the late Leontine Seguin and the late Albert Roberts. Wife of the late Lt. Col. Thomas F. De Barbieri. She is survived by her children Frederick Leontine and Victoria Marie. Cherished sister of Albert (New York) and Bob (Georgia). A memorial mass will take place at 10AM, Saturday, July 4, 1998 at the church of the Ascension of Our Lord in Westmount, Quebec. In lieu of flowers donations to the Victorian Order of Nurses of Montreal or the Regroupement de solidarite avec les Autochtones/Solidarity with the Native Peoples would be appreciated.

title: Food; The Purist
description: To the organic cooks of temperate climes, April is not the cruelest month. Not by a long shot. Not even the frustration of a peekaboo sun and the tease of spring's first tender greens can compare to the endless parade of cabbages, potatoes and the other stubborn root vegetables of winter.

title: The Embattled Vendor-Poet
description: Dow Kevin Buford, seller of sundries to the Staten Island Ferry's commuting masses, thinks nothing's so sublime as a clever rhyme. ''I got it aaall in my little shopping mall,'' he says about the two-wheeled cart he has pushed through the aisles on rush hour boats since 1983.

title: West Puts Pressure on Serbs With a Ban on Investment
description: The main Western industrial nations imposed an investment ban on Serbia today and froze its assets abroad as their concern grew about the violence in Kosovo, a southern Serbian province. They also froze the overseas assets of Yugoslavia, which is made up of Serbia and Montenegro.

title: The Soul of Wit
description: KENNETH TYNAN LETTERS

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: He Got Game

title: 'Little Women' Tries a School For Boys
description: Louisa May Alcott's Little Men

title: I Remember Grandma
description: I LOVE GOOTIE

title: Bullish on Buybacks? Take a Second Look
description: WHEN a publicly traded company says it will buy back some of its stock, the reaction on the Street is almost always positive. Even if analysts were not enthusiastic about the company before the announcement, many investors cast aside caution and dive in, on the theory that no one knows better than the company's management whether a stock is a bargain and a good investment. Are they right?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHUSTER, JONATHAN DAVID
description: SHUSTER-Jonathan David. July 3, 1953-May 10, 1988. Ten years makes thousands of days filled with memories and loving thoughts.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the special Summer Movies section last Sunday misstated the history of the documentary ''Kurt and Courtney,'' about Kurt Cobain and his widow, Courtney Love. Originally scheduled to be shown in January at the Sundance Festival in Park City, Utah, the film was withdrawn because of a dispute and shown instead at the Slamdunk Festival there. Slamdunk is one of two alternative festivals that run at the same time and in the same city as Sundance. (The other is Slamdance.)

title: Amanda Clothier, J.P. McNichol
description: Amanda Stevenson Clothier, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Baird Clothier Jr. of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to James Patrick McNichol 3d, a son of Mr. McNichol Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Barbara Ann McNichol. The Rev. John R. Francis performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill, Pa.

title: Visual Play's the Thing; Teacher Uses Cartoons to Win Converts to Shakespeare
description: Whenever Jovan Myers came across a movie version of a Shakespeare play while flipping channels, he would always dart past -- quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAVENGOOD, RUSSELL W., JR.
description: LAVENGOOD-Russell W., Jr. M.D. Nov. 21, 1924-May 11, 1988. Beloved husband, father and brother. Surgeon, healer, and devoted friend to many. ''He left large footprints in the sands of time.'' His loving family

title: Ex-Student's Hate Note
description: After his arrest last month, a former student at Eastchester High School pleaded guilty to threatening a math teacher, Superintendent of Schools Robert W. Pellicone said.

title: A New Luxury Hotel In Beverly Hills
description: The hotel L'Ermitage Beverly Hills opened last month near the boutiques and galleries on Rodeo Drive. Featuring Art Deco decor, a rooftop pool and large rooms with views of the city, the Getty Museum, Beverly Hills, Bel Air and the Hollywood Hills, the hotel -- formerly L'Ermitage Hotel -- is owned by Lahotel Corporation, and has undergone a major redesign.

title: Fast Forward; It's Your Problem (Not Theirs)
description: I seem to remember that when I subscribed to, oh, The New Yorker, I sent in some money and eventually the magazine started arriving in my mailbox. Not so simple in the digital era. The other day I used my computer to subscribe to Slate, an on-line magazine owned by Microsoft, and after I gave up my name, E-mail address, postal address, credit card number and choice of gift (I declined the free umbrella), the screen presented me with the first few lines of a 2,000-word contract. Below this was a button marked ''I Agree.'' There was also a button marked ''Cancel.'' I looked in vain for a button marked ''Let's Negotiate -- My Lawyer Will Be in Touch With Your Lawyer.''

title: The Answer Is Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: On Being a Bunny
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALLER, JULIUS B.
description: MALLER-Julius B. May 8, 1959. Remembered with love and admiration. Your son, Michael

title: Africans Before Americans
description: EXCHANGING OUR COUNTRY MARKS The Transformation of African Identities in the Colonial and Antebellum South. By Michael A. Gomez. 370 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $18.95.

title: Ever the Spellbinder With a Violin's Voice
description: JAZZ musicians often characterize their improvisational art as storytelling, and that conceit of soulful narrative seems a perfect fit for the playing of the great Russian violinist David Oistrakh.

title: Austere, Voluptuous Provence
description: Friends who summer in the Vaucluse whisper the name of a favorite village still unravaged by the indignities of upscale tourism and hint darkly that, if I write about it, our friendship might be in trouble. Planning a trip to the south of France, I understand their concern: the dread of seeing town after town redecorated in sprigged cotton by some local, pastis-crazed, Provencal Martha Stewart.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 26 about United States observances of Israel's 50th anniversary misstated the date for a showing of the documentary ''The Long Way Home'' at Radio City Music Hall. It is Tuesday, May 19, not today.

title: Third World Fills a Void As Villagers Run Schools
description: Yasmin Aidbar had never heard of charter schools. But as the only girl in her small village to get a secondary education, she seized an offer of free teacher training in return for a promise to come back home and open Bhumlairi's first school -- a project conceived and planned by parents, most of whom are poor farmers tired of waiting for a Government school.

title: Endangered Chocolate
description: To the Editor:

title: EARNING IT; Forget the Formal Training. Try Chatting at the Water Cooler.
description: SOME bosses say productive work can occur only if employees toil away in their work stations or cubicles -- and with few distractions. Casual strategizing in chance meetings in the hallway or banter over coffee can't measure up, they say.

title: Mona Mennen, Jonathan Gibson
description: Mona Vance Mennen, the daughter of Carolyn C. Mennen of Dallas and G. Jeff Mennen of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan William Gibson, a son of Elizabeth and George R. Gibson 3d of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Zachary W. M. Fleetwood performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Stephen B. Swann, the headmaster of the Episcopal School of Dallas, took part in the service.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: A Four-Sided Bed By Elizabeth Searle. Graywolf, paper, $14.95.

title: Cuban Doctors Find Niche in Rural South Africa
description: In the two years since he arrived at the tiny hospital here deep in the misty hills of KwaZulu/Natal, Dr. Abel Gonzalez Perez has learned the Zulu words for lie down, relax, breathe deep, where is the pain?

title: M.M.L. MBacke, Makunda Abdul
description: Makunda Abdul was married yesterday to Mohammed Moustapha Lamine MBacke. The Rev. Claudia A. Highbaugh, a Disciples of Christ minister, performed the nondemoninational ceremony at the First Church of Christ in New Haven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALYI, EMERY
description: VALYI-Emery. Of Katonah and Riverdale, on May 5, at age 86, husband of Elisabeth, father of Kathy and grandfather of Aran, Kieran and Clara. An inventor with over 200 U.S. and foreign patents who made original technical contributions to foundry technology, mass and heat transfer systems, packaging technology and automotive structures, Emery Valyi was active in his community and an early director of Wave Hill. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Elizabeth and Sandor Valyi Foundation. A memorial service is planned.

title: Greenway Grant
description: The County Department of Planning has been awarded a $10,000 grant and is eligible to receive an additional $30,000 from the Hudson River Valley Greenway to work on a compact plan designed to strengthen the Hudson River area economically and ecologically.

title: Leslie Cauceglia, Guy Corcoran Jr.
description: Leslie Ann Cauceglia, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Cauceglia of Palm City, Fla., was married on Friday to Guy McKee Corcoran Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Corcoran of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Michael A. Hanly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Unleashing Opinions on Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Building a Better Bee
description: Every spring for the past 20 years, a quiet experiment has played out in Alvin Hamson's orchard in northern Utah. While the snow melts and the grass greens up in the fertile Cache Valley, hundreds of sleepy bees emerge from wooden shelters and fly off in search of provisions. If the apple and pear blossoms aren't open yet, then dandelion flowers will do.

title: Ordway Hilton, 84, Authority Who Detected Forged Papers
description: Ordway Hilton, a budding mathematician who emerged as one of the nation's foremost authorities on detecting forged documents, died on April 15 at a hospital in Spartanburg, S.C. He was 84 and had played a role in exposing some of the century's most celebrated forgeries, and, in an embarrassing episode, erroneously authenticating one.

title: Baby Balms
description: Look out, Johnson & Johnson. There's a new kid on the block, and Takashimaya wants to powder its bottom. ''We were inspired by customer demand for baby body care products,'' said Corky Tyler, senior vice president and general merchandise manager of Takashimaya, the Japanese-owned department store at 693 Fifth Avenue (54th Street). ''So, after much experimenting Takabebe was born,'' she said. The line includes four new preparations: bubble bath, skin moisturizer, shampoo and hair detangler.

title: Streetscapes/Pratt Institute, Brooklyn; A Venerable Campus in a Largely Urban Mode
description: PRATT INSTITUTE in Brooklyn, founded in 1887 by Charles Pratt, one of John D. Rockefeller's partners, started out as a trade and art school in a hodgepodge of factorylike buildings. But recent projects at the venerable institution seek to give more of a collegiate air to what was for a long time a largely urban campus.

title: Powerboat Crew Aims for a 76-Day World Cruise
description: The whimsical account by Jules Verne of rounding the world in 80 days is rooted in 19th-century fiction. But the author's story line was retold in 20th-century fact four years ago when a French sailing team broke the mythological barrier with a 79-day circumnavigation. Now, powerboaters want to prove that they too can revise the book.

title: A Slow Climb for Mortgage Rates
description: Just as the home-buying season heats up, mortgages seem to be getting more expensive.

title: Pink-and-Lavender Graphics, Spiced With Vitriol
description: In her day job, Angela Martini helps give Web sites for A & E Television Network and the History Channel a conservative look, with parchment backgrounds and blue-and-gold graphics. On her own time, she does something more subversive.

title: Penang Sights
description: To the Editor: Although I do not recall hearing people add ''la!'' to their sentences during my stay in Penang nearly 30 years ago, as Martha Stevenson Olson did (''Polyglot Penang, a Special Place, La!'' April 19), several tailors offered to make me a ''suita.''

title: The Nation; Baiting the Hook With Small Fry
description: THERE is a saying around Federal courthouses these days about an emerging strategy of prosecutors: They will only try to harpoon a great whale after first netting a few minnows.

title: Judging the Many Newsletters That Judge Fidelity's Funds
description: ERIC M. KOBREN, executive editor of Fidelity Insight, a newsletter that picks Fidelity funds, boasts about the loyalty of his 75,000 subscribers. Which, of course, is cause for a rival, Donald R. Dion Jr., publisher of the Fidelity Independent Adviser, to snipe, ''It used to be 125,000.''

title: Many in Congress Oppose Mayor's Casino Plan for Governors Island
description: Over the strong objections of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, members of Congress from New York and New Jersey are preparing to introduce legislation that would sharply reduce City Hall's role in planning the future of Governors Island, the historic nugget of surplus Federal land nestled in Upper New York Bay.

title: The Mother's at Home, And the Pitcher Is In
description: The dainty woman with the English accent gave herself one memorable rule as a mother: always be home when any of her seven children returned from school. Not at a neighbor's or buying a gallon of milk. Home. She wanted to be there with a hug or a cookie. She had to be there to give what she had lost as a child.

title: Rosemary Rogers, Robert Downey
description: Rosemary Rogers, a music producer and writer, was married on Friday in Manhattan to Robert Joseph Downey, the film director and screenwriter. The Rev. Frank Scanlon, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the apartment of Kathy and Thomas McKeever, the bride's sister and brother-in-law.

title: Main Street, The Movers Behind A New Look
description: EAST HARTFORD, tucked away across the Connecticut River from its parent city and namesake, has always had something of an identity problem.

title: Unleashing Opinions on Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Roughing It With Mom: Nurture in Nature
description: MOST of my friends think it's crazy ever to leave civilization with your mother. Now and then, I've agreed. Take the time I found myself hip deep in the San Juan River in Utah, trying to push an inflatable kayak off a sandbar. My mother was in that kayak. She refused to climb out and help push because, she said, I had been too bossy in the stern. I wound up falling, bashing my knees on rocks and longing to give her stern a swift kick.

title: Mosley Outpunches Molina To Keep Lightweight Title
description: Shane Mosley was seeking to raise his profile. He wanted to defeat Juan (John-John) Molina in spectacular fashion. Mosley did both at Trump's Taj Mahal Grand Ballroom tonight.

title: Message in a Bottle
description: Miami, Paris, Philadelphia, even Roswell, N.M., have been featured, as has every kind of cultural subject you might think of, in those clever Absolut vodka ads, the ones in which a central image turns out to be in the shape of a bottle. Since the campaign began in 1981, there have been more than 500 of the advertisements. And now New Jersey has been christened. Absolut New Jersey is appearing in 18 national and regional magazines this month. The ad, from the TBWA/Chiat Day New York agency, shows an aerial view of a classic diner, with nine cars clustered around it. Sure enough, one end of the diner is shaped like the neck of a bottle. The agency came up with the idea via a book about New Jersey diners. It also thought about calling it Absolut Joisey, and then thought again. We'll drink to that.

title: Workfare Lacks the Vision of Roosevelt's W.P.A.; Disincentives to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Gives a Bronx Boy A Summer on the Beach
description: As natives of Northport, N.Y., J. R. and Laurie Morrissey spent their childhood summers rising at dawn and watching the fishing boats head out. They spent their days on the beach, went to barbecues in the evening with family and friends and camped in the Montauk Hills.

title: The World; Rolling Some Big Dice In the Euro Casino
description: THREE decades ago, the French writer Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber electrified Europe with his book ''The American Challenge,'' warning of the dangers of the ''economic invasion of Europe by the United States.'' The world, he predicted, might soon be dominated by three great industrial powers: America, Russia and American industry in Europe.

title: The Task Of Filling School Jobs
description: WHILE school enrollment soars -- leading to more advertisements for teachers -- vacancies are also appearing at administrative levels. Searches for high school principals are under way in Ardsley, Chappaqua and Pelham, and superintendents are needed in Irvington, Hendrik Hudson, Scarsdale, Mount Vernon, Tuckahoe and Yonkers.

title: Immunization Campaign Ignores Breast Feeding
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Costumes and Tea

title: What's for Breakfast?; Berlin
description: On a recent trip to Berlin my wife, Paula, and I met friends for Sunday brunch, as much of a Berlin institution these days as the Brandenburg Gate or hawkers of chunks of the old Berlin wall. We ordered coffee and eggs, our Berlin friends beer.

title: Walking the Line Between Selling and Selling Out
description: ON the road to the release of its latest album, ''A Thousand Leaves,'' Sonic Youth took perhaps the most startling creative detour in the band's 17-year history: it compromised its artistic vision for commercial gain. Or so it appeared.

title: Beyond the Traditional in Sports Medicine
description: AT 8 o'clock on a recent morning, Dr. Howard J. Luks, chief of sports medicine and arthroscopy at the Westchester Medical Center here, could be found watching television. But the television, in operating suite No. 8, was not tuned to the morning news programs. Instead, the screen displayed the inside of the right knee of a woman in her 30's on the table before Dr. Luks.

title: Political Briefing; Washington Ponders Mayor Barry's Plans
description: The buzz in Washington these days is, once again: Will Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. seek re-election?

title: Essay on Sidewalk Cafes Was Restaurant-Bashing
description: To the Editor:

title: On Wealthy Island, Being Black Means Being a Police Suspect
description: A conservative in style and outlook, long active in business and the community, 53-year-old Wayne Perryman is not the kind of man who would seem to invite police interrogation. He stands out on this island in only one regard -- he is one of only 300 blacks among the 21,000 residents of one of the wealthiest communities in America.

title: Rain-Soaked Event A Memorable One
description: Despite adverse weather conditions, including wind gusts that exceeded 30 miles an hour, three high school athletes registered impressive performances yesterday at the rain-soaked 31st annual Loucks Games at White Plains (N.Y.) High School.

title: Melissa Lentz, Douglas McDonnell
description: Melissa Patricia Murdoch Lentz and Douglas Thomas McDonnell were married yesterday in Ruxton, Md., at the home of the bride's father, Francis Brooks Lentz. The Rev. Alexei Michalenko, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Literary Pilgrimages; William Faulkner
description: This is not a dream. It's real. For lunch, one warm perfect day in Oxford, Miss., I had a grilled portobello mushroom and Italian ham sandwich. The mushroom had been quickly flamed so that it was nicely browned along the edges, but as juicy in the middle as rare beef. When I dipped a chunk of it into the olive oil in a shallow bowl beside my plate, I was careful to scoop up some of the freshly ground pepper at the bottom.

title: Joshua Targoff, Kimara Leibowitz
description: Kimara Joy Leibowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Leibowitz of New York, was married last evening to Joshua Laurence Targoff, a son of Cheri Kamen Targoff of Irvington, N.Y., and Michael B. Targoff of New York. Rabbi Edward Schecter officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Q. & A.
description: Rules on Combining Apartments

title: Backtalk; Time's Right To Lose One For Gipper
description: This would be a good week to begin dismantling the National Collegiate Athletic Association, a bloated, useless anthology of hypocrisies, distractions and sins. Although it has announced plans to appeal the most recent unnecessary lawsuit it has lost, the N.C.A.A. would do better to just pack up, close down and help its too many employees find jobs tutoring all the college athletes who need and deserve remedial education.

title: Elizabeth Kandravy, Joseph Cassidy
description: Elizabeth Ann Kandravy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Kandravy of Ridgewood, N.J., and Joseph Patrick Cassidy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myles Dodge Cassidy of Norwell, Mass., were married yesterday at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood. The Rev. Charlotte H. Sommers, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in which the Rev. Richard W. Bauer, a minister of the United Church of Christ, took part.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRUN, MARCIA
description: BRUN-Marcia. Gone two years today. Always in our thoughts, forever in our hearts. Wish you were here.

title: Rhode Island Moves to End Sodomy Ban
description: Only five people spoke on the bill, and the tally was an undramatic 49 to 40. But when the Rhode Island House of Representatives voted on Thursday to lift the state's ban on sodomy, it took ''perhaps the biggest step in 15 years on these archaic laws,'' the bill's sponsor, Representative Edith Ajello, said on Friday.

title: Famed, and Spacious, Army Post Is Focus of Housing Fray
description: Just as the American colonists were establishing their independence from Britain in 1776, the Spanish rulers of Mexico claimed a 1,400-acre plot here at the mouth of the San Francisco Bay as their northernmost military post, and called it the Presidio.

title: Broadway Video Opens A Second Production Factory
description: Broadway Video, a production company owned by Lorne Michaels, the television producer, opened a 8,600-square-foot video duplication factory at 3280 Broadway (at 132d Street) on April 27. The Harlem site is Broadway Video's second plant; the other is at 1619 Broadway (at 49th Street) in midtown.

title: INSIDE
description: Knicks Win Game 3

title: Think Masses of Tulips, a Sea of Color
description: THIS glorious spring cries out to be recorded with notebook or camera. There is so much to see and learn from bulb displays, especially for those who are novices at gardening.

title: Backtalk; Children Are Hurting for Some Exercise
description: ''Youth,'' Somerset Maugham wrote, ''is wasted on the young.'' A good line, but I'm afraid it may no longer be true. And I do mean afraid. Our young seem to have lost their right to youth and along with it the right to health.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: This list is selective, and programs are subject to change. More information is available through individual ticket offices.

title: Reviving Labyrinths, Paths to Inner Peace
description: When the Rev. Battle Beasley spray-painted 12 large concentric rings on the grass in his front yard three years ago, he handed out fliers to his neighbors explaining that it was a copy of the labyrinths found in medieval Christian cathedrals, and he invited them to walk it.

title: Unrest Deepens in Indonesia, But Suharto Offers Defiance
description: When President Suharto boarded a flight for Cairo here this morning, he left behind a country on the verge of a nervous breakdown. In the last six days, Indonesia has been riven by riots, widening student protests, a sudden increase in fuel prices and a free-falling currency.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Cannons and Cavalry

title: An Audit Uncovers Soft Profits In Software
description: If Hollywood made movies about accountants, instead of about lawyers, the just-completed audit of the Baan Company, a Dutch software concern with extensive operations in this country, would be a prime candidate for filming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESCHLER, MILTON E.
description: WESCHLER-Milton E. On May 3, 1998. Family and friends join in mourning the sudden passing of Milton E. Weschler, age ninetyone, of Coconut Creek, Florida, and formerly of Great Neck, Long Island. He was healthy and vibrant until the end. He was preceded in death by his loving wife, Estelle, and is survived by his three sons, Stephen, David and Kenneth; his sisters, Isabelle and Muriel, and many loving family members. We celebrate his long and joyous life. Love, His Sons

title: Putting It in Writing: Views of New Jersey -- FICTION; Sleuthing By the Shore
description: As writers reach into their memories and imaginations, New Jersey turns up in a variety of guises. Here are excerpts from a variety of books that appealed to editors of this section.

title: What's for Breakfast?; Tokyo
description: Nearly every morning I, and hundreds of thousands of Japanese, start the day with a steaming bowl of okayu. This thick rice porridge makes a subtle, but splendid, backdrop for the sour, rosy and softly wrinkled pickled plums (umeboshi) that jolt me, and my palate, awake. Some mornings, I'll add semidried, minuscule sardines (chirimen-jako) to my breakfast tray alongside homemade pickles: usually bran-pickled cucumbers and citron-infused cabbage. In summer I often add shredded basil-like shiso leaves to my porridge, while in the winter I'll briefly blanch and chop up radish and turnip tops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLLMAN, PHILLIP
description: STOLLMAN-Phillip. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a longtime friend who, with his late brother Max and late sister-in-law Frieda, was a YU Guardian and a Founder of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine. We extend our heartfelt condolences to son Dr. Gerald (and Leila) Stollman and daughters Shirley, Annette, and Rochelle; grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLEISCHMAN, MINNIE
description: FLEISCHMAN-Minnie. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Frances (Stanley), Sheila (Kenneth) and Howard (Grace). Cherished grandmother of Cheryl (Michael), Charles (Carol), Alan, Andrea, Richard and Brian (Andrea); great-grandmother of Robby. Loving sister. Services private.

title: Solutions to Traffic Problems
description: The number of cars in the state keep increasing, but there is no room for new roads. How should the state handle its traffic problems?

title: Adrenaline-Pumping Day for Woods at Bell South
description: It was the kind of day Tiger Woods had been waiting for.

title: Tanya Radowicz, Dominique Boillot
description: Tanya Gail Radowicz and Dr. Dominique Claude Boillot were married yesterday by the Rev. Glen Fisk at the Carmel (Calif.) Presbyterian Church.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Sludge Takes a Shuttle

title: East Brunswick Students Win National Civics Title
description: East Brunswick High School has been a civics powerhouse since the inception of a national competition called ''We the People . . . the Citizen and the Constitution,'' placing in the top 10 in each of the first 10 years. Last week, the school's 27-member team won first place in the 11th competition. In the three-day event in Washington, among the winners of all 50 state competitions, students debated in mock Congressional hearings to demonstrate their knowledge of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights. A panel of judges (including real judges, plus legislative staff members, lawyers, professors, journalists and state officials) chose 10 finalists, who competed on Monday.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; For Inner-City Child, a Breath of Fresh Air
description: Hassan Corley-Perry, who is 10 years old and lives in Harlem, likes waking to the sound of roosters cock-a-doodle-dooing. He doesn't miss the city traffic, sirens and street vendors shouting through the steamy air. This summer, like the past three, Hassan will leave his apartment and take a train to spend a two-week vacation with a family in Cold Spring Harbor as part of the 111-year-old Fresh Air Fund program, which provides inner-city children with summer vacations in rural surroundings.

title: Bulkhead Seats
description: To the Editor: As a mother of two preschoolers, I heartily endorse efforts to make air travel with children as easy as possible (''Having Second Thoughts in the Air,'' Jan. 4). But an experience with Lufthansa makes me think that the policy of seating children in the roomier bulkhead might sometimes be a convenient excuse for shifting passengers around to accommodate the more ''important'' passengers.

title: Weed-Choked Acres Bring Forth Frustration, Not Housing
description: ''Future Site of Gateway Estates,'' reads a sign at the edge of a weed-encrusted plot of land in East New York. ''A Planned Community of 3,000 Affordable Homes, Regional Shopping, Parks and Schools.''

title: Checking Medicine's Vital Signs
description: We can add the term ''consumer'' to the list of misnomers used by health care administrators. ''Consumers'' of health care are essentially large employers. These ultraconsumers are more likely to expend fewer resources, even if it means risking a misdiagnosis or two. (The economist's cost-benefit analysis comes in here.) Weinstein's article perpetuates the myth that we are the consumers, that we are the ones doing the choosing.

title: Matchmaking With No Visual Aids
description: SJEVA Kaplan is no Howard Stern. He has no shock of hair. And his radio show is only occasionally shocking. But the Russian-born Mr. Kaplan is trying to give Russian expatriates in New York (and New Jersey and Connecticut) drive-time talk radio they can call their own.

title: Retaining Classic Elegance and Charm
description: WHEN Long Islanders discuss their favorite restaurants, La Pace in Glen Cove usually makes the short list. Is this a sentimental vote for an aging (nearly two decades) doyenne or is its popularity deserved?

title: Taking a Right Turn Off the Road to Rage
description: They were a class of future road warriors, about 20 teen-agers gleefully admitting that they break the speed limit, get mad at slow drivers, cut corners so close that they hit the curb, and make obscene gestures at people whose driving is not up to par.

title: Toshiba Takes Lead By Newfoundland
description: The American yacht Toshiba grabbed the lead from Merit Cup yesterday in the eighth leg of the Whitbread Round the World race.

title: South Korea
description: In the earliest days of my childhood, I thought Korea was a mythical place, imagined like Avalon or the Land Before Time. Never mind that I was born there. My only memories of my birthplace, which I left in 1968, involved flashes of color and scent that merged with the stories my mother told about her homeland. Her Korean stories involved ghosts and rice fields, mountain gods and demon-fighters and fire-heated floors -- everything implausible, equally unreal to her American-reared children.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Tarzan and the Lost City

title: Princess Delays Debut Of Biggest Cruise Ship
description: The maiden voyage of the world's largest cruise ship was delayed Monday, just 10 days before the scheduled sailing. Princess Cruises said it would need an extra week to finish the 109,000-ton Grand Princess, which was fully booked with 2,600 people for a 12-day cruise from Southampton, England, to Istanbul. Julie Benson, a Princess spokeswomen, said Monday that the finishing touches included furnishing and carpeting public areas. The ship's maiden trip is now to be a 12-day cruise from Istanbul to Barcelona starting May 26 -- which, like all the ship's summer cruises, is fully booked.

title: All-Terrain Vehicle
description: A cluster of women with strollers gathered excitedly in front of Zabar's. ''In this neighborhood it's stroller gridlock,'' said Kirsten Hayes, as she adjusted the hat on her 6-month-old son, Trevor. ''And don't think no one's paying attention to what you're wheeling around.''

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Make This a Test Of Ewing
description: PLEASE don't ''Willis Reed'' him anymore. Please don't make his whole career hinge on whether he finds his form and leads the Knicks into the next round.

title: From the New Hong Kong, an English Take on China's Past
description: ONE evening last June, So Hon Wah sat backstage at the Hong Kong Cultural Center and pulled a pair of gold-trimmed boots off his callused feet. He was only changing costumes, he explained on the telephone from Hong Kong, but to him the gesture epitomized his title role in ''The Last Emperor,'' Wayne Eagling's tragic new dance for the Hong Kong Ballet. Like Bernardo Bertolucci's 1987 film of the same name, which won nine Academy Awards, the dance chronicles the epic life of Pu Yi, from his coronation at age 3 to his final years as a gardener during the Cultural Revolution.

title: Retracing a Cuban Patriot's Path Through His Productive Exile
description: For many New Yorkers, Jose Marti is just the name on a bronze statue near Central Park South -- a man on a horse clutching his chest with his right hand. Mortally wounded in battle, he is looking down, lips parted in agony or shock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMANN, HEINZ
description: LIPPMANN-Heinz. The Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine mourns the loss of Dr. Heinz Lippmann, who was a member of our department for 43 years. He will be missed by his many friends and colleagues. Avital Fast, M.D. Professor and Chairman

title: Music and Nature In a Japanese Flute
description: A JAPANESE scroll with bold bands of black on white adorns a wall in Ronnie Nyogetsu Seldin's music studio in Manhattan. The calligraphy translates as ''seven times down, eighth time up.'' Mr. Seldin explained: ''It refers to the resilience of the human spirit. It's like those Joe Palooka dolls that always pop up after you punch them down.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When the Colombians saw the Mexicans becoming greedier and even develop into rivals, they began to look to the Dominicans as more reliable partners.''

title: To 'Mommie Dearest,' a Twisted Mother's Day
description: IT has been 90 years since Anna Jarvis of Philadelphia, reportedly troubled by the thoughtlessness of grown children toward their mothers, asked that her church hold a service for all mothers, giving birth to the most sentimental of holidays.

title: Where Death Shall (or Shall Not) Have Dominion
description: WHEN Thom Fitzgerald refers to his first feature film, ''The Hanging Garden,'' as ''a goofy riff on the gay suicide movie,'' don't be put off. Mr. Fitzgerald, a 29-year-old writer and director, is merely demonstrating his darkly comic side, which is also evident throughout his movie, highly serious as it is.

title: Photographer Is Frustrated by the Shock of Recognition
description: Two weeks ago, Richard Berenholtz, a commercial photographer who specializes in images of the city, was strolling down Broadway on his way to an assignment photographing the courtyard of the majestic Apthorp building between 78th and 79th Streets. Just outside the Apthorp, he came upon a street vendor selling photographs from a makeshift booth. One shot was a silhouette of two buildings that Mr. Berenholtz himself had once photographed and included in one of his three published books of New York scenes. Several other images also looked familiar.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: HIGH CONCEPT

title: Reviving Port Chester
description: Finally realizing its long-held economic dreams, the Board of Trustees and the Industrial Development Agency of Port Chester signed a contract late last month with G&S Investors, a developer from Old Bethpage on Long Island, to build a retail center of more than 300,000 square feet on the village's waterfront.

title: Putting It in Writing: Views of New Jersey -- FACT; It Came From Beneath the Sink
description: As writers reach into their memories and imaginations, New Jersey turns up in a variety of guises. Here are excerpts from a variety of books that appealed to editors of this section.

title: Putting It in Writing: Views of New Jersey -- FACT; What It Takes To Make It
description: As writers reach into their memories and imaginations, New Jersey turns up in a variety of guises. Here are excerpts from a variety of books that appealed to editors of this section.

title: May 3-9; Masterpieces on the Move
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art grew a lot richer when Natasha Gelman, an honorary trustee who died on May 2, bequeathed to it 85 works by Picasso, Braque, Miro and other 20th-century modern masters. The gift, worth at least $300 million and one of the most important in the museum's history, includes Matisse's ''The Young Sailor II'' and Dali's ''The Accommodations of Desires'' among other icons. The Met will also get its first Matisse paper cutout, ''Snow Flowers,'' and its first paintings by Francis Bacon and Alberto Giacometti. JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI

title: Sara Meltzer and Adam Ames
description: Sara Paige Meltzer, the daughter of Meryl and Robert Meltzer of Southampton, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Paul Ames, a son of Sharon Ames of New York and Steven Ames of Rye, N.Y. Leon B. Polsky, a retired judge of the New York Court of Claims and a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner took part in the service.

title: Women at Helm Set A Course To the Top
description: ONE built an empire from her kitchen table, another turned her back on a Fortune 500 employer and struck out on her own and the third was determined to fly solo even though she was married to the boss. These three entrepreneurs from Westchester are on Working Woman magazine's first list of the largest 500 female-owned businesses in the United States, published in the May issue.

title: Textiles in Toronto
description: THE garment industry was once one of the mainstays of Toronto's economy. Now that most manufacturing has moved out of the city, only vestiges of the wholesale side of the fashion business linger along Spadina and funky West Queen streets in downtown. Here, shop windows draped with brocades and velvets, flannel and gabardine, or filled with disorderly heaps of buttons, zippers, ribbons and shoulder pads, still grace some of the seedier storefronts scattered among an abundance of cafes, bookstores and shops purveying up-to-the-minute millinery, fine French soaps and vintage clothing.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Completing Exhaust Fan Installation
description: LAST week this column focused on the preliminary procedures for buying an exhaust fan and choosing the proper location for it. The fan should be mounted between two joists above the toilet. Locate the joists and drill a 1/8th-inch hole between them through the ceiling into the cavity above.

title: What's for Breakfast?; Eastern Pa.
description: The sturdily pragmatic Pennsylvania Dutch could never be accused of wasting time trying to develop a fine cuisine. Their country fare, distinguished mostly by the size of the portions, can be an acquired taste -- maybe nothing more so than scrapple.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; As Office Squeeze Tightens, Builders Grab Trowels
description: THE signs are clear -- dirt being moved here, steel going up there -- that after two good years of job growth, declining vacancy rates and rising rents, 1998 is shaping up to be a year of development and redevelopment in the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market.

title: Ideas & Trends; Of Men and Mice: Here They Come to Save the Day
description: THE importance of mice in human affairs is all too easy to minimize. But last week the little rodent scampered into the catbird seat. There were 18 mice orbiting the planet, outnumbering the 7 humans aboard the space shuttle Columbia. And down on Earth, mice moved media and markets as news broke of a miraculous-seeming cure for mouse cancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, PAUL
description: COHEN-Paul, CPA. August 17, 1914-May 3, 1998. Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Lido Beach, L.I., NY. Former managing partner of Harry Abramowitz & Co., certified public accountants. New York University graduate, class of 1935. Adored husband of Regina (Schoenberg). Loving father of Edward, Steven & Linda. Beloved grandfather of Andrew and Glenn. Great grandfather of Michael, Ariel, Aaron and Ashley. He will be missed and remembered by all for his kindness, generosity, goodness, compassion, understanding, wisdom and ethics. We loved him dearly (his family).

title: The Silence of the Honeybees
description: HOWARD BRONSON JR. used to enjoy listening to the hum of the honeybees flying among the blossoms in his apple orchard in Roxbury. ''On a nice quiet day during bloom you could stand real still and you'd hear the bees working,'' Mr. Bronson said. ''When you walk in there now, you have to look for a bee.''

title: Sogen Shops for a Suitor, But Manager Must Say 'I Do'
description: Yet another fund company is on the block and, as a result, the veteran fund investor Jean-Marie Eveillard may soon have a new boss.

title: May 3-9; Take That, I.R.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service has never had many friends, and it has had even fewer since Senate hearings last fall and again this month produced tales of incompetence and vindictiveness throughout the tax-collection agency. So it was not surprising that the Senate voted 97-0 to pass a bill overhauling the agency and creating new protections for taxpayers.

title: 'Intimate Exchanges' By Fleetwood Stage
description: TO take in all of Alan Ayckbourn's ultimate conceit, ''Intimate Exchanges,'' a theatergoer would need to tough it out for 32 hours. That means sitting through 8 plays and 16 different endings, because a variant resolution exists for each play.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, LENORE
description: NEWMAN-Lenore. Died quietly at home on May 6 in her apartment in New York City. Family and friends join together in sorrow at the departure of this caring, loving person who carried her professional social work training as a way of life. She retired from Roosevelt-St. Luke's Hospital as supervising medical social worker. Lenore was proud of her volunteer work at the United Nations where after her retirement she dedicated increasing time as a representative of Economists Allied for Arms Reduction. Her surviving family include her nieces Sharon and Marla, her nephew Bernarr, her grandnephews Frank and Jeremy, & her sister-in-law Janis Newman. The service will be at noon on Monday, May 11, at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, and the family will be receiving there on Sunday 6-8 P.M., and at the residence of L. Levi, 91 Central Park West (69th Street), Monday 6-8 P.M., and Tuesday 4-8 P.M. Interment will be at the Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: In London, Three Revelations of Cosmic Despair
description: Arancorous old novelist lolls on a seat on the Paris-to-Frankfurt express, inwardly accusing his life work of incoherence, repetitiveness and failure. A woman lies on her death bed in a Dublin hospital, brooding about the waste she sees in herself, her family and her nation. A bunch of bums slump in a bar based on Jimmy the Priest's, the Fulton Street hell hole where Eugene O'Neill drank bad whisky and attempted suicide in 1911. All these topers have their pipe dreams, ranging from achieving pastoral bliss in New Jersey to becoming an ace New York attorney to crushing capitalism and liberating the masses, and their chances of fulfilling them are roughly those of Lazarus becoming J. P. Morgan.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Chicken Or Beef? Aim Higher
description: UNITED STATES airlines have generally returned to profitability, so they have a golden opportunity to deal with a big problem: the blight on their food carts. For too long, they have been content to serve rubber chicken, lead-pellet rice and pretzel-peanut munch.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRATT, ROSE
description: DRATT-Rose. May 14, 1993. If only my empty arms could hold you again; if only my tears could be kisses felt by you again. Your wisdom and love are with me each day, but can't mend my broken heart. Your One and Only

title: Ideas & Trends: The Rush to Enhancement; Medicine Isn't Just for the Sick Anymore
description: WE are witness to a raging epidemic of biomedical discovery.

title: Creditors Lead Push To Curb Bankruptcy
description: WHAT was once a staple of the economic cycle -- recession driving more people into bankruptcy and then recovery thinning their ranks -- seems to have disappeared.

title: Pampering Times Two
description: When Pamela Door, a writer in New York, became pregnant, her desire to be pampered grew acute. ''I remember leaving work in the middle of the afternoon to get a pedicure just so I could get my legs massaged for a few moments,'' the soon-to-be mother of two said. ''My body was screaming out for attention.''

title: Style; Vulture Culture
description: It was one of those Los Angeles days when meter maids lounge and waiters giggle. The soft, warm sun made it a sweet day for estate sales.

title: Thugs in Bassinets
description: GHOSTS FROM

title: Van Shooting Revives Charges of Racial 'Profiling' by New Jersey State Police
description: The furor over an incident in which two New Jersey State Police officers fired 11 shots into a van during a traffic stop comes against a backdrop of years of allegations that troopers in New Jersey have illegally used race-based profiles to stop black and Hispanic drivers in hope of making drug arrests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, ELISABETH FEIST
description: HIRSCH-Elisabeth Feist. Died quietly on May 8, 1998, in Newtown, PA. Beloved wife of the late Felix E. Hirsch. Loving mother of Roland Felix Hirsch of Germantown, MD, and Thomas Feist Hirsch of Brooklyn, NY. Devoted grandmother of Elizabeth, Daniel, Sallie and Paul. Great-grandmother of Sarah. Born in Mainz, Germany, November 2, 1904, to Samuel Sigmund and Toni Rawicz Feist. Grew up in Berlin. Studied at Marburg and Freiberg. Emigrated to USA 1938. Married in New Haven in 1938. Taught at Bard and Trenton State College. Held Rockefeller and Guggenheim Fellowships. Retired to Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA. Member of Newtown Friends Meeting. Interment there Monday, May 11, at 3 PM. For information contact Swartz/Givnish Funeral Home, 215-968-3891.

title: A Rising Rap Star Puts Content Ahead of Style
description: ON the back lot of Universal Studios, hip-hop's rising star Canibus is lounging in a trailer parked in front of the clock-tower building best known from the set of the ''Back to the Future'' movies. On break from filming a video for ''How Come,'' a single he raps on from the Warren Beatty movie ''Bulworth,'' Canibus is waiting for a meeting with an executive at Dreamworks Records who wants to sign him to a publishing deal. In his back pocket is a cassette of a song that the teen-age singer and sitcom star Brandy wants him to rap on, and in his hands is a bottle of Hype, a natural energy beverage that he says he drinks to immunize himself from the hype constantly bombarding him. The drink, he says, keeps him from getting ''hype-notized'' and succumbing to ''hype-nitis,'' which occurs when you believe your own hype. It is a disease common among pop stars.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 10, 1998
description: Weeks

title: The Chicken-Bagel War
description: On a block where Bruegger's Bagels is one of six restaurants, competition has always been fierce. Then came the Ranch 1 chicken people with ''guerrilla marketing.'' With reports from SoHo, Chelsea, Manhattan Valley, Jamaica, Middle Village, Jackson Heights, East New York, Boerum Hill and Cobble Hill. PAGES 5-9 (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

title: One Executive Predicts More Auto Mergers
description: Two days after announcing a merger with Daimler-Benz A.G., the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation predicted at a news conference today that the auto industry would continue its global consolidation and said that auto makers were engaged in ''half a dozen talks going on right now'' for further deals.

title: Fightin' Mad
description: An epic battle between a 12-year-old boy and the owners of a claymation horse is over -- with the owners in full retreat. Last December, Christopher Van Allen of Macungie, Pa., received a registered letter from a lawyer representing the Prema Toy Company, which owns the trademarks to the characters Gumby and Pokey. The letter demanded that the boy stop using ''pokey.org'' as the name of his Web site, hinting legal action if Van Allen didn't comply.

title: Too Close to TV Life for Comfort
description: ABC is canceling ''Ellen,'' the BBC is killing off Sister George and Carl Wallnau is no dummy.

title: 5 Teams Advance From the A.C.C.
description: Two men's teams and all three women's teams from the Atlantic Coast Conference advanced yesterday in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I tournaments.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 26 about the absence of democracy in parts of the Middle East and North Africa misstated the percentage of the world's population that lives in Arab countries. It is about 5 percent, not one-fifth.

title: Show of Artisans, Show of Versatility
description: THE latest in crafts can be seen at the Bruce Museum's 13th annual Outdoor Craft Festival being held Saturday and next Sunday in Greenwich.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Battery Park City; Urban Suburb w/Yacht Basin
description: WHERE else in Manhattan can you sail away from a harbor only steps away from your apartment building as well as plant and tend your own small plot of land with advice from a horticulturist? Not to mention walk five minutes to a corporate job in a financial center?

title: International Terminal Is Opening at Kennedy
description: Terminal One at Kennedy International Airport -- the first new terminal at the airport in 27 years -- is scheduled to open May 28. The four foreign airlines that have jointly developed the $434 million terminal -- Air France, Japan Air Lines, Korean Air and Lufthansa -- will eventually be joined by several other carriers, including Singapore Airlines and Air Afrique.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Aiding Disabled Who Want to Work
description: WHILE the bulls may be stampeding across Wall Street, one major portion of the working population is being forced to sit out one of the nation's most sustained economic booms in our history. Because of a thicket of regulations, of some 16.9 million people with disabilities who have stated their desire to work, only 4.5 million are employed nationwide for fear of losing crucial Medicaid payments that enable them to meet their extraordinary medical costs.

title: May 3-9; Easy to Hide: the Mini-Gun
description: Airport security people in the United States and elsewhere have gone on the alert for a gadget 3 inches long and 1 inch wide, with a ring on the end. It looks like a key ring. In fact, it is a pistol. Pull the ring and the pistol is cocked; press a button and it fires a .32-caliber bullet. From 20 yards, it kills. The Bulgarian-made gun is available on the streets there for $20. In an alert last month, Interpol, the international police agency, said the key-chain pistol was readily available in southern Europe.

title: Campaign Reform Falls Prey to Partisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Defending the Indefensible
description: Of all the upsetting things in Tina Rosenberg's chilling article ''Defending the Indefensible'' (April 19), the one that sticks with me the most is that it is only the fact that Alan Dershowitz has a policy of not working for fugitives that prevents him from acting as counsel to Radovan Karadzic when Karadzic is eventually brought to trial in The Hague.

title: Political Briefing; Gore, a Former Critic, Extols Cars, in Detroit
description: Back in 1992, when he was a Senator and taking the lead on many environmental issues, Al Gore wrote a book titled ''Earth in the Balance,'' in which he whacked the automobile industry as one of the great polluters and warned that its products posed ''a mortal threat to the security of every nation.'' Then he called for elimination of the internal combustion engine.

title: To Live and Drive in L.A.
description: The lineup for summertime fun: multi-striped, sun-bright swimwear that can play on land or sea.

title: Circular Makes the Rounds and Residents Complain
description: Last month, Sandy Balboza set out to do some spring cleaning. She and a few neighbors got about 200 Boerum Hill residents to sign a petition calling on The Marketeer, a free weekly advertising circular, to cease its ''indiscriminate littering of our neighborhood.''

title: Don't Tread on My Tax Rate
description: As an avid reader of the magazine, I am pained to tell you that your article on Vermont's new education law was inflammatory and misleading (''Don't Tread on My Tax Rate,'' by Elinor Burkett, April 26). Not only was the entire supposition wrong, but it contained factual errors. Furthermore, characterizations by the author referring to the act as a ''centralized, intrusive and redistributive scheme of mind-boggling complexity'' more properly appear on the editorial page.

title: To Fight Stress, Change the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: Play Dates Aren't Just for Children Anymore
description: IT was Abigail's third birthday. For the big day, her family arranged a gathering that included her two best friends, 2-year-old Romeo and 1-year-old Barkley.

title: 'Fun Stuff' in '48: British Gentile in Israel Air Force
description: Reminiscing over the drone of planes taking off from an airstrip near this Tel Aviv suburb, Gordon Levett, a 77-year-old Englishman, savored the memories of his days as a volunteer combat pilot at Israel's birth half a century ago.

title: County Includes Integrity as Part Of Carting Contract
description: ON its continuing cable television commercials, viewable sometimes between innings of Yankee games, Suburban Carting Corporation, the county's largest private hauler of trash, tells viewers, ''We've beenyour friends and neighbors'' for more than 30 years, and the company adds that it cares about the environment.

title: Bebe Rebozo, Loyal Friend in Nixon's Darkest Days, Dies at 85
description: Bebe Rebozo, a self-made Florida millionaire who met Richard M. Nixon in 1950 and became his longtime friend, died on Friday night at Baptist Hospital in Miami. He was 85 years old, born two months before Nixon, the man who became the 37th President of the United States.

title: Feeling a Bit Like a Laboratory Mouse?
description: CARL HATHAWAY was sitting on the geyser when it erupted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, LILLIAN
description: BLUM-Lillian. Died May 8, 1998 at 102. Beloved daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Siegfried Blum. Loving friend of Dr. Alice Khan Ladas and Ann Taylor.

title: A Waterfront Dream Still Deferred
description: Ten years ago, the Hudson River Waterfront Walkway -- envisioned as a continuous, 30-foot-wide waterfront path stretching for 18 scenic miles -- was a just a few red squiggles scattered on a map, 300 feet of path here, 500 feet there. But as Manhattan slowly connected its waterfront paths, Hudson County seemed ever nearer to completing its parallel dream. ''Bicyclists and rollerbladers will be able to roll their way from Bayonne to Fort Lee without getting in a car,'' declared a glossy full-color map and brochure printed in 1995 by the Hudson River Waterfront Conservancy, an advocacy group.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 19 about Penang, Malaysia, misstated the price of a tour of the Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion. It is about $2.75, not free.

title: The Hill Gets Steeper For State's Land-Use Plan
description: When Governor Whitman vowed earlier this year to use the state development plan to help slow down suburban sprawl, she was applauded by the lobbying group that represents local officials.

title: Kennan's Consistency
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE BAKER

title: Romania's Lost Boys
description: Nearly a decade after the collapse of the brutal Communist regime of Nicolae Ceausescu, Romania remains one of the poorest and most fractured societies in Eastern Europe. In Bucharest -- a cold, hard and desperate city, even for people with jobs and shelter -- nearly a thousand children spend their lives in the streets.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: The following list of performers and concert dates is selective. Performances are subject to change.

title: New Life for an Old Neighborhood
description: WHEN Doreen Tate first saw the house in the Timothy Dwight section of New Haven, it was abandoned and ramshackle. ''And ugly!'' Mrs. Tate recalls. ''But I kept thinking, what can I do to make it decent?''

title: Pataki's Resolve on Shifting Aid to City Schools Is Questioned
description: Sixteen months ago, Gov. George E. Pataki, who hails from the Hudson River Valley, took up a call normally heard from New York City politicians. The city's schools do not receive a fair share of state aid, he said, and he pledged to correct the inequity.

title: Lousy Luck for Teddy Bears
description: IT was supposed to be a special day, the day of the Teddy Bear Sleepover. Every kid, up to the toughest third grader, came to school with a teddy bear. Even the teachers brought them.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about John White Hughes Bassett, a prominent figure in Canadian journalism, politics and sports who was publisher of a Toronto newspaper that closed in 1971, misstated the newspaper's name. It was The Toronto Telegram, not The Telegraph.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 26 with the What's Doing column, about Athens, misidentified the monument shown. It was the Tower of the Winds, not the Monument of Lysicrates.

title: In the Name of King Rat
description: Sharp as a surgeon's scalpel, a northeast wind from the Irish Sea slices through the dreary afternoon, severing any semblance of April from the greening hills and rolling meadows. A bone-chilling rain mingled with sleet falls in slanting sheets, and bright, new leaves, ripped from their trees, climb the air.

title: The Nation: Growing Pains; No Room for Children in a World of Little Adults
description: TIMES SQUARE, the oversized advertising capital of the universe, has always been the lurid home to all the icons of the adult consumer culture -- smoke-puffing Camels, racy Calvin Kleins, sophisticated Canadian Club rye, Maxwell House coffee, world-class smut and other pleasures of the marketplace, illicit or otherwise.

title: Carrie Hazard, Brian Feeney
description: Carolyn Marie Hazard and Brian Thomas Feeney, both lawyers, were married yesterday in Portland, Me. The Rev. John Keegan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph.

title: STATS ON THE RUN
description: Here's something new on the infoglut front: Sports Trax, a hand-held beeper-type device that displays the latest major league baseball scores and stats at the push of a button. Working off microwaves like a cellular phone, the gizmo relays inning-by-inning details -- who's on first, outs, fouls, scores, cancellations -- from every game in the big leagues, with just a 45-second delay, all for only $79.95. ''You can put it on your desk and people will think it's just a beeper,'' says Charlie Key, owner of USA Page in Vero Beach, Fla., which markets the device. Key seems to know who his customers are: hard-core addicts. ''No one has to know you are keeping up with a game,'' he says conspiratorially, ''or two or three at the same time.''

title: Corrections
description: A review on April 26 about ''Faust's Metropolis'' and ''Berlin and Its Culture,'' two books on the history of Berlin, misstated the relationship between King Edward VII of England and Emperor William II of Germany. Edward was William's uncle, not his nephew.

title: Melissa Garnock And Russell Low
description: Melissa Dana Garnock, the daughter of Ellen and Jay Garnock of Huntington, N.Y., was married last evening to Russell L. Low, the son of Cynthia and Stanley Low of Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Ian S. Jacknis performed the ceremony at the South Huntington Jewish Center in Melville, N.Y.

title: Dangerous Drug Imports
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Not Even Sorry
description: Another day, another atrocity.

title: Boogie Nights
description: EASY RIDERS, RAGING BULLS

title: Some Couples May Find Viagra a Home Wrecker
description: For a former New England auto dealer, years of retirement to Florida brought two major changes: his golf scores improved as his sexual powers declined.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEMPLE, ANNA
description: TEMPLE-Anna. 25 years have not dimmed loving memories of our most wonderful and caring mother and grandmother.

title: Q&A/Maj. Gen. David W. Gay; Multiple Missions of the National Guard
description: THE Connecticut National Guard, founded in 1672, has been around longer than the nation has. Pride goes with the tradition. ''The National Guard today is better than it has ever been,'' says Maj. Gen. David W. Gay, the State Adjutant General and commander of the Guard. He cited a high level of training, education and physical fitness and continued: ''I think in terms of management, people, morale, equality, dealing with the public and our mission, we're doing as well as we can do.''

title: What's for Breakfast?; Paris
description: Like many foods of Paris, the fluffy, butter-fragrant, yeast-leavened, crescent-shaped pastry known as the croissant is sacrosanct. Each croissant lover has a favorite place, a favorite hour, a favorite accompaniment to this feather-light morning pastry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, EUGENE
description: ZIMMERMAN-Eugene. Beloved husband of the late Daisy. Devoted father of Robert, Barbara Sirotkin and Judy. Loving grandfather of Michael, Amy, Sharon and Susan; and Joanne and Michael. Adoring great-grandfather of Yehuda and Ryan. Service Sunday 1PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Tax Relief ? It Must Be An Election Year Session
description: THE morning before the General Assembly in Hartford approved up to $150 rebates for most state taxpayers, State Representative James A. Amann, Democrat of Milford, listened to his wife berate the idea as a stupid gimmick. So he finally asked her if she thought he should vote against it.

title: Putting It in Writing: Views of New Jersey
description: WRITE what you know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDA, ARTHUR A.
description: RUDA-Arthur A. Dearest friend and father of Barbara Melnick and Stan Preiser, Jessie and Bob Einhorn, Prisilla and Sy Polishook. Beloved husband of the late Pearl and Toni Ruda.
