Cherished grandpa of David and Jackie Lipson, Paul Lipson, Jacquie Lipson, Papa to, Yael and Doni Simckes, Sage Smiley, Lauren Kogod and David Smiley, Irene and Alan Aronoff. The icing on the cake great-grandfather Keshet Simckes and Jacob Aronoff. Services Sun. 12 noon at Schwartz Bros Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd & 76 Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. Vivid, sweet memories and deepest gratitude to my beloved, unforgettable mother.

title: Workfare Lacks the Vision of Roosevelt's W.P.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Say New Movie Theater Means 'Let Them Eat Popcorn'
description: This week, the Titanic will do something it has never done before: sink on a movie screen in East New York. On Friday, the 3,200-seat Linden Boulevard Multiplex Cinemas is opening, the first movie theater to come to the neighborhood in decades.

title: Hospice Boom Is Giving Rise To New Fraud
description: Pauline Moskal was not sure her mother qualified for the care promised by the hospice service. But she had watched other patients at the nursing home receive more attention from the staff and she did not want anything less for her mother.

title: Bad Publicity
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 Months In Style
description: Martha Southgate, articles editor at Essence magazine, is pregnant with her second child, and the topic of maternity clothing makes her cringe. ''The cheap stuff is really ugly,'' she said. ''And I especially hate anything with panels. They drive me crazy.''

title: A Living Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: Unleashing Opinions on Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Bringing Color To Central Park
description: The fragrant, spicy perfume of the mauve wisteria dripping from the great iron trellis wafted over the Conservatory Garden. Amid the beds of pink tulips, the 1,170 luncheon guests suggested an Impressionist painting in their pastel-colored spring clothes. The annual Frederick Law Olmstead Awards Luncheon, given on Wednesday by the Women's Committee and the Board of Trustees of the Central Park Conservancy, raised $1.6 million and honored Sheila Labrecque, right, the group's president for 1995-97, and Lewis Bernard, a former vice chairman. The luncheon, oversubscribed by 250 people, dramatized the fashion divide between designers with their all-black style and the taste of their clients for cheerful color.

title: Co-ops Get Flexibility On Rules
description: CO-OP shareholders have often been told that one of their most significant responsibilities is to attend the annual meeting. But it might come as a surprise to some to learn that this year, attendance really does matter.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: The Sophisticated Traveler

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 26 about Disney World's Animal Kingdom reported that the United States Department of Agriculture was investigating several animal deaths that had taken place there. On April 22, after the section had gone to press, the department announced that its investigation had found no violations of the Animal Welfare Act.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Riverhead Considers 2 Offers on 2,900-Acre Site
description: JUST over two years ago Northrop Grumman closed its operations at the 2,900-acre Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant here, laying off or transferring the last of 3,000 workers and leaving behind 1.1 million square feet of industrial and office space and two runways.

title: Modest but Artful, Portions and Prices
description: COZY and casual, Darwoods in New Milford is just the ticket for a pre- or post-movie dinner at very modest prices. (A movie theater is just across the street.) What tickles us about Darwoods is its simplicity. But don't be deceived. The decor may be modest and the manner of the staff unpretentious but at the same time this is a professional operation. For all its artlessness, Darwoods knows what it is doing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLSTEIN, JEANNE S.
description: PERLSTEIN-Jeanne S. We are so sad, our 18th Mother's Day without you. We love & miss you. Audrey, Ellen and Suzanne

title: Kimberly Ahto And David Bush
description: Kimberly Christina Ahto, a daughter of Charles Ahto of Florham Park, N.J., and the late Margaret Ahto, was married yesterday to David Mark Bush, the son of Nancy and Alfred Bush Jr. of West Chester, Pa. The Rev. William Mooney officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family in Florham Park.

title: Sign Opponents Are Seeing Red and Claiming Victory
description: Ending a controversy over its three-story sign on a Northern Boulevard apartment building, a McDonald's restaurant has covered the ad with red paint. While possibly sparing the building's owner a maximum fine of $2,500, the action has also energized a group of activists who see it as a victory in a campaign against what they consider garish business displays.

title: Right Thinking
description: The Power

title: Bookend; Tolstoy's Pen
description: It was a simple pen of Russian pine, slightly gnarled in the middle, theend pitted with the master's tooth marks. With its point of Georgian steel, Count Leo Tolstoy had penned his immortal War and Peace.

title: Gay Bar Gains a Foothold
description: When entrepreneurs proposed a business on 109th Street and Amsterdam Avenue last year, it seemed good for the blighted Manhattan Valley neighborhood.

title: Round About the Other Cape
description: Anyone who lives on Cape Ann, Mass., and actually leaves from time to time, gets used to explaining the map and the world in this way: No, we're the other cape. North of Boston. That's right, the small one ... And after a few years (to those of us who aren't natives) this becomes a method of assessing one's allegiance, because everybody who lives here eventually realizes that they are really inhabiting an island, linked to the big mainland only on sufferance and by a couple of bridges that emphasize the disconnection as much as they conveniently let us on and off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENDSEL, PETER DAVID
description: BRENDSEL-Peter David. Age 27. On Wednesday, May 6, at his residence in McLean, VA. Beloved son of Leland C. & Diane Brendsel. Brother of Jon and Michael Brendsel. Grandson of Lars Brendsel & William and LaVerne Christensen. Services held at Vienna Presbyterian Church, 124 Park Street N.E., Vienna, Virginia, on Tuesday, May 12, 11 A.M. Valet parking provided. title: Makeover Time for a Once and Would-Be Star
description: CATHERINE ZETA JONES may be the only actress ever to move to Hollywood seeking anonymity -- and to be so delighted at having succeeded. Speaking in a cafe here recently, she laughed her bright Welsh laugh and marveled at the fact that she could carry on a conversation over cappuccino and a muffin and not have to fend off a single paparazzo, a new-found freedom for a woman who was not so long ago a tabloid favorite in Britain.

title: Schools Scramble to Meet Big Enrollments
description: A GROWING student population on Long Island is causing school districts to reconfigure their schools, add wings, install portable classrooms and reclaim leased buildings. Many will go ahead with the projects despite Gov. George Pataki's veto of a $500 million ''rescue'' package intended to help districts pay for major maintenance, renovation or new construction.

title: Disabled May Get Easier Cruise Access
description: Rules may yet be written governing access for the disabled aboard passenger vessels that visit the United States. A Government agency known as the Access Board is preparing to convene an advisory committee to discuss a rule to be established under the Americans With Disabilities Act.

title: Pressed by U.S., China Frees Catholic Bishop Loyal to Vatican
description: The Chinese authorities have released, six months early, one of their most prominent religious prisoners, an elderly Roman Catholic Bishop who was jailed for refusing to submit to the authority of the Government-sponsored church. The release, which had been sought by American officials, was clearly timed to soften American concerns about human rights before President Clinton visits China in late June.

title: May 3-9; Another Bang, Big
description: An international group of astronomers announced it had measured a celestial explosion so violent that for about 40 seconds it outshone the radiation released by the rest of the universe. This ''gamma-ray burster'' was detected Dec. 14, but only recently did astronomers measure its distance from the Earth as a staggering 12 billion light years. Gamma ray bursts might be caused by colliding black holes, but no one knows for sure. If one were to occur within a few thousand light years of the Earth, it might wipe out life. MALCOLM W. BROWNE

title: Ms. Anuszkiewicz and Mr. Berkley
description: Christine Marie Anuszkiewicz and Stephen William Berkley were married yesterday at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church in Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Joseph O'Brien performed the ceremony.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Wilde Thing
description: ''Somehow or other I'll be famous,'' Oscar Wilde told a friend when he was an undergraduate at Oxford, ''and if not famous, notorious.'' He became both -- first as the deliberately outrageous exponent of estheticism, caricatured in Punch and lampooned by Gilbert and Sullivan; later as the brilliantly witty playwright whose work mocked and subverted all the easy pieties of Victorian England. He became a social lion, the dazzling talker every London hostess clamored to have at her table. Then came scandal and ruin: in love with Lord Alfred Douglas, petulant, beautiful son of the Marquess of Queensberry, Wilde allowed himself to be talked into a lawsuit against the brutish Marquess that eventually landed him and not Queensberry in prison. In the 98 years since Wilde's death, his story has been recounted by everyone from the man who ruined him to the distinguished scholar Richard Ellmann. Now Merlin Holland, Wilde's grandson, has published THE WILDE ALBUM (Holt, $19.95), which brings together hundreds of images of Wilde and his circle, accompanied by a biographical text. Some of the photographs have never been published before; others are classics of Wildeiana, like the studio shots of a dreamy, languorous young Wilde, in a fur-lined coat, velvet jacket and knee breeches, taken during his triumphant lecture tour in the United States (where he famously told a customs officer that he had nothing to declare but his genius, and won over the miners of Leadville, Colo., by drinking with them). Holland has no dramatic revelations or bold new theories to offer, but his narrative serves to remind us all over again of what an extraordinary man his grandfather was -- and how much he influenced the art of the 20th century. Evelyn Toynton

title: Sheryl Cuker, Randy Appleyard
description: Sheryl Elise Cuker, a daughter of Rita and George Cuker of Weston, Mass., was married yesterday to Arthur Randall Appleyard, the son of Joan Appleyard-Tucker of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late Dr. Arthur Appleyard. description: KAWALEK-Roman, M.D. Graduated University of Vienna in Medicine. Survived Krystal Nacht in Vienna. Served residency at University Hospital in Little Rock, AR. Enlisted US Army 1943-attained rank of captain. Awarded Bronze Star, Presidential Unit Citation, Commendation ribbon w/ Pendant, Combat Medic Badge. Commanding Medical Officer of Unit which liberated Buchenwald Death Camp. Practiced medicine w/specialty in general surgery in East Orange, NJ. Served as police surgeon, City of East Orange. Avid tennis player. Beloved father to Marlene Kawalek Josephs, Jeffrey Kawalek, and Kim Kawalek Vogel, and grandfather to Molly Kawalek Josephs, Sophie, Madeline, and Drew Kawalek, and Michelle Vogel. title: To Prevent a Wider War in Kosovo
description: The long-simmering tensions in Serbia's province of Kosovo turned violent in recent weeks and threaten to ignite a wider war in the Balkans. Only a concerted diplomatic effort by the United States can keep the conflict from escalating. Though he has been attentive to the problem, President Clinton must do more to take the lead with European nations to insure that Kosovo is not left adrift.

title: Warren Beatty Is Trying to Say Something
description: There was no one moment when Warren Beatty decided not to run for President. In the late 60's and early 70's, he was greatly distracted and intrigued by Presidential politics, working on the short-lived campaign of Robert Kennedy in 1968 and then, in 1972, for George McGovern. ''I enjoyed the tumult,'' he recalls. ''Partly it was because it didn't have to do with the work that I did.'' But he was never really tempted to run himself, for President or anything else. ''I've never seriously found it attractive,'' he says. ''Everyone who has any involvement with politics thinks about what it would be like to be stuck with having to get elected.''

title: The Nation: Judicial Privilege; The Right To Secrecy
description: IN his memoirs, Judge John J. Sirica recalled the solemn anticipation with which everyone viewed a coming court battle over President Richard M. Nixon's first effort to invoke the notion of executive privilege during Watergate.

title: Dominicans Allow Drugs Easy Sailing
description: In the early 1990's, Colombia's drug barons were fed up and eager to rearrange their business. Impatient with the Mexican traffickers who were demanding half of every load delivered and distributed in the United States, they went looking for a country with weak law enforcement, proximity to the United States and established drug distribution networks.

title: POSTINGS: 2,500 Wooded Acres on Staten Island; State Buys Friars' Land For Greenbelt

title: May 3-9; The Eye In the Eye Of the Beholder
description: Take any portrait painted within the last 600 years and find a point halfway between the left and right sides of the frame. Then draw a vertical line straight down through the painting. According to a scientist who carried out this exercise (in preparing for a study on how the left and right sides of the brain perceive works of art), something quite unexpected will happen. One of the portrait subject's eyes will almost always fall on the center line. This holds true if the subject is looking straight ahead or to one side.

title: Huddled Masses Of the Wealthy

title: Using the Art of Fiction to Enliven Truth

Doing a halfhearted impression of Al Pacino as Michael Corleone, Sammy turns to his best friend and says, ''Fredo, you're my older brother and I love you, but don't ever take sides against the family.''

Two that currently lure me from my computer at lunchtime also sell goodies to go, which makes a drive even more worthwhile.

title: Seattle

title: Checking Medicine's Vital Signs
description: Michael M. Weinstein's call for physician ''report cards'' that grade, among other things, the ''curing of illness'' is troublesome (''Checking Medicine's Vital Signs,'' April 19). While no one can deny that errors are made by physicians and hospitals, it is dangerous and unrealistic to equate poor outcomes with inadequate care. Even with today's knowledge and technology, many disease processes are poorly understood. With the exception of infectious diseases, most illnesses (diabetes and hypertension, for example) are chronic; they cannot be cured, merely managed. Furthermore, the treatments themselves come with risks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, MAURICE ANTHONY
description: BRENNAN - Maurice Anthony. Passed away peacefully on May 9, 1998, at 91. Beloved husband of the late Emily Humphrey Brennan. Cherished father to Laraine. Father-in-law to Steven and beloved grandfather to Catherine, Tanya and Erin. Formerly of Little Neck, NY, he was born in Limerick, Ireland, and became a U.S. citizen in 1929. A Consolidated Edison employee for 47 years, he was a recipient of a medal from the National Safety Council for meritorious service and a founding member of the original Irish Theater Company that produced Sean O'Casey's plays on the site that is now Lincoln Center. An accomplished artist, a lover of Irish history and a scholar of nature, his gentle spirit and great wisdom will always guide us. We will miss you Pom Pom. For funeral arrangements, contact Jacob Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave., Maplewood, NJ, 973-762-2200.

Venus Williams has beads in her hair that sway when she moves and a statuesque presence that turns heads, even in a city full of arresting art. Martina Hingis has neither an eye-catching coiffure nor an imposing physique, and the only things about her appearance that hint at her profession are the calluses on her right palm.

title: Dominican Drug Traffickers Tighten Grip on the Northeast

He has sold thousands of bags of heroin, worn out countless beepers and become a familiar figure on the streets of Washington Heights and Harlem. Now, he and his Dominican-led gang have dramatically expanded their sales operations, moving well beyond upper Manhattan to deliver Colombian drugs in a territory from Maryland to Massachusetts.

description: Consolidated Edison Inc. is expected to announce today that it will acquire Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. for about $790 million in cash, people close to the talks said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Road to Riches Starts In the Golden Triangle
description: Chauffeured about town in his gleaming white sedan, Lo Hsing-han befits his reputation as one of the most influential businessmen in Myanmar, as Burma is now called.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DEA, BESSIE (NEE MCLAUGHLIN)
description: O'DEA-Bessie (nee McLaughlin) of Westwood, NJ on Saturday, May 9, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Honorable Arthur J. O'Dea. Devoted mother of Anna Morris, Elizabeth Kennedy, Arthur J. O'Dea, Esq., Thomas P. O'Dea, M.D., Maureen Feeney, Joseph J. O'Dea, Esq. and Susan Boland. Dear sister-in-law of Anne O'Dea. Also survived by twenty-eight grandchildren, nine great grandchildren, one niece and one nephew. Funeral from Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, NJ on Tuesday at 10 AM. Funeral Liturgy at St. Andrew R.C. Church, Westwood, NJ at 11 AM. Interment, Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah, NJ. The family will receive their friends on Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: The Plain Hard Truth: Ewing Is No Answer
description: He tipped the ball out. That is what exhausted players do when they can't get position and they want to make sure no one else gets a layup under the basket. They bat the ball away from the rim and pray that their teammates will gather it in with both hands.

title: Tobacco Bill Said to Cost 50% More
description: An analysis of anti-smoking legislation released today by the Senate Republican leadership concludes that the bill before the Senate would cost the tobacco industry more than half again as much over 25 years as the amount estimated by the White House and the measure's chief sponsor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 29 about Kathryn W. Davis's financial support of Russian studies misstated the source of the contributions. They come from the Shelby Cullom Davis Foundation, which she oversees, not from Ms. Davis herself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, HENRIETTA OWENS
description: ROGERS-Henrietta Owens. Age 91. Died peacefully at home on May 9. Devoted wife for 64 years of James G. Rogers. Beloved mother of Patsy Rogers, Kathie McQuarrie and James G. Rogers III. Proud grandmother of Michael, Mollie, Amy, Kate and Jamie. Services will be held at St. Mark's Church, New Canaan, CT, on Wednesday, May 13, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Henrietta O. Rogers Poetry Award, c/o Development Office, Connecticut College, New London, CT 06320.

title: Filmmakers Optimistic On Summer
description: The summer movie season opened this weekend with a catastrophe that delighted Hollywood. ''Deep Impact,'' the disaster film about a colossal comet the size of New York City hurtling to Earth, opened the season with an unexpectedly strong box office.

title: Valentine Is Upbeat Amid the Raindrops
description: Bobby Valentine answered the telephone in his office at Shea Stadium yesterday morning and responded to a friend's question by telling him not to drive to Flushing just yet. The weather forecast was gloomy, the field was a swamp and the doubleheader with the St. Louis Cardinals was likely to be postponed. It was a direct answer.

title: Sumitomo Likely To Pay Big Fine
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission may announce as soon as Monday that the Sumitomo Corporation has agreed to pay a record fine totaling $150 million to settle charges of illegal copper trading, a person close to the situation said.

title: Another Land Mine Retreat
description: The Clinton Administration has already drawn worldwide criticism for its refusal to join an international treaty banning land mines. Now, at the urging of the Pentagon, it seems ready to undo even the modest steps it has taken to reduce American reliance on this crude weapon. The Administration is trying to repeal a one-year moratorium on the use of land mines, due to go into effect next February, that Congress and President Clinton himself endorsed two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, LUBA
description: FELD-Luba. On May 9, 1998. Beloved wife of Sam, loving mother of Michael, and mother-in-law of Linda, dear grandmother of Daniel and Benjamin. Funeral service was held May 10, 1998.

title: Crackdown on Mob Lowers Trash Fees
description: New York City officials say a two-year-old city crackdown on abuses in the garbage industry has resulted in steep price cuts and improved service for large and small customers.

title: In Haiti, Not All Gifts Well Received
description: When Fritz Martial left Haiti in 1969 to immigrate to the United States, his hometown of Tiburon had one elementary school, no hospital and no potable water to serve the town's 50,000 or so residents. Today, Tiburon, a dusty outpost about 100 miles southwest of the capital, Port-au-Prince, boasts of six schools, including two high schools and one of the best irrigation systems in Haiti.

title: Youth Shoots Paraplegic Over $5 Tip, Police Say
description: A paraplegic who drove himself to a Brooklyn hospital with two gunshot wounds yesterday morning told detectives he had been shot by one of three teen-agers who helped him get into his wheelchair, rejected the $5 tip he offered as too little and then robbed him, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, ELISABETH FEIST
description: HIRSCH-Elisabeth Feist. Died quietly on May 8, 1998, in Newtown, PA. Beloved wife of the late Felix E. Hirsch. Loving mother of Roland Felix Hirsch of Germantown, MD, and Thomas Feist Hirsch of Brooklyn, NY. Devoted grandmother of Elizabeth, Daniel, Sallie and Paul. Great-grandmother of Sarah. Born in Mainz, Germany, November 2, 1904, to Samuel Sigmund and Toni Rawicz Feist. Grew up in Berlin. Studied at Marburg and Freiberg. Emigrated to USA 1938. Married in New Haven in 1938. Taught at Bard and Trenton State College. Held Rockefeller and Guggenheim Fellowships. Retired to Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA. Member of Newtown Friends Meeting. Interment there Monday, May 11, at 3 PM. For information contact Swartz/Givnish Funeral Home, 215-968-3891.

title: Long After Dvorak, Perils and Promise of the 'New World'
description: The austere, comforting melody of the Largo movement of Antonin Dvorak's ''New World'' Symphony drew on the spirituals and parlor songs that the Czech composer heard during his residency in the United States. A century later, the theme set Rob Hyman, Rick Chertoff and various collaborators thinking about American roots, immigration and cross-cultural encounters; the result is the ambitious album ''Largo'' (Blue Gorilla/Mercury). In variations and extrapolations of Dvorak's tune, the collaborators came up with homey songs about an America where exploitation and promise are inseparable.

title: Sports of The Times; It's All Gravy; Pacers Steal It Anyway
description: HOUSE playoff money. That's what the Knicks were playing with this weekend, and that's what they lost yesterday to a couple of guys who were practically raised inside Madison Square Garden and another who has the audacity to think of it as home.

title: For the Apollo, Audits and Anger; A Landmark, in Eclipse, Faces Questions About Finances
description: Almost two decades ago, Percy E. Sutton had a vision: he would buy the Apollo Theater, a spiritual home of African-American music whose doors had been shut, fix it up and put on shows like the ones he remembered from his youth, which featured stars like Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan.

title: Is Timbuktu Ready to Go on Line?
description: To the Editor:

title: Onward, Marchers, To Britannia
description: Possibly only someone inordinately fond of every Fifth Avenue parade, by whatever group and for whatever cause, could enjoy every moment of George Balanchine's ''Union Jack,'' which the New York City Ballet presented on Wednesday at the New York State Theater. The first scene of this peculiar three-part tribute to Britain is nothing but a parade for Scottish clans. The last scene begins with a hornpipe, then becomes a parade for the Royal Navy.

title: Ronald Ridenhour, 52, Veteran Who Reported My Lai Massacre
description: Ronald L. Ridenhour, the Vietnam veteran who in 1969 first disclosed the My Lai massacre of Vietnamese civilians by United States Army troops, died yesterday in Metairie, La. He was 52.

title: 'Guess Who's in Town': It's May; Must Be Bobby Short
description: Bobby Short has always shown an uncanny ability to find the right song for the right moment. And in opening his 31st spring season at the Cafe Carlyle, the eternally ebullient singer and pianist gleefully trotted out a 1936 Cole Porter chestnut, ''Rap Tap on Wood,'' that he first recorded 28 years ago. ''When every meal you take/Is made of milk and honey/ When every stock you stake/Is making mints of money,'' the song cautions, then it's time to ''rap-tap on wood.'' What lyric could be more relevant for this season of the booming stock market and soaring sales in Viagra?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYNE, BELLE (NEE SAUNDERS)
description: KAYNE-Belle (nee Saunders). On May 9, 1998, at age 88. Cherished mother of Lisa Kayne Lieberman. Loving grandmother of Rebecca and Charlotte. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on May 11, 1998 at 11:30 AM. The family will receive friends and relatives at the home of Lisa and Jonathan Lieberman from 4 PM on May 11 and from 6 PM on May 12-15. We will miss you and love you always!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENDSEL, PETER DAVID
description: BRENDSEL-Peter David. Age 27. On Wednesday, May 6, at his residence in McLean, VA. Beloved son of Leland C. & Diane Brendsel. Brother of Jon and Michael Brendsel. Grandson of Lars Brendsel & William and LaVerne Christensen. Services held at Vienna Presbyterian Church, 124 Park Street N.E., Vienna, Virginia, on Tuesday, May 12, 11 A.M. Valet parking provided. Interment private. No flowers, please. Contributions may be made to the Peter David Brendsel Fund for Children's Literacy, C/O Freddie Mac, 8200 Jones Branch Drive, McLean, Virginia 22102. Money & King Funeral Home, Vienna, Virginia.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Tuesday in the Footlights column of the Arts section about the opening of the Boston Pops season on Wednesday misidentified a competition won by the piano soloist, Wendy Chen. It was the 1997 Young Concert Artists International Auditions, not the Young Artists Guild Competition.

title: Hearst Magazines Quits Trade Group in a Dispute With Its Longtime Rival, Conde Nast
description: Lest anyone doubt the often cutthroat competitiveness of the magazine industry, witness the latest contretemps between age-old rivals, Hearst Magazines and Conde Nast Publications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERBY, HAROLD
description: SERBY-Harold. On May 9, 1998. Of North Massapequa, LI. Beloved husband of Marcia. Devoted father of Stephen, Mark and Randee, Lori and Dave Stinson, Gary and Roberta. Dear brother of David. Adored grandfather of Gillian, Hadyn, Eric, Stephanie, Andrew and Sam. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Clinton Is Right To Pressure Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAZEROFF, NATHAN
description: GLAZEROFF-Nathan. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Sidney Freedman, President

title: With a Whoosh, Miller's 3 Sends Knicks to Edge of Abyss
description: Reggie Miller, wispy thin but bright as tinsel on the court, had managed to slither free and take his favorite spot in Madison Square Garden. On the fringe of the 3-point arc, in front of Spike Lee.

title: Nissan Is in Talks With Daimler-Benz
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest car maker, confirmed today that it was in discussions with Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany about a potential ''business tie-up'' between Daimler and Nissan's heavy-truck manufacturing unit, the Nissan Diesel Motor Company.

title: Costs Plummet As City Breaks Trash Cartel
description: Jon Hendel manages the Gift Building, an office tower on Fifth Avenue, and for years his bills for garbage removal kept rising until they peaked at $10,000 a month. Now a different trash-collecting company provides the same service for $950 a month.

title: INSIDE
description: Sinn Fein Backs Irish Accord

title: Young & Rubicam Selects Executive
description: Young & Rubicam Advertising named Stephen James Creet executive vice president and chief creative officer in its San Francisco office. Mr. Creet, 41, who reports to Austin McGhie, president and chief executive, succeeds Peter L. Angelos, who left in January to join the new San Francisco office of TBWA Chiat/Day, a unit of Omnicom Group. Mr. Creet previously held a similar post at BBDO Canada in Toronto, also a unit of Omnicom.

title: Tough Stance Urged On Imported Foods
description: Federal investigators are urging the United States to stop importing food from nations that do not meet American health and safety standards. They say the Government has failed to create a system to prevent imported foodborne illnesses. But Federal officials fear that demanding better food-safety systems from other nations could disrupt trade, and have not made that demand.

title: Is Timbuktu Ready to Go on Line?; Missteps on Rwanda
description: To the Editor:

title: City of Angels Is the City of Death for Magazines
description: When Buzz magazine put out its first issue in 1990, seven other city magazines were trying to distill the essence of Los Angeles and find a loyal following. With its focus on hip clothing designers, personalities and inside-Hollywood tales, Buzz outlived nearly all its rivals. But even a booming California economy was not enough to insure that the monthly made money. Buzz filed for bankruptcy-law protection last month.

title: Vatican Diagnosis
description: To the Editor:

title: Baker Hughes Likely to Buy Western Atlas
description: Baker Hughes is close to reaching agreement to buy Western Atlas Inc. for about $5 billion in stock, according to people close to the transaction, giving it services to compete better with bigger oilfield companies.

title: Food Safety in Jeopardy
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Town Buries 90 After Mudslide
description: As bulldozers raked mud for more bodies, 95 carved wooden coffins were lined up in a soccer field today for an outdoor funeral in which rescue workers, wearing orange coats and hygiene masks, acted as pallbearers and mourners in splattered dress shoes sobbed uncontrollably.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENSOHN, WILLIAM LASKER
description: ROSENSOHN-William Lasker. October 19, 1921-May 11, 1995. You'll always be with us. Sam, Marguerite, Dan, Elizabeth

title: Macedonia's Albanians Are Restive
description: At dawn, under spindly Turkish minarets that rose above cobblestone streets, silver-domed shops and cramped bazaar stalls, several hundred sleepy laborers gathered near a bus stop.

title: Court Eases the Requirements for Lawyers Seeking to Practice in New York
description: New York State's highest court announced a plan today to ease some of the rigorous academic requirements for lawyers from other states and nations who want to take the bar exam here.

title: Bellamy Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for the art dealer Richard Bellamy, who died on March 29, will be held on Wednesday at 3 P.M. at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Arts Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens. The speakers will include the artists Richard Serra, James Rosenquist, Mark di Suvero and Alfred Leslie; the critics Barbara Rose and Jill Johnson, and the dealers Ivan Karp and Joan Washburn.

title: People
description: * Guy Chauvel was named chairman and chief executive at J. Walter Thompson France, Paris, part of WPP Group, succeeding Daniel Cole, who left. Mr. Chauvel was previously executive vice president at Klaus Jacobs Holdings, Zurich, which is a Thompson client.

title: Alice Faye, Hollywood Star Who Sang for Her Man, Dies
description: Alice Faye, one of the few movie stars to walk away from stardom at the peak of her career, died Saturday at Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif. She was in her mid-80's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, PATRICIA
description: GORMAN-Patricia. On May 9, 1998, of Sands Point, NY. Beloved wife of Kenneth. Cherished mother of Kathleen and Michael. Mother-in-law of Joseph Macdonell and Maura Gorman. Beloved grandmother of seven grandchildren. Loving daughter of Ellen O'Connor. Past President of Visiting Nurses Association and longtime resident of Manhasset and Sands Point. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, Monday and Tuesday. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Fatima Church, Manor Haven. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the United Network of Organ Sharing, 1100 Boulders Parkway, Suite 500, Richmond, Virginia 23225-8770.

title: Is Timbuktu Ready to Go on Line?
description: To the Editor:

title: Choreography Running in Reverse
description: For contrast, the New York City Ballet presented Jerome Robbins's ''Two- and Three-Part Inventions,'' an intimate work, on the same program with George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3,'' a ballet conceived on an opera-house scale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISS, PAULINE
description: LISS-Pauline. On May 9, 1998. Beloved wife of Ernest. Loving mother of Michael and Marcia. Adoring and adored Bubbie of Daniel, Rachel and one grandchild to be. Dear sister of Goldie Karan. Devoted to daughter-in-law Debbie and son-in-law John. Never was there a finer, more decent person, who will be more greatly missed. In lieu of flowers or contributions, the family asks that an act of kindness be done in her name. For funeral information call 718896-9000.

title: Kinko's Parts Ways With Its Agencies
description: Kinko's Inc. said that it had parted ways with its agencies -- Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland and CPM Media Management, both of Chicago -- on its domestic account and was searching for a new agency with worldwide capabilities. Billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: Support Grows For Faster Modem Speeds
description: Lending international support to an American effort to give consumers high-speed access to cyberspace, the largest foreign telecommunications companies have agreed to join an industry group to work on ways to transmit huge volumes of information over standard telephone wires.

title: There's More to College Than Getting Degrees
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HARRY B.
description: COHEN-Harry B. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted, longtime member and Trustee of our Men's Club and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Judith Schindler, Assoc. Rabbi

title: Mitchell Journal; Farmer Turns Geneticist in Quest for Black Kernel
description: Maybe this will be the summer for black corn. In a barn as clean as a clinic and as richly arrayed as a curio shop, Dean Strand pried the lid off an old plastic bucket labeled ''black by dark red'' and sank his hand into the liver-colored kernels inside.

title: Sinn Fein, Almost Unanimously, Approves Peace Pact
description: In a significant change of its traditional policies, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army, today approved almost unanimously the agreement that is intended to end sectarian warfare in Northern Ireland.

title: Cold Houston Didn't Warm to Final Shot
description: Allan Houston sat in front of his locker, the game over and the interview session done, too. He held a sock in front of him as he sat barefoot, but the simple task of putting it on seemed far from his mind as he stared blankly ahead, motionless, while reporters and players milled around him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, JAMES F.
description: O'CONNOR-James F. Age 69, of Beaver, PA. Formerly of Smithtown, NY. Died peacefully on May 8, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Barbara A. Devoted father of Kathy Baxendell, Robert, Thomas and Stephen O'Connor. Dear brother of Thomas and Noreen. Loving grandfather of Christine, Kellyann, Kyle and Christian. Reposing at the Branch Funeral Home, Inc., 190 East Main St., Smithtown. Funeral Mass St. Patrick's R.C. Church, 11:15 AM, Wednesday. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery. Visiting 7-9:30 Monday, and 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM Tuesday.

title: After Keeping Title, Mosley Wants to Improve His Status
description: Shane Mosley, the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion, said he was ready to step up to the status of Oscar De La Hoya, Roy Jones Jr., Prince Naseem Hamed and Evander Holyfield, which is the pound-for-pound best boxer category. And after his impressive showing against the veteran Juan (John-John) Molina on Saturday night in Atlantic City, it was hard to argue with him.

title: Nine West Names Team for Easy Spirit
description: Nine West Group named the team of Toth Advertising and Design in Concord, Mass., and PGR Media in Providence, R.I., to handle the creative and media portions of its Easy Spirit women's footwear account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million. The account had been handled for five years by Lotas Minard Patton McIver in New York, which handled creative, and Media That Works in Cincinnati, which handled the media.

title: A Prosecutor's Fervor Gains Him Praise and Criticism
description: Through all the murk and melodrama of Whitewater, W. Hickman Ewing Jr., the special prosecutor closest to the Clintons' tracks in Arkansas, has proved himself the quiet bulldog willing to follow his quarry from closed grand jury to open grave.

title: Customer fears and risks have yet to be worked out with airline electronic tickets.
description: WITH its razor-thin profit margins and endless battles for customer loyalty, the $102 billion commercial airline business is one of the few industries that stand to benefit, or to lose, much from a successful transition to electronic commerce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCKSTADER, LEONARD A. II
description: HOCKSTADER-Leonard A. II, age 66, died suddenly on May 8 of acute asthma. He is survived by his wife, Diane Deschamps Hockstader, a son, Lee Hockstader, two daughters, Kalen Hockstader Holliday and Avery Diane Hockstader, a granddaughter, Pierson Holliday and a brother Alan Hockstader. A memorial service will be held at 3:30 PM, Monday, May 18, at Frank E. Campbell, 81st St. and Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the American Lung Association, 1740 Broadway, NY 10023.

title: MediaTalk; Motley Fool to Produce A Weekly Radio Show
description: Who says foolishness doesn't pay?

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 2 about efforts to exonerate the court-martialed captain of the cruiser Indianapolis misstated the ship's route in ferrying the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945. It went to Tinian, not Guam.

title: U.S. Gives Netanyahu a Reprieve On Pullout Decision for 2 Weeks
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel won a two-week reprieve today in the battle over the 13 percent withdrawal from the West Bank that the United States has set as the threshold for resuming peace negotiations with the Palestinians.

title: Financial Scandal Mars Utility's Decorous Past
description: For much of its history, Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. was the definition of an old-fashioned utility company. Serving roughly 275,000 customers in Rockland, half of Orange County, much of northern New Jersey and a sliver of Pennsylvania, the company quietly enjoyed steady profits from a territorial monopoly.

title: Jefferson Smurfit Agrees to Buy Stone Container for $2 Billion
description: The Jefferson Smurfit Corporation, a maker of paper products, has agreed to acquire the Stone Container Corporation for $2 billion in stock to create one of the world's largest manufacturers of paperboard and paper-based packaging products, company executives said yesterday.

title: Clinton Is Right To Pressure Israel; Not a Grave Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Proposal Would Bar Food Exported by Some Nations
description: Federal investigators are calling on the United States to stop importing food from nations that do not meet American health and safety standards. They say the Clinton Administration and Congress have failed to create a system to prevent imported food-borne diseases from sickening and killing people.

title: Adrift in the Global Economy
description: When the heads of state of the top industrial nations hold their annual summit meeting this week in Birmingham, England, one of their most important tasks will be to figure out how to prevent another Asian-type crisis. Unfortunately, they cannot succeed.

title: Meet the Mets, Mayor, It's a Two-Team Town
description: A New York lawyer, a lifetime observer of the New York baseball scene, said yesterday that he recently read about new penalties for jaywalking in the city, a $50 fine or time in jail. He suggested a third alternative.

title: O'Neal Lets His Game Do the Talking in Style
description: Got them all, he said with a cartoon smile. The crossover dribble, the baseline turnaround, the pianist's touch with his left hand and even the all-important eyes-in-the-back-of-his-head, no-look pass. Shaquille O'Neal sat in front of his locker yesterday feinting with his head, striking Earl Monroe poses so violently that the roll around his belly danced, and swore he had them.

title: John Peter, Art Director and War Propagandist, 81
description: John Peter, the New York art director whose poster of a blue rooster with fluttering Allied flags atop the message ''Le Jour Se Leve'' cheered war-weary Parisians after the Liberation in 1944, died on May 1 in Philadelphia on a business trip. He was 81 and had homes in Norwalk, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: New cable services are everywhere, but they all seem to be owned by the same big companies.
description: A LITTLE more than a decade ago, Children's Television Workshop might well have been willing to start a cable programming service on its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, MILTON
description: FOX-Milton. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Nettie (nee Feldman). Devoted father of Allan and Beth Chanin and Lori and Victor Golani. Dear brother of the late Emanuel, Herbert, Jerry and Seymour. Loving grandfather of Craig, Megan and Ilyssa. Services at ''Wien & Wien,'' Englewood, NJ Tuesday, 11 AM.

title: Nike will focus on the soccer and women's sports markets while making cuts in its budget.
description: AFTER reporting a surprising 69 percent plunge in earnings in its fiscal third quarter, Nike Inc., in an effort to regain a firmer footing, is returning to a place where it feels comfortable and in control: its role as the underdog.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on April 28 about potential effects of the euro, the planned common currency for Europe, misstated a study's estimates of its impact on the economies of the United States and Europe. The study, by Richard Portes of the London Business School and Helene Rey of the London School of Economics, said Europe could gain as much as four-tenths of 1 percent of gross domestic product (not half a percentage point of growth), while the United States could lose as much as a quarter of 1 percent of G.D.P. (not half a percentage point of growth).

title: As Their Dominance Erodes, Networks Plan Big Changes
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Top Democrat Issues Threat To Head of House Inquiry
description: All but assuring a partisan showdown in Congress this week, the House Democratic leader threatened today to try to oust the Republican chairman whose committee is investigating campaign finance practices, if he fails to work with Democrats.

title: Abroad at Home; 'I Don't Think It Works'
description: With President Clinton going to China next month, attention is focusing again on the question of how the United States should try to improve the human rights situation there. I raised the question in an interview with the Dalai Lama, who for 40 years has been a pre-eminent symbol of resistance to oppression by the Chinese Communist Government.

title: Bipartisan Support Grows For Managed Care Patients
description: A bipartisan consensus has emerged in Congress on the need for legislation to define and protect the rights of patients and to regulate managed-care companies, which provide health insurance for most Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, REVEREND MONSIGNOR
description: WALSH - Reverend Monsignor James J. Pastor Emeritus, Church of the Immaculate Conception, Irvington, NY, on May 9, 1998. Devoted brother to Helen Williams, Margaret Crimmins, Richard Walsh and the late Mary Chartrand. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visiting Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry; Tuesday at Immaculate Conception Church, 16 N. Broadway, Irvington, from 2 PM. Mass of the Eucharist, Tuesday, 7:30 PM. Mass of the Resurrection, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, New Rochelle. Memorials to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Revealing the Mysteries Of the Born-Again Lover
description: Relax. There's not a single Viagra joke in ''The Truth About Impotence.'' Tomorrow night's ''Nova'' is a straight-faced look at what the doctors call erectile dysfunction, how it gets that way (smokers, beware!) and what urologists have been doing about it for the last 20 years.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actress and singer Alice Faye in some editions yesterday misidentified the source of the song ''You'll Never Know,'' which won an Academy Award in 1944. It was from the film ''Hello, Frisco, Hello,'' not ''Tin Pan Alley.'' The obituary is reprinted today on page A15 for readers who did not receive it.

title: Campaign Reform Illusions
description: The long history of attempts to rid American politics of the corrupting influence of money proves that politicians are infinitely inventive at designing laws that can easily be circumvented. That danger is precisely why lawmakers should now be wary of legislation pushed by a bipartisan group of freshmen, which is gaining support in the House. The bill is less likely to curb the money flowing into the system than to rechannel it. It may be seized by Newt Gingrich and other defenders of the status quo as the means to deflect more effective reform.

title: F.A.A. Grounds Scores of 737's To Check for a Wiring Problem
description: The Federal Aviation Administration grounded scores of old Boeing 737's for inspections today after finding damage to fuel-pump wiring in some planes. Some flights around the nation were canceled, and the agency said it expected delays to persist for several days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENBAUM, MARILYN
description: SCHOENBAUM-Marilyn. Age 56. On Saturday, May 9, 1998, after an 18 year courageous battle with breast cancer. Loving mother of Patti Finkelberg and Tracy Schoenbaum. Beloved companion of Stan Mintz. Cherished daughter of Lillian Cohen. Dear sister of Susan Tolchin. Proud Mema of Sydney. Services 1:30 today, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway (Route 4 West), Fair Lawn, NJ.

title: There's More to College Than Getting Degrees
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWER, LINCOLN
description: BREWER-Lincoln. Age 93. On May 8, 1998. Loving husband of Juanita Brewer. Devoted uncle of Marguerite Smith. Family will receive friends on Tuesday, May 12 from 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 St., Bronx. Religious service at funeral home chapel on Wednesday, May 13 at 10:30 AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Patents; A device to scan the cards in a dealer's hand in hopes of providing a fairer game of blackjack.
description: WITH so much money changing hands at casinos, cheating can be a big temptation. An unscrupulous blackjack dealer, for example, might tip off his hand to a confederate by scratching his left ear or placing a card slightly askew.

title: Recalcitrant Barnaby Gets On the Sabres' Bus
description: At the beginning of the season, Matthew Barnaby of the Buffalo Sabres threatened to knock over his own goalie in practice. It didn't matter that the goalie, Dominik Hasek, was the most valuable player in the National Hockey League last season and might be again this season. Barnaby is an emotional young man and he was angry.

title: Imaginary Jazz Encounters The Real Thing
description: Stravinsky's ''Histoire du Soldat'' is not the modest theater piece it first appears to be. Its newness, or better its anti-oldness, encapsulates more or less everything 20th-century composers have ever tried to do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELB, SARAH
description: GELB-Sarah. On May 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Judy Gelb Vogel and Hal Gelb. Adoring grandmother of Michael S. Vogel and Reilly Joseph Gelb and great-grandmother of Edward Arthur Kenney Vogel and Charles Taft Vogel Kenney. Dear sister of Tema Nason and mother-in-law of Howard Vogel and Pat Gelb. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday, May 12, 11:30 AM.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: 2 BELL COMPANIES ARE SET TO REJOIN IN $60 BILLION DEAL
description: SBC Communciations Inc., the West's dominant local telephone company, is expected to announce today that it is acquiring the Ameritech Corporation for about $60 billion in stock, people close to the talks said. The deal would recreate much of the old Bell system.

title: The Preschool Mess
description: The New York State Legislature passed a law last year directing school districts to make pre-kindergarten classes available to all 4-year-olds within four years. But carrying out that goal is proving to be difficult for New York City.

title: Con Ed to Acquire Utility
description: Consolidated Edison is expected to announce that it is acquiring Orange and Rockland Utilities of Pearl River, N.Y. Con Edison will pay about $790 million in cash. Page B1.

title: Digital Culture Pioneer Sold to Conde Nast
description: In a slap-happy measure of Wired magazine's five-year roller coaster ride, staff members took to greeting one another on Friday with a variation of America Online's goofy ''you've got mail'' audio clip: ''You've been sold!'' they informed each other, and indeed they had.

title: Ravens Still a Franchise Under Construction
description: Welcome to the Baltimore Ravens' spiffy, new 68,000-plus-seat stadium next door to Camden Yards, the Baltimore Orioles' home. Construction on the Ravens' new building is nearly complete and will be ready for the start of the 1998 National Football League season in September.

title: Accounts
description: * Cushman & Wakefield Inc., New York, to Gillespie, Princeton, N.J., to handle advertising for the international real estate company, which was previously handled in house. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: American Publishers Add Readers in Booming Latin America
description: In this languid beachfront city, home to Latin America's oldest newspaper, newsstands are suddenly filling with glossy upstarts -- Selecoes, a new Brazilian edition of Reader's Digest, and newspaper supplements of Time and Fortune in Portuguese.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief sports article on Tuesday about the Don King fraud trial misidentified the boxing title for which Buster Douglas and Lou Savarese will fight on June 25. It is the International Boxing Association heavyweight crown, not the International Boxing Federation title.

title: Eye Catching: How New Media Are Racing to Become the Mass Media; The Search Services Want Your Eyes to Find No Reason to Wander
description: Seek and ye shall find?

title: TV Listings Stir Windows 98 Dispute
description: Buyers of new personal computers equipped with Windows 98, Microsoft's updated operating system, are to get something thrown in free of charge: an electronic program guide that tells what is on television.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Ongoing Revival of Oscar Wilde
description: ''How narrow, and mean, and inadequate to its burdens is this century of ours,'' wrote Oscar Wilde in prison, referring to the century that closed in 1900 with his death at 46. He meant, among other things, that his era was quick to reward success -- to give it ''its palace of porphyry'' is the way he put it -- but made no provision at all for what he called ''Sorrow and Shame.'' Wilde's own life proved what he was saying. That is one reason that in New York at this moment you can see three dramatic portraits of Oscar Wilde -- the new film, called ''Wilde,'' starring Stephen Fry; the play by David Hare called ''The Judas Kiss,'' starring Liam Neeson, and the Off Broadway play, called ''Gross Indecency,'' by Moises Kaufman.

title: Mendoza-Milton Matchup Makes Deal Look Even Better
description: Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager, did not participate directly in the trade talks for Chuck Knoblauch in February. Isolated from the group doing the actual haggling, Torre sat by and waited until someone solicited his opinion, late in the negotiations.

title: No Escape From 'News'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMETT, PHILIP M.
description: HAMMETT-Philip M. Esq. On May 5, 1998, of Philadelphia, age 77; beloved husband of Mary Jane Hammett, father of Theodore M. and Peggy Hammett, Janet Hammett Pratt and Nan Hammett, stepfather of John, Robert, Thomas and Christopher Palmer, Susan Palmer Austin, Catherine Roy, Virginia Beaulac and Charles K McManus; also survived by four grandchildren, 11 step grandchildren, and one sister Jane Zwemer. Memorial Service to be held on Saturday May 16, at 1 P.M. from The Racquet Club of Philadelphia, 215 South 16th St, Philadelphia. Memorial contributions made in his name to Pennsylvania Hospital, 8th and Spruce Sts, Philadelphia, PA. 19107, would be appreciated. (Oliver H. Bair Co.)

title: Though Illegal, Child Marriage Is Popular in Part of India
description: If a wedding is supposed to fulfill a girl's earliest dreams, Hansa's in this tiny hamlet in Rajasthan State seemed more like a nightmare.

title: Tobacco Company Subject of Investigation, Officials Say
description: Justice Department prosecutors have notified the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation and several of its officials that they are subjects of the Government's investigation into fraud by cigarette makers and could be prosecuted, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Milken Group Enlists TCI In Bidding
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television operator, has joined a consortium that includes a company controlled in part by Michael R. Milken to bid for Viacom's Simon & Schuster publishing house, a person close to the bidding said yesterday.

title: Chastened by Loss, Jeb Bush Looks Unbeatable in Florida
description: Leaning into the microphone before a rapt audience of about 125 people, Jeb Bush related how he went through a midlife crisis after losing the Florida governor's race in 1994 and emerged a better man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIVIERI, NOEL L.
description: OLIVIERI-Noel L., 49. Of Bloomfield, Conn. Husband of Judy (Brown) Olivieri. Died on Friday, May 8, at McLean Home, Simsbury after a courageous battle with brain cancer. Founder and President of Olivieri Communication, Inc. of Windsor Ct, a marketing services firm which specialized in serving the plastics industry for 22 years. The agency attracted national and international accounts active in every facet of the industry from injection molding machines to training programs for plastics professionals. He was also involved in the flexible packaging industry. Noel was a U.S. Coast Guard Charter Captain and an avid sport fisherman as captain of the fishing vessel ''Vixen,'' docked in Noank, Ct. Besides his wife, Judy, he leaves his mother, Palma (Barraco) Olivieri of Roxbury, Ct, his father, Ernest Olivieri of Baja, Ca., two daughters, Lora April and Lisa Noelle, and three brothers. A memorial services will be held Wednesday, May 20, at the Mystic Shipyard, Essex Street, West Mystic, at 3 P.M. His family will receive friends following the service. Donations may be made to St. Francis Hospital Cancer Center, 114 Woodland St., Hartford, CT., or the McLean Home, 75 Great Pond Road, Simsbury, CT., which will be used for perennial plants, trees and flowers. For more information Carmon Windsor Funeral Home, Windsor, CT.

title: Fake Bomb Threat Empties All Schools in Syracuse Area
description: A bomb threat disrupted classes for tens of thousands of students in and around Syracuse yesterday, three days after a similar hoax closed schools in neighboring Oswego County.

title: Magazine Dismisses Writer Accused of Hoax
description: It was an editor at Forbes magazine's Web site who first got suspicious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, GERALD F.
description: BOYLE-Gerald F., Br. Beloved brother of Catherine, Lillian and Rosella. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at MurrayWeigel Hall at 515 East Fordham Rd. Visitation Wednesday, 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Thursday 11:30AM. For information contact Farenga Brothers Inc. Directors

title: Combining the Muscular And the Analytical
description: Krystian Zimerman, pianist

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARLUCK, NORMAN
description: ARLUCK-Norman. Died May 11, 1998 at the age of 93. Peacefully, at home, in Spring Valley, N.Y. Beloved father of Heather and Richard. Grandfather of Lisa, David, Jonathan, Michael and Jessica. Great-grandfather of Eric.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day yesterday about an offering by Protosource misstated the size of the offering and the name of the underwriter. The company is offering 1.05 million units, not 900,000, and the underwriter is Andrew, Alexander, Wise & Company, not Andrew Alexander.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMPHILL, HERBERT WAIDE., JR.
description: HEMPHILL-Herbert Waide., Jr. We mourn the passing of a very special person, Herbert Waide Hemphill, Jr., beloved son of the late Emma Bryan Bradley Hemphill and the late Herbert Waide Hemphill, Sr. Born in Atlantic City, NJ, January 21, 1929, died in New York City, NY, May 8, 1998. Curator and collector of American Folk Art of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries, his insights contributed greatly to the growing awareness of art ''of the people, by the people, for the people.'' A memorial tribute will be held at a future date.

title: Amid Big Losses, Sunbeam Plans To Cut 6,400 Jobs and 8 Plants
description: The Sunbeam Corporation stunned employees yesterday by announcing a plan to eliminate 6,400 jobs, or 40 percent of its work force, and to close 8 of 24 plants to help absorb 3 businesses it recently acquired.

title: U.S. Carriers in Deal With Air China
description: Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines are expected to announce a partnership today with Air China, China's biggest airline. The deal would allow the carriers to combine frequent-flier programs and share passengers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKEL, DOROTHY
description: HECKEL-Dorothy. Age 74. Of Milford, NJ. Died Friday, May 8, 1998. Married to the late Albert A. Born in NYC. Retired bookkeeper for G.H.K. Assoc. of New York City. Funeral services private. Memorial to National Multiple Sclerosis Society, Mid-Jersey Chapter. For more information, contact Martin F.H., Clinton, New Jersey 08809.

title: Adventures In Life As a Blues Traveler
description: At the first of three sold-out shows at the Beacon Theater on Friday night, Bonnie Raitt responded to her role as a 40-something role model with a wink and a sneer. ''Maturity is so cool, isn't it?'' the guitarist and singer scoffed before breaking into ''Spit of Love,'' a green-hearted declaration of romantic pain from her latest album, ''Fundamental.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EREZ, VARDENA
description: EREZ-Vardena. 1939-1998. Died suddenly in Tel-Aviv, Israel. Beloved friend of many years. She will be sorely missed. The Sanders Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, ADELE (NEE ROTHKRUG)
description: ALPERT-Adele (nee Rothkrug). Beloved aunt. The Rothkrug Family

title: Cicero Journal; In a Town of Scandal, Yet One More
description: Over the years, this old town of brick bungalows on Chicago's western edge has been famous as the headquarters for Al Capone, as a haven of strip clubs and after-hours taverns, as a place where blacks, if they valued their safety, steered clear.

title: New Jersey Prep Star Enters Draft
description: The New Jersey high school basketball star Al Harrington will skip college and enter next month's National Basketball Association draft.

title: Vexed, Mexico Deports 40 in Italian Rights Group
description: The Government deported 40 members of a delegation of Italians at dawn today after they had clashed repeatedly with the authorities during a weeklong tour through conflict-torn villages in the state of Chiapas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFEY, JOSEPH E.
description: DUFFEY-Joseph E. Of Short Hills, NJ on Sunday, May 10, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Mary K. Zimmerman Duffey. Devoted father of Margaret Carpenter; Joan Duffey Good and Kathleen E. Seidel. Also survived by 8 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home 2122 Millburn Avenue, Maplewood, N.J., on Wednesday, May 13 at 9 A.M., thence to St. Rose of Lima Church, Short Hills where a Funeral Mass will be offered at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover. Visiting hours Tuesday, 7-9 P.M. only. In lieu of flowers contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Giuliani Asks City to Extend Rights to Unmarried Couples
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed legislation yesterday that would require the city's government to treat unmarried couples the same as those who are married, allowing them to continue as tenants in apartments leased to their partners and insuring their rights to be buried together in a city-owned cemetery.

title: TESTS BRING A SHARP OUTCRY
description: Nearly 24 years after it detonated its only nuclear explosion, India conducted three underground nuclear tests today at a site in the country's northwestern desert. The move appeared to signal India's determination to abandon decades of ambiguity in favor of openly declaring that it has nuclear weapons.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the art collector Natasha Gelman on Wednesday referred incorrectly to her native region. Her birthplace, Prostejov, is in Moravia, not Bohemia. At her birth, around 1911, the region was part of Austria-Hungary, and it is now in the Czech Republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFFER, BEA
description: SHAFFER-Bea. Died, as she lived, peacefully and at peace, at ninetythree, on May 1, 1998 in West Palm Beach where she & her late and beloved husband, Joe, had lived happily since 1969. Daughter of the late Sarah and Paul Leibowitz, sister of the late Ruth White, she took great joy and pride in her sons, Jerry and Larry, grandchildren, Diana, David, Greg, Adam, and Deena, and in her greatgrandchildren, Rebecca, Megan and Mellissa. She was loved, admired, and an inspiration to all. Who will worry about us now?

title: Colony Capital Raises $1 Billion
description: Colony Capital Inc. said today that it had raised $1 billion for a new real estate investment fund, the latest in a string of funds formed in recent months to take advantage of a hot property market.

title: Recalling The Lost Generation
description: Twenty years ago, Rick Davis was one of the most recognized and highly touted American-born soccer players. He and a handful of other good American players were members of the Cosmos, the storied New York franchise of the defunct North American Soccer League. They were Yanks playing a foreign game among a constellation of international stars.

title: Monsanto to Acquire 2 Seed Companies
description: The Monsanto Company announced deals today valued at about $4.4 billion that would give it control of the DeKalb Genetics Corporation and the Delta and Pine Land Company, two seed companies that had been its partners in creating genetically modified crops.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: The Yankees Can Learn to Share; Costs of Astroturf
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Building Official Is Accused of Misconduct
description: A former official of the State Treasury Department was charged yesterday with accepting $20,000 worth of landscaping and plumbing services from two contractors in exchange for helping them obtain construction business with the state.

title: What's New in Concert Halls? A Taste for the Old
description: If the Bauhaus and the modernist architecture that ensued had never happened, Edward P. Bass said as he gestured out from the mezzanine over an entrance foyer graced with pilasters, fluted columns and a frescoed dome, ''This is what you would get.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HYDER P.L.C., Brecon, Wales, sold its 6 percent stake in NTL Inc., New York, an operator of cable and telephone systems, for $71 million. The buyer's name was not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRIGLER, MORDECHAI
description: STRIGLER-Mordechai. A powerful voice has been stilled. The readers, publishers, editors, writers and staff of The Forward Newspapers mourn the death of Mordechai Strigler, editor of our Yiddish edition. Educated in one of the great yeshivas of pre-war Poland, he survived torment and slaughter and found the words not only to describe what he had seen, but then also to write of Yidishkayt and of Israel. He was among the most prolific writers of his generation, spanning increasingly disparate worlds in his erudition and his creativity. A gentle soul to his colleagues, he was respected for his knowledge, lucidity and craftsmanship. May his wife Esther and daughter Leah be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Zol di erd im gring zayn. The Forward Assocation Barnett Zumoff, M.D. President Samuel Norich General Manager

title: Insignia to Buy Brokerage
description: Insignia Financial Group Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Hotel Partners, a privately held brokerage firm that focuses on the hospitality segment of the real estate industry. Term were not disclosed. Insignia, based here, is a commercial real estate service company, offering brokerage, consulting, investment sales, debt placement and property management services. It had revenue of $400.8 million in 1997. Hotel Partners, of Chicago, will operate as a unit of Insignia/ESG Hotel Partners Inc., a commercial real estate subsidiary of Insignia Financial.

title: Ruling Party in Paraguay Maintains Its Long Grip on Presidency
description: Overcoming bitter divisions within its own ranks, the Colorado Party appeared today to have swept presidential elections here on Sunday, defeating a coalition of opposition parties to maintain its half-century-long hold on power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLAHAN, WILLIAM, JR.
description: HOLAHAN-William, Jr. Formerly of Norwood, N.J. and Boca Raton FL., 84. Died quietly, with dignity on May 10, 1998. Deeply loved; greatly missed; in our hearts forever. Services on June 2, at Grace Church, Amherst, Mass. Donations in his memory may be made to: Pathfinder Village, RR 1, Box 32A, Edmeston NY 13335-9798.

title: Rookie Aims to Deliver for Liberty
description: If the New York Liberty learned one lesson from its loss to the Houston Comets in the Women's National Basketball Association championship game, it was that the team needed a stronger presence in the paint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCUS, JULES
description: PINCUS-Jules. We are saddened by the death of the dynamic Chairman of our San Diego Chapter. Our sincerest condolences to Teddie and his family. America-Israel Cultural Foundation Vera Stern, President Kathleen Ron, Executive Director

title: A Symphony by Dukas, Almost as Remembered
description: New York Philharmonic

title: For Long-Term AT&T Investors Stock Has Skyrocketed Since '84
description: AT&T Corporation investors who have held their shares since the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company have earned returns of 1,128 percent.

title: PHYMATRIX TO EXPLORE STRATEGIC ALTERNATIVES
description: The Phymatrix Corporation, a medical management company based in West Palm Beach, Fla., intends to explore strategic alternatives for the company, including the possibilities of merging, selling assets or entering other business combinations. Dr. Abraham D. Gosman, the company's chairman and chief executive, said, ''We strongly believe that the market has not adequately valued our company, and we intend to explore a variety of transactions that may enhance shareholder value.'' The company cautioned, however, that it was possible that no action would be taken. Phymatrix's stock was unchanged yesterday at $10, giving the company a current market capitalization of about $330 million.

title: Adhering to a Justice's Spirit, Not Footsteps
description: IN 1995, when Justice William J. Brennan Jr. agreed to lend his name to the Brennan Center for Justice, the public-interest law center at New York University, he extracted a promise from E. Joshua Rosenkranz and the other former law clerks and friends who founded it.

title: TELEPHONE GIANT: THE INDUSTRY -- Giving Old Ma Bell New Lease on Life; More New Math: Promoting Competition by Addition, Not Division
description: Fourteen years after the Government forced the breakup of the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company -- a policy step taken to promote competition and consumer choice -- much of the old Bell System is being put together again.

title: Checks of 737's Show More Damaged Wiring
description: Half of the 96 Boeing 737's inspected by tonight under an emergency order grounding the oldest models showed some degree of wear in the fuel-pump wiring, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Albright Gets New Mission: Patch Rift With Israel
description: Risking more signs of friction in his Mideast policy, President Clinton today ordered Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to meet here on Wednesday with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to resolve the latest impasse in the peace talks.

title: AMERICAN INDUSTRIAL EXPANDS PROPERTY HOLDINGS
description: American Industrial Properties said yesterday that it had bought six light-industrial and low-rise office properties and two parcels of land for about $43.5 million, expanding its holdings in the United States Southwest. The properties, which contain about 537,000 square feet and are about 98 percent occupied, are in Austin, Tex.; Phoenix and Tucson, Ariz.; Albuquerque, N.M., and Colorado Springs. The real estate trust, based in Irving, Tex., has increased its real estate assets in the last nine months from $70 million to about $330 million.

title: After 12 Sodden Days, the Rain Should Slacken, and the Sun Is Due to Return Tomorrow
description: After nearly two weeks of dampness, drizzle and downpours, forecasters predicted yesterday that the metropolitan region would finally begin to get some better weather today. But throughout the region, homeowners and businesses continued to grapple with the unceasing rain, particularly in New Jersey communities where flooding has long been a problem.

title: Watch Out for Those Newts: They're a Threat to the World
description: A great satirical fantasy came to life on Friday night when Stephan Koplowitz and Company staged its adaptation of Karel Capek's ''War With the Newts'' at Dance Theater Workshop.

title: Calpers Wants a Separate E.D.S. Chairman
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's largest public pension fund, appealed to other shareholders of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation in a letter today to strip Lester Alberthal of the chairman's job at the lagging computer-services company.

title: By Design; It's Easy Being Green
description: Even men who live in gray and blue most of the time get a little adventurous with color in their summer clothes. This season, the color of choice is green in shades like sage, celadon and lime.

title: Does Nothing Matter If Nothing Ends?
description: THE T-shirt is more than 20 years old and stained with paint, but it's a hand-me-down that still fits the youngest child, who wears it around the house sometimes.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a joint performance at Alice Tully Hall by the Chamber Music Society and Jazz at Lincoln Center on Friday night misspelled the given name of the trumpet soloist. He is Wynton Marsalis, not Winton.

title: Sunbeam Shopping And Consolidating
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said yesterday that it was searching for an agency to handle its worldwide consolidated advertising and promotional account, with billings estimated at $160 million. The majority of the account has been handled by the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, which creates campaigns for Sunbeam and Oster home appliances.

title: Rhapsody's Out, OS X In, in Shift Of Gear at Apple
description: Continuing to gamble big in his efforts to resurrect Apple Computer Inc., Steven P. Jobs, the company's interim chief executive, today effectively killed the Rhapsody operating system, which Apple acquired when it bought Mr. Jobs's company Next Software Inc. for $425 million in 1997.

title: The Reno Paradox
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to request an independent counsel to investigate influence-peddling and illegal fund-raising allegations against Labor Secretary Alexis Herman is consistent with the letter and spirit of the Independent Counsel Act, and carefully worded so as not to prejudge Ms. Herman's culpability. We only wish Ms. Reno's sensitivity to conflicts of interest and her clarity in interpreting her duty under the act extended to the broader and more important matter of the 1996 Presidential fund-raising scandals.

title: Engineers Plan to Send a River Flowing Back to Nature
description: FOR nearly four decades, levees lining 23 miles of the Snake River here have held high spring runoff from the Teton Mountains in check, allowing lavish homes to blossom amid cottonwood forests in the river's flood plain.

title: Fine-Tuning Appeal For a Certain Audience
description: Projekct Two

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MILTON
description: COHEN-Milton, 91. Of Lawrence, N.Y. On May 7, 1998, of heart failure. He was former Associate Director of Brookdale Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MOSES
description: KAPLAN-Moses. On May 10, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Eva. Devoted Father of Jerry and Rhoda Kaplan and Lorraine Perdeck. Cherished grandfather of Dr. Martin and Perla Perdeck, Dr. Lee and Lana Perdeck, Sharon and Stanley Perlman and Jill and Jeffrey Jonas. Adored great grandfather of Robin, Jessica, Danny, Linsey, Jay and Adam. Service today, 11 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, (corner 66th Avenue)

title: Irish Accord Proves To Be Trickier Sale Than First Imagined
description: In designing a logo for the campaign here to approve the peace accord for Northern Ireland, the London advertising agency of Saatchi & Saatchi proposed three options: a dove, an olive branch, or children. The logo was to be accompanied by a stark reminder of the harrowing violence that overwhelmed Ulster for years: photographs of unruly mobs and bombed buildings.

title: Patterns
description: An Oudejans Surprise

title: Q&A
description: Mighty Mites

title: Tobacco Smugglers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGHTER, SARAH WILLIAMS
description: RIGHTER-Sarah Williams. Age 90, May 9, 1998. Of Bedford Hills, NY. Beloved wife for 67 years of Volney F. Righter. Mother of James and Robert. Also survived by two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Funeral service on Wednesday, May 13, at 3PM at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, NY. Interment St. Matthew's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22, Katonah, NY 10536, 914-232-9555.

title: Jury Selection Is Delayed In Long Island Beating
description: A judge heard arguments yesterday on a prosecution request to merge the retrial of man accused in a racially charged beating in Westhampton Beach with the trial of a former New York City police officer who is accused in the case.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are surprised at the naivete of the Western world, and also of the United States, that they did not take the cautionary signals that we were flashing to them. I think they could have restrained India.''

title: GREATER BAY BANCORP ACQUIRES PACIFIC RIM BANCORP
description: Greater Bay Bancorp said yesterday that it had acquired Pacific Rim Bancorp, the holding company for San Francisco's Golden Gate Bank, for $30.9 million in stock. Greater Bay, a bank holding company, said that Pacific Rim's sole shareholder would receive about 950,000 of its shares in the merger. The combined company will have total assets of $1.3 billion and equity of about $80 million. Greater Bay, based in Palo Alto, Calif., had total assets of $1.09 billion in 1997.

title: Judge Approves City's Foster Care Efforts
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled yesterday that New York City's child welfare agency had made diligent efforts to resolve a severe bed shortage that had left more than 2,000 foster children sleeping in city offices over the last year.

title: VIAD INCREASES OFFER FOR MONEYGRAM PAYMENT SYSTEMS
