description: The Viad Corporation sweetened its offer for Moneygram Payment Systems Inc. by about 2 percent a share, to $17.35 from $17, stepping up efforts to add Moneygram's wire-transfer services to its money order and electronic bill-payment businesses. Viad, through its Travelers Express Unit, is the largest United States processor of money orders. After Viad offered $17 a share for Moneygram in April, shareholders with stakes totaling at least 40 percent refused to tender their shares in the company, a wire-transfer services concern spun off by American Express in 1988. Some filed a lawsuit to prevent the takeover. The transaction value remains about $287 million because there are fewer Moneygram shares outstanding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCKSTADER, LEONARD A. II
description: HOCKSTADER-Leonard A. II. The Board of Trustees of the Fred L. Lavanburg Foundation is deeply saddened by the death of our colleague and descendant of our Founder. Leonard A. Hockstader II brought compassion to the Foundation's focus on Public Housing and served as a Trustee for more than 35 years. We will miss him and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Diane and his children and his brother. Oscar S. Strauss II President

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK WEAKENS. Germany's currency fell for a third day on news of benign inflation there, diminishing the possibility that the Bundesbank would soon raise interest rates. In New York, the dollar rose to 1.7766 marks from 1.7701.

title: A Child Disappears: What's the Real Story?
description: FREEDOMLAND

title: Two West Point Cadets Have Marriage Annulled to Avoid Expulsion
description: Two West Point Military Academy cadets who secretly wed in violation of academy regulations avoided expulsion by having their marriage annulled, academy officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRAVER, RICHARD
description: KRAVER-Richard. November 27, 1946-May 12, 1997. You are greatly missed but in many ways still with us. Roberta and Jerry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATZER, R. KIRK.
description: BATZER-R. Kirk. On Saturday, May 9, 1998. Age 82. Of Summit, NJ. Husband of the late Marjorie White Batzer. Father of John L. & Kirk W. Batzer, Reverend Barbara B. Rivers, Mrs. Susan M. Reyes & Laura M. Batzer. Also survived by 7 grandchildren. Family & friends are invited to attend religious services on Thursday, May 14, at 10 AM at Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Avenue, Summit, NJ. Visitation Wednesday from 7-9 PM at the Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Avenue, corner of Morris Ave., Summit, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the World Foundation for Girl Guides and Girl Scouts, Inc., 420 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10018-2798.

title: Ray Noble, New York Giants Catcher, 79
description: Ray Noble, a catcher on the New York Giants team that staged a memorable comeback to overtake the Brooklyn Dodgers for the 1951 National League pennant, died on Saturday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He lived in Brooklyn and was 79.

title: Demand Is Still High for Impotence Pill
description: Americans are still rushing to get Viagra, Pfizer's new impotence pill, but the market has already begun to change, according to I.M.S. Health, a health care information company.

title: For Those Between-the-Weekends Days of Summer
description: Summer is supposed to be a time of easy clothes encounters, just T-shirts, shorts, khakis, sundresses and swimsuits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTAWAY, ALAN
description: WESTAWAY-Alan, 75. Died on Monday, May 11, at his home in Riverdale. He is survived by his wife Evelyn. Dear brother of Bryan and Hugh, who reside in England. Cherished father to daughter Patricia and son Paul and daughter-in-law Priscilla. Beloved grandfather to Kristen. Memorial service will be announced shortly. Contributions may be made to Cancer Research Institute, 681 Fifth Ave., New York City 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKMORE, CLARA
description: ROCKMORE-Clara. On May 10, 1998, at the age of 88. Violin protege of Leopold Auer, pre-eminent virtuoso of the Theremin, now reunited with her pianist sister, Nadia Reisenberg. Mourned by her other beloved sister, Anna Sherman, her nephews Alexander, Robert and Ron, their children and the family of her late husband, Robert Rockmore. Services on Wednesday, May 13, 12 noon at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Rain Helps Collapse Roof of Queens Day-Care Center
description: Recent heavy rain contributed to a roof collapse at a day-care center and preschool in Queens early yesterday, about five hours before 65 children, many of them developmentally disabled, would have streamed through the door for the day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, EILEEN M.
description: CLARKE-Eileen M. On May 8, 1998 of Garden City. Beloved wife of the late Frank Clarke. Loving mother of Frank Clarke, Margaret Clavin and Marilyn Clarke. Cherished grandmother of seven grandchildren and eighteen greatgrandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, 2-5 and 7-9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, 11 AM, Thursday. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Jammin' for France: The Reggae Boyz on Tour
description: On the way to its first World Cup, Jamaica has literally decided to see the world. What began as a buildup to soccer's world championship has become a travelogue that may be great for frequent-flyer miles but might ultimately prove as exhausting to the players' legs as it is disruptive to their body clocks.

title: NBC's Thomas Learns From Rookie Season
description: John Madden's first contract with CBS guaranteed him $12,000 for working as an analyst on four obscure National Football League games.

title: Metro Business; Executive Gets Prison Term
description: A defense contractor from Paterson, N.J., was sentenced yesterday to three months in Federal prison and three months of house arrest for trying to block an investigation into charges that he sold defective parts to the Navy, Federal prosecutors said.

title: The Yankees Can Learn to Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Slow Response on Police Misconduct
description: The weakness of the New York City Police Department's internal system for investigating and punishing misconduct by police officers is an established fact. Apparently the department's difficulties are not limited to cases of brutality against citizens. The saga of John Wrynn, a 33-year-old detective, reported last week in The Times by David Kocieniewski, suggests that it extends even to cases where the alleged misconduct jeopardizes the lives of fellow officers.

title: At Last, Payton Is Activated
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine decided a few hours before tonight's game with the Padres that he would wait another one or two days to activate outfielder Bernard Gilkey from the disabled list. So Jay Payton was eligible to play in his first major league game.

title: Surging Up the Ratings List, Shirov Takes Over as No. 4
description: The player who made the greatest leap forward in the first quarter of 1998 is Alexei Shirov, a 25-year-old former Latvian grandmaster who moved to Spain. He captured second place in the Linares Supertournament in Spain behind Viswanathan Anand and then shared first place in the Melody Amber Quickplay Tournament in Monaco with Vladimir Kramnik. He thus leapfrogged Vladimir Ivanchuk, Veselin Topalov and Anatoly Karpov to reach fourth place in the International Chess Federation rankings behind Kasparov, Kramnik and Anand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, HENRY
description: FINKELSTEIN-Henry. On May 10, 1998. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Shirley (Nee Weissman) for 44 years. Loving and proud father of Bill and dear father-in-law of Lisa. Cherished brother of Albert and the late June Neiman and devoted Uncle of Sandy Neiman, Lowell and Stuart Finkelstein. Dedicated and zealous President of the Senior Adult Program of the 92nd Street ''Y''. Proud World War II Veteran of The 69th Depot Repair Squadron of the 14th Army Air Force-The Flying Tigers. Visitation Tuesday, May 12 from 6PM to 9PM at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street. Services at 9:30AM on Wednesday, May 13. in lieu of flowers, please send donations in Henry's memory to The ''YMHA Senior Adult Program'' at the 92nd Street YMHA, C/O Senior Adult Program, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10128.

title: Shuttle Diplomacy Leads to New Corporate Marriage
description: SBC Communications Inc.'s agreement to buy the Ameritech Corporation in a $62 billion stock swap got its start over dinner in a St. Louis restaurant in early March.

title: A Cold Fact: High Stress Can Make You Sick
description: EXPLANATIONS of why people catch colds are almost as numerous as the viruses that cause colds. They range from the environmental -- living with small children, riding the subway at rush hour, getting chilled to the bone -- to the personal -- smoking too much, exercising too little, sleeping poorly, eating erratically, working too hard.

title: Moody's Cuts Ratings On South Korean Banks
description: The cost of borrowing for South Korea's three state-owned banks rose about 15 basis points yesterday as Moody's Investors Service Inc. lowered their ratings, already at the junk-bond level, because of a deepening recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, MAURICE ANTHONY
description: BRENNAN - Maurice Anthony. Passed away peacefully on May 9, 1998, at 91. Beloved husband of the late Emily Humphrey Brennan. Cherished father to Laraine. Father-in-law to Steven and beloved grandfather to Catherine, Tanya and Erin. Formerly of Little Neck, NY, he was born in Limerick, Ireland, and became a U.S. citizen in 1929. A Consolidated Edison employee for 47 years, he was a recipient of a medal from the National Safety Council for meritorious service and a founding member of the original Irish Theater Company that produced Sean O'Casey's plays on the site that is now Lincoln Center. An accomplished artist, a lover of Irish history and a scholar of nature, his gentle spirit and great wisdom will always guide us. We will miss you Pom Pom. For funeral arrangements, contact Jacob Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave., Maplewood, NJ, 973-762-2200.

title: Prison Folds Up Tents For Processing Inmates
description: A dozen Army-style tents that served as temporary housing for inmates at the crowded Bayside State Prison for nine years will be dismantled this week, the State Department of Corrections announced yesterday.

title: Scientist at Work: Edward O. Wilson; From Ants to Ethics: A Biologist Dreams Of Unity of Knowledge
description: LAID out on a desk in Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology is a neat array of white-sided boxes, each with pinned specimens of ants belonging to the genus Pheidole. Dr. Edward O. Wilson is writing a monograph on the genus, which is the world's largest. There are 326 new species, many of which he discovered himself, and each is in need of a precise description and a scientific name. The work is pure taxonomy, ''scientific knitting,'' he calls it. The ants, little black specks mounted on white triangles of cardboard, seem perfectly indistinguishable. But under the microscope each species looks as different as a bear does from a tiger, Dr. Wilson assures a visitor.

title: Treasuries Slip With a Big Supply of Debt Coming to Market
description: Treasury prices ended lower in light trading, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury above 6 percent, as the market braced for about $33 billion in new debt this week.

title: Jose Pena Gomez, 61, Rare Black Dominican Figure, Dies
description: Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, a three-time candidate for President of the Dominican Republic who rose from a childhood of extreme poverty to become one of the most prominent black political figures in Latin America, died on Sunday night at his home outside Santo Domingo. He was 61.

title: Republicans Target Public Aid Funds to Pay for Highway Bill
description: Republican leaders of Congress, looking for ways to help pay for a highway bill that exceeds budget limits, want to cut Medicaid, food stamps and social service programs, but they have encountered vehement objections from governors of both parties.

title: Metro Business; Con Ed Makes Bid For New York Utility
description: Consolidated Edison announced yesterday that it planned to acquire Orange and Rockland Utilities for about $790 million. The merger would give Con Edison a service area of nearly 2,000 square miles, with 3.3 million electricity customers and 1.2 million natural-gas customers.

title: A Fatal Shift in Cancer's Gender Gap
description: AN epidemic is raging in this country, and no one seems to be paying much attention to it. It is an epidemic of lung cancer in women.

title: An Outpouring of Sound Onstage, and a Frenzy Off
description: Jessye Norman's recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening suggested that she is becoming a victim of her own success. Over the years, the soprano has acquired a diva cult, which she has not exactly discouraged. On Sunday her dramatic entrance in a flowing turquoise gown and matching turban was followed by a spotlight. The audience erupted into frenzied applause and bravos, and from then on it was difficult for Ms. Norman to quiet them, even when she wanted to.

title: Paths of 2 Executives In a Proposed Merger
description: They both started out working for Ma Bell while still in college, one stringing telephone line and the other washing trucks. And Edward E. Whitacre Jr. and Richard C. Notebaert both flourished in the upheavals following the Federal Government's successful drive to break up the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company's monopoly.

title: DuPont to Spin Off 20% of Conoco, the Rest to Be Sold Later
description: In a move that many investors believe was long overdue, E. I. du Pont de Nemours announced yesterday that it would divest itself of 20 percent of its $22 billion Conoco oil subsidiary in a tax-free stock offering that could bring in as much as $5 billion. Charles O. Holliday Jr., DuPont's chief executive, said he would dispose of the rest of Conoco ''as soon as practical.''

title: Art You Can't See
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAWFORD, JOHN HAMILTON, JR.
description: CRAWFORD-John Hamilton, Jr. Esquire Of Locust Valley, L.I. on May 10, 1998. Husband of Zella K. Father of Robin C. Perito (Paul), Terrell K., Philip K. (Lisa), J. Hamilton III (Patricia) and Paige T. Brother of James L. Grandfather of seven. Memorial Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Wednesday, May 13 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to American Heart Association, NYC Affiliate, 122 East 42nd Street, New York City 10168 or the American Cancer Society.

title: Mayor's Office at Stake as Newark Votes
description: Mayoral candidates in Newark's elections on Tuesday engaged in last-minute sparring for votes today at centers for the elderly around the city and at a candidates' forum at Arts High School.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Latin America, New Wealth Shakes Out Old Family Habits
description: NEW YORK  As their Asian and Middle Eastern clients retrench, private bankers are turning to Latin America, where stable economies and rapidly growing markets are encouraging investors to shed some of their conservatism.

title: A Sweeping Style For Straightforward Ideas
description: Jennifer Muller/The Works

title: Dutch Company Sells Packaging Operations
description: Royal KNP N.V. of the Netherlands said yesterday that it had sold its packaging division for 3.4 billion guilders ($1.7 billion) in cash to two European venture-capital companies, Cinven Ltd. and CVC Capital Partners B.V., which plan to seek a separate stock listing for the business, to be called Kappa Packaging. KNP, which is Europe's third-biggest maker of corrugated cardboard, had said it wanted a price above the 2.4 billion guilder estimate of what the packaging business would bring in a public offering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELB, SARAH
description: GELB-Sarah. On May 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of Judy Gelb Vogel and Hal Gelb. Adoring grandmother of Michael S. Vogel and Reilly Joseph Gelb and great-grandmother of Edward Arthur Kenney Vogel and Charles Taft Vogel Kenney. Dear sister of Tema Nason and mother-in-law of Howard Vogel and Pat Gelb. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday, May 12, 11:30 AM.

title: Foreign Affairs; G-7 Draft Picks
description: Well, it's that time again. This weekend the Group of Seven major industrial democracies, and Russia, gather in Britain for their annual gabfest about the world economy. And once again I offer my annual alternative G-7 -- the ones you would really invite if you were organizing a summit meeting of the world's seven most important economic actors today and you weren't stuck with Canada, France, Italy, Britain, Japan, Germany and the U.S.

title: Yanks' Girardi Leaves His Ego in the Clubhouse
description: About the only things that might slow the Yankees' inexorable march toward an incredible season are the elements and self-inflicted wounds.

title: Not Even Idleness Ruffles Rivera
description: As the chilly rain battered Yankee Stadium yesterday, Mariano Rivera sat silently near his locker reading a book and figuring that another night would pass without him pitching. Rivera was right, as the Yankees-Royals game was postponed and the closer did not get the chance to close. Again.

title: Beyond Sequencing of Human DNA
description: THE sequencing of the human genome, a historic goal in biomedical research, was snatched away last Friday from its Government sponsor, the National Institutes of Health, by a private venture that says it can get the job done faster. Now Government officials are scrambling to adjust to the stunning turn of events, saying that the task of interpreting the genome may begin much sooner now, and that there is every reason for Congress to continue to fund the project.

title: Drawing Inspiration From Antarctica's 'Heavenly Music'
description: For some time, the National Science Foundation has allowed a small number of artists and writers to travel to Antarctica to record the research that goes on there and the wild landscape in which it takes place. Painters, poets, photographers, authors and others have been ''to the Ice'' under the auspices of the agency's Writers and Artists Program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNE, VERA SOKOLOVA
description: THORNE-Vera Sokolova. Aged 97, widow of Samuel Thorne, died at her home in Old Lyme, CT on May 11, 1998. Born in Moscow, Russia, she left in 1918 with her first husband Ivan Dabrowski and ultimately landed in New York in 1920. She and Dabrowski subsequently were divorced and he changed his name to John Graham. He became a painter of some renown in The New York School. Mrs. Thorne married Samuel Thorne in 1928. He predeceased her in 1992. She is survived by a son Samuel Thorne, Jr. of Manchester by-the-Sea, MA; her other son Nicholas also died in 1992. She is also survived by seven grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. There will be a private interment in Manchester, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to the ASPCA, 42 East 92nd Street, New York, New York 10128-6804 or Hospice of Southeastern CT, 179 Gallivan Lane, PO Box 902, Uncasville, CT 06382-0902.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, LEO
description: RUBINSTEIN-Leo. The Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School mourns the passing of Leo Rubinstein, devoted father of Harry and Tobi Rubinstein, dedicated parents of our Early Childhood student, Lola.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS UP 2.2 PERCENT. Natural gas rose on forecasts of exceptionally warm weather, raising expectations of higher demand to generate electricity for cooling. June contracts rose 4.8 cents, to $2.215 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: Termites Thrive After a Mild Winter; Professional Pest Fighters Are Busy, Much to the Dismay of Homeowners
description: The telephone calls Walter Schroeder takes as executive director of the Long Island Pest Control Association are often of the urgent, frantic variety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, ETHEL
description: EPSTEIN-Ethel. The New Lincoln School community mourns the passing of Ethel Epstein, beloved parent, former Head and dedicated Trustee for over half a century.

title: Excerpts From Application for Independent Counsel
description: Following is an excerpt from Attorney General Janet Reno's application to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, Independent Counsel Division. The application was filed today and released by the Department of Justice.

title: Companies Offer a New Service to Back Up Files
description: WITH a couple of keystrokes, you accidentally delete your groundbreaking manuscript about the last days of Amelia Earhart, along with all the research. No problem: You simply grab a handful of backup disks and restore the information.

title: Scratch, Scratch, Wah-Wah: Sounds Real
description: Sylk 130

title: Tagliabue Questions Clancy
description: The author Tom Clancy met with National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue and other league officials yesterday in New York regarding his bid to purchase the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, HENRIETTA OWENS
description: ROGERS-Henrietta Owens. Age 91. Died peacefully at home on May 9. Devoted wife for 64 years of James G. Rogers. Beloved mother of Patsy Rogers, Kathie McQuarrie and James G. Rogers III. Proud grandmother of Michael, Mollie, Amy, Kate and Jamie. Services will be held at St. Mark's Church, New Canaan, CT, on Wednesday, May 13, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Henrietta O. Rogers Poetry Award, c/o Development Office, Connecticut College, New London, CT 06320.

title: Texaco Plans to Sell Unit
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it was seeking buyers for its British gas marketing division, Texaco Natural Gas. The company is also looking to sell its 50 percent stake in the retail gas-marketing company Calortex. The company said it wanted to focus on its core oil and gas businesses. Texaco will pull out of Calortex -- a joint venture with Calor Gas and the Dutch utility Nuon International N.V. -- if a suitable buyer emerges for its 50 percent stake.

title: Full Pension Is Backed for Former Top Soldier
description: Disgraced or not, the Army's former top enlisted soldier apparently will get full retirement benefits despite his recent conviction for obstructing justice in the sexual-harassment case against him.

title: Nostalgic Visit With a Man Who Sashays in Pink Pants
description: Hurry! Only one week left to catch one of the funniest half-hours in town! Anyone in favor of throat-clogging guffaws should high-tail it to 52d Street between 10th and 11th Avenues for an encounter with the tickling sensation that has been devised by Paul Rudnick, the king of the barbed bon mot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOFSKY, HARRY
description: JACOFSKY-Harry. On May 11, 1998. Loving husband of Rosalie, beloved father of David and Marc, cherished son of Ruth, devoted brother of Bernie and Glen.

title: Deutsch Awarded Big Galant Account
description: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America in Cypress, Calif., has expanded its relationship with Deutsch Inc. in New York and Marina del Rey, Calif., by naming the agency to handle advertising for the 1999 Mitsubishi Galant, according to executives who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Billings were estimated at $55 million.

title: A Dangerous Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, DONALD W.
description: GREEN-Donald W. Of South Orange, NJ on May 9, 1998. Husband of Cynthia Bear. Father of Katrina Bardecker and Conan Green. Son of Donald and Marion Green. Brother of Lori Ascani, Connie Carruthers. Also survived by three grandchildren. Funeral service Saturday, May 16, 11 AM, St Andrew and Holy Communion Church, South Orange, NJ. Family will receive visitors at home, Thursday and Friday, 3-5 PM and 7-8 PM. qq

title: A Dangerous Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: Trusts Cast Off Fusty Image
description: MANCHESTER  If the mention of trusts and trust funds conjures up images of old money and bespoke private banking arrangements for the truly wealthy, think again. Trusts can be a useful and cost-effective financial planning tool for individuals with modest fortunes who wish to preserve family assets and ease the settling of their financial affairs after death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HARRY B., JR.
description: COHEN-Harry B., Jr. Westchester Jewish Community Services mourns the loss of its devoted thirty year Board member, Harry B. Cohen, Jr. We will miss him. Philip Halper, President Ronald Gaudia, Exec Dir/CEO

title: Pre-Humans Stood Up and Walked 4 Million Years Ago, Researchers Say
description: NEW, more definitive age estimates, combined with the discovery of more fossils, have apparently dispelled lingering doubts that skeletal remains found in Africa three years ago are indeed those of the earliest known human ancestors to walk erect, scientists reported last week.

title: Papers on a Potential Defect In Ford Cars Are Released
description: Highway safety officials in Washington released nearly 200 pages of internal documents from the Ford Motor Company yesterday that State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance, the large auto insurer, contends back up its assertions that for years the auto maker withheld information about potential fire hazards in millions of vehicles from Federal investigators and customers.

title: Concern About Rate Rise Cuts the Size of a Dow Rally
description: News of a huge telephone deal pushed stock prices higher early yesterday, but concern about rising interest rates overshadowed the merger euphoria, leaving stocks mixed.

title: Manhattan School Chief Is Finalist for Hawaii Job
description: Anthony Amato, the Superintendent of Community School District 6 in Washington Heights, is one of four finalists for Superintendent of Education for the State of Hawaii, a spokesman for the Hawaii Board of Education said yesterday.

title: Harvard and Its Sister, Radcliffe, Are Feuding Over Mission and Money
description: Some say the students are just full of springtime vim. Some say Harvard and Radcliffe are just long-bickering siblings. Some dismiss all the talk as too gossipy for the lofty brows of Cambridge even to contemplate.

title: Punishing the Jobless
description: To the Editor:

title: Wrangler Jeans Venture
description: The VF Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a joint venture to manufacture and market Wrangler jeans in Japan. VF, a maker of apparel based here, said it owned majority rights in the venture, which is expected to begin operations in July. Other partners are the Toyobo Company of Japan, a current licensee of Wrangler, and the Mitsubishi Corporation, the Japanese conglomerate.

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACH, REVA T.
description: BACH-Reva T. On May 10, 1998. Loving wife of the late Morris. Mother of Judith Iris Bach and Ilene Heidi Amar, mother-in-law of Yehuda Amar, grandmother of Yishai Ben and Medad Arik Amar and aunt to many beloved nieces and nephews. Loved by all her family and friends who remember her with love and affection. Services Tuesday, May 12, I.J. Morris, Hempstead, New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks' Fans Are Asking, Who's Guilty?
description: WITH the Knicks' loss to the Pacers on Sunday, New Yorkers have freely indulged in a favorite pastime: find the guilty party. Assign blame. Who's the scapegoat? Knick fans have been perfecting this game for the last 25 seasons, the last 13 seasons in earnest.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Friday about the choice of Select Communications in New York to handle Jordache Enterprises' jeans account, included one agency erroneously among those that competed. Arnell Group Brand Consulting did not take part.

title: For Reno, a Difficult Call Based on the Law, Not the Evidence
description: In becoming the fifth member of President Clinton's Cabinet to be examined by an independent counsel, Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman will now face months of investigation and big legal bills.

title: Indonesian Values
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: LEBACH-Grete (nee Weilheimer), 88, on May 10, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Erich. Beloved mother of Dorothy and Joan. Adored Oma of Netanya. Services Wednesday, May 13, 1 P.M., at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY. Any contributions to Temple Beth El.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, HARRY D.
description: GARBER-Harry D. The Community Preservation Corporation mourns the passing of its long time Director and past Chairman Harry D. Garber. He was a visionary in understanding how private industry might address social problems, and helped lead our company to expand our low and moderate income housing efforts. His social judgement, commitment and friendship, which will continue to inspire us, will be sorely missed. The Board of Directors The Community Preservation Corporation John A. Somers, Chairman Michael D. Lappin, President

title: CASTLE & COOKE TO REPURCHASE 3 MILLION SHARES
description: The shares of Castle & Cooke Inc. rose yesterday after the company, a real estate developer, said it would buy back up to 15 percent of its stock through a Dutch auction. Castle & Cooke, based in Los Angeles, said it would buy three million of its shares from investors who tender their shares to the company at prices ranging from $17.75 to $19.50 a share. Castle & Cooke's shares rose $1.875, to $18.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. ''We believe that our company's stock is undervalued at the present time,'' David H. Murdock, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. In a Dutch auction, the company pays the lowest price that allows it to purchase the total number of tendered shares that it is seeking.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS BUYS BIOTECHNOLOGY CONCERN
description: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Apollon Inc., a biotechnology company that has been working on DNA-based vaccines for herpes, hepatitis and the virus that causes AIDS. Terms were not disclosed. In December, Apollon withdrew its initial public offering, which valued the company at as much as $105.9 million. Apollon and American Home's Wyeth-Lederle unit have collaborated on research since 1995. Apollon will continue its work at its site in Malvern, Pa. The company, based in Madison, N.J., makes the estrogen-replacement therapy Premarin and the painkiller Advil.

title: Bloop Hit Gives Brown The Edge Over Leiter
description: Al Leiter and Kevin Brown pitched here tonight as if it were a grudge match. The only real difference between the former teammates on last season's World Series champion Florida Marlins was a bloop single and a base-running mistake.

title: Oakley Brings Out an Unusual Sports Shoe
description: To break into the intensely competitive sport shoe market, Oakley Inc. has devised several secret weapons, including an unusual black and yellow woven shoe with a motorcycle racing tire for a sole, and Shane Bonifay.

title: People
description: * Kathy Kayse, Midwest advertising manager at Time magazine, Chicago, part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc., was named publisher at a sibling magazine, Your Company, New York, succeeding Geoff Dodge, who continues as publisher of the sibling Money magazine.

title: Angry at the Mayor, Cabbies Plan to Make Tomorrow the Day New York Stood Still
description: Jose Chavez is not going to work tomorrow. And, if enough of his colleagues follow suit, many New Yorkers may not be showing up to work or anyplace else -- at least on time.

title: Netanyahu's Rare Opportunity
description: If Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu rejects the Clinton Administration's latest proposal for Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank, he will not just have harmed the prospects for further peace negotiations. He will also have missed out on a rare opportunity to strike a blow against Palestinian terrorists.

title: From Garden to Freezer
description: In Grandma's day, blanching the garden vegetables before freezing them was a standard, if steamy, kitchen routine. Lately, busy cooks are skipping that step, but a University of Illinois food scientist has found a solution: the microwave.

title: Protesters In Indonesia Find Allies In Parents
description: At 72, with a career as an army general and provincial governor behind him, G. P. Solichin is no revolutionary. But he believes that Indonesia desperately needs change.

title: Thomas Dashiell, 70, Builder, And Dismantler, of Germ Arms
description: Thomas R. Dashiell, who became a major figure in America's effort to develop offensive biological weapons but later worked to destroy them, died on May 4 in Frederick, Md., where he lived. He was 70.

title: More Should Take Aspirin
description: MANY older survivors of heart attacks, a recent study finds, are not getting the standard treatment to prevent repeat attacks: a daily low dose of aspirin.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article yesterday described the concern of television network executives about challenges from cable channels and other sources. In commenting on the plight of the various networks, Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Television, was quoted as saying that NBC's profits would decline next year to $100 million, from $500 million.

title: Yes, Childs Erred, but He Had a Lot of Company
description: There was a timeout and an intense discussion that had a ''Where's Waldo?'' element to it.

title: INSIDE
description: Trying to Pay for Roads

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELDEN, DAVE
description: SELDEN-Dave. Dave Selden, who lead the American Federation of Teachers from 1968 through 1974, a period of rapid membership growth & collective bargaining successes for teachers, died late on Friday at Bronson Methodist Hospital in Kalamazoo, MI. of heart failure. His health had steadily deteriorated since suffering a stroke two years ago. Sandra Feldman, the current AFT President said, ''Dave Selden was a brilliant organizer and strategist. The teachers of America owe him a debt of gratitude for the major role he played in helping them achieve collective bargaining.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, ELIZABETH BOULTON
description: JACKSON-Elizabeth Boulton of S. Norwalk, CT on May 9, 1998. Wife of Thomas C. Jackson. Mother of Thomas C. Jackson Jr, John Andrew Jackson, Timothy Boulton Jackson, & Sally Jackson Lawrence. Sister of Richard N. Boulton. Memorial service United Church of Rowayton in Rowayton, CT on Wednesday May 13, 1998 at 3:30pm. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorials to: Nursing & Home Care, Inc PO Box 127 Wilton, CT 06897-0127 or Douglas College New Brunswick, NJ 08901.

title: Police Seek Suspect In Bomb Threat Hoax
description: The police were searching yesterday for a man who made a bomb threat and planted what turned out to be a harmless box in a McDonald's restaurant Sunday. The police said he was trying to extort the release of a man jailed for making a similar bomb threat.

title: Taking On an Industry, And Doing Quite Well
description: ''Until Big Tobacco met the boys from Ole Miss, they were undefeated in hundreds of lawsuits,'' says Lowell Bergman, the reporter on ''Frontline: Inside the Tobacco Deal.'' Setting up a David and Goliath struggle is one certain way to enliven a complicated news story. Tonight's lucid though naggingly short-sighted documentary lionizes the men who devised the strategy that brought the giant tobacco companies not to their knees, but at least to a bargaining position.

title: Governor Chiles's Everglades Moment
description: Lawton Chiles may have done more than any other Florida governor to help restore the Everglades to its rightful status as one of the world's great ecosystems. He settled a lawsuit brought by the Bush Administration against the state for allowing Florida's sugar cane industry to pollute the Everglades with agricultural runoff. He also pushed through the 1994 Everglades Forever Act, which committed the state to a long-term restoration plan in partnership with the Federal Government, and extracted substantial sums from the sugar cane industry to help underwrite the cleanup.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Best Paroled Man

title: Hard Truth of the Mideast
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has turned his back on an American deadline but is coming to Washington on Wednesday, and the Clinton Administration today decided once again to cut him some slack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ANNA H.
description: LEVINE-Anna H. of West Orange, NJ, on Sunday May 10, 1998. Wife of the late Morris J. Mother of Howard H. and the late H. Leonard, Dr. Robert H., and Beatrice. Dear mother-in-law of Jacqueline, Yetta, and Joan. Also survived by eight grandchildren and 14 greatgrandchildren. Graveside services were held on Monday May 11, 1998 at B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union NJ. Contributions in Anna's honor may be made to the Daughters of Israel Geriatric Center, 1155 Pleasant Valley Way, West Orange, NJ 07052. ''We mourn her death and celebrate her life.'' Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ

title: Pataki Picks Upstate Judge As His New Running Mate
description: Four years after he elevated Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross from obscurity in what proved to be an embarrassing political mismatch, Gov. George E. Pataki has picked Mary O. Donohue, a little-known upstate judge, as his re-election running mate, senior Republican officials said today,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRANGE, WALTER H.
description: STRANGE-Walter H. On May 11, 1998 of Rye, New York. Devoted husband of Jane Dee. Beloved father of Michael, Walter H. Jr., Louise, Mary Taylor, Sarah and Charles. Loving brother of Charles and Lily Socci. Dear grandfather of Sarah, William, Travis and Mary Jane. Family will receive friends Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of the Resurrection, Thursday, 10AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Lung Association of Hudson Valley, 35 Orchard St, White Plains, N.Y. 10603-9924.

title: Mordechai Strigler, Editor Of Yiddish Forward, Dies at 76
description: Mordechai Strigler, the editor of the Yiddish-language Forward and one of the most prolific Yiddish writers of the postwar period, died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: Filipinos Favoring Ex-Actor
description: Squatting on tiny schoolroom benches, their heads buried in three-sided cardboard boxes marked ''Voting Booths,'' millions of Filipinos cast their ballots today for President, Vice President and 17,000 other local and national officials.

title: Epiphany Names New Executive
description: Roger Siboni, deputy chairman at KPMG Peat Marwick L.L.P. and a veteran high-technology industry consultant, will become chief executive of Epiphany Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up backed by Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the venture capital firm.

title: Wiggly Excursions for Sensuous Sound
description: In its diligent search for new languages that work, music has pushed originality to the top of its requirements list. And it is really not the thought that must be original; it is the mechanism -- the software, if you will -- by which the thought is expressed.

title: Mullin Revels in Chance To Play in Big Games
description: Last year, Chris Mullin came to Madison Square Garden for the Eastern Conference semifinals. He came to watch, not to play. His former teammate Tim Hardaway was out on the court dueling with the Knicks as a member of the Miami Heat. Mullin, who grew up in Brooklyn and starred at St. John's, was Hardaway's guest, and he sat in the stands, observing and thinking.

title: The Law That Spells Out Sanctions
description: With India's announcement today that it had conducted three underground nuclear tests, the question of possible United States sanctions arises. Here are excerpts from the relevant law, the Nuclear Proliferation Prevention Act of 1994.

title: A New Measure Of Disparities: Poor Sanitation In Internet Era
description: Around the world, more people are getting telephones and access to the Internet while at the same time an increasing number are without basic household sanitation -- toilets, or even simple latrines -- according to a new report.

title: For Scientists, A Dose of Caution
description: To the Editor:

title: AT&T and 2 Unions in Tentative Pact
description: The AT&T Corporation reached a tentative agreement today with two unions on a four-year contract that increases wages and pensions and links bonuses to performance for about 50,000 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYMAN, RALPH
description: LYMAN-Ralph. Passed away peacefully on May 11, 1998 at age 79. Beloved husband of Clara. Cherished father of Paula and Mark. Devoted grandfather of Arianne, Forest, Aaron and Ariel. He was an accomplished printer, dedicated teacher, talented writer and loving individual. Funeral service, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NYC, 212-362-6600.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAJARIAN, KARNIG R.
description: NAJARIAN-Karnig R., of Old Tappan, NJ, on Friday, May 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara Najarian (nee SanGiovanni). Devoted father of John and Laura Najarian. Relatives of Najarian and Paragian families. Memorial gifts to The Museum of Modern Art, 11 W. 53rd Street, New York, NY 10019 in his memory.

title: Will That Takeover Be Cash or Stock?
description: Another day, another deal. And another reason for the stock market to go up.

title: Gobble, gobble, gobble: Another independent (Riney) is bought by a biggie (Publicis).
description: MADISON AVENUE keeps consolidating as fast as the telecommunications, banking and automotive industries. Another leading independent shop -- Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco -- has agreed to be bought by an acquisitive worldwide agency company.

title: On My Mind; The Simple Question
description: For almost two years now, the House of Representatives has been the center of a struggle to answer a simple question about the meaning and purpose of America:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLED, LOU
description: SOLED-Lou. Died peacefully on May 10, 1998 in North Miami Beach, FL. Formerly of Bayside, N.Y. Beloved husband of Selma. Loving father of Gerard, Stephen and the late Carol (Cohen). Grandfather of Amanda and Julie.

title: Exalting the Libido, Social Justice, Jah and Good Dancing
description: Prayers and politics, history lessons and bawdy jokes, sage counsel and incitements to dance all fit together in Afro-Caribbean music. African tradition assumes that listeners can take in good ideas while partying. The Radio City Music Hall stage was taken over by dancing preachers and joking commentators over the weekend, with four-hour shows that surveyed reggae on Friday and calypso on Saturday.

title: Good For Them And Us
description: Remember when many Americans saw foreign mergers with United States companies as a sign of failure? Today the opposite is true, the latest example being the reaction to last week's proposed Daimler-Benz deal with Chrysler. In a recent survey of 2,600 managers, I found that people working for companies that served only local markets felt threatened by foreign owners. But the managers for companies with international markets -- those with the most experience with globalization -- believed there was nothing to fear from foreign conglomerates.

title: Indians Risk Invoking U.S. Law Imposing Big Economic Penalties
description: India's nuclear tests today brought into play an American law that could block billions of dollars of aid to India, and it prompted American officials to plead with Pakistan not to intensify a regional arms race by conducting its own atomic tests.

title: Smith, Returning Tomorrow, Plans on Preakness
description: The dawn was breaking, gray and wet, in the stable area of Belmont Park, and rain pelted the windows of the Morning Line, a small, bustling restaurant there. Inside, amid the smell of frying sausages and coffee, were jockeys, trainers, agents and others involved in racing, including a small, dark-haired, dark-eyed man who is lucky to be alive.

title: Haskins Steps Down At L.I.U.
description: Ray Haskins, who led Long Island University to renewed basketball prominence the past two seasons, resigned as head coach yesterday.

title: $62 BILLION DEAL TO SHIFT BALANCE IN PHONE INDUSTRY
description: The announcement that SBC Communications Inc. would acquire the Ameritech Corporation for about $62 billion significantly shifts the balance of power in the United States telecommunications industry. The deal announced yesterday would create the nation's largest local phone company and threaten the remaining regional Bells with the specter of having to compete eventually with a wealthy, aggressive leviathan that will control about a third of the nation's local phone lines.

title: Safety Inquiry on Damaged Plane
description: Government safety officials are investigating whether the Airtran Airlines jet that flew through a hailstorm north of Atlanta on Thursday had properly functioning weather radar and what meteorological information the crew had received from the airline and air traffic controllers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SBC Communications Says It Will Acquire Ameritech

title: For Scientists, A Dose of Caution
description: To the Editor:

title: State Police Deny Claim of Racial Stops
description: The New Jersey State Police, under increasing scrutiny over a shooting on the state turnpike, yesterday vehemently denied stopping drivers based on race in the hopes of making drug arrests.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the News Summary yesterday about the Justice Department's inquiry on cigarette marketing referred incorrectly to the scope. The department is investigating whether cigarette makers, including the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, made false statements to Federal officials, manipulated nicotine levels, misrepresented health information or marketed cigarettes to under-age smokers. It has not identified a specific interest in Brown & Williamson.

title: Reno Seeks Independent Counsel For Investigation of Labor Chief
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today asked a Federal judicial panel to appoint an independent counsel to investigate accusations that Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman engaged in a plan involving kickbacks and illegal campaign contributions when she worked as a Presidential aide at the White House.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: All Right, Goodbye Already!; Parting Is Such Sweet Sitcom
description: It's as if we've all tacitly agreed to go crazy. On Thursday night, the cable channel TV Land will stop regular programming for an hour and hang out a sign saying it'll be back after the ''Seinfeld'' finale. In tomorrow's episode of ''Dharma and Greg,'' the couple decide to have sex in public and chooses the perfect time: when the rest of the world is watching the last ''Seinfeld.'' And that's just the hype NBC is not responsible for.

title: Learning Another Language: The Notes Between the Notes
description: To many concertgoers, the concept of microtonal music may seem intimidatingly complex. But the actual sound of the music, in a sense, is familiar to anyone who has heard a blues singer bend a phrase.

title: Israeli Drug Company Pursues European Deal
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire an unidentified European pharmaceutical company with annual sales of $100 million. Teva, based in Jerusalem, makes drugs, medical supplies and veterinary products. The company, which had net income of $25.1 million on revenue of $269 million for the quarter that ended March 31, said the acquisition would add to its earnings after one year, but did not elaborate.

title: Mideast Peace Pressures
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has successfully resisted President Clinton's proposal for immediate talks conditioned on a further 13 percent withdrawal from the West Bank, making this an especially tender moment for his visit to the United States. The Administration is showing more and more frustration, and Israelis are feeling more resentment over American pressure. Mr. Netanyahu arrives tomorrow for a five-day trip, and a newly scheduled meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine Albright offers some hope of progress. But time does appear to be running out before the Administration makes its threatened reassessment of the American role in the Mideast negotiations.

title: Thyssen Agrees to Sell German Phone Business
description: Thyssen A.G., the German industrial giant, said yesterday that it would sell its Plusnet fixed-line telephone business to Esprit Telecom Group P.L.C. for 315 million marks ($180 million), taking another large step in its retreat from the German phone business. Acquiring Plusnet, which is Thyssen Telecom's biggest phone business and provides two-thirds of the division's revenue, gives Esprit 1,000 customers to add to the 400 it already has in Germany as well as an estimated 84.5 million marks in sales this year.

title: Walking Like a Human
description: Typically, robots move on wheels, unable to maneuver on rough terrain. Some have many legs. But few walk like humans because engineers have had trouble figuring out an efficient way to get a robot to walk on two legs.

title: Enlarging Already Big Holdings in Europe
description: SBC Communications Inc.'s plan to buy Ameritech for $62 billion in stock and assumed debt is likely to expand the already sizable investments in Europe made by Ameritech, analysts said today.

title: A Record Penalty for Sumitomo, a Lesson on Market Volatility
description: It's really not so easy to make money by cornering a commodity market -- even if you are playing with a lot of money and are quite willing to ignore the rules.

title: THE N.B.A. PLAYOFFS: The Kid, The Coach And the Critics; O'Neal and Harris Quiet Harsh Reviews
description: Two kids bounce and roll on a big purple exercise ball in the middle of the locker room as a handful of Los Angeles Lakers wait to get to the showers. One of the kids is 18-month-old Chase Aldridge, the son of a front office employee. The other is Shaquille O'Neal, who drops his 7-foot-1-inch, 315-pound frame to the ground and plays Gulliver. It's hard to tell who's having more fun.

title: Arguing Against Stock Deals
description: Wall Street adores stock-for-stock mergers, like SBC-Ameritech, but long term, two finance professors contend, cash is king. Page D1.

title: Right to Bear Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Guernica Journal; Fascism's Prey: Now Healing and a Quest for Truth
description: Inaki Arzanegi, like others of his generation, can still speak with strong emotion of that spring day when Guernica was destroyed. It was a Monday, market day, and many farmers and their animals had come to town.

title: Taming Lizard Venom
description: WHEN an expert on toxins took a look at the venom of the Mexican beaded lizard and Gila monster, he expected to find poisons that were similar to the snake-venom chemicals that jam the nervous system of a bitten animal. But lizard venom turns out to affect the animal's blood pressure instead, causing a precipitous drop.

title: Clara Rockmore, 88, Virtuosa Of an Unusual Instrument
description: Clara Rockmore, a musician who was trained as a violinist but became famous principally as a soloist on the theremin, an early electronic instrument, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.

title: Needless Pain Among Aged
description: Too many elderly people are needlessly suffering pain, a panel of pain experts said last week.

title: Grand Jury Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Uneasy Lies the Head That Runs a Suburban School System
description: When Judith Sarris Conk was selected as Superintendent in this small town where the school system is considered one of the best in the state, school board members and parents were ecstatic that she signed a five-year contract, because her predecessor had been there only a year.

title: Larry King Signs CNN Accord Totaling $7 Million a Year
description: The Cable News Network has signed its talk show host, Larry King, to a new contract that will bring his salary close to parity with the leading news anchors on the broadcast networks.

title: Cola Upstart Bubbles Over From Britain
description: Virgin Cola, the upstart British soft-drink company started three years ago by the music industry and airline executive Richard Branson, plans a plunge into the crowded and hostile American beverage market starting today. Perhaps fittingly, Mr. Branson plans to ride down Fifth Avenue in a vintage Army tank.

title: Spy Agencies Under Attack for Providing No Warning : Clinton Vows to Punish India
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton vowed Tuesday to apply U.S. laws imposing strong sanctions against India after its underground nuclear tests, and he implored other countries in the region not to follow India "down the path of a dangerous arms race."

title: Kerris Ann Wolsky, 41, Founder Of Textile Workshop in Harlem
description: Kerris Ann Wolsky, the president and founding director of Harlem Textile Works, died on May 3 at her home in Jackson Heights, Queens. She was 41.

title: Journal; The 'Seinfeld' Hoax
description: Like nature, which it has now usurped as America's backdrop, the media circus abhors a vacuum. O. J. and Princess Di haven't done much to fill it lately, and neither has Monica, so it's all up to ''Seinfeld,'' whose marathon farewell has become a cultural stunt more impressive than the ''postmodern'' humor of the show itself. It's a media frenzy built on next to nothing.

title: Dow Mirrors Rally in Bonds To Close 70.25 Points Higher
description: Stocks maintained their ties to the bond market yesterday, falling early in the day as bond prices fell, then gaining as bonds reversed course and rallied.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHNER, RITA
description: SCHACHNER-Rita. Passed away May 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Bruno Schachner. Survived by sister, Estelle Mond, a step-sister, four nephews and seven greatnieces and nephews. Graveside service private. A memorial service will be held in the future. For information call Robert J. Kent at 914-576-3939 or during normal business hours at 212-437-1666.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER AT 4-MONTH LOW. Silver fell 2.9 percent on the threat of economic sanctions against India, a leading silver user, because of its nuclear tests. July contracts fell 16.7 cents, to $5.565 an ounce, the lowest since Jan. 12.

title: Pondering 'Seinfeld' Finale's Ratings and Rivals
description: There are only three questions left about the ''Seinfeld'' finale: How will it end, how many millions of people are going to watch, and is there anything else on tomorrow night that anybody is going to watch?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYNE, BELLE SAUNDERS
description: KAYNE-Belle Saunders. It is with sadness that the staff and volunteers of The Jewish Museum note the loss of Belle Saunders Kayne, longtime devoted and talented volunteer and friend to the Museum. We remember Belle fondly and will certainly miss her. Our condolences to her family and friends. The Jewish Museum Joan Rosenbaum, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLHOUN, RICHARD NEWBOLD, JR.
description: COLHOUN-Richard Newbold, Jr., a resident of Millbrook, New York, died from injuries resulting from a race car accident at Lime Rock, Connecticut on Saturday, May 9. He was 50. Mr. Colhoun was the New York - New England sales manager for and a key factor in the success of Landmark Vine yards in Sonoma, California. He formerly owned and operated The Powerhouse, an outdoor power equipment distributor, located in Brewster, New York. Particularly concerned with the field of education, Mr. Colhoun returned to serve the school from which he graduated, the Kents Hill School in Kents Hill, Maine. He served in several positions and was formerly president and chairman of the board. He was a member of the board of trustees of the Dutchess Day School in Millbrook, New York and he was an active supporter of the Millbrook School. Mr. Colhoun was born in New York City. He attended New Canaan Country Day School in New Canaan, Connecticut, and earned a bachelor of arts degree from Iowa's Parson's College. He was an ardent sailor and outdoor enthusiast. He is survived by his parents, Richard N. Colhoun and Damaris D.W. Ethridge; his wife, Betsy; two sons, Ian Colhoun and Trevor Colhoun; and a stepdaughter, Kyle Utter. In lieu of flowers, Mr. Colhoun's family has requested donations be made to Kents Hill School, Box 257, Kents Hill, Maine 04349-0257.

title: 13 Shopping Centers Sold
description: Malan Realty Investors Inc. said today that it would buy 13 shopping centers in six Midwestern states from the Sandor Development Company for $33.7 million. Malan, based in Birmingham, is a real estate investment trust. It owns and operates 54 shopping centers, freestanding stores and entertainment sites. Sandor, based in Indianapolis, is a closely held real estate company.

title: Feud With Harvard Diminishes Radcliffe
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Getting the Chance To Do It Himself; Out of the Shadows to Run Home Depot
description: Their roles were always clear.

title: Indian's Letter to Clinton On the Nuclear Testing
description: The following is the text of a letter sent on Monday to President Clinton from Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee of India:

title: China Is 'Seriously Concerned' But Restrained in Its Criticism
description: After a day of silence, China today condemned India's underground nuclear tests with notable brevity and restraint.

title: In London, a Big Talent With a Dash of Gall
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Feud With Harvard Diminishes Radcliffe
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Talk; Amarone Replaces All the Usual Suspects
description: THERE was a time, not too long ago, when waiters in Italian restaurants had a standard response to any question about wine: ''We've got Soave, Bardolino and Valpolicella.''

title: Britain to Spend $520 Million to Pep Up Ulster
description: Stepping up its effort to obtain voter approval of the Northern Ireland peace settlement, the British Government announced a $520 million aid package to the province today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTMAN, HELEN
description: GUTTMAN-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Bert. Loving mother of Jane (Lionel) DePass. Cherished grandmother of Paul and Richard (Andree), adored great-grandmother of Evan.

title: Sharon Won't Join Netanyahu in Meeting Albright
description: Ariel Sharon, a Cabinet minister considered crucial to Israeli Government approval of any peace deal, announced today that he would not join Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in his meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, in protest against what he described as unauthorized ''promises'' by the Prime Minister.

title: Along the Loire, Dedication To a Fried-Fish Delicacy
description: THE air along the Loire River is moist and dewy, and the sunlight showers down in thick, rich rays. It is no wonder that the Loire Valley is so lush or that the region has long been noted for its fresh produce and elegant wines.

title: In Assault Case, Judge Finds Grounds for Very Long Sentence
description: Employing a rarely used provision of a law aimed at career criminals, a Bronx judge said yesterday that he planned to sentence a man to 15 years to life for assaulting an emergency medical technician with a knife -- far more than the maximum four-year sentence for such a crime.

title: LOMAK PETROLEUM PLANS TO PAY $215 MILLION FOR DOMAIN
description: The Domain Energy Corporation, an independent oil and gas exploration company, agreed yesterday to be acquired by Lomak Petroleum Inc. for about $215 million in stock. The combined company will be named the Range Resources Corporation and have more than $1.1 billion in assets. Under the agreement, Domain's shareholders will receive $14.50 in Lomak common shares for each Domain share. The final exchange ratio will be determined just before the merger is completed. Shares of Domain, based in Houston, rose $1.3125, to $13.8125; shares of Lomak Petroleum, based in Fort Worth, fell 6.25 cents, to $13.9375.

title: Body Shop Chief To Step Down
description: The Body Shop International P.L.C. announced today that its founder, Anita Roddick, would step aside as chief executive after 22 years as the ailing cosmetics retailer seeks to cope with declining sales and a falling stock price.

title: David Selden, 83, Union Chief Jailed During Teachers Strike
description: David Selden, whose combative leadership of the American Federation of Teachers earned him a 60-day jail term alongside striking teachers in Newark in 1968, died on Friday at Bronson Methodist Hospital in Kalamazoo, Mich. He was 83, and lived in Kalamazoo.

title: A Right to Anthrax?
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Department Expected To Seek Contract Restraints
description: The Government is expected to sue the Microsoft Corporation to place limits on the contracts the company strikes with personal computer makers, Internet service providers and Web site operators.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Rwanda Tribunal Staff
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNULTY, ALFRED P.
description: McNULTY-Alfred P., beloved husband of Dorothy (nee John), dear father of Matthew J. McNulty (wife Margo) of University Heights, Peter D. McNulty of Long Beach, CA. and William R. McNulty of London, England; dear grandfather of Alex; dear brother of Eileen Dana (Mrs. Howard) of N.Y., Kathleen Hogerton (Mrs. John) of Quogue, NY, Margaret McNulty and Alice Martin both of Albuquerque, NM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to Cleveland Restoration Society, 1127 Euclid Ave, Cleveland, OH 44115; or St. Peter Restoration Fund, 1533 E. 17th St, Cleveland 44114. Funeral Mass will be held at St. Dominic Church, 19000 Van Aken Blvd, Thur., May 14th. at 4pm. Brown-Forward

title: Jordan Is Key to Palestinian State
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Backs Halt to Phone Service Switching
description: The Senate tonight overwhelmingly approved a measure that authorizes stiff fines and penalties against telephone companies that switch the long-distance phone service of customers without their permission.

title: BCE PLANS TO SELL 14.25% STAKE IN CABLE AND WIRELESS
description: BCE Inc., the owner of Canada's biggest phone company, said yesterday that it would sell its stake in Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C., worth about $1.54 billion, and use the proceeds to expand in faster-growing markets and businesses. BCE is selling its 14.25 percent interest in the British cable company to focus internationally on markets like Latin America. The company is also building a Canadian network to serve business customers. BCE acquired the stake in Cable and Wireless in 1992. BCE's shares, traded in the United States and in Canada, rose 56.25 cents each yesterday, to $44.75.

title: PACKARD BELL NEC TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND CUT 400 JOBS
description: Packard Bell NEC will close two plants and slash 400 jobs, or 5 percent of the work force, in an effort to cut costs and turn around the falling market share at the personal computer maker. Packard Bell said its plants in Fife, Wash., and Boxborough, Mass., would close and the notebook computer and sales and service groups and most of the engineering group that were based at those sites would move to the company's 400-acre headquarters in Sacramento, Calif. Last year, unit shipments for Packard Bell, the fifth-largest personal computer maker, fell 8.3 percent, and its market share slipped to 4.8 percent, from 6 percent, according to Dataquest Inc.

title: Two Leading Horses Will Miss the Preakness
description: Four days before the Preakness, the Triple Crown suffered the loss of two more contenders today when Rick Pitino's Halory Hunter fractured his left front ankle while working out at Pimlico and the prospective favorite for the race, Indian Charlie, was withdrawn because of weariness and loss of weight.

title: Tigers Seek an Answer in Goal
description: In the men's Division I quarterfinals at Hofstra Stadium in Hempstead, N.Y., on Saturday, Princeton's goals may come slowly against a defensively skilled Duke team. But there should be enough of them for the faster Tigers.

title: Runaway NATO Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Equality for Domestic Partners
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has offered enlightened legislation to make registered domestic partners, whether heterosexual or homosexual, equal to married spouses under all New York City government rules and policies. The proposal will give new rights to those in domestic partnerships who either work for the city or seek access to city services or programs. Mr. Giuliani should be applauded for fulfilling an election-year promise made to the gay community. It stands to become one of the finer legacies of his administration.

title: The Chef; A Taste of Summer When Corn Joins Its Perfect Mate
description: WITH the lobster season upon us, I am powerfully drawn to the classic combination of sweet corn and the tenderest, briny lobster. It is a pairing that I begin to work with in late spring and one that just gets better and better as the summer arrives and progresses into early fall. There is a problem right now, of course: the sweet corn part of the equation.

title: In New Retreat, Senate Restores Food Stamps for Legal Immigrants
description: The Senate today voted to restore food stamps to a quarter of a million legal immigrants and refugees, retreating from some of the provisions of the 1996 welfare overhaul law.

title: Bosnia War Tribunal Finds Hidden Bodies of Slain Muslims
description: Deep in a remote rural stretch of Bosnia, war crimes investigators today found a tangle of buried bodies that they say are some of the 7,500 Muslim men hidden in an effort to thwart the prosecution of Bosnian Serb leaders for genocide.

title: Vegetarian That's Filling
description: A VOLUPTUOUS vegetarian dish is not a contradiction in terms. In at least two cuisines, those of India and Korea, where meat is not the focal point of a meal, vegetarian dishes can be sensuous, juicy, crunchy, spicy -- and very filling.

title: Moscow Opposes Sanctions
description: Russia today resisted the call to take tough action against India because of the underground nuclear tests.

title: Metro Business; Executives Charged In Securities Fraud
description: Two more former executives of the defunct Monroe Parker Securities brokerage firm were arrested and charged with netting $3 million for the company from the illegal manipulation of Steven Madden Ltd. and the United Leisure Corporation securities.

title: Agency Company Stock A Hit on the Big Board
description: The stock of Young & Rubicam Inc. performed strongly in its premiere yesterday, closing at a 12 percent premium to its initial public offering price.

title: New Respect for Tubby Smith
description: Tubby Smith is ever the coach. Forty-three days after leading Kentucky to the national title, Smith sat at table autographing basketballs at the New York Athletic Club, where he was the third recipient of the Winged Foot award as coach of the championship team last night. He was asked to comment on everything from recruiting to resignations.

title: They Might Be Nearsighted
description: I'm a middle-aged accordion player, and inspecting myself just now I see that I look tired and badly need a haircut. So you can imagine my confusion when I got a call last week from the manager of my band telling me that my name had turned up in People magazine's on-line poll of the most beautiful people of 1998.

title: CABARET
description: True Love? Hah!

title: In the Words of Albright: A Crisis of Partnership
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's address today to the National Press Club, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House:

title: Arts in America; Love Story of a String Quartet and a County in Maine
description: In the morning, the DaPonte String Quartet held a regular rehearsal, working on Bartok's fourth quartet in its regular rehearsal hall here, behind the pews at the Lincoln County Assembly of God Church. It was early in the process of adding the piece to their repertory, and in order not to muddy the waters with any emotive playing, the four played without vibrato, the squirrelly rhythms and whining glissandos of the piece punctuated by the incessant chirp of a metronome.

title: Boston Properties in Deal for Embarcadero
description: Boston Properties Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire San Francisco's Embarcadero Center from the Prudential Insurance Company of America and a partnership including David Rockefeller for $1.22 billion.

title: Newark Mayor Wins Vote, Defeating 2 for a 4th Term
description: Sharpe James won a fourth term as Mayor of New Jersey's largest city tonight, capping a campaign that had relentlessly stressed good news, such as the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and new housing development.

title: Unorthodox Wilson Gets Results
description: When he is in a chipper mood and not carrying a chip on his shoulder, Coach Ron Wilson of the Washington Capitals is philosophical about his final resting place. Having his name engraved on the Stanley Cup would be better than anything chiseled on his tombstone.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Con Ed Customers Await a Deregulation Lottery
description: Later this week, thousands of managers of New York City and Westchester commercial and residential properties will learn if they have been selected to participate in an energy deregulation program that could significantly trim their power bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, DONALD W.
description: GREEN-Donald W. Of South Orange, NJ on May 9, 1998. Husband of Cynthia Bear. Father of Katrina Bardecker and Conan Green. Son of Donald and Marion Green. Brother of Lori Ascani, Connie Carruthers. Also survived by three grandchildren. Funeral service Saturday, May 16, 11 AM, St Andrew and Holy Communion Church, South Orange, NJ. Family will receive visitors at home, Thursday and Friday, 3-5 PM and 7-8 PM. qq

title: Jordan Is Key to Palestinian State; Ending the Impasse
description: To the Editor:

title: VERO ACCEPTS $190 MILLION OFFER FROM APPLIED POWER
description: Applied Power Inc. said yesterday that Vero Group P.L.C. of Britain had agreed to be acquired for 192 pence a share, or a total of $:115 million ($190 million). Vero, based in Southampton, England, makes racks and enclosures that house cables and electronic equipment. Applied Power, based in Butler, Wis., makes similar enclosures and industrial and electrical tools. Vero Group was the subject of a brief bidding war between Applied Power and Pentair Inc., a diversified industrial manufacturer based in St. Paul. On April 23, Applied Power offered to buy Vero for 157 pence a share. On May 5, Pentair countered with a bid of 170 pence a share. Shares of Vero closed above the new offer price, gaining 13 pence, to 195.5 pence.

title: By the Book; Salads to Make Your Frisee Frizz
description: IN his latest book, ''Salad Days'' (Simon & Schuster Editions, $27.50), Marcel Desaulniers, the chef and co-owner of the Trellis in Williamsburg, Va., brings the same complexity and perfection to main-course salads that he did to chocolate in ''Death by Chocolate.'' In place of layers of ganache and disks of spongecake are rings of wheat berries and arugula and sweet glazes of late-harvest wine dressing.

title: CREDITORS OF BARNEY'S TERMINATE PURCHASE AGREEMENT
description: The creditors of Barney's Inc. announced yesterday that they had terminated Dickson Concepts International Ltd.'s $322 million agreement to buy the New York retailer. Dickson, a retail conglomerate based in Hong Kong, agreed to buy Barney's last year, but completion of that agreement stalled and the termination was expected. The creditors of Barney's now favor a reorganization plan to be filed soon by the retailer and its creditors. The plan would let Barney's emerge from Chapter 11 protection under the control of creditors and investors. Dickson is supposed to receive a $1.5 million breakup fee if its agreement to buy Barney's is terminated for any reason, plus an additional $6.5 million if Barney's receives a higher offer from another suitor.

title: Man Charged in Killing At a Birthday Party
description: A Penns Grove man was arrested Monday night and charged with killing an acquaintance during a shootout at a birthday party in a Gloucestor County hotel, county prosecutors said yesterday.

title: A Right to Anthrax?
description: To the Editor:

title: Feud With Harvard Diminishes Radcliffe
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants; Like Dining in a Private Club
description: BREAKFAST

title: In Bulgaria, Tiny Handguns Are Easy to Get
description: SOFIA  For an ordinary tourist  or a terrorist  few things could be easier in Bulgaria than buying a tiny handgun that looks like a key chain flashlight and can kill a man at close range.

title: With Drugs and Gangs Rife, Mexican Governor Resigns
description: A state Governor who faced growing citizen protests over the blatant local activities of kidnapping gangs and drug traffickers announced today that he was stepping down.

title: Temptation; Rejoicing in What a Quarter Will Get You Nowadays
description: YOU can spend that extra quarter on a one-bite candy at the cash register. Sometimes it will buy a banana or a tangerine. That's about it. Unless you head to the Bowery, just where that boulevard begins, near East Third Street.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SOLECTRON CORP., Milpitas, Calif., an electronics maker, said it would buy I.B.M.'s electronic-card assembly and test centers. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Albright Says U.S. Issues No Ultimatum To the Israelis
description: Insisting that the United States is not trying to impose a settlement on Israel, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright offered a broad defense of American policy in the Middle East today and urged Israel to move quickly to grab a chance for peace.

title: An anti-award ceremony that seeks to bury Madison Avenue, not praise it.
description: CRITICS who contend that advertising fosters an unfortunate consumerist culture among Americans had a field day last night, presenting counter-awards meant to dishonor Madison Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTERO, FRANK
description: MONTERO-Frank. We will miss the counsel and comradeship of our longtime chair, whose commitment to the African freedom struggle strengthened our own resolve. The Africa Fund

title: North Korea Says It Will Unseal Reactor
description: North Korean officials have announced that they are suspending their efforts to carry out the 1994 nuclear freeze agreement that was intended to dismantle that country's nuclear program. United States officials have said the program was intended to produce weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGHTER, SARAH WILLIAMS
description: RIGHTER-Sarah Williams. Age 90, May 9, 1998. Of Bedford Hills, NY. Beloved wife for 67 years of Volney F. Righter. Mother of James and Robert. Also survived by two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Funeral service on Wednesday, May 13, at 3PM at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, NY. Interment St. Matthew's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22, Katonah, NY 10536, 914-232-9555.

title: Shadowing the Man Who Has Made '60 Minutes' Last for Decades
description: Using techniques that generations of television news producers have picked up from Don Hewitt, tonight's ''American Masters'' pursues the making of a ''60 Minutes'' story or two from the initial idea to the final editing. That Mr. Hewitt, the presiding genius of the longest-running, most popular and by far the best of the news magazines, belongs in the television pantheon is no revelation, and ''Don Hewitt: 90 Minutes on '60 Minutes' '' catches the personality of the man and his creation.

title: Business Travel; Air fares between the United States and Japan are falling, partly because of an aviation accord.
description: AIR fares between the United States and Japan have dropped dramatically in the last week, as most carriers have joined in a sale begun by UAL's United Airlines.

title: Nike Pledges to End Child Labor And Apply U.S. Rules Abroad
description: Bowing to pressure from critics who have tried to turn its famous shoe brand into a synonym for exploitation, Nike Inc. promised today to root out underage workers and require overseas manufacturers of its wares to meet strict United States health and safety standards.

title: Pataki Rushes to Replace CUNY Trustee for Vote on Remedial Classes
description: Hoping to win approval of a controversial measure to abolish remedial classes at the four-year colleges of the City University of New York, Gov. George E. Pataki is trying to speed approval of a new CUNY trustee to replace one who was opposed to the measure, an aide to the Governor said yesterday.

title: Koreans Arrest Ex-Head of Kia
description: The former head of South Korea's troubled Kia Motors, Kim Sun Hong, was arrested today on charges of embezzling 52.3 billion won ($37 million) in company funds and other wrongdoing.

title: HBO Talks With Lewis Intensify
description: HBO's negotiations to extend the contract of Lennox Lewis, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, have intensified and moved to London, where the two sides are meeting this week.

title: VENCOR TO EXIT HOSPICE AND HOME HEALTH BUSINESSES
description: Vencor Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its hospice care and home health care operations in separate deals as part of its plan to focus on nursing homes and related services. Financial terms of the deals were not disclosed. The closely held Vistacare USA Inc., based in Scottsdale, Ariz., agreed to buy Vencor's 21 hospice agencies. Caretenders Healthcorp, based in Louisville, Ky., agreed to buy 11 of Vencor's 21 home care agencies. Vencor, also based in Louisville, said businesses being sold accounted for less than 2 percent of its annual revenues of $3.11 billion. Its stock rose 18.75 cents, to $11.6875.

title: Fort James to Shut 2 Plants
description: The Fort James Corporation said today that it would close an aging food-wrap plant in Menasha, Wis., and a Houston plastic cutlery plant, eliminating 173 jobs, to trim costs and focus on its Dixie brand flatware. The plants employ 345, but some work will be moved elsewhere, adding 172 jobs. Fort James was formed when the James River Corporation acquired the Fort Howard Corporation.
