title: Ballet Bites, to the Tune of a Benefit
description: You know it's time to rethink the ballet-benefit formula when the star of the show is not in tights, much less a tutu.

title: Els Is Going for No. 3 At Buick Next Month
description: Understandably, the Buick Classic has become one of Ernie Els's favorite tournaments.

title: Bond Bonanza Amid Lilco Takeover
description: When the largest municipal bond issue in the nation's history went on sale this week, the telephones at the David Lerner Associates brokerage headquarters here began lighting up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, SEYMOUR
description: FREEDMAN-Seymour. Beloved husband of Mickey. Devoted father of Jeffrey, Lisa and Chris. Adored grandfather of Rebecca, Matthew and Nicole. Dear brother of Arthur. Services Wednesday, 10AM, at the Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park.

title: U.S. Blundered On Intelligence, Officials Admit
description: The United States' inability to foresee or forestall India's nuclear tests, despite ample warnings, was a failure of both the Central Intelligence Agency and American foreign policymakers, Government officials said today.

title: Hoping For Bigger Than Big
description: It's still days before the film's release, but the cultural airwaves are thick with the double message that Godzilla, the monster, is bigger than any of its celluloid predecessors, and that ''Godzilla,'' the movie, will be huge at the box office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITHERS, CHARLES F.
description: SMITHERS-Charles F., 82, died May 8, 1998 in Fort Pierce, FL. He was a native of New York City and and a resident of Lynbrook and Copake Falls, NY, and spent his winters in South Hutchinson Island. Mr. Smithers attended New York University and served in the Merchant Marines during WWII. He developed his own contracting business and was fondly referred to as ''Smitty.'' He devoted 56 years to the Lynbrook Vulcan Chemical and Hose Fire Company where he was affectionately referred to as ''Lucky'' and was granted the title of Honorary Chief. He demonstrated his commitment and love of community mentoring young men who admired him for his dedication, sense of humor, intelligence and unique ability to bridge generations. Charlie was a man who symbolized values. His essence of life was in his commitment to the family. The love and comfort in his life were his wife of 57 years, Dorothy, daughters, Nancy Hescheles and Janet Virkus and sonin-law David; four grandchildren, Kimberly, Matthew, Jennifer and Jessica. He was an influential and powerful figure in all their lives. Memorial services will be held at a later date in Lynbrook, NY.

title: Liberties; As I Told Madeleine . . .
description: There is no more entertaining spectacle than an ego endlessly exfoliating.

title: Attorney General Agrees To Discuss Police Action
description: The State Attorney General has agreed to meet with black ministers to discuss allegations that state police troopers stop drivers based on their race.

title: Gay Groups Celebrate New Rights Bill
description: Many gay and lesbian groups spent yesterday celebrating Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's bill to make domestic partners equal to spouses in the eyes of the city, and critics used the occasion to issue an obituary of his hopes for national office.

title: Runaway NATO Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Lipinski: Hard Sell for a Soft Drink
description: Tara Lipinski endorsed Minute Maid before the Winter Olympics, but now the reigning women's Olympic figure skating champion has jumped to Snapple, which is making her the face of its new line of Refreshers drinks.

title: Knick Victory? Isn't It Pretty To Think So?
description: Logic was posting the Knicks up today, backing them in deep and talking more truth than trash.

title: Sanitation Workers Approve Salary Deal
description: The union representing New York City sanitation workers overwhelmingly approved a deal yesterday that contains productivity incentives for employees who pick up more trash and recyclables than they do now.

title: John Hancock Insurance Switching to Stock Company
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company announced a structural change yesterday that is expected to provide a windfall for its four million policyholders and, management hopes, help strengthen the company's position as a leading insurer.

title: Doctor Says Murders Were Ignited by Job Rejection
description: A psychiatrist who examined a man accused of murdering three people in a Brooklyn social club testified yesterday that the defendant, a former jail guard, told him that the victims were killed after he had been rejected for a management or ownership position at the club.

title: Judge Merges 2 Trials in Racial Beating Case
description: A judge announced today that he would merge the retrial of Austin Offen, a Queens man, with the trial of Constantine Chronis, a former New York City police officer. They are accused in a racially charged beating outside a nightclub in Westhampton Beach.

title: Feud With Harvard Diminishes Radcliffe
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau Police Lead a Drive to Stem Growing Gang Violence
description: Six weeks after a 21-year-old immigrant from El Salvador was shot and killed here in a confrontation with a rival Salvadoran street gang, Nassau County officials announced today that they were forming a rare partnership with Federal and local agencies to stem the growing problem of gang crime.

title: Senate Democrats Praise a Bill by D'Amato, Then Try to Bury It
description: A casual observer might have been excused for feeling confused. On the floor of the Senate, Democrats were rising to applaud legislation proposed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Long Island Republican who is facing a fierce battle for re-election this fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, ALBERT (ALBIE)
description: MYERS-Albert (Albie). Age 79. On May 11, 1998. Beloved husband of Norma (Nathel). Devoted father of Ronald and Lance. Father-inlaw to Jill (Yagoda) and cherished grandfather of Danielle and Hillary. He was a giving and loving man who will be greatly missed. We will remember him always. Funeral service Thursday, May 14th, 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Four Universities Announce Recipients of Journalism Fellowships
description: Four universities have named the recipients of journalism fellowships for the 1998-99 academic year. Applicants for the grants, which are awarded to senior and midcareer journalists, are judged on the basis of past performance and future promise. The fellowships involve a range of study options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIS, HERBERT, M.D.
description: CHASIS-Herbert, M.D. Age 92. Professor of Medicine, New York University School of Medicine. Died peacefully on May 11, 1998. Survived by wife Barbara Parker, daughers Joel Anne and Sarah, grandsons Dan and Garrett Roll, Jonathan Hiles, and granddaughter Rachel Hiles. Services private. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions may be made to NYU School of Medicine for the Herbert Chasis Memorial Fund.

title: T CELL SCIENCES IN $70 MILLION DEAL FOR VIRUS RESEARCH
description: T Cell Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company that uses immunology to prevent and treat disease, will buy Virus Research Institute Inc. for $70 million in stock and warrants, the companies said yesterday. Shareholders in Virus Research, which develops vaccines and designs ways to deliver others, will receive 1.55 T Cell shares and two-tenths of a warrant for each share of common stock. The companies did not break out how much the warrants were worth and used T Cell's closing price on Friday to value the transaction. The combined company will be called Avant Immunotherapeutics Inc. Shares in T Cell, based in Needham, Mass., fell 70.31 cents, to 3.5468. The stock of Virus Research, based in Cambridge, Mass., rose $1.25, or 36 percent, to $4.6875.

title: Once Modern, Now 20th-Century: New Category Attracts Strong Bidding
description: Labels really don't matter. In the art market today, where demand far outweighs supply, a painting, drawing or sculpture of reasonably good quality will draw strong prices, especially in an auction room where the spirit of competitive biddding can gently push prices skyward.

title: Fiery Youth Entrapped In Choreographic Parable
description: The New York City Ballet offered a choreographically rich and well-danced program on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater. But the matinee was dominated by Damian Woetzel's powerful performance in the title role of George Balanchine's ''Prodigal Son.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHKIN, DR. WILLIAM
description: ASHKIN-Dr. William. The Town Club announces with profound sorrow the death of our esteemed member. Bernard Friedman, President Irving Friedman, Chairman of the Board

title: How a Gangsta Rapper Turns Entrepreneur; At 28, Master P Has Created One Of the Biggest Independent Labels
description: Percy Miller sat behind the large oak desk in his office here recently, wearing a pound of gold jewelry and a bulletproof vest and playing one gangsta rap song after another from his forthcoming album, ''Da Last Don.'' Record retailers say the album is a shoo-in to hit No. 1 on the pop charts when it is released next month, but Mr. Miller says it will be his last as a solo artist. He wants to concentrate on being an entertainment executive.

title: Six Ways to Get the Best of a Feisty Lobster
description: ALTHOUGH lobster is sweet and irresistible now, lobster aficionados like Jasper White believe that a good lobster can be made at any time of year. It's a matter of knowing the character of your lobster and choosing a cooking technique that will bring out the best in it. With that in mind, Mr. White embarked on a whirlwind demonstration of six approaches, offering tips along the way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLINTOCK, MARGOT K.
description: McCLINTOCK-Margot K. On May 11, 1998 of Solebury, Pa. Wife of the late Franklin T. Mother of Robert O.; grandmother of Moira and sister of Charles deBruyn Kops. Services will be 2pm Thursday at Solbury Friends Meetinghouse, Sugan and Meetinghouse Roads, Solbury, Pa. Contributions to Trinity Episcopal Church, Route 263, Solbury, Pa. 18963.

title: The Glorious Prime Of the Atlantic Lobster
description: MOST lobster lovers turn manic in mid-May when, for six slender weeks, the king of Atlantic crustaceans is hard shelled, gloriously sweet -- and so plentiful that its price can dip from the nearly prohibitive to the very possible.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of the House & Home section on Thursday about a sale of antique Tibetan furniture at ABC Carpet and Home misstated the given name of the store's creative director. She is Paulette Cole, not Paula.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MACGREGOR, SIR IAN
description: MacGREGOR-Sir Ian. There will be a memorial service for Sir Ian MacGregor on Friday, May 15, 1998, 11AM at Saint Bartholomew's Church, 109 E. 50 St, NYC.

title: From the Fringes, Post-Punkers Rant Against 'Alternative'
description: Watching the young members of Modest Mouse careen around the Tramps stage on Sunday night, it was possible to imagine that ''alternative'' had never happened. That marketing category is a curse that bands like this trio -- the brightest new group from the Pacific Northwest that fed the category in the early 1990's -- strive to lift. This is especially true now that alternative's veteran bands and generic inheritors, from Pearl Jam to Verve Pipe, are on the down slope of cultural influence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, MAURICE ANTHONY
description: BRENNAN - Maurice Anthony. Passed away peacefully on May 9, 1998, at 91. Beloved husband of the late Emily Humphrey Brennan. Cherished father to Laraine. Father-in-law to Steven and beloved grandfather to Catherine, Tanya and Erin. Formerly of Little Neck, NY, he was born in Limerick, Ireland, and became a U.S. citizen in 1929. A Consolidated Edison employee for 47 years, he was a recipient of a medal from the National Safety Council for meritorious service and a founding member of the original Irish Theater Company that produced Sean O'Casey's plays on the site that is now Lincoln Center. An accomplished artist, a lover of Irish history and a scholar of nature, his gentle spirit and great wisdom will always guide us. We will miss you Pom Pom. For funeral arrangements, contact Jacob Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave., Maplewood, NJ, 973-762-2200.

title: Appeal Is Filed In Timmendequas Case
description: Lawyers for Jesse K. Timmendequas, the Hamilton Township man convicted last June for the rape and murder of 7-year-old Megan Kanka, have asked a state appeals court to overturn his death sentence or grant him a new trial.

title: City Is Sued By Woman Who Left Baby Outside
description: Last May, Anette Sorensen, a Danish tourist visiting New York City, was arrested for leaving her infant daughter in a stroller outside a Lower East Side restaurant where she and the child's father were dining. Ms. Sorensen was charged with endangering the welfare of a child, the child was placed in foster care for a few days, and city officials scolded the mother for ignoring American customs.

title: Home Loans Discriminate, Study Shows
description: Racial discrimination and abuse by lenders of a Federal mortgage program are helping to create pockets of blight in black and Hispanic neighborhoods, according to a study of lending in the Chicago area.

title: Jordan Is Key to Palestinian State; Israel Needs Assurances
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Mass Grave in Bosnia

title: More Nuclear Peril
description: Saying that the United States had failed to honor its promises, North Korean officials announced that they were suspending their efforts to carry out the 1994 nuclear freeze agreement intended to dismantle the country's nuclear program.

title: JAZZ
description: Talking the Talk: Musical Conversations Highlights in Jazz

title: Commuters Brace for Cab-Less Wednesday as Drivers Protest
description: By 1:30 P.M. yesterday, the dispatcher at Safeway Car Service in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, had stopped taking reservations. The company's 42 aqua Ford Crown Victorias had already been booked to ferry commuters around Manhattan this morning, including one car that was to go to Central Park West at 5:30 A.M. to pick up a doctor who is scheduled to perform surgery at a downtown hospital at 8 A.M.

title: Indonesian Riot Police Open Fire At Protests, Killing Six Students
description: Security forces killed six students and wounded at least a dozen others when they opened fire on a demonstration that had spilled from a college campus onto a major highway here on Tuesday, witnesses said.

title: Taxi Strike Looms
description: As the city's yellow cab drivers threatened a 24-hour work stoppage starting today to protest proposed changes in taxi regulations, drivers of livery cabs prepared for a jump in business. Skittish riders reserved many of the cars.

title: Mets Add A Catcher But Don't Get to Play
description: Who needs a divining rod? Just follow the Mets from coast to coast, and chances are you'll get wet.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about the peace agreement for Northern Ireland, showing a poster advocating approval, carried an incorrect caption in some editions. It showed Sir Richard Needham, a supporter, and three unidentified men, not five opponents.

title: PRIMARK CANNOT FIND BUYER AND WILL REPURCHASE SHARES
description: The Primark Corporation, a financial information provider that was considering buyout offers, said yesterday that it could not find a buyer to pay its price and would now repurchase 15 percent of its stock to soothe investors. Primark will buy back four million shares, and possibly more, in a ''Dutch auction,'' for no less than $34 a share and not more than $41.50. Its stock rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $34.50. Shares of Primark, based in Waltham, Mass., climbed more than 60 percent in the last year as investors bet the company would follow through on an effort to find a buyer. In a Dutch auction, the company sets a price range within which shareholders can tender their stock. The final price is the highest price necessary to obtain all the shares it wants.

title: Free Fall Not Seen for the Pound Despite Soros Rumblings
description: George Soros, the man who broke the Bank of England six years ago, is said to be betting against pound sterling once again. Does that mean it's deja vu for currency investors?

title: Deutsche Telekom Plans Rescue of Unit
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. said today that it would set aside as much as 4.5 billion marks ($2.5 billion) this year to cover the cost of its money-losing cable TV operation after a regulator rejected its attempt to raise fees.

title: Roots of Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title: Reno's Move Underscores Paradox in Counsel Act
description: At first glance, Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to seek an independent counsel to investigate Labor Secretary Alexis Herman seems to turn the special prosecutor statute on its head.

title: It's Like a 'Seinfeld' Episode; An Obsessive-Compulsive Concern With Nothing Much
description: The magazine that has rented Bill Nikolakis's place for a party tomorrow night wants to rip out the plastic-topped tables and the vinyl benches and hang big television monitors from the ceiling. You got a problem with that?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTTIERES, JEN
description: GUTTIERES-Jen. On May 9, 1998. She is survived by her loving son Alexander and dear brother Philip Mariani. Funeral Mass at Saint John the Evangelist, 55th Street and 1st Ave, NYC, Thursday, May 14th 11AM. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery. Donations in Jen's memory may be made to Saint John the Evangelist.

title: House Is Set To Revisit Bill On Bank Rules
description: The House is expected to revisit on Wednesday legislation that would rewrite the nation's banking laws and allow for new combinations of financial services companies. For more than two decades, and on 11 different tries, similar measures have come before Congress only to be defeated by a welter of conflicting financial interest groups.

title: Danone Dairy Account Now All Under Y.& R.
description: Groupe Danone in Paris yesterday named Young & Rubicam Inc. to handle its worldwide consolidated dairy products account, according to executives who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Billings were estimated at $250 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESAR, JOE
description: MESAR-Joe. We are greatly saddened by the untimely passing of Joe Mesar, Financial Secretary of the National Organization of Legal Services Workers. Joe was not only a client to us, but was a good friend over these past twenty years. We are going to miss him terribly. However, in the immortal words of Joe Hill, ''We will not mourn, we will organize.'' Eisner & Hubbard, P.C.

title: Intuit Executive To Become Chief
description: Intuit Inc., the maker of personal-finance software, said today that it planned to promote William Harris to president and chief executive, succeeding William Campbell, who will become chairman.

title: Suissa Miller Joins Roster at Schwab
description: Charles Schwab & Company has expanded its agency roster by naming Suissa Miller in Los Angeles to handle advertising for what is known as its core brokerage services. Billings were initially estimated at $20 million and may grow to as much as $30 million to $40 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARCH, DAVID JOSEPH ANTHONY
description: SARCH-David Joseph Anthony, October 27, 1940 - May 9, 1998: On May 9 suddenly, at home, of a heart attack. Loved immensely by Ros, Louise and Terri, his family and all his many friends throughout the world. A highly respected lawyer and advisor-a great loss to his profession. Mr. Sarch will be profoundly missed. Funeral will be held at The Priory Church of St. Gregory the Great, 10 St. James Square, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, on Saturday May 16, 1998 at 11:30am. Flowers very welcome to Selim Smith & Co, 74 Prestbury Rd, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire GL52 2DJ: Tel (01242) 525383.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSACK, YVONNE
description: CUSACK-Yvonne. On May 5, 1998. Beloved wife of Maurice Cusack. Memorial service to be held Thursday, May 21st, 3:30PM at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave at 66 St, NYC.

title: India Glows With Pride As Outrage Rises Abroad
description: The Indian Government won overwhelming support at home today for three nuclear tests it conducted in the desert on Monday, but senior officials hinted that they might try to soften the international outcry against them by considering signing the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWARTNER, JACK
description: KWARTNER-Jack. The Board of Directors and Officers of the American Red Magen David for Israel (ARMDI) Southeast Region mourn the passing of Jack Kwartner, beloved humanitarian, philanthropist and life-long friend of Magen David Adom and the people of Israel. His generous contributions to his beloved State of Israel include 65 fully equipped MDA ambulances and a wing of the MDA National Blood Center in Ramat Gan, Israel. He will be sorely missed by his legion of friends and admirers in Israel and the United States. We extend our deepest sympathy to his dear wife Irene and children. Joel Wilentz, M.D., President Seymour Brief, Chrman Emeritus William F. Brown, Chairman Robert L. Schwartz, Exec Dir.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Face to Drink To

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about the first concert in the American Festival of Microtonal Music on Thursday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University referred incorrectly to one of the works on the program. Virgil Moorfield's ''(Slight Return)'' is scored for violin, cello, baritone sax, electric guitar and a synthesizer, not solely for electronic instruments.

title: In Phoneland, It Gets Lonely At the Middle
description: When is huge not big enough?

title: CLINTON TO IMPOSE PENALTIES ON INDIA OVER ATOMIC TESTS
description: President Clinton decided tonight to impose a raft of economic sanctions on India's Government on Wednesday for detonating three underground nuclear explosions, senior Administration officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILFEN, ETHEL
description: SILFEN-Ethel. On May 11, 1998. Age 84. of Hallandale FL, formerly of Woodmere NY. Beloved wife of the late Joe, loving mother of Ellen (Marty) Wohl and the late George. Dear sister of Dale (Rod) Spirn, Sid (Claire) Fersten, and the late Nat (Bea) Feierstein. Adoring grandmother of Amy Wohl, Sheri (Roy) Lapidus. Proud great grandmother of Carly. Services at Mt.Hebron Wednesday, 2PM.

title: Metro Business; Luxury Rentals Planned
description: A records storehouse in the financial district of Manhattan has been sold for $4 million to the Barrington Development Corporation of Manhattan, which plans to spend more than $8 million to convert the building into 113 luxury studio and one-bedroom rental apartments.

title: Hermann Lenz, 85, Author Of the 'Swabian Chronicle'
description: Hermann Lenz, who sprang from decades of obscurity to become one of modern Germany's most significant and prolific authors, died today in Munich, his publisher, Suhrkamp, said.

title: CUNY and California Curbs: Parallels in Approach
description: The call by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki to end three decades of remedial education and open admissions at the City University's four-year colleges carries strong parallels to the University of California's decision to abolish affirmative action in admissions.

title: The Minimalist; When Flavor Is of the Essence
description: REDUCTION sauces are made by boiling solids in liquids, concentrating the juice until little more than an essence remains. The most common example involves splashing water into a skillet after you've roasted or sauteed meat or vegetables in it. The water gathers up the remaining bits, all of which have been nicely browned, and absorbs their flavor. As the quantity of water reduces, the flavor becomes more concentrated and the water is transformed into a sauce.

title: Calendar
description: Summer Wine Preview

title: SGS-Thomson Hopes To Raise $267 Million
description: GS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V. said yesterday that it would sell new stock worth an estimated 1.6 billion francs ($267 million) to finance growth in expectation of better demand for semiconductors later this year. The company, Europe's second-biggest chip maker after Royal Philips Electronics N.V., said it would sell three million new shares in the United States and France, and majority shareholders, French and Italian state-controlled companies, would sell 16 million of their shares. Shares of SGS-Thomson fell on the prospect of the new shares. The United States shares fell $2.625, to $83.75, in New York.

title: Buyout Funds Exploring Bid For Polygram
description: Forstmann Little & Company and the Thomas H. Lee Company, two of the nation's largest leveraged buyout funds, are weighing a bid for Polygram N.V., the giant music company, several people close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: 684 Graduate at Parsons In Graphic Arts
description: After 12 consecutive days of rain, it was a clear morning for the 684 graduates of the Parsons School of Design, and the school's acting dean, Lesley A. Cadman, reminded the students yesterday at the school's 102d commencement how their education had prepared them for creative jobs in the graphic arts.

title: 2 IN TEXACO CASE FOUND NOT GUILTY
description: Two former executives of Texaco Inc. who had been taped discussing the destruction of documents demanded in a racial-discrimination lawsuit against the company were found not guilty yesterday on charges they had tried to obstruct justice.

title: Jordan Is Key to Palestinian State; Netanyahu's Realpolitik
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, ZELDY
description: APPEL-Zeldy July 23, 1916 - May 8, 1998. A sparkling star flashed her eternal light-streaked across the heavens for a moment-now in our hearts forever. Family asks that donations go to the Fresh Air Fund, NYC. Memorial May 24, 1998. For details contact family members in FL.

title: A Nuclear Threat From India
description: India's explosion of three nuclear devices in the Rajasthan desert makes the world a more dangerous place. By arrogantly challenging international efforts to control the spread of the most lethal weapons, the new Hindu nationalist Government of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee may win applause at home from those who confuse military might with self-esteem. But for a paltry and short-lived domestic gain, India now faces a ruinous cutoff in foreign aid, a self-defeating arms race with Pakistan and isolation even from friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKMORE, CLARA
description: ROCKMORE-Clara. On May 10, 1998, at the age of 88. Violin protege of Leopold Auer, pre-eminent virtuoso of the Theremin, now reunited with her pianist sister, Nadia Reisenberg. Mourned by her other beloved sister, Anna Sherman, her nephews Alexander, Robert and Ron, their children and the family of her late husband, Robert Rockmore. Services on Wednesday, May 13, 12 noon at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, LEWIS
description: PHILLIPS-Lewis died peacefully in East Hampton on May 10, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Barbara T. Phillips. Devoted father of Amy Penn, Michael, and Samantha D'Olivera. Beloved grandfather of Gabriel, Eli and Sophia.Beloved brother of Brenda P.Ballin. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: About New York; CUNY Cure That Lacks A Disease
description: THERE have been times in Peter Sylver's life when he would be puzzled by his fate. It happened in the late 1980's when, after graduating from high school, he was breaking his back in highway construction, sweating and smarting alongside rivers of hot tar.

title: Off the Menu
description: A New Delmonico's

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDINE, SYLVIA (BLOCK)
description: BEDINE-Sylvia (Block). Of Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Hewlett, N.Y. ON May 11, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Alexander, loving mother of Barbara Menachem, and Marshall and Richard Bedine, sister of Sidney Block, cherished grandmother of Jeffrey, Matthew and Jeremy Bedine, Andrew, Fred, Seth and Mara Menachem, Marc and Zachary Bedine. Her legacy is a deep and enthusiastic lifelong dedication to her family. Memorial contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society. Funeral services to be at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL. Interment at Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, Boynton Beach, FL.

title: CAROLINA FIRST TO EXPAND IN STATE WITH $57 MILLION DEAL
description: The Carolina First Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held First National Bank of Pickens County for $57 million in stock, expanding its business in South Carolina. First National Bank of Pickens County operates four branches in the county and has $120 million in assets. Carolina First, based in Greenville, S.C., operates 64 banking offices throughout the state and has assets of $2.3 billion. First Carolina plans to exchange 1.994 million of its shares in total. The stock closed yesterday at $27.50, down 93.75 cents.

title: He Still Has the Touch: Bird Named Top Coach
description: When Larry Bird interviewed his former teammate Rick Carlisle for the job of assistant coach for the Pacers last summer, he wound up on the other end of the interrogation process.

title: Speech and the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: Ad Agency Urges Avoiding Black and Hispanic Radio
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton yesterday accused 10 companies of withholding advertising dollars from New York City radio stations because they cater to black and Hispanic listeners, and he threatened to organize a boycott against them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUGLIESE, REV. JOSEPH B.
description: PUGLIESE-Rev. Joseph B. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the former administrator of St. Benedict the Moor Church, Jamaica. Reposing in Walsh/LaBella Funeral Home, 8713 87th St., Woodhaven, Thursday, May 14, from 1-4 and 7-10 pm. Funeral Mass in St. Thomas Apostle Church, 87-19 88th Ave, Woodhaven, Friday, May 15, at 10:30 am. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: U.S. Offers Defense Of Policy in Mideast
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright yesterday offered a broad defense of American policy in the Middle East and insisted that the United States was not trying to impose a settlement on Israel.

title: Wells Brushes Back Doubters in Victory
description: Neither David Wells nor Bernie Williams would admit it, but both were fortunate last night because they found a team that could provide them some relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGLER, RUTH
description: HAGLER-Ruth. The Malverne Jewish Center records the passing of our charter member and friend, Ruth Hagler. Condolences to Murray and family. Barry J. Chesler, Rabbi Murray Greenspan, President

title: Judge Rejects Leniency for Bomb-Plot Witness
description: A Federal judge today rejected a plea for leniency for Michael J. Fortier, who testified against the men convicted in the Oklahoma City bombing after failing to warn the authorities of the plot.

title: Clintons' Assets Rise, but Debts Rise Faster
description: The financial holdings of President and Mrs. Clinton, fueled by a rising stock market, grew last year, according to a financial disclosure form released today. But their legal bills from the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit and the Whitewater investigation rose even faster, threatening to swamp them with debt.

title: In Community Used to Floods, River Rises Again
description: It was getting close to 4 o'clock on this dank afternoon, just about time for Frank Crozier to pick up his wife, Betty, from grocery shopping. So Mr. Crozier, who lives in Hoffman Grove, a hamlet of old bungalows along the Pompton River here, put on his green rubber wading pants and set out to cross the flood waters surrounding his house in a blue canoe named The Last Resort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWLEY, KATHARINE T.
description: CROWLEY-Katharine T. May 12, 1998. Survived only by her nieces and nephews. Memorial Service Friday, May 15th in Farmington, MI. Interment Holy Sepulchre Mausoleum, Southfield, MI. Memorial tributes to Angela Hospice, 14100 Newburgh Rd, Livonia, MI 48154. Heeney-Sundquist Funeral Home, Farmington, MI 248474-5200

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of the House & Home section on Thursday about a sale of antique Tibetan furniture at ABC Carpet and Home misstated the given name of the store's creative director. She is Paulette Cole, not Paula.

title: U.S. Reportedly Backed British Mercenary Group in Africa
description: A British mercenary force that helped carry out military operations in Sierra Leone this year kept the Clinton Administration fully informed of its activities and had its tacit support, the military group and a senior Administration official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLED, LOU
description: SOLED-Lou. Died peacefully on May 10, 1998 in North Miami Beach, FL. Formerly of Bayside, NY. Beloved husband of Selma. Loving father of Gerard (Brenda), Stephen (Ronni) and the late Carol (Cohen). Grandfather of Amanda and Julie.

title: German Analysts See Slight Rise in Rates
description: German interest rates will rise only slightly before the introduction of European currency union next year, with three-month money market rates staying about 4 percent in 1999, Germany's six leading economic research institutes said yesterday in their semiannual assessment of the economy. Currency union members with higher rates, such as Italy, Spain, Portugal and Ireland, will have to bring their interest rates down to meet German levels, the institutes said.

title: ANTITRUST ACTION AGAINST MICROSOFT IS CALLED IMMINENT
description: Only three days before it is scheduled to begin shipping Windows 98, the Microsoft Corporation is girding for an escalating round of lawsuits that could block the release of the latest version of its operating system and impose profound limits on the company's freedom to add features to future generations of Windows.

title: Sagas of the Future From the Icelandic Diva
description: With her forehead and the bridge of her nose painted white and her matching vinyl dress equipped with pleated wings, Bjork Gudmundsdottir accomplished her latest metamorphosis at the Hammerstein Ballroom Monday night. ''I don't recognize myself,'' sang the cutting-edge Icelandic diva as an eight-piece string section conjured a lush grove entangled by the beats and blips emerging from Mark Bell's bank of machines. ''This is very interesting.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDEN, SIMON L.
description: GARDEN-Simon L. On May 11, 1998 in his 95th year. Husband of the late Florence. Cherished father of Amoree Beckman Blasenheim and Iris & Jerry Schwartzbaum. Proud grandfather of Joel & Shari, Karen, and Eric Beckman; Marilyn & Bill Graber; David & Rena Schwartzbaum. Loving great-grandfather of seven.

title: Tougher Aircraft Scrutiny
description: The Federal Aviation Administration displayed good reflexes last week when it was confronted with fuel-pump wiring problems in older Boeing 737's. It ordered inspections of all the oldest airliners -- those with more than 50,000 hours of flight -- within seven days when faulty wiring was discovered in a Continental Airlines 737. When new cases of damaged wiring appeared, the agency grounded those planes. The F.A.A.'s performance in this emergency underscores the need for a broader program for inspecting all older aircraft. The objective would be to discover or anticipate unseen defects in wiring and other non-structural systems before a mechanic spots them.

title: Lucent Lists Charges For 2 Acquisitions
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. expects to take $668 million in charges this quarter for its acquisitions of the networking equipment maker Yurie Systems Inc. and the German software maker Optimay G.m.b.H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JAMES A.
description: HENRY-James A. Beloved husband of Carole Wiley Henry. Loving father of Julie and Judd. Dear step-father of Dina and David. Cherished grandfather. Services Thursday, May 14, 1998, 1PM, at Congregation Col Ami (JCC), 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY.

title: The Art of the Fugue, With a Ballet
description: Olli Mustonen needs to be saved from himself. He is an interesting player and an interesting programmer: his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon proceeded through the first book of Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier,'' substituting preludes and fugues from Shostakovich's Opus 87 half the time, and a lot of it was absorbing and extraordinary.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the increasing turnover of suburban school superintendents misstated the expiration date for the doctoral candidacy of Judith Sarris Conk, the Superintendent in Glen Ridge, N.J. Her candidacy, at Teachers College of Columbia University, expired in 1988, not 1984.

title: The Latest Bipartisan Effort: No-Holds-Barred Donations
description: Republicans and Democrats are aggressively expanding their efforts to raise and spend the largely unregulated political contributions known as soft money, even suing Federal elections officials in an attempt to remove the last restrictions on those donations.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Herbert Waide Hemphill Jr., Folk Art Collector, Dies at 69
description: Herbert Waide Hemphill Jr., a collector and curator whose passion for American folk art helped redefine the field, died on Friday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 69 and lived in Manhattan.

title: F.B.I. Says 2 Men Joined Robber on Run
description: Federal agents have arrested two men who they say bumped into a bank robber on a street in downtown Princeton in November and took money to help him escape, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend on May 1 about a show of Alex Katz's landscape paintings at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, misidentified the editor of the artist's recent autobiography, ''Alex Katz: Invented Symbols'' (Cantz). He was Vincent Katz, the artist's son. (Rolf Lauter is editor of the series that includes it.)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Moscow Journal; Yeltsin Takes to the Internet for a Half-Hour Chat
description: ''Good day, citizens of the Internet,'' the salutation began. ''This is my first live Internet experience.''

title: Yankees Not Winning at Gate
description: The winningest team in the major leagues sold only 16,606 tickets for last night's opener of a nine-game homestand.

title: On-the-Job Training
description: It has become a little like Republican Lotto, hasn't it? We speak of the business of getting plucked from obscurity to run for lieutenant governor of New York State. If Gov. George Pataki owned the job, his blend of cynicism and whimsy might be acceptable. But this is the second-highest constitutional office in the state, and with all respect to Mr. Pataki's reported running mate, a novice upstate judge named Mary Donohue, the people deserve a more serious process.

title: U.S. Urges Indonesia To Reform
description: The United States said tonight that Indonesia needs to undergo ''political reform'' if it is to have any hope of regaining stability, the first public insistence from Washington that President Suharto loosen his iron grip on the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, CHALA
description: RUBIN-Chala. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved mother of its devoted member, Wolf Rubin. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President

title: REIT Buys Office Complex
description: Brandywine Realty Trust said today that it had bought a complex of office buildings in Camp Hill, Pa., and Harrisburg, Pa., for $48.5 million. Brandywine Realty, a real estate investment trust, said it had also bought a 17-story office building, One Christina Centre, in Wilmington, Del., for $41.6 million. Brandywine Realty, based in Newtown Square, had 1997 revenues of $61 million.

title: Newspaper Refuses to Reveal Sources on Bombing Suspect
description: Defying a state judge's order, reporters and editors at The Atlanta Journal-Constitution will not identify its anonymous sources for articles that named Richard A. Jewell as a suspect in the bombing of Centennial Olympic Park during the 1996 Summer Games.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; An accounting method favored in mergers may get a new name
description: WALL STREET deal makers have come to count on a certain accounting method almost as much as they count on bubbles in their celebratory champagne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNE, GLADYS L.
description: BROWNE-Gladys L. May 7, 1998. Survived by sisters Shirley Evans of Pownal, VT and Geraldine Bemis of Hanson, MA, and many nieces, nephews and friends.

title: Childs Discounts One-Shot Theory
description: The open 3-pointer by Reggie Miller, which sent the game into overtime and the Knicks to defeat, is the enduring memory from Game 4 Sunday at Madison Square Garden. But Chris Childs, who left Miller unguarded to try to help defend Mark Jackson on the play, said today that responsibility for the loss went beyond one single possession.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Government Antitrust Push Against Microsoft Picks Up

title: Nissan to License Technology to Daimler
description: One day after announcing it was discussing ''business tie-ups'' with Daimler-Benz A.G., the Nissan Motor Company said it would license pickup truck manufacturing technology to the German industrial giant, which shocked the world last week with a deal to acquire the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBACH, GRETE (NEE WEILHEIMER)
description: LEBACH-Grete (nee Weilheimer), 88, on May 10, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Erich. Beloved mother of Dorothy and Joan. Adored Oma of Netanya. Services Wednesday, May 13, 1 P.M., at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY. Any contributions to Temple Beth El.

title: A Blast of Reality
description: It may be difficult to acknowledge, but India's test of three nuclear devices on Monday morning was, among other things, an act of impatience with failed American efforts to stop China and North Korea from developing and spreading strategic weapons. ''It is clear that by the time the Clinton Administration wakes up to the danger posed by the China-Pakistan-North Korean axis, it will be too late for India,'' The Times of India said on Tuesday.

title: A Filmmaker's Family Faces Mental Illness
description: SO, a nice chat about mental illness,'' the director Alan J. Pakula said yesterday, settling in for an interview in his apartment on the Upper East Side. ''What a nice way to start the day.''

title: Jordan Is Key to Palestinian State; The Bully Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Intimate Burdens Of the One Left Behind
description: SPEAKING WITH STRANGERS

title: Haskins Quit Over Budget, Security
description: Ray Haskins, who resigned unexpectedly as Long Island University's basketball coach on Monday, said the parting was amicable. But John Suarez, the athletic director, acknowledged yesterday that the school and Haskins had different ideas about where the program should be headed.

title: Wal-Mart Profit Beats Estimates
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. reported a better-than-expected 27 percent increase in fiscal first-quarter earnings yesterday, as the chain cut inventory and consumers snapped up low-priced household goods and Easter baskets.

title: Sports of The Times; Larry Bird Almost Runs A Democracy
description: DONNIE WALSH, who wanted Larry Bird as his coach 90 minutes after he met him, tells this story about the coach of the year:

title: 'Monster' and 'Wise Man' Share Mannes's Stage
description: For its final production of the season, the Mannes Opera -- the opera department of the Mannes College of Music -- presented ''The Monster Bed'' and ''The Other Wise Man,'' by Stefania de Kenessey, at the school on Sunday evening. Ms. de Kenessey, who was a student of Milton Babbitt, has clearly rejected the rigors of Mr. Babbitt's style in favor of tonality and old-fashioned lyricism, and she advocates that position in the Derriere Guard, the group she founded recently with like-minded (''traditionalist,'' as she puts it) composers, poets, artists and architects.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Today, I've been working since 5 A.M. I had four hours sleep. I'm working intensively. I still have a long day ahead of me, and it does not affect either my appearance or my energy.''

title: $25 and Under; Two Out of Three (Food, Price, Service) Isn't Bad
description: WITH terrifically inviting food at moderate prices, Ribollita has a lot going for it. It's almost the kind of casual restaurant that any neighborhood would love to call its own. I say almost because Ribollita has significant service problems that can drive away customers even as they are trying to embrace the restaurant.

title: Experts Take a 2d Look At Virtue of Student Jobs
description: Shane Jones sometimes catches a nap in class at Morgan Park High School, where he is an honor roll student. The reason is not boredom, he explains, but his job -- ''the best job I ever had.''

title: BMW to Invest More In Sport Utility Area
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. said yesterday that it would invest a total of $600 million to develop a new sports utility vehicle in the United States. BMW said it would hire 1,000 more workers and invest $400 million in its Spartanburg, S.C., plant in the next two years to meet the growing United States demand for sport utility vehicles. BMW makes its popular two-seat Z3 roadster at the Spartanburg plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERSTANDIG, WILLIAM
description: VERSTANDIG - William. Oldest and most treasured friend, we shall never forget you. Condolences to entire Verstandig family from Birnbach families of New York and Tel Aviv.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about the New York Liberal Party's choice of Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross as its candidate for governor misspelled the surname of a physician assistant she met during a campaign stop at a Manhattan clinic and misstated the name of the clinic. The physician assistant was Tonia Poteat, not Poteati. The clinic is the Michael Callen/Audrey Lorde Community Health Center, not the Callen/Lorde Mental Health Center.

title: 'Look to the Cookie': An Ode in Black and White
description: THE characters on ''Seinfeld'' did not eat well, but they ate very New York. The ''Seinfeld'' diet was an Upper West Side smorgasbord of cheap eats: Chinese takeout, soup in a paper cup, rye bread, gyros, pizza, muffins and calzones. The piece de resistance, however, the New Yorkiest bit of food in television's New Yorkiest series, was the oversize black-and-white cookie, a New York standby that is sold in bakeries and delis all over the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIMES, MADELAINE (MADY)
description: HAIMES-Madelaine (Mady). Dearest beloved wife for 51 years of Alex. Ever loving mother of Ted and Barbara. Devoted daughter to the late Willy and Anna Reiner. Fond aunt to many nieces and nephews. Services 11AM Thursday May 14, Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue. Family will receive Wednesday evening, 6-8:30PM at Chapel.

title: Korean Banks Weigh Response to Crisis
description: South Korean banks said yesterday that they would decide by the end of June whether to let dozens of the country's industrial groups collapse or keep them alive with new loans. The banks, led by Commercial Bank of Korea, will assign all companies one of three grades: normal, savable and nonviable, the bank said. ''For the first two groups, we will seek ways to turn them around,'' the bank said. ''For the third category, we will seek early liquidation.''

title: Food Stuff
description: What's in a Name? An Ice Cream That's Gelato

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a possible bid for Polygram, the giant music company, included an artist erroneously among those who record for it. Janet Jackson is on Virgin Records, which is owned by EMI Group P.L.C.

title: Leggett & Platt Stock Split
description: The engineered-products maker Leggett & Platt said today that it would split its shares 2 for 1 and increase its dividend by about 7 percent. The stock split will double the number of diluted shares to 199.6 million, halving the value of a share. Shares of Leggett & Platt gained $1.1875 each, to $52.3125. The new shares will be issued June 15 to shareholders of record as of May 29. A quarterly dividend of 16 cents, up from 15 cents, will be paid June 15 to shareholders of record as of May 29.

title: A $1 Billion Development Is Proposed For Hartford
description: Three major Hartford companies that have seen the value of their property plummet with the city's fortunes unveiled an ambitious $1 billion downtown development plan today that features a convention center and sports stadium.

title: Nomura Gets Stake in Hardage Hotels
description: The Nomura Asset Capital Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire a 35 percent interest in Hardage Suite Hotels L.L.C., a property and development company, for $81.5 million. Nomura Asset Capital is a unit of the Nomura Investment Company, which is a unit of the Nomura Securities Company of Japan.

title: House Acts to Ease 30's Banking Curbs By One-Vote Margin
description: Banking legislation that would overturn Depression-era restrictions on financial services industries squeaked past the House tonight by one vote, amid intensive lobbying by competing groups that have fought for nearly two decades about such far-reaching changes.

title: Cable Isn't Behind Networks' Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: Moderate in Nebraska Pulls an Upset
description: One candidate had plenty of money. Another had a strong conservative record in Congress. There was also a third candidate in the Republican primary for governor on Tuesday, Mike Johanns, a political moderate who ran without an overabundance of money or charisma. Most experts overlooked him.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESAR, JOSEPH R.
description: MESAR-Joseph R. He lived his life fully and passionately. My beloved. Devoted son to the late Priscilla Alden Mesar, caring cousin to Elaine. Leader in the fight for justice, true friend. Regina C. Little, Esq.

title: Past Rushes Back for Relatives of Two Lost in Vietnam
description: Whatever emotions run through them as they watch a coffin being removed from the Tomb of the Unknowns in Arlington National Cemetery on Thursday, the relatives of two men lost in the Vietnam War are apt to feel the years just fall away.

title: Next-Door Neighbor Demands That World Powers Shun India
description: Pakistani leaders demanded today that the United States and other world powers act decisively to isolate India after its five nuclear tests this week. They strongly hinted that the strength of the world's response would shape their decision on whether to detonate nuclear bombs of their own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNE, VERA
description: THORNE-Vera. The Dames of the Loyal Legion (New York State) records with sorrow the loss on May 11th of our loyal 97 year old member, Mrs. Samuel Thorne. Helen Leale Harper, Jr., President

title: Second Group Weighs a Bid For Polygram
description: Interest is mounting in Polygram N.V., the giant music company, as a second investment group has said that it is exploring a possible bid.

title: Judge Rejects Seizure of 2 Schieles
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the Museum of Modern Art could return two borrowed Egon Schiele paintings to a Viennese foundation despite a continuing criminal investigation into their ownership by the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: Telefonica of Spain Reports Jump in Net
description: Telefonica S.A., Spain's largest telecommunications company, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income jumped 17.8 percent as strong sales from international operations and mobile phones offset slower growth in its domestic phone operations.

title: Fraschilla Is Out, and It's One Big Puzzlement
description: Fran Fraschilla, a native New Yorker brought to St. John's University to put a new face on a tradition-rich basketball program, left the school yesterday after just two seasons -- the final chapter in a cryptic conflict that reportedly involved his contract status and interest in the head coaching job at Arizona State.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, EDWARD C.
description: McKENNA-Edward C. On May 13, 1998, of Williston Park. Active in The Irish American Society of Nassau, Suffolk and Queens. Devoted husband of the late Ellen F., loving father of Peggy Brennan, Edward and Neil. Fond brother of Mary Jane Phillips and Patrick. Cherished grandfather of five and three great-grandchildren. Friends may call on Thursday 2-5, 7-10 at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 412 Willis Avenue (between Hillside & Jericho), Williston Park, New York. Funeral Mass Friday, 10 AM, at Saint Aidan's RC Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Viacom Gets Three Bids for Simon & Schuster
description: Viacom Inc. received three bids yesterday for Simon & Schuster, the giant publishing company that it is offering for sale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, JONI
description: ROSS-Joni. Beloved daughter of the late Lazarus and Marie Ross, died May 10, 1998. Was a Quaker activist & advocate for the homeless. Memorial service Sunday, June 21, 1:30-4PM, 15th St Quaker Meeting, 15 Rutherford Place NYC

title: Cabbies Say Overly Harsh Rules Lump Good Drivers With Bad
description: There are a few bad cabbies New York wants to get rid of: rude hellions in a hurry to get to places they cannot find, who seem to pause only to run people down.
