title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: CANADIAN DOLLAR AT 3-MONTH LOW. Canada's currency fell on a central bank monetary report indicating that interest rates there would not rise soon. In New York the dollar settled at 1.4444 Canadian dollars, up from 1.4338.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MACGREGOR, SIR IAN
description: MacGREGOR-Sir Ian. There will be a memorial service for Sir Ian MacGregor on Friday, May 15, 1998, 11 AM at Saint Bartholomew's Church, 109 E. 50 St, NYC.

title: Houses Now; Homes of Metal: Great Shining Hope?
description: FROM the air, the West End of Houston blazes below, an unearthly apparition. It's not just the roofs that are glinting: it's the houses. In this neighborhood, some are clad entirely in metal.

title: Site Makes Silliness A Science
description: TECHNOLOGY prompts people to ponder many anomalies: for example, if electricity travels at the speed of light, why do electronic mail messages take so long to arrive? Or how does a thermos know whether to keep a liquid hot or cold?

title: MOTOROLA TO CLOSE MODEM PLANT, AS DEAL COLLAPSES
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it would close its modem plant in Huntsville, Ala., in July because the sale of its transmission-products division to an unnamed investor group fell through. Motorola said two weeks ago that it would sell the business to international investors for an undisclosed price. But the group cannot complete the purchase ''due to a lack of cohesion,'' Motorola said, without elaborating. The company said the plant's 500 employees would be offered severance packages if they could not find other jobs in the company. Its shares rose $3.50 yesterday, to $59.375, amid speculation that Siemens A.G. would offer to buy Motorola, though Siemens said it had no intention of doing so.

title: Five New Cancer Cases For a Town's Children
description: Five new cases of cancer were diagnosed in children in Toms River over a three-week period last month, the leader of a local cancer patient support group said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, FLORENCE EDITH
description: KAUFMAN-Florence Edith. Of Floral Park, NY and The Fountains, Lake Worth, FL. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Stuart and Susan, Louis and Diane, and Diane and Woody (Saland) & grandmother of David and Stacey, Teddy, Danny, Renee, Lauren and Nancy. Adored sister of Abel Jack Schwartz.

title: Economic Scene; Do Mergers Really Yield Big Benefits?
description: Boeing-McDonnell Douglas, Worldcom-MCI, Citicorp-Travelers, BankAmerica-Nationsbank, Daimler-Chrysler -- and now SBC-Ameritech: Sometimes it seems that a primitive urge to merge has been unleashed, a dread that corporations will cease to matter unless they can conjure up a market value of $50 billion.

title: Heaviness of the Body But Not of the Heart
description: A one-woman show about a naked fat woman working as an art-class model and reflecting on the defeat of South African apartheid may not be what everybody had in mind for entertainment this season. But here it is, quiet and very powerful, and Aviva Jane Carlin is wonderful in it.

title: India Has a Right To Nuclear Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTLE, ROSLYN
description: GERSTLE-Roslyn. On May 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Adored aunt and great-aunt. Services were held today, May 14.

title: Sale of Bonds For Lilco Deal Is a Success
description: The Long Island Power Authority's first bond sale was a hit on Wall Street. Although the offering was the nation's biggest municipal bond issue ever, demand far outstripped the supply. When the sale ended today on the initial $3.5 billion offering, it had attracted $18 billion in orders.

title: Cable Isn't Behind Networks' Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL-OILWELL IN DEAL FOR PHOENIX ENERGY PRODUCTS
description: National-Oilwell Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the privately held Phoenix Energy Products Inc. for $115 million plus $35 million in assumed debt. Phoenix Energy Products, based in Odessa, Tex., makes oilfield equipment. National-Oilwell, based in Houston, makes machinery, equipment and tools used in oil and gas drilling and production. It had revenue of $301.9 million in the quarter that ended March 31. Shares of National-Oilwell rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $39.4375.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Virtually every discussion we have with companies about their strategy begins with one word: Microsoft -- how do you compete against Microsoft in the future?''

title: French Cuisine Isn't Home Grown
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIA CARRIES OUT 2 MORE ATOM TESTS DESPITE SANCTIONS
description: Less than 12 hours after President Clinton appealed for a halt to all nuclear testing by India, the country's Government carried out two underground tests today to add to the three blasts it conducted at the same testing range in the northwestern desert on Monday.

title: Op-Art; 57 Channels and Nothing Else On
description: Mark Katz, a speechwriter and humorist, is the author of "'I Am Not a Corpse!' and Other Quotes Never Actually Said."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, HANNAH R.
description: LEVINE-Hannah R. On May 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Levine. Dear mother of Vivian and (Bernard) Sonnenfeld. Cherished grandmother of Natalie & Pamela and great grandmother of Hannah Rose & Jason. Services Thursday, May 14, 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment will take place in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida.

title: Cable Isn't Behind Networks' Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: French Cuisine Isn't Home Grown
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on May 11 about Ronald L. Ridenhour, the Vietnam veteran who in 1969 disclosed the My Lai massacre of civilians by United States troops, misstated the title held at the time by Morris K. Udall. He was Mr. Ridenhour's Representative, not a Senator.

title: The Perfect Swing: Is It an Unattainable Ideal?
description: In ancient Greece, it was a matter of philosophy that in building the classic buildings such as the Parthenon that each should have an imperfection. Nothing big, a column just a tad askew, say. Point being, nothing is or should be perfect.

title: Cable Isn't Behind Networks' Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HERTZ CORP., Park Ridge, N.J., the car and industrial-equipment rental company, agreed to buy Big 4 Rents Inc., San Francisco, an equipment-rental company, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Design Notebook; The Twain Not Only Meet, They Collaborate
description: On the face of it, they couldn't be more different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCE, LEWIS H.
description: SPENCE-Lewis H. Died peacefully on May 12, 1998 at his home in Cranbury, New Jersey. Husband of Eleanor K. Spence and father of Padraic, Harry, Matthew, & Olivia and grandfather of nine. He was founder of Lewis Spence & Co., co-founder of Cranbury Housing Associates and author.

title: Judge in Brawley Trial Cuts Witness List
description: The judge in the Tawana Brawley defamation case, noting ''the great length of this trial,'' issued a decision today that would speed up at least one part of the meandering trial.

title: CUNY's Short Shrift
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Criticize Delays in Receiving Newborns' H.I.V. Data
description: A New York State program that mandates testing of newborns for the AIDS virus is taking too long to report results, many health care professionals say, citing delays in crucial treatment for the virus in some cases and in others, increasing exposure to it through infected breast milk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMNAS, JO ANN B.
description: COMNAS-Jo Ann B. Of Bridgehampton, New York, on May 11, 1998. Predeceased by her husband George in November 1997, Survived by her sons Basil G. of Dushanbe, Tajikistan; and Demetrie G. of London, U.K., and her daughter Aspasia Comnas Neuman of Wainscott, New York. She is also survived by her sister Christine Caras of Somers, NY and five grandchildren. Reposing at the J.M. O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Road, Southampton, NY on Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral services will be held at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Hamptons on Friday at 12 Noon. Burial will follow at the Edgewood Cemetery, Bridgehampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Greek Orthodox Church of the Hamptons, 111 St. Andrew's Road, Southampton, NY 11968 or East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, N.Y. 11978 would be appreciated.

title: Software and Hardball
description: For all the attention Microsoft's antitrust confrontation with the Justice Department has received, for all the headlines and all the commentary on the subject, it often seems that the Government is stepping into what is essentially an intramural spat within the software industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONDON, DEBORAH GAIL VICTORIA (NEE HANRAHAN)
description: CONDON-Deborah Gail Victoria (nee Hanrahan). On Wednesday, May 13th, 1998. Beloved wife of Kevin Condon. Devoted mother of Katherine, John & Bryan Condon. Dear sister of John J. Hanrahan, Jr., Christopher Hanrahan & David Foley. Loving daughter of Joan (Corke) Hanrahan & the late John J. Hanrahan, Sr. Also survived by her grandmother Victoria E. Corke and her mother-in-law Patricia Condon. Reposing at Whalen & Ball Funeral Home, 168 Park Avenue, (corner of Glenwood), Yonkers, NY. Mass of Christian Burial in Sacred Heart Church on Saturday, May 16 at 9:30AM. Interment family plot. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 79PM. Donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, C/O Colon Cancer Research, New York, New York.

title: CVS to Split Stock, 2 for 1
description: The CVS Corporation, the drugstore-chain operator, said today that it would split its shares 2 for 1 and increase its dividend. The stock split will double the number of diluted shares to 361.4 million. CVS's shares closed at $68.875 today, up $2.125. The new shares will be issued June 15 to shareholders of record as of May 25. A quarterly dividend of 5.75 cents will be paid Aug. 1 to shareholders of record as of July 23. Before the split, the dividend was 11 cents.

title: Emery I. Valyi, 86, an Inventor Known for Work With Plastics
description: Emery I. Valyi, a prolific inventor whose innovations included a way for Pepsi drinkers to more easily pour a 2-liter plastic soft-drink bottle, died May 5 at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Building Virtual Cities And Good Citizenship
description: Decisions. Decisions. Decisions.

title: Williams and Jeter Lift Yankees With 2 Swings
description: Bernie Williams hit his second home run last night. It was even better than the first, which he had hit only 24 hours earlier.

title: Clarence C. Pell, 86; Revived Medieval Game
description: Clarence Cecil Pell, an aviation insurance executive, who was probably better known as the preserver of medieval court tennis in America, died on Tuesday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. R.I. A former resident of Old Westbury, N.Y., he was 86 and had made Narragansett, R.I., his permanent home since retiring in the mid-1970's.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM RISES 12 PERCENT. Palladium surged to a record on fear that a five-month halt in Russian exports could last through summer. June contracts rose $39.80 an ounce, to $372.65, double a year ago.

title: The Cab Crackdown Is Overdue
description: New York's cityscape seemed less frantic than usual yesterday, thanks to a strike that cleared the streets of all but a handful of taxicabs. The protest was aimed at Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's 17-point plan for disciplining and weeding out reckless cabbies. Though the drivers regard many of these rules as excessive and discriminatory, Mr. Giuliani is surely correct in principle. Driving a cab is a privilege, not a right, and reasonable steps to make the streets safer -- tighter rules, stiffer fines and tougher insurance requirements -- are justified by the requirements of public safety.

title: Metro Business; Ship Lines Threaten To Abandon Ports
description: In a move that could cut the cargo-container business at Port Newark and Port Elizabeth, N.J., by a third, the largest steamship lines in the New York region have announced that they are considering relocating to different ports along the Eastern Seaboard.

title: 4 California Rivals Brawl in First Debate
description: The four major candidates for governor of California squared off today in the first face-to-face encounter of a primary campaign marked mostly by the cut-and-thrust of television advertising -- and promptly fell to squabbling over the cut-and-thrust of television advertising.

title: Derby Winner Is Ready, Says Baffert
description: Bob Baffert began the year with 10 prospects for the Triple Crown, was down to two by the time of the Kentucky Derby, and showed up today at Pimlico with just one colt for Saturday's 123d Preakness Stakes. But the trainer believes it's the right one: Real Quiet, who won the Derby.

title: Nomura Plans Ventures With Industrial Bank
description: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's biggest brokerage firm, said yesterday that it and the Industrial Bank of Japan Company would form two joint ventures in an effort to compete more effectively with foreign firms. They said they would set up two jointly owned affiliates, one specializing in financial derivatives and the other in asset management.

title: Essay; Not-So-Silent Cal
description: The nation's most populous state is on the verge of leading the nation away from the eat-your-peas domineering of teachers, lawyers and union officials. The voices of parents, clients and rank-and-file workers are about to be heard.

title: Bridge; The Last Hand of the Match Can Bring a $100,000 Swing
description: The last putt in a golf tournament often swings $100,000, but the bridge equivalent is very rare. It happened Sunday in the Cavendish Invitational Pairs in Las Vegas, where nearly all the top partnerships in North America were assembled with a sprinkling from other parts of the world.

title: Deploring Giuliani Proposals, Cabbies Shun Fares for a Day
description: Spurred to action by stiff regulations proposed for their industry, thousands of taxi drivers went on a one-day strike yesterday, eerily erasing the familiar packs of yellow cabs from the city's streets and leaving those accustomed to being ferried around town to rely on subways, buses and private car service companies that eagerly tried to fill the void.

title: First Gene to Be Linked With High Intelligence Is Reported Found
description: Psychologists using a new genetic technique have found a gene associated with high intelligence. The technique, they say, should help to identify several more of the many genes thought to affect human intelligence and personality. If the work is confirmed by other researchers, it would be the first time that a gene contributing to intelligence had been found.

title: In America; When Polls Deceive
description: Deja vu?

title: Finding a Key to Fit Most Search Engines
description: Q. Search techniques can vary depending on which search engine you're using, but is there a standard symbol for ''and'' on all of them?

title: Federated and Kmart Post Higher First-Quarter Income
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Kmart Corporation, two of the nation's biggest retailers, reported better-than-expected earnings for the fiscal first quarter yesterday, after they cut costs and remodeled their stores.

title: Arts Abroad; A Conductor Paris Didn't Send Back to the Kitchen
description: Audiences at the Paris National Opera may often boo productions and sets, but, echoing the critics, they invariably applaud the orchestra and its American principal conductor, James Conlon.

title: THERMO BIOANALYSIS TO BUY ANOTHER THERMO BUSINESS
description: The Thermo Bioanalysis Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay around $66 million in stock and assumed debt of $38 million to acquire the clinical-products group of Life Sciences International. Both companies are units of Thermo Instruments Systems Inc., which in turn is a subsidiary of Thermo Electron, based in Waltham, Mass. Thermo Bioanalysis and the clinical-products group of Life Sciences make instruments for biochemical research. Thermo Bioanalysis had 1997 revenue of $139.5 million. The clinical-products group had revenue of about $75 million last year.

title: An Even Smaller Phone With Even More Stuff
description: Small is good, or at least that's what the designers at Ericsson, the Swedish-based telecommunications giant, are betting as the company introduces its smallest mobile telephone-and-more to the United States.

title: Public Eye; Windows Shopping: What Price Freedom?
description: DESIGNERS have a phrase for it: ''lock-in.'' From the roll of toilet paper four and a half inches wide that fits toilet paper holders to the complex rules regulating digital video disks, certain shapes and sizes have become standards for their industries -- and not always the best ones. Like it or not, we are locked into a world in which faucets are arranged with hot on the left, cold on the right. Razor blades are designed to match razors. Batteries come in standard sizes.

title: For 'Seinfeld' Viewers, a Super Bowl Party
description: According to the calendar, it's the second Thursday in May. But according to Madison Avenue, it looks a lot like the last Sunday in January -- Super Bowl Sunday.

title: G.O.P. Shows Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Party On
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross insists that New York State's Liberal Party chose her as its gubernatorial nominee last weekend because the party leaders were impressed by her ideas. Ms. McCaughey Ross is either extremely evasive or incredibly naive. The Liberals have not been in the idea business for eons. Their attempts to influence public policy have long been limited to demanding jobs for Liberal Party loyalists and their relatives.

title: Floods Giving Argentine President a Political Lift
description: In his nearly nine years in office, President Carlos Saul Menem has subdued 4,000 percent inflation, calmed mobs, cut the military's budget and slashed the Government bureaucracy.

title: Events; From Parks to Flowers
description: Planning Parks

title: Both Sides of Spam
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, RUTH (ROVNER)
description: RUBIN-Ruth (Rovner). May 13, 1998. Wife of Jerome. Mother of Dr. Harvey (Elizabeth) Rubin and the late Adrienne Davidson. Grandmother of Karen, Elaine, Matthew and Benjamin. Great grandmother of Erica and Allison. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services Friday 1PM at Goldsteins Rosenbergs RaphaelSacks, 6410 North Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA. (1-800) 622-6410. Interment Montefiore cemetery. Shiva will be observed at the residence of Dr. Harvey and Elizabeth Rubin through Sunday and then at her late residence.

title: Kremlin Soft-Pedals Its Rebuke to India, and Opposes Sanctions
description: Russia today reaffirmed its refusal to join other countries in punishing India for resuming nuclear tests, and has so far failed to register an especially strong diplomatic protest.

title: Stuyvesant's Student Paper Prints Again
description: The presses are running again for The Spectator, the student newspaper at Stuyvesant High School, a month after the school's principal suspended publication. The suspension followed months of infighting among the student editors and recent complaints by teachers about several articles, including one criticizing the policies of the city teachers' union.

title: Clinton Calls Tests a 'Terrible Mistake' And Announces Sanctions Against India
description: President Clinton sharpened his criticism of the Indian Government today, calling its decision to detonate five nuclear explosions underground a ''terrible mistake'' as he announced a raft of economic sanctions in reprisal.

title: Accounts
description: * NBC, New York, part of General Electric Co., renewed its multiyear contract with Horizon Media Inc., Los Angeles, for media buying and local in-market promotions in the United States for the television network. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Adding Polish to Home Video
description: DR. STEPHANIE EISENSTAT of Concord, Mass., had only a basic working knowledge of personal computers when her neighbor encouraged her to learn a video editing program for the Macintosh.

title: Handling Fast Stock Cars
description: NASCAR RACING 2

title: Panel Looks at Using Part of Tobacco Tax for Self-Employed
description: Gearing up for a donnybrook on tobacco legislation next week, the Senate Finance Committee today considered using part of the revenues that would be raised from an increase in cigarette taxes to give a tax break to self-employed workers and workers whose employers do not pay for medical insurance.

title: Garden Notebook; Native Species Are Replacing the Neon Azalea
description: THIS week, mothers across America will be standing in their yards with pots of azaleas in hand -- Mother's Day presents -- ready to plug them into the ground. The azaleas are blood red, hot pink, magenta, brick red, purple; the mothers are confused. Where can they plant these testimonials of love? If the answer is ''next to the one they got last year,'' a potential color war is in the offing.

title: Learning About a Dead Twin, and Affirming Life
description: Death may seem an unlikely subject for children's theater, especially when the subject is the death of a sibling, and more particularly, a twin. But a willingness to confront that profound loss is what makes ''Nicky, Somewhere Else'' something special. And the ability to go about that daunting task with humor, creativity, immense charm and touching sensitivity is what makes so worthwhile a visit to the New Victory Theater for Speeltheater Holland's affirmation of life in the face of death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIGEL, KALMAN
description: SEIGEL-Kalman. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Kalman Seigel, associated with The Times from 1939, until retiring in 1981.

title: The Unratified Treaty
description: The decision by India's new Government to openly pursue ''the nuclear option'' sets that nation on a provocative course that threatens the security of South Asia as well as global efforts to reduce the danger from nuclear weapons everywhere. Pakistan will be motivated to follow India's nuclear testing example, and other states with nuclear capabilities may be tempted to exploit them.

title: Another Hurdle for the Tobacco Bill
description: Senate Republicans face a test today that will show whether they are still in thrall to the tobacco industry. The tobacco bill drafted by Senator John McCain, which was approved by the Commerce Committee by a vote of 19 to 1, is now under heavy attack by conservative Republicans who oppose higher cigarette taxes and more Federal regulation of that industry. They are looking for a way to weaken the McCain bill in the Finance Committee, which will work on the legislation today.

title: Killing of Arab in Jerusalem Is Called Revenge
description: A Palestinian laborer was stabbed to death in an Orthodox Jewish neighborhood here today in what the police said was apparently an act of revenge for the fatal stabbing of a yeshiva student in the Old City last week.

title: Underground Test Suggests India Seeks to Make a Variety of Nuclear Warheads
description: India's test this week of a thermonuclear device deep beneath its northwestern desert is significant because it suggests the nation is trying to develop for various weapons systems a variety of nuclear warheads, including hydrogen bombs.

title: Making Books; An Appetizer Or a Big Bite?
description: Book excerpts begin in fantasy, with the dream that putting a fragment of a book in a magazine (or a newspaper) will romance large numbers of people into wanting more of the same and, therefore, scurrying to buy the complete opus. Sometimes the fancy happens; sometimes it doesn't.

title: Rapp's Four-Hitter Snaps a Losing Streak
description: ROYALS 4, DEVIL RAYS 0

title: NEWS WATCH
description: GOT A TV TUNER CARD? -- According to a recent survey of Internet surfers in the United States, 51 percent of them are expected to curb their on-line cruising for a while tonight to watch the on-air series finale of ''Seinfeld.''

title: Help Along the Campaign Trail From Kohl's Friend 'Dear Bill'
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany welcomed the President of the United States as ''dear Bill'' in Potsdam today. And for good reason: Facing the direst political fight of his career with elections just four months away, Mr. Kohl is receiving an extraordinary political assist from Mr. Clinton -- his ally of more than five years, former pupil in world affairs and frequent eating buddy.

title: Road Races Are a Challenge But Graphics Don't Keep Up
description: CART PRECISION RACING

title: A $12 Million Monet Leads a Solid, if Stodgy, Sale
description: Despite the taxi strike, collectors, dealers and art lovers came in droves to Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art last night. But getting there seemed to be more of an adventure than the sale itself. Although strong prices were achieved -- and at times several bidders fought for works of art -- the evening seemed painfully dull.

title: SAMSONITE PLANS REPURCHASE OF UP TO 59% OF SHARES
description: The Samsonite Corporation said yesterday that it would buy as many as 12 million shares at $40 a share. The shares rose 93.75 cents, to $29.875. The buyback, which represents about 59 percent of Samsonite's shares outstanding, is part of a new recapitalization plan and replaces a planned special dividend of $12.50 a share announced in March. Samsonite, the Denver-based luggage company, expects that repurchasing the shares, refinancing debt and paying fees and expenses will cost $700 million. The cash offer, Samsonite said, will enable shareholders to receive a significant premium for about three-fifths of their shares while keeping an ownership interest in the company. Samsonite earned $40.7 million on revenue of $736.9 million last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, BETTY JEAN (NEE GIBSON)
description: JOHNSON-Betty Jean (nee Gibson). Died suddenly on May 13, 1998. Mrs. Johnson was a teacher for many years at The Browning School. Beloved wife of Glenn. Loving mother of Marta Judson, Mark and Craig. Cherished grandmother. For service information, call Frank E. Campbell at 212 288-3500.

title: Pataki's Push for Trustee At CUNY Is Questioned
description: Albany legislators and members of the New York City Council raised questions yesterday about Gov. George E. Pataki's effort to speed the approval of a new trustee for the City University of New York to insure that the board passes a curb on remedial classes that he has urged.

title: French Cuisine Isn't Home Grown
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Tax Ban Is Called Biased
description: The affluent would receive a tax break at the expense of people of modest means if the proposed moratorium on taxing sales made over the Internet becomes law, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group in Washington, said in a report this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, ALBERT (ALBIE)
description: MYERS-Albert (Albie). Age 79. On May 11, 1998. Beloved husband of Norma (Nathel). Devoted father of Ronald and Lance. Father-inlaw to Jill (Yagoda) and cherished grandfather of Danielle and Hillary. He was a giving and loving man who will be greatly missed. We will remember him always. Funeral service Thursday, May 14th, 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: U S West Faces Suit Over Long-Distance Venture
description: The AT&T Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation and four other organizations filed suit today in United States District Court in Seattle seeking to block U S West Communications Group's plan to market long-distance phone service in its region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHINS, SUSAN REINGOLD
description: OSHINS-Susan Reingold. Cherished wife of the late Alfred Beno Oshins, devoted mother of E.J., Jo Ann, & son-in-law Ray, treasured sister of Barbara Diamond, Joyce Baumgarten, and the late Ruth Joseph, loving aunt, and loyal friend. Our 'SuSu'. A New Yorkers' New Yorker. Shared her energy, verve, and civic pride with The Hunger Project, Manhattan Theater Club, n.g.o. at the UN, School Volunteers and Abzug campaigns. Her optimism & courage inspired and guided all. She will always be a sparkling presence in our universe. Donations in memory to: The Hunger Project, 15 East 26th Street, New York, New York 10010. 212-251-9100

title: Small Digital Camera Adds Video Possibilities
description: Sanyo Electric Company this week unveiled a new palm-size compact digital camera that not only takes snapshots but also can capture up to 10 seconds of sound and motion pictures. The images, still or video, can be shown on a standard television or sent over the Internet as E-mail.

title: Cable and Wireless Had Profitable Half
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., which says it is the third-biggest carrier of international phone traffic, reported yesterday that its net income rose 9 percent in the second half of the year that ended on March 31 as acquisitions and its mobile phone business increased the customer base of the company by 70 percent. Second-half net, calculated by deducting first-half net from full-year figures, was $:348 million ($567 million), up from $:319 million a year earlier.

title: Retreat on Times Square Subway Plan
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has allowed the developer of one of four office towers in Times Square to scale back the size of a new entrance to the busiest subway station in the country, at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue.

title: Nissan Chief Talks of a Deal With Daimler at Some Point
description: The president of the Nissan Motor Company dangled the possibility on Wednesday that Daimler-Benz, the German industrial giant that is buying Chrysler, might some day make a similar deal with his company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DI PAOLA, ROBERT
description: Di PAOLA-Robert. A memorial symposium for Professor Robert A. Di Paola will be held Monday, May 18, at 1pm in Room 202 of the City University of New York Graduate Center, 33 West 42 St. Professor Di Paola, who died April 1, was a leading mathematical logician who taught in the Computer Science Doctoral Program.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A networking stock vaults on a takeover story, quickly denied.
description: THERE are not many rock-solid articles of faith about the future of the technology business, but if any belief comes close, it is that companies that make telecommunications equipment and companies that make data-networking equipment are destined to merge.

title: G.O.P. Shows Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Markets Are Bolstered as Investors Flee Rout in Asia
description: The stock market advanced yesterday, but apparently without any real zeal.

title: Personal Shopper; Topiary Minus the Foliage
description: ''WE all have blinders on and think we must use objects for only one thing,'' said Katina Arts-Meyer, one of the designers at this year's Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club Decorator Show House.

title: Taylor Is Arrested in Child Support Case
description: Lawrence Taylor, the former Giants linebacker who has had an array of legal troubles since he retired from football in 1993, was arrested again early Tuesday during a police sweep in Bergen County for parents who failed to pay child support.

title: Jiggling Livers, and Advertising, in a Lively Screen Saver
description: A new series of free screen savers is poised to splash not only comical animation across your monitor but also advertising.

title: Silence of the Spies
description: To escape obsolescence when the cold war ended, America's intelligence agencies said they would tackle threats like terrorism and the spread of nuclear weapons. Yet after spending billions of dollars on these efforts, the spy services inexplicably gave President Clinton no warning that India was ready to test nuclear weapons this week. That failure requires not only a searching inquiry into the mishandling of India's nuclear threat but also a broader examination of how effectively spy agencies are tracking the development of nuclear technologies abroad.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Plant Slow for Long Life

title: Coronado's Quest Is Minding His Manners
description: It was still hours before Belmont Park's season would open, but a small crowd gathered yesterday in the chilly morning air as Coronado's Quest stepped onto the track, calmly following a stable pony. Trainer Shug McGaughey watched and held his breath as the colt backed up the stretch, then began a slow jog around the track.

title: The Information Superhighway and Its Back Roads
description: The backbone metaphor is regularly used to describe the huge data pipes that make up the, well, backbone, of the Internet. But the old cliche of the Information Superhighway is probably more accurate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, JULES
description: COOPER-Jules. The Officers, Directors, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center extend their heartfelt sympathy to Leonard Cooper, a vice president on the Board of Directors, and Rosalyn Gordon, a member of the Board of Directors, on the loss of their beloved brother, Jules Cooper, of Oceanside, CA. Our condolences to the entire family. Joseph Gurwin, President Alfred W. Levy Chairman of the Board Herbert H. Friedman Executive Vice President

title: A Family Links Up, But United We Fall
description: From: Dan Slatalla

title: Fuji 2d-Half Net Off On Weak Asia Demand
description: Net earnings of the Fuji Photo Film Company fell 4.1 percent in the second half of the year that ended on March 31 as slack demand for film in Japan and Asia offset gains in the United States. Fuji said second-half net fell to 38.61 billion yen ($294 million) from 40.26 billion yen a year earlier. Sales grew 8.26 percent, to 704.781 billion yen.

title: Officials Are Uncertain as to How Punishing India Is Likely to Affect U.S. Businesses
description: The sanctions that President Clinton imposed against India yesterday are likely to hurt a wide swath of American industry, but for most of those companies the impact will be small, executives and Government officials said. That is because India, while potentially a huge future market for American companies, is a small market today.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Mission to Indonesia

title: Sticker Shock at The Flea Market
description: Bringing England's heritage back home from the colonies is turning out to be much more expensive than Kate Dyson had been led to believe.

title: GLIMCHER REALTY TRUST BUYING 5 MALLS FOR $375 MILLION
description: Glimcher Realty Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy five shopping malls for a total of $375 million. The malls, bought from various sellers in privately negotiated deals, have about 5 million square feet of space, raising Glimcher's total holdings to more than 30 million square feet in 124 properties. The properties are in Alabama, California, Minnesota, North Carolina and Oregon. Shares of Glimcher, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $21.3125.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the awarding of journalism fellowships misspelled the names of two mid-career winners at Columbia University. They are Carol Lutfy, not Lufty, and Laura Sydell, not Sydel. The article also misstated the title of Carter Harris, another mid-career fellow at Columbia. He is features editor of Vibe magazine, not an arts writer.

title: Seriously, With Fire And Light Turned Low
description: Choreographers who turn to serious composers often feel compelled to turn serious on us, sometimes with tedious results. Or so it seemed again when Elisa Monte and David Brown each presented two New York premieres with Elisa Monte Dance on Tuesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, DR. LAURA
description: SIEGEL-Dr. Laura, age 49, of Shokan, N.Y. and NYC, on May 10, after a long and valiant battle with cancer. Laura was the beloved and loving wife of Chrissandy Rodulfo and devoted stepmother to Damien, Nicholas, and Jaaron. She is survived by father Martin and brother Paul. Laura was a cherished friend and gifted healer in both Chiropractic and Psychotherapy. She will be deeply missed but held tightly in the hearts of all of those who knew and loved her. Contributions in Laura's memory may be sent to Gilda's Club, 195 W. Houston St., NY, NY 10014.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBLATT, ELAINE
description: WEINBLATT-Elaine. On May 13, 1998. Always in our hearts. Husband Jules, daughter Margery, son Michael, son-in-law Kenneth, daughter-in-law Vicky, grandsons Evan, Daniel, Brian, grand daughter Leah, sister-in-law Judy, nieces Amy, Jennifer, Emily, grandniece Lucy. Services Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapel, Manalapan, New Jersey, Friday, May 15, 11 AM.

title: Sulzberger Family Sells Some Times Co. Shares
description: Four members of the Sulzberger family, including two directors of The New York Times Company, said yesterday that they had sold more than one million shares of stock in the company, taking in more than $76 million.

title: Real Quiet Takes Back Seat at No. 11
description: Real Quiet, the winner of the Kentucky Derby, arrived today for the $1 million Preakness but found that he was second choice in the field of 11 to Coronado's Quest, who skipped the Derby because of a pattern of unruly behavior.

title: For Wall Street, Big Fees In Bond Sale for Takeover
description: The denizens of Wall Street may have been even happier than the residents of Long Island yesterday as the Long Island Power Authority sold $3.5 billion in bonds -- the biggest municipal bond issue ever -- to finance its takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIMES, MADELAINE (MADY)
description: HAIMES-Madelaine (Mady). Dearest beloved wife for 51 years of Alex. Ever loving mother of Ted and Barbara. Devoted daughter to the late Willy and Anna Reiner. Fond aunt to many nieces and nephews. Services 11AM Thursday May 14, Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, LEWIS
description: PHILLIPS-Lewis died peacefully in East Hampton on May 10, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Barbara T. Phillips. Devoted father of Amy Penn, Michael, and Samantha D'Olivera. Beloved grandfather of Gabriel, Eli and Sophia.Beloved brother of Brenda P.Ballin. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Scooby Doo, Where Are You?
description: I LEFT the San Diego airport in a Hertz rental equipped with a navigation system confidently named Never Lost. On a small screen that displayed the car's location, I punched in my destination, which I happened to know was about 10 miles to the north. But Never Lost's synthesized voice instructed me to take the freeway south.

title: Confession Released in Shelter Island Slaying
description: On the night he was arrested and accused of shooting and killing his neighbor, a Shelter Island man told the police that he believed the neighbor had molested an 8-year-old girl and was bragging about how he planned to get away with it, officials said.

title: Gore to Announce 'Electronic Bill of Rights' Aimed at Privacy
description: Vice President Al Gore will announce on Thursday a new ''Electronic Bill of Rights'' to help insure the privacy of consumers' medical records, Internet transactions and other computerized personal data, Administration officials said.

title: Putting the RAM in the Ram-a-Lam-a-Ding-Dong
description: THE repetitive THUMP THUMP THUMP THUMP of a techno beat was pulsing when a young composer, Lowell Pickett, decided to make a few changes. ''Let me go into edit mode,'' he said as he sat in front of a computer screen.

title: Current Account Surplus Off in March in Japan
description: Japan's current account surplus fell 28.4 percent in March from the month before. It was the seventh contraction in 10 months, as Asian countries bought fewer machines and materials for manufacturing. The March surplus shrank to 1.116 trillion yen ($8.3 billion), with exports falling 1 percent and imports rising 6.4 percent from February, the Finance Ministry said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks' Void Pointed Out By Jackson
description: ANOTHER season gone. Another one ended with people talking about what the Knicks do not have, besides a championship, for the 25th consecutive year. First and foremost, no genuine, multipurpose point guard. Not enough poise under pressure. And when they are perfectly honest with themselves, they know there was only the remote possibility that the results would have been dramatically different had Patrick Ewing not taken that terrible fall in Milwaukee five months ago.

title: Albright and Netanyahu Agree to Continue Talks on Ways to Restart Mideast Peace Effort
description: After meeting for 90 minutes today, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright agreed to continue their talks on Thursday in an effort to restart the stagnant Middle East peace negotiations.

title: India Has a Right To Nuclear Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review yesterday about a benefit performance by American Ballet Theater on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House misidentified the person who introduced Hillary Rodham Clinton, the event's honorary chairwoman. The speaker was Kevin McKenzie, the company's artistic director, not one of the evening's chairwomen, who were Caroline Kennedy and Blaine Trump.

title: Japan Freezes Some Grants; Other Nations Seem Doubtful
description: The Japanese Government today froze new grants to India as punishment for the nuclear tests, and said it would consider cutting some of its much bigger loan programs. Germany also suspended some of its aid, but other major trading partners ruled out sanctions.

title: Tobacco Marketing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERSTANDIG, WILLIAM
description: VERSTANDIG-William. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Henri Verstandig on the loss of his brother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: CD Quality Vs. Vinyl
description: To the Editor:

description: BRENNER-Joseph (Formerly of Rockville Centre). Beloved husband of the late Selma. Cherished father of Steven Brenner and Shelley LaFauci. Dear brother of Jerome and Zalick. Adored grandfather of Greg and Kim LaFauci. Serivces Sunday 11:30am Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Sending a Marketer to Do an Administrator's Job
description: Joe Paterno once said that you had better be a pretty good athletic director to fire more than two head coaches. No one knows how good or bad Edward J. Manetta Jr. is as an athletic director, but he has reached his limit awfully fast. He has been the St. John's athletic director for less than three years, and he has already fired two head coaches.

title: More Heartbreak For a Proud Ewing
description: The clock struck midnight for Patrick Ewing in the first quarter, when arguably the greatest player in Knicks history poked at the ball like an infant stretching for a mobile in his crib.

title: Democrats Reject Immunity in Fund Inquiry
description: Calling the proceedings an embarrassment and a soap opera, House Democrats on the panel investigating campaign finance practices blocked a crucial vote in the inquiry today and set the stage for another showdown with Republicans.

title: A Mosaic Minus a Familiar Hue; Miles of Streets With Nary a Yellow Taxicab
description: Those were in fact the streets of New York yesterday. They were not Alma, Mich.

title: New Mac Gets an A For Offbeat Cuteness
description: Some people who have seen the iMac, the new Apple computer that is scheduled to be in stores in August, say it reminds them of a Volkswagen Beetle, a cartoon turtle or even a giant electronic gum drop. Its mouse glows in the dark.

title: Developer to Buy Atlantic City Track
description: A Michigan real estate developer has agreed to buy the financially troubled Atlantic City Race Course, which was scheduled to close within a month, officials of the track announced yesterday.

title: With New Toilet Rules, Beaches Are Set to Open
description: With Memorial Day approaching, the state has eased its rules on the placement of public toilets at 17 beaches on Long Island, clearing the way for the beaches to open for the summer season.

title: Tenacious West Bank Settlers Await Fate in War of Percent
description: Perched on an isolated hilltop south of Hebron, 10 miles from any other Jewish settlement, Otniel has a direct stake in the percentage war being waged in distant Washington between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Clinton Administration.

title: If a Pay Phone Rings, Who Will Answer?
description: SOMEWHERE there's a pay phone ringing, thanks to Mark Thomas.

title: Executive Changes
description: AVON PRODUCTS INC., New York, said Charles Perrin would become chief executive in July, consistent with a management succession plan disclosed last December. Mr. Perrin, 52, will succeed James Preston five months after being appointed vice chairman and chief operating officer. Mr. Preston, 65, will remain chairman until his retirement next year. Andrea Jung, 39, who was named president earlier, will succeed Mr. Perrin as chief operating officer, also in July.

title: Newest Data Ease Concerns About Rate Increase by Fed
description: Retail sales rose for the fifth time in six months in April, while producer prices were hardly changed for nearly everyone except smokers, suggesting little reason for concern about the economy.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Political Briefing column on Sunday referred incorrectly to the effort by Gov. David Beasley of South Carolina to lower the Confederate flag that flies over the state Capitol dome. He proposed moving the flag elsewhere, and the Legislature refused; he did not order the flag lowered.

title: By Driving In Runs, Kent Raises Money for Female Athletes
description: It is perhaps too much to ask male athletes to focus both attention and generosity on women's sports. Today's headlines suggest we should just be grateful for each day that passes without news that athletes have made sport of brutalizing women.

title: India Has a Right To Nuclear Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleaning Up in the Dark; Companies Disclose Little About Costs of Toxic Sites
description: Eighteen years after the passage of sweeping legislation to clean up the worst of the nation's toxic waste dumps, much of the job remains undone. American companies will have to spend billions of dollars in coming years to decontaminate the most polluted Superfund sites. But that is not at all obvious from scouring the companies' annual financial reports and filings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWARTNER, JACK
description: KWARTNER-Jack. The Board of Directors of Friends of Israel Disabled Veterans (Beit Halochem) notes with sorrow the passing of Jack Kwartner, a great and benevolent friend of the disabled veterans of Israel. Susan Aberbach, National Chairperson, FIDV, USA Joseph Luttenberg, Chairman, ZDVO Israel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONDY, PHILIP
description: BONDY-Philip, on May 11, 1998. Beloved brother of Geraldine and Melvin. Loving uncle and friend. Graveside services on Friday, at 11 A.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Upset Over Theft Report, City Sues for Defamation
description: City officials are planning to file a defamation lawsuit against an insurance industry group that released a report last month claiming that Jersey City had the nation's highest rate of automotive theft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALTER, BERT
description: BALTER-Bert. Of Fort Lee, NJ. Beloved husband of Roslyn and the late Norma. Devoted father of David, Barbara Laschober and Richard. Loving grandfather of Christopher, Evan and Brett. Services ''Gutterman - Musicant,'' Hackensack, NJ, Friday 10 AM.

title: A Little Help From His Fame: Ringo Starr Is Still a Natural
description: In what was probably his first club show since the Beatles played at the Cavern in 1963, Ringo Starr brought his band to the Bottom Line on Tuesday night for 45 minutes of jovial, pretension-free rock. Mr. Starr was warming up for an appearance on the VH1 series ''Storytellers,'' previewing a summer tour and plugging his coming album, ''Vertical Man'' (Mercury), which is due for release on June 16.

title: Making Art About Art With a Murky Spectacle
description: Evidently the crew of the Irondale Ensemble Project, as they developed ''Degenerate Art: Germany Attacks the Avant-Garde,'' decided that their notion that the assault on modern art by the Nazis in the 1930's could be turned into pertinent commentary about current conservative attacks on the National Endowment for the Arts was not altogether sound. At one quite preachy moment in the performance, an actor steps out of all of his several characters and utters a cautious disclaimer. Actually, that is reassuring; through the years Irondale has been mercilessly candid about its political and social stands, so it is nice to hear it cluck when it lays an egg.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Pataki Cancels Plan to Widen Expressway in Part of Queens
description: Bowing to pressure from Queens community groups and elected officials, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday canceled a $72 million plan to widen a milelong stretch of the Long Island Expressway in eastern Queens.

title: U.S. to Appeal to Indonesia Military to Stop Crackdown
description: The Clinton Administration, concluding that it has almost no remaining diplomatic leverage with the Government of Indonesia to stem the growing violence there, has decided to dispatch a high-level military delegation to demand that the security forces end their attacks on civilian demonstrators, officials said.

title: Specialty Magazines Sold
description: Primedia Inc. is acquiring the niche magazine publishers American Trucker Group and In-Fisherman. Financial terms were not disclosed. American Trucker has 18 monthly journals featuring truck parts, equipment and services. In-Fisherman, based in Brainerd, Minn., aims at fresh-water fishermen through such magazines as the In-Fisherman and Walleye In-Sider; the cable television program In-Fisherman Television, and the In-Fisherman radio show. Primedia, based in New York, publishes Seventeen, New York and Soap Opera Digest, among other magazines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELL, CLARENCE C.
description: PELL-Clarence C., May 12, 1998. Husband of Francesca Hinkley Pell. Father of Eve Pell, of Mill Valley, CA; Peter J. Pell, of Glen Cove, NY; Haven N.B. Pell, of Washington, DC; and the late Clarence C. Pell III. Grandfather of nine, great grandfather of 2. Residence Narragansett, RI. Memorial service Saturday, May 16, 1PM in St. Peter's By the Sea, Narragansett. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Pomfret School, Pomfret, CT. 06258.

title: Saatchi Sets Up Co-Marketing Unit
description: Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. in New York said yesterday that it had formed a unit, Saatchi & Saatchi Co-Marketing Services, focusing on joint promotional programs for consumer marketers and retailers intended to increase product sales and burnish brand images.

title: Net Metaphors Stretch to Fit The Evolution Of Data Flow
description: THE long stretches of fiber optic cable carrying large volumes of data have been known as ''backbones'' for a long time by folks inside the data shipping business. Internet consumers are starting to hear the term as well, thanks in large part to Internet service providers who tout the speed of their backbones.

title: Metro Business; Starwood Moves to Region
description: Starwood Hotels & Resorts moved this week to its new headquarters on Westchester Avenue in White Plains, where it is combining its administration with that of its two big acquisitions, the ITT Corporation and Westin Hotels.

title: Desert Site Approved for Burying Plutonium
description: After 24 years of preparations and almost as much time in litigation, the world's first deep, underground nuclear waste storage site won a Federal license today to begin burying plutonium, with deliveries that could begin on June 19.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, MINOR BUFKIN
description: FINKELSTEIN - Minor Bufkin. Wife of Edward W. Finkelstein, mother of Ellen Holmes Finkelstein. Found peace on Monday, May 11. No funeral services. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Lenox Hill Hospital Cancer Research, 100 E. 77 St, NYC 10021.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: House Narrowly Approves Financial Services Changes

title: Heat Doesn't Want Albert in the Booth
description: Will Marv Albert be shouting Yes! for the Miami Heat next season?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SULLIVAN, BENJAMIN
description: O'SULLIVAN-Benjamin. Left this world on May 2, 1998. During his life, he found interests in many social issues, but one moved him to become actively involved-his interest in the poverty, homelessness and grave injustices to the American Indian. Mr. O'Sullivan devoted many years to helping American Indians where he could. In the early 1960's, he accepted a position on the Board of Directors for the Association on American Indian Affairs. He was elected to the position of Treasurer, which he held for many years, and later was elected as Vice President of the Board. During his tenure, the Association was in the forefront in crafting national policy for American Indians. Ben O'Sullivan was part of the organization that saw its board discussions turn into Congressional action. AAIA was responsible for numerous actions that make life a little better for all Native America. He will be greatly missed. Brad Keeler, Board President

title: Sports of The Times; Wild and Bossy, and in His Last Scene
description: TONIGHT is George Steinbrenner's last as the Yankees' principal owner. But only on ''Seinfeld.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, F.J. (JERRY)
description: GOULD-F.J. (Jerry), Ph.D., Chairman Professor Emeritus, University of Chicago on May 12. Cofounder of Investment Research Company, Dr. Gould is responsible for coordination of all aspects of IRC activity, with particular emphasis on performance, product research, new strategy development, and client relations. During his 25 years of teaching and research, he spent 15 years as the Hobart W. Williams Professor of Applied Mathematics and Management Science Graduate School of Business at the University of Chicago. Dr. Gould has been a consultant in financial markets as well as portfolio manager and trader in futures and equities for over 20 years. He founded Investment Research Company along with Professor Garcia in 1985 and became Professor Emeritus in 1990. He holds memberships in the American Finance Association, The American Economic Association, The Operations Research Society of America, The Institute of Management Service and The Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics. While a member of the Statistics Department at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, he was the first Chairman of the Curriculum in Operations Research and Systems Analysis. Dr. Gould authored five books, published over 80 papers in professional journals, and wrote prolifically on aspects of active equity management. He was also a contributor of articles appearing in the Wall Street Journal as well as other news publications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRIGLER, MORDECHAI
description: STRIGLER - Mordechai. The Workmen's Circle mourns the passing of a stalwart of the Yiddish world; scholar, author, journnalist, thinker. Mark Mlotek, Pres. Robert A. Kaplan, Exec. Dir. Chava Lapin, Ed. Dir.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Tempting Fruit Is Only for the Eye

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGFAN, HANNAH (HANKIE)
description: LANGFAN - Hannah (Hankie). Died on Tuesday, May 12, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late Max and Mary Langfan. Cherished sister of William and Barbara, and the late Rubin and Janet. Caring sister-in-law of Marion and Hilda. Devoted aunt of Lorraine and Alex, Robin and Jay, Mark and Sherri, Dayna and Larry, and the late Judy and her surviving husband Wayne. Loving great aunt of Steven, Michael, Adam, Benjamin, Justin, David, Bennett, Penelope, Mitchell, Leah, Susan and Joel. Hankie created beauty and grace throughout her life. She watched over us with care and compassion. She cared deeply for the State of Israel. She will live on in our hearts and remind us to seek harmony & peace. Funeral service Thursday, May 14, at 10 AM at Sutton Place Synagogue, 25 East 51 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Yeshiva University and Sutton Place Synagogue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUIGG, H.D., JR.
description: QUIGG-H.D., Jr. May 12, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Polly, devoted father of Susan. Funeral service to take place in Boonville, MO. on Saturday May 16, 1998. A memorial service in New York will be announced at a later date.

title: PC Makers Cool to Microsoft's Push for WebTV
description: One of the few innovations in Microsoft's Windows 98 operating system is the integration of television-viewing software, but many makers of personal computers are giving it the cold shoulder.

title: Conjuring a Dead Husband to Ease the Loneliness
description: GLORIE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, BETH FINE
description: KAPLAN-Beth Fine. Age 41. Beloved wife of Daniel. Loving mother of Joshua and Aaron. Loving sister of Janet Fine and Diane Fine. Devoted daughter of Charles and the late Marylln Fine. Cherished daughter-in-law of Mickey and Jeri Kaplan. Also survived by many other relatives and many, many friends. Funeral services & interment were held in Chicago. For contribution info. Please call 1800-288-5701

title: In an Immigrant's Tatters, Comfort for the Dreamers
description: In America, where nothing succeeds like success, newspapers and magazines endlessly celebrate the entrepreneurs who preside over vast corporations, amass great personal fortunes and even have the foresight to float clear of failure in golden parachutes.

title: Raising the Dead for Guest Appearances
description: Gary, the hero of the struggling CBS series ''Early Edition,'' usually gets a copy of tomorrow's paper today and wards off a future tragedy. In Saturday's episode he gets bopped on the head and lands in the 19th century instead. On his return he tries desperately to explain this to his best friend, Chuck, only to be interrupted by an unmistakable voice and face.

title: Web Site Designed to Let Free Speech Ring Out
description: Proponents of free speech may have found a new window of expression on the Internet with a Web site that is dedicated to posting censored and banned writing on line.

title: House Proud; My Son, the Decorator
description: WHEN you're a decorator you don't go for the throat. You go for the furniture.

title: Charge Dropped By Morgenthau
description: Beaten to the punch by Federal prosecutors, the Manhattan District Attorney's office is dropping its own effort to press charges against a former Wall Street compliance officer who has admitted selling inside information.

title: As a Civilization Crumbles, Mechanical Goliaths Battle
description: THERE are two ways to convey the power of machines. One way is to make them small and sleek and quiet, powerful in their discretion, the kind of toys that James Bond carries around. The other is to make them out of seven-inch-thick steel with huge rattling engines and big rusty bolts, powerful in their sheer mass, the way battleships are powerful. In our age of micronism, where everything is getting smaller and faster, design caters to the former esthetic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, AARON
description: KAUFMAN-Aaron, born 1897. Devoted husband of Carry Kaufman. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. At Judge Kaufman's request, funeral arrangements are private.

title: National News Briefs; Restitution for Bombing Is Imposed on Nichols
description: Judge Richard P. Matsch of Federal District Court said today that he would order Terry L. Nichols to pay $14.5 million in restitution for conspiring to bomb the Federal Building in Oklahoma City and set June 4 as Mr. Nichols's sentencing date.

title: Offense, Defense, ... Wilkins Is Ready
description: Rick Wilkins knows plenty about offensive expectations, strange as that may seem for someone who hasn't played more than 84 major league games in a season since 1994.

title: Metro Matters; Liberal Party Has One Ideal: Its Survival
description: RAYMOND B. HARDING is his own smoke-filled room.

description: In percent

title: Belfast Journal; 'Silly Cows' of Ulster Take the Bull by the Horns
description: It might have been the spectacle, immortalized on national television, of a male politician telling a member of the Northern Ireland Women's Coalition to ''shut up and sit down, you stupid woman.''

title: Holyfield Expects A Clean Fight
description: Evander Holyfield said yesterday that when he defends his World Boxing Association and International Boxing Federation titles on June 6 at Madison Square Garden against Henry Akinwande, he does not expect the same type of dancing and clutching that Akinwande displayed against Lennox Lewis last year.

title: Riots Break Out in Jakarta After Shooting of Students
description: Riots exploded near the central business district of the Indonesian capital today as residents outraged over the police shootings of students on Tuesday tore down lampposts, set fire to trucks and looted stores.

title: Panel to Vote on Measure To Tighten Bankruptcy Law
description: With the number of personal bankruptcies soaring, the House Judiciary Committee considered a controversial bill today, promoted by the banking and credit-card industries to make it more difficult for people to declare themselves legally broke.

title: Donald Conroy, 77, Model For 'The Great Santini,' Dies
description: Col. Donald Conroy, a storied Marine fighter pilot whose domestic code dictated that he never strike his daughters and not begin beating his sons until after they had learned to walk, died on Saturday at a hospital in Beaufort, S.C. He was 77 and best known as the model for the tyrannical title character in the book and movie ''The Great Santini.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about New York Apple Tours' new bus ride through Brooklyn misstated the year the Brooklyn Bridge was completed. It was 1883, not 1893.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLANCY, KEVIN F.
description: CLANCY-Kevin F. Of Yonkers, N.Y. On May 12th, 1998. Beloved husband of Nancy (Ann Marie Williams). Dear father of Kevin and Nora. Loving son of Nora O'Brien Clancy & the late James J. Clancy. Brother of Maureen Bellis, Patricia Coxen, Joseph Clancy and the late James P. Clancy. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Son-inlaw of Anne Williams. Brother-inlaw of William K. Williams. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home Bronxville, between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9PM Thursday and Friday. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Saturday, May 16th, 9 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorials to The Leukemia Society of America.

title: Steinbrenner Laments Crowd
description: As expected, George Steinbrenner issued a statement yesterday lamenting the small crowd at the Yankees' game with Kansas City on Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium. Steinbrenner also praised Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for urging fans to go to Yankee games.

title: Unexpected Profit at Tele-Communications
description: Tele-Communications Inc. reported an unexpected profit in the first quarter -- its first in more than two years -- on strong demand for digital cable television and a surge in advertising.

title: Even in a Game, a Formula One Course Can Test Courage
description: F1 RACING SIMULATION

title: Chase Manhattan Picks Foote, Cone
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has ended one of the most closely watched reviews by selecting Foote, Cone & Belding in New York to handle its consolidated corporate branding, worldwide consumer and business-to-business advertising account. Though billings had previously been estimated at $40 million to $50 million, they were estimated yesterday at $75 million.

title: Both Sides of Spam
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivals' Elbows Jostling Palm Pilot
description: FOR two years, the Palm Pilot has had a unique hold on consumers. More than a million of the little computers have been sold. It has no keyboard, but it has room for many addresses, a date book, games and translators. And it can be dressed up with a modem and the ability to send faxes, exchange E-mail and surf the Web. And it has had next to no competition.

title: Two Studies Shed New Light On Cocaine's Effect on Brain
description: The leading hypothesis for how cocaine works in the brain appears to be wrong, or at least incomplete, according to two studies being reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OSMUNDSEN, LITA
description: OSMUNDSEN-Lita. August, 1926 to January, 1998. Memorial Service at the New York Academy of Sciences, 2 East 63 St., NYC, Thursday, May 14th, at 6PM.

title: Guarantees? Pacers Eliminate Knicks
description: There were still a few seconds left on the clock when Patrick Ewing unwrapped his wrist tape, wadded it up and discarded the support he had needed to bang, score and rebound.

title: MARSULEX ACQUIRING 2 COMPANIES FROM TRELLEBORG
description: Marsulex Inc., a Canadian environmental concern, agreed yesterday to acquire two chemical waste-handling businesses from the Swedish industrial conglomerate Trelleborg A.B. for $51 million. The companies are Intertrade Holdings Inc. and the BCT Chemtrade Corporation, which have combined annual revenue of $130 million. Marsulex provides environmental services to the mining, oil refining and electric utility industries. Intertrade, based in Atlanta, provides removal and resale services to generators of sulfur-based byproducts. Chemtrade, based in Zug, Switzerland, works with smelters and oil refineries, mostly in northern Europe, to remove sulfur and sulfuric acid.

title: Holmes May Get Dream Bout
description: It looks as if Larry Holmes will get his wish: a fight with George Foreman. Plans are under way for the two to square off on either this Oct. 3 or Jan. 10, 1999, Foreman's 50th birthday. Holmes will turn 49 on Nov. 3. The tentative sites for the fight are Houston at the Astrodome, Atlantic City, Las Vegas or Madison Square Garden.

title: India Has a Right To Nuclear Security
description: To the Editor:

title: City Is Sued By a Woman Whose Home Was Raided
description: The no-knock search warrant, for a drug raid that the police carried out last June at 396 New Jersey Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn, was quite specific. ''Upon reaching the second-floor landing,'' it said, ''one turns to the left and proceeds to the gray metal door clearly marked with the letter and number '2M.' ''

title: Kalman Seigel, 80, Times Editor Who Oversaw Letters to Editor
description: Kalman Seigel, who spent 13 of his 41 years at The New York Times as editor of the Letters to the Editor department of the paper, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. and Russia Reach Accord on Weapons Inspections in Iraq
description: The United States and Russia have reached a broad agreement on how to proceed with future nuclear-arms inspections of Iraq now that the International Atomic Energy Agency has declared itself ready to move out of an active disarmament phase and into long-term monitoring.

title: Lopez Is Back on the Prowl Seeking Past Glory
description: It has been 20 years since Nancy Lopez roared to the forefront of women's golf, winning a record-setting five consecutive tournaments, and becoming the Ladies Professional Golf Association's most recognizable face.

title: CD Quality Vs. Vinyl
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Island Man Held In Customs Agent's Death
description: A Long Island man was arrested yesterday in connection with the 1981 slaying of an off-duty United States Customs Service officer, the police said.

title: Pakistan Looks Ready to Test Its Own Bomb
description: Pakistan is preparing for an underground nuclear test that could take place as early as Sunday, American officials said today, citing clear signs from spy satellites, foreign agents and Pakistan's political leaders.

title: Racing's Thrills Without Dirt or Danger
description: VIRTUAL reality comes in many forms. One evening in 1976, for example, I went putt-putting around the streets of Monaco in a Mini-Cooper, not much more than a motorized garden shed, following the same course that the world's best racing drivers would take the next day in their Formula One cars.

title: Marcos Family Big Winners in Philippine Elections
description: MANILA  For the family of the late President Ferdinand Marcos, election day has emerged as a turning point in its drive for renewed power and respectability in the Philippines, and aides are now openly talking of a possible presidential pardon for his widow, Imelda.

title: Ousted Again in Round 2, Knicks Ponder Future
description: Ernie Grunfeld did not want to disclose his off-season personnel plans fresh off the team's fourth straight second-round elimination in the playoffs.

title: Chronicling Family Life High Above the City
description: ACROSS the nation the talk may be of ''Seinfeld,'' but in Central Park, the bird-watchers who call themselves the Central Park Regulars couldn't care less. They are hanging out on their usual perch, a bench beside the Boat Pond, their high-powered mounted telescopes and binoculars fixed on the Fifth Avenue co-op across the way.

title: Man Ray Without The Secrets
description: The new Man Ray show at the Grand Palais is not one that he would have been likely to endorse. Like many an artist, Man Ray, an expatriate American, was secretive about the way he worked and he was careful about what he displayed. Indeed, well before his death here in 1976 at the age of 86, he had selected just a few dozen photographs -- including the images that forged his reputation -- for frequent exhibition around the world. And he seemed happy to forget the rest.

title: New Faces Put Spark in Newark Election
description: Spirited and surprisingly close campaigns waged by a number of younger candidates have forced runoff elections next month for six at-large and ward City Council seats in Newark, and led to an apparent upset in one other Council race.

title: Banque Nationale Offers To Buy Rest of Unit
description: Banque Nationale de Paris S.A., France's second-largest retail bank, said yesterday that it was offering to buy the 18.1 percent of its Banque Nationale de Paris Intercontinentale S.A. unit that it does not own for 1.1 billion French francs ($186 million). It is offering three of its shares, plus 21 francs in cash, for each share of the unit, a 13.5 percent premium to the unit's closing price of 1,420 francs on Tuesday.

title: India Has a Right To Nuclear Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JAMES A.
description: HENRY-James A. Beloved husband of Carole Wiley Henry. Loving father of Julie and Judd. Dear step-father of Dina and David. Cherished grandfather. Services Thursday, May 14, 1998, 1PM, at Congregation Kol Ami (JCC), 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY.

title: Racers Battered
description: Brisk winds and rough seas battered competitors yesterday off Cape Hatteras, N.C., in the Worrell 1000, the 1,000-mile catamaran race along the East Coast. Leading by 7 minutes after 11 days of racing was Chick's Beach, a 20-foot multihull being sailed by the defending champions, Randy Smyth and Jason Sneed, both of Fort Walton Beach, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIS, HERBERT
description: CHASIS-Herbert, M.D. Age 92. Professor of Medicine, New York University School of Medicine. Died peacefully on May 11, 1998. Survived by wife Barbara Parker, daughters Joel Anne and Sarah, grandchildren Dan and Garrett Roll and Rachel and Jonathan Hiles, and sons-in-law Joe Roll and Clay Hiles. Services are private. Memorial service at a later date. Contributions may be made to NYU School of Medicine for the Herbert Chasis Memorial Fund, Facility and Friends Campaign, 550 First Avenue, NYC 10016.

title: Bankruptcies By Musicians Inspire a Bill
description: The House Judiciary Committee approved today a bankruptcy bill that includes a special provision for record companies, making it harder for singers to break their contracts by filing for bankruptcy.

title: A Throwback To Hitchcock
description: How do people whose lives have been devoted to quotidian pursuits like socializing and maintaining normal jobs suddenly excel at plotting, or foiling, immensely complex murders?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIMES, MADELAINE
description: HAIMES-Madelaine. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Madelaine Haimes. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Qwest Marketing Deal With Ameritech
description: Qwest Communications International announced today that it had an agreement with the Ameritech Corporation to market their long-distance and local telephone services jointly.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS -- Cinderella, Italy Preps For Euro Ball; But as Midnight Nears, Some Business Sectors Brace for Pain
description: Giovanni Franco Masello sheds no tears over the imminent demise of the Italian lira. Pietro Montagna sometimes wishes the funeral could be delayed a bit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Wins Reprieve From Big Antitrust Action

title: Yanks' Bullpen Fumbles Away Lead and Game
description: The Yankees have stared down the American League for six weeks. Last night, they blinked.

title: Equitable Adopts Stock Buyback Plan
description: The Equitable Companies has adopted a plan to buy up to eight million shares of its stock in what would be the first such effort by the concern, a financial services company.

title: Giuliani Threatens Action If Cabbies Fail to Cancel a Protest
description: Escalating his showdown with the city's taxi drivers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani threatened yesterday to allow vans and livery cars to pick up passengers off the street beginning on Monday unless yellow cab drivers cancel plans to hold another demonstration next week.

title: Nature's Ancient Handiwork
description: ''Deep Impact,'' a film about a comet barreling toward earth, was No. 1 at the box office last weekend, earning $49.1 million. This weekend you can buy your own meteorite, that is, a fragment from outer space that has already hit the earth. Phillips New York is auctioning a total of 50 of them from Siberia, China, the United States, Argentina and Germany, as well as fossils, minerals and Mars rocks, at its natural history sale on Sunday at 1 P.M., at 406 East 79th Street, Manhattan.

title: Political Briefing; California Labor Gains on Ballot Plan
description: Polls show that more than half of all California voters still favor an initiative on the June 2 primary ballot that would require unions to get written approval from members before using their dues to promote political causes. But support is slipping.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: A 20-Year-Old Rookie Shoots a 65 With Poise
description: People who have watched Se Ri Pak play golf have been predicting a special performance like today's.

title: Sprint to Salute Candice Bergen
description: The final bows Candice Bergen will take on the last episode of ''Murphy Brown,'' to appear Monday night on CBS, have been overshadowed by the end of ''Seinfeld'' last night on NBC. The Sprint Corporation, for which Ms. Bergen has served as a spokeswoman since 1990, will try to offset that disparity with a special commercial saluting her.

title: Role of Military: A Potential Unifier Split by Conflicting Goals
description: As Indonesia suffers its worst crisis in 30 years, its capital seething with rage and its President struggling to keep control, the key to the nation's future lies increasingly in the hands of its powerful military.

title: Is He a Werewolf, or Just a Little Hairy?
description: Trinh, a blond lesbian waitress who never takes off her sunglasses, has a new girlfriend. Katherine, a soft-spoken young wife, is having daylong blackouts. Phil, a mild-mannered payroll manager, thinks he's turning into a werewolf.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Times Mirror Buys Interest In Rival Group
description: The Times Mirror Company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times and other papers, said yesterday that it had made an investment in Garden State Newspapers Inc., the parent company of the Los Angeles Newspaper Group, one of its chief local competitors, and had agreed to a local joint advertising venture with it.

title: Davis Looking Toward August
description: Every three weeks or so, Chili Davis appears at Yankee Stadium for treatment or examination of his surgically repaired ankle, and he feels as if he is progressing well. But his return to the lineup is still more than two months away.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: House Votes to Bar Religious Abuses Abroad
description: The House overwhelmingly approved a bill today to punish foreign countries that persecute people for their religious beliefs.

title: Ever a Pragmatist, Microsoft Compromises
description: Microsoft's last-minute gesture toward the Justice Department, a new-found taste for compromise in the hopes of avoiding a major antitrust suit, speaks volumes about the company.

title: Man Said to Be Zodiac Killer Becomes Enraged at Trial
description: Heriberto Seda waited nearly two years to dispute the charge that he is the Zodiac killer, a violent criminal who preyed on the vulnerable and who terrorized the city in two separate crime sprees in the early 1990's.

title: Sideline Wisdom
description: When Larry Bird agreed last year to become the head coach of the Indiana Pacers, there were many doubters. Few superstars have made the successful transition from playing to coaching. Why should Bird break the mold?

title: Commencement; Gore Promotes Privacy Bill at N.Y.U.
