description: Under a cloudless sky, Washington Square Park blossomed with violet and white balloons and pompoms yesterday morning as Vice President Al Gore, Spike Lee and 14,000 graduates and their guests gathered for New York University's 166th commencement.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section yesterday misstated the date of a tribute to the poet Allen Ginsberg at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. It was yesterday; it is not today.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Treasury Securities Prices Fall on Fears of Higher Interest Rates
description: The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday after a report on consumer prices kept alive concern the Federal Reserve may increase interest rates, though few expect a move when central bankers meet Tuesday.

title: Mayor Opposes Parking Limits on Outsiders
description: Three city councilmen proposed yesterday that parking spaces in New York City should be reserved for its residents, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that the plan might be illegal.

title: Killer of 3 Is Mentally Fit to Be Executed, a California Jury Finds
description: A competency hearing that was supposed to have lasted a week ended here today after more than a month when a divided Marin County jury found a deeply disturbed death-row inmate with an IQ hovering in the 60's mentally fit enough to be executed.

title: Galaxies Apart in Style Yet Following a Certain Path
description: Wednesday evening's chamber concert at Merkin Hall, presented by the League of Composers/I.S.C.M., included five pieces, wildly different in style and achievement, but with a few recurrent features. Three had handmade piano sounds, plucked or muted inside the instrument. All the composers, when called upon to talk about their music during a break in the program, drew on analogies from modern science: chaos theory, the structure of galaxies. And yet -- though perhaps this is not such a big contradiction -- most of the pieces turned out to be rather traditional in moving evenly through time by means of motivic development and instrumental dialogue.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MCDONALD'S CORP., Oak Brook, Ill., the restaurant chain, plans to invest more than $400 million to open 400 restaurants in Central Europe in the next three years.

title: Earnings Climb 61% At German Utility Giant
description: Veba A.G., Germany's largest utility company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit soared 61 percent as gains from asset sales more than offset losses at its United States silicon wafer unit. Veba, which also has interests in oil, chemicals and telecommunications, said its first-quarter profit jumped to 905 million marks, or $509.6 million, up from 560 marks in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: 'Seinfeld' Goes Out in Self-Referential Style
description: The endless frenzy about the end of ''Seinfeld'' has certainly exaggerated its impact and importance. Reports on the show and its stars read like obituaries, and it all became ludicrous. They're not dead; they've just quit. But that frenzy and the weak current season have also obscured the show's genuine strengths.

title: A One-Man New York-Washington Shuttle
description: MANY executives bounce between private industry and public service in the course of their careers. But Frank G. Zarb seems to oscillate, like a radio wave, between Wall Street and Washington.

title: Republicans Crush Effort To Chastise a Chairman
description: In the latest salvo over the beleaguered House inquiry into campaign fund-raising, Republicans fought off a bid by Democrats to chastise the chairman of the panel spearheading the investigation.

title: Joy of Living, and Singing
description: ''The secret of life is enjoying the passage of time,'' Rosemary Clooney sings in the opening number of her new cabaret act at Rainbow and Stars. The how-to-be-happy advice song by James Taylor includes the observation that ''if we're on our way down, we might as well enjoy the ride.''

title: Sports of The Times; We'll Get 'Em Next Year? It Doesn't Jibe
description: A RARE presence in the Knicks' locker room who has been part of a championship team said that painful losing was part of the natural progression. Brendan Malone joined the Detroit Pistons as an assistant coach in 1988, one season after a phantom foul against Bill Laimbeer on Kareem Abdul-Jabbar cost them a title, which was one season after a shocking steal of Isiah Thomas's inbounds pass by Larry Bird denied them their first title series.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUIT SAYS IT RECEIVED TAKEOVER OFFER
description: Integrated Circuit Systems Inc., a chip maker based in Valley Forge, Pa., said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from an undisclosed buyer. The company's stock closed 43.75 cents higher, at $18.6875, giving the company a market capitalization of $232 million. Earlier in the day, the stock touched $22, which is half of its 52-week high in October. The company makes frequency-timing generators to help personal computers keep track of time. It also makes chips used in Fast Ethernet cards that connect personal computers to networks.

title: Value of Spin On Wall Street Is $15 Billion To 2 Companies
description: What's the value of some good spin on Wall Street nowadays? By yesterday's reckoning, about $15 billion.

title: Playground Legend In Critical Condition
description: Earl Manigault, one of New York's playground basketball legends of the 1960's and 1970's, is in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital, a spokesman at the hospital said last night. Manigault has heart problems and has been in the hospital for two weeks.

title: MEDPARTNERS SAYS IT WILL DISMISS 900 WORKERS
description: Medpartners Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss about 900 of its 9,500 employees in Southern California as the company, an operator of physician practices, struggles to return to profitability under a new chief executive. The company, based in Birmingham, Ala., said the cuts include 49 of 998 doctors it employs in the region. It will impose a temporary 7 percent pay cut on the physicians who are not losing their jobs. These are the first dismissals since Medpartners hired Mac Crawford, who engineered a turnaround at Magellan Health Services Inc., as chief executive in March. He was brought in after the company posted a larger-than-expected fourth-quarter loss. Medpartners' stock fell 37.5 cents, to $9.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Indispensable I.M.F.
description: Suppose a group of prominent experts declared that the Federal Reserve should no longer be allowed to lend money during bank runs. Far from helping prevent financial panics, they say, such lending actually fosters them by encouraging the public to be careless; if we returned to the good old days when banks were free to fail, depositors would make sure that a bank was sound before placing money in its care.

title: Sunset for President Suharto
description: There are no magical answers to the political and economic troubles engulfing Indonesia. A lethal combination of corruption, irresponsible economic management and autocratic leadership has brought the world's fourth-most-populous nation to the brink of chaos. But it is now clear that recovery cannot begin as long as President Suharto remains in power.

title: Obscure Videos In Abundance
description: When he ran a chain of video stores in New England, Stuart Skorman didn't stint on film categories. (He had more than 200 of them, he said.) On Reel.com, the video site he began on the Internet two years ago (www.reel.com), the categories, from ''burned-out cops'' to ''so bad it's good,'' now number about 7,000.

title: Israelis Shouldn't Question Stability of Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, A. WILLING.
description: PATTERSON-A. Willing. Age 87 of Gladwyne, PA., on May 13, 1998. Husband of Leila D. Patterson, father of Leila P. Peck, Eleanora Patterson and David D. Patterson. Also survived by 4 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held 3PM Saturday, May 16, in the Church of the Redeemer, Pennswood and New Gulph Roads, Bryn Mawr, PA. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his name may be made to: American Friends Service Committee, International Division, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, PA 19102. Stuard Funeral Home, Ardmore, PA, 610-649-0243.

title: Drug Is Found to Fight Return of Breast Cancer
description: The anti-breast cancer drug tamoxifen significantly reduces the rates of recurrence and death from the disease among a surprisingly wide range of women but is being prescribed to far too few patients, researchers reported yesterday in the world's largest analysis of any cancer treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NELSON, DORIS SIEGEL.
description: NELSON-Doris Siegel. In loving memory of our dearest mother, grandmother & motherin-law who remains always in our thoughts. We miss you. Elizabeth, Margery, Jonathan, Karen, Amy, Andrea, Meredith, Bill, Laurie and Maisie

title: Wesley A. Pomeroy, 78, Security Chief at Woodstock Festival
description: Wesley A. Pomeroy, a peace-loving peace officer who maintained order with such friendly persuasion at the 1964 Republican National Convention in San Francisco that he was recruited by the Justice Department and who later became a counterculture hero as the benign and highly effective security chief at the 1969 Woodstock music festival, died on May 4 at a hospital near his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 78 and had retired in 1995 as head of the Dade County police review board.

title: After the Homer: Works at a Price
description: News that William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, paid more than $30 million for a major seascape by Winslow Homer last week has set off debate among American art collectors and dealers over whether the already heated market for American paintings will rise even more -- perhaps another 25 percent -- at the important auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's next week. Not only was the price a record for an American painting, but it also catapulted American fine art into the same financial stratosphere as European paintings.

title: News Corp. Role In Bidding Seen
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation will invest in a bid by Michael R. Milken and others for the Simon & Schuster publishing house, a person close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Brawley Witness Ends Testimony After 24 Days
description: After 24 days on the witness stand, Steven A. Pagones completed his testimony yesterday in his defamation suit against three former advisers of Tawana Brawley.

title: Akinwande to Spar At Penn Station
description: Henry Akinwande, who will meet Evander Holyfield in a heavyweight title bout at Madison Square Garden on June 6, will hold a public workout at noon on Monday at New York's Penn Station.

title: Tragedy Waiting to Happen, and the Sad, Brutish Youth at Its Center
description: ''Life of Jesus'' (''La Vie de Jesus'') was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 8, 1997. The film opens today at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: On My Mind; The Shout From India
description: The decision was made by India, and India will pay the economic price. But Americans should understand that it was the West, particularly the U.S., that built the policy road leading to the Indian underground explosions.

title: Inner Child's Pain Endures In Adulthood
description: The drama of an urbane gay man returning to the provinces to confront the ghosts of his troubled youth is such a familiar scenario that it hardly bears repeating. But Thom Fitzgerald's film ''The Hanging Garden,'' which veers wildly between harrowing kitchen-sink realism and surreal fantasy, adds enough bizarre touches (including the naming of its characters after various herbs and flowers) to this version of the prodigal son parable that it reinvents the formula.

title: Recruit Sticking With St. John's, for Now
description: Whoever replaces Fran Fraschilla should add ''Can get along with Anthony Glover'' to his resume.

title: Tension? What Tension? Not on a Smiley Day for Netanyahu.
description: Far from the bickering of his own Parliament, away from the tensions of the negotiating table, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu finally found a refuge of welcome today, in the hallways and lunchrooms of Congress.

title: Think Like Callas, Jump Like a Cat
description: Rare is the ballet star who creates a new image of a familiar role and even of what dancing can be.

title: McDougal Wrote Of Lie, Lawyer Says
description: Susan H. McDougal's lawyer said at her arraignment today that he had a document from her late husband, a major witness in the Whitewater case, suggesting that he considered lying in exchange for immunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, LEWIS A.
description: PHILLIPS-Lewis A. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the staff of the Jeanette & Morris Kessel Volunteer Services Department in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Lewis A. Phillips, cousin of Beth Israel Trustee Carol P. Green, and her brother, our generous benefactor Lawrence Phillips. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and worked with him. To the entire Phillips family and all who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Board of Trustees Matthew E. Sink, M.D., President Terry Williams, Director Jeanette and Morris Kessel Volunteer Services Department

title: Pepsi Official Opposes Exclusive Drink Deals
description: In a carefully choreographed act of saber-rattling before an audience of his peers, Philip A. Marineau, the president of Pepsi-Cola North America, declared Pepsi's desire for ''freedom of choice'' yesterday and said exclusive deals pursued by soft-drink companies were not ideal for consumers.

title: $17.3 Million 'Marilyn' Sets Record for Warhol
description: ''Orange Marilyn,'' Andy Warhol's iconic 1964 image of Marilyn Monroe, broke all records for the artist and became the highest-priced painting of the spring auction season last night when it was sold at Sotheby's for $17.3 million, more than four times the previous record for a Warhol. Two unidentified telephone bidders fought a tense battle, and when it ended, the packed salesroom burst into thunderous applause.

title: A Pregnant Candidate Discovers She's an Issue
description: As she ordered a morning latte in Boston's Faneuil Hall Marketplace today, Jane Swift made a point of making the point that it was only a decaf.

title: Ban on Land Mines Goes Too Far; Mixed Comfort
description: To the Editor:

title: Professor Named S.E.C. Counsel
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission named Harvey J. Goldschmid, a Columbia University law professor, today as its top lawyer.

title: Philips-Seagram Deal Seen Near
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V. has given the Seagram Company an exclusive arrangement through Monday to negotiate an acquisition of Polygram N.V., the music company, according to a person close to the discussions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSHINS, SUSAN REINGOLD.
description: OSHINS-Susan Reingold. Cherished wife of the late Alfred Beno Oshins, devoted mother of E.J., Jo Ann, & son-in-law Ray, treasured sister of Barbara Diamond, Joyce Baumgarten, and the late Ruth Joseph, loving aunt, and loyal friend. Our 'SuSu'. A New Yorkers' New Yorker. Shared her energy, verve, and civic pride with The Hunger Project, Manhattan Theater Club, n.g.o. at the UN, School Volunteers and Abzug campaigns. Her optimism & courage inspired and guided all. She will always be a sparkling presence in our universe. Donations in memory to: The Hunger Project, 15 East 26th Street, New York, New York 10010. 212-251-9100

title: Helms Plans $100 Million Aid Package for Cuba
description: Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, proposed a $100 million aid package for Cuba today that he said would improve the lives of Cubans while weakening the hold of Fidel Castro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, BERNARD
description: SCHNEIDER-Bernard. On May 13, 1998. Dearly beloved husband of Adele. Loving father of Evan and Mindy. Devoted brother of Shirley Becker. Dear father-in-law of Susan and Tim. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Emily and Maxwell. Service today, 10 A.M., at The Riverdale Temple. In lieu of flowers, donations to National Stroke Assn, 96 Inverness Drive East, Suite I, Englewood, CO 80112-5112.

title: Padres Hand Mets Double Disappointment
description: Forgive Dennis Cook if Tony Gwynn starts showing up in his nightmares. Plenty of other National League pitchers know the feeling.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Chantal Akerman

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 26 about a proposal to promote skeptical scientific views of the theory of global warming included an organization incorrectly among the proposal's advocates. The Science and Environmental Policy Project was invited to participate but declined, according to its spokeswoman, Candace Crandall. A spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute confirms that a memorandum by an employee, on which the article was based, identified Ms. Crandall incorrectly as a member of the committee that drafted the proposal.

title: U.S. Talks With Israel On Mideast Move Slowly
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel ended a second round of talks this evening without achieving a breakthrough on reviving stalled Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Papa John's Pizza Deal
description: PJ America Inc. said today that it had acquired a 22-store Papa John's Pizza territory in southern Louisiana, which includes nine existing restaurants and five under development. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. PJ America, based in Birmingham, is a large franchisee of Papa John's International Inc. restaurants. The company had sales of $34.5 million for the first nine months of 1997. Papa John's is based in Louisville, Ky. The company had revenues of $364.1 million for the first nine months of 1997.

title: INSIDE
description: Cancer Drug Is Underused

title: Fastest Rise In Six Months For Price Index
description: Consumer prices in the United States rose in April at the fastest pace in six months, the Government said today in a report that suggested inflation might accelerate from the 30-year lows reached earlier this year.

title: Domestic Partners' Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: Vouchers Can Ease School Crowding
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrat Fund-Raiser Said to Detail China Tie
description: A Democratic fund-raiser has told Federal investigators he funneled tens of thousands of dollars from a Chinese military officer to the Democrats during President Clinton's 1996 re-election campaign, according to lawyers and officials with knowledge of the Justice Department's campaign finance inquiry.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Jewish settlements in the West Bank referred incorrectly in some editions to the meeting between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright that Israel's Infrastructures Minister, Ariel Sharon, refused to attend. It was the one in Washington this week, not the one in London last week.

title: Allied Signal Buys 2 Concerns
description: Allied Signal Inc. said today that it would acquire two closely held companies to bolster its specialty chemicals and plastics businesses.

title: Driver Hits 2 Pedestrians And a Child On East Side
description: A woman trying to park her car on the Upper East Side of Manhattan jumped a curb yesterday, striking two pedestrians and the small child who was with them, the police said. One of the pedestrians, a 48-year-old woman, was pinned against the stone wall of a building and was rescued by passers-by, the police added.

title: Monsanto-Cargill Genetic Venture
description: The Monsanto Company and Cargill Inc. agreed today to form a joint venture to develop genetically enhanced food and feed products, linking Monsanto's gene technology with one of the world's most powerful food-processing and distribution companies.

title: New Video Releases
description: As Good as It Gets

title: Bill Would Scuttle Gambling Cruises
description: Gambling cruises from New Jersey like those based in New York would not even be allowed to leave the dock under a bill approved by the Assembly Commerce Committee yesterday.

title: Ban on Land Mines Goes Too Far
description: To the Editor:

title: House G.O.P. Leader Opens Drive to Kill Campaign Finance Bills
description: As the House prepares to take up campaign finance legislation next week, the House majority whip began the Republican assault today on efforts to revise the way campaign money is raised, saying the measures would violate free speech and weaken political parties.

title: Dark Days of a Contemporary Cave Man
description: The darkness was so profound I couldn't tell whether my eyes were open or shut. I was in a ''wild'' cave in Central Pennsylvania, in a chamber 100 feet below the ground, with no idea which way was out. The five experienced cavers I was with had suggested we turn off our headlamps to show me, the novice, how dark it is in a place where the full-time residents use sonar to get around.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BOSTON CHICKEN INC., Golden, Colo., named Lawrence White chief financial officer, filling the post vacated by Mark Stephens earlier this month during sweeping management resignations.

title: Korea Lifts Limits On Foreign Investment
description: South Korea will scrap restrictions on foreign ownership of stocks from May 22, the Finance and Economy Ministry said yesterday. The changes will allow foreigners to own 100 percent of most companies -- up from 55 percent -- and 30 percent of two state-owned companies, the Pohang Iron and Steel Company and the Korea Electric Power Corporation, up from 25 percent now.

title: Developer Seeking Campaign Reform Tops Lobby List
description: Forest City Ratner, a major New York developer whose president pledged recently to help curtail the influence of big donors on the city's political campaigns, spent more on lobbying the municipal government last year than any other business group, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Yonkers Spends $700,000 To Settle Police Assault Suit
description: Four and half years ago, a retired Yonkers police officer smiled in relief and an active police officer brushed away tears as they heard a Federal jury pronounce them not guilty of charges that they took two handcuffed Irish immigrants to a deserted railroad station and beat them with nightsticks.

title: German Central Bank Leaves Rates Unchanged
description: The Bundesbank left its full set of interest rates unchanged at its meeting yesterday, confirming expectations that the German central bank is not ready yet to help short-term interest rates converge across Europe. The bank left its floor discount rate unchanged at 2.50 percent and its ceiling Lombard rate, at which it makes emergency loans to banks, at 4.50 percent. The Bundesbank also kept its securities repurchase rate at 3.30 percent.

title: 9 Palestinians Die in Protests Marking Israel's Anniversary
description: Palestinians today marked the 50th anniversary of the creation of Israel, an event they call the ''catastrophe,'' with two minutes of silence and several hours of violence during which Israeli forces fired on crowds and nine Palestinians were left dead.

title: What's Green, Newly Mown And Irksome?
description: ''Lawn Dogs'' is about the unlikely alliance between a smart little girl and a charmingly insouciant gardener. United by loathing for the squeaky-clean suburb where Devon (Mischa Barton) lives and Trent (Sam Rockwell) mows lawns, these two are drawn together by loneliness and a shared spirit of mischief. While John Duigan's pointedly whimsical film overworks the fairy-tale aspect of this friendship, it also shows off a poised young actress and a leading man with charisma to burn. Sooner or later, Mr. Rockwell's robust good looks and wryly engaging manner will put him on the map.

title: Studies of Mental Illness Show Links to Violence
description: After a generation of believing that the mentally ill are no more violent than other people, psychiatrists and advocates for the emotionally disturbed are wrestling with studies that show that the mentally ill may indeed be more violent in some circumstances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEILER, ANNETTE
description: WEILER-Annette. On May 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Edwin. Loving mother of Elaine Asch-Root and special mother to Mildred Guzman. Cherished grandmother to Andrew and Thomas and special friend of Altagracia Nunoz. Services private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Humane Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPARBER, BEATRICE
description: SPARBER-Beatrice. Beloved wife (59 years) of Norman. Dearest mother of Merryl & Roy. Darling grandmother & great grandmother. She leaves a tremendous void in all of our lives. Services are at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre on Sunday, May 17 at 12:15 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEEL, TED
description: SCHEEL-Ted. Caricaturist-Cartoonist, Author, former member St. Louis Cycling Club. On May 8, 1998. Age 99. In New York City. Adored husband of Lita, beloved father of Eugene and family. Cherished uncle of Tinker. His wit, gentleness, modesty and encouragement of the talents of others will forever enrich the lives of those he touched.

title: An irreverent agency creates a campaign to help a fledgling Episcopal church expand its reach.
description: A PRODUCTION studio best known for irreverent cartoons for ''Saturday Night Live'' might seem an unlikely choice for church advertising. But the campaign for a fledgling Episcopal church in suburban Maryland is unconventional by design.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFT, BUNNEE L.
description: TAFT-Bunnee L. In Norwalk, CT, on May 13, 1998. Predeceased by husband, Allen R. Taft, and son, James Gordon Taft. Devoted mother of Denise Taft Davidoff of Norwalk, CT, sister of Robert Zuckerman of Valley Stream, NY, Martin Zuckerman of Buffalo Grove, IL, grandmother of Douglass Taft Davidoff, Lauren Taft Balk, John O.A. Davidoff, Peter James Taft, James Gordon Taft, and great grandmother of seven. Services Friday 1:00PM, at Old Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY. Memorial contributions to American Friends of The Hebrew University 11900 Biscayne Blvd, Suite 410, N. Miami, FL 33181-2726.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Mangelos

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Minister is Sentenced In Pornography Case
description: A psychoanalyst and part-time minister in Chatham was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison for ordering pornographic video tapes of children through the mail, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Increased Production Compounds Problems for Gold
description: No wonder gold is in trouble. Last year, when the price of gold plunged below $300 an ounce to an 18-year low, what did the world's gold mines do? They produced more gold.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Israeli Police In a Clash With Arabs
description: Gunfire echoed through rubble-strewn streets in East Jerusalem today as the commercial heart of the Arab area became a battleground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACE, NEIL
description: PACE-Neil. On May 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Carol Share Pace. Devoted father of Matthew and Marcy Pace. Loving son of the late Mary and Benjamin and Ilse Pace. Dear brother of Richard Pace and James Mann. Graveside service Friday, at 2 P.M., New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Fighting Received Wisdom With Heart, Mind and Soul
description: A MOTHER'S PLACE

title: Companies Pull Back To Protect Employees
description: After yesterday's violence in Indonesia, foreign companies began taking precautions to protect their employees there.

title: Audacious Social Climbing In a '25 Gershwin Souffle
description: ''Give me an example of the word satiate,'' says one vaudevillian to another.

title: Working 9 to 5: Sedition and Subjugation
description: When your whole life revolves around meaningless office drudgery, molehills become mountains, petty theft looms like grand larceny and the most casual glances exchanged among co-workers can acquire a dark conspiratorial significance. This particular blend of boredom and paranoia is expertly evoked in Jill Sprecher's small, gently surreal comedy, ''Clockwatchers.''

title: HAILING DANGER: A special report.; Behind the Wheel: Long Hours and Hard Feelings
description: Like generations of poor immigrants before him, the Bangladeshi Mamun Masud sought to fulfill the sunny promise of America behind the wheel of a yellow taxi. Each day spent amid Manhattan's potholes and gridlock was a gift to his young daughters, whose lives, he said, ''should be better than mine.''

title: Metro Business; Xerox Sues Over Printers
description: The Xerox Corporation of Stamford, Conn., sued the Hewlett-Packard Company yesterday for patent infringement, claiming Hewlett-Packard's color ink-jet printers use a technology Xerox invented seven years ago.

title: A Cradle of Conflict, Poetry and Religion
description: Massachusetts' Pioneer Valley offers a pastoral escape from the urban agglomerations of New York and Boston, but it's more than simply a place to catch up on quiet time.

title: U.S. Neglect Leads to Missed Signals
description: When the Soviet Union crumbled nearly a decade ago, India, a lumbering, unpredictable giant, some would say a troublesome one, was cut adrift from old allies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, IDA BELL.
description: KING-Ida Bell. On May 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Lloyd, Sr. Survived by her two sons, Lloyd, Jr., and Ronald, her granddaughter Roni, her grandsons, Terry, Jeffery, Rodney and Todd, and her two great-grandchildren, Chloe and Major. Funeral services Friday, 10 AM, at St. James Presbyterian Church, 141 Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROTHENBERG, RICHARD
description: ROTHENBERG-Richard. May 15, 1997 (9 Iyar 5757). Beloved Stuyvesant HS alumnus, teacher, and Math Department Chairman. Dr. Rothenberg influenced thousands of students and scores of teachers with his scholarship, award-winning teaching ability, guidance, and warmheartedness. His gentlemanly, humane nature lives on in those who had the privilege of knowing him.

title: Greek Restaurants
description: With its relatively simple preparations, direct spicing and emphasis on seafood, elemental Greek food is like a fresh summer breeze, perfect for warm weather. Here are a dozen restaurants that display the spectrum of Greek cooking. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Sneaking U.S. Jets to Iran: The Canadian Route
description: Several times over the past few years, Reza Akrami, an Iranian, left his home in the Vancouver area and flew to San Francisco to see a mysterious man who spoke in Persian and called himself Dr. Afshar.

title: An Inconsistent Season That Leaves Much to Fix
description: A pack of photographers was walking backward today with their lenses aimed on Patrick Ewing. One clumsy photographer backed into Ewing's Mercedes and bent the hood ornament back like a beer tap. Instead of throwing a tirade, Ewing just scowled and slipped into the front seat. It seemed appropriate for him to drive away from this Knicks season.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Conceptual Photography From the 60's and 70's'

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Defining the Edge'

title: Israelis Shouldn't Question Stability of Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; Minnesota Governor In New Hampshire
description: Add the name of Gov. Arne Carlson of Minnesota to all those out-of-state politicians tramping around New Hampshire, dropping in on quaint New England villages, visiting with state legislators and showing up on radio talk shows -- even if the first Campaign 2000 primary is still the better part of two years off.

title: Macklowe Properties Plans Stock Offer
description: Harry Macklowe, the Manhattan developer of Metropolitan Tower, will seek to raise as much as $520 million for his real estate company through a stock offering.

title: Two Chances For a First
description: Julie Taymor, director of ''The Lion King,'' is among the favorites to win a Tony for best director of a musical. Garry Hynes, director of ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane,'' is among the favorites to win the Tony for a straight play.

title: MAIL-WELL AGREES TO ACQUIRE FIVE COMMERCIAL PRINTERS
description: Mail-Well Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire five commercial printers: Accu-color and Color-Art, St. Louis; Clarke Printing, San Antonio; French Bray, Baltimore, and United Lithograph, Boston. Mail-Well said combined 1997 sales for the five printers exceeded $140 million. It did not disclose the terms of the acquisitions. Mail-Well, based in Englewood, Colo., makes envelopes, filing products and packaging materials. It had 1997 sales of $897.6 million. Gary Lorenz, president of Color-Art, is to be president and chief executive of the company's new commercial printing division.

title: Breen Sinks His 3-Pointer As Interest in Albert Dims
description: Mike Breen is always aware that his good fortune -- calling Knicks games on the MSG Network and national games on NBC -- came at Marv Albert's expense. Albert's legal woes elevated Breen from Knicks radio and created a slot for him at NBC.

title: Observer; Life Among The Swells
description: Whenever I need to feel humble I get the car out and head for Nantucket.

title: Vouchers Can Ease School Crowding
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Real Estate; Housing Units Will Replace Armory
description: The 14th Street Armory has stood like a fortress for the last 27 years between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. But in 1995 the state-owned building closed, leaving its fate in doubt.

title: Remains of Vietnam Unknown Are Disinterred
description: In a brief ceremony filled with somber hope, an honor guard carried a coffin away from Arlington National Cemetery's most sacred monument today as onlookers prayed to learn the identity of a Vietnam War serviceman ''known but to God.''

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Mel Bochner

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about India's nuclear tests misstated the comparison between the force of explosions on Monday and the size of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima. The blasts, reported by an Indian seismic institute at 55 kilotons, were about 4 times as powerful, not 50 times.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Beyond Tepees And Peace Pipes

title: Assists Make the Team
description: Even viewers who are generally indifferent to basketball watch the N.B.A. playoffs for the cliff-hanging games that eventually produce a champion. Since the broadcasts inevitably focus on the stars, these same viewers could easily conclude that the most talented individuals are teams unto themselves. But the superstars do not win championships on their own, even Michael Jordan. The winning franchises are those that develop strategies for spreading responsibility over the entire team, and find complementary players who master strong supporting roles.

title: Founder of Media Watchdog Magazine Kills NBC Deal
description: A proposal by a media watchdog magazine to co-produce segments on errant journalism with ''Dateline NBC'' is dead, the founder of the new magazine said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOVSKY, GARY
description: TOVSKY-Gary. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member Gary Tovsky and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife Roslyn and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Harry Laufer, President

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: INDONESIAN CURRENCY FALLS 21 PERCENT. The rupiah tumbled for the third straight day as protests and violence intensified in Indonesia. In New York, it cost 11,700 rupiah to buy a dollar compared with 9,237.50 on Wednesday.

title: Monitors Picked Up Only 1 of 5 India Blasts
description: Only one of the five nuclear tests that India announced this week was detected by the thousands of seismometers around the world set up to track earthquakes and atomic blasts, renewing a debate among experts about how effectively a test ban treaty can be monitored.

title: A Party Where No One Is Allowed to Feel Left Out
description: The menu for ''Aunt Chooch's Birthday,'' the new interactive show about an Italian-American family from Staten Island that gives the world's most unsurprising surprise party, is all wrong. The Fontanas serve members of the audience heaping portions of penne, when they should be handing out Excedrin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELL, CLARENCE C.
description: PELL-Clarence C., May 12, 1998. Husband of Francesca Hinkley Pell. Father of Eve Pell, of Mill Valley, CA; Peter J. Pell, of Glen Cove, NY; Haven N.B. Pell, of Washington, DC; and the late Clarence C. Pell III. Grandfather of nine, great grandfather of 2. Residence Narragansett, RI. Memorial service Saturday, May 16, 1PM in St. Peter's By the Sea, Narragansett. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Pomfret School, Pomfret, CT. 06258.

title: Auditors Back Nikko Over Compensation
description: Coopers & Lybrand L.L.P. has confirmed the Nikko Securities Company's earlier findings that the Japanese brokerage firm had no obligations as of Jan. 30 to compensate clients for losses over ''tobashi'' transactions, officials of the accounting firm and Nikko announced yesterday. Tobashi is the practice of concealing losses by shifting them among client accounts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If I'm driving 40,000 miles a year, does that mean I'll get a lot of tickets? Probably. Does it mean I'm a bad driver? No. If I get into six accidents a year, does it mean I'm a bad driver? Probably.''

title: Woman Dies After Crash On Sidewalk In the Village
description: A woman was killed last night when a sport utility vehicle crashed into a group of pedestrians on a sidewalk in the East Village.

title: Buffalo Completes Sweep
description: SABRES 3, CANADIENS 1

title: Ban on Land Mines Goes Too Far; Only a Threat for Days
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: ''We're not serving that yet,'' the maitre d'hotel said with a touch of embarrassment when I ordered the selection of the fruits of the sea. I suspect, however, that the iced shellfish platter of clams, oysters, mussels, scallops, shrimp, lobster and calamari will be a very big seller at the new American Park at the Battery. Something about the big room overlooking the harbor makes you feel so lucky that you are tempted to be extravagant. You might even, as the menu suggests, try a glass of Hudson Valley Farmhouse Pear Cider with the oysters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LILIEN, HELEN H.
description: LILIEN-Helen H. The absence in years is forty-nine. During all those years for you I pine and cherish the memories that will always be mine. Herbert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, BETTY JEAN (NEE GIBSON).
description: JOHNSON-Betty Jean (nee Gibson). Died suddenly on May 13, 1998. Mrs. Johnson was a teacher for many years at The Browning School. Beloved wife of Glenn. Loving mother of Marta Judson, Mark and Craig. Cherished grandmother. Memorial service Friday, May 15, 2PM, St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71st Street, New York City.

title: Pakistan Is Under Growing Pressure Not to Respond to India With Atom Test
description: Pakistan came under increasing pressure from foreign governments today to refrain from answering India's recent nuclear tests with tests of its own. Many Pakistanis continued to insist, however, that joining India in the nuclear club is vital to their country's security.

title: In Germany, Clinton Voices Hope for Mideast Peace
description: President Clinton, speaking to a group of auto workers here, said today that his most urgent foreign policy goal before leaving office was to secure ''a peace agreement in the Middle East that will last for a long time.''

title: Airlines Ordered to Check a Further Set of Wires in 737's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration tonight issued an emergency order -- its third in a week -- requiring airlines to inspect hundreds more Boeing 737's for damage to wires, this time the wiring for the center fuel tanks.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'El Movimiento'

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Cab Showdown Escalates
description: Mayor Giuliani threatened to allow vans and livery cars to pick up riders on the street unless cabbies called off a demonstration. Page B7.

title: India, Cabbies And Giuliani Go Nuclear
description: THE reason India chose to resume nuclear testing this week was revealed yesterday.

title: Latest Civic Taboo: Holding Subway Doors Open
description: Another item has been added to the list of ''don'ts'' for New Yorkers: Thou shalt not prevent subway doors from closing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUIGG, H.D., JR.
description: QUIGG-H.D., Jr. May 12, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Polly, devoted father of Susan. Funeral service to take place in Boonville, MO. on Saturday May 16, 1998. A memorial service in New York will be announced at a later date.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Crackdown Set on Seat Belt Use
description: IN the long struggle to increase the number of people who wear seat belts and buckle up their children, safety experts and the police say they have reached a milestone. For most of the last 30 years, since manufacturers were first required to put seat belts in every car, safety officials used persuasion and education. But by now, they say, virtually all of the people amenable to persuasion have been persuaded.

title: Rodeo's the Thing for Giants' New Runner; LeShon Johnson Learned Tricks of the Trade on His Father's Ranch in Oklahoma
description: Back home last year on the Five Bar Ranch in Haskell, Okla., a town without a traffic light, LeShon Johnson watched a television special: Garth Brooks performing in Central Park.

title: A Political Animal
description: Though Warren Beatty plays a Senator who flamboyantly drops out of the political establishment in ''Bulworth,'' this sharp-edged comedy returns Mr. Beatty (at left with Halle Berry) to the Hollywood mainstream. He bops, he raps, and he takes on race and big insurance companies. These aren't tricks every matinee idol should try, but they work in the film to raucously funny and liberating effect.

title: Bomb at Moscow Synagogue Causes Extensive Damage
description: A bomb ripped through the outer wall of Moscow's Lubavitch synagogue on Wednesday night, and alarmed Jewish leaders called on Russian authorities today to act to halt the growing threat of violence directed at ethnic and religious minorities.

title: Metro Business; Lefrak Plans Tower For Jersey City Site
description: In one more sign of confidence in the region's commercial real estate market, the Lefrak Organization, a developer in Rego Park, Queens, said yesterday that it would build another office building along the Jersey City waterfront this fall.

title: Healing a Girl, Her Horse and Maybe Even Her Mother
description: Contained within Nicholas Evans's novel ''The Horse Whisperer'' is the blueprint for a voluptuously soapy movie, a blueprint that Robert Redford wisely chose to ignore. Mr. Redford has found his own visually eloquent way to turn the potboiler into a panorama, with a deep-seated love for the Montana landscape against which his rapturously beautiful film unfolds.

title: To Spur Economies Upstate, Pataki Revives Campaign to Legalize Casinos
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has revived a controversial campaign to bring casinos to New York State, appealing to legislative leaders in both parties to begin immediately the lengthy process toward a constitutional amendment legalizing casino gambling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERSTANDIG, WILLIAM
description: VERSTANDIG - William. The Board of Directors, staff, and membership of the Diamond Trade & Precious Stone Association wishes to extend our most heartfelt condolences to the entire family of our past president of eight years. He was a leader in the true sense of the word and will be deeply missed. The Diamond Trade & Precious Stone Association of America

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, GEORGE Z., M.D.
description: MITCHELL-George Z., M.D. On May 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Alice Mitchell. Dear father of Z. Peter and (Mercedes) Mitchell. Services Sunday, May 17. For information, call 212-749-5553.

title: Rodale Sells Magazine
description: BET Holdings Inc. has acquired Heart & Soul magazine from Rodale Press Inc., the publisher based in Emmaus, Pa. Financial terms were not disclosed. BET Holdings said the bimonthly publication, which has a circulation of 292,000, is a national health, fitness and beauty magazine aimed at black women. BET Holdings, based in Washington, is the parent of Black Entertainment Television.

title: Accounts
description: -- U.S. Mint, Washington, to Grey Advertising, New York, for an integrated communications campaign to introduce the Fifty States Quarter Commemorative Coin Program, featuring quarters with special state designs. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million a year for an initial two-year contract, which can be renewed over 10 years.

title: H.I.V. Tests on Newborns
description: Mandatory testing of newborns for exposure to H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, raised heated opposition from civil liberties groups concerned about confidentiality. But the New York State Legislature approved infant testing because early detection can mean earlier treatment.

title: Adventures of Some Square Pegs at the Round Table
description: One of the most glaring indications that all is not well with ''Quest for Camelot,'' the first feature-length animated film by Warner Brothers, is the confusing body language of its central character, Kayley. A plucky Anglo-Irish farm girl who aspires to be a knight at King Arthur's Round Table, Kayley is a mass of odd facial grimaces.

title: Work on the Wild Side, Raw, Rank and Morbid
description: Art in the 20th century has regularly gone to extremes, with the monochrome painting, the ready-made art object and art as idea. But many of its most disturbing manifestations have involved performance art: the presentation of actual human-driven events as art.

title: As Strife Grips Indonesia, U.S. Asks Citizens to Leave and Delays Aid Payment
description: The United States today urged most of the nearly 11,000 Americans living in Indonesia to leave the country immediately, citing the worst political violence there in more than three decades.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about bids for Simon & Schuster referred incorrectly to another publishing company, HarperCollins, a unit of the News Corporation. While industry executives had said in recent years that the News Corporation was seeking to sell HarperCollins, the company says the unit is not for sale.

title: O'Connor Assails Sunday Little League
description: His first pitch was hurled at Major League Baseball. Now, it's Little League and soccer.

title: Friend Focuses on Lead In Byron Nelson Classic
description: He knew he must have fired a great round, because it took him 10 minutes to figure out his scorecard. For Bob Friend that is not a sign of confusion, but confirmation that he had played an organized and mental game.

title: Playground Star Dies
description: Earl Manigault, one of New York's playground basketball legends of the 1960's and 1970's, died last night at Bellevue Hospital. A spokesman at the hospital, where Manigault was admitted two weeks ago, said that the cause of Manigault's death was congestive heart failure.

title: Vouchers Can Ease School Crowding
description: To the Editor:

title: NE RESTAURANT TO BUY REST OF BERTUCCI'S FOR $89 MILLION
description: The NE Restaurant Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the 95.2 percent of Bertucci's Inc. it does not already own for $10.50 a share, or $88.9 million. Bertucci's, based in Wakefield, Mass., operates 85 pizzerias and steakhouses, mainly in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states. NE Restaurant, a privately held company with headquarters in Westborough, Mass., operates 31 Chili's Grill and Bar and two On the Border restaurants in five New England states as a franchisee of Brinker International Inc., which is based in Dallas. Bertucci's stock rose 34.375 cents yesterday, to $10.21875.

title: Fidelity Closing a Small-Stock Fund
description: Fidelity Investments closed the $764 million Small Cap Stock Fund to new investments yesterday, less than two months after the fund opened. Even current investors will not be allowed to put in new cash, but they will be able to reinvest dividends.

title: Like a Phoenix, T-Bird Rises Again
description: TO promote its futuristic, finned 1957 models, Chrysler used the line, ''Suddenly it's 1960.'' Now, as cars like the Volkswagen New Beetle and the Plymouth Prowler street rod take to the streets, it may be time to twist that theme around to, ''Suddenly, it's the 1950's.''

title: Water World: Surf's Up, and It's Rough Out There
description: ''In God's Hands'' is as pretty as a scenic calendar and about as exciting.

title: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp
description: More than 25 years after hemp was last grown legally in America, a group of farmers and trade organizations will file suit against the Federal Government on Friday to make hemp a lawful crop again.

title: Vouchers Can Ease School Crowding
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Publisher Is Hard To Leave Behind

title: Marjory Douglas, Champion Of Everglades, Dies at 108
description: Marjory Stoneman Douglas, the spirited writer and environmentalist who was known as the patron saint of the Florida Everglades for her ceaseless campaign to preserve the fragile wetlands, died yesterday at her home in Miami. She was 108.

title: Don't Mess With the Underboss in Indy
description: His coaching tree should be mapped out like one of those mob graphics, in which family connections are revealed. Dick Harter was a known associate of the Bad Boys in Detroit. Until Pat Riley moved all his operations to South Florida, Harter worked as an underboss for him in New York.

title: Everglades Restoration
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAINES, BARBARA G., PHD.
description: RAINES-Barbara G., PhD. Died peacefully on May 14 at the age of 89. She is survived by her two children Martha Raines Burt and Richard C. Raines, her loving sister Mildred (Mimi) Adler, and her brother Bernard Goldberg. Dr. Raines served as the first woman appointed Leader by the Society for Ethical Culture in the 20th Century and helped to found several Societies for Ethical Culture in California. She was also Professor Emeritus at Antioch College, where she taught at its Columbia, MD. campus until her retirement. A memorial service will be held June 7, 1998 at 3PM at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, 53 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

title: Law to Repeal Pakistani Arms Ban Is Proposed
description: With the tacit blessing of the Clinton Administration, two Senators today proposed repealing a law that has prohibited American military assistance to Pakistan since 1990 as an incentive to Pakistan's Government not to conduct an underground nuclear test.

title: Fighting the Drug Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Extra Training Ordered To Improve Police Fitness
description: Saying that police officers need to stay in shape like athletes to do their jobs and prolong their careers, state officials yesterday unveiled updated training rules for new local and county police officers throughout New York.

title: Wisconsin Abortion Clinics Shut Down, Citing New Law
description: Every abortion clinic in Wisconsin stopped performing abortions yesterday after a Federal judge refused to block a new state law requiring the life imprisonment of any doctor who performs a particular kind of abortion.

title: Golly, Jimmy Olsen Writes Librettos!
description: When the writer Jack Larson was in his 30's, he received the first grant the Rockefeller Foundation ever awarded to a playwright. But that's not what he will be remembered for. His elegant, fanciful plays, written mostly in rhymed verse, have been presented in theaters from the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, his hometown, to the Edinburgh Festival Theater in Scotland. He also wrote the libretto for Virgil Thomson's opera ''Lord Byron.'' And in another turn of career, he was associate producer on films like ''The Paper Chase,'' ''Urban Cowboy'' and ''The China Syndrome.''

title: Iran Arms Smugglers Take the Canadian Route
description: A shadowy Iranian effort to smuggle American-made jets and sophisticated military equipment across Canada and into Iran was recently exposed by a United States undercover agent. But this attempted violation of the American embargo of Iran was not an isolated case, according to a joint investigation by The New York Times and CBS News. A significant portion of the American-made weapons and parts that Iran buys illicitly move through Canada, taking advantage of regulatory loopholes and the Canadian Government's decision not to support the American embargo.

title: Indonesian Capital Engulfed by Rioting
description: Indonesia's capital descended into chaos on Thursday, as rioting and looting broke out in virtually every quarter of the city and the death toll rose. Bands of people swept up and down Jakarta's main streets, setting fire to cars, shattering windows in office buildings, and burning and pillaging stores.

title: CORDANT TECHNOLOGIES TO BUY JACOBSON MANUFACTURING
description: Cordant Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Jacobson Manufacturing Company for $270 million. Jacobson makes custom-designed metal parts and fasteners and precision-engineered plastic products. The company is owned by Harvey Jacobson, its founder and chairman. Cordant said Jacobson's 1998 projected revenues were about $145 million. Cordant, which recently changed its name from the Thiokol Corporation, had $890 million in sales in the year that ended June 30, 1997. The company, based in Ogden, Utah, makes solid rocket boosters as well as fasteners, rivets and lock bolts for the transportation and construction industries. Its stock rose $1, to $54.25.

title: Payment Gives Jets Options
description: The Jets will pay Neil O'Donnell another $1 million today, meeting a salary advance deadline and keeping him under contract for at least several more weeks. O'Donnell's agent, Leigh Steinberg, said the team contacted him yesterday to say that they would make the payment.

title: CALIFORNIA REIT TO BUY 38 PROPERTIES FROM PRUDENTIAL
description: Health Care Property Investors Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a portfolio of properties from the Prudential Health Care Plan Inc. for $86 million. The portfolio consists of 36 clinical operations and two undeveloped parcels of land. Health Care Property, based in Newport Beach, Calif., is a real estate investment trust. It has interests in 276 properties in 40 states. Prudential Health Care Plan is a managed care unit of the Newark-based Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest mutual insurance company. At the end of 1997, the parent had assets of $260 billion.

title: DNA Test Helps Convict Man in 1989 Murders
description: Improved DNA testing has helped convict a Queens truck driver of murdering a Long Island woman and her two young sons nine years ago, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Where Writers Find Peace (Well, Sort of)
description: Here in Manhattan -- the citadel of capitalism, where the financially challenged are crushed like cockroaches underfoot -- there is something defiantly contrarian about the survival of archaic ''artists' clubs.'' A score of Old World institutions still exist for the use of painters, sculptors and photographers, financed by the legacy of some dotty 19th-century dowager or evil industrialist. But most heartwarming of all are the few clubs devoted to providing space for impecunious writers, testimony that New York's chaos may provide creative stimulation but that it's also supremely exasperating to work in.

title: All Is Calm, at Present, With Coronado's Quest
description: Coronado's Quest, the missing man at Pimlico this week but already installed as the 2-1 favorite for the $1 million race on Saturday, galloped one mile this morning at his home base at Belmont Park in New York and, according to his trainer, Shug McGaughey, ''came off the track playing like a kid.''

title: Political Tumult and a Dying Dynasty
description: As a full-length ballet, ''The Last Emperor,'' which introduced the Hong Kong Ballet to New York on Wednesday night, is a curiosity, even worth a visit for that reason.

title: BBDO Offices Win At Clio Awards
description: Offices of BBDO Worldwide have won the most honors at the 1998 Clio Awards ceremonies.

title: U.S. Cites Japan Aid in Limiting Privacy
description: The White House will announce Friday that Japan has endorsed its unregulated, tax-free approach to electronic commerce, including its stance against strict privacy regulations planned by the European Union.

title: Vouchers Can Ease School Crowding
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITALITY IN BUY-AND-LEASE DEAL WITH CANDLEWOOD
description: Hospitality Properties Trust agreed yesterday to buy and lease back 16 hotels in 12 states from the Candlewood Hotel Company for about $135 million in the second such agreement between the two companies. Hospitality Properties, based in Newton, Mass., bought 15 hotels from Candlewood in November for $100 million. It has spent about $491 million on purchases this year. The acquisition brings its portfolio to about $1.7 billion in 166 hotels in 35 states, under names like Courtyard by Marriott and Residence Inn.

title: A Suitable Nuclear Waste Dump
description: Barring last-minute legal problems, a mile-square maze of tunnels and vaults carved into a geological salt formation 2,150 feet below the desert near Carlsbad, N.M., will soon be open for business. On Wednesday Federal regulators gave final approval to a project known formally as the Waste Isolation Pilot Project, a vast subterranean complex where the military plans to inter five million cubic feet of radioactive debris produced during the last half-century at 23 nuclear weapons sites around the country.

title: White-Bread Senator Turns Homeboy
description: It's great to see a grown man cry when the man has as many good reasons as Senator Jay Bulworth, the formerly viable American politician. He has a campaign speech (''We stand at the doorstep of a new millennium . . . '') that bores even him to tears. He has a wife (Christine Baranski), but she shows up only for ceremonial occasions. He has a staff best suited to snaring campaign contributions. (''Will the Sultan be in Beverly Hills?'') He has enemies who pronounce him ''an old liberal wine trying to pour itself into a new conservative bottle.''

title: Judge Hears Starr-Clinton Clash on the Secret Service
description: Recalling the assassination of Presidents from Lincoln to Kennedy, a Clinton Administration lawyer argued before a Federal judge today that the Secret Service would be unable to protect President Clinton ''and all future Presidents'' unless its agents had a legally recognized privilege that shielded them from grand jury questions about Mr. Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Political Briefing; Second Thoughts By Oregon G.O.P.
description: Gov. John A. Kitzhaber is so well regarded by his Oregon constituents, fellow Democrats as well as Republicans, that for a while Republican leaders had trouble finding someone willing to challenge his re-election bid. But eventually the state's leading anti-tax crusader, Bill Sizemore, the executive director of the Oregon branch of Taxpayers United, stepped forward and top Republican officials, taking what they could get, figured that at least he would keep the flag flying against the popular Governor.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Dennis Oppenheim

title: Derby Victory Doesn't Insure Respect
description: On the first Saturday in May, the winner of the Kentucky Derby is blanketed in roses at Churchill Downs and becomes the embodiment of horse racing's richest tradition, trying to follow in the footsteps of Secretariat, Citation and the nine others who have swept the Triple Crown.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about New Yorkers' ways of coping with the rain referred incorrectly to Hollis Lehv, a 3-month-old baby in a stroller in Central Park. The child is a girl.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the fatal stabbing of an Arab in Jerusalem misstated the location of six recent stabbings of Arabs there. They occurred in Orthodox Jewish neighborhoods in the western part of the city, not in the Old City area of East Jerusalem.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Domestic Partners' Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPHAEL, SYDNEY M.
description: RAPHAEL-Sydney M. The Officers, Board of Governors and Members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed life member, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Murray B. Hirsch, Pres. Howard Ecker, Secretary

title: Something's Out There, and It's . . . Aieeee!
description: ''Peter Benchley's 'Creature' '' asks the question, ''What if the shark in 'Jaws' had had claws and a real brain and could have come out of the water and climbed trees?''

title: A Chip Maker Says It Expects More Bad News
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation delivered bad news to Wall Street today for the fourth time in four months, warning that revenues will fall below analysts' estimates and that it expects a loss for the current quarter and possibly the next.

title: Giuliani Marks 54th Birthday by Raising a Cool Million
description: Although Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani takes great pains to distinguish himself from those he derides as ''professional politicians,'' he has always excelled at the most basic of political chores: fund-raising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, C. EDWIN.
description: FITZGERALD-C. Edwin. May 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted brother of Ann Garlick, Elizabeth Fitzgerald and Agnes Davis. Loving uncle of 11 nieces and nephews and 16 grand-nieces and nephews. Executive secretary of Partridge-Invitation Scholarship Foundation Inc. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Sunday, May 17, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, May 18, 10:30 AM at St. John the Evangelist Church, 55th St. at First Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to Portsmouth Abbey School, Portsmouth, RI.

title: Costly Pataki Veto
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIGEL, KALMAN
description: SEIGEL-Kalman. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of Ann and Carolyn; father-in-law of Barry. Grandfather of Suzy, Michael, Daniel Mark and Emily. Funeral, 11:30, Friday, IJ Morris, 1895 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: An Appraisal: A Return to the Glamour of Flying; Kennedy's New Terminal Offers Style and Comfort for Jaded Travelers
description: No one goes to Kennedy International Airport expecting other than a deeply grim hour or two before boarding time. At best, the hour might be thought of as an anthropological field trip. This is the best place in New York to verify the news reports: Americans are indeed obese. We probably got that way in airports, gobbling french fries in an effort to dispel the anxiety produced by ugly surroundings, no smoking, irrational fears of crashing and the reasonable expectation that our luggage is on its way to the moon.

title: 94 in Latin Kings Are Arrested Citywide
description: A thousand law enforcement officials fanned out across New York City before dawn yesterday and struck what the authorities called a crippling blow to the Latin Kings gang, seizing 94 members and associates, including top leaders, on charges ranging from possessing guns and drugs to conspiring to commit murders.

title: Hearing on Pataki Budget Vetoes Fails to Stir Much Outrage
description: It was billed as the best opportunity yet to protest Gov. George E. Pataki's $1.6 billion worth of budget vetoes: a hearing in which teachers, parents and community leaders in New York City could rail against the $800 million in cuts affecting public schools.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Marion Post Wolcott

title: Political Briefing; Hot Issues Keeping State Legislatures
description: Roughly half of the country's state legislatures are currently in session. So what is going on out there?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARWICK, KENNETH M.
description: WARWICK-Kenneth M., 62. Was a rare human being who exuded brilliance, strength, generosity and a dry northern Irish sense of humor throughout his life, even in the face of terminal illness. He died of cancer at home with beloved family on May 13, 1998. Born in Belfast Northern Ireland in 1936, he was a graduate of Queens University and received his Ph.D. in psychology and statistics at The Institute of Psychiatry at London University. He worked for and with the renowned psychologist, Hans Eysenck at The London University Hospital of Psychiatry at Maudsley. Ken, who rarely referred to himself as Dr. Kenneth M. Warwick, was best known as an eminent expert in statistical research for the marketing industry. A Fellow of the Royal Statistical Society and member of Econometric Society, he was internationally known to be among preeminent statisticians. Ken Warwick & Associates, Inc., specializing in multivariate statistical analysis, consults in advertising, corporate management consulting and market research businesses, and in the legal system and government. As he hoped, his distinguished partner continues his reputation through her expertise. His company has always been a part of his family. His prior career included positions as Associate Research Director and Vice President at SSC&B and Grey Advertising. He was an Executive Vice President of a pioneering market research company. He taught at London, Columbia, and New York Universities. For years he has been an Editor of the Journal of Marketing Research and has written numerous articles on marketing and psychological research. He has been a speaker at and active with The American Marketing Association, The Advertising Research Foundation, The American Psychological Association and The Association of Consumer Research. Ken has contributed to the Partnership For A Drug-Free America, a part of his extensive pro bono work. Dr. Warwick is a recognized authority on the use of multivariate statistical procedures in business research and has initiated the implementation of many methods on digital computers. He has developed numerous proprietary techniques. Ken co-authored the book ''Multivariate Descriptive Statistical Analysis'' with the distinguished Ludovic Lebart and Alain Morineau and has been credited for initiating the use of correspendence analysis from France in American marketing research. Ken and his colleague and friend, Alan Hendrickson, started Cybernetics Research Consultants, a groundbreaking computer statistical analysis co. in Britain. Ken's zest for knowledge and inexhaustible drive for work and excellence were only surpassed by his love for his family. He encouraged and nurtured his children with strong work ethics, empowerment for achievement, zeal for learning, and love for family. His pride in and support for his children was an inextricable part of his nature. This giving spirit, characteristic of his entire family is his legacy. Ken is survived by his wife, Jane Chicoine Warwick, four children, Dr. Zoe Warwick Forsyth, John Alexander Warwick, Alan Warwick, and Richard Warwick; three grandchildren, Daniel, Ryan, and Eric and twins expected in June. His three rescued cats and dog are just one manifestation of love for animals. In lieu of flowers the family suggests that contributions be made according to his wish to The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, or an organization reputed for animal humaneness. A memorial service to be held in New York will be announced shortly. Ken will be laid to rest in his homeland, Northern Ireland with his parents and brother.

title: Silk Cut Takes Lead
description: With only light puffs of breeze prevailing, Silk Cut of Britain regained the lead from Toshiba yesterday on the eighth of nine legs in the Whitbread Round the World race. The nine boats are scheduled to arrive in La Rochelle, France, tomorrow on a 3,390-nautical-mile stretch from Annapolis, Md.

title: A Tour Through Chelsea, The New Center of Gravity
description: Doubts may have lingered even a year ago, but there's no question that the commercial center of gravity of the New York City art world has shifted from SoHo to Chelsea. A passel of ex-SoHo heavyweights (Paula Cooper, Barbara Gladstone, Metro Pictures) have made the switch. Others are poised to arrive (Luhring Augustine and Andrea Rosen will both open on West 24th Street the week after next). Still others, notably Jay Gorney, are scouting for Chelsea space.

title: Defiant Senate Panel Votes for Steep Rise in Tobacco Tax
description: Anti-smoking forces in Congress won an important early round today in the political fight over tobacco legislation. The Senate Finance Committee voted to raise the tax on a pack of cigarettes by $1.50 over the next three years.

title: Deal for Cataract Surgery
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a licensing agreement with Optex Ophthalmologics Inc. and its parent company, Atlantic Pharmaceuticals Inc., to complete the development of Catarex, a cataract-removal technology invented by Optex. Under the agreement, Bausch & Lomb Surgical and Optex will complete the design and development of Catarex. Bausch & Lomb will assume responsibility for marketing Catarex worldwide. Shares of Bausch & Lomb rose $1.9375, to $51.4375.

title: MICROSOFT SEEKS ACCORD WITH U.S. AND DODGES SUIT
description: Less than an hour before state and Federal governments were set to file sweeping antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corporation, the company announced today that it would postpone the release of its new operating system, Windows 98, for three days so that settlement talks could proceed.

title: ZIONS BANCORP AGREES TO ACQUIRE COMMERCE BANCORP
description: Zions Bancorp, Utah's second-biggest bank, agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Commerce Bancorp for an undisclosed amount in stock, expanding into Washington State for the first time. Zions, based in Salt Lake City, has $10 billion in assets and branches in seven Western states. It said buying the parent of Commerce Bank of Washington would give it $330 million in assets and one branch in Seattle. In the last five years, Zions has made more than 15 acquisitions in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Nevada and New Mexico. Zions shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $51.75.

title: Goldsmith Promoted At Lowe & Partners
description: Gary Goldsmith, executive vice president and deputy creative director at Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, was promoted yesterday to the new position of vice chairman and executive creative director. Mr. Goldsmith, 43, will work with Lee Garfinkel, co-chairman and chief creative officer, to manage the creative department and creative output; he continues reporting to Mr. Garfinkel and Marvin Sloves, co-chairman. Mr. Goldsmith joined Lowe -- part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies -- when Lowe acquired his New York boutique shop, Goldsmith/Jeffrey, in 1996.

title: Chief of S.E.C. Chides Funds On Information
description: Mutual fund investors, blinded by stunning investment returns the last several years, are not getting enough information about how much they are paying for a fund company's services, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today.

title: U.S. Will Rely On Makeshift Lineup
description: The United States will open the final leg of its World Cup preparations with a friendly against Macedonia on Saturday night, but injuries to key players will force Coach Steve Sampson to play an unintended game of lineup roulette in the midfield.

title: Huitzilac Journal; A Long Fire Season Torments Mexico
description: Alejandro Manilla's clothes reek of smoke and his eyes are bloodshot. A town official in this mountainous county bordering Mexico City, he has spent weeks battling wild fires here with an axe and shovel, alongside forest rangers and army troops.

title: Zia's Quiet Partner Cuts Off Opponents to Make a Game
description: A week ago the phone rang in a room in the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas. Zia Mahmood reached for the handset and glanced at the clock. ''You shouldn't call me so early,'' he said. ''I never get up before 10.''

title: Contrary Folkies Reveling in That Old-Time Anarchy
description: More than 35 years after they first got together, the Holy Modal Rounders are in no danger of turning professional. In their latest reunion, on Wednesday night at Under Acme, Peter Stampfel and Steve Weber argued over songs, keys and tempos. Backed by Dave Reisch on bass, they ambled through more than a century of American folk music, from celebrations of freed slaves to a put-down of Barney the dinosaur. The looseness was a whiff of the 1960's; so were the freewheeling songs.

title: Manetta Begins Searching For Next Coach at St. John's
description: The phones are ringing in Ed Manetta's office.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLFF, BLANCHE SILVER.
description: WOLFF-Blanche Silver. The family of the late and beloved Blanche Silver Wolff wish to inform you of the Unveiling of her Memorial Sunday May 17, 1998, 1pm, Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island.

title: Pak Becomes A Presence In L.P.G.A.
description: Se Ri Pak, a 20-year-old rookie from South Korea, continued to show poise and skill beyond her years today as she maintained her lead in the McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COULOUCOUNDIS, CLEOPATRA
description: COULOUCOUNDIS-Cleopatra. On May 14, 1998. Beloved wife of Emmanuel, cherished mother of John and Sonya Couloucoundis, loving grandmother of Emmanuel and Michael, cherished daughter of Eleftheria Pitsironis, loving sister of Nicholas and Maria Pitsironis. Funeral liturgy Monday, 11AM, at Holy Trinity G.O. Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street (between 1st & 2nd Avenue), NYC. The family will receive friends at the Cathedral between 10-11AM Monday morning. Interment Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations would be welcome, in the deceased name to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 Street, NY, NY 10019, (Memorial Department).

title: The Fighter's Son
description: There was once a tattooed and florid little blue-eyed Sicilian-born prizefighter named Martin Sinatra, who, wishing to enhance his employment opportunities in America at a time when there were no discernible advantages to having an Italian surname (except in the Mafia), presented himself in the ring as ''Marty O'Brien.''

title: MELLON BANK IS SELLING ITS COMMERCIAL MORTGAGE UNIT
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation plans to sell its commercial mortgage servicing business, including $17 billion of servicing rights, and focus its energies on the residential mortgage business. Mellon is seeking buyers for the Income Property division of the Cleveland-based Mellon Mortgage Company. The commercial business includes 200 employees, 12 branches and the fourth-largest servicing business in the United States. Michael Kula, chief operating officer of Mellon Mortgage, said the company had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to seek buyers. The plan, first reported in Commercial Mortgage Alert, follows less than a year after Mellon Mortgage acquired a $7.9 billion servicing portfolio from the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.

title: Target Practice in Geneva on the Global Trade Body
description: The World Trade Organization has come under attack recently from critics who say it ignores environmental and social issues in settling trade disputes.

title: Journal; Sinatra Without Tears
description: When Mom talked about the riots at the Paramount Theater, it was an abstraction, really, as was everything that happened during the war that ended just before she had her kids. You couldn't imagine your mother being a teen-ager or screaming about a skinny singer in a bow tie whose songs were as old hat as the hats he wore. It was the Kennedy era now, and men didn't wear hats anymore. No teen-ager listened to the music of Rodgers or Porter or Jimmy Van Heusen.

title: Mets Waste Strong Pitching
description: This is how bad things are for the Mets: for the 11th straight game, their starter allowed two or fewer runs, and, after tonight's 3-2 defeat to the San Francisco Giants, the Mets are 6-5 over that span.

title: Gotti's Old Haunt Sold By U.S. For $1 Million
description: The Little Italy apartment building that gained notoriety in the early 1990's as being the locale for John Gotti's Ravenite Social Club has been sold to an investment group for $1.03 million, Government officials said yesterday.

title: SUHARTO REVERSES HIKE IN FUEL PRICE DEMANDED BY I.M.F.
