description: Bowing to his countrymen's anger and a death toll from rioting that has grown into the hundreds, President Suharto has rolled back fuel-price increases he imposed only days ago at the insistence of the International Monetary Fund.

title: Ex-Clinton Aide To Berkeley Post
description: Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the former chief economic adviser to President Clinton, has been named dean of the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBISH, CELIA
description: HOBISH-Celia. On May 15, 1998 in Pompano Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Harry, dear mother of Herbert and Toby Hobish and Dr. Stanley and Ruth Hobish, adored grandmother of six and great-grandmother of six.

title: Dresdner Bank Pledges To Pursue Growth
description: Dresdner Bank A.G. pledged to shareholders yesterday that it would seek to expand in Europe and the United States as part of a wider strategy to bolster earnings and return on equity in coming years. ''The most important goal,'' the chairman, Bernhard Walter, said at the bank's annual shareholders meeting, ''is to strengthen our position in the key countries of Europe.'' Belgium, the Netherlands and Austria are particular ''white spots'' in Dresdner's European market presence, he said.

title: Karolj Seles, 64, Tennis Coach Who Led Daughter to No. 1
description: Karolj Seles, the playful and innovative editorial-cartoonist-turned-tennis-coach who masterminded the double-handed strokes that helped turn his daughter, Monica, into the world's No. 1 ranked player by the time she was 17, died Thursday afternoon at a hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 64 years old and had been in declining health since suffering a recurrence of stomach cancer in December 1996.

title: Woman Helps Jews Trace Eastern European Roots
description: Miriam Weiner is consumed by other people's roots, but it isn't because her own life lacks interest. A former California private investigator who became road manager for Bobbie Gentry, the country singer, she has now carved out a growing career as a genealogist helping Jews rediscover their European heritage by marking paths through the forests of old-world family trees.

title: Can the Taxi Drivers Stay on Strike, Please?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If more Americans had his grit, we'd have more success.''

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES ORDERS 25 MORE BOEING AIRCRAFT
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it had ordered 25 more 737-800 aircraft from the Boeing Company, adding to a $7 billion purchase of more than 100 planes announced in November 1996. The 737, one of the most widely used jetliners in commercial aviation, will replace 727-200's, the oldest planes in American's fleet. The 25 new planes, worth $1.29 billion before discounts, are scheduled to be delivered between January 2000 and January 2002. American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, now has 100 737's on order. The carrier expects to replace all its 727's by 2004. American originally ordered 103 planes from Boeing in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGREICH, HARRY
description: WAGREICH-Harry. Born November 29, 1908, died May 13, 1998. Professor Emeritus Chemistry, City College of NY. Survived by daughter Barbara and two brothers, Dr. Samuel Wagreich and Dr. Paul Wagreich. Service Sunday, May 17, 1 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Ruling Made On TV Signal
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that the New York Racing Association had the right to withhold its television signal of races supplied to New York City Offtrack Betting.

title: India's Nuclear Gamble Exposed U.S. Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the killing of six students by Indonesian security forces misstated the timing of the Government shutdown of an Indonesian magazine, Tempo. It occurred in 1994, not six months ago.

title: Hewlett-Packard Quarterly Profit Falls 13%
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported a 13 percent decline in quarterly earnings today after having warned two days earlier that its results would show unexpected weakness, largely because of lower prices for personal computers.

title: Spree Suspect Convicted In Murder of Elderly Man
description: A man who is suspected in a series of violent crimes against elderly people was convicted yesterday of bludgeoning a 65-year-old man to death in his Westchester County home with an automobile hood ornament.

title: Some Restrictions on Baby Bells Are Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court, ruling in a closely watched case, today upheld regulations that restrict the nation's regional Bell companies from entering the electronic publishing business.

title: Job Retention After Workfare Isn't Studied
description: In a hearing long delayed by political sparring, Jason A. Turner, Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, said yesterday that he could provide no information about the number of workfare graduates who had failed to keep their new jobs and had to return for more public assistance.

title: Reinsurer in Acquisition
description: The Life Re Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the privately held North American Financial Services Inc., the parent of the Atlas Life Insurance Company of Tulsa, Okla. Terms were not disclosed. Life Re, based in Stamford, provides reinsurance through its principal subsidiary, the Life Reassurance Corporation of America. Atlas is a provider of life insurance and annuities.

title: A Las Vegas High Roller Comes Under Scrutiny Again
description: The gambling industry has its legendary names, from Bugsy Siegel, the mobster and big-time betting pioneer in this once-barren desert, to Steve Wynn, the Mirage chairman who helped transform modern-day casinos into legitimate businesses with entertainment suitable for families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHARGEL, ARTHUR
description: SCHARGEL-Arthur. Beloved husband of Ruth. Cherished father of Ellen (Rosenbach) and Steven. Loving grandfather. On May 12, 1998 in Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Plainfield and Westfield, NJ.

title: Parents' Nightmare, Children's Quest
description: As she crisscrosses the United States giving lectures about her surprise best seller, ''The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust of World War II,'' Iris Chang often finds herself playing an unusual role: the historian as healer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENTERGY CORP., New Orleans, an energy company, said it was negotiating with a number of European utilities over a possible international merger aimed at capturing a larger share of the world electricity market.

title: Even Scholars Say It's Witchcraft
description: It is not easy to organize a scholarly conference on Frank Sinatra.

title: Rating for 'Seinfeld' Finale Grazed Super Bowl Country
description: In the end, ''Seinfeld'' attracted a huge audience -- just not a record-breaking one.

title: U.S. Steps Up Its Pressure On Japanese
description: President Clinton stepped up the pressure on Japan today to deal with its ailing economy, urging Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to quickly resolve the Japanese banking system's festering problems.

title: Georgia Bank Purchase
description: The Regions Financial Corporation agreed today to buy the VB&T Bancshares Corporation for about $18.1 million in stock, expanding its banking operations in Georgia. Regions, which is based in Birmingham, said that the purchase of VB&T, which is based in Valdosta, Ga., would give Regions an additional $75 million in assets. Shares of Regions fell 68.75 cents, to $42.50, in Nasdaq trading today.

title: Can the Taxi Drivers Stay on Strike, Please?; Bucolic for a Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Tries New Strategy in '98 Elections
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O., which stormed back into the political arena two years ago by spending $35 million to help Democratic Congressional candidates, is charting a different -- and, union leaders say, less partisan -- strategy for this fall's election campaign.

title: Bruise on Coronado's Quest Leads to a Scratch
description: Coronado's Quest, who became the favorite when Indian Charlie was withdrawn earlier this week, was scratched today from the Preakness Stakes on Saturday after a bruise was detected on his right rear foot following an exercise gallop at Belmont Park.

title: Central Bank In Indonesia On Sidelines; Worry Grows
description: Indonesia's financial markets ground to a halt yesterday when the central bank stopped acting as a middleman in foreign-currency transactions for a second day, further weakening confidence in the battered economy.

title: On and Off the Beaten Path; Outdoor Gear Isn't Just for the Adventurous Anymore
description: In the 1960's, two hiking enthusiasts who owned a mountaineering shop in Berkeley, Calif., stitched together some backpacks and sleeping bags and put them on their shelves. It was the modest beginning of a company they called the North Face.

title: Scant Increase In U.S. Output
description: Industrial production rose one-tenth of 1 percent in April as manufacturing output increased for only the second time this year and output by utilities and mines declined, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JACOB J., M.D.
description: MILLER-Jacob J., M.D. age 99, died peacefully on May 14, 1998. Dr. Miller was a revered physician who was a founding member of the Bronx section of the American Psychiatric Association & served as Director of Mental Hygiene at the Morrisania Hospital & Director of the Psychiatric Day Hospital of Bronx Lebanon Hospital until 1987 when he retired from practice. A 1924 graduate of New York Medical College, his long career was punctuated by his skill, compassion & integrity. Beloved husband of the late Leah Miller, he is survived by his daughter, Marilynn, his son, Dr. Robert E. Miller and daughter-in-law, Marjorie, three grandchildren, Christopher, Jonathan and Peter, five great grandchildren, Ryan, Peter, Eric, Jacob and Abigail. Interment is private.

title: 'Come Fly With Me,' He Called
description: The finale of all this is that Frank turned up in our hometown, Albany, as the opening act for the brand-new Knickerbocker Arena, with 17,000 seats. Would Albany turn out for him in any numbers? Word had gone out, as it always does with these myth-making events, that Frank wasn't well, might not show up, that Liza Minnelli was standing by to go on if he crumbled. What's more, Ava had just died and so maybe this was not one of those very good years.

title: More Tobacco Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: Can the Taxi Drivers Stay on Strike, Please?; Giuliani's Disrespect
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia to Play Maryland in Final
description: Virginia, the top-seeded team, defeated No. 4 Dartmouth, 10-7, last night in a semifinal contest of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women 's Division I lacrosse tournament at the University of Maryland-Baltimore.

title: MOMA's Pyrrhic Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: McCaughey Ross Is Caught Between Two Party Pledges
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross said yesterday that she would not honor a pledge she made to upstate Democratic leaders to support her party's nominee for Governor because it might force her to renege on another pledge -- one she recently made to the Liberal Party to win support for her own gubernatorial campaign.

title: Capitalistic Sideline Drives China's Army
description: The Chinese Army, a colossus of three million soldiers, is a sprawling organization that controls or owns parts of a vast array of businesses, from arms dealers to airlines, pharmaceutical makers to vegetable growers.

title: India's Combustible Mixture
description: There's probably nothing more dangerous that has happened on the Indian subcontinent since independence in 1947 than this week's series of nuclear tests. But the American Government's reaction to them, while understandable, may turn out to be, in its way, equally dangerous.

title: When Denmark Didn't Look the Other Way
description: Since it was revived last fall, ''The Wonderful World of Disney'' has been an exasperating mix of ambitiously thoughtful stories and disjointed accounts of adolescent antics. Tomorrow night at 7 on ABC, the series puts on its best face with ''Miracle at Midnight,'' a gripping if occasionally cloying drama about the protection of Jewish citizens in Denmark in the fall of 1943.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen dropped to its weakest level in nearly six weeks, hurt by the crisis in Indonesia and fears of further economic decline in Japan. In New York the dollar cost 134.52 yen, up from 133.73.

title: Layoff Deal At Hospitals Hits a Snag
description: An agreement to avoid laying off 900 employees of New York City's public hospitals appeared on the verge of unraveling yesterday as a major union leader asserted that he would rather see his members lose their jobs than sign a pact that he said was unfair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, C. EDWIN.
description: FITZGERALD-C. Edwin. The members of the Partridge-Invitation Scholarship Foundation mourn the death of our dear friend C. Edwin Fitzgerald on May 14, 1998. Our deepest sympathy goes out to Ruth and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTOCK, JUDGE SIMON.
description: ROSENSTOCK - Judge Simon. May 14, 1998. Of Loudonville, NY. First President of the first elected Albany School Board. Husband of Alice Freedman Rosenstock. Father of Lawrence M. Rosenstock and Joan L. Rosenstock, both of New York City. Memorial services will be Sunday, May 17, 1998, in the Mendelson Chapel at Beth Emeth Cemetery in Loudonville, NY. For information, contact Levine Memorial Chapel, 649 Washington Ave., Albany, NY.

title: 39 Charged in Crackdown on Lower East Side Drug Gang
description: They called themselves the Cut Throat Crew, and the authorities say that in one horrific incident, the drug gang more than lived up its name -- by beating, trying to rape and then throwing a customer off an apartment roof to her death.

title: Mayor Urges Photos Be Taken Of Patrons Entering Sex Shops
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who prides himself on having a solution for everything, did not hesitate yesterday when a caller to his radio show complained about X-rated video stores and topless bars in the caller's Queens neighborhood.

title: New Delhi Premier Indicates Resolve to Produce Nuclear Weapons
description: Only 48 hours after India ended a series of five underground nuclear tests that stunned the world, Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee indicated today that India would not hesitate before deploying the nuclear weapons the tests were designed to perfect.

title: The Target Of Violence In a Time Of Wrath
description: They huddled in hotel lobbies, trying to book plane reservations. They stood on street corners, pleading with taxi drivers to take them to the airport. Those who could not flee cowered in their shops, peering out of corrugated metal barriers at a city that had turned on them once again.

title: Book by McDougal Says Pardon Was Pledged for Ex-Wife
description: Moments after President Clinton gave videotaped testimony for the criminal trial of James B. and Susan H. McDougal, his former Whitewater partners, he privately agreed to give Ms. McDougal a pardon if she was convicted, a new book by Mr. McDougal says.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: INSIDE
description: Allegations From McDougal

title: The Partial-Birth Stratagem
description: Doctors in Wisconsin stopped performing abortions on Thursday when Judge John Shabaz of the Federal District Court refused to issue a temporary restraining order against the state's newly enacted ''partial birth'' abortion ban. The doctors quickly concluded that performing any type of abortion in Wisconsin would subject them to prosecution and possible life imprisonment under that law. After all, the point of this kind of partial-birth ban is to end access to abortion in general.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, GEORGE Z., M.D.
description: MITCHELL-George Z., M.D. On May 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Alice Mitchell. Dear father of Z. Peter and (Mercedes) Mitchell. Services Sunday, May 17. For information, call 212-749-5553.

title: Turner Sports Shows An Interest in Albert
description: Marv Albert is expected to meet soon with officials of Turner Sports about calling National Basketball Association games. There have been preliminary indications of interest from Turner, although its N.B.A. announcing crew for games on TNT and TBS is complete with Dick Stockton, Bob Neal and Kevin Harlan.

title: 8 World Leaders Urge Suharto to Show Restraint in Handling Indonesian Turmoil
description: The leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies and Russia called on Indonesia's leader today to show restraint in responding to the country's growing unrest, and said a solution would have to involve political as well as economic changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, ESTHER DONER.
description: SILVER-Esther Doner. Beloved wife of the late Milton Liszt Silver, of a heart attack on May 11, 1998. A leading social work professional in New York, and the Midwest, and a winner of the Presidential Medal of Freedom in World War II, she was ninety-one. Survived by her sister, Margaret Buckingham of Napa, CA, her stepchildren Jeanne Silver Frankl of Amagansett, NY, David Anthony Silver of Los Angeles, CA., and son-in-law Kenneth R. Frankl, three granddaughters, a great-grandson, two nieces, five grand nephews and two grand nieces. Memorial on Saturday, 10 AM at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Tarrytown, New York.

title: America's Loses May Exceed India's When Sanctions Are Applied
description: Analysts and foreign business executives warn that American sanctions against India for testing nuclear bombs may have only a limited impact on India but a broad and lasting one on American business interests there.

title: Officers in Beating Case Must Feed the Homeless
description: Judge Walter R. Barisonek let the punishment fit the crime yesterday when sentencing six correction officers who admitted participating in or covering up the 1995 beating of illegal immigrants at the Union County Jail.

title: Can the Taxi Drivers Stay on Strike, Please?; Debts Cause Accidents
description: To the Editor:

title: YACHT RACING; Crew Scrambles as Sail Piece Floats Off
description: The nine remaining boats in the 31,600-nautical mile Whitbread Round the World Race are on the eighth of nine legs, 3,390 nautical miles across the Atlantic from Annapolis, Md., to La Rochelle, France. On this leg, Toshiba currently stands first, Silk Cut second and Chessie Racing third. Over all, after seven legs, the standing had EF Language first, Swedish Match second and Merit Cup third. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women crew of EF Education of Sweden, which stands fourth on this leg and ninth over all, will continue to file periodic updates of life at sea until the race's scheduled return to Southampton, England, later this month. This is her 18th report.

title: Navy Ships Put on Alert for Evacuation
description: More than 10,000 American troops and a flotilla of United States Navy ships now steaming through the South China Sea are ready to help evacuate American citizens from Indonesia if a planned airlift becomes impossible because of the chaos there, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Hoboken to Hollywood and Beyond, Mourning the Man and His Magic
description: From Hollywood to the back streets of Hoboken, from seats of power in Europe and America to gritty barrooms where the old romantic ballads still intoxicate the soul, they mourned Frank Sinatra yesterday, not only as one of a century's most influential singers but as someone who had touched them intimately with a voice, a mood, a poignant memory.

title: A Lesson For Sutton: Treat Golf As an Art
description: A simple conversation with a legend did what equipment and psychologists could not: reinvigorate Hal Sutton's golf game.

title: From Morocco to Brooklyn, A Runner's Road to the Top
description: His is an immigrant's tale: Barely 22, Khalid Khannouchi scrubbed dishes in a Middle Eastern restaurant and hauled tables at grade school track meets, anything to make a dollar. He spoke little English but settled near other Moroccans in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. He found a tiny apartment and a mosque for Friday prayers.

title: Godzilla, Present And Past
description: A new, high-tech ''Godzilla'' makes its cinematic debut in a few days, a reincarnation of the cult movie classic of the 1950's. This Godzilla vents its wrath on New Year's revelers in Times Square, but the monster's trail stretches back to a time of fear and mistrust in Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONNER, ALBERT
description: TONNER-Albert. Most adored and loving husband of Hortense for 55 wonderful years. Devoted father of Leslie and Richard Curtis and Patty and Joel Winetz. Precious Poppa to Emily, Debra and Charles. Beloved brother of Sylvia Leef and Elaine Goldsmith. A truly remarkable man, one of President Bush's ''Thousand Points of Light.'' Service Sunday 11:30AM ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: New Jersey's Democratic Senators Declare End to Their Cold War
description: Detente has been declared in the cold war between New Jersey's Democratic Senators, Frank R. Lautenberg and Robert G. Torricelli. For now, anyway.

title: U.S. Inquiry Opens Window On the Military Elite of China
description: In the long life of Gen. Liu Huaqing, a pioneer in Communist China's history since the first battles of the revolution, fortune has rewarded him with a ''gaogan zidi'' -- a ''high cadre child'' of privilege, his daughter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAASE, CHARLES PETER.
description: MAASE-Charles Peter. On Tuesday, May 12 in the company of friends and family at the home of his parents in Brockville, Ontario, at the age of 49 years. Beloved son of Charles A. and Janet E. Masse of Brockville. Dear brother of Jill Maase and her partner John Richardson of Ottawa, and John Maase and his wife Wilda Madden of Brockville. Also survived by his niece Lily Elizabeth Richardson Maase. Peter's great style, humour, creativity, and loving friendship will be greatly missed by all who knew him. We are grateful for the kindness and care of so many of Peter's friends during his difficult and prolonged illness. In accordance with Peter's wishes, there will be a private cremation and interment service in Montreal. A memorial service will be planned at a later date in New York City, where Peter resided for the past 26 years. In remembrance, donations to Friends In Deed, 594 Broadway, Suite 706, New York City, NY, U.S.A. 10012 would be greatly acknowledged.

title: The Widow Is So Merry, And With Good Reason
description: There isn't a thought in the giddy, pretty head of Ronald Hynd's production of ''The Merry Widow.'' And American Ballet Theater gave the ballet full measures of good humor and sumptuous spectacle on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Chanting in Homage to Allen Ginsberg
description: It was a typical, raucous Allen Ginsberg event, with chanting and music and blunt speeches on gay rights and the nuclear threat, as some 2,500 of his friends and fans gathered at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Thursday evening to pay tribute to this poet, who died in April 1997 at the age of 70.

title: Upbeat Schumer Battles Poor Polls, Low Turnouts and His Image
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn barreled into the main hall at the Harvard Club the other night and took in the bleak scene that awaited him: the spotlighted lectern, the humming sound system, the 300 seats arranged in neat rows -- and the 17 people there to hear him speak. Mr. Schumer's tiny audience was almost lost in this vast expanse of a hall, with its soaring ceilings and a huge elephant head mounted on a wall peering down at the Congressman.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jerry Brown, in New Incarnation, Brings Celebrity to Oakland Race
description: Over the course of his unconventional adventures, Jerry Brown has popped up in many places, wearing many faces: India, where he ministered to the wretched with Mother Teresa; Japan, where he sought Zen enlightenment; Sacramento, where he spurned the Governor's mansion for a private apartment with a mattress on the floor.

title: India's Nuclear Gamble Exposed U.S. Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: DAVEL COMMUNICATIONS GROUP SELLS A 28% STAKE
description: Davel Communications Group Inc., one of the largest United States pay phone operators, has sold a stake of about 28 percent to Equity Group Investments Inc., a closely held investment group controlled by the Chicago billionaire Samuel Zell, for $28 million. Equity Group will receive one million newly issued common shares in Davel, plus warrants to purchase an additional 218,750 shares, which can be exercised if the stock reaches $32. Davel, based in Tampa, Fla., is selling the stake instead of pursuing a previously announced secondary equity offering.

title: Dominicans Mourn Death Of Candidate
description: In politics here, personalities have always mattered more than parties. So it should surprise no one that the death earlier this week of Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, one of the country's most popular and charismatic figures, has replaced the debate over any single issue as the focal point of elections scheduled for Saturday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINATRA, FRANK
description: SINATRA-Frank. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved Abbot Emeritus Frank Sinatra. To the world he was the Chairman of the Board, but to the Friars he was a friend who touched our lives, not only in song, but also through his personal guidance. He was fierce in his dedication and continued support of humanitarian causes, which was always achieved with modesty. He helped us preserve the rich theatrical roots of the Friars Club and his name belongs among the legendary & immortal Friars like Jack Benny, George Burns, Enrico Caruso, George M. Cohan, Cary Grant, George Jessel, Joe E. Lewis, Dean Martin, Ed Sullivan and Mike Todd, and, like them, he shared a legacy of commitment to the very best. We are honored and proud to have been touched by the legend that will always be Frank Sinatra. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jack L. Green, Dean Emeritus David W. Tebet, Chamberlain Jean Pierre Trebot, Exec. Dir.

title: Can the Taxi Drivers Stay on Strike, Please?; Fleet Owners Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Pullout of Front-Runner Puts Pace Into Question
description: When Coronado's Quest, the morning-line favorite, was scratched today from Saturday's 123d Preakness Stakes, it changed the complexion of the race's early pace and placed a premium on strategy for the riders of the 10 remaining runners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIRECTOR, NATHAN (PETE).
description: DIRECTOR-Nathan (Pete). On May 15, 1998. Devoted husband of Phyllis. Beloved father of Jon, Roger and Lisa. Loving father-in-law of Jeanne and Jan. Cherished grandfather of Gillian, Geoffrey and Chloe. Service Sunday, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Sports of The Times; The Legend And Legacy Of the Goat
description: BY 9 o'clock yesterday morning, word began filtering out in Harlem that the Goat was dead. Earl Manigault, the playground legend, the player Kareem Abdul-Jabbar once called ''the best basketball player his size in the history of New York City,'' was dead at age 53. His heart, which had undergone two major operations, finally gave out.

title: Generale des Eaux Holders Approve Bid
description: The shareholders of Compagnie Generale des Eaux S.A. backed the purchase for 34.2 billion francs ($5.7 billion) of the media company Havas S.A. yesterday, culminating the 144-year-old utility's rebirth as a faster-growing communications company. Symbolic of the renaissance, shareholders also approved changing the company's name to Vivendi.

title: Russia Resists I.M.F.'s Strategy for Reducing Budget Deficit
description: Russia is at odds with the International Monetary Fund over the politically charged question of how to reduce the nation's huge budget deficit.

title: Bomb Scanner For Airports Is Underused, Audit Finds
description: The bomb-detection machines that the Federal Aviation Administration bought for the airlines at $1 million each are going largely unused, a Transportation Department audit has found. The aviation agency said that this was because the airlines had been slow to shift to other security methods that would make more use of the machines. They said those methods would be coming into place in the near future.

title: GIULIANI PLANS CUT OF 1,000 WORKERS WHO AID HOMELESS
description: The Giuliani administration plans to cut as many as 1,000 positions from the Department of Homeless Services -- roughly half of the agency's total -- as it presses on with efforts to contract out the counseling and shelter that is provided to the city's homeless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDES, GERTRUDE PIES.
description: LANDES-Gertrude Pies. May 14, 1998 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Joseph W. Landes and the late Louis Pies. Loving mother of Robert and Phyllis Landes and William and Elisabeth Landes. Cherished grandmother of Bonnie, Joseph, Erica, Jeffrey, Lucy and Kathy. Adoring greatgrandmother of Alexander, Maxwell, Philip and Charles. Graveside service on Monday at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, New Jersey.

title: It Was Child's Play to Seize and Barricade the Latin Quarter
description: THE FIRST surprise was how easy it was for the students to take charge without adult approval: buildings, then streets, finally the Latin Quarter, together with schools and factories across the country. Paris street skirmishing erupted May 3, a Friday and two days after the trade unions' traditional May Day parade. The flash point occurred the following Friday, May 10, the night of the barricades. Students fought riot police for 12 hours in the Rue Gay Lussac and nearly 1,500 people were hurt, a third of themseriously. Of these, 250 were policemen. When the police retreated, the barricades were still there.

title: More Tobacco Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: Aftermath of Riots and Arson: Identifying the Dead
description: Roy Effendi found the body of his 21-year-old son in a hospital today, his tousled hair, crooked front tooth and surprised expression making him look almost lifelike despite the bullet wound in the back of his head.

title: Canada Sets Bail for Iranians Held in Weapons Smuggling
description: Two Iranian men arrested here this week on charges of conspiring to smuggle American-made weapons and military parts to Iran were ordered released on bail today over the objections of the United States Government, which is trying to extradite them.

title: Republicans Ask Clinton to Show Donations Didn't Breach Security
description: Armed with new evidence that Chinese military intelligence funneled money to the Democrats in 1996, Congressional Republicans today challenged President Clinton to prove that United States national security had not been threatened.

title: PURCHASE OF BALTIMORE GAS AND ELECTRIC UNIT PLANNED
description: Corporate Office Properties Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company's real estate unit for $203 million in cash and securities, increasing its office property holdings by about 59 percent. The unit, Constellation Real Estate Group Inc., owns eight buildings in the Baltimore and Washington, D.C., areas. Under the terms of the agreement, Corporate Office will pay $107 million in cash or assume the same amount of debt. It will also issue 6.88 million common shares valued at $96 million and $24 million of convertible preferred stock. After the transaction, Corporate Office will own 45 properties.

title: At Jakarta's Airport, Planes Arrive Empty and Leave Packed
description: JAKARTA  When her sister called and said that looters had broken down the door, ransacked the house and taken everything  television set, stereo, clothing and shoes  Elizabeth S. knew it was time to leave Indonesia.

title: FPA MEDICAL MANAGEMENT SHARES LOSE HALF THEIR VALUE
description: Shares of FPA Medical Management Inc. lost nearly half their value yesterday after the company said it planned to take pretax charges of $200 million in the second quarter, ending on June 30. FPA Medical, based in San Diego, operates a network of 7,700 physicians that treat 1.2 million people nationwide under contracts with health maintenance organizations. In the quarter ended March 31, it lost $9.1 million on revenue of $392 million. Shares of FPA lost $5.50 to close at $6 on the Nasdaq stock market. The company said the charges included $125 million for good will impairment, a $40 million write-down of shared risk and other receivables, and $35 million for severance payments, office consolidation and other expenses.

title: On the Tattoo Map, It's the Sticks; New York Plays Catch-Up at First Skin Art Convention
description: Jonathan Shaw has been putting ink under people's skin for a quarter of a century. He is something of a tattoo celebrity; his work can be found on Kate Moss, the model, and Johnny Depp, the actor. When Mr. Shaw learned the art, it was practiced in basements and back rooms and had the same illicit thrill buying marijuana did, because tattooing was also illegal in New York City.

title: A Deep Silence of 60 Years, And an Even Older Secret
description: It remains one of the great mysteries of American letters: What made Henry Roth pour forth a novel at age 28 that is widely considered a literary masterpiece and then spend the next 60 years producing nary a short story -- immobilized, barren, silenced?

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Thursday about President Clinton's criticism of the Indian Government over its nuclear tests misspelled the name of the site in Potsdam where he met with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. It was the Sans Souci Palace.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Fall a Second Day On Worries Over Asia

title: Parents Held in Public Flogging of Son, 13
description: Police arrested the parents of a 13-year-old Sunset Park, Brooklyn, boy on charges that they tied the boy naked to a chair in front of a window and flogged him with a belt as a crowd of 10 to 15 neighbors gathered outside to watch.

title: O'Donnell to Be at Mini-Camp
description: The Jets yesterday not only met the deadline to pay quarterback Neil O'Donnell a $1 million salary advance, but they also announced that O'Donnell would be attending the team's minicamp for veterans May 26-29.

title: Earl Manigault, 53, New York City Basketball Legend, Dies
description: Earl Manigault, a New York City playground legend whose superior basketball talent deteriorated with years of heroin use, depriving him of a chance for a professional career, died Thursday night at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. He was 53.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about precautions being taken by foreign companies in Indonesia misspelled the name of a company that advises corporations on security. It is the Kroll-O'Gara Company, not Kroll-O'Geara.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPARBER, BEATRICE
description: SPARBER-Beatrice. Beloved wife (59 years) of Norman. Dearest mother of Merryl & Roy. Darling grandmother & great grandmother. She leaves a tremendous void in all of our lives. Services are at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre on Sunday, May 17 at 12:15 P.M.

title: Can the Taxi Drivers Stay on Strike, Please?; Vigilante Cabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLCOTT, VIRGINIA
description: OLCOTT-Virginia. We regret to announce the death of our dear aunt, Virginia Olcott, of East Orange, New Jersey on Thursday, May 14, 1998.

title: Cruelty Like Caesar's
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUME, GERTRUDE (KITTY)
description: TANNENBAUME-Gertrude (Kitty), 97 years. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Carol and George Kaplan and Marian and Jay Grossman. Loving grandmother of James, Jill, John, Susan, and Robert. Cherished great-grandmother of six. Service 11am Sunday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Technology Issues and Disney Are Vanguard of Retreat
description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by computer-chip makers, after National Semiconductor warned late on Thursday that it would lose money until the end of August.

title: Our Towns; All or Nothing For Sinatra In Hoboken
description: THE wake had started two years ago in the back room of Leo's Grandevous, in the cramped aisle of Lepore's Chocolates and at the counter of Piccolo's Clam Bar, places not shy about declaring Frank Sinatra the greatest entertainer in the world.

title: Canceled Tour Leaves A Void in the Heartland
description: The New York City Ballet's plan for an ambitious 50th-anniversary national tour was never formally announced, so the company's decision to cancel the tour drew little attention. But throughout the nation, performing arts producers faced with the last-minute loss of a major attraction greeted the news with emotions ranging from disbelief to fury.

title: Court Is Said to Avoid Lewinsky Dispute
description: A Federal appeals court has decided not to get involved, for the time being, in the dispute over whether Monica S. Lewinsky should have immunity from prosecution, according to news reports.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT SET TO CUT ITS DIVIDEND
description: Waste Management Inc. said yesterday that it would cut its quarterly dividend to conserve cash and take a second-quarter pretax charge of $70 million to $90 million for costs related to the year 2000 software bug. The trash company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., cut its dividend to a penny a share from 17 cents, payable on July 2 to shareholders of record on June 17. It said it would license USA Waste Services Inc.'s plan to eliminate the 2000 problem from its computer systems and discontinue its own plan. The moves come two months after the beleaguered company agreed to be bought by its rival, USA Waste, for $21.8 billion. Waste Management shares fell 43.75 cents yesterday, to $33.125.

title: San Francisco Journal; Gift of Millions, and a Pile of Trouble
description: It was a gesture, and a tale, that had tongues wagging and hearts swelling throughout this often blase city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITING, EDWARD V.
description: WHITING-Edward V. It is with deep sorrow that we record the untimely passing of our esteemed member, Edward V. Whiting and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Rose and son Julian. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President Robert Fensterman, Secretary

title: U.S.-Microsoft Negotiations Get Under Way
description: The Government began negotiations with the Microsoft Corporation in Washington yesterday in a first tentative step to try to reach a settlement and avoid filing a major antitrust suit against the company.

title: An Exclusive Economic Summit
description: This weekend's meeting in Britain of leaders from industrialized countries is dealing with the crisis in Indonesia and the economic tribulations of other Asian nations. But only one Asian country, Japan, is represented. Fighting international crime and increasing the jobs that globalization creates are also on the agenda. But the countries most affected by these issues are absent. It is useful to have an annual summit where leaders can talk about solving global problems. But that gathering can no longer exclude the developing world.

title: More Tobacco Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: Tainted Food Imports
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs
description: A corner display window of an art gallery in Seattle has recently been exhibiting paintings by an obscure artist that feature nuns, a Pope, oral sex, Jesus hanging from a cross of penises, a pedophile priest in flagrante delicto and pages of the Bible defaced with satanic marks.

title: Radio Ad Marketer Apologizes for Memo Offending Minorities
description: A New York company that sells national advertising for radio stations apologized yesterday for an internal strategy document whose disclosure caused a furor among operators of radio stations catering to black and Hispanic audiences.

title: Piazza Traded for What's Left of the Marlins
description: The Florida Marlins and the Los Angeles Dodgers agreed last night to an unprecedented swap of nearly $100 million in contracts in a seven-player deal that included Mike Piazza and Gary Sheffield.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, EMMA LAMPERT.
description: MEYER-Emma Lampert. Friday, May 15, 1998. Of Silver Spring, MD. Beloved wife of the late Gerard Previn Meyer. Mother of Eugene Lampert Meyer and Deborah Meyer DeWan. Sister of Harry Lampert. Grandmother of Eric, David and Aaron Meyer and Tara Rothstein. Graveside service on Sunday, May 17, Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY at 3 P.M.

title: India's Nuclear Gamble Exposed U.S. Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Singapore Airlines Orders Airbus Jets
description: Singapore Airlines agreed yesterday to buy 10 wide-bodied A340-500 aircraft from the European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie for a total of $2.2 billion. The deal consists of five firm orders and five options, with deliveries to begin in 2002. The long-range aircraft, which have four engines and can carry more than 300 passengers, would be used for nonstop flights between Singapore and Los Angeles and San Francisco. The planes will be powered by Rolls-Royce engines.

title: Frank Sinatra Dies at 82; Matchless Stylist of Pop
description: Frank Sinatra, the singer and actor whose extraordinary voice elevated popular song into an art, died on Thursday night in Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: Student Revolt in Paris Lasted Barely a Month, and a Lifetime
description: Suddenly, the world focused on Paris. In modern French history, May '68 is probably the best-known dateperhaps the only one that is recognized around the world. The monthlong student revolt on the Left Bank in Paris during that time fired imaginations everywhere and still does. Its slogans, stenciled on the city's walls, laminated themselves onto minds in a new utopian capital whose rules would be: "It is forbidden to forbid," "Under the paving stones, the beach" and, perhaps most prophetic of all, "Run, comrade, the old world is catching up with you." Those heady spring days and nights of student power in the streets created an icon in the French specialty of revolution.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLAPHOLTZ, ANNE
description: KLAPHOLTZ-Anne March 22, 1902 to May 16, 1994 Remembered Francene

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 4 about Gregory Peck and his current projects misstated his age when he portrayed Ahab in the 1956 John Huston version of ''Moby Dick.'' He was 40, not 35.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISELS, RAPHAEL
description: MEISELS-Raphael. On May 14, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Zelda. Beloved father of Deborah, Naomi and Anna. Cherished grandfather of ten and great grandfather of nine. Former District Director of Internal Revenue, Chairman of H. Hentz & Company, Honorary Chairman Emeritus of Shearson American Express and longtime Member and Treasurer of the Dessoff Choir. Service on Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Central Park Conservancy.

title: Can the Taxi Drivers Stay on Strike, Please?; Yuppies on the Bus
description: To the Editor:

title: Pettitte Sags, And Yankees Falter Again
description: A tempest of emotion swirls within Andy Pettitte, driving him. But in those rare moments when Pettitte starts to flounder, the tempest becomes a cyclone, raging out of control, obliterating the qualities that make him one of the game's best pitchers.

title: Scooped on Tests, U.S. Scorns a Sikh Journal
description: The Central Intelligence Agency may have missed India's preparations for its nuclear tests this week, but a tiny weekly newsletter by a Sikh separatist group did not.

title: Foreign Affairs; Indonesian Meltdown
description: You can learn everything you need to know about Indonesia's problems by catching a blue taxi when you arrive at Jakarta airport and then riding into town to the Grand Hyatt Hotel. The taxi company is owned by one of President Suharto's children, so too are the toll roads that you have to pass through to get from the airport to Jakarta and so too is the Hyatt. Nice roads. Nice tolls. Nice hotel. It's no wonder that Indonesians say about the Suharto family that they are so lucky. They have everything in the world. Except one thing -- a sense of shame.

title: Too Much Political Bonding
description: The biggest bond issue in United States history got off to a successful start this week when a first offering of $3.5 billion attracted $18 billion worth of orders. The bonds to bail out the Long Island Lighting Company are expected to give Long Island's electricity customers an immediate break from years of soaring bills. They could also give Gov. George Pataki a boost in his re-election campaign if these consumers get refund checks of $100 or more a few weeks before the vote.

title: Sports of The Times; Storm's Thinking Must Go Beyond City
description: IT is definitely time for St. John's University to give up on the ancient ideal of the basketball coach who loves the school and the city so much that he stays for 40 years.

title: MERCURY FINANCE SEEKING BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: The Mercury Finance Company, the troubled car-loan concern, said yesterday that it would file in 60 days for bankruptcy-law protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. The moves were announced as Mercury, based in Chicago, said it had reached agreement with its senior lenders and subordinated debt holders for a recapitalization that would reduce debt and enable the company to return to profitability.

title: Girl, 6, Fractures Her Skull In a Fall From School Roof
description: A 6-year-old girl was critically injured yesterday afternoon when she fell four stories from the roof of her school in Brooklyn, school officials said.

title: Sold China 'Spirit Tree' May Have Been Stolen
description: Chinese officials charged with protecting relics are investigating the possibility that a spectacular ancient bronze candelabra recently sold in New York for a reported $2.5 million may have been illegally unearthed last year in south-central China and smuggled out of the country.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHOEN, RITA
description: SCHOEN-Rita. Lovingly remembered today, on your birthday. Marcos Del Forn and Family

title: Netanyahu Voices Newfound Optimism on Peace Talks
description: As he began a three-day visit to New York City, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said yesterday that the most recent talks with American officials have produced ideas that might contribute to breaking the impasse in the Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: A contents entry in The Metro Section on Thursday about the sale of Monet's 1908 painting ''Grand Canal'' referred incorrectly in some editions to the auction house involved. It was Sotheby's, not Christie's.

title: Prayer Vigil Planned At Site of Van Shooting
description: Hundreds of people are expected to attend a prayer vigil at the Molly Pitcher Rest Area on the New Jersey Turnpike this afternoon for three young men shot by two state police troopers who pulled over their van.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL FALLS 4 PERCENT. Crude oil took the biggest one-day drop in two months on fears that Indonesia's paralysis could worsen a global glut caused partly by falling Asian demand. June contracts fell 61 cents, to $14.47 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, SHEPARD
description: COLEMAN-Shepard. Cellist. Died May 12 in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, NJ. Born Brooklyn April 23, 1924. He had acted as conductor and/or musical director for ''Hello Dolly'' Tony 1964, ''Bye-Bye Birdie'' ''Mama'', ''Golden Boy'', ''Henry Sweet Henry'', ''Oh what a lovely War'' and ''The Student Gypsy''. He held positions in the NY Philharmonic, WQXR, and WMCA in New York City. Mr. Coleman trained at Juilliard and recently taught and worked for local theatre groups in Orange County, NY. He is survived by a sister Diana Hoffman and a brother Avron both of Manhattan. A private funeral was previously held. A memorial service is planned for June in Warwick.

title: Mets Weigh Joining The Chase For Piazza
description: The buzz in the visiting clubhouse here, as it almost certainly was in every other clubhouse around the major leagues today, concerned the blockbuster trade between the Los Angeles Dodgers and Florida Marlins.

title: Steady Job, Steady Rhythms
description: The guitarist John Scofield and his band have been on the road for nearly two months, and their first set at Iridium on Tuesday night paid tribute to steady work in jazz. The band, taking rhythms from popular music and improvising from a jazz musician's point of view, had the interaction and dynamic change that comes from playing regularly together in front of an audience. It was hard, vital music, exciting in its flexibility.

title: Ol' Blue Eyes
description: Unlike many cultural icons, Frank Sinatra never seemed frozen in time. He appeared always in the prime of life, a man of resilience whose talent survived not only setbacks and scandal but 60 years of turbulent cultural change. Of the three most powerful male forces in 20th-century pop music -- the others being Elvis Presley and the Beatles -- Sinatra started earliest and lasted longest.

title: Store Owner is Sentenced For Transporting Fetuses
description: A SoHo store owner who pleaded guilty to illegally transporting human fetuses and selling the remains of endangered species has been sentenced in State Supreme Court to 90 days in jail and fined $10,000, prosecutors said.

title: Temple Worship: Celebrating an Academy's 100th Anniversary
description: The American Academy of Arts and Letters, perhaps the nation's most exclusive club of artists, is celebrating its 100th anniversary. Throughout its history, the academy -- or the Temple, as it was called in a poem placed in the building's cornerstone -- has been ridiculed and envied by some of the country's most respected artists and writers. This week, as it inducts new members and gives out $850,000 in awards, a history of the academy, ''A Century of Arts and Letters,'' published by Columbia University Press and edited by John Updike, will reach bookstores. Here are excerpts from a chapter by Cynthia Ozick on the period 1918 to 1927.

title: No Decision On Testing, U.S. Is Told
description: Pakistani leaders told a high-level American delegation today that they had not yet decided whether to test nuclear weapons, as India did this week, and suggested that they might still be dissuaded.

title: In Cab Fight, City Sets Fares For Street Hails of Liveries
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission set rates yesterday that will allow meterless livery drivers to accept street hails beginning next week as part of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's effort to thwart a planned protest by taxi drivers.

title: MEDITRUST BUYING 12 GOLF COURSES FOR $130 MILLION
description: The Meditrust Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 12 golf courses for $130 million. The courses will be managed by Cobblestone Golf Group and are near courses that Cobblestone runs in Florida, Georgia, Texas and Virginia. The acquisition, expected to close next month, also includes courses in North Carolina and New Jersey. Meditrust, based in Needham Heights, Mass., is a real estate investment trust with investments in 474 health care facilities in 40 states. Meditrust acquired Cobblestone Holdings Inc., a Del Mar, Calif., operator of golf courses, earlier this year for $241 million.

title: Voting on Peace in Northern Ireland
description: The peace deal signed last month after two years of painstaking negotiation in Northern Ireland goes to the voters there and in Ireland later this week. While it is not a perfect agreement, its flaws are the byproduct of its great virtue -- that it is a compromise. Voters should endorse it, and excise the intolerance and division that have too long characterized Northern Ireland's politics.

title: Starwood Is Coming
description: The world's largest hotel company, now based in Phoenix, is moving to Westchester, said Jim Gallagher, a spokesman for Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: RED ARCTIC

title: Eclipse Chase
description: To the Editor: I am glad that Arthur Lubow (''Chasing an Eclipse,'' April 12) enjoyed the total solar eclipse in Guadeloupe on Feb. 26. It was also great from Aruba, where I saw it.

title: In an Anniversary Year, Quest for Land Heats Up
description: The youngish couple were strutting along the matted-down carpet of leaves that rolled through the woods beyond the house they had just bought. Yes, strutting. They were marveling at the turn their lives had taken: the deal, the house, the pool, the ocean a bike ride away, the woods as fresh and as fine as when Indians padded along trails like this one. Even the birds: happy, fluttery creatures with small red and yellow stripes on their blue-black wings.

title: The Nation; When Mega-Mergers Are Mega-Busts
description: MARRY reliable old Daimler-Benz with go-go Chrysler? The union is bound to yield better cars. How about SBC and Ameritech, the telecommunications giants? Streamlining their front offices and linking all those zillions of phone cables into one awesome network ought to save billions.

title: Marking the Trails in the Hamptons
description: IF, as someone once said, you can't get there from here, then perhaps some road signs can speed you on your way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODRICH, FLORENCE BARLOW (RUTHRAUFF)
description: GOODRICH - Florence Barlow (Ruthrauff). Of Westwood, MA. Died on May 14, 1998. Wife of the late Burt Rapalyea, Jr. and the late John W. Goodrich. Mother of Dick Rapalyea of Elverson, PA, David Rapalyea of Salisbury, NH, Steven Rapalyea of Beverly, MA, Dennett W. Goodrich of Dedham, MA and John A. Goodrich of NYC. Grandmother of Lucia and Johanna of Salisbury, Sarah of Denver, CO, Lydia of Eugene, OR, Blair, Mallory and Taylor of Beverly, Denny of Seymour, CT, Ramsey of NYC, Rob and Cam of Dedham, Catherine, Lauren, Jock and Winthrop of NYC. Daughter of the late Wilbur Barlow and Abbie Hagerman (Bourne) Ruthrauff. Sister of the late Wilbur Bourne Ruthrauff. Memorial service, 11 A.M., Tuesday, May 26, Church of the Redeemer, 379 Hammond St., Chestnut Hill, MA. Memorial donations may be directed to Children's Hospital General Fund, Attn: Development Office, 300 Longwood Ave., Boston, MA 02115.

title: Long a Hot Stock, Is Fannie Mae Settling Down?
description: THE specters of rising interest rates and weaker earnings growth -- along with a dollop of political uncertainty -- have slowed the advance of Fannie Mae stock in recent weeks. Indeed, some analysts say the housing market is near or past its peak; if they are correct, Fannie Mae's run as a great growth investment may be ending, too.

title: Ahead of His Time
description: To the Editor:

title: The New New Left
description: ACHIEVING OUR COUNTRY

title: Voters' Anger at H.M.O.'s Plays as Hot Political Issue
description: Public anger over the state of managed care has burst into this year's election campaigns as a major issue, up there with perennials like education, crime and Social Security. In speeches and television advertising, Democrats and a few Republicans are seizing on consumer complaints and calling for a sweeping ''patients' bill of rights.''

title: How 90 and 43 Add Up
description: Harry Biele studied anthropology at Columbia University with Franz Boas and Ruth Benedict, both pioneers in the field. He raised money for the Republicans in Spain during the Civil War there, and he labored in America, Portugal and France in behalf of Jewish refugees during World War II. After the war, in New York, he became a fund-raiser for Israel, working closely for decades with Golda Meir, among others.

title: Still Dressing To a Different Beat
description: Miniskirts over pants embody the fast track of youth. Nothing has changed; teen-agers are doing what they have for all of this century -- tearing down fashion boundaries to establish their own look. What's hot today are oversized cargo pants with pouch pockets on the legs, replacing tight blue jeans; skirts of all lengths; platform shoes; bead chokers, and feather boas for fun. For beauty marks, there are body tattoos, face piercing and colored hair.

title: A Rarely Seen Romp Through a Stravinsky Classic
description: PARISIANS cheered at the 1923 premiere of ''Les Noces.'' But the ballet has had a complicated history ever since. Bronislava Nijinska, who choreographed that first version for Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, had no qualms about tackling Igor Stravinsky's harsh-sounding, rhythmically complex score, a re-envisioning of Russian peasant songs that the composer called a cantata with dances. Nijinska was intrigued by Stravinsky's stylized, sometimes brutal depiction of an arranged Russian peasant marriage, which would require her, she saw, to allow the wedding to ''speak only in the purest movement.''

title: Touring Metropolitan Ostia
description: TWO millenniums ago, the city of Ostia was one of the most important in the world, a bustling port that fed and supplied Rome. Today, its ruins offer armchair archeologists a rare opportunity to clamber over 2,000 years of history.

title: 7,300 Days Later . . .
description: IT was already getting hot as Allan Singer waited for the bus on the morning of May 26, 1978.

title: Bird Smooths Over His Rift With Celtics
description: Larry Bird said he might give his coach of the year award to the team's public relations director. His Boston Celtics memorabilia? Most of it is in boxes at an Indianapolis hotel. Bird is not sure where his most valuable player trophies are.

title: Explaining Mom
description: ME & YOU

title: Being 13; Do Not Disturb
description: Perhaps more than anywhere else, a 13-year-old's bedroom is the sanctuary where childhood and adolescence coexist.

title: Under the Big Top: If It's Party Time It's Fun to Have a Tent
description: IN the mid-1970's when the one-day Southampton Horse Show was held at the Topping horse farm in Sagaponack, two tents were hastily put up to shelter the food service. One measured 4 feet by 8 feet -- ''probably somebody's beach tent,'' said Kelsey Marchal, one of the show's founders and was big enough for two people and a barbecue grill. The other was for the tables.

title: Brazil Congress Rejects President's Plan for Pension Changes
description: The Brazilian Congress has dealt President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's plans for social security reforms their most significant defeat, rejecting a constitutional amendment earlier this month that would have raised the minimum age for retirement.

title: Seaweed to Wood Chips, Mulch Is a Plus
description: MULCHES may invite giggles, but they are a necessity nonetheless. The most obvious plus about mulches: when the ground is properly covered with an organic material of some type, weeds do not have an easy time growing. Also, the soil remains cool and moist and the garden looks as though someone cares.

title: For New M.B.A.'s, Instant Fame
description: THESE have been heady days for Jon Isaacson. For months, he could dine free almost any night of the week at some of the best restaurants in Silicon Valley, and many nights he did. He cruised San Francisco Bay, ate shrimp cocktail, toured Napa Valley vineyards, all expenses paid. On several weekends, he was flown from California to New York, where he stayed free at the Palace Hotel on Madison Avenue.

title: Taking the Helm Is Not All Plain Sailing
description: SAILORS are a breed apart. They are able, it seems, to deal with whatever comes up -- a sudden gust, a tangled rudder, a twisted halyard, even an improperly welded thingamabob that breaks in a gale, sending the sail down the mast. All of them are Mr. Fixits. I even know a 10-year-old sailor who can do almost anything.

title: A Whale of a Bond Sale For Long Island Power
description: IT was the biggest municipal bond offering in the nation's history, but the market had no trouble swallowing it, and came up hungry for more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOZYAN, MARGARET BLISS
description: BOZYAN-Margaret Bliss. Of Hamden, CT, and Middletown, RI. Died at home on May 13 at age 97. The widow of H. Frank Bozyan, Yale University Organist Emeritus, she is survived by four children, Elinor B. Warburg, Gladys B. Lavine, Margaret B. Jefferys and Frank Arakel Bozyan; eleven grandchildren; and seven greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, May 20, at 11 AM, in Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale University. For information, contact Beecher & Bennett Funeral Home, 203288-0800.

title: Commencements; At UConn, Bush Warns of Isolationism's Appeal
description: Former President George Bush, regarded by many in this state as a native son, told the graduating class of the University of Connecticut today that while the world was a safer and freer place than at any other time in modern history, the United States must not withdraw from international affairs.

title: Savarese Scores Two Goals To Help Defeat D.C. United
description: All he does is score goals. Giovanni Savarese annoys purists with his slow footwork, but no MetroStar has filled the net up like him.

title: All Hands On Deck! Now Wash It
description: ONE of the most useful structures on the suburban landscape, the outdoor deck, is also frequently one of the most neglected parts of the house.

title: Laura Siegel, Lee Bonios
description: Laura Rachel Siegel, the daughter of Martin Siegel of Brooklyn and the late Bernice Siegel, was married last evening to Lee Jordan Bonios, the son of Barbara and Fred Bonios of Del Ray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated at the Puck Building in Manhattan.

title: Political Briefing; Big Democratic Guns Salute Illinois Senator
description: Weakened by a shortage of campaign money, questions about possible fund-raising irregularities and complaints about her political judgment -- she once visited an African dictator accused of human rights abuses -- Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois is a top Republican target this election year. But fellow Democrats have begun rallying 'round, big time, in an all-out effort to save her seat and keep the Senate from tipping even more Republican in the fall.

title: Commercial Property/Hotels; Will the Former Ritz-Carlton Thrive as a Westin?
description: FOR six months it was a hotel with no name. After a bitter, protracted dispute with the then-owner of the hotel at 112 Central Park South, the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company lowered its trademark lion flags from the front of the building last August and severed its agreement to manage the property.

title: Writing on the Water
description: We've all encountered airline in-flight magazines. As of this month, ferry riders heading to and from New Jersey have an in-voyage magazine -- Pierless. It hit the docks and boats this month, 25,000 copies distributed free. The monthly publication will include guides to places served by ferries (like Atlantic Highlands, the hometown of John and Ellen Bollinger, the husband and wife who publish Pierless), articles on waterfront history and profiles of ''aquammuters.'' The magazine also includes a map of ferry routes, fares and schedules that is so thorough that the Port Authority and the Department of Transportation have asked to use it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONNER, ALBERT
description: TONNER-Albert. Most adored and loving husband of Hortense for 55 wonderful years. Devoted father of Leslie and Richard Curtis and Patty and Joel Winetz. Precious Poppa to Emily, Debra and Charles. Beloved brother of Sylvia Leef and Elaine Goldsmith. A truly remarkable man, one of President Bush's ''Thousand Points of Light.'' Service Sunday 11:30AM ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXWELL, MICHAEL PHILLIP
description: MAXWELL-Michael Phillip. A customs attorney, died of a heart attack on May 9, 1998, in Los Angeles, CA, at the age of 48. He will be sorely missed by his family and many friends. He received his B.A. degree from Memphis State University, a law degree from Memphis State University and a Master of Law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. He practiced law in New York City and Los Angeles. He is survived by his parents Mike and Irene Maxwell of FL; a sister Amanda Maxwell, of Miami; and a brother James, of New York City. Services were held at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles, CA, on Thursday, May 14, 1998. Memorial donations may be made to either a scholarship fund established in the name of Michael P. Maxwell by Women in International Trade, Inc., P.O. Box 3972, Barranca Parkway, Suite J200, Irvine, CA 92604, (310) 522-0200 ext 340, or to the American Heart Association, (800) 242-8721.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIGGS, J. KIRK
description: BRIGGS-J. Kirk, 54. Of Bristol, RI and Truro MA., died Sunday, May 3, of cancer, at his home on Cape Cod. Surviving are his wife Louise Briggs, his sister Kearsley Monroe Briggs, his aunt Monica Brice Hobbs, and his cousin William Brice Hobbs. A memorial is planned for 12 Noon, Saturday, May 30th, at the Briggs home in Truro, Mass. The memorial will be followed by a reception. Donations may be made in Mr. Briggs' memory to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute. Gifts may be directed to DFCI, Gift Processing Office, 1309 Beacon St., Brookline, Mass. 02146. Information Devito Funeral Home, Watertown, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RESNICK, LEAH
description: RESNICK-Leah ''Much music is found in dreaming and the tickets are free for each dance.'' You are forever and always in my heart. Happy birthday, May 18, Mother darling. I love you. Judith Sheila

title: The Greatest
description: To the Editor:

title: Preaching to the Converted
description: LESSONS LEARNED

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Walk on Water

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Backtalk; Power Game Has Coaches On the Move
description: The Cult of Coach, that search for serial dads who will lead us to personal bests and group riches, continues to spread. College football coaches were once the favored faux father figures, then professional baseball managers replaced them. Now college and professional basketball coaches are the golden gurus. While the Bulls' Phil Jackson continued to lead us on the path to enlightenment last week, it was three college basketball coaches who showed us just how rocky that path can be.

title: Airport Plans
description: The Board of Legislators is reviewing a decision by a State Supreme Court justice in White Plains blocking a proposal by General Electric to build a $20 million hangar and seven-acre extension of a runway for company jets at Westchester County Airport, the Board's Chairman, George S. Latimer, said last week.

title: HOW CHINESE WON RIGHTS TO LAUNCH SATELLITES FOR U.S.
description: On Oct. 9, 1995, Secretary of State Warren Christopher ended a lengthy debate within the Clinton Administration by initialing a classified order that preserved the State Department's sharp limits on China's ability to launch American-made satellites aboard Chinese rockets.

title: Paradise Lost
description: SUMMER AT GAGLOW

title: Demand for Land For Development Besieges East End
description: THE very essence of the East End, its open fields of summer corn and green vegetables, its orderly vineyards and fragrant strawberry fields and varied plant nurseries, continue to be threatened by developers, despite increased private and government efforts to preserve farmland.

title: The Clues Are in The Blood
description: I saw my own image in the distorted faces of Editha Bensi and her children, and understood what my parents confronted when their Depression-era firstborn arrived, in a small-town hospital in western Texas (''The Clues Are in the Blood,'' by Lisa Belkin, April 26).

title: Progress on All Fronts in Race to Map Genes; Why Do Research?
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books in Brief
description: STAND FOR CHILDREN

title: Walk Softly and Make a Big Statement
description: FOR those who know how to decode the signs, few items yield as much information about their wearer as the shoe.

title: The World: Everybody Knew. Now They Care.; Out of the Nuclear Closet
description: PROUDLY ripping off a veil last week, India removed the artificial ambiguity from what the world already knew -- that it could produce and deploy nuclear weapons. But if everyone already knew, why all the fuss?

title: Race Case Rejected
description: A Federal judge has rejected a claim of a racially hostile work environment in a county workplace, which was brought by a former employee against the County District Attorney and the county itself.

title: Don't Tread on My Tax Rate
description: Mary Barrosse is not, nor will she ever be, a ''Vermonter'' (''Don't Tread on My Tax Rate,'' by Elinor Burkett, April 26). As people here like to say, ''Just because the cat had her kittens in the oven don't make 'em biscuits.'' The vitriol and antagonism coursing through Vermont in the wake of Act 60 has been simmering for a long time and comes, in part, from the influx of those like Barrosse who bring money and yuppie expectations to the state and price the working folk out of their own communities.

title: Meredith Lane, Bryan Verona
description: Meredith Lauren Lane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Lane of New York, was married last evening to Bryan Scott Verona, a son of Jane R. Kornblut of Highland Park, Ill., and Dr. Steven R. Verona of Chicago. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: South Fork Gardens Abloom With Art
description: ALTHOUGH the South Fork's towns and villages can boast little publicly sponsored sculpture, several private properties offer outdoor exhibitions that the public is welcome to view and, in some cases, visit.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Poet Gives a Reading

title: Ewing and Teammates Seem Chiseled in Stone
description: Other than a few more age lines, the face of the Knicks is very likely to remain the same next season. It is a team with limited options to produce change.

title: Coronado's Quest Recovering
description: Coronado's Quest, the early favorite for the Preakness, spent today recuperating in his stall at Belmont Park in New York, nursing an injury that forced his withdrawal from the race on Friday. Coronado's Quest has a small bruise on the sole of his right rear foot. ''We've worked on him for the last few hours, and he's doing better now,'' Buzz Tenney, the assistant to the trainer Shug McGaughey, said this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, JOSEPH
description: BRENNER-Joseph (Formerly of Rockville Centre). Beloved husband of the late Selma. Cherished father of Steven Brenner and Shelley LaFauci. Dear brother of Jerome and Zalick. Adored grandfather of Greg and Kim LaFauci. Serivces Sunday 11:30am Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: East Hampton at 350: A Chronology
description: Beginning in 1648 as a tiny English settlement, caught in turmoil during the American Revolution, and then languishing in splendid, self-sufficient isolation for mroe than a century, the Town of East Hampton became in the development-mad 20th century an international resort clinging to a glorious past. As the town celebrates its 350th anniversary, here is a chronology of selected events - great, small and curious - based in part on the book ''East Hampton, a Town and its People, 1648-1994,'' by Nancy Hyden Woodward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDERER, HY
description: LANDERER-Hy. May 14. Loving Husband of Lyla. Father of Gail, Shelley & Andy. Cherished ''Poppa'' of Isabel. Devoted Brother. Dear Friend to all who knew him. He will be in our hearts always.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article last Sunday about Kerry Wood, the Chicago Cubs pitcher, misstated his achievement in striking out 20 batters in a nine-inning game. He broke the National League record; what he tied was the major league record.

title: Producers of Noise Should Pay for Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: Turmoil Results From Dethroning of Colorado Beauty Queen
description: The fight to be Colorado's reigning beauty queen has become an ugly matter. The unfolding drama over the crown peaked this week with two young women asserting that they were Miss Colorado and the state pageant organization contemplating bankruptcy.

title: Let Senate Act On Test Ban Treaty; Distracting Scandals
description: To the Editor:

title: Assistant Coach Takes On New Role
description: As St. John's embarks on a search for a new head basketball coach, the longtime assistant coach Ron Rutledge has officially removed his name from consideration and will leave the bench for an administrative role.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNBLUTH, SAMUEL
description: KORNBLUTH-Samuel. Died May 14 in Nashville, Tennessee. Former Controller/Vice President of Finance of Service Merchandise and Treasurer of Macy's. Survived by loving wife Pearl. Devoted sons Jesse and Richard and adoring granddaughters Lily and Irys. Memorial services will be in held Nashville at a later date.

title: As We Lie Dying
description: FRAGMENTS ON THE DEATHWATCH

title: Valhalla Singer in Joan Baez Tour
description: PART way through her recent sold-out concert at the Music Hall here, Joan Baez yielded the spotlight to Richard Shindell, a 37-year-old Valhalla resident, songwriter and performer who had contributed three of his songs to her newly released CD ''Gone From Danger.''

title: In Greece
description: To the Editor: I hardly feel reassured to read that despite a series of terrorist bombings targeting American businesses in Athens, ''no one has been killed or injured.''

title: 'Eyebrow Man': The Lawyer Has Two Faces
description: GEORGE WHIPPLE 3D is an in-house counsel for the investment banking firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and the other night he went to a black-tie tribute at Avery Fisher Hall for the director Martin Scorsese. No surprise there. Until, that is, you learn that Mr. Whipple, 43, was covering the event as the celebrity reporter for New York 1, the all-news cable channel. There he was, in his Brooks Brothers pinstripes and hunting-dog tie -- ''My uniform since I was 10,'' he said -- waiting behind the press barricades, along with the camera crews in blue jeans, for the sight of somebody, anybody, famous.

title: Flavors of Spring From a Cornucopia of Young Vegetables
description: TENDER young vegetables, picked fresh from the garden in spring, make you forget about the damp days of winter. ''For best results, you should ideally go out into your vegetable garden and pick what you need,'' Roger Verge, the celebrated Provencal chef, said, ''either at dawn or after the sun has set. But if you can get up early and visit a local farmer's market first thing in the morning, you should be able to get wonderfully fresh vegetables.''

title: Being 13; Grief at an Early Age
description: How has your relationship with your friends changed?

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; Montauk
description: ST. Patrick's Day starts Montauk's season with a big parade. Then there's the Blessing of the Fleet, a big parade of boats. If you have never been to the Blessing of the Feet, here's some advice: stay inside the cabin immediately after being blessed. You'll thank God you did.

title: Life of the Party
description: George Seaton's PLEASURE OF HIS COMPANY (1961) delightfully shifted gears from Broadway, with Fred Astaire perfectly cast as a worldly charmer who attends his daughter's wedding in his ex-wife's home and slyly tilts things. He is in winning company: Debbie Reynolds as the sensible daughter, Tab Hunter as her husband-to-be, Lilli Palmer as the former wife, Gary Merrill as her annoyed new spouse and Charles Ruggles as a wise grandpa. The colorful San Francisco settings cushion the plain fact that Astaire's character is a selfish, scheming sybarite, and Seaton's direction smoothly renders some clever dialogue. But it's the Astaire charm that nails down this ''Pleasure'' so seamlessly -- SUNDAY/EARLY MONDAY at 12:30 A.M. on AMC Howard Thompson

title: Renee Anisko, Mark Rockefeller
description: Renee Anne Anisko, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anisko of Watchung, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Fitler Rockefeller, a son of Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., and the late Mr. Rockefeller, the Vice President and Governor of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERSTANDIG, WILLIAM
description: VERSTANDIG-William. Died May 12, 1998. A wonderful friend and colleague, a man of grace and charm, and above all else, a man of courage. A man of iron will, determined to fight to the last breath that his body could muster. And so the unequal struggle came to its end. Everyone in our industry, both here at home and abroad, mourns the passing of one of our outstanding leaders over the years. Heartfelt condolences to his loving and steadfast wife, Inge, and to the entire family. Manny Cohen

title: A Stage Where the Homeless Star
description: ONE man is in recovery from crack-cocaine addiction. Another recently completed a four-year prison term. A woman struggles with manic depression.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98
description: SPRING in the Hamptons means workmen coming out of the woodwork. Roads teem with trucks carrying garden, pool and construction tools. Renovations, new beginnings and sounds of buzz saws fill the air as everyone readies for The Season after a rain-besotted and sleepy winter.

title: How Many Writers Does It Take . . . ?
description: WHEN moviegoers see the screenwriting credit for ''The Horse Whisperer'' -- ''written by Eric Roth and Richard LaGravenese'' -- they may envision a team working cozily together, one partner banging the keys while the other paces the room. Two creative people united in both labor and spirit.
