title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the opening paragraphs of an article yesterday about the Indian Prime Minister's determination to produce nuclear weapons were omitted from some copies. (The article was erroneously labeled a continuation from page A1.) The article, by John F. Burns from New Delhi, reported that Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee said there should be no ambiguity about the nation's plans: ''India is now a nuclear weapons state. We have the capacity for a big bomb now.'' Readers wishing a copy of the entire article may write to Pro duction Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal return address.)

title: Five-Shift Lunches to End?
description: Four hundred people showed up at a meeting on Thursday to demand that something finally be done about overcrowding at Public School 135, a 69-year-old school where classes are held in closets and the cafeteria is so small that students eat lunch in shifts from 9:30 A.M. to 2:15 P.M.

title: For the Creative, Havens in Sag Harbor
description: EVER since James Fenimore Cooper went to Sag Harbor where he wrote two novels, writers and artists have been drawn to the East End. But it was not until after World War II that large numbers of artists and writers began going to the East End and decided to stay. Many became famous -- artists like Pollack, DeKooning, Sherry Lord and legions of writers, among them, Willie Morris, Joseph Heller, E. L. Doctorow, Peter Matthiessen, Kurt Vonnegut, George Plimpton, Wilfred Sheed, James Salter and the playwrights Lanford Wilson and Terrence McNally.

title: May 10-16; Acquittals in Texaco Case
description: Few workaday meetings have had the impact of those secretly recorded by a Texaco executive several years ago. Those tapes, first disclosed in 1996, contained disparaging comments about minorities that led to boycotts of the oil company and raised new questions about workplace racism.

title: The View From/Torrington; Spring Brings Visions Of Flowers (by Mail)
description: SPRING. And the acquisitive fancy of many a gardener turns to Torrington, the home of White Flower Farm Inc. Begun as a nursery in Litchfield some four decades ago, White Flower Farm Inc. is now the parent company of three thriving mail-order and pick-up-your-own plant subsidiaries: the 300-acre White Flower Farm on Route 63 on the outskirts of Litchfield; Shepherd's Garden Seeds, a catalogue company focusing on vegetables and herbs, and the Daffodil Mart, a predominantly wholesale catalogue company. All three pack and ship from a former ball bearing factory in Torrington, making the small city the plant mail-order capital of Connecticut, if not the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, SAUL BAER, MD
description: APPEL-Saul Baer, MD, in El Paso, Texas, on April 17, 1998. Beloved husband of Cecile, cherished father of Deborah & Richard Spindel, Carol and Ira Cohen, Anne, Allen, Gary, grandfather, uncle, brother of Ethelyn and Mark Bruck, Sybil Silberman, brother-in-law of Elaine and David Gill. He served his country as a major in the U.S. Army Medical Corps and was President of the El Paso and Texas Heart Associations. He was honored by the El Paso Medical Society for 50 years of devotion and service as a cardiologist to the community and medical profession. Graduate of NYU-Bellevue, 1947. He is greatly missed by all those whose lives he touched.

title: For Top Chefs, All Roads Lead to the Island
description: JUST a few years ago, restaurants on the East End seemed more noted for their owners than their food -- places like Herb McCarthy's Bowden Square in Southampton and the first Bobby Van's in Bridgehampton. Now rarely a week goes by without a chef receiving a prestigious award, being invited to cook at the James Beard Foundation or being approached about a job at a top restaurant in Manhattan.

Levine, President and CEO Leonard E. Schiffman, DMD, President, Medical Board

If the Detroit Red Wings eliminate the St. Louis Blues today in Joe Louis Arena, Fedorov will receive the money on July 1, completing a season of high-stakes free agency in which he would bank $28 million for less than four months' work.

description: IN a little more than a year, the law that authorized the appointment of independent counsels is set to expire, to the delight and relief of the Clinton Administration, many Democrats and a good number of Republicans as well.

Every Friday, cars and trucks -- thousands of them -- snake across the parking lots toward the shed, forming two dozen lanes of bumper-to-bumper traffic.

description: Summer is the obvious season for outdoor celebrations, from concerts to parades. And because this year marks the 100th anniversary of the consolidation of the five boroughs into the metropolis of New York City, there will more summer festivity, both indoors and outdoors, than usual.

title: Airport Changes Under Debate
description: AVIATION experts say they will never know for sure if approach lights would have made the difference last month when Charles Gunzburg of Jericho, N.Y., apparently missing a runway in fog and driving rain, crashed his single-engine plane into an Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport parking lot and died.

The trade that sent Gary Sheffield, Bobby Bonilla and Charles Johnson to the Los Angeles Dodgers, Selig said, is no different from so many others in baseball history.

title: William Louther, Virtuoso Modern Dancer, Dies at 56
description: William Louther, a leading American modern dancer who also directed the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel and helped to establish modern dance in England, died on May 7 at St. George's Hospital in London. He was 56 and lived in London.

title: Following the Red-Brick Road: Boston's Freedom Trail
description: THE FREEDOM TRAIL is 40 years old, and following its red-brick road is such a mainstay of Boston tourism that it comes as a surprise that an urban walking trail linking the city's abundant Revolution-era landmarks was itself once revolutionary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, MAX B.
description: MEYER-Max B., 81. May 11, 1998. Husband of Edith, father of Peter and the late Elizabeth Glaser. Graduate of Harvard, Max was Vice President of General Cigar Co. for 31 years, and Chairman of Ex-Lax Inc., for 8 years. At his time of retirement when a relaxed life was the wish, Max was called upon to show the courage and compassion that made him so cared for by others. He and Edith moved to California to help support their daughter, who had been infected with the HIV virus, while giving birth to Ariel. Max shared in the sorrows & triumphs that marked Elizabeth's life. Throughout this period, Max remained steadfast in his caring & support of his family. He is survived by three grandchildren, Jake Glaser, and Craig and Jason Meyer. There will be no funeral service. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric Aids Foundation, 1311 Colorado Avenue, Santa Monica, California 90404.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PATAI, FRANCES S.
description: PATAI-Frances S., died January 18, 1998 in New York City. Teacher, writer, historian, activist for social justice, feminist, friend of the Volunteers in the Spanish Civil War, generous donor of the Frances Patai Fund on the Holocaust. At the City College Center for Worker Education, 99 Hudson St., (corner Franklin St.) Thurs, May 21st at 6 PM, 6th FL. All Welcome

title: Deadbeat Dads (and Moms) Are Rounded Up in Raids
description: In a sort of belated Mother's Day observance, sheriff's officers in all 21 counties last week rounded up hundreds of deadbeat parents, mostly men, and collected more than $88,000 in owed child support payments.

title: Under Stress? YES!
description: FIVE forces govern the universe: the strong force, the weak force, electromagnetism, gravity and absurdity. Nobel Prize types haven't discovered that last one yet, which is why they can't pin down details like what's holding the cosmos together, but me, I've known about it for years. And that's why I had a feeling things weren't going to go very well the day I was sent to cover a news conference on stress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNNY, MARGARET (REATH) KENNEDY
description: LUNNY-Margaret (Reath) Kennedy. May 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Larry, Jimmy, Joan Saia, Marge Gatti, Bernard and Eileen Olenick. Devoted mother-in-law of Marilyn, Alicia, Frank, Pat and Tom. Dear sister of the late Mae Mauch. Loving aunt of Gale and Richard Mauch and Maryann and Bob McLean. Also survived by 17 grandchildren and thirteen greatgrandchildren. Reposing, Lloyd Funeral Home, 39th Avenue at 215 Street, Bayside. Visiting 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass, Sacred Heart Church, Bayside, Monday at 9:45 AM.

title: The Egg Woman
description: IT was around the time she signed up for a radiation experiment that Carrie Specht made her decision. A graduate student at New York University's film school, she had already worked a string of menial jobs, from dog-walking to monitoring alcohol consumption at fraternity parties, and was borrowing a buck or two a day to feed herself on plain bagels and pizza specials. Now she found herself sitting in a sensory deprivation chamber, participating in a scientific inquiry into the effect of isotopes on the human memory and earning $250 for four days.

title: For Want of a Road, An Airport Languishes
description: APRIL was to be the month that Hong Kong's new international airport opened, symbolizing the former British colony's role as a gateway to China and putting an end to the stomach-churning, rooftop-skimming approaches for which Hong Kong's old airport, Kai Tak, was famous.

title: A.T.M. Security Cameras Don't Always Do Their Job

''She said I looked better than the last time she saw me,'' Ms. Goodman said. ''That was nice, but I had never been there before.''

Funeral liturgy Monday, 11AM, at Holy Trinity G.O. Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street (between 1st & 2nd Avenue), NYC. The family will receive friends at the Cathedral between 10-11AM Monday morning. description: The Old Blue club of New York earned a chance to return to the national semifinals by defeating Kansas City, 59-21, yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSOWSKI, PAUL DAVID
description: OSOWSKI-Paul David. (August 17, 1947-April 29, 1998) ''Not farewell, not farewell, but faring.'' The gentlest, sweetest, most compassionate, loving man we were privileged to share our lives with, became an angel on April 29th, succumbing to liver cancer after 18 years of successfully living with HIV and AIDS. Paul inspired everyone with his honesty, strength, courage, sensitivity, humor, caring and love. He taught us how to live ...to the fullest, and how to die... with dignity and grace. Paul entered this life in Chicago and left it in Sea Ranch, one of his favorite places. A Berkeley graduate, he lived in San Francisco for many years when not traveling the world viewing his beloved art and nature, sharing with family and friends his very special way of seeing that world. He was on the Advisory Board of The Community Consortium and worked with the HIV Health Services Planning Council and ACT UP in San Francisco. Paul is reunited with his mother, Helene, and survived by his loving sister/best friend Pamela, father Aloysius, brothers Alan and Mark, sisters Joyce Weber, Monica Tyre and Denice Kounalis, their families, and innumerable friends, doctors, nurses and helpers who became his extended family. An August memorial is planned. Condolences may be sent to the family at 414 East 52nd Street, New York, New York 10022. Contributions in Paul's memory may be made to The Community Consortium, 3180 18th Street, Suite 201, San Francisco, CA. 94110. ''Peace to you all, and love''.

title: May 10-16; A Flaw in Airliners Is Caught in Time
description: When mechanics at Continental Airlines first went to fix a fuel leak in an old Boeing 737 on April 25, the problem did not seem unusual. But after closer inspection by Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration, the problem set off alarms throughout the airline industry.

title: The World: Riding the Tiger; India Charts a Pariah's Path to Glory
description: FOR optimists who look toward the 21st century for the emergence of a more rational and harmonious world, there was little encouragement to be had from the dialogue of the deaf that developed between India and the United States last week after India announced itself as the world's newest nuclear power.

title: The Nation; Reining in the Market, Gently
description: NOT so long ago, people responsible for managing the economy were pretty sure they had all the necessary tools. They could use them to tinker, making the economy grow faster or slower by lowering or raising interest rates, or doing the same with taxes, or by pumping money into highway construction and other public projects that created jobs.

title: Diplomatic Immunity? Ask Vandals
description: No one seems to know exactly when the gray sedan with the diplomatic plates turned up on East 89th Street in front of a fancy apartment building near the Guggenheim Museum. But people who live and work on the block between Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue knew one thing: the Ford Taurus LX hadn't budged in weeks.

title: Middle-Class Master
description: To the Editor:

title: Advice; Teen Angst? Nah!
description: So, you've turned 13, and suddenly you feel as if you're in Death Valley. You come home from school and Oprah is on, talking about America's Youth in Crisis; your parents assail you after dinner with antidrug literature, asking what you've been experimenting with lately; and from every corner -- school, home, church -- you're being told: ''Be careful! These are four of the most important years of your life!''

title: Critic's Choice; Glib, Teasing, Unembarrassed by the Suds
description: ONE of the trademarks of ''Dawson's Creek'' is its load of pop-culture references. So of course the show can't have a cliffhanging season finale without talking about how tired that creaky technique is.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; Amagansett
description: THE hamlet of Amagansett is a great place to spend a long weekend if you are coming from the city without a car. There are several small inns, like the Gansett Green, right next to the Jitney stop in the center of town, where you can walk or bike to Atlantic Beach, Gordon's Restaurant or the Stephen Talkhouse for live bands, and Amagansett Taxi is always running if the need arises.

title: It's the Colonial Revival, in Spinning Wheels and Costumes
description: A COMPOUND of buildings under the auspices of the Historical Society of the Town of Greenwich huddles on a hillside overlooking Strickland Brook in the Cos Cob section of Greenwich: a boardinghouse for the first art colony in Connecticut, a weathered barn where they painted, an archives building, some outbuildings, the Justus Luke Bush storehouse and Cos Cob post office. Recently some have been restored and converted into a visitors' center with galleries and a shop to serve as an introduction to the overall site.

title: About New York; Musicians Who Can Heal Themselves
description: THIS afternoon in the Bronx, Stephen Moshman will conduct a Dvorak symphony that just might make you swoon in delirious delight. If so, don't worry whether there's a doctor in the house. There are plenty on stage.

title: A Swank New Hotel In Beverly Hills
description: The hotel L'Ermitage Beverly Hills opened on April 30 in Beverly Hills near the boutiques and galleries on Rodeo Drive, featuring Art Deco decor, a rooftop pool and large rooms with views of the city, the Getty Museum, Beverly Hills, Bel Air and the Hollywood Hills. The hotel -- formerly L'Ermitage Hotel -- was bought by Lahotel Corporation, which has links with Amanresorts, and has undergone a multimillion-dollar redesign. Rooms have fax machines, computer printers, video and compact disk players, television in the bathrooms and walk-in closets; most also have balconies. Each guest is issued a cellular telephone with a private number.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

title: Sewing Second Skins
description: Elisa Jimenez's stretchy, body-hugging dresses aren't well known to the mainstream, but celebrities like Parker Posey and Baby Jane Holzer collect them. ''It's sexy without being slutty, and she makes really elegant cuts,'' Ms. Posey said. When it's time for a fitting, Ms. Jimenez treats a woman like a wrapped piece of art. It is a hands-on-body experience -- her hands, your body. ''I lay the fabric down on the floor, you lie down on it, and I measure you,'' Ms. Jimenez said. She makes patterns in the jersey fabrics by burning holes to create laciness (as shown in the dress here). Finally, she sews each garment by hand, using transparent 60-pound monofilament fishing line. Six one-of-a-kind items, from a shawl to a gown ($500 to $1,000) are sold at Linda Dresner, 484 Park Avenue (58th Street). For custom-made clothes, ($150 to $1,500), the designer can be reached through Holly Solomon, the art dealer, at (212) 941-5777. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Boat Gains Indy Pole After Run-In With Wall
description: A day after Billy Boat drove his primary car into the concrete wall during practice for next Sunday's Indianapolis 500, he drove his backup car to the front of the field, winning the pole with the fastest lap yet for the new Indy Racing League engines.

title: Washing That Winter Right Off Their Windshields
description: THE urge springs up with the tulips. Wouldn't it be nice to have a clean car, literally to wash away the memories of winter?

title: Curious Women Are Seeing if Viagra Works Wonders for Them
description: RECENTLY, eight female friends in their 30's and 40's gathered for lunch at Coco Pazzo Teatro on West 46th Street. After two weeks of rain, the sun was shining, the women were in high spirits, and after one showed a picture of the man she is dating (an underwear model), talk turned to spring fever, love, sex -- and Viagra.

title: May 10-16; Microsoft Ducks a Lawsuit
description: Standing intransigent to the brink, the Microsoft Corporation blinked moments before state and Federal prosecutors planned to file sweeping antitrust suits against the software giant. The company agreed to delay the release of Windows 98, its updated operating system, so that settlement talks could be given several days to produce results.

title: Word Aversion
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Being 13; Riding The Rails
description: 'Thirteen is a hard age, very hard. A lot of people say you have it easy, you're a kid, but there's a lot of pressure being 13 -- to be respected by people in your school, to be liked, always feeling like you have to be good. There's pressure to do drugs, too, so you try not to succumb to that. But you don't want to be made fun of, so you have to look cool. You gotta wear the right shoes, the right clothes--if you have Jordans, then it's all right.

title: Can Multinationals Be Trusted?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dress Code For Fun
description: The climate in elementary schools has made uniforms the fastest growing segment of the children's clothing industry. With the news that New York City will require uniforms in 670 schools next year, the Fashion Institute of Technology staged a show of speculative designs on May 7 by 25 of its students -- all graduating children's wear majors. They broke the dress code by offering long skirts, fuzzy fake-fur trim, Dalmatian prints, vinyl vests and appliques in the shape of mushrooms. Not exactly what the school board had in mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVELL, FRANK
description: LOVELL-Frank. A prominent socialist writer and author on trade union issues, died in New York City May 1 of a heart attack at the age of 84. He had lived in Manhattan for the past thirty years. Attracted to a revolutionary and democratic variety of socialism often associated with the Socialist Party of Eugene V. Debs and the militant Industrial Workers of the World (IWW) as well as the idealism of the early Communist movement, Lovell became part of the small international movement led by Leon Trotsky known as the Fourth International. His political commitment and analytical insight were widely appreciated in left-wing and labor circles-as were his warmth, avid intellectual curiosity, adroit sense of humor, and engaging interest in persons of all ages and backgrounds. He was born on July 24, 1913, in Ipava, Illinois, a farming town where his father was a local entrepreneur. In the early 1930's Lovell attended the University of California's radical Berkeley campus, earning a Bachelor's Degree in philosophy. He was drawn into the socialist movement just after the San Francisco general strike, joining the Workers Party of the United States, led by James P. Cannon and A.J. Muste, in 1935. He consequently became a seaman and an organizer for the Sailor's Union of the Pacific. In 1938, Lovell was a founding member of the Socialist Workers Party, & for many years played a leading role in that organization, especially as a trade union activist. For a number of years he served on national leadership bodies of the SWP. He wrote extensively for socialist publications on labor issues and other matters, and under the pen-name Frederick Lang wrote a classic-''Maritime!'' (New York: Pioneer Publishers, 1943). In Portland, Oregon in the late 1940s he edited ''The Defender'', a rankand-file paper opposing the conservatism and anti-left purges triumphing throughout the maritime industry and unions. In the early 1950s Frank moved to Detroit with his wife Sarah and their infant daughter, Joan. There he became an auto worker and a member of the United Auto Workers. With close friends, George & Dorothea Breitman, Frank and Sarah played an especially significant role in the Detroit labor and socialist movements of the 1950s and 1960s. They initiated and maintained for many years the influential Friday Night Socialist Forum (later called the Militant Forum), a weekly series tht drew a broad range of prominent trade unionists and workingclass militants, civil rights and black liberation activists, scholars, intellectuals, students and others. They also ran openly socialist electoral campaigns-such as Frank's campaigns for Governor of Michigan on the SWP ticket in 1954, 1958 and 1964. In the late 1960s they moved to New York City, where Frank served as the Socialist Workers Party's trade union director. Expelled with hundreds of others from the SWP in the early 1980s, Lovell initiated publication of ''Bulletin In Defense Of Marxism'' in December of 1983. He served as first editor of this magazine, and later on its Editorial Board. (Before her death in 1994, Sarah Lovell played a central role as the magazine's treasurer and chief copy editor.) In Frank's final years he was also active in the Metro New York Labor Party and worked effectively to secure financial support for the Ernest Mandel Institute in Brussels, Belgium and the Leon Trotsky Museum at Coyoacan in Mexico City. Frank Lovell is survived by his dear companion, Miriam Braverman, of Manhattan; his beloved daughter, Joan Lovell, and son-in-law Mark Weiss, of Detroit, Michigan; his sisters-in-law, Mollie Kerchner, of Delray, Florida, and Josephine Lovell of California; his longtime friend and comrade, Dorethea Breitman, also of Manhattan. He will be fondly remembered by the many people whose lives he touched with his generous spirit. A memorial meeting is planned at the Tamiment Labor Library, New York University, date to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ABRAHAM A., M.D.
description: KAUFMAN-Abraham A., M.D. Of NYC and Lake Worth, FL, died at Mount Sinai Hospital, May 4, 1998. Survived by his beloved wife, Pamela, and loving son, Brian. Memorial service at New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, Tuesday, May 26, at 5 PM. Contributions in his memory to Friends of Art and Design, High School for Art and Design, 1075 Second Ave., Room 203, NYC 10022.

title: It's a Rout, All Right, But It's by the Jazz
description: After all the pomp and pageantry surrounding Shaquille O'Neal and the Los Angeles Lakers' inexorable march toward June, you could not have blamed John Stockton and Karl Malone for monitoring their heart rates with one hand and perusing their life-insurance policies with the other.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TAUB, DR. RENA
description: TAUB-Dr. Rena. A memorial will be held on Saturday, May 23 at 1:30 PM at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

title: May 10-16; As Stalemate Continues, Palestinians Show Rage
description: Two weeks after Israelis celebrated the 50th anniversary of the founding of their state, Palestinians staged a demonstration of their own -- of frustration and rage over never having attained a state themselves. The Palestinians have a name for the founding of Israel -- The Catastrophe -- and in that spirit, throughout the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem, they observed two minutes of silence on Thursday and then took to the streets in what was billed as a ''million-man march.''

title: Collages as Riddles: Visual and Verbal
description: RAY JOHNSON (1927-95) stands out as an eccentric in a field routinely clogged with them, yet the basic facts of his life are simple. Those begin with his birth in Detroit and continue with his admission first to the Art Students League, then to Black Mountain College in North Carolina and, after a life in Manhattan devoted to collage, they end with the artist's suicide by drowning at Orient Point on Long Island.

title: Through the Looking Glass
description: THE EVERLASTING STORY OF NORY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, JOHN (TOMMY)
description: HARRINGTON-John (Tommy). Devoted husband of Christine. Beloved son of Kitty and Michael Harrington. Brother of Michael, Denis and Maryann. Brother-inlaw of Lynne and Gail. Uncle of Denise, Vanessa and Vincent. He was Senior Vice President Equity Trader at Nash Weiss and Company, a division of Fleet Bank. The family will receive friends at the Fairchild Funeral Home, Garden City, Sunday 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, May 18, 11 AM at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the Imus Branch 1-888-550-4687.

title: Juvenile City
description: AS the ''Seinfeld'' era ended on Thursday night, some wondered what all the fuss was about. Here were four characters who weren't all that likable, who seemed downright juvenile. Entertainment magazines have spent reams analyzing Jerry, Elaine, George and Kramer and their various neuroses. ''What's wrong with these people?'' they want to know. Why can't they make some other friends, get real jobs, get married, grow up? The reason is simple: they're not dysfunctional, they're New Yorkers.

title: Adieu, My Beloved House, I Knew It Well
description: WHAT I remember most about the December 1979 afternoon that I went to closing on a three-bedroom ranch in the pine woods outside Sag Harbor was the alternating sense of excitement and dread I felt.

title: A Mini-Strike by Cabbies, Daily
description: The taxi strike on Wednesday may have inconvenienced him along with many other New Yorkers, but Edmund Bogen usually has no trouble getting a cab from the Upper East Side to his job on Wall Street.

title: Teachers' Union Offers Plan to Save a Failing School
description: The United Federation of Teachers has pledged to turn around a failing Bronx school if the Board of Education cooperates by accepting a 10-point road map proposed yesterday by the union's president.

title: Exploring Worlds Within a City, With Guides
description: AS the weather encourages the city-dweller to take walks of exploration, several recent books suggest a number of trails to follow. Undiscovered delights abound for lovers of literature, of architecture and, yes, of nature.

title: Rich Leaders Turn Eye to Crime and Debt
description: With concern over India and Indonesia lurking in the background, the leaders of eight major countries turned their attention today to other issues, agreeing to cooperate more in battling international crime and pledging to do more to help the world's poorest countries.

title: Visiting Hanoi
description: To the Editor: Katherine Ashenberg's comment that ''paradox abounds in Hanoi'' ('' 'Moderne' Lives on in a Colonial City,'' April 19) reminded me of an experience I had in March. I went to see my sister, who works there, and she insisted that I could not visit without ''being received by Uncle Ho,'' meaning Ho Chi Minh. We went to the mausoleum on a Sunday morning and saw a line of pilgrims stretched around the monument for probably a mile, including many elderly men and women in their best outfits.

title: Hitting Power of Braves' Lineup Silences Skeptics
description: Take Andres Galarraga out of the Rocky Mountains and he'll become an ordinary hitter. Put him in Turner Field and he'll become even more ordinary. Walt Weiss? Sure, he'll cover more infield ground than Jeff Blauser, but he won't provide as much offense. What are the Braves to do with all those great pitchers if they can't score any runs for them?

title: Joanne Knowlton, Stephen Gabriel
description: Joanne Knowlton and Stephen William Gabriel were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Ronald Evans performed the ceremony.

title: More Flights to France Are on the Way
description: The United States and France reached an agreement April 8 that will add new flights and new routes between the countries, possibly reduce fares, and most likely increase tourism in both directions. It will also allow United States and French carriers to forge code-share alliances, enabling each partner to market the other's flights and allow passengers to earn and redeem frequent-flier miles on partner airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAFIN, BONNIE DEBORAH
description: KAFIN-Bonnie Deborah. November 1, 1947-May 3, 1998. At home in Coconut Creek, FL. Formerly of Philadelphia. Beloved daughter of Ann and Jacob, sister of Robert & William, aunt to Tammy, Peter, Philip, Joshua, and Sabrina. Her love of music, nature, literature, and caring for others will always be remembered. She was an avid observer of life and its meanings, and maintained a daily journal for 20 years. Her diaries reflect a passion for knowledge, insight, spirit and wisdom. We were blessed to know a gifted and poetic soul who lived life to the fullest, in her unique way, and who died, too soon, with promises unkept. It is an unbearable sadness for those of us who love her, and we will always cherish her for who she was.

title: Backtalk; All Sugar and Competitive Spice
description: Bridgid Godbout entered Miss Porter's School four years ago, knowing she would get a good education at an institution with a history of instructing the nation's young female elite that stretches back before the Civil War. Godbout also knew she was going to lose a lot of lacrosse and soccer games.

title: DIARY
description: BABY BELLS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MARTIN
description: MILLER-Martin. Beloved husband of Irma. The love of my live. Loving father and grandfather. Dear brother. Services today at 12:30 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Same Name, Same Two Rooms, But Now It's a Lounge
description: First a restaurant, now a recently restyled upscale lounge, Two Rooms is the second venture, with the same name and location, for two brothers, Adam and Larry Hock, and the third owner, Wes Wang. Situated at 313 East 58th Street (near Second Avenue), in a historic carriage house built in the 1850's, the space was once home to le Club, a private club that closed in 1996 after 20 years.

title: Being 13; American Pastoral
description: One of four sons growing up on a family farm in west-central Iowa, Eric Eischeid lives a life not much different than his father did as a child. But he also loves Nintendo, 'The Simpsons' and his Air Jordans.

title: Budget Cuts Open a Rift For Democrats
description: Deep fissures have emerged in the Democratic campaign against Gov. George E. Pataki's $1.5 billion budget vetoes, with Democrats from conservative districts reluctant to attack a Republican governor who is popular among their constituents.

title: May 10-16; Military Rules Meet Love. Love Retreats.
description: When the first inter-cadet marriage known to have taken place at West Point came to the attention of academy officials, the cadets were faced with a choice between love and military honor. The officials said the cadets chose honor.

title: But It's Friday, Isn't It?
description: As the weather improves, so does the climate for casual days, those corporately sanctioned breaches of formal office wear. Who wears what on casual day in your office, and does any of the attire make you pine for a bit less latitude in personal style? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Apartheid's Architects Losing White Votes in South Africa
description: Three small local elections this week all won by the tiny but influential Democratic Party -- gave the first sign that there may be a big swing of white voters away from the National Party, which ruled this country from 1947 to 1994.

title: In America; Making The Babe Proud
description: Something special is happening in the Bronx. Forget for a moment the controversy over whether the Yankees will move in the next few years to the West Side or to New Jersey or at all.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about investing in biotechnology through mutual funds referred incompletely to funds that bill themselves as pure plays in the sector. At least two such funds, Fidelity Select Biotechnology and Franklin Biotechnology Discovery, have assets of more than $30 million, qualifying them for listing in The Times's mutual fund tables; there are also smaller funds in the category.

title: Meg McGinity, James Shannon
description: Mary Margaret McGinity, a daughter of Justice Leo F. McGinity and Mrs. McGinity of Baldwin, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Francis Shannon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Shannon of Lynbrook, N.Y. Msgr. John Weist performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church in Point Lookout, N.Y.

title: U.S. World Cup Hopes Rest in Dooley's Hands
description: When he arrived in the United States from Germany in 1992 as a soccer import, Thomas Dooley spoke little English. He could order food, say hello and understand the lyrics of the Kingston Trio song that bore his name. Beyond that, he was at the mercy of his teammate Paul Caligiuri, who had played professionally in Germany and who became Dooley's full-time translator.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Park Corrals Art

title: Summit Talks Shift Focus To Atom Tests By New Delhi
description: Until last Monday, President Clinton had planned to use the international economic summit meeting here this weekend strictly to advance his vision of 21st-century global harmony strengthened by security pacts, environmental treaties and commercial ties.

title: AMERICAN CITIES; The Green Heart Of The Hub
description: EASTER Sunday afternoon and the Public Garden in Boston's Back Bay is so mobbed you'd think they are giving something away. And, in a sense, they are: the elegant, well-groomed and seductive landscape of a piece of the country smack in the middle of a city, a Victorian park with a French accent. Though the trees have not yet begun to leaf, and the flower beds are still mainly dormant, the air is clear and warm, and people are positively festive while doing nothing but walking down one carefully defined path and up the next. This is Sunday in the Park the way its Victorian-era founders no doubt envisaged it -- except that the clothes of the female resemble those of the male.

title: Seventysomething
description: GLORIE By Caryn James. 229 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Zoland Books. $24.

title: World News Briefs; U.N. Aid Agency Seeks Access in North Korea
description: The United Nations World Food Program has told North Korea that if large areas of the country are not opened to international aid workers, food supplies will be scaled back, the program's director said on Friday.

title: Sports of The Times; 'I'm Right There With Ali,' Says Holyfield, Who Puts Tyson in Past
description: EVANDER HOLYFIELD had been up since 4 in the morning for his workout in Houston and now, over a lobster dinner Friday night at Ben Benson's Steakhouse, the boxing public's heavyweight champion was asked what he thinks about when he does his roadwork in the morning.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Blocked in Stamford, Cendant to Move to Wilton
description: THE Cendant Corporation's decision last month to move from here to Wilton shows the level of maturity that the Stamford office market has reached. With a vacancy rate of around 6 percent, the city cannot accommodate companies that need to expand.

title: New Game in Town
description: MOST of the games that keep Atlantic City in business, like blackjack and poker, have been around for centuries, in one form or another. But the casinos are constantly competing to bring new games to their gamblers, to give those who feel they've been there, done that, ever more compelling ways to put their money at risk.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 35 of the Arts & Leisure section last Sunday with an article about growing critical respect for the once-maligned Russian composer Sergei Rachmaninoff misstated the date of a photograph of him. It was 1939, not 1959.

title: A Century of Art on a Blackboard Canvas
description: ONE century ago, the man selected to lead the public schools of newly consolidated New York City delivered an acceptance speech. William Henry Maxwell had earned a reputation for eloquent oratory long before assuming the office of superintendent on March 15, 1898, and on that morning he turned his bass voice to a suitably grand theme.

title: The Sound of His Music
description: RICHARD RODGERS

title: A Spot Where Wildflowers Grow Freely
description: As he does every Thursday morning from early spring until early fall, Ira Schiffer hiked down a fern-fringed path today, unlocking a wrought-iron gate and crossing a gently arching wooden bridge over a small lake rippling with frogs, turtles and fish.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEPARD, MARTIN
description: SHEPARD-Martin. Fiftieth Birthday Twenty-five years shared, lovingly remembered. The family

title: Jennifer Beber and David Frankel, Neena Beber and Marc Turkel
description: Jennifer Beber and Neena Beber, the daughters of Joyce Beber and Dr. Charles R. Beber of Miami, are to be married today in ceremonies performed by Rabbi Roberto Della Rocca at the Spanish Synagogue in Venice. Jennifer Beber is to marry David Frankel, and Neena Beber is to marry Marc Turkel.

title: Amy Comeau, Albert Robbins
description: Amy Robin Comeau and Albert Murray Robbins are to be married this morning by Rabbi Camille Angel at the Bowery Bar in New York.

title: Politically Speaking and Tweaking
description: JOHN BENDEL was not at the New Jersey legislative correspondents' dinner on Wednesday night. That's probably fitting for a political commentator who calls the Governor ''Big Mom'' and disparages her Administration's marketing slogan, ''New Jersey: What a Difference a State Makes,'' by asking, ''What the hell difference does a state make?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOOROCK, NORMA
description: TOOROCK-Norma. On May 15, 1998. Loving sister of Miriam Sack. Adored aunt of the Sack, Meiselman and Silverstien families. Services Monday 10AM at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Hempstead, NY.

title: International Gene Project Gets Lift
description: The politics of the human genome project, the plan to sequence or analyze the entire DNA of human cells, has become suddenly more complicated, on both a personal and international level.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, FREDERICK M.
description: SCHILLER-Frederick M. On May 15, 1998. Devoted husband of Delia Gilormini-Schiller. Loving son of Anne and the late Samuel. Beloved brother of Rosalyn. Service Monday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GUSOFF, GERRY
description: GUSOFF-Gerry. May 17, 1994. The void remains infinite. Our love for you undiminished. Ileen

title: Thomas Williams, 61; Led Depository Trust
description: Thomas A. Williams, the president of the Depository Trust Company in Manhattan, died April 25 at the United Hospital Medical Center in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: On the Far Side of Innocence, Politely, With Christina Ricci
description: IT'S late on a cool spring night in Manhattan, and yet another movie is being made in the East Village, location du jour for young urban cinema. While a dozen executive kibitzers from Paramount and its co-producer, MTV, get on the nerves of the crew, two teen-age actresses in perilously high heels clatter down wet metal stairs into a dead-end courtyard behind Second Avenue. The one in the pink fishnets and spiky black hair is Gaby Hoffmann. The lacquered blonde in strapless red satin with lipstick pout to match is Christina Ricci.

title: BENEFITS
description: A Grand Tour

title: Scenes From an Unusual Marriage
description: YOU ARE NOT I A Portrait of Paul Bowles. By Millicent Dillon.Illustrated. 340 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $27.50.

title: Conservatives And GOP in Split Over Abortion
description: AS the Westchester County Conservative Committee struggles with internal fighting intensified by its chairman's guilty plea on an election-law violation, its decades-long alliance with the Westchester Republican Committee is being threatened by disagreement on the issue of abortion.

title: Suharto, a King of Java Past, Confronts Indonesia's Future
description: Behind the grillwork on the windows of an unmarked and unexceptional house on a narrow tree-lined street here in the capital lives a wily old widower who, some people say, seems to think he is king.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Evening Hours page of Sunday Styles last week with a report about the International Center of Photography's presentation of its Master of Photography award to Roy DeCarava misidentified one woman present. She was Sherry Turner DeCarava, not Nicole Bernard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNE, VERA SOKOLOVA
description: THORNE-Vera Sokolova. Aged 97, widow of Samuel Thorne, died at her home in Old Lyme, CT on May 11, 1998. Born in Moscow, Russia, she left in 1918 with her first husband Ivan Dabrowski and ultimately landed in New York in 1920. She and Dabrowski subsequently were divorced and he changed his name to John Graham. He became a painter of some renown in The New York School. Mrs. Thorne married Samuel Thorne in 1928. He predeceased her in 1992. She is survived by a son Samuel Thorne, Jr. of Manchester by-the-Sea, MA; her other son Nicholas also died in 1992. She is also survived by seven grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. There will be a private interment in Manchester, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions are suggested to the ASPCA, 42 East 92nd Street, New York, New York 10128-6804 or Hospice of Southeastern CT, 179 Gallivan Lane, PO Box 902, Uncasville, CT 06382-0902.

title: Weightier With Time
description: IT was an odd celebration at the opening of Two River Theater Company's last production of its fourth season, which is also its last show at the Lauren K. Woods Theater at Monmouth University. Before the first act of ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' the audience was assured by Robert M. Rechnitz, producing artistic director, that it ''won't have to come here anymore,'' since the company is to open a theater all its own in 1999. But it's an ''amicable parting,'' Mr. Rechnitz went on. ''There is no longer room for us here, which is as it should be.'' Next year's repertory is to be produced at the Algonquin Arts Theater in Manasquan.

title: Tourism Thrives on the Coattails of Kykuit
description: THE jewel in the crown, the magnificent mansion, the big fish, the cash cow. No matter how Kykuit is described, the Rockefeller family estate in Tarrytown has become a national and international tourist destination, bringing economic benefit in its wake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MILTON
description: COHEN-Milton. The Board of Trustees, Administration & Medical Center Staff of The Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center note with profound sorrow the death of our distinguished past Associate Director. Milton Cohen was a dedicated & inspired leader, as well as a man of great vision. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Edwin L. Schulman Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank J. Maddalena President & CEO Alvin I. Kahn, MD Sr Vice President Medical Affairs

title: Programs Squeezed For Space
description: LIKE ancient soothsayers scanning the heavens for portents, directors of the county's independent child-care programs for school-age children study enrollment projections.

title: For Peter Falk, Mysteries of a Deeper Sort
description: PETER FALK is wearing a raincoat. The high-ceilinged room is warm, and it seems faintly ridiculous that a man should be sitting indoors dressed to go out.

title: Schools Shop Around for Corporate Money
description: ALL schools need money. All taxpayers feel the pain. So Connecticut public schools are starting to look at a sort of corporate sponsorship, offering advertising opportunities in exchange for cash payments or goods in kind. Sports scoreboards are particularly popular. And Coca-Cola and Pepsi have been battling each other to provide them.

title: Soley Victories Lead Uniondale
description: Keyon Soley led the girls' track team from Uniondale High School to the title at the Eddy Memorial Interscholastic Games yesterday in Schenectady, N.Y. Uniondale, from Long Island, won by 77-76 over Saratoga Springs.

title: Assembling Your Basic Tool Kit
description: IF you own your own home, you need tools to maintain it properly. Most homeowners buy their tools over the years as they are needed, but you always have to start somewhere, especially if you are a new homeowner.

title: Composer Writes Piece For Philharmonic's 15th
description: WHEN Melinda Wagner began to compose her ''Concerto for Flute, Strings and Percussion'' she would walk away from the piano, lay the sheets of music on her bed in her Mount Vernon home and conduct through what she had so far written. ''I envisioned the orchestra,'' she said. ''I was trying to get a sense of what might come next.''

title: Tigers and Orange Advance
description: With his team in trouble, behind by four goals, Princeton Coach Bill Tierney turned to his son, the freshman Trevor Tierney, to help bail out the Tigers today.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; Remsenburg Area
description: HOLLYWOOD comes to Hampton Bays with five United Artist screens. Baja Blues Mexican Cafe just opened its doors on Main Street and the word is good. A few doors down, the guys at Scotto's Pork Store are hoping to do the same. They will concentrate on Italian lunches. Just remember, you are what you eat. Across the street, Jagger's Live Cafe will feature live musical acts.

title: Let Senate Act On Test Ban Treaty; Heads in the Sand
description: To the Editor:

title: Montclair School Budget: The Mayor and the Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Sirens Outside, Miserable Folks Inside
description: ''IS there hope and lightness in his heart?'' asks Nora, the mother-in-law of Junior, an unwitting drug-dealing punk who lies bleeding on the kitchen floor, having been viciously beaten. He is ordered to get up instantly. Why should the family be made so miserable because of Junior's misery?

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Of Truth, or Rather 'Truth,' and Early Music
description: LIKE a slow-moving army of ants, the early-music movement has eaten Baroque and Classical music right down to its roots. An information barrier keeps it from reversing directions, so onward into the Romantic repertory and perhaps beyond. Will it really be long before authentic Rachmaninoff is restricted to Steinways made before 1940? Can the rectitude of early recordings be upheld only if we include the pops, hisses, distant sound and four-minute breaks of the 1920's 78-rpm?

title: Uta Hagen: A Legend In Theater
description: ''HUG the ocean to the dead end.'' As Uta Hagen gives those directions, a driver is left to ponder whether she is merely describing the route to her home on the cliffs of Montauk, or delivering a metaphor for life.

title: AMERICAN CITIES; In Just 50 Blocks, A World of Choice
description: I'M a Central Park bird-watcher, with some butterfly, dragonfly, turtle, raccoon and squirrel watching on the side, not to mention mushroom hunting and star gazing. There's a bunch of us who come to the park regularly to enjoy its beauty and get our fix of nature.

title: On Shelter Island, A School Enters The 21st Century
description: Attention, parents: How would you like to send your children to a small school where every senior has his own laptop computer, where instead of buzzers or bells Bach, Beethoven or Bernstein signals the end of class periods and where an up-to-date fitness center will soon be in place?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUCHOMEL, PHILLIP EMIL.
description: SUCHOMEL-Phillip Emil. Guitarist Phil Suchomel, age 29, died unexpectedly of complications due to asthma on Saturday, April 25, 1998 in Fresno, California. He was born April 19, 1969, in Madison, Wisconsin. He mastered electric guitar. He studied classical guitar at the University of Wisconsin-Madison with renowned guitarist Javier Calderon. Phil and his wife Kirsten Patches (singer) moved to California in 1992. They were professsional musicians in the band ''Naked Aggression''. Between U.S./European tours they released 4 CD's on Broken Rekids and Mighty Records. Their new CD, Phil's finest work titled ''Gut Wringing Machine'' is on Grilled Cheese/Cargo Music. They started touring with the new CD when Phil's respiratory system failed before a show. Director Penelope Spheeris featured them in her documentary ''The Decline of Western Civilization, Part III''. It won the ''Freedom of Expression Award'' at Sundance Film Festival, 1998. Phil wrote his first soundtrack for this film. His band also appeared in the movie ''Senseless''.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Hamptons Old Hat? Try a Nassau Summer Rental
description: TIRED of coping with traffic jams on roads leading to the Hamptons, some city dwellers looking for a summer getaway are renting houses much closer to home -- in the bedroom communities of Nassau County, a short commute from midtown Manhattan.

title: A Half-Baked Art Business That Involves No Crackpots
description: A few months ago, Ellen Stalonas, a 24-year-old Brooklyn native, was just one of New York City's many aspiring young actors, looking for a break and working as a bartender. Now, she is the owner of a craft store-social spot, Clay Play, in Park Slope at 229 Fifth Avenue (between President and Carroll Streets). Ms. Stalonas had toyed with the idea of starting her own business, but a visit to a similar ''paint bar'' in Connecticut set her on an entrepreneurial path.

title: Political Briefing; G.O.P. Flatlander Riles Vermont Party
description: Here's how they play politics in Vermont.

title: A Touch of Luxury Away From Home: Hamptons B &B; 's
description: BED AND BREAKFASTS, a longtime popular choice for visitors to New England and Europe, are popping up everywhere in the Hamptons.

title: On the East End, a Heightened Resolve to Preserving Land
description: AT the corner of Sagg Main Street and Hedges Lane, there sits a copper beech tree so large that two people spreading their arms around it cannot touch fingertips. The beech is set in a meadow dotted with daffodils and catalpa trees.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; A Convergence Of Companies, And of Futures
description: CONVERGENCE is in the air these days.

title: Ms. Granat and Mr. Greensfelder
description: Sari Beth Granat, a daughter of Phyllis Z. Granat of Roslyn, N.Y., was married last evening to Timothy Allan Greensfelder, the son of Linda and Edward Greensfelder Jr. of Washington. Rabbi William Cutter officiated at the Yale Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORWAND, HILDA LEVY
description: FORWAND-Hilda Levy. Of Coral Springs, FL. Formerly of NYC, May 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Henry Forwand; Devoted mother of Dr. Stanley Forwand (Ann) and grandmother of Elizabeth and Amy.

title: Treasures of the Boston Larder
description: AMERICAN eaters owe Boston a great deal beyond praise for its baked beans and cod. Didn't Fanny Farmer, a local housewife, introduce uniform kitchen measurement and Cambridge-based Julia Child bury our culinary provincialism?

title: Beyond the Harvest of the Sea, An Abundance of Modern Art
description: MARSEILLES has been famous for many things over the years, among them its harbor, its bouillabaisse and its pickpockets. Long ago, a bishop who came to bless one of the galley ships built here for French kings defied the jostling spectators to pick his pockets. No one did, but by the time the ship was blessed the bishop had been relieved of the gold cross that ordinarily hung about his elderly neck.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; Water Mill
description: THE hamlet of Water Mill has caught the strip mall-craze and will now feature Blockbuster Video, EZ Mail Center and Double Rainbow Ice Cream as well as liquor and fast food shops.

title: Enlisting Troops in Battle Over Planned Shopping Center
description: A few months ago, a group of Chinese business owners and residents in Sunset Park were introduced to a potential new neighbor. Gathered in Ocean Palace, an Eighth Avenue restaurant, they listened to Charles Katz, a Borough Park developer who was accompanied by a Chinese-speaking employee, describe the shopping center he wants to build just blocks from their businesses.

title: May 10-16; Retreat on Welfare Reform
description: For the second time in a year, Congress is backing away from measures in the 1996 welfare overhaul law, which has been criticized as harsh on immigrants. The Senate voted almost unanimously to restore food stamps to some 250,000 legal immigrants -- children, the elderly and the disabled -- who got cut from the rolls under the 1996 law. Refugees would also be permitted to receive food stamps for seven years, instead of five.

title: Worcester to Consult At New Haven Event
description: Anne Worcester, who stepped down as chief executive officer of the Corel WTA Tour at the close of 1997 and has since formed her own sports marketing firm, APW Sports, has been hired by the Pilot Pen International Championships of New Haven to consult on the marketing and promotion of the August event, which recently expanded to a two-week format.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZER, HERBERT
description: HOLZER-Herbert. Age 68. On May 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Scott and Joan. Beloved grandfather of James and Daniel. Also survived by his brother Sydney. Funeral service Monday, 11:30 AM, Port Jewish Center, 20 Manorhaven Blvd. Interment private.

title: Miss Whamond, Mr. Burnell
description: Patricia Glennon Whamond, a daughter of Patricia G. Whamond of Murrieta, Calif., and the late James D. Whamond, was married yesterday to Matthew Hart Burnell, a son of Devin B. Burnell of Evanston, Ill., and Edward J. Burnell 3d of Los Angeles. The Rev. Martin T. Crowe performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Augustine in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Design War Is in the Streets
description: A civil war has erupted inside Manhattan's interior design industry, and the battle has taken to the streets; or at least to the names of streets.

title: Keeping Life in Balance Despite Diabetes
description: IMAGINE a world where the icing on a birthday cake could result in a medical emergency for a toddler. Or where a sleepover at a friend's house could be life threatening, if the child's medication is not packed with the pajamas and toothbrush. Or where a normal adolescent's desire to act just like every other teen-ager could in time lead to blindness or kidney failure.

title: May 10-16; Introducing the Sanitation Gap
description: Lester Brown, president of the Worldwatch Institute in Washington, is fascinated by trends other people may not be measuring. In an annual summary of economic and social indicators by the group, a ''sanitation gap'' emerged.

title: Training the Disabled to Lift an Eyebrow and Open Worlds
description: NAME -- Eamon P. Doherty, 34, of Parsippany.

title: ON THE MAP; A Town's Early History, Interred in a Backyard Cemetery
description: On a bluff overlooking the Saddle River lies the VanBuskirk Cemetery, burial ground of the first European settlers in the region now known as the Borough of Saddle River.

title: Silent Prayer for Mt. Vernon Schools?
description: ALARMED by increasing violence, drug use and other social ills among youth, a coalition of 12 churches in this city has organized a movement to bring silent prayer into the public schools. While the controversial proposal worries constitutional rights groups and heartens those on the religious right, members of Saving Our Children Through Prayer Power say they hew neither to the political left nor right and are focusing solely on the moral dilemmas facing the young.

title: Miles Kirkpatrick, 79; Lawyer Who Oversaw F.T.C. Reform
description: Miles W. Kirkpatrick, who oversaw a study that was sharply critical of the Federal Trade Commission and was then given the job of rejuvenating the agency as its chairman, died on May 2 at his home in Strafford, Pa.. He was 79.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the blurring of lines between childhood and adulthood referred incorrectly to the producer of the new animated movie ''Quest for Camelot.'' It is Warner Brothers, not Disney.

title: State Regulations Hailed by Boaters For the Revival Of Sport Fishing
description: THE fish are back.

title: Ruth Shu and Peter Diamond
description: Ruth Shu, a daughter of Lihli Y. Kuo of New York and Ping Shu of New Hyde Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter William Diamond, a son of Olga and Theodore Diamond of North Greenbush, N.Y. The Rev. Patric Legato performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Archangels in Stamford, Conn.

title: Exercise in Any Way
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BLUEBACK A Contemporary Fable. By Tim Winton. Scribner, $14.

title: Ms. Bekkedahl And Mr. Parent
description: Mary Ann Bekkedahl, a daughter of Victoria and Clifford Bekkedahl of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas Charles Parent, the son of Jeanne and Richard Parent of Westborough, Mass. The Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Bridgehampton (N.Y.) Tennis and Surf Club.

title: Patting Dad on the Back
description: DADDY WILL BE THERE

title: Being 13
description: Why 13-year-olds? You could make a case that in America now adolescence really starts at age 10 or 11, and that it continues well into the 20's. We have both intensified and elongated what used to be a simple biological transition, and have turned it into an arduous rite of cultural passage. To say that kids nowadays grow up too fast is a truism; it's equally true that we have made such a fetish of youth that not only adolescents but also many of us ostensible grown-ups dwell in a perpetual state of immaturity. But as an arbitrary cutoff, 13 has the virtue of standing at the beginning of what continues to be the heart of the journey -- the teen-age years -- and as these photographs amply document, 13 is the age that may most vividly embody all the paradoxes and contrasts of adolescence. These kids are still recognizably children, even as they are also premature grown-ups. Sometimes they're both at once -- children trying to act grown-up -- and sometimes you sense a younger self clinging forlornly to an older one. Many of the kids seem to be in a state of constant transition, slipping back and forth from one extreme to the other, as in Lauren Greenfield's pictures of suburban girls getting ready for a party in Edina, Minn. They're teeny-boppers one minute, miniature cocktail-dressed matrons the next.

title: Pick a Number, As State Starts a New Lottery Game
description: Those looking for a way to win at the New Jersey Lottery will have plenty of chances with a new game called Lotzee, the first nonscratch game introduced by the state in six years.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Giving a Suburban Sprawl a Sense of Community
description: LIKE other developing suburbs in New Jersey, Washington Township in Mercer County is a sprawling community with a patchwork of tract houses and a highway shopping strip, but no communal heart.

title: May 10-16; A Place for Nuclear Trash
description: With its plutonium bomb waste stored in temporary dumps in 16 states, the Energy Department won permission from the Environmental Protection Agency to open a permanent repository for hundreds of thousands of barrels, 2,150 feet below the New Mexico desert. When the department applied, its studies and arguments ran 80,000 pages; by the time it had finished answering the E.P.A.'s questions, the total was 100,000.

title: Sleek Reflections Of a Satiny Age
description: IN 1928, Templeton Crocker, a writer, naturalist and heir to a railroad fortune, went to Paris to commission fashionable furnishings and objects for his San Francisco penthouse. He visited several artist-designers; among them was Jean Dunand, who along with Jean-Michel Frank and Pierre Legrain were the taste makers for the elite. Crocker ordered wall reliefs, screens, furniture and accessories -- some 400 objects in all -- many with surfaces of shimmering lacquer, exotic furs or sharkskin and painted cubist motifs.

title: May 10-16; You Got a Permit For That Banana?
description: Wash it, peel it, cook it or don't eat it: sound advice for American travelers eating in the third world. But what about third-world produce on supermarket shelves in the United States?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a review of two watercolor exhibitions in South Jersey misidentified the gallery exhibiting ''Walk in Jazz,'' by Doree Loschiavo. It is the Hopkins House in Haddon Township, not the Perkins Center for the Arts in Moorestown.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; East Hampton Village
description: UNLESS that meteor bears down on East Hampton, favorite haunts like Nick and Toni's, Della Femina, the Maidstone Arms, Blue Parrot, Rowdy Hall, East Hampton Cinema, East Hampton Bowl and Main Beach will probably be there.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Purple America

title: A Time to Heal. A Time to Move?
description: THE REV. WILLIAM HANOUSEK, who grew up in Astoria and was educated at Stuyvesant High School and City College, took over the Bethany Reform Church on the southeast corner of First Avenue and 67th Street in 1977. He came from a church in Canarsie with his wife and three small children because he wanted to live and minister in Manhattan, and in a racially mixed neighborhood.

title: Aerial Combat Breaks Out In an Edgy Border War
description: These days, when New York and New Jersey are grabbing at each other's sports teams and Fortune 500 companies the way toddlers grapple over toys -- everything seems more valuable the moment the other kid wants it -- almost no issue seems immune to border-war fever.

title: The View From/Tarrytown; Music of the Andes Helps a Culture Live On
description: TAHUANTINSUYO was playing pipes and drums; Kausaynan was dancing. The rhythm was strong, elemental, almost like a heartbeat; the melody, haunting. The male dancer wore a wool poncho and a brimmed hat; the female, blue material draped over a white frilly blouse. The audience, riveted, clapped along, seeming to forget the surrounding four walls and modern theater equipment.

title: A Homecoming At Fannie Mae; Franklin Raines Takes Charge Of a Most Political Company
description: AS a child in Seattle in the 50's and 60's, Franklin D. Raines saw his father build the family a house with his own hands.

title: Building a Business, Quarter by Quarter
description: CLEMSON BROWN is no Ma Bell, but he has come a long way.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 26 with a play review of ''The Cripple of Inishmaan'' at the Joseph Papp Public Theater misidentified the actress shown with the actor Ruaidhri Conroy. She was Roberta Maxwell, not Elizabeth Franz.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: JACOB'S LADDER

title: A New Major Player Joins Winery Business
description: TEN years ago, Long Island's maritime wine industry, then still in its adolescence, sought gurus among chateau executives and grape-growing experts in maritime Bordeaux. It invited a team of renowned grape-cultivation and wine-making experts, and picked their brains during four days of field trips and symposiums.

title: A Family in Dysfunction
description: ''IS there hope and lightness in his heart?'' asks Nora, the mother-in-law of Junior, an unwitting drug dealing punk who lies bleeding on the kitchen floor, having been viciously beaten. He is ordered to get up instantly. Why should the family be made so miserable because of Junior's misery?

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE CRASHER By Shirley Lord. Brandon Tartikoff/Warner, $24.

title: Retirement Havens, Even for U.F.O.'s
description: IF you're thinking about relocating when you retire but are weary of reading about the usual places that pop up on most lists of recommendations, the June issue of Kiplinger's offers some relief.

title: Kathryn Maris, Herman Deetman
description: Kathryn Anne Maris, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter J. G. Maris of Old Westbury, N.Y., was married yesterday to Herman Jan Deetman, the son of Geertruida M. C. Deetman of Windsor, England, and the late Arie Deetman. The Rev. Dr. Robert G. Stephanopoulos, the dean of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York, performed the ceremony at the cathedral.

title: Political Briefing; Clinton's Party Fights Erosion in Home State
description: If pollsters have it right in Arkansas, State Senator Fay Boozman, an anti-abortion conservative from Rogers who has strong Christian-right support, will capture the Republican Senate nomination in Tuesday's primary voting. The only other candidate on the ticket, former Mayor Tom Prince of Little Rock, has been touting his own bedrock conservatism, but was still well behind Mr. Boozman.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: For two of its biggest stars, MGM cooked up Robert Z. Leonard's DANCING LADY (1933), a standard but glitzy musical that filled theaters. Audiences savored both the energetic Joan Crawford, as an eager chorus girl drawn to a society suitor (Franchot Tone), and the world-weary Clark Gable, as her tough director. One Tyrolean number pairs Crawford with a prancing dude from New York named Fred Astaire (his screen debut) -- Tuesday at 8 P.M. on TCM.

title: Now at a Gym: Botox Injections
description: ONCE, health clubs were places for pumping iron and huffing on treadmills, for those who believed you had to sweat to achieve a perfect physique. More recently, many clubs have branched out into spa treatments like seaweed wraps and facials for their appearance-conscious members. Now comes what may be the culmination in this progression: in-house plastic surgeons, for those who want to look comely with much less effort.

title: Liberties; Nicotine-Stained Halo
description: George Mitchell was trying to bask in his diplomatic glory.

title: Nancy Weiss, William Kopp
description: Dr. Nancy Lynn Weiss, an internist, and Dr. William Kenneth Kopp, an oral and maxillofacial surgeon, are to be married this morning by Cantor Susan Alcott at the Performing Arts Center of the State University College at Purchase, N.Y.

title: VIEWPOINT; In Changing Copyright Laws, Don't Throw Away the Key
description: IT'S no accident that the United States is the leader in medicine, business, technology and other areas. Our nation has reaped the benefits of a copyright policy that fosters research, innovation and creativity.

title: SOAPBOX; The Last Word
description: I HAVE become almost as knowledgeable as anyone about the New Jersey laws, case law and regulations regarding the rights of people, even in their own homes, who are sick, dying or already dead, even with a ''do not resuscitate'' (D.N.R.) order. The misplaced reliance on such an order is almost as touching as it is ignorant.

title: Path Seen as a Road to Ruin
description: An Eastern towhee crooned its love song while perched among the pine trees and underbrush that separate Black Bank Marsh, part of the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, from busy Cross Bay Boulevard. Honeysuckle sweetened the air and the sun was finally shining last week. But Al Ott, a passionate bird-watcher, shook with anger as he described the plan for a paved path through what he called ''a nesting area that provides shelter and habitat for birds.''

title: Nara Milanich, Nicola Cetorelli
description: Nara Bales Milanich, the daughter of Dr. Maxine L. Margolis and Dr. Jerald T. Milanich of Gainesville, Fla., was married there yesterday to Dr. Nicola Cetorelli, the son of Concetta Rovo and Raniero Cetorelli of Rome. Judith Angley, a notary public, officiated at the Sweetwater Branch Inn.

title: Plastic Gaining on Traveler's Checks
description: MUCH-traveled people tell me that they seldom use traveler's checks abroad anymore. They count on finding an automated teller machine in an airport and getting an instant supply of the local currency. As they move along, when they cannot charge a hotel expense or a meal, they get more local currency from A.T.M.'s.

title: And No Television, Either
description: BOOM TOWN

description: WAITZMAN-Pearl (nee Rosen). Died May 15, 1998, age 81, of Copake, NY, and Deerfield Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Mara Conan and Barbara Kuhn. Mother-inlaw to Marvin and Peter. Dear sister of Evelyn Leipziger, Jilda Rosenblatt and the late Martin Rosen. Beloved grandmother of Jesse, Jordan, Matthew, Michael and Jonathan. Services ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Monday, 11 AM.

title: Pilots Press to End Forced Retirement at 60
description: James A. Fitts says his parents thought he was crazy when as a boy of 5 in 1940 he began drawing pictures of sleek airplanes with swept-back wings and no propellers. But Mr. Fitts was convinced that he would one day pilot such seemingly outlandish aircraft, and he was right.

title: Yacht Owners Want to Sit in the Driver's Seat
description: It used to be that buying a new racing yacht was a simple matter of finding the fastest boat. But now the purchase of a new one-design sailboat comes with a set of rules and conditions as restrictive as buying a cooperative in a high-rent district.

title: A Sampling of Summer Activities on North and South Forks
description: Today
