description: SINATRA-Francis Albert. Beloved friend and Chairman of the Board of the world of popular music and of The Songwriters' Hall of Fame who always remembered and saluted the men and women who wrote the songs. We'll miss you Frank. Farewell and Godspeed. The Songwriters' Hall of Fame Bobby Weinstein, President

title: Q and A
description: San Juan Islands

title: Woman Is Killed Beneath Wheels of Bus
description: The police are searching for two people who may have killed a woman last night by throwing her underneath a passing bus on 40th Street.

title: A Country's Response to the Nazis: No
description: TO understand how the producer John Davis came to make his latest film, ''Miracle at Midnight,'' you must begin in October 1943 with a 15-year-old boy in Copenhagen.

title: The New Jersey Yankees?
description: Should the New York Yankees move to New Jersey?

title: David Rievman And Anne Oh
description: Anne Myung Oh and David Mitchell Rievman are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Peter Kessler at Historic Waverly, a house museum in Marriottsville, Md.

title: Master Harold, Growing Up and Grown Old
description: IN the peerless Athol Fugard's extraordinary body of work, ''The Captain's Tiger,'' now in its American premiere at the McCarter Theater here, represents the autobiographical continuation of '' 'Master Harold' . . . and the Boys,'' the next phase in the 17-year-old Hally's coming of age. In ''Master Harold,'' Mr. Fugard's most rending play, Hally is the startled discoverer of how racism begins.

title: Niche Farming in New Jersey: Is It Diversity or Gimmickry?
description: WHEN Bill Maxwell quit his job as a newspaper reporter at age 38, he had a roto-tiller and five acres of land in Changewater. Now he has a thriving 45-acre farm that sells its vegetables exclusively in New York City open-air markets.

title: Sports of The Times; The Heart of It: That Song Belongs in the Bronx
description: START spreading the news; I'm leaving today. For a couple of decades, we have been leaving Yankee Stadium with Frank Sinatra's voice in our heads, telling us we have just been privileged to watch a ball game in the center of the baseball universe, Noo Yawk, Noo Yawk.

title: Sinatra's Lasting Image: The Voice or the Vices?
description: Frank Sinatra has gone, but of course he will always be with us. But which Frank Sinatra will be the one who is most remembered?

title: Hard-Pressed, Suharto Plans To Shuffle His Cabinet
description: Retreating another half-step in the face of national outrage, President Suharto announced today that he would shuffle his unpopular Cabinet. But several Indonesian and foreign analysts said he must make deeper changes in his autocratic rule if he is to stay in office.

title: What the Artist Sees Looking Back at Him
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you don't have refrigeration and temperature control and you don't have hand washing, you're asking for an outbreak.''

title: The Clues Are in The Blood
description: The blood samples shown on the cover of the magazine would be worthless for genetic analysis. They have been collected in red-top vacutainer tubes, which contain no anticoagulant, and would therefore be clotted. For DNA analysis, a lavender-top vacutainer tube, which contains the anticoagulant EDTA, is generally used.

title: The Man Who Raised America
description: DR. SPOCK

title: 'New' Politics In Siberia: Biased Press, Funny Money
description: This city in southern Siberia has become the center ring of Russian politics in the last several weeks -- a place where movie stars, pop singers, image makers and dirty-tricks artists have been busily parading their campaign skills.

title: THE N.B.A. PLAYOFFS: The Lords Of the Rings; Sparkle of Bulls' Titles Touches Stars and Standbys
description: Robert Louis Hansen 2d is 37 years old, an insurance broker from Des Moines, and a rather tall one at that. He stands 6 feet 6 inches and is a onetime basketball player. On occasion, he wears a large, gaudy ring to prove it. He is also a part-time broadcaster. Some time ago, he was working a girls' state basketball tournament in Des Moines and was wearing his ring, a diamond-studded piece of jewelry emblematic of his having been a member of the 1992 Chicago Bulls championship team.

title: Many Customers Still Balk At Push-Button Banking; Skipping A.T.M.'s for Tellers and Passbooks
description: In an age of money machines, on-line banking and the quicksilver transfer of cash via computer, Maria Russo, a 38-year-old typist, is holding fast to another age. Hers is the gentle -- some might say fusty -- world of teller windows, withdrawal slips and passbook savings accounts.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; The North Fork
description: THE North Fork of Long Island is a true resting place but not in the sense that one sits and soaks up the rays. There are no discos, no cool shops, no bikini beaches, no heels, ever. The First Annual Wine Stomping Competition planned for late summer might just be the social event of the season. The North Fork is promoting the arts this season and the East End Arts Council is promoting the 1998 Wine Country Concert series, so brush off the picnic basket.

title: A Capital Life
description: TITAN The Life of John D. Rockefeller, Sr. By Ron Chernow. Illustrated. 774 pp. New York: Random House. $30.

title: Westhampton Aims for Respect With Arts Center
description: IN a coming together of the Westhampton Beach community,the East End village is enjoying a cultural and economic revival. At the center is the new Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center, now receiving its finishing touches and scheduled to open in July.

title: Restoring What Time, and Editors, Took Away
description: ''HEY, shorty,'' the truck driver calls to Cabiria on the dingy videotape of ''Nights of Cabiria,'' Federico Fellini's 1957 masterpiece about the ruin of an altogether winning but hopelessly naive prostitute in Rome. Another night, another assignation on the Passeggiata Archeologica, a hookers' staging ground near the Baths of Caracalla.

title: Elections Not Over For Newark Councilmen
description: Most of the votes have been counted from Tuesday's nonpartisan municipal elections. But the contests are not over for some candidates in Newark, where elections for the Council members from the Central and West Wards and for four at-large Council seats will be decided in runoffs June 9.

title: At the Intersection of Good Taste and Bad
description: ''MY father told me -- and I resent this -- that we light the eight Hanukkah candles to acknowledge the suffering of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.'' That zinger comes from ''Too Many Santas,'' a CD by the Bobs, a smart-mouth vocal quartet that calls itself a rock-and-roll band without instruments.

title: Subsidies for High-Income Families
description: On a sunny afternoon, a Porsche, a BMW and two Mercedeses sparkled in the tenant parking lot of this city's largest public housing project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, ABRAHAM
description: WEISBERG - Abraham. Passed away peacefully on May 13, 1998 at age 89, in Red Bluff, CA. Son of the late Kopel and Maryashe Weisberg, beloved husband of Carol Ashley Weisberg for 38 years, and the late Edith Israel Weisberg and the late Mary Beth Collister Weisberg. Cherished father of the late Carol Nan Kaplan, Ellen Massie (Barry) of Mill Valley, CA., Jadis Norman (Jim Torczyner) of Montreal, Kenda Brown (Neil) of Red Bluff, CA., David Weisberg (Julie) of Peterborough, NH, and Michael Weisberg Wheat (Zalia) of New Orleans. Adored grandfather of Eric, Michael, Lisa and Dana Kaplan; Jennifer and Rebecca Massie; Carla and Ben Norman; Ashley Brown; and Zane Wheat. He was a dear brother, uncle, friend, and advocate. A man who encouraged all to be their best and to give to life. A graduate of St. John's Law School and its Post Graduate Law Studies, 1933. A respected and trusted senior partner in the New York City maritime law firm of Standard, Weisberg, P.C., (formed in 1924) before retiring in 1982 after 53 years of service. He was a member of the U.S. Maritime Law Association and the American Trial Lawyer's Association and served as general counsel for the National Maritime Union of America until 1946. He represented every client as if (s)he was the most important person in the world. He is greatly loved and will be missed and remembered for his wit, strength, love, and wisdom. A memorial service will be held in New York City and Keene, NH at a later date. For information contact: Ellen Weisberg Massie (415) 381-9910, 6 Lula Way, Mill Valley, California 94941. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Heart Association. May his memory be a blessing.

title: Eleven Benefits in May
description: Aiding organizations that help the Lower East Side, hospitals, writers, museums the arts, the ballet, the mentally ill, the blind and a college.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on April 26, about Athens, misspelled the name of a main street for shopping in the Plaka quarter. It is Kidathenion Street, not Kithadenion.

title: Under the Laser, Up Close and Personal
description: ROBERT POWERS was obviously nervous. It was a March morning, Friday the 13th, there was a full moon and he and his friend Joe Beitz were having eye surgery.

title: It's the Hamptons as a Battleground
description: SPRINGTIME in the Hamptons. The sun is shining, but the air is cool; the ocean is sparkling, but the beaches are empty; the restaurants are open, but there are seats for everyone. There is little traffic, few pedestrians, and if you stand in front of the Corwith House Museum on Main Street in Bridgehampton, it is easy to imagine the harmonious Hamptons of yesteryear -- the Hamptons before Hollywood moved in, before the big bull market, before outsized egos clashed with zoning laws, before neighbor-against-neighbor lawsuits.

title: Claudia Lewnowski, James Joyce
description: Claudia Isabelle Lewnowski and James Jarrett Joyce were married yesterday by the Rev. Frank Reitzel at St. Patrick's Catholic Church in Smith's Parish, Bermuda.

title: Correction
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Pratt Institute, misspelled the given name of a former president of the school. He was Frederic Pratt, not Frederick.

title: Depicting Women's Work: A Carnival of Roles
description: MANY an artist worked from sun to sun to construct the exhibition ''A Woman's Work Is Never Done.'' The exhibition, an end-of-the-century assessment of women's roles in American culture, will begin on Wednesday and continue through June 21 at Hudson Square, a sprawling commercial expanse on Hudson Street that was once home to a furniture showroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIRECTOR, NATHAN (PETE)
description: DIRECTOR-Nathan (Pete). On May 15, 1998. Devoted husband of Phyllis. Beloved father of Jon, Roger and Lisa. Loving father-in-law of Jeanne and Jan. Cherished grandfather of Gillian, Geoffrey and Chloe. Service Sunday, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Material Basis of the Human Voice
description: There is evidence, scientists now say, that the capacity for speech arose in ancestral humans 400,000 years ago. The evidence is structural. The hole in the back of the skull, the hypoglossal canal, through which nerve fibers connect to the tongue is larger in early and modern humans than it is in chimpanzees and australopithecines, implying a more dexterous, more articulate tongue. We humans naturally think speaking divides us from the rest of the animals. So it is good to be reminded that the root of our difference and the source of so much proud philosophizing over the past 400 millennia lies in the material structure of the body itself.

title: Let Senate Act On Test Ban Treaty; Hypocritical Response
description: To the Editor:

title: The Parrish Marks a Century
description: AS the art museum founded in Southampton by Samuel Parrish in 1898 celebrates its centennial -- making it the oldest on Long Island -- it is pushing for recognition as one of the country's leading small museums.

title: Bookend; Reading at Escape Velocity
description: Have you ever had the feeling that your children are turning into beasts -- chimpanzees, maybe, or slovenly, lazy, greedy brown bears? It actually happens in the inventive and wildly popular ''Animorphs'' series. ''All the kids are asking for those books; we can't keep them on the shelves,'' the clerks in my local bookstore say. Some adults, on the other hand, don't care for the Animorphs: my niece Clarissa, who is a children's librarian in New York City, tells me her system won't purchase them.

title: Netanyahu Is Closely Guarded as He Visits Temple
description: When he was Israel's representative to the United Nations in the 1980's, Benjamin Netanyahu would occasionally drop by the Fifth Avenue Synagogue on Manhattan's East Side, knowing that many of his friends worshiped there and that many congregants agreed with his conservative Israeli politics.

title: Marcia Lane, Richard Clair
description: Marcia Fairfield Lane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Garrison Fairfield Lane of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Richard Lee Clair, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond C. Clair of Buffalo. Canon Sydney A. Woodd-Cahusac performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Jewelry Raffle to Help Charity
description: ILA MANNER calls it the ''grand, first public viewing of the Heart of Katonah, in the heart of Katonah.'' What she is talking about is that next Saturday, at Ila Manner Jewelers and Design Studio, her shop in the center of the hamlet, people will be able to see a necklace of pearl, diamond and sapphire, which she and her husband, Robert, designed and are raffling off for charity. Worth $10,000, the necklace is not for sale, but anyone can buy a raffle ticket for $5 (or three tickets for $10) for a drawing for the necklace in September. The money will benefit the Community Center, a nonprofit organization, which helps people who need food, clothing and employment counseling.

title: May 10-16; Nike Makes Amends
description: For years, human rights and labor groups have singled out Nike Inc. as an example of an American company that should demand better treatment of the workers at its suppliers' factories in Asia. Now the company has agreed to raise the working age in its shoe and garment factories, to hold the foreign factories to the same health and safety standards imposed in the United States and to let outside observers help insure that its promises are carried out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSNER, ABRAHAM
description: WASSNER-Abraham. Died May 16, 1998, due to complications of lymphoma. He was the devoted husband of his late wife Clara, loving father of Joan and Steven, and doting grandfather of Regina, Ari and Nancy. A man of immense ability, a linguist par excellence, and an interpreter and translator in over 25 languages. He initially served as supervisory interpreter for the INS in NYC, and after his retirment, as an invaluable resource and friend to immigration professionals thoughout NY and beyond. Respected by all who met him, loved by all who knew him. Funeral services Monday, at Parkside Chapel, Queens Blvd.

title: Pictures, Perhaps, of Her Despair
description: PLAINLY, Francesca Woodman's photography should be judged for what it is, not for what it promised. Yet, once acquired, the knowledge that she committed suicide at the age of 22 is bound to influence how her work is seen. It deepens admiration at the talent of one so young and, yes, it does raise the question of where it might all have led. More perversely, it provokes an almost unconscious search for evidence of impending self-destruction in her powerful and often disturbing self-portraiture.

title: Knotty Issue for Belfast: Fate of Royal Ulster Police
description: Streets shiny from rain, arched stone bridges, weathered men in oatmeal sweaters and tweed caps, pubs with hearty laughter inside and names outside that begin O' -- the villages of Northern Ireland have the same postcard allure as those in the South.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODAI, YITZHAK
description: MODAI-Yitzhak. WIZO USA joins Michal Modai, President of World WIZO, and the people of Israel in mourning the loss of Yitzhak Modai, a great builder and leader of the State of Israel. Evelyn Sommer, President

Steven Stolman on Main Street has gone ''dressy,'' adding satin pique dresses and strappy shoes made especially for lawn parties -- no more aerating the host's lawn. Accessorize at M. S. Boutique, a new jewelry shop at the old RVS Fine Art gallery space.

title: Car Safety Report Explores Controversies
description: CONSUMER REPORTS, the magazine that does testing for Consumers Union in Yonkers, publishes at least one article about automobiles in every issue and for 60 years has produced an annual issue devoted to cars. Yet employees associated with the magazine's special televised report on car safety become impassioned when they discuss it.

description: SINCE 1978, Peter Rosazza has served as auxiliary bishop for the Archdiocese of Hartford, which encompasses about 220 parishes and 800,000 Roman Catholics in Hartford, New Haven and Litchfield counties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALAMON, ALEXANDER ''ABA.''
description: SALAMON - Alexander ''Aba.'' Age 90, born in Kolysvar, Hungary. Lived in Israel, NY and West Palm Beach. Lived a full life and enjoyed every moment of it. His joie di vivre will always be an inspiration to his family: son Itamar and his wife Linda, grandchildren Peggy, Tommy, Betsy and her husband Michael. He leaves behind his loving companion Sally Epstein. The family expresses its gratitude for the devoted care he received in his final years from Martha Flores Lopez.

These days, they deliver a sidewalk smorgasbord as varied as the city itself -- the traditional hot dogs and pretzels, along with hamburgers, chicken, pork, lamb, duck, even fish and tripe.

A native of Brooklyn, he had a 22 year career at the Chicago Tribune as a writer, editor, Moscow correspondent and mentor to many reporters. He is survived by his wife Barbara, sons Colin, Seamus, Patrick, Neil and Rory; a brother Thomas and a sister Eileen McCaul. A visitation for family and friends will be held from 1-4 PM Sunday at his brother's residence in Manhattan.

description: BIKING Sag Harbor is a delightful way to spend a day. There are many hidden antique stores to browse through, historical museums to visit and cafes for refueling, not to mention the beautiful scenery of Victorian houses and gardens.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Helping City Children Find Their Country Niche
description: ''New York smells,'' Sam Magnus said, explaining why he wanted to get out of New York City for a few weeks this summer. His mother, Sharon, pointed out that the grass might be greener in the countryside, but the horse manure that helps keep it that way has never been mistaken for flowers.

title: A Flourishing Industry, Predicting What Is and Isn't Flourishing
description: SUCCESSFUL investing, it is often observed, is a lot like predicting who will win a beauty contest. The idea is not to spot the prettiest contestant but to identify whom the judges will decide is prettiest. Replace ''pretty'' with ''profitable,'' and you enter the world of earnings forecasting, where a small circle of highly influential companies compete intensely to gather predictions from Wall Street analysts and circulate their combined wisdom to portfolio managers and investors.

title: A Head Coach's Hoop Dreams
description: A SMILE creased Tim O'Toole's face when he reflected on his junior year at Fairfield University and the advice his father had offered. ''I was thinking about going to work on Wall Street,'' he said, ''and my father, who was a stockbroker, looked at me and said, 'You need something you can find to do so you can make your vocation your vacation. He told me, 'Your job is going to be your life, so you'd better enjoy it.' ''

title: Closed-End Fund Investors Gain Clout
description: AS the Securities and Exchange Commission put the nation's closed-end fund managers in the firing line? A little-noticed decision by the S.E.C. has given investors in these funds an enormous amount of power, handing them the right to oust investment managers by vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWARTLER, DR. CHARLES
description: KWARTLER-Dr. Charles. At his home in NYC with his family on May 1, 1998. He and his beautiful Ruth just celebrated their 57th anniversary. Born in Stanislau, Austria in 1911, he spent most of his life in the Hackettstown, NJ area. Best known for his pioneering work in the development of pharmaceutical drugs, including Demerol and Chloroquine, he held 21 patents. During the last 50 years he taught organic chemistry at NYU and held many executive positions in the chemical industry. He had an ardent lifelong commitment to help human rights and education and he worked tirelessly for many organizations: Hackettstown Community Hospital; Warren County Community College; Warren County Vocational Technical School; Hackettstown Board of Education; Warren County Health Care Agency; NJ Board of Higher Education; Jewish Center of Northwest Jersey. Dr. Kwartler was a man with a tremendous life force and a powerful presence. Whether in his lab, in the community, or in his much-loved gardens, he exemplified Kipling's description of filling ''every minute with 60 seconds' worth of distance run.'' He is also survived by his children: Alice, Jeanne and David; his brother, Alan; and by Marcia Aronoff, Rosalie Newman, and Lana Predko. The family would appreciate contributions to Hackettstown Community Hospital, 651 Willow Grove, Hackettstown, NJ 07840 or to Warren County Community College, State Hwy No. 57, Washington, NJ 07882.

title: Doing Hollywood; The Life of Wylie
description: It's 7:45 a.m., and adam Wylie has 15 minutes to finish his cereal and get from his house in Upland, an hour east of Los Angeles, to his kung-fu lesson, the first stop in a crammed schedule on a typical Saturday. Adam, a seventh grader at Upland Christian School, already has the television series ''Picket Fences'' and the movie ''Kindergarten Cop'' on his resume, but at the moment he'll settle for one of the dozens of high-school genre films being pumped through Hollywood studios to satisfy the teen-age children of the baby boomers.

description: A costly city program to help immigrants obtain citizenship will continue, city officials say, despite the expected passage of a law that could make the program obsolete.

The attention that the rest of the country devotes to cars is funneled into food: Where did you get that smoked salmon? How much a pound? What about that coffee?

title: Hindu Nationalists Move to Rule India's Atom Era
description: As India adjusts to its new status as a nuclear weapons state, many Indians are wondering whether they should prepare for a new era of dominance by the Hindu nationalist leaders who ordered five nuclear tests this week in the country's northwestern desert.

description: Whitney Hiroko Onishi, a daughter of Esther Onishi of Mercer Island, Wash., and Frank Onishi of Seattle, was married yesterday to Timothy Edward Carr, a son of Nancy Carr and Dr. Ronald E. Carr of New York. Judge Charles French of the Snohomish County Superior Court in Everett, Wash., officiated at the Ranier Chapter House of the Daughters of the American Revolution in Seattle.

But while most first-time owners come to that status as young adults, the Zaccardos have gotten there in their 60's, and more by accident than design.

Mr. DelFavero's Mediterranean flare should give the old creekside spot a shot of adrenalin. This year's new name is . . . Hong Kong Taste. The Chinese restaurant in the shopping center seems to change its name every year, but thefood is consistent and not neon orange.

The alternatives often turn up in communities without ''Hampton'' in their names. These off-the-beaten-track finds offer great food, smooth service and charming ambiance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACIVER, LOREN
description: MacIVER-Loren. Died peacefully at her home in Greenwich Village, NY, on May 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late poet and critic Lloyd Frankenberg. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend. As we move forward, her extraordinary spirit lives through our memories and her art. At Loren's request, no services are planned. Philippe Alexandre Andrew H. Arnot Eric Brown Tibor de Nagy Gallery

description: Ireland, which has never fought in a war in its 76 years as an independent state, is debating whether it should remain officially neutral or join a European military alliance.

title: Union Wins a Long Battle at an Investment Bank's Cafeteria

description: Entering this spiffy new deli on a recent Saturday morning, I thought I'd mistakenly wandered into someone's party. ''I was born the day of San Giuseppe!'' a customer was shouting. Another customer and a counterman were having a loud, good-natured debate over the best way to rescue hardened Parmesan. A counterman passed a panful of hot zeppole among the half-dozen waiting customers and ordered, ''Taste!''

title: Political Briefing; Primary Calendar
description: In addition to Arkansas, Oregon and Pennsylvania will hold primaries on Tuesday.

title: Part's Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: The New China Connection
description: The White House used to dismiss Johnny Chung as a hustler whose prodigious political fund-raising in 1996 was illegal but harmless. Now, in a breakthrough for the Justice Department's investigation of the campaign scandals, Mr. Chung has admitted that a large portion of the money he raised for the Democrats originated with the People's Liberation Army in China. The first hard evidence of the China connection to the last Presidential campaign should compel Attorney General Janet Reno to move at last for the selection of an independent prosecutor. Even more important, it obliges the Administration to come forward with a full explanation of whether any campaign contributions were connected to its decision in 1996 to loosen controls over the sharing of military technology with China.

title: Persistence Pays Off for a Janus Manager
description: STRANGE. As an M.B.A. candidate at Duke University, David C. Decker had the hardest time getting in the door at the Janus Capital Corporation in his hometown of Denver. ''I wasn't recruited,'' Mr. Decker recalled. ''I actually went to them.'' On his first try, Janus looked him over but didn't hire him.

title: Home Sweet Workplace, Nest of Neuroses
description: CARTER, the token gay black male in his office, plans to go on ''Good Morning America'' and embarrass his employer (the Mayor) with a firsthand story of urban racism. Mike, the Deputy Mayor, tries to dissuade him. ''Look, Carter, we're a family here, O.K.? Let's just deal with this problem the way any American family handles a crisis.'' ''And how is that?'' asks Carter (Michael Boatman). ''Well,'' says Mike (Michael J. Fox), ''we sweep it under the rug, get drunk and don't talk about it.''

title: Livery Drivers Reject Giuliani's Call to Take Street Hails
description: With a bumper-to-bumper protest by yellow-cab drivers looming, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to retaliate starting tomorrow by allowing livery cars and vans to pick up passengers on the street. But in interviews yesterday, many livery-service drivers said they were not interested.

title: A Bond-and-Stock Package Equipped With Seat Belts
description: IS it time for a spin in a convertible? With the Dow galloping toward 10,000, investors torn between the relative safety of bonds and the risk of stocks have this third option: convertible bonds that in effect are part bond, part stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, LOUIS
description: LEVY-Louis. On May 13, 1998, of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of Brooklyn. ''A mensch to everyone.'' Loving husband of Edith and the late Clara. Adored father of Rabbi Jerrold (Ruth) Levy, Vivian Levy and Sheila (Dr. Harry) Romanowitz. Cherished grandfather of Judith, David and Cherilyn, Ari, Avra and Daniel. Edith's children Joan and Ron, Arthur and Sandy, Jay and Barbara, and their children and grandchildren were like his own. Memorial contributions to your UJA Federation Campaign. Interment 11:15 AM Sunday, May 17, 1998, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. For further information, Gutterman's Inc., Rockville Centre, Long Island. (516) 764-9400.

title: A Holdover Plans to Leave

But the Menorah Nursing Home for the Aged and Infirm has remained, occupying an entire block of Bushwick Avenue, which once had a thriving Jewish community. About 270 people of all ethnic groups call it home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE BOWER, LUANA
description: de BOWER-Luana, age 87. Died May 5, 1998 after a long illness. Devoted godmother of John W. Ryan, III and great aunt of David Andrew, nieces Kyle and Lisa of Sydney, Australia. Donations please to her favorite charity, Intergroup and American Red Cross, c/o Dolores Swern, 150 Amsterdam Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10023.

title: The East End
description: From kayaking to wine tasting, from Riverhead to Montauk, the East End of the Island will cater to every taste again this summer. This special issue looks ahead to The Season on the North and South Forks.

title: Losing Our Grip On Godzilla
description: I SEE that a new $120 million computer-generated Godzilla is about to clump through the nation's multiplexes, and I feel that tug of regret you get when you leave an old friend you may never see again. Loosing Godzilla in ''Jurassic Park''-like animatronics is a bit like putting Edward G. Robinson in a Quentin Tarantino faux noir. Half the charm of the old Godzilla films was their hokey Super-8 cheesiness: the dubious dubbing, the Tinker Toy sets that looked like Tinker Toy sets, the undisguised fact that the monster was played by a man in a baggy rubber suit.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: They Are Ruining Ibiza By A. C. Greene. University of North Texas, $21.95.

title: School Budget Faces Vote
description: WITH school districts presenting their proposed 1998-99 budgets to communities on Tuesday, in most places parents, school board members and other supporters of public education have spent the last few days reminding their neighbors to vote.

title: Correction
description: The Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Elizabeth Standish Darst and Henry Baird Tenney Jr., omitted the last two words of a quotation from the bride. She said, ''I didn't care about getting married; I just wanted to find someone I could love.''

title: Investing to Cover College Cost
description: FOR Townsend Smith, a second grader from Darien, the future is a shining sea that he intends to sail across. ''When I graduate from college I want to be in the Navy,'' he said. ''I like boats a lot. I'd like to be a captain.''

title: Corrections
description: A Bookend essay on April 19, about the pleasures of reading while traveling, misstated the first name of a British secret agent who impersonated a Bolshevik secret agent in central Asia after World War I. He was Frederick Bailey, not George.

title: Leaving the Freeway, Paying a Price
description: SOME say that the frontier closed in 1867, when barbed wire was first patented. For others it was 1869, when the transcontinental railroad was completed. In 1893 Frederick Jackson Turner declared it closed in a seminal paper presented at a meeting of the American Historical Association. Entitled ''The Significance of the Frontier in American History,'' it argued that ''The existence of an area of free land, its continuous recession, and the advance of American settlement westward, explain American development. . . . The true point of view in the history of this nation is not the Atlantic coast, it is the Great West.'' This region, he suggested, was made up of a series of frontiers -- the trader's frontier, the miner's frontier, the rancher's frontier, and lastly, the farmer's frontier.

title: Ms. Birnbaum And Mr. Surkin
description: Jacqueline Claire Birnbaum and Dean Leslie Surkin are to be married this afternoon in Syosset, N.Y., at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Florence and Morton Surkin. Rabbi Robert I. Summers is to officiate.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; A Poet's Environment
description: As an epigraph to his book JOSEPH BRODSKY/LENINGRAD: Fragments (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35), the photographer Mikhail Lemkhin has chosen the late Russian poet's own words, from his tribute to Stephen Spender: ''People are what we remember about them. . . . With death, it gets unstitched, and one ends up with random, disjointed fragments. With shards or, if you will, with snapshots.'' Of the 186 photographs included here, some are of Brodsky -- reading, smiling, wiping his face, smoking -- and some are of Leningrad (as it was called from 1924 to 1991), the poet's native city. Lemkhin identifies a few of the places in the photographs in random notes -- the Alexandrine Column in Palace Square, the sphinx on the embankment of the Neva River, apartments Brodsky lived in, the Leningrad headquarters of the K.G.B., the prison where Brodsky was incarcerated, Dostoyevsky's tombstone -- but most of the photographs of Leningrad are not so grand or specific. Instead, there are universal scenes of children playing in the snow; busy, crowded streets; people leaning out the windows of their apartment buildings or sitting on park benches. There are no close-up portraits of people, however, other than those of Brodsky. ''Rather than a collection of images,'' Lemkhin writes in a brief note at the end, '' 'Fragments' is a single portrait. Each photo is like a word or a phrase I use to tell my story, to sketch my subject's portrait.'' Enriched by Czeslaw Milosz's foreword and by Susan Sontag's moving, elegiac afterword, Lemkhin has successfully -- and beautifully -- arranged the many shards of his book into that whole, single portrait to which he aspired. Robin Lippincott

title: On a Museum's Menu, Sophisticated Fare
description: AN oasis of calm in downtown Hartford at lunchtime is the Museum Cafe, tucked unobtrusively into a section off Avery Court in the rear of the Wadsworth Atheneum. The dining room space is generous, with clear views through wide windows of some of the museum's outdoor sculpture. The gray-toned interior, punctuated by splashes of color in the paintings on the walls, adds to the tranquillity.

title: Getting Close to Nature in a Sea Kayak
description: THE sweeping seaside vistas of Eastern Long Island might sometimes make visitors feel that they've stumbled onto the Gates of Eden. Unfortunately, without the appropriate beach permit, or waterfront property, the gates don't always open.

title: Montclair School Budget: The Mayor and the Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Accessible Bus
description: To the Editor: Regarding Betsy Wade's article ''In Motion: Buses for the Disabled'' (Practical Traveler, April 26), we would like to tell your readers about our service here in New York City. H.A.I., or Hospital Audiences Inc., is a nonprofit organization that operates two transit-style vehicles fully accessible for wheelchair users. Each bus can hold up to 10. Another feature is a rear ramp that allows up to five special stretcher beds to be used. Various combinations of riders in wheelchairs and beds, and ambulatory people are also possible. We have specially trained drivers and an assistant on each bus.

title: Children's Books in Brief
description: Chuck Close Up Close

title: Somebody's Boy Next Door
description: ONE OF OURS

title: No Ordinary Joe
description: The Queen Of Whale Cay

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: ON-LINE PLANNING

title: POSTINGS: Seminar on Wednesday; The Penthouses Of TriBeCa
description: What's happening to the rooftops of TriBeCa? They are increasingly becoming hosts to penthouses -- little buildings perched atop big ones.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; Bridgehampton
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON is home to the Hampton Classic Horse Show and perennial state high school basketball champions, the Killer Bees. Hanging-on-for-dear-life, the Bridgehampton Race Circuit will not be operating this season but will offer private schools for interested thrill seekers.

title: A Site for Modern-Day Scientific Voyagers
description: The HMS Beagle is named not after a dog but the ship Charles Darwin sailed to the Galapagos Islands, a journey that led to his theory of evolution. Biomednet of New York hired Sarah Greene, a publisher of an acclaimed series of books on the life sciences, to designa site that would woo doctors and health researchers to buy articles from Biomednet's professional data base.

title: POSTINGS: $10 Million Campus Centerpiece With 5 'Socratic' Classrooms; Pace Plans to Add Law School Building in Fall
description: Expected to be completed by the fall, a $10 million classroom building will be the centerpiece of the Pace University School of Law campus at 78 North Broadway in White Plains.

title: Performances by Children, a Show for Children
description: THE Litchfield Chamber Orchestra calls it a season this afternoon with a 3 o'clock concert at the Congregational Church, the program including Schubert's Symphony No. 1 and with several members of the ensemble as soloists Haydn's Notturno and a concerto grosso by William Boyce. For a performance of Karl Stamitz's Viola Concerto, however, the group's music director, Maurice Steinberg, has invited Dawn Hannay, a member of the New York Philharmonic, to be the guest artist.

title: Bikini Line Battle
description: Bikini season is only weeks away, and Tend Skin, a product that reduces razor bumps, ingrown hairs and razor burn, has become a hot commodity at skin-care salons. It's a clear liquid that's swabbed onto the bikini line before and after waxing, shaving and electrolysis. ''Tend Skin is the only thing I've ever found that works for the bikini line,'' said Diane Higgins, who sells it for $18 in her salon, Beauty Basics, at 1166 Lexington Avenue (80th Street). What's the magic ingredient? Acetylsalicyate -- plain old aspirin. ''The aspirin acts as an astringent and squeezes the hair follicle, causing the hair to exit the pores and straighten out so it can be cut off or removed by waxing or electrolysis,'' explained Doug Keeling, sales manager of the Tend Skin Company in Davies, Fla. The product also helps reduce facial razor bumps in men. Tend Skin is also available for $20 by calling (800) 940-8423. ELIZABETH HAYT

title: Q&A/Richard D. Parsons; From Law to President of Time Warner
description: RICHARD D. PARSONS, Nelson A. Rockefeller's personal lawyer and prodigy, was someone the former Vice President thought should someday be a nominee to the Supreme Court of the United States. But Mr. Parsons's career went a different way. He gave up law, became a chief executive officer at a bank and in 1994 was made president of Time Warner. As such, he played a key role in the negotiations that led last year to the media giant's purchase of Ted Turner's cable network, including Cable News Network.

title: Whence The Beef?
description: So dense are the annals of hamburger history that divining the time and place that ground beef was first made into patties is about as likely as identifying a single cell of E. coli in a ton of chopped meat.

title: The Pink-and-Green Police
description: BANISH the black dress: it is not true Lilly.

title: How Windsor II Saw A Treasure in Chrysler
description: LEAVE it to a chronic collector of classic cars to make one of the biggest killings in the biggest industrial merger ever, the marriage of Daimler-Benz, parent of Mercedes-Benz, and Chrysler, the No. 3 Detroit auto maker.

title: Stephanie Dunne, Christopher Cohen
description: Stephanie Jill Dunne, the daughter of Gail Glickman of Boca Raton, Fla., and Steven P. Dunne of New York, was married last evening to Christopher Eric Cohen, a son of Margery Rubin and Robert S. Cohen, both of New York. Rabbi Sarah Reines officiated at the Mark Hotel in New York.

title: Being 13; Popular Culture
description: It's probably not a coincidence that America's largest shopping mall, the Mall of America, is just three miles from Edina, Minn., a suburb of Minneapolis. With two middle schools where shopping is a prime leisure-time activity, Edina does its part for America's youth-driven consumer culture. The students shown here, from South View and Valley View Middle Schools, are concerned with the things that teen-agers have always been concerned with: who's in and who's out, what's in and what's out, competitive sports and, not least, academic achievement.

title: Philharmonic to Appear at School
description: TWO conductors, two soloists, and it is all free: that is the outlook today at 3 P.M. when the Yonkers Philharmonic appears at Saunders Trades and Technical High School in Yonkers. The guest conductor, Stephanie Merkado-Weiss, a Hartsdale resident and orchestra director at Ossining High School, opens the program with Mozart's ''Eine Kleine Nachtmusik'' after which the music director, Jerome Sala, leads the guest soloist, Toshihiko Kono, in the First Cello Concerto by Saint-Saens. The other soloist, Christine Kwak, who was only 10 when she played the Paganini Violin Concerto with the orchestra two years ago, play the Mendelssohn E minor Concerto. The ''Polovtsian Dances'' from Borodin's ''Prince Igor'' concludes the program.

title: Closely Guarded Secrets: Some Islands You Can't Get to Visit
description: STANDING on the shores of the East End, you can see across the water to some of Long Island's greatest treasures, tantalizingly close yet forbiddingly inaccessible.

title: Ms. Miller, Mr. Hutchinson
description: Lesley Shane Miller, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barnett M. Miller of Mount Vernon, N.Y., is to be married today to Richard Julian Hutchinson, a son of Margaret M. Hutchinson and Dr. James H. Hutchinson, both of Bethesda, Md. Cantor David Benedict is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; Shelter Island
description: SHELTER ISLAND history has been tragically altered with the first murder in memory, weeks ago. As the island is proving, life goes on. Partying goes on at Sunset Beach, the 90-room motel, bistro and snack bar on Crescent Beach. Some of the kitchen staff at Balthazar in Soho will move to the island for the summer. And to top it off, there'll be a weekend DJ. What more could you ask?

title: Using Thin Air To Let Buildings Grow Taller
description: MORE and more, the castles in the air rising around New York City are a combination of one landlord's castle and another landlord's air.

title: Angelo's Many Pizza Relatives (It's Easier With a Pie Chart)
description: Sorting out the complicated web of John Pashalis's family-run pizza parlors might call for a genealogical chart. Mr. Pashalis added another branch to his family restaurant tree last Month when he opened Angelo's Pizza, at 117 West 57th Street. For 22 years, Mr. Pashalis worked with Nick Angelis, a cousin who owns Pizza Chef in Brooklyn and Nick's Pizza in Forest Hills, Queens. (Angelo's is named for Nick's father, who used to own the Pizza Chef.) Other relatives own four of the Patsy's Pizza Restaurants in Manhattan.

title: Sincere Flattery Is Afoot
description: Great, Tretorns are back! But wait, what's that Nike swoosh doing on the side?

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Classical Brief
description: J.S. BACH: CHORAL WORKS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHERT, HENRY GEORGE, JR.
description: REICHERT-Henry George, Jr. Of Baldwin on May 15, 1998. Sergeant U.S. Marine Corp. Retired from the New York Times after 30 years of employment. Beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Mark, Craig and the late Gary. Loving grandfather of Todd. Dearest son of May. Dear brother of Dorothy Schellhaas. Reposing at Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave., Baldwin. Visiting hours Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Services Monday 10 AM at Bethlehem Lutheran Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to A.L.S. Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEKNIGHT, AVEL C.
description: DeKNIGHT-Avel C., May 15, 1995. Remembered, brilliant artistic talents extinguished far too soon, your lyrical mirage, Mediterranean and Monument series and the rest of your remarkable art work is a living legacy. Rene, Frances, Stephen, Lynn

title: Corrections
description: An excerpt from an essay by Dani Shapiro last Sunday carried an incomplete credit. The essay ''New Jersey, 1963'' was included in the book ''A Place Called Home: Twenty Writing Women Remember,'' edited by Mickey Pearlman.

title: A Blue-Collar Horse Reaches the Verge of Greatness
description: As Kent Desormeaux crossed under the wire with Real Quiet following their victory in today's Preakness Stakes, he thrust a fist into the air and alternated flashing two fingers and then a lone index finger.

title: City's Head Is in Sand On Fresh Kills Closing
description: To the Editor:

title: Call It Lasik, A Return To Normal Vision
description: EVERY once in awhile, Sandy Riddle does this funny move with her fingers up the profile of her nose, as if she's adjusting an imaginary pair of eyeglasses. It's not surprising. For more than 20 years, she needed very thick lenses to see. As of December, however, she has better than 20/20 vision.

title: A Republican With Rough Edges
description: I am prepared to vote for my first Republican, John Kasich (''A Republican With Rough Edges,'' by R.W. Apple Jr., April 26). I have the impression that he favors no-nonsense politics, equity for the common man and fiscal restraint, a rare combination in this politically combative era. Here's an open invitation for him to hold one of his sit-down discussions at my house.

title: Insufficient Funds and the I.R.S.
description: THERE is dumb. There is dumber. And then there is bouncing a check off the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article last Sunday about East Brunsick High School students who won a civics competition in Washington misidentified the school's principal. The principal is Benedict Tantillo; Amy Fisher is the spokeswoman for the school district.

title: 'Cities of the Plain'
description: Late that night lying in his bunk in the dark he heard the kitchen door close and heard the screendoor close after it. He lay there. Then he sat and swung his feet to the floor and got his boots and his jeans and pulled them on and put on his hat and walked out. The moon was almost full and it was cold and late and no smoke rose from the kitchen chimney. Mr Johnson was sitting on the back stoop in his ducking coat smoking a cigarette. He looked up at John Grady and nodded. John Grady sat on the stoop beside him. What are you doin out here without your hat? he said.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Nolita; A Slice of Little Italy Moving Upscale
description: NO ONE is quite certain what to call this part of town. Nolita -- north of Little Italy, that is -- certainly pinpoints it geographically. The not-quite-acronym was apparently coined several years ago by real-estate brokers seeking to give the area at least a little cachet.

title: Streetscapes/East 80th Street Between Fifth and Madison Avenues; Town-House Block Returning to Single-Family Use
description: ALTHOUGH it originally had some of the largest private houses on any side street on the East Side, 20 years ago only two or three of the 20 town houses on 80th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues were single-family residences. In the last decade, however, a wave of renovation has more than doubled the number, as a new group of owners restores the block.

title: Ignoring Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime
description: Kinsey Millhone is great fun when she's out on a limb. In Sue Grafton's ''N'' IS FOR NOOSE (Marian Wood/Holt, $25), the cocky private eye nearly gets her head handed to her by the inbred natives of Nota Lake, a little burg in rural California that was founded by colonial-era convicts in exile. (''The worst of 'em came west and settled in these mountains,'' the townies are proud to tell her.) Having been summoned to this backwater on an innocuous quest -- a widow wants to know what made her husband so stressed-out that he had a heart attack on the highway -- Kinsey is nonplused to find herself ignored, insulted and attacked by the grumpy locals.

title: The Summer People
description: GOD BLESS THE CHILD By Ellen Feldman. 251 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: The Women Behind the Nameplates
description: They are the city's women of mystery: Pauline on Morningside Avenue, Lucille on West 135th Street, Bertha on West 111th; names carved over the doors of apartment houses.

title: Being 13; On-Line Confidential
description: LeonardoDiCapriofan: 'I think I like getting to know Internet people -- 'cause even if they were ugly or had a disease, that wouldn't matter. I would like to get to know people better starting from the inside.'

title: Children's Books in Brief; Bananas With Everything
description: Anthony Browne's hero in Willy the Dreamer (Candlewick, $16.99; ages 3 and up) is a mild, unassuming chimpanzee with a marvelous imagination. When Willy falls asleep in his easy chair, we are invited to visit his fabulous dream world. Here we see some odd dreams familiar to all of us -- you try to run but your feet stick to the ground, or you feel all out of proportion, way too large or too small for your surroundings. In this book, the fifth about Willy, we visit his daydreams as he wonders what it might be like to be a beggar or a king. And we share Willy's memories of his infancy and his fantasies of his future life as a father. In one picture, Browne, a British artist with an international reputation, makes it clear that Willy's dreams are all vivid and exciting, but the people watching television are pale and expressionless. The simple text provides a minimal accompaniment to the gorgeous watercolor paintings. There are beautifully subtle underwater scenes; lush, exotic jungles; and bizarre, surreal landscapes. And running through the books is a hilarious banana motif, with bananas serving some ingenious function on every page. While young readers are busy searching for bananas in disguise, grown-ups will enjoy identifying the artists and writers to whom Browne pays homage, finding the influences of Dali, Magritte, Henri Rousseau, Lewis Carroll, Robert Louis Stevenson and others displayed with great wit. This is a wonderful and thought-provoking book, encouraging us to take a moment, close our eyes, and see what we can see. Robin Tzannes

title: Hoofers
description: Cole Porter wrote his first original Hollywood score for the 1936 film BORN TO DANCE, and it's a honey, with hits like ''Easy to Love'' and ''I've Got You Under My Skin.'' The boy-meets-girl story of a shy sailor (James Stewart) and a shy, rising star (Eleanor Powell) is highlighted by song-and-dance rehearsal and show numbers. Under Roy del Ruth's direction, the rest of the cast, including Virginia Bruce, Frances Langford and Buddy Ebsen, add to the geniality. The rich orchestrations make it all sound wonderful -- and Powell, with her clattering shoes and dazzling smile, is an appealing heroine. If only she had closed her mouth -- just once! -- WEDNESDAY at 6 A.M. on TMC. Howard Thompson

title: The World: Pitching Peace; Imagine Politics Without TV. Now Think About Ireland.
description: IF opponents of the peace accord that will be put to referendum here and in the Republic of Ireland on Friday were looking for the perfect 30-second television commercial to make their point, they need not go farther than the 1988 Presidential campaign in the United States. Their model could be the infamous Willie Horton commercial declaring that Michael S. Dukakis, as Governor of Massachusetts, let a murderer go free on a weekend pass.

title: Real Quiet Has 2 Legs Up on Triple Crown
description: Two weeks after he won the Kentucky Derby in an upset, Real Quiet came back today to win the 123d Preakness, putting him one race away from becoming the 12th horse to sweep the Triple Crown.

title: PULSE; Globe-Trotter Bag
description: For years, European hipsters have been sporting bags and backpacks designed by the Tokyo-born industrial designer Makio Husuike. Envious New Yorkers had to go abroad to get the goods, bearing the subtle MH logo, at MH Way boutiques in Milan and Paris. But now, thanks to a California distributor, the MH Way pieces are available in America, much to the glee of accessories aficionados. ''I discovered these bags five years ago in Milan and have worn them ever since,'' Antonio DaMotta Leal, an interior and product designer, said. Like the backpack shown here (Vespa line, $210), all bags are made from neoprenelike material, which is water repellent and resists staining and tearing. The bags and packs, priced from $115 to $215, are available by calling (877) 466-4929 (toll free). RIMA SUQUI

title: Christina Prunier and David Doss
description: THE executive producer of NBC's ''Nightly News With Tom Brokaw,'' David Doss, is known for combining the looks of Val Kilmer with the organizational skills and wardrobe of a military man.

title: Everybody Starts Out Small
description: EMILY JUST IN TIME

title: The Royal Shakespeare: Renewing Itself Under Fire
description: THE Royal Shakespeare Company, the great theater ensemble that has served as a cradle for gifted directors and actors, is showing signs of a midlife crisis. It can still produce work of excellence, but to some critics it is not as daring or consistently accomplished as it once was. Among the charges: misconceived productions and a predictable roster of Shakespeare war horses that lacks star directors and actors.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YEGEN, GLADYS (DR. GLADYS WINTER)
description: YEGEN-Gladys (Dr. Gladys Winter). Memorial will be held on May 30 at 2PM at the Clinton Inn, 145 Dean Drive, Tenafly, N.J.

title: What's New in the Hamptons and the North Fork for '98; Noyac
description: NOYAC locals are already touting O'Malley's as their ''home away from home.''The pub's newest location, a staple in Amagansett, has another hit on its hands at the Waterside on Noyac Road. Waterside Catering will still throw parties in the downstairs portion of the building with O'Malley's using the upstairs, overlooking Noyac Bay.

title: Argentina Arrests 8 Iranians and Ousts 7 in Anti-Jewish Bombings
description: The Argentine Government, saying it is nearing a breakthrough in the investigation of two bombings of Jewish centers in recent years, has arrested eight Iranian residents and ordered the expulsion of seven of Iran's eight embassy employees stationed here.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: We Are Our Mothers' Daughters

title: Origin of Species
description: To the Editor:

title: Fewer Fish and Dwindling Lives
description: THE life of an East End bayman has never been easy. Even in the good years, when shellfish blanketed the bay bottoms and fin fish were plentiful and free of pollutants, it was difficult, often dangerous work. The hours -- from early morning to late at night -- were a test of endurance.

title: A Dowager Loosens Up
description: WHEN the Hispanic Society of America was founded in 1904, Washington Heights was rich and rural, just the place for the Hispanophile son of a railroad baron to house his works by El Greco, Goya and Velasquez. As the neighborhood grew poorer and more Hispanic, the society gained a reputation for being out of touch and out of place. Like a stranded dowager, the Beaux-Arts temple at 155th Street and Broadway found itself across the street from Broadway Tire and Maria's Beauty Salon.

title: In Greece
description: To the Editor: Having enjoyed a 12-day visit to Athens in February, I turned to ''What's Doing in Athens'' on April 26. Looking first at the Vital Statistics box, I was amazed to see that the average hotel price for one was given as $210.50 a night (not a week). The tiny print at the bottom led me to believe that Runzheimer was the source of that figure, and that the people who travel on business obviously aren't real folks.

title: The Nation: Corporate America Plays Scrabble; Name That Behemoth
description: IT is wedding season on Wall Street, and the most vexing issue faced by titans of industry as they prepare to tie the corporate knot is the same one pondered by a modern bride-to-be: Should she take his name? Keep her own? Hyphenate?

title: Mara Schwartz, Jeffrey Einstein
description: Mara Schwartz and Jeffrey Paul Einstein are to be married today by Rabbi Marcia Rappaport at Coindre Hall, a historic house in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Mendoza Discovers His Pitch, and Now He's Dominating
description: The nickname bestowed upon Ramiro Mendoza long ago was El Brujo, the Witch Doctor, a moniker with added significance now that he has discovered his own personal formula for success.

title: Cute, Packaged? Sure. But They're Talented.
description: EVERY time I leave an interview with Hanson, I wonder whether I've been had. The three of them are always a little too mature for their age, a little too down-to-earth about their success, a little too perfect in their answers and attitudes. They never slip up. Any attempt to prove that they are a manufactured phenomenon, that their parents put them up to it, that their music comes from anywhere or anyone other than themselves is instantly and candidly defeated. It's not that I want to expose Hanson. I like Hanson. I'm not talking about finding its hit ''MMMBop'' a great hummable novelty along the lines of ''Yummy Yummy Yummy.'' I'm talking about the album, the band, the harmonies, the musical craft. And everybody I talk to -- be they friends, relatives, supermarket baggers or colleagues who haven't really listened to the band -- tells me I must be kidding. I'm not.

title: What's what, where and when in New York's great playground
description: THE DAIRY is a good first stop in Central Park. This information center, mid-park at 65th Street, carries maps, books and brochures, and shows informational videos. (The Dairy, a one-story wooden building, never had cows; in the 19th century, milk from New Jersey was sold there to children.) Hours: Tuesday through Sunday 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; (212) 794-6564.

title: Mr. Feynman Wasn't Joking
description: THE MEANING OF IT ALL

title: Nuclear Programs Built on Deceit and Fear
description: India and Pakistan have been working to build a bomb for decades. Until this week, their nuclear programs were powerful symbols of modernity for two poor nations. They are not mere symbols anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNENBAUM, GERTRUDE (KITTY)
description: TANNENBAUM-Gertrude (Kitty), 97 years. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Carol and George Kaplan and Marian and Jay Grossman. Loving grandmother of James, Jill, John, Susan, and Robert. Cherished great-grandmother of six. Service 11am Sunday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: All of Lucca
description: To the Editor: I agree generally with Annasue McCleave Wilson that there are no heart-stopping paintings to see in Lucca (''Puccini's Stage: All of Lucca,'' March 15), but it is a great place for lovers of Romanesque-Gothic ecclesiastical architecture, and especially of Gothic and Renaissance sculpture, both inside churches and on their facades (binoculars help).

title: Here We Go Again
description: It is often argued that nuclear weapons have no redeeming value, and that any state that goes nuclear is engaging in dangerous and self-defeating behavior. Thus, President Clinton maintains that India's recent nuclear tests were a ''terrible mistake.'' The implication is that nuclear weapons should be eliminated altogether.

title: From Brazil, the Echoes Of a Modernist Revolt
description: ''BRAZIL, what a funny country,'' said the Brazilian singer Tom Ze a few weeks ago. He was in New York to mix his new album and took a break to remember his homeland's response 30 years ago to the beginnings of Tropicalia, a Modernist movement that encompassed visual art, architecture, poetry, drama and especially popular music. It was part of his own history; one of his songs can be found on the newly available 1968 album called ''Tropicalia,'' a collaborative document that includes the other musicians and composers central to the movement like Caetano Veloso, Gilberto Gil, Gal Costa, Rogerio Duprat and the band Os Mutantes (the Mutants).

title: In a Self-Centered City, Life Styles of the Communal
description: THE SETTING -- A panel discussion on the practicalities of communal living in New York City, held at the Libertarian Book Club's Anarchist Forum at 122 West 27th Street. The event last Tuesday drew socialists, squatters, radical Roman Catholics, veteran commune members and other unconventional types.

title: New Means to Friendship: the House Sitter
description: IT used to be that, come Labor Day, summer residents of the Hamptons would drain the pipes, board up their cottages and head home.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Redemption at the Auto Show
description: Words take on uncommon qualities in the poet Diane Glancy's brief new novel, FLUTIE (Moyer Bell, $18.95). The title character is an adolescent girl, part Cherokee and part German, who is so plagued by anxiety and shyness that she can barely speak. Meanwhile, ''her mother shot words that hit her. Flutie picked them up from the floorboard and put them in her mouth. She chewed the brass casing of a cartridge.'' Glancy's prose is studded with such moments, in which metaphors solidify into physical objects. Flutie is said to have thrown her tongue into a pond when she stopped speaking -- and, in the context of the mystical Oklahoma landscape that surrounds her, it seems natural enough that the severed tongue then swam away like a fish. The novel's plot is almost impossibly spare, but the impoverished existence of Flutie's family and the difficulties imposed by its mingled ancestry are so richly detailed that the reader quickly comes to understand Flutie's solipsistic, dysfunctional and sometimes euphoric state of mind. At an auto show, for example, she senses a redemptive bridge between the clouds, where her mind so often dwells, and the daily sensation of speeding along the highway: ''There was transformation. There was hope. Cars were the angels of America. They were full of invisible wings. Chevys. Fords. Plymouths. Buicks. Studebakers. Restored. Rebuilt. Customized. Polished. Worshiped.'' It is surprising images like these that make Glancy's account of Flutie's world so unexpectedly satisfying. Elizabeth Gaffney

title: May 10-16; Introducing . . . Cyber Boris
description: Boris N. Yeltsin routinely turns down interviews with the Western press, but he just loves to surprise an audience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CONSTANCE KAUFMAN
description: SOLOMON-Constance Kaufman. Connie - an extraordinary wife, mother, grandmother, human being, who immeasurably enriched the lives of all who knew her. She will be terribly missed. With love, Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro

title: Please Mr. Postman
description: P.S. LONGER LETTER LATER By Paula Danziger and Ann M. Martin. 234 pp. New York: Scholastic Press. $15.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, MARY PATRICE
description: WHITE-Mary Patrice. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Cherished mother of Janis and David. Mother-in-law of Robert Sale. Grandmother of Peter, Andrew, Ricky, Chris and Mike Sale and Jimmy, Patrick and Ellen White. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM, and funeral service Monday, 10 AM, at the Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, NY.

title: In the Movies, Older Boy Gets Girl
description: AMONG the movies coming this summer amid the meteors hurtling toward Earth and Godzilla clomping through New York City -- are a host of older men romancing a bevy of women young enough to be their daughters. It's enough to make women in the much-celebrated prime of life join the N.R.A.

title: Visual Poetry in the Spirit of a Rock Video
description: MOST of us don't watch MTV because we're too old, which is to say we're over 12. But, happily, Pipilotti Rist has watched MTV for us. A 36-year-old Swiss artist who has won much acclaim in Europe, she takes the pop form of the music video and does poetical things with it. Her videos have lush visual effects and larkish, sometimes nutty heroines whose activities decidedly do not include fabled Swiss pastimes like eating fondue or scaling the slopes of some alp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISELS, RAPHAEL
description: MEISELS-Raphael. On May 14, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Zelda. Beloved father of Deborah, Naomi and Anna. Cherished grandfather of ten and great grandfather of nine. Former District Director of Internal Revenue, Chairman of H. Hentz & Company, Honorary Chairman Emeritus of Shearson American Express and longtime Member and Treasurer of the Dessoff Choir. Service on Sunday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Central Park Conservancy.

title: Driver With Sex Change Finds Her Career Stalled
description: For more than a year, Terri O'Connell has been tireless in her pursuit of a sponsor. She spends hours on the phone daily. She spends even longer preparing and mailing proposals, trying to come up with the money she needs to resume her career as a race car driver.

title: Beyond Finger Paint
description: If there's one thing that children dislike even more than spinach, it's probably art museums. They're both good for you, the surest way to induce aversion. It's curious, then, that books geared for junior esthetes are so numerous as to amount to an honest-to-goodness phenomenon; in the past decade, at least nine publishers have started their own series of children's art books. While little museumgoers (at least male ones) have always discerned a romance in dinosaur bones and suits of armor, when, exactly, did Monet's blurry water lilies, Mondrian's chaste rectangles and Picasso's precisely butchered demoiselles appear on the list of childhood passions?

title: Mary Bishop, Andrew Schenkel
description: Mary Katherine Bishop was married yesterday to Andrew Chance Schenkel at St. Christopher's by the Sea, an Episcopal chapel in Gibson Island, Md. The Rev. Robert D. Schenkel, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony.

title: School Aide's Death Grows Into Case of Multiple Mysteries
description: Midwood High School prides itself on a culture of achievement. Students come from outside the district for its special humanities and premed programs. This year, the school had more semifinalists in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search than any school in the country. It is not a place where misbehavior is common, and violent incidents have been unheard of there, many say.

title: Jennifer Donaldson, Thomas Janes
description: Jennifer Ann Donaldson and Thomas Warham Janes were married last evening at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington. The Rev. William L. George performed the ceremony.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEON, LILLIE (NEE KORNHABER)
description: LEON-Lillie (nee Kornhaber). On May 16, 1998. Passed away peacefully, early Saturday morning. Devoted wife of the late Jacob. Beloved mother of Carla and Tonia. Cherished grandmother of Danny, Jeff, Jessica and David. Proud great-grandmother of Jacob. She was a lover of learning and of nature. Service Monday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Please make donations to Planting Trees In Israel, Jewish National Fund, 1-800542-8733, or donation to your local library in her name.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz C43 and Chrysler 300M: Star Vehicles, Suddenly Related by Marriage; A Chrysler With the Flair Of Europe
description: THE Imperial was overthrown, the New Yorker retired to Florida, the Fifth Avenue lost its lease. So the Chrysler brand has been searching for a new flagship, a luxury car that sums up what the nameplate stands for and casts a halo over the plainer models in a Chrysler showroom.

title: Bettina Elias, Martin Siegel
description: Bettina Elias and Martin Jonathan Siegel are to be married today by Rabbi Gordon Yaffe at the Americas Society in New York.

title: In Bridgeport, It's Time to Play Ball Once Again
description: ON Thursday, a new sports era begins for Bridgeport when the Bluefish play their first professional baseball game in the new Atlantic League. An opening-day sellout is assured; all 5,300 seats in the new stadium, the Ballpark at Harbor Yard, have been sold for the 4:05 P.M. opener against the Newark Bears. Pre-game ceremonies with Gov. John G. Rowland and Mayor Joseph P. Ganim will begin at 2:15.

title: CityHawks Win In Final Seconds
description: With three seconds left on the clock last night, Mike Perez passed 26 yards to James Bowden to give the visiting CityHawks a 42-38 victory over the Florida Bobcats in West Palm Beach.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 6/

title: The World; From Guru to Rogue: America Re-Examines India
description: JOHN KENNETH GALBRAITH remembers India as a nation that ''stood apart and above the conflicts of the world,'' scorning arms races and alliances. ''That was very much the tradition of Gandhi and Nehru,'' he said last week, as the United States imposed sanctions after five nuclear explosions shook the Thar desert of Rajasthan -- and Mr. Galbraith's faith in a country where he was ambassador more than 30 years ago. ''There was a strong feeling here that they took a position that was related to the survival of us all. That's why India was sought out so much.''

title: Let's Rescue Poor Schumann From His Rescuers
description: DON'T look now, but Robert Schumann is being rescued again. This time the deliverers are John Eliot Gardiner and the Orchestre Revolutionnaire et Romantique, his period-instrument ensemble, performing the four numbered ''canonical'' symphonies, plus the early unfinished one in G minor (in somebody's eclectic conflation of its two extant sources); the original 1841 version of the Fourth; the Overture, Scherzo and Finale, and the ''Konzertstuck'' in F for four horns and orchestra, all in a three-CD Archiv set (457 591-2).

title: As an Institution Empties, Community Fears Force Nine Men Back
description: After years of preparation, the state Department of Human Services has closed the North Princeton Developmental Center, a turn-of-the-century institution in Somerset County that had served as a home of last resort for tens of thousands of people with mental retardation, cerebral palsy, autism and other problems that are now grouped under the designation ''developmental disabilities.''

title: Plea for Green For Men in Blue: Some See Red
description: Two weeks ago, Allan Costas got a call at his furniture shop in Long Island City, Queens, from a man asking him to place an ad in the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police quarterly newspaper.

title: Antitrust Talks With Microsoft Are Called Off
description: Negotiations between the Microsoft Corporation and state and Federal officials collapsed today after the company's chairman, William H. Gates, ordered lawyers to withdraw earlier concessions, and Justice Department officials said they intended to file a sweeping antitrust suit on Monday.

title: The Object of My Obsession
description: IDENTITY By Milan Kundera. Translated by Linda Asher. 168 pp. New York: Harper Flamingo/ HarperCollins Publishers. $23.

title: Texans Coping With Smoke Cloud From Fires in Mexico
description: With a tickle in the throat, an itch in the eye and a bit of a wheeze in the lungs, Texans have been coping with an extraordinary weeklong health alert brought on by smoke and haze from uncontrolled fires thousands of miles away in Mexico.

title: From Oil to Fish to the Internet: Zapata Tries Another Incarnation
description: Alice Bradley sits at a desk in the very office in midtown Manhattan from which she was laid off months ago, back at her job as the editor of the on-line sports magazine Charged. When the publication, and its culture-watching sister, Word, were shut down by the owner, Icon CMT, in March, hopes were slim for finding a buyer to revive the Webzines.

title: Pakistan Seems Mixed On Holding Nuclear Test
description: Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan said today that Pakistan has decided to begin testing nuclear weapons in response to India's tests last week, but other Government officials were less clear on whether a decision had been made.

title: Poised Pak Completes a Wire-to-Wire Victory
description: It was difficult to determine what was most intriguing about Se Ri Pak -- her poise, her performance or her potential.

title: Peter Falk's Search for Meaning
description: No lightning flashes of insight, no revelations of divine patterns and not even a smidgeon of what the self-help psychologists and talk show hosts refer to as closure. The view from the threshold of death is simply murky in ''Mr. Peters' Connections,'' Arthur Miller's portrait of the interior of the mind of an ailing old man, which opened last night at the Signature Theater.

title: Insurers Swindled Jews, Nazi Files Show
description: In an outburst of anti-Semitic violence that presaged the Holocaust, mobs incited by the Nazis rampaged through Berlin and other German cities on Nov. 9 and 10, 1938, smashing and torching an estimated 171 synagogues and thousands of Jewish shops and homes.

title: Bill Sale Is Only Item on Treasury Schedule
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: In Another Game, Leiter Shows He's Fallible
description: Al Leiter said he did not want to say anything uncomplimentary about his hitters. But the tall left-hander, and every other Mets starter, can be forgiven if their patience is wearing thin.

title: The Endless Unknown
description: The recent discovery of huge bursts of gamma radiation coming from far away in the universe is one of those mind-stretching advances that astronomers seem to be making with increasing regularity. Like so many of the greatest discoveries of modern astronomy, like pulsars and quasars, gamma-ray bursts were entirely unexpected when they were first seen a few years ago.

title: Biology Theory Slights Other Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He won't forget it. He'll think about it every day, like I do.''

title: Gimmicks, Glamour And Guts At Cannes
description: Ersatz Blues Brothers were carried down this city's main boulevard yesterday by a Volvo, as if more proof were needed that the Cannes International Film Festival is not quite itself this year. John Travolta's bodyguard was one of the luminaries mentioned in accounts of Wednesday night's opening ceremony, which featured ''Primary Colors.'' Filmmakers giving interviews are liable to be asked less about mise en scene than about the death of Frank Sinatra. On the 30th anniversary of the student uprising that shut down this festival, a poster vendor along the Croisette is selling 22 different portraits of Leonardo DiCaprio, 5 of the Simpsons, 3 of the Spice Girls, 2 of Bob Marley, 1 of Che Guevara and 1 of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Penn Pulls an Upset
description: The Penn men's varsity eight surprised everyone by leading from start to finish to capture the Eastern Sprints' main race yesterday on Lake Quinsigamond in Worcester, Mass., and prevent a Princeton sweep of the regatta.

title: After Midnight, a Radio Talk Show Is Growing Coast to Coast
description: Insomniacs, truckers and graveyard workers already know Art Bell, a talk-show host who in five years has become the star of late-night AM radio by encouraging his audience to share tales of strange phenomena.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 7 about a picnic sponsored each year by Thomas Stewart of Seattle for the King County Republican Party included an outdated reference to a Defense Department review of Food Services of America, a company he heads. The department concluded on April 14 that the company met standards for doing business with the Government, despite past penalties for selling tainted meat and poultry. The article also described the refreshments incorrectly. No alcohol is served.

title: A Garden Caught in a Housing Squeeze
description: Gardeners look at the corner of Crimmins Avenue and East 141st Street in the Bronx and marvel at the transformation of a vacant, garbage-strewn lot frequented by drug dealers into the garden of their dreams. There are flowers, vegetables and herbs. There are tables for dominoes, a scampering puppy and even a chicken coop.

title: People
description: * Andy McQuin will join Ammirati Puris Lintas, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as regional director for Central and Eastern Europe and chief executive of the office in Budapest. He had been worldwide client director on the SmithKline Beecham account at Ogilvy & Mather London, part of WPP Group P.L.C. As regional director, Mr. McQuin succeeds Dieter Lockemann, who is retiring after 34 years with the agency. At the Budapest office, Mr. McQuin succeeds Pierre-Emmanuel Maire, who moves to the London office of Ammirati Puris for a new post on the Unilever account.

title: Well-Known Korean-American Couple Are Shot and Critically Hurt in Queens
description: A husband and wife who were described as well-known Korean-Americans in Queens were in critical condition last night after each was shot in the head while in their Lexus in the Elmhurst section.

title: Clinton Seeks to Limit Effects of India's Test by Pressing Yeltsin on Arms Pact
description: President Clinton urged President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today to press for the ratification of a pending nuclear weapons treaty even as the United States and its allies searched for ways to head off a nuclear arms race between India and Pakistan.

title: Which Art Is Best?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reaffirming the Graham Legacy
description: The planets came together auspiciously in a celebration of Martha Graham's art and legacy by the Library of Congress this weekend. ''Appalachian Spring,'' a Graham signature piece choreographed to an equally famous score by Aaron Copland, was performed for the first time in 54 years on the same stage where it had its premiere on Oct. 30, 1944. Graham's archetypes of the American frontier reaffirmed their faith in the future again. But here, in the library's intimate Coolidge Auditorium, the work's sculptural and architectural qualities came into sharper relief than in a larger standard theater.

title: WHERE FEAR LINGERS: A special report.; A Neighborhood Gives Peace a Wary Look
