description: In Washington Heights, until recently one of New York's most murderous communities, a disturbing truth reveals itself in the empty stoops on West 162d Street in late afternoon, in the thinly peopled parks overlooking the Harlem River, in the greetings not exchanged by lifelong neighbors on Audubon Avenue:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ALBERT, PETER
description: D'ALBERT-Peter. Of Locust Valley, L.I., suddenly on May 15, 1998. Age 78. Former husband of Margaret Towne, father of Richard B., Kevin T. and Maria K., brother of Susanna, Maria and Babetta. Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Thursday, May 21, at 11 AM.

title: Too Late on Indonesia
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Harpsichord, a Night of High Drama
description: Rameau was a man of the theater long before he wrote his first opera. His keyboard music is a continuing act of joyous display, filled with the high drama of crossing hands, brilliant runs and wide musical spaces. Rameau's harpsichord pieces are about people, places, moods and other instruments; and despite the formalities of the late Baroque esthetic, the pungency of his observations comes through, even reaching to 20th-century ears long used to the precept of anything goes.

title: Alternative doorways to the Internet are popping up in the spirit of free-flowing information.
description: THERE were only a few snickers last week at a new-media conference in Chicago when someone asked a group of executives from Web-search companies which of them would be the first to buy a major television network. It was a sign of just how quickly the likes of Yahoo, Lycos, Excite and Infoseek have grown, how grand their mass media dreams have become and how much their original vision of the World Wide Web has changed.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Sports of The Times; Point Loma Yankees Are a Couple of Perfectionists
description: DON LARSEN was puttering around the house yesterday afternoon when the golf broadcaster said David Wells of the Yankees had just pitched a perfect game. That brought back a few thrills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMISH, HARRY
description: KAMISH-Harry. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father to Eugene, Lisa and husband Michel. Loving brother to May Krakow, husband Herman, and the late Sofia K. Levy. Cherished uncle of Robert, Lori, Marianne, Jarrad, Lara and Carly. Distinguished patriarch of our famly and his colleagues. He will always be the light that warmed our hearts and touched our spirits. His eloquent speeches and carefully chosen words of wisdom, always delivered with humor, made Harry everyone's favorite philosopher, guru, mentor and friend. Funeral services at Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Tuesday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to ACRMD, 345 Hudson Street, New York, NY 10014.

title: A Spectrum of Jewish Life on Parade
description: Many wore yarmulkes, some wore nose rings. There were throngs of teen-agers in color-coordinated T-shirts as well as crisp files of war veterans who had squeezed into old uniforms. As Holocaust survivors watched alongside children too young to have heard an ethnic slur, a panorama of American Jewish life overtook Fifth Avenue yesterday in celebration of 50 years of Israeli statehood.

title: Frank Ragano, 75, Lawyer for Mob and Hoffa
description: Frank Ragano, a lawyer for both a Florida mob chieftain and James R. Hoffa of the teamsters' union and later co-author of a book about his experiences with organized crime, died in his sleep on Wednesday at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, LILLIAN
description: STEINBERG-Lillian, R.N. Died peacefully May 14, 1998, at the age of 82. Devoted wife to the late Leo, beloved mother of Gail Jacobs and Richard, cherished grandmother of Hilary Jacobs, Amanda Wolf, Makaela and Ezra, greatgrandmother of Samantha, Kate, and Peyton Lee. A completely charming, loveable and adorable woman with great spirit, she gave us the gift of unconditional love and we shall miss her so very much.

title: Slugfest Is Last Thing That the N.B.A. Needs
description: In retaliation for the beating his team took in Game 1, the next, great star in the National Basketball Association -- the person enlisted to sell the product after Michael Jordan retires -- is threatening to use physical aggression rather than his low-post finesse.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Long Run, Jobs Help Students; Real-World Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: Baseball's Untouchable 15
description: David Wells's perfect game yesterday was only the 15th in major league history and the second on Yankees' history.

title: Luyendyk Is In
description: Arie Luyendyk, last year's winner, was one of the final seven drivers to qualify yesterday for next Sunday's Indianapolis 500. Luyendyk, who twice failed to get a spot on the starting grid in Saturday's first day of qualifying because of engine trouble, turned a fast lap of 219.352 miles an hour yesterday with the last available engine in his Dallara-Aurora.

title: Parents Object to Cardinal's Comments Over Sports on Sunday
description: The mere mention of John Cardinal O'Connor's name at Little League baseball fields in and around New York City yesterday drew the kind of ire from some parents that is usually reserved for opponents.

title: Aid Cuba, Not Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Rev. Walter Wagoner Sr., 79, Theology Educator
description: The Rev. Walter Dray Wagoner Sr., a leader in theological education, author and senior minister emeritus of the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., died on May 7 at Greenwich Hospital. He was 79 and lived in Greenwich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVEIS, NORA E. (NEE LACEY)
description: OVEIS-Nora E. (nee Lacey). On May 16, 1998. Of the Bronx and Holmes, NY. Wife of the late Frank. She is survived by her son Frank and his companion Thomas Struhs and by her son Dennis and his wife Ann and their son Alexander. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox and Sons, Inc., 201st Street and Grand Concourse, Bronx, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 AM, St. Philip Neri Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Report Says New York Cuts Environmental Enforcement
description: An exhaustive report by the Assembly's committee on the environment says that under Gov. George E. Pataki, New York State workers are spending far less time than they once did on crucial functions like enforcing environmental laws and managing resources like forests, wetlands and fisheries.

title: The Group of Seven Now Eight, Officially
description: This year, for the first time, the annual summit meeting of the world's seven major industrial democracies and Russia became formally known as the Group of Eight, reflecting the gradual effort to give Russia an expanded voice in global economic and political issues.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on Saturday, about reaction to the death of Frank Sinatra in his hometown of Hoboken, N.J., gave an incorrect surname for the owner of Leo's Grandevous, a bar. He is Leo di Terlizzi, not Leo Terlizzi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, HELEN (NEE HOCHHAUSER)
description: GREENFIELD-Helen (nee Hochhauser). Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted mother of Stanley and Ellen Greenfield. Dear sister of Jeanne Ellner and Rosalind Halpern. Loving grandmother of Jeff and Debi. Great-grandmother of Andrew, Matthew, Jamie. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Riverside Mt. Vernon. Information, ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Magazines Bowing to Demands for Star Treatment
description: Madonna wanted something material -- in writing, a contract. She would pose for Rolling Stone's 30th anniversary cover story on women in rock under certain conditions -- several single-spaced, typed pages of them to be exact. Among her terms: that she could approve the layout, approve the photographs and own the copyright to the photographs.

title: Remedial Lessons for CUNY
description: Where do you think you'll be 10 years from now?'' As my classmates turned to stare, the words caught me gazing out the window with nothing on my mind but that afternoon's game and that night's date. The blackboard was a blur of diagrammed sentences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIFKA, BELLE
description: SLIFKA-Belle. Devoted mother of Ruth Mindling, Lew Spence, and Evelyn Dilloff. Beloved grandmother of Jim Mindling, Leni Newman, Toni Schulman and Nancy Schlesinger. Loving greatgrandmother of Jessie Schulman, Abby Schulman, Rachel Schlesinger and Natasha Mindling. Born 1899, passed away peacefully in her sleep after a long and full life. Funeral private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSOHN, RANDOLPH
description: MENDELSOHN-Randolph. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Ray L. and Phyllis G., Kenneth O. and Jeri, Ellen M. and Ben Borenstein. Cherished grandfather of Leah, Justin, Benjamin, David, Jake, Zachary and Hannah. Loving brother of Miriam Lubar, Milton, Stewart and Seymour. Service 12 noon, Monday, Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Rd, Croton on Hudson.

title: Austin Koenen, an Authority On Public Finance, Dies at 56
description: Austin V. Koenen, a well-known Wall Street banker and public finance specialist who was chief executive of the China International Capital Corporation, an investment banking company owned by the Chinese Government and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, died early this month in Beijing. He was 56.

title: To Some of Indonesia's Poor, Looting Gives Taste of Power
description: All around the slum where he lives are the shattered and smoking ruins of stores that offer a vivid reminder of last week's riots, but Edy and his neighbors were feeling pretty flush today.

title: John Hawkes Is Dead at 72; An Experimental Novelist
description: John Hawkes, a veteran and highly praised author of avant-garde and experimental fiction, died on Friday at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 72 and lived in Providence.

title: The Boys of Spring
description: David Wells added the finishing touch to the New York Yankees' divine spring yesterday by pitching a perfect game against the Minnesota Twins. In a major league season ridiculed for thin pitching, Wells produced a masterpiece of a kind Yankee fans have not witnessed since Don Larsen retired every Dodger he faced in the 1956 World Series. Perhaps his artistry will even slow the unseemly rush to abandon Yankee Stadium.

title: Ulster's Fire-and-Brimstone Loyalist Preaches 'No!'
description: Commanding the stage the other night at a lectern draped with the British flag, the Rev. Ian Paisley issued a rallying cry so ferocious and frightening that you almost expected the 500 people crowded into a grand old hall to grab weapons and rush out to war -- not to their polling stations.

title: Long Before Microsoft's Internet War: A Peaceful Ethernet
description: Robert Metcalfe looks at the Microsoft civil war and other open hostilities in the software industry and remembers when the computer business was a kinder, gentler place to work.

title: Commencements; Carter Speaks of 'Chasm' Dividing Rich and Poor
description: Former President Jimmy Carter urged 477 graduates of Trinity College here today to remember victims of what he called the greatest form of discrimination in American society: ''rich people against poor people.''

title: I.R.S. Says Tax Refunds Are Up by 7.1%
description: The Treasury Department has sent out 7.1 percent more in tax refunds to taxpayers so far this year than in the comparable period in 1997, a jump that helped increase American consumer spending and the economy during the first quarter of 1998.

title: A Video Middleman as Shopkeeper, Too
description: Now, the revenge of the middlemen. Since the advent of on-line retailing, doomsayers have predicted failure for companies in the middle of the retail food chain -- wholesalers that distribute products to local stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBEY, VIRGINIA HARRISON
description: TOBEY-Virginia Harrison. Died peacefully on May 16, 1998, at age 93. Devoted wife of the late William Tobey. Loving mother of Charles, Jane (Addis) and Paul. Dear sister of Gladys Scroggins. Mother-in-law of Judy and Ronnie. Grandmother of Jackie, Emily, Deborah, Jesse, Michael, Eric and Brett, and great-grandmother of William, Justin and Lily. She touched all our lives with her warmth, generosity and sense of humor. We will always be inspired by her creativity. Services Wednesday, May 20, 2:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to the American Parkinsons Disease Foundation.

title: In Long Run, Jobs Help Students; Best Role for Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Leading Nations Discover Their Limits
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  The annual summit of leading industrialized nations here was designed by its host, Prime Minister Tony Blair, as an informal brainstorming session on the global economy. But as it ended on Sunday, overshadowed by dramatic events in Asia, the meeting served instead to highlight the limits of power in an increasingly complex world.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Take Jazz, Add Art, Poetry And Dance
description: The yearly Vision Festival, which against all practical odds begins its third season this evening, stands quite apart from New York's other festivals of jazz and improvised music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, MORTON
description: ROSENTHAL - Morton. Died peacefully at 89. Husband of Rosalind for 63 years. Loving father of Judy March Rosenthal, Jane Goldman, Sarah Hart and John Rosenthal. Devoted father-in-law of John Goldman and Nancy Rosenthal. Adoring grandfather of Bruce, Carolyn, Linda, Jill, Charlie and Kate. Dear brother of Miriam Passerman, the late Edward Rosenthal and Hannah Feldstein. Service Monday, May 18, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Family will be receiving in Chappaqua on Tuesday from 5 to 8 PM.

title: Honoring Two Danes and Having Some Fun
description: American Ballet Theater presented its first mixed program of the season on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The choice of works honored August Bournonville, the greatest Danish choreographer of the 19th century, and Harald Lander, the greatest Danish choreographer of this century.

title: Antitrust Talks Founder On Microsoft's 'Desktop'
description: The stakes and the drama, it seemed, could scarcely be higher. The Microsoft Corporation, emblematic titan of the nation's high-tech economy, was locked in last-minute, closed-door negotiations with the Justice Department and 20 state Attorneys General. The goal was to find a way to avert a major antitrust suit -- a confrontation that could rival the Government's assault on Standard Oil early this century in defining the ground rules of competition for decades to come.

title: For the repetitively stressed and those otherwise challenged, a computer mouse operated by foot.
description: WHAT, with a double click of the heel, can transport creatures across time and space? If your guess is Dorothy, in her red slippers, wishing herself home from the Land of Oz, you're wrong. Think less magical, less whimsical. Think computers.

title: Savoring the Song Recital And Tending Its Heritage
description: ''I'll be your Beverly Sills tonight,'' the pianist Steven Blier told the audience that came to the 92d Street Y on Thursday night for the 10th Anniversary Gala Concert of the New York Festival of Song. He meant that he would serve as a chatty host for the evening, introducing the program and the 15 other participants and reminiscing about what he and Michael Barrett, the festival's artistic directors, have tried to accomplish.

title: Khannouchi Upset
description: Simon Rono of Kenya built an insurmountable lead after the first mile and cruised to victory yesterday in the Bay to Breakers 12-kilometer race in San Francisco. His time of 33 minutes 58 seconds was 11 seconds better than that of Kahlid Khannouchi of Morocco, who nearly closed the gap during the second mile but could never catch Rono.

title: Corrections
description: A review and a headline in Weekend on April 24 about the television movie ''Dallas: War of the Ewings'' referred incorrectly to the character Pamela Ewing on the original CBS series ''Dallas.'' Pamela, who was badly injured and disfigured in a fiery automobile crash, was described on the series as having disappeared. She was never declared dead.

title: Abroad at Home; Turn of the Tide?
description: What Congress does not do may be as important as what it does. So it was recently when the House defeated, by a vote of 249 to 171, an amendment that would have cut off Federal aid to any public college or university that considered race, ethnicity or gender in its admissions process.

title: Bulls Are Outbumbled In a Game of Miscues
description: In a game sometimes played so sloppily that it might have rendered mud wrestling elegant, the Chicago Bulls beat the Indiana Pacers, 85-79, this afternoon in the United Center to take a 1-0 lead in the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Equity Offerings Set This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Palestinians Reduce Toll During Riots To 5 From 9
description: Palestinian human rights groups and medical officials said today that after checking with families and hospitals, they had concluded that five Palestinians were killed in rioting on Thursday, and not nine as the Palestinian Authority had reported.

title: Voting for Higher Cigarette Prices
description: The Senate Finance Committee made a comprehensive anti-smoking bill stronger last week when it voted to increase cigarette taxes by $1.50 per pack over three years. That hefty increase should go far to deter youth smoking, and it is not apt to encourage widespread smuggling of cigarettes as industry propaganda suggests. Indeed, such smuggling can occur on a large scale only if the industry itself allows it.

title: Sele Wins Number 7, Fanning 9
description: RANGERS 1, INDIANS 0

title: A World Away, Strife Hits Home; Indonesian Students Look Back With Guilt and Unease
description: In the basement of a mosque in Astoria, Queens, the New York chapter of the Indonesian Students Association dispensed with much of its agenda. Members discussed a fund-raiser and a Boston trip for an athletic meet. The ticklish item involved what to do about the riots and student uprisings back home.

title: Amex Sending Deal's Details To Members
description: Two months after leaders of the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market announced a plan to combine their markets, the Amex is submitting details to its members for a make-or-break vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMERANTZ, PROFESSOR ALLEN
description: POMERANTZ-Professor Allen. Of New York City. Retired professor at Bronx Community College. Died on May 16, 1998. Father of Alison W. Stevelman. Brother of Donald Pomerantz. Also survived by two grandchildren. Funeral service on Monday, May 18, at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, at 1 PM. Interment South Salem Cemetery.

title: Essay; U.S. Security for Sale
description: A President hungry for money to finance his re-election overruled the Pentagon; he sold to a Chinese Military Intelligence front the technology that defense experts argued would give Beijing the capacity to blind our spy satellites and launch a sneak attack. How soon we have forgotten Pearl Harbor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, GEORGE T.
description: NORTON-George T. Of Atlanta, GA. passed away on May 12, 1998. Born in New York City on April 22, 1910, he attended Columbia University with a B.A. in 1932, New York Law School LLB in 1941. He is survived by four sons: George, Jr. of Birmingham, William of Atlanta, John of Reston, VA., Douglas of Bernardsville, NJ, 10 grandchildren & 2 great grandchildren. He was former Vice President and General Manager of Utilities Mutual Insurance, New York City and member of The Downtown Association. Memorial Service, May 30, 4PM at Grace Episcopal Church, Plainfield, New Jersey 07060. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Grace Church.

title: As Print Revenue Ebbs, www.juneplaymate.com?
description: The on-line version of Playboy, with 25,000 paying customers, is not going to obscure the magazine's 4.5 million subscribers worldwide anytime soon. But the Internet business was the only bright spot in an otherwise dismal quarterly report this month.

title: Four Apples for the Teacher: Nadia Boulanger Is Honored
description: ''Nadia Boulanger: Teacher of the Century'' was the sweeping title of the conductor Leon Botstein's program with the American Symphony Orchestra on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MARION
description: SHAPIRO-Marion. A strong and beautiful woman, died on May 14, at the age of 85, in San Francisco. Formerly from New York City, Port Washington, and Delray Beach. Loving daughter of Yetta and Nathan Britt. Beloved wife of Nat Shapiro. She is loved and missed by her children, Richard and Judith, their spouses Nancy and David; and her granchildren in San Francisco, Summer and Jeremy, and in Israel, Yael, Shaul, Liron and Netta. Services at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont Road, Elmont, NY, at 11 AM, Tuesday, May 19. The family may be visited or contacted at the Garden City Hotel, 45 7th St., Garden City, NY, 516-747-3000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, DEL
description: WHITE-Del. Passed away on May 14, 1998, in Lake Oswego, Oregon, at the age of 68. He now joins his wife Nancy who passed away May 6, 1997. He was born in the little town of Kelso, Washington, but his life and love took him around the world. He was the Personnel Director for White Stag for 37 years. He traveled and was respected throughout the United States. The people who knew him in the garment industry will be saddened by his loss. He was also the Personnel Director for Kienow's Food Stores for 10 years and was respected and admired in the grocery industry. He will be missed. He married Nancy in 1950. He is survived by his mother, sister, three daughters and one son, and many grandchildren. He was a proud and honorable man. His love and legacy will live on in his children, grandchildren and many generations to come. His family will miss him and grieve for him, but will also find comfort in the fact he has joined our mother in a place of peace where they can live together for eternity. The family requests remembrances to St. Vincent Hospice, 9340 SW Barnes Road, Suite ''M'', Portland, Oregon 97225.

title: Metro Matters; Shrugging Off An Old Vow To Step Down
description: IT'S been nearly six years now since Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato made his last comeback, Nosferatu-like, from the political undead.

title: INSIDE
description: Cancer Drug Shows Promise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HISCOX, EDWARD M.
description: HISCOX-Edward M. May 15, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Maggie E. Gerig Hiscox. Devoted father of Patricia Ann and Pamela Jane. Beloved friend of Charlie Gerig, Leo and Anneliese Bannwart of Lucerne, Switzerland. You will always be our hero, our best friend and the love of our lives. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, May 20, 7-9 PM, with a service at 8 PM. High Mass service will be held on Friday, May 22, 10:30 AM, at Holy Innocents Church, 128 West 37th Street, NYC. Mom and dad you are always with us and we are always with you.

title: A Hockey-Like Brawl Over 'Polo'
description: Is it real Polo or Ralph's Polo?

title: New York Team Heads to Final Four
description: The Old Blue Rugby Football Club of New York earned a trip to the men's national Final Four yesterday by defeating the Chicago Lions, 52-10, in the national men's Division 1 club rugby quarterfinals at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Old Blue will play Atlanta Life in the semifinals on May 30. Greg McAllister led Old Blue in scoring with 15 points, including a try and five conversions. Kevin Fwords had 10 points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, ERNEST
description: BLOCH-Ernest. On May 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Amy. Father of Geoffrey. Services today, 2 PM, Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx.

title: Light Cast on Ties Of Insurers to Nazis
description: Newly unearthed documents suggest that German insurance companies went beyond what was previously known in conniving with the Nazis to avoid paying Jewish policyholders after the rampage through German cities in 1938 known as Kristallnacht.

title: Henry Tanner, 79, a Foreign Correspondent
description: Henry Tanner, a Swiss-born reporter who covered everything from wars to diplomatic receptions with equal aplomb during a half-century career in journalism, died on Friday night at a hospital near his weekend home in Honfleur, France.

title: Creators in a 'Caldron of Neurosis'
description: REMEMBERING MR. SHAWN'S NEW YORKER

title: Times Mirror Weighs a By-the-Numbers Approach to Expanding Coverage of Minorities
description: In his latest challenge to the established mores of American newsrooms, Mark H. Willes, the chief executive of the Times Mirror Company and the publisher of The Los Angeles Times, is devising an unorthodox plan to give more coverage and to sell more newspapers to women, African-American, Asian and Hispanic readers.

title: All Is Forgiven After Wells's Glorious Performance
description: Bob Tewksbury knew the feeling. He was most impressed with David Wells's composure.

title: SIMON & SCHUSTER IN SALE TO BRITISH
description: Pearson P.L.C., Britain's largest publisher, and a Dallas investment firm agreed yesterday to buy most of Simon & Schuster's operations from Viacom Inc. for $4.6 billion in cash, accelerating the flow of America's publishing houses into foreign hands.

title: A Hyperbolic Baffert Raves About Real Quiet
description: The Triple Crown is supposed to sap the strength of the horses, but Real Quiet seems to be thriving despite the hectic schedule. He felt so good this morning, the day after his stirring victory in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Race Course, that his trainer, Bob Baffert, practically guaranteed that Real Quiet would capture the Belmont Stakes, too, on June 6.

title: L.A. Cellular Selects Deutsch for Account
description: L.A. Cellular has named the Marina del Rey, Calif., office of Deutsch Inc. to handle its account, with billings estimated at $20 million. The account had been handled for two years by the BBDO West unit of Omnicom Group in Los Angeles, which declined an invitation to participate in a review.

title: Savoring the Jazz Singer's Art and Tricky Balance
description: We all want ways to shape the material that life has to offer: the pleasures and the messes, the unsolicited shocks, the excitement we're always on the prowl for and the situations we're always trying to avoid. We want to believe that, faced with any of this, we can do something inventive, even dazzling, and what better vehicle for this belief than a 12-, 16- or 32-bar popular song? Because that's what they're here for, to give melodic, harmonic, rhythmic and verbal shape to life as we know it or wish we knew it.

title: Accounts
description: * PGA Tours International Federation, Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., to Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago, part of True North Communications, to handle the worldwide introduction of the World Golf Championships. The Foote, Cone sports marketing unit, San Francisco, and its Impact Communications Group, which handles sales promotion, will also work on the account. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: In Long Run, Jobs Help Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNAN, JOHN J.
description: BRENNAN-John J. Suddenly on May 16, 1998. Beloved brother of Loretta Rodden and Eileen Brennan. Family will receive friends Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Visitation Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Dissolve to Blackout: U.S. Game Is Best Left Unseen
description: With no live television and a finish well after midnight on the East Coast, a virtual news blackout was assured for Saturday night's friendly between the United States and Macedonia. If ever a game deserved invisibility, it was this one.

title: Frank Sinatra: A Newspaper Story
description: It was not a movie, so nobody got to yell, ''Stop the presses!'' But it came close to that.

title: U.S. vs. Private Industry: A Look Back
description: If the Justice Department and Attorneys General of 20 states file antitrust lawsuits against Microsoft today, as they are expected to do, the ensuing fight could be one of the biggest ever between the Government and private industry over what constitutes unfair monopolistic business practices. Here are some of the biggest past cases. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

title: 2 Web Ventures End Merger Plan
description: Citing incompatibilities in cultures and technology, Citysearch and the Zip2 Corporation, two of the leading developers of local World Wide Web sites known as city guides, have called off merger plans that were announced April 3.

title: Perfect Fit: Pitches, Weather, Umpire
description: When David Wells was in a bit of a cold war with his manager last Tuesday, Joe Torre said the pitcher's ability was so great that on any given day, he could pitch a no-hitter.

title: Blanche Revere Long, 93, Louisiana Legend
description: Blanche Revere Long, the Louisiana Governor's wife who played Margaret Dumont to Earl K. Long's Groucho Marx in one of the great comic turns of American political history, died on May 11 at a nursing home in Covington, La. She was 93 and best known for the zany day in 1959 when she drew the line at her husband's increasingly erratic behavior and bundled him off to a mental hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACIVER, LOREN
description: MacIVER-Loren. Died peacefully at her home in Greenwich Village, NY, on May 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late poet and critic Lloyd Frankenberg. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend. As we move forward, her extraordinary spirit lives through our memories and her art. At Loren's request, no services are planned. Philippe Alexandre Andrew H. Arnot Eric Brown Tibor de Nagy Gallery

title: Arts Education, for a Week
description: As New York City's budget cutters scanned the numbers over the last two decades, arts education always seemed to have the vulnerable look of luxury. Culture for schools too often became a ''frill'' that could be sacrificed to fiscal responsibility. Now, even with modest budget increases for arts in the schools in the last few years, the arts education program is not what we should expect for the culture capital of the world. There is not even an arts curriculum for New York City's public schools.

title: Omnicom Merges 2 of Its Units
description: Omnicom Group is forming TBWA Worldwide by merging its TBWA International unit with BDDP Worldwide, acquired when Omnicom recently bought GGT Group P.L.C.

title: A Clipper Triumph: No. 1 Pick
description: Ten years ago, when the Los Angeles Clippers last won the National Basketball Association's draft lottery, Elgin Baylor, their vice president for basketball operations, reached under his seat and pulled out a Clippers jersey emblazoned with Danny Manning's name and number.

title: In Long Run, Jobs Help Students; New York City Lags
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns, Kids and Adults
description: To the Editor:

title: Biology Theory Slights Other Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: Biology Theory Slights Other Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: Reaching a Verdict on 'Seinfeld' Ads
description: Why were advertisers so absorbed by ''Seinfeld''? Was it because when a prosecutor attacked Jerry, Elaine, George and Kramer in the final episode, castigating their ''selfishness, self-absorption, immaturity and greed,'' he could have also been listing the negative traits long attributed to Madison Avenue?

title: $200 Billion Transit Bill Clears Some Obstacles
description: Congressional negotiators reached agreement today on major elements of a $200 billion transportation bill, raising expectations that the full Congress will approve the measure before recessing for the Memorial Day holiday on Friday.

title: 50 Years Later, Pollsters Analyze Their Big Defeat
description: As they wandered between discussions of why people don't answer their questions or how the Internet will affect their business, the nation's leading pollsters continually confronted evidence of their worst failure: the Presidential election of 1948.

title: I.B.M. Is Close to Deal On Phone Service Over the Internet
description: Throwing its weight behind the nascent business of Internet telephone calls, I.B.M. has agreed to promote the cyberspace phone service of the IDT Corporation, according to executives close to the negotiations.

title: INDIA DETONATED A HYDROGEN BOMB, EXPERTS CONFIRM
description: In a disclosure with potential to accelerate further a nuclear arms race with Pakistan, Indian scientists confirmed today that the largest of the five underground nuclear tests they conducted last week involved a hydrogen bomb, a device with potentially enormous power that is known in American military circles as a ''city buster.''

title: Students in Jakarta March Into Parliament
description: Hundreds of university students chanting ''Reform!'' and ''Succession!'' marched peacefully into the Parliament building today for an extraordinary meeting with Governent officials.

title: Teflon Secret Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, BETTY WILLIAMS
description: CARTER-Betty Williams. Aged 97, of Irvington, NY on May 15, 1998. Wife of the late Frederic D. Carter, mother of Charles W., Frederic, Jr., and Samuel P.W. Also survived by eight grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:30 AM on Saturday, June 6, 1998 at the Irvington Presbyterian Church, 25 North Broadway, Irvington, NY 10533. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to this church would be appreciated.

title: Sidney Cobb, 81, Researcher Who Studied Cancer Rates
description: Dr. Sidney Cobb, an epidemiologist who studied the effects of job stress and who in retirement helped inspire a national study of cancer rates near nuclear reactors, died on April 7 at the Woolman Hospital at the Medford Leas, a retirement center near Mount Holly, N.J. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, INGRID
description: BERMAN-Ingrid. Beloved wife of Daniel. Devoted mother of Joel and Michelle. Adored grandmother of Jake and Leah. Services Monday, 10:30 AM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: One of 3 Potential Polygram Bidders Is Said to Have Dropped Out
description: One of the three potential bidders for the music company Polygram N.V. has decided not to make a bid, a person close to the group said yesterday.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Defending Life of Killer Who Flirted With Death
description: For the last two months, a team of lawyers has been working to keep a former jail guard named Darrel K. Harris from becoming the first person sentenced to death under New York State's 3-year-old capital punishment law.

title: Cook Takes Advantage As Couples Unravels
description: Two weeks ago, John Cook took a 10 on the 17th hole of his opening round and missed the cut at the Shell Houston Open, then took some time off to search for inner peace. Today, Fred Couples waltzed to the 17th tee here tied for the lead in the GTE Byron Nelson Classic, pretty much convinced that he had already found such a nirvana.

title: Create Another I.M.F.
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, HAROLD (RED)
description: GOLDMAN-Harold (Red). On Saturday, May 16. Cherished husband of Edie. Adored father of Chuck and Debbie, Jill and Max, Riki and Larry. Proudest grandfather of Arin, Isaac, Alissa, Channi, Josh, Bennie, Molly and Dassie. Loving brother of Arline and George, Marilyn, Marvin and Marilyn, and Helen and Jack. Beloved uncle. Dearest friend of hundreds. He leaves a legacy of love, humor and good times. His twinkling green eyes will sparkle always for all of us who knew him. His Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOONAN, SR. MARGARET
description: LOONAN-Sr. Margaret. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity and Elementary School Educator, died Saturday, May 16, 1998. Survived by a niece and several cousins. The wake will be Sunday from 1 to 8 PM, at the Convent of Mary The Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial will be Monday, 9:30 AM, at the Convent. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetary, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471.

title: Create Another I.M.F.
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Is Shown to Shrink Tumors in Breast Cancer Characterized by Gene Defect
description: The first full-scale trials of an experimental drug that homes in on a genetic defect in breast cancer cells show significant promise for women with advanced cancer, scientists reported today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Republicans Have Grip on Pennsylvania Politics
description: On the outskirts of this state capital, in a nondescript office building, Don Bailey, a beefy lawyer and former Congressman, is reviewing a legal case at his cluttered desk.

title: Clinton Says Chinese Money Did Not Influence U.S. Policy
description: President Clinton said today that reported political campaign contributions from China to the Democrats had not influenced his foreign policy, but he welcomed further investigation into decisions that made it easier for China to launch American satellites and possibly obtain sensitive technology.

title: Blunt Ex-General Wins Siberia Governorship
description: Aleksandr I. Lebed, the former paratroop general whose political ambitions are a cause of worry for President Boris N. Yeltsin and his Communist opposition, won a sweeping victory tonight in a runoff gubernatorial election in the Siberian region of Krasnoyarsk, assuring himself of a foothold in Russia's presidential race in 2000.

title: Adversarial Quality Of a Court TV Sale
description: Having been tossed and kicked like a rugby ball for the last few weeks, the ratings-deflated Court TV remains unsure of its future as its three co-owners haggle about how to sell it. But one option now seems more unlikely than it did a week ago -- selling Court TV to Discovery Communications, which would convert it into something new, like a Discovery Health channel.

title: Miscellany
description: * Tara Lipinski, the Olympic figure skater, has become the national spokeswoman for the Boys and Girls Club of America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CONSTANCE KAUFMAN
description: SOLOMON-Constance Kaufman. Connie - an extraordinary wife, mother, grandmother, human being, who immeasurably enriched the lives of all who knew her. She will be terribly missed. With love, Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro

title: Biology Theory Slights Other Fields
description: To the Editor:

title: Forging Artistic Connections Between Diverse Composers
description: In his three concerts for Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, the Finnish pianist Olli Mustonen is exploring the connections and contrasts between Bach and Shostakovich. Although structural connections seemed to be the point of the first concert, a program of preludes and fugues by both composers, the contrasts were more purposefully stark at the second installment on Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall. This time Mr. Mustonen was joined by Pekka Kuusisto, a violinist.

title: New Plan for Junk E-Mail Is Dividing Internet Camps
description: Legislation quietly passed last week by the Senate to control spam, the annoying junk E-mail that has increasingly been flooding the Internet, has driven a wedge between two camps of Internet activists -- free-speech advocates and anti-spam crusaders.

title: Nike's New Labor Practices
description: With his company in danger of becoming a symbol of worker exploitation, Philip Knight, the chief executive of Nike, announced some important changes in labor practices last week. While falling short of critics' demands that Nike pay a living wage and pull out of countries where workers cannot organize, the reforms set a standard other companies should match. But Nike must see that its new policies reach the factory floor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORENSEN, FRANK C.
description: SORENSEN-Frank C., M.D. On May 16, 1998, of Rockville Centre, N.Y. Beloved husband of Vera (nee Mari). Dear father of Mark F. Sorensen, M.D., John F. Sorensen, David F. Sorensen (Beth), Paula F. Lucore (Dr. Charles Lucore). Cherished grandfather of Eric, Emily, Jordan, Alex and Anna. Fond brother of Betty Sorensen. Reposing at Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, N.Y., Monday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Interment St. Johns Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y. The family suggests memorial contributions be sent to Cancer Care at Mercy Medical Center, 1000 N. Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y. 11570.

title: Blazing a Path of His Own
description: Kerry Wood needed to strike out 15 Cincinnati Reds today to break a major league record held by his hero, Nolan Ryan, for most strikeouts in three consecutive games.

title: Rarest Gem for Yankees' Wells: A Perfect Game
description: Nervousness gnawed at David Wells in the seventh inning yesterday, when he began realizing that he might pitch a perfect game. He wanted the roaring Yankee Stadium crowd of 49,820 to remain silent, and he desperately needed his superstitious Yankee teammates to speak and ease the mounting tension.

title: THE ARTS IN: Wilmington, N.C; Where Movies Take Root, All the Arts Flower
description: In 1983, Frank Capra Jr. came here in search of an antebellum mansion to burn down. As the producer of ''Firestarter,'' a film being financed by Dino De Laurentiis, he had already been to Virginia, Texas and Louisiana looking for just the right house. Then, on the cover of a magazine, he saw a picture of the Orton plantation in nearby Winnabow, built in 1725, with a chapel on the grounds and 20 acres of landscaped gardens.

title: No Need for Marketing When Drama Is Real
description: For the second year in a row, horse racing rises up from its low ratings and raises a glorious vision: a thoroughbred on the threshold of sweeping the Triple Crown. And an unlikely one at that: Real Quiet, a horse with a crooked right foreleg who was known as The Fish around Bob Baffert's barn because he once was so skinny.

title: When Revenues Don't Match Ratings
description: ''Your listeners don't buy our cars,'' a Chicago radio executive recalled being told by an official of a luxury-car maker who had just rebuffed an advertising sales pitch. ''They steal them.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEBEL, VICTOR
description: SCHWEBEL-Victor. Age 101. Beloved husband of the late Pauline Pfeffer Schwebel. Father of Jack P. and Stephen M. Schwebel. Father-in-law of Renata Manasse Schwebel and Louise Killander Schwebel. Grandfather of Judith Lerman, Barbara Davis, Diane Freedman, Jennifer and Anna Schwebel. Great-grandfather of David and Adam Lerman, Alexander and Sara Davis, and Samuel and Anna Freedman, all of whom will miss his devotion and loving smile. Private family service.

title: Seeking Dramatic Footage No Matter What the Cost; Competing for Images From Trouble Spots, TV Crews Can Put Lives, and Ethics, at Risk
description: The video news clip is startling: 10 hostages being herded into a blind alley at gunpoint. Agitated guards dart in and out of the picture.

title: Corrections
description: An Arts in America article on Tuesday, about the opening of the Nancy Lee and Perry R. Bass Performance Hall in Fort Worth, misstated a rival plan to develop a performance site. Robert M. Bass, a son of the couple, proposed the renovation of the Will Rogers Auditorium, not of a coliseum used for livestock shows.

title: A Taboo Gives Way To a Gem By Wells
description: Jim Kaat and Ken Singleton proved yesterday that if you talk about a perfect game when a pitcher is pitching one, the guy on the mound will not hear what you are saying and the fates will not be disturbed.

title: Berger Manages a Welter of Crises in the Post-Cold-War White House
description: When Samuel R. Berger arrived at the White House at 7:30 A.M. last Monday he was stunned to learn that India had just completed three underground nuclear tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSPAN, FRANCES H.
description: ROSENSPAN-Frances H. On May 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Devoted mother of Marcia and Jay Sternin and Norman Rosenspan. Cherished grandmother of three, adored great-grandmother of three. Dear sister of Joan Delaunay. Service Tuesday, 11:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, NY (near Avenue V).

title: More Children Go Uninsured Despite Status For Medicaid
description: A new Federal study finds that 4.7 million children far more than previously estimated -- are eligible for Medicaid but are not enrolled in the program and have no health insurance benefits.

title: Mainframe Business, Though Faded, Is Still Far From Extinct
description: In a recent conference call with the International Business Machines Corporation, a securities analyst asked if the company ever again expected to win a new mainframe customer. This was a serious question.

title: Dominican Opposition Wins Without Chief
description: Despite the death of its charismatic leader, this country's main opposition party has won a sweeping victory in congressional and municipal elections that were being closely watched in the United States because of their probable effects on efforts to curtail drug trafficking and to modernize the economy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Simon & Schuster Units Sold to Pearson Group

title: On Trip, Netanyahu Speaks Softly And Leaves Hard Words to Others
description: The angry-looking man who stood on the stage yesterday denouncing the Palestinians and the Clinton Administration was not Benjamin Netanyahu, the Prime Minister of Israel. No, Mr. Netanyahu was just a few feet away, smiling broadly, allowing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to be the one to say that there was no moral equivalency between Israel and the Palestinians, and that the United States was going soft on Yasir Arafat.

title: Pressure From Clinton
description: At the meeting of major industrial democracies, President Clinton urged President Yeltsin of Russia to press for the ratification of a pending nuclear weapons treaty.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: It Looked Like a Misstep But Turned Out to Be a Coup
description: There are some basic elements of defensive card play that players beyond the beginner stage use without thinking. If your partner leads a suit in which you hold A 7 3, you return the seven, not the three, if you are going to return the suit at all.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  UNGER, LAURENCE N., MD.
description: UNGER-Laurence N., MD. Happy Birthday, Lar. Wish you were here. We miss you so very much. Love

title: In Indonesia, the Grab for Power May Hinge on the Rivalry of 2 Generals
description: When Indonesia's first President, Sukarno, was stripped of power in the winter of 1966, the message was delivered by an obscure major general named Suharto. Now, if Mr. Suharto is forced to resign as Indonesia's President, the message may once again be delivered by a general. And that man could well become the next President of Indonesia.

title: Even without 'Seinfeld,' NBC is the network that others build their fall schedules around.
description: FOR sheer intensity and nail-biting suspense, nothing on any show on any television network compares with what will happen this week inside suites of rooms here in New York that will be occupied by executives trying to decide which shows will go where in prime-time schedules next year.

title: Hoopla, but Little Suspense, As D'Amato Says He'll Run
description: The ballroom at the Waldorf Astoria was packed yesterday afternoon, the political banners mounted on the walls, and the center of the day's activities -- Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- was hurtling toward the part of his speech where he talks about his mother. Suddenly, he stopped mid-sentence and surveyed the scene he had so carefully staged.

title: Serious Crime Fell in U.S. For 6th Year in a Row in '97
description: Reports of serious crime fell across the nation in 1997, the sixth consecutive annual decrease, with the biggest drop in the Northeastern states and in big cities, the Justice Department said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAVITCH, JANE E.
description: JAVITCH-Jane E., 97. Died May 16, 1998 in Harrisburg, PA. Surviving are a daughter, Phyllis Lipsett of Harrisburg, a son, Lee H., of Harrison, NY; six grandchildren; and 13 great grandchildren. Services and burial took place in Beth El Cemetery, Harrisburg. Reese Funeral Home, Harrisburg, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELSEN, HENRIETTA
description: FELSEN-Henrietta. On May 18. Devoted wife of Samuel. Dear mother of Neil and Jill. Grandmother of Todd and Lauren. Great grandmother. Graveside services 1 PM, today at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, BETTY WILLIAMS.
description: CARTER-Betty Williams. Aged 97, of Irvington, NY on May 15, 1998. Wife of the late Frederic D. Carter, mother of Charles W., Frederic, Jr., and Samuel P.W. Also survived by eight grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:30 AM on Saturday, June 6, 1998 at the Irvington Presbyterian Church, 25 North Broadway, Irvington, NY 10533. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to this church would be appreciated.

title: Enraptured by His Verse, Deflated by His Politics
description: On the rare occasions when the poet Jaime Sabines leaves his self-imposed seclusion to give a reading, he always draws enraptured overflow crowds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZFELD, MORRIS
description: HERZFELD-Morris. Beloved husband of the late Etta. Devoted father of Rosalie Lipton, Dorothy Herzfeld, Allen, and the late Herb. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Service will be held Wednesday, May 20 at 2:30 P.M., at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, New York. For information contact Jewish Memorial Chapel, 625 McLean Avennue, Yonkers.

title: Jordan Is Winner Of M.V.P. A 5th Time
description: Much like the legend, the Michael Jordan Hardware Drive continues.

title: 3 Playwrights Urge CUNY to Keep Taking Remedial Students
description: Broadway came to the City University of New York yesterday as three playwrights -- Wendy Wasserstein, Tony Kushner and David Henry Hwang -- attended a public hearing to urge the trustees to continue accepting remedial students.

title: As Commodity Indexes Fall, Palladium Still Seems Strong
description: Political turmoil in Indonesia, the collapse of many economies in Asia and the threatened economic sanctions on India all sent a key commodity index to its lowest level in more than four years yesterday.

title: Drying Out The Red Neon Umbrella
description: AND the people said, Let there be no light. And there was no light.

title: National News Briefs; Hotel Workers Select Organizer as President
description: The Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union has elected one of the nation's most respected labor organizers, John W. Wilhelm, to be its general president, effective Aug. 1.

title: Southern Cal Is Next for Fordham
description: Fordham, which had to win four games in 24 hours to qualify for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, now faces another imposing obstacle. The Rams (27-18) will meet Southern Cal (41-15), the nation's sixth-ranked team, on Thursday in an East Region first-round game at Clemson University.

title: Genetically Altered Virus Kills Some Cancer Cells in Tests
description: A novel form of cancer treatment, based on recent discoveries about the inner working of tumor cells, has shown impressive results with a small group of patients with advanced head and neck cancers.

title: LUCENT SELLS MAPPING UNIT TO BANYAN SYSTEMS
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., a maker of telephone equipment, sold its Maps On Us Internet map unit to Banyan Systems Inc., which plans to add the maps to its on-line phone directory. Lucent's technology, which gives Internet users street maps and directions, is used by the AT&T Corporation's Worldnet Internet division as well as USA Today and Nintendo. Banyan, which makes software for voice mail and messaging products and is based in Westborough, Mass., will take a $1 million to $1.5 million charge this quarter for research at the unit. Other terms were not disclosed. Banyan also acquired Lucent's Maps On Us Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNEY, HARVEY G.
description: BURNEY-Harvey G. On Saturday, May 16, 1998 of Parsippany. Beloved husband of Joan F. (nee Farley). Loving father of Robert S. of Morristown and Ellen Burney Wells of Gaithersburg, MD. Cherished grandfather of Jocelyn and Douglas Burney. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a memorial gathering to be held on Wedesday evening, May 20, 1998 from 7-9 pm at the Par-Troy Funeral Home. 95 Parsippany Road, Parsippany, NJ

title: Playground Bill Requires Safety Changes in 5 Years
description: The State Senate approved a bill yesterday that would require operators of about 5,000 public and private playgrounds to install shock-absorbent surfaces under all play equipment within five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTWEIN, SAMUEL
description: GUTWEIN-Samuel. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved father of its devoted member, Miriam Gutwein. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: China May Give Pakistan Defense Assurances, Averting A-Tests
description: A high-level Pakistani delegation arrived in Beijing today, and analysts here said China might give Pakistan the defense assurances it needs to refrain from responding to India's recent nuclear tests with tests of its own.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, omitted the last line. The final paragraph, referring to Mr. Berger, should have read:

title: Mayor Proposes a Law Requiring Trigger Locks on All Guns
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made a surprise proposal yesterday to require the owners of all 250,000 guns in the city to buy trigger locks for their weapons.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ann Taylor has big plans and investors have high hopes. But more housekeeping seems in order.
description: IN some ways, Wall Street is like the fashion industry. It places its bets on faddish concepts that it believes will fly, despite their short life spans.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 7 about the primary race for governor in Nebraska referred incorrectly to the years that James McFarland, a Democratic candidate, played football at the University of Nebraska. It was the late 1960's, not the late 1980's.

title: A Home At Last For Vipers
description: The only soccer team that plays in New York City won its home opener on Sunday by 1-0 over the Long Island Rough Riders.

title: Shoreham School District Contends With Tax Trauma as Power Plant Subsidies Fade
description: For most Long Islanders, the ill-fated nuclear power plant here was a white elephant that pushed their electric bills into the stratosphere.

title: Divided Senate Begins Debate on Tobacco Legislation
description: Splintered into countless factions, the Senate began debate tonight on legislation meant to discourage youth smoking by raising cigarette prices.

title: Nationwide Mutual Seeks Allied Group
description: The Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company offered $1.59 billion for Allied Group Inc. yesterday, a 69 percent premium over the target company's market value, in a rare hostile takeover attempt in the insurance industry.

title: INSIDE
description: A Plan on Social Security

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Fax for Freedom

title: Experts Greet India's H-Bomb With Suspicion
description: BIG claims require big evidence to back them up. That is a rule of thumb in science and, for that matter, in many fields.

title: A Gothic Jigsaw Puzzle In a Small Kansas Town
description: NOW IT'S TIME TO SAY GOODBYE

title: President Tentatively Settles On a Choice to Head F.D.A.
description: The White House has tentatively chosen a cancer specialist who is vice president of the University of New Mexico to be head of the Food and Drug Administration, a position that has been vacant more than 14 months, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUSIN, LEO
description: DRUSIN-Leo. Suddenly on May 17. Beloved husband of Pat (Furst), devoted father of Julie (Steven) Fidelman, Harris (Roberta) Drusin, loving Poppy of Robert and Evan, dear brother of Phyllis (Sam) Weissman and most caring uncle. Services today, 12 Noon, Riverside Nassau North, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: WARNACO TO MAKE CALVIN KLEIN CHILDREN'S CLOTHING
description: The apparel maker Warnaco Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the license to make Calvin Klein children's jeans and related clothing for $41 million from Commerce Clothing, adding to the products that it makes for the designer. Warnaco, based in New York, is already the No. 1 maker of Calvin Klein merchandise. The company makes and markets clothing under the Warner's, Olga, Bodyslimmers, Chaps by Ralph Lauren and Van Raalte names, among others. Shares of Warnaco fell 68.75 cents, to $40.125.

title: Mr. D'Amato Goes for Four
description: Previous opponents have gone to battle with Senator Alfonse D'Amato confident that his normally poor showing in opinion polls meant he was an easy mark, and all of them have come to grief. New York's junior Senator has always been able to convince voters that despite their reservations, he is worth keeping around.

title: Raytheon Unit Gets NASA Job
description: The Raytheon Company said today that its Raytheon Systems unit had received a five-year, $148 million contract to provide information processing services at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center in Mountain View, Calif.

title: 'Intelligence Gene' Only Fuels Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONK, ANTONY (TONY)
description: MONK-Antony (Tony) suddenly on May 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Andrea. Adored father of Samantha, Joanna and Jonathan. Loving brother of Dennis and Myra; uncle of Anton and Barbara, Kerry and Gary, David and Alison. As we move forward, his extroadinary spirit lives through our wonderful memories. Service Tuesday, May 19, 1PM at Westchester Reform Temple. Memorial contributions may be sent to Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY 10583.

title: On TV, a Defiant Gates Faults Tactics by U.S.
description: A defiant William H. Gates took to a television studio stage today on the Microsoft Corporation's campus to defend his company's business practices and to assert that by filing broad antitrust lawsuits against his company, the Government and a group of state Attorneys General were threatening the pace of technological innovation in the personal computer industry.

title: A Courtroom Disciplinarian Who's Unintimidated by Technology
description: Skeptical of the Microsoft Corporation's insistence that its Internet browser could not easily be separated from its Windows 95 operating system, United States District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson decided on his own one day to embark upon a simple experiment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBEY, VIRGINIA
description: TOBEY-Virginia. The residents of the Kenilworth mourn the loss of our dear friend and neighbor. Virginia enhanced the lives of our children with her arts and crafts skills. We offer our condolences to her family. Arthur Sarnoff, President Kenilworth Apartments

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, FLORENCE
description: FINKELSTEIN-Florence. A warm, wonderful and beautiful woman passed away May 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Sidney. Daughter of Pearl and the late Ben Gerber. Daughter-in-law of Ella and the late David Finkelstein. Mother of Joy and Barry. Mother-in-law of Cindy. Grandmother of Blair, Abby and Lindsey, and cousin of Carole. Her brothers-in-law and sisters-in-law will miss her always and she will forever be in our hearts and minds. She touched all of our lives with kindness and love. Irving and Shirley Finkelstein Doris and Norman Chenenko Allen and Shelley Finkelstein

title: Satellite Maker Gave Report to China Before Telling U.S.
description: A leading American satellite maker acknowledged for the first time today that a committee headed by one of its top executives provided a report in 1996 to the Chinese on a failed Chinese rocket, without first consulting Federal officials, and contrary to the company's own internal policies.

title: Alcohol Use Skews Mental Illness Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Bipartisan Plan for Rescue of Social Security Involves Markets and Retirement at 70
description: A commission including members of Congress from both parties will propose a sweeping plan today to shore up Social Security, calling for the establishment of personal investment accounts and a gradual increase in the retirement age to 70.

title: Bob Wolff on Edge of His Seat Again
description: Bob Wolff was at home Sunday afternoon in South Nyack, N.Y., writing short biographies of high school students for a scholar-athlete program, when his producer called.

title: KODAK AND AMERICA ONLINE TO OFFER PHOTOS VIA INTERNET
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is expected to announce today that it is joining with America Online to offer developed photographs via the Internet. Starting this fall, America Online subscribers who drop film off with participating retailers can, for the charge of from $5 to $7, have small versions of their pictures uploaded directly to America Online within 48 hours. The America Online subscriber can put the pictures in on-line photo albums, and can electronically order prints. America Online, Kodak and the retailers will split the profits from the extra fees and from reprint orders. The system uses technology created by Picturevision Inc.; Kodak owns 51 percent of Picturevision, and America Online plans to buy 10 percent of the remaining shares.

title: So, How Big Is It Again? Sizing Up the Lizard King
description: Well, yes. As the ads for ''Godzilla'' proclaim, ''Size does matter.'' Even in the movies, there's such a thing as too big.

title: United States v. Microsoft
description: In their sweeping antitrust suit against Microsoft, the Justice Department and 20 state attorneys general have made reasonable demands to preserve competition in the world of computers and the Internet. Bill Gates needs to respond with something better than disingenuous countercharges that his company is being punished for its success. Instead of forcing a protracted court battle over remedies, Microsoft should work with Federal and state lawyers to reshape the marketplace to help consumers obtain the products they may want.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EUGENE
description: COHEN-Eugene. Tifereth IsraelTown and Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extends heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Fred Karp, President

title: Go Slowly in Indonesia
description: Both Republican and Democratic Senators wrongheadedly attacked the Clinton Administration yesterday for its unwillingness to issue an explicit call for President Suharto of Indonesia to step down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMISH, HARRY
description: KAMISH-Harry. The Board of Directors, staff and families of the Association for Children with Retarded Mental Development deeply mourn the passing of our beloved colleague and dear friend, founder and former Associate Executive Director. An advocate for people since the 1940's, he was widely known for his lifelong dedication to those with developmental disabilities and their families whom he served. We were all his friends. Funeral services will be held at the Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York, at 11:30AM, Tuesday, May 19, 1998. Jefferson W. Woodcox, President Lawrence Hirsch, Vice President Rose Podolsky, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOLL, WALTER A.
description: SCHOLL-Walter A. Age 79, retired vice president and member of the New York Stock Exchange passed away at home on Sunday, May 17, 1998 in Boynton Beach, Florida. Mr. Scholl was born on Staten Island, NY and graduated from Cornell University where he distinguished himself on the football field and baseball diamond. He was elected to the Cornell Athletic Hall of Fame and threw the famous fifth down pass play that beat Dartmouth in 1940. He served as an officer in the Army Air Corps during WWII and received many citations including the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Silver Star. He was a member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 2007 of West Palm Beach, the American Legion Post 0012, the Buttonwood Club of the New York Stock Exchange, Vasa Order of America Royal Palm Lodge #

title: Islanders Rehire Milbury and Throw in a Support Staff
description: Creating an operation unprecedented for hockey, the last of the mom-and-pop team sports, the Islanders rehired Mike Milbury yesterday as coach and general manager for five years. But the team added at least half a dozen people to assist him in both the front office and on the ice.

title: LG ELECTRONICS MAY SELL MOST OF ZENITH'S ASSETS
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation's majority shareholder, South Korea's LG Electronics Inc., said it might sell most of the assets of the struggling United States television maker in a reorganization that could wipe out the value of Zenith shares. LG Electronics said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the plan would result in a ''substantial change'' in Zenith's capitalization and business operations. LG Electronics and its LG Semicon affiliate own about 55 percent of Zenith stock. Zenith has lost money every year but one since 1985. Analysts said LG's moves would mark the end of Zenith as a television manufacturer, turning it into a marketing company controlled by creditors. Shares of Zenith, based in Glenview, Ill., fell 93.75 cents, to $2.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, CHARLES (CHARLIE).
description: RATNER-Charles (Charlie). Of Lawrence, N.Y., and Hollywood, FL. On May 17 at age 87. Devoted husband of the late Ruth. Loving father of Michael and Joan and dear grandfather of Jessica, James, David and Jonathan. Brother of Eli and the late Louis. Founder and longtime head of Richter + Ratner Contracting Corp. Services on Tuesday 11:30AM, at Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett.

title: Eight People Are Wounded by Gunfire at a Downtown Brooklyn Mall
description: Six women and two men were wounded by gunfire last evening when a gunman, apparently fighting with an acquaintance, burst out of a clothing store and began shooting into a crowded pedestrian plaza in the heart of downtown Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times; After an Exit In 7th Inning, A Lost Gem
description: THE imperfect family left the perfect game.

title: Glaxo Wellcome Sales Fell 7% in 4 Months
description: Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. said sales in the first four months of 1998 fell 7 percent as the British drug maker suffered from the patent loss for its biggest selling drug, the anti-ulcerant Zantac, and from the stronger pound. Glaxo said sales in the four-month period fell 7 percent, to $:2.56 billion ($4.15 billion). The decline would have been only 1 percent if measured at constant exchange rates. Excluding Zantac and currency effects, Glaxo said sales growth was 11 percent.

title: Executive Changes
description: FORD MOTOR CO., Dearborn, Mich., moved the head of its Ford division, Ross Roberts, to a new position directing the auto maker's efforts to restructure its dealer organization and reduce distribution costs. Jim O'Connor, 55, vice president of the company's Lincoln-Mercury division, will succeed Mr. Roberts, 60, as head of the Ford division. Mark Hutchins, 52, vice president for Latin American operations, will succeed Mr. O'Connor at Lincoln-Mercury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TACA, STEVEN
description: TACA-Steven. 45, of Sayville, LI, suddenly on Sunday, May 17th. Beloved husband of Erin. Loving father of Kyle Patrick Brogan Taca, Connor Liam Brogan Taca, Ryan Eagan Taca, Rory Quinn Taca, and Delaney Elizabeth Taca. Cherished son of Henry and Rita Taca and brother of Sandra and Bobby Kant. Reposing at Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Hwy., West Sayville, Tuesday 2-4:30p.m. and 7-9:30p.m. Funeral service Wednesday 11a.m. at the funeral home. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to: Hospice Care Network, Children's Bereavement Program, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, N.Y. 11590, or Fire Island Lighthouse Preservation Society, 4640 Captree Island, Captree Island, N.Y. 11702, appreciated.

title: Hiker's Bible Changes With God's Country; Latest 'New York Walk Book' Chronicles Nature's Losses and Surprising Gains
description: It was a ''noble gift,'' ''a kind of country club for the recreation of the educated and refined.'' That was the lyrical description of the rustic 13-mile Salt Hill hike in Upper Westchester, as celebrated in 1923 in the first edition of the ''New York Walk Book,'' the hiker's bible for the metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTON, GEORGE T.
description: NORTON-George T. Of Atlanta, GA. passed away on May 12, 1998. Born in New York City on April 22, 1910, he attended Columbia University with a B.A. in 1932, New York Law School LLB in 1941. He is survived by four sons: George, Jr. of Birmingham, William of Atlanta, John of Reston, VA., Douglas of Bernardsville, NJ, 10 grandchildren & 2 great grandchildren. He was former Vice President and General Manager of Utilities Mutual Insurance, New York City and member of The Downtown Association. Memorial Service, May 30, 4PM at Grace Episcopal Church, Plainfield, New Jersey 07060. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Grace Church.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with the obituary of Frank Sinatra referred incorrectly in some copies to an actress who appeared with him in the 1957 film ''Pal Joey.'' She was Kim Novak, not Novack.

title: A Master Stroke to the Yankees' Masterful Season
description: Managing the Yankees to a championship in 1996 was special to Joe Torre, but he says he feels he is part of something extraordinary this season. The Bronx's baseball team is challenging historical standards for excellence.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a lingering fear of violence in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan despite a drop in crime misstated the circumstances of a fatal shooting by the police in 1992 that prompted rioting. A grand jury found that the man who was killed had drawn a .38-caliber revolver; he was not unarmed.

title: High Cost of Bailing Out Bankers; A Poor Analogy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Break in Brawley Trial After Plaintiff Rests Case
description: Six months to the day after the Tawana Brawley defamation trial began, the lawyer for Steven A. Pagones rested his case yesterday.

title: Tadpoles to Aid Eye Studies
description: Tadpoles with eerie fluorescent green eyes may help researchers see in detail how eye disease develops.

title: Do Consent Forms Tell Enough? One Case From the Front Lines
description: ONE of the experiments whose consent process has come before the National Bioethics Advisory Commission is a study carried out at the Maryland Psychiatric Research Center at the University of Maryland in Baltimore, by Dr. Carol Tamminga and her colleagues.

title: High Cost of Bailing Out Bankers; Colonialist G-8
description: To the Editor:

title: California Governor Vetoes Bill On Bilingual Education Choices
description: Gov. Pete Wilson of California today vetoed a bill that would have given school districts broad freedom to select or discard bilingual education programs. In addition, the Governor announced for the first time that he was supporting a ballot initiative that would essentially eliminate bilingual education in the state.

title: Judges May Review Deportation Orders, Appeals Court Rules
description: In a significant rebuke to the Government's tougher policies on immigration, a United States appeals court has ruled that immigrants cannot be barred from contesting their deportation orders in Federal court.

title: Robbery Suspect Shot After Finding Escape Route Is Blocked
description: The jewel heist fell apart when it came time for the getaway. It all began when a man and a woman walked into Flanzer Jewelers at Eighth Avenue and 15th Street in Manhattan yesterday morning and pulled out a gun, menaced a customer, tied up the owner and emptied the safe, the police said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We should be happy to have a great American company like Microsoft.''

title: Wireless Unit Spinoff Called Near at Sprint
description: The Sprint Corporation is close to an agreement to spin off its wireless telephone business as a publicly traded company, allowing its cable television partners to escape a venture that never reached its lofty goals, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Frenchman Seeks the Rest Of Christie's
description: Francois Pinault, the French takeover investor and art collector who bought 29.1 percent of Christie's, the international auction house, for $243.2 million two weeks ago, announced yesterday that he intended to buy the rest of it in a deal that values the entire company at $1.2 billion.

title: Leaping Toward Liberation
description: Leaping and lifting become signs of liberation in Jerome Robbins's ''Glass Pieces,'' which the New York City Ballet presented on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Campaign Money Clout
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES AND BRITISH AIRWAYS SEEK IBERIA STAKE
description: American Airlines and British Airways P.L.C. plan to buy a 10 percent stake in Spain's flagship carrier Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana S.A., controlled by Sepi, a Spanish holding company, before the end of June. Under the Government's plan to sell the airline, British Airways and American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, would buy a 10 percent stake, to be followed by the sale of at least 50 percent of the carrier on the stock market. The United States Department of Transportation approved American's plan to share its reservation codes with Iberia last week. Analysts expect the carrier to be valued at 500 billion to 600 billion pesetas ($3.3 billion to $4 billion).

title: Policy by Anecdote
description: The debate over Proposition 227, the California ballot initiative on bilingual education, is not about education. It is about language, politics and, ultimately, race.

title: What to Serve for Dinner, When Dinner Is on Mars; Menu Is Vegetarian-Only -- If You Can Get a Table
description: HE task facing food scientists at Cornell University here is formidable: devising tasty, appealing, nutritious dishes for consumption on the Moon, Mars, Jupiter -- anywhere that astronauts might set up long-term housekeeping -- using only about two dozen foods from crops that can be grown hydroponically in space.

title: Up Amid the Neon, Smiles for Jell-O
description: The list of brands putting up their names in lights in Times Square is growing again as Kraft Foods signs an agreement for a spectacular sign to promote Jell-O desserts. The terms of the three-year lease were estimated at $4 million.

title: In the On-Deck Circle for the Punchless Mets: Frustration
description: The usually mild-mannered Bernard Gilkey was ejected for arguing a key called third strike. Al Leiter, without a victory for a month despite possessing the lowest earned run average in the major leagues, practically implored his offense to give him some runs to work with. Manager Bobby Valentine tore apart a plastic hanger during a post-game interview.

title: Kohl Paints Opponent As Far Leftist
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Europe's elder statesman and Germany's political colossus, launched his re-election campaign today with a harsh, personal attack on his main challenger, accusing Gerhard Schroder of steering the land toward a ''leftist republic.''

title: Stopping a Monopoly from Begetting Others
description: Some monopolies are good -- or at least inevitable.

title: Routine Screening For Prostate Cancer Is Said to Cut Deaths
description: A study announced here today provides the first evidence that routine screening of men for prostate cancer can substantially reduce the deaths from the disease.

title: Times Sq. Dilemma: So Many Tourists, So Few A.T.M.'s
description: Times Square may have the reputation of being the center of the universe, but it is a virtual black hole when it comes to finding an automated teller machine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONK, ANTONY
description: MONK-Antony. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted longtime member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Judith Schindler, Assoc. Rabbi

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 'Intelligence Gene' Only Fuels Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Office Depot in Deal for Direct Marketer
description: The intensely competitive world of paper clips and other office supplies grew more so yesterday when Office Depot said it would acquire Viking Office Products for $3 billion in stock.

title: New Jersey Legislators Vote To Overhaul Auto Insurance
description: Prodded by voter anger over paying the nation's highest automobile insurance rates, the New Jersey Legislature gave final approval today to a bill that would guarantee a 15 percent reduction in rates for most drivers.

title: Damaged Track Expected To Reopen for Weekend
description: Flemington Speedway is expected to be open this weekend, officials said, despite the collapse of a section of grandstand last Saturday in which five people suffered minor injuries.

title: San Francisco Journal; The Newsman and His Movie Queen
description: Long before his nuptials commanded breathless attention from supermarket tabloids and People magazine, Phil Bronstein was already well on his way to becoming a local legend.

title: Rabbi Moshe Sherer, 76, Who Contributed to Rise of Orthodoxy's Right Wing in U.S.
