description: Rabbi Moshe Sherer, who built a relatively small Orthodox Jewish organization, Agudath Israel of America, into a politically and religiously influential force among American Jewish groups, died Sunday afternoon in Manhattan. He was 76 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONNER, ALBERT
description: TONNER-Albert. Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to his family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: Belgium's Largest Bank Is to Be Acquired
description: Fortis, a Belgian-Dutch banking and insurance group, announced an agreement today to acquire Generale de Banque, Belgium's largest, for 409 billion Belgian francs, or $11.1 billion.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column of Science Times last Tuesday about dust mites misclassified fleas. They are insects, not members of the arachnid class, which includes dust mites.

title: Sports of The Times; Larry Bird the Coach Has to Make Changes
description: EARLIER this season, someone accused Larry Bird of treating his players like adults. The rookie coach of the Indiana Pacers -- and the recently anointed coach of the year -- smiled his slightly crooked smile. ''Sometimes,'' he said, ''they are.''

title: After Perfection, He's Toast of the Town
description: David Wells wonders how long his revel can last. It is not a probing self-analysis; he's too free spirited for that. But on the day after pitching a perfect game -- a day when he was the talk of Howard Stern's radio show and a guest on David Letterman's television show -- the Yankee left-hander sat at a table in a black leisure suit after his Letterman gig and twirled an empty bottle of water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, CHARLES D.
description: WEBSTER-Charles D. Of Islip, NY, on May 15, 1998 in his ninetythird year. He was the devoted husband of the late Natalie Peters Webster & is survived by nephews John W. Mitchell of Greenwich, CT, James Fitz of CA, and a niece Mary Mitchell of AZ. A graduate of Dartmouth College in 1926, he served as a naval officer during World War II. He had leadership and advisory roles in many diverse organizations concerned with wildlife and environmental conservation, scientific research, horticulture, the arts, and civic improvement. These included Chairman of the Board, The Seatuck Environmental Association, Islip, NY; Chairman Emeritus of The Horticultural Society of NY; Trustee, (1971-95) the Bayard Cutting Arboretum, Oakdale, NY; Director, International Wild Waterfowl Association, Jamestown, ND; Chairman Emeritus, Caribbean Conservation Corporation, Tallahassee FL; Field Associate in Ornithology, NY Zoological Society; Fellow, Old Westbury Gardens; Administrative Board, Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology; Chairman, Garden Committee, The Cloisters; Visiting Committee, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Medieval Art Dept.; Fellow, The Frick Collection; and many other organizations. Mr. Webster resided at ''Twyford'', located on the Seatuck National Wildlife Refuge, Islip NY. The refuge property was donated by Mr. Webster and his late wife to the Fish and Wildlife Service of the US Dept. of the Interior in 1968. A memorial service will be held at 11 A.M., on Friday, May 22nd, 1998, St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Islip, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Seatuck Environmental Association, P.O. Box 31, Islip NY 11751 or to St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 754 Montauk Highway, Islip NY 11751 would be appreciated.

title: 600 Laid Off In Hospitals As Deal Fails
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday ordered the immediate layoff of 600 public hospital workers, ending a tense confrontation in which a strong-willed labor leader defied the Mayor -- and other union leaders -- by refusing a package of benefits that was intended to soften the blow of impending cutbacks.

title: Metro Business; Grand Union Revises Plan
description: The Grand Union Company of Wayne, N.J., said yesterday that its shareholders and noteholders agreed to a revised revamping plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CONSTANCE KAUFMAN.
description: SOLOMON-Constance Kaufman. The Directors and staff of the Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding join our esteemed Board member, Adam Solomon, in mourning the loss of his beloved mother. Our hearts go out to his father, Tony Solomon, and the rest of the family. Connie died peacefully after a long illness. She remained spirited, elegant and valiant until the end. She will be greatly missed by all of us who knew and admired her. Georgette F. Bennett, President

title: Election Law Is Hot Topic in Congressional Primary
description: Dan Papermaster walked the streets of this affluent suburb, preaching a message that voters here have rarely heard: This town's political bosses, he told the voters, have worked to keep him off the Democratic primary ballot for Congress, and only by going to the polls Tuesday to vote for his slate of supporters can this injustice be righted.

title: Silent Night Therapy
description: PEOPLE with severe snoring problems sleep better and feel more rested after radio wave energy is used to shrink their soft palate tissue, a doctor has reported.

title: A Prosecutor Goes on the Defensive
description: If the name Donald Smaltz doesn't ring a bell, blame the competition. He is an independent counsel, but not that independent counsel. While Kenneth W. Starr has been reveling in the likes of Monica Lewinsky and Susan H. McDougal, Mr. Smaltz has been dogging Mike Espy, the former Agriculture Secretary, who has been indicted on charges of taking a few thousand dollars' worth of airplane trips, tickets to sports events and other ''gratuities'' from companies under his regulation.

title: Remediation at CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Psychiatric Researchers Under Fire
description: ANDREW BROWNSTEIN, a severe manic-depressive, was desperate. None of his medicines could keep the anxiety and depression of his illness at bay. So in the fall of 1994, he agreed to become a research subject at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md. It would put him, he recalls hoping, at ''the cutting edge of medicine,'' where he would learn much about his disorder and get superior treatment.

title: U.S. V. MICROSOFT: THE REACTION -- A Goliath Needs the Little Guys; Microsoft Faces Challenge of Image Among Consumers
description: As news of the Justice Department's impending historic assault on Microsoft spread this weekend, Robert Nolfe, 32, headed for his local computer superstore in the Los Angeles suburb of Burbank, not far from the headquarters of the Walt Disney Company. Having just designed his own Web site with Microsoft's word processing program, he was looking for a fancier tool: Microsoft Front Page.

title: The Firecracker Kid Is Perfect Inspiration
description: The legend grows.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS TO 6 1/2-YEAR LOW. The yen tumbled in a broad selloff of Asian currencies because of the Indonesia crisis. In New York, the dollar rose to 136.25 yen, from 134.52 yen Friday, the highest since September 1991.

title: Slaves, Not Prostitutes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERER, RABBI MOSHE.
description: SHERER-Rabbi Moshe. Outstanding leader of Torah Jewry whose essence reflected a boundless commitment to Klal Yisrael. He creatively united the Yeshiva and Chassidic worlds into a force for public advocacy, the dissemination of Torah and the defense of Jewish rights. A steadfast proponant of the Torah value of Jewish unity, he was an articulate and skilled spokesman for the American Orthodox community. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Orthodox Union Mandell I. Ganchrow, M.D., Pres. Marcel Weber, Ch. Bd of Directors Dr. Marcos Katz, Ch., Bd of Gov. Rabbi Raphael B. Butler, Exec V.P. Rabbi Pinchas Stolper, Sr. Exec

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHMAN, ALLAN
description: BACHMAN-Allan. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, trustee and former officer. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his bereaved wife, Sheila, to his children Ira, Mark and Michael and to the entire family. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus Mark Bunim, President

title: Where Fine Lines Blur
description: The Government explained its landmark antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation today as a principled defense of the time-tested, bedrock values of capitalism, protecting consumer choice and economic competition from the predatory assault of a modern monopolist.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Poetry and Merriment on 'Ice'
description: Prettiness, if unlike beauty, is not to be disdained. American Ballet Theater's revival of Frederick Ashton's delightful skating ballet, ''Les Patineurs,'' made the point on Saturday's mixed bills at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Winds Blamed for Levels Of Mercury in Fish
description: The same winds carrying pollutants from the Midwest that cause acid rain in the Adirondacks and Catskills appear to be the cause of elevated levels of mercury in some fish in one of New York City's upstate reservoirs, according to Federal geologists and New York City environmental officials.

title: Borough Park Mourns Jewish Luminary
description: The armada of yellow buses that usually clog the narrow streets of Borough Park, Brooklyn, shuttling students from yeshivas to their homes, was nowhere in sight yesterday. Instead, the streets were filled with thousands of people mourning the death of Rabbi Moshe Sherer, whom many considered the elder statesman of the American Orthodox Jewish community.

title: 4 in the Running For Sony Project
description: Sony Electronics said that it was seeking an agency to handle the fall introduction of HiFD, a computer data storage product, with billings of about $20 million. John Heenan, advertising director for Sony in Park Ridge, N.J., confirmed a report of the review in Adweek. ''We're looking at this as a project only,'' he said, adding that ''the current incumbents will continue to support their respective divisions.''

title: Excerpts From the Government's Lawsuit Filed Against Microsoft
description: The following are excerpts from a complaint filed against Microsoft by the United States in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.

title: New Deal May Loom for Simon & Schuster
description: The sale of Viacom's Simon & Schuster assets may not be over. Its chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, chose not to include the publisher's consumer trade company in the deal with Pearson P.L.C. and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst on Sunday for the educational and professional divisions. But several people close to the company said that he might still be seeking a joint venture partner to help spread its publishing costs over a larger business.

title: MCI Said to Be Soliciting Bids For a Division
description: Trying to placate regulators who are weighing its $37 billion sale to Worldcom Inc., the MCI Communications Corporation has quietly solicited bids for part of its fast-growing Internet business, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Man Working in Yard Discovers Body of Baby
description: A man doing yard work outside his sister's Long Island home yesterday discovered the body of a 6- to 9-month-old baby in a shallow grave, the police said. Investigators believe the baby was buried three to seven days ago.

title: High Cost of Bailing Out Bankers
description: To the Editor:

title: Alabama Governor's Race Tests Strength of Christian Conservatives
description: Even his campaign advisers are telling Gov. Fob James Jr. of Alabama to change the subject. But when it comes to his obsessive crusade to reconcile church and state, the Governor has maintained the relentless tenacity he once showed as a hunkered-down halfback for the Auburn University Tigers.

title: Whitman Announces Plan To Improve Transportation
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman outlined a $30 billion transportation plan today, a mix of new and existing initiatives with a focus on expanding mass transit and repairing bridges and highways.

title: More Polygram Bidders Seen Dropping Out
description: The team of Forstmann Little & Company and the Thomas H. Lee Company that had considered a bid for Polygram N.V. has decided not to make an all-cash offer for the company, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE GROUP INC., Miami, an insurance holding company, agreed to acquire MS Diversified Corp., of Jackson, Miss., a seller of extended automobile warranties, for $54.6 million in cash.

title: Kindergartner Chasing Bus Is Crushed Under Rear Wheel
description: A 6-year-old kindergarten student chasing a school bus he had just missed was crushed under its right rear wheel and killed when the bus made a right-hand turn yesterday morning in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Anthropologist Links A Shift in a Skull Bone To Face of Modern Man
description: ONE look at the face of a human being and the skull of a Neanderthal is enough to see a striking difference. The Neanderthal face projects out from the cranium. The human's is aligned more vertically, directly below the cranium. In fact, humans are unique among mammals in their lack of forward projecting faces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, ALAN D.
description: WILLIAMS-Alan D. May 16, 1998. Loving husband of Robin Rue. Devoted father of Wistar Rawls, Anne, Marjorie & Rosina Williams. Grandfather of Alan Rawls, William and Alice Noah. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to New York University Medical Center, 530 First Ave., New York, N.Y. 10016 or St. Luke's School, 487 Hudson St., New York, N.Y. 10014. Memorial service on Wednesday, May 27, 4 P.M., The Century Association, 7 W. 43 St.

title: NBC Shifts 'Frasier' To Defend Thursdays
description: NBC moved yesterday to defend its longtime stronghold of hits on Thursday night by replacing the most popular comedy of the past five years, ''Seinfeld,'' with the most award-winning comedy of the past five years, ''Frasier.''

title: Topics of The Times; Help for Battered Women
description: Under current New York State law, any person convicted of a violent crime is not eligible for work release. That usually makes sense, but exceptions could be made for battered women convicted of violent crimes without endangering society at large. Repeated abuse drives some women to assault or kill their abusers. Most of them have no prior criminal record and are unlikely to commit other crimes. They are therefore logical candidates for work-release programs that bridge the transition from prison to community life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIT, ILENE
description: FEIT-Ilene. Wife of Philbert. Mother of Scott, Mark, Jacqueline, and Marianne. Grandmother of Spencer, Zachary, Kaela, and Matthew. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 11:30AM, Wednesday.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: In a Suharto Fief, 'Hang Suharto!'
description: For four hours this afternoon, a line of battle-ready soldiers stood at the top of the broad staircase leading into the Parliament building, their rifles at the ready, their gas masks and riot helmets hanging at their hips.

title: Remediation at CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Finalists Disclosed In Two Big Reviews
description: Two advertisers disclosed finalists yesterday in large account reviews.

title: Foreign Affairs; Who Is Bibi?
description: Surely it must mean something. How can it not?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIGER, MARVIN
description: TIGER-Marvin. The Board of Trustees of The Brookdale University Hospital & Medical Center record with profound sorrow the untimely death of our beloved and distinguished Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Marvin Tiger joined Brookdale in 1994. His dedication to the healthcare sector of over 30 years and his leadership in the financial management of this institution has enabled us to flourish as a leading provider of healthcare in the community. Marvin Tiger also served as Past President of the Healthcare Financial Management Association. Our condolences to his wife Michele and daughters Lisa McKinnon and husband Ewen; Caryn Paillex and husband Bruce, and to his sister Roberta Tavss. The family requests that all charitable contributions be forwarded to: The International Myeloma Foundation, 2129 Stanley Hill Drive, Los Angeles, CA 90046. 800452-CURE or fax 213-656-1182. Edwin L. Schulman, Chairman David I. Schachne, Chairman, Executive Committee

title: Rumors of Mideast Deal Bring Denials, Fueling More Rumors
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and American officials in Europe and Washington today denied news reports here that Israel had agreed to the 13 percent withdrawal from the West Bank sought by the Clinton Administration.

title: High Stakes for Suharto: No Graceful Way Out?
description: Faced with mounting demands for his resignation, President Suharto may see his options narrowing to a choice that could be catastrophic for the entire region: crush or be crushed.

title: Guest Conductor Offers A Composer He Favors
description: There is no shortage of familiar repertory from the Mahler-Strauss wing of the early 20th century. Yet several significant musicians have been trying to make space there for Alexander von Zemlinsky, who was born in Vienna in 1871 and died in Larchmont, N.Y., in 1942. Chief among Zemlinsky's advocates is the conductor James Conlon, who led an involving performance of ''Die Seejungfrau,'' a fantasy for orchestra, with the New York Philharmonic on Friday afternoon.

title: Halting Loans Isn't Enough, Both Parties Tell Clinton
description: The Clinton Administration came under intense attack in the Senate today for its unwillingness to call on President Suharto of Indonesia to step down, even as the United States and its allies changed policy by indefinitely suspending a $43 billion economic bailout of the country.

title: The Birth Of a Novel: Up North, Down South
description: When Richard Price took off for Union, S.C., four years ago to join the media mob following the Susan Smith child abduction case, he wasn't quite sure what he was looking for, but he knew he wasn't going to find all of it south of the Mason-Dixon line.

title: A Drug-Money Sting Nets Mexico Bankers
description: A Federal grand jury in Los Angeles charged three Mexican banks and 26 Mexican bankers with laundering millions of dollars in drug profits, culminating a huge three-year sting operation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OVEIS, NORA E. (NEE LACEY).
description: OVEIS-Nora E. (nee Lacey). On May 16, 1998. Of the Bronx and Holmes, New York. Wife of the late Frank. She is survived by her son Frank and his companion Thomas Struhs and by her son Dennis and his wife Ann and their son Alexander. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox and Sons, Inc., 201st Street and Grand Concourse, Bronx, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday at 10 A.M., St. Philip Neri Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIRECTOR, NATHAN
description: DIRECTOR-Nathan. NCJW, New York Section, is saddened by the death of ''Pete'' Director, beloved husband of Phyllis. Sincerest condolences to the family. Bernice Friedes, Co-Pres. Jean Krosner, Co-Pres.

title: This Is We Want More of Your Money Day
description: Don't worry if you didn't send chocolates or roses. For the record, though, yesterday was not just any day -- it was ''Don't Do Dishes Day.''

title: Savvy Jazz Takes Command in the West
description: John Stockton knew what the Los Angeles Lakers were thinking after their Game 1 debacle on Saturday, that humbling feeling of searching for your confidence amid the wreckage of a rout.

title: A New Lightweight Portable Printer Yields Some Heavyweight Results
description: TRAVELING virtuosos of the computer keyboard quickly master the art of being on the go without a printer. For those times when nothing but a piece of paper will do, no matter how ugly, you can use your modem to fax a crucial document to yourself at your hotel.

title: Tokyo Journal; Like the Geisha, the Good-Time Bar Is Endangered
description: For six years Takashi Katakura has made weekly visits to a tiny bar where a cuddly hostess pours whisky for him as he tries to talk business with his colleagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HISCOX, EDWARD M.
description: HISCOX-Edward M. May 15, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Maggie E. Gerig Hiscox. Devoted father of Patricia Ann and Pamela Jane. Beloved friend of Charlie Gerig, Leo and Anneliese Bannwart of Lucerne, Switzerland. You will always be our hero, our best friend and the love of our lives. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, May 20, 7-9 PM, with a service at 8 PM. High Mass service will be held on Friday, May 22, 10:30 AM, at Holy Innocents Church, 128 West 37th Street, New York City. Mom and Dad you are always with us and we are always with you.

title: Excerpts From the Lawsuit Filed by 20 State Attorneys General
description: The following are excerpts from the complaint filed yesterday against Microsoft by 20 state Atorneys General in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.

title: Reel 1, Dazzling Hope; Reel 2, Dimmer Results; Dreamworks Disappoints Hollywood by Being Merely Successful
description: Will the powerful players at Dreamworks, who have suffered a surprising slump, finally score a home run?

title: PETERSEN COMPANIES TO BUY 2 STEREOPHILE MAGAZINES
description: The Petersen Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two magazines, Stereophile and Stereophile Guide to Home Theatre, from Stereophile Inc. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Stereophile is a monthly publication that reviews high-end audio components. Stereophile Guide to Home Theatre, which is published 10 times a year, provides information on video and multichannel audio technologies. Petersen, based in Los Angeles, publishes special-interest magazines including Motor Trend, Hot Rod, Teen and Skin Diver, with more than 70 million readers.

title: Topics of The Times; Starving Legal Services
description: As lawmakers in Albany weigh trying to restore some of the programs imprudently vetoed by Gov. George Pataki last month, two small items with big implications for fair justice should not be overlooked. The items are $7 million blanked out by the Governor for civil legal services for the poor and $4.8 million deleted for Prisoners' Legal Services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTIROCCO, MATTHEW M.
description: SANTIROCCO-Matthew M. On May 16, 1998. Attorney and former teacher Cardinal Hayes High School. Beloved husband of Mary, loving son of Matthew. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Nicholas of Tolentine Church, Bronx, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINATRA, FRANK
description: SINATRA-Frank. In memory of Francis Albert Sinatra. Sadly missed by your friends in Lakeglen Close, Belfast, Ireland.

title: Cardinal Health in Surprise $2.2 Billion Deal
description: Out to broaden its reach within the pharmaceutical industry, Cardinal Health Inc., one of the nation's largest drug wholesalers, said yesterday that it would buy the R. P. Scherer Corporation for $2.2 billion in stock.

title: Menacing Mutants Who Like Junk Food
description: It's not as if anyone at the Fox network expected people to say, ''Now that we've seen 'Gargantua' we don't have to bother with that 'Godzilla' movie.'' Their made-for-television monster flick is an attempt to hitch a ride on the reptilian tail of all that ''Godzilla'' publicity.

title: Sighting No. 1 While Only 12
description: The final bell at Junior High School 226 sent a wave of screaming children crashing onto the streets along Rockaway Boulevard in the South Ozone Park section of Queens.

title: Akinwande Misses The Plane to the Train
description: Henry Akinwande and Thomas Hearns were supposed to spar yesterday at Penn Station, part of a public workout in advance of Akinwande's June 6 heavyweight title bout against Evander Holyfield. But Akinwande missed his flight from Orlando, Fla., to New York and by the time he descended a staircase into the lobby for Amtrak and New Jersey Transit passengers, two hours late, Hearns had stolen his thunder.

title: Finding a Route to Victory In a Maze of Uncertainties
description: Chess is shot through with ambiguities and uncertainties. When you sacrifice concrete values -- rooks or knights -- for a less tangible attack, are you bluffing or creating a work of art? Your opponent has to expend a lot of mental effort to figure out your intentions, whether they stand a chance of being realized and what to do about the situation.

title: U.S. V. MICROSOFT
description: QUESTION OF IMAGE -- Microsoft must now try to keep buyers on its side. Page D1.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about two Indonesian generals misstated the former colonial power in East Timor, which was invaded and annexed by Indonesia in the 1970's. It was Portugal, not the Netherlands.

title: French Utility Bids For Belgian Company
description: Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. offered 25 billion French francs ($4.1 billion) for the 37 percent of Societe Generale de Belgique S.A. it does not own, allowing the utility to expand in Belgian electricity and gas.

title: Peru, Epicenter Of El Nino, Fears For Its Wildlife; Some Lean Years Lie Ahead For Seals, Sea Lions And Other Beach Dwellers If Ocean Waters Get Warmer
description: POPULATIONS of marine mammals and seabirds on the coast of Peru, including an endangered penguin species, were devastated in the now-fading El Nino, the strongest one of the century.

title: Patterns
description: A Makeover for Laura Ashley

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Attacks Microsoft In 2 Broad Antitrust Suits

title: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds
description: Culminating a three-year undercover sting operation described as the largest case of laundering drug money in American history, a Federal grand jury in Los Angeles today charged three Mexican banks and 26 Mexican bankers with laundering millions of dollars in drug profits.

title: No Sympathy for Gates in Parts of Silicon Valley
description: The Microsoft Corporation's many dependents offered a muted reaction to today's suits by the Department of Justice and state Attorneys General, but the software maker's outspoken adversaries called the action a major step toward dismantling its dominance.

title: 'Intelligence Gene' Only Fuels Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENINGTON, MATHILDE JOHNSTON.
description: BENINGTON-Mathilde Johnston. Mathilde Johnston Benington died Saturday, May 16, 1998 in Hobe Sound, FL. Beloved wife of the late Arthur, devoted mother of Mathilde and George. Survived also by her sister Molly Brent Lucas, step-sister Edwina Shea Millington, and sister-in-law Edwina Leggett. A memorial service will be held at noon on Tuesday, May 26, 1998 at First Presbyterian Church, New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice of Martin & St. Lucie, Inc. 2030 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL. 34996.

title: Liveries Aren't Rushing to Get Street Hails
description: On the day that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began allowing livery cars, limousines and commuter vans to pick up curbside customers, livery drivers and owners appeared to shrug off the offer, while lawyers for the yellow-cab industry prepared to go to court to block the Mayor's directive.

title: Bombardier Plane Order
description: Bombardier Inc. said today that Germany's Augsburg Airways had ordered four Dash 8 Series 300 aircraft and two Dash 8 Series 200 aircraft in a contract valued at $78 million. The turboprop planes will come in 50-seat and 37-seat configurations. The contract was originally signed in November for three firm aircraft, and was increased to six aircraft. Augsburg also has options on seven additional Dash 8 planes. The Series 400 is in certification flight tests. It is scheduled to enter airline service in the first quarter of 1999, Bombardier said.

title: U.S. AND 20 STATES FILE SUITS CLAIMING MICROSOFT BLOCKS COMPETITION OVER INTERNET
description: The Federal Government and 20 state Attorneys General filed two broad, aggressive antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corporation today, launching the most concerted government attack on a single company in a generation.

title: Major Indexes Show Decline For a Third Consecutive Day
description: Major stock market indexes fell for the third consecutive trading day yesterday on the dampened demand from investors concerned about the chaos in Indonesia and the Government's legal action against the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORGENSTERN, STANLEY A.
description: MORGENSTERN-Stanley A. In the circle of life remembering Stanley A. Morgenstern. Forever in my heart. 7/18/36-5/19/97.

title: Alcohol Use Skews Mental Illness Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Morality Tales Rooted in Dark Secrets
description: The plays of William Inge have always seemed something of a poor relation to those of Tennessee Williams, and an evening of five Inge one-acts being presented by the Willow Cabin Theater Company under the title ''Bus (Riley) and Company'' offers ample evidence why.

title: Panel Weighs Testimony On Insurers Of Nazi Era
description: Evidence of widespread Nazi theft of the insurance assets of European Jews in collusion with German and other European insurance companies was presented yesterday in Manhattan. The sources were Nazi-era documents, insurance experts and a few Holocaust survivors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, ERNI (NEE AARON).
description: WALDMAN-Erni (nee Aaron). On May 18, 1998. Age 74. Funeral private. Interment in Mount Holly, Vermont.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROAD, MONROE MAXIMILIAN, MD.
description: BROAD-Monroe Maximilian, MD. 25 February 1909-19 May 1987. In Loving Remembrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, MORTON
description: ROSENTHAL-Morton. The members of the City Athletic Club mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Morton Rosenthal, and wish to express heartfelt sympathy to his family. Board of Governors

title: Ending Silence, Suharto Insists On Staying Put Until Elections
description: President Suharto addressed the nation today, saying ''I am not drunk with power,'' but insisting that he would stay in office to oversee broad-ranging reforms that would lead to new presidential elections in which he would not take part.

title: Giuliani Is Quick to Point Out Another Drop in Crime Rate
description: Crime in New York City continued its six-year decline during 1997, according to statistics released yesterday by the F.B.I., as the number of crimes reported in the city fell by 7 percent. Once again, the city's crime reduction outpaced the statistics for other cities with more than one million residents, which experienced an overall drop in crime of 5 percent.

title: Real Quiet Arrives In Louisville
description: Real Quiet, the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner, returned to Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky., yesterday to begin training for the final jewel in the Triple Crown, the Belmont Stakes on June 6.

title: Miller and Faldo Inducted Amid Fanfare of New Hall
description: Some of the greatest names in golf history gathered on one podium today: Gene Sarazen, Sam Snead, Kathy Whitworth, Nancy Lopez, Lee Trevino and Arnold Palmer, among others.

title: Gardens and Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST CHARTER TO BUY HFNC FINANCIAL FOR $241 MILLION
description: The First Charter Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the HFNC Financial Corporation for $241 million in stock, more than doubling its business in the Charlotte, N.C., area. First Charter will swap 0.57 share for each share of HFNC, the parent of Home Federal Savings and Loan Association, in a tax-free pooling of interests worth $13.97 a share based on its closing price Friday. The purchase will give First Charter another $980 million in assets and 10 branches in the Charlotte region. First Charter, based in Concord, N.C., has $776 million in assets and 23 branches in and around North Carolina's capital city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, MILTON
description: HALPERN-Milton, 92. Unexpectedly on May 16. Adored husband of Gertrude for 51 years. Beloved father, father-in-law, grandfather, brother, brother-in-law, uncle, great-uncle, musician, mentor and friend. At his request, no services.

title: To Clear Air With Europe, U.S. Waives Some Sanctions
description: Trying to resolve two of the toughest disputes between the United States and Europe, the Clinton Administration waived sanctions today against three foreign companies that are doing business in Iran and said that it would seek legislation to head off sanctions against businesses that operate in Cuba.

title: For a Grand New York Stage, 119 Fine Sets
description: IF Grand Central Terminal is a ''gigantic stage on which are played a thousand dramas daily'' -- the booming lead-in to the 1930's radio soap opera ''Grand Central Station'' -- then Robert F. Works and Michael J. Ewing are at the start of the second act, with people still moving the scenery around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, RUTH RITA (NEE JESELSON)
description: WILSON-Ruth Rita (nee Jeselson), RN. Died on May 16 at St. Camillus Health Center, Stamford, Ct. Beloved wife of the late John A. Wilson and stepmother of Ethel Arlene Wilson and the late John Wilson, Jr. Survived by nieces and nephews, notably Dorothy Jeselson Nicholson of Savannah, Ga. and her daughters Maura, Tara and Ann Frances along with other loving grand-nieces and nephews. Visitation at the Leo Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. from 9:30AM to 10:30AM Wednesday May 20. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 11AM May 20 in St. Michael's Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. Burial will follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Coloring a Black-and-Beige World
description: Say to people in the fashion world that there is no color on the runways and no color in the stores, and they'll say: ''There is color. There's white, off-white, beige . . . .''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCWILLIAMS, CATHERINE MABE,
description: McWILLIAMS-Catherine Mabe, 53, of New York, NY and West Point Island, NJ. Owner of Fairfax Physical Therapy and Fitness, New York. Former director of Physical Therapy Lenox Hill Hospital. Graduate of Caldwell College for Women Caldwell, NJ and The Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, Physical Therapy Degree Program. Wife of James Marren. Daughter of Elizabeth ''Josephine'' McWilliams. Sister of Mrs. Andrea Smith. Aunt of Christine Smith, Caryn Paravecchio, & Andrea Smith. Family will receive friends on Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, NY Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Timothy E. Ryan Home for Funerals, 706 Grand Central Ave. Lavallette, New Jersey. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered on Thursday 11AM, at St. Bonaventure RC Church, Lavallette, NJ. Burial will follow at St. Joseph Cemetery, Toms River, NJ. The family has asked for donations to The Columbia University Physical Therapy Scholarship Fund, NY, NY.

title: RESIDENTS' HOURS TERMED EXCESSIVE IN HOSPITAL STUDY
description: Almost a decade after New York State passed laws to protect patients by reducing the grueling hours of medical residents, an investigation of 12 hospitals by state medical officials has found that all 12 consistently break the laws, that many residents work longer than 24 hours straight and that more than half of surgical residents work more than 95 hours a week.

title: Markets Editor Joining Times Editorial Board
description: Floyd Norris, markets editor and columnist for The New York Times, is joining the paper's editorial board. His appointment was announced yesterday by Howell Raines, editorial page editor.

title: Keeping Nuclear Arms in Check
description: India's nuclear weapons tests threaten to undo 35 years worth of work by the United States and other countries to limit the spread of nuclear arms. Instead of abandoning those efforts and improvising new approaches, a course recommended by some arms control experts, Washington and its allies should redouble their commitment to make the international control system work effectively.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Rule for 2 Defendants, and Reveal a Divide
description: A pair of Supreme Court decisions today in which criminal defendants won the right to new hearings offered a tantalizing glimpse of a fault line between the Justices that is not often seen: a division not between conservatives and liberals, but within the conservative bloc itself.

title: Standings Still Show Orioles in A.L., Barely
description: Are the Baltimore Orioles still in the American League?

title: Two Retailers In Deal Worth $2.9 Billion
description: In one of the largest department store mergers in recent years, Dillard's Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the Mercantile Stores Company, a Midwest retailer, for $2.9 billion in cash.

title: Metro Business; Newspaper Concern Continues Expansion
description: The Journal Register Company of Trenton, N.J., announced yesterday that it had signed a contract to buy five daily newspapers and 20 other publications from the Goodson Newspaper Group of Lawrenceville, N.J., for $300 million.

title: HOME PROPERTIES TO BUY 4,000 APARTMENT UNITS
description: Home Properties of New York Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a portfolio of 4,000 apartment units in 17 communities in the Northeast and Midwest from an unidentified seller for $155 million in cash. Home Properties, based in Rochester, is a real estate investment trust that operates 231 apartment communities with 26,090 units in the Northeast and Midwest, including properties in New York, Michigan, Pennsylvania, Maryland, New Jersey, Virginia, Connecticut, Ohio and Indiana. Home Properties also manages 1.7 million square feet of commercial space.

title: Senate Approves Measure On Deadly Force in Home
description: The use of deadly force, even before attempting to flee, would be an acceptable defense against domestic violence in a victim's own home, under a bill passed 34-0 yesterday by the State Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWORDS, JAMES J.
description: SWORDS-James J., 63. Of Brooklyn on May 17, 1998. Brother of Donald F. Swords; and uncle of Liam and Alana Swords. Calling hours will be held at the Higgins Memorial Home, 20 Center St., Freehold Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9PM. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated at St. Rose of Lima Church Friday at 10AM, followed by interment at St. Rose of Lima Cemetery, Freehold. Memorial donations to the American Diabetes Association would be appreciated.

title: Q&A
description: Bird Olfaction

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANKOOS, HARRY
description: TANKOOS-Harry. Age 83, formerly of Great Neck, NY, died May 16, in Boca Raton. Devoted husband of Meryl. Loving father of Susan, Alan and Amy. Beloved grandfather of Michael, Rebeccah and Sophie. Interment private.

title: Highway Bill Accord Rejects Tougher Standard on Alcohol
description: Congressional negotiators said today that they had reached broad agreement on a $200 billion transportation bill but had rejected a tough new national standard for drunken driving, a move that was immediately denounced by highway safety groups as a capitulation to the liquor lobby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWKES, JOHN
description: HAWKES-John. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of literature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEDINE, EDITH D.
description: MEDINE-Edith D., 89, Arlington, VA., formerly of West Palm Beach. Survived by her beloved husband William; children Amy Stein, Laurie and Art Alexander, grandchildren Eric, Tony, George and Mary Stein, Paul, Stacia, Peter and Nancy Saperstone, great grandchildren Amanda, Zachary and Emily. Edith, and her husband, Bill, were the Founding Directors of Camp Echo Lake, Warrensburg, New York, 1946-1964. Her warmth and vivacity set a tone for her campers and the two generations that follow. Palm Beach paper copy.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHT, LEE
description: WACHT-Lee. At age 93 on May 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Harvey. Loving mother-in-law of Judy. Cherished grandmother of Lauren and Michael. Dear sister of Philip Hirschhorn. Funeral services private. Contributions may be made to United Hebrew Geriatric Center, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Mastectomy Alternative Often Ignored, Study Says
description: Tens of thousands of American women with breast cancer are losing a breast unnecessarily each year because their doctors do not follow national guidelines in treating the breast cancer, the first comprehensive study of current practices shows.

title: Chanteys Of Labor And Loss
description: From 1980 to 1985, when they were two-thirds of the Minutemen, the bassist Mike Watt and the singer-guitarist D. Boon wrote dozens of songs that referred to the band members by name. To go with their punk-funk miniatures, they amassed a language of oblique inside jokes; their songs could sometimes seem like film shorts about themselves, complete with their own lingo and constant references to their hometown, San Pedro, Calif.

title: Limited Reports Rise in Earnings
description: Limited Inc. said today that fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 34 percent, as sales rose at its women's clothing stores, including the Limited and Express chains.

title: Court Says Public TV Debates Can Bar Fringe Candidates
description: Government-owned television stations that sponsor candidate debates have the editorial discretion to exclude fringe or minor-party candidates who have little chance of success, the Supreme Court ruled today, as long as the exclusion is not based on the candidates' views.

title: Still Barred From the Main House
description: Earlier this month, I went to Monticello in Charlottesville, Va., for the first time in more than 10 years to attend the annual meeting of the Monticello Association, a group of about 800 descendants of Thomas Jefferson. Its members own the graveyard behind the house and have decreed that only the direct descendants of Jefferson are allowed to be buried there.

title: Benefits of Assistant for Childbirth Go Far Beyond the Birthing Room
description: AS a physician's assistant, Marcia Gaddy has delivered many babies, but the first time she went into labor, she panicked. ''I didn't know what to do,'' she said. ''I was very scared and I felt very alone, even though my husband was there to hold my hand.''

title: Ferraro Assails D'Amato Over Breast Cancer Effort
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro sought yesterday to undercut Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's effort to present himself as a champion of victims of breast cancer, asserting that he was a captive of the insurance industry who was pushing breast cancer legislation that served ''the interests of insurance companies.''

title: Gardens and Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; Summer Heels Take a Drop
description: Even Manolo Blahnik, the king of the stiletto, is aware that such towering heels have a limited appeal and are not for all women. He has also designed graceful midhigh heels that are slim, with a slight curve.

title: Disqualified by M&M's
description: EVER given peanut M&M's to a horse?

title: From the Andes to Epcot, the Adventures of an 8,000-Year-Old Bean
description: WHAT may be the world's oldest bean has driven Daniel Debouck, a Belgian plant geneticist, in and out of Andean mountains and valleys from Bolivia to Ecuador for 20 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIFKA, BELLE
description: SLIFKA-Belle. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Ruth Mindling, Lew Spence and Evelyn (Jerome Dilloff). Beloved grandmother of Jim Mindling, Leni (Robert Newman), Toni (John Schulman) and Nancy (Andrew Schlesinger). Loving greatgrandmother of Meg Newman, Rachel Schlesinger, Jessie and Abby Schulman and Natasha Mindling. Passed away peacefully in her sleep after a long and full life. Services were held.

title: Senate Votes to Increase Number of Foreigners Allowed in U.S. to Fill Technology Jobs
description: Heeding the calls of the high-technology industry, the Senate voted today to increase the number of foreign workers who would be allowed into the United States to fill thousands of short-term computer programming and other similar jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, JAMES
description: McINTYRE-James. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of James McIntyre, former Director of Development, who did so much to bring about the restoration and renovation of Carnegie Hall and its performance spaces. Isaac Stern, President Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Judith Arron, Executive Director

title: County Attorney Cleared In a Dispute Over Ethics
description: The former Westchester County Attorney and her deputy did nothing unethical when they negotiated the spinoff of a hospital from the county government and then went to work as the hospital's top lawyers, a legal ethicist who was hired by the hospital said in a 50-page opinion released yesterday.

title: Sour Note in the Viagra Symphony
description: WHEN a revolutionary new treatment is discovered for a life-limiting condition, millions of sufferers are likely to forsake caution in hope of reaping its benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWECK, HARRY S., M.D.
description: DWECK-Harry S., M.D. The Dept. of Pediatrics of New York Medical College/Westchester Medical Center mourns the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague. A giant in the field of neonatology, he pioneered innovative care for sick infants. He established the Regional Tertiary Care Neonatal Center in Westchester and fostered ideals and standards that will improve quality of life for sick infants for generations to come. He will be surely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLMAN, JANE
description: COLMAN-Jane. On May 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Seymour, devoted mother of Cathy and Peter and mother-in-law of Rose. Cherished grandmother of Hillary Roth, and Molly Colman. Memorial service will be Friday, May 22, 10 AM at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church -Dana Chapel, 921 Madison Avenue at 73rd Street.

title: The Minimalist; A Grilled Tuna Pocket Overflowing With Greens
description: A FEW years ago around Memorial Day, a friend and I were about to grill a two-inch slab of tuna. We made a quick marinade and washed some greens for a salad. And in a flash of inspiration, we decided to combine everything on the counter in one dish.

title: Temptation; A Creamy Taramosalata, at a Store With a Fan Club
description: NINTH AVENUE INTERNATIONAL, the Greek foods store right behind the Port Authority Bus Terminal, is filled with dazzling displays of nuts, legumes, grains, olives, spices, cheeses and olive oil at rock-bottom prices. The grocery selection is wonderful -- no question -- but for an immediate goodness fix, head directly to the counter and ask for a container of taramosalata.

title: Test Kitchen; Time to Dust Off That Blender? (Or Check Into These)
description: THE season for cold drinks, cold soups and smoothies is fast approaching, and soon a familiar whirring sound will be heard across the land.

title: Calpers Raising Stake in Fund $275 Million
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System said it would increase its investment in Relational Investors L.L.C., an activist fund, to about $500 million.

title: Letting There Be Light at Kennedy Airport
description: Anew airline terminal, a technological cathedral of glass and space and natural light, is about to open at Kennedy International Airport. The New York Times critic has hailed it as ''dazzling,'' an ''excellent building,'' one ''packed with a breathtaking amount of thrust.''

title: Coronado May Not Make Met
description: Coronado's Quest, the morning-line favorite who was scratched the day before the Preakness Stakes, walked around his barn at Belmont Park yesterday to test the bruise on his right rear foot, but some doubt was expressed that he would recover in time to run in the Metropolitan Mile on Monday.

title: On the Diamond, Perfection Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Sinatra Gave the Voice To Sports' Soundtrack
description: WITH a 10-9 lead in Super Bowl XXI, the Denver Broncos had hurried to their locker room at halftime with John Denver's ''Rocky Mountain High'' floating over the Rose Bowl public-address system. But now, as the Giants emerged for the second half, punt-returner Phil McConkey was wildly waving a towel and Frank Sinatra's voice was booming, ''It's up to you, New York, Neeew Yoork.'' In the stands, the Giant loyalists roared.

title: QUANTUM AGREES TO PAY $300 MILLION FOR ATL PRODUCTS
description: The Quantum Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the computer tape-library maker ATL Products Inc. for $29 a share, or about $300 million, in stock and said it would buy back as many as 14 million of its shares. The buyback, valued at $311.5 million based on Monday's closing share price, would wipe out about 9.2 percent of Quantum's shares outstanding and is aimed at offsetting dilution from the shares issued to ATL for the purchase. Buying ATL will add to Quantum's existing tape-storage business. ATL, based in Irvine, Calif., is a maker of high-end tape libraries, while Quantum makes the drives that go into the machines. Quantum, based in Milpitas, Calif., also makes smaller, less sophisticated tape libraries. Shares of Quantum rose 25 cents, to $22.50. ATL fell18.75 cents, to $26.5625.

title: In Seattle, Bill Gates Is Still a Hometown Hero
description: The money-making machine at the Microsoft Corporationpurred along today, the soldiers of software touting their new operating system while assuring friends and colleagues that no, the ride was not over. Not by any stretch.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARAN, JACQUES
description: HARAN-Jacques. May 19, your birthday. You're missed and loved by all your friends. Pensees... William Franz Feldman

title: James Carlton Tucker, Sailing Champion, 38
description: James Carlton Tucker, a national sailing champion in multihulls, died last Thursday at the Fort Walton Beach Medical Center in Florida. He was 38.

title: Liberties; Center Holding
description: Here is what you need to know about the Irish soul.

title: QWEST COMMUNICATIONS EXTENDS FIBER OPTICS NETWORK
description: Qwest Communications International Inc. plans to announce today that it has activated five new segments of its transcontinental fiber optic communications network with a combined length of 3,051 miles. With its high-speed network, Qwest, which is based in Denver, is attempting to become the latest long-distance company to shake up the telecommunications industry. The additions bring the total extent of Qwest's system to almost 8,500 miles. By the second quarter of next year Qwest intends to complete a network of 18,409 miles, connecting 130 cities.

title: Crude Oil Prices Fall 8% as Supplies Soar
description: Crude oil prices tumbled 8 percent yesterday to their lowest in almost a decade, reflecting the pressure caused by bountiful supplies and full storage tanks nationwide.

title: China Issue Resists Usual White House Defenses
description: The White House scandal-control brigade has answered many a call, from Arkansas real estate deals gone sour to the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit, and has always found a way to mount a vigorous counteroffensive.

title: Call for Review of Stops By the State Police
description: Following the shootings of three young minority men by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike last month, two state legislators called yesterday for the creation of a bipartisan panel to investigate whether the State Police stop motorists based on race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAFFREY, BERNARD MICHAEL
description: McCAFFREY-Bernard Michael. Of Atlantic Beach, New York, on May 17th, 1998. Graduate of Manhattan College. Executive Director of St. Mary's Hospital, Brooklyn for 25 years. Beloved husband of the late Patricia Elizabeth (nee Connelly). Loving father of Eileen, Christopher, Michele Miranda, Steven and Brian. Dear father-inlaw to Christine and Dominick. Adored grandfather of Saoirse Patricia Miranda. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y. today and tomorrow 2-4, 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Martyr R.C. Church, Long Beach, Friday, 11:15 A.M. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations to Winthrop Eager Breathers, C/O Winthrop Hospital, Mineola, N.Y. or St. Mary's Hospital in Mr. McCaffrey's name would be appreciated.

title: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting
description: Mexican officials sought today to belittle the results of a huge United States undercover operation that exposed the laundering of drug money in 12 Mexican banks.

title: Decline in Gun Violence Bypasses Philadelphia
description: For all the years he spent as a criminal and a drug user, Jose Rojas never saw the kinds of things now taking place in working-class neighborhoods like his in north Philadelphia.

title: Manetta Starts To Make Calls
description: The St. John's University athletic director, Ed Manetta, began the official process yesterday of calling other schools for permission to speak to the prospective coaches on his list as he seeks a replacement for Fran Fraschilla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUGHTON, GAYNOR B.
description: HOUGHTON-Gaynor B. Essex, CT. died May 18. Wife of David A. Houghton Sr, mother of David Jr, Michael, Peter and Constance, sister of Burt, Conna, Barbara, and Faith. Service May 21, 10:30 AM, Our Lady of Sorrows Church, Prospect Street, Essex, CT.

title: Inside Beltway, Microsoft Sheds Its Image as Outsider
description: Whether it is giving free computer software to the Republicans, making hefty campaign contributions or hiring some of Washington's priciest and best-connected lobbyists, the Microsoft Corporation is quickly maturing from a novice in the ways of Washington to one of the most active players on Capitol Hill.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about NBC's prime-time programs for the fall season, and a list of them, misstated the title of a new show, and the list misstated the time for another. The new show is ''Wind on Water,'' not ''Wind on the Water''; ''Third Rock From the Sun'' is to be shown on Wednesday nights at 9, not 8:30.

title: N.F.L. Symposium to Stress Head-Coaching Jobs for Blacks
description: When George Young was general manager of the Giants, he took his share of criticism. From some of his draft picks to the coaches he hired, his decisions always prompted someone to take shots at him. Yet Young persevered because he stayed true to what he believed, and in the end, most of the time, he was proved right.

title: Utah Is Keeping It Simple And Just Keeps Winning
description: Pick-and-Roll U. is still dissecting Run-and-Gun State, one possession at a time.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about Ingram Entertainment's plans to distribute videocassettes on line misstated the ownership of the company. It is an independent company; it is no longer a division of Ingram Industries.

title: Queens Grocer Charged In Death of Couple
description: A Queens greengrocer was arrested and charged yesterday in the killing of a Korean-American financier and his wife Sunday during a disagreement about a business loan, law enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLITY, JOHN P.
description: CULLITY-John P. Of Rutherford, New Jersey. On May 19, 1998. Brother of Ann Hayser of West Orange, N.J. Uncle of Elizabeth Cicchino, Michael & John Hayser. Also survived by many friends. Funeral Mass Saturday, May 23rd, 9:30AM at Saint Joseph's Church corner of Pavonia and Baldwin Avenues, Jersey City. Interment Holy Name Cemetery. Visiting Thursday & Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Quinn-Hopping Funeral Home of Livingston, 145 East Mount Pleasant Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the American Heart Association or Saint Joseph's Home for the Blind, Jersey City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLAVSIC, HELEN R.
description: PLAVSIC-Helen R. On May 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Alfred Rivces and the late Zachary Plavsic. Loving mother of the late Peter Philip Rivces.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: DuPont to Buy Out Merck In Joint Drug Venture

title: Chinese Officials Denounce Reports of Gifts to Democrats
description: Senior Chinese officials today angrily dismissed as ''groundless rumors'' renewed accusations that Chinese citizens had illegally contributed to the Democratic Party in an effort to influence United States policy, suggesting that the assertions were intended to undermine President Clinton's visit to China in June.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS FURTHER. The yen fell to the lowest point since August 1991, extending its drop from Monday, on worries over the effect of Indonesia's instability on Asia. In New York, the dollar rose to 136.44 yen from 136.25.

title: 9 Awarded Knight-Bagehot Fellowships
description: The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism has chosen nine Knight-Bagehot fellows in economics and business journalism for the 1998-99 academic year.

title: Young at Heart and in Fact
description: The people who run the New York Youth Symphony aren't easy on their young charges. Every Sunday from September through May, the 102 students ages 13 to 21 meet for a four-hour rehearsal, and several times a year the ensemble performs at Carnegie Hall for an audience swelled by the lure of a bargain, namely a $5 ticket. Newly commissioned works are prepared and performed alongside standard repertory, and there seem to be no concessions to youth in the selection of works. There is also no tenure in this orchestra: returning players must audition again every year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORKNER, CLAUDE E., JR., M.D.
description: FORKNER-Claude E., Jr., M.D. On May 15 in Scottsdale, AZ. Husband of Judith Yengling Forkner. Father of Stanley, Peter, Adam and Benjamin Forkner, Karen Wells & the late Thomas Forkner. Stepfather of Dr. Megan Duffy and David Duffy. Grandfather of Brad and Dana Forkner. Brother of Helen Haskell and Lucy Greene. Memorial service Wed., June 3, 11 AM, First Church of Christ Congregational, Sharon, CT. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Barrow Neurological Institute, Brain Tumor Research, C/O Dr. William Shapiro, 350 W. Thomas Road, Phoenix, AZ 85013.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAY, ELLA MARTIN
description: DAY-Ella Martin. Of West Hartford, CT., and Delray Beach, FL died in Hartford on May 17, 1998. Widow of Pomeroy Day, and predeceased by first husband, Edwin Harvey Stover. Survived by sisterin-law, Mary Paulding Martin, nieces, Rebecca Martin Anderson and Emy Martin Rouse, grandnephew, Hugh McDonald Anderson, grandnieces, Molly Rouse and Anne Rouse, and stepchildren, Pamela Day Pelletreau, Elizabeth Day Bolton, George C. Day, and Roger P. Day. Memorial service at noon on Friday, May 22nd at St. John's Episcopal Church, 679 Farmington Avenue, West Hartford, followed by reception at the Day residence.

title: Mr. Suharto's Nebulous Promises
description: Indonesia does not have a history of peaceful political succession. During the fight for power won by Mr. Suharto in 1966, perhaps half a million people on the country's political left were murdered. Violence on that scale is not likely to be repeated today, but it should be a warning to a country that has already seen 500 people perish in political unrest over the last few weeks. President Suharto's hazy pledge yesterday to hold elections and step down merely promises further indecision, political manipulation and confrontation. To avoid anarchy, Indonesia urgently needs democratic elections that give people a voice in a new government.

title: G.O.P. Incumbents Hold Off Challengers in Pennsylvania
description: In a display of Republican Party muscle, Representative Bill Goodling fended off a challenge tonight from an insurgent conservative.

title: A Country's Commerce Is Paralyzed and a Food Shortage Looms in the Capital
description: As President Suharto rebuffed demands for his immediate resignation and Indonesia drifted into political limbo, the nation's economy is paralyzed and a potential food shortage looms in the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIFF, FRANCES P.
description: SHIFF-Frances P. Of Stratford, CT., on May 19, 1998. Devoted mother of Laurie Shafer of Fairfield, CT, loving sister of Bernice Perlman of Scarsdale, NY, and cherished grandmother of Peter Shafer. Mrs. Shiff was a former resident of Scarsdale for 36 years, and was affiliated with I.B.M. Services Wednesday, 1:30 PM at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York. Memorial contributions to the American Cancer Society.

title: Police Sergeant Is Guilty Of Faking a Burglary
description: A New York City police sergeant who filed a false burglary report claiming that thieves had ransacked his Westchester County home was found guilty yesterday of mail and wire fraud and was immediately suspended from the police force.

title: NEWS CORPORATION TO SELL DIMAC MARKETING
description: The News Corporation said it would sell its Dimac Marketing Corporation unit to McCown De Leeuw & Company for an undisclosed price. McCown, a private investment firm, also said it would buy Americomm Holdings Inc. of Atlanta from one of its own funds, with both purchases having a total value of more than $450 million. The News Corporation and McCown did not break out terms for the Dimac portion of the transaction. The News Corporation said it was focusing on its media division, which produces and distributes movies and television programs and publishes newspapers, books and magazines, and its advertising and marketing unit, which produces newspaper inserts, advertising and in-store promotions.

title: U.N. Gives Its First Grants From Big Ted Turner Gift
description: The first round of grants from Ted Turner's $1 billion gift to the United Nations will be announced on Wednesday, with nearly three-quarters of the initial $22 million going to help women, children and victims of war in poor countries, the president of the fund, Timothy E. Wirth, said today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think this whole business of trying to prevent kids from smoking being the impetus behind legislation is great politics. But it is nonsense in terms of anything that you can put numbers next to.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A little information often goes a long way -- the wrong way.
description: FOR individual investors in the stock market, a little knowledge can be very dangerous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGEL, VIVIAN
description: ANGEL-Vivian. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Very devoted mother of Mitchell and Robert. Loving sister of Charles Richman. Loving grandmother of Allison and Danielle. Services are today, 10:30 A.M., at The Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: By the Book; Grilling the Usual Suspects, and More
description: JUST as sacks of charcoal briquettes are taking over shelves of hardware stores and bottles of barbecue sauce are doing the same in supermarkets, new cookbooks about grilling are proliferating in bookstores.

title: Campbell Soup hopes a new campaign aimed at children will help bolster sagging sales.
description: THE Campbell Soup Company is trying to come out of its can.

title: The French Resist Again: This Time, Over Cheese
description: IN the early 1990's, word broke that the European Union was going to require all cheese to be pasteurized. It was a rumor. But it spread through France like a brush fire fanned by the mistral.

title: After Pressure From Giuliani, Taxi Group Cancels a Protest
description: After nearly a week of unrelenting pressure from City Hall, organizers of a taxi protest who had pledged to ''make Manhattan a parking lot'' tomorrow called off their planned demonstration yesterday after being told that city officials would meet with them.

title: Alan D. Williams, 72, Editor Of Thrillers and of Literature
description: Alan D. Williams, a skilled and versatile editor and publisher of books by authors ranging from the thriller-writer Frederick Forsyth and the horror writer Stephen King to the novelist Nadine Gordimer, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1991, died on Sunday at his home in Jersey City, N.J. He was 72.

title: Arsenals of Peace? Not for India; Stop Coddling China
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Barometer Dips a Bit in Germany
description: Business confidence in western Germany was little changed in April, close to a three-and-a-half-year high, a sign that the country's economy is weathering the effect of slowing demand in Asia, the Ifo research institute said yesterday. Ifo said its index of business confidence in western Germany fell to 98.7 in April, from a revised 98.9 in March.

title: Bohn to Test Hot Streak Amid Comforts of Home
description: A woman bowling with Parker Bohn 3d at a pro-am event tonight watched him snap off a ball that gripped the lane halfway down and sliced directly into the pocket. Every pin fell but one.

title: In the Schools, a Week to Open Eyes and Ears to the Thrill of the Arts; Students Astound Students
description: The students at the Bronx Dance Academy on East 204th Street spend their afternoons training in dance. Sometimes they perform with the Bronx Dance Theater, whose theater and studios double as classrooms during the day. But the children at this public school, one of two middle schools devoted to the arts in District 10, were goggle-eyed when three young dancers visited from the School of Ballet, which is affiliated with the New York City Ballet.

title: KPMG to Pay $75 Million In Settlement
description: KPMG Peat Marwick agreed yesterday to pay $75 million to settle four lawsuits brought by Orange County, Calif., and three smaller local governments, which had accused the accounting firm of failing to detect and warn of risky investments that led to the nation's biggest municipal bankruptcy.

title: Food Chain
description: Getting Strawberry Jam Right

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVANAGH, LAWRENCE J.
description: KAVANAGH-Lawrence J. On May 16, 1998. Former Treasurer of West Vaco Paper Co. Beloved husband of the late Sadie. Loving brother of Rev. Joseph Kavanagh, S.J. and sister Mary Charitina Kavanagh R.S.M. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. The funeral was celebrated at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills, NY this morning.

title: Wine Talk; When In Doubt, They Just Say Merlot
description: MY first merlot was in 1969. It was a pleasant enough red wine from Louis M. Martini in California, and the price was about $1.75. Which is undoubtedly why I bought it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, BETTY MARTONE
description: PETERS-Betty Martone. Died peacefully on May 18, 1998, at age 84. Devoted & patient wife of the late Leone J. Peters; beloved mother of Paul Leone Peters and Gail Peters Beitz; adored grandmother of Adam & Jaime Peters, and Bradley and Drew Beitz; cherished mother-in-law of Kenneth Beitz; dear sister of Loretta Goldman; and a great, elegant lady who was loved and respected by all her family and friends. A generous and independent woman with great spirit, she gave her family the gift of unconditional love, and we shall miss her so very much. Memorial service will be held at 11 A.M., on Thursday, May 21, 1998, at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to this church would be greatly appreciated by her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, LILLIAN (ZINN)
description: BLOCH-Lillian (Zinn). Adored wife of the late Marvin J. Bloch, loving sister of Ruth Zinn Becker, beloved mother of Linda, Willa and the late Paul Bloch, cherished mother-in-law of Louise Hollinger, Rob Grambau and Douglas Fishman, and doting grandmother of David, Daniel, Marni, Mark, and Zoe. She devoted her life to people, especially children. Her legacy of love, thoughtfulness, common sense and humor will live on through all who were lucky enough to have known her. Donations in her memory may be made to the NYC School Volunteers or the Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Medical Center. Services: Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue and 91 Street, May 21 at 10:00 o'clock. Shiva at her late residence this Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, LOUIS C.
description: ROSS-Louis C., 93. Passed away on Sunday, May 17, 1998 in San Diego, CA. A 34 year resident of Eastchester, NY, he lived in San Diego for the past 12 years. He was a C.P.A. and had an active practice well into his 70's. A good man with a gentle nature, he will always be remembered by his wife Blanche, son David, daughter Jane Burdick, his grandchildren Gary & Stacey Ross and Jennifer and Janna Stammer as well as all who knew him. Services are today, 1:00 PM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, N.J. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Assoc.

title: Arsenals of Peace? Not for India; Bombs for Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, BELLE
description: WEINGARTEN - Belle. Loving mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Passed away May 18, 1998. Funeral services held.

title: Take Force, Add Envoys And 'Fudge,' Then Stir
description: TO END A WAR

title: A New President Is Named at Wells Fargo
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it had named Rod Jacobs, who is currently its chief financial officer, as president, filling a post vacated by the departure last year of William Zuendt.

title: Student, 19, At Yeshiva U. Is Reported To Be Missing
description: At 8:30 P.M. on May 12, Joshua Bender, a sophomore at Yeshiva University, told his roommate that he was planning to meet some classmates later that Tuesday night to study for last Thursday's final exam in finance. He also told his roommate that he was looking forward to their grilling each other in the days to come to prepare for their statistics final on Sunday.

title: Journal; Godzilla of the Right
description: James Dobson, the radio psychologist who is the new Godzilla of the religious right, looks like a guy who would smack you down if you gave him any lip. And not without reason: he's in favor of corporal punishment. At the moment he is applying his belt to the Republican Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, BENJAMIN
description: MOSS-Benjamin. May 12, 1998, brother of the late Anna, Sidney and Morris Moss. Survived by nephews Bernard and Franklin Moss and sister-in-law Lillian Moss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIROLA, ELVIRA ANGELA
description: TIROLA-Elvira Angela. On May 16, 1998 at the age of 88. She was born in New York City. Retired as an Executive Secretary for New York County Medical Society after 43 years. She was a member of the American Association of Medical Executives and Emeritus since 1979. She is survived by her niece Angela Krauss, brother Vincent Tirola, nephew Vincent Tirola, great nephews Ian Lawson and Douglas Tirola. Reposing Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 PM at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home. Mass Friday 10AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Margaret of Cortona Church or The American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Stalking The Wild Morel in The Woods Of Oregon
description: JACK CZARNECKI can't remember when he didn't hunt morels, those elusive aristocrats among mushrooms, but this is his first Oregon spring. So he was as psyched as a sprinter in the starting blocks when I met him at 6:30 one dewy Tuesday morning in late April.

title: Wisconsin Abortion Law Allowed to Stand
description: A Federal appeals court today let stand, at least for now, a Wisconsin law that bans the form of late-term abortion that opponents call partial-birth abortion and calls for life prison sentences for doctors who perform the procedure.

title: Senate Debates Lawyers' Fees in Tobacco Cases; Refuses to Set Limit at $250 an Hour
description: The Senate today spent most of the first full day of debate on anti-smoking legislation talking about how to handle the knotty problem that some trial lawyers could become instant billionaires from the settlement of lawsuits against tobacco companies.

title: Suharto's Stealthy Foe: Globalizing Capitalism
description: For decades President Suharto and other Asian leaders spent billions of dollars hunting down guerrillas in the jungle or building up internal security networks to trap leftists and send them to prison.

title: Minorities Achieve High Success Rate in Bar Exams, Study Says
description: In findings that are likely to provide important support for advocates of affirmative action, a six-year study by the Law School Admission Council has found that 61 percent of African-American law school graduates passed the bar exam on their first try, and 78 percent had done so after repeated efforts.

title: An American at Pearson Shakes Up Status Quo
description: Pearson P.L.C. has been known as a somewhat dowdy, meandering, blue-blooded media group -- a conglomerate run more like an investment firm than an aggressive outfit. Its empire has been stitched together with interests as varied as the prestigious Financial Times, Madame Tussaud's famed Wax Museum, 60 percent of The Economist magazine, Pearson Television programming and Penguin, the consumer book publishing outfit, and a share in the investment bank Lazard Freres & Company.

title: DuPont to Buy Merck's Share of Venture
description: After eight years of a relatively untroubled but unscintillating marriage, Merck & Company and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company are calling it quits.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York, a bank holding company, said its shareholders had approved a 2-for-1 split of its common stock. The new shares will be payable June 12 to shareholders of record as of today.

title: Man Found Dead After Killing 3 Officers and Taking Hostage
description: Two Tampa police officers and a Florida Highway Patrol officer were shot and killed today by a man who hours later was found dead, apparently from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head.

title: $25 and Under; A Refuge for Grown-Ups on the Party Animal Strip
description: ON a warm night, the sidewalks of First Avenue near 90th Street can look like a giant fraternity party, as just-out-of-college revelers bounce among the multitude of bars. Here, tiny La Foret is an adult refuge, serving deliciously adult food. How did such a restaurant end up in this neighborhood, which -- don't get me wrong -- can certainly use a place like this?

title: Police Misconduct Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EFFRAT, ALICE
description: EFFRAT-Alice. Died at age 85 on May 19, 1998 in West Palm Beach, FL. Devoted wife for 53 years of former New York Times sports writer Louis, who predeceased her; loving mother of Linda and Lee Zolet and Carol and Albert Effrat; caring grandmother of Beth and Brian Zolet, Stephanie and Alan Fineman and Alec and Elana Effrat; proud great-grandmother of Rebeca Zolet and Liam Fineman. An active volunteer leader of the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn, NY and of ORT in Royal Palm Beach, FL.

title: Antitrust Excess?
description: Without a doubt, Microsoft has become a monopoly that needs to be kept under control. But in their antitrust lawsuits, the Justice Department and 20 state Attorneys General may be pressing too far.

title: Royal Ahold Set to Acquire Giant Food
description: Royal Ahold N.V. extended its reach into the American supermarket business yesterday with a $2.6 billion deal to acquire the Giant Food Inc. supermarket chain.

title: ARMY OUT IN FORCE TO HALT PROTESTS AIMED AT SUHARTO
description: Thousands of protesters gathered early today at the Parliament building chanting for the removal of President Suharto, despite a military blockade intended to prevent the demonstration.

title: Coke and 3 More In Brazil Venture
description: The Coca-Cola Company and three Brazilian bottlers said Monday that they had formed a company to bottle Coca-Cola products in the fast-growing northeastern region of Brazil.

title: Anti-Catholic Art
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Diamond, Perfection Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Schools, a Week to Open Eyes and Ears to the Thrill of the Arts
description: At a Brooklyn school with no music teacher, a concert pianist worked magic on a slightly out-of-tune, worn piano, sending riffs of Chopin through the auditorium in an attempt to charm children weaned on pop music.

title: Joyfully, Indonesian Students Thumb Noses at Authority
description: For a few surreal hours here today, Indonesia's political hierarchy seemed to be turned on its head.

title: NETSCAPE AGREES TO LICENSE ITS SOFTWARE TO CITIBANK
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation agreed to license its electronic commerce software to Citibank, as Netscape focuses on the corporate software business. Netscape said Citibank had a permanent license to use its CommerceXpert line of software that allows the financial institution to conduct business over the Internet. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Netscape's CommerceXpert software suite lets companies automate procurement, on-line sales and customer service over the Internet. Citibank, owned by New York-based Citicorp, already offers some on-line-banking services that will be expanded using Netscape's software. The bank also plans to use the software to broaden its electronic commerce among corporations and consumers.

title: Iran Smiles After U.S. Waives Sanctions Against 3 Companies
description: Iran today trumpeted a Clinton Administration decision to waive sanctions against three foreign companies that are doing business here as a moral victory for the European Union and one that should signal an end to American attempts to deter similar investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSACK, YVONNE
description: CUSACK-Yvonne. On May 5, 1998. Beloved wife of Maurice Cusack. Memorial service to be held Thursday, May 21, 3:30PM at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street, NYC.

title: Calendar
description: How-To Grilling Lessons

title: On the Diamond, Perfection Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Fight Will Be Waged On Wide Front
description: The Government's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation is shaping up as a high-decibel, often nasty battle to sway public opinion as well as the courts.

title: Aging in Hollywood
description: To the Editor:

title: Dramatic Rally Leads to Rumble in the Bronx
description: The Yankees went from playing a perfect game Sunday to participating in the most imperfect of games last night, when an ugly and lengthy brawl with Baltimore punctuated a Yankee comeback in the eighth inning, spilling into the visitors' dugout at Yankee Stadium.
