title: To Go; Soup to Dessert (Not in That Order)
description: WHEN Johannes Sanzin resurfaced last year, it was as an owner of SOUPERMAN , a small takeout soup operation in lower Manhattan. It seemed an unlikely venture for Mr. Sanzin, who had been an up-and-coming young chef until he unceremoniously split with his partners in two restaurants. But he stuck with it, and now has opened a second Souperman, at a downstairs site in the canyons of the financial district.

title: Man in the News: Avul Pakir Jainulabdeen Abdul Kalam; Self-Made Bomb Maker
description: Among the Indian scientists who successfully detonated five nuclear tests in the northwestern desert last week, none seemed more visibly delighted by the acclaim waiting in New Delhi than Dr. A. P. J. Abdul Kalam. An impish, shaggy-haired bachelor, Dr. Kalam is widely regarded as the central figure in India's drive to join the small club of nuclear-armed nations.

title: Spectacle Of Angels Who Are So Very Human
description: It was a pity that the Olga Roriz Company of Lisbon slipped in and out of the New York area so quickly. The company, which made its United States debut with a single performance at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, is an impressive group of good-looking, smart and formidably gifted young actor-dancers. Even more, Ms. Roriz is an artist of rare authority and imagination, to judge by ''Angels, Archangels, Seraphs, Cherubs . . . and Potentates,'' presented on Saturday night.

title: In the Schools, a Week to Open Eyes and Ears to the Thrill of the Arts; The Discipline of Music
description: James McBride, the best-selling author and composer, stood on the steps of Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Bayside, Queens, wearing neatly pressed slacks and a necktie. It was a remarkable departure from the 1970's, when he would stand outside skipping class.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, DEDOMENICO, IELYNE
description: KOHL-DEDOMENICO-Ielyne. Artist. Age 49. Died May 16, 1998. Inspired all who knew her. Beautiful daughter of Regina Kohl. Loving sister of Susan Kohl and brotherin-law Danny Osterweil. Devoted mother of Orange and Reyne. Her courage and love of life will be missed.

title: Dutch Officials Won't Contest Modern's Claim To a van Gogh
description: ''Olive Trees,'' a van Gogh landscape that was left to the Museum of Modern Art just weeks ago by Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney, was nearly caught up in the flurry of claims for art that changed hands during World War II. But the Government of the Netherlands, which says it has a right to the painting, is itself bedeviled by claims for works in Dutch museums and has decided not to demand the painting's return.

title: Sousuke Uno, Who Led Japan For 2 Months, Is Dead at 75
description: Sousuke Uno, a former Prime Minister who resigned after two months in the post because of accusations of an extramarital affair, died today in Moriyama, Japan. He was 75.

title: Men's Title Games Set for This Weekend
description: The competition has been so keen in this year's National Collegiate Athletic Association tournaments that of 40 games, 13 have been decided by one goal, including the national championship in women's Division III. There have been four single-goal decisions in women's Division I, four in women's Division III, three in men's Division I and two in men's Division III.

title: Metro Business; MGM Grand Says Roads Threaten Plan
description: Following Mirage Resorts Inc.'s successful demand that the state build a tunnel and access road for a hotel-casino complex the company plans in Atlantic City, MGM Grand Inc. threatened yesterday to cancel a $700 million project unless improvements are made to its access road.

title: Big Board Seat Price Dips
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold for $1.4 million, down from the most recent sale of $1.6 million on April 3. The most an investor is willing to pay for a seat now is $1.35 million, and the lowest price at which an owner is willing to sell is $1.7 million, the exchange said yesterday. A seat gives the holder the right to trade stocks and vote at exchange meetings. One of the 1,366 seats last sold on March 9 for a record $2 million.

title: Police Suspect Gang Dispute in Shooting
description: A hail of gunfire that left eight people wounded at a downtown Brooklyn mall Monday night may have been the result of a gang-related dispute, the police said yesterday.

title: James C. McIntyre, Arts Executive, 49
description: James Carroll McIntyre, a fund-raiser for the arts and a former executive at Carnegie Hall and the Big Apple Circus, died on Friday at his home in Saylorsburg, Pa. He was 49 and also had a home in Greenwich Village.

title: Restaurants; Reborn Bistro, With an Ambitious Chef
description: THE man in the corner leans toward his companion, looks soulfully into her eyes and murmurs, ''You would have been such a good actress.'' I do not, unfortunately, catch Leona Helmsley's response, but she certainly looks pleased.

title: Treating Cancer in Elderly Baffles Experts
description: With more older Americans needing cancer therapy, oncologists are having increasing difficulty in determining the safest and most effective drug regimens for them, experts reported here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDEL, REGINA
description: SEIDEL-Regina. On May 18, 1998 in Williamsburg, VA., formerly of NYC. Beloved wife for 65 years of the late Dr. Harry Seidel. She is survived by and will be remembered as the loving mother of Suzanne Schoenbaum. Cherished grandmother of Carol Wolf and Robert Schoenbaum. Adored great-grandmother of Michelle and Rachel Wolf. Dear sister of Joan Scheichet, Dorothy Tave and Sophie Lawrence.

title: Commencements; At a Poignant Return, Cosby Praises Teachers
description: In a monologue reminiscent of the tender-hearted curmudgeon he plays on television, Bill Cosby chided students at the 110th master's convocation of Teachers College of Columbia University with jokes about graduates who return home to freeload off of their parents. He later grew serious when he challenged the graduates to change the world -- and themselves.

title: HBO's 'Shining Lie' Draws Early Complaints
description: Perhaps it should come as no surprise, but an HBO movie about one of the most politically charged periods in recent American history, when the nation's policy in Vietnam unraveled under the weight of lies and missteps, is raising debate and causing a little fresh rancor of its own.

title: Bob Hope's Gift to the Nation? Quips, of Course
description: Bob Hope gave thanks to his adopted country today by donating his 95 years of memories to the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WARWICK, KENNETH M.
description: WARWICK-Kenneth M. A service in loving memory of Ken Warwick will be held Friday, May 29th, 1998, 1 P.M., at the Second Presbyterian Church, 6 West 96 St, NY, NY. The Church is on the south side of 96th St, just west of Central Park West, the entrance is a red door. Please call Ken Warwick & Associates for further assistance 718-243-2030

title: Don't Typecast Rhubarb As Dessert
description: ONE of the cheering sights of spring is rhubarb, whether as big-leafed plants in the garden or as strong red stalks in the market. Cooks usually think of rhubarb in terms of sweet dishes like compote, pie or jam, often mixed with strawberries. But it is a wonderful addition to the savory side of the pantry as well.

title: About New York; Lampposts As a Forum For Opinion
description: A STREET sign was set to go up yesterday outside the New York State Office Building near Foley Square to mark the intersection of Goldberg and Kelly. The two did not meet on a corner, but in a courthouse, as parties in a 1970 lawsuit that gave welfare recipients the right to keep receiving benefits until a hearing determined whether they could be removed from the rolls.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Homes for Elderly Replacing Family Care as China Grays
description: Liu Xiaoying, 80 years old, widowed and full of spark, decided to move into the East Wind Elderly Home last fall. It is a privately run 15-bed home off a bustling lane where, with help from her seven children, she paid an entrance fee of more than $1,000 and now pays $90 a month to live. She walks to the park to practice tai chi; she window shops; she gets visits from her children and grandchildren.

title: Bear Stearns Is Loser in Court
description: The Bear Stearns Companies lost a $108 million verdict Friday after a Federal jury found the investment bank negligently advised the Daisy Systems Corporation in its ill-fated acquisition of the Cadnetix Corporation.

title: INSIDE
description: Fed Declines Rate Increase

title: Starr Sought Waiver of Privilege
description: Investigators in the Monica S. Lewinsky inquiry asked the White House recently to waive a privilege that the Clinton Administration has claimed blocks the testimony of Secret Service officials, but the White House refused, according to court papers unsealed by a Federal judge today.

title: Questionable Act Born of the Orioles' Frustration
description: It was not enough that the character of the Baltimore Orioles was up for examination again. After last night's display of utter frustration by the Orioles, the basic courage of at least one Baltimore player could also be called into question.

title: Toiling for Nike
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Assemblyman's Trial Opens
description: The Federal corruption trial of Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn opened yesterday with a prosecutor painting him as a thief who took thousands of dollars in kickbacks, while a defense lawyer praised Mr. Hikind as ''one of the most extraordinary political figures of our time.''

title: Hacking Away at the Libraries
description: Back in 1901, Andrew Carnegie promised to erect 65 branch libraries throughout New York City if the city would provide the land and operating expenses. Carnegie kept his promise. But the city has repeatedly welshed on the deal, allowing buildings to decay and curtailing hours when times get tough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, MYRON ''MIKE''
description: SOLOMON-Myron ''Mike''. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the passing of their fellow member, Myron ''Mike'' Solomon, and offer their deepest sympathy to the entire Solomon Family. Alpine Country Club Michael Bergstein President

title: Irish Feel Fierce Crosswinds as Fateful Vote Nears
description: Dressed in black and wearing two gold earrings, Bono, star of the Irish rock group U2, took to the stage here tonight beneath a giant ''YES'' banner and played buffer to two stiff middle-aged politicians wearing ties and jackets.

title: Shooting Spotlights Troubled Side of a Brooklyn Mall
description: In yesterday's summertime sun, the Fulton Mall buzzed to the tune of money: as the third busiest shopping district in the city, it trails only Herald Square and Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. Each day, more than 120,000 people visit the strip, spending more than $1 million at the 200 stores between Adams Street and Flatbush Avenue.

title: Food Stuff; It's All Systems Go for Cookout Season
description: A Charcoal Grill That's Sleek and Portable

title: Treasuries Dip on Fed Inaction
description: Treasury prices ended slightly lower yesterday after the Federal Reserve, as expected, left interest rates unchanged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEID, CHARLES J. JR., M.D.
description: SCHEID-Charles J. Jr., M.D. On May 18, 1998 of Forest Hills, NY. Attended Georgetown University and Georgetown Med School. Practicing Physician for 40 years associated with The Brooklyn Hospital and St. John's Hospital, Queens. A member of the AMA and a Fellow of the American College of Physicians. Beloved husband of Marye, loving father of Sharon Flynn, Mary Louise Duncombe and Charles J. Scheid III. Devoted grandfather of 9 grandchildren. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc. Forest Hills, Wednesday, May 20, 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Prayer service at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Thursday, May 21, 1998 at 10:15 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, 110-06 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY 11375 would be appreciated.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP TO SELL ITS FRESH START BAKERIES UNIT
description: The Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that it planned to sell its bakery products division, Fresh Start Bakeries. Campbell, based in Camden, N.J., the maker of canned, frozen and refrigerated food items, said the sale was part of its plan to divest itself of its nonstrategic businesses and focus on making soup and sauces, biscuits and confectionery. Since September 1996, the company has shed six businesses, spun off its frozen-food and condiment business and acquired soup companies in Germany and France.

title: Helms's Cuba Aid Ploy; Hospitals Held Hostage
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics of Youth Smoking Fueled by Unproven Data
description: It is the mantra of the nation's opponents of smoking: sweeping changes in the way cigarettes are marketed and sold over the next decade would stop thousands of teen-agers each day from starting the habit and spare a million youngsters from untimely deaths.

title: ABC Remakes Every Night for Fall
description: Scrambling to recover from its worst season ever in the Nielsen ratings, ABC announced a new fall schedule yesterday that features changes for every night of the week and that combines its two news magazine programs into one, called ''20/ 20,'' scheduled for three nights a week.

title: Dow Regains Some Ground After Three-Session Decline
description: Stocks closed slightly higher yesterday, rebounding from three days of declines as Federal Reserve policy makers left short-term interest rates unchanged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, PAUL
description: WEISS-Paul. Devoted to and adored by his family, his wife, Carolyn, and sons, Erik and Nicholas. Cherished brother of Marc and Fred. Passionate, dedicated and beloved teacher, he touched the hearts and lives of many deeply. Services Thursday, 10:30 A.M., at ''Parkside'' Chapel, 66th Avenue & Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Arts in America; Jurassic What? Exhibitor Seeks Grants (Don't Ask)
description: How does an institution, in this case the idiosyncratic Museum of Jurassic Technology, remain true to its ironic self when it quite suddenly and desperately needs money from foundations that may not be expected to understand what is going on within its walls?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORENSEN, FRANK C., M.D.
description: SORENSEN-Frank C., M.D. On May 16, 1998. With everlasting appreciation for lives untangled, dreams realized, demons defeated. Your legacy lives on in us all. Your loving patients, families and friends

title: A Tax Catches On in New Jersey; Crowded Towns Are Raising Rates to Buy Open Space
description: Like thousands of residents in 52 other once-rural New Jersey towns, Anita Calotta and Melinda Kryger are happy to pay a little more in property taxes to buy and preserve woodlands and farms, and, they hope, help slow the development boom that has transformed the countryside here.

title: Shea Stadium Gets a Kosher Food Stand
description: Until now, baseball fans who kept kosher had two choices: pack their own food or sit and watch others feasting on hot dogs, peanuts and Cracker Jacks.

title: Arsenals of Peace? Not for India
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Schools, a Week to Open Eyes and Ears to the Thrill of the Arts; Tangos and Spins
description: They sat in the same red velvet seats as the usual patrons at the Metropolitan Opera House, but it was easy to tell they were not the usual patrons. They swayed and bounced to the music. They applauded enthusiastically every time they liked something, not just when the music stopped. And a few got up and danced in the aisles -- when their teachers were not looking, of course.

title: Union's Tactics Questioned in Failed Deal
description: A day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dismissed 600 public hospital workers, labor experts questioned the tactics and motives of a union president who rejected a plan that would have cushioned the damage from cuts in the hospital work force.

title: New York Parking
description: To the Editor:

title: Wells, With Key to City, Seeks Key to Fenway
description: David Wells shuttled from one television appearance to another in the aftermath of his perfect game, and yesterday Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani honored him with a ceremony at City Hall. Smiling relentlessly, Wells said he enjoyed the instant fame immensely.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Scandal Time

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, MORRIS
description: ALTMAN-Morris. At the age of 91. Beloved husband of the late Rosalyn. Loving mother of Jerold Altman and Marilyn Schwartz, and father-in-law of Anita and Louis. Cherished grandfather of Hugh, Debra, Sharon, Steven and Rory, and great-grandfather of Rachel, Brooke and Paige. Services Thursday, 1 P.M., at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, Long Island.

title: Computers at 2 Agencies Found Vulnerable
description: Crucial computers at the State Department and the Federal Aviation Administration are vulnerable to criminal or terrorist attack because the agencies do not properly control access to them, Congressional auditors say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, JAMES C.
description: McINTYRE-James C. Died unexpectedly in his sleep on May 15, 1998 at his country home in Pennsylvania. Jim has a legacy of success in arts management from North Carolina to Carnegie Hall to the Big Apple Circus. He left each organization in better shape then when he arrived, a real accomplishment in this day and a testament to his management skills. More important, he maintained the friendship and respect of his colleagues throughout his career. His wit, laughter and caring nature will be missed by all whose lives he touched. Services are scheduled for Wednesday, May 20th, 5PM at the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine (1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112 Street, NYC.) There will be a brief reception following the service at the Cathedral. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Big Apple Circus, Clown Care Unit.

title: New Broad Street Site Is Proposed To Keep Stock Exchange in Area
description: Faced with the possibility that the New York Stock Exchange's quest for a new home would lead it to either Battery Park City or perhaps even New Jersey, officials of New York City and the state said yesterday that they would try to acquire five properties on Broad Street for the exchange, in a bid to insure that lower Manhattan remains the financial capital of the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, COLIN (JOHN)
description: SULLIVAN-Colin (John). It is with great sadness his family announce the unexpected, but peaceful death of John Sullivan in Haslemere, England, on Thursday 14th of May, 1998. Dearly loved brother, uncle and friend. Inquiries to Peter Norman, 44 1483 503221.

title: Interactive Deals And Assignments
description: There have been account assignments and acquisitions in the realm of interactive advertising and marketing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERER, RABBI MOSHE
description: SHERER-Rabbi Moshe. The national administration of Agudath Israel of America mourns the loss of the beloved president Rabbi Moshe Sherer, a man of vision whose extraordinary qualities of intelligence and integrity, strength & stamina, character & charisma, piety and personality, determination and dignity, lifted the Agudath Israel movement to heights unimaginable to anyone but himself. His humble devotion to Torah and its scholars, his untiring efforts on behalf of Jewish education, his unbridled love for all Jews, his passionate defense of authentic Judaism, inspired all who were privileged to know him. May his dear family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem, and may the Agudath Israel movement find the strength to carry on his remarkable legacy. Rabbi Shmuel Kamenetsky, Chairman, Rabbinic Presidium Albert Reichmann, Chairman, National Board Benjamin Fishoff, Chairman Board of Trustees Louis Glueck, Chairman Commission on Social Services Dr. David Diamond and Moshe Zafir, Chairmen, Vaad Hanhala

title: PLUS: GOLF -- Long Island Championship; Hartmann Wins
description: Rick Hartmann, a former New York State Open titleist, defeated Dave Gosiewski, 2 and 1, in the final of the Met P.G.A. Long Island Championship at the Indian Hills Country Club in Northport, N.Y. Hartmann, in his third year as pro at the Atlantic Club, Bridgehampton, N.Y., also has earned three other sectional titles -- two Long Island Opens and the Met P.G.A. Head Pro.

title: Political Memo; Resolute Giuliani Raises His Profile
description: If the last several days in City Hall suggest anything more than the usual melodrama of New York City government, it would be that Godzilla has nothing on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- in tenacity, in execution of plan and, some would say, in temperament.

title: Really Big Money Shouts in a California Contest
description: Shirley Nelson is wise to the ways of fund-raising in Northern California's Democratic politics, having rounded up campaign cash for Senator Dianne Feinstein and President Clinton, among others. But when she offered to put together a lunch for Al Checchi the other day, it was Mr. Checchi himself who opened his wallet.

title: Time (30 Years) and Space (29-2 1/2) Leap From Past
description: Three decades after he electrified the world with a long-jump record that stood for 23 years, Bob Beamon said yesterday that he still felt as if he were ''in the twilight zone'' during his 29-foot-2 1/2-inch leap.

title: U.S. Has Spent $26 Million Since '95 on Suharto Opponents
description: While trying to shore up President Suharto, the Clinton Administration has also been giving support to some of the most important Indonesian opposition groups, hoping to promote a transition to a democratic society.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an investigation by New York State into the work schedules of medical residents referred incorrectly to a state sanction advocated by Dr. Bertrand M. Bell, who helped develop laws to restrict residents' work hours. He advocates threatening the licenses of hospitals, not those of doctors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORWIN, ROSWELL W.
description: CORWIN-Roswell W. Of Amityville, Long Island (formerly of Massapequa), on May 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy E., devoted father of Gail E., Thomas W. and Richard A. Corwin, fond father-in-law of Sara Jane and Bonnie, dear brother of Harold, Carol LaPierre, Edith Van Vleet & the late Alden and Burton, loving grandfather of Peter, Christopher, Lynn, Kristen and Wendy. Cremation & interment of cremains in Aquebogue Cemetery private.

title: Fire at Coney Island Damages Roller Coaster
description: The defunct Thunderbolt roller coaster in Coney Island was damaged early yesterday in a fire that investigators said was believed to be caused by arson, fire officials said.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of the Tastings column last Wednesday, about the 1994 cabernet sauvignon made by the Mount Veeder Winery in Napa Valley, Calif., referred to the wine incorrectly. It is red, not white.

title: Milan Journal; 'The Black Widow' Goes on Trial in Gucci Slaying
description: The Gucci trial opened today to a packed house. The case of Patrizia Reggiani, a wealthy socialite accused of ordering the killing of her ex-husband, Maurizio Gucci, the heir to Italy's most famous leather goods business, is, even by Italian standards, sensational.

title: 4 Agencies Form International Alliance
description: Four agencies specializing in business-to-business marketing communications have teamed up to form a worldwide alliance named B-to-B World Class.

title: Off the Menu
description: Frites and Curry

title: Lawyers' Fees at Issue
description: Some senators tried unsuccessfully to limit legal fees in the tobacco settlement, placed at $4 billion a year for 25 years. A Republican leader said the effort would continue.

title: Pager Service Is Disrupted By a Glitch With Satellite
description: Millions of the nation's paging customers lost service late yesterday after a failure by a satellite operated by the Panamsat Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, FLORENCE
description: FINKELSTEIN-Florence. Temple Hillel, North Woodmere, L.I. records with profound sorrow the passing of a devoted congregant, and extends sincere condolences to the entire family. Dr. Alan Lavin, Rabbi Arthur Singer, President Dr. Morris S. Friedman, Rabbi Emeritus

title: Foul and Outrageous? Well, That's Show Biz
description: Riggs has just about had it with Bobby Supreme, his trash-talking, hate-spewing client. Bobby's race- and gay-baiting comedy act is a national scourge; his frenzied audiences ransack clubs after his appearances, and several deranged copycat fans have gone on what the tabloids label ''Bobby Supreme crime sprees.''

title: In the Schools, a Week to Open Eyes and Ears to the Thrill of the Arts; Talking Shop With an Artist
description: Alex Katz knows art, and as he discovered this week, so do the students at the Daniel Hale Williams Middle School for the Arts in Co-op City, the Bronx.

title: Report Says Entry Tests Would Sharply Cut CUNY Enrollment
description: A report by the City University of New York says that five colleges, including City College, would lose more than half of their entering students if the university decided to prevent students who did not pass placement tests from enrolling at the four-year colleges.

title: Accounts
description: * H-E-B Food/Drugstores, San Antonio, to Richards Group, Dallas, to handle its account, previously handled in-house and fielded out on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: Jordan Lives Up To Trophy: 41 Points
description: Michael Jordan had a skip to his stride and a boyish grin on his face as he left the court like a kid who had just wowed the class at show-and-tell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECHTOLD, PAUL E.
description: BECHTOLD-Paul E. Age 86. Of Port Washington, Long Island. Died May 18, 1998. Surviving are his wife of 57 years, Mary Louise, his sons Stephen of Northport and Alec of Port Washington, four grandsons, Reuben, Mark, Ned and Gus and one granddaughter, Sandy. Memorial gathering at 28 Kaywood Road, Port Washington Saturday, June 6. The family has suggested donations to the Port Washington Public Library.

title: BELLSOUTH TO OFFER HIGH-SPEED INTERNET ACCESS SERVICE
description: The BellSouth Corporation plans to announce today that it will offer high-speed Internet access using a new technology to three million customers by the end of the year. The new technology, known as ADSL, for asymmetric digital subscriber line, allows Internet data to flow through normal telephone wires at speeds up to 30 times faster than are allowed by today's fastest consumer modems. BellSouth, which is based in Atlanta, plans to offer the service in seven markets -- including Atlanta, Charlotte, N.C., and Raleigh, N.C. -- by the end of the year. The service will cost $59.95 a month plus one-time installation and equipment fees that total $299.90.

title: Thousands of Immigrants Gain In a Ruling on Deportations
description: In a decision that affects several thousand immigrants across the country, a Federal appeals court has ruled that some forms used by the immigration authorities are so hard to understand that they deprive the accused of their right to a hearing before deportation.

title: I.B.M. TO BUY 2 COMMUNICATIONS SOFTWARE COMPANIES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two privately held real-time communications software companies. Financial terms of the deals were not disclosed. Under the agreements, the companies, the Data Beam Corporation and Ubique Ltd., will become part of I.B.M.'s Lotus Communications Products division. Data Beam is based in Lexington, Ky. Ubique is based in Rehovot, Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, ERNEST
description: BLOCH-Ernest. My professor, teacher, mentor and above all, dear friend. Your perspectives, insights and rich sense of humor will be sorely missed. Neil A. Mitchell

title: Sports of The Times; Brawling Extinguishes An Afterglow
description: FOR David Wells, it was a bizarre ending to a special day. At noon, he had been at City Hall receiving the key to the city. By 10:30 last night, Wells was on the field at Yankee Stadium amid a throng of violent melees, Yankees and Orioles swarming at each other like two medieval armies -- fists flying, bodies tumbling into the visitors' dugout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, CHARLES D.
description: WEBSTER-Charles D. Of Islip, NY, on May 15, 1998 in his ninetythird year. He was the devoted husband of the late Natalie Peters Webster & is survived by nephews John W. Mitchell of Greenwich, CT, James Fitz of CA, and a niece Mary Mitchell of AZ. A graduate of Dartmouth College in 1926, he served as a naval officer during World War II. He had leadership and advisory roles in many diverse organizations concerned with wildlife and environmental conservation, scientific research, horticulture, the arts, and civic improvement. These included Chairman of the Board, The Seatuck Environmental Association, Islip, NY; Chairman Emeritus of The Horticultural Society of NY; Trustee, (1971-95) the Bayard Cutting Arboretum, Oakdale, NY; Director, International Wild Waterfowl Association, Jamestown, ND; Chairman Emeritus, Caribbean Conservation Corporation, Tallahassee FL; Field Associate in Ornithology, NY Zoological Society; Fellow, Old Westbury Gardens; Administrative Board, Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology; Chairman, Garden Committee, The Cloisters; Visiting Committee, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Medieval Art Dept.; Fellow, The Frick Collection; and many other organizations. Mr. Webster resided at ''Twyford'', located on the Seatuck National Wildlife Refuge, Islip NY. The refuge property was donated by Mr. Webster and his late wife to the Fish and Wildlife Service of the US Dept. of the Interior in 1968. A memorial service will be held at 11 A.M., on Friday, May 22nd, 1998, St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Islip, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Seatuck Environmental Association, P.O. Box 31, Islip NY 11751 or to St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 754 Montauk Highway, Islip NY 11751 would be appreciated.

title: The Chef
description: THIS recipe has never appeared on any of my menus. I created it on the spur of the moment 10 years ago, when John Fairchild, the publisher of Women's Wear Daily, and Bill Blass, the clothing designer, came for lunch at Le Cirque. They asked for a simple chicken with robust flavor, and I've been making this dish for them every spring ever since, with a few changes here and there.

title: For Congress, Even Computer Politics Are Local
description: To Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, the antitrust suit against his state's most valuable company shows that the Clinton Administration is trying to have judges and lawyers design the future of the computer industry.

title: Pressed by U.S., City Hall Agrees To Build a Plant to Filter Water
description: Thirteen months after the Clinton Administration filed suit against New York City to force it to build an $800 million water filtration plant, the Giuliani administration agreed yesterday to settle the case and build the plant by the year 2006, Federal officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOD, STAYTON
description: WOOD-Stayton. The Board of Trustees, students, faculty, and adminisration of the Fashion Institute of Technology mourn the death of Dr. Stayton Wood, FIT Vice President for Student Affairs. To his wife and family, we extend our sincerest condolences. He was gentle and humane, and his life changed the lives of many. Dr. Stuart Steiner, Pres. Edwin A. Goodman, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAVITCH, JANE HERVITZ
description: JAVITCH-Jane Hervitz. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff of CLAL-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership, extends deepest condolences to Lee H. Javitch, esteemed Board Member and Past Chairman, on the passing of his beloved mother, Jane Hervitz Javitch. May he and his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Rabbi Irving Greenberg, President Emeritus Donna M. Rosenthal, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Going to the Top In Bluegrass, And Honoring The Old Ways; Ralph Stanley Keeps It Modest
description: Ralph Stanley's grief-blasted mountain-tenor voice, singing a spiritual, can temporarily erase pain, flood the constitution with courage, leave one feeling profoundly alone in the world. At least once, it actually caused violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORMENDI, JOAN
description: KORMENDI-Joan. On May 18, 1998. Actress, teacher and founder and artistic director of The Children's Repertory Group, a nonprofit theater by children and for children which performed plays at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Beloved wife of the late Laszlo, loving mother of Katherine. Memorial service will be on Friday, at 11 AM at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, NY. In lieu of flowers donation can be made to the American Cancer Society or Central Park Conservancy.

title: Helms's Cuba Aid Ploy
description: To the Editor:

title: Across Colombia, Demonstrators Protest the Political Violence
description: A spate of political killings during the current presidential campaign drove hundreds of thousands of Colombians to take part in nationwide demonstrations today to demand an end to the violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, CHARLES
description: RATNER-Charles. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: Van Gundy and Riley Get Lecture From Stern
description: Jeff Van Gundy and Pat Riley emerged from their meetings with Commissioner David Stern of the National Basketball Association yesterday having received 50 lashes with an olive branch. The message was simple: make peace, not war.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Mets Sweep And Now Hope That the Fans Take Notice
description: There were fewer than 500 fans at Shea Stadium when Bobby Jones uncorked the first pitch of yesterday's twilight-night doubleheader between the Mets and the Reds. It was quiet enough to hear whether fans in the loge section ordered regular or diet sodas and empty enough for them to have entire rows to stretch out in.

title: A Capella Singers Assemble To Honor A Master
description: The world of Medieval and Renaissance a cappella choral music has been doubly enhanced in recent years by two fine groups: Anonymous 4, composed of four women, and Lionheart, five men. Both bring tonal clarity, radiance, dead-on pitch and affecting restraint to their performances.

title: Another Indy 500 Brings Another Unser to the Track
description: Driving in the Indianapolis 500, it seems, is what Robby Unser was born to do. After all, his surname appears on the championship award, the Borg-Warner Trophy, more than any other.

title: BASF Export Surge Raises Profit by 14.1%
description: BASF A.G., Germany's largest chemicals and pharmaceuticals company, said first-quarter profit rose 14.1 percent as rising exports to North America outweighed declining prices for its oil and gas products. First-quarter net income rose to 815 million marks ($456.2 million), or 1.31 marks a share, from 714 million marks, or 1.16 marks a share, a year earlier.

title: Jury Convicts Former Guard Of Murders
description: A former jail guard who admitted to killing three people in Brooklyn was convicted last night of first-degree murder by a jury that must now decide whether to sentence him to death under New York State's capital punishment law.

title: Detention Center Escape Prompts State Inquiry
description: The state is investigating whether a 15-year-old boy should have been placed in a more secure facility after he escaped from a boot camp orientation program in Farmingdale on Monday and assaulted a woman with a carving knife, stole her sport utility vehicle and crashed it while being pursued by police.

title: Lilco Takeover Foes Lose Round
description: In a loss for opponents of the state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity service, the Suffolk County Legislature today failed to override the County Executive's veto of a referendum aimed against the takeover.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OELLERICH, JOHN
description: OELLERICH-John. Age 60, of Old Saybrook, CT. died suddenly on Monday, May 18, 1998 at his home. He was a partner in the consulting firm of M&O. He was the husband of Noel Sagarese Oellerich. He leaves 2 daughters, Kim Oellerich and Kelley Watson. Friends may call at the Swan Funeral Home in Old Saybrook, on Thursday, from 3-5 P.M.

title: Nuclear Arms to Plowshares; Cleaning Up Financially by Cleaning Up Oak Ridge
description: When the Energy Department looks around Oak Ridge, its huge weapons enclave some 20 miles outside Knoxville, Tenn., it sees a truly daunting cleanup problem. There are centrifuges, reactors, pumps, hundreds of acres of buildings and soil, all bearing troublesome radioactive memories of the roles they played in building nuclear bombs.

title: Fed Lets Rates Stand, Fearing Harm to Asia
description: The Federal Reserve declined once again today to increase short-term interest rates, apparently determining that the threat of inflation remained remote and that the latest phase of the worsening Asian economic crisis might be exacerbated by any rate rise now in the United States.

title: A Minor Orchestra Has a Major Imprint
description: Britain's City of Birmingham Orchestra and its music director, Simon Rattle, are making a farewell tour of sorts. Mr. Rattle, who came to this orchestra at 25 in 1980 and has directed its fortunes ever since, will shortly go off to pastures undetermined. The Birmingham will continue to graze at its present location with a new music director, the Finnish conductor Sakari Oramo.

title: Robert Griffin, 81, Coach at Florida A&M
description: Robert Griffin, a retired track coach at Florida A&M University who helped guide the career of the sprinter Bob Hayes, died last Wednesday at Tallahassee Memorial Hospital in Florida. Griffin, who lived in Tallahassee, was 81.

title: Sips; A Subtle New Gin Goes Easy on the Juniper
description: I LOST my taste for gin decades ago, after an unfortunate encounter with at least one martini too many at Chumley's, a speak-easy turned pub in Greenwich Village. After that, I wanted no hint of the distinctive, juniper-berry flavor that gives gin its character and its name: juniper in Dutch is genever.

title: In the Schools, a Week to Open Eyes and Ears to the Thrill of the Arts; Mazurkas at P.S. 298
description: The pianist Misha Dichter, known for his touch with Brahms, Gershwin and Chopin, visited Public School 298 in Brownsville, Brooklyn, where Puff Daddy, Usher and Canibus seem to reign.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: On the Diamond, Perfection Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Entrepreneur Forms Partnership With Mt. Sinai for Cancer Clinics
description: Going ahead with plans to dominate the cancer care market in the New York metropolitan area, Dr. Bernard Salick, a California doctor turned entrepreneur, said yesterday his company has agreed to a $150 million deal with Mount Sinai Medical Center to open 24-hour-a-day cancer care clinics in Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn and New Jersey.

title: $225 Million Nikko Deal For Roadchef of Britain
description: Nikko Europe P.L.C., the European arm of the Nikko Securities Company of Japan, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Roadchef P.L.C., Britain's third-largest motorway services company, for about $:139 million ($225.2 million) in cash and more than $:35 million in assumed debt.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday detailing the nuclear programs of India and Pakistan gave an incorrect chemical formula for heavy water. It is D(2)O, not H(2)O(2).

title: Speculation on Piazza Leaves Hundley Fuming
description: Todd Hundley has obviously heard the suggestions that the too-often lifeless Mets should try to obtain catcher Mike Piazza from the Florida Marlins to boost their punchless offense. He has heard it enough to where it bothers him, to the point where Hundley said yesterday that he would abandon his plans to return from elbow surgery and play catcher by midseason if the Mets acquired Piazza.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Short Spaces Stand Out In West Queens Market
description: On Park Row in Manhattan, J & R Music World operates in a set of stores specializing in music and consumer electronics and computers. Within a few months, the company expects to start building its flagship store along the Ann Street corner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINATRA, FRANCIS ALBERT
description: SINATRA-Francis Albert. A client first but a friend foremost. I will miss you, Mr. S. Mort West

title: Tobacco Bill Improvements
description: The Senate today debates amendments to a tobacco bill that can significantly reduce youth smoking if some critical provisions are strengthened. The bill, drafted by Senator John McCain and approved by the Senate Commerce Committee, would raise cigarette prices by $1.10 per pack over five years. That amount should be increased to at least $1.50 per pack, which most public health experts estimate is needed to cut youth smoking rates roughly in half. The higher tax was approved by the Senate Finance Committee last week.

title: Odd Chamber Couple: Cello and Electric Guitar
description: As part of its Music of Our Time series, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center glanced in the direction of rock-and-roll on Saturday evening when one of its cellists, Fred Sherry, shared the stage of Merkin Concert Hall with Steven Mackey, a composer whose preferred instrument is the electric guitar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEENEY, CORMAC C.
description: FEENEY-Cormac C. May 18, 1998. Infant son of Michael J. and Bernadette Feeney of Nantucket, brother of Kristofer, Greta, Ingrid and Aidan Feeney and the late Michael J. Grandson of Mrs. Louise (Buisson) Mannix of Boston and Vero Beach, FL, the late James J. Mannix, the late John J. and Margaret (Naab) Feeney, nephew of James and Rebekah Mannix of Cambridge, MA, James and Rosemary Lonborg of Scituate, MA, Katie and Paul Hayes also of Scituate, John and Krista Feeney of Highland Mills, NY, Grace Rothwell of Ashburn, VA. Graveside services will be held on Thursday at 10 AM in St. Joseph's Cemetery, Lynn, MA. Solimine Landergan and Rhodes Funeral Home, 426 Broadway, Lynn, MA.

title: Left and Right With Bill Gates
description: The legal impact of the lawsuits against Microsoft was accompanied by a more subtle upheaval in the ideological realm. The old certainties of conservative opposition to government intervention, fixed since the Reagan era, are shifting on this issue. New technologies, new business rules and, perhaps most important, the power of lobbying and campaign money are producing odd new alliances and redefining what is left and right and who is up or down.

title: It's Not Just the Hours
description: The New York State Department of Health released a study this week that found that nearly all the residents in the hospitals studied worked longer hours than the law allows. Many residents worked more than 24 hours straight, and a few worked more than 126 hours in a week.

title: Business Travel; American Airlines to offer new discount fares for weekend getaways over the Internet.
description: AMERICAN AIRLINES, emboldened by the response to the discounted fares for last-minute weekend getaways it offers in weekly E-mail messages sent free to more than 1.5 million subscribers, is now offering another round of last-minute mini-getaways to selected destinations.

title: Arsenals of Peace? Not for India; Russian Weapons Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich Plans Panel on China And Clinton Tie
description: Saying that ''very stark questions of national security'' are at stake, Speaker Newt Gingrich announced today that he would create a special committee to investigate President Clinton's decision to waive export controls over advanced space technology to China.

title: Aging Hackers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Posts Financial Results Of Auto Parts Subsidiary
description: The Ford Motor Company, once a pioneer in making virtually every auto part, disclosed the financial results of its parts operations for the first time today, a move widely seen as a prelude to the possible sale of a stake in the giant division someday.

title: For Scott Goodyear, a Miss Is as Good as 500 Miles
description: The final mile has been the most difficult mile for Scott Goodyear at the Indianapolis 500.

title: In America; Nike Blinks
description: Let's not be too quick to canonize Nike.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Last night I paged my husband to say 'What do you want me to pick up for dinner?' I paged him four times and I was so angry that he didn't return my call that I was like, 'I'm going to divorce you if you don't page me back right now.' ''

title: EQUITY OFFICE PROPERTIES ADDS A COLORADO BUILDING
description: Equity Office Properties Trust, whose chairman is the billionaire financier Sam Zell, said yesterday that it had bought the Millennium Plaza office building in Englewood, Colo., for $46 million. The property, with 330,033 square feet of space, is leased to the First Data Corporation. The seller was the closely held Shorenstein Realty Investors L.P. of San Francisco. The purchase comes less than a month after the Chicago-based Equity Office agreed to buy 13 office buildings in Denver and Albuquerque, N.M., for about $394 million, making it one of Denver's largest commercial landlords. Over all, Equity Office owns 268 buildings with 69.7 million square feet of space in 24 states and the District of Columbia.

title: Joy and Anger Erupt at Main Symbol of Government
description: Victory came to Indonesia's student movement today, in a delirious outpouring of joy at the Parliament, a building the protesters have occupied for three days and turned into a symbol of a ragtag resistance that helped to topple a giant.

title: LIBRARY/WEB SITES FOR GIRLS: WWW.PURPLE-MOON.COM; Fun, but Based on Products
description: EVER since the Purple Moon site made its debut in September 1997, it has been a huge success. It has more than one million visitors and more than 60,000 registered users who visit at least once a day. To date, girls have sent more than 3.5 million virtual postcards to one another through the site.

title: Ring Those Pay Phones
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLMAN, JANE
description: COLMAN-Jane. On May 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Seymour, devoted mother of Cathy and Peter and mother-in-law of Rose. Cherished grandmother of Hillary Roth, and Molly Colman. Memorial service will be Friday, May 22, 10 AM at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church -Dana Chapel, 921 Madison Avenue at 73rd Street.

title: LIFE BY DESIGN; Gene-Mapping, Without Tax Money
description: Sometimes, it's smart not to compete. The Energy Department and the National Institutes of Health are spending $3 billion to decode the entire human genetic structure by 2005. But this effort has recently been upstaged by a new private company founded by Dr. J. Craig Venter, president of the nonprofit Institute for Genomic Research, and the Perkin-Elmer Corporation. This venture, which will spend about $200 million, promises to complete the job in a mere three years. In response, the Wellcome Trust, a British foundation, pledged to double its $185 million grant to a nonprofit laboratory for similar work.

title: Day After Brawl, Retaliation Is Still in the Air
description: Any Yankees who were being sane and sensible last night should have wanted the stinging memories of Tuesday night's massacre to vanish. Quickly. There was nothing for the Yankees to secure by retaliating against the Baltimore Orioles again last night, and no intelligent reason for Hideki Irabu to select an Oriole and turn him into a clown atop a water tank.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JALONACK, SYLVIA (NEE SOLOW)
description: JALONACK-Sylvia (nee Solow). On May 19, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Devoted mother of Carol Blum and Richard. Cherished mother-in-law of Tibi Jalonack. Loving grandmother of Susannah, Asa and Mattie. Services Thursday, 12:30 PM at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Hempstead.

title: Border Patrol Is Criticized As Abusive
description: Despite some improvements in the way complaints of abuse are handled, people detained by Federal immigration agents along the United States-Mexican border are still often subject to ''cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment,'' according to a lengthy report released today by the human-rights group Amnesty International.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIER, ALLEN M.
description: SCHNEIER-Allen M. On May 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Susan, Leslie and Andrew; father-in-law of David, Robert and Jovana. Loving brother of Florence and Harriet. Funeral today (Thursday) 12 noon Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home 64 Ashford Ave., (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, NY.

title: Bouncing Graphics and Light That Love Music and Dancing
description: If run-of-the-mill screen savers have become all too predictable, or the steady gray rain of text and spreadsheets is making you depressed, the people at Madeira Software may have a solution for you. This week Madeira, a four-year-old company in Beverly, Mass., released Screen Dance 98, which turns your computer screen into the kind of light show you might have seen in a discotheque.

title: Separating Bogus Stogies From the Real Cohibas
description: Cigar smokers beware, but this time not of the health concerns often associated with the recreational puffing of smoldering tobacco leaves. This time the threat comes from dastardly interlopers who would dare pass off fake smokes for the real Cohibas, say editors at Cigar Aficionado, the hefty bimonthly magazine dedicated to celebrating premium cigars and the good life they have long symbolized. The magazine's Web site now has a Counterfeit Gallery to alert cigar smokers to the ruse. Just in time for Fathers' Day next month, the site (www.cigaraficionado. com) offers a virtual rogues' gallery of common cigars posing as the genuine articles.

title: Shortage of Parks Forces Baseball on Sunday
description: To the Editor:

title: Heavy Demand for Blue-Chip Issues Pushes Dow Up 116
description: The stock market snapped a weeklong slump late yesterday and sent most indexes sharply higher, creating another upward loop in Wall Street's roller coaster ascent this year.

title: Uncertainty Leaves Publishers Holding the Books
description: As computer instruction books go, this is as close to a cliffhanger as it gets.

title: Currents; It's the Easy, Breezy, No-Sweat Summer House Look
description: FOR many, it all begins this weekend: the sprucing up of a long-dormant country house, or the plotting of a brilliant career as a house guest. New design items, large and small, can give a jump start. Let the exodus begin!

title: Union Pacific Selling Overnite Trucking Unit
description: The Union Pacific Corporation made plans today to sell its Overnite Corporation trucking unit in a stock offering that could raise as much as $550 million -- $650 million less than what Union Pacific paid for it 12 years ago.

title: TREDEGAR INDUSTRIES IN DEAL FOR EXAL ALUMINUM
description: Tredegar Industries agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Exal Aluminum Inc., for undisclosed terms, to expand its aluminum operations in Canada. Exal employs about 270 people at two aluminum-extrusion plants in Ontario and had about $92 million in sales last year. Its products are used in the transportation, electrical, machinery and equipment and construction industries. Tredegar, which makes aluminum and plastic products, said Exal would become part of its William L. Bonnell unit. The unit operates six aluminum-extrusion plants and had sales of $267 million last year. Shares of the Richmond-based Tredegar rose $2.375 yesterday, to $85.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, NOAH
description: BROWNSTEIN-Noah. 5/21/52 to 8/1/92. Happy ''sixth'' birthday in heaven, dearest Noah. 46 years ago today was the happiest day of our lives and now our aching hearts reach out to you and the tears flow silently but steadily. Our wonderful, cherished son is now our Guardian Angel. How wonderful it would be if we could hear your sweet voice and help you blow out the candles on your cake, but you're so far away. Hugs and kisses forever, Mom and Dad.

title: New Managers Are Not Fixing Lab's Problems, Coalition Says
description: A coalition of community groups charged today that the new management of Brookhaven National Laboratory was failing to grapple with the lab's environmental problems. The president of the lab denied the allegations, but said he would continue to work with the coalition.

title: Making Books; It's the Cachet, Not the Money
description: Like pledges, like the Pleiades even, the entry-level world of editorial assistants in book publishing is singular and sometimes wondrous. It is also difficult, and generally only open to those who can afford to work for poor pay. Advancement often depends as much on the art of networking as on actual accomplishment. So why do so many bright literature majors from top schools want to get into it? Because they like books. Because there's a certain perceived glamour and cachet in producing them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHWIN, PATRICIA GREENER (NEE GLASGOW)
description: GERSHWIN - Patricia Greener (nee Glasgow). On May 19th, in her 85th year, peacefully in her sleep after a 5 year illness. Widow of Dr. Ben Gershwin and Prof. Abraham Greener. She leaves a multitude of devoted friends, four children, nine grandchildren and 3 great - grandchildren. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Our Towns; Making Lawns Fit for Flora And Fauna
description: KAREN WILLIAMS pondered Norma Brooke's well-clipped lawn, looking for something nice to say. ''Oh,'' she said finally, ''you've got dandelions. And over here, this looks like crane's bill.'' She dropped to her knees to get a better look. ''Yes, it is,'' she said, picking up a tiny purple flower. ''And, see here next to it, this is clover. This is all good stuff.''

title: INSIDE
description: Minority Enrollment Falls

title: When One Operating System Just Can't Satisfy a Customer
description: As Bill Gates and his Microsoft Corporation get ready to butt heads this week with the United States Justice Department and a slew of state attorneys general who say the company unfairly stomps its competition, another high-tech company is preparing to make room for Microsoft's Windows 98.

title: Fordham Ready For No. 6 Trojans
description: The Fordham Rams are not very talented, according to their coach. Their ace was a full-time center fielder who sometimes pitched relief. And they finished 10-8 in the Atlantic 10 conference.

title: Drug Agency Moves Against an Anti-Cholesterol Product
description: For more than a year, a California company has put red yeast rice from China into capsules and marketed them as a way to reduce cholesterol. Today, the Food and Drug Administration declared that those capsules, which the company calls dietary supplements, are in fact unapproved drugs.

title: Microsoft: Consumers' Savior or Evil Empire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Appoints Two Executives
description: The Walt Disney Company today named Thomas O. Staggs executive vice president and chief financial officer and Peter E. Murphy executive vice president and chief strategic officer.

title: Make a Right, You Can't Miss It
description: YOU are lost but you're not ready to admit it. You refuse to stop at a gas station and place your vacation plans in the hands of an untrustworthy teen-age gas-pump jockey. You have thrown away the maps in your glove compartment because you couldn't refold them. Worse yet, you are haunted by the childhood memory of a missed turn and a road sign (''Next Exit 65 Miles'') that reduced your family to sobbing wretches.

title: Feud Puts Harry Winston's Glitters Up for Sale
description: From his opulent, vaultlike store on Fifth Avenue, Harry Winston once bathed movie stars and princesses in diamonds, rubies and emeralds. His personal assistant remembers him staring at his favorite diamonds ''the way parents look at their newborn child.'' And two decades after Mr. Winston's death, few actresses would ever think of going to the Academy Awards ceremony without first arranging for a loan of a costly Harry Winston necklace or tiara.

title: Microsoft: Consumers' Savior or Evil Empire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Litton Gets Navy Contract
description: Litton Industries received a $138.6 million contract today to modernize the Navy's Ticonderoga class of Aegis cruisers. Litton will replace older engineering control and bridge systems with modern digital systems. The work is expected to be completed by December 2003. Litton Industries, based in Woodland Hills, makes electronic military and information systems and ships.

title: Interpublic Merging A Pair of Units
description: The Octagon sports marketing division of the Interpublic Group of Companies has merged two units -- Advantage International in Washington and API Group in London -- after Octagon acquired the 40 percent of API that it did not already own. The merged company, not yet named, has more than 500 employees in 21 offices worldwide, handling sports stars and marketers like Michael Chang, Steffi Graf, Guinness, I.B.M. and Mastercard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, LILLIAN (ZINN)
description: BLOCH-Lillian (Zinn). Adored wife of the late Marvin J. Bloch. Loving sister of Ruth Zinn Becker. Beloved mother of Linda, Willa and the late Paul Bloch. Cherished mother-in-law of Louise Hollinger, Rob Grambau and Douglas Fishman. Doting grandmother of David, Daniel, Marni, Mark and Zoe. Services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue today 10AM. Shiva at her late residence through Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 15 about Maurice H. Stans, a former Commerce Secretary in the Nixon Administration, misstated his position at the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace Foundation. Mr. Stans was finance chairman and a member of the board; he was not the chairman. This correction was delayed by an editing error.

title: AT HOME WITH: Maya Lin; Making History On a Human Scale
description: EVER since she created what is arguably the most moving architectural touchstone of her generation -- the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington -- Maya Lin has been identified with her monuments. To the world at large, she has seemed something of a distant figure, a sober, somber wisp, unyielding as a monolith.

title: ORACLE TO BUY ACTIVA SOFTWARE FROM PRICE WATERHOUSE
description: The Oracle Corporation agreed to buy Activa software, which helps companies track their cost and profit performance, from Price Waterhouse L.L.P. Terms were not disclosed. Price Waterhouse, the New York-based accounting and consulting firm that developed the software, will continue to use it with clients and will receive royalties from license sales. Oracle, one of the world's largest software companies, specializes in helping companies manage large data bases. It said it did not expect any financial charges because of the purchase. The company, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., said it would hire most of the current Activa development team and expected to begin worldwide sales of the software immediately.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: GOLDSTEIN-Abraham. On May 5, 1998. The Society of Jewish Science mourns the loss of its Leader, Chairman and 63-year member at the age of 90. The builder of our home and the guiding light of our Society, may he find eternal peace in G-d's resting place with our other great ones. Memorial services to be held on June 28 at 11am at the Society of Jewish Science, 109 East 39 Street, NY NY 10016. For info 212-682-2626

title: Credit Lyonnais Bailout Is Given Approval
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it had cleared a 125-billion-franc ($21 billion) bailout of Credit Lyonnais S.A. after France agreed to sell the state-controlled bank next year and shed a fifth of its assets before then.

title: Soros Is Said to Buy Caracas Bank Stake
description: The financier George Soros has expanded his holdings in Venezuela, buying a 5 percent stake in Banco Caracas, his partners said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, MYRON (MIKE)
description: SOLOMON-Myron (Mike). On May 18, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Betty, loving father of Nancy and Jane, dear brother of Sylvia Lindner, adoring grandfather of Steven and Janelle, devoted father-in-law of Jeff. Service Thursday 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory to Temple Kol Ami, 15030 North 64 Street, Scottsdale, AZ. 85254.

title: G.O.P. Bill to Back Parental Consent Abortion Laws
description: Seeking to chip away at abortion one bill at a time, Republican leaders in Congress launched an offensive today with a bill that would frequently make it a Federal crime to take a minor across state lines for an abortion.

title: Republicans' New Man in the Middle
description: Representative Christopher Cox, the designated chairman of the latest of many House investigations of the Clinton Presidency, is wary of ''the well-worn rut'' of Congressional partisanship. And so the conservative California Republican who will examine the Administration's export of space technology to China vowed today to treat his mission as a grave national security issue and not as another heated foray into campaign finance abuses.

title: Arts in America; Giving Newfoundland's Celtic Melodies a 90's Sound
description: Newfoundland rhymes with understand, and no one does, at least not in the eyes of the people who live in what is surely one of the most isolated and eccentric places in North America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIMMELBERGER, PERKINS, ROBIN
description: HIMMELBERGER - PERKINS - Robin. We are deeply saddened by the passing of the beautiful and beloved daughter of Robert and Marge Himmelberger, sister of Mark and Craig, aunt of Zachary and sister-in-law of Yolanda and Paige. Robin will be greatly missed. All of Brighton Towers Family extends their deepest sympathies to the Himmelbergers. The Bernstein and Fox Family

title: Agency.com Buys Rest of Online Magic
description: Agency.com in New York, an interactive marketing and communications agency, said yesterday that it had acquired the shares of Online Magic that it did not already own. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Art Thieves in Rome Take 2 Van Goghs and a Cezanne
description: With astonishing ease, three armed men hid in the National Gallery of Modern Art here after closing time, tied up the guards and stole three priceless paintings: two Van Goghs, ''Le Jardinier'' and ''L'Arlesienne,'' and a Cezanne, ''Le Cabanon de Jourdan.''

title: In New York, Emotional Fallout From India's Nuclear Tests
description: In the week since India's Hindu-nationalist Government staged five nuclear tests, the discussion among Indian and Pakistani immigrants in the New York area has sounded at times like debate over a high-stakes soccer match, with a mix of pride, excitement and rivalry.

title: Company Warns of Rise In Computer Virus Numbers
description: Computer viruses are growing rapidly in number, according to a new report issued by a data security company based in Helsinki, Finland.

title: Bridge; How a Disastrous Accident Can Produce a Top Score
description: It can reasonably be argued that if Maj. John Andre had not sleepily permitted his horse to take the wrong road, he would not have been arrested, Benedict Arnold would have succeeded in capturing West Point, and the Revolutionary War would have taken a totally different course. Minor accidents can have major results, in life and at the bridge table.

title: LIBRARY/WEB SITES FOR GIRLS: WWW.AGIRLSWORLD.COM; Where Young Volunteers Run Their Own On-Line World
description: A GIRL'S WORLD isn't nearly so slick as Girl Tech or Purple Moon, and it is easy to understand why. A self-described ''on-line clubhouse,'' the site was invented by four girls from Southern California who met on line in 1994. Today, A Girl's World is run by a staff of volunteers, almost all of whom are girls themselves. The result is an admirable, if unsophisticated, zine for girls between ages 7 and 14.

title: People
description: * Andreas Panayi was named to the new position of president at Brand Dialogue, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. that specializes in interactive marketing and commerce. He had been senior partner and international operations director at Poppe Tyson, New York, part of True North Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, JOHN A.
description: UNGAR-John A., 52. Of Sky Top Farm, died Monday, May 18, at home after a brief illness. The son of the late Sidney & Helen Ungar, Mr. Ungar was a native of New York City and a graduate of the University of Michigan. He was a Real Estate developer and owner. For the last thirty years, he owned and operated Sky Top Farm, breeding field jumpers. Known as a sportsman, businessman, and philanthropist, Mr. Ungar was president of Jarc Realty of New York & New Jersey. Mr. Ungar was a member of the Atlantic Salmon Federation & Trout Unlimited. He served as a member of the boards of Ampal, and the National Committee of Native American Rights Fund. He and his wife, Aine Dougherty Ungar, directed the Ungar Foundation. Besides his wife, Mr. Ungar leaves 2 sons, Harrison and Cole, and daughters Sari and Sage from a previous marriage to Blossom Ungar. He was a member of congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, and his hobbies included fly fishing, skiing, and horseback riding. Those wishing to do so may make memorial donations to the Native American Rights Fund, Boulder, Colorado; Green Chimneys Children's Services, Brewster; The American Diabetes Foundation; American Heart Association, and Miracle House, Inc. of New York City. Funeral services will be held at home, Sky Top Farm, 325 Sky Farm Road, Copake Lake, New York, Thursday, May 21, at noon.

title: Spam by Any Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Marriott Holders Vote Against Revamping Stock
description: Shareholders of Marriott International Inc. voted today against the hotel company's new stock structure, which used two classes of shares with different voting rights.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Wine Talk column in the Dining section yesterday, about merlot, lacked a final line. The column should have ended: ''Paris, too, has a restaurant honoring merlot. It's called Petrus.''

title: 'Good Home' vs. a Family
description: Some of the sad perplexities of foster care emerge tomorrow night in ''Taken In: The Lives of America's Foster Children.'' The particular children in question are the four sons and one daughter of Anna and Russell Smith, who lost them to their addiction to drugs.

title: Public Eye; Little Man With a Past
description: WHEN 11 European nations met earlier this month to formally agree upon a new common currency, the euro, the ceremony marked the culmination of a long process. For a decade now, as the European Union has moved toward greater economic integration, new rules have wiped away many local differences. For instance, when the bureaucrats drew up a list of fruits approved for shipment within the community, many prized local varieties were omitted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS, NAT
description: FIELDS-Nat. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Loving father of Ellen and Robert. Cherished grandfather. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made in his name to The American Cancer Society or to your favorite charity. Services today, 12 noon at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: An 'Illegal' Function? Only in Computer Lingo
description: Q. When Windows says the computer has performed an ''illegal'' function and it's closing the program, is it my fault?

title: Accounts
description: * Manco Inc., Avon, Ohio, a unit of Henkel K.G.a.A., to DDB Needham Chicago, a unit of Omnicom Group, as the first agency to handle advertising for the maker of Duck brand duct tape. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million.

title: Turf; Still For Rent: Hamptons Summer
description: WILLIAM SOKOLIN is frustrated, trying to rent out his four-bedroom villa overlooking the vineyards in Water Mill, part of the Long Island townships known as the Hamptons. Asking $45,000 for the summer or $25,000 for August, he has been advertising in the local papers for six weeks.

title: Renewed Call for Motorcade Against Giuliani's Taxi Rules
description: Several organizations of yellow cab drivers, who only a day earlier called off plans for a protest procession against proposed taxi regulations, reversed themselves yesterday and resurrected the demonstration after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani rebuffed their request for a meeting and stood by the proposals.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: No. 2 and Not Enjoying the Ride; Nissan Announces New Losses and Sweeping Changes
description: For some time, the Nissan Motor Company has confidently predicted that by 2000 it will command a quarter of Japan's automotive market. Today, that seems a pipe dream.

title: DEVELOPERS DIVERSIFIED TO BUY SALT LAKE CITY PROPERTIES
description: The Developers Diversified Realty Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy nine shopping centers and other properties mainly in the Salt Lake City area for about $300 million. The seller was the closely held Hermes Associates of Salt Lake City. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Developers Diversified, a real estate investment trust based in Moreland Hills, Ohio, said the price included a ''significant'' amount of securities. The Utah properties are Developers Diversified's first in the area. The company's shares slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $39.125.

title: Boy Who Vanished in 1979 Is Dead, Ex-Prosecutor Claims
description: Revisiting a case that came to symbolize the issue of missing children, a former Federal prosecutor said yesterday that he believed that a 6-year-old SoHo boy who disappeared in 1979 is dead and that his killer is behind bars.

title: Visiting Nuclear Site, Indian Leader Puts Pakistan on Notice
description: Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee today visited the site of India's nuclear tests and put Pakistan on notice that it should adopt a more conciliatory attitude that recognizes India's newly enhanced military power.

title: Shortage of Parks Forces Baseball on Sunday
description: To the Editor:

title: House Votes to Separate Training for Male and Female Recruits
description: The House cleared the way today for legislation that would segregate male and female recruits in the Army, Navy and Air Force during much of basic training, setting the stage for a new legislative fight over the role of women in the military.

title: Shortage of Parks Forces Baseball on Sunday
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS's Fall Lineup Adds Urban-Based Shows
description: Emphasizing stability and a move toward more shows with city settings, CBS yesterday announced a lineup of new series for next fall that its executives hope will help the network reach younger and urban viewers.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL REMAINS WEAK. A five-year high in stockpiles and lack of storage space further hurt oil prices. The July contract fell 83 cents, or 5.5 percent, to $14.18 a barrel. On Tuesday, the expiring June contract cost $12.98, a 9 1/2-year low.

title: Call Waiting
description: A wise person, on learning that a Galaxy 4 satellite had mysteriously pointed itself toward the rest of the universe instead of aiming its communications widgets at the earth where they belong, would have spent yesterday at the ball park. Sorry, boss, were you looking for me? I was out doing some field research and never heard a beep or felt a quiver. Thus the nearly 50 million people normally tethered to a beeper might safely arrange a day when you could get in touch with them but they could not get in touch with you. It would have been like a snow day from outer space.

title: Water Settlement May Not Settle Much
description: Settling a lawsuit brought by Federal environmental officials, New York City promised yesterday that it would finally proceed with plans to build a huge filtration plant to purify city drinking water from Westchester and Putnam Counties. But even as the settlement was announced, city officials said they still hoped to convince the Federal Government that the plant was unnecessary.

title: Teacher Accused of Selling School First-Aid Certificates
description: A Bronx high school teacher has been accused of selling hundreds of medical training certificates to coaches who did not want to take time-consuming classes in first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation, officials said yesterday.

title: Jones Will Now Fight Any and All
description: Roy Jones Jr., has another ring date on Aug. 15 and it is one that he wants to keep no matter whom he has to fight, according to his promoter, Murad Muhammad. That is in keeping with the attitude of the new Roy Jones Jr.

title: After the Web's Arrival, the Deluge of Log-Ons : On-Line Identity Crisis:Seeking a Unique Name
description: NEW YORK  "Please choose a log-on name." Five words that strike terror, or at least ennui, into the heart of your average Netizen. Even before the Internet allowed consumers to deal directly with businesses, there were identities and passwords for mainframes at work, automated teller machines and home and office security systems.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball's Antiquated Discipline
description: WHEN the sentences came down, Armando Benitez deserved to serve the most time, eight games. The huge Oriole right-hander had ignited Tuesday night's commotion by firing a fastball into the upper back of Tino Martinez, the Yankee slugger, after Bernie Williams had fired a three-run homer into the upper deck.

title: Congo Leader Losing Luster
description: For a brief moment last May, when his fighters swept into this capital and put an end to Africa's longest dictatorship, Laurent Kabila, the new President, loomed huge on the political stage as a national hero and as Africa's brightest star.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the first round of grants from Ted Turner's $1 billion gift to the United Nations referred imprecisely to the donor of the grants. It is the United Nations Foundation, an independent group, not the United Nations itself.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, REV. MAURICE
description: CARROLL-Rev. Maurice. On May 19, 1998. Pastor of St. Vincent De Paul Catholic Church on West 23rd Street. Son of the late Kathleen & David. Beloved brother of Eileen McKeown. Survived by six nieces and nephews and 11 grandnieces and nephews. Reposing at the Horn-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23 Street, NYC, Friday. Visiting hours: 1-5 PM. Transferral to St. Vincent De Paul Church on Friday evening with a 7:30 PM mass. Funeral mass on Saturday at 11 AM with burial to follow in the Calvary Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in his memory to: St. Christopher's Inn Inc.-Graymoor, Box 150, Garrison, New York 10524.

title: Beilein Will Listen
description: The St. John's athletic director, Ed Manetta, continuing a search for a successor to Coach Fran Fraschilla, is waiting to hear from the University of Richmond coach, John Beilein.

title: Calendar; Art Exhibitions, Talks, A Benefit and a Tour
description: French Master

title: LIBRARY/WEB SITES FOR GIRLS: WWW.GIRLTECH.COM; Girl Tech: Smart Place To Gather
description: GIRL TECH is no pretty-in-pink playground. It is a site with a distinctly intelligent, feminist agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, RICHARD ''DICK''
description: WEAVER-Richard ''Dick'', 89. Former Secretary-Treasurer of ATPAM. Elder statesman, mentor and lion of the New York theatre world. Beloved husband & father, survived by his wife Jill, and sons Chris and Jed. Memorial service to be held Friday 11:30 AM at Stephen Wise Synagogue, 30 West 68 Street. We will all miss your fire.

title: France and Germany Report Output Gains
description: French manufacturers increased output in March by 1.2 percent, a three-month high, while German output rose eight-tenths of a percent in the month, reports from the countries showed. Germany's exports boomed in the same month, while its money supply, a key inflation indicator, fell in April, two other reports showed.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: House Votes to Prohibit Satellite Exports to China
description: In a bipartisan stampede on a politically explosive issue, the House overwhelmingly voted today to bar the export of American-made commercial satellites to China.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSTEIN, HARRY L.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Harry L. Always in our hearts. Barbara and family

title: LIBRARY/WEB SITES FOR GIRLS; Offering Curious Girls Room for Exploration
description: AS the mother of a 5-year-old girl, I have high hopes that my daughter will achieve Internet literacy. At the same time, I know how tough it can be to find great Web sites where a girl can safely hang out and have fun. Try typing in ''girl'' on a search engine, and you will see what I mean. There is a plethora of Las Vegas-style entertainment, but not much to comfort a parent.

title: Shelves of Snooping Aids Make Privacy Hard to Buy
description: A MAN stepped through the door of a spy store in West Hollywood and muttered that his company, a ''major movie studio,'' was tapping his telephone. He needed a device to examine the phone, hunt down the tap and shut the thing off.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Dividing Hostas

title: Injured Coronado's Quest Will Probably Miss Belmont
description: Coronado's Quest, the early favorite for the Preakness who was scratched from the race because of a foot injury, is not likely to challenge the Triple Crown hopeful Real Quiet in the June 6 Belmont Stakes either, the trainer Shug McGaughey said yesterday.

title: When Celebrities Edit
description: To the Editor:

title: Troubled Nuclear Plant Takes a Key Step
