description: The Millstone Nuclear Power Station, which regulators barred from operating because of its management's disregard of workers' safety complaints, was notified today by Federal officials that its two-year recovery effort had made enough progress in that area to justify a restart of operations.

title: Legislators Seek Return Of 'Garden State' Name
description: In an effort to bolster pride in New Jersey's agricultural heritage, three lawmakers hope to pressure the PNC Bank Arts Center's corporate sponsor to put the ''Garden State'' back into the center's name.

title: A Game of Many Rules Has None on Fighting
description: The National Basketball Association warns its players that if they leave the bench to join an on-court fight, they will be suspended and fined. National Hockey League players incur automatic suspensions for leaving the bench for an on-ice altercation. The National Football League tells its players to ''stay away'' if a fight breaks out among other players or face the imposition of fines.

title: Godzilla, Policy Wonk
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable Modems: For a Few, Real Speed
description: SWITCHING her home Internet access from a fast dial-up connection to a cable modem has made Dana Chee much more popular around her house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSWIT, EUGENE
description: ELSWIT-Eugene. Devoted husband of Muriel for 54 years. Proud and loving father of Larry and Bob, grandfather of Rebecca, Justin and Sarah, father-in-law of Bernice Speiser. A truly gentle and giving man who was more concerned for others than for himself. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Hospice Care in Westchester & Putnam, 100 South Bedford Rd, Mount Kisco, NY 10549, or Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America, 280 Hillside Avenue, Needham, MA 02194. Services Friday at 12 noon, Clark's Chapel, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY

title: WATERLINK BUYING BUSINESSES FROM SUTCLIFFE SPEAKMAN
description: Waterlink Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the activated carbon and environmental systems businesses of Sutcliffe Speakman P.L.C. for $45 million. Sutcliffe Speakman is a chemicals and environmental engineering company based in Britain. Waterlink, based in Canton, Ohio, provides water purification and waste-water treatment services. It had revenue of $59.3 million in the six months ended March 31. The activated carbon and environmental systems businesses, with annual revenue of more than $55 million, make products and services that use activated carbon for the separation, concentration or purification of water, liquids and gases. The carbon group directs its operations from eight locations in the United States and Britain.

title: U.S. v. MICROSOFT: THE CASE; Separating Fixations From Fixes
description: Many analysts predict that the Government's attempt to protect the Netscape Communications Corporation's Navigator browser from the onslaught of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows operating system and its Internet Explorer browser will prove futile.

title: Judge Declares Accord on Bias Isn't Honored
description: Two years after New Jersey's Department of Corrections settled a racial and sexual discrimination suit brought by black and female prison guards, a Federal judge has found that the department has failed to do all it said it would.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Surges 116, But Nasdaq Declines 14

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A paging company faces problems in the heavens and on earth.
description: SUDDENLY, the beepers didn't work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIFRIN, HERBERT E.
description: SHIFRIN-Herbert E. On May 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Norma. Loving father of Roy and David Shifrin and Laura Tarlowe (Paul). Brother of Beatrice Saltzman. Adoring grandfather of William Shifrin and Stephanie and Ezra Tarlowe. Services today, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Movement Lacked Leader In Streets
description: Even as students celebrated the resignation of President Suharto this morning, they began calling for an even greater change in the country's leadership.

title: U.S. v. MICROSOFT: THE SPIN; Analogies As Complex And Murky As the Case
description: Monday's showdown at the Windows 98 Corral may not have been dueling six-shooters at 20 paces, but it was certainly dueling metaphors at 3,000 miles. And by the time the smoke had cleared in Washington East and Washington West, both sides had shot themselves in the foot.

title: Shocking, Amusing or Both?
description: For sustained emotional and intellectual excitement in the theater this spring it would be hard to find an equal to Repertorio Espanol's production of ''El Publico,'' by Federico Garcia Lorca. Robert Weber Federico's set and lighting create a spectacle suggestive of vast paintings reflecting some of Garcia Lorca's own drawings. Adolfo Vazquez's choreography moves 10 actors in 30 roles elegantly through a 90-minute ballet of fury, lust, anger and comic bewilderment. Marshall Coid's muted music appropriately puts one in mind of racing horns or calls to battle. And Garcia Lorca's torrent of ideas battering down sexual, social and theatrical convention seem at times to contort and convulse the characters, who are at least as shocked or amused by what they say and do as the audience is.

title: Garden Notebook; Lucky's the Man Who Gardens at Work
description: ''IT was my height and my age,'' Nicholas Callaway, 44, said, explaining how 10 years ago he came to buy a Hinoki cypress that now towers by the entrance to the office of Callaway Editions Inc., at 70 Bedford Street in Greenwich Village. Unlike most corporate outdoor spaces -- handsome but impersonal rooftops or entrance courts -- Mr. Callaway's gardens are filled with private meanings. The Katsura tree (Cercidiphyllum japonicum) is there because his wife, Yukine, is Japanese and because he loves Japan; the peonies because he thrust a peony into Georgia O'Keeffe's hand when she received an honorary degree at Harvard University.

title: How Servers Find Needle In Haystack Of the Net
description: THE Defense Department created the Internet and so the nature of its offspring should come as no surprise -- it's a vast hierarchy with redundancy added in case of war.

title: Best Way to Teach Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: Help From College Board
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CULLITY, JOHN P.
description: CULLITY-John P. Of Rutherford, New Jersey. On May 19, 1998. Brother of Ann Hayser of West Orange, N.J. Uncle of Elizabeth Cicchino, Michael & John Hayser. Also survived by many friends. Funeral Mass Saturday, May 23, 9:30AM at Saint Joseph's Church corner of Pavonia and Baldwin Avenues, Jersey City. Interment Holy Name Cemetery. Visiting Thursday & Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Quinn-Hopping Funeral Home of Livingston, 145 East Mount Pleasant Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the American Heart Association or Saint Joseph's Home for the Blind, Jersey City.

title: Corrections
description: The Arts in America column yesterday, about the Museum of Jurassic Technology in Culver City, Calif., misidentified the creator of ''Object,'' a well-known Surrealist artwork that consists of a fur-covered cup, saucer and spoon, cited as an example of idiosyncratic creativity. The piece, in the collection of the Museum of Modern Art, was created by Meret Oppenheim in 1936, not by Marcel Duchamp.

title: Microsoft: Consumers' Savior or Evil Empire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Sign Up Venezuelan, 17
description: Gregorio Machado, a part-time scout for the Mets in Venezuela, was at Shea Stadium last night, observing his latest signing, the 17-year-old free-agent first baseman Kenji Garcia.

title: Morton Rosenthal, 89; Helped Form Warner
description: Morton Rosenthal, whose family's funeral business evolved through mergers and acquisitions into Time Warner Inc., died on Friday. He was 89.

title: Senate Rejects 2 Measures on Cigarette Fee
description: The Senate handily rejected today the main alternatives to what would amount to a $1.10-per-pack increase in the Federal tax on cigarettes over the next five years.

title: Jones Sprinting and Leaping Toward the Record Books
description: Some words seem off-limits among competitors in women's track and field, said Marion Jones, the budding sprinting star. Chief among them: any mention of breaking Florence Griffith Joyner's 10-year-old world marks of 10.49 seconds in the 100 meters and 21.34 in the 200 meters.

title: Community College Role; Classmates Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Information Highway Maps Speed Traps
description: DID a momentary lapse on the road ever leave you at the mercy of a radar-equipped, revenue-hungry highway patrol officer with a pack of speeding tickets? Well, what the asphalt highway may take away, the information highway may give back.

title: Music on a Mac
description: To the Editor:

title: More Widows, the Merrier
description: ''The Merry Widow,'' Ronald Hynd's witty ballet version of Franz Lehar's operetta of the same name, was the American Ballet Theater's surprise hit last year, and this season's different casts have plunged in with the same enthusiasm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, MORTON
description: ROSENTHAL-Morton. The Board of Trustees, Clergy and staff of Temple Beth El of Northern Westchester notes with profound sadness the death of Morton Rosenthal, a founder and past president of our congregation. We share in the grief of his wife Rosalind and his daughter Jane Goldman and their entire family. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Chaim Stern, Sr. Rabbi Dana Anesi, Cantor David Thomas, Assistant Rabbi Gloria Meisel, President

title: Clinton Welcomes Suharto's Exit but Says Indonesia Still Needs 'a Real Democratic Change'
description: President Clinton tonight welcomed the resignation of President Suharto of Indonesia but said that the nation still needed to begin ''a real democratic transition'' that ''enjoys broad public support.''

title: Millions Await Beep, but Box Remains Silent
description: Paging companies and other communications providers scrambled to restore service yesterday to the tens of millions of people nationwide whose electronic devices shut down late Tuesday because a satellite began rotating uncontrollably.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, HAROLD LEO, M.D.
description: HARRIS-Harold Leo, M.D. The officers, members and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of Dr. Harold Harris of Evanston, Ill. As a Technion Guardian, he demonstrated the highest level of commitment to the TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology, the ATS and Israel. He supported scholarships and a project to make the campus handicapped accessible, as well as teaching annually for many years at the Faculty of Medicine. He served as past president and chairman of the Chicago Chapter and on the National Board of Directors and Board of Regents. A passionate supporter of Israel, Dr. Harris often said that the highlight of his career was when he volunteered during the Yom Kippur War in the Burn Unit of the Israel Defense Forces. His lifetime commitment influenced his son, Ron, who endowed the Dr. Harold Leo Harris Academic Chair and the Margaret Mosenfelder Harris Academic Chair at the Technion in honor of his father and mother. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Harris' wife, Margaret, and the entire Harris family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Irving A. Shepard, President Ben Z. Sosewitz, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Joel Rothman, Chicago Chapter President Jerold A. Jacover Chicago Chapter Chair Fred Greenberg West Central Region Director

title: Community College Role; A California Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Design Showrooms Go Back on Tour
description: THIS weekend, Richard's Traveling Home Furnishings Center will turn up in the Hamptons again. At last year's sale in Bridgehampton, Isaac Mizrahi, Martha Stewart, Deborah Norville and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware were seen milling around fancy decor that had been trucked in (and marked down) from Manhattan's design showrooms -- those to-the-trade-only enclaves that sell to designers at 20 percent to 40 percent off list prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, JAMES C.
description: McINTYRE-James C. The clients, volunteers, staff and Board of Directors of Gay Men's Health Crisis mourn the passing of former board member James C. McIntyre. His dedication will be deeply missed. Mark Robinson, Executive Director. David Hollander, Board Chair.

title: M.T.A. Won't Reduce Service On Subway Lines in Summer
description: With the introduction of new fare incentives sending thousands of additional riders pouring onto city subways and buses, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will not reduce subway and some bus service schedules this summer for the first time in decades, a transit official said yesterday.

title: Fewer Minorities Entering U. of California
description: Far fewer black and Hispanic students will enroll as freshmen at the University of California's most competitive campuses this fall, although their numbers will drop only slightly throughout the state system and some campuses will have an increase, officials said today.

title: COINMACH LAUNDRY PLANS TO ACQUIRE GORDON & THOMAS
description: The Coinmach Laundry Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Gordon & Thomas Companies, an East Orange, N.J., provider of laundry equipment services, for about $58 million in cash plus the assumption of $2 million in liabilities. Gordon & Thomas had revenues of about $40 million for the year ended Sept. 30, 1997, Coinmach said in a statement. Coinmach, based in Roslyn, N.Y., provides about 680,000 coin-operated laundry machines to multi-tenant properties nationwide. For the year ended March 31, it had revenues of $324.9 million.

title: House Republicans Resume Drive to Cut Government and Taxes
description: The House budget committee approved on a party-line vote tonight a $1.72 trillion fiscal blueprint for next year that resumes the Republican drive to scale back the Federal Government and cuts taxes by an additional $101 billion over five years.

title: Arts Week at P.S. 164
description: On a small stage at Public School 164 in Queens, three ninth graders formed a tableau vivant portraying the emotion ''hopeless.'' They were performing for their peers, who had enacted emotions like ''suspicion'' and ''jealousy,'' but they were also performing for Greer Hansen, their teacher; for Barbara Brown, the principal of P.S. 164, and for the playwright Wendy Wasserstein, who came to this classroom as part of Arts Education Week. It was, in fact, the kind of class and the kind of school where hopelessness seemed in very short supply. When, to much laughter, one student asked Ms. Wasserstein, ''What's it like to have all your hopes fulfilled?'' the question seemed to measure an ambition rather than a deficit.

title: Economic Scene; The airline industry is lurking on a second antitrust front.
description: ALL eyes are on the Justice Department's antitrust assault on Microsoft, but Washington's efforts to preserve competition in the airline industry may prove equally contentious. While the case against the airlines does not turn on the modern complexities of software integration, the old-fashioned sins that some contend the airlines have committed may prove equally difficult to pin down.

title: SUHARTO, BESIEGED, STEPS DOWN AFTER 32-YEAR RULE IN INDONESIA
description: President Suharto apologized for his mistakes and resigned today after 32 years in power, handing over his office to his Vice President, B. J. Habibie, in a nationally televised ceremony.

title: CONSOLIDATION CAPITAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE 6 COMPANIES
description: The Consolidation Capital Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire five electrical contractors and one janitorial service company for $51.1 million in cash and $63.2 million in stock. Consolidation Capital, based in Washington, is creating a national building-maintenance system. Combined annual sales at the six companies, which it would not identify, are $160 million. That would increase Consolidation Capital's annual revenue to more than $800 million. The company's shares fell $1.625 yesterday, to $19.75.

title: Queens Man Arrested In Brooklyn Shootings
description: Police detectives have arrested a Queens teen-ager who they said is a member of the Bloods street gang on charges that he shot eight pedestrians in downtown Brooklyn after becoming irritated by a girl's request to leave the gang.

title: No. 8 Auburn Doesn't Faze Rutgers
description: To hear Dave Marciniak, Rutgers's outstanding second baseman, tell it, the Scarlet Knights are hardly awed by the prospect of taking on Auburn, the No. 8-ranked team in the nation, at Tallahasse, Fla., today in a regional opener of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Five Players Barred After a Nasty Brawl In a Yankees Game
description: The day after a nasty bench-clearing brawl between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles at Yankee Stadium, Gene Budig, the American League president, yesterday suspended five players involved in the incident, including an eight-game ban for Baltimore's Armando Benitez for intentionally throwing a pitch at the Yankees' Tino Martinez.

title: The consolidation trend reaches the industry's second tier as Lois/USA acquires a smaller rival.
description: MERGER mania, which continues to remake the largest agency companies, is also reshaping the ranks of the smaller shops as they strive to maintain a role in a revamped Madison Avenue.

title: The Cart Issue Is Awaiting Resolution
description: The thing about the United States Open is that it allows men to chase their dreams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, PHILIP SEMPLE
description: BARRY-Philip Semple. Of New York City and Beverly Hills, California, on Saturday, May 16, 1998 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Husband of Patricia White Barry, father of Miranda Robbins Barry and Stephanie Anne Thankful Barry Agnew, grandfather of Alexandra Anne and Hailey Ellen Agnew. Funeral Services will be at 3:00PM, Saturday, May 23 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, New York, burial at Most Holy Trinity Cemetery. A memorial service will be held at 3:00 P.M., on Tuesday, June 9 at the St. James Theatre, 246 West 44th St. in New York City. A memorial service at the Director's Guild of America in Los Angeles is planned, date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations in New York to the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theatre Center or Lenox Hill Hospital, in California to the American Film Institute or the John Tracy Clinic. For further information contact Williams Funeral Home of East Hampton.

title: Go West, West End: The Risks Are Dramatic
description: David Pugh propped a scuffed sneaker on the edge of a coffee table in his suite of offices overlooking Shaftesbury Avenue. ''The minute the play opened, we were picking up the newspaper and reading where various New York producers were claiming that they were going to do it with us on Broadway, which was interesting because we'd never even spoken to them,'' he said.

title: And the Winner Is . . . the Marketing Team
description: I CAN'T decide whether Nintendo 1080degrees Snowboarding is a video game or a business school case study. It's a great piece of digital entertainment: a full-scale, motion-captured simulation of the extreme sport du jour, complete with real-world physics, techno soundtrack, jump mode, stunt mode, flying powder, lens flares, water reflection, shaded snow, shooshing audio effects and instant replays.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Holocaust Exhibits Now Accessible to a Larger Audience
description: More than 1.7 million people have visited the Simon Wiesenthal Center's Museum of Tolerance since it opened in Los Angeles in 1993. And now, officials of the museum say they are hoping to make their collection of documents, photographs and artifacts from the Jewish Holocaust and related topics available to millions more on the Internet.

title: Microsoft: Consumers' Savior or Evil Empire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, IRENE
description: LANDAU-Irene. Devoted wife of the late Maurice. Beloved mother of Steven (Sara), Joyce Kole (Michael) and Daniel. Adored grandmother of Larry, Ali, Leigh, Debbie and Avi and great grandmother of Danielle, Maayan and Sam. Beloved sister of Bella & Amanda. Her long life was one of devotion to Israel and Jewish women's organizatons. Her loving spirit will live forever in each of us.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday showing no-hitters by Yankee pitchers included one incorrectly. In 1990, in what was considered a no-hitter at the time, Andy Hawkins pitched eight innings in a Yankee loss at Chicago. But Major League Baseball changed the rule the next year, requiring at least nine innings for a no-hitter.

title: Shoreham Voters Reject 48% School Tax Increase
description: By an overwhelming margin, voters in the Shoreham-Wading River School District yesterday rejected a proposed $32.8 million budget that would have raised school property taxes 48 percent. In a record turnout at the polls there, the budget lost 2,383 to 993.

title: U.S. v. MICROSOFT: THE MARKET; Microsoft Suit's Earliest Result: Surge of Buyers
description: The Government's sweeping antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation is already having an impact in the marketplace, though an unintended one.

title: The Calm Instead of The Storm At Cannes
description: Sundance grads, pedophiles and dogmatic Danes dominate the cinematic landscape here. And all around this uncharacteristically quiet town, tails drag. The combined effects of art and adrenaline have yet to kick in at this year's Cannes International Film Festival. And the event has only until Sunday's closing-night ceremonies to make its mark.

title: Do You Have Bad Cyberkarma?
description: LYSON O'MAHONEY is well acquainted with the Macintosh frownie face. It has become her second mirror of sorts, giving her the stinkeye with alarming frequency when she turns on her monitor.

title: Finis Davis, Long a Benefactor To Blind People, Is Dead at 86
description: Finis E. DavisFinis E. Davis, an executive, educator and fund-raiser who spent his life serving the blind at home in Kentucky and around the world, died last Friday at the Episcopal Church Home in Louisville. He was 86.

title: Caesar's Fate, Played Out in Mali
description: The soothsayer approaches Caesar and urges him, ''Beware the seventh of Odwira.'' The assassins greet one another with ''Salaam aleikum.'' Brutus explains his actions with the words ''Not that I loved Caesar less but that I loved Mali more.''

title: Washington's Mayor Is Coy, But Reports Say He Won't Run
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of the District of Columbia has dodged and weaved his way through questions about his political future for months, insisting that his ''thinking and praying time'' is not over and that no one is going to force him to announce his plans until he is good and ready.

title: Trade Deficit Rose in March To New High
description: The nation's monthly trade deficit rose to a new high of $13 billion in March, the Government reported today, providing the clearest evidence yet of how Asia's mounting economic woes are restraining American growth for good and for ill.

title: Community College Role; Remediation Is No Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Blood Deepens as the Yankees Just Rub It In
description: Armando Benitez sparked a brawl with a beanball on Tuesday, but he was not at Yankee Stadium last night to see the lasting consequences of his explosion.

title: After Windows 98: The Future According to Microsoft
description: THE fight between the Microsoft Corporation and the Department of Justice has placed Windows 98, the upgrade to the Windows 95 operating system, under a microscope. But in the fast-paced world of software development, Windows 98 is already yesterday's news -- it may be shipping now, but it went into development nearly three years ago.

title: Microsoft: Consumers' Savior or Evil Empire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Commencements; On a Hot Day, Columbia Hails Annan and Bacall
description: It was a bathing suit kind of day, and Sinatra music was playing in the background -- ''Start spreading the news, I'm leaving today'' -- as some 20,000 people gathered on Columbia University's main lawn yesterday to see their friends and relatives graduate.

title: Local Clubs Prepared For Legal Challenges
description: As Casey Martin moves forward with his campaign to ride a golf cart in competition, local golf organizations await the legal challenges that seem sure to come in the wake of Martin's groundbreaking effort.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the perfect game pitched by David Wells of the Yankees misstated the date of Don Larsen's perfect game in the 1956 World Series. It was Oct. 8, not Oct. 6.

title: Toyota Reports Record 1997 Earnings
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's biggest auto maker, said today that it had a 17.7 percent gain in earnings for its 1997 fiscal year, reaching a record, as strong sales in the United States and Europe offset weakness in Asia.

title: Measure on E.D.S Chairman Is Defeated by Shareholders
description: In a slap at management, 21 percent of Electronic Data System's shareholders voted today to ask the company chairman to relinquish his post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRING, BERTHA (NEE COHEN)
description: SPRING-Bertha (nee Cohen). On May 19, 1998. Age 91. Of Kensington, Maryland. Formerly of Glen Cove and Roslyn, N.Y. Of Alzheimer's disease. Survived by a son Warren Kotler, son Richard Spring, daughter Stephanie Krulik and a sister Muriel Katz, nine grandchildren and ten greatgrandchildren. Devoted mother, grandmother, aunt & best friend.

title: Thinking Convergence
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Chemistry at Furniture Fair
description: NEWNESS is the whole point of the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, which ended on Tuesday. The fair, at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, is the nation's main showcase for inventive design; yet, designers, in their perennial quest for modernity, have previously veered off in two directions: novelty for the sake of novelty, and the pious rehashing of modern classics. Both camps -- the kooky and the reverent -- typically face off without saying anything extremely new.

title: Group Is Seeking Total Protection for Atlantic Salmon
description: Seeking to halt what could be the journey of wild Atlantic salmon toward oblivion, the Atlantic Salmon Federation is proposing a halt to the killing of the species by all fishing interests.

title: Joys of Hanging Out On a Virtual Corner
description: THE other day, as I was scrolling down a ranking of the most popular Web sites, I found myself stifling a yawn as I was confronted with the usual suspects: Yahoo (been there), Netscape (done that), America Online (ho-hum), Microsoft, Lycos, Excite (yeah, whatever), Mirabilis. . . .

title: Drama Off the High Seas; Lawsuit Rages Over a Decaying, and Historic, Tugboat
description: Even in her prime, the Catawissa was never glamorous. Built to haul coal up and down the East Coast, the 158-foot tugboat spent half her life feeding power plants from Charleston, S.C., to Boston and the second half steam-cleaning sludge from the insides of freighters docked in New York Harbor.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GOLD BANC CORP., Leawood, Kan., a bank holding company, agreed to buy First State Bancorp Inc., Pittsburg, Kan., for $25 million in stock.

title: Director Tries a Fantasy As He Questions Reality
description: Peter Weir was despondent. It was 1995, and after directing acclaimed films like ''The Year of Living Dangerously,'' ''Witness,'' and ''Dead Poets Society,'' he was seeking his next project but finding every script either predictable or derivative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANK SHEIRR, CAROLINE
description: BANK SHEIRR-Caroline. On May 20, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Samuel Sheirr and the late Robert Bank. Loving mother of Bruce Sheirr and the late Mark James Sheirr. Beloved grandmother of Valerie, Claudia, Suzanne and Kenneth. Proud great-grandmother of Jordan and Julia. Graveside service May 21, 11 AM, Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey.

title: SOCCER: They All Come to Play for America; Regis Is the Newest Citizen on Polyglot U.S. World Cup Soccer Team
description: David Regis was a citizen of France and is a professional soccer player in Germany. He speaks little English, has been to the United States only three or four times and has trained for only a week with the American soccer team as it prepares for the coming World Cup in France.

title: Chinese Delegation Seems to Deny Pakistan a Nuclear Umbrella
description: As Pakistani leaders struggled to decide whether to conduct a nuclear test in response to India's recent tests, a high-level delegation from Pakistan slipped quietly into Beijing early Monday. Today, just as quietly, it left.

title: Behind the Low Oil Prices
description: The United States is getting a bonanza from sliding oil prices, which have boosted economic growth and helped to mask the deteriorating trade deficit with the rest of the world. But if oil prices rebound later this year, as the oil industry generally expects, that economic benefit could vanish.

title: Satellite Failure Is Rare, And Therefore Unsettling
description: Tens of millions of Americans became keenly aware of their dependence on yet another space age technology yesterday, after a communications satellite orbiting 22,300 miles above the Equator went on the blink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, PAULINE
description: KAYE-Pauline. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Pauline Kaye, and extends heartfelt condolences to her family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Dr. Philip Adler, President

title: Hotel Workers' Leader Quit Under Pressure, Documents Show
description: The Federal Government unsealed an agreement yesterday in which Edward T. Hanley, the longtime president of the nation's largest union of hotel workers, agreed to retire after being pressured to do so by a court-appointed monitor.

title: Mets' Pitchers Squander Bounty by Their Hitters
description: While the Mets have drawn attention for their lack of hitting prowess, they had little trouble scoring runs of all sorts last night. They went deep, slamming a pair of two-run home runs in one inning. They chipped away for runs, moving runners with efficiency and taking advantage of openings given by Cincinnati Reds pitchers.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Climbs to New High
description: The nation's monthly trade deficit reached a new high of $13 billion in March, the Government reported, providing the clearest evidence yet how Asia's mounting economic woes are restraining American growth for good and for ill.

title: 2 Sudden and Fierce Storms Bring Hail and Flooding
description: With a ferocity that was both swift and unexpected, two thunderstorms converged over New York City yesterday evening, lashing lower Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn with hail the size of golf balls and rain so heavy that it flooded 14 of the city's 25 subway lines within a matter of minutes.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: On the Trail, With Wit and Insights
description: A WALK IN THE WOODS

title: Three New Yorkers Charged in Kidnapping of a Businessman in Kazakhstan
description: Three New York residents have been arrested on charges that they participated in the kidnapping of a businessman in Kazakhstan, who was then forced to wire ransom money to a bank branch in New York, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: T.W.A. to Get 3 New Jets
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. has acquired three more Boeing 757-200 jetliners from the International Lease Finance Corporation. Terms of the deal, which was announced Tuesday, were not disclosed. The company said the aircraft were scheduled for delivery in 1999 and 2000, bringing T.W.A.'s fleet of 757-200s to 23 aircraft by January 2000. International Lease, based in Century City, Calif., leases planes to airlines. It is a unit of the American International Group, an insurance company based in New York.

title: Fistfight in Brooklyn Leads to Man's Death
description: A fistfight yesterday between two men on a Brooklyn street corner led to one man's death early this morning, the police said.

title: Metronet Acquiring Phone Unit from Rogers
description: The Metronet Communications Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the Rogers Telecom unit of Rogers Communications Inc. for $1.08 billion (Canadian) or $745 million (United States) in cash and stock.

title: Treasures Are Cloistered but Still on View
description: APRIL 30 has passed, and with it the chance to see a once-in-a-millennium exhibition of icons, rare manuscripts, silver and gold vessels, shimmery vestments and other artifacts from the Eastern Orthodox monasteries of Mount Athos in northern Greece, which had been on view at the Museum of Byzantine Culture in Salonika since last June.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Dressing Down

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMANN, ELAINE
description: FUHRMANN-Elaine. May 20, 1998, beloved wife of the late Louis Grinthal, and the late Mort Furhmann. Loving mother of Karen Grinthal Vernon, & the late Jamie Grinthal. Devoted sister of Dr. Robert Rubin. Cherished grandmother of William and Emma Vernon. Service Thursday, May 21, 1998, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Contributions in her name may be made to The American Cancer Society or to Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Talking Fast to Get Artists Into Classrooms
description: IT is tempting to get the cliches about Martin E. Segal out of the way early, because he actually is irrepressible and perhaps a bit cherubic and so overflowing with twinkly stories from years back that entire trains of thought can get lost in an anecdotal fog. But what is far more important to know about this 5-feet-3-inch impresario is that behind the daily rosebud in his lapel is an armor-plated will, one incapable of taking no for an answer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODNER, LEO
description: BODNER-Leo. Beloved father of Gilda and David Kaufman, Allen & Robin Bodner, Howard and Sara Bodner, cherished grandfather and adored great grandfather. Funeral at 9:30 AM on May 21 at Shomrei Hadas, 3803 14th Ave, Brooklyn, NY. Shivah to be observed at 1134 East 7th St, Brooklyn through Wednesday morning, May 27. A good man with a gentle nature, he will always be remembered for his devotion to the Jewish people and the land Israel.

title: NYCOMED AMERSHAM SELLING 2 FACTORIES TO MONSANTO
description: Nycomed Amersham P.L.C., a British-Norwegian health care concern, agreed to sell its two factories in Puerto Rico to the Monsanto Company for $66 million. The sale is part of a consolidation of manufacturing operations after the merger last year of Nycomed of Norway and Amersham International of Britain. The deal includes a bulk-chemical manufacturing plant closed since 1995 and a pharmaceutical plant that makes imaging agents used in medical diagnostics. Monsanto, the St. Louis-based chemical company, has been building up its pharmaceutical and biotechnology businesses. Its G. D. Searle pharmaceuticals division will continue to supply products to Nycomed Amersham Imaging, a unit in Princeton, N.J., for up to five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERER, RABBI MOSHE
description: SHERER-Rabbi Moshe. As charismatic president of Agudas Israel, he shaped and sustained one of the most vital and vibrant Torah communities in America. He was a master conciliator who never compromised his steadfast spiritual principles and values, as he forged lifesaving bridges among disparate groups. With indomitable spirit, he fought for Klal Yisroel's religious and civil rights, and reparations for Holocaust victims. He interfaced with seven American presidents and the world's most powerful leaders, yet his center was always family and faith. Rabbi Sherer was the authentic Halachic man who perceived the human condition ''with both eyes.'' Touro College will miss his friendship and counsel, and extends its deepest sympathy to his wife Deborah; his children, Rochel Langer, Elky Goldschmidt, and Rabbi Shimshon Sherer; and his son-in-law, Prof. Robert Goldschmidt, our esteemed Dean of Students. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Yerushalayim. Dr. Bernard Lander, President Mr. Mark Hasten, Chairman of the Board

title: N.F.L. Coaches Stage Protest, but Tagliabue Calls It Silly
description: A symposium for National Football League coaches in Miami came and went yesterday, and by many accounts it was a success. But that wasn't the big story coming out of the owners' meetings, nor was it the novelist Tom Clancy, who withdrew his bid to purchase the Vikings.

title: Ethiopia and Eritrea Seem Ready to Do Battle
description: Eight years after they jointly won a civil war against a Communist dictator, the leaders of Ethiopia and Eritrea seem to be on the verge of attacking each other over a triangle of rocky land along their shared border.

title: Financial Records Are Introduced at Assemblyman's Trial
description: Introducing into evidence a blizzard of canceled checks, accounting ledgers and other financial records, Federal prosecutors yesterday began painstakingly building their corruption case against Assemblyman Dov Hikind of Brooklyn and his co-defendant, Rabbi Elimelech Naiman.

title: U.S. v. MICROSOFT; The Kitchen Sink Operating System
description: Over the years, Microsoft has continually worked to improve and expand its personal computer operating system by acquiring, licensing and developing new technologies. These constant upgrades have made the system the industry standard and given it a virtual stranglehold on the world of personal computers. At the same time, companies that pioneered some of these technologies have found their products becoming irrelevant as Microsoft added features that replicated those products' functions. Here is a chronology of some of the more significant steps in the evolution of Microsoft's operating system. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

title: Metro Business; Circuit City to Mail Return-Fee Refunds
description: Circuit City, the country's largest consumer electronics chain, will mail refund checks to more than 300 customers who paid a 15 percent restocking fee but were not given adequate warning of the fee, New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Microsoft: Consumers' Savior or Evil Empire?
description: To the Editor:

title: Albright Nudges Suharto to Resign : 'An Opportunity For Statesmanship'
description: WASHINGTON  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED MAY 22, 1998

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARLIN, GEORGE
description: MARLIN-George. After a long illness. Died on May 18, 1998. For many years an Arbitrator for the ILGWU and 32B among other unions and associations. Husband of Loretta and the late Lebe (nee Goldin). Father of Jeffrey (Joan) and Daniel. Grandfather of Jacob. Step-grandfather of Cara and Melanie. Graveside services to be held on Thursday, May 21.

title: Butts, Harlem's Prominent Pastor, Calls Giuliani a Racist
description: The Reverend Calvin O. Butts 3d, a prominent Baptist minister from Harlem, stunned city officials and black leaders alike yesterday by calling Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani a racist who is on the verge of creating a fascist state in New York City.

title: Hope And Education
description: In 1953, someone took a chance on me. I wanted to go to college, but I had nothing to offer but the G.I. Bill. I had no high school education, never mind a diploma. But someone at New York University admitted me on probation: if I maintained a B average for the year, I would be allowed to matriculate.

title: Discovering Salsa With a Presence
description: The young singer Frankie Negron's show at S.O.B.'s on Monday night was a little bit more proof that there's plenty of talent lurking in the salsa of New York and Puerto Rico. Mr. Negron, 21, has had a stack of hits, produced by Sergio George. But those hits, pure examples of how Mr. George has completely changed the sound of salsa, guarantee nothing in live performance. Mr. George's productions are so influential, and so powerful, that his artists' performances have suffered greatly by comparison. It's as if the style, recorded by Mr. George's house band, is too radical to be handled correctly in concert.

title: Yeltsin, Facing Impeachment Vote, Tries to Keep Investors Calm
description: As troubles continue to rain down on Russia's new Government, President Boris N. Yeltsin, himself now facing the latest in a series of impeachment votes, tried today to reassure jittery investors that the country would not shift off its ''balanced, finely tuned course.''

title: Community College Role
description: To the Editor:

title: New President, With High-Tech Background, Brings Confidence: His Own
description: One of President Suharto's last worries before deciding to step down today as President was that his longtime friend and hand-picked Vice President, B. J. Habibie, would not be up to the job he inherits, an associate of Mr. Habibie's said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINGOLD, LEW
description: FEINGOLD-Lew. On May 18, 1998, at Miami Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Ellen and Billy. Cherished grandfather of Robert and Nicole. Dear brother of Harry, Sylvia and Thelma. Services at ''BoulevardRiverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30 PM, Thursday.

title: Kodak and AOL Plan To Offer Photos on Web
description: In a bold move designed to revive its digital photography operation, the Eastman Kodak Company announced this week that it had joined with America Online in a service to be introduced in the fall.

title: Filling Power Vacuum: Will Army Rule?
description: When President Suharto announced his resignation this morning, perhaps the fundamental question looming over the nation and the entire region is who will hold the reins of power that he says he is giving up.

title: The Law and Mr. Clinton's Money
description: The story of the White House and its Chinese campaign money will not die, for the simple reason that there is too much evidence of wrongdoing to be suppressed or ignored. House Speaker Newt Gingrich is right, beyond argument, to demand a full investigation of the export of sensitive technology to China at a time when both the Chinese Government and an American technology company were pouring money into Democratic accounts. But we differ with Mr. Gingrich when he says the issue ''has nothing to do with campaign finance'' and is solely about national security.

title: South Korea's Kohap To Sell Tape Unit
description: Kohap Ltd., a South Korean nylon and polyester manufacturer, plans to sell its German tape unit to a group of investors. DG Bank said Kohap had signed a letter of intent to sell its Emtec Magnetics G.m.b.H. unit to a group whose members include Legal and General Ventures Ltd., funds advised by the German company Apax Partners & Company and a DG Bank unit, BmU.

title: Family and Friends Bid Sinatra Farewell
description: For two hours this afternoon, the icons of a vanishing era assembled one last time to celebrate the life and career of their friend Frank Sinatra in a starry formal funeral that drew mourners from Hollywood's geriatric set to the Gen-X fans who stood quietly across the street, craning their necks for a glimpse of magic.

title: Excerpts of Letter On Export Policy
description: Following are excerpts from a letter dated today from Charles F. C. Ruff, the counsel to President Clinton, to Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, as provided by the White House:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, JAMES P.
description: HUNT-James P. Of Roseland, N.J. on May 20, 1998. Husband of Eileen A. Hunt. Father of Colleen, James J., Brian C. Brother of Mona Dittmeier, Elizabeth Mullaly, Francis Hunt. Funeral mass in St. Raphael's Church, Livingston, N.J. on Saturday at 9:30AM. Visiting in the Farmer Funeral Home, 45 Roseland Avenue, Roseland, N.J. on Thursday 7-9 and Friday 24 and 7-9. Interment Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, JEAN, PAUL
description: JOSEPH-Jean-Paul. May 20, 1998. Died suddenly at his home in New York City. Beloved husband of Jessica Friedman Joseph. Adored father of Alexandra, Michaela and Talia. Devoted son of Soeurette Levy Joseph. Loving brother of Sylvia Joseph Galambos. Managing Director of JP Joseph & Co., Inc., New York. Services today, 12:30PM at Plaza Memorial, West 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: Term-Limits Advocates Take a Bad Thrashing
description: Here lie the tatters of the term-limits movement: disconnected phones, empty doughnut boxes, blank computer screens and an exhausted, unshaven Congressional candidate, slumped in a chair in shorts.

title: Sold-Out Crowd Greets Baseball in Atlantic City
description: The Atlantic City Surf was the home team for the opening game of baseball's new Atlantic League last night before a sold-out crowd of 5,900, despite an unfinished stadium that forced both teams to change in the local high school's locker rooms.

title: Abortion Bill Is Dropped In About-Face By Silver
description: Six weeks after proposing a limited version of a late-term abortion ban, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has reversed course, saying today that the measure would not be put to a vote.

title: Rodman Is a Problem, the Bulls' Problem
description: It is difficult for the Bulls to sit down and savor their delicious two-games-to-none lead in the Eastern Conference finals when all they want to shout is, ''Waiter, there's a Dennis Rodman in my soup.''

title: Mother Cleared in Case Of Her Newborn's Death
description: A 17-year-old Voorhees girl who had been accused of suffocating her newborn son was found not guilty of manslaughter charges yesterday by a family court judge in Camden.

title: Essay; Privacy = Freedom
description: When Monica Lewinsky telephoned Linda Tripp, the White House intern had what the law calls ''a reasonable expectation of privacy'' -- a right to assume she was not being surreptitiously recorded.

title: Deneen in Venture With Cadwell Davis
description: Cadwell Davis Partners in New York and Denneen & Company, a management consulting company in Boston, have teamed up to form a joint venture, Cadwell Davis Denneen, specializing in integrated consulting, marketing and advertising services.

title: Memo From Belfast; Gerry Adams Blunders, and Peace Drive Stumbles
description: It is every campaign's worst fear: everything at risk with one searing image.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK UP. The mark rose as a higher German trade surplus and a higher American trade deficit, suggested German interest rates will rise before American rates. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7698 marks from 1.7834.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: With its grip on the Mitsubishi account slipping, Grey Advertising says it will close its G2 unit.
description: GREY ADVERTISING in New York said yesterday that it would close its G2 unit in Huntington Beach, Calif., the stand-alone shop that has handled the national brand advertising for Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Carrie Mae Weems

title: Warning Issued About Viagra
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it was warning paramedics and emergency room physicians not to administer nitroglycerin to patients taking Pfizer's impotence pill Viagra.

title: A Niche of Treasures From Indian Territory
description: Even in a museum collection as encyclopedic as that of the Metropolitan, there are inevitable gaps, and art by North American Indians is one of them. The museum's holdings in the area are fairly slim, and just a few pieces are on permanent display.

title: THE FALL OF SUHARTO
description: MILITARY POWER BROKERS -- The army has a low profile, but great influence. Page A9.

title: Two Leases Issued For Times Sq. Signs
description: Two more marketers said yesterday that they had signed leases for so-called spectacular signs in the Times Square area. Terms were not disclosed.

title: The Roots Of 'Little Tree'
description: When Paramount releases ''The Education of Little Tree'' on tape in July, it will again raise interesting issues, not so much about Richard Friedenberg's film, which played in theaters last winter, but about the book behind the movie.

title: Newcomer Hallock Shares the Lead
description: Playing in only her second tournament on the Ladies Professional Golf Association Tour, Sara Hallock, a former field hockey star at Stanford, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday, tying Tammie Green for the first-round lead at the Corning Classic in Corning, N.Y.

title: Drug for Advanced Breast Cancer Is Also Found Effective in Early Treatment
description: A drug already used to treat advanced forms of breast cancer can cut the death rate from the disease when used in early treatment, doctors said here this week.

title: Bar Exam Data Don't Support Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: In Bulgaria, Students Bone Up on Pax Americana
description: BLAGOEVGRAD, Bulgaria  They waited through the valedictorian's oration, through the honorary degree for a minor poet, through an address by a distinguished foreign ambassador, until finally the moment came when the provost pronounced them "Bachelors of Arts." Tasseled mortarboards were tossed into the air, only to be carefully retrieved for family photographs.

title: The Layers of Time Distilled Into a Moment
description: So this is what time looks like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, MARTIN
description: RUBIN-Martin. Beloved husband of the late Mollie Rubin. Services will be held on Friday, May 22, 1998 in Los Angeles, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, HAROLD
description: ORENSTEIN-Harold. On May 15, 1998. Dear and loving husband of Indira; father of Donna; brother of Joe; grandfather of Rebecca. Memorial service in near future.

title: A Big Ad Campaign Helps Stall the Bill To Reduce Smoking
description: The tobacco lobby has pulled off a surprising public relations coup, and won a round on Capitol Hill today, thanks in part to the televised image of a harried, sweaty waitress with earrings the size of onion rings who leans into the camera and sighs: ''I'm no millionaire. I work hard. Why single me out?''

title: Bar Exam Data Don't Support Affirmative Action; The Role of Preferences
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Agrees to Land-Mine Ban, but Not Yet
description: In a shift in policy, the Clinton Administration has pledged that by 2006 the United States will sign the international treaty that bans anti-personnel land mines, but only if the Pentagon comes up with an alternative weapon, Administration officials said today.

title: Sumitomo and Daiwa Take Losses on Loans
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd., Japan's second-largest lender, said yesterday that it lost 251.3 billion yen, or $1.85 billion, in the year ended March 31 as it wrote off a record amount of bad debt. And Daiwa Bank Ltd., the nation's ninth-largest commercial lender, had net income of 12.65 billion yen, or $93 million, after tax benefits were factored in. Write-offs drove the bank to a pretax loss of 142.5 billion yen, or $1.05 billion, its third straight loss.

title: East Isn't Wholly East (Same Story in the West)
description: One can learn a lot from Kipling, but from a purely musical point of view, his observation about the inability of East and West to meet could not have been further from the truth. In the last century, Asian composers have embraced a variety of Western languages, and if the Asian influence on Western music is more subtle, it can be traced. At a concert of French and Japanese works presented by the Guild of Composers on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, three eloquent young pianists showed that the currents have flowed in both directions.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ON THE STREET

title: Show of Force Checks Protest By Cabdrivers
description: The city responded with decisive force yesterday to plans by some angry cabdrivers to disrupt a weekday's commerce and commute. It blocked cabs without passengers from coming into Manhattan, ringed City Hall with barricades and dispatched dozens of police officers to follow a chanting crowd of drivers marching from midtown to downtown in protest.

title: THE STANLEY CUP PLAYOFFS: As Hasek Dominates, His Trophy Case Fills; After Winning Olympic Gold, Sabres Goalie Has Sights on Lord Stanley's Silver
description: The goalie in hockey is like the king in chess, poised in the back row, the last line of defense, guarded by skating knights, rooks and pawns. The position requires concentration, anticipation and cunning. One bad move, or even a good one if made too soon, can mean defeat at the hands of a clever, aggressive opponent.

title: For Mo Mowlam, at Least, Yes for a Job Well Done
description: Regardless of the outcome of the referendum on the peace settlement for this conflicted province, one sure winner is Mo Mowlam, Britain's Secretary for Northern Ireland.

title: New Labour, Old Goal:Strong Workers' Unions
description: LONDON  The government of Prime Minister Tony Blair undertook an ambitious attempt on Thursday to roll back the labor-market deregulation of the Thatcher era by unveiling a package of proposals to guarantee a worker's right to union representation and strengthen protection against unfair dismissals.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Owning and Leasing; U.S. Tax Bite on Foreign Luxury
description: IT starts out as a cheaper way to buy a foreign luxury car. But for some buyers, intentionally or not, it ends up as a crime: tax evasion.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Political Briefing; Democrats in Nevada Bolstered by a Filing
description: Democrats have controlled the Nevada governorship for the past 10 years. But with the current incumbent, Bob Miller, on his way out because of the state's term-limits law, and with no other big-name Democrat in the state willing to run to replace him, the party was all but resigned to losing control of the office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENZER, JESSE
description: MENZER-Jesse. At age 93, on May 21, 1998. Loving husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Susan and Larry. Beloved grandfather of Wendy, Zachary and Jonathan. Services will be held today, May 22, at The Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, New York.

title: Council Leaders Seek to Pay Down Debt
description: City Council leaders yesterday proposed using part of an anticipated budget surplus to pay off $1.5 billion of the city's long-term debt over the next four years. The Giuliani administration immediately attacked the idea as ''fantasyland'' and warned that the budget, which by law must be adopted by June 5, might be delayed.

title: Democracy Advocate in China Reports Detention
description: A leading democracy advocate who recently helped set up a human rights monitoring group said today that he was detained for 24 hours and that his fax machine, papers and letters and other items were confiscated by the police.

title: The Shadow of 3,200 Dead Falls on Ulster Vote Today
description: In tones trembling with hurt, the people on the folding chairs in the municipal gymnasium were trading indignant charges over the referendum on Friday on the Northern Ireland peace settlement.

title: Whitman Seeks Rise in Gas Tax for Transit and Conservation
description: Risking her reputation as a tax-cutter to promote conservation and transportation, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman called today for an increase of 7 cents per gallon in New Jersey's gasoline tax to help finance transportation improvements and a plan to preserve almost half the undeveloped land left in the state.

title: The Tortured Path Of a Troubled Youth
description: The Kinkel family lived in a wooded neighborhood along the McKenzie River in the foothills of the Cascades, a quiet world where friends thought the world of the mother and father, both popular teachers of Spanish, and Kristin, a college cheerleader.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on May 2 about a former Rwandan Prime Minister's plea of guilty to genocide charges before a United Nations tribunal in Tanzania, and a correction in this space on May 5, referred imprecisely to the history of war-crimes pleas in international courts. This was not the first guilty plea, but the first for the crime of genocide, according to the United Nations. The correction also misattributed the May 2 error; it resulted from editing at The Times, not from a United Nations news release.

title: In the Northwest, a Stroller's Delight
description: My favorite Oregonian, bar none, was Tom McCall, the unorthodox scion of an old New England family. Governor from 1966 to 1974, he was such a straight talker that his fellow politicians, obfuscators all, never admitted him to full membership in their lodge.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MONATH, HORTENSE
description: MONATH-Hortense. May 22, 1955, age 51. Co-founder of Manhattan's famed New Friends of Music (1936); first American woman pianist to solo with Arturo Toscanini. ''One of the foremost interpreters of Mozart now before the public.'' -Jerome D. Bohm, N.Y. Herald Tribune. Lovingly remembered. For a family journal, reminiscences of Hortense or the New Friends of Music would be greatly appreciated. Adelaide Husserl Weismann 27 Bayview Avenue Sag Harbor NY 11963

title: Metro Business; City Jobless Rate Falls to 8.1 Percent
description: Unemployment in New York City fell to 8.1 percent in April from 8.6 percent in March, after adjustment for seasonal fluctuations, according to New York State Department of Labor figures released yesterday by the City Comptroller's office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHON, KEVIN WALTER
description: MAHON-Kevin Walter. On May 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Pamela. Loving father of Meaghan. Devoted son of Walter and Eleanor. Cherished brother of Eileen Noonan and Nancy Plate. Also survived by three nieces and three nephews. Funeral mass at St. Patrick's, on Saturday, May 23. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, CT.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBSTER, CHARLES D.
description: WEBSTER-Charles D. The Cloisters celebrates your life and your passion for gardens everywhere. We are grateful for your years of leadership and devotion to our gardens.

title: A Love Triangle Where Rage Is a Problem
description: Given its setting among the close-packed, impersonal skyscrapers of Tokyo, and its protagonist, an exhausted young insurance salesman, ''Tokyo Fist'' might be assessed as an insightful commentary on the pressures of life in a crowded nation of repressed individuality.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS 4.7 PERCENT. Natural gas weakened to a four-month low after the American Gas Association reported an unexpectedly large increase in stockpiles. June contracts fell 10.2 cents, to $2.067 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Hugo on Hiatus For Repair Job

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Resume Retreat, Nasdaq at Six-Week Low

title: House G.O.P. Opens Floodgates on Campaign Finance
description: Just two months ago, House Republican leaders tried to defeat any comprehensive overhaul of the campaign finance law by limiting debate and blocking a leading bill from the House floor. But late tonight they took the opposite tack, opening the gates to 11 separate campaign finance bills and more than 580 amendments.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Urban Schools
description: Following are excerpts from the New Jersey Supreme Court's unanimous decision yesterday in Abbott v. Burke, the school-financing suit, whose predecessor case began in 1970. Yesterday the court largely accepted the Whitman administration's plans for improving poor urban schools, declined to set a specific school-financing level and said this would probably be the court's last major decision on the subject. The opinion was written by Justice Alan B. Handler, and was provided by the court through the Internet in cooperation with Rutgers Law School.

title: Bar Exam Data Don't Support Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Law Is Real Villain in China Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Venture Capital Meeting
description: The New York City Economic Development Corporation will hold its third annual Venture Capital Conference on June 22 and 23 at the Marriott Marquis Hotel, at 1535 Broadway in Times Square.

title: Bird Calls for Fouls on Pippen's Defense
description: There was a time when Larry Bird was the one who roamed the court with the friendly whistles on his side as the resident superstar.

title: Two Hospital Patients Jump to Their Deaths
description: Within a period of nine hours, two patients at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn jumped to their deaths on Monday from windows on different floors, the police said.

title: Musical Surprise Turns Into a Family Tradition
description: About 9 A.M. on Memorial Day, when West End Avenue couldn't feel more deserted, and its quiet, tree-lined side streets are lazily waking up to the gleam of sunlight, the Upper West Side can seem a thoroughly livable little place, where strangers are almost tempted to greet one another, and where the man buying a newspaper, or the one walking his dog, or the couple sitting on a park bench in an island on Broadway, or the jogger taking fitful sips from her water bottle as she races past where Rachmaninoff composed his Rhapsody: all are persuaded that the best thing they could have done this weekend was turn down friends' invitations to the Hamptons.

title: National News Briefs; Judge Declares Mistrial In Houston Bribery Case
description: A Federal judge here declared a mistrial today in the case of several current and former City Council members charged with bribery and conspiracy in a downtown development project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINKOFF, DUSSIA
description: MINKOFF-Dussia. Died peacefully at home, at 92, on May 20th. The widow of Isaiah Minkoff, the founding Executive VP of NJCRAC and a life-long leader in national Jewish and labor causes; she was the mother of Nina M. Cohen of Jacksonville, FL and Washington, DC; & Paul Minkoff of NY. Grandmother of Daniel, Elizabeth, Catherine and Caroline Cohen; Kate De Vito & Vanessa Nemeth; as well as Rebekah, Naomi and David Minkoff; and great-grandmother of David Isaiah Cohen. Joining her late husband in national Jewish community affairs, she later devoted herself to classic Russian literature. Her charm, dignity and grace will be cherished by her family and many friends. Funeral: Sunday, May 24, 12 Noon at Plaza Memorial, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva on Monday, May 25, at her home.

title: PLAN BY WHITMAN ON URBAN SCHOOLS BACKED BY COURT
description: In a major victory for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the New Jersey Supreme Court today embraced her plan to improve the state's urban schools without spending millions of dollars on new programs to help students overcome the disadvantages of poverty.

title: Army Is a Power Broker, But Subtly This Time
description: Among the players in Indonesia's grand political drama this week, the army has been an elusive presence. Commonly thought to be the decisive force in Indonesian politics, the army and its powerful generals played no public role in pushing President Suharto to resign.

title: Getting Serious at Ben & Jerry's; Cherry Garcia and Friends Trade Funky for Functional
description: First Jerry Garcia, leader of the Grateful Dead and inspiration for the popular Cherry Garcia flavor, died. Then the Peace Pop was ruled obsolete. Next, a plan to create an organic ice cream line suffered a meltdown on business principles.

title: Rediscovering 'Lost' Culture Of Thrace
description: The auction houses put ancient art into nice, recognizable categories: Egyptian, Phoenician, Greek, Etruscan, Roman and Byzantine. Sotheby's has now dropped its London antiquities auctions, so it has added two additional categories, Western Asiatic Antiquities and Islamic Works of Art, to its June 4 antiquities sale in Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: Ulster Votes Today

title: Midtown Steakhouse Is Damaged by Fire
description: A fashionable midtown steakhouse caught fire yesterday evening, forcing patrons into the streets as 127 firefighters battled the blaze.

title: William Hewitt, 83, Responsible For Overseas Expansion of Deere
description: William A. Hewitt, who transformed Deere & Company from a midsized Midwestern tractor company to the world's largest producer of agricultural equipment, died on Saturday at his home in Rutherford, Calif. He was 83.

title: Mexico Faults U.S. Secrecy In Bank Sting Of Drug Profit
description: Mexico said today that it will formally protest a United States undercover operation that exposed drug money-laundering of more than $110 million through 12 Mexican banks, because American agents acted secretly in Mexico without informing the Government.

title: Hostess of Her Own Party, 6 Nights a Week
description: THIS is a pick-up-the-pieces-and-get-on-with-your-life story. If it were a television pilot, the first scene would flash back four years, when a smart and ambitious New Jersey girl picks up the telephone to learn that her live-in lover of two and a half years, the brilliant Le Bernardin chef Gilbert Le Coze, has had what his staff calls ''an accident.'' The young woman rushes to the hospital, but is too late. Mr. Le Coze, 49, is already dead of a heart attack. The woman, unemployed and 26, thinks her world has come to an end.

title: Judge in Brawley Case Pares Down Defense's Witness List
description: Suggesting that he is frustrated with the length of the Tawana Brawley defamation trial, the judge today limited the questions the defense can ask some witnesses and barred other witnesses who had been subpoenaed by the defense.

title: Prize Money Up By 18.4 Percent
description: The rich will get richer, to the tune of $14 million, and the largesse will drip down to the have-nots at the 1998 United States Open. The $14 million is the prize money the men and women will split evenly in the event from Aug. 31 to Sept. 13 at Flushing Meadows, Queens. It is an increase of 18.4 percent over 1997.

title: Lucent Networking Deal
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. has signed a four-year agreement under which it will supply equipment and software for the first phase of a global undersea communications network known as Project Oxygen, the company said on Wednesday. Lucent said it would provide land-based optical networking equipment and installation services for the CTR Group project.

title: Thousands Face a Delay For Residency Interviews
description: Thousands of immigrants in New York City will have to wait another year before they can become legal residents of the United States because the local immigration office is so understaffed that it can no longer handle the volume of applications, immigration officials said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Stern Picks Up a Foul For Wrist-Slapping
description: THE first time Jeff Van Gundy demonstrated the indelicate art of starting a brush fire before scrambling madly to stomp it out occurred a couple of years ago as he took the opportunity to berate a newspaper reporter in behalf of a defenseless player, John Starks.

title: Six Hurt in Brooklyn In Low-Speed Chase
description: A 15-year-old driving a stolen car through Brooklyn last night was arrested after he struck two police cruisers, a patrolman and a civilian car, injuring a total of six people, the police said.

title: Old Iconoclasts In New Territory
description: The nurse, who has the proportions of an inflatable sex doll, bends over a desk or a filing cabinet; the doctor who employs her drools or bites his knuckle as he admires the view; the audience, of course, laughs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, KEMP L.
description: MITCHELL-Kemp L. Of Laguna Beach, CA., formerly of Morris Township, NJ, on Tuesday, May 19, 1998. Son of the late Frank L. and Elodie Mitchell. Brother of Blair D. Mitchell of Morris Twp., NJ. Also survived by two nephews and one aunt. Funeral services will be private, but those who wish to make a contribution may do so in Kemp's memory to either The American Heart Association or to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUGER, JOSEPH
description: KRUGER-Joseph. Ninety-three, of Boca Raton, FL., & Lenox, MA, May 21st, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Frances (Sturm) Kruger, father of Laurie Richman, grandfather of Allison Richman of Newport Beach, CA., and Deborah Richman of Livingston, N.J. Funeral service at Oheb Shalom Congregation, 170 Scotland Road, South Orange, NJ, 10 A.M. Friday. Contributions can be sent to The New Jersey Y Camps-Kruger Fund, Fairfield, NJ, The American Camping Assn., Martinsville, IN, or The New York Section American Camping Assn., New York, NY.

title: Campaign Law Is Real Villain in China Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIZENS BANCSHARES TO BUY MID AM FOR $681 MILLION
description: Citizens Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Mid Am Inc., a rival Ohio bank holding company, for $681 million in stock, creating a bank with assets of more than $4 billion and a market capitalization of $1.3 billion. Under the agreement Citizens will exchange 0.385 share for each Mid Am share. The exchange ratio will increase to 0.77 on June 1, after Citizens splits its stock 2 for 1. Citizens, based in Salineville, Ohio, operates banks in Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia. Mid Am, based in Bowling Green, Ohio, operates banks and other financial-services businesses. Expenses related to the merger are expected to lower the new entity's pretax earnings by $20 million to $30 million, but expected cost reductions should add significantly to earnings next year, the companies said. Citizens shares were unchanged at $72.75 yesterday, while Mid Am slipped 18.75 cents, to $26.8125.

title: Journalism That Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: Coetzer Upset
description: Top-seeded Amanda Coetzer was one of three upset victims in the quarterfinals of the Strasbourg Open in France, losing to Julie Halard-Decugis, 7-6 (7-3), 6-2.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Parole Board Refuses to Free Ayala
description: The New Jersey State Parole Board yesterday denied the parole of Tony Ayala Jr., the former junior middleweight contender who has served 15 years of a 30-year sentence on a 1981 rape conviction. Unless the decision is overturned on appeal, Ayala will spend at least another 12 months behind bars and will be released outright around June 1999.

title: CENDANT TO ACQUIRE ROYAL AUTOMOBILE CLUB
description: The Cendant Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the Royal Automobile Club Ltd., Britain's third-largest provider of roadside emergency-services operations, for $730 million. The deal would give Cendant two of the top three roadside emergency-services providers in Britain. Last month, Cendant agreed to acquire the No. 2 concern in the field, the National Parking Corporation. The purchase of RAC Motoring Services, which includes a roadside emergency-service club, is expected to add less than a penny to Cendant's earnings per diluted share this year and to add 3 to 5 cents a share in 1999, the company said. Cendant, based in Parsippany, N.J., and Stamford, Conn., owns and operates hotels and real estate companies. Its shares rose 56.25 cents yesterday, to $22.3125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERSZT, ROGER
description: FERSZT-Roger. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Stephen and father-in-law of Robin. Devoted grandfather of Jacqueline and Courtney. Services today, 9:45 a.m. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: No Headline
Riffs on America in an Abstract Direction
description: ''Colonial Cubism,'' one of Stuart Davis's great late paintings, is among the first signs of maturity in his lean, sparkling retrospective at the National Museum of American Art. The high-stepping interlocking forms of this 1954 painting, rendered in well-distributed chunks of slightly off-key red, yellow and blue plus black and white, beckon from the end wall of a long hallway gallery that contains some 20 examples of Davis's often accomplished early works. They date from 1912, when the artist turned 20, to 1928, when he made his only visit to Paris.

title: Residential Real Estate; Downtown Building Joins in a Conversion Trend
description: A tower of scaffolding clings to the side of the empty 17-story building at the southeast corner of West and Carlisle Streets in the financial district. When the scaffolding comes down, the building will be part of the latest downtown trend: office buildings that have become homes.

title: Some Enchanted Evening, Man Sees True Love Across a Crowded Nation
description: Can a hunky free-spirited street performer from San Antonio thaw the icy heart of a beautiful Los Angeles fine arts consultant who is so burned out on men that she fakes the symptoms of AIDS to drive suitors out of her house?

title: Indonesia After Suharto
description: Handing power from President Suharto to Vice President B. J. Habibie does not solve Indonesia's political and economic problems. Mr. Habibie is little more than a Suharto acolyte. The only way he can gain legitimacy even as an interim leader is by immediately setting a date for democratic elections, giving his Cabinet a reform agenda and moving decisively against the corrupt business practices of the Suharto era.

title: Political Briefing; A Democratic Mormon Offers Hope in Utah
description: Hardly any state is more Republican than Utah, where only one Democrat holds statewide office and only 29 of the 104 members of the State Legislature are Democrats. In fact, just about the only thing more ubiquitous in Utah than Republicanism -- not counting desert and salt flats -- is Mormonism.

title: Jobless Claims Remain at Low Level
description: The number of Americans filing for state unemployment benefits rose in line with expectations last week, with first-time jobless claims increasing 8,000, to a seasonally adjusted 313,000, the Labor Department said today.

title: N.F.L. Back on CBS: Pow, Right to the Moon
description: CBS is embracing the return of the National Football League after a four-year absence with more ardor than if Ed Sullivan, Lucille Ball, Jackie Gleason and Arnold the pig were resuscitated for prime time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, WILLIAM
description: MILLER-William. We extend our sincerest sympathy to Dorothee and her children on the loss of her dear husband, Willie, on Sunday May 17, 1998. He was always a legend to us. His brother and sisterin-law, brother-in-law, nieces and nephews, and their families share in your grief. Ben & Rea Miller, Barbara Miller and Marko Lampas, Judith Miller & Terry Shultz, Stan Miller, Janie Miller Wendt, Herb Freeman, Josh Freeman, Rebecca Freeman, Amy Freeman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALLEK, PHYLLIS
description: DALLEK-Phyllis. Died suddenly May 21, 1998 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of Godfrey, loving mother of Steven, Nancy and sonin-law Jeff Pearlstein. Adored sister of Dick and Dorothy Bernstein. Sister-in-law of Shirley and Joe Cohen. Survived by cherished nieces and nephews. We will deeply miss her warmth, her love, her creativity and generosity. Chapel services will be held at 12 noon, May 22nd (today) at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, NY. For shiva information call chapel.

title: 'Les Noces' With a Muted Stravinsky
description: The New York City Ballet would not be what it is without the contribution of Jerome Robbins. George Balanchine shrewdly recognized that another master choreographer's creative voice, very different from his own, would only benefit his young company in 1948.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Joan Mitchell

title: INDONESIAN LEADER PICKS NEW CABINET AND VOWS REFORMS
description: Indonesia's new President, B. J. Habibie, named a compromise Cabinet today that swept out the daughter and best friend of his predecessor, Suharto, and brought in members of other parties but retained half of the previous lineup.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SCHUFF STEEL CO., Phoenix, a manufacturer and erector of steel, will pay about $50.6 million for its previously announced acquisition of Addison Structural Services Inc.

title: Suharto Fostered Rapid Economic Growth, and Staggering Graft
description: Like the Shah of Iran and Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, President Suharto was a reforming autocrat who clung to power so long that he undermined his legacy and considerable accomplishments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, MARTIN
description: BERLINER-Martin. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted father of David and Thomas. Loving grandfather. Services Friday 1PM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, N.Y.

title: $10.6 Billion Seagram Deal For Polygram
description: The Seagram Company, accelerating its shift from a beverage and spirits giant into an entertainment powerhouse, said yesterday that it would acquire one of the world's largest music companies, Polygram N.V., for $10.6 billion in cash and stock.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Brushed Voices'

title: Asian Markets Cheer Suharto Resignation
description: HONG KONG  Asian stock and currency markets struggled with and then welcomed the news of President Suharto's resignation Thursday. But analysts said the gains could easily vanish if Indonesia's political future remained muddy, or if the newly sworn-in president, B.J. Habibie, lived up to his reputation as a profligate spender.

title: Motorola Drops Plan for Its Own Data Satellites
description: Motorola Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to scrap its $12.9 billion plan to build a satellite network capable of delivering high-speed data communications anywhere on earth and instead join a rival but equally ambitious project to build an ''Internet in the sky.''

title: Netscape Signs Web Directories
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation said today that it had signed agreements with Internet directory companies including Lycos Inc. and the Infoseek Corporation to feature them on its World Wide Web site.

title: Dorothy Donegan, 76, Flamboyant Jazz Pianist
