description: Dorothy Donegan, a jazz pianist who brashly mixed swing, boogie-woogie, vaudeville, pop, ragtime and Bach -- sometimes within a span of 10 minutes -- and who was known for an outrageous sense of humor, died on Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 76.

title: PACKARD BELL TO USE CYRIX CHIPS FOR FIRST TIME
description: Packard Bell NEC Inc., the world's largest maker of consumer personal computers, said yesterday that it would use processors from the National Semiconductor Corporation's Cyrix unit in some of its computers, ending its exclusive use of chips from the Intel Corporation. Packard Bell, a privately held company based in Sacramento, Calif., will use the Cyrix Media GX and MII processors in some of its personal computers sold in stores. It also will join a National Semiconductor initiative that aims to put all the circuitry needed inside a PC on one chip. The agreement with Cyrix is the first time Packard Bell will use a processor from an Intel rival. Shares of National Semiconductor, based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose 25 cents, to $16.50.

title: Defense Dept. to Spend Millions to Bolster Germ-Warfare Defense
description: The Defense Department decided yesterday to spend $50 million to create biological response units in the National Guards of 10 of the most populous states, including New York, as President Clinton prepares to unveil several actions to increase the nation's defenses against germ attacks, Government officials said.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Vernon Fisher

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: Sports of The Times; Whatever Happened To Hockey?
description: FIRST hockey writer: I'm going to Washington for the weekend.

title: China's Military-Civilian Complex
description: In high dudgeon, the House overwhelmingly passed a bill this week that would prohibit the export of satellites to China. The action was a quick response to a string of allegations that the Clinton Administration changed its policy on satellite exports to China after the Democratic National Committee received donations from agents of the Chinese military and American businessmen.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Alfredo Jaar

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZMAN, WILLIAM
description: HOLTZMAN-William. On May 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Ethel Holtzman. Dear father of Janet (Solomon) Lomita and Laurie (David) Buell. Services were held on Thursday, May 21, at The Riverside, New York City.

title: The Rink's Freedom, the Stage's Imagination
description: Dance attempts to defy gravity and traction. Ice dancing seems like cheating. But several choreographers explored both forms to revealing effect in a program presented by the Ice Theater of New York on Wednesday at the Chelsea Pier Sky Rink.

title: Accounts
description: -- Cotelligent Group Inc., San Francisco, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle advertising for the provider of information technology and system support services. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Zapata Finds Its Internet Bid Is Not Taken Seriously
description: You can't blame the executives of the Zapata Corporation for trying. Zapata, a Houston oil-and-gas company turned fish-meal producer, announced last month that it was changing its name to the much zippier Zap and planning to enter the Internet world in a big way.

title: Mets Need Piazza? They Have Yoshii
description: It is only two months into the regular season. But so far it looks as though Masato Yoshii might have had a tougher time finding an apartment in Manhattan than he has had in adjusting to the National League.

title: Campaign Law Is Real Villain in China Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Commencements; Power Failure Doesn't Disrupt Ceremonies at Rutgers
description: The Louis Broom Athletic Center at the Livingston Campus of Rutgers University went dark for several moments today, right in the middle of the national anthem. A power surge had knocked out the lights at the gym, where faculty members, honorees and many of the 2,971 master's and doctoral degree recipients and 6,852 baccalaureates were gathered for the 232d commencement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSWIT, EUGENE
description: ELSWIT-Eugene. Devoted husband of Muriel for 54 years. Proud and loving father of Larry and Bob, grandfather of Rebecca, Justin and Sarah, father-in-law of Bernice Speiser. A truly gentle and giving man who was more concerned for others than for himself. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Hospice Care in Westchester & Putnam, 100 South Bedford Rd, Mount Kisco, NY 10549, or Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America, 280 Hillside Avenue, Needham, MA 02194. Services Friday at 12 noon, Clark's Chapel, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY

title: The Retold Orton Murder Gets Another Retelling
description: ''Nasty Little Secrets'' is another walk down the dark hallway of the playwright Joe Orton's enigmatic affair with Kenneth Halliwell, his sad sack of a live-in lover who ended their lives in a fit of paranoia and resignation in 1967. As in many a nonfiction novel, the play uneasily weaves real and imagined events, using crime details to justify a highly speculative invasion of privacy.

title: Guns in the Schools
description: It is no longer possible to pretend that fatal school shootings are an aberration that can be shrugged off as too hard to control. The latest shooting spree -- by a 15-year-old boy in Springfield, Ore., according to police -- cries out for national guidelines to handle these cases and stronger laws to deny children access to guns and ammunition.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: 'The Iceman' May Be Coming

title: U.S. Wants Concrete Steps by New Leaders Before It Lends More
description: The International Monetary Fund and the United States will watch for concrete signs that Indonesia's new President is committed to addressing his nation's deep-rooted economic problems before deciding on further financial aid, Administration officials and economists said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMANN, ELAINE GRINTHAL
description: FUHRMANN - Elaine Grinthal. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Elaine Grinthal Fuhrmann. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORE, LEO
description: GORE-Leo. On May 21st, 1998. Beloved husband of Ronny. Devoted father of Lesley and Michael. Service Friday, May 22nd, 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Short-Sellers Show Increasing Interest in Compaq
description: A short position is created when an investor borrows shares and then sells them. If the share price subsequently declines, the investor can profit by buying shares at the lower price to replace the shares that were borrowed.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on May 2 about a former Rwandan Prime Minister's plea of guilty to genocide charges before a United Nations tribunal in Tanzania, and a correction in this space on May 5, referred imprecisely to the history of war-crimes pleas in international courts. This was not the first guilty plea, but the first for the crime of genocide, according to the United Nations. The correction also misattributed the May 2 error; it resulted from editing at The Times, not from a United Nations news release.

title: Lakers See A Chance Despite 0-2 Hole
description: Shaquille O'Neal and the Los Angeles Lakers have been on a fast track since the playoffs began, bucking odds and critics and any older and wiser team standing in their way.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He kicked the door, and he was in this trench coat, and I thought it was part of the play that we were supposed to have today. Then people started falling and screaming and bleeding. People were pushing to get out.''

title: Zenith Approves Full-Scale Revamping
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation, the struggling American television maker, approved a revamping plan today that would make its present shares worthless and its majority shareholder, LG Electronics Inc. of South Korea, the sole owner.

title: Experts Say Indonesia Can Boom, Long-Term
description: While no one disputes that the Indonesian economy has stumbled badly and shows few signs of imminent recovery, specialists are strikingly optimistic about its long-term prospects. Three decades of balanced development, they suggest, have positioned it for sustained growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEBERMAN, MERWYN AL
description: BEBERMAN-Merwyn Al, of North Hills, NY on May 19, 1998. Age 68. Beloved husband of Michele, devoted father of Joseph and Stephanie, Steven and Penny, SueEllen and Philip. Loving step-father of Nicole and Keith and Amy and Greg. Grandfather of Erica, Scott, Mallory, Jordana, Samantha and Max. Devoted brother of Muriel. We will all cherish your loving memory in our hearts always.

title: Bar Exam Data Don't Support Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Oasis With a Dark Side
description: There is no more idyllic spot in May than Springfield, Ore., and its sister city, Eugene, Ann Rule wrote in ''Small Sacrifices,''a nonfiction work that was a paperback best seller in the late 1980's. ''Sheltered by the Cascade Range to the east and the steel-blue and purple ridges of the coastal mountains on the western horizon,'' Ms. Rule wrote, ''the valley was an oasis for pioneers a century ago.''

title: LICKING RURAL TO PURCHASE NATIONAL GAS AND OIL
description: Licking Rural Electrification Inc., a closely held electricity cooperative, said yesterday that it would buy the National Gas and Oil Company, a natural-gas utility based in Newark, Ohio, for $93 million, or $13 a share, to expand its service area and offer more energy services. National Gas shares closed yesterday at $12.75, up 62.5 cents. Licking is a customer-owned electrical cooperative with 20,000 customers in nine Ohio counties, while National Gas has 27,000 customers in 13 Ohio counties. Their service areas overlap in five counties.

title: Six-Month Earnings Fall 74.3% at Sanyo Electric
description: The Sanyo Electric Company, the Japanese maker of audiovisual equipment and home appliances, indicated yesterday that second-half earnings plunged 74.3 percent on falling prices in Japan and weak demand. Changes to Japan's corporate tax laws and foreign-exchange losses also sapped earnings, Sanyo said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLER, ANNA TANJELOFF
description: ELLER-Anna Tanjeloff. On May 21, 1998. Beloved wife of Edward Eller and the late Julio Tanjeloff. Loving stepmother of Edgar and Jorge Tanjeloff, and grandmother of Dennis, Eric, Marc, Jasime and Zachery Tanjeloff. Devoted sister of Mimi & Jorge Cuomo. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, Friday 2-5 P.M. & 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial at St. John the Martyr Church, 250 East 72 Street, Saturday 10 A.M. Entombment to follow at Ferncliff Mausoleum.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day, actually May 30, will be legally observed.

title: A Jets Highlights Film, Finally, With Highlights
description: Finally, a Jets highlight film with Jets highlights. For the past five years the team called its annual video a ''preview film,'' but yesterday it unveiled ''Back to the Future,'' a look at last year's 9-7 campaign.

title: Savory Treats
description: Whether you call them dumplings or pirogis, pelmeni or empanadas, even kreplach, every culture seems to have its little doughy treat stuffed with a savory center. Here are a dozen restaurants where the filled things are worth sampling. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When it comes to food, Central Park has not generally used its resources well. But it seems that things are changing.

title: After a Decade of Penance, Ftorek Gets the Nod
description: In his first full season as a National Hockey League head coach almost a decade ago, Robbie Ftorek's Los Angeles Kings finished 11 games over .500 and reached the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. Ftorek left the job that summer amid the widespread perception that his all-players-are-equal approach did not please Wayne Gretzky.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 15-Year-Old Seen by Some As Troubled and Violent
description: His parents were popular teachers at two high schools in Springfield, Ore. His older sister is a college cheerleader who has won honors in national cheerleading competitions.

title: President of Transport Union Re-elected After Bitter Fight
description: After a protracted, bitterly contested fight for control of the union that represents most of New York City's subway and bus workers, Willie James, the incumbent president, narrowly defeated Tim Schermerhorn, the head of a rival group, the union said yesterday.

title: Washington Opera to Stay and Grow at the Kennedy
description: Effectively ending its plan to build a new opera house in an old department store downtown, the Washington Opera has reached a tentative agreement with the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to perform there more often.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, SHIRLEY
description: BERNSTEIN-Shirley. On May 20, 1998. Loving sister of Burton and the late Leonard. Dear aunt of Jamie, Nina, Karen, Michael and Alexander. Service on Friday 11:15 AM, at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, ROGER LOUIS, SR.
description: MARTIN-Roger Louis, Sr., of Boxford, MA. Died May 19 at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington at age 66. He was the husband of Esther M. (Stewart) Martin of Boxford, father of Dr. George Martin, D.M.D. of Lansdowne, PA., Roger Louis Martin, Jr., of High Wycombe, England, and Monique Marguerite Martin of NYC. He was also the brother of Paul Georges Martin of Brazil. A funeral Mass and burial will be Friday in Georgetown, MA. Merton E. Roberts Jr. Funeral Home, 14 Pleasant Street, Georgetown, Mass. 01833. Memorial contributions may be made to the Catholic Charities, 49 Franklin Street, Boston, MA. 02110.

title: Day of Detours for Frustrated Cabbies
description: They tried to drive a cavalcade of empty cabs across the Queensboro Bridge. No way, the police said. Then they marched miles to City Hall to hold a rally, only to find barricades and an impenetrable wall of blue uniforms. They were shooed off street corners and threatened with arrest.

title: From Talismans, 3 Vietnam Vignettes
description: Some 35,000 objects have been left at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, we are informed at the end of ''The Wall,'' a Showtime movie on Sunday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, CLAIRE K.
description: ROSENBERG-Claire K., on May 20, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Gerald and Janet Rosenberg and Joan and Paul Weissbluth. Cherished grandmother of Michael and Steven Weissbluth, David and Andrea, and Carol Rosenberg.

title: A Whistle and a Wheeze, Not to Mention a Growl
description: Iva Bittova began her encore at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night with a whistle. Hers was not the coy snippet of melody a cabaret singer might employ to set a casual mood, but a spit-producing wheeze amplified by a plastic noisemaker this Czech vocalist and violinist held between her lips.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Josef Albers

title: Pregnant Candidate
description: To the Editor:

title: No Good Land Mines
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Police Officer Is Indicted in Sex Case
description: A Newark police officer was indicted yesterday on charges of official misconduct and faces accusations that he engaged in a sexual act with a prostitute while on duty, county prosecutors said.

title: Campaign Law Is Real Villain in China Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Executive Denies Making Donation to the Democrats
description: Liu Chaoying, the Chinese aerospace executive accused of contributing nearly $100,000 to the Democratic Party through a middleman in 1996, emphatically denied today that she had ever done so.

title: Misbegotten Cuba Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Moving Along the Border Between Past and Future
description: CITIES OF THE PLAIN

title: Boy Questioned In Fatal Stabbing
description: The police said last night that they believed an 11-year-old boy fatally stabbed a man who was beating his mother in their Brooklyn apartment.

title: O'Neill Agrees to a Contract for 1999
description: Paul O'Neill could have become a free agent after the season and fielded offers from teams other than the Yankees. He could have waited for the highest offer, packed up his family one more time and relocated for the most lucrative paycheck. O'Neill just said no to that notion.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Keeping a Promise Of College Tuition

title: Deadly Games, Then Chirping Crickets
description: The Juilliard Dance Division deserves to celebrate. The Class of 1998 offered its senior graduation performance on Monday night at the Juilliard Theater, and all the participants were technically and stylistically assured. Benjamin Harkarvy, the dance division's artistic director, assembled an ambitious program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDERMAN, PHYLLIS
description: ALDERMAN - Phyllis. Beloved mother of Randi Walz and Jacqueline Alderman. Cherished motherin-law of Bob Walz and loving sister of Carole Wind. Services today 1 P.M., Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue, New York City (at 10th Street).

title: Search Continues
description: The St. John's athletic director, Ed Manetta, has obtained permission from at least four schools to speak with their coaches concerning the Red Storm's search for a successor to coach Fran Fraschilla.

title: Pallbearer for Victim Is Convicted of Murder
description: A Wildwood man who was a pallbearer at his victim's funeral in 1996 was found guilty yesterday of rape and murder, county prosecutors said.

title: New Yorker Merger Will Begin Next Month
description: The merging of the New Yorker magazine into the rest of Conde Nast's operations is about to begin -- sooner than expected.

title: U.S. Welcomes Resignation But Is Cool to the Successor
description: The Clinton Administration stepped up its calls today for a transition to democracy in Indonesia and, while welcoming the resignation of President Suharto, attempted to distance itself from his successor, B. J. Habibie. Senior officials said the United States assumed -- and hoped -- that Mr. Habibie's tenure as President would be a short one.

title: FIFTH THIRD GETTING 4 BANC ONE BRANCHES
description: Fifth Third Bancorp of Cincinnati has agreed to buy four Banc One branches in southeastern Ohio for an undisclosed amount. The branches, with $135 million of deposits and $76 million of loans, will become part of Fifth Third Bank of Southern Ohio, which has 15 branches and $400 million of deposits. The branches were part of Bank One Ohio, a unit of the Banc One Corporation, based in Columbus. Fifth Third is one of the most profitable bank's in the country for its size.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Deal Turns Former Disco Owner Into City's Largest Private Hotelier
description: Fifteen years ago, Ian Schrager was a former discotheque operator and a convicted felon who found it difficult to open a bank account or raise a dime.

title: Insurer Buys Unit of Aetna For $1 Billion
description: The Lincoln National Corporation said today that it had agreed to pay Aetna Inc. $1 billion for its United States individual life insurance business.

title: After 25 Years, Just Days Till Freedom; With New Evidence, Judge Voids a Woman's Murder Conviction
description: The case had elements of a Hollywood thriller: a murder in a dark alley, a roundup of suspects in the demimonde of prostitutes and transvestites, hushed accounts of suspects beaten and witnesses intimidated by the police, a woman convicted on coerced testimony, a hard-digging reporter exposing long-hidden facts, a fight by activists and a lawyer to get at the truth.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jane Freilicher

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about United States aid to Indonesian groups opposed to President Suharto misspelled the surname of a professor of political science who commented on the aid, and misstated his affiliation. He is William Liddle, not Little, and he teaches at Ohio State University, not Ohio University.

title: More Victims and Much Less Sense in the String of Shootings at Schools
description: Yesterday's school shootings in Springfield, Ore., following the string of recent killings by students, are part of a shift in the nature of school violence, some experts said, with more incidents escalating beyond one-on-one disputes into movie-style scenes of mayhem.

title: April U.S. Budget Had Record Surplus
description: The United States recorded its highest monthly budget surplus ever in April as the robust economy and booming stock market generated strong tax revenue, setting the stage for the first annual budget surplus since the late 1960's.

title: Israeli Court Wants to Pass Torture Issue To Legislature
description: After years of allowing Israel's secret service to use physical violence when questioning Palestinians, the country's Supreme Court has voiced frustration that the court -- and not the Parliament -- has been saddled with responsibility for practices that human rights groups denounce as the illegal use of torture.

title: The Mayor's Graciousness Gap
description: With crime down and the economy up, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has reigned over a revival of New York City. That said, it is time to note that seven months into his second term, the Mayor often exhibits an unnecessary imperiousness that ultimately cannot serve his city, his political aspirations or even his legacy.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOBIN, BERTA H.
description: JOBIN-Berta H., A.I.A., on May 21st, 1998 of Bedford, New York. Hospital Architect, consultant on operating suites worldwide. Survived by five loving nieces and nephews. Service at 2 PM, St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, New York. Interment, Raymond Hills Cemetery, Carmel, NY.

title: Fed, at March Meeting, Saw Manageable Inflation Risk
description: The Federal Reserve saw an increased risk of resurgent inflation when it met on March 31, but decided to hold interest rates steady in the belief that Asian financial woes would help cool down the domestic economy and keep price increases in check, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANKEL, HAROLD L.
description: ZANKEL-Harold L. Aged 83, son of Max and Lena Zankel, will be missed by his sisters, Gertrude Alpern and Adele Shapiro, and his partners and associates at Ratner's Restaurant. Funeral today at 1 PM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery. Shiva at Shapiro's, 555 Green Place, Woodmere, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, REV. MAURICE
description: CARROLL-Rev. Maurice. On May 19, 1998. Pastor of St. Vincent De Paul Catholic Church on West 23rd Street. Son of the late Kathleen & David. Beloved brother of Eileen McKeown. Survived by six nieces and nephews and 11 grandnieces and nephews. Reposing at the Horn-Dannecker Funeral Home, 336 West 23 Street, NYC, Friday. Visiting hours: 1-5 PM. Transferral to St. Vincent De Paul Church on Friday evening with a 7:30 PM mass. Funeral mass on Saturday at 11 AM with burial to follow in the Calvary Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in his memory to: St. Christopher's Inn Inc.-Graymoor, Box 150, Garrison, New York 10524.

title: When a Glint in the Eye Showed Crime in the Genes
description: In ''Police Pictures: The Photograph as Evidence,'' at the Grey Art Gallery, I noticed a copy of Cesare Lombroso's ''Criminal Man.''

title: Asteroid Season: One Too Many?
description: It's every studio's nightmare.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the transfer of plays from London to New York misstated the sum that one London producer, Robert Fox, said it takes to mount a play on Broadway. It is $1.5 million, not $:1.5 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a plan to replace a Bronx community garden with housing gave an incorrect spelling in some editions for the surname of a resident who helped build the garden. He is Julio Reynoso, not Reynosa.

title: 'I'll Throw in 5 Bucks,' and Record Prize Is Claimed
description: Pretty much every day since Frank Capaci retired from his job as an electrician, he has stopped in at his favorite bar, Bill's on Bartlett, and downed a few beers.

title: New Video Releases
description: Deconstructing Harry

title: Two Forces That Tug at Indonesia: Change and Stability
description: Two images in the Indonesian kaleidoscope capture the tug-of-war whose outcome will define this nation for years or decades to come.

title: Worries About Prices and Profits Send Dow 39.11 Lower
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday on worries that corporate profit growth was slowing and that prices were already too high.

title: Most of Silenced U.S. Pagers Are Said to Operate Again
description: Most pagers in the United States were revived yesterday as communications companies worked to repair damage to their networks caused by the failure of the Panamsat Corporation's Galaxy 4 satellite on Tuesday night.

title: Decorators Given Lighter Terms for Money Laundering
description: In another unusual twist to an unusual case, two San Francisco decorators convicted of laundering money for a Colombian drug lord received reduced sentences yesterday from a United States District Court judge in Brooklyn who said he granted leniency in part because he thought that as homosexuals the two would be vulnerable in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, PHILIP SEMPLE
description: BARRY-Philip Semple. Of New York City and Beverly Hills, California, on Saturday, May 16, 1998 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Husband of Patricia White Barry, father of Miranda Robbins Barry and Stephanie Anne Thankful Barry Agnew, grandfather of Alexandra Anne and Hailey Ellen Agnew. Funeral Services will be at 3:00PM, Saturday, May 23 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, New York, burial at Most Holy Trinity Cemetery. A memorial service will be held at 3:00 P.M., on Tuesday, June 9 at the St. James Theatre, 246 West 44th St. in New York City. A memorial service at the Director's Guild of America in Los Angeles is planned, date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations in New York to the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theatre Center or Lenox Hill Hospital, in California to the American Film Institute or the John Tracy Clinic. For further information contact Williams Funeral Home of East Hampton.

title: Buffeted by Death And a Whirlwind Of Self-Punishment
description: ''Under the Skin'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 28. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: D'Amato Schedules Hearing on Banking Laws
description: In a move intended to accelerate Senate consideration of legislation to remove Depression-era regulations on banking, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, scheduled hearings for June yesterday, the first step toward a full Senate vote.

title: Moscow Journal; Tale With a Dark Russian Hint: Publish or Perish?
description: The most famous author in Russia is not a novelist or a poet. He is the former head of Russia's privatization agency whose main preoccupation these days is simply staying out of jail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIMMELBERGER, PERKINS, RO BIN
description: HIMMELBERGER - PERKINS - Ro bin. We are deeply saddened by the passing of the beautiful and beloved daughter of Robert and Marge Himmelberger, sister of Mark and Craig, aunt of Zachary and sister-in-law of Yolanda and Paige. Robin will be greatly missed. All of Brighton Towers Family extends their deepest sympathies to the Himmelbergers. The Bernstein and Fox Family

title: Auto Makers Seek to Make Light Trucks Safer in Crashes
description: Auto makers have quietly begun trying to design sport utility vehicles that will be less dangerous to other motorists.

title: Videos You Sing Along With
description: Memorial Day weekend can leave a New Yorker feeling trapped. Tourists throng the streets asking one another for directions to Washington Square. Escape routes from the city are clogged with traffic; those who brave them find that nearby beaches and country retreats are doubly packed with holiday weekenders and people setting up for the summer.

title: Nurses Train Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer; Testy Forgotten Land
description: When someone says ''Indians,'' most Americans probably think of gambling-casino operators. So isolationist have we become.

title: Beijing Gets Nuclear Data From Satellites, Experts Say
description: Every time a Chinese rocket company launches an American-made satellite into orbit, Beijing's weapons engineers learn more that could enable them to improve the accuracy of nuclear missiles, space-policy experts told a Senate panel today.

title: Woman Sues Ex-Officer Accused of Beating Her
description: A 72-year-old woman has filed a $25 million lawsuit, claiming she was assaulted and falsely arrested by an Edison police officer last year after she lodged a complaint about him to his superiors.

title: The Rugged Face of BMW
description: WHILE Daimler-Benz and Chrysler were announcing their marriage with great fanfare, BMW was quietly expanding its American assembly operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, RUTH
description: ROSS-Ruth. Wife of Sidney, sister of Stanley, devoted and adored mother of Jerilyn and Richard. Treasured mother-of-law of Gerald and Cissy. Cherished grandmother in the lives of Evan, Joy, Dana, Nick and Leela. She will always be missed.

title: At Shortstop, 3 Leaders of the Pack
description: The Yankees' Phil Rizzuto had to wait 38 years before his induction into baseball's Hall of Fame certified the golden age of shortstops that he, Pee Wee Reese and Alvin Dark created in New York City in the 1940's and 1950's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUNDLICH, MARTHA P.
description: FREUNDLICH-Martha P. On May 20, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late Solomon & Rosa Freundlich. Dear sister of the late Margaret Laufer, George Freundlich and Martin Freundlich. Adored aunt and great aunt. Services today, May 22, 12:15 PM ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN STRENGTHENS. Japan's currency rose on the resignation of President Suharto of Indonesia, which encouraged speculation that Asian economic instability might lessen. In New York the dollar fell to 134.78 yen from 135.98.

title: VLASIC PREDICTS LOWER-THAN-EXPECTED EARNINGS
description: Vlasic Foods International Inc. said yesterday that its second-half earnings would be far lower than analysts had expected because of declining sales of pickles and Swanson frozen foods. The company, which was spun off from the Campbell Soup Company in March, said its fiscal third- and fourth-quarter earnings would also be hurt by a higher-than-expected tax rate and increased costs to create a new computer system. Vlasic was expected to earn 18 cents a share in the quarter ended May 3 and 31 cents in the quarter ended Aug. 2, according to I.B.E.S. International Inc. Shares of the company, which is based in Cherry Hill, N.J., tumbled $2.5625 yesterday, to $21.6875.

title: Fox and UPN Offer New Lineups
description: Promoting itself as the network that wants to be ''distinctive, different and aggressive,'' Fox Broadcasting unveiled a new prime-time schedule yesterday that would add six series and move one of the network's biggest hits, ''King of the Hill,'' to a new night.

title: Campaign Law Is Real Villain in China Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Catching Perfection
description: A perfect game and a donnybrook in the same week? Who says baseball is dull?

title: Political Briefing; Another G.O.P. Primary, Another Term-Limits Test
description: The term-limits law overwhelmingly approved four years ago by Idaho voters is just about as restrictive as any in the country. But it does not apply to members of Congress -- courts have said it cannot.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL LIFTS BID FOR MORE GROUP
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had raised its bid for the British outdoor-advertising company More Group P.L.C. to $:575 million ($939 million), topping a rival bid of $:475 million by Decaux S.A. of France. Earlier in the day, the British Trade and Industry Secretary referred Decaux's bid to the British Monopolies and Mergers Commission, Clear Channel said, adding that the secretary's action means the Decaux bid for More Group now lapses. Clear Channel said it had raised its bid ''to reflect the importance we place on this acquisition'' and to obtain a quick resolution to the uncertainty surrounding More Group. Clear Channel agreed in March to buy More Group for $:446 million, but Decaux made a rival offer later that month. More then withdrew its recommendation for the Clear Channel offer. Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, owns radio and television stations. Its shares rose $1 yesterday, to $96.50.

title: Campaign Law Is Real Villain in China Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Loose Bricks Close Section of Third Avenue
description: A dangerous bulge in a section of bricks on a 17-story building forced city officials to close Third Avenue between 14th and 15th Streets yesterday, and the busy avenue remained blocked during the rush hours.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Times Company Directors Vote to Split Stock 2 for 1
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its board had approved a 2-for-1 split in its class A and class B shares and an 11.8 percent increase in the quarterly dividend.

title: Manslaughter Charge Is Dropped in Beating
description: A judge dismissed a charge of manslaughter yesterday against a Brooklyn teen-ager accused of beating a teacher's aide in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNIS, SELMA
description: KENNIS-Selma. The employees of Schmutter, Strull, Fleisch send their heartfelt condolences to Bernard Kennis and his family on the passing of his beloved wife Selma

title: Yankees Refuse to Give The Orioles Even an Inch
description: The floundering and frustrated Orioles were anxious to leave the Bronx and get far, far away from the brawl with the Yankees that might hamper them all season. There was one more game last night, one fleeting chance for the Orioles to grab something, anything, positive to take with them. Forget it. It only got worse.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the theft of three works of art, including ''L'Arlesienne'' by van Gogh, from the National Gallery of Modern Art in Rome, referred incorrectly to a New York museum that has another van Gogh painting by that name. It is the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Companies Fear Costs Of Suharto Partnerships
description: For American and foreign companies seeking riches in Indonesia's fast-growing market over the last three decades, President Suharto, his family and coterie of cronies have been commercial gatekeepers, sometimes becoming partners in business ventures with a brashness that would have made other Asian dictators blush.

title: Oregon Student Held in 3 Killings; One Dead, 23 Hurt at His School
description: Minutes before the 8 o'clock bell rang to start the day at Thurston High School today, a student carrying three guns opened fire on hundreds of other students gathered in the cafeteria, killing one, the police said. Twenty-three other students were injured, five critically, by gunfire and in the resulting melee.

title: Microsoft Fires First Salvo In Antitrust Fight With U.S.
description: The legal trench warfare in the Microsoft antitrust case began yesterday as the embattled software maker asked a Federal judge to give it seven months to prepare for a hearing.

title: European Coke Concern Expects 10% Profit Gain
description: Europe's newest Coca-Cola company, whose July listing in London and Sydney, Australia, is expected to give it a market value of $:1.3 billion to $:1.7 billion, or $2.1 billion to $2.9 billion, said yesterday that it would increase sales and profit by at least 10 percent starting this year.

title: Lord Cudlipp, Tabloid Creator Who Lived to Rue It, Is Dead
description: Baron Cudlipp of Aldingbourne, who as editorial director and chairman of the wildly popular Mirror newspapers in the 1950's and 60's brought a new populist vigor to the tabloid press in Britain, died at his home in Chichester, West Sussex, on Sunday. He was 84 and had been suffering from lung and prostate cancer.

title: Coronado's Quest Drops Belmont From Agenda
description: One of the chief threats to Real Quiet's pursuit of the Triple Crown was removed yesterday when the speedy Coronado's Quest was withdrawn from the Belmont Stakes because his bruised foot had cost him too much training time.

title: A Devotedly Drug-Addled Rampage Through a 1971 Vision of Las Vegas
description: In the teeming lobby of a Las Vegas hotel, the face of a woman behind the reservations desk warps, her features spilling across her face like a clown mask. As the camera pans around the plush, dimly lighted room crowded with hard-shelled tourists sipping cocktails, they suddenly turn into a sinister convention of lizards smacking their lipless mouths and casting conspiratorial glances. Conversations decompose into animalistic growls while the bland piped-in voice of Robert Goulet singing ''My Love Forgive Me'' remains eerily unaltered.

title: Hopeful Words of Arrival, Contrite Words of Departure
description: Following are excerpts from the inaugural address yesterday by the new President of Indonesia, B. J. Habibie, and the resignation speech by President Suharto. Mr. Habibie's speech was translated and transmitted by Agence France-Presse, and Mr. Suharto's speech by The Associated Press.

title: Plan to Let Employers Give Tax-Free Transit Benefits Is Included in Congressional Bill
description: Congressional negotiators said today that they had reached agreement on a measure that would substantially cut the cost of bus and subway travel in the New York metropolitan region and across the nation by allowing employers to give workers up to $65 a month in tax-free mass transit benefits instead of salary.

title: With Attack on Giuliani, Pastor Returns to Fiery Past
description: Some years ago, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d said, he decided to leave the marching in the streets and ''banging on the mayor's door'' to other black civil rights leaders. Instead, he decided he would knock softly on the doors of power, negotiate with city officials, cultivate relationships with the leaders of large corporations, all in an effort to attract investment, development and sorely needed jobs to his impoverished community in central Harlem.

title: Leo Burnett Buys Australian Agency
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago said yesterday that its Leo Burnett Worldwide unit had acquired Cartwright Williams in Sydney, described as the largest independent direct marketing agency in Australia. The two privately held agency companies did not disclose financial terms of the deal.

title: Queens Man Is Charged With Killing Over Debt
description: A Queens man who was having trouble making payments on a gambling debt shot his lender in the head then buried him under a tree stump in Bear Mountain State Park, N.Y., the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Unusual Senate Coalition Opposes Limiting Tobacco Industry's Liability
description: Anti-smoking legislation hit a potentially serious snag in the Senate today, and further action was postponed until next month.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Paul Klee

title: Celebrating Flower Power
description: If you thought taxi drivers were angry, you haven't seen anything yet. On Sunday, the gardens of the Lower East Side will rise up (symbolically, at least) to protest concrete encroachment and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's mandate, issued on April 24, to turn over 741 community gardens to the Department of Housing, Preservation and Development. So don't be surprised to see flowers, trees and grass walking the streets, performing their own passion play.

title: AMERICOLD LOGISTICS TO BUY CARMAR FOR $144 MILLION
description: Americold Logistics Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Carmar Group for $144 million in cash and the assumption of $14 million of debt, extending its position as the nation's largest provider of cold storage warehouse space. Americold is 60 percent owned by Vornado Realty Trust of Saddle Brook, N.J. The other 40 percent is owned by the Crescent Real Estate Equities Company of Fort Worth. Carmar owns and operates five refrigerated warehouses in the Midwest and Southeast.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 19 about Fannie Lou Spelce, a nurse who became a prominent folk artist, misspelled the name of the Arkansas town where she was born and misidentified both the residence of Mrs. Spelce's sons and the town in which she lived before moving to Austin, Tex. Her birthplace is Dyer, not Dwyer. The sons, Neal and Bennett, live in Austin, not Dallas. Mrs. Spelce previously lived in Houston, not Dallas. This correction was delayed by inadvertent misrouting at The Times.

title: CORE LABORATORIES IN DEAL FOR OWEN OIL TOOLS
description: Core Laboratories N.V. of the Netherlands said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the privately held Owen Oil Tools Inc. for $55 million in stock plus $7 million of assumed debt. Owen Oil, based in Fort Worth, makes well completion and well drilling products. It had revenue of about $46 million in 1997. Core Laboratories, based in Amsterdam, is a petroleum services company that operates in more than 50 countries.

title: Stock Market In Indonesia Reflects Hope
description: Indonesian stocks rose at the opening of the stock market today, lifted by hopes that the resignation of President Suharto might allow a new Cabinet to push ahead with economic and political changes.

title: Setting the Sextant Aside
description: In a 1942 handbook for merchant seamen called ''How to Abandon Ship,'' there is a terse chapter on navigation. ''If your lifeboat is without a navigator,'' it begins, ''these directions are for you.'' Nautical history is full of stories about small boats guided across the oceans by experienced celestial navigators, often by amateurs, like the redoubtable Joshua Slocum, and sometimes by professionals who are driven to extremity, such as William Bligh or Ernest Shackleton. Celestial navigation -- the art of using a sextant and the heavenly bodies to determine one's position -- is, in fact, a central element of nautical tradition.

title: George D. Grundy Jr., 99, Last of Pioneers in Aviation
description: George D. Grundy Jr., the last of the world's first fliers, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Leesburg, Fla. He was 99 and had been the sole surviving member of the Early Birds, an international organization of aviation pioneers.

title: Marion Barry Isn't Running For Fifth Term
description: Ending months of uncertainty about his political future after 16 years as Mayor of the District of Columbia, Marion S. Barry Jr. announced today that he would not seek another four-year term.

title: Name-Calling Cuts 2 Ways At City Hall
description: THIS niche of the newspaper has never stood accused of being an amen corner for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Far more often than not, the voices heard here take on the Mayor for showing zero tolerance for even mild disagreement and for seeming to be obsessively, sometimes laughably, convinced that he alone is graced with competence and wisdom.

title: Op-Art; Your Ad Here
description: Pedestrians look at Manhattan's skyscrapers and see an urban redwood forest -- strong, beautiful. But building owners see billboards-in-waiting. More and more buildings now scream the benefits of cigarettes, pantyhose, vodka, whatever.

title: 50 Swings and No Winces
description: It was only batting practice. But taking the swings was Todd Hundley, facing his first live pitches since undergoing reconstructive elbow surgery last Sept. 26. So for the Mets, yesterday was a good day even before they went out and beat Cincinnati, 6-1.

title: House Asks Clinton to Aid in Inquiry
description: The House today passed two symbolic resolutions meant to keep the spotlight on investigations of President Clinton and to urge him to cooperate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEID, CHARLES, M.D.
description: SCHEID-Charles, M.D. The members of the Physician Organization of Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens mourn the passing of Dr. Charles Scheid, attending physician at Catholic Medical Center. We offer our hearfelt prayers and our deepest sympathy to the Scheid family on their great loss. Steven C. Garner, M.D., President Catholic Medical Center Physician Organization

title: Studies Must Protect the Patients; A Few Bad Examples
description: To the Editor:

title: Bold Decisions in New Jersey
description: Persistently overshadowed by its neighbors, New Jersey bears the burden of many slights. But in education and the environment, the state has an impressive record of innovation. This week the New Jersey Supreme Court withdrew from direct oversight of the school system after establishing equality in funding for rich and poor districts. The justices also directed the state to upgrade programs in poor urban schools. In addition, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman called for a gasoline tax hike to help safeguard undeveloped land. Taken together, these were steps forward that could show the way for other states.

title: JUDGE REJECTS BID TO CITE 'PRIVILEGE' IN CLINTON INQUIRY
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that Secret Service agents can be compelled to testify about President Clinton's relationship with a former White House intern, rejecting Administration claims that a novel privilege is required to protect Presidents from assassins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODNER, LEO
description: BODNER-Leo. The Yeshivah of Flatbush deeply mourns the passing of Leo Bodner, beloved father of Allen J. Bodner, Honorary President, Gilda Kaufman and Howard Bodner. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Bodner family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Steven R. Shamah, President Dennis M. Eisenberg, Exec. Dir.

title: The Story We Didn't Print on Page 1
description: ''Kids ambush kids'' was the front-page headline in The Chicago Sun-Times on March 25, the day after the school shootings in Jonesboro, Ark. We ran all the details on page 1, with a large photo. When a 15-year-old boy was arrested and accused of plotting to ambush students at a high school in the Chicago suburbs last week, we also ran that on page 1.

title: Studies Must Protect the Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, JEAN, PAUL
description: JOSEPH-Jean-Paul. In memory of our dear friend and colleague. We will never forget you. Tendler Beretz LLC

title: In a Poor District, Success With New Curriculum
description: At the heart of the final State Supreme Court ruling Thursday in the decades-long battle over funding for urban schools was a prescription for instituting a single teaching method to lift reading and math scores.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Issues Extend Selloff, Weakening Market

title: He Wants You In Driver's Seat; Marketing G.M. Brands As if They Were Detergent
description: It was an open invitation either to career swashbuckling or to career suicide: the General Motors Corporation, the world's biggest company and America's biggest advertiser, was looking for a new marketing guru four years ago.

title: Callaway Is Prepared to Fight Any Ban on Clubs
description: The United States Golf Association is taking a hard look at technological advances in equipment with an eye toward potentially changing the rules. And if the U.S.G.A. decides to ban some of today's equipment, the Callaway Golf Company is prepared to fight.

title: Newark Woman Accused Of Abandoning Baby
description: A Newark woman was arrested Thursday night and charged with child endangerment after she left her 10-month-old baby unattended in a stroller on the street while panhandling in the North Ward, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITLITZ, BONNIE
description: GITLITZ-Bonnie. The NYS Coalition of Nurse Practitioners mourns the loss our friend and leader, a pediatric nurse practitioner devoted to her friends, her family, profession and her patients.

title: INSIDE
description: Air Traffic System Criticized

title: Newspapers Join On-Line Network
description: The Gannett Company, Central Newspapers Inc. and the McClatchy Company have agreed to join the Classified Ventures on-line network, as the newspaper chains seek to bolster ties with local readers and attract more advertisers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERSON, BERNARD MORDECHAI
description: MEYERSON-Bernard Mordechai. Of Boynton Beach, FL., formerly of Brooklyn. Passed away May 22, 1998. Loving husband, adored father, cherished grandfather and great grandfather, beloved brother. Services Sunday, May 24, 1998, 2:45 PM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. For further information ''Gutterman's'' 516-764-9400.

title: NASA Advises Another Delay In Construction of Space Station
description: NASA has recommended that construction of the international space station be delayed until the end of the year because Russian-made components for the orbiting outpost are behind schedule, agency spokesmen said today.

title: STATOIL OF NORWAY INVESTS IN NEW YORK POWER STATIONS
description: Statoil of Norway said yesterday that its American unit had bought stakes in two New York power stations from Community Energy Alternatives for $70 million to increase its share of the power market in the Northeast United States. The Norwegian state-owned oil company bought 50 percent stakes in the Kennedy International Airport Facility in Queens and the State University of New York operation, which have a capacity of 107 megawatts and 40 megawatts, respectively. It also said its United States unit had changed its name from the Eastern Group to Statoil Energy. Electricity from the Kennedy station is used to power the airport, with excess supply sold to a local utility. The university plant's power is delivered under a long-term contract to the university and its associated hospital on Long Island.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS SEEKS SPARGO CONSULTING OF LONDON
description: The Computer Horizons Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy Spargo Consulting P.L.C. of London for stock valued around $67.4 million. Spargo is an information technology consultant. It reported net income of about $2.8 million for 1997. Computer Horizons, based in Mountain Lakes, N.J., offers outsourcing, systems integration, systems analysis and design. It had revenue of $107.1 million in the quarter ended March 31. Under the offer, Spargo shareholders would receive 0.15096 Computer Horizon share for each Spargo share. Computer Horizons closed at $33.25 yesterday, down $1.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, SIMON D.
description: STRAUSS-Simon D., 86. Of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Lenox, MA., May 22, 1998. Peacefully at home of cancer. He was the husband of Janet M. Strauss for 15 years following the death of Elaine M. Strauss; the father of Peter L. Strauss of Hastings-on-Hudson and Susan D. Orr of Sacramento, CA.; the grandfather of Katie Thomas and David Samuel Orr and Benjamin and Bethany Strauss; and the great-grandfather of Gwen and Bevan Thomas. He will be greatly missed by them and so many others for his wisdom & the enormous strength and generosity of his soul. As he wanted, his funeral will be private, and a memorial service will be held for his extended family and many friends in New York City in September. Contributions can be sent to the Simon and Elaine Strauss Fund at Barnard College or to the Manhattan School for Music.

title: Gently, Indonesia's Military Ends Seizure of Parliament
description: Indonesia's army retook Parliament in an overnight raid by hundreds of soldiers, who pushed, prodded and cajoled more than 2,000 students to leave the complex they had occupied for five days.

title: Sailing by the Stars; Busman's Holiday
description: To the Editor:

title: Best N.Y. Buildings Don't Need Signs to Advertise
description: To the Editor:

title: Anderson's Big Boost Off Bench Lifts Jazz
description: He didn't skip college and step into the hot lights of Hollywood like Kobe Bryant. He didn't star in a Michael Jordan commercial like Eddie Jones. But Shandon Anderson does have something in common with the two young stars of the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE BRON, INA
description: Le BRON-Ina. Temple B'nai Sholom mourns the loss of our long time member. We extend condolences to the family. Graveside Services, New Montefiore Cemetery Sunday, May 24, 1 PM. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Shares of Ciena Fall on Outlook
description: Shares of the Ciena Corporation, the top maker of special equipment used to bolster phone networks, fell 5.4 percent today after the company said it was unsure when orders from Worldcom Inc. and the AT&T Corporation would come in.

title: Weekend Features Three Stakes Races
description: Belmont Park will run three stakes in three days this holiday weekend, and the master of the upset is there drawing a bead on all of them: Allen Jerkens, the Hall of Fame trainer renowned for saddling the horses who outran Secretariat twice and Kelso three times.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL ADDS EUROPEAN SECURITY UNIT
description: Tyco International Ltd., which owns the No. 1 security systems provider ADT, said yesterday that it would buy CIPE France S.A. in a move it said would make it the largest security systems provider in Europe. Terms were not disclosed. Tyco said it had agreed with certain shareholders to acquire a majority of CIPE and would make a tender offer for the rest of CIPE's shares next week. The purchase of CIPE, which has about $230 million in annual revenue, is Tyco's latest in a shopping spree that topped $10.5 billion last year and that is intended to expand Tyco's four main businesses: security systems, disposable medical products, electronics and valves. Shares of Tyco slipped 75 cents yesterday, to $55.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Bridge; When the World Was Young And Two-Bids Were Strong
description: Readers who are reaching for an indignant pen to complain about the bidding diagram may relax. It actually happened as written at the Eastern Regional Championships in 1962. In those long-dead days the fields were far bigger for the major events, the Goldman Pairs and Reisinger Knockout Teams, and play was always in Manhattan. This weekend, because hotel space is at a premium in New York City, enthusiasts who are used to playing in midtown must grumble their way to the Sheraton Hotel in Stamford, Conn.

title: Foreign Affairs; Where's The Crisis?
description: It is hard to pick up a newspaper these days without finding some expert proposing controls on the huge flows of capital and investments in today's global economy. The argument usually goes like this: The global currency market now trades in excess of $2.5 trillion a day; billions more slosh around to stock and bond markets. This has created a huge electronic herd of traders, but when a herd this big stampedes, small and large countries that have opened their economies up to it can be crushed -- far beyond what they deserve. Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia are held up as examples of countries that were doing just dandy before they got stampeded and are now all in crisis (Russia could be next). Therefore, the argument goes, the world needs some kind of super-regulatory body that will control the capital markets and protect all these countries from wild stampedes and further crises.

title: From Misery to Flight: A Cambodian Soars Through His Poetry
description: On April 13, 1975, U Sam Oeur, a captain in the army of the American-backed Government of Gen. Lon Nol in Cambodia who wrote poetry on the side, was celebrating the Buddhist New Year at his home near Phnom Penh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, SR. MARY FRANCIS
description: SLATTERY-Sr. Mary Francis. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity and noted scholar on May 22, 1998. Dear sister of Duard. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, New York, on Monday from 1-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday 10 AM at the convent. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 30 about a recycling campaign run by the city's Sanitation Department misstated the number of households involved in a pilot program in Brooklyn. It was 200, not 100. The article also misstated the program's goal. Paula E. Young, a department spokeswoman, said it was to inform and educate the public on recycling, not to save the city money.

title: The Rural Life; Nightfall and the Call to Come Inside
description: For the last few evenings it has been almost impossible to come inside before dark. The shadows deepen and converge, the breeze shuffles the leaves in the sugar maples, and an unappraisable sweetness slips down from the woods -- all of it with such careful modulation, the entrance of one player after another, that to call it artful sounds like dispraise. I sit and watch from civil twilight until astronomical twilight. Or, to put it another way, I watch from the time the bats first fly, cutting across the bay of light between the trees that outline the pasture, until the bats can be seen only when they eclipse the stars.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen fell after minutes from the Bank of Japan's April 9 meeting, released yesterday, suggested it might reduce interest rates to help the weak economy. In New York, the dollar rose to 135.90 yen from 134.78.

title: A Hollywood Star Takes On Broadway
description: The only way to overshadow the virtually unbeatable Yankees is with candlepower of immense proportions. Mike Piazza, acquired yesterday, instantly becomes the only Met with that kind of brilliance.

title: Lilly Forms Research and Development Pact
description: Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc. and Eli Lilly & Company said today that they had formed a marketing and development collaboration in the genitourinary field.

title: Daiwa Securities to Move Some Offices to London
description: The Daiwa Securities Company said yesterday that it would move its international business headquarters to London from Tokyo to cut costs and increase efficiency, and because it saw London growing in prominence as an international financial center. Daiwa said Shuichi Komori, currently head of Daiwa Securities America Inc., would move to London to head the new operation. The office will be responsible for planning and strategy of all overseas business for Daiwa, officials said.

title: Blasphemy, Not Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Backs Bill Limiting Chemical Arms Ban
description: The Senate approved legislation today that some arms-control experts warned would significantly undercut enforcement of an international treaty banning chemical weapons.

title: Debate on Campaign Finance Begins
description: In the hours before its third recess of the year, the House today sandwiched debate on the overhaul of campaign finance laws between a battle over food stamps and consideration of a public works bill. But it put off any votes on the issue until June.

title: Wyoming Is Left Out Of the Rockies' Boom; Population, Already Smallest, Is Falling
description: With the nation's smallest population, windswept Wyoming has been called a small town with a very long main street. Now that street has become a one-way highway leading out of state.

title: Excerpts From Justice Dept. Brief and Ruling on Secret Service Testimony
description: Following are an excerpt from a Justice Department brief arguing that Secret Service agents not be forced to testify before a Federal grand jury amd excerpts from the decision of Judge Norma Holloway Johnson of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia issued by the court yesterday. Notations that the decision was redacted by the court indicate sections that were eliminated to avoid violating the secrecy of grand jury proceedings.

title: Sailing by the Stars; Beepers Were an Omen
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, NANCY T.
description: SPIEGEL-Nancy T. May 22, 1998. Beloved wife of Leo. Beloved mother of Wendy. Dear friend to Ninfa. Private memorial,later date

title: Some Divided Nations Do Find a Way to Stand
description: ''Out of Ireland have we come./Great hatred, little room,/Maimed us at the start.'' William Butler Yeats's lines, written in 1931, could stand as well for scores of other quarrels in this fractious century, each feeding on great hatred, little room. Yet out of Ireland there came yesterday, from both the republican south and the British-ruled north, the prospect -- nobody would dare claim more -- of genuine peace.

title: RADIO UNICA ADDING TO SPANISH-LANGUAGE STATIONS
description: The Radio Unica Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the radio station KBLA-AM in Los Angeles from Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. for $21 million, bolstering the Spanish-language radio network's presence in the nation's largest Hispanic market. If regulators approve the purchase, the closely held Radio Unica, based in Miami, will own or operate six radio stations, all in the nation's top 10 Hispanic markets, along with a network of satellite affiliates. The Baltimore-based Sinclair Broadcast owns television and radio stations and provides programming services across the country.

title: In Slap at G.O.P. Leadership, House Stops Move to Deny Food Stamps to Immigrants
description: In a startling rebuke to the Republican leadership, the House today thwarted a conservative move to deny food stamps to a quarter of a million immigrants, leaving the fate of the legislation in doubt.

title: U.S. Companies Wary Of Their Prospects Now
description: Earlier this month, 40 American business executives on a trade mission to Indonesia met with a man who had recently been appointed Vice President. The man, B. J. Habibie, assured his skeptical visitors that unlike his predecessors, he had real power over domestic and foreign policy.

title: Switzerland Said to Have Backed Nazi Trade in Looted Gold
description: Days before an important Swiss panel rules on the extent of official Swiss connivance in a wartime trade in looted Nazi gold, declassified United States documents suggest for the first time that the Swiss Government itself endorsed the trade and that, in one instance at least, Swiss bankers deliberately sought out gold they knew to be looted.

title: When Pupil Is Threat, Schools See Dilemma
description: To sense the depth of the dilemma that school officials face when a student seems to pose a threat, consider two recent incidents in the Seattle suburb of Issaquah.

title: Op-Art; Rejected Instructions for How to Use a Subway Metrocard
Studies Must Protect the Patients; Indecent Experiments
description: To the Editor:

title: Hundley Takes Off as New Guy Moves In
description: Todd Hundley was not so shocked when the Dodgers traded Mike Piazza. He said he was more surprised that the Marlins traded Charles Johnson.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEUMAN, KENNY
description: HEUMAN-Kenny. Now the world can know Superman wasn't Clark Kent, it was Kenny Heuman. He showed us the meaning of true strength, the beauty of the mountains, the poetry of snow. He leaves behind a legacy of friendship and memories, & his loving wife Karen, his Lois Lane. She matched him strength for strength through unbearable adversity. To his children, Randi, Harvey and Cheryl & his granddaughter Alexis for whom he willed himself to stay alive until she was born. Know that his memory is for a blessing. Kal, Peggy, Brynn, Josh & Danny Dolgin

title: Herbert Chasis, 92, Leader in Kidney Research
description: Dr. Herbert Chasis, a medical researcher at New York University College of Medicine whose early analysis of how the kidney works became required reading for generations of American medical students, died on May 11 at Tisch Hospital in Manhattan. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Rivalry That Puts Red Sox to the Test
description: He said what?

title: Police Arrest Suspect In 4 Brooklyn Rapes
description: A man accused of raping four women after posing as a plumber to gain entry to their apartments was arrested in Brooklyn yesterday after a crowd noticed him peeping into windows, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAUENGLASS, WILLIAM
description: FRAUENGLASS-William. On May 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Tillie. Loving father of Richard. Dear grandfather of Neil Frauenglass and Andrew Betts. Thanks, Dad. Graveside service on Sunday, 10:30 A.M., at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Fujitsu to Post Loss As Chip Prices Fall
description: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer maker, indicated yesterday that it had lost 9.763 billion yen ($72.1 million) in the six months ended March 31 as prices of computer memory chips tumbled and growth in shipments of personal computers slowed.

title: Top General Strengthens His Grasp On Power
description: Indonesia's most powerful military man, Gen. Wiranto, consolidated his power under the country's new President today, removing his chief rival from command of troops and evicting student protesters from Parliament.

title: Don't Punish CUNY; Help Local Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Wrecks Later, a Rookie Qualifies
description: After his first crash, Jimmy Kite brought doughnuts to his team's garage the next morning. It was a rookie driver's way of apologizing for destroying another good race car.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some copies on Thursday about President Suharto's life and rule in Indonesia omitted two sources. Information in the chronology came from Reuters and The Associated Press as well as from The Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTERO, FRANK C.
description: MONTERO-Frank C. Activist; advocate of justice in all that he did in his working life especially in the area of equalizing opportunities for minorities. Father of Curle M. Lee of England, Marianne Montero of Riverdale in the Bronx, Laurie Montero of Ashland, Oregon; grandfather of Lindsey, Nicholas and Amanda; beloved brother of Marian Johnston of Seacliff, N.Y. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 6, 3PM, at the Ethical Culture Society, 4450 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, Bronx. Your family and friends will miss you but will continue to be inspired by you!

title: Steinbrenner Shrugs Off Yankees' Loss
description: George Steinbrenner picked at a plate of food in the visitors' clubhouse tonight after the Yankees had surrendered a four-run lead to the Boston Red Sox and lost, 5-4. He spoke breezily of the well-behaved Fenway Park crowd and about how nice it is that this old rivalry is revived.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day, actually May 30, will be legally observed.

title: About New York; Businessman Speaks Freely, And Pays for It
description: MOE STEIN should stick to selling shorts and sneakers rather than debating the Constitution with cops. He's a good enough salesman that his family's store, Frank's Sporting Goods on Tremont Avenue, has been a Bronx institution since the 1920's. His urge to question a police officer who was writing a ticket on a car parked near his store landed him in another institution -- the 48th Precinct station house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EAKINS, JOHN BARKLEY
description: EAKINS-John Barkley on May 21, 1998 of Naples, Florida and Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Alberta. Dear father of John Barkley Eakins Jr and grandfather of Kevin Eakins. Graveside service on Saturday at 12pm at The Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, JOHN A.
description: UNGAR-John A. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed friend and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Aine, his family and friends. Board, Staff, and Volunteers Federation to Preserve the Greenwich Village Waterfront

title: 6 Taking Viagra Die, but the F.D.A. Draws No Conclusions
description: Six people taking the impotence drug Viagra have died, the drug's maker and the Food and Drug Administration say. But the F.D.A. said it had no information linking -- or not linking -- the deaths to the drug.

title: Cabdrivers Go to Court Seeking To Restage a Quashed Protest
description: The bitter fight over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plans to impose stiff new rules on the taxi industry moved into the courts yesterday as a Federal District judge heard arguments that taxi drivers should be allowed to recreate a demonstration that was largely quashed by the police on Thursday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is not at all clear that a President would push Secret Service protection away if he were acting legally or even if he were engaged in personally embarrassing acts. Such actions are extremely unlikely to become the subject of a grand jury investigation.''

title: MERRILL LYNCH IN TALKS WITH REGENT PACIFIC GROUP
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is in talks to buy the East European and Russian businesses of Regent Pacific Group Ltd., a Hong Kong-based fund manager and securities firm, according to reports circulating in London. The purchase, which would be for $20 million to $30 million, would be the first for Merrill in Eastern Europe and would make Merrill one of Russia's five largest brokerage firms. Securities firms, including Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, SBC Warburg Dillon Read and Robert Fleming Holdings Ltd., view Russia as one of the fastest-growing emerging markets. Shares of Merrill rose $1.625 today, to $93.875.

title: $200 Billion Bill For Public Works Passed by Congress
description: Congress overwhelmingly approved today the largest public works program in the nation's history, voting to spend more than $200 billion over the next six years for roads, bridges, buses, subways, ferries and even parking garages in virtually every Congressional district.

title: Pocket Change, Not Social Change; New Deals Give New Yorkers Small but Instant Benefits
description: Sales tax cuts on clothing. Free rides on the Staten Island Ferry. Reduced express-bus fares. Suburban railroad ticket discounts. Bonus Metrocard rides on city transit and free transfers between buses and subways. E-Z Pass discounts for bridge, tunnel and New York Thruway tolls. And, thanks to the state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, planned for Thursday, customers will soon see their electricity bills cut by about 20 percent; just before Election Day, they'll be getting refund checks, too.

title: Think Tank; Banishing Racial Strife on the Wings of Love
description: When Senator Jay Billington Bulworth, played by Warren Beatty, is at the climax of his truth-telling dementia, he experiences a political epiphany: The only way to end racism in America, Bulworth tells millions of presumably shocked Americans on national television, is for the races to disappear through intermarriage. If America cannot bring itself to be colorblind, then let there be no colors.

title: Boy, 11, Is Said to Have Killed Mother's Brutal Boyfriend
description: When paramedics took the bleeding body of William Koonce from the Brooklyn apartment of his girlfriend Thursday night, neighbors thought that she had finally had enough of his drunken beatings. None suspected that the knife in his chest might have come from her son, a thoughtful 11-year-old boy known for his kindness to elderly residents and his unfailing protection of his young sister.

title: Big Board to Seek Comment on Executive Stock Plans
description: The New York Stock Exchange will start accepting comments next month on a new rule that gives member companies more leeway to adopt stock option plans without shareholder approval.

title: REIT Sets a Final Payout
description: The Americana Hotels and Realty Corporation said today that it planned to pay a final liquidating distribution of $1.16 a share on June 24 to stockholders of record on June 10. Americana, which is a real estate investment trust, or REIT, also said that it had sold its last investment, a Canyon Hotel property in Palm Springs, Calif., for $8 million. The company said that it would continue with a short-term plan to merge or sell the corporate shell, or, failing that, it would complete the liquidation plan.

title: A Punch And Out? Well, Not Exactly
description: Having served the first two games of a three-game suspension, Darryl Strawberry appealed the ruling today and was immediately reinstated. His decision had far more to do with his batting average against Tim Wakefield, Boston's starting pitcher tonight, than any dispute with the harshness of his penalty.

title: Union Says Air Control System Will Be Unsafe
description: A billion-dollar air traffic control system that is scheduled to start service next spring will jeopardize air safety, the union representing the technicians who will maintain it says, because it lacks alarms and monitoring systems to give warning when it is beginning to fail.

title: Journal; Prime Time Live
description: Few movies nailed the 1960's before they became The Sixties more presciently than did ''The Graduate'' and ''Bonnie and Clyde.'' This year the catalysts for those classics -- Mike Nichols and Warren Beatty -- have returned with ubiquitously publicized comedies, ''Primary Colors'' and ''Bulworth,'' that have been hailed by a press bandwagon for capturing the Clinton 90's. Both give us a politician whose liberal ideals have been compromised by worldly temptations -- whether campaign contributors bearing big bucks or campaign groupies bearing big hair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVELL, LILLIAN (NEE LEVINE)
description: SHEVELL-Lillian (nee Levine). On May 22, 1998. Age 91. Wife of the late Nathan A. Shevell. Beloved mother of Myron (Mike) Shevell, Janice Fischman and the late Daniel E. Shevell. Also survived by eight grandchildren and eight great grandchildren.

title: Dealer in U.S. Debt Is Ending Operations
description: Eastbridge Capital Inc., one of the 36 primary dealers that deal directly with the Federal Reserve's securities trading desk, said yesterday that it was closing down operations.

title: Piazza Deal Draws Cheers, But Mets' Pitchers Do, Too
description: Every time Mike Piazza's name was announced over the public address system at Shea Stadium last night the crowd cheered, even though Piazza will not play his first game as a Met until this afternoon.

title: Inspections Of 747 Parts Are Advised
description: The Boeing Company today advised airlines operating its 747's to inspect fuel tank wiring and related parts on some older models, after the investigation into the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 discovered conditions that might add to the risk of fire or explosion.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROPERTIES LIFTS U.S. HOLDINGS
description: The International Properties Corporation bought 24 office and retail properties yesterday for $350 million, the biggest single foray by the Canadian developer Paul Reichmann into the United States real estate market since his Olympia & York Developments Ltd. collapsed earlier this decade. The purchase includes 18 office properties and 6 shopping centers, with a total of 3.54 million square feet in various cities, including Louisville, Ky.; Wichita, Kan., and Manchester, N.H. The seller was Intell Investment and Management, according to the Grubb & Ellis Company, the broker that handled the sale. Intell will reinvest the proceeds into its New York holdings, including the development of the 50-story Planet Hollywood Hotel in Times Square. Both it and International Properties are closely held.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Arts Education Week in New York City misidentified the school affiliated with the New York City Ballet. It is the School of American Ballet, not the School of Ballet.

title: Second Man Is Charged in Voodoo Burn Case
description: A second man has been charged in New Jersey with trying to kill a Haitian immigrant during a voodoo ceremony that left the immigrant, a woman, badly burned, officials said yesterday.

title: Black Officers on Patrol For Racial Profiling
description: More than 75 black police officers from New Jersey and New York plan to patrol the New Jersey Turnpike over the Memorial Day weekend to watch for signs that the state police are stopping motorists based on their race.

title: Wounded Teen-Ager Is Called a Hero
description: On Thursday, his 17th birthday, Jacob Ryker was sitting with friends in the school cafeteria, waiting for classes to begin, when a boy in a trench coat walked in and began shooting.

title: Bill to Punish Giving Missile Help to Iran Passes in Senate
description: The Senate voted nearly unanimously today to punish foreign enterprises or institutions -- especially those in Russia -- that provide sensitive missile technology or expertise to Iran.

title: Don't Punish CUNY; Help Local Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Weekend Brings a Rush for Some Time Away
description: Tall ships slipped up the Hudson, sailors in dress whites were on the town, commuters made an early getaway and hundreds of thousands of travelers thronged airports and highways across the New York metropolitan region yesterday as the long Memorial Day weekend, the informal start of summer, got under way.

title: Religion Journal; In New York, 2 Buddhist Celebrations
description: Over the last year, Buddhism has enjoyed a high profile in the United States. Movies like ''Seven Years in Tibet'' and ''Kundun,'' a Time magazine cover and, most recently, a visit by the Dalai Lama to the United States have, to one degree or another, all put the dharma in view.
