title: Holstein Calves Cloned From Cells, Paper Says
description: Nearly 15 months after the publication of the landmark scientific paper announcing the creation of Dolly the sheep, the first paper has appeared extending cloning to another species. This time the clones are Holstein calves, created from genetically engineered fetal cells.

title: Irish Turn Out in Large Numbers; Exit Polls Show a Vote for Accord
description: In overwhelming numbers, the people of Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic voted today in a referendum that would transform the island's political institutions and social traditions.

title: John William Berry Sr., 75; Made Fortune on Yellow Pages
description: John William Berry Sr., a philanthropist who made a fortune taking the Yellow Pages global, died on Wednesday at Miami Valley Hospital in Dayton, Ohio. He was 75 and lived in New Carlisle, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELLER, BELLE
description: ZELLER-Belle. The Professional Staff Congress mourns the passing of our founding President Emeritus Professor Belle Zeller. Prof. Zeller was not only an outstanding leader of the faculty but she was also an unrelenting advocate for The City University of New York. Dr. Zeller established a national reputation for our union and for our University. Even though she was retired as a Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College for more than twenty-five years, she still actively participated in affairs that affected The City University of New York. We will deeply miss her. Irwin H. Polishook, President Professional Staff Congress City University of New York

title: Clinton Tells of Anti-Terrorism Plans
description: Warning that ''we must be ready to fight the next war, not the last one,'' President Clinton announced measures today to guard against terrorism.

title: Trying to Make 'Hamlet' Less Depressing
description: Welcome to Elsinore, the party capital of Northern Europe! Gertrude, the glamorous Queen of Denmark, has just gotten married again, to her late husband's brother, and the revels of these hard-living sophisticates are in full swing. The music is blaring, the balloons are afloat, the lights are bright. The recently crowned King is groping his bride in full view of the guests. And when a grumpy ghost shows up on the dance floor, he at least has the good taste to wear a smart set of evening clothes.

title: Don't Punish CUNY; Help Local Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: An Arts Revival Grows in New York Schools
description: New York City schools, enjoying the biggest infusion of money for art and music in more than two decades, are bringing back orchestras and field trips and art classes that had been dropped as luxuries during budget crises.

title: Rome Journal; 3-Step Justice System: Conviction, Appeal, Escape
description: It seemed like a gaffe worthy of Inspector Clouseau: Pasquale Cuntrera, a Mafia boss convicted of drug trafficking and released on a technicality, this week managed to evade his police monitors and escape in his wheelchair.

title: Masur's Interpretation Invites Another Listen to 'Leningrad'
description: Shostakovich's Symphony No. 7, the ''Leningrad,'' has always presented listeners with a full slate of structural, philosophical and historical problems, but it seems to be gathering champions. Kurt Masur, whose performances of the Shostakovich symphonies have been highlights of his tenure at the New York Philharmonic, is clearly among the work's partisans, and on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, he led the Philharmonic in a performance that was so finely polished, driven and intensely dramatic that listeners with doubts about the work's musical merits had reason to reconsider.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINKOFF, DUSSIA
description: MINKOFF-Dussia. The Officers, staff and members of the Jewish Labor Committee note with sadness the passing of Dussia Minkoff, longtime member of the JLC, and widow of Isaiah Minkoff, former Executive Director of our organization. Our sympathies to son, Paul, daughter, Nina, and their families. Funeral: Sunday, May 24, 12 noon at Plaza Memorial, 91 St & Amsterdam. Shiva: Monday, May 25, at 200 Haven Avenue Lenore Miller, President Avram Lyon, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKEER, JUDY
description: SKEER-Judy, 95. On May 21. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Jacob. Loving mother of Fred & motherin-law of Barbara. Devoted grandmother of Jeffrey and Kenneth. Services Tuesday, 10AM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J), Brooklyn, New York.

title: Attack Hits Home for Many in a Middle-Class Neighborhood Both Modern and Rural
description: First, a chain-link fence was erected outside the suburban high school here to keep out deer. Then gates were added to keep out drug dealers. Today the fence bore flowers, poems and prayers in memory of teen-agers shot by a fellow student.

title: Floyd G. Lounsbury, 84, Expert In Decoding Mayan Hieroglyphs
description: Floyd G. Lounsbury, who brought an anthropologist's eye to the study of American Indian languages and helped decipher the hieroglyphs of the Maya, died on May 14 at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 84 and lived in East Haven, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIRIS, BURT J.
description: SIRIS-Burt J. Always remembered Always loved Linda and Helin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOELET, FRANCIS
description: GOELET-Francis. 1926-1998. Died at his home in Riverside, Conn, May 21st. Son of Robert Walton Goelet and Anne Marie Guestier. Survived by his sister, Beatrice G. Manice and two brothers, Robert G. Goelet and John Goelet. A patron of the arts and a businessman who looked after his family interests, he will be deeply missed by his friends and relatives. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Recorded Anthology of American Music, c/o New World Records, 701 Seventh Ave., New York, New York 10036.

title: McCall Wins Court Order For Records
description: In a unanimous ruling by an appeals panel of the State Supreme Court, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was ordered this week to release records long sought by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall in his effort to study the effectiveness of six city agencies.

title: What They Meant to Say
description: Highlights from 1998 graduation addresses that may not have been given but should have been:

title: On Road to Jersey Shore, Little Enthusiasm for Plan to Raise Gas Tax
description: Here at the Garden State Parkway's Cheesequake rest area, an oasis of fast food and gas pumps on the long asphalt trail to the Jersey Shore, southbound motorists were somewhat predisposed to smiles and contentment today, the start of the Memorial Day weekend.

title: At the End of a Long Trek, Ulster's Apostle of Peace Is Still Trekking
description: In the last days before the referendum on the new Northern Ireland peace agreement, John Hume was still trudging through the towns and villages, continuing his life's work: trying to persuade Catholics and Protestants that a negotiated peace is better than endless sectarian warfare that leaves their loved ones dead in the streets.

title: Just Do It? Nah, Just Study It!; Working Up a Sweat Over the Deep Meaning of Sport
description: On the first day of class in her course ''Sport and Contemporary America,'' Professor Cheryl Cole of the University of Illinois distributes photographs of Michael Jordan and then asks the students a question: What do they see?

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas'' misidentified the actor who provides narration between scenes in the movie. He is Johnny Depp, not Donald Morrow. (Mr. Morrow's voice is heard in a scene in which a film clip is played at a drug law-enforcement conference.)

title: Sailing by the Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: Oregon Freshman Goes to Court As Number of Deaths Rises to 4
description: A skinny high school freshman whose obsession with guns and bombs was all but ignored by adults at a school strapped for counselors, was formally accused of four counts of murder today, not long after a second student died here from the Thursday shootings at Thurston High School.

title: Frank Lovell, Marxist Leader And Writer, 84
description: Frank Lovell, an American disciple of Leon Trotsky's brand of Marxism-Leninism and a New York City writer and editor concerned with socialist and trade-union issues, died on May 1 at his home in the East Village. He was 84.

title: Patches of Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New McNally Play Canceled After Protests and Threats
description: Bowing to what it called security problems that are reported to have included bomb threats, the Manhattan Theater Club has canceled its production of a play by Terence McNally that a Roman Catholic civil rights group complained depicts a Jesus-like character having sex with the Twelve Apostles.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a vote by the shareholders of Marriott International Inc. against a plan to have two classes of stock misstated the symbol under which the single stock will trade. It is MAR, not MAR.A.

title: TRIZECHAHN OF CANADA ADDS OFFICE BUILDINGS
description: The TrizecHahn Corporation, a Canadian real estate concern, said yesterday that it had acquired an office building in Memphis and one in Maryland for a total of $77 million. TrizecHahn, based in Toronto, bought the Clark Tower in Memphis, for $55 million, and Silver Spring Center in Silver Spring, Md., for about $22 million. The buildings total 870,000 square feet. The company spent $1.2 billion in the first quarter on office acquisitions, mainly in Toronto and Washington.

title: CYBEX IN ACQUISITION OF TECTRIX FITNESS EQUIPMENT
description: Cybex International Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Tectrix Fitness Equipment Inc., a maker of cardiovascular fitness equipment. Financial terms were not disclosed. Cybex International said Tectrix had 1997 revenues of more than $30 million. Cybex, based in Medway, Mass., said it planned to consolidate the two company's general, administrative, sales and marketing functions. Tectrix, based in Irvine, Calif., makes Climb Max stair climbers, Bike Max stationary bikes, treadmills, climbers and associated products. Cybex makes strength and cardiovascular equipment. Its shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $10.25.

title: In a Gothic Tale, the Evil Feels Modern
description: If Wilkie Collins were alive today, he would undoubtedly be in Hollywood, demanding hefty fees for screenplays that cater to a late-20th-century taste for glossy luridness. As it was, Collins was a British lawyer who spent most of his time writing novels that catered to 19th-century popular tastes and often appeared serially in a magazine run by his friend Charles Dickens.

title: Brazil Phone Company Breakup Approved
description: Brazil's Government today approved the breakup of the state-controlled telephone company Telecomunicacoes Brasileiras S.A., known as Telebras, into 12 holding companies. The move was a key step in preparations for the company's planned $20 billion sale in July.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Frank Sinatra's funeral in Beverly Hills, Calif., included an attribution error and a punctuation error in a quotation from a eulogy provided by The Associated Press. It was Gregory Peck, not Frank Sinatra Jr., who referred to Mr. Sinatra as a ''reckless rogue, sentimental fella.'' The phrase, which also appeared in a subheading, should not have had a comma after ''reckless.'' The A.P., one of the few news organizations represented at the church service, later corrected its account, but the revision went astray at The Times.

title: Microsoft Case Is Set for Trial In September
description: Rejecting the Microsoft Corporation's request for a considerable delay, a United States District Court judge ordered a fast-track schedule this morning for the Federal and state lawsuits filed against the software company on Monday, setting a trial date just three and a half months from today.

title: Computer and Drug Shares Pull Lethargic Market Down
description: Stocks fell yesterday in one of the slowest trading days of the year. Computing issues led the market lower on continuing worries about Asia's slump and earnings growth.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON UP 2.1 PERCENT. Prices closed at a seven-week high on fear that hot, dry weather in the South will further reduce a crop already expected to be the smallest in five years. July contracts rose 1.41 cents, to 67.99 cents a pound.

title: Microsoft Case Gets September Trial Date
description: A Federal judge rejected Microsoft's request for a considerable delay, and ordered a fast-track schedule for the Federal and state lawsuits that were filed against the software company on Monday, setting a trial date for Sept. 8.

title: Mush! Mush! The Eyes of Texas Are Upon Stars-Wings as Final 4 Begins
description: Mighty television, all-seeing and all-knowing, will be served. The Fox network, hoping to stop the melting of its hockey ratings with late-spring Sunday games of the Stanley Cup playoffs, will resume its coverage this weekend with the conference finals and will continue through mid-June, when the championship will finally be determinded.

title: Sports of The Times; The Right Man Faces a Hard Choice
description: I HAD barely settled into the back seat of his taxi when Bill Race, eyeing his fare through a crooked rearview mirror asked, ''You from St. John's?''

title: Prosecutors Subpoena Records on Underwriting in Lilco Deal
description: Federal prosecutors have issued subpoenas in an investigation into how the state's Long Island Power Authority selected bond underwriters for its partial takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, said people involved with the transaction.

title: Two Admit Bribing West New York Police
description: Two business owners in West New York, N.J., have pleaded guilty in a widening corruption case to making payments to police officers so they would ignore illegal after-hours bars and gambling operations, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Cuomo Criticizes Call for Stadium Referendum
description: Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has been acting as an unpaid adviser to George M. Steinbrenner 3d, says a November referendum that would decide whether the city should use tax money to help finance a ball park for the Yankees in Manhattan would be a big mistake that could drive the team from New York.

title: A 1995 Executive Pay Plan Led to Big Bonus This Week
description: Lots of people check the price of their stocks every day, but probably no one watched more closely this week than the three top executives of Computer Associates, a Long Island software company known for how richly it compensates its chief executive, Charles B. Wang.

title: Russian Oil Concern May Bid for Rival
description: Lukoil Holding said it might bid for Sidanco, a smaller oil company worth about $2.55 billion, a move that would allow Lukoil to remain Russia's biggest oil company and give it needed refining capacity.

title: Papers Show White House Staff Favored a China Satellite Permit
description: The White House released a trove of internal documents today showing that President Clinton approved the Chinese launching of an American satellite last February after his top staff advised him that the economic and diplomatic advantages outweighed the opposition of Federal prosecutors.

title: A Tragedy Repeated in History
description: The longing for a bygone age -- a time when life was slower, sweeter, simpler -- is such a basic human impulse that it often blinds us to the fact that the good old days were less than ideal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMMERS SCHAUER, DIANA
description: STAMMERS SCHAUER-Diana. of Palm Desert, California. Formerly of New York and Surrey, England. Died May 19, 1998. She is survived by her husband Joseph R. Schauer, and her brother Michael Stammers. Services to be held at Church of Religious Science of the Desert, Palm Desert, California, on May 27th, 2 P.M. Reception following at the church.

title: Text of Correspondence on Waiver to Permit Satellite Export
description: Following are the text of a letter from Thomas B. Ross, vice president of Government Relations at Loral Space and Communications, to Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, and the text of a memorandum for the President prepared by Mr. Berger; Larry Stein, the White House Congressional liaison, and Daniel K. Tarullo, then assistant to the President for international economic policy. The memorandum, which was declassified on Thursday, was dated Feb. 12 and dealt with a Presidential national-interest waiver for the Chinasat 8 communications satellite project by Loral. The letter from Mr. Ross was dated Feb. 13.

title: Mets Get Piazza's Power at Bat and at the Gate
description: The Mets, who manage to win more games than they lose without generating much offense or drawing many fans, decided to do something about both problems yesterday. They acquired the slugger Mike Piazza from the Florida Marlins in exchange for three minor leaguers, giving themselves a bona fide cleanup hitter, a more legitimate chance in the National League's wild-card race and a more compelling reason for people to fill the seats at Shea Stadium.

title: S.& L. Expands Pledge on Loans
description: Washington Mutual Inc., whose $9.8 billion purchase of H. F. Ahmanson & Company is pending, said today that it was designating $120 billion for loans to lower-income consumers and communities over 10 years.

title: Muzzling Yugoslavia's Media
description: Slobodan Milosevic is at it again. The Serbian leader has now essentially banned the voices he fears most, Yugoslavia's independent radio and television stations. He apparently believes that he can get away with it because the world is concerned with the growing conflict in Kosovo, and with trying to get Mr. Milosevic to agree to serious, internationally supervised talks there. But the media are the only voices in Serbia that ever challenge his nationalist assault on Kosovo. Preserving them is crucial for a settlement in Kosovo and to keep alive any hopes of democracy in Serbia.

title: Deutsche Bank Shares Rise on Merger Rumor
description: Shares of Deutsche Bank A.G. rose as much as 3 percent yesterday on speculation Germany's largest bank could merge with the Chase Manhattan Corporation. Deutsche Bank declined to comment, citing a bank policy of not discussing market speculation. Deutsche Bank shares rose 1.8 marks to close at 160.7 marks, down from a high of 164.65 marks earlier in the day. At the beginning of the day the shares had fallen because shares traded now are no longer eligible for the 1997 dividend of 1.80 marks.

title: For Some In Republic: The Vote? What Vote?
description: To judge by Ireland's most popular radio talk show, all the weeks of campaign polemics leading up to today's referendum on the Northern Ireland peace pact have left the voters weary and ready to listen to something else.

title: Big Board Seat Is Sold
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold for $1.35 million on Thursday, down from the previous sale of $1.4 million on Tuesday. It was the third time the price of a seat had slipped since setting a record of $2 million on March 9. The most an investor is willing to pay for one of the exchange's 1,366 seats now is $1.325 million and the lowest price at which an owner is willing to sell is $1.775 million, the exchange said.

title: CISCO SYSTEMS PLANS SILICON VALLEY LAND PURCHASES
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase 230 acres in California's Silicon Valley to be used for future growth. Financial terms were not disclosed. Cisco, which supplies data networking products, bought 80 acres in Milpitas and 150 acres in San Jose, where the company is based. The company said it had no immediate plans for construction, but that ultimately the land could accommodate 16 to 19 buildings for nearly 10,000 more employees. About 8,500 of Cisco's 13,000 employees worldwide work in the San Francisco Bay area.

title: Some Japanese Banks Report Largest Losses Ever
description: Six of Japan's biggest banks reported their largest annual losses ever today, a result of an effort to slash unrepaid loans and put the worst of a mountainous burden of bad debt behind them.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Barry's Decision Welcomed at Capitol
description: While Marion S. Barry Jr.'s decision not to seek re-election as mayor of the District of Columbia heartened a dozen would-be successors, the more profound impact of his departure is likely to occur on Capitol Hill.

title: New Candidate Joins Race To Lead Teamsters Union
description: The head of the teamsters' 250,000-member warehouse division announced yesterday that he would challenge James P. Hoffa for the union's presidency after union officials indicated that another challenger to Mr. Hoffa was withdrawing from the race because of medical problems.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CACI INTERNATIONAL INC., Arlington, Va., a provider of information technology services, said it planned to buy Questech Inc., Falls Church, Va., another information technology company, for $35 million in cash and $7 million in assumed debt.

title: Sports of The Times; Hard Part Is Keeping Piazza Here
description: IN THE era of the rent-a-player, commitment does not come easily. If it did, Mike Piazza would still be in Los Angeles, bound to the Dodgers by contract and by heart, making five figures a year the way Campy and Hodges and Pee Wee and Duke did for their entire careers.

title: Blurting, Bending, Bunching and Phrasing
description: For their third tune Tuesday night at Iridium, the saxophonist Joe Lovano and the pianist Gonzalo Rubalcaba played an Ornette Coleman composition, ''Bird Food,'' and all of their empathetic abilities were evident. The tune dissolved; Mr. Lovano, on soprano saxophone, broke up his phrases, blurting out single bent notes or querulous short phrases. Mr. Rubalcaba followed, plastering chunks of silence between splayed chords, or his own single notes. They were making music out of nothing.

title: Jefferson's Other Family?
description: To the Editor:

title: Shareholders and Corporate Hiring
description: Five years ago the Securities and Exchange Commission decided that the shareholders of American companies had no right to vote on the hiring policies of the companies. Now the commission has rightly, if belatedly, reversed course.

title: Francis Goelet, Philanthropist And Music Lover, 72, Is Dead
description: Francis Goelet, a philanthropist who underwrote the commissions for dozens of new musical works, many opera productions and an important contemporary music recording project, died on Thursday at his home in Riverside, Conn. He was 72.

title: Best N.Y. Buildings Don't Need Signs to Advertise
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslav Leader Curbs TV and Radio
description: As part of a drive to consolidate power that was lost after huge street protests more than a year ago, President Slobodan Milosevic has used federal licensing authorities to clamp down on independent radio and television stations.

title: Buying Spree From U.S. Sets Record in Asia
description: United States takeovers of Asian companies have hit a record this year, reflecting the economic distress in parts of Asia and the opportunities that many American buyers see in picking up valuable businesses at bargain prices.

title: Man on Cellular Phone Slightly Injured by Train
description: It's a good bet that Heath Hess will check his whereabouts the next time he makes a call on his cellular phone.

title: Crafty Abortion Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorker's Top Executive Is Replaced
description: Thomas A. Florio, the president of The New Yorker, was moved out of his job yesterday by his older brother, Steven T. Florio, the president and chief executive of the magazine's parent company, Conde Nast Publications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWARTLER, HARRY F.
description: KWARTLER-Harry F. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mr. Harry F. Kwartler, an esteemed member, and extend to his beloved wife Pearl and family its deepest sympathy. Saul Friedland, President Sidney Gottlieb, Secretary

title: First Ladies to the First Lady
description: WHITE HOUSE social secretary. Just the sound of it conjures another time -- ballrooms dotted with decolletage and long white gloves. The social secretary herself might be a tall, no-nonsense-type woman, her tiny black books holding the private numbers of all the right people, happy to be summoned at a moment's notice.

title: May 17-23; Tobacco Bill Weighed
description: Supporters called the anti-smoking bill before the Senate the most important public health measure to reach Congress in years. Opponents said it was a large tax increase on the poorest Americans. Both were right.

title: Men's Swim Trunks Pay Homage to 007
description: CHOOSING a swimsuit has long been one of women's most beleaguering style rituals. But with men's bodies increasingly subjected to the same kind of rigorous standards that women have long faced (consider the rising rate of male liposuction), the inequality in dressing-room anxiety is narrowing.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HAWAII

title: Patricia Ryan, William Knox
description: Patricia Ann Ryan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Ryan of Hinsdale, Ill., was married yesterday to William Upshaw Knox, a son of Elizabeth Knox of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late William B. Knox. The Rev. Aidan Hynes performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church in Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Travel With Mom
description: To the Editor: I smiled as I read Melissa Balmain's ''Roughing It With Mom: Nurture in Nature'' (May 10). Every summer my mother, who lives in Puerto Rico, comes up to New York to visit las nenas (the girls). My sisters always steer clear of my bonding time with Mami. I guess they know better.

title: P. W. Manchester, 91, a Critic And Expert on History of Dance
description: P. W. Manchester, a Britain-born critic with wide-ranging interests who edited important dance magazines in London and New York, co-edited a dance encyclopedia and taught dance history, died on Monday at Deaconess Hospital in Cincinnati. She was 91 and lived in Clifton, Ohio.

title: Yeshivish at Yale
description: As Batsheva Greer was leaving a class several months ago, she mentioned to a fellow Yale freshman that she needed to make a telephone call. The classmate invited Batsheva to use the phone in her dormitory room. And the offer filled Batsheva with distress.

title: IRISH VOTERS, NORTH AND SOUTH, GIVE RESOUNDING 'YES' TO PEACE
description: The voters of Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic have given overwhelming support to the peace agreement aimed at settling the sectarian conflict that has convulsed their island for centuries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, THOMAS
description: JONES-Thomas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas Jones, associated with The Times from 1977, until retiring in 1983.

title: An Airlift Marks the Beginning of the Cold War
description: June 1948. A defeated Germany had been carved into four occupation zones by the wartime allies Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. Berlin, laid within the Soviet zone, but was controlled by all four powers. On June 24, Stalin lay siege to the city's three western zones by blockading all land, rail and canal access, holding the city hostage as he tried to prevent the West from creating a unified West Germany.

title: A Top Clinton Donor Says Money Didn't Buy Approval on Satellites
description: In the six years that Bernard L. Schwartz built a friendship with President Clinton -- fortified with $1.3 million in donations to the President and his party -- the 72-year-old New York aerospace executive stresses that he never asked for special treatment.

title: SUNDAY: May 24, 1998: Gear; Mayhem Is Our Business
description: Spring is a busy time at Defense Technology Corporation of America, a company that manufactures ''less lethal'' munitions, like tear gas, for use by police and the military. Every May, jittery law-enforcement officials call from N.B.A.-playoff cities, afraid their team will bring home the world championship and its attendant civil disorder. The answer from the Casper, Wyo., company? Relax. The proper crowd-control tools are just a phone call away.

title: Herbal Tobacco Substitutes On Rise and So Are Worries
description: A growing number of herbal substitutes for cigarettes and snuff are being sold in convenience stores, smoke shops and health food stores, directed at people who are trying to quit smoking or who want the look and feel of smoking or snuff chewing without the tobacco.

title: Ending a Recital Year With a Commencement
description: FOR the past three years, a free Commencement Concert has marked the official conclusion of the Yale University recital year. The event is meant to acquaint parents and friends of graduating students with music at Yale as well as allowing regular concertgoers to enjoy one more performance by students at Sprague Memorial Hall. That said, today's 4 o'clock Commencement Concert program lists works for various combinations of piano, voice, winds, brass and percussion by Schubert, Debussy, Barber and a graduating Yale composer, Roshanne Etezady. No admission is charged.

title: Baron Plows More Into Vail Resorts
description: HAPPY Memorial Day weekend. But please forgive Ronald Baron, the chief executive of Baron Capital Management, if his thoughts these days are turning more toward downhill and slalom than beach and surf. The hot-handed fund manager has bought four million shares of Vail Resorts Inc., the storied Colorado ski complex, raising his stake to 31 percent of the outstanding shares, from 19.3 percent.

title: Just Desserts
description: I was relieved to read Colman's article. I am past 80 and have been a useful and productive citizen all my life. I've been there and done that. Now, when I tell friends I am not interested in ''doing'' anymore, they say, ''You are in depression.'' Really!

title: Crack Down on Rage, Not Guns; Too Easy to Get Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Challenge That Tests Teamwork In a Family
description: Monice Giakoumakis had been away from her home in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, for less than a day and she was already missing her mother's cooking. ''What are we having for lunch?'' Monice, 13, asked as she walked through the woods of Camp Hidden Valley on her way to the dining hall.

title: Alina Arenal and David Pogrebin
description: Alina Arenal, the daughter of Electa R. Arenal of New York and Marcial Rodriguez-Brossoise of Jim Thorpe, Pa., is to be married this afternoon to David Malcolm Pogrebin, the son of the writer Letty Cottin Pogrebin and Bertrand B. Pogrebin of New York. Rabbi Mychal Springer is to officiate at the Old Tavern in Grafton, Vt.

title: Whit Stillman's Theory of Group Dynamics
description: A FEW weeks ago, Whit Stillman had several notes taped on the wall of the sound studio where he was working on his new film, ''The Last Days of Disco.'' Among the notes, mostly jokes and reminiscences, was one line of dialogue from the movie: ''We can change our context but we can't change ourselves.''

title: Food; Dr. Peel Good
description: The simple but exacting act of zesting a lemon can engender a Zen state of mind. The fruit to be scalped rests in the palm of one hand, while the other grasps the peeler and negotiates between the rind and the spongy part beneath. The rind is packed with an aromatic oil so powerful as to change the odor of a large room (not to mention adding a clean edge to savory dishes and a subtle perfume to bread and cake). The pith, or albedo, on the other hand, is dense with pectin, a soluble fiber bitter enough to wreak havoc on almost any dish. The cook must therefore tease apart this nearly inextricable mesh of pleasure and pain. Every citrus fruit is different. And only the practiced hand knows the precise force necessary to lift the golden peel from the bitter dross.

title: Voss Beats Criss In Title Match
description: With two children and a mortgage, even a bowling veteran like Brian Voss can feel the pressure after failing to earn money in four straight tournaments.

title: Jewelry: Pharmacy Chic
description: Louis Hohenstein's passion for fashioning pharmaceuticals into jewelry may draw some unexpected consequences (Sunday: ''Jewelry: Pharmacy Chic,'' May 3). It appears that he is delivering controlled substances without a license. Although it could be argued that Hohenstein's treatment of dipping the pills in urethane changes the nature and purpose of these controlled substances into art, I would doubt that the same treatment on rocks of crack cocaine would be viewed as legal by law enforcement. I am not trying to inject a poison pill into your article. However, I would be careful not to wear such jewelry when traveling to, say, Turkey or Singapore.

title: For Future Mozarts, No Place To Shine?
description: THERE used to be a theory of Western music that great works -- which according to this theory will often be derided when they are new, and if they do indeed so offend, will only thereby prove their greatness -- eventually take their places in the repertory and are loved by all. Throughout the 19th century, and for a decade or two thereafter, it kind of worked. Compositions by Schumann and Chopin, Wagner and Verdi, Brahms and Debussy all became valued alongside those of Mozart and Beethoven.

title: Ms. Goetcheus And Mr. Wolf
description: Victoria Gray Goetcheus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon M. Goetcheus of Brooklyn, is to be married this afternoon to Kenneth Jon Wolf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Wolf of Hicksville, N.Y. The Rev. Terrence W. Ryan is to perform the ceremony at the First Church of Christ Congregational in Sharon, Conn.

title: Mr. Hochman and Ms. Pershan
description: Pamela Pershan and Alexander Bruce Hochman are to be married today at the University Club in New York. Rabbi David Posner is to perform the ceremony.

title: Liberties; A Hug From Bill And Tony
description: There is an old Gaelic saying, ''Never bolt the door with a boiled carrot.''

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Mia Kelly, James Walton
description: Marguerite Grace Kelly and James John Walton were married yesterday at the Old Post Chapel at Fort Meyer, Va. The Rev. William E. Hartgen Jr., a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, SIMON D.
description: STRAUSS-Simon D., 86. Of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Lenox, MA., May 22, 1998. Peacefully at home of cancer. He was the husband of Janet M. Strauss for 15 years following the death of Elaine M. Strauss; the father of Peter L. Strauss of Hastings-on-Hudson and Susan D. Orr of Sacramento, CA.; the grandfather of Katie Thomas and David Samuel Orr and Benjamin and Bethany Strauss; and the great-grandfather of Gwen and Bevan Thomas. He will be greatly missed by them and so many others for his wisdom & the enormous strength and generosity of his soul. As he wanted, his funeral will be private, and a memorial service will be held for his extended family and many friends in New York City in September. Contributions can be sent to the Simon and Elaine Strauss Fund at Barnard College or to the Manhattan School for Music.

title: Revolutionary Fort Held Hostage to Decay and Apathy
description: THE name of Fort Montgomery does not appear very often in American history books. And although it has been listed as a National Historic Landmark since 1972, it has no particular fame, is not a part of American military lore, contains no distinguished service academy and thin gray line, is never mentioned in public schools and millions of people do not flock to see it. Those honors are reserved for its esteemed next-door neighbor, West Point.

title: Lakers' Young Guns Nearing Summer Recess
description: It was near the end of the third quarter on Friday night, and Shaquille O'Neal had sawed a 9-point Utah lead down to 1 with a lay-in inches from the rim. Noise and expectation flooded the Great Western Forum, whose scoreboard quickly flashed two messages:

title: Help Wanted: School Superintendent
description: When Bert Nelson, Superintendent of the Hewlett-Woodmere School District, announced he would be retiring at the end of this school year, there were about 50 applications submitted for his position -- far fewer, he said, than had been expected.

title: A Catcher Stirs Dreams Of Brilliant Tomorrows
description: When the Mets announced the acquisition of the All-Star catcher Mike Piazza on Friday, the phone began ringing with inquiries about season-ticket packages. That is called a ripple effect.

title: F.Y.I.
description: City Milk's Hard Life

title: Debra Rosenberg And David Levy
description: Debra Lisa Rosenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Rosenberg of Miami, is to be married this evening to David Evan Levy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. Levy of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Barry Tabachnikoff is to officiate at the Westin Resort Miami Beach.

title: Sinatra's True Legacy: The Singing Itself; The Voice That Defined The Jet Age
description: FRANK Sinatra transformed the interpretation of popular song, imparting a deeper and darker understanding of lyrics while pioneering a rhythmic mid-ground between pop's gentility and jazz's swing.

title: Giuliani to Bar Food Vendors On 144 Blocks
description: Pressed by business owners eager to ease the sidewalk congestion around their office towers, the Giuliani administration has agreed to ban food carts from 144 blocks of Manhattan, including nearly the entire financial district and two large swaths of midtown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIS, JACK
description: REIS-Jack. Of North Lauderdale, FL., formerly of NYC, died May 21st, 1998 at 89 years of age. Jack is survived by Marion, his wife of 62 years, son, Michael, daughterin-law, Leslie, and grandchildren, Aaron and Rachelle. Services to be held at Menorah Chapel, Sunrise, FL, on Sunday, May 24.

title: I Want to Be a Chairborne Ranger: Boot Camp for the Office
description: IT'S Thursday afternoon, the rain is rattling rooftops and workers from the Vandor Corporation are huddled in a tent in the middle of nowhere, dressed in Army fatigues and combat boots. One of them is about to be named platoon leader, the person in charge, and right now they all wish they were invisible.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Westport, Conn.; Close to Manhattan, Rich in Resources
description: WIDELY known as a favorite hideaway of the rich and famous, Westport has a celebrity-driven cachet. And young families are attracted by the town's exceptional school system, a wide range of recreational opportunities and a strong sense of community.

title: Our Towns; A Candidate Talks of Revolt On the Radio
description: RANDALL TERRY, nationally syndicated radio talk show host, ''the voice of insurrection,'' is on a roll. The topic of the day is taxes, taxes and more taxes, which Mr. Terry, the founder of Operation Rescue, says he hates almost as much as abortion.

title: Cultural Traditions Make a Difference
description: In the polyglot of communities in and around Los Angeles, ethnic heritage, more than class, can determine whether cash gifts are offered.

title: Iran's Tension Underscored In Celebrating Its President
description: A year after an election that changed the face of Iranian politics, students and ordinary Iranians rallied by the tens of thousands here today to revel in the openness instilled by the new President, Mohammad Khatami.

title: 'A Mother's Place'
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicole Maxwell, a Bold Seeker Of Medical Herbs, Dies at 92
description: Nicole Maxwell, a free-spirited San Francisco debutante who plunged into the remote Amazon jungles of Ecuador and Peru and came out with a trove of medicinal plants that she said Indians used to cure virtually every known ailment, died on May 5 in a nursing home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 92, and left no immediate survivors.

title: Piazza Swings a Bat and Suddenly It's the 80's
description: Not long before Mike Piazza strode to the plate for his first at-bat in a Mets uniform yesterday afternoon, the team's co-owner, Fred Wilpon, was speaking wistfully of the feeling of electricity that used to exist at Shea Stadium and how he hoped Piazza could help bring that energy back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, RUTH
description: ROSS-Ruth. Died on May 16, 1998, in Florida, after a long illness. Beloved wife of Norman, mother of David & Jane, four grandchildren, Jason, Leah, Brittany, and Ian.

title: Correction
description: Two picture captions with classical-music listings in the Summer Festivals section on May 10 were reversed. The string ensemble on page 47 was the Pacifica Quartet, which is to perform at the Cape and Islands Chamber Music Festival on Cape Cod in August; the Baroque ensemble on page 52 was Musica Pacifica, which is to perform at the Berkeley Festival and Exhibition in June.

title: But You Said 'Casual'
description: As the weather improves, so does the climate for casual days, those corporately sanctioned breaches of formal office wear. Who wears what on casual day in your office, and does any of the attire make you pine for a bit less latitude in personal style? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Alternative Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: Rachel Censor, Kirk Wilson
description: Rachel Anita Censor, a daughter of Linda and Walter Censor of New York, is to be married this evening to Kirk Eugene Wilson, a son of Heidrun and David Wilson of Geneva. Rabbi Brian Z. Mayer is to perform the ceremony at Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAURUSKA, VICTORIA
description: LAURUSKA-Victoria. On May 22, 1998. Devoted daughter of Albin and the late Felicia. Dear sister of John and loving niece of Nora Vessio. The family will be present on Tuesday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., Funeral Home, 726 Morris Park Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Dominic's Church. Interment will follow at Buena Vista Cemetery, Brodheadsville, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, HERBERT J.
description: COOPER-Herbert J. Of Port Liberte, Jersey City, and Long Beach Long Island, NJ. Formerly of Short Hills, South Orange and Hillside. Beloved husband of Deborah; devoted father of Martha and Sarah; Loving grandfather of Jacob Palmer; dear brother of Stuart F. Cooper. Memorial service Monday, May 25, at 10 AM, in the Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be sent to: YM-YW Hebrew Association, Union, NJ, Columbia Engineeering Fund, Fu Foundation, S.E.A.S. or the Jersey City Public Library Literacy Program in his memory.

title: Speaking of Precision
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, MELVA MORRIS
description: KENT-Melva Morris. On April 26, 1998. Beloved sister, aunt, great aunt and friend. She will be missed.

title: Where's the Harm In a Sculpture?
description: Re: ''When Is a Sculpture Actually a Structure?'' (April 19).

title: HOT DIGGITY! DOG DIGGITY! -- QUICK BITE/Hot Dog Factory; No Mass Production
description: At the Hot Dog Factory, the manager, Mazin Abuanouf, wants to make sure he has something for everybody. For the breakfast crowd, he offers hot dog and eggs and for snackers, he has hot dog nuggets (each is $2.49.)

title: Andrea Oki, Jeffrey Pomeroy
description: Andrea Oki was married last evening to Jeffrey David Pomeroy. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated at Bretton Woods, a caterer in Morris Plains, N.J.

title: Correction
description: A chart on May 10 detailing the status of a walkway on the Hudson riverfront in Bergen and Hudson counties omitted a section that is under development in Bayonne. A shopping center that has broken ground at the northwestern end of the Constable Hook peninsula includes a walkway.

title: Backtalk; The Brooklyn Myth
description: Fred Wilpon, owner of the Mets, recently unveiled a model of a proposed stadium for his team that he said would include elements of Ebbets Field, notably the rotunda, the entrance to the old Brooklyn ball park.

title: At a High School, a Cafe Where Seniority Has Its Privileges
description: A big green awning with gold lettering hangs over white enameled patio chairs and tables surrounded by a white wooden fence. Although the scene looks like an outdoor cafe, neither is it outdoors nor does it serve coffee. The cafe is actually a status symbol for the members of the senior class at North Hunterdon High School in Clinton Township.

title: A Taskmaster Tells His Troupe, Surprise Me
description: GENTLY but firmly, Alonzo King, the director and choreographer of Lines Contemporary Ballet, urged his 12 sleek dancers to soften a movement. ''It should look like a reverberation,'' he explained, at a rehearsal last month. ''The inner body has to move the outer body.'' The dancers started into a sequence of sinuous turns and off-center balances that required great strength and concentration. Long into the afternoon in the company's airy, old-fashioned studios in downtown San Francisco, they practiced the same combinations, joking and urging one another on.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Fragments Make the Man
description: The presiding voice in Milena McGraw's first novel, AFTER DUNKIRK (Houghton Mifflin, $24), belongs to Flying Officer Wayne Luthie. He is 20 years old and describes himself as ''a just man in a just war.'' From the fragments of his stream-of-consciousness narration, we learn that he was born in the Punjab in 1919, that he spent his childhood there and his youth in England, that he grew into manhood at Dunkirk. His experiences flying with the R.A.F. and falling in love with a gentle English war widow dominate his memories, which arise (perhaps unbidden) in vivid flashes of language. Over and over, he repeats, ''I am a man who loves words.'' He demonstrates this in sequences of haunting revelations: ''I want to fly without killing people.'' ''A human being burning to death sounds like a piece of bacon frying.'' ''I do not want a woman to gentle my wounds. I do not want a woman to be repelled by my wounds.'' ''My father the pacifist gave me a knife.'' These bursts of language eventually organize themselves into stories -- unbearable stories of loss, pain, horror, humiliation and death. ''Things repeat themselves: the same, yet different; different, yet the same,'' Luthie explains near the end of the novel. For this narrator, repetition is an attempt to understand, organize and master intolerable events. For the reader, repetition allows these events to come into an increasingly sharper and shapelier focus. More important, repetition starkly and unsentimentally displays the desperate gyrations of Luthie's tortured mind. Barbara Fisher

title: OUT THERE; At Cannes, Partying Is a Grind in Sequins
description: To the innocent bystander, the Cannes Film Festival may seem dedicated to the projection of movies, but in fact it is devoted to all-hours, highly competitive, Hollywood-strength party going. The sharpest elbows are thrown not to get into screenings of films like ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,'' starring Johnny Depp, but to get into cocktail parties like the one at which Mr. Depp announced that his next movie would be ''Ninth Gate,'' directed by Roman Polanski.

title: SUNDAY: May 24, 1998: QUESTIONS FOR:; Terry Gilliam
description: Gilliam, a founding member of Monty Python, is the director of ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.''

title: What Only-Child Syndrome?
description: Americans are often enthralled with pretty images, and the large family is one of them. The reality is that raising children is a tricky business. Too many parents have bought the image, yet are overwhelmed with the actual task. It might be a good idea to get out the message that it is really fine having just one child.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ARTHUR M.
description: LEVY-Arthur M. Adored husband of Elaine. Loving father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Services today, 12 noon, Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHENBAUM, GERTRUDE AND DR. SOL M. SCHENBAUM
description: SCHENBAUM-Gertrude and Dr. Sol M. Schenbaum. 1983 and 1986. We will always love, miss and remember you. Your Loving Family

title: Taxi Owners Deftly Dodge Claims of Accident Victims
description: The taxi came barreling up Third Avenue late on a damp October night. As the driver tried to bear left, the cab skidded onto a traffic island, slamming into Edward Shalala, who was waiting to cross the street. He was hurled onto the pavement, his face a bloody mess and his right leg shattered, as his surgeon put it, ''like cornflakes.''

title: February Attack on Gay Man Is Reclassified as Bias Crime
description: The Police Department has reclassified a February attack on a gay man in Chelsea as a bias incident. Many lesbian and gay New Yorkers celebrated the decision and commended police for their willingness to reconsider the issue.

title: Travelers to Benefit From Debut of the Euro
description: HERE is a pop quiz for bargain-hunters traveling in Europe. A pair of leather loafers from J. P. Tod's costs about 308,000 lire in Rome, 26,500 pesetas in Madrid and 400 marks here in Frankfurt.

title: Building Has No Name, but Neighbors Have Names for It
description: The brick building, nestled among Atlantic Avenue's antique stores and bail-bond offices and Arab meat markets, is a mystery. It has no sign. The windows are opaque. There is no indication that it is a way station for troubled youth, and that it is the target of neighbors' wrath.

title: Drury Lane
description: To the Editor: A recent question about guided tours of major London theaters reminded me of the fascinating tour we took two summers ago of Drury Lane: the foundations date back to the late 17th century, and the present theater (the fourth on the site), opened in 1812. We were shown the principal public rooms, the auditorium, parts of backstage, and even the ancient cellars. Although focusing on the present occupant, ''Miss Saigon,'' our guide also covered the theater's great past, so that the tour was enjoyed by casual tourists as well as theater buffs. Information about the tours is available in the lobby of the theater.

title: Sonali Lakhani, Sanjay Mody
description: Sonali Lakhani, the daughter of Shakuntala and Narendra Lakhani of Watchung, N.J., is to be married today to Sanjay Mody, a son of Hansa and Shanti Mody of North Brunswick, N.J. Harendra Dave, a Hindu priest, is to perform the Hindu Vedic ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: To Travel More Easily, Make a Special Place
description: CAR travel with your pet. This statement evokes images as varied as the pets themselves, each having its own interpretation of our motorized steel compartments. Reactions affected by personality, experience and breeding must be shaped creatively, and the first step is understanding how your pet internalizes its experience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, ROBERTA
description: BAKER-Roberta. We are deeply saddened at the passing of Roberta Deal Baker of Woodhaven, NY, on May 20, 1998. She was the beloved daughter of Dr. A. W. and Gladys Deal of Lewistown, MT, and the loving wife of the late Raleigh Baker. She is survived by her loving children, grandchildren and two sisters. A spirited and generous person, Cissie performed in jazz bands as a young woman, was a highly decorated Army officer in the First WAAC outfit and an accomplished craftsperson featured in national magazines and local television. A philanthropist and animal lover, she supported the work of the Humane Society and donated numerous hours to visting shut-ins. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Humane Society would be appreciated.

title: Where Man Bites Dog
description: THE hot dog has made a big impact not just on our diets but on our landscape as well.

title: An Empire Built on Hot Dogs, and All in the Family
description: IN the New Jersey Restaurant Association, Rena Levine Levy is known as the Queen of Hot Dogs.

title: Helen Wang, Christopher Fong
description: Helen B. Wang, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chung-Kuang Wang of Manalapan, N.J., is to be married today to Christopher L. Fong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kon Yin Fong of Laurinburg, N.C. The Rev. Richard Leonard is to perform the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: May 17-23; Off the Beam
description: Talk about deep impact! In movie theaters during this season of supermega cinema, comets and asteroids are heading toward our innocent planet with alarming regularity. Disasters like this, though, are shrugged off; highly paid movie stars are there to save us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMER, ARLENE
description: SCHUMER-Arlene. The employees of Marcus Brothers Textiles and Knit Trends express their deepest sympathy to Jerry Schumer and his family at the passing of their beloved wife, mother and grandmother.

title: Making Gardens Grow and Communities Glow
description: ''WE must cultivate our garden,'' Voltaire wrote in his philosophical fantasy, ''Candide.'' On Saturday, in the Big Dig, at more than 750 of New York City's public gardens, visitors can heed this advice by planting, enjoying the scheduled events and cultivating community awareness.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Variety Marks Show of Council's Award Winners
description: Showcase '98

title: HOT DIGGITY! DOG DIGGITY! -- QUICK BITE/Libby's; Deep in the Heart of . . .
description: Paterson's cuisine has had three profound influences on American society.

title: Gisele Garcia, Matthew Shelley
description: Gisele Eve Garcia, the daughter of Susan Garcia of Palo Alto, Calif., is to be married today to Matthew Brandon Shelley, the son of Gabrielle and Joseph Shelley of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Paul S. Johnson is to perform the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of Princeton.

title: SUNDAY: May 24, 1998: Resting Places; If You Bury It, He Will Come
description: Fame and fatality collide queasily in the extracurricular career of James Starrs, a law and forensic-science professor at George Washington University whose hobby is exhuming dead celebrities. An undertaker's grandson, Starrs, 67, relentlessly roams the land, trying to get his hands on the famously dead, often hinting at conspiracies to convince descendants and officials that there is a mystery to be solved that requires a body dug up. Ostensibly disdainful of media attention, Starrs nonetheless favors high-profile projects that he jazzes up with talk about dark doings and possible cover-ups. But for all their creepy allure, Starrs's exhumations tend to move more earth than they shake, and their main outcome is usually publicity for the garrulous gravedigger. Here's a Memorial Day gallery of the dead whose names have made his list.

title: Political Briefing; Primary Calendar
description: Besides Kentucky, Idaho will hold primaries on Tuesday.

title: Expanding to Manhattan With a Brass Bed Store
description: In 1912 Morris Goldstein opened a brass bed factory in Borough Park, Brooklyn. In 1952 his son Izzy took over the business, Elegante Brass and Iron Beds. He eventually moved the factory and showroom to 1460 65th Street in Brooklyn, and meticulously turned out handmade beds. On April 19, Saul Goldstein, Izzy's son, expanded the family business he took over in 1985, and opened a Manhattan store at 88 Orchard Street (near Delancey Street).

title: At Hofstra, a Statue Unclothed, or Is It Naked?
description: No Fig Leaves, Please

title: In the End, Voters Found, a Real Chance at Peace Was Irresistible
description: No one was a more stubborn or obstreperous opponent of the Northern Ireland peace agreement than the Rev. Ian Paisley. So moments after its resounding passage was announced at the King's Hall here this afternoon, ''yes'' supporters encircled the ''no'' preacher, taunting, ''Dinosaur!''

title: Taking the Wiener to the World
description: Kimberley Bow has a job -- and a car -- that lots of people love.

title: Emergency Workers Deserve Law's Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: United Airlines Adding Improved Air Filters
description: United Airlines is installing air filters, built to the same standards as those used in operating rooms treating burn patients, in all of its jets.

title: POP/JAZZ; As Categories Blur, One Diva Rules
description: TIME was, when divas were as innumerable as dinosaurs. They devoured one another for real, without animatronics. Today there is only one true diva, and she does not stalk opera houses. Aretha Franklin has created what can only be called gospel bel canto.

title: From Africa, Pointing to Modernist Ideas
description: A COUPLE of years ago, approaching its centenary, the great Belgian Royal Museum for Central Africa at Tervuren, near Brussels, decided to send some of its art on tour. After a few stops elsewhere, the show, with 125 objects, has arrived with relatively little fanfare at the small Museum for African Art in Manhattan (it's there to Aug. 9, then in Chicago, Dusseldorf and Barcelona).

title: Cars in Prospect Park Don't Add to Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Zanardi Takes Motorola 300
description: Alex Zanardi overtook Michael Andretti during a pit stop on the 176th lap and went on to win the Motorola 300 today at Gateway International Speedway.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WAITING FOR THE HEALER

title: Like a Painting In Slow Motion
description: TRADITIONALLY, art reaches the Whitney Museum by truck, heavily guarded and insured. This week, in a radical break from custom, an exhibition will arrive -- completely unprotected -- by subway.

title: A Playground, Once a Battlefield
description: THERE is not much Greek countryside I'd call lush, yet that's just the word for Messenia, the southwest corner of the Peloponnesus. Messenia's sybaritic pleasures include juicy Kalamata olives and succulent figs and melon, as well as the Peloponnesus's best sand beaches, many flanked by the small hotels and restaurants favored by savvy German and Italian travelers. One restaurant, the Klimataria in the village of Methone, serves what may well be the best food in the Peloponnesus, in a garden shaded by a grape arbor, just steps from Methone's medieval fortress.

title: SUNDAY: May 24, 1998; COLD COMFORT
description: This year's Telluride Mountainfilm festival, now under way, features a documentary short about a cryogenically frozen Norwegian in Nederland, Colo., a mountain hamlet northwest of Denver. Cryogenics is the art of freezing dead bodies for possible revival in the future. The film, Grandpa's in the Tuff Shed, was directed by Kathy, Robin and Shelly Beeck, and recounts how a Nederland resident, Trygve Bauge, froze his dead gramps inside a Tuff Shed, a wooden storage hut made in Denver. Bauge had to go home to Norway in 1994, but in one of those inspiring moments that make neighborliness come alive, Nederlanders agreed to keep tending the body -- which requires tons of dry ice every year.

title: A Key Figure Says the Need For Elections Is Imperative
description: Indonesia's new President, B. J. Habibie, swore in his new Cabinet here this morning, and one of its most influential members immediately questioned whether the Government should survive.

title: Gandhi's Voice Summoned to Condemn India's A-Tests
description: For years now, it has been hard for the followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi and his creed of nonviolence to make themselves heard above the clamor and indifference of modern India.

title: Classical Briefs
description: BERLIOZ: 'LES NUITS D'ETE,' OPERA ARIAS

title: Allison Adato, David Van Biema
description: Allison Beth Adato and David Herman Van Biema were married yesterday at the Ebell of Los Angeles, a private club. Rabbi James Lee Kaufman performed the ceremony.

title: In School Shooting, One Youth's 2 Sides
description: Kip Kinkel's parents had worried about his temper since he was a little boy. They sent him to a psychiatrist and taught him at home for a time. In recent months, they thought that their work and concern were making a difference and that Kip, at 15, was turning around.

title: Making Plans for the Arrival of the Local Strawberry Crop
description: PERHAPS it will be another week or two before the local strawberry crop is on farm stands and in markets. But it is not too soon to plan for that glorious moment -- and the month, at most, that the season runs.

title: Helping Young Moms Hold Fast to Dreams
description: SHAWNNA wants to pull the covers up tight over her head and catch just a few more minutes of sleep. But her kids wake up early. They jump on her bed in the morning and plant kisses on her through the soft cotton sheets. They want juice, breakfast, her.

title: After a Gaffe, I.R.S. Could Stand for 'I'm Really Sorry'
description: THE grim prospect of delayed refunds for hundreds of thousands of taxpayers has largely evaporated as the Internal Revenue Service -- a stickler for accuracy on returns -- now considers one of its projections a whopping overestimate.

title: Whitbread Finish Is Imminent
description: It has taken 31,600 nautical miles to get there, but the nine sailboats competing in the Whitbread Round the World Race are expected to finish today where they started nine months ago -- in Southampton, England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSSOVE, ELIZABETH
description: KOSSOVE - Elizabeth. Beloved mother of Michael Kossove and Barbara Brochstein. Cherished grandmother of Scott, Larry, Steven, Nathan and Sarah.

title: New Wave of Businesses Is Still Offshore for the Seaport
description: Outside the South Street Seaport's Fulton Market, on Fulton and Front Streets, a few Chrysler automobiles have been put on display to attract prospective buyers.

title: Political Briefing; In Massachusetts: To Be Or Not to Be Big Spender
description: Acting Gov. Paul Cellucci and Attorney General Scott Harshbarger of Massachusetts have a money problem.

title: Peasant Stock
Paid Notice: Deaths  NEMITOFF, MYRON
description: NEMITOFF-Myron. Beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Michael and daughter-in-law Ruth. Dear grandfather of Adam and Matthew. Great friend to all, loved people and will be missed. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM at Gramercy Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, New York City, New York.

title: Ceiling Fans Have a Role All Year
description: BY improving air circulation, ceiling fans can keep a room cooler in the summer and warmer in the winter. They can help to reduce electrical and heating bills.

title: Sacred Snakes
description: To the Editor: The article ''Polyglot Penang, a Special Place, La!'' (April 19), brought to mind my visit there 30 years ago. I lived in the Philippines then, teaching at the Union Theological Seminary near Manila. On a trip to Singapore, I was invited by one of my former Chinese students, now a pastor on the island of Penang, to come up for a visit.

title: Santa Fe
description: Santa Fe, the city of Holy Faith, this year celebrates the 400th anniversary of Spanish settlement in New Mexico. But Santa Fe was already old when the Spaniards arrived, and central to nearly 100,000 native people living in 70 nearby adobe pueblos. This summer, the activities of the Hispanic Cuatro Centenario blend with the calendar of Native American feast days and the flux of all-American tourism that characterizes the City Different.

title: Hotels Spruced Up in Two National Parks
description: Two hotels in national parks listed on the National Register of Historic Places have undergone restoration or renovation.

title: Restraint By Pakistan Is Eroding, Leader Says
description: With the world awaiting his decision on whether to lead his country into the nuclear weapons club, Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, said today that he was trying to act with restraint but that India's recent nuclear tests pose a ''threat that may materialize at any moment.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From the Times
description: Many of the news articles that appear in this paper's weekly Science Times section remain permanent news in the perspective of constant, continuing scientific discovery and development. Two new volumes in a series of Science Times books, ''The Science Times Book of Fossils and Evolution'' and ''The Science Times Book of the Brain'' (Lyons Press, $25 each), edited by Nicholas Wade, are collections of recent reporting and analysis on subjects that range, in the ''Fossils and Evolution'' volume, from how life on earth began (volcanoes may be responsible) through newly discovered dinosaurs and prehumans to how life disappears in great extinctions (volcanoes again). The ''Brain'' collection reports on such aspects of mentality as memory, perception, sex differences in the brain and the neurological machinery of emotion; the final selection is happily entitled ''The Conscious Mind Is Still Baffling to Experts of All Stripes.''

title: Ankle Hobbles Miller, But Bulls Can't Stop Him
description: The pop that Reggie Miller heard in his right ankle today could have been the Indiana Pacers' season bursting like a soap bubble. But there are times when some tape, and one man's will, can hold a desperate team together.

title: A Hit All Along
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TAFFEL, ABRAM
description: TAFFEL-Abram. Thank you for forty-six wonderful years. I shall cherish your memory always. Love Helen

title: California Marijuana Clubs Defy Federal Judge's Order to Close
description: Seeking a showdown with the Federal Government, the founders of three medical marijuana clubs in this area have defied orders to shut down, hoping to place their fate in the hands of a jury.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday about China's effort to win the right to launch American satellites referred incorrectly to the message conveyed in September and October 1993 to President Clinton by Michael Armstrong, the chief executive officer of the Hughes Electronics Corporation, an American maker of communications satellites. Mr. Armstrong, in letters to Mr. Clinton, complained that State Department sanctions against Chinese missile companies hurt his business; he did not mention the China Aerospace Corporation specifically.

title: The Sick and the Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Focal Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Style; Going Nowhere
description: 'Purity unencumbered by style'' is how William Stern, an architect and an associate professor at the University of Houston, described Donald Judd's objective during a recent conference on art and architecture, in Marfa, Tex. The impact of Judd's work, not only as an artist and an architect but also as a designer of furniture and household objects, has lately resonated far and wide, as fashion has come around to the stripped-down esthetic -- popularly known as minimalism -- that he helped pioneer. On this occasion, some 600 people made the pilgrimage to Marfa, the town where Judd settled; the Chinati Foundation, which sponsored the event, turned away 400 more. Even so, the notion that Marfa -- population 2,424 -- might prove to be ''the next happening place,'' in the words of one resident, seemed highly unlikely for any number of reasons, not the least of which is that it's smack in the middle of nowhere: 90 minutes into the three-hour drive from the airport in El Paso, you run out of radio stations.

title: Congress Must Lead Inquiry on China
description: To the Editor:

title: Shoulder Woes Nag Martinez
description: Tino Martinez was scratched from the Yankee lineup today with a mildly sprained right shoulder, sustained when he jarred it sliding into third base Friday. Initially injured when Armando Benitez drilled him in the back with a fastball Tuesday, causing him to miss two games, Martinez believes the injuries are connected -- possibly because he did not have full strength or flexibility in his shoulder Friday.

title: Cars in Prospect Park Don't Add to Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: So Many Parties, So Little Time; It's the Madness of the Children's Birthday Celebration Season
description: Birthday parties are normally festive experiences -- until you go to 50 of them. Every year.

title: Time to Fix Up the Castle
description: THE castle, viewed from a boat on the Connecticut River, is a strange and unexpected sight. Suddenly there it is, a great stone pile perched 200 feet above the water on the east side of the river in the village of Hadlyme, a panorama out of place and time. It should have been built centuries ago, on the Rhine in Germany or the Danube in Hungary.

title: Don't Even Think About It. (The Cupid Cops Are Watching.)
description: Why do the illustrations accompanying your article imply that women are the provocateurs of sexual encounters within the workplace? There are three illustrations, and in each one there appears to be a clear message (seductive facial expressions and body language) depicting the woman as flirtatious temptress and the man (timid and reluctant) as passive -- but willing -- victim.

title: May 17-23; Mexican Bankers Indicted
description: The Federal Government charged 3 of Mexico's largest banks and 26 Mexican bankers with allowing drug traffickers to launder millions of dollars in illegal proceeds from the United States. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Attorney General Janet Reno described the three-year undercover operation as ''the largest, most comprehensive drug money laundering case in the history of U.S. law enforcement.''

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks, Please Don't Bury the Red Sox, Too
description: FOR any Yankee fans worth their pinstripes, happiness was burying the Orioles with that three-game sweep. Especially after what Armando Benitez did to Tino Martinez. Dragging their $70 million payroll, the Orioles were 14 games behind the Yankees (and 17 in the loss column) as they fluttered weakly out of town.

title: Ms. Han and Mr. Lasersohn
description: Helen Hisun Han, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sae Dong Han of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Thomas Daniel Lasersohn, a son of the late Virginia P. Lauricella and the late Jack W. Lasersohn. Msgr. William H. Toohy performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York.

title: Streetscapes/1 Bond Street; A Cast-Iron Building That Once Yielded Gold
description: THE cast-iron building at 1 Bond Street offered up a good-sized mine of gold after a watchmaker moved out in 1892. For many years afterward, however, Bond Street was not a golden address. But the street is coming back after long decades of neglect, and the co-op at 1 Bond is beginning to make repairs ignored in its conversion a decade ago.

title: In Analysts' Eyes, Microsoft Is Still a Giant With Legs
description: THE Government's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation is expected to be long and arduous. Shareholders naturally wonder what it bodes for the stock.

title: Opponent of Lead-Paint Bill Misstated Its Provisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Genevieve Donepp, Mark Reynolds
description: Genevieve Virginia Donepp, a daughter of Leona Mattson and Matthew H. Donepp, both of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark David Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Robert Reynolds of West Harwich, Mass. The Rev. Francis Geer performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Phillips Church in the Highlands in Garrison, N.Y.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Two Prague Hotels Subject to Sanctions
description: A hotel group in the Czech Republic has been declared off-limits for American citizens by the United States Embassy in Prague because its Libyan ownership makes it subject to sanctions. The Top Spirit hotel chain, with two major hotels in Prague (the Forum and the Panorama) and three others in the Czech countryside, was purchased earlier this year by the Malta-based Corinthia Hotels International group, which is 48 percent Libyan owned.

title: Albee's 'Tiny Alice,' The Whole Enchilada
description: HAS the time for ''Tiny Alice'' come at last?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, JACOB
description: ROSENZWEIG-Jacob. Yeshivat Sha'alvim extends sincerest expressions of sympathy and condolences to Ruthi and our Board of Governors member Joey Bodner, upon the loss of her dear father, Jacob Rosenzweig. May the Almighty comfort you among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rav Avraham Avidan Rosh HaYeshiva Rabbi Mallen Galinsky Dean Alex Hornstein President Werner Rosenbaum Chairman of the Board Rabbi Philip H. Singer Executive Chairman

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about how corporations choose new names referred incorrectly to the company formed by the merger of SBC Communications and Ameritech. It will be called SBC Communications, not SBC-Ameritech.

title: DIARY
description: TRADE

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Baby Sitters in the Wings
description: Talk about fun baby sitters.

title: Marginalia
description: MAN OR MANGO?

title: Culture Zone; God Give Us Music
description: Like Joe Dimaggio throwing out the first ball of the season, Burt Bacharach gamely stepped to the podium at a recent awards show to announce the best-selling album of 1997. It was an oddly unsettling moment, but not because the winner was the Spice Girls' ''Spice,'' or even because the 68-year-old Bacharach kept a straight face. If he's at all as sharp as his songs, he probably realized that the resurgence of bubble-gum acts like the Spice Girls and Hanson was one of the few heartening developments in pop music in 1997.

title: 2 Budgets Fail
description: For the most part, voters approved the school budgets that were proposed last Tuesday. Exceptions were in Greenburgh Central 7, where voters rejected the proposed budget, 1,594 to 457, and Eastchester, where the budget failed 1,006 to 897. Both districts will decide how to proceed in the next few weeks. Under state law, the choices are proposing a revised budget, presenting the same budget to voters or bypassing a public vote by declaring an austerity budget. ELSA BRENNER

title: What Only-Child Syndrome?
description: Only children are responsible, self-reliant, problem solvers, leaders, decision makers (''What Only-Child Syndrome?'' by Bill McKibben, May 3). They are mischievous, serious, curious, sometimes lonely but also need to be alone, work hard, need to play more, can dine or travel alone and are some-times overprotected as kids. Adulthood isn't a shock because we develop the skills to cope early. I wouldn't trade it for the world.

title: Eating His Way to the Top
description: He is, without a doubt, one of the greatest champions in the annals of hot dog eating in New Jersey, and, quite possibly, the world.

title: From Submarine Warfare to Show Biz
description: FOR a while, as they sat in a studio at Sonalysts Inc. in Waterford, the composing partners Neil Goldberg and Dave Fraser cheerfully answered questions about the business of scoring a prospective television documentary. As the questions became more technical, the two men suddenly clammed up.

title: Kimberly Morgan, David Blank
description: Kimberly Dara Morgan, a daughter of Eleanor Morgan and Dr. Howard L. Morgan of Villanova, Pa., is to be married in Philadelphia today to David Michael Blank, the son of Dr. Bette A. Blank and Dr. Stuart L. Blank of Madison, N.J. Rabbi Marshall J. Maltzman is to officiate at the Philadelphia Horticulture Center in Fairmount Park.

title: A Composer Caught in Alice's Web
description: AFTER 30 years spent obsessed with Lewis Carroll's ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland,'' the American composer David Del Tredici says he has had enough. But Mr. Del Tredici has said as much before. ''Final Alice,'' of 1976, following four other ''Alice'' pieces, served as a proclamation that there would be no more. Then came more Carroll: the radiantly lyrical ''In Memory of a Summer Day,'' of 1980, which won a Pulitzer Prize in music, and the unperformed opera ''Dum Dee Tweedle.''

title: Just Desserts
description: Congratulations to Hila Colman (Lives: ''Just Desserts,'' May 3.) We see a parallel between the ''hurried child'' syndrome and the new ''hurried elderly.'' Being busy for its own sake is common to both constructs.

title: Wendy Zajack, Andrew Lipshultz
description: Wendy Alaine Zajack was married last evening to Andrew Lance Lipshultz. Cantor Jan Morrison officiated at the Tidewater Inn in Easton, Md.

title: Congress Must Lead Inquiry on China; A Waste of Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHERT, HENRY G.
description: REICHERT-Henry G. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Henry G. Reichert, associated with The Times from 1963, until retiring in 1994.

title: Elise Stockly, Jeremiah Eck
description: Elise Stockly, a city planner, and Jeremiah Lee Eck, an architect, were married last evening at the Gamble Mansion, a historic house in Boston. The Rev. Deborah Pope-Lance, a Unitarian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Lesnick, Jonathan Gross
description: Elizabeth Ann Lesnick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel D. Lesnick of Bedford Corners, N.Y., was married last evening to Jonathan Robert Gross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eston M. Gross of Evanston, Ill. Rabbi Niles Goldstein officiated at Lyndhurst Castle, the Jay Gould house in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: HOT DIGGITY! DOG DIGGITY! -- QUICK BITE/Max's; A Bipartisan Institution
description: A lot of people -- including the last four Governors of New Jersey -- swear that the thousands of hot dogs that have hit the buns at Max's in Long Branch since it opened in 1928 are among the best in the universe.

title: A Fine-Tuned, Engaging Hamptons Spot
description: PECONIC COAST is different. Many of the other new Hamptons' restaurants, no doubt, are in a panic this weekend. They have been open only a few scant weeks (or even days) and now the hoards of summer people are upon them.

title: What Only-Child Syndrome
description: My husband and I would like to recommend to your readers what we call ''serial only-children.'' When we met, he had a 9-year-old son from a former marriage. We married and, when his son was 15, I gave birth to our daughter, now 12. Each child, in serial fashion, benefited from receiving our full attention. Each is engaging and well adjusted. Moreover, as ''older'' parents, we appreciated the less chaotic pace of raising just one at a time. And the bonus is, with 15 years separating them, they adore each other.

title: Hot Diggity! Dog Diggity!
