description: Americans will eat an estimated seven billion hot dogs between Memorial Day and Labor Day. Inside: a guide to help you do your part, pages 4, 6, 7, 8 and 11.

title: Word and Image; The Oldest Bias
description: The media, like societies through history, have been dominated by the young. It's time to look again.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Sailing Without a Sailboat

title: Echoes Of Ancient Lives
description: KARYSTOS, on the southern half of the Greek island of Evia, is not a pretty town, nor is it particularly popular with tourists. Concrete multistory dwellings ring its port, behind which looms the 4,600-foot Mount Ohi.

title: Democrats Hope to Trim Their Pool of Candidates
description: In a nod to an era of politics that has almost passed in New York State, Democratic leaders and candidates will assemble in Westchester County this week for a convention that is shaping up as a freewheeling if inconclusive gathering, with just a hint of the suspense that was once a staple of such meetings.

title: Don Wharton, 92, A Magazine Writer
description: Don Wharton, an editor and a prolific writer of magazine articles, died on May 6 at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONCEPCION, RENE
description: CONCEPCION-Rene. Two years went by without you, but your smile and your courage will always stay with those you loved. You'll be forever in our hearts. Will love Steven and Adolfo

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: TWITCH AND SHOUT

title: Westchester Q&A/Rita Zess Magilton; Fire Kills Adopted Pets but Not the Spirit
description: SOMEHOW abandoned or abused animals seem to know that in Rita Zess Magilton they have found someone who will give them medical care, love and a home. A former director of a shelter for homeless people in the Bronx, Mrs. Magilton is not a person who easily turns away from a needy person or animal.

title: Night Moves
description: EVERY three or four weeks a sense of oppression descends on Amy Lesser. The walls of her one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side seem to close in. The knocking noises of the elevator outside her door grate on her. Faxes keep coming, reminding her of work and responsibility. On nights like these, Ms. Lesser said, she feels like a caged hamster on a treadmill.

title: Ink Long Dry on Angola Pact, but Peace Hasn't Set
description: The rebel headquarters here, once reduced to rubble, have been rebuilt. Its white walls, lacquered front door and jaunty green wrought-iron fence stand in sharp contrast to the bullet-pocked buildings and sewage-clogged gutters all around it.

title: Books on Cows
description: To the Editor: In her sweet essay about cows, Ms. Winckler wrote ''I have bookshelves full of guides to birds, bats, plants . . . but I have never come across a field guide to livestock.''

title: Astrid Kleinbeck, Scott Peters
description: Astrid Kristine Kleinbeck and Scott Philip Peters were married yesterday in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Alan G. Dennis, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the St. Luke's Parish church.

title: On Language; Back to My Roots
description: 'Dear sirs,'' begins a letter to The New York Times from Stephen Sondheim, the noted Broadway songwriter whose ''Send in the Clowns'' won the 1975 Grammy Award for Song of the Year and whose ''Sunday in the Park With George'' won the 1985 Pulitzer Prize for drama.

title: Mysterious Virus at Source Drives Up the Price of Pearls
description: In simpler times, only nature could make a pearl. Then mankind came up with the cultured variety, and pearls were transformed from nuggets of magic to predictable commodities.

title: The View From/Hartford; Where Produce From Afar Gets Serious Attention
description: THE sky is still flecked with stars as Eleanore Rhodes and her dog comb the farmers' stalls at the state's Regional Market in Hartford in search of day lily and mock orange plants.

title: Recreating Oregon's Storied Past
description: IT sounds like something out of a time-machine tale. But oddly enough, the people of Baker City, Ore., can thank the hardy pioneers who set out on the Oregon Trail more than 150 years ago for the recent renovation of an elegant hotel built here 109 years ago.

description: The Great Betrayal

description: Susan Gene Price and William Andrew Rubin are to be married today at the Forrestal Hotel in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Benjamin M. Levy is to officiate.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDON, NORMAN
description: CARDON-Norman, M.D. On May 18, 1998. Cherished son of the late Simon & Lillian Cardon. Devoted father of Eric S. Cardon. Former husband of Andrea Theodore Kove. Services were private.

title: Just Desserts
description: Colman's article made me think that her life of ''dessert, the whipped cream of leisure'' is quite the opposite of what I, as I approach the age of 79, would want. The concept of usefulness as a way of life is a rejuvenating one. I was brought up to cherish the words ''when you rest, you rust.'' The only something new that Colman is savoring is boredom.

title: HOT DIGGITY! DOG DIGGITY! -- QUICK BITE/Cousin Pete's; Deals From a 52-Dog Deck
description: Call it the Baskin-Robbins of hot dogs.

title: Emily Morris, Mickey Miller
description: Emily Anne Morris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Griffith R. Morris of Millington, N.J., and Lieut. Mickey Allen Miller, a son of Barbara Miller and Gene M. Miller, both of Evansville, Ind., were married yesterday at the Cadet Chapel of the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y. The Rev. Edson J. Wood, a Roman Catholic priest and an associate chaplain at the Academy, officiated.

title: Day Trips With Style And a Long History
description: THE nation's oldest orchestra, and one of its foremost, is about to weigh in at New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. Its legal name, Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, came from a 1928 merger with Walter Damrosch's Symphony Society of New York, but it is best known as the New York Philharmonic.

title: Q and A
description: Normandy's Beaches

title: For the Death Penalty, No Longer If, but When
description: LIFE'S small moments haunt Helen Williams. She recently saw a robin and thought of her son, Walter, who watched for the bird each spring and promptly reported his first sighting. Mr. Williams, a Waterbury police officer, was shot in the back of the head while patrolling the city's North End in 1992. His killer, Richard Reynolds, is on death row.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: BELMONT

title: Surprise! Commuters Find They Can Now Come and Go
description: Pleasantly surprised subway riders are finding that shiny new turnstiles have been installed, without fanfare, at the downtown entrance to the No. 6 train at the IRT station at Bleecker and Lafayette Streets.

title: The Up and Down World of House Closings
description: On the first floor of a Garden City office building, tiny rooms are lined up like the dressing cubicles at Macy's. In each room is a table, and a story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOZICK, IDA WENER
description: VOZICK-Ida Wener. Died Thursday, May 21, 1998, at age 87. Cherished wife of 64 years of the late Hyman Vozick. Beloved mother of Michael, David, Alexandra and Tina, and mother-in-law of Michele Vozick, Paul Levinson, and Paul Hans. Treasured grandmother of Eric, Julie and Jesse Vozick; Zachary, Marc and Ben Isaac Thacher; Simon and Molly Vozick-Levinson. Daughter of Michael and Zeasel Wener, sister of Dinah Cohen, and the late Mollye Nueman and William Wener. A woman of strength and vision with uncompromising devotion to her family and unmatched generosity, she made everyone feel welcome at her table. Her remarkable work in cooperative housing and credit unions helped tens of thousands of families from all walks of life receive quality housing. She insisted that everyone she met be treated with respect and dignity. She will be remembered and missed. Services Tuesday, May 26, 1998, at 10 AM, Parkside Hirsch, 167th St. and Jerome Ave., Bronx, NY.

title: Easy Night for Hasek As Caps' Tactics Fail
description: The Capitals made their strategy obvious in the first period tonight against the Buffalo Sabres. They bumped Dominik Hasek, Buffalo's goalie, not once but twice. Doing the deeds were Chris Simon and Craig Berube, ruffians who look like part of the casting call for the movie ''Slap Shot.''

title: May 17-23; Panel on Clinton-China Tie
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich moved to create a special committee to investigate President Clinton's decision to waive export controls over advanced satellite technology to China, as Republicans found a new political weapon to wield against Mr. Clinton: national security.

title: Wells's Follow-Up Is Not Perfect, But Good Enough
description: David Wells finally talked to someone this morning who did not care about his perfect game, did not want an autograph, did not offer him an endorsement opportunity and did not want to interview him.

title: A Doctor's 'Nebulous Hope'
description: ''I THINK a lot about losing my dignity,'' says Scott, a 33-year-old out-of-work doctor with bipolar disorder. ''I'm so needy I drive people away. I meet a nice girl, after two dates I slink away. How can I tell her I can't make love because of the side effects of the antidepressants? I look at street people. I could end up like that. I feel like I'm walking a tightrope without a net.''

title: Commercial Property/Insignia Financial Group; Shedding Residential to Focus on Commercial
description: LATER this year, Insignia Financial Group will be merged out of existence and replaced by a new entity called Insignia/ESG Holdings. In the process, a company that was dominated by residential real estate ownership and management and based in Greenville, S.C., will become mostly a commercial real estate services operation based in New York and with international aspirations.

title: Crediting Helpers Of Divorced Parents
description: As a co-founder of the Parent Education and Custody Effectiveness (Peace) program, I would like to thank you for the April 5 article ''Program Helps Divorced Parents Ease the Effect on Children.''

title: Emergency Workers Deserve Law's Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TARNAPOLL, ALEX
description: TARNAPOLL-Alex. 5/24/97. Your laughter, your friendship, your love-I will miss you forever. Your Rosie

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLFF, CARMEN ALVA
description: OLFF-Carmen Alva. Died peacefully May 18, 1998, losing a courageous battle against lung cancer at 55. Well-known in the music business, long-time Manager of the Lone Star Roadhouse, NYC, he immeasurably enriched the lives of all who knew him. He is survived by his beloved children Cassandra Davidson and Erik Christian Olff. He will be remembered each day with love.

title: Congress Must Lead Inquiry on China; Privacy Law Details
description: To the Editor:

title: Later Closing Times For Museums in Italy
description: Through the end of the year, more than a dozen of Italy's most famous museums are extending their hours, a move that officials hope will alleviate one of the most vexing problems for tourists in Italy: waiting in lines.

title: Fast Times for Engineering Graduates, as a Slump Ends
description: With the economy booming, college graduates are facing the best job market in years. And for students in engineering and computer science -- a small group who chose their majors when companies were downsizing and engineers were being tossed aside like used Kleenex -- the market is sizzling.

title: Classical Briefs
description: ELLY AMELING: THE EARLY RECORDINGS, VOLS. 1-4

title: Telford Taylor, Who Prosecuted Top Nazis At the Nuremberg War Trials, Is Dead at 90
description: Telford Taylor, a principal prosecutor of high Nazi officials and leading German industrialists at the Nuremberg war crimes trials after World War II, died yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Spoken Word Finds a New Partner in Music
description: SOMEWHERE toward the middle of the CD version of Spalding Gray's monologue, ''It's a Slippery Slope,'' his autobiographical narrative about birth, death and the transcendental joys of skiing, Mr. Gray's richly nuanced voice is joined by the sound of shoes striding across the pavement during an anxiety-ridden walk in Washington Square Park. When the narrator is confronted by a drug dealer who casually asks him, ''Hey, man, what's happening?,'' the footsteps come to a halt. ''Hey,'' Mr. Gray responds with the mocking irony of a man who senses that his whole life is about to change, ''Good question: what is happening?''

title: Cindy Beth Ganis, Scott Roskind
description: Dr. Cindy Beth Ganis, the daughter of Renee and Harvey Ganis of Stamford, Conn., is to be married today to Scott Charles Roskind, the son of Diane and Robert Roskind of Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua J. Hammerman is to officiate at the Plaza in New York.

title: Congress Must Lead Inquiry on China; Let Chinese Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY: May 24, 1998: Computers; Private Eyes
description: The man's E-mail said, ''I wish there was some way I could meet someone like you.'' The woman's reply came back: ''There is. Where do you want to meet?''

title: Melanie Bartol And Greg Jones
description: Melanie Anne Bartol, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Bartol Jr. of Alexandria, Va., was married there yesterday to Samuel Gregory Jones, the son of Helen Von Salzen of Annapolis, Md., and Samuel S. Jones Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Pierce W. Klemmt performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Ms. Davidson, Mr. Chachkes
description: Charlotte Elizabeth Davidson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Davidson of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Alex Verbin Chachkes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chaim Chachkes of Phoenixville, Pa. Judge Jose A. Cabranes of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan officiated at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Don't Even Think About It. (The Cupid Cops Are Watching.)
description: Human resource counselors are going to have a hard time stamping out romances between nonequals in the workplace because the imbalance of power sparks and fuels the love affair in the first place (''Don't Even Think About It.. . .'' by Philip Weiss, May 3). Very simply, power attracts. Females of all species are attracted to males with power, and in the workplace the power is palpable and always visible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COAKLEY, CHARLES E.
description: COAKLEY-Charles E. Of New York City and Saltaire, Fire Island. On May 21, 1998. Devoted husband of Trudi. Loving stepfather of Lyssa and Greg. Proud grandfather of Tess, Nicholas and Sylvie. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 West 72nd St. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, private.

title: Natasha Leibel and Harlan Levine
description: Natasha Iran Leibel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rudolph Leibel of New York, was married last evening to Harlan Brett Levine, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Levine of Los Angeles. Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony at the Union League Club in New York.

title: Or Would You Rather Watch Laws Being Made?
description: Consider the hot dog paradox: Almost everybody eats them, but who knows -- really knows -- what goes in them?

title: The Nation: Parallel Universe; Listen Up, Out There. Here's What Cabbies Think of You.
description: TIME was, the stereotypical New York cabdriver was a gabby if slightly gruff man with a Brooklyn accent who knew every pothole in every street in every borough and greeted people with the world-weary query, ''Where to, Mac?''

title: Ideas & Trends: Invisible Hand; Diplomacy's Erratic Hit Man: The Dollar
description: THE last time an Indonesian strongman tested Washington's patience, the Central Intelligence Agency dipped into the movie business. In the late 1950's, it put together a mildly pornographic film starring a lookalike for President Sukarno, caught in bed with a blonde playing a Soviet agent. The humiliation was supposed to drive Indonesia's first president from office.

title: Books on Cows
description: To the Editor: In ''Over the Moon About Cows'' (May 3), Suzanne Winckler bemoans the absence of a ''field guide to livestock,'' and asks, ''Could it be that I am the only nonagrarian in America who cares to distinguish between a Guernsey and a Charolais?'' Ms. Winckler is not alone.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article on the Investing It pages last week examined some companies' private placements of convertible preferred stock with floating and discounted conversion rates. Such stock is convertible to common shares at a floating ratio based on the common stock's market price; the lower that price when an investor decides to convert, the more common shares the investor gets. The article discussed a hazard of such placements: that they may offer an incentive for unscrupulous investors to drive down the price of the common stock by selling it short.

title: BENEFITS
description: Opportunities for Women

title: Click Here If You Have an Opinion
description: Around the beginning of 1996, two full-grown men -- brothers, in fact -- were sitting around their computer company, in Mesa, Ariz., bantering, as brothers will. That day, they were musing about odd ways to cook hot dogs, like on car engines.

title: A Five-Year Journey to a Better Mousetrap
description: JERRY FREE, an installer of drywall, has lately been leading a crew in putting 230,000 square feet of it into a new hotel in Fishkill, N.Y. It is a bone-tiring task by any measure, but Mr. Free has the advantage of using the Speed Bead, a device for joining pieces of wallboard that he invented nearly five years ago -- and is just now being introduced commercially by United States Gypsum.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about East End wineries misidentified a worker at Macari Vineyards in Mattituck. He was Randy Armour, not Greg Gove.

title: Storing Crime's Detritus
description: In her 15 years as a secretary at the police property clerk's warehouse, Gerry Kiel has witnessed objects as odd as a coffin come through the door. But one day she was thinking that there had never been a piano.

title: Rising Tide of Anger At Teen-Aged Killers
description: The 15-year-old boy arrested in the school shooting in Springfield, Ore., will be charged as an adult and could face a life sentence, while the 11- and 13-year-old boys in the similarly chilling shooting in Jonesboro, Ark., in March are being prosecuted as juveniles and could be released when they are 18.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about novice landlords helped by the Neighborhood Housing Services organization misidentified the bank that administers a loan pool for closing costs. It is the Bankers Trust Company, not the Bank of New York Mortgage Company.

title: Classical Briefs
description: BILLINGS: HYMN TUNES AND PATRIOTIC SONGS

title: Corrections
description: Another picture caption, about stores on a village Main Street, misidentified the locality. It was Southampton, not East Hampton.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 5/

title: Fidelity Follows a Crowd It Shunned
description: WHAT a difference a year makes.

title: If You REALLY Want to Know More
description: The National Hot Dog and Sausage Council, a project of the American Meat Institute Foundation, conducts research to benefit hot dog and sausage makers, and provides information to consumers and journalists.

title: Q&A/Nicholas S. Perna; How Asia's Crisis Helped State's Economy
description: IT is Nicholas S. Perna's job to peer into the future and forecast economic trends. ''Reading computer printouts and chicken entrails,'' he said, quoting a friend's characterization of his work. He focuses on Connecticut and the surrounding region -- New England, New York and New Jersey.

title: The Dish On Satellite Dishes
description: WHEN Barry Hart bolted a satellite television dish to the wall of his terrace on the eighth floor of a condominium in Chelsea, he expected at least a bit of static. The interference he encountered, however, did not come from his television, but from his condominium board.

title: Drawn to Good Works, Two Women Keep Busy Together
description: They met through their hairdresser at Dudley's salon, who thought they'd be a perfect match: Frances Jennings, 74, retired from work as a nurse's aide, and Wilhelmina Hall, 71, who spent decades working for the phone company before signing up as a volunteer for the city's Retired and Senior Volunteer Program, also known as R.S.V.P.

title: Cheating the Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Activist Government, Anxious Markets
description: Sometimes in the stock market, the past really is prologue. That's why the search for historical parallels between markets is a favored pastime of many strategists.

title: The View From/Rye; The Osborn Seven: 700-Plus Years of Perspective on Living
description: IF only all women could wind up like the Osborn Seven. If only they could grow old like Florence Adamson, Eleanor Patterson, Margaret Fletcher, Lucille Canfield, Anne Dirkes, Grace Lewis and Margaret Woodward.

title: Christine Grounds And Jonathan Mir
description: Christine Ann Grounds, a daughter of Marilyn and Peter Grounds of Princeton, N.J., is to be married this evening to Jonathan Philip Mir, the son of Judith and Leon Mir of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Sarah Reines is to officiate at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York.

title: Whidbey Island
description: To the Editor: Timothy Egan confined himself to the southern part of Whidbey Island.

title: Peter Begley and Anne Bazin
description: Anne Bazin and Peter Higginson Begley, both of Rome, were married in a civil ceremony on Friday at the town hall of Caen, France, by Dr. Jean-Pierre Viallaniex, the deputy mayor. Yesterday, the Rev. Xavier de Chalendar performed a Roman Catholic ceremony at the Abbaye-aux-Dames, also in Caen.

title: Jennifer Frankel, Lawrence Krasin
description: Jennifer Sue Frankel, the daughter of Joan and Charles Frankel of Woodbury, N.Y., was married on Thursday evening to Lawrence Philip Krasin, the son of Judith and Jerome Krasin of Old Bethpage, N.Y. Rabbi Bruce Ginsburg performed the ceremony at the Woodbury Jewish Center.

title: A 1920's Flowering That Didn't Disappear
description: THE era of the Harlem Renaissance is one of the most intensively studied periods in the history of black life in America. It has been the subject of countless scholarly books and articles, and a fair number of museum exhibitions, and its basic chronological and geographical outline tends to change little from telling to telling.

title: An Unlikely Candidate Rattles the Establishment
description: As he suffers through a disastrous year in Washington, Representative Dan Burton is facing the ultimate in the politics of disrespect here at home: Democrats have chosen a convicted felon and occasional female impersonator to challenge the flamboyant Republican incumbent.

title: British Library Opens Its Treasures to Public
description: Following the opening of its first reading rooms last November, the British Library added three exhibition galleries last month at the library's new home in St. Pancras in London. Visitors to the new library, which was designed by Colin St. John Wilson, can see hundreds of treasures from the library's collection that spans almost three millenniums and comes from all over the world.

title: Corrections
description: An entry last Sunday in the calendar of summer activities misstated the phone number for a 100-mile bike ride from New York to the Hamptons on June 13. It is (516) 479-6016.

title: Cycling to Montauk: Blood, Sweat and Rain
description: We have a heckler. Perhaps he got off the train from New York; perhaps his blood-alcohol level is still a mite high after a big night on the town. In any case, he has seen a large group of cyclists gathered in the parking lot of the Hicksville station of the Long Island Rail Road. He has made a few inquiries, and taken it upon himself to point out our folly.

title: The Medical Center Tests Privatized Waters
description: SEVERING the ties that bound it to the meddling of government bureaucrats for almost 80 years, the Westchester Medical Center here set off on a fresh course in January. As an independent entity, the hospital was freer to forge alliances with other health institutions, do battle in the highly competitive arena of managed care, pursue its own sources of income and -- without an annual cash infusion from the county -- succeed or fail on its own merits.

title: Bows and Ribbons Can Look Much Better
description: Giving cash gifts can be a touchy subject in this city on the Mississippi River where three of the least affluent states -- Tennessee, Mississippi and Arkansas -- converge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLSRUHER, NELLIE MAY
description: KARLSRUHER-Nellie May. Wife of the late Herbert P. Karlsruher and the late Willard F. Greenwald. Devoted mother of Mary Jane Denzer of White Plains, NY and the late Dr. Willard F. Greenwald, Jr. Stepmother of Jane Shedlin of Palm Beach, FL. Also survived by 11 grandchildren and 12 greatgrandchildren. Funeral service at the Mishkan Israel Temple, 785 Ridge Road, Hamden, CT, Tuesday at 2 PM. Interment in Mishkan Israel Cemetery, Whalley Avenue, Westville. For more information call Weller Funeral Home.

title: Opponent of Lead-Paint Bill Misstated Its Provisions
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 24, 1998
description: Weeks

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Vegas Here? No Dice
description: SHOULD Atlantic City resemble Las Vegas in any way?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KWARTLER, HARRY
description: KWARTLER-Harry. Remembering those wonderful growing up years with you in Raananah. We'll miss you. Anita and Bill Newman

title: Hunting Sharks Without Reverence
description: Regarding your article about Russell Drumm, who wrote a book about Frank Mundus [''A Book With Bite: The Tail About 'Jaws,'' April 12]. Mr. Mundus is often regarded as the person upon whom the character of the sea captain in the movie ''Jaws'' is based.

title: POSTINGS: A Second Excelsior for Hackensack; 267 Rentals on a Ridge With Manhattan Views
description: A 267-unit rental apartment building, almost a twin to one completed next door in 1990, is rising at 170 Prospect Avenue in Hackensack, N.J., set on a ridge facing Manhattan.

title: Film Extra Runs Into Godzilla. Flees. (Stay Tuned.)
description: Hank Eulau has a face Hollywood loves. With Coke bottle glasses, a beaming smile and a classic sweep-over coiffure, he has been seen in the film ''Copland,'' a Rolling Stones video and the HBO television series ''Sex in the City.''

title: The Disconnected; Attachment Theory: The Ultimate Experiment
description: On a bright, cold day in February, at a clinic in the mountains outside Denver, a mother sits with her arms folded across her chest and a polite, bewildered smile on her face. She is talking about her adopted son, the boy whose troubles have brought her here to the Attachment Center at Evergreen, where she hopes he can be taught to love her. It's just that the boy is so ''strange,'' she says, his emotions so ''artificial.'' When she and her husband brought him home from Romania in June 1991, the boy was 4 and his sister, whom they also adopted, was 8. Their mother was dead, the Romanian adoption broker had said, and their father was an alcoholic and nearly blind. When he wasn't forcing them to beg in the streets or looking for ways to fob them off on childless foreigners, he neglected them.

title: Ms. Wolpert, Mr. Scharfenberger
description: Pamela Wolpert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Wolpert of Northport, N.Y., is to be married there today to Joseph Michael Scharfenberger Jr., a son of Joan M. Reilly of Centerport, N.Y., and Mr. Scharfenberger of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y. The Rev. Eric J. Weaver is to perform the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Crown Affair
description: A passionate romance between a dashing Spaniard (John Gilbert) and a 17th-century Swedish monarch (Greta Garbo) may be ficticious but it seems real, as does everything in QUEEN CHRISTINA (1933), a brilliant, literate vehicle for the great Greta. With exceptionally effective dialogue and stylishly direct piloting by Rouben Mamoulian, the story moves forward compellingly, in a lavish production. Gilbert is entirely persuasive as the fiery Spaniard, but it is the simple, forthright and luminous performance of Garbo that vivifies this splendid production. The last shot -- of her face at the prow of a ship carrying her dead lover -- is one of the screen's historical close-ups -- Saturday at 5 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies. Howard Thompson

title: The Fine Art of Making the Invisible Visible
description: PHOTOGRAPHY'S potential to assist science was trumpeted from the moment the medium was introduced to the world. Small wonder: Francois Dominique Arago, the persuasive force behind the French Government's sponsorship of the daguerreotype, was a distinguished physicist and astronomer excited by photography's possible contributions to science. Daguerre himself reportedly took the first photographs of the moon, probably at Arago's suggestion.

title: Hospital Lawyers Are Upheld
description: WESTCHESTER County's two former top lawyers did nothing wrong when they took jobs at the Westchester Medical Center, but they should be barred from dealing with the county government in certain matters, a nationally known expert on legal ethics has concluded.

title: Jenny Fahnestock, Michael Axelman
description: Jenny Hadden Fahnestock, a daughter of Mimi B. Fahnestock of New York and the late Anthony E. Fahnestock, is to be married today to Michael Joshua Axelman, a son of Elaine Broudy of Narberth, Pa., and Sidney Axelman of Wyncote, Pa. Rabbi Paul Cohen is to officiate at Migis Lodge in South Casco, Me.

title: Transportation Survey
description: In its first quarterly survey of commuters, Metro-North received an average grade of 8 out of 10 points from about 4,000 travelers who responded to the questionnaire, Dan Brucker, a spokesman for the transportation system, said.

title: Meatless in Jersey: Faux Franks
description: Armed with a 16-ounce bottle of French's mustard and a six-pack of Diet Coke, I ventured into unknown territory: the land of the meatless hot dog.

title: Political Briefing; Kentucky Election Derby Focuses on Senate Seat
description: With Kentucky voters headed for the polls on Tuesday to nominate a Democrat and a Republican to compete in the fall for the Senate seat being vacated by Wendell H. Ford, a Democrat, the Republican contest appears to be over already -- if the pollsters have it right. Representative Jim Bunning, a former big-league pitcher who represents the Fourth Congressional District in the state's northeast corner, leads State Senator Barry Metcalf of Richmond by better than 3 to 1, the latest surveys say.

title: States Embrace The Web
description: THE information superhighway now runs through all 50 states and the District of Columbia. For generations, travelers have written to state capitals to get maps and event calendars, plus thick bunches of motel brochures and discount tickets to amusement parks. But now this sort of travel information that was requested by mail and sent by the same route is findable on the Worldwide Web. The Travel Industry Association of America even has a Web site, www.tia.org, that provides a list of the state Web sites in hypertext, which means that most states' Web pages can be called up from a central site.

title: Corrections
description: A Reuters obituary of the film and television director Gene Fowler Jr. last Sunday misidentified the recipient of an Academy Award for the 1947 documentary ''Seeds of Destiny.'' The award went to the Army Pictorial Service of the Signal Corps, the producer of the film, not to Mr. Fowler, its editor.

title: Creative Unconscious
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pizza Delivery Prized by the Cognescenti
description: PIZZA restaurants called Albert's, Anna's, Alfredo's, Jimmy's, Maria's, Matt's, Rocco's, Sam's and Sonny's cover Long Island. Many open and close without fanfare. Understandably, when Nick's opened about three and a half months ago, few Long Island diners took notice. Some, however, knew that Nick's was not just another pizza joint, but an Island branch of the now almost legendary Nick's Pizza in Forest Hills.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It shows that the best way to resolve our problem is by spilling our sweat together and not our blood across the divide.''

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Tax to Preserve Open Space Gets Growing Support
description: WITH development pressures on the rise so are concerns about the loss of open space, prompting a growing number of municipalities and counties across New Jersey to establish trust funds supported by special taxes to maintain open space.

title: Sign Jars a Landmark Area
description: When a huge vinyl billboard depicting a young blond couple frolicking suddenly appeared on the wall of a building at 123 Waverly Place, near the Avenue of the Americas, some Greenwich Village residents were furious. They worried that the sign could be a beachhead for more like it in the landmarked district.

title: Desperate for Contact, Even With Cameras
description: ONCE again, Anthony loses control. Housed in a small dormitory room, he has found one of his roommates looking through his things. Anyone would be angry, but Anthony explodes. Alerted by the ruckus, dormitory supervisors separate the boys and quickly remove two of them from the room. Anthony, 13, is alone with a counselor named Boris Zimbrano, called Z.

title: The Nation; How To Break Up Microsoft
description: STACKED against the landmark antitrust cases of the past, the actions taken by Department of Justice against Microsoft last week are pint-sized. The behemoth Standard Oil Company was broken up more than 80 years ago into 34 refining companies, pipelines and other pieces. AT&T was broken up into one long-distance and seven regional phone companies. The Government spent 13 years trying to dismantle I.B.M. before dropping the effort in 1982 out of exhaustion. All the Government wanted from Microsoft last week was less heavy-handed behavior.

title: The Most Religious Century
description: It was hardly an opinion one expected to hear from Norman Mailer. ''Religion to me is now the last frontier,'' the writer said in a recent interview.

title: POSTINGS: $1.5 Million Restoration of Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater in Central Park; A New Look, With Strings Attached
description: Third-graders laughed as King Noggin of the Lilliputians served bubble-gum soup and popcorn sandwiches to Dr. Lemuel Gulliver during a rehearsal of ''Gulliver'' at the newly restored Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater in Central Park a few days ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPOSANU, PAMFIL
description: RIPOSANU-Pamfil. On May 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Marguerite. Loving father of Ann Maria and son-in-law Jan Ter Haar. Also survived by a brother-in-law, two sisters-in-law and 10 nieces and nephews. Lawyer and former Ambassador from the Kingdom of Romania to Washington. A very special, gentle and giving man who loved people and always will be remembered by his family and friends. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday, May 26, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, May 27, 10 AM, St. Catherine of Sienna Church, 411 E. 68 St.

title: An Irish Filmmaker Takes On a New Set of Troubles
description: Like most people of his generation, Terry George grew up with the war and, of course, the protests. It was the defining event of his youth; he even served time in jail for it. And he has made it the center of his art as a screenwriter and a director.

title: MetroStars Win 2d in a Row
description: The MetroStars won their second game in a row tonight, once again building a substantial lead and then hanging on, barely, at the end. This time it was the Miami Fusion making things interesting in the final 15 minutes, before losing, 4-2, before 56,404 fans at Giants Stadium.

title: Pow! The Punches That Left Marvel Reeling
description: FOR decades, Spider-Man, the Incredible Hulk and other Marvel Comics characters have battled all manner of foes, escaping death and saving millions of lives with the help of their special powers. But all their conquests in the rough-and-tumble Marvel Universe could not prepare them for the real world.

title: VIEWPOINT; Why Microsoft Should Be Left Alone
description: UNDERLYING the recent antitrust action against the Microsoft Corporation is the belief that technology markets operate differently from other markets in a way that allows certain products to lock in a dominant competitive position.

title: Peace Advances in Northern Ireland
description: With Friday's historic referendum on the peace accords, voters strongly endorsed a new politics for Northern Ireland, one in which differences are settled by political institutions instead of guns. It will take years to construct a permanent peace, but the vote was a vital down payment. Even though exit polls showed that Protestants were considerably less enthusiastic than Catholics, more than 70 percent of voters in Northern Ireland embraced a turn toward tranquillity. That achievement and the prospect of further progress are not diminished because some voted no.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the Arts & Leisure section today about the idea of the diva in pop music as well as classical misspells the surname of an Argentine tenor. He is Jose Cura, not Curra.

title: The Art of Discovery At Purchase College
description: OUTDOOR sculpture lends itself to discovery, inviting responses as spontaneous as the environment itself.

title: Trusting a Playwright's Language
description: MOST actors believe there is nothing harder than going on stage with a child. But is it any easier to play one? And what if the performer has to age from 10 to 80 in mid-sentence?

title: SUNDAY: May 24, 1998; YOUR HALL OF HALLS
description: On Saturday, the American Museum of Natural History in New York will open its Hall of Biodiversity, a new 11,000-square-foot, $17.8 million permanent exhibit celebrating the interdependency of life on Earth. *This was some undertaking. To build a huge diorama of a rain forest, 500,000 plastic leaves, representing 61 different species, were cut -- including 5,000 snipped by the pudgy hands of 25,000 school kids. *Sixty species of arthropods are represented, including millipedes whose every leg was trimmed by hand. *Part of the message, of course, is that the rain forests are under siege, so the diorama is split into pristine and degraded sections. *In case you're wondering: no animals were harmed to make it all possible. The body hair on the Emperor moths, for instance, was made from recycled scrap fur.

title: Practiced Deception
description: A TANGLED WEB

title: May 17-23; $195 Million Lottery Prize
description: Beating odds of more than 80 million to 1, a 67-year-old retired electrician from Illinois won the biggest lottery jackpot ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOCHEVER, JOAN ALINE
description: BOOCHEVER-Joan Aline. Beloved sister of Margery Boochever Perlo, died on May 6, 1998. She was a wonderful, loving human being who enriched the lives of all who knew her. Her family is deeply saddened by their loss. There will be a private family memorial.

title: Prosperity Makes Generosity Grow
description: Maybe it's the fat economy, or Midwestern generosity. Whatever the reason, graduates and newlyweds in De Kalb, Ill., are taking in larger financial gifts these days.

title: Sports of The Times; Will the Numbers Work Out for Piazza as He Shifts to New York?
description: THE uniform was waiting for Mike Piazza, and so was the number. Thirty-one. John Franco had worn that number for 15 years, but on Friday he voluntarily gave it up to help acclimate Piazza after his wild Pac-Man ricochet from coast to coast to coast.

title: Patricia Cooper, Andres Guevara
description: Patricia Ann Cooper and Andres Rene Guevara, assistant district attorneys in Manhattan, are to be married today at the Church Center for the United Nations. The Episcopal ceremony is to be performed by Suffragan Bishop Catherine S. Roskam of New York.

title: The Heart of Israel
description: SOLDIER OF PEACE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISNER, CHARLES H.
description: WISNER-Charles H., 91. Of Manasota Key, Florida, died May 20 1998 in Englewood, Florida. He was born October 30, 1906, in New York City, was raised in Summit, New Jersey and later moved to Weston, Connecticut where he lived most of his life before coming to Manasota Key in 1971. Mr. Wisner graduated from Lawrenceville Preparatory School in 1924 & from Princeton University in 1928. He then was a Commander in the United States Navy during W.W. II and as National Skeet Champion he was recruited by the Navy prior to W.W. II to be a member of the Staff of Naval Air Command Training to head their gunnery program. Mr. Wisner was co-owner of Wisner & deClairville Stock Brokers in New York City which later sold to Spear, Leeds and Kellogg where he was a limited partner until his death. He was past President of Buttonwood Club (Noon luncheon group of the New York Stock Exchange), Founding member of Aspetuck Valley Country Club and the Weston Gun Club, Past President of Manasota Key Association, and member of Squadron ''A'' in New York City. Survivors include three daughters; Matilda J.W. Barrett and Susan A. Wisner both of Venice, Florida and Penelope J. Wisner of San Francisco, California and a granddaughter; Christopher Lee Barrett of Boca Raton, Florida. He was preceded in death by his wife of sixty years, Mary Jane Wisner, in 1996. A memorial Service for Mary Jane Wisner and Charles H. Wisner will be held at 11:00 A.M. on Tuesday, June 16th, 1998 at Emmanel Church, Lyons Plains Road, Weston, Connecticut. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Southwest Florida, 5955 Rand Boulevard, Sarasota, Florida 34238.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHBARDT, SEYMOUR
description: ROTHBARDT-Seymour. The Accident Prevention & Safety League notes with sorrow the death of Seymour Rothbardt. Seymour served as President of the League for over 25 years and was instrumental in developing and promoting its insurance programs for the Building Maintenance Industry. His gruff exterior could not conceal his warm heart or the love he felt for family and friends. To his dear wife, Charlotte, and his beloved children Patty and Mitchell we extend our heartfelt condolences. Stanley Doobin, President Louis Dauber, Vice President George Gersten, Secretary Philip Bell, Treasurer Joseph M. Gnesin, Manager

title: Sponsor Retention Of Unsold Shares
description: To The Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITLITZ, BONNIE SUE
description: GITLITZ-Bonnie Sue. On May 21, 1998. Loving daughter of Jerry and the late Jacqueline. Beloved sister of Kenneth. Devoted granddaughter of Jean Scher. Cherished aunt of Rebecca and Lindsay and respected friend of many. Service Sunday 11:15AM, ''The Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Special Care Given to Centenarians
description: The May 3 article, ''Living to be 100: Anger, Arthritis and Occasional Joy,'' caught my eye because it was graced by a picture of my 104-year-old grandmother, Ida Cohen. The article noted that advanced age poses many problems and that sometimes there is no alternative to a nursing home. What should be added, however, is the difference that quality care can provide.

title: May 17-23; Putting Some Pop in Economics
description: The audience in Windhoek, the tiny desert capital of Namibia, was full of government ministers from all over Africa and the corporate executives who do business with them. They were listening to a Harvard University professor give a speech -- a pretty fiery one for an economist -- calling on the West to forgive Africa's debt and on Africa to pull itself together and endure the pain of free trade.

title: For Art And Life
description: To help a museum; to remember a giant of music and encourage those who would emulate him; to give comfort and hope to those whose lives are touched by cancer.

title: The Nation; Rating the Bigshots: Gates vs. Rockefeller
description: LET the competition begin to write the first rough drafts of the Bill Gates chapter in American history.

title: Balancing Act for State Arts Council Chief
description: THROUGHOUT a decade of major readjustment in the area of public financing of the arts, the New York State Council on the Arts has played a constant if sometimes shaky role in the life of the arts community. When Nicolette B. Clarke took charge as executive director in 1996, the agency had been devastated by cutbacks that severely undermined its mission.

title: Suharto's 'Painful' Fall? Not for Indonesians
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor Tryon
description: To the Editor: When I visited the Tryon Palace in New Bern, N.C. (''Time and Again in North Carolina,'' April 26), I, a New Yorker, was surprised to learn that the same Governor William Tryon who lived there in the 1760's, subsequently became the last royal Governor of New York in the 1770's. Fort Tryon Park in Manhattan is named for him.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on page 4 of the Travel section today misspells the surname of a spokeswoman for the Virginia tourism agency. She is Martha Steger, not Stager.

title: SOAPBOX; Horses Deserve Better
description: MOVIEGOERS are lining up to see ''The Horse Whisperer'' and weep as patient love redeems a badly injured horse and just coincidentally fosters a gauzy romance between whisperer and mom. And recently readers -- in best-selling numbers -- were moved by ''The Man Who Listens to Horses,'' Monty Roberts, and his denuciations of cruelty. But these gallons of tears, I suspect, will do exactly nothing for the thousands of actual horses who suffer at our hands.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAIFETZ, CHARLOTTE
description: CHAIFETZ-Charlotte. On May 23. Dearest mother. 13 years have passed since you left us. Our thoughts and our love are with you each and every day. Rest in Peace. Sons, Barry, Alan;, daughters-in-law, Maureen and Lynn and the family.

title: A Bob Hope Clause Means Without Him, All Bets Are Off
description: Bob Hope celebrates his 95th birthday on Friday. On Tuesday night at 10, AMC will show ''Bob Hope: The Road to the Top,'' a new one-hour special that traces his career from vaudeville to television.

title: A Six-Screen Plan Goes Dark
description: It has been a bone of contention for nearly two years, ever since it was proposed. But a plan to erect a six-screen movie theater in TriBeCa has now been abandoned by its developers, who think they can make more money with apartments than with films.

title: In SoHo, The Art of Cooking
description: ALISON ON DOMINICK STREET ** [rating: two stars]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELLER, BELLE
description: ZELLER-Belle, Ph.D. On May 22, 1998. Beloved aunt of Laura Glass, Alice Glass and Mark Gutman, Susan and Richard Weiss, Marjorie Wishbow, David Zeller, and Janet Zeller. Contributions in her memory to Belle Zeller Scholarship Trust Fund, c/o Professional Staff Congress, 25 W. 43rd Street, Suite 620, NY, NY 10036. Service private.

title: For Women and Girls, a Global Forum for Navigating the Web
description: ALISON BERKE'S desk is a mess.

title: Ms. Mennone And Mr. Reilly
description: Katherine Mennone was married yesterday to Thomas J. Reilly 3d at the Unitarian-Universalist Fellowship in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. James R. Covington performed the ceremony.

title: Sinatra's True Legacy: The Singing Itself; Turning a 32-Bar Song Into a 3-Act Play
description: IN the 25 or so years before the advent of Frank Sinatra, America produced a body of magnificent songs, unique on earth. They were beautifully constructed melodies with literate, sensitive and often witty lyrics. In Sinatra, they finally got a singer worthy of them, who set them in frames in a museum of what is now seen as a golden age, when much popular music was good and much good music was popular.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Black Ajax

title: Political Briefing; Candidate in Wild Brawl, But It's With Former Aide
description: Geoffrey Fieger has never been one to hide his candle under a bushel. As the lawyer for Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who has assisted more than 100 suicides, Mr. Fieger has seldom missed an opportunity to grab a microphone or podium.

title: A Plucky Damsel Tests Her Mettle in Camelot
description: Quest For Camelot

title: Not Much in Common, Except Commitment to a Vision
description: THE three current exhibitions at the Jersey City Museum would seem to lack a common thread: one consists of hard-hitting realist painting, another of sculpture presented as toys, the third of ethereal abstract painting made with lace. It's evident that all the work was made by artists with ambition and obsessions, and the attitudes driving their art turn out to be strongly complementary.

title: Guest Is Assaulted at a Park Avenue Hotel
description: A guest at a luxury hotel on Park Avenue opened his door Friday night to what he thought was room service, but instead was confronted by two armed men who robbed and sexually assaulted him, the police said.

title: HOT DIGGITY! DOG DIGGITY! -- QUICK BITE/Cathy's; Ordering a la Cart
description: Catherine Fogarty, whose sign is featured on the cover, has held court -- or, dare we say, has held cart -- for 15 years at the corner of Bergen Boulevard and Edsall Boulevard in Palisades Park.

title: Backtalk; Answers Start With Us
description: ''To be a good sport in an elite athletic group requires moral resistance or moral courage,'' said Brenda Jo Light Bredemeier, a psychologist at the University of California at Berkeley. ''It's considered a disadvantage to be moral because you put at risk the opportunity to win.''

title: Congress Must Lead Inquiry on China; Security on Satellites
description: To the Editor:

title: Carol Marquardt and Peter Carr
description: Carol Ann Marquardt and Peter Paul Carr were married yesterday by the Rev. Edwin C. Fredrich at St. Lucas Evangelical Lutheran Church in Kewaskum, Wis.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Rising Tide: The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927

title: Suharto's 'Painful' Fall? Not for Indonesians
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time, Peter Falk Is Part of the Mystery
description: THE enduring concern of Arthur Miller, playwright, novelist, screenwriter and memoirist, is America's loss of its sense of the past, its sense of the continuity that is only apparent when past and present blend as they do in the lap-dissolve once favored in silent movies. One image is superimposed on another, each informing the other to give us some fix as to where we have been and where we're now heading. To heaven, one might hope, but, the playwright warns, possibly to hell in a handbasket.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Lost and Found

title: Spirit Versus the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION; Confessions of a Daytime Television Addict
description: YEARS ago, while living in Chicago, I took a job stripping woodwork with a fellow named Harry. We'd enter a client's home, unload our tankards of poison and immediately turn on the TV. It was Harry's idea. A self-proclaimed addict, he was the sort of person who went to bed and woke up to the sound of a television. If the homeowner was a bookworm, my boss would bring his own set, a full-size model stained and disfigured by chemical stripper.

title: Where Movie Fans Can Retreat From the Heat
description: The summer season of the New Jersey International Film Festival, sponsored by the Rutgers Film Co-op and the New Jersey Media Arts Center, runs from Friday through July 29. Unless otherwise noted, all programs begin at 7 P.M. and take place at one of the following locations: Borders Books & Music, Mid-State Mall, Route 18 South, East Brunswick; West Windsor-Plainsboro Middle School, 55 Grover's Mill Road, Plainsboro; Room 123, Scott Hall, Rutgers University, College Avenue and Hamilton Street, College Avenue Campus, New Brunswick, or the State Theater, 15 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick. All double features are screened in the order listed with a 10-minute intermission. Unless otherwise noted, admission to programs at Borders and Plainsboro are free; at Scott 123, $5 ($4 for members); at the State Theater, $8 ($6 for members). Information: (732) 932-8482 or http://www.rci. rutgers.edu/nigrin.

title: No Lizards, Just People
description: ''Godzilla'' it's not. But then, ''West New York'' cost $130,000 to make, which might cover a couple of minutes of giant-lizard special effects. ''West New York,'' made by Steve Bretschneider of South Nyack, N.Y., and Phil Gallo of Glen Oaks on Long Island, was inspired by the disappearance of a truckload of corporate bonds somewhere in New Jersey a few years ago. The film is about a bank security officer who filches some bonds and gets caught up with a lot of bad people. It was filmed almost entirely in New Jersey: West New York, Jersey City, Hoboken, Weehawken and the Meadowlands. People in these places are fairly jaded about film making, Mr. Bretschneider said, but when they saw his tiny crew dragging equipment out of a car, the shop owners, police officers and town officials ''showed pity and really helped us out.''

title: The World; Formerly Arrogant, Utterly Argentine
description: AT the Summit of the Americas in Santiago, Chile, last month, several foreign ministers from Latin American countries derided President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina after he arrived late for the official photo session, making 33 other heads of state, including President Clinton, wait.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Ink Spots Perform in Nyack

title: Tanker Regulations
description: As a result of a fatal crash in Yonkers on Oct. 9, 1997, involving a car and a gasoline tanker, the National Transportation Safety Board has announced a ban on carrying gasoline and other hazardous material in so-called ''wet lines,'' the loading nozzles where fuel is pumped into tankers.

title: Corrections
description: A credit with a cartoon on May 10 about the Clinton family's attitude toward sex misstated the affiliation of the cartoonist, Henry Payne. His work is distributed by the Scripps Howard News Service, not U.S. News and World Report.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: INVISIBLE WRITER

title: HOT DIGGITY! DOG DIGGITY! -- QUICK BITE/Callahan's; A Family Kind of Place
description: The diners two tables away were discussing whether it's possible to overdose on hot dogs. This is not a frivolous question at Callahan's, whose name invariably comes up when you ask where to get a good hot dog in northern New Jersey.

title: Berlin, Still the City of a Fateful Century
description: FOR most of this century, this city has been at the epicenter of Europe's history, from two world wars to the cold war, sometimes the pugnacious core of aggression, sometimes the pampered victim -- a hub of conflict whose spokes first reached out to distant empires and the death camps themselves, then drew Washington and Moscow into a destiny computed on the threat of nuclear war.

title: May 17-23; Oregon Student Is Held In Killing of Four
description: Pearl, Miss. West Paducah, Ky. Jonesboro, Ark. Edinboro, Pa. Now Springfield, Ore. For the fifth time in less than a year, an angry student went to school with a gun and opened fire. And for the fifth time, a nation asked, ''How is this possible?''

title: Lewis Feldberg, Tzipora Taube
description: Tzipora Taube, the daughter of Esther Taube of Tel Aviv and the late Shmuel Taube, is to be married today to Lewis Robert Feldberg, the son of Barbara Feldberg and Prof. Meyer Feldberg of New York. Rabbi Judd Levingston is to officiate at Arden House in Harriman, N.Y.

title: Ms. Steinberg And Mr. Golick
description: Katharine Tracy Rachel Steinberg and Jeffrey Scott Golick, book editors in Manhattan, are to be married today by Rabbi Joel S. Goor at the Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum in the Bronx.

title: Bookend; Winging It
description: Perhaps the strangest line in the movie ''City of Angels'' is uttered by Dennis Franz, playing an ex-seraph who has voluntarily become mortal to enjoy earthly life. Franz says that he's never told his wife about his former career because ''no one believes in us anymore.'' No one? Hasn't he noticed the best-seller lists of the past few years? A quick computer search, or a tour of the New Age section of any Barnes & Noble, would have told him otherwise: there are countless books on angels, near-death experiences, seances, to say nothing of ''Angels in America,'' ''Highway to Heaven'' and ''Touched by an Angel.'' If he had come clean to his wife, her memoirs might be in their third printing by now.

title: A Diplomat Who Says 'Read My Pins'
description: FOR Madeleine K. Albright, a woman who likes jewelry, temptation didn't begin with an apple but with a serpent. But by now, temptation has become a trademark, and even a bit of shtick.

title: Just Desserts
description: I was charmed by Hila Colman's vision of how she wants her old age to be different from her youth. In today's climate of youth worship, the simple philosophy of acceptance can offset much misplaced energy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEDER, MANDY, THOMAS T.
description: HEDER-MANDY-Thomas T. 55, on May 22, 1998 in Sarasota, FL. Loving husband of Sondra Kay. Father of Tyson, Christy Collins and Brian Hutson. Son of Klara Heder and nephew of Laszlo de Mandy. Tom spent his entire career in the hotel and club business and was the General Manager of the Yale Club of NYC from 1987-1994. A memorial service in New York will be planned for a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the Marie Selby Botanical Gardens, 811 South Palm Avenue, Sarasota, FL 34236.

title: Development Group Builds High-End Houses
description: TAKE a strong-minded Wall Street financier, a quality home builder and an award-winning architect who is a woman, put them together and they become a tenacious real estate development group, currently building Westchester's largest single-family community of 93 houses at Hardscrabble Lake in Chappaqua.

title: Transplanting A New Lotus
description: SHOULD Lotus sell its Elise roadster in the United States? Lotus wants to know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIGNER, HANA
description: EIGNER-Hana. Beloved wife of the late Ernst. Loving mother of Michael (Linda). Cherished grandmother of Alyson and Dana. Services today, 10 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapels, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon.

title: One Man's Fire Hydrant Is Another's Objet Trouve
description: The fire hookup pipes that dot the sidewalks often do double duty as seats for weary pedestrians. But one standpipe, near the northwest corner of Broadway and 43d Street, has taken on a third role. It has become a work of art. A museum-style plaque reading ''Paul Richard Untitled 1998'' has been attached to its stem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACIVER, LOREN
description: MacIVER-Loren. Died peacefully at her home in Greenwich Village, NY, on May 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late poet and critic Lloyd Frankenberg. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend. As we move forward, her extraordinary spirit lives through our memories and her art. At Loren's request, no services are planned. Philippe Alexandre Andrew H. Arnot Eric Brown Tibor de Nagy Gallery

title: Planting the Seeds Of a College Fund
description: In the New York area, a Jewish child raised in well-to-do circles can spend every weekend of his or her 13th year at lavish bar and bat mitzvah celebrations. Much of the money spent on the affairs comes back -- in the form of cash gifts.

title: Classical Briefs
description: BEETHOVEN: PIANO CONCERTO NO. 5; VIOLIN CONCERTO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMUTTER, JOSEPH A.
description: PERLMUTTER-Joseph A. May 20, 1998 in Boca Raton, Florida. Born in Poughkeepsie, New York. Beloved husband of Bette. Father of Joel and Fred. Brother of Alvin. He contributed so much to his family and his communities in Poughkeepsie and Boca Raton. He will be deeply missed.

title: Sandy Leads His School
description: Doug Sandy led Boys and Girls High School of Brooklyn to its seventh straight boys' outdoor title yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League championships at St. John's University. Sandy, a senior, won the 400 and 800 meters and anchored the winning 4X400 relay. Boys and Girls totaled 117 points to 69 by the runner-up, Jefferson. The girls' title went to A. P. Randolph of Manhattan, 76 points to 73 over Tottenville of Staten Island.

title: On 'Terminator 2'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bulworth Critique
description: It would be nice to say that ''Bulworth,'' Warren Beatty's new political farce, gives a distorted picture of the role of money in Washington. But the fact is the movie pretty well nails the real-life truth of campaign finance. Congress has crafted and is fighting to preserve a system of campaign finance that amounts to legalized bribery.

title: Good Time, Good Cause
description: It's hard to think about an all-you-can-eat hot dog dinner as an austerity measure, but, in a way, that's how it all began.

title: SOAPBOX; Plate Tectonics
description: WITH the millennium close at hand, it may be time to take stock. How far have we come in confronting the myriad forms of discrimination that beset us? Apparently not very, as I recently learned. I can report that there is at least one ''ism'' that has bypassed the courts, legislatures, think tanks and talk shows. It knows no gender, race or religion. Though admittedly trivial in comparison with the racism, sexism and nationalism that have plagued the 20th century, it nonetheless cries out for attention. I call it plateism -- an irrational hatred of those with out-of-state license plates, particularly those from New Jersey.

title: Growing Pains
description: 1898 The Birth of the American Century.

title: A Little Something 'For Good Luck'
description: Jenny Wyatt, editor of Ten to Eighteen, a national newsletter for parents of teen-agers based in Seattle, likes to give 50 one-dollar bills as gifts for special birthdays of nieces and nephews. For their four children, she and her husband have each given a dollar bill for each year of age.

title: If Sentiment Fails, Cold Cash Will Do
description: WHEN Rema Giordano prepares for a big occasion at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia, there is no need to set out a table for elegant packages. These days, Ms. Giordano says, most gifts come in small white envelopes.

title: Homers and Hot Dogs, Still Perfect Together
description: THIS is truly cooking for a crowd, the operation in the stainless steel expanse behind the concessions counters at Waterfront Park. On a summer night, fans at Trenton Thunder games put away an astonishing array of food, but mostly they eat hot dogs.

title: Word for Word / Godzilla Lit; When Cineastes Meet Dragon, The Breathing Gets Hot
description: WELL, so what if the new ''Godzilla'' movie stinks? It is protected by an immutable dictum of Godzilla cinema: To be good, it is preferable for a Godzilla movie to be bad. A good movie with Godzilla in it (have you ever seen one?) may be by definition a bad Godzilla movie. Conversely, a bad movie in which Godzilla appears is bound to be a good Godzilla movie. In summation, the ideal Godzilla movie is, paradoxically and counterintuitively, the classic ''good bad'' movie, the elements of which can include but are not limited to lousy dubbing and stentorian proclamations from Raymond Burr.

title: INSIDE
description: Nuremberg Prosecutor Dies

title: Classical Briefs
description: GRIFFES: CHAMBER AND PIANO WORKS

title: A Spanish Civil War at Scudder
description: YOU'D figure they would shout, ''Ole!''

title: One Kind of Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Introduction
description: The cover article on office romance drew reprimands for its ''overemphasis'' on the looks of the women interviewed and for the ''sexist slant'' of its illustrations. Readers without siblings, and parents in general, were reassured by ''What Only-Child Syndrome?''

title: Editorial Observer; Campaigning for Office on the Mommy Track
description: Massachusetts was buzzing this month with news that Jane Swift, a Republican candidate for lieutenant governor, is pregnant. Congratulations were not necessarily in order. ''The surprising thing is the way people keep telling me: 'I defended you,' '' says Ms. Swift, who was unaware until recently that her condition needed defending. Talk-radio callers claimed mothers-to-be should be nesting, not campaigning. An executive of the Christian Coalition predicted that Ms. Swift's pregnancy would spark discussions about whether children were better off at home with their parents or in ''institutional day care.''

title: Keeping It All in the Gabelli Family
description: MARIO GABELLI, the famed investor and the chief executive of Gabelli Funds, has garnered much attention as he prepares his money management complex for a public offering.

title: Eloquent And Elated: 'Great Day For Ireland'
description: From Dublin on the Irish Sea to rocky Connemara and Galway Bay in the west, from Cork in the south to Dundalk near the border with Northern Ireland, people in the Irish Republic congratulated themselves and their northern neighbors today on their overwhelming vote for the Northern Ireland peace agreement in Friday's referendum.

title: A Sensational Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Colonial Minstrel Makes It 5 in a Row
description: In a sizzling homestretch duel between two superior fillies, Colonial Minstrel slipped through along the rail to defeat Dixie Flag by one length in the Shuvee Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday and extend her winning streak to five.

title: Tracy Torre, Sean McManus
description: Tracy Lynne Torre was married yesterday to Sean Joseph McManus, the president of CBS Sports, at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Harold Ridley, the president of Loyola College in Baltimore, performed the ceremony.

title: Keelin Murphy, Paul Gallagher
description: Keelin Kathryn Murphy, a marketing associate in the New York office of the Starbucks Coffee Company, and Paul Christian Gallagher, an associate producer in New York of ''60 Minutes,'' the CBS television news magazine, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington. The Rev. Joseph V. Gallagher, a former president of the Paulist Order and the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony.

title: In the Region/Long Island; For Assisted Living, There's Someplace Like Home
description: AT first glance the Victorian-style building on Forest Avenue looks like yet another of this North Shore community's many mansions, but on the new side.

title: Janeen Renaghan, Gary Stellato
description: Janeen Nell Renaghan, the daughter Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Renaghan of Glen Cove, N.Y., was married last evening to Gary Francis Stellato, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony C. Stellato of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Marcia Grace, an interfaith minister, officiated at the de Seversky Center in Old Westbury, N.Y.

title: Science Fiction
description: Jonathan Lethem has no patience for rigid genre boundaries. His recent novel ''Gun, With Occasional Music'' (1995) mixed noirish detective fiction a la Raymond Chandler with near-future science fiction to produce an entertainment of delicious irrelevance. GIRL IN LANDSCAPE (Doubleday, $22.95) marries science fiction and the western, but this time around Lethem is deadly serious.

title: Just Why Do We Buy?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Ideas! It's a Novel!
description: A WIDOW FOR ONE YEAR

title: Ideas & Trends; DNA Teaches History a Few Lessons of Its Own
description: HISTORY, with all its horrors, accidents and astonishments, has been interpreted as an epic tale of great men and as a tragic tale of alienated labor. It has been interpreted through the eyes of religion, psychology and metaphysics. But now the search for another kind of history is taking place.

title: Christopher Mitchell, Saori Horikawa
description: Saori Horikawa and Christopher Scott Courtney Mitchell were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Dr. Stephen Jones, a Baptist minister, officiated at the Park View at the Boathouse restaurant in Central Park.

title: Deep Impact
description: Robert Duvall, Tea Leoni, Elijah Wood, Vanessa Redgrave, Maximilian Schell, Morgan Freeman.

title: Panel to Hear Public on Millstone Reactor
description: IN 1986, as the battle over the 800-megawatt Shoreham nuclear power plant raged across Long Island, the opening of an even larger commercial reactor less than 15 miles from East End beaches all but escaped notice.

title: Belle Zeller, 95, Union Leader And Political Science Professor
description: Belle Zeller, an emeritus professor of political science at Brooklyn College and a scholar of the legislative process who was an indomitable leader of unions representing City University of New York professors for more than 30 years, died on Friday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 95.

title: Washington Sideshow for Technology
description: LAST MONDAY, as the Department of Justice and 20 state Attorneys General filed their antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corporation, a question circulated among the venture capitalists huddled in partners meetings on Palo Alto's Sand Hill Road and other nerve centers of high-technology finance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIRO, ERNEST J. SR.
description: PIRO-Ernest J. Sr. Of Plantation, FL. Loving husband of Matilda (nee Sabbatino), cherished father of Patricia, Ernest J. Jr., and the late June Elizabeth. Grandfather of Ernest III & Deborah Piro, and Kathleen & Nevin Okay. Precious great-grandfather of Abigail. Reposing at Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd, Flushing, NY, Monday and Tuesday 2-5, 710PM. Mass Wednesday 10:15AM, St. Joan of Arc R.C. Church, 82-00 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the friendship of two West Side men of widely different ages, Harry Biele and Gary Null, misstated Mr. Null's age. He is 53, not 43. Mr. Biele is 90.

title: On the Road to Exotic Places With Two Connecticut Artists
description: PAINTINGS by the Connecticut artists Robert Cunningham and Michael Patterson at Randall Tuttle Fine Arts in Woodbury might prime viewers for making their travel plans in earnest. The two artists have been out and back, and provide clear reports of what they saw and mused upon.

title: Pradnya Haldipur, Joseph Cyriac
description: Pradnya G. Haldipur, the daughter of Gurudatta A. Haldipur of Bloomfield, N.J., and the late Dr. Asha G. Haldipur, is to be married today to Joseph Mathew Cyriac, a son of Teresa and Joseph T. Cyriac of Elizabeth, N.J. The Rev. Francis T. Maione, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Kirkpatrick Chapel of Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: At the End Of a Brief, Brilliant Turn
description: EVERYTHING ends, and the most cherished things seem to end more swiftly than anything else. No one is exempt from this dismal truth, and ballet dancers are among those most subject to it. Theirs is ''the butterfly profession,'' in the words of Anna Marie Holmes, director of Boston Ballet. ''Dancers have a short-lived time of real beauty,'' she says, ''and then you go.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOELET, FRANCIS
description: GOELET-Francis. We mourn with profound sadness, the death of our dear friend Francis Goelet. A Member of our Board of Directors for more than four decades, the longest tenure of any board member in the Metropolitan Opera's modern history, Francis Goelet's distinquished service on our board continued his family's commitment to the Metropolitan Opera, which dates back to the creation of our company more than 100 years ago. We recall his love of opera, particularly his commitment to 20th century opera and the French repertory. His extraordinary patronage leaves a legacy of 16 Met productions. In addition to his annual patronage, Francis Goelet enabled the Metropolitan Opera to present the world's premiers of three operas by American composers-''Vanessa'' and ''Antony and Cleopatra'' by Samuel Barber and ''The Ghost of Versailles'' by John Corigliano. His interest in the French repertory is represented by his gifts of the new productions and revivals of ''Les Troyens'', Samson et Dalila'', Pelleas et Melisande'', Dialogue of the Carmelites'', ''Parade'', Les Contes d'Hoffman'', and a concert version of ''The Damnation of Faust''. His commitment to young opera artists is represented by his gifts to our Young Artists Development Program, through the Kathryn T. Long Trust, where he served as the principal trustee. All of us who were privileged to know Frank, will remember his friendship with deep affection. His service to the arts, especially music and opera, will be a singular inspiration for future generations. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and his friends. The Metropolitan Opera Association

title: To Love a Lupine (or Something Like It)
description: A MILD winter and benign spring have been good for my lupines. The small plants set out last spring have become healthy clumps, and fat flower buds are forming.

title: Tribute to the Dog in Art, Belief and Everyday Life
description: FOR thousands of years, dogs and human beings have been companions, and some of that history together can be seen in ''The Wild and the Tame: Dogs in Native America'' at the Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: BOXING: Big Money, Big Fallout For Tyson; The Ex-Champion Blames the Promoter for Financial Problems
description: Early last February, Mike Tyson, staggering from an unpaid $12 million tax bill and suspended from the sport that had provided him with riches, left his Las Vegas estate desperate for cash and for a divorce from his longtime promoter, Don King.

title: Not Just a Pretty Face
description: Roses were delivered to the locker room from a female admirer, women still slip business cards under the windshield wipers of his car and he had worn fabulous clothes in photo spreads of the glamour magazines. Mike Modano gets his fair share of notice.

title: N.F.L. Is Uneasy About Diet Supplements' Use
description: During the week of Super Bowl XXXII, several Denver Broncos players, including quarterback John Elway and running back Terrell Davis, wore hats or T-shirts bearing the logo of the Colorado-based Experimental & Applied Sciences, EAS. Many Broncos are paid spokesmen for the company, which produces nutritional supplements. But the hats were not National Football League-sponsored merchandise, and wearing them during Super Bowl week while doing interviews violated league rules.

title: Lawmakers Shift View On Satellites for China
description: Earlier this week, the House overwhelmingly agreed to ban the export of American satellites to China, fearing that Beijing could glean technical expertise from the technology to improve the accuracy of its nuclear-tipped missiles.

title: A Feminist Trailblazer
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN; Serving Food for Stomach and Soul, Under One Roof
description: It's easy to overlook the little sidewalk easel on Centre Street, especially since it stands in the shadow of the majestic Police Building across the road.

title: HOT DIGGITY! DOG DIGGITY! -- QUICK BITE/Hot Grill; Staying Power, to Go
description: The Hot Grill in Clifton, another venerable institution in the wiener world, was featured as a Quick Bite in the New Jersey section on Jan. 12, 1997.

title: Principal Leaves and Parents Claim Victory for School
description: Just weeks ago, parents skewered Manuel Feliciano, principal of Community Elementary School 64, for failing to improve students' below-average test scores during his three-year tenure. Now they are rejoicing at the news that he plans to resign.

title: Rock Slide
description: Following a rock slide in Greenburgh earlier this month that damaged three passenger cars, the New York State Thruway Authority Chairman, Howard E. Steinberg, said he would step up his department's surveillance of rock walls along the highway.

title: Humankind Battles for Scrabble Supremacy
description: The day before they defended the honor of their species in Scrabble, Matt Graham and Joel Sherman convened for a final training session. Matt, who lives in a studio apartment in Manhattan crammed with dictionaries and word lists and Scrabble newsletters, went out to Joel's small house in the Bronx, which was crammed with the same stuff. The living room's decorative highlight was a Scrabble board showing the final game of last year's world championship, in which Joel defeated Matt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAUENGLASS, WILLIAM
description: FRAUENGLASS-William. On May 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Tillie. Loving father of Richard. Dear grandfather of Neil Frauenglass and Andrew Betts. Thanks, Dad. Graveside service on Sunday, 10:30 A.M., at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Ideas & Trends: Payback Time; Give Me an 'A' or Else
description: EVERY year at about this time, just as classes are winding down, college professors begin handing out a test that could be the most important of the course.

title: Miss Andringa And Mr. Pine
description: Deborah Rene Andringa, a daughter of Patricia Perkins Andringa of Bethesda, Md., and the late Calvin B. Andringa, is to be married today to Philip Stephen Pine, a son of Betsy P. Tucker of Great Neck, N.Y., and the late Richard C. Pine. Rabbi Jeffrey Wohlberg is to officiate at the Congressional Country Club in Bethesda.

title: Beatrice Williams And Alan Rude
description: Beatrice R. W. Williams and Alan J. Rude were married on Friday at the Harvard Club in New York. The Rev. Daniel Mattila, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Wells Falls to Earth Along With Fluke Hit
description: David Wells should have asked for a do-over. He was entitled to that much.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: GRACE A Fictional Memoir. By Robert Ward. Golden Books, $20.

title: Springfield Struggles to Heal Itself in Wake of Shootings
description: Springfield tried to act like a small town on a holiday today, with residents attempting to get on with their lives two days after this city became the latest embodiment of the nation's struggle with violence at schools.

title: Staid Approach, Flashy Return
description: JOHN O'TOOLE lives in a suburb of Pittsburgh, just a few miles from where he grew up.
