In an industry where portfolio managers are wont to switch jobs at the drop of a headhunter's hat, he has worked for the same company, the conservative Mellon Bank, since earning an M.B.A. 19 years ago from the University of Chicago. He drives not a sports car but a sedan -- an Oldsmobile, no less -- his latest in a succession of General Motors cars.

title: When French Actors Dare to Look West
description: ''IF you can't beat them, join them.'' A tired old cliche in English perhaps, but Cartesian enough to explain the growing numbers of French screen actors who are now seeking English-language careers in the United States. After all, if they make only French films they will reach little more than French-speaking audiences. If they join ''the other side,'' English-language movies can carry their names around the world.

title: At 5 Feet 9 Inches, Rios Has Opponents Looking Up to Him
description: He is Napoleon in Nike. He is the little man who has managed to outserve and outslide everybody else just in time for the French Open. He has John McEnroe's instincts and Andre Agassi's reflexes crammed into a 22-year-old body set atop the fastest legs since Secretariat. Like that champion, he is an athlete of few words but many moves.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Lotus Esprit V8; Nimble, Exotic and Out of Date
description: THE test track behind Lotus Group's headquarters once was an airstrip used by the Allies in World War II. Jimmy Stewart flew bombing missions over Germany in B-24's based here.

title: Concerns on Growth In Riverhead
description: Regarding ''Coalition and Builder Battle in Riverhead'' (April 12):

title: Benitez Sparks a Lively Debate on the Protocol of the Brushback Pitch
description: Before Gene Budig suspended Armando Benitez last week for hitting Tino Martinez with as purposeful a pitch as a pitcher can throw, he consulted members of his staff. The newest member of the American League president's staff is Bob Gibson.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Now You See It
description: Getting there, seizing the drama and grabbing the shot: that is what sells newspapers and attracts prizes -- in the case of The Associated Press, 25 Pulitzer prizes for photography. From Pol Pot's corpse laid out in a jungle hut to the debris of tornado-wrecked houses in Alabama, A.P. images are part of our daily fare. Since the cooperative started in 1848, technological advances have transformed news transmission into an instantaneous electronic process. But gathering the material from wars, natural disasters, and social and political upheavals remains arduous and often dangerous. Six A.P. staff members have been killed on duty during this decade alone. FLASH! The Associated Press Covers the World (The Associated Press/Abrams, $39.95) celebrates the news service's 150th anniversary with 170 photographs, introduced by the war correspondent Peter Arnett. Some of the images are among the world's best known, like Joe Rosenthal's picture of marines raising the flag at Iwo Jima during World War II. Vietnam yielded Eddie Adams's shot of the impromptu execution of a suspected Vietcong member and Huynh Cong Ut's horrific image of burned children fleeing napalm. Most images reproduced here reach for a peak moment, whether of a fiery crash or a perfect dive. So many diverse images make for a rather disjointed and unsatisfying book, and its pedestrian layout does nothing to enhance its photos. Nonetheless, the book does record much of the fury and folly of the 20th century and pays tribute to the intrepid photographers who showed up to record the spectacle. Rosemary Ranck

title: 25 Kinds of Coffee Beans And 40 Kinds of Teas
description: Concoctions so secret that even employees are kept from learning the ingredients are specialities at Java N' Jazz, a coffee bar at 868 Broadway (near 18th Street) that opened on May 16. It is known, however, that the confidential drinks are called Jazzy Mochas and Jazzy Vanillas.

title: Mark Golovcsenko, Julie Feldman
description: Julie Mara Feldman, the daughter of Frayda and Ronald Feldman of Chappaqua, N.Y., is to be married today to Mark Ivan Golovcsenko, a son of Judith and Igor Golovcsenko of Dayton, Ohio. Dr. Robert Berson, the leader of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, is to officiate at Studio 450, a party space in New York.

title: Don't Forget the Bumblebees and Other Allies
description: SOMETIMES gardeners are so busy planting and tending, they forget that there are other things going on about them. But some curious little events recently bore this out. Along the front walk one recent nippy morning, there appeared what seemed to be a dead bumblebee. But closer inspection proved it was not the case. The tiny creature seemed to be somewhat stunned in the coolness. Since all seemed well with the bumblebee, it was carefully bypassed. It seemed the sun would soon warm the day and the tiny insect would be on its way.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: CHILDREN OF GOD

title: Trendy Menu, Windows Over New Haven
description: HOTEL dining rooms have tough competition from local restaurants these days, especially in a city like New Haven, an enclave of diverse ethnic cuisines.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Gifts of the Jews

title: Lethal Fantasies of a 15-Year-Old Became a Reality
description: A week before this small city of lumber yards and computer chips was changed forever on Thursday morning, Bill Kinkel, a widely respected retired high school Spanish teacher, made a tennis date with an old friend over the telephone.

title: Assault Rifles-Dirt Cheap . . .and Legal!
description: Cars pack the lot outside hugo's show hall this bright Saturday morning -- but it's not clear what has brought the crowd here to Bealeton, Va., a small town not far from the nation's capital. That's all right with both the promoters of the event and the people showing up for it. For this is a gun show, and everyone involved seems to understand that they'll all be better off if it doesn't attract too much attention.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Unseen Strings of the Chrysler Deal
description: THERE is an old story about a couple celebrating their golden anniversary. Asked the secret to a successful marriage, they smile and reply, ''low expectations.''

title: Latvia's Library
description: The United States Information Agency has selected Maurice J. Freedman, director of the Westchester Library System, to serve as a consultant for the National Library of Latvia. Dr. Freedman will develop a catalogue database and otherwise modernize the country's services to make them more accessible to the Latvians. Dr. Freedman has consulted for libraries and established automated services in Turkey, Italy, Czechoslovakia, Kenya and Korea.

title: Splendor in a Garden of Antiquities
description: JUST north of the Piazza Navona, lines have been forming around the block to enter the newest museum of antiquities here, the Palazzo Altemps. The public apparently shares in the enthusiasm once expressed by Goethe in his ''Italian Journey'': ''Standing amid antique statues, one feels as if all the forces of Nature were in motion.''

title: Memorial Day Tomorrow
description: NEW YORK

title: Lives; Primary Colors
description: A few weeks after my daughter was born, i took her to a new pediatrician for an exam. The doctor took one look at Samantha and exclaimed: ''Wow! She's so light!'' I explained that my husband is white, but it didn't seem to help. The doctor commented on Sam's skin color so often that I finally asked what was on her mind.

title: Mayor May Trade a Term Limits Deal for Support on Stadium Issue
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will consider leading a campaign to abolish term limits for City Council members if the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, drops his drive for a referendum on a new Yankee Stadium, the Mayor said yesterday.

title: Which Bar Is One Too Many?
description: How many are too many? To the 75 plaintiffs in a lawsuit that was heard last week, 17 places serving alcohol within a four-block radius are more than enough for their SoHo neighborhood. They sued the State Liquor Authority in State Supreme Court to stop another from opening.

title: Even Out of Driver's Seat, Foyt Is Top Contender
description: A. J. Foyt, a four-time winner of the Indianapolis 500 and a Brickyard legend, will get his best chance to win the race on Sunday since he traded in his helmet for a headset.

title: FILM; Far From the Tea Ceremony, at the Heart of Japan
description: ''I AM interested in the relationship of the lower part of the human body and the lower part of the social structure,'' the Japanese director Shohei Imamura once said. ''This is where the reality of daily Japanese life supports itself.''

title: Lisa Chin, Kenneth Potash
description: Lisa Y. Chin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Chin of Forest Hills, Queens, is to be married today to Kenneth Martin Potash, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Potash of Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Richard Eisenberg is to officiate at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Don't Even Think About It. (The Cupid Cops Are Watching.)
description: There's a simple solution. Pass a law that employers cannot be sued for sexual harassment in the workplace -- only the individual can be sued. This would remove the deep-pocket financial incentives for both victims and their lawyers. I don't think my suggestion will be adopted. There is too much money at stake in keeping things the way they are.

title: VIEW; What Color Is Your Uniform?
description: ONCE upon a time -- in the 1960's and 70's, that is -- clothing for teen-agers seemed to serve a single purpose. One dressed either for or against the establishment, whatever that nebulous establishment might be. My mother read McCall's. I read ''Steal This Book,'' dressed accordingly and got precisely the reaction I craved.

title: Action Sought on Ads Favoring Incumbents
description: IF it looks like a duck, walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, the saying goes, it is a duck. But at election time, some mailings and televised announcements from elected officials often bear a strong resemblance to political campaign material -- except that they are called constituent mailings and public information announcements or newsletters and are paid for by taxpayers instead of campaign committees.

title: Hudson Trio in Lyndhurst Recital
description: THE annual Jeffrey Weiss Memorial Concert brings the Hudson Trio -- consisting of Margaret Sanzo, Constance Barrett and Maryellen Shepley -- to Tarrytown today at 1 P.M. for what promises to be ''refreshing music for a springtime afternoon.'' The recital in the restored Carriage House at Lyndhurst includes music for harp, cello and flute by Gluck, Carl Abel, C. P. E. Bach and one of the Hotteterres, the 18th-century French family that had three flute-playing brothers.

title: Two Rippers, P.C., With Relish Mother Made
description: THE restaurant of my dreams is undoubtedly some three-star something in France; my husband's is Rutt's Hut.

title: When Friends Rebel, A Reign Ends Quickly
description: It was a quick, stunning series of betrayals that shook President Suharto out of office this week. One after another, the men he had groomed and manipulated to shore up his power told him the harsh truth that he had seemed unable to grasp: It was time for him to go.

title: The Craftsmanship Of Timber Framing
description: FOR 20 years, H. Michael Lempert has been harvesting trees from his secluded 150-acre farm and cutting them into logs with a portable saw. He fits them together with handmade joints and pegs to build houses in a time-honored method of construction called timber framing. Usually he builds only one house a year.

title: Q. & A.
description: Rules on Creating Driveway

title: Habitats/200 West 20th Street; Case of Social Insecurity
description: APARTMENT-HUNTING in New York City reduced Thibaut Diez to a number. One he did not have.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Two Hollywood milestones -- a shattering antiwar tale and an early all-star drama -- are at the top of this week's film list, which also includes a nifty thriller and a stylish adventure.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Clear the Aisles for Yet Another Multiplex Cinema
description: THE latest in a long line of proposals for yet another multiplex for the county comes from National Amusements, which already owns one of the Westchester's largest and busiest movie theaters, the 10-screen All Westchester Saw Mill Multiplex Cinemas in Hawthorne.

title: Crack Down on Rage, Not Guns; Enforce the Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Hooked, Despite Pain, on Fly-Fishing for Shad
description: The Carpal Tunnel Syndrome Information Page on the Internet blames this potentially debilitating nerve strain primarily on such repetitive tasks as typing, factory work and the use of vibrating power tools. Fly-fishing for shad is not listed. But according to Richard Fasanello, who catches hundreds of shad each year on his fly rod, carpal tunnel syndrome is one of the risks -- along with swollen hands, sore muscles and gashed fingers -- facing those who cast flies for these hard-fighting gamefish.

title: How the Glitz Stole Greenwich
description: DAVID OGILVY, son of the founder of Ogilvy & Mather, the global advertising giant, sat in his real estate company's white clapboard headquarters in Greenwich, Conn., on a scorching afternoon last week.

title: Heads Up!
description: Comets

description: The chief administrative officer of the Rwanda war-crimes tribunal was here this week to ask for help, not for the first time.

title: Avoiding Sheetrock Rush Hour
description: THE SETTING -- The nighttime crowd at the Home Depot on Avery Street on a recent Friday, at the height of the home-repair season. This 168,000-square-foot store has been open all night for three years; it was the first of Home Depot's 661 stores to go around the clock.

title: Gay Cruises
description: To the Editor: As president of the International Gay and Lesbian Travel Association, I read Edwin McDowell's article ''Gay Cruises Draw Hostility in the Caribbean'' (May 10) with much interest.

title: Tigers-Terps Final; Orange Coach Retires
description: He did not go out a winner -- his team lost, 11-10, to Princeton. But for Roy Simmons Jr., the Syracuse coach who announced his retirement after yesterday's game, this moment -- a semifinal match in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament at Rutgers -- was the peak of his long career.

title: Crack Down on Rage, Not Guns; Unheard Cries for Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting Medical Fraud
description: The County Office for the Aging is looking for volunteers to help seniors fight fraud, abuse and waste in the Medicare-Medicaid system.

description: Caroline Wendy Laguerre, a Brooklyn assistant district attorney, was married yesterday to Llewelyn Owen Brown, a registered nurse at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. The Rev. Jean Miguel August performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, JOHN
description: UNGAR-John. The Ramaz School family mourns the passing of its devoted alumnus and benefactor who always appreciated the education he received in our school and helped others to benefit from it as well. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his dear wife Anne, to his children and to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn, Chairman, Board of Trustees

description: THE LAST PATRICIAN

title: The Real General Tso Was No Chicken
description: It is one of the minor, if nagging, mysteries of New York restaurant life: Who is General Tso, as in General Tso's Chicken, an enduring staple of Chinese restaurant menus throughout the city? If he existed, was he some Auguste Escoffier on horseback, a Laotzu of the culinary arts? Or was he a general in the same way that Colonel Sanders was a colonel, in name only?

title: Correction
description: A report in the Benefits column last Sunday about a dinner on June 2 for the Phoenix House Foundation, the national drug treatment, prevention and education organization, misstated the location. The event is to be at the Plaza Hotel, not the Pierre. Tickets and information: (212) 997-0100.

title: Alexandra Hines, Gerald Russello
description: Alexandra Everett Hines, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. W. Hines of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Gerald Joseph Russello, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Russello of Brooklyn. The Rev. Steven E. Woolley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

title: Sophia Morton, William Friedman
description: Sophia Morton, a daughter of the Very Rev. James Parks Morton and Mrs. Morton of New York, was married yesterday to William Hallson Friedman, a son of Linda Friedman of Houston and Seymour Friedman of Fair Lawn, N.J. The bride's father performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where he is the dean emeritus.

description: DIAMOND-Judge Ted. June 6 1995. Forever missed, loved and remembered. Your Loving Family

title: Suharto's 'Painful' Fall? Not for Indonesians
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Tunes to Eat Hot Dogs and Drink Margaritas By
description: LAST year it was the Dave Matthews Band. This year it's the Spice Girls, a five-woman invasion from Britain, who are heating up the concert scene on the Jersey Shore. Teen-age girls galore, and a lot of self-sacrificing parents, stood in line this month to buy the coveted tickets for the Spice Girls' show on June 25 at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel Township.

title: May 17-23; A Major League Brawl
description: The veteran New York Yankee pitcher David Cone called the brawl between the Yankees and Baltimore Orioles at Yankee Stadium ''the most frightening thing I've seen.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 26 about living in Ridgefield, Conn., included an outdated reference to the D. F. Bedient & Company Home and Garden Center. The hardware store went out of business after the reporter's visit.

title: Barbara Mangini and Eric Andersen
description: IN the spring of 1997, Barbara Mangini hit a low point, actually a sinkhole. She was about to turn 40 and her long-term live-in boyfriend showed no signs of proposing marriage.

title: Classical Briefs
description: 'A COPLAND PROFILE'

title: The Old College Try
description: A FEW years ago, some of the city's university clubs tried to shake their stuffy images and rebuild their membership rolls by changing their menus, adding sleek new gym equipment and organizing trips to SoHo. Now some clubs for graduates of elite universities, like Yale, Princeton, the University of Pennsylvania and Williams College, are doing something else to increase membership. Opening their doors wider, they have been bringing in alumni of other colleges, including some less prestigious ones.

title: Clothing as Architecture and Two Perspectives on Painting
description: CLOTHING as a surrogate for the absent human figure has become something of an artistic cliche over the last 25 years. In the early 1970's, Judith Shea began exploring clothing as sculpture and Robert Kushner began using it as a springboard for painting, to take just two prominent examples of a broader trend. Martha Posner at her best, however, manages to banish familiar images, finding new potential in an old idea.

title: Looking Back, Already, at 1998: A Good Year, Except for Those Floods
description: WHILE renovating Ocean City's City Hall recently, workers found a time capsule concealed earlier this century. The discovery inspired city officials to collect material for a new capsule to be secreted in the building's steps until the year 2098. The New Jersey section requested a sneak preview of what people will learn when they open the capsule 100 years from now, based on these essays written by local schoolchildren.

title: 'A Mother's Place'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHRACH, ROSE
description: BACHRACH-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Otto. Services 11:45 AM, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Crack Down on Rage, Not Guns; Violence in the Media
description: To the Editor:

title: The State on a Bookshelf
description: What book, fiction or nonfiction, do you recommend to give readers a flavor of New Jersey?

title: Sinatra's True Legacy: The Singing Itself; Style and Swagger: Pop's 'Big Bang'
description: AT least three branches of music have claimed Frank Sinatra as one of their own: jazz, classical and rock. He came from a big-band background, and the essence of his style is swing. ''I once mentioned to Miles that I was listening to Sinatra,'' the saxophonist Bob Berg recalled, referring to Miles Davis, ''and Miles said something to the effect that he had been influenced quite a bit by Frank. Miles said that he was attracted to Frank's phrasing.'' The bassist Dave Finck goes as far as to claim, ''To me Frank is a jazz hero, like Louis Armstrong, Miles or Coltrane.''

title: A Wild Man on Good Behavior
description: WHEN Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic perform ''La Valse'' by Ravel on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the tambourine will be entrusted to a wild man on good behavior. This is Gordon Gottlieb, one of New York's premier percussionists, a performer of protean range and unclassifiable gifts. In an era of shifting musical boundaries, Mr. Gottlieb is both an anomaly and a harbinger. A frequent but irregular addition to the Philharmonic's percussion corps, he is as likely to turn up in a recording studio supporting Sting or Michael Jackson. His recent gigs included a stint with the Paul Winter Consort, and a Madison Square Garden concert with Stevie Wonder. ''He's simply the best,'' Mr. Gottlieb croons behind tinted glasses. ''A complete musician. Deeply soulful. I loved the ride.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPITZ, BEATRICE
description: SPITZ-Beatrice. Dear sister, remembered with love, May 25, 1978.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KANTERMAN, EDGAR A.
description: KANTERMAN-Edgar A., D.D.S. A devoted and beloved husband of Phyllis Cogin Kanterman. He was graduated from Tilden High School, City College & NYU School of Dentistry. In World War II, he was a Captain with the Military Police in Massachusetts, Maine, United Kingdom, France & Manila and served with great distinction. Then he established a dental practice in Bayside in 1949 and he also attended the Institute of Graduate Dentists under his mentor, Dr. Myron Lieb. At the school, he taught and ran the family dental clinic for many caring years, he was a member of the board of trustees. His hobby was photography, at which he spent many happy hours in the field and in the dark room as a member of the Great Neck Camera Club, where he had many of his photos shown.

title: 29 Works Are Exhibited By 18 Artists in a Biennial
description: WESTCHESTER'S first biennial 29 works by 18 artists -- steals in on little cat feet at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle here -- with little or no fanfare. Not that it needs it, because a small biennial is an oxymoron worthy of attention and, though devoid of chauvinism, this one comes with an introduction directed at Westchester artists who, like their comrades in other parts of the state, Connecticut and New Jersey, experience ''feelings of inferiority or isolation.''

title: May 17-23; Trade Deficit Jumps
description: The nation's trade deficit jumped sharply in March, providing the clearest evidence yet of how Asia's economic woes are being felt in the United States. The gap rose to $13 billion, far higher than analysts had expected.

title: 'Skin' Is on Stage At Bronx Playhouse
description: ''EVERYBODY has a story,'' Susan Ross tells the audience at the beginning of ''Naked at the Bar,'' the second in the double bill collectively called ''Skin'' at the Belmont Italian American Playhouse here.

title: I'll Give You Three Mickey Mantles for a Schneerson . . .
description: Six years ago, Avrumi Gross, a 47th Street diamond dealer, was at home watching his 7-year-old son, Eliezer, play with baseball cards. Eliezer arranged his cards on the floor by player's position. Then he picked them up and rearranged them by team. Then, without looking at the backs of the cards, by player's birthday.

title: Skin Couture
description: Elaborate tattoos, from a Renaissance madonna to Charles Lindbergh, were displayed through cutout T-shirts and dresses at the first New York City tattoo convention, held last weekend at the Roseland ballroom. These were some of the more tasteful designs seen on the throngs who crowded 70 booths of artists from America, Europe and Asia. Most amazing were the hundreds of women with major body tattooing, from models to rock band members and their fans, reviving one of the oldest forms of body adornment. One visitor (bottom, second from left) wore a tattoo T-shirt.

title: A Little Night Music
description: IN the youth hostel, as everywhere in Stockholm, you would think no one ever ran a bath or opened a door or sat in a chair before Ikea. It is 1993. Everything I touch is clean and woody. Everything is contemporary. Everything is thoughtfully designed.

title: Ralph Branca Is Forgiven: A Bank Greets 3 Ex-Dodgers
description: Most people would not place three retired baseball players and one new bank branch in the same thought. But last month, Ralph Branca, Gene Hermanski and Joe Pignatano, three former Brooklyn Dodgers, attended the dedication of the European American Bank's new branch in Brooklyn Heights at 211 Montague Street (at Court Street). The connection: the modern four-story building that houses the new bank was built on the site of the Dodgers' executive offices. The Dodgers were there from 1938 to 1957, when they moved to Los Angeles.

title: What a Swell Party It Was
description: EVERYBODY WAS SO YOUNG

title: Indonesia Struggles to Find New Reasons to Stay Intact
description: To travel around Indonesia is to be overwhelmed by its diversity, from the tribespeople at the eastern end of the country who wear loin cloths (or even less) to the strict Muslims at the western tip, where some women could scarcely wear more.

title: PULSE: HAMPTONS EDITION
description: Suddenly, This Summer: Here's a prediction of how the style-conscious will be looking on (and sometimes off) the beach, from Shinnecock Inlet to Hither Hills State Park.

title: In America; Unwarranted Tactics
description: Nearly eight years have passed and the city still has not produced the warrant that allowed nearly a dozen police officers to invade the Bronx apartment of Tayibat Akande, a pregnant woman with no criminal record who was hauled away in handcuffs and thrown in jail on a false charge of drug dealing.

title: Unnatural Selection
description: ARK BABY

title: Loren MacIver, 90, a Painter Known for Her Eclectic Style
description: Loren MacIver, a painter of dreamlike, half-abstract landscapes, city views and close-ups of natural forms, and a close friend of many American poets, including Elizabeth Bishop, E. E. Cummings and Marianne Moore, died on May 3 at her home in Greenwich Village in Manhattan, where she had lived and worked since the early 1940's. She was 90.

title: Pledge of a Water Plant Won't End a Long Battle
description: When New York City promised in Federal court last week to build a huge filtration plant for the most troubled portion of its water supply, the pledge did not end the long struggle over the plan. It simply opened a new chapter in the story.

title: May 17-23; Priceless Paintings Stolen
description: Rich in Renaissance masterpieces, Italy is impoverished when it comes to great 19th-century European art. The nation found itself even poorer after three gunmen stole two Van Goghs and a Cezanne from the National Gallery of Art in Rome.

title: Keeping Reagan's Legacy Alive at His Old Ranch
description: It hangs on a hat rack by the front door, stained with the sweat from chopping wood, clearing brush and building fences, a worn navy blue baseball cap embroidered in gold: ''United States Mounted Secret Service.'' Its owner loved it and resisted his wife's entreaties to retire it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUGER, JOSEPH
description: KRUGER-Joseph. The Board of Directors of the New York Section of the American Camping Association notes with deep sadness the passing of our esteemed Past President and current Endowment Fund Chairman, Joseph Kruger. His vision, leadership, hard work and continued involvement in the field of organized camping has enriched our profession as well as the lives of thousands of children. Joe Kruger's generosity and his work on behalf of the American Camping Association are legendary, and he will be forever remembered. Jay S. Jacobs, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEUMAN, KENNETH B.
description: HEUMAN-Kenneth B. Our beloved Kenny, cherished by all who knew him. The very best father and adoring husband imaginable. His zest for living never waned. He was a hero in every sense of the word. How fortunate for us that he was our dear friend. Karen, Randi and Harvey, Cheryl, and Alexis we love you. Ellen and David Flatow and Family

title: Tecumseh's Namesake
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing's the Theme in South Salem
description: DESPITE the saddles, tack, bold swaths of clubhouse blue and the restaurant's name -- said to be that of a famous Irish racehorse -- Coolmore does not attract a horsey set.

title: Edward Chen and Jane Chew
description: Dr. Jane Chew, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Qwie T. Chew of Brooklyn, was married yesterday in Manhattan to Dr. Edward Sheau-Kang Chen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sir-Hoi Chen of Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Judy Stevens performed the Methodist ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, from which the couple graduated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVELL, LILLIAN (NEE LEVINE)
description: SHEVELL-Lillian (nee Levine). On May 22, 1998. Age 91. Wife of the late Nathan A. Shevell. Beloved mother of Myron (Mike) Shevell, Janice Fischman and the late Daniel E. Shevell. Also survived by eight grandchildren and eight great grandchildren.

title: Not the Full Monty
description: HEMINGWAY'S CHAIR

title: Democrats Push for Vote on Naming Gay Man as Ambassador
description: Democrats in the Senate are pushing Republicans for a showdown over President Clinton's nomination of James C. Hormel, who is openly gay, as Ambassador to Luxembourg. The nomination means little in itself -- Luxembourg is the size of Rhode Island -- but it helps Democrats in this election year portray Republicans as captive of their right wing.

title: Doll Gives a Taste of Real Life
description: JESSENICA at 17 is no stranger to teen-age pregnancy. ''All my cousins and all my friends that I grew up with, they all have babies already,'' she said. ''They've been having babies since they were like 12 or whatever. And my mother was 15 when she had me.''

title: Yes, Risk-Taking At the World Bank
description: MANY people view the World Bank as a plodding, grand-scale embodiment of bureaucracy's worst features, the last place where a fleet-footed money manager might thrive. But Afsaneh Mashayekhi Beschloss seems bent on shattering stereotypes.

title: Defense Team Seeks to Win Mercy for a Killer
description: A week after convicting a former jail guard of first-degree murder for killing three people during a robbery, a Brooklyn jury is to return to court Tuesday to begin deciding whether he should live or die.

title: Clinton Leads Americans' Cheers on Irish Vote
description: An elated President Clinton today offered a warm message of congratulations to the voters in both the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland after their approval of a wide-ranging peace accord.

title: Firefighter Accused Of Raping Daughter
description: A city firefighter was charged yesterday with repeatedly raping his 9-year-old daughter, the police said.

title: Sinatra's True Legacy: The Singing Itself
description: BEYOND the brawling, beyond all the wildly variable films, it will be Frank Sinatra's music that will shape his legacy. True, his image as a vulnerable tough guy, and his actorly skills, pervaded his best singing. But it was that singing itself, as he moved from callow youth to lonely swinger to aging but still magisterial stylist, that defined Sinatra's artistry.

title: Recharging in Sunny San Diego
description: YOU can take the girl out of California, but you can't take the California out of the girl. This may be true, but nonetheless, I occasionally need to return to my home state for a refill -- of palm trees and surf, and margaritas on a flower-filled patio, with mariachi music in the background.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNIS, SELMA
description: KENNIS-Selma. Beloved wife of Bernard (Kenn). Loving mother of Jane and Robert Crystal and Jeffrey and Ann Kennis. Dear sister of Helen Alter, Lillian Eisler and Mildred Mund. Adored grandmother of Kim, Jourdan, Alexandra, Benjamin, Maureen and Stephen. Devoted great-grandmother of Erin. Services were held Friday at Parkside Memorial Chapel.

title: Starting Simply, the Story of a Business
description: OFFICE, shmoffice. When it comes to building an empire, all you need is a kitchen table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINMAN, ESTELLE
description: STEINMAN-Estelle. Beloved wife of the late Irving Steinman. Adored mother of Harriett Schiffman and Marjorie and Melvin Fritz. Cherished grandmother of Robert and Emily Schiffman, Meryl and Larry Handler, Steven and Kevin Fritz, and treasured greatgrandmother of Stephanie and Gregory Handler.

title: Sports of The Times; Striking Back at the Marlins
description: WHERE is the introspection? Where is the outrage? Attention, baseball: your south Florida ecosystem has chased away its Fish and what are you going to do about it?

title: It's Spring, and Bushwick Blossoms
description: A BOY on a bicycle wove around a man sucking on a mango outside his home on Bleecker Street. Up and down the block, families relaxed beside brick houses radiating newness. The soundtrack was salsa, pumped from a window at pane-shaking decibels.

title: Suddenly, for Legislators, The Living Is a Little Easier
description: When the New Jersey Legislature gave final approval last week to a bill that promises to lower auto insurance rates, it seemed as if lawmakers heaved a collective sigh of relief.

title: What Only-Child Syndrome?
description: I am a middle-aged only child. I hated being an ''only'' as a small child, and I hate it still.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRONICK, EVE
description: KRONICK - Eve. 7/29/13 - 5/24/96. Mom, I miss you terribly. Marc and Marcelle have given you the most beautiful twin great-granddaughters, Eve and Hope. Watch over them. Love, Bobby

title: Shopping al Fresco, Regretting ad Infinitum
description: THIS is the season of hope and impulse shopping. Behold the warm weather, the irises, the birds, the bees, the nurseries shimmering with hanging fuchsia. Behold, too, capitalism in the great outdoors: the craft fairs, the street festivals, the garage sales.

title: Newport Manhattan Series Heats Up Racing Scene
description: With the waning this week of the Whitbread Round the World Race, new fire is being breathed into America's Cup racing efforts. Nowhere is that flame brighter than in round-the-buoy racing.

title: Classical Briefs
description: PROKOFIEV: 'IVAN THE TERRIBLE'

title: 'Tis Pity She's a Whore; 'Tis Surprise She's a Puppet, Too
description: If the great English painter, engraver and satirist William Hogarth could be returned to life for a single day, he would surely find himself at home in New York City.

title: Martinez's Words Unrelated To Facts
description: Pedro Martinez is the richest player in baseball history. He attained that status by being the best pitcher available last winter. The Red Sox acquired him at the Montreal Expos' latest fire sale, then induced him to stay in Boston beyond this season by giving him $75 million for six years.

title: Big Parade in Jerusalem; Arabs Call It Big Bluster
description: Thousands of Israeli soldiers marched through Jerusalem today to note the anniversary of Israel's capture of East Jerusalem in 1967 and Israel's jubilee year with the largest military parade in more than 20 years.

title: Caring Is Now In: Full House for Surging Mets
description: There were no great heroics on the field for Mike Piazza yesterday, no home runs, no runs batted in. And for the second day in a row since his heralded arrival as the slugging savior of Shea Stadium, the Mets' starting pitcher had more hits than he did.

title: Harold Orenstein, 84, Lawyer for Musicians
description: Harold Orenstein, an entertainment lawyer who helped redefine the copyright status of musical theater, died on May 15 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Quirky PC Games Try to Find Market Niche in a Virtual Pet Cemetery
description: The Virtual Pet Cemetery (www.lavamind.com/pet.html) is one of the more oddly compelling Webside attractions to have sprung up along the Internet.

title: Her Mother Isn't Pleased As Daughter Rips Gates
description: In the acknowledgments of her new book, ''Barbarians Led by Bill Gates: Microsoft From the Inside,'' the author, Jennifer Edstrom, thanks her mother for encouraging her to write, ''even though this isn't particularly what she had in mind.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMPKINS, LESLIE JAY II
description: TOMPKINS-Leslie Jay II. At Toronto, on Friday, May 22, 1998, at the age of 50. Grandson of the late Professor and Mrs. Leslie Jay Tompkins of New York, son of the late James B. Tompkins, and brother of the late James, Jr. Survived by his mother Patricia Tompkins, sister Teresa Tompkins, and aunt Hallie Tompkins Thomas, all of Toronto. For information contact the Humphrey Funeral Home-A.W. Miles Chapel, Toronto (800-616-3311).

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Connections; Not Quite a Virus, but a Contagion Brain to Brain
description: A few years ago, I was infected by a relatively harmless virus. I thought it would quickly run its course, like a flu strain that strikes each winter. When it persisted, I consulted the literature more fervently, but, the more I read the more the virus hung on. In fact, reading may have even caused the viral assault in the first place.

title: Data Are In: Bilingual Classes Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Kenneth Wells, 89, a Founder Of a Group Promoting Patriotism
description: Kenneth Dale Wells, a founder and the spiritual father of the Freedoms Foundation at Valley Forge, which fosters patriotism and understanding of the Constitution and Bill of Rights, died on May 10 at his retirement home in Edgewater, Fla. He was 89.

title: Cardinal Sees Marriage Harm In Partners Bill
description: John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday condemned a proposal before the City Council to make domestic partners the legal equals of married couples, calling it a violation of natural law and a blow to traditional marriage as the ''first and vital cell of society.''

title: Haitians Bear H.I.V. Alone, Waiting for Word on Asylum
description: When Amos Dacy fled his native Haiti in a wobbly boat, he had a simple goal: to live. But though he left behind the political persecution he says could have killed him, his ordeal continues.

title: Democratic Party Loves Vallone, but He's Mostly Unknown Upstate
description: For some of the Democrats running for Governor, this week's state party convention will be a struggle for delegate support, even a fight for survival. For Peter F. Vallone, the clear favorite of party leaders, it could be more like an anointment, at least among party loyalists.

title: Knowledge Scarce on Cost Of College, Study Finds
description: Americans worry about how they will afford their children's college educations, but they are poorly informed about college costs and how to pay them, according to a report to be released today.

title: Networks' Choice of Fall Programs Begins With Let's Make a Deal
description: Coming soon to a television channel near you: the best shows the networks can find -- as long as the deal is right.

title: Nuclear Risks in South Asia
description: If Pakistan tests nuclear weapons, as many expect, South Asia will have a pair of hostile nuclear powers. While a nuclear standoff between the United States and Soviet Union may have helped to keep the cold war from becoming a hot war, Pakistan and India face a more unstable equation. Measures the superpowers employed to reduce mutual mistrust would be useful, but even their adoption would leave South Asia in peril of a nuclear conflict.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about assistants for women in childbirth misspelled the surname of a Kaiser Permanente obstetrician who said the assistants, or doulas, could help lower Caesarean rates. He is Dr. David M. Roth, not Ross.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Some Little-Known History
description: The soldiers in the military re-enactment wore homespun tunics, tricornered hats and carried muskets as they recreated Revolutionary War battles and life. All of them were black, yet the flag over their camp was the Union Jack.

title: Taking Salsa by Storm With a Power Punch of Rock-and-Roll
description: Salsa from Puerto Rico and New York City is built on a notion of containment, that the powerful rumble of the oncoming explosion will be contained by the performer's grace and elegance. At the Latin Quarter on Saturday night, Victor Manuelle, a 28-year-old Puerto Rican singer who is the most important young star in salsa's new wave, did away with all of that. He came to tear the place apart. His show, with its overwhelming rawness and volume, had as much in common with the power of rock-and-roll as it did with salsa.

title: It's a Struggle for Cone But Not for the Yankees
description: Maybe the problems of David Cone should hearten the Boston Red Sox or any other team with designs on challenging the Yankees. Cone is supposed to be the leader of the staff and his earned run average is 6.00, and he spent much of today's game raging at himself on the mound. Maybe this is a sign the Yankees are vulnerable.

title: Memorial Day Menace
description: The Memorial Day weekend is the unofficial beginning of summer and also, unfortunately, the weekend when thousands of Americans will trundle out to the garage and lift the green plastic cover from a mechanical beast that has been waiting all winter to roar back to life and begin shattering eardrums from Maine to California. This machine is known technically as a PWC, or personal watercraft, and colloquially as a Jet Ski, the Kawasaki Corporation's trade name. Mutant offspring of America's romance with the internal combustion engine, PWC's are as out of place on the water as snowmobiles are in Yellowstone. Now comes further evidence that they are not only an insult to the environment but a menace to life and limb.

title: Data Are In: Bilingual Classes Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Dummies' Publisher Files for Stock Sale
description: IDG Books Worldwide Inc., the publisher of ''Windows for Dummies,'' ''Wine for Dummies'' and other instructional books, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise as much as $50 million through the sale of common stock.

title: Orioles Keep Languishing, And It's Time for Changes
description: It's as if baseball executives have hung out a sign that says, For Sale: Superstars. Mike Piazza has already been traded twice, landing with the Mets on Friday. Gary Sheffield, Charles Johnson and Bobby Bonilla were shipped to Los Angeles.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I joined for extra money for college. I thought there'd be a blizzard or a flood, some emergency at home, and we'd go help.''

title: If Microsoft Loses, Consumers Will Win; Split the Giant in Half
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers Challenge Casinos' Role as a Haven for Smokers
description: The buses pull up to the Atlantic City casinos every day, each one full of elderly day-trippers like May Riches, 66, who disembark and head straight for the slot machines and gambling tables, toting their pocketbooks, rolls of quarters and lighted cigarettes.

title: Data Are In: Bilingual Classes Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUIRIN, EDWARD J.
description: QUIRIN-Edward J. 87, of 9 Bayberry Ridge Road, died Friday, May 22, 1998 at Essex Meadows Healthcare Facility, Essex, CT. Mr. Quirin was born in New York City on April 26, 1911 the son of Lewis and Bertha Krepps Quirin. He has lived in Old Lyme for the past 25 years and was formerly from New York City where he was the former chairman and president of Frederic R. Harris, Inc. He joined the firm in 1939; 12 years after it was founded by Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris, retired Chief of the U.S. Navy's Bureau of Yards and Docks. He rose to lead the firm shortly after the Admiral's death in 1949 and oversaw a period of unprecedented growth and diversification. Originally focused predominantly on ports and marine work, he quickly steered the company into other sectors such as highways, mass transit and oil industry related facilities. Harris became global in its business operations, securing assignments in Europe, Latin America, Africa, Australia and Southeast Asia. Harris became one of the first true multinational corporations, creating joint companies in many countries including Turkey, Iran, Spain, Italy and Venezuela. Under Mr. Quirin's leadership, the firm secured and performed some of the world's largest projects of the late 1950's and early 1960's including the design and construction management of a program to build U.S. military bases in Spain; the Kharg Island Oil Terminal in Iran and the Inner Ring Road project in Antwerp, Belgium, for which he received an award from the Belgian Government. Mr. Quirin, who retired from the firm in 1972, held a Bachelor of Science Degree in Civil Engineering from Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. After retirement, he served for two years as president of his alma mater and was also president of the Board of Directors of the Knickerbocker Hospital in New York City. He was a licensed Professional Engineer in several states as well as an accomplished writer, having authored several articles on dry docks for the Encyclopedia Americana. He was a member of Christ the King Church in Old Lyme, a past president and life trustee of the Connecticut River Museum in Essex and was a partner in the engineering consulting firm of Besier, Gibble and Quirin in Old Saybrook, CT. He married Margaret M. O'Hara in New York City on December 16, 1972. In addition to his wife he is survived by two daughters: Barbara Ann Badran of Cambridge, Maryland and Eleanor Catherine Loss of Los Angeles, California, a sister Louise Spahn of Oneonta, New York, four grandchildren and one greatgrandson. He was predeceased by a brother, Karl Quirin and a sister Betty Kelly. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 11:00 A.M. on Wednesday, May 27, 1998 at Christ the King Church. Burial will follow in Eight Mile River Cemetery, Lyme. Friends may call on Monday evening from 7:00 to 9:00 P.M. and Tuesday from 2:00 to 4:00 and 7:00 to 9:00 P.M. at the Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home, Beckwith Lane, Old Lyme, CT. Donations may be made in his memory to Christ the King Church, PO Box 443, Old Lyme, CT 06371.

title: Frank C. Montero, Racial Pioneer, Dies at 89
description: Frank C. Montero, a racial pioneer who in his various guises as political gadfly, government official, foundation executive and real estate developer devoted his life to smoothing the way toward an integrated society, died on May 8 at a nursing home in Oberlin, Ohio. He was 89 and a longtime resident of the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Bogota Halts Unit Faulted Over Rights
description: A Colombian Army intelligence brigade that had come under increasing international criticism for suspected links to political killings will be disbanded and its members reorganized, the military command has announced.

title: Working With Clay a Challenge in Paris
description: When the red dust last settled at this two-week ordeal on clay, the 1997 French Open had produced a pair of breakthrough champions: Gustavo Kuerten, the Brazilian string bean who transcended obscurity and a world ranking of 66, and Croatia's Iva Majoli, whose final-round performance was the match that kept 16-year-old Martina Hingis from achieving a historic Grand Slam sweep last season.

title: Dr. Mark Tarail, 87, Adviser and Expert On Mental Health
description: Mark Tarail, an expert in community mental health programs and an adviser on the Federal and state levels, died on May 5 at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 87.

title: School Opens Doors To Grief on Holiday
description: The superintendent of Springfield schools said today that Thurston High School would be open in the afternoon on Memorial Day so students could gather ''as part of the healing process'' after the deadly shooting there last Thursday.

title: If Microsoft Loses, Consumers Will Win; Word Dominates
description: To the Editor:

title: Reducing Class Sizes
description: President Clinton's initiative to spend $12 billion over seven years to reduce class sizes in first through third grade will provide needed Federal support to states trying for smaller classes in the primary grades. The plan, as introduced in the House, would pay for 100,000 new teachers. The Federal investment is relatively small, but the impact on literacy could be substantial if that money is directed, as Mr. Clinton proposes, to reducing class size to an average of 18 students.

title: Peca Leads the Sabres by Example
description: Just past the midway point of Saturday night's game, the Washington Capitals were on the power play, with a chance to cut into Buffalo's 2-0 lead in the opener of the Eastern Conference finals. The Sabres' captain, Michael Peca, killing a penalty, lined up Washington's Sergei Gonchar with his head down and crashed into Gonchar, knocking him back with a heavy, legal check.

title: The Fear Is Palpable as Doom Stalks a Spanish Beach
description: ''La Playa Vacia'' (''The Empty Beach''), by Jaime Salom, is almost 30 years old, and it relies heavily on ominous symbols that may still resonate in the Spanish imagination but that are likely to make the play seem melodramatic to Americans. Yet it may explain better than any of his works why Salom remains so popular throughout Europe and Latin America. His effort to seize the emotions of an audience is relentless, and often successful against the odds. ''La Playa Vacia'' is still capable of making one feel fear: not the illusion of danger we pack action movies to find, but a gathering apprehension that people we care about cannot escape a grisly end.

title: Technology; 'Baby Softs'? Envisioning A Breakup Of Microsoft
description: Now that the Justice Department and the Attorneys General of 20 states have filed long-threatened antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corporation, the question remains why the most obvious, and perhaps cleanest, solution has yet to be put on the bargaining table: the breakup of Microsoft into its component businesses.

title: Commencements; Speakers Counsel Courage, Perseverance and Hope
description: The president of Cornell University, Hunter R. Rawlings 3d, reminded 6,200 graduates yesterday of its mission to prepare students for life outside its walls.

title: An Australian Novelist Takes Another Look at Dickens's Inimitable Convict
description: When Peter Carey read ''Great Expectations,'' he was ''mad at Dickens for giving my imaginary ancestor a bad rap.'' That ''ancestor'' is Magwitch, the fierce convict who endows the orphan Pip with his wealth. Mr. Carey's irritation was the spur for him to write his new novel, ''Jack Maggs.''

title: But Even The Ardent Brechtian Can Smile
description: Brecht fun?

title: Essay; The China Connection
description: Think of ''the China connection'' as two-tracked. One track is the purchase of White House influence by U.S. aerospace corporations eager to sell advanced missile technology to China. The second is the plan by China to affect Clinton policy by directing money through various fronts into the Clinton-Gore campaign.

title: 2 Czech Cities to Wall Off Their 'Problematic' Gypsies
description: USTI NAD LABEM, Czech Republic  Two Czech cities have decided to fence in what they call "problematic" public housing residents, creating what is virtually a ghetto for the residents, mainly Gypsies, who officials say ruin the calm, orderly life of their neighbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPOSANU, PAMFIL
description: RIPOSANU-Pamfil. On May 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Marguerite. Loving father of Ann Maria and son-in-law Jan Ter Haar. Also survived by a brother-in-law, two sisters-in-law and 10 nieces and nephews. Lawyer and former Ambassador from the Kingdom of Romania to Washington. A very special, gentle and giving man who loved people and always will be remembered by his family and friends. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Tuesday, May 26, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, May 27, 10 AM, St. Catherine of Sienna Church, 411 E. 68 St.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the House & Home section on Thursday about the International Contemporary Furniture Fair misstated the Dolly folding chair's material. It is made of fiberglass-reinforced polypropylene, not aluminum.

title: Rubin, Denying Yen Report, Calls Policy on Dollar Unchanged
description: Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said today that American policy on the strength of the dollar was ''absolutely unchanged,'' despite a report that he was willing to let the currency's value rise to an exchange rate of 150 yen to help invigorate Japan's flagging economy.

title: Cayard's EF Language Sails to Glory in Whitbread Race
description: ''Learn a Language,'' read the message on the side of Paul Cayard's well-traveled boat, but as he and his polyglot crew crossed their final finish line today in the Whitbread Round the World Race, all any observer needed to understand was body language.

title: Summer's Plague of Angels Arrives; After Scraping By, Adirondack Town Braces for Crowds and Jobs
description: Three months ago, the streets of this Adirondack hamlet were nearly deserted. In Hamilton County, where Long Lake -- population 750 -- is practically a metropolis, the unemployment rate was up to 18 percent, higher than any other county in the state. Business was so slow at the grocery store here that the owner had to take out a loan to cover expenses, and he said later that he had stayed open only as a public service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARBONI, DANIEL
description: CARBONI-Daniel. Of NYC, formerly of Teaneck, NJ, on May 19, 1998. Beloved son of Francesco and Susan (Gordon) Carboni. Dear brother of Peter. Loving grandson of Alice Gordon. Cherished nephew of Martin Gordon. Dan did stand-up comedy in various clubs in NY; he also interned at Politically Incorrect and the Conan O'Brien shows. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 26, 1998, at 7:30 PM, at the Volk-Leber Funeral Home, Teaneck, NJ. The family requests donatons be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., NYC, in Dan's memory.

title: U.S. May Have Helped India Hide Its Nuclear Activity
description: When American spy satellites photographed clear signs that India was preparing for a nuclear test in 1995, Frank Wisner Jr., then the United States Ambassador to India, showed the photographs to top Indian officials in a successful effort to persuade them not to test. It was a triumph of intelligence and diplomacy's working together to stop the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: For Cheever, a Monaco Dream Fulfilled at Indy
description: Eddie Cheever Jr. never won a single race in his 10 seasons driving on the road courses of Formula One. So eight years ago, frustrated and too big for the shrinking race cars, he came to the oval tracks of Indy cars, hoping for a change of fortune.

title: Patents; A wedding-dress kit that lets the bride-to-be custom-design her gown at off-the-rack costs.
description: WITH the average wedding costing $10,000 to $12,000, matrimony is a lucrative business. And a number of inventors with new wedding-inspired patents are looking for a slice of the profits.

title: Small Gannett Paper Won't Print Gay Weekly
description: A small daily newspaper in Georgia last week reversed its earlier decision to print the largest gay newspaper in the South after a group of 47 ministers met and encouraged parishioners to cancel subscriptions and advertising.

title: Sport of The Times; Sacrifice of the Lambs Makes Yanks Giggle
description: WHATEVER there actually was of a division race came to an unmerciful halt yesterday in the visitors' third inning, with Bret Saberhagen on the mound and Chuck Knoblauch at the plate. Metaphorically, it may as well have been Mike Torrez facing Bucky Dent.

title: Underwater Theater for Briny Stars; A Designer of Artful Aquariums Lets Drama Upstage Science
description: An aquarium is not an obvious place to start a revolution. But that is precisely what Peter Chermayeff has been plotting during his 30 years as an architect. Gone are the old rows of fish tanks set in the walls, framed with picture windows. Gone is the aquarium as science museum.

title: When Acting Is as Important as Dancing
description: Betrayal, remorse and regeneration make up the very stuff of ''Giselle,'' the crown jewel of 19th-century Romantic ballet. Amanda McKerrow and Vladimir Malakhov brought out these themes with their thoughtful acting and elegant dancing on Thursday night. It was the first of several performances of ''Giselle'' that American Ballet Theater is presenting this season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Advances, If Not a Cure, In a Long, Hard Battle
description: ''Cancer Wars'' begins with the little-publicized news that Nazi Germany's scientists were pioneers in research that linked cancer to smoking and diet. Hitler, remember, was a nonsmoking vegetarian who made an ideological connection between physical health and the purity of the Nordic race. The Nazi record is not meant to exonerate cigarettes on the principal of innocence by association, merely to draw attention to how long it took for the United States and other countries to get serious about the causes of cancer and what to do about them.

title: The Tale of an Ill-Fated Airship
description: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A., which no longer has any links with its parent in Italy, opened here over the weekend in unseasonably humid weather. For the next two weeks, the place will be in almost constant artistic eruption, with operas (by Janacek and Cavalli), plays (by Wilde and Fugard), dance performances and concerts each night and chamber recitals in the middle of the day.

title: The Daily News tries to stem a tide of watery ink in new color presses as costs mount.
description: SOME companies cannot keep their heads above water and find themselves drowning in red ink. At The Daily News, things are a little different: it's the red ink itself that is drowning in water.

title: Believing Impossible Things, Even While Eating Breakfast
description: ''Why sometimes,'' the Queen told Alice in ''Through the Looking-Glass,'' ''I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.'' If you are reading this at breakfast, see if you can believe the following impossible thing: In a major tournament with world-class players, the declarer has Q J 10 x opposite a small tripleton in dummy. The opponents lead the suit twice but take no tricks in the suit.

title: Visiting Cuban Musicians Inspire a Family Reunion
description: A Cuban dance band, Orquesta Reve, spent a recent week playing around New York. The group started at Hostos Community College in the Bronx, then worked its way through several different constituencies, hitting S.O.B.'s, the Copacabana and the Latin Quarter before returning to Havana. By now this isn't news; Cuban bands play in the city regularly. But at the shows, it was clear that something extraordinary was occurring, in musical, political and personal terms.

title: Paris Journal; Barricades of '68 Are Down, and the Boutiques Are Raised
description: The Latin Quarter, torn by riots in a student revolution 30 years ago, has more Giorgio Armani, Louis Vuitton and Cartier boutiques nowadays than radical bookstores or Spartan student cafes. But according to the best-known leader of the revolt, the right to enjoy life was what ''May 1968'' was really all about.

title: Abroad at Home; Their Suharto And Ours
description: In December, 1975, President Ford and his Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger, visited President Suharto in Indonesia. They reacted with a nod and a wink to his plans to seize East Timor. The day after they left, Indonesian forces invaded the distant island, using American arms. In the invasion and ensuing occupation, a third of East Timor's 600,000 people died.

title: Charles D. Webster, 92, Leader Of Garden and Wildlife Groups
description: Charles Drake Webster, a Long Island conservationist, gardener and stalwart of organizations like the Horticultural Society of New York and the Seatuck National Wildlife Refuge in Islip, died on May 15 at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore. He was 92 and lived at Twyford, his home and part of the nature preserve.

title: Impressions And a Bit Of a Prank
description: From its inception, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's ''Music of Our Time'' series has been both exciting and frustrating. The series usually presents three concerts of new works at Merkin Concert Hall. But by separating new music from the more mainstream series at the far larger Alice Tully Hall, ''Music of Our Time'' sends a negative message: that new music is for small audiences of specialists.

title: Riding High, Bush Eases Into 2000 Election
description: As his campaign plane bounced from town to town over the piney woods of East Texas this week, George W. Bush said he had a message: ''I am totally focused on getting re-elected as Governor. My head and my heart are in Texas.''

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Netscape Plays It Cool as Rival Is Sued
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation has done a lot of crowing in the last week. It announced it had won a big contract to supply Citibank with software for electronic commerce. It outlined details of its new strategy to turn itself into a Web-based information service in competition with America Online and Yahoo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELMAN, ABRAHAM
description: ENGELMAN-Abraham. Passed away on May 23 in Springfield, MA, at age 94. He was born in Russia but spent most of his life in NYC. He was an eminent constitutional jurist who had cases before the state and federal courts in NY including the Appellate and Appeals Court of the State of New York and the United States Supreme Court. Mr. Engelman had the foresight to procure leases for apartment buildings in Greenwich Village on East 8th and 9th Streets and was a principal in the construction of these multi-level dwellings, which were the pride of the Village in the 1950's. He also started the real estate firm of Engelman & Co. in association with his brothers. He was the husband to the late Tillie Torgowitz Engelman, and of the late Dorothy Feinbloom Engelman. He is survived by his only son, Richard of Longmeadow, MA, his daughter-in-law Jane, grandchildren Daniel of Boston, Margery Grodsky of Longmeadow, MA, and Andrea of NYC. He has four great-grandchildren. He is survived as well by four siblings, Max, Howard and Pete of NYC, and Minna of Miami.

title: A DOWNSIZED ARMY LEANS ON RESERVES FOR DUTY IN BOSNIA
description: As the United States peacekeeping mission in Bosnia continues and eats away at military resources, the number of reservists and National Guard members who are finding themselves thrust into military life is growing sharply.

description: Never mind Juan Gonzalez, the Texas Ranger slugger, or Ken Griffey Jr. from the visiting Seattle Mariners. During batting practice tonight, fans lining up in the aisles at the Rangers' ball park are leaning across the railings for autographs from a league champion in leveraged buyouts.

description: Who has bragging rights as the most-listened-to talk radio host in the country? This is shaping up into a real war of words.

description: ZELLER-Belle. The University Faculty Senate of the City University of New York mourns the loss of Professor Emerita Belle Zeller. She was a political scientist by trade and advisor to the administrations of President Roosevelt and Truman and inspiration to generations of students who studied under her at Brooklyn College. Her monument is the numberless graduates who are committed and politically active in virtuous causes. Bernard Sohmer, Chair, The University Faculty Senate

title: Grand Slam Wins and Could Be a Belmont Threat
description: If you were looking for a horse to challenge Real Quiet on the lip of the Triple Crown, look no further: Grand Slam, trained by D. Wayne Lukas, won the Peter Pan Stakes yesterday to stay undefeated at Belmont Park and create a new role as the potential spoiler.

description: To the Editor:

title: David Schneider, 77; Led Fight for the Concorde
description: David Schneider, who as an executive for British Airways led the successful fight to bring the supersonic Concorde to New York, died May 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 77.

title: Still Our Best Idea
description: A British Ambassador to the United States once called the national parks our ''best idea.'' The assertion that Yellowstone National Park or the Lincoln Memorial exceeds the Constitution and the Bill of Rights in intrinsic value may seem odd, but in fact all of them are linked in spirit. The preservation of Federal real estate for the pleasure and benefit of the citizenry is, like freedom, a revolutionary impulse springing from the Enlightenment.

title: Greek Director Wins Top Prize at Cannes Festival
description: The Greek filmmaker Theo Angelopoulos, who shook up the Cannes International Film Festival three years ago by complaining bluntly about winning a mere second prize for ''Ulysses' Gaze'' (top honors that year went to Emir Kusturica's ''Underground''), has finally received his overdue Palme d'Or. Mr. Angelopoulos won for ''Eternity and a Day,'' which stars Bruno Ganz and had not initially looked like one of this year's strongest contenders. It was shown on Saturday, the last day of the competition, which is often the event's least auspicious slot. But the jury -- led by Martin Scorsese and including the actresses Sigourney Weaver, Winona Ryder, Lena Olin and Chiara Mastroianni, along with other members including the director Chen Kaige -- unanimously voted Mr. Angelopoulos's film its foremost prize.

title: Washington College And Adelphi Win
description: Washington College won the championship that had eluded its teams for years. The Sho'men from Chestertown on Maryland's Eastern Shore defeated Nazareth, 16-10, yesterday at Rutgers Stadium in Piscataway, N.J., to capture the Division III crown. The Golden Flyers from Rochester had won the title the past two seasons.

description: President Suharto has quit, but he remains the wealthiest man in Indonesia, and it may be years before his poverty-stricken country recovers any of the billions of dollars he siphoned from the economy.

Barbara and Steve Schainman Directors

His daughters Lucy Johns and Ellen Kauffman, their children, spouses, aunts, and generations of cousins celebrate Milton's extraordinary life and mourn our loss.

description: President Clinton's national security adviser said today that ''it would be an enormous mistake'' to postpone Mr. Clinton's trip to China next month simply because of the current political storm over the export of satellite technology.

title: Sports of The Times; Piazza Tries to Get Comfortable in a Mets Uniform
description: THE newest member of the Mets, a catcher named Mike Piazza, slipped into town Saturday without attracting much notice, like Godzilla. Mr. Piazza, traded twice in one week, has proved himself over the last several years to be quite proficient at striking a baseball, and thus, naturally, is in a position to be handsomely rewarded for such talent, so splendidly rewarded, in fact, that earlier this year he turned down a contract extension with the Dodgers for a reported $85 million for six seasons.

description: In the first election here since China regained control of this former British colony, voters turned out in record numbers on Sunday to elect a new legislature, defying torrential rains and returning to office pro-democracy politicians ousted by Beijing after the handover.

title: Philip Barry Jr., 74, Producer Of Plays, Films and TV Shows
description: Philip Barry Jr., a producer of plays, films and a number of highly regarded television shows, died on May 16 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Treasury Will Auction Bills and Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills and sales of two-year and five-year notes on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively. Since today is Memorial Day, a Federal holiday, there is no trading in Treasury securities.

title: Utah Plods Right Back To the Finals
description: The enduring image of the Western Conference finals will not arouse curiosity on Madison Avenue today: the balding power forward who uses a hair-growth product receiving a pass from a 36-year-old point guard with a surgically repaired knee. The play ending in a nondescript layup instead of a scintillating dunk, followed moments later by two free throws to seal the game.

title: Marion Barry's Sour Legacy
description: Marion Barry emerged during the 1960's as a charismatic politician whose civil rights credentials seemed perfect for the District of Columbia. The majority-black city was longing for statehood when Mr. Barry first surfaced in local politics. After 30 years as a city leader -- and four scandal-ridden terms as Mayor -- Mr. Barry announced last week that he would not seek a fifth term and would carry on the fight from somewhere outside city government. As he departs, it is inescapably clear that he has hurt the cause of autonomy for the District more than any other politician in the city's history.

title: Sony Comes On Strong in Video-Game War
description: Mario the plumber has always done a good job of running and jumping though video games. But Parappa the Rappa has him worried about his age and his place in the living room.

description: Since the doors on the first yellow school bus swung open at the first morning stop last fall, at least a dozen students and two teachers have been slain by schoolmates around the country, in lunchrooms, in schoolyards, at morning prayers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CONSTANCE KAUFMAN
description: SOLOMON-Constance Kaufman. A leader of several volunteer groups including the Bellevue Hospital Asssociation and the New York Women's Foundation, died at the age of 74 on Friday, May 15, 1998 in Belvedere, CA. from pneumonia and chronic emphysema. Connie remained active until two days before her death. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, Anthony; her brother George Kaufman; her son Adam; her daughter Tracy; her grandchildren Peter and James and two poodles Cobb & Rust. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, June 2 at the New York Historical Society, 2 West 77 St., at 4 PM. Donations should be sent to the New York Women's Foundation.

title: Wild Rush Zips By Tough Bunch to Capture the Met
description: Wild Rush cruised through the mud yesterday at Belmont Park and almost outran history. He not only won the 105th Metropolitan Handicap against a strong field but also ran the fourth fastest mile delivered in the race, one of the classics of New York racing.

title: Philip H. Rhodes Is Dead at 72; Designed Ocean Racing Yachts
description: Philip Hardy Rhodes, a yacht designer of sailboats as diverse as modern ocean racers and topsail schooners, died May 5 at Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 72.

title: China Is No Russia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMANN, JULIA (NEE POLYATCHEK)
description: ULLMANN-Julia (nee Polyatchek), on May 24, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Georges D. Ullmann. Adoring mother of Nadine U. Brozan and the late Judith Anne Posner. Loving grandmother of Theodore R. Posner, Jacqueline P. Glassman and Alexander M. Brozan. Great-grandmother of Jacob H. Glassman and sister of Stanley Paley. Services Wednesday, May 27, 11:30 AM, Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, L.I.

title: By Design; Bikinis, Bare and Not So
description: Bikinis go in and out of favor, and this summer they are very much in. Some thoughtful designers have even provided matching cover-up skirts.

title: Boardwalk Ramp Collapses On Coney I., Injuring One
description: A 10-foot-high concrete ramp from a sidewalk to the Coney Island Boardwalk collapsed yesterday, slightly injuring a homeless woman, city officials said.

title: Deal Expected From Homestake
description: The Homestake Mining Company, a gold mining company based in San Francisco, is expected to offer to acquire a 49.4 percent stake in Prime Resources Group, a precious metals company that operates mines in Canada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORE, DAVID URI
description: CORE-David Uri. On May 24, 1998. Son of the late Hugo and Elsa Bergman. Beloved husband of Ofra, father of Orly Ann, grandfather of Sandra & Kara. Services on Tuesday, May 26, 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AZUMBRADO, JOHN
description: AZUMBRADO-John. On 5/21/98. A veteran of W.W. II and the Korean War. Beloved husband of Anne and father of Michele, Roberta, and Cory. Also survived by four granddaughters. Interment at Calverton National Cemetery today.

title: As Brawley Trial Plods, the Public Shrugs
description: Turn right at the top of the stairs in the Dutchess County Courthouse on most weekdays. Go through the double doors and there it is: the perpetual Brawley trial.

title: Princeton Wins Title as 3 Seniors Take a Bow
description: Princeton won its third consecutive national lacrosse championship today, defeating Maryland, 15-5. And when it was all over, Coach Bill Tierney had a dismaying thought amid the triumph. ''I won't get to coach Jon Hess, Jesse Hubbard and Chris Massey again,'' the coach said. ''These three took this program to a level no one had ever predicted.''

title: SOWING DEATH: A special report.; How Japan Germ Terror Alerted World
description: In repeated germ attacks in the early 1990's, an obscure Japanese cult tried to kill millions of people throughout Tokyo and, a cultist has now testified, at nearby American bases where thousands of service people and their families live.

title: Gazprom Cites Pressure to Buy Oil Company
description: Gazprom, Russia's natural gas monopoly, said the Government was pressing it to buy the oil company Rosneft as other potential bidders appeared short of cash and unable to pay the $2.5 billion asking price.

title: Doctors Need Sleep?
description: To the Editor:

title: States Are Trying to Cheat Tobacco Lawyers; A Smoking Rebate
description: To the Editor:

title: India Revises Stock Rule
description: India will permit closely held companies to sell their shares overseas, reversing an earlier policy that blocked such sales if the companies did not have shares traded in local stock markets, the Ministry of Finance said.

title: Tarnished Golden Door: The Hidden Side of Ellis I.
description: ANY day now, the United States Supreme Court is expected to decide whether jurisdiction over most of Ellis Island should go to New York State or to New Jersey.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Crossed Identities In the Hamptons

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JAMES JEROME
description: SMITH-James Jerome. Of Bay Ridge, on May 24, 1998. Beloved father of Stephen E. and James M. Loving brother of Edwin V. Husband of 51 years of the late Margaret (nee McCarter). Also survived by 4 loving grandchildren. Long-time member of the Cathedral Club, the Municipal Club of Brooklyn and the Breezy Point Surf Club. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 PM and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 9:30 AM, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Brooklyn.

title: States Are Trying to Cheat Tobacco Lawyers; Try a Distribution Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurant Staff to Get Job Offers After Fire
description: About 160 employees of the Chart House restaurant will be offered jobs elsewhere in the chain after a fire that destroyed the Hudson River pier restaurant on Sunday, the company said yesterday.

title: Red Moons of Uranus
description: Astronomers who discovered two tiny red moons circling the planet Uranus have now confirmed their orbits and given them names: Caliban and Sycorax, for two characters in Shakespeare's ''The Tempest.''

title: N.B.A. Planning to Review Skirmish
description: Once more, the outcome to a playoff series could be partly determined by the league after the vice president of operations, Rod Thorn, reviews the tape of a skirmish between Indiana's Reggie Miller and Chicago's Ron Harper.

title: Regulators Set to Block Digital TV Pact
description: The European Commission said it was set to reject the planned digital television alliance of a Bertelsmann A.G. venture and the Kirch Group as early as Wednesday, after the companies failed to ease antitrust concerns over the weekend.

title: Toxic Sludge Cleanup to Cost Spain 100 Million
description: The toxic sludge that burst from a mine reservoir and flooded rivers and farms in southern Spain late last month will take more than $100 million to clean up, according to the Spanish Government.

title: Hartford Ballet Dismisses a Director
description: The Hartford Ballet has dismissed Kirk Peterson, a former member of the American Ballet Theater and the artistic director of the Connecticut troupe since 1993.

title: Burning a Landscape in Order to Save It
description: THE sandplain ecosystem of coastal Long Island and southeastern New England is among the most unusual on earth. Formed by ice and shaped by wind, rain and fire, grassy sand plain moors are home to dozens of rare plants and animals.

title: Intensity And Jokes At Spoleto
description: Spoleto Festival U.S.A. is in good shape. To get the world premiere of Steve Reich's ''Hindenburg'' was a coup, even if the outcome was disappointing. The two other big musical events, productions of Janacek's ''Jenufa'' and Cavalli's ''Giasone,'' are both estimable and well worth a visit: they continue in repertory until June 5-6.

title: Heady Days Return For Textbook Sales
