description: Despite dire predictions of the death of the printed word, makers of textbooks and instructional materials are having banner years. Last year, purchases of elementary school books increased by 13 percent, to $3 billion, and college texts rose by 7.4 percent, to $2.7 billion.

title: President of Polygram Film Unit Said to Be Leading Buyout Effort
description: Michael Kuhn, the president of the film unit at Polygram N.V., has expressed an interest in staging a management buyout of that unit for more than $:1-billion ($1.63 billion), The Sunday Times of London reported.

title: Spontaneous Combustion
description: Q. Is spontaneous human combustion real?

title: Betsy Carden, Leader in College Dance, 68
description: Betsy Carden, a former dance teacher at Brooklyn College and a leader in American college dance, died on May 5 at her home in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 68.

title: A Grab Bag of 'Victimless Crimes'
description: John Stossel, libertarians' gift to television, takes up the cause tonight of people who are being punished for ''victimless crimes.'' They include pornographers, drug users and sellers, gamblers, ticket scalpers, prostitutes, homosexuals and sufferers in search of help in committing suicide.

title: Using Earth's Magnetic Pull To Track Ancient Treasure
description: THERE would not be another miracle here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNSEND, RICHARD EDWARD
description: TOWNSEND - Richard Edward. Died of a stroke on May 22, 1998 in Buckinghamshire while on a tour of the British Isles. He was 68 years of age. Richard Townsend was born on January 22, 1930 in San Bernardino, CA. As a youth, he was trained as a Hollywood actor and dancer and pursued a career in theatre and film. He earned a B.A. degree from UCLA and later studied playwriting and directing in graduate school. From 1951-1955, he served in the U.S. Air Force as a Russian language specialist. After marrying Ruth Greene in 1955, he began a career in advertising and marketing with American Standard and then as Vice President with Schieffelin & Co. After retirement, he devoted his attention to civic and church activities. He served on the Board of Directors of the Westchester Mental Health Association, the Mt. Kisco Food Pantry, and the Chappaqua Drama Group. He was a longtime member of the Rotary Club for which he served as past President of District 7230. He was also a Paul Harris Fellow. His commitment to the Mt. Kisco Presbyterian Church is reflected in his service as a deacon, a trustee and as editor of ''Lifeline,'' the Church's newsletter. He was wellknown locally for his bi-weekly column for The Patent Trader. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, his two sons, Dr. Gavin Townsend of Chattanooga, TN and Bryan Townsend of NYC, & one grandson. Funeral services will be held at the Mount Kisco Presbyterian Church at 3 PM, Saturday, May 30. His family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions may be mailed to the Richard Townsend Memorial Fund, C/O Mt. Kisco Pres. Church, Mount Kisco, New York 10549.

title: Editorial Observer; Blocking Promising Students From City University
description: California's decision to outlaw the use of race in public college admissions has barred most black and Latino students from the elite campuses and raised the specter of a whitening professional class in a steadily browning state. Politicians elsewhere have recognized the potential for harm and have backed away from proposals that would limit minority access to higher education. But a different and more destructive plan has emerged in New York City, where Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is pushing a proposal that would scuttle open admissions at the City University of New York. This would depress graduation rates, not just for blacks and Latinos but for every ethnic group. Such a result would be terrible for the city's work force and economy.

title: In Revenge, Jews Build In Muslim Part Of Old City
description: Jewish settlers poured foundations today for new houses in the Muslim Quarter of Jerusalem's walled Old City, expanding their foothold in the Arab neighborhood in response to the fatal stabbing of a settler this month.

title: Foreign Affairs; Today's Trick Question
description: So my friend Michael Mandelbaum, the foreign policy expert from Johns Hopkins University, calls me the other morning with a trick question: ''What's the difference,'' he asks me, ''between NATO expansion and the Indian nuclear tests?''

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball's Godzilla Has a Bat
description: BOTTOM of the 14th inning. Tie score. Two out. Nobody on. Just pitch to the next hitter, right?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In the late 1980's and early 1990's much of the talk about education centered on the emerging technologies -- that the book was dead and traditional publishing was out. And now, through all the hype and hoopla about it, textbooks have actually started to sell at a brisker pace.''

title: Scientists See a Mysterious Similarity In a Pair of Deadly Plagues
description: SIX hundred and fifty years ago, the Black Death was stalking Europe. It arrived on ships from Asia, carried by fleas that had infected rats on board the ships. Before it burned itself out, the epidemic had killed about a third of the European population.

title: Hearst to Acquire Pulitzer's Broadcast Unit
description: Hearst-Argyle Television agreed yesterday to pay $1.15 billion in stock and assume $700 million in debt for the television and radio stations owned by the Pulitzer Publishing Corporation.

title: The Sun and O'Neal Set Again in the West
description: We interrupt this contentious post-season for another dismissal of Shaquille O'Neal. Yes, Shaq -- the Daddy, the Diesel, Shaq-Fu, truly Our Hero After Michael -- is done again, swept in a playoff series for the fourth time in five years.

title: Early Out of the Blocks In the Race for Speaker
description: Springtime in Washington makes Robert L. Livingston the man to see. As chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, he allocates the money that keeps the Government running and keeps members of Congress in good standing at home. Now he has added to his power by declaring that he wants to be Speaker of the House.

title: People
description: * Bob Pearson was named to the new position of executive vice president and managing director for the North American health practice at GCI Group, New York, part of Grey Advertising. He had been vice president for sales and marketing at Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPOSANU, PAMFIL
description: RIPOSANU-Pamfil. On May 22, 1998. Beloved husband of Marguerite. Loving father of Ann Maria and son-in-law Jan Ter Haar. Also survived by a brother-in-law, two sisters-in-law and ten nieces and nephews. Lawyer and former Ambassador from the Kingdom of Romania to Washington. A very special, gentle and giving man who loved people and always will be remembered by his family and friends. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, May 26, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, May 27, 10 AM, St. Catherine of Sienna Church, 411 East 68 Street.

title: Miami Journal; From Cheers of '97 To Jeers (and Worse)
description: Fifty games into the season as baseball's reigning champions, the new-look Florida Marlins ran onto the field for a game on Sunday, essentially a nine-man cliche: you could not tell the players without a program.

title: Angelus N. Cotsidas, 96, Pastry Executive
description: Angelus N. Cotsidas, a founder and chairman of the Table Talk Pastry Company, died on May 10, at his home in Westboro, Mass. He was 96.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the wealth controlled by the former president of Indonesia carried an incorrect headline in some copies yesterday. It is Suharto, who resigned on Thursday, not his predecessor Sukarno, whose riches are the subject of investigation.

title: With Estrada's Victory Certain, Everybody's in His Parade
description: MANILA  Suddenly, shining new stickers bearing the word "Erap" or "Estrada" are appearing on the bumpers of the big vans and limousines that carry the elite of Metro Manila from their rambling homes in walled "villages" to the high-rise office buildings of Makati, the central business and financial district.

title: McGwire's Pace a Cue To Join in the Swing
description: Everyone is raving about Mark McGwire's long-distance home runs and how Big Mac is making Roger Maris and his home run record of 61 in a season look oh so small.

title: Behind the Camera On Indy's Pit Road
description: When you think Ahmad Rashad has endured a full day of grueling electronic journalism by tagging behind Michael Jordan or eavesdropping on the Bulls' bench, think of the job done by ABC's Jack Arute, Gary Gerould and Jerry Punch, the jump-suited reporters who worked the pits Sunday at the Indianapolis 500.

title: Facing Viagra's Emotional Ripples
description: WITH men and women from the Bob Doles on down extolling the virtues of Viagra, it is easy to lose sight of potential problems and limitations of the potency pill. Not the least of them is the fact that erectile dysfunction, as impotence is called medically, can often be more than just a physical matter, especially when it has persisted untreated for years.

title: Laser Technique to Spot Hazardous Air Turbulence Is Tested
description: A laser-based system for detecting air turbulence and other invisible hazards to planes has been tested at Kennedy International Airport in New York with results that could improve airline safety.

title: Big Rally Not a Good Idea, Food Vendor Group Warns
description: Hoping to learn from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's rebuff of cabdrivers, the city's largest food vendors association scrambled yesterday to dissuade members from demonstrating against the Mayor's plan to close huge swaths of Manhattan to sidewalk food carts.

title: Jobs Out of Reach for Detroiters Without Wheels
description: At about 3 on weekday afternoons, Dorothy L. Johnson heads to her job in the suburbs cleaning office buildings. Two buses and two hours later, she reports to work. At 11 P.M., her shift ends and she begins the trip back home. A little before midnight, she steps off a suburban bus just inside the Detroit border, and waits for the city bus that will get her home by 12:30.

title: INTERNATIONAL SPORTS: A Quiet Revolution in Iran; Beneath Coat and Scarf, Women Discover the Freedom to Play
description: Dressed in a scarf and a long blue coat, Lida Fariman practiced her target shooting on a recent afternoon, looking down the barrel of her rifle toward the Asian Games later this year and the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, Australia, where she hopes to be more of a competitive athlete than simply a pioneer.

title: Sharp's Move Into Mexico
description: The Sharp Corporation of Japan, the world's biggest maker of liquid-crystal display screens, plans to more than double its first investment in Mexico, to $60 million, the Mexican Government said today. The Sharp plant, in Rosarito in the northern state of Baja California, is expected to have 1,100 workers making products with tariff-free access to the United States.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In the Box With the Zodiac Suspect
description: When police Sgt. Joseph Herbert persuaded a young man who had shot his half-sister to put his guns down, his action led to a lucky break in one of the city's most notorious unsolved crime sprees -- the Zodiac shootings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, SIMON J.
description: LIEBOWITZ-Simon J. Attorney, NYS Senator, NYS Civil and Supreme Court Judge. Adored husband of Elsie. Devoted and caring father of Gloria and Bernard Herman, Burt and Linda Liebowitz, and the late Sonia Brodsky. Cherished grandfather of Esther, Ruth, Judith, Mindy, Steven, Suzanne, Ellen & Eileen. Great grandfather of nine. Father-in-law of Leonard Brodsky. Services at ''BoulevardRiverside'', 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, New York, Wednesday 12 noon. Memorial donations may be made to the Brooklyn Law School or your favorite charity.

title: Market Place; Consultants Sing the Siren Song of Wall Street
description: Consulting firms do not make things that can be seen. Often, they struggle to explain what they do. Their major asset -- smart people -- can simply walk out the door.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about John Cardinal O'Connor's criticism of a proposal to make domestic partners the legal equals of married couples misstated his views on when Major League baseball games should not be played. It is Good Friday, not Sundays, on which he said the scheduling of games ''cheapens our culture.''

title: Maple Ends Riding Career
description: Eddie Maple accepted the Mike Venezia award for extraordinary sportsmanship and citizenship yesterday at Belmont Park, then surprised his audience by announcing his retirement as a jockey after 33 years and 4,398 winners in 33,973 races. The 49-year-old rider said that he had intended to step down next year, anyway, ''but to tell you the truth, I really didn't make up my mind until this morning when I was heading for the paddock tent for the ceremony.''

title: Sampras Is Determined to Not Leave the French Open Empty-Handed
description: As usual, his socks were stained and smudged by the Roland Garros clay. When Pete Sampras looked down at his feet today, they appeared to be rusting in place on the first day of the French Open, where everyone gets covered with grit. Those who have the most grit in their game often hang around the longest and hoist a trophy on the last day.

title: Roslyn Bancorp Is Expected To Acquire T.R. Financial
description: Roslyn Bancorp is expected to acquire the T. R. Financial Corporation in a stock swap valued at about $1.1 billion, according to people close to the merger talks.

title: David Rauch, Educator, 79
description: Dr. David Rauch, a lifelong New York educator and specialist in adult education, died on May 9 at White Plains Hospital Center. A former resident of Fresh Meadows, N.Y., he was 79 and had been living in a nursing home in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Officials Say a Bomb Caused Explosion at Church in Illinois
description: A bomb caused the explosion that ripped through a church here during Sunday morning services, Federal officials said today.

title: A Pot of Gold For Publishers Of Textbooks
description: If public passion for the printed word has died, as some say, then a textbook case of resurrection is taking place.

title: More Trades Are Possible, Phillips Says
description: Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, stood on the field before Sunday afternoon's game, and while the questions posed to him concerned his acquisition of Mike Piazza two days earlier, he repeatedly threw out tantalizing hints that he was not through dealing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COWIN, DANIEL.
description: COWIN-Daniel. Our dear daughter Dana was married 10 days ago. Thank you for enabling me to give Dana and Barclay the wedding they dreamed about. You were, without question, there in spirit. Those of us who knew you best miss you every single day. Joyce

title: San Juan Ozololtepec Journal; In the Hills, Marijuana Fields and a Priest's Murder
description: When the lone telephone in this mountain hamlet rang recently, it was the Archbishop of Oaxaca calling with bitter news: San Juan's parish priest, the Rev. Mauro Ortiz Ca rreno, was dead.

title: Older and Wiser
description: ELEPHANT families assume that the oldest head is the wisest. This matriarch decides where the group will go and what it will eat. But many African elephant families -- males leave their families in adolescence -- are bereft of their most experienced members, a legacy of rampant poaching in the 1970's and 80's.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Clean-Air Standards Are Urged for Utilities
description: A lobbying group plans to begin a campaign today urging the state to force out-of-state utilities to comply with Federal clean air standards as a condition of selling electricity in New Jersey.

title: Accounts
description: * Canandaigua Wine Co., Canandaigua, N.Y., to Trone Advertising, Greensboro, N.C., to handle advertising and promotion for a new wine brand, Arbor Mist. Billings were estimated at more than $6.5 million for the first six months. Trone handles other Canandaigua brands like Mystic Cliffs wine, Paul Masson brandy and Cook's champagne.

title: Report Says Swiss Knew Some Nazi Gold Was Stolen
description: A long-awaited report about wartime dealings in Nazi gold concludes that Swiss National Bank officials knew that some gold sent to Switzerland had been looted from occupied areas, and confirms allegations that the gold included some stolen from Holocaust victims.

title: Foreign Banks Pulled Out Of Asia Late, A Report Says
description: International banks began pulling their money out of Asia during the last half of 1997, with South Korea and Thailand bearing the brunt of the withdrawals, according to a report released yesterday by the Bank for International Settlements.

title: Raytheon to Resume Annual Meetings
description: The Raytheon Company will hold its first annual meeting in two years on Wednesday as the military and aerospace company continues the consolidation of all of its businesses.

title: Why Poppers can be found in the freezer aisle, and does New York have an official uniform?
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLERSON, JULIA (NEE GARBAW)
description: DELLERSON-Julia (nee Garbaw). Of Pembroke Pines, Fl. Died Sunday, May 24, 1998, at age 94. Devoted wife of the late Norman David Dellerson, beloved mother of Gladys Shaffer and Melvyn Dellerson, mother-in-law of Dr. Joseph C. Shaffer and Mrs. Ritva Dellerson. Cherished grandmother of Ava Burke, Roberta Shaffer and Thor Dellerson. Interment will be at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island, on Wednesday, May 27, at 2 P.M.

title: City Names Basketball Court To Honor the Goat Who Flew
description: His legend hovers above basketball courts across New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINDLER, BARBARA H.
description: SHINDLER-Barbara H. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Robert and Arlene and Daniel and Janice. Grandmother of Robyn, Matthew and Karen, Barbara, Amanda, Maria and Eddie. Great grandmother of Bryanna. Retired NYC teacher. Funeral Service 2 P.M., Tuesday at Sharon Garden Cemetery. Contributions may be made to the Tomorrow's Childrens Fund of Hackensack Hospital or to the Alzheimer's Fund.

title: Filling the Gas Tank Goes Easier on the Wallet
description: Lila Michael ordered a tuna fish hero from the Tiger Mart at the Exxon station on Route 4 in Englewood, N.J., and said, ''I stop, fill up, get my sandwich and coffee and go.'' The going part for her, she said, has become more pleasant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDY, ANNA
description: RUDY-Anna. Beloved mother of Arthur, beloved grandmother of Debra Reichman and Jennifer, and loving mother-in-law to Paulette and Marcia. Forever in our hearts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGERMAN, ANNA
description: INGERMAN-Anna, 96. Adored wife of the late Maxwell G. Ingerman; beloved mother of Sidney (Doris), Arnold (Barbara), Ed (Joan); dear grandmother of Judy (Jim), Tom (Nancy), Paula, Robert (Denise), Lisa (Michael), Neil, Marc and Karen; greatgrandmother of 5; sister of Mollie Silvers and Jack Elberger. Former member of Metropolitan Opera Chorus. Graveside service on Wednesday, May 27, 1998, 11:30 A.M., New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: What Becomes a Trio? Perhaps the Founder
description: American Indians name their children by evoking the phenomena of nature or the attributes of animals, hoping that such qualities will adhere to the lives of their recipients and mark their character. Manufacturers name their products with a thought to permanence, hoping that a logo or a label will survive in the eyes of consumers and that the comings and goings of chief executive officers will be overlooked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIDDER, HENRY
description: KIDDER-Henry. Of Oyster Bay, NY. Died Saturday morning, May 23, 1998, at his home in Oyster Bay. Much loved and survived by his wife, Reine, & sons, Henry, Tracy, and Tim. He is also survived by sisters, Anne, Maria, and Amy as well as by 3 grandchildren. After graduating from Harvard College & Harvard Law School, Mr. Kidder served in the Pacific Theater in WWII as a naval captain. He retained the position of Commander (Ret.) in the U.S. Naval Reserve. Mr. Kidder was a member of the N.Y. Bar and a practicing lawyer in NYC for thirty years, ten years in Huntington, LI, & ten additional years in his home. He was a member of Christ Church, Oyster Bay, and on the Church's Investment Advisory Board. For eight years he served as Village Justice of Oyster Bay Cove. Mr. Kidder was a life-long sailor. Funeral services will be held at the Christ Church, at 11 A.M., May 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOSELSON, BEATRICE URIS
description: NOSELSON-Beatrice Uris. Died peacefully May 25, 1998 at age 94. Beloved wife of the late Moe B. Noselson. Dear mother of Abby & B.H. Friedman and Kal and Judi Noselson. Loving grandmother of Daisy Friedman, Petra & Jackson Friedman, Betsy and Michael Hockstein, Susie and Rob Koltun and the late Adam Noselson. Great grandmother of Katie and Max Hockstein, Fannie and Moe Koltun. Graveside Service on Tuesday 1:30PM at Old Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers please consider a contribution to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARLAMIS, FRANK
description: PARLAMIS-Frank. On May 24, 1998. Beloved husband of Georgia, loving father of Michael and Marguerite. Survived by three grandchildren, Franklin, Christine and Alexander, one great-grandchild, Isabella. Funeral liturgy Thursday, 12 noon, at St. Demetrios G.O. Church, 84-35 152 St., Jamaica Hills, NY 11432. The family will receive friends at church Tuesday 79 PM, Wednesday 3-5 and 8-10 PM. Interment Cypress Hills Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to the St. Demetrios School Fund and the St. John the Theologian Church, Tenafly, NJ.

title: Green, the Energizer Candidate, Proudly Holds the Liberal Line
description: Mark Green opposes the death penalty; in fact, as he likes to tell audiences, he is the only candidate running for United States Senate who is against it. In a field of Democrats who all support abortion rights, he goes so far as to assert that ''life begins at birth,'' opposing virtually any restrictions on the procedure.

title: Murder Is Charged In Death by Heart Attack
description: A Pemberton man has been charged with murder in a case involving an 88-year-old woman who died of a heart attack Thursday while he burglarized her home, the Ocean County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, SHIRLEY AUDREY
description: SACKS-Shirley Audrey. With her family at her bedside, she died at home, at peace, on Sunday, May 24, 1998, after a valiant struggle with cancer. Her partner and companion of 43 years, Dr. Leonard S. Sacks; her children Leo, Joanne and David; her brother Arthur; and her grandchildren Mira, Rachel, Julia, Shana and Moses, are drawing comfort from a lifetime of beautiful memories. Born in Yonkers, N.Y., Shirley and Leonard enjoyed a wonderful life on Manhattan's West Side. A graduate of Barnard College, Shirley was deeply committed to the education of humankind. She received her Ed.D. in Health Education from Teachers College at Columbia University, at the remarkable age of 65. The National Council on Women's Health was close to her heart; Shirley was a passionate Board member and her peers have established a lecture series in her name and honor, with a generous endowment from Pfizer, where Shirley spent twenty-five years as Senior Medical Writer. Her kindness and compassion; her sensitivity, grace and dignity; her radiant smile; and, most of all, her unconditional love, made the world a better place. Contributions can be made to the National Council on Women's Health, 1300 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, June 16, at 12 PM, West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 West 76 Street, New York.

title: Microsoft's Futurism
description: To the Editor:

title: Jenny Craig Invites Bidders for Account
description: Jenny Craig Inc. in La Jolla, Calif., which operates weight-loss programs, is inviting 24 agencies and 4 media services to compete for its domestic account, with billings estimated at $40 million. For the last four years, the creative portion of the account has been handled by Suissa Miller Advertising in Los Angeles and the media portion has been handled by Western Media International in Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: It's Like Really Weird: Another Bad-Luck Babe
description: BRIDGET JONES'S DIARY

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Banks Pulled Money From Asia in 1997

title: After School and Before Home; Parents Seek Havens Like 'Homework Club' to Fill the Gap
description: Pam Carrano tells one child to take off his hat before dinner, another to abandon the computer and the rest to settle down. She asks who wants sesame chicken and who wants baked ziti.

title: Take Bishop Over Knight? It Depends on Many Things
description: No factor in chess is so important that it can be taken in isolation from the others. For example, the bishop pair is often a very strong weapon, but that is so only when the other factors of the situation are equal. Nevertheless, in the heat of battle it is easy to forget that evaluative comparisons must be made.

title: INSIDE
description: Town Buries Its Young

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDH, KATHLEEN DAVIS (KATHY)
description: LINDH-Kathleen Davis (Kathy). Died Thursday, May 21, 1998 at her home in Greenwich, Ct. Kathy was devoted to the New York Philharmonic and actively involved in Blue Hill Troop. She continued her avid interest in horses as a member of the Entertainment Committee of the National Horse Show. Kathy is survived by her husband Henry C.B. Lindh, a daughter Jennifer of Eugene, Or., a son Andrew of Hartford, Ct., and a brother Chester R. Davis of Winnetka, Il. A celebration in honor of her life will take place Saturday, May 30 from 11 AM-1 PM at the Audubon Center, Riversville Road, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations in Kathy's name may be made to the New York Philharmonic, 10 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023-6990 or Blue Hill Troop, POB 6800, New York, New York 10128.

title: Genetic Pawprints Are Leading Game Wardens to the Poachers
description: THERE was not much of a crime scene left by the time the game warden arrived -- just some blood and hair in the dirt of a windswept patch of Wyoming range. But through the use of DNA tests, the evidence may be enough to link an accused poacher to the site.

title: On the Fringes of the Bell Curve, The Evolving Quest for Normality
description: AT first glance it seems an item that might vaguely interest furniture sellers or interior designers: Before the dismantling of the Berlin Wall, psychotherapists in the German Democratic Republic practiced in rooms fitted with circles of chairs; now they do so in rooms furnished with a couch.

title: Miscellany
description: * Dubois L.L.C., New York, an agency specializing in advertising to consumers ages 18 to 35, was opened by Ken Dubois, who is chief executive.

title: Dollar Hits Highest Level Against Yen In 7 Years
description: The dollar rose above 137 yen today for the first time in almost seven years as expectations mounted that neither the United States nor Japan would be willing to stem the yen's decline. The dollar also gained against the mark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAFETZ, BENJAMIN
description: CHAFETZ-Benjamin. Age 80, passed on peacefully in his sleep May 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Rosalind (nee Balterman) for 59 years. Devoted father of Helen Frank and Judy Good. Proud and loving grandfather of Bob, Ronni, Adam, Lauren, Bryan and Allison & uncle of several nieces. Retired CPA and Veteran of W.W. II 10th Mountain Army Division. Services Wednesday at 12:15 P.M., at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Dix Hills, Long Island. Interment following services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, New York.

title: In Democrats' Corner, a Resolute Optimist
description: PERHAPS any state political leader whose party is out of power would be just as defensive. Perhaps any Democratic leader who had watched in horror as New York State's biggest political prizes fell to George E. Pataki, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Alfonse M. D'Amato would exude just as much Nellie Forbush optimism, assuring one and all that the Democrats are just weeks from reconquering their old Fort New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OUIMETTE, MARGARET YANOW
description: OUIMETTE-Margaret Yanow. On May 25, 1998. Beloved wife of Robert; mother of David and Michael; sister of Barbara and Philip Lichtenstein and Caryl Yanow and William Grueskin; aunt of Sarah Lichtenstein; niece of Robert and Sandra Levine and Mildred and Marvin Wallach; daughter of the late Mitchell and Elaine Yanow. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Tuesday, May 26, 5-7PM with service Wednesday, May 27, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: City's Reliance On Wall Street Raises Concern
description: Even as Wall Street's boom continues to feed the budget surplus in New York City, fiscal monitors and others say City Hall remains dangerously tied to the fortunes of the securities industry and question whether it has done enough to prepare for any downturn in the markets.

title: Chinese Entanglements
description: The American Government over the years has been involved in dubious relationships with foreign military institutions, but there has rarely been a more tangled or troubling connection than that between the Clinton Administration and the People's Liberation Army of China. It has produced campaign funding abuses, serious American security lapses and now a political furor in Washington less than a month before President Clinton is to make the first Presidential visit to China since 1989.

title: Indian Culture, at Risk at Home, Finds Fans Abroad
description: While American Indians fear that their languages, songs, dances, arts, crafts, rituals and oral history may not survive the cultural melding of the 21st century, they are finding a growing audience in Europe and Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COAKLEY, CHARLES
description: COAKLEY-Charles. It is with deep sorrow that the Mayor and Board of Trustees record the death of Charles Coakley of 208 Beach Walk, Saltaire, on Friday, May 22nd, 1998. A resident of the Village for over 25 years, Charles was a man of learning, wit and caring to all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Trudi, his family, Greg and Kim and Lyssa and Glenn, and his grandchildren. Charles will be greatly missed.

title: Despite Iranian Overtures, U.S. Remains Wary on Relations
description: When the ritualistic chants of, ''Death to America!'' began to rise here again at a public gathering last weekend, the Iranian President was ready with an unusual retort.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRISS, BRUNO R., MD.
description: KRISS-Bruno R., MD. A humane and sensitive caring friend. Never forgotten, remembered on this day. Ittom

title: Raids, and Complaints, Rise As City Draws on Drug Tips
description: Mary and Cornelius Jefferson were turning in for the night last June 24 when they heard the deafening boom of a battering ram tearing the front door of their Bronx apartment from its hinges. ''They kept on banging until the whole door had splintered,'' said Mrs. Jefferson, 63. ''I thought they were coming to rob us, coming to kill us.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, BETTY
description: BLOCK-Betty. On May 25, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Ira, and motherin-law of Doris. Devoted grandmother of Adam and Erica. Funeral service at Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, New York, on Wednesday, May 27, at 11 AM. Interment to follow at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, N.J. For further information, contact John J. Fox Funeral Home, 914-834-0144

title: An Empire Imperiled : Jakarta Sets Out on Road to Reform
description: JAKARTA  The new government made its first move on Monday to review, and possibly dismantle, parts of the enormous business empire and cartels built up by former President Suharto and his family during his 32-year rule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGORZALY, STANLEY FRANCIS, M.D.
description: OGORZALY - Stanley Francis, M.D. of North Palm Beach, Florida on May 21, 1998. He was Chief of Cardiology and Co-Chairman of Intensive Care Unit, St. John's Riverside Hospital, Yonkers, New York. Graduate of Fordham University & Georgetown University receiving his medical degree. Survived by sister-in-law Jewel C. Ogorzaly, 7 nieces & nephews. Funeral Mass in North Palm Beach. Donations to the American Heart Association, 2701 North Australian Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407

title: Barrage Helps Irabu Gain First Shutout
description: Four months and two days remain in this baseball season, and already white flags are being raised before the Yankees. The juggernaut is gathering momentum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURT, JAMES JACKSON
description: BURT-James Jackson. Award winning sculptor & painter of Stamford, CT., age 43. A victim of bi-polar illness, he took his own life on May 4. Beloved son of Eleanor Jackson Burt Migdal of New York City & David Burt of Stamford. His art appeared in solo exhibitions at the Kalarson, Kerr & Humphrey Galleries in Manhattan, the Elaine Benson Gallery, Bridgehampton, N.Y., the Silvermine Guild, New Canaan, CT., Syracuse University and the Rich Forum Lobby in Stamford. Memorial service on June 7, 3 PM, at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, at the intersection of Scoffieldtown Road with High Ridge Road, 3/4 mile north of the Merritt Parkway. Service will be followed by the opening of a retrospective exhibition of Burt's art.

title: No Vote Is Expected Today on Remedial Programs at Meeting of CUNY Board
description: Despite lobbying by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's office, trustees of the City University of New York said they were not likely to vote on any change in remedial programs at their meeting this afternoon, because no plan seems to have enough support for passage.

title: Stake in Jones Intercable Being Sold To Comcast
description: The Comcast Corporation agreed today to buy a 37 percent stake in Jones Intercable Inc., a cable television operator, in transactions with BCE Inc. valued at more than $500 million, as it seeks to bolster its cable television system in the mid-Atlantic region.

title: Patterns
description: A Downtown Alliance

title: Government Must Keep Up Basic Gene Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, FLORENCE (NEE LEVITAS)
description: LEVINE-Florence (nee Levitas). In her 91st year. Devoted wife of the late Charles Levine, daughter of the late Gerson and Yetta Levitas, beloved mother of Abraham (Toddie) and Trudy, Benita and Murray Gross, Leon and Sybil and Jack and Frances. Adored grandmother of fourteen and great grandmother of fifteen. Hunter College Class of 1928. A woman of great dignity, inordinate courage and uncompromising integrity, who inspired all who knew her. She will be forever in our hearts. Donations to AMIT Women would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNLAVY, ALFRED
description: DUNLAVY-Alfred. On May 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Francine (nee Alessi), devoted father and father-in-law of Patricia and Peter Valenti, loving grandfather of Christine and Marco Valenti. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St., NYC, Tuesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday, 9:30 AM at Our Lady of Guadalupe Church, 229 West 14 St. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Hear Now, 9745 East Hampden Ave., #

title: Espada Withdraws From Bronx Politics to Advance Son's Career
description: In a decision that will avert what had been expected to be a turbulent political battle in the Bronx, Pedro Espada Jr. said yesterday that he would not run for his former seat in the State Senate this year.

title: States Are Trying to Cheat Tobacco Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: States Are Trying to Cheat Tobacco Lawyers; Are Ads Effective?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAROOGIAN, RHODA
description: GAROOGIAN-Rhoda. Of Boca Raton, FL. Died on May 21st, 1998. Beloved wife of Andrew, loving mother of David (Jacqueline) Garoogian, Neill (Carla) Garoogian. Cherished grandmother of Nicholas & Alyssa. Funeral services were held on Friday, May 22, 1998 in Delray Beach, Florida.

title: Mysterious Figure, Strong and Tender
description: American Ballet Theater attracted large audiences with three different casts in ''Giselle'' over the weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House. A major debut came on Saturday afternoon when Nina Ananiashvili, partnered by Guillaume Graffin, danced the title role for the first time with Ballet Theater. In the evening, Jose Manuel Carreno was seen in New York for the first time as Albrecht, performing opposite Julie Kent, while the familiar partnership of Alessandra Ferri and Julio Bocca was seen on Friday night.

title: Metro Business; Again, TV Company Grows in Manhattan
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation, the television network that only eight months ago expanded from a tiny operation at 780 Third Avenue to the entire 35th floor at 1330 Avenue of the Americas, has expanded again.

title: A Balancing Act of Otherworldly Grace and Broadway Glitz, by Balanchine
description: The New York City Ballet fell into an inspired bit of programming on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. When an injury prevented the scheduled performance of Jerome Robbins's ''Suite of Dances,'' the company filled in with George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux,'' thereby balancing two understated Balanchine gems with two popular favorites from the Balanchine repertory.

title: No Place Like Home, Bad As It Was
description: Anthony, 13, is the new boy at Green Chimneys. His drug-addicted mother has just died; his father has disappeared. Eddie arrived two weeks ago. He and his siblings struck back at their physically abusive father. (''We had to beat him up with a bat,'' Eddie explains.) Mike has been at Green Chimneys for two years. His mother was raped at age 14 and gave birth to Mike as a result; he doesn't know who his father is.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WARWICK, KENNETH M.
description: WARWICK-Kenneth M. A service in loving memory of Ken Warwick will be held Friday, May 29th, 1998, 1 P.M., at the Second Presbyterian Church, 6 West 96 St, NY, NY. The Church is on the south side of 96th St, just west of Central Park West, the entrance is a red door. Please call Ken Warwick & Associates for further assistance 718-243-2030

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, DAVID
description: ROSENBERG-David. On May 24. Beloved husband of Esther, devoted father of Hannah, cherished grandfather of Michael, Deborah and Linda. Services 10:45 Tuesday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Famous Einstein 'Fudge' Returns to Haunt Cosmology
description: THERE are few scientists of whom it can be said that their mistakes are more interesting than their colleagues' successes, but Albert Einstein was one. Few ''blunders'' have had a longer and more eventful life than the cosmological constant, sometimes described as the most famous fudge factor in the history of science, that Einstein added to his theory of general relativity in 1917. Its role was to provide a repulsive force in order to keep the universe from theoretically collapsing under its own weight.

title: One More Tuneup Before World Cup
description: The American national team made the transcontinental trip from Portland, Ore., to Washington yesterday to prepare for its final domestic tuneup before next month's World Cup finals in France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIULIANO, FELIX T.
description: GIULIANO-Felix T. ''Philly,'' on May 22, 1998. Proud, retired member of Local #

title: Tell Me Again: Why Are S.A.T. Scores So Crucial?
description: Every time I debate a foe of affirmative action on television, the conversation invariably degenerates into a heated discussion of a familiar hypothetical: why should a white student with a combined score on the Scholastic Assessment Test of, say, 1,250 be denied admission to college in favor of a black applicant who scored 100 to 200 points lower?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAINES, CHARLES MURRAY ROBERT
description: HAINES-Charles Murray Robert. May 19, 1998 in Ottawa, Canada. Born on May 22, 1928. Professor & Critic. He is survived by his wife, Claudia, his son, Charles Henry Persi Haines, and his sister, Mrs. Barbara Edwards. In lieu of flowers, please buy a theatre ticket.

title: Art in the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion; A More Modern Approach to Fur
description: Fur collections can often be precious, because furs like sable, chinchilla and mink are as precious as gems. But the modern spirit calls for a more casual approach to fur, in keeping with the casual mood permeating fashion. And it's just that nonchalant, throwaway chic that ready-to-wear designers have brought to the rarefied world of fur. As more of them enter that world, the breezier the styles become, so that a woman of any age can throw on a fur the way she tosses on a trench coat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTEK, JAMES V., M.D.
description: BASTEK-James V., M.D. It is with profound shock and sorrow that we mourn the untimely and tragic death of our esteemed colleague, Dr. James V. Bastek. A retinal associate with our ophthalmic practice for over ten years, we knew him to be a brilliant and caring physician. We also knew and respected his devotion to his closeknit family. His sudden death will leave a personal and professional void in the lives of many. Our sincerest sympathy to his wife, Carol, and his children, who all survived the tragedy. Marvin C. Kochman, M.D. Mark A. Lebowitz, M.D. Laurey G. Mogil, M.D. Brooklyn Eye Surgery Center and the entire Staff

title: Good News From the Front in the War Against Cancer
description: FOR weeks, a barrage of good news about cancer in people has come from scientists and public health officials.

title: Putting Africa On Coke's Map; Pushing Soft Drinks on a Continent That Has Seen Hard, Hard Times
description: On the edge of the black South African township of Soweto, perched atop Vic de Villiers's gas station roof, is a retired South African Air Force warplane, known as the Coke Bomber. Earlier this month, workers showed up to give the plane, which bears the Coca-Cola Company's trademark red logo, a fresh paint job, courtesy of Coke. Coke is now also paying Mr. de Villiers to illuminate the plane at night.

title: 'Godzilla' Roars In But Fails To Devour
description: In a telling statement on the skewed economics of movie making today, ''Godzilla'' roared into 3,310 theaters for the long Memorial Day weekend and earned an estimated $74 million through Monday. And that made it, by Hollywood standards, a relative disappointment.

title: High-Tech Hypocrisy About Government
description: In the mid-1980's, during my tenure at Lotus, I was, I believe, the first person to publicly compare Microsoft to Standard Oil. Both companies sought and used monopoly control over a new industry critical to the nation's economy. And both were headed by men -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. and Bill Gates -- who would stop at virtually nothing to gain what they sought. Back then no one took the comparison seriously -- except Bill Gates himself, who made it clear to me how irate he was about it.

title: Wry Showmanship Amid the Chaos
description: Thirty-five years on, free jazz is still undefined. Depending on how you feel about it in the abstract, the music fits one of two opposite characterizations: an ironclad vocabulary of Coltrane- and Albert Ayler-derived screeching and banging, or an idea of collective music making that abominates cliche. Get a little closer and you see many more possibilities: humor, scholarly dryness, chaos, patterns, provincialism, one-worldism, modesty and self-mythologizing showman-shtick.

title: Russia Takes Steps To Assure Investors Economy Will Hold
description: Shaken by global financial turmoil, Russia tried to assure anxious investors today that it would not follow the path of Indonesia and other faltering Asian economies.

title: Sorrowful Town Honors Teen-Ager Killed in School Shooting
description: Their faces taut and their eyes red, mourners filled the meeting hall at the Springfield Faith Center here today as a stunned and grieving community gathered to mark the death of Benjamin A. Walker, one of two Thurston High School teen-agers killed in a shooting at the school cafeteria last week.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Krygier's Overtime Goal Evens Score With Hasek
description: The President of the United States enjoyed his first hockey game tonight and didn't even stay to see the celebration that followed the home team's winning goal in overtime. President Clinton left after Washington's Esa Tikkanen accidentally tipped a puck past his own goaltender in the final minute of regulation, helping the Buffalo Sabres to tie the score at 2-2 and send the game into another period at the MCI Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOELET, FRANCIS
description: GOELET-Francis. The Board and staff of the Metropolitan Opera Guild join the musical world in mourning the death of our friend, Francis Goelet. First elected to the Guild's board of directors in 1952 at the age of 27, he served with distinction and contributed significantly to the Guild. In 1987 he was elected a director emeritus, serving as such until his death. His love and deep knowledge of music was remarkable as was his great generosity to the Metropolitan Opera. His support through commissioning of music in the second half of the 20th century was particularly noteworthy. To many of us at the Guild, he was a good friend and he will be sorely missed. We extend to his family and friends our deepest symmpathy. The Metropolitan Opera Guild

title: A Novelist Who Stalks Authenticity
description: A zealot-tangled Jerusalem just a bomb blast away from Armageddon may be a hard act to follow. But now that his acclaimed literary thriller ''Damascus Gate'' is ensconced on the best-seller lists, Robert Stone is mulling over his next book. It might be something about Alaska. It might be a comic novel. It might conceivably tackle New York City.

title: States Are Trying to Cheat Tobacco Lawyers; Plenty of Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Shots That Haunted 3 Generations; A Family's Struggles in the Aftermath of an Attack on Congress
description: But for the scars on her wrists, Irene Vilar looks much like the students running to and from classes on the sprawling grounds of Syracuse University. The scars suggest a different story, though, one that began two generations before she was born.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, DORIS ELISE
description: SILVERMAN-Doris Elise. Died at the Jewish Home and Hospital after a long battle with Juvenile Diabetes. Caring sister of J. Herbert and his wife Betty R. Silverman, aunt of Braden L. Silverman and his wife Dr. Amelia Case, Chicago, and Nora E. Kinne and her husband Aaron Kinne, Boston. Ms. Silverman was a graduate in 1935 of the Calhoun School for Girls, a leading member of that school's debating team and a graduate of Columbia University in 1939. She was a founding staff member of Travel Weekly Magazine and held an executive post at Yachting Magazine among other publishing associations. Contributions in her memory to the American Diabetes Association would be appreciated.

title: Miller Upstages Jordan In the Blink of an Eye
description: Deep inside Reggie Miller's hollow frame bubbles a total disregard for the pressure of the moment or the greatness of another player before him, a gunslinger's mentality that tends to spill over for moments just like this.

title: Tyco to Pay $3.3 Billion In Stock for U.S. Surgical
description: Tyco International Ltd., an international manufacturing and service company on an acquisition spree, announced yesterday that it would acquire the U.S. Surgical Corporation for $3.3 billion in stock.

title: Becoming An American
description: At a soccer game against Mexico in February, the American national team listened in frustration as a chorus of boos erupted during ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' Thousands of fans threw cups and bottles at the United States players, often striking them. They also attacked someone in the stands who tried to unfurl an American flag.

title: Brooklyn Fire May Lead to Revolutionary Graves
description: Most people looking at the charred remains of the Bona Fide Fuel Oil Company in a gray, industrial section of Gowanus, Brooklyn, see hills of bricks, rusted scrap metal and a bunch of old tires.

title: 'Microsofties' Say They're Right as Rain
description: Of all the Government's affronts that the Microsoft Corporation feels it has had to endure, including a request that it ship a competitor's product with its own, the most galling to many here at One Microsoft Way was the admission last week by Attorney General Janet Reno that she did not use a personal computer.

title: NEW LEADER VOWS EARLY ELECTIONS FOR INDONESIANS
description: Bowing to pressure from both outside and inside his Government, Indonesia's new President, B. J. Habibie, said today that he would be only a transitional figure and would hold an election before his term expires in 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALIMIR, SUZANNE
description: GALIMIR-Suzanne. On May 24, 1998. Beloved wife of Felix. Loving sister of Martin Hirsch, Margaret Hirsh and the late Stephen Hirsch. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Services on Thursday, at 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Loopholes in I.R.S. Reform
description: No one ever lost an election by abusing the tax collector. So it is probably inevitable that a bill overhauling the Internal Revenue Service will become law before November. It has already been passed by the House and Senate in different forms. The Clinton Administration has also clambered on board. The Treasury Department says that Congressional plans to reorganize the I.R.S. bureaucracy and make the agency more user-friendly are almost precisely what it intended to do anyway.

title: Founder to Resign At Think New Ideas
description: Think New Ideas Inc., an Internet marketing and technology company in New York, has announced that Scott Mednick, its founder, chairman and chief executive, would leave to pursue a career in philanthropy. The company also said it had dismissed its outside auditor, BDO Seidman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLLOY, ROBERT
description: MOLLOY-Robert. Of Walpole MA. Formerly of Madison, N.J. Age 80 years. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice (Landy) Molloy, loving father of Amy L. Molloy and her husband Bruce J. Houston of Natick, MA. Brother of Mrs. John M. (Dorothy) Butler of Paramus, N.J. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend the funeral services in The Grace Episcopal Church, 150 Chapel St, Norwood, Ma., Thursday at 11 AM. Visiting hours are Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9, in James H. Delaney & Son Funeral Home, 48 Common Street, Walpole, Ma. Interment will be private. Memorial donations may be made to either Neponset Valley Hospice or V.N.A., both at 3 Edgewater Drive, Norwood, MA. 02062 U.S. Marine Corp. veteran.

title: States Are Trying to Cheat Tobacco Lawyers; Real Help for Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNAUD, DANIEL L.
description: ARNAUD-Daniel L., 62, Of Bloomington, IN, died on May 24th. Mr. Arnaud was born May 29, 1935 in New York City, the son of Leonard E. and Martha Lindemuth. He was Associate Director of the Salzburg Seminar in Salzburg, and was Executive Director of the Thomas J. Watson Foundation with primary responsibility for administering its fellowship program. Mr. Arnaud is survived by his children Martha Beasley Arnaud of San Francisco, Frances Ellison Arnaud of Brookline, Massachusetts, and Maxwell Charles Leonard Arnaud of New Orleans, and by his sister MarieLouise A. Smith of Bloomington, IN. Services Wednesday, May 27, 3PM at Trinity Episcopal Church, Bloomington, IN, a reception will follow the service in the Great Hall at the church. Private family interment to be held at a later date.

title: A Broader Benefit Is Found in a Drug To Cut Cholesterol
description: A new study provides the first evidence that people with average cholesterol levels can substantially reduce their risk of heart attack by taking a drug that drives their cholesterol levels even lower.

title: Clinton Projects $39 Billion Budget Surplus in '98
description: President Clinton announced today that the Federal Government would run a budget surplus of $39 billion this year, as he maneuvered to deprive Republicans of an election-year issue by demanding that the money be protected from ''short-term schemes'' for tax cuts.

title: Accord Is Reached in Food-Poisoning Case
description: In what is believed to be the largest settlement of a case involving food poisoning from fresh foods, Odwalla Inc., agreed today to a multimillion-dollar settlement to resolve claims by five families whose children were sickened in an October 1996 outbreak caused by the bacterial contamination of the company's apple juice.

title: Wuhan Journal; Selling in China: A Smile, a Shoeshine and a Scam
description: Door-to-door sales networks can seem dangerously intriguing to people still gullible about tales of easy money, so when a craze for selling ankle massage machines hit this city early this year, it spelled trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, TELFORD
description: TAYLOR-Telford. The Board of Directors, faculty, students and staff of Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University deeply mourn the death of our colleague, mentor and model. A member of the original Cardozo faculty, Professor Taylor helped found and guide the law school, providing his ideals and gifts to a then-young institution. Fiercely committed to international human rights and accountability for war crimes, renowned for his role at Nuremberg, and beloved as a teacher, Professor Taylor instilled generations of law students at Cardozo, Yale, and Columbia with his zeal for constitutionalism. The Telford Taylor Fellowships in Public International Law and the Telford Taylor Award at Cardozo have been established first in his honor and now in his memory. We extend our condolences to Professor Taylor's wife, Professor Toby Golick, director of Cardozo's Bet Tzedek Legal Services Clinic, and the entire family. Earle I. Mack, Chairman Cardozo Board of Directors Paul R. Verkuil, Dean

title: Tidbit; For the Happy Couple, a Hope Chest of Pasta
description: BRIDAL gifts usually have a certain durability, even permanance: the Limoges, the Waterford, the Calphalon. They're important, expensive. But, hey, these are the 1990's, and marriages aren't what they used to be.

title: RYDER SYSTEM IN TALKS TO SELL BRITISH RENTAL BUSINESSES
description: Ryder System Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its commercial truck-leasing and rental business in Britain so it can focus on its faster-growing business of managing shipments of goods for manufacturers. The company expects most of its British business, which generated $392 million in revenue last year, to be sold for cash by Sept. 30. Ryder said it would continue to offer logistics services, which manage shipments of inventories and finished products, to global customers in Britain. The Miami-based Ryder hired investment banker Schroder & Company to assist with the sale. Ryder shares fell 62.50 cents, to $32.50.

title: About New York; One Man's Gold, One Man's Lead: Bits of Coney I.
description: THE object of Lenny Goodstein's adolescent affection lived in Coney Island, had a gap-toothed smile, ratty hair and a plaid frock. But oh, when she tossed her head and opened her mouth! So what if she laughed at you? To the young boy from Bushwick, it was a siren song.

title: Signs of Economic Slowdown Help Aid Treasury Price Rally
description: Prices of Treasury securities rallied yesterday, spurred by a strong dollar and signs that the economy may be slowing, thus easing the threat of inflation. The slumping stock market also created strong demand for short-term Treasuries.

title: Netscape Breaks Even With Unexpectedly Strong Revenue
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation reported results for its fiscal second quarter today that were essentially break-even. On an operating basis, the company reported the loss expected by most analysts, although revenue was stronger than anticipated.

title: The Four-Sided Taxi Farce
description: In the heat of his confrontation with New York's taxi drivers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called the drivers' May 13 strike ''theater of the absurd.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERARD, JULIAN
description: GERARD-Julian, eighty. Died peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, FL on May 25, 1998. He will be sorely missed by his family and many friends there, in New York, N.Y. & Redding, CT where he also maintained homes. In accordance with his wishes, there will be no memorial service and the interment will be private in New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society will be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEETOO, LYNETTE (NEE CHAR)
description: SEETOO-Lynette (nee Char). On May 21, 1998. Age 35. Of New York City, N.Y. Formerly of Honolulu, Hawaii. Beloved wife of John Stuart Seetoo; devoted mother of Gwendolyn Minglyn Seetoo; loving daughter of Lloyd and Aileen Char; dear sister of Kendall, Nelson and Edwin Char, Laureen Char Desantis, and Cynthia Char Ong. Dedicated private tutor, neurobiologist and actress (appeared nationally in ''A Chorus Line''). Visitation Friday, 4-9 PM. Funeral services on Saturday, 12 Noon at Wah Wing Sang Funeral home, 26 Mulberry St, NYC. 212-962-0273. Contributions in her name can be made Gilda's Club.

title: Hong Kong Votes for Democracy
description: Hong Kong's first legislative election under Chinese sovereignty was encouraging. Voter turnout on Sunday was high and a large majority of ballots were cast for candidates from democratic parties. That should be read as a powerful call to restore the democratic electoral system that was developing during the last years of British rule but was dismantled after the transfer to China last July. Hong Kong's Chief Executive, Tung Chee-hwa, should respond by expanding the number of democratically elected seats.

title: Now, there's a familiar face. And his Madison Avenue comeback reflects a change in attitudes.
description: IT'S Magic Time again for marketers.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Nightclub to Reopen in Gothic Church
description: Abruptly, the music stopped in 1996. Ever since, the picturesque Gothic landmark on the Avenue of the Americas at 20th Street has greeted nightfall as quietly as the rural parish church it was built to be.

title: Marlins Strike Early As the Mets Strike Often
description: Dave Mlicki had another difficult outing and the much-touted Mike Piazza stranded six base runners, but on this night the Mets easily brushed aside those shortcomings with one glorious inning.

title: The Pop Life; Girl Power Is Squelched
description: The most controversial music group in the country this month was not a gangsta rap or shock rock band, but the Indigo Girls, the politically and ecologically minded, Grammy-winning female guitar duo. A spokeswoman for the band's label, Epic, said no one was more surprised than the Indigo Girls themselves when three of five performances on a tour of high schools this spring were canceled by school administrators.

title: Business Travel: Road Warriors Losing Options; Corporate Ire Rises Along With Business Air Fares
description: Corporate air travel is no longer the land of the blank check.

title: $25 and Under; Beyond Tex-Mex: Duck Confit Tamalitos and More
description: ROCKING HORSE calls itself a Mexican cafe, which is perfectly true but doesn't begin to tell the story. Yes, this bright, crowded little restaurant serves frozen margaritas and huge baskets of chips, and you can make a meal of enchiladas and guacamole, just as you would at dozens of other neighborhood Tex-Mex restaurants. But if you look beyond the familiar items, you'll find some of the most exciting Mexican food in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAFETZ, BENJAMIN
description: CHAFETZ-Benjamin. Age 80, passed on peacefully in his sleep May 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Rosalind (nee Balterman) for 59 years. Devoted father of Helen Frank and Judy Good. Proud and loving grandfather of Bob, Ronni, Adam, Lauren, Bryan and Allison & uncle of several nieces. Retired CPA and Veteran of W.W. II 10th Mountain Army Division. Services Wednesday at 12:15 P.M., at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Dix Hills, Long Island. Interment following services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, New York.

title: O'Neill's Home Run Helps the Yankees Maneuver Nicely
description: There are no standard operating procedures for the manager of a team that wins every game. The Yankees are 35-10 after coming back tonight to beat Chicago, 7-5, and for their manager, Joe Torre, there are new and different decisions every day.

title: Thanking Satyajit Ray
description: When Ismail Merchant and James Ivory embarked on their filmmaking career more than 30 years ago, they received valuable guidance and help from the great Indian filmmaker Satyajit Ray.

title: THE ARTS IN: El Paso -- Dreams on the Streets of El Paso; Home-Grown Culture Blooms in a Struggling Border Town
description: The gallery that just opened in the heart of this city's historic downtown has a dreamy, almost flower-child feel to it. Just a few blocks from the Mexican border, it is an artists' collective, with the exhibition space in an old furniture showroom on the ground floor, chaotically messy studios upstairs and a performance area in the basement.

title: Rusty, Maybe, but Not Forsaken
description: WHAT with all the seductive new kitchen equipment on the market these days, it's a miracle anything old survives. But some things do -- or should -- because they're just better, no matter what Madison Avenue says.

title: City Plans to Avoid Layoffs In Cuts at Homeless Agency
description: A city plan to cut as many as 1,000 jobs from the Department of Homeless Services -- roughly half of the agency's total -- will not be achieved through layoffs, but by reassigning the workers to other city jobs and through attrition, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRISS, BRUNO R., MD.
description: KRISS-Bruno R., MD. A humane, sensitive and caring friend. Never forgotten, remembered on this day. ITTOM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, LAWRENCE
description: FRIEDMAN-Lawrence. Former Postmaster of Teaneck, NJ died May 25, 1998 after a long illness. He leaves his loving wife, Clara; daughters Barbara Friedman and Karen Glaser; two grandsons and sister, Miriam Drabkin.

title: Metro Business; Forstmann in Acquisition
description: Forstmann & Company of Manhattan yesterday acquired the Arenzano Trading Company, a maker of women's business suits, for $2 million, adding the Oleg Cassini brand name to its private-label men's and women's apparel.

title: Wine Talk; Languedoc Succeeds by Switching from Quantity to Quality
description: THE Languedoc, a vast scimitar-shaped region that sweeps from the Rhone almost to the Spanish border, is France's oldest, largest and most troublesome wine-producing area. The vines reach from Montpellier in the east through the ancient Roman city of Narbonne, northwest to Carcassonne and south to Perpignan and the foothills of the Pyrenees.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SNYDER OIL CORP., Fort Worth, said it swapped properties in Wyoming's Jonah field for a 75 percent interest in Amoco Corp.'s Wyoming Beaver Creek natural gas field and two related gas processing plants, resolving a legal dispute between the two companies.

title: Moral Guidance Isn't on Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: Roy Evans, 88, Architect of Ping-Pong Diplomacy, Dies
description: Roy Evans, the longtime president of the International Table Tennis Federation, died on May 18 in Cardiff, Wales, where he was born. He was 88 and has been credited with coming up with the idea of what he winced at having called Ping-Pong Diplomacy, the 1971 initiative that paved the way for the establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States and Communist China.

title: Edison Project Gets Aid to Open New Schools
description: With the help of a new $25 million grant, the Edison Project, the New York company that seeks to operate public schools for a profit, announced yesterday that it would double the size of its business this fall to 48 schools in 25 cities nationwide.

title: When Maman Gets Ill, Pretty Daughter Gets a Bill
description: Only in a certain kind of earnest French movie are you likely to find a beautiful 17-year-old girl reciting the poetry of Arthur Rimbaud and solemnly pondering its relevance to her own life. According to Beth (Judith Godreche), the seething central character of Benoit Jacquot's melancholy film, ''La Desenchantee,'' Rimbaud grew up disillusioned and spent his life searching futilely for something that would enchant him. In her premature awareness of life's pressures and limitations and her urge to flee the family nest, Beth thinks of herself as a spiritual sister of the Rimbaud she imagines.

title: Deutsche Telecom Plans To Spin Off Cable Unit
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., Germany's dominant phone company, said yesterday that it would spin off its cable television unit to head off possible antitrust concerns by European Union regulators. Deutsche Telekom, whose cable service is Germany's largest, will create a new wholly owned holding company as of Jan. 1, which will incorporate the cable business's assets, employees and services subsidiary. It will also seek partners for its operating units.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on May 18 about the opening of the 22d Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., referred incorrectly to Francesco Cavalli's Baroque opera ''Giasone.'' Its performance at the festival last Sunday was not the United States premiere. The opera has been performed in this country at least twice before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANES, MORRIS A.
description: MANES-Morris A. Trial attorney with N.Y.C.T.A. for 60 years. on May 25, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Lillian. Beloved father of Susan Arlene Braunstein and George. Cherished grandfather of Tina Michelle and Alysha Rachel Stein-Manes. Loving father-in-law of Barbara Faye Stein. Service Thursday 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Cancer Society.

title: To Keep a Promise To Her Father, Seles Returns to Paris
description: On a gloomy afternoon when a flu-plagued, second-seeded Petr Korda was upended by a 213th-ranked Argentine in a soccer shirt, and Andre Agassi slunk out of the first round with his shoulder and his ego in a sling, it was Monica Seles who made good on a comeback vow.

title: Rose Dealt One-Game Suspension; 3 Fined
description: No matter how daunting the situation, Larry Bird's voice has been as soothing as a warm bath for the Indiana Pacers. His words and advice have had a way of relieving stress.

title: Student Drawing Results In Weapons Confiscation
description: Prompted by the recent fatal shootings by children in schools, the police said yesterday that they had confiscated 20 guns and ammunition owned by the father of a boy showing his teacher a drawing of a person in the cross hairs of a rifle scope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENIHAN, KENNETH J.
description: LENIHAN-Kenneth J. We mourn the passing of Ken Lenihan, retired Professor of Sociology at John Jay College. Ken had extraordinary compassion, an uncommon wit and the brilliance and melancholy of the finest Irish poets. He will be treasured and missed by his dear sisters, Eileen, Moira, Jean & Sue; his loving children, Bill, Andrew & Jean, & his bereft grandchildren, Psachya, Tsvi and Julia. Service on Friday, May 30, 1:15 P.M., at Riverside Chapel.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I lost my own money, my wife's money, my parents' money, my brother's money, my friends' money. My wife says I have a year to pay it all back or she wants a divorce.''

title: AES TO ACQUIRE 90% STAKE IN ARGENTINE ELECTRIC CONCERN
description: The AES Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 90 percent of Empresa Distribuidora La Plata S.A., or Edelap, an Argentine electric distribution company, for $350 million. AES, based in Arlington, Va., is a power company that owns or has an interest in 91 power-generating plants in the United States and 11 other countries. It had revenue of $1.41 billion in 1997. AES purchased the stake from a joint venture of Houston Industries Energy Inc. and a unit of Technit S.A., an Argentine industrial company. Edelap has 278,000 customers in and around the city of La Plata. With Edelap, AES will have 680,000 retail customers in Argentina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELLER, BELLE
description: ZELLER-Belle. The Trustees and Staff of the Belle Zeller Scholarship Trust Fund mourn the death of Dr. Belle Zeller, founding President Emerita of the Professional Staff Congress/CUNY. A woman of indefatigable energy, intellectual honesty and personal integrity, the 223 CUNY students to date, and those who will follow as recipients of scholarships in her name, will remain a testament to her finest qualities; leadership, community service and academic excellence. Shirley Beheshti, Chairperson

title: Shad and the Other Roes of Spring
description: SHAD roe is a delicacy that is a hallmark of spring, but shad is hardly the only fish whose eggs make a delightfully rich supper or snack this time of year.

title: The Rift Widens Between Hundley and the Mets
description: Todd Hundley will leave the Mets for his home in nearby Port St. Lucie, Fla., on Wednesday, and there is reason to wonder whether the All-Star catcher wants to leave for good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, LILLIAN
description: KINGSLEY-Lillian. On May 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Robert Helene and the late Murray Kingsley. Dear mother of Rochelle (Harry) Reese, Howard (Carol Mann), Helene and Joseph (Linda) Kingsley. Adored Grandmother of Adam, Seth, Robert, Matthew, David and David. Cherished sister of Dorothy Fialkoff and Norbert Beck. Lillian was president of Alan Paul Hecht Chapter-City of Hope and a retired New York City school teacher. Services were held on Tuesday, May 26th.

title: Welfare Workers Rate High In Job Retention at Companies
description: Some companies hiring welfare recipients say they have found, to their surprise, that such workers stay on the job longer, with less turnover, than other employees.

title: Moral Guidance Isn't on Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: 'Surprise' on Welfare Work

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 15 about the House's approval of a bill to punish countries that persecute people for their religious beliefs misstated the Heritage Foundation's view of the legislation. While the foundation was critical of the original bill, later changes resolved many of the concerns.

title: Microsoft and ICL of Britain In 'Enterprise Computing' Pact
description: The Microsoft Corporation, which already enjoys a virtual monopoly in operating systems for personal computers, today announced a European alliance that will make it a formidable contender in the network operating systems that connect many types of computers throughout an entire company.

title: TV Notes; Court TV Settlement
description: For Court TV, the ownership problem has been resolved, but the future is still hazy.

title: Discord Mounts After Play Is Canceled
description: As protests spread over last week's decision by the Manhattan Theater Club to withdraw its production of a new play attacked by a Roman Catholic group, the South African playwright Athol Fugard said he would not allow the theater to present his latest play. The theater club, meanwhile, defended its decision not to stage Terrence McNally's new play, ''Corpus Christi.'' The club's two top administrators said yesterday they had acted after anonymous telephone threats to burn down the theater, kill the staff and ''exterminate'' Mr. McNally.

title: Microsoft Has A Stronghold In Office Suites
description: When employees of the New York Attorney General's office sat down last week to prepare the final draft of the multistate lawsuit accusing the Microsoft Corporation of monopolistic, anticompetitive behavior, they typed the document using Microsoft Word, the word processor installed on the office's computers as part of a group of business programs known as Office.

title: Kraft Joins Frierson & Mee
description: Neil Kraft, one of the best-known figures in fashion and fragrance advertising, has joined Frierson & Mee in New York as a partner and creative director.

title: Moral Guidance Isn't on Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: Abbott's Return Hinges On White Sox Audition
description: Right away, right after the California Angels released him, Jim Abbott missed the camaraderie of baseball, being around the other players. Being at home on summer nights, that was strange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVER, GERALD R.
description: DEVER-Gerald R. On May 25, 1998. Educator/Guidance Counselor. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Tully); devoted father of Michael; loving brother of Carol Dever and Joan Mikusinski. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 9105 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 9:45 AM at St. Francis DeSales Church, Belle Harbor, NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10PM. To perpetuate his work and love for education a memorial fund has been established. Donations may be made to the Gerald R. Dever Scholarship fund, c/o Pat Walsh, J.H.S. 180, 320 Beach 104th St., Rockaway Park, New York 11694.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Business Digest column yesterday showing the number of hotel rooms being built each year omitted a scale label. The numbers shown were in the thousands, not the hundreds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OUIMETTE, MARGARET YANOW
description: OUIMETTE-Margaret Yanow. On May 25, 1998. Beloved wife of Robert; mother of David and Michael; sister of Barbara and Philip Lichtenstein and Caryl Yanow and William Grueskin; aunt of Sarah Lichtenstein; niece of Robert and Sandra Levine and Mildred and Marvin Wallach; daughter of the late Mitchell and Elaine Yanow. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Tuesday, May 26, 5-7PM with service Wednesday, May 27, 11:30 AM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBSON, STUART EDWARD
description: JACOBSON - Stuart Edward. 1954-1989. Your life has been a blessing to us all. Dad, Mother and Kyle
