description: To the Editor:

title: Road to Weehawken: Hamilton's Burr Baiting
description: A FATAL FRIENDSHIP

title: One-Act Plays Get Their Chance
description: Send for vitamin supplements, stat! The Ensemble Studio Theater marathon is developing a severe case of anemia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NITTI, SAVINO
description: NITTI-Savino. Of Head of the Harbor, New York. Formerly of West Hempstead, on May 25, 1998 on his 87th birthday. Beloved husband of Nancy. Devoted father of Francis Mazzara and Maria Frase. Cherished grandfather of Marissa, Stephanie and Elizabeth. Loving great grandfather of David. Dear brother of Margaret Mazzola and Gloria Julian. Reposing at the Branch Funeral Home, Inc.,190 E. Main Street, Smithtown Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 7-9:30 PM. Funeral Mass St. Philip and James RC Church, at 10 A.M., Saturday. Intombment in Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Coram, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABARSKY, DAVID
description: SABARSKY-David. Died shortly after his 80th birthday on May 26th, 1998 after suffering from a long illness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, JULES
description: KRAFT-Jules. Beloved grandfather of Dylan, Morrison, Marley and Stella; loving father of Neil, Ronald and Susan; husband to Susan; died May 26, 1998. A gathering in his memory will be held at the CAC, 50 W. 54th St, at 11AM on May 29. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Mastocytosis Society Research Fund, 4771 Waynes Trace Rd, Hamilton, Ohio 45011. He will be missed.

title: Simon J. Liebowitz, Ex-Judge And New York Legislator, 92
description: Simon J. Liebowitz, a former New York State Supreme Court justice and State Senator from Brooklyn, died on Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92 and a resident of Palm Beach and Brooklyn.

title: This Year, the Business of Commencement Was Business
description: College commencement speakers are customarily drawn from the ranks of judges, authors, former Presidents, entertainers and journalists, but the number recruited from the business world this year appears to have been larger than usual.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUDMAR, MILTON W.
description: LUDMAR-Milton W. Dear Dad, it is now five years since your passing. I visit you nightly in my dreams, and know you are well in the arms of God. You are forever in my heart and the hearts of those who loved you. I love you and miss you very much. Your loving son, Scott

title: Metro Business; Roslyn Plans to Buy A Savings and Loan
description: Roslyn Bancorp of Roslyn, N.Y., agreed yesterday to buy the T. R. Financial Corporation for $920.4 million in stock, more than doubling its business on Long Island.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Shares Slide on Concerns About Valuation and Profits
description: A growing fear among investors that stocks may be overvalued and that corporate earnings growth may be stalling sent equities tumbling for a third day, as all major market gauges lost more than 1 percent of their value yesterday.

title: N.C.A.A. Alters Learning Disabled Policy
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today reached an agreement with the Justice Department to alter its eligibility policies so that hundreds of freshmen with dyslexia and other learning disabilities may be able to compete in college sports.

title: Hong Kong Confronts Democracy: How Soon?
description: Emboldened by their sweeping victory in Sunday's elections here, Hong Kong's pro-democracy politicians are calling for a swifter transition to full democracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMENY, NAT
description: KAMENY-Nat, 1923-1998. Nat Kameny, 74, a public relations executive widely credited with having launched the Japanese camera industry in the United States, died at his home in Bergenfield, N.J. on Monday, May 25 of complications from heart failure. A dedicated and creative activist for Israel as well as local causes, Mr. Kameny's major interest was the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith of which he had been a National Vice Chairman. In the late 60's, when professional public relations was virtually unheard of in Israel, he founded Israel Communications, Inc., which soon became that country's largest advertising/ p.r. firm. In New Jersey, he worked closely with Bergenfield authorities on many civic projects, including the town library, and served on the board of the Bergen County United Jewish Community, the Solomon Schechter Day School, the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, American Friends of the Haifa University, and the Jewish Foundation for Christian Rescuers. He is survived by his wife of 55 years, the former Ruth Zatal of the Bronx, their children, Leslie Kameny and John Lindberg, Ellen and Martin Eber, Debbie and Ken Tracht, and grandchildren, David, Michael, Anna, Sophie, Adam and Raphael. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 AM on Wednesday, May 27th, at Wien and Wien in Hackensack. Contributions may be made to the ADL or to the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center Heart Institute.

title: A Very Public Case of Sinatra Fascination
description: THESE are a few of the things that concern Jonathan Schwartz:

title: High-Speed Headaches Are a Joy for Cheever
description: Driving a race car at speeds of more than 230 miles an hour, Eddie Cheever said, is much easier than being a team owner.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, SIMON J.
description: LIEBOWITZ-Simon J. Attorney, NYS Senator, NYS Civil and Supreme Court Judge. Adored husband of Elsie. Devoted and caring father of Gloria and Bernard Herman, Burt and Linda Liebowitz, and the late Sonia Brodsky. Father-in-law of Leonard Brodsky. Cherished grandfather of Esther, Ruth, Judith, Mindy, Steven, Suzanne, Ellen & Eileen. Great grandfather of nine. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, New York, Wednesday 12 noon. Memorial donations may be made to the Brooklyn Law School or your favorite charity.

title: Justices Allow Broad Leeway to Police Chases, Even Those Causing Deaths
description: High-speed police chases that cause death or injury do not violate the Constitution unless the police acted with ''a purpose to cause harm,'' the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision that resolved an important question of liability for law-enforcement tactics gone awry.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Fetal Protection Law Is Threat to Women; Pandering to the Left
description: To the Editor:

title: At Gateway To America, Just Another Spring Day
description: The highest court in the land has spoken and this tablet of rock in New York Harbor now belongs more to New Jersey than to New York. So politicians in New Jersey gloated and their counterparts in New York griped, but here at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum, the sentiment today seemed to be that this island belongs to everybody.

title: Arts Abroad; Brand-New Work at Paris Opera? Yes, and It's a Hit
description: While theater, literature, dance and the visual arts have all found ways of breaking out of their classical molds, opera remains strangely resistant to renewal as an art form. One attempt to do so has involved presenting traditional operas in modern dress and settings. Another has led composers to write new operas in a contemporary musical idiom. Opera lovers frequently balk at both.

title: Campaign Reform Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: New Rules May Cost CUNY Millions
description: Eliminating remedial classes at the City University of New York will affect as many as 13,000 freshman and transfer students each year and could cost the university hundreds of millions of dollars in tuition revenue, according to CUNY estimates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPOSANU, PAMFIL
description: RIPOSANU-Pamfil. The Marymount School Board of Trustees, Administration and entire School community mourn the death of our beloved friend, colleague and Trustee Emeritus, Pamfil (Rip) Riposanu. A member of the Board since 1977, he shared his legal expertise and provided strong leadership and generous support. He will be fondly remembered for his love of Marymount and the warmth and wit that he brought to the School. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Marguerite, his daughter, Ann Maria '78, and his entire family. Kathleen Fagan, RSHM, Head Mistress

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRKHAHN, RUTH P.
description: BIRKHAHN-Ruth P. At age 90. Mother of Judith and William Abelow and the late Steven Birkhahn. Grandmother of Janie Finn, Debbie Abelow, Tracy Spicer and Ted Birkhahn. Great-grandmother of Zachary Finn and Jacob Finn. A generous and special woman to her family and friends. Services on Wednesday 12 noon at the Union Reform Temple, 475 North Brookside Avenue, Freeport, L.I. In lieu of flowers, kindly donate to Family & Childrens Association, 100 East Old Country Road, Mineola, New York 11501.

title: TV Notes; Emergency Measures
description: Imagine the reaction in the corporate offices of NBC when they heard about a plan being floated by the cable channel TNT to stack three consecutive repeats of NBC's biggest show, ''E.R.,'' on Thursday nights next fall. The line ''Must Sue TV'' comes to mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEGLER, ELMIRITA A.
description: KOEGLER-Elmirita A. Of New York, died in her 93rd year on May 19, in St. Petersburg, Florida, where she had resided since 1997. She was the widow of George Koegler of New York, who at his death in 1956 was General Counsel of the Standard Oil Co. (NJ). She was the daughter of Dr. Raoul Amador of Paris, France, and of Mrs. Jennie Smith Amador of New York and a granddaughter of Dr. Manuel Amador, a native of Spain who became the first president of the Republic of Panama. Her son, Kurt Koegler, of Dubois, WY, died in 1996. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. George P. Tilley of Fayetteville, NY, her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Kurt Koegler of Jackson Hole, WY, her grandchildren, Mrs. Brian Farlow, Dallas, TX, Mrs. John Cavo, Tampa, FL, Mr. Keith Koegler, San Francisco, CA, Miss Carolyn Koegler, Concord, N.H., Miss Katherine Koegler, Chicago, IL., and a grandchild, Francesca Amador Farlow, Dallas, TX. Funeral services at 1 PM Friday, May 29, St. James Church, 71st Street and Madison Avenue, New York, Reverend Craig Townsend officiating. Private interment immediately following, Greenwood Cemetery.

title: From American Ballet Theater, Tricks and Fine-Tuned Pairs
description: American Ballet Theater celebrates itself tonight in ''Variety and Virtuosity: American Ballet Theater Now,'' a glittering compendium of new and familiar star turns on view on PBS (Channel 13 in New York, tonight at 9). The program, recorded in November at City Center for ''Dance in America,'' part of the ''Great Performances'' series, provides an overview of one of the world's greatest ballet troupes. It is also a feast of very good dancing. If the invited audience sometimes seems to be responding to ''applaud and cheer'' cue cards, the Ballet Theater dancers do offer plenty of chances for wholehearted roars of appreciation.

title: An Era Of Romance Shimmers In Revival
description: NEW YORK CITY is crowded, noisy and expensive, so naturally, when New Yorkers seek diversion in the form of a nice meal, they are very picky. They head straight for a restaurant that is crowded, noisy and expensive. In the waning minutes of the 20th century, the high-style dining experience more often than not means tricky fusion cuisine served in a room with the acoustics of an Elks lodge, eaten by patrons dressed for a night at T.G.I. Friday's and presented by waiters who, on taking an order, shrug and say, ''No problem.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILEY, DOROTHY SPENCE
description: BRILEY-Dorothy Spence, suddenly on May 25, 1998. Beloved mother of Karen and Michael. Devoted grandmother of Justin. Editor in Chief and Publisher, Clarion Books; Vice President, Trade and Reference Division, Houghton Mifflin Company. Plans for memorial service have not been announced.

title: Fighting Breaks Out in Georgia Buffer Region
description: A flareup in a five-year-old conflict over the Black Sea region of Abkhazia forced President Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia to accept a wave of tens of thousands of refugees today and to cancel Independence Day celebrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, ROCHELLE
description: FEUER-Rochelle. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member and past President, Willy Feuer on the loss of his beloved wife, and to the children, Ezra, Daniel, David and Esther on the loss of their devoted mother. May the families be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mark Spund, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Italian Officials Seek Charges in Ski Lift Case
description: Italian prosecutors asked a judge in northern Italy today to issue indictments for multiple manslaughter against the four crew members of the Marine jet that sliced through ski lift cables last February and killed 20 people. The prosecutors also moved to indict the crew's commanding officers on the same charges.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Senate approval of a bill to penalize foreign enterprises that provide restricted missile technology or expertise to Iran misstated the next step. The bill now goes to a House-Senate conference committee to work out minor differences, not directly to the White House.

title: Richmond Coach Pulls Out As a St. John's Candidate
description: After a week of narrowing down the list of candidates for the vacant head basketball coaching position, St. John's athletic director, Ed Manetta, began the interviewing process yesterday. But while he was playing host to two of the candidates, one of the final four, John Beilein of the University of Richmond, dropped out of the running.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGER, PAULINE
description: LAGER-Pauline. Beloved wife of the late Max, loving mother of Barbara Beauregard and Judith Glazer Raymo, cherished grandmother of Helen, George, Ellen, Jodi, David, Ed, and Dan, and great grandmother of Jonathan, Daniel, Nicholas, Morgan, Brian, and Eric. Services on Thursday at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: I.M.F. Assesses New Indonesia Government
description: Indonesia's political upheaval has worsened its severe economic problems, and a high-level team from the International Monetary Fund arrived here today to explore ways to restart its rescue package.

title: F.D.A. Experts Back a Vaccine Against Lyme
description: An advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration recommended approval of the first vaccine against Lyme disease tonight, but expressed serious concerns about its safety and effectiveness.

title: Moral Guidance Isn't on Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, SIMON D.
description: STRAUSS-Simon D. The Trustees and Administration of the Manhattan School of Music mourn with deep sadness the death of our dear friend, Simon D. Strauss. A member of our Board of Trustees for two decades, we recall his wisdom, generosity and commitment. His friendship and loyalty will be remembered with warm affection. We extend our deepest sympathies to his dear wife Janet and all the members of the Strauss family. Marta Istomin, President David A. Rahm, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: TV Notes; Attention, Word Fans
description: It is an event requiring considerable brain power but no brawn whatsoever, so it might seem a strange event for ESPN. But tomorrow the cable sports network will televise the Scripps Howard National Spelling Bee, live from Washington, at 1 P.M. It will be replayed at 7:30 on ESPN2. More than 200 students age 15 or younger will compete. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: Dividing Ellis Island
description: From the foot of Battery Park, Ellis Island seems no nearer and no farther than the rest of New Jersey visible across Upper New York Bay. Yet somehow, after yesterday's Supreme Court decision awarding sovereignty to New Jersey over all but 5 of the island's 27.5 acres, Ellis Island seems a little more remote than it did just a few days ago. The decision was not surprising -- the special master appointed by the Court came to a similar conclusion last year -- and it resolves only the question of where Ellis Island is, not who owns it, since it is owned in fact by the United States. But to many New Yorkers, the Supreme Court's conclusion feels nonetheless like a rather narrow-minded victory over the clear weight of tradition.

title: The Chef
description: AS an 18-year-old assistant cook at La Mere Blanc, I was surrounded by grand cuisine -- none of which my fellow cooks and I could afford. On our days off we headed to the area we thought of as the bayou of Lyons, Les Dombes, and ate local crayfish in cheap bars and truck-stop cafes. I date my love for these freshwater creatures from that time.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELSON, WILLIAM A.
description: BELSON-William A. May 27, 1973. Missing you 25 years. Love you forever. Loving wife, Ginny Belson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. Died on May 25, 1998 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Irene for 61 years; loving father of John and Helga, Mason and Elizabeth; loving grandfather of Peter. You will be in our hearts forever. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimers Disease Foundation.

title: Cabbies Denied Free Speech, A Judge Rules
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled last night that the Giuliani administration was violating the First Amendment rights of taxi drivers by preventing them from protesting regulations and fines that the city is seeking to impose on their industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, BETTY
description: BLOCK-Betty. Tifereth IsraelTown and Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extends heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Fred Karp, President

title: A Theatrical Infusion Of Energy and Tension
description: Weekend programs by the New York City Ballet were remarkable for their choreographic variety and high-powered dancing.

title: Some Remarkable Twists On the Path to Graduation
description: Members of the class of '98 showed resilience and persistence as they worked toward that sheepskin. A little serendipity did not hurt, either. Take, for example, the stories below:

title: Judaism Reaches Out to Converts
description: When Valley Beth Shalom, a large synagogue in the San Fernando Valley, wanted to invite people to an intensive four-month lecture course on Judaism, it bought advertising space in The Los Angeles Times and other area newspapers.

title: CUNY TO TIGHTEN ADMISSIONS POLICY AT 4-YEAR SCHOOLS
description: Trustees of the City University of New York last night voted to exclude students from the university's four-year colleges who cannot pass proficiency tests in reading, writing and mathematics, making the most fundamental change in standards since instituting open admissions nearly three decades ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, IRWIN (ROBE)
description: ROSENBERG-Irwin (Robe). Of Englewood, NJ. Beloved husband of Elaine (nee Geduld), devoted father of Bobbie Frankfort and Ellen Goldfein. Dear father-in-law of Lew Frankfort and Shep Goldfein. Dear brother of Sy. Dear brotherin-law of Carmel. Loving Papa of Leslie, Tamara, Briana, Sam, Joshua and Alana. Services Temple Emanu-El, 147 Tenafly Rd., Englewood, NJ, Wednesday, May 27, 1998 at 12:30. Contributions to the American Heart Association would be appreciated. For further information: ''Wien & Wien'' at 800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHNMAN, FLORA
description: CAHNMAN-Flora, 92. Of Miami, Florida. Dear sister of Else Meier of Bay Harbor Islands, FL and Toni Hoebel of NY. Loving aunt of Norman Meier and family of Pembroke Pines, FL and NY, Margo (Bob) Cunn and Ann (Irwin) Kellner of NY. Graveside services Thursday, 3:45 PM at Lakeside Memorial Park, Miami, FL.

title: Sheffer Leads Team to Title
description: The former University of Connecticut guard Doron Sheffer scored 19 points yesterday as Maccabi Tel Aviv defeated Hapoel Eilat, 94-80, giving Maccabi its fifth straight Israeli Basketball League title. Sheffer also had five assists as Maccabi completed the three-game sweep in the championship round.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LILIENSTEIN, NATALIE
description: LILIENSTEIN-Natalie. Mother, friend, wife, social activist and community organizer; a beautiful, caring woman with an indomitable spirit and sunshine bright smile has reluctantly bid us farewell. She leaves behind her two devoted children, Nan Shuker and Alan Ross, someone who was like a daughter, Janice Dompke, and so many special friends and confidantes it is impossible to mention; all of whom are in her debt for the kindness, sensitivity and support she offered freely, without condition. A lifelong activist and humanitarian, working with organizations ranging from the NAACP, Women's Strike for Peace, Southern Christian Leadership Conference, League of Women Voters and the Morris Dees Center for Peace and Justice to Victims Services Agency, Greenwich Village Coalition and the Samaritans Suicide Prevention Center, Natalie was an advocate for the elderly, women, minorities, the oppressed and all victims of political tyranny. She was someone who sought out the good in everyone and, by touching them, made them better; someone who always looked on ''the bright side of life.'' She has joined her beloved late husband, Emil Lilienstein, and we know they are once again holding hands and happy to be together. We celebrate her life and spirit knowing she leaves us having made the world a warmer, and better, place. Friends and family are invited to a memorial in her honor to be held Sunday, June 14, 2PM at Grace Church School, 86 Fourth Avenue (at 11th Street). In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to The Samaritans of NY, PO Box 1259, New York, New York 10159

title: VANGUARD CELLULAR PLANS TO SELL FLORIDA PROPERTIES
description: Vanguard Cellular Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its systems in the Pensacola and Fort Walton Beach, Fla., markets to Wireless One Network L.P. for $172.5 million. Vanguard Cellular, based in Greensboro, N.C., operates cellular telephone systems under the Cellular One brand name in 29 markets on the Eastern seaboard. Wireless One is a private company based in Fort Myers, Fla. The sale of its Florida properties will allow Vanguard to concentrate on its markets in the Northeast corridor, Vanguard said.

title: 5 Nations See World Cup Threat : European Police Detain Algerians
description: BRUSSELS  Police in five European countries on Tuesday raided the homes of people suspected of supporting an Islamic extremist group in Algeria. Officials said the coordinated operation  in Belgium, France, Germany, Italy and Switzerland  was aimed at forestalling the threat of terrorist violence during the World Cup soccer tournament, which opens in France next month.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Talk column of Business Day on Monday about the credits given by Harper's Bazaar on its cover for the designer who dresses the cover model or celebrity misspelled the given name of the editor of a rival magazine, Elle, which also credits the designer on occasion. The editor is Elaina Richardson, not Elena.

title: U.S. Delays World Bank Loans For India in Response to A-Tests
description: The Administration made good today on its threat to make India pay for conducting five nuclear tests earlier this month, forcing what the World Bank called ''an indefinite delay'' on $865 million in loans for an electric power grid and other projects.

title: Moral Guidance Isn't on Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: Vallone Moves Strongly for Democrats' Support in Race for Governor
description: Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker and candidate for governor, moved aggressively today to dominate the Democratic State Convention in the hope of forcing his competitors to give up their campaigns or to begin the costly process of petitioning for a place on the September primary ballot.

title: Words of Wisdom for the Nation's Graduates
description: As students leave the cocoon of college for the so-called real world, commencement speakers across the country share their pearls of wisdom, lend earnest advice and provide a pep talk for life. These excerpts from addresses were taken from transcripts provided by the schools.

title: After Melee, New Houses In Jerusalem To Be Razed
description: Jewish settlers built makeshift dwellings today on disputed land in the Muslim Quarter of the Old City here, setting off a melee between the Israeli police and Palestinians and prompting the Mayor of Jerusalem to issue a demolition order.

title: Sale of Russian Oil Company Gets No Bidders
description: After months of high-stakes maneuvers, the long-awaited auction for Russia's last big oil company came to an unceremonious end today.

title: Violent Queens Afternoon Leaves 2 Teen-Agers Dead
description: Two teen-agers died and another was critically wounded in a series of unrelated violent incidents in Queens that occurred within two hours yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LLOYD, ELIZABETH GIBBS
description: LLOYD-Elizabeth Gibbs. Of Bronxville, NY, on May 25, 1998. Wife of the late H. Wilson Lloyd, mother of David and Sally. Memorial services at The Christ Church of Bronxville at 12 noon on Thursday.

title: The Minimalist; Pasta in Wine, Simply Splendid
description: FINISHING pasta by cooking it for the final minute or two in stock is not all that uncommon. But simmering it in flavorful liquid for nearly all of its cooking time, almost as you would a risotto, is highly unusual. And when that liquid is red wine, you have a pasta dish that is an attention grabber.

title: CINCINNATI BELL WARNS OF LOWER EARNINGS AND LAYOFFS
description: Cincinnati Bell Inc. warned yesterday that its second-quarter earnings and sales would be less than expected and that it would dismiss workers to improve profit. Shares of the phone company, which handles billing and customer services for the AT&T Corporation and others, fell $4, to $32.375. Earnings will be about 27 cents to 31 cents a share, while analysts were expecting 32 cents, based on a poll of five by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Cincinnati Bell said it was offering 2,500 workers at the former AT&T Solutions Customer Care unit a benefits package to leave the company. Cincinnati Bell hopes 150 people will accept. Those cuts are separate from the 250 positions the company already has said it will eliminate at the unit in hopes of saving $10 million. The company has a total of 30,000 employees.

title: Bringing Financial Respectability to a Drug Maker
description: Had he engineered the reunification of Yugoslavia, where he served as Prime Minister for six months in 1992 and 1993, Milan Panic would not have produced a bigger surprise.

title: Ex-Bishop Urges Solution To Mend Episcopal Rift
description: A clergyman who was appointed to help reunite the divided Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey yesterday recommended appointing an assistant to Bishop Joe Morris Doss and called on church leaders to cease their attacks on the Bishop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALIMIR, SUZANNE
description: GALIMIR-Suzanne. On May 24, 1998. Beloved wife of Felix. Loving sister of Martin Hirsch, Margaret Hirsh and the late Stephen Hirsch. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Services on Thursday, at 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Profit and Earnings Fears Send Dow Index Tumbling

title: Sports of The Times; Some Advice For Piazza And Hundley
description: UP until yesterday, I had two words for Mike Piazza: ''Gil'' and ''Hodges.'' And two words for Todd Hundley: ''Elston'' and ''Howard.'' Just in case I had not yet made my point, there were two words for both of them: ''Yogi'' and ''Berra.''

description: A Herring Fest

title: New Demand For Samples From Intern
description: Investigators this week renewed their demand that Monica S. Lewinsky submit handwriting, voice and fingerprint samples, lawyers involved in the inquiry said today.

description: ULLMANN-Julia (nee Polyatchek), on May 24, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Georges D. Ullmann. Adoring mother of Nadine U. Brozan and the late Judith Anne Posner. Loving grandmother of Theodore R. Posner, Jacqueline P. Glassman and Alexander M. Brozan. Great-grandmother of Jacob H. Glassman and sister of Stanley Paley. Services Wednesday, May 27, 11:30 AM, Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, L.I.

title: Restaurants; Fancy Chinese Food From Another Era
description: ''WHY doesn't he go away?'' my friend said crossly one day at lunch. She looked at the captain standing at attention near the table and added, ''I can't stand being watched while I eat.''

description: If only Leonard Bernstein could see it: Gerry Adams in Armani from Macy's, with all the New York society babes chasing after him.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN AT NEARLY 7-YEAR LOW. The yen fell on speculation the United States and Japan would tolerate a decline because that could help the weak Japanese economy. In New York, the dollar rose to 137.83 yen from 135.90.

title: Excerpts From the Supreme Court's Decision on Ellis Island
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 6-to-3 decision today on Ellis Island. Justice David H. Souter wrote the majority opinion.

title: Home Resales Down Slightly; Consumer Confidence Slips
description: Two economic indicators released today suggested that the economy might be throttling back from the pace it reached earlier this year. Sales of previously owned homes fell in April, while consumer confidence edged lower this month.

title: IVAX EXPLORES STRATEGIC REORGANIZATION AND SPINOFFS
description: The board of the Ivax Corporation authorized its management yesterday to explore a reorganization of the company's business, including possible spinoffs and related transactions. In a statement the company said its board had approved the hiring of Schroder & Company to explore the feasibility of an initial public offering of its Norton Healthcare unit, which is a generic drug company in Britain. Lehman Brothers will advise the board on possible spinoffs or other transactions involving Zenith Goldine, its United States generics pharmaceutical business; DVM Pharmaceuticals Inc., its veterinary products business, and the Diamedix Corporation, its diagnostics business. Ivax, based in Miami, also said it planned to change its name to IVX Biosciences.

title: Thigpen's Alchemy: Turning Dust Into Gold
description: Everyone living in the country has family who visit from the city. Yancey Thigpen knows this. He was born in as country as country gets, in Conetoe, N.C., where the towns nearby were Tarboro and Rocky Mount. In 1979, when Thigpen was 10, there were no Pop Warner football leagues in Conetoe. You simply chose sides -- I've got Willie, Junebug and Peaches, you get Boot Boy, Jamie and Freddie.

title: Journal; Beat the Press
description: Is it possible that there's even more embarrassing news yet to be learned about Linda Tripp?

title: Taming Little Tyrants
description: For some years there has been conflict between older women who were stay-at-home moms and their career daughters and sons about the rearing of their children. I, along with several other grandmothers of my acquaintance, believe that children today are being indulged.

title: 2 Hustlers with a Van and a Scam
description: When Congress next contemplates revision of the penal code, perhaps in its wisdom and compassion it will consider making the interstate shipment of attempted comedy a Federal crime.

description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes; Expanding The Bookshelf
description: C-Span, the cable-industry-sponsored channel that provides extensive coverage of politics and Government, announced yesterday that it would devote its full 48 hours of weekend programming to the world of books and literature.

title: Clinton Cuts Gulf Forces in Half As Showdown With Iraq Recedes
description: The Pentagon announced today that the United States was reducing by half the size of its forces in the Persian Gulf, as last winter's military showdown with Iraq fades into memory.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Internet Monopoly?
description: To the Editor:

title: Remember When: Stylish Classics
description: MY mother says that every restaurant meal for the first third of my life involved exactly the same three dishes: shrimp cocktail, broiled filet mignon and New York cheesecake. I like to think I had a taste for classic dishes at an early age. My mother likes to say I had a taste for whatever was the most expensive thing on the menu.

title: ABN Amro Bids for Generale de Banque
description: ABN Amro Holding N.V. offered more than $12 billion for Generale de Banque S.A. today, exceeding a takeover proposal from Fortis, which last week reached an agreement to buy the Belgian bank.

title: A New Voice for Van Halen
description: The big news about the Van Halen tour is that the set lists go all the way back to the band's beginnings. But that's little consolation; its concert at Madison Square Garden on Friday night was hollow, almost devoid of presence, pacing or drama.

title: The Commission Dodge
description: The cause of overhauling the nation's campaign finance laws has faced endless assaults by Newt Gingrich and other foes. But now just as reform legislation is making headway in the House, a new danger is posed by those who say they are friends. The threat is embodied in a bill commanding wide support that would simply create a new commission to study and propose changes in the campaign laws. If it passes by a big margin, it could bury legislation calling for actual and immediate change. Now is the time for backers of the commission approach, including many pro-reform Democrats, to withdraw and vote for real change.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DESOSA, COUNT MAXIM
description: DeSOSA-Count Maxim, 2/8/61-5/ 26/92. Five years have passed, but your memory is with me always. Eric

title: South African Producer Of Fuels to Buy AECI
description: Sasol Ltd., a South African synthetic fuels and chemicals producer, agreed yesterday to acquire AECI Ltd., a maker of chemicals, mining explosives and fertilizer, for 30 rand a share cash, or about 4.6 billion rand ($904 million). The price excludes AECI's interim dividend for the six months ending June 30. AECI's shares fell a tenth of a rand, to 27.9 rand. AECI shareholders holding about 75 percent of the ordinary shares have said they would vote in favor of the plan.

title: High Court Gives New Jersey Most of Ellis Island
description: New Jersey won the battle of Ellis Island today.

title: U.S. Raid Takes Down a Onetime Canadian Highflier
description: A small cinder-block building in a suburban office park outside Philadelphia is an unlikely setting for a complex tale of international intrigue.

title: ARBOR IN $762 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR HYPERION
description: The Arbor Software Corporation will acquire the Hyperion Software Corporation for about $762 million, based on Friday's closing price, creating one of the largest United States makers of financial software for businesses. Arbor will issue 0.95 share for each share of Hyperion. Arbor makes customized programs for sophisticated financial planning and Hyperion makes prepackaged software that lets companies analyze large amounts of management information. The shares of both companies plunged. Arbor, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., tumbled $8.25 a share, to $33.875, while Hyperion, based in Stamford, Conn., dropped $6.75, to $31.375.

title: Officer Is Killed in Brooklyn; Suspect, a Parolee, Also Dies
description: A New York City police officer was fatally shot yesterday morning in Brooklyn while trying to arrest a parolee who had missed a court date on a month-old drug charge, and officials were investigating whether the suspect was on the streets because of an administrative failure.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Top Singer And a Big Seven-0

title: 'Pataki,' the Potboiler
description: While the idea of a biography is to tell an interesting story about a person's life, a politician's autobiography usually attempts something close to the exact opposite. To be a success, the political memoir for a working politician must be carefully dull. In this regard, Gov. George Pataki's forthcoming tome is a smash. It is so denuded of anything that could offend or stimulate that if ''Pataki, an Autobiography'' is ever transferred to tape it should bear a warning about driving or operating heavy machinery.

title: Flyers Invite Woman to Camp
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have invited Hayley Wickenheiser, a member of the Canadian women's Olympic team, to their prospects camp, giving her the chance to test her skills against some of the National Hockey League team's top hopefuls.

title: Teen-Agers With Infants Languishing In Foster Care
description: New York City's severe shortage of foster homes has left dozens of teen-age mothers and their newborn babies languishing for weeks in local hospitals while child welfare officials scramble to find permanent beds for them, city and hospital officials said yesterday.

title: Licensing Deal For Real Quiet
description: Mike Pegram, owner of Triple Crown contender Real Quiet, has granted the horse's licensing and merchandising rights to the National Thoroughbred Racing Association, a new coalition of the racing industry's interests.

title: Where the Noble White Asparagus Is King
description: THE men gathered in the field, as they do every spring, at a small farm in the Rhine River valley. They were dressed in traditional Alsatian costume: gray wool coattails and black tricorn hats. Around their necks, they wore bronze medallions. But beneath the air of ceremony was an almost giddy excitement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECK, JEROME L.
description: SCHECK-Jerome L. The Officers and employees of Scheck-Rosenblum-Sierra Textiles, Inc. mourn the passing of our retired Chairman of the Board. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Eleanor, and his family. We will all miss his guidance and friendship. Bob Rosenblum, Chairman Murray Yenis, President

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: FRONTIER CORP., Rochester, the fifth-largest United States long-distance phone company, named an AT&T Corporation executive, Rolla Huff, as chief financial officer to replace Louis Massaro, who retired in February.

title: Sharpton Rests Defense After Calling 2 Witnesses
description: After recalling two witnesses who had already testified, the lawyer for the Rev. Al Sharpton rested his defense yesterday in the Tawana Brawley defamation case.

title: Internet Monopoly?

description: Ronald Disanto remembers standing on the roof of the family station wagon as a 6-year-old and staring straight up at the belly of an airliner as it rumbled over him.

description: Somewhere on its hopeful way toward being a gritty little thriller, ''West New York'' took a few wrong turns.

title: 2 Kentucky Representatives Are Chosen for Senate Race
description: Two members of the House of Representatives from Kentucky got a step closer to the Senate when they won primaries today to fill a seat that Wendell H. Ford, a Democrat and staunch supporter of tobacco farmers, is giving up after 24 years.

title: Police Officer Is Guilty In Attack on a Suspect
description: A former Paterson police officer accused of beating a suspect during a 1993 arrest pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal civil rights charges.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPPMAN, BERT J.
description: LIPPMAN-Bert J. Seventeen long years have passed since he left us. We miss you everyday. You are always in our hearts. We love you. Ruth, Jane, Robin, Chuck, Stefan, Jessica and Bradley

title: CBS TO SELL UNIT TO EMERSON ELECTRIC FOR $265 MILLION
description: The CBS Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Westinghouse process-control unit to the Emerson Electric Company for $265 million as CBS sheds its industrial businesses to focus on radio and television. Under the agreement, St. Louis-based Emerson will assume pension obligations and other liabilities related to the unit, which makes plant-monitoring instruments. New York-based CBS said it was in talks with unnamed suitors to sell its other industrial units. They are its nuclear energy business and a government contracting business that cleans up nuclear waste. Shares of CBS fell $1.5625, to $30.5625, and Emerson fell $1.6875, to $60.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DE JUR, FRANCES
description: DE JUR-Frances. May 27, 1898May 27, 1998. Mother -Grandmother In sweet memory of her unconditioned love, her unwavering devotion and her gentle strength. Loved and remembered with eternal gratitude on her 100th birthday. The Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYDEN, PAULA
description: HAYDEN-Paula. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its Founder Member, Paula Hayden. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASULO, LOUIS E.
description: FASULO-Louis E. Beloved husband of Elena (nee Lambrosa). Dear father of Louis Vincent and Edward. Grandfather of Arianna and Alexa, brother of Virginia. Reposing at Guido Funeral Home, 440 Clinton Street (cor of Carroll), Brooklyn. Wake on Thursday and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Charles Borromeo R.C. Church, Sat. 9:30 AM.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP TO SELL COOKIE UNIT TO UNITED BISCUITS
description: The Campbell Soup Company agreed yesterday to sell its European premium cookie unit, Delacre, to United Biscuits Holdings P.L.C. of Britain for $125 million as it sheds nonstrategic operations. The soup and cracker maker, based in Camden, N.J., said it would continue to focus on its Pepperidge Farm and Arnotts cookie and cracker businesses. Arnotts is in Australia. Last week, Campbell reported a $90 million third-quarter loss, reflecting a revamping charge and lower revenue from discontinued operations. Delacre sells premium cookies in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany.

title: Newark Is Pushed to Build More Public Housing Units
description: Nine years ago, when Newark was beginning to demolish its high-rise public housing complexes in favor of low-rise housing, a Federal court agreement directed the city to make sure it quickly replaced 1,777 lost units and just as quickly renovated others.

title: Campaign Reform Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Senate candidacy of Mark Green referred incompletely to the position of one of his rivals, Geraldine A. Ferraro, on late-term abortions. She supports a ban on the procedure, except for cases in which the woman's health is in danger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMILLEN, ROBERT
description: McMILLEN-Robert. Born June 3, 1916 in Covington, Indiana. Died May 19 in Loudoun County, VA. A graduate of Columbia University and Ohio Northern University, Robert McMillen was a Lieutenant Commander in the Navy, a journalist and a specialist in agriculture. A memorial service will be held at Goose CreeK Friends Meeting, Lincoln, VA., on June 6th at 2PM.

title: Lemieux Is Not Returning
description: Mario Lemieux will remain in retirement, contrary to a report in a Toronto newspaper that he will return to the ice to collect deferred contractual payments the Pittsburgh Penguins have been late in paying.

title: Five Countries Seize Islamic Terror Suspects
description: In a synchronized operation, the police in five European countries raided the homes of people suspected of being Islamic militants today and detained at least 88, according to French Government officials.

description: ''Do they still show it in America?'' said Saeed al-Owairan, the Saudi Arabian who scored the most spectacular goal during the last World Cup finals four years ago.

title: Bilingual Education Battle Splits Santa Barbara
description: On the night this city's school board decided whether to end a quarter-century of bilingual education, more than 600 people showed up. It was the largest board meeting that anyone could recall. It was also the most emotional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATRISS, JAMES B.
description: WATRISS-James B. On May 25, 1998 in Baltimore, MD. Beloved husband of Mary Wanamaker Watriss. Devoted father of Wendy V.H. Whitney, Patrick A. Watriss and Michael B. Watriss. Survived by one granddaughter, Samantha Williams. Stepfather of Alix W. Hopkins, Mary Devereaux Hopkins & Lindsay Hopkins Weld. A memorial service will be held in Baltimore at a later date. Inquiries may be directed to Henry W. Jenkins & Sons 410-435-0200.

title: A 'Stand-Up Guy' Who Watched Out for Others
description: Even before he became a delegate in the police union, Officer Anthony Mosomillo was the kind of officer who made it his business to help his colleagues who were enduring hard times.

description: Mayonnaise That Tastes Like the Real Thing

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SILVER FALLS 2.9 PERCENT. Silver fell to a six-month low, weakening on fear that the dollar's surge will diminish demand for silver and other precious metals priced in dollars. July contracts fell 15 cents an ounce, to $5.105.

title: Fetal Protection Law Is Threat to Women; Focus on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Abuse, Boy Getting Wish to Go Home
description: Before Nina Jackson took him in three years ago, Jermal Kirnon was just another motherless boy, abandoned as a baby and handed from foster family to foster family. But in Mrs. Jackson, he found a foster mother who kissed his sleepy eyelids, who steadied his wobbling bicycle, who promised to make him her son.

title: Market Hits an 11-Year Low As a Strike Begins in Korea
description: South Korea's economic crisis, which seemed to be receding only a few months ago, worsened today with the beginning of a nationwide strike and a deepening weakness in the stock market to an 11-year low.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCK, DAVID J.
description: LUCK-David J. L. The Rockefeller University community mourns with abiding sadness the loss of our distinguished colleague and beloved friend David J.L. Luck. Dr. Luck, Alfred E. Mirsky Professor & Vice President for Academic Affairs at the Rockefeller University, was a pioneer in the field of cell biology. He will long be remembered for his deep commitment and selfless dedication to the university. He was a wise counsellor, a dedicated teacher and a good and caring friend to old and young alike. Dr. Luck will be profoundly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Torsten Wiesel, President Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman, Board of Trustees David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Citing Gains, Clinton Says He Will Make China Visit
description: Defending the success of Washington's ''partnership'' with China, President Clinton said today that he would go ahead with his trip next month, the first visit by an American President to Beijing since the crackdown on demonstrators for democracy in Tiananmen Square.

title: BERKSHIRE REALTY CONSIDERS A POSSIBLE SALE OR MERGER
description: The Berkshire Realty Company said yesterday that it had hired the investment bankers Lazard Freres & Company and Lehman Brothers Inc. to help it evaluate the possible sale, merger or liquidation of the company. Berkshire, based in Boston, is a real estate investment trust that buys, renovates and manages apartment communities. It owns 75 apartment complexes with 22,400 units in the Southeast, Middle Atlantic and Texas, and manages another 19 apartment communities. The company's stock rose 12.5 cents each, to $12, giving the company a market capitalization of $442 million.

title: Winter Game, Spring Identity Crisis
description: Hockey evangelists roam the sports wilderness telling skeptics, ''If only you'd come to the rink, you'd feel the magic and excitement of our underappreciated and misunderstood game.'' But even the zealots have had a hard time keeping the faith during this long, tedious season. They have endured low-scoring, boring games, a concussion crisis, Olympic misbehavior and mediocre survivors playing on mushy ice in the on-again, off-again Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Too Young to Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: By the Book; The Cuisine of Bruculinu, Just a Subway Ride From Palermo
description: FEW people have told the story of Sicilian-American Brooklyn as well as Vincent Schiavelli, whose new book, ''Bruculinu, America'' (Houghton Mifflin, $24), is a tumultuous chronicle, a rich memoir woven around an equally compelling cookbook.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CONSTANCE KAUFMAN
description: SOLOMON-Constance Kaufman. A leader of several volunteer groups including the Bellevue Hospital Asssociation and the New York Women's Foundation, died at the age of 74 on Friday, May 15, 1998 in Belvedere, CA. from pneumonia and chronic emphysema. Connie remained active until two days before her death. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, Anthony; her brother George Kaufman; her son Adam; her daughter Tracy; her grandchildren Peter and James and two poodles Cobb & Rust. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, June 2 at the New York Historical Society, 2 West 77 St., at 4 PM. Donations should be sent to the New York Women's Foundation.

title: Partners Face S.E.C. Inquiry At Andersen
description: Federal regulators said yesterday that two Arthur Andersen partners violated securities laws when they advised a company on accounting policies over the phone that resulted in the company reporting profits when it really had losses.

title: Jury in Jail Guard's Trial Is Open to Death Penalty
description: The 12 jurors who last week found a former jail guard guilty of first-degree murder for killing three people in a Brooklyn robbery said yesterday that nothing had occurred during the trial to prevent them from considering sentencing him to death.

title: Prison Guard In Drug Deal, Prosecutors Say
description: A guard at a Federal prison in Manhattan has been accused of conspiring this month with a jailed drug dealer to steal more than 100 kilograms of cocaine from a rival dealer and to sell the drugs himself on the street, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Off the Menu
description: Exit for Mesa City

title: The Awakened Stars Surprise Themselves
description: The checking line scored, the goalie brawled, and by the end of a bruising evening that resembled mortal combat, the Dallas Stars battered the Detroit Red Wings, 3-1, to send the Western Conference finals to Detroit knotted at one game each.

title: Juice Maker Settles Food Poisoning Case
description: Odwalla, the company that produced apple juice contaminated by bacteria that killed one child in 1996, has agreed to a settlement of at least $12 million with the families of five children who became ill in the outbreak.

title: The End of Lilco, as Long Island Has Come to Know It
description: When 2.7 million Long Islanders wake up Thursday and turn on their lights, toasters and blow-dryers, it will be the last time they do so as customers of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Shaping Politics From the Pulpit; Archbishop and Citizen
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Wandering Lilacs

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 11 about Dominican drug traffickers in the United States misstated the name of the lawyer for Rene Antonio Aquino, a Dominican immigrant awaiting trial in Hartford on drug charges. He is David Touger, not John Tauger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIK, TED
description: LEVIK-Ted. Passed away on Tuesday, May 26, 1998. Survived by his wife, Celia, daughter, Carol DeBear, and son-in-law Elliot DeBear, Jesse and Hannah, and son Richard. Funeral services Friday, May 29 at 10:30 A.M., Scarsdale Synagogue,

title: Network Helps Children Cope With Serious Illness
description: WHEN 16-year-old Thricia DrePaul logged onto Starbright World, a computer network for hospitalized children, she usually chose to be a silver pony, her favorite character of the 40 offered. Although she was comfortable trading messages with any of the other children roaming the three-dimensional landscape, the idea of entering the network's video-conferencing area and talking face to face with someone was intimidating to her.

title: Skittish Speculators Didn't Reform Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: INLAND STEEL TO HOLD DUTCH AUCTION AFTER SALE OF UNIT
description: Inland Steel Industries, which agreed in March to sell its steel-making unit to Ispat International N.V., said yesterday that it would distribute the proceeds to shareholders through a Dutch auction. In a Dutch auction, Inland will specify a range of prices at which it is willing to buy back its common shares. The sale to Ispat is expected to be completed next month. After the tender offer, Inland Steel Industries will be combined with the company's remaining unit, the metals distributor Ryerson Tull. Inland Steel Industries owns 87 percent of Ryerson. Inland Steel Industries shares rose $1.25 each, to $27.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, JOHN F.
description: SHEPARD-John F., 91. Of Bethesda, MD, formerly of Spring Lake, NJ, and New York City, Tuesday, May 26, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy V. (Boylan). Loving father of John P., Paul P., James R., Donald J., Anne, Jane and the late William A. Shepard, Sr., and Mary Plummer. Cherished grandfather of seven. Funeral from the O'Brien Funeral Home, Highway 35 and New Bedford Rd., Wall, NJ, Saturday, May 30, 1998, 9 AM. Mass offered at St. Catherine R.C. Church, Spring Lake, New Jersey, 10 AM. Interment will follow at St. Catherine's Cemetery, Wall. Visiting Friday, 2-4 and 7-9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, GORDON R.
description: GILBERT-Gordon R. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Brian and Irene. Darling son of Doris. Dear brother of Stephen. Services Friday, 10 AM, ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd and 66th Ave, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Sewage Rules Planned For Boaters on 2 Rivers
description: Boaters on the Shark and Manasquan Rivers will have to carry their sewage ashore under a ban on discharges that environmental officials are to announce today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDOR, JOSEPHINE (MRS. RALPH) BEARDSLEY
description: SANDOR-Josephine (Mrs. Ralph) Beardsley. Passed away after a long illness in a New Jersey nursing home on May 17, 1998, just four days short of her 84th birthday. Mrs. Sandor was born in New York City and grew up and lived in Bronxville, NY before settling in Oakland, NJ in 1964 her present home. She studied sculpture at The Grand Central School of Arts, The Art Students League and for five years at Columbia University School of Painting and Sculpture. Mrs. Sandor was a member of The Pen and Brush Club, Knickerbocker Artists, Catharine Lorillard Wolfe Art Club, Allied Artists of America, National Art Club and Salmagundi Club all in New York City. She exhibited her work regularly in all of the above clubs and also in Washington, DC, Providencetown, MA, New Rochelle, NY Art Association, Montclair, NJ, AT&T Headquarters in Basking Ridge, NJ among others. During her long career she won many honors and awards in sculpture including several solo awards. Mrs. Sandor maintained sculpture studios in Oakland, NJ and East Orleans, MA. Surviving are her husband Ralph, a nephew Douglas Kuhn of Morristown, NJ and two nieces, Barbara Kuhn of Harrison, N.Y., and Mrs. Donald Wendell (Meredith) of Huntington, CT.

title: Composer Conducts Composers Orchestra
description: At 40, the Chinese-born composer Tan Dun seems to be one of the most sought-after composers in the United States. This season, James Levine conducted an orchestral work by Mr. Tan in a concert with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, and the New York City Opera presented his ''Marco Polo.'' An opera commissioned by the Met will be his next major project.

title: Judge Upholds Reinstatement Of Syracuse Union Supporter
description: A judge has ruled that Kathy Saumier, a union supporter at a Syracuse plastics factory, was wrongly dismissed on grounds of sexual harassment and that the company that fired her committed numerous other illegal acts in fighting a unionization drive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO., Palo Alto, Calif., will buy Samsung Electronics Co.'s 45 percent stake in Hewlett-Packard Korea for $36 million, helping Samsung raise money during South Korea's economic crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITZ, HENRY
description: HITZ-Henry. Beloved husband of Helen Hitz. Loving son of the late Alice and Karl Hitz. Passed away on May 26, 1998 after a long illness. Former owner of the Henry Hitz Advertising Studio. Services on Thursday, 11:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: After Shootings in Schools, Officials Are Treating Student Threats Seriously
description: In the aftermath of the recent string of school shootings by students in Oregon, Arkansas and Pennsylvania, officials are taking all youthful threats -- from the vile to the idle -- far more seriously, and in some cases, arresting the youths who make them.

title: Miscellany
description: * MDC Communications Corp., Toronto, agreed to acquire 75 percent of Cybersight, an interactive agency with offices in Santa Monica, Calif., and Portland, Ore. Terms were not disclosed.

title: INSIDE
description: Safety Warnings on Mir

title: Personal Shopper; Flashlights That Can't Wait Until Dark
description: THEY'VE come a long way since summer camp. In this age of specialization, there are flashlights that brighten a mile-long path while others have small, intense beams focused enough to read a Playbill without disturbing your neighbor.

title: True North Reports Agency Merger
description: True North Communications said yesterday that two agencies specializing in interactive advertising and marketing -- Modem Media Inc. in Westport, Conn., and Poppe Tyson in New York -- would be merged to form Modem Media.Poppe Tyson.

title: Beyond Tape Measures: A New Human Scale
description: HOLLYWOOD, for one, knows that you need scale: ''His tail is as big as four subway cars.'' ''His foot is as big as this billboard.'' Even Godzilla's scales have scale.

title: You Can't Always Judge a Domain by Its Name
description: AS one might expect, the Web site www.ringlingbrothers.com featured stories of elephants, but it did not focus on the amazing and heartwarming feats of circus pachyderms. Instead it claimed that Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus degrades, chains up and even hastens the death of elephants.

title: Labor Chips Away at Ballot Nemesis
description: For months, the conservative effort to shatter organized labor's political war chest here in California looked like a sure winner.

title: Selling Sites Like Soapflakes
description: I DON'T know what you did in your life that was so good that you deserve to hear this,'' a sales representative for a company called Big Planet told about 150 people at the Warwick Hotel in Manhattan last month. The event was a weekly recruiting session for a company called Big Planet, but it sounded more like an EST seminar with a good dose of Internet World hyperbole mixed in.

title: MOSCOW ATTEMPTS DRASTIC MEASURES TO SAVE ECONOMY
description: As Russia's financial markets teetered on the brink of collapse, Moscow mounted a drastic effort today to preserve the value of its currency and stem the exodus of foreign investors.

title: HICKS, TATE SEEKS LATIN AMERICA MEDIA HOLDINGS
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a buyout firm based in Dallas, agreed yesterday to pay $700 million for about 30 percent of the Argentine media company CEI Citicorp Holdings S.A., accelerating its drive into Latin American media. Hicks, Muse has about $1.2 billion either invested or dedicated to the region. Hicks agreed to buy a 10.3 percent stake in CEI from Citibank N.A., a unit of Citicorp, and about 19.5 percent from Los W S.A., a group headed by the Werthein family of Argentina, CEI said in a filing with regulators. CEI's interests include Cointel, which controls Telefonica de Argentina, the country's largest telephone company, and Cablevision S.A., the largest cable television operator.

title: FURNITURE COLLECTION: Cuteness Comes in Two Sizes
description: Had enough of Laura Ashley's mother-and-daughter dresses? For an alternative mode of big-and-small cuteness, there is a collection of furniture -- in two sizes, child and adult -- from the Barcelona designer Agatha Ruiz de la Prada. (Catalan designers are known for witty designs for children as well as for their parents.) Made of curved plywood finished with color laminate, chairs have tubular steel frames and come in six shapes (flower and cloud not shown) and five colors: blue, yellow, green, white and red. Adult chairs are $192; children's, $179. Tables are $355 to $489. Available from Janus et Cie in Los Angeles; (800) 245-2687.

title: Art in the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Plans Medicaid Coverage Of Viagra by States
description: The Clinton Administration has told state officials that it intends to require their Medicaid programs to pay for medically approved uses of the impotence drug Viagra. But states could limit the number of pills and prescriptions for the drug.

title: Shaping Politics From the Pulpit; Preach Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, JULES
description: KRAFT-Jules. Beloved grandfather of Dylan, Morrison, Marley and Stella; loving father of Neil, Ronald and Susan; husband to Susan; died May 26, 1998. A gathering in his memory will be held at the CAC, 50 W. 54th St, at 11AM on May 29. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Mastocytosis Society Research Fund, 4771 Waynes Trace Rd, Hamilton, Ohio 45011. He will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEGLER, ELMIRITA A.
description: KOEGLER-Elmirita A. Of New York, died in her 93rd year on May 19, in St. Petersburg, Florida, where she had resided since 1997. She was the widow of George Koegler of New York, who at his death in 1956 was General Counsel of the Standard Oil Co. (NJ). She was the daughter of Dr. Raoul Amador of Paris, France, and of Mrs. Jennie Smith Amador of New York and a granddaughter of Dr. Manuel Amador, a native of Spain who became the first president of the Republic of Panama. Her son, Kurt Koegler, of Dubois, WY, died in 1996. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Dr. and Mrs. George P. Tilley of Fayetteville, NY, her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Kurt Koegler of Jackson Hole, WY, her grandchildren, Mrs. Brian Farlow, Dallas, TX, Mrs. John Cavo, Tampa, FL, Mr. Keith Koegler, San Francisco, CA, Miss Carolyn Koegler, Concord, N.H., Miss Katherine Koegler, Chicago, IL., and a grandchild, Francesca Amador Farlow, Dallas, TX. Funeral services at 1 PM Friday, May 29, St. James Church, 71st Street and Madison Avenue, New York, Reverend Craig Townsend officiating. Private interment immediately following, Greenwood Cemetery.

title: The Chicago Stomp: Bulls Rout Pacers
description: Question the Bulls' greatness, and doubt their might. It only serves to anger the gods.

title: Crying Racism Upsets City's Delicate Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUSCHLE, WILLIAM F., SR.
description: HUSCHLE-William F., Sr. On May 26, 1998, of Garden City. Graduate of Fordham University. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Devoted father of Patricia, William F., Jr., and Claire. Dear brother of Teddy Colbert. Dear uncle of many loving nieces and nephews. A Memorial Mass will be offered at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Saturday at 9:45 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. The family would appreciate contributions to Flying Pond Improvement Association C/O H. Hateman, Box 275, Mount Vernon, ME. 04352.

title: It's Serb vs. Serb in Montenegro Vote
description: As the presidential motorcade crawled up a narrow road toward barren hilltops of rock and scrub, clusters of peasant farmers ambled out of stone hovels to taunt the passing cars.

title: From Toy Rings to Sophisticated Codes, a Quest for Secrecy
description: IF philosophers taught a class on encryption, they would probably begin by saying: ''Before we ask what encryption is, we must wonder, What is secrecy? What is disclosure? What is information? What is deception? Ultimately we must truly ponder whether the true nature of human existence is to communicate or miscommunicate.''

title: A Frenzy of Global Anxiety Kicks Up Dust That Had Been Settling
description: Investors stampeded in and out of financial markets around the world yesterday, raising new concerns about the global reverberations of the Asian economic crisis that began nearly a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, SIMON
description: LIEBOWITZ-Simon. We record with regret and sadness the death of Simon Liebowitz at age 92 on May 24, 1998. Prior to serving in the New York Senate and as Justice of the State Supreme Court, he had been our Union's first General Counsel and later was the impartial chairman of our Legal Benefits Program. He brought to his responsibilities those great qualities of heart and mind which meant and made great occasions. Our profound condolences to his wife, Elsie, and the other members of his family. District 1115, SEIU, Jay Sackman, General President Michael Sackman, Pres. Emeritus

title: DESIGNER LAMPS: The Accent's On Curves
description: Like women in tight patterned dresses, Ladylites have curves that accentuate the grain. The Nina lamp (right) is hand-turned birch plywood. The other Ladylites, Maude and Pearl, are maple and alder. Designed by a sculptor, Emily McLennan, the lamps are available at Dakota Jackson in the D.& D. Building, 979 Third Avenue, starting at $1,155. Information, (212) 838-9444.

title: Sports of The Times; Coaches Blow Whistle On the Referees, Too
description: Ever since referees were intro duced to the game of basketball sometime shortly after the peach basket was devised for unnatural use -- there has been an attempt to manipulate these officials.

title: Shaping Politics From the Pulpit; What Makes a Family
description: To the Editors:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COIMBRA, CARLOS
description: COIMBRA-Carlos. Died May 24, 1998 after a courageous struggle with AIDS. Carlos was the beloved life companion of the late Chip Conrad as well as his business partner in Larkspur Flowers. Carlos created beauty and joy and will be deeply missed by those he touched. Carlos leaves his sister, Ana Maria, and his parents, Estefania Rodrigues and Anibal Coimbra, who reside in Portugal. Carlos' family and friends express their deepest gratitude to Dr. Usha Mathur Wagh at the Peter Krueger Clinic for her loving care. A service will be held at St. Luke in the Fields, 487 Hudson Street on Thursday, May 28 at 3:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Peter Krueger Clinic, Beth Israel Medical Center, 317 East 17th Street, NY, NY 10003.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on the Public Lives page yesterday about the radio disk jockey Jonathan Schwartz misstated the duration of his weekly WQEW radio program devoted to the music of Frank Sinatra. It is four hours on Saturday, from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M., not two hours.

title: ON IRVING PLACE WITH/Merlin Holland; The Importance Of Being Honest
description: ADOLESCENCE is a trying time. For Merlin Holland, the summer he turned 15 was particularly tempestuous. He was finally introduced to the 1895 scandal in which his paternal grandfather, the celebrated Victorian playwright and esthete Oscar Wilde, was convicted in London of gross indecency -- homosexuality -- and sentenced to two years in prison at hard labor.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about commencement at Pace University's Westchester campuses misstated the number of nursing degree candidates at the ceremony. It was 279, not 33.

title: Economic Scene; Raising cigarette taxes will surely punish tobacco's victims.
description: BIG Tobacco is on the run. While specific provisions of the Federal legislation remain in doubt, there is no question the industry will pay hundreds of billions of dollars to compensate states, individual smokers and their lawyers for the medical costs and premature death of smokers. Nor is there much doubt that the settlements will be financed almost entirely by new cigarette taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALKALAY, NAOMI
description: ALKALAY-Naomi. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of Peter and Florence Alkalay, and Susan and Joseph Moldovan. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Jessica, Leslie and Gregory. Loving sisterin-law of Nora Harmon. Graveside services 10:30 A.M., Thursday, May 28th, Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, New York.

title: Great Pretenders: Pop Imitators Sing The Same Old Song; But Nothing Like the Real Thing, Some Oldies Performers Complain
description: The Platters sang ''The Great Pretender'' at the Beacon Theater on Saturday, on an oldies bill that included the Drifters, the Coasters and the Marvelettes. But the only original member of the Platters still performing, Herb Reed, was singing with his Platters in East Windsor, Conn. Yet another Platters group has a steady engagement in Branson, Mo. Other Platters regularly work on the West Coast.

title: Overlooking the Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Get More Than You Pay For
description: I WAS desperate to get a copy of an obscure shareware program called Abuser. The entire purpose of the program is to generate off-color insults based on a person's characteristics. Those of you who are familiar with my life -- my bosses, my brothers, those people who phone with credit-card offers during dinner -- can understand why.

title: LIBRARY/WEB-SITE SOFTWARE; Simplicity Limits Options
description: MICROSOFT FRONT PAGE 98(Microsoft; $149; Windows 95 and NT, Macintosh.)

title: Scofflaw Opportunity Passes Unnoticed
description: It's too late to do so now, but yesterday morning a driver might have been able to park in front of a fire hydrant or at a bus stop or even up on the sidewalk, with a note on the dashboard reading ''tow me,'' and return later to find the vehicle precisely where it had been left.

title: 4 Colombians Pledge Change but Carry Lots of Old Baggage
description: With the end of four turbulent, demoralizing years under President Ernesto Samper in sight, change has become the byword of four candidates hoping to replace him in coming elections. All four, however, have past associations that undermine their promises to transform the country.

title: SOUTHERN TO BUY 9 POWER PLANTS IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The Southern Company, an electric utility holding company, agreed yesterday to buy nine power plants from Commonwealth Energy System and Eastern Utilities Associates for $537 million to bolster its electricity-trading operations in the Northeast. The gas- and oil-fired power plants are in Massachusetts. The purchase also includes a 1.4 percent interest in a Maine power plant. Combined, the plants will give Southern about 1,260 megawatts of generating capacity. Southern, based in Atlanta, is buying the plants to have a secure supply of electricity in New England as that market opens to competition.

title: U.S. Is Preparing to Sue Intel Over Microchip Dominance
description: The Federal Trade Commission is preparing to file a major antitrust lawsuit against the Intel Corporation, charging the company with abusing its position as the dominant manufacturer of microprocessor chips for personal computers and bullying some computer manufacturers, Government lawyers said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, BARBARA
description: CASEY-Barbara. Of New Canaan, CT., on May 25, 1998. Daughter of Karen McDevitt Casey and the late Eugene J. Casey Jr. Granddaughter of Eugene J. and Inez Tango Casey. Also survived by 5 aunts and 3 uncles. Memorial Mass will be held at St Thomas More R.C. Church in Darien, CT on Friday, May 29, 1998 at 11:00 AM. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Kids in Crisis, One Salem Street, Cos Cob, CT. 06807.

title: Psyching Out a Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; Cleansing CUNY
description: In case you had any doubt about the motivation behind the tightening of admissions standards at the City University of New York, listen to Anne Paolucci, who heads the board of trustees:

title: U.S., Australia and Portugal Call for the Release of Resistance Leader : Jakarta Under Pressure on East Timor
description: JAKARTA  Indonesia came under mounting pressure Wednesday to resolve one of its most contentious foreign policy problems  East Timor  as the United States, Portugal and Australia called for the release of the imprisoned East Timorese resistance leader to hasten a settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SYLVIA K.
description: KAPLAN-Sylvia K. On May 27, 1998, in her 89th year. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Kaplan, loving mother of Rona Roob, Steven Kaplan, Susan Diamond, and the late Richard Kaplan, cherished grandmother of Nancy, Helen, Nathan, Edward, Joseph, Nicholas, Michael, Sara, and David, great grandmother of Hanna, Sophie, and Ella, and cherished friend of Helen McGrath. Services are on Friday, May 29, at 10:45 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Consolidations by Frito-Lay and Pepsico move a host of choice assignments to BBDO Worldwide.
description: THE snack giant Frito-Lay is joining the ranks of large marketers that are consolidating global accounts by unexpectedly moving virtually all its creative advertising assignments to BBDO Worldwide.

title: Primary Ahead in Attorney General Race
description: Setting the stage for a bruising intramural battle, all three Democratic candidates for attorney general picked up enough support today at the state party convention to get their names on the primary ballot in September.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review in Weekend on Friday about a performance by the Juilliard Dance Division misidentified the pianist for Christopher House's ''Schubert Dances.'' He was David Shimoni, not Vasily Primakov.

title: A Deal in England, A Deal in France
description: Two agencies have made acquisitions overseas, financial terms of which were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, JACOB
description: KATZ-Jacob. The Center for Israel and Jewish Studies, Columbia University, mourns the passing in Jerusalem of Professor Jacob Katz, one of the greatest Jewish scholars of our century. Born in Hungary and educated in Germany, he taught Jewish history at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem from 1950 and served as the rector of that university for several years. Since his retirement, he continued to publish seminal books and articles on Jewish history and culture through the ages. We extend our sympathies to his family. May his memory be for a blessing. Yosef Hayim Yerushalmi, Dir Michael Stanislawski, Assoc. Dir

title: Heftel to Buy 2 Stations
description: The Heftel Broadcasting Corporation, the nation's largest Spanish-language radio group, has agreed to purchase two San Diego radio stations from Jacor Communications Inc. for $65.1 million. Heftel said it would change the programming of the stations KJQY-FM and KKLQ-FM to Spanish-language formats. Jacor, based in Covington, Ky., said the sale was a prerequisite to its pending $620 million purchase of Nationwide Communications Inc. Nationwide already operates two stations in San Diego, and Jacor operates eight.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP TO BUY SOUTHERN BANCSHARES
description: Old National Bancorp agreed yesterday to acquire Southern Bancshares for $80.9 million in stock. Old National is a bank holding company based in Evansville, Ind. Southern Bancshares is a holding company for the First National Bank and Trust Company of Carbondale, Ill. Upon completion of the merger, which is expected in the fourth quarter, Old National will have assets of about $6 billion. Old National's First National Bank, based in Harrisburg, Ill., will merge with the First National Bank of Carbondale.

title: Mets Rally Once More To Clobber Marlins
description: Coincidence or cause and effect? Whatever it is, the Mets have turned into a virtual offensive juggernaut since Mike Piazza was inserted into the heart of their order four games ago.

title: Cuban Aims for Big Escapes in Ring
description: Eliecer Castillo says he gets goose bumps when he sees a movie with sharks in it. It brings back memories from four years ago, when he and five others tried to escape Cuba in a rubber and canvas raft.

title: Iraqi Leader's Daughter Tries Lawsuit to Seek Smuggled Millions
description: A daughter of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has begun legal action in Amman, Jordan, to recover millions of dollars that she claims belonged to her husband, who turned against Mr. Hussein and was killed in 1996.

title: Reclamation Projects: The Greening of a Landfill
description: The golf course architect, Michael Hurdzan, laughs when he hears complaints about forced carries over water hazards at his Widow's Walk layout 26 miles southeast of Boston.

title: Trade Secrets; The Great Divide: Screens Enter the Future
description: AFTER 1,000 years of history as a decorative accessory, the screen is entering a new age of architectural innovation. Once made of simple paper or embroidered tapestry, tooled leather or lacquered wood, screens are being reinvented through new manufactured materials like optic fibers, ceramics, acrylics and polyester silks. Whether folding, freestanding or used like wall paneling, screens are solving problems of interior design that only building used to tackle.

title: As India Adds Up Costs of Its A-Tests, Dissent Grows Louder
description: Only two weeks after India detonated five underground nuclear tests to popular acclaim, the Hindu nationalists who lead the Government ran into a storm of protest in Parliament today that reflected growing disquiet about the risks and costs of acquiring nuclear weapons.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Maybe It's the Analyst Who Needs Treatment
description: THE TREATMENT

title: Orchestra Celebrates Clarinetist's 50 Years
description: Stanley Drucker has a succinct but vivid memory of his first rehearsal as a member of the New York Philharmonic's clarinet section. The orchestra's home was Carnegie Hall then, and Dmitri Mitropoulos was on the podium. The work at hand was Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra.'' And it was fully 20 years before that score's opening phrase -- the slow, rising arpeggio and the two brass-heavy chordal blasts followed by pounding kettledrums -- became irrevocably linked to Stanley Kubrick's film ''2001: A Space Odyssey.''

title: Allies Upset as U.S. Eases Stance on Kosovo
