description: America's closest European allies are upset that Washington has changed tack yet again on the issue of Kosovo, pushing to ease the pressure on the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, despite his intensified repression in the province.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK DROPS. The German currency fell in reaction to the economic crisis in Russia and its possible impact on Germany, Russia's biggest lender and trading partner. The dollar rose to 1.7829 marks in New York from 1.7705.

title: Shaping Politics From the Pulpit
description: To the Editor:

title: GTE LEADS GROUP SEEKING PUERTO RICO TELEPHONE STAKE
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it was leading a consortium of investors that would acquire a controlling interest in the Puerto Rico Telephone Company for $375 million. GTE's consortium will purchase 50 percent plus one share of the telephone company. Popular Inc., the holding company of Banco Popular de Puerto Rico, will acquire a 5 percent stake in Puerto Rico Telephone from GTE for $37.5 million. An additional 5 percent will be sold for $37.5 million to other local partners in the GTE group. GTE itself will retain a 40 percent stake in Puerto Rico Telephone and will elect a majority of its directors. Puerto Rico Telephone will also issue $1.5 billion in debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAO, CHIEN YUAN
description: KAO-Chien Yuan. Died unexpectedly at the age of 70 Tuesday evening at his home in Pound Ridge, New York. He was born in Shanghai, China on Decembr 20, 1927; son of Dr. Ching Lang and Mrs. Yu Yuen Kao. Chien Yuan Kao came to the United States in 1948, and earned his medical degree from SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, New York. While conducting research at the Rockefeller University, he met Rita Christine Rothlin; they were married on June 20, 1957. Dr. Kao was an active Professor of Pharmacology at SUNY Downstate Health Sciences Center at the time of his death. He frequently spent summers performing rsearch at the Marine Biological Laboratories at Woods Hole, Massachusetts. He was a leading authority on the actions of tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin, which are responsible for fugu and paralytic shell fish poisonings. In addition, Dr. Kao's recent work involved the use of lidocaine to suppress uterine smooth muscle contractions which cause pre-term labor and premature births. In addition, Dr. Kao served as a trustee for the Harvey School in Katonah, New York. His numerous interests included avid reading of history, and sculpting, especially with metals. Chien Yuan and Christine Kao were married for forty years, before her death last July from ovarian cancer. At the time of his unexpected death, he was engaged to be married to Geraldine Kelly of Pound Ridge. Dr. Kao is survived by his sons, Dr. Peter Nicholas Kao of Palo Alto, California, a faculty physician-scientist at Stanford University and Hilary Rothlin Kao of Arlington, Virginia, an attorney, and three grandchildren. He is also survived by his sisters, Rose Chang, Mary Chin, Lillian Luh, Florence Shen, Evelina Loke, Miranda Linne, and Judith Ng. In recognition of his lifelong devotion to education, the family will establish a scholarship fund for medical student research. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to SUNY Downstate Medical Center, c/o the Dr. C.Y. Kao Memorial Medical Student Research Fund, 450 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, New York, 11203. The family will receive friends at the F. Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan. Connecticut on Friday, May 29 from 5 to 8 PM. A graveside service will be held at Lakeview Cemetery, South Main Street, New Canaan, Connecticut on Saturday, May 30 at 3 P.M.

title: Music Appreciation By Two Ballerinas
description: American Ballet Theater once again showed off its dancers in a varied program on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: MODERN FURNITURE: The Way to Keep It Simple: Do Less
description: Sitting on the very modern Peter Maly Bed was Peter Maly himself, designer of both the bed and the new store it was sitting in, a Ligne Roset outpost at 155 Wooster Street in SoHo. Mr. Maly, a German furniture designer and interior architect, said, ''You know, I try to keep it simple.''

title: Microsoft Gives A Freer Hand To Gateway
description: Gateway Inc. offered yesterday a glimpse of the future that the Government is seeking in its antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation: more freedom for personal computer makers, and less control by Microsoft over precisely what people see on their computer screens.

title: THE GOLF REPORT: Tour Leader Is an Ordinary David; Duval's Approach to Life Is to Keep It Simple and Stay Focused
description: The most emotion you are likely to see from David Duval during a round of golf is a quick wave to the gallery after making a birdie putt. He is intense but analytical, playing with cool efficiency behind the trademark dark glasses that cover his eyes and camouflage some of his expressions.

title: 2d Subway Entry Planned At 72d St. and Broadway
description: After more than 20 years of aborted plans to expand the subway station at 72d Street and Broadway in Manhattan, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would construct a new entrance building across 72d Street from the current one, providing four new stairways and elevator service to the subway platform.

title: Stocks Recoup Most Losses, With the Dow Off 27 Points
description: Asia's continuing financial crisis reverberated around the world yesterday, sending some financial markets into a tailspin and briefly punishing stocks in the United States.

title: Political Spin Decked in Royal Trappings
description: The English King's gilded throne positively shimmers at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, but gold is not all that glisters in the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''Henry VIII.'' Distinguished by the sparkling portrayals of Paul Jesson as Henry and Jane Lapotaire as the first of his six wives, Katherine of Aragon, this superb new staging brings out just about all the luster one could hope for in what has always been considered one of Shakespeare's lesser history plays.

title: Doubt Cast on Arrest Of Man in Shootings
description: A 19-year-old Queens man charged with unleashing a hail of gunfire that wounded eight people at a downtown Brooklyn mall last week was released from custody yesterday after his lawyer produced a videotape that appears to show the man was in Queens when the shootings occurred.

title: Commencement; Cooper Union Protest Silenced for Giuliani's Oratory
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani seized upon the rich oratorical tradition of Cooper Union's Great Hall yesterday to urge 195 graduates of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art to find their individual paths toward contributing to the public good -- and to silence a handful of protesters.

title: For Assemblyman, Hearing Turns Into Night in a Jail Cell
description: The State Assemblyman from the Upper West Side had simple plans for Tuesday night: to attend a public hearing being held by the Board of Trustees for the City University of New York. Instead, he spent the night in a city jail cell, without food or a clue to why he was detained.

title: TILES: Aluminum Siding on the Inside
description: ''I didn't see any aluminum tiles anywhere so I decided to make them myself,'' said Sallie Trout, the founder of a Culver City, Calif., company known for its witty hardware and furniture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBRIN, ESTELLE
description: KOBRIN-Estelle. Age 79 of Woodcliff Lake, New Jersey, on May 27, 1998. Survived by her beloved husband Bernard, daughter Roni and sister Frances Nadler. Services are Friday, 12 noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SKELLY, ALTMAN, FLORENCE
description: SKELLY-ALTMAN-Florence. A memorial service honoring our friend and colleague will take place Monday, June 1 at the Penn Club, 30 West 44th Street, New York, at 9 A.M.

title: Clear Thinking That Swings To Make People Feel Good
description: Greatness comes in different varieties, and the pianist Oscar Peterson's brand is defined by clarity, by the ability to make obvious what he's thinking. That clarity, combined with the joy Mr. Peterson exudes, has made him one of jazz's most enduring stars, and on Tuesday at the Blue Note the audience gave him a standing ovation as he walked to the stage.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Inside Intel, Latest Setbacks Provoke Worries
description: Immortal. Beloved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CONSTANCE KAUFMAN
description: SOLOMON-Constance Kaufman. The Bellevue Association will be forever grateful to Connie for her leadership and dedication to Bellevue Hospital Center. Connie and Tony chose to commit their energies and resources to ensuring the traditionally underserved were well served. We mourn with their family and friends. Lola Finkelstein, President William Constantine, Treasurer

title: Under Sony's Wing, Novel Games Incubate
description: ONCE upon a time in the land of game designers, computers were humble machines. Software tools were crude, but they were available to everyone. And each night, after they had done their homework, hundreds of enterprising young hackers would sit in front of Altairs and Commodore 64's and program their own games. Every so often, a particularly clever young lad would invent a game that no one had ever played before and distribute it as ''zip-lock-ware''(floppy disks in plastic bags) and become quite successful. And all the hackers would rejoice because innovation was the coin of the realm.

title: Microsoft and Sega Creating Windows-Based Game System
description: In keeping with the far reach Microsoft is striving for -- both on and off the desktop -- the company announced plans last week to collaborate with Sega Enterprises Ltd. on a home video game system based on Windows CE.

title: Algonquin, at Wits' End, Retrofits
description: AT the Algonquin Hotel, it's out with the old, in with the nouveau-old. When the plastic wrap is peeled back on Monday, a small but significant renovation will have altered the soul of New York's most beloved -- and proudly fuddy-duddy -- literary canteen.

title: A Loft Where Art And Life Collide
description: ''COME up -- see the roof,'' Kobo said, swinging open a side door to reveal thin metal stairs and a long corridor whose floor was cluttered with dog bowls and bones belonging to his two Labrador retrievers, Bugsy and Cuba.

title: Canceled Play May Be Staged
description: Several theaters have come forward with offers to stage a play about 13 gay men who meet to enact the story of Jesus after the Manhattan Theater Club canceled its production, the play's author, Terrence McNally, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONLIFF, MAZIE M.
description: CONLIFF-Mazie M. Beloved mother and friend. My love and gratitude go with you. Your daughter, Phyllis

title: Metro Matters; The Party Convention That Won't Be Disciplined
description: EVERYWHERE you looked at the Democratic convention yesterday, there were big people talking about weighty matters.

title: Lucent Extends Its Reach to Internet Technology
description: Extending its reach further beyond the traditional telecommunications equipment industry, Lucent Technologies Inc. yesterday announced a new set of products that transmit digital information using Internet technology rather than older network systems.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 17 about local elections in South Africa referred incorrectly to the state of nationwide opinion polling there. Scientifically accurate polls of likely voters do indeed exist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERSON, BERNARD
description: MEYERSON-Bernard. The Yeshivah of Flatbush deeply mourns the passing of Bernard Meyerson, beloved father of Elaine Stieglitz and father-in-law of Financial Secretary and Trustee, Charles M. Stieglitz. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Meyerson and Stieglitz family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Steven R. Shamah, President Dennis M. Eisenberg, Exec. Dir.

title: Davis Love Planning to Play
description: After resting his sore back for three weeks, Davis Love 3d will return to action Thursday at the Memorial Tournament. Love has a bulging disk, and although the injury will not require surgery, he has to stretch and do strengthening exercises to improve his condition. Love was not 100 percent today, but was fit enough to compete. ''If this was not a big tournament, I probably would be trying to ease back into it at home,'' Love said. ''If I hit it the way I did the last two days, I can get through the week.''

title: Out of the Shadow of a Noted Family Name
description: PEGGY DULANY was always considered one of the more unorthodox ''Cousins,'' as the fourth-generation Rockefellers are known, although she was utterly orthodox when it came to family rebellion. Ms. Dulany joined the S.D.S. at Harvard, lived in a squatters' colony in Brazil and was among the first to drop the Rockefeller name for Dulany, her middle name from her mother's side. In the 1980's she met Oliver Tambo, the president of the African National Congress.

title: Breezing Into Town With Ideas on Mixing Styles
description: A breeze gusted in from California on Tuesday night when Alonzo King's Lines Contemporary Ballet opened at the Joyce Theater. Mr. King and his company, based in San Francisco, march to their own beat. The rhythm can be problematical. But there is no denying that the company has a sparkle all its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, WALTER
description: GOTTESMAN-Walter. On Tuesday, May 26, 1998, Walter of North Plainfield, NJ. Formerly of East Orange, NJ. Dear brother of Bertram J. Gottesman. Graveside services at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ on Friday, May 29, 1998 at 11 AM. For information call the Menorah Chapels at Millburn 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OUIMETTE, MARGARET YANOW
description: OUIMETTE - Margaret Yanow. The Trustees, administration, faculty and students of the Birch Wathen Lenox School express deep sympathy to Robert, David and Michael on the loss of Peggy, a beloved, talented and revered member of our community. We share in your bereavement and will remember your family in our prayers. Frank J. Carnabuci Headmaster The Birch Wathen Lenox School

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Uneasy Friendship: Expanding NATO Courts Russia
description: When Anatoly G. Krivolapov was a young officer in the Soviet Strategic Rocket Forces, he saw NATO fixed in a set of crosshairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALVORD, ARTHUR MOODY, JR.
description: ALVORD-Arthur Moody, Jr. Died on May 9, 1998 at 87. Resident of Norwalk, CT. Husband of the late Eleanore W. Alvord. A memorial service will be held Saturday, June 6, 1998 at 11:00 AM in the Chapel of Noroton Presbyterian Church, Darien, CT. Memorial gifts may be made to the American Parkinsons Disease Association. Smith & Heald Funeral Home, Milford, N.H. for further information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, IRVING
description: GOLDSTEIN-Irving. Born October 27th, 1920. Died on May 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Harriet, wonderful father to Ronni and Susan and giving grandfather to Dana and Eli. Services May 28, 1998 in Tuscon, AZ. Please send all contributions to TMC Hospice, 5301 East Grant Road, Tuscon, AZ. 85712.

title: Vallone Wins the Most Votes, But Fails to Get Democratic Nod
description: The state Democratic Party voted today to set up a two-way primary for its gubernatorial nomination this September, foiling an aggressive effort by Peter F. Vallone to leave here as the favored candidate to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki this November. Two other Democrats said they would circulate petitions to force themselves onto the ballot as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSBERG, WALTER
description: JACOBSBERG-Walter. On May 27, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Hanne. Beloved father of Dr. Lawrence & Barbara, Steven and Terry. Adored Opa of Zoe. Service Thursday 1:30PM ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Correction
description: A May 26 letter incorrectly described the relationship between William A. Haseltine, chief executive of Human Genome Sciences, and the Institute for Genomic Research, a nonprofit company that is decoding human DNA. Human Genome Sciences stopped helping finance the institute in 1996.

title: Wolf Mankowitz, Novelist And Screenwriter, Dies at 73
description: Wolf Mankowitz, a writer of eclectic interests whose prolific output extended to novels, plays, television drama and films, died on May 20 in County Cork, Ireland, where he lived. He was 73.

title: New Evidence Of China Tie To Clinton Is Asserted
description: In a bid to jumpstart an inquiry hampered by recalcitrant witnesses and staff defections, House Republican investigators today released what they portrayed as further evidence of a Chinese Government connection to President Clinton's re-election campaign in 1996.

title: 900,000 More Leave the Welfare Rolls
description: President Clinton announced today that another 900,000 people have left the welfare rolls since September, reducing the total receiving welfare benefits to 8.9 million. Since Mr. Clinton signed a law changing the welfare system in August 1996, 3.3 million people have left the rolls.

title: Fred Inbau, 89, Criminologist Who Perfected Interrogation
description: Fred E. Inbau, an early criminologist who helped elevate trickery and deceit to a high art of police interrogation, died on Monday at a hospital near his home in Chicago. He was 89 and had been a longtime law professor at Northwestern University.

title: Gingrich, Darling of Israeli Rightists, Tangos With Arafat
description: Under sharp criticism from the White House for interfering with its efforts to broker an Israeli-Palestinian peace and for remarks considered insulting to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, the House Speaker Newt Gingrich took a conciliatory stance today with the Palestinian leadership.

title: ANDROGYNOUS HUMANOIDS: Maybe They're Not Better, But They're Certainly Bigger
description: It's about time. Ancient Egypt had its sphinxes. Greece built caryatids. And China erected plenty of gigantic Buddhas. But there hasn't been much contemporary androgynous humanoid architecture worth worshiping, or at least ogling, until now.

title: German Digital TV Deal Is Blocked by Regulators
description: Europe's antitrust regulators yesterday blocked an ambitious digital television alliance among three of Germany's most powerful media companies, marking a milestone in the growing power of the European Commission over events in individual countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, EUGENE J. JR.
description: CASEY-Eugene J. Jr. Of Rowayton, CT on May 25, 1998. Husband of Karen McDevitt Casey. Father of late Barbara Casey. Son of Eugene J. and Inez Tango Casey. Brother of Susan Casey Engel, Maureen Casey LeFebvre, Christine Casey Rovics, Brian Stephen Casey, Francis X. Casey, Mary Grace Casey Tsujimoto, & Robert Patrick Casey. Memorial Mass will be held at St Thomas More R.C. Church in Darien, CT on Friday May 29, 1998 at 11:00 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to St. Thomas More R.C. Church, 374 Middlesex Road, Darien, CT 06820.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, JEANETTE
description: ADAMS-Jeanette. The officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member Jeanette. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Democrats Get Together, Sort Of
description: New York's Democratic establishment gathered to choose a gubernatorial nominee yesterday from among five candidates, but managed only to narrow the field to four. The New York City Council Speaker, Peter Vallone, got the most votes. But his failure to get the majority needed for an official nomination opened the way for a multi-candidate primary and showed that the delegates had little confidence in his potential. When a hoarse, tired-looking Mr. Vallone urged his supporters to ''begin our trek to Albany,'' his task did indeed seem like a long, hard haul.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Are Off Slightly on Nasdaq
description: Many of the investors who rushed in last month betting that Worldcom Inc. stock was overvalued appear to have won their bet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLER, CHAIM
description: SULLER-Chaim, died May 26, age 96, at Beth Israel Hospital. For many years co-editor of the Yiddish Morning Freiheit, journalist and teacher. Survived by his wife, Elsie; daughter, Dina Brey; grandchildren, David, Samantha and Isaac. Services Friday, May 29, 12 o'clock, at the Gramercy Chapels, 2nd Avenue and 10th Street, NY.

title: Market Anxiety in Russia
description: The world's financial markets have tumbled in the past two days, and worries about the fate of Russia's Government and economy are one reason. The turbulence, in turn, has further shaken an already wobbly Russian economy. As Southeast Asian nations learned last year, this kind of economic chain reaction can be difficult to reverse, but a crisis can be averted in Russia if international investors and Russians themselves do not panic.

title: When Music Speaks to the Eye as Well as the Ear
description: After Memorial Day, art life in New York is said to go quiet. But the Pierpont Morgan Library has just opened an exhibition in which there is a lot to look at, a lot to read and a lot to listen to. It has, in short, a multiple vibration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLICK, CORINNE
description: WALLICK-Corinne. Beloved wife of Sanders (Sandy) Wallick. Died suddenly on May 27th. A loving mother of Steven and Don Schatzberg, a gentle, generous lady who gave of herself to the many causes she supported. Survived by her sister, Sue and Ted Kaskel, brother, George (Shirley) Loeb. Stepmother of Jimmy and Andrea Wallick, and Michelle & Steven Williams, sister-in-law Rhoda Lohre, and many nieces, nephews and grand-nieces and nephews. Services Friday, May 29th at Riverside Nassau, 12 Noon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LEEUW, DAVID BIRNEY
description: de LEEUW-David Birney. May 22, 1998. Beloved son, brother, poet, & friend. David's humor, courage and intelligence, will be sorely missed. Memorial donations can be made to the Dystonia Foundation of Greater New York.

title: Ravaged by War and Massacre, Rwanda Faces Scourge of AIDS
description: Emiriene Nirere lay dying in a hospital here, a victim, she said, not only of the AIDS virus, but also of the Rwandan tradition that extols having many children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONCADA, MAXIMO
description: MONCADA-Maximo. May 23, 1998, beloved husband of Lila, devoted father of Marlene, Nelson and Max, cherished grandfather of Kyle, Michael, and Christopher. Services Thursday, May 28th, 2-5, and 7-9 P.M. at Barrett Funeral Home, 424 West 51 Street. Funeral service Friday May 29th with Mass at 10 A.M. at Sacred Heart Church, NYC with interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Proxy Peace; Prosperity and Hushed Deals Quiet the Annual Meeting
description: It is the season for annual meetings. So where are all the angry shareholders, imperious directors and bitter proxy fights of seasons past?

title: Study Hints Stress-Drug Link to Gulf War Illness
description: A new study in which mouse brains were examined says prolonged stress and drugs like those given to troops in the Persian Gulf war can have long-lasting effects on the brain. The results, the researchers say, could help explain two controversial afflictions of some service members: post-traumatic stress syndrome and gulf war syndrome.

title: With New Admissions Policy, CUNY Steps Into the Unknown
description: With their decision on Tuesday night to phase out remedial courses at four-year colleges by 2002, the trustees of the City University of New York have set in motion a transformation of the university, but they have done so without a road map.

title: Girl Zone for Hip Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Dies in Crash In Lincoln Tunnel
description: A New Jersey woman was killed in the Lincoln Tunnel yesterday in a crash involving her car, a taxi, two sport utility vehicles and two buses in the New York-bound lanes of the center tube.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRINDROD, ROBERT JOHN
description: GRINDROD-Robert John. We sadly announce the untimely death of our Robert. Family and friends will be celebrating his life at St. George's Episcopal Church at Stuyvesant Square, 209 East 16th St, Saturday, May 30, 5 PM. Friends and family welcomed. Visitation at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St) on Friday, May 29, 2 to 5 PM and 7 to 9 PM and Saturday, May 30, 2 to 4 PM. Robert will be forever with us.

title: DOWNTOWN VIEWS: The Big and Small Of Revitalization
description: Poor old Newark; you knew it well. Doesn't everyone know a downtown they would like to save from extinction? In ''Cities Back From the Edge: New Life for Downtown,'' Roberta Brandes Gratz (with Norman Mintz) argues that regular citizens shepherding small projects (say, Greenmarkets) do better than bigwigs building tourist meccas like stadiums. The authors have amassed successes from all over the country.

title: Caruaru Journal; In Brazil, Despair Once Again Feeds on a Drought
description: The day before Andre Carnio became a threat to public order, his breakfast was weak coffee. For his wife and four children, lunch was manioc flour in a soup made from the umbu, a local fruit that managed to grow while his children were withering. There was no dinner.

title: LIBRARY/WEB-SITE SOFTWARE; Power for Expert Hands
description: DREAMWEAVER(Macromedia; $299; Windows 95 and NT, Macintosh.)

title: LIBRARY/WEB-SITE SOFTWARE; Home Page: Pared Down But Versatile
description: HOME PAGE 3.0(Filemaker; $99; Windows 95 and NT, and Macintosh.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, EDWARD J. JR.
description: HAMMOND-Edward J. Jr., of New York City, New York, suddenly on May 26, 1998. Beloved son of Kathleen and the late Edward J. Hammond, Sr. Dear brother of Victoria Mayer and Thomas Hammond. Fond Uncle and Godfather of Kent Mayer. Visiting Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, Long Island. Funeral Mass 9:15 AM, Saturday at St. Anthony of Padua R.C. Church, East Northport, L.I. Cremation private.

title: Excerpts From Ruling on Compelling Testimony of 3 in the Lewinsky Case
description: Following are excerpts from the ruling of Judge Norma Holloway Johnson of Federal District Court here about the motion of the Office of Independent Counsel to compel testimony before a grand jury by two White House aides, Bruce Lindsey and Sidney Blumenthal, and an unidentified third person. Parts of the decision, including the name of the third person, edited by the court are indicated by the phrase ''redacted'' in the text.

title: Skittish Speculators Didn't Reform Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTSTEIN, SYDELL (NEE BERNSTEIN)
description: ROTSTEIN-Sydell (nee Bernstein). In Jerusalem, Israel on May 26, 1998 at age 62. Devoted wife, mother and grandmother of Saul Rotstein, Nitza Rotstein and Yair Inbar, and Talya and Michael Inbar. Beloved sister of Rita Breslau and Rosalie Bernstein. Too soon. She will be missed.

title: Landlord Says Fire Dept. Is Ogling, Not Inspecting
description: The Elite Model Agency is accustomed to having people gawk at Claudia Schiffer, Naomi Campbell, Linda Evangelista and its many other models -- in magazines, on runways, in the Fashion Cafe. But now the owner of a Manhattan building that offers dormitory-type housing to Elite models says there is a new group of gawkers: New York City firefighters who are on the job.

title: Skittish Speculators Didn't Reform Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIMBEL, NICHOLAS STEINER
description: GIMBEL-Nicholas Steiner. Died May 25, 1998. Cherished husband, father, brother, grandfather, uncle and friend. His wife, Amy, his children, Elizabeth, Victoria and Nicholas, his brothers, Tom and Stinor, and his grandchildren, Beatrice, Chloe, Emma, Amos, Rebecca, Isabella, Eliza and Anne, mourn his loss. Graduate of Fessenden, Hotchkiss, Yale, and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. His life as a surgeon and teacher was distinguished by compassion and insight. Memorial service will be on June 19th.

title: Giving Money Local Color; A Small Connecticut Town Issues Its Own Currency To Urge Hometown Spending
description: At the end of a 60-foot mahogany bar under a celestial 21-foot ceiling, Cindy Wollner watched the final lunchtime stragglers seep out of her new restaurant and fingered a few bills, part of the afternoon's take.

title: 11th-Hour Wrinkle Became Basis for the Intel Case
description: A claim added almost as an afterthought in a civil lawsuit filed last fall in Birmingham, Ala., paved the way for a broad antitrust suit that the Federal Trade Commission plans to file soon against the Intel Corporation.

title: Wanted: Web-Site Addresses That Won't Twist the Tongue
description: IT'S a question of syllables. The letter W has too many -- three times the number of every other letter, to be precise. And that's three too many for Dave Yost.

title: Sports of The Times; No Warmth In the Jets' Big Chill
description: ALTHOUGH together again, finally, Bill Parcells and Neil O'Donnell appeared just as far apart. And when the Jets' season starts, the coach and the quarterback may be even farther apart.

title: New York City Loses an Event and a Title
description: The oldest event on the tournament calendar is the Goldman Pairs, first played in 1929 and won by the great Oswald Jacoby, with a forgotten figure, George Reith. It has almost always been played in Manhattan and almost always won by New York experts.

title: Web Sites Provide the Details To Authenticate Beanie Babies
description: First it was a phony Grunt. Then came a welter of fake Kiwis and Chops. Now the market is being flooded with counterfeit Pekings.

title: The War Between the States
description: A lot of commentators are saying that the war between New York and New Jersey is over now that the Supreme Court has finally ruled that 90 percent of Ellis Island belongs to New Jersey. I would argue that, if anything, the ruling may make things worse.

title: Yankees' Middle Relief Springs a Leak Again
description: Since the first week of April, managing the Yankees has come easy for Joe Torre. He respected his players; they all flew around the country and won just about every game.

title: World Markets Slump
description: The plunge in the Russian market helped prompt sell-offs worldwide. The declines revived worries about the global effects of Asia's economic crisis. Business Day, page D1.

title: Shaping Politics From the Pulpit; Abandoning the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid the Game, Worries Over Home
description: There were youngsters in every cranny and nook of Stade Roland Garros on this soggy Wednesday. It was Kids' Day: an annual occasion high on enthusiasm and low on decorum.

title: Censoring Terrence McNally
description: Every work of art -- every painting, every poem, every play -- redefines the open space, the cultural freedom, within which it has been created and presented to the public. But in a city as rich, culturally, as New York, it becomes possible to forget that fact until a case comes along to refresh our memories. The case now at hand is the Manhattan Theater Club's decision, prompted by threats of violence, to withdraw its production of Terrence McNally's new play, ''Corpus Christi.''

title: Barnes & Noble Adds Software To Expand On-Line Bookstore
description: Software is not the first thing that springs to mind at the mention of Barnes & Noble, the nation's leading purveyor of books. But the company is betting that it can change that. As part of a major overhaul of its on-line bookstore (www.barnesandnoble.com), Barnes & Noble announced yesterday that it had opened a software superstore with 1,000 software titles.

title: Top Safety Official for Astronauts Says NASA Ignored Warnings About Mir's Dangers
description: Last year, as the Russian space station Mir suffered a fire, a collision and several major equipment failures, the top safety official for astronauts at the Johnson Space Center in Houston warned that the East-West program of shuttle visits and stays on the Mir by NASA astronauts was ''a disaster waiting to happen'' and that an American on board the Russian outpost might soon die in a space catastrophe.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Who Knows Father Best?

title: Change in Taxi Code Seen as Unlikely to Pass Intact
description: Faced with some opposition from several Taxi and Limousine Commission members and the prospect of hundreds of public speakers, the Giuliani administration conceded yesterday that its 17-point plan to overhaul the taxi industry probably would not be passed in its entirety at today's meeting of the commission.

title: Jerry Brown Dominates Oakland Race
description: Propelled by unbeatable name recognition, unmatchable press attention and a potent appeal to voters willing to try something new and decidedly different, Edmund G. Brown Jr. has zoomed so far ahead in this city's mayoral race that he seems poised to win outright in the primary on June 2, according to a new poll.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM FALLS 10 PERCENT. Prices of palladium plunged on speculation that Russia, the top supplier, would soon end a long suspension of exports to help ease its debt crisis. June contracts fell $36.55 an ounce, to $313.50.

title: New System Checks Fingerprints Swiftly
description: In the not-so-distant past, the police checked a suspect's fingerprints by slowly thumbing through stacks of index cards bearing inked sets of prints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTIUS, HELEN E. MENZEL
description: MANTIUS-Helen E. Menzel. On May 25, 1998. Wife of the late Ernest E. Mantius, mother of the late Antonia E. Mantius, cousin of Charlotte Benner of Yarmouth, MA, and of Philip K. Mantius of Sun City, AZ; aunt of Mrs. Robert Anderson of Pembroke, MA. Burial service private.

title: The Millennium Bug
description: On Jan. 1, 2000, the world will probably wake up with a hangover. But it will be nothing compared with the one felt by computers and computerized systems all around the globe, many of which will awake not to Saturday, which some deem the dawn of a new millennium, but to Monday, Jan. 1, 1900. Because much computer hardware and software has, until recently, stored years in two-digit forms -- 98, not 1998, for instance -- their internal clocks will make a disastrous mistake when they roll over to 00, interpreting it as 1900, not 2000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Antitrust Suit Against Intel Prepared by Regulators

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, ELSA JANE HARTWIG
description: CAMPBELL-Elsa Jane Hartwig. November 28, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Alec Campbell. Adored mother of Constance Alessandra Campbell. Dearest daughter of the late Carl and Karen Hartwig of Minneapolis. Formerly with the International Division of the YMCA, and later with her husband's company, Prime TV Films. Memorial service Thursday, May 28th, 11AM, St. Bartholomew's Church, 50th and Park, New York City.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: Gateway announced a new computer purchasing program yesterday. For about $50 a month, you get a customized PC, software, unlimited Internet access and ''obsolescence protection.'' But the program -- called Your:)Ware -- is fairly restrictive. It allows anyone who buys a new Gateway computer through the program to trade in that computer no sooner than two years, and no later than four years, after the sale. The customer can apply the wholesale value at the time of the trade-in only toward a new Gateway computer. And the customer pays shipping. No haggling. Be:(Ware might be a more appropriate name. ''It's a good idea, poorly executed,'' said Rob Enderle, an analyst at Giga Information Group.

title: Black Clergymen Protest Policy on Traffic Stops
description: Black clergymen and top state law enforcement officials had what both sides called a productive meeting yesterday on the issue of whether troopers stop motorists because of their race, although state officials rejected a demand for an independent investigation into a police shooting on the New Jersey Turnpike last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTIFIDIS, CLEOPATRA
description: ASTIFIDIS-Cleopatra. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center Family joins with the staff of the Seymour J. Phillips Health Sciences Library in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Cleopatra Astifidis, the mother of our esteemed friend and collegue, Maria Astifidis. We extend our sympathies to Maria, the entire Astifidis Family and all who loved her. Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President Donald W. Hoskins, M.D., Vice President & Medical Director of Academic Affairs

title: Overlooking the Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable Modems' Other Side
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTDOOR SCULPTURE: A One-Year Engagement
description: A diamond may be forever, but Dennis Oppenheim's ''Engagement'' -- a three-story sculpture of two colossal steel rings, to be installed starting on Monday -- will last but one year in front of the Flatiron Building. The rings, shown here at their last installation, in Austria, have diamondlike settings (actually glass houselike boxes) that will light up every night for a year. As engagements go, that's long. The Flatiron Building is at Broadway and 23d Street.

title: Shaping Politics From the Pulpit; Marriage Under Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We think about AIDS only afterward, after the sexual act. There are women here who lost children in the war and they just want to replace them.''

title: Zine of 'Literate Smut' Finds a Significant Other
description: Nerve, the on-line magazine that bills itself as ''literate smut,'' has found a mainstream partner, a magazine that is more used to covering celebrities and news than publishing long personal essays about sexuality and artful nude photographs.

title: Hernandez To Try Relief
description: The Yankees have begun refining plans to get Orlando Hernandez to the big leagues.

title: Conviction Canceled, She Is Free For the First Time in 25 Years
description: Twenty-five years to the day after her arrest in the strangulation death of a businessman, Betty Tyson left the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility here this afternoon and headed home to Rochester a free woman, after the Monroe County District Attorney announced that he would not seek a new trial.

title: South Koreans Protest Spread Of Layoffs In I.M.F. Plan
description: Tens of thousands of workers walked off their jobs today and staged polite protests against layoffs and the increasing use of temporary workers.

title: LIBRARY/WEB-SITE SOFTWARE; Templates With Humor And Beauty
description: NET OBJECTS FUSION 3Net Objects; $295; Windows 95 and NT, Macintosh.)

title: Garden Notebook; A Turn-of-the-Century Jewel in the New Jersey Rough
description: PLANTS often last longest as witnesses to human habitation. A pair of Norway spruces mark a ghostly front door; a straggly lilac, an overgrown garden.

title: Calendar; Gardens, Workshops And Shows
description: Air-Tight Design

title: LIBRARY/WEB-SITE SOFTWARE; Tools to Help You Stake a Claim on the Web
description: AS the World Wide Web threatens to become as beguilingly popular as television, more viewers are being captivated by the slick presentation and intriguing animation on sites like Hotwired and Shockrave (at www.hotwired. com and www.shockrave.com). And because the Web is still a do-it-yourself medium, many might start to think, ''Gee, I want to do that, too.''

title: Psychiatric Unit's Ethics Faulted
description: The University of Maryland and its psychiatric research center in Baltimore have been found in violation of Federal ethics laws in some experiments at the center.

title: Boeing to Cut Production Of 747 Jumbo Jets in 1999
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that weakening demand from Asian airlines would probably force it to cut production of its 747 jumbo jet next year. The company also said it still faced difficulties meeting demand for the new version of its popular 737 narrow-body jet.

title: Parcells and O'Donnell Defrost Cold War, a Bit
description: For the first time in 156 days, the coach of the Jets spoke to his (starting?) quarterback today, adding to the confusion.

title: Deciphering Those Growls
description: Q. When my computer is idling, without screen-saver or antivirus programs running, I still hear occasional hard-disk action. What is it doing?

title: Restless And Old: Jazz Wait
description: The more downtime the Utah Jazz had, the more restless Jerry Sloan grew. He gave his team Monday off and put it through light drills on Tuesday. Finally, fed up with what amounted in his eyes to a vacation, the coach decided to simulate a basketball game today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELLER, BELLE
description: ZELLER-Belle. The Hunter College Community mourns the loss of Belle Zeller, a 1921 graduate of Hunter College High School, and 3 years later, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Hunter College. She was a professor of political science for 47 years, and was a mentor and counselor to many legislative leaders. Her books analyzing lobbying and state legislatures made her a national authority on governmental operations. She was also a leader in the fight to win collective bargaining rights for CUNY faculty and served as head of the Professional Staff Congress, City University's Union, for 32 years. In recognition of her many years of dedicated service to the city and the nation and her lifelong advocacy for CUNY students, she was awarded the President's Medal of Hunter College in 1994. David A. Caputo, President Hunter College

title: Big-Byte Options for Storage
description: ABOUT a year ago, Carolyn Betts-Stambaugh swore that things were finally over between her and the 3.5-inch floppy disk. ''I decided that nothing else of mine was ever going onto those little things,'' she said.

title: Return to Tighter Standards, And Renewal of Old Debate
description: Tougher admission policies adopted by the City University of New York reflect an effort to return to the relatively selective standards the university's senior colleges maintained before open admissions.

title: Lewinsky's Lawyer Sees 'Prosecutorial Abuse'
description: Asserting that ''the Government has no business in our bedrooms,'' the lawyer for Monica S. Lewinsky has called Kenneth W. Starr living proof ''that prosecutorial abuse can and does exist in America.''

title: Sampras's Dream Buried in the Clay Once Again
description: He let his racquet become a shovel, digging him into trouble, and then he let his obscure opponent, 97th-ranked Ramon Delgado of Paraguay, bury him alive.

title: Crying Racism Upsets City's Delicate Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: Next 'Asian' Crisis?
description: The financial panic that struck Russia today had distinctly Russian causes: the Government cannot collect taxes, it suffers from an economy that is nearly moribund and it has an untested new economic team. But in Washington the Russian crisis looks very much like the next phase of the Asian crisis.

title: Mies's Romantic Side, In a Newfound Picture
description: ROMANTIC is not a word used to describe the work of the archmodernist architect Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. But one of his rare early drawings may change that. The unusually large gouache on canvas -- 4 1/2 by 8 feet -- is a severely symmetrical rendering of two flanks of columns marching toward a hemispherical stone fortress. Presumed lost, it has just been acquired by the Museum of Modern Art.

title: New Jersey Officials Move to Put Ellis Island on Map
description: Exultant state officials today moved swiftly if mostly symbolically -- to exert New Jersey's sovereignty over most of Ellis Island, with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announcing the creation of a panel to consider the island's future and Attorney General Peter G. Verniero seeking to put the historic immigration site literally on New Jersey's map.

title: Reduced Term for Witness to Bombing Plot
description: Instead of receiving a maximum sentence of 23 years in prison, Michael J. Fortier, who had not warned anyone of the Oklahoma City bombing but later testified against the men convicted in the plot, was sentenced today to 12 years by Judge G. Thomas Van Bebber of Federal District Court here.

title: Do Computers Have to Be Hard to Use?
description: BILL GATES, the chairman of Microsoft, once said that if automobile manufacturers had kept up with technology as well as the computer industry had, people would all be driving $27 cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMOWITZ, BERNARD
description: HYMOWITZ-Bernard. Beloved husband of Judith and the late Ronnie. Loving father of Ira, Phillip and Fran Lerner; stepfather of Eric, Todd and Jonathan Sorrin; adored grandfather of Adam, Rachel, Samantha, Jason, Michelle, Elana, Joshua, Jacob, Aaron & Daniel; dear brother of Stanley. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 11:30 A.M., Friday.

title: Ex-Officer Admits To Taking Bribes
description: A retired Union City police lieutenant who was arrested in a corruption sweep in January pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to taking bribes to protect local gambling operations, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGUIRE, HAROLD V.
description: MAGUIRE-Harold V. On May 26, 1998. Founder of Maguire Insurance Agency: W.W. II Navy Sea Bee. Beloved husband of the late Ellen (nee Sheridan). Loving uncle of Joan Fischer, Benita Hughes & Franklyn Mento. Dear brother-inlaw of Elizabeth S. Ferris. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, New York. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 A.M., at St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting Friday 2-5 PM and 7-10 PM.

title: Risk of Hong Kong Recession Sparks a Sell-Off : Major Stock Markets Fall Amid Anxiety Over Asia
description: NEW YORK  Warnings that Hong Kong is headed for recession and that Japan's banking system may be in trouble sent the world's stock markets into a fresh tailspin Wednesday.

title: Boy's Death in Chase Is Found to Be Homicide
description: A 13-year-old Queens boy who collapsed on a sidewalk on Tuesday after being chased was killed by a blunt impact to his back and his death has been classified a homicide, the City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Turner, NBC, Left Out Of N.F.L., Plan League
description: NBC and Turner Sports, which refused to pay the enormous cost of renewing their National Football League rights last January, announced last night that they had decided to move forward with the creation of a new football league.

title: Metro Business; Regional Economy Was Strong in May
description: Business activity in the New York region grew at a faster pace this month as manufacturing and services strengthened, according to a survey of service and factory executives released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALIMIR, SUZANNE
description: GALIMIR-Suzanne. The Musicians, Trustees and Staff of the Marlboro Music School and Festival share the loss of and extend deepest sympathy to the family of Suzanne Galimir. For over forty years, she was instrumental in helping to plan and arrange events at Marlboro that brought generations of exceptional young musicians together into a warm and caring community that was as much a family as it was an inspiring musical environment. Suzanne will be missed by us all.

title: THE FINE PRINT: A close look at the highway bill; Proviso in Highway Bill Stalls Pollution Curbs
description: In a last-minute change to the big highway bill that President Clinton will sign next week, Congress has postponed for several years new plans to clear the haze of pollution that often obscures the vistas in parks, wilderness areas and other relatively pristine sites.

title: South Africa Relents a Bit on Ousting Reporter
description: After months of refusing to let an award-winning journalist return to fight a deportation order, the South African Government has abruptly reversed itself.

title: Police to Tighten the Scrutiny Of All Suspects Under Arrest
description: Responding to the shooting of a police officer by a fugitive parolee who was mistakenly set free, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that anyone arrested for even minor offenses, such as fare beating or drinking in public, must now remain in police custody until a computerized fingerprint check verifies the person's identity.

title: Essay; Who's Losing Russia?
description: It can't happen here, but assume our Dow average were to drop substantially. Not just the 10 or 15 percent correction customary after big run-ups, but all the way down to 4,000. What would our reaction be?

title: Carl H. Builder, 67, an Expert On Military at Rand Corporation
description: Carl H. Builder, an analyst with the Rand Corporation whose views on military affairs were widely quoted, died on May 20 at his home in Culver City, Calif. He was 67.

title: How Many Bill Gateses Does It Take to Change a Light Bulb?
description: FASTER than a speeding O.J. joke, able to leap large oceans in a single cc'd E-mail, the yuks over Microsoft's latest contretemps with the Justice Department are spreading, viruslike, across the monitors of America -- many via Microsoft Word and Internet Explorer, the traitorous finks.

title: Mets Are Uneasy Over Hundley Leaks
description: Todd Hundley left the Mets today for his Port St. Lucie, Fla., home to continue rehabilitating his surgically repaired right elbow. But lingering behind were uneasy feelings about an apparent leak in the Mets' organization to reporters that was critical of Hundley's work ethic and drinking habits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, LAWRENCE
description: FRIEDMAN-Lawrence. Former Postmaster of Teaneck, NJ died May 25, 1998 after a long illness. He leaves his loving wife, Clara; daughters Barbara Friedman and Karen Glaser; two grandsons and sister, Miriam Drabkin.

title: Secret Session Led to Ruling Over Privilege
description: A Federal judge has ordered two top White House officials to appear before the grand jury investigating the Lewinsky matter only after the independent counsel made a secret presentation to her, outside of the presence of Administration lawyers, to demonstrate that the need for the aides' testimony outweighed President Clinton's right to claim executive and attorney-client privilege.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROZETT, JACK
description: ROZETT-Jack. In Branford, CT, May 27, 1998 of 8 Huntington Dr., Branford, CT. formerly of NY. Beloved husband of Barbara Goldman Rozett; a devoted employee of Legett & Platt, he is also survived by three daughters, Pamela Hettrich, Lisa Friedman and Shawn Senning; brother Lawrence Rozett of Florida, and sister, Doris Smirlock of California, and nine grandchildren. Services Thursday, 11 A.M. in Curtis-Sisk Funeral Home, 69 South Main Street, Branford, CT. on the Green, CT.

title: Skittish Speculators Didn't Reform Asia
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODEL, ERICK W.
description: MODEL-Erick W. On May 26, 1998. Precious friend of Celeste Martin and Stephen Leung. Reposing at Guidetti Funeral Home, 33 Spring St. on Thursday 5-9PM. Services Friday 1 P.M., at the funeral home. Entombment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: Firstenergy to Cut Jobs
description: The Firstenergy Corporation said today that it planned to cut 485 jobs at its Illuminating Company unit. Firstenergy will reduce staff at its power plants in Ashtabula, Avon Lake, Eastlake, Lake Shore and Perry, Ohio. The energy services company was created last year by the merger of Centerior Energy and Ohio Edison. Illuminating employs about 5,300 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, IRWIN
description: ROSENBERG-Irwin. Dear Robe. We have had over 50 years of wonderful friendship together and we shall always miss you. Arlene and Bernie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, FRANK
description: FREEMAN-Frank. Of New York City and Point O' Woods, Fire Island, age 77, on May 24, at home. Beloved husband of Beverly, loving father of Howard and James, and daughters-in-law Karen and Rachel. Also survived by his stepmother Mary Freeman, brothers George and Richard and sister Mary Catherine Rockey. He was a retired advertising vice-president. A memorial service will be held at The Church At Point O' Woods on Saturday, June 20 at 3:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Salvation Army would be appreciated.

title: Girl, 16, Is Slashed Outside Bronx School
description: A 16-year-old girl was severely slashed with a box cutter outside her high school in the Bronx yesterday, the police said, but her attacker, another teen-age girl, escaped.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Mexicans Were Denied U.S. Rights, Suit Says
description: Four Mexican unions filed an unusual legal complaint yesterday, charging that thousands of Mexican migrants who pick and pack apples in Washington State are deprived of their basic labor rights, including overtime pay, safety protections and the right to form unions without facing retaliation.

title: BOSTON CHICKEN MAY SELL STAKE IN EINSTEIN/NOAH BAGEL
description: Boston Chicken Inc. said yesterday that it had hired the investment banker Morgan Stanley to help the company sell some or all of its interest in the Einstein/Noah Bagel Corporation. Boston Chicken owns 17.3 million shares, or 52 percent, of Einstein/Noah Bagel. At Einstein/Noah's closing price on Tuesday, the shares would be worth $95 million. Einstein/Noah, based in Golden, Colo., franchises 200 bagel stores under the names Einstein Brothers and Noah's New York Bagels. Boston Chicken, also based in Golden, franchises more than 1,600 Boston Market fast-food restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMES, RAIE
description: HAMES-Raie. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of its esteemed member, Dr. Regina Pozner, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman William Schwartz, President

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Brian Tolle

title: Half-Year Profit Slid 91%, NEC Says
description: The NEC Corporation, Japan's largest maker of personal computers and computer chips, indicated yesterday that its earnings fell 91 percent in the second half of the year that ended on March 31 as plunging prices for memory chips and a slowdown in PC shipments cut into profits. Group net income for the second half of the fiscal year dropped to 5.539 billion yen ($40.4 million) from 60.370 billion yen a year earlier. Revenue declined 6.6 percent, to 2.53 trillion yen from 2.71 trillion yen.

title: Invitation to Justice Thomas Creates Furor
description: The nation's largest organization of black lawyers and judges is in turmoil over an invitation to have Justice Clarence Thomas be the main speaker at its annual convention in July and is considering disinviting him, senior members of the National Bar Association said today.

title: NUCLEAR ANXIETY
description: AFTERMATH -- Experts say they fear an India-Pakistan war and a new arms race. News analysis, page A9.

title: FRANCE '98: World Cup Profile -- From Onlooker to Playmaker; After a Four-Year Wait, Reyna Will Finally Get His Shot
description: Four years ago, Claudio Reyna was the boy wonder of American soccer. The two-time national high school player of the year at St. Benedict's Prep in Newark and three-time national champion at the University of Virginia was 20 years old and challenging for a starting spot in the midfield of the United States team.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Open Admissions Cheats Best Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Touchstone Pictures Expected to Quit, Executives Say
description: Donald DeLine, president of Touchstone Pictures, a division of the Walt Disney Company, is expected to resign his post within the next few months, executives at Disney said tonight.

title: Waiting to Derail: A Cheerleader's Fall and Rise
description: Sandra Bullock is actually seen cheerleading in a flashback during ''Hope Floats,'' which suits this role and so many others she has played. In her best approximation of America's high school sweetheart since ''While You Were Sleeping,'' Ms. Bullock is cast as a one-time prom queen named Birdee Pruitt who falls on hard times. So Birdee goes back home to sweet little Smithville, Tex., and basks in the small-town wisdom she finds there. Like: ''Maybe you were like the rest of us, 'cept you were ridin' around on flowers made out of toilet paper. That's all.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Open Admissions Cheats Best Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Cadets Won't Discard Their Sextants
description: It seems that American naval cadets, taught since 1845 to navigate by the stars, are not going to discard their sextants quite yet.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: ROCHESTER INTERNATIONAL

title: Gerber Recalls Food Sold in Elizabeth Store
description: The Gerber Products Company has asked customerswho have bought jars of Gerber baby food from the Shop-Rite supermarket on West Grand Avenue in Elizabeth since Tuesday to return it because of possible product tampering.

title: Caps Seize On Sabres' Weaknesses In Overtime
description: He is not now the Dominik Hasek who led the Czech Republic to the gold medal in the Winter Olympic Games. Nor is he the same Hasek who finished among the three finalists for the Hart trophy this season as the most valuable player in the National Hockey League.

title: A Dangerous Abortion Curb
description: Republican leaders in Congress, eager to placate supporters from the Christian right, are promoting cruel and constitutionally suspect legislation that would jeopardize the lives of frightened young women seeking abortions. The G.O.P. calls this new measure, which plays cleverly on the issue of parental consent, the Child Custody Protection Act. It should be called the Teen Endangerment Act.

title: Steward Is High On Akinwande
description: When Emanuel Steward took on the assignment of training Henry Akinwande, he saw a battle looming not only in the physical sense for the bout with Evander Holyfield at Madison Square Garden on June 6, but also in the mind of his fighter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROZETT, JACK
description: ROZETT-Jack. In Branford, CT, May 26, 1998 of 8 Huntington Dr., Branford, CT. formerly of NY. Beloved husband of Barbara Goldman Rozett; a devoted employee of Legett & Platt, he is also survived by three daughters, Pamela Hettrich, Lisa Friedman and Shawn Senning; brother Lawrence Rozett of Florida, and sister, Doris Smirlock of California, and nine grandchildren. Services Friday, 11 A.M. in Curtis-Sisk Funeral Home, 69 South Main Street, Branford, CT. on the Green, CT.

title: All Jazz, All June
description: ''We jazz June.''

title: After the Drilling: Martinez Pays, Benitez Walks
description: Baseball may spend the next hundred years tinkering with the method of punishing headhunters and never get it right. Today, though, it is evident that the punishment of the Baltimore Orioles' Armando Benitez, the pitcher who threw at and injured the Yankees' Tino Martinez, did not fit the crime.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: N.C.A.A. WOMEN'S CHAMPIONSHIPS

title: This Time, The Men Are Balletic Stars
description: The men of American Ballet Theater achieved a seeming impossibility by shining as individuals in Jiri Kylian's ''Sinfonietta'' on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FONSECA, GONZALO
description: FONSECA-Gonzalo. A memorial for Gonzalo Fonseca, Monday June 1, 6 P.M., at the Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, NY.

title: Placed in the Shadows By a Chiaroscurist
description: Prem Murthy Trivedi of Howell, N.J., stood on a stage in Washington yesterday and tried to do what only one person has done before: top his previous year's second-place finish by winning the National Spelling Bee.

title: Accounts
description: -- Franklin Electronics Publishers, Burlington, N.J., to DiMassimo Inc., New York, to handle advertising for Rex PC Companion, a hand-held PC card and personal digital assistant, which had been handled by Della Femina/Jeary & Partners, New York, a joint venture of Jerry Della Femina and Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Economy Brisk, But Data Offer Some Cautions
description: In the midst of fresh crises in Asia and Russia, the Commerce Department announced yesterday that the American economy in the first quarter was even stronger than originally thought, but there was a suggestion in the new figures of slower growth ahead.

title: Corrections
description: A byline was omitted yesterday from the main front-page article in Circuits, about demands to simplify computers. The writer was Katie Hafner.

title: The Millennium Bug; Too Few, Too Late
description: To the Editor:

title: MCI to Sell Wholesale Internet Unit to Cable and Wireless
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its wholesale Internet business to Cable and Wireless P.L.C. for $625 million in cash.

title: The Millennium Bug
description: To the Editor:

title: Yet Another Century of Faith?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Today, we have settled the score with India.''

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Tony Nominee Is About to Close

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUPTA, NAWAL
description: GUPTA-Nawal. On May 28, 1998. Employed by Cahill Gordon Reindel, NY, NY. Beloved husband of Pushpa (nee Gupta) loving father of Romel and Susan, and Rahul Gupta. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd St. Visiting hours Friday, 10:30 AM to 1:15 PM. Cremation Fresh Pond Crematory.

title: Market Place; Late but Emphatic, Asia's Woes Reach Latin America
description: Just when it began to look as if Latin America had dodged the bullet of Asia's financial and economic woes, stock markets from Mexico to Chile began to tumble. The decline, which began in earnest three weeks ago, accelerated earlier this week, ushering in a period of increased volatility, stock market analysts said.

title: Stocks Gain Slightly as Wary Buyers Return to Blue Chips
description: The stock market rebounded modestly yesterday, ending a four-day slump as investors crept back into some of their favorite blue-chip stocks as well as a broad variety of smaller issues.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Tasting Fruits at a Painterly Produce Stand
description: Although he calls himself ''something of a pear freak,'' the art historian William H. Gerdts and his wife, Abigail, also an art historian, have managed to make room for a remarkable assortment of other flora in their very focused collection of 19th-century American still-life paintings.

title: GUINNESS TO ACCEPT MATTEL OFFER FOR BLUEBIRD SHARES
description: Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would accept the offer of 116.5 pence a share in cash from the toy maker Mattel Inc. for its shares in Bluebird Toys P.L.C., bringing to an end a four-month bidding war for the British toy company. Guinness Peat, an investment company that owns 23 percent of Bluebird, said it would let its earlier 116 pence bid for Bluebird lapse, ending its participation in the bidding. Mattel, which distributes Bluebird's Polly Pocket miniature dolls in Britain has traded bids with Guinness Peat since March. Its final offer is worth about $78 million.

title: AES TO GET HANWA ENERGY'S POWER BUSINESS
description: The AES Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the power plant business of the Hanwha Energy Company of South Korea. AES, a power developer based in Arlington, Va., will inject $370 million of cash into the South Korean business within two weeks and will also invest about $230 million to complete construction of an unfinished power plant. AES may also assume $270 million of debt, said Jeffrey Safford, vice president of the AES China Generating Company. AES agreed this week to buy a Buenos Aires electric utility for $350 million.

title: INSIDE
description: Yeltsin Wants Help on Ruble

title: Her Mouth Is Poison, and Her Heart Is Fool's Gold
description: Christina Ricci has morphed enchantingly from wicked little Wednesday of the ''Addams Family'' comedies into Lolita's evil twin. Voluptuous and scheming in Don Roos's gleefully acerbic comedy ''The Opposite of Sex,'' she plays the nasty little baggage named Dedee whose sexual chicanery and self-interest know no bounds. Neither does Mr. Roos's barbed humor as he mocks preconceptions about straight and gay life styles with total abandon, rude epithets and all. What redeem the film's surface bitterness are sharp observations, laceratingly funny dialogue and something Dedee claims to find especially loathsome: a secret heart of gold.

title: Unexpected Vistas In Quilting by Men
description: Back in 1991, the board of regents of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington unanimously approved the concept of a National African-American Museum, to open in the Arts and Industries building on the Mall. Legislation authorizing the museum was, however, repeatedly turned down in Congress, and the project as envisioned remains unrealized.

title: Yet Another Century of Faith?; Invitation to Tyranny
description: To the Editor:

title: A Polite Defender of SoHo's Cast-Iron Past
description: THERE is a copy of ''Final Exit,'' the manual of assisted dying, on a bureau in the bedroom of the preservationist Margot Gayle, not far from the aged copying machine she uses to assist her in her battle, and since Mrs. Gayle is 90 and troubled by arthritis and cannot take her daily one-mile walk without the assistance of a companion, it seems only right to ask:

title: Police Detective Charged With Attempted Murder
description: A New York City narcotics detective who was stripped of his gun last week after his estranged girlfriend brought a domestic violence complaint against him slashed her with a knife Wednesday night, law enforcement officials said yesterday. He then drove his car into hers in a futile attempt to make her wounds appear accidental, the officials said.

title: In Whirlwind of Paperwork, State Authority Takes Over Lilco
description: Five billion dollars in bonds changed hands, a public utility was born and two energy companies merged today, all in marathon proceedings that completed New York State's takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company's retail electricity service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODEL, ERICK W.
description: MODEL-Erick W. On May 26. Precious friend of Celeste Martin, Noel Tursi and Stephen Leung. Reposing at Guidetti Funeral Home, 33 Spring St, NYC, today 11 AM to 1 PM. Services at 1 PM at the funeral home. Entombment in the Hillside Mausoleum II Atrium at Greenwood Cemetery.

title: A Top Female Executive Leaves Disney/ABC
description: Geraldine B. Laybourne, the most prominent female executive in the television industry, announced yesterday that she had resigned as president of cable television operations for the Walt Disney Company and ABC Inc. in order to form her own company, devoted to creating programming for both television and the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAWLIN, EDWARD T.
description: PAWLIN-Edward T. Age 69. Died May 23, 1998 in Old Lyme, CT. Many will miss him, a few miss his friendship. Louis Weinel

title: Selling Coffins From a Storefront; Savings Are Large, but Some Find the Setup Unnerving
description: Window-shopping does not describe the pedestrian rubbernecking yesterday in front of Direct Casket, the newest storefront on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn. One man stopped, squinted and began laughing. One woman made the sign of the cross.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUZZO, ANTHONY
description: GUZZO-Anthony, 75. Died May 28, 1998 at Rome Memorial Hospital, Rome, NY. He was born October 8, 1922 to Anthony and Fannie Guzzo in Brooklyn, New York. Would any kin or anyone knowing any next of kin contact the Central New York DSO (collect) at 315336-2300 regarding any special funeral arrangements.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Edwin Zwakman

title: Only Clear Round Produces Winner
description: El Campion Jo Jo, ridden by 23-year-old Nicole Shahinian-Simpson of Hidden Valley, Calif., posted the only clear round in a four-horse jumpoff to win the $50,000 Grand Prix of Devon, Pa., beating a field of 45 horses and riders. It was the largest field in the 21-year-history of the Devon event.

title: Immersion In the Amazon
description: No matter how hot and humid New York City gets, you don't expect to encounter a tropical rain forest on the Upper West Side. This year, however, you can be enveloped by one, right on Central Park West.

title: China Voices 'Regret,' but Still Faults India
description: China, Pakistan's oldest and most powerful Asian ally, expressed ''deep regret'' today over Pakistan's decision to conduct nuclear tests. But Chinese officials continued to reiterate their opinion that India had touched off the crisis by testing its own nuclear devices earlier this month.

title: Upset With Restrictions Proposed by Giuliani, Food Vendors Are the Latest to Plan a March
description: Hundreds of street vendors announced last night that they would shut down their food carts on Wednesday so they could march in protest of the Giuliani administration's plan to ban snack wagons from 144 blocks of Manhattan.

title: But Is the Play Worthy?
description: Like almost everyone else, I have not seen Terrence McNally's play ''Corpus Christi,'' which apparently is about a gay Jesus-like figure who has sex with his apostles. I don't know whether the play is worth producing. I also don't know whether the threat of violence was the real reason for the Manhattan Theater Club's initial decision to cancel the play. The artistic director reversed that decision yesterday, claiming the only issue was security.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about American policy toward Yugoslavia misstated the positions at stake in elections in Montenegro on Sunday. The elections are for Parliament, not the presidency.

title: Prosecutors Tell Jurors That Freemen Case Is About Fraud, Not Politics
description: Opening arguments were delivered today in the trial of the Freemen's central leadership, with prosecutors saying that the case against the anti-government group centered on fraud, not politics.

title: Misfortune Lingering in Victory Gallop's Camp
description: Victory Gallop has been the hard-luck colt in this year's Triple Crown, and a dark cloud continues to hover over him. He finished second in both the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes to Real Quiet, then came down with an unsightly skin rash. And on Wednesday night, his trainer, Elliott Walden, broke his right ankle in a pickup basketball game near Monmouth Park in New Jersey.

title: Baby Starves, And Mother Is Accused Of Homicide
description: For weeks, Tatiana Cheeks fussed happily over her newborn baby, who gurgled and squirmed but never seemed to thrive. The little girl always seemed hungry, no matter how often she nursed. And when the child died in her sleep in March, relatives said, Ms. Cheeks wailed inconsolably, overwhelmed by the shock of losing her 6-week-old daughter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SYLVIA K.
description: KAPLAN-Sylvia K. On May 27, 1998, in her 89th year. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Kaplan, loving mother of Rona Roob, Steven Kaplan, Susan Diamond, and the late Richard Kaplan, cherished grandmother of Nancy, Helen, Nathan, Edward, Joseph, Nicholas, Michael, Sara, and David, great grandmother of Hanna, Sophie, and Ella, and cherished friend of Helen McGrath. Services are on Friday, May 29, at 10:45 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Yet Another Century of Faith?; Believer Bandwagon
description: To the Editor:

title: Slain Officer Is Remembered as a Man Who Made Peace
description: Police officers and relatives at the wake of Anthony Mosomillo, a Brooklyn police officer killed on Tuesday morning, remembered him yesterday as a man who made peace: as a brother, as a union delegate and as a warrant server.

title: Let's Leave Darwin Out of It
description: As a paleontologist by trade and (dare I say it?) a card-carrying liberal in politics, I have been amused, but also a bit chagrined, by the current fad in conservative intellectual circles for invoking the primary icon of my professional world -- Charles Darwin -- as either a scourge or an ally in support of cherished doctrines.

title: Complex Warriors and Victims
description: It is 1962, and Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann has just arrived in Vietnam, having been told by his Army superiors about the toughness and dedication of the South Vietnamese troops he will advise. He watches as a photographer records South Vietnamese soldiers standing proudly above Vietcong corpses laid at their feet. The photographer finishes; the corpses get up and walk away. The entire episode has been a ghoulish photo op, staged, a Vietnamese colonel says, because it is ''good for morale.''

title: Comfort in an AIDS Clinic, Despite Death's Domination
description: Kate has been working too hard at the AIDS clinic. At least that's what her friends conclude when she announces that her oven is talking to her. At first the voice is that of an English professor from Austin, Tex., flirting a little and giving her his hummus recipe. But when Kate claims to be receiving messages from beyond the grave, the other characters in Gary Bonasorte's sweet, sad, funny play ''Ascendancy'' decide she has gone around the bend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHHEIM, SIMON
description: BUCHHEIM-Simon. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Simon Buchheim, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Harry Laufer, President

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Edward Henry Potthast

title: Davidson Coach Talks to St. John's
description: Ed Manetta, the St. John's athletic director, met with Davidson Coach Bob McKillop yesterday, completing the first of his interviews with the three candidates for the men's basketball coaching position.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Rebecca Horn

title: Night Life of the the Young, Urban and Genteel
description: Leave it to Whit Stillman, in completing the beguiling, literate trilogy that includes ''Metropolitan'' and ''Barcelona,'' to begin a film about the New York nightclub scene of the early 1980's with a caste distinction and a lofty show of utter confidence. At a disco entrance presided over by the usual elitist doorman, Charlotte (Kate Beckinsale) makes only the teensiest concession to self-doubt. She and her college chum Alice (Chloe Sevigny) decide to arrive in a cab rather than on foot, but that hardly matters; stunning, assured Charlotte might as well float in on a cloud.

title: REPUBLIC SECURITY TO BUY FIRST PALM BEACH
description: The Republic Security Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire a crosstown bank, First Palm Beach Bancorp, for $279.3 million in stock. Republic Security will issue 4.194 shares for each First Palm Beach shares, valued at $55.05 a share based on its closing price on Wednesday. Adding First Palm Beach, the parent of First Bank of Florida, will give Republic Security $2.8 billion in assets and 83 branches in five south Florida counties. Republic Security, the parent of Republic Security Bank, which is based in West Palm Beach, has $1 billion in assets and 32 branches. First Palm Beach, also in West Palm Beach, has $1.8 billion in assets and 51 branches. First Palm Beach's shares rose $7.75, or 21 percent, to $44.25, and Republic Security fell $1.625, to $12.625.

title: Nonsmoking Casinos
description: To the Editor:

title: Calm and Collected, Pate Takes Memorial Lead
description: Steve Pate's nickname used to be Volcano. He once snapped a golf club in two, over the back of his neck. If Pate double-bogeyed the first hole, his tirades could last an entire day.

title: Judge Limits City's Power to Take Away Newsstand Licenses
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that new regulations for city newsstands give the Giuliani administration too much latitude in revoking an operator's license.

title: Governor Pataki and Gun Control
description: Last week's deadly school massacre in Oregon should make it harder for the nation's lawmakers to ignore the urgent problem of children having easy access to guns and ammunition. That certainly ought to be the case in New York State, where pending legislation to keep loaded guns out of the hands of youngsters presents the Legislature and Gov. George Pataki with a test of political and moral leadership.

title: Treating Shareholders Like Workers
description: Is it fair that union leaders can give union money to politicians who may or may not be supported by individual union members? That is the question posed by Proposition 226, a California budget initiative being voted on in the primary election next Tuesday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Shopping for a Recovery; In Japan, Housewives Seen as Key to Reviving Economy
description: Naomi Ueda considered buying a new air-conditioner this spring. The one she has is 20 years old, and while it still works, she thought she could save a few yen on electricity with a more efficient model.

title: National News Briefs; Nursing Home Company Fails in Defamation Suit
description: A Federal judge in Pittsburgh has dismissed a defamation lawsuit that Beverly Enterprises, the nation's largest nursing home company, brought against a Cornell University professor of labor relations who said the company was ''one of the nation's most notorious labor law violators.''

title: New Light on Wyeth's Outer and Inner Landscapes
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art might almost have written ''Give the guy a chance'' across the walls of its exhibition of Andrew Wyeth's landscapes.
