Its very title, ''Unknown Terrain,'' promises a fresh take on Mr. Wyeth's well-known oeuvre, which has for decades been wildly popular with the general public and largely disdained by the art world. The first wall text says ''new light'' will be shed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, HILDA
description: FRIEDMAN-Hilda. Fashion Designer and Professor of Fashion Design. Former Chairperson of the Apparel Design Department at Fashion Institute of Technology. Dear sister of Lee Zasloff. Loving aunt of Jeffrey and Todd Gross, Rudy, Jonathan and David Zasloff. Services Fri. 1 P.M. at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Sharks Sign Sutter To a New Contract
description: The San Jose Sharks signed their coach, Darryl Sutter, to a new contract, a reward for guiding the team to the playoffs in his first season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRADER, MARTIN
description: SCHRADER-Martin. Died peacefully on May 28th, surrounded by the family he created. Beloved husband of Ceil, adored father of Howard, Dan and Esther and blessed grandfather of Hannah and Gregory. Magazine publisher, writer, intellect, adventurer, creator, raconteur, Dad was a man of unparalleled energy and unstinting love. He built a life of extraodinary success, happiness and devotion to us all. Services today 12noon at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Croton, New York.

title: Metro Business; Company Settles Sex Harassment Case
description: A Long Island insurance brokerage company agreed yesterday to pay $1.2 million in damages to settle a case brought in behalf of female employees who complained that they were fondled and propositioned in the office by a partner and a vice president, the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said.

title: Excerpts From Counsel's Court Plea on Clinton Appeal
description: Following are excerpts from a petition filed with the Supreme Court by the independent counsel's office seeking a quick review of a White House appeal of a Federal court decision that compelled grand jury testimony by two Presidential aides who had sought to invoke executive privilege:

title: Open Admissions Cheats Best Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMMANEY, JOHN J.
description: TOMMANEY-John J. Of New York City, Stockbridge, MA and Bellair, FL. May 23, 1998. He was born in Albany, N.Y. on August 25, 1920. Mr. Tommaney attended All Hallows and Fordham University and received his Jurist Doctorate from Columbia Law School. He proudly served in the 10th Mountain Division in Italy during WW II. He was a practicing attorney. He began his legal career at Van Voorst, Siegal & Smith and, most recently, was of counsel to Lane & Mittendorf. Her served on numerous boards including philanthropic foundations and arts groups. He is survived by his wife Mary C. Tommaney, his son Peter, his daughter Liza and his grandchild Zachary T. Elardo. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the charity of your choice. A memorial will be held June 27th, 11AM at Epiphany Parish, 22nd St and 2nd Ave, NYC.

title: PAKISTAN, ANSWERING INDIA, CARRIES OUT NUCLEAR TESTS; CLINTON'S APPEAL REJECTED
description: Pakistan responded to India's nuclear tests on Thursday with underground nuclear tests of its own. Within hours, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif declared his country a ''nuclear power,'' fulfilling a secret plan made by a predecessor nearly 30 years ago that Pakistan would build an ''Islamic bomb.''

title: Florida Governor's Veto Challenges Sugar Growers on Everglades
description: Gov. Lawton Chiles today vetoed two bills backed by the Florida sugar industry that environmentalists had said could have crippled efforts to restore the Everglades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASLOW, LEWIS
description: MASLOW-Lewis. Of North Miami Beach. Passed away May 27, 1998 in his home. He is survived by daughter Linda Maslow of Arlington, VA. and son Bob Maslow of Brooklyn, NY; grandchildren Chelsea, Susan, Peter, Katy; sister Ruth Lewis. Services Monday in Florida. For information contact Riverside-Gordon, 1-800-759-1151.

title: Individuality and Poetry in Lives That May Be Short and Brutish
description: With the aplomb of a born post-modernist, the Guatemalan photographer Luis Gonzalez Palma has adapted Victorian portraiture and more recent post-modern photography for his own masterfully expressive work.

title: Two Agencies Make Acquisitions
description: Two agencies made acquisitions yesterday involving interactive advertising.

title: Gilkey and Baerga Add to Buzz in Mets' Dugout
description: The Mets' offense, according to Carlos Baerga, was becoming enlivened even before the arrival of Mike Piazza.

title: Moynihan's Lofty View Leaves Democrats Grumbling
description: The state's Democratic faithful had gathered this morning all primed for another day of partisan bashing of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Gov. George E. Pataki, buoyant talk of their party's revival and woeful predictions about life under Republican rule. Instead, they got an apocalyptic Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: Ketchum Expands Ethnic Operations
description: Ketchum Public Relations Worldwide in New York, part of Omnicom Group, expanded its ethnic communications operations yesterday by forming a unit in Atlanta to specialize in public relations campaigns aimed at black consumers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RETREATS. The price of crude oil fell for the first time in five days after an industry report showed an unexpected drop in gasoline demand last week, the start of the vacation season. July futures fell 14 cents, to $14.85 a barrel.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Yeltsin to Ask Western Help for Ruble as Markets Steady
description: As Russian financial markets steadied slightly after this week's record plunge, President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that he would call on Western leaders to help defend Russia's embattled ruble.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Roy Newell

title: BOWNE MAKES BID FOR DONNELLEY ENTERPRISES
description: The printing company Bowne & Company offered yesterday to buy Donnelley Enterprise Solutions Inc. for $21 a share, or about $105 million. Shares of Donnelley, an information management services company, rose $7.5625, or 57 percent, to $20.625, in Nasdaq trading. Donnelley Enterprise, based in Chicago, had 1997 revenue of $110 million. R. R. Donnelley & Sons, which owns 43 percent of the shares of Donnelley Enterprise, has agreed to tender its shares. Bowne & Company, based in New York, provides document preparation, printing and distribution services, as well as consulting and development services. It had revenue of $194.3 million in the quarter ended March 31.

title: In a revised campaign, American Business Press drops familiar faces in favor of anonymous eyes.
description: THE American Business Press is making sweeping changes in advertising efforts to try to build a broader buzz for the trade publications that are its members.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLEVENGER, JAMES LOGAN III.
description: CLEVENGER-James Logan III. A memorial service will be held at 11 A.M., Monday, June 1 in the James Madison Room of the Princeton Club, 15 West 43 Street, New York, New York.

title: Method Amid the Madness In Schoenberg's Textures
description: Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire'' always sounds strange. Its voice -- the voice of the soloist who declaims elegantly crafted nightmare poems in a manner between speech and song -- comes from somewhere unfamiliar, a place known only to this piece. The voice speaks of sexual obsession, cruelty and blasphemy, of lurid visions and black practical jokes. It does not seem to have heard of normal behavior, nor does it take the bizarre events and feelings it describes entirely seriously. A psychiatrist might want to describe it as the voice of a paranoid; and contrary to popular belief, there are not too many authentic psychotics among the characters presented to us by music and opera.

title: Yankees Fight Off Fatigue and Knock Off Red Sox
description: The Yankees played host to Boston at Yankee Stadium last night, and of course the bleachers filled and the 42,182 partisan voices had an edge to them. These are the Yankees, they are the Red Sox, and every baseball fan who cares understands the difference.

title: Whitman Helps Republicans in Ohio, Strengthened by String of Victories Back Home
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, making her first political foray outside New Jersey since her bruising re-election campaign last fall, came here today to help fill Republican Party coffers and bolster party candidates for statewide office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLICK, CORINNE
description: WALLICK-Corinne, of Manhasset, NY and Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of Sanders (Sandy) Wallick. Died suddenly on May 27. A loving mother of Steven and Don Schatzberg, a gentle, generous lady who gave of herself to the many causes she supported. Survived by her sister, Sue and Ted Kaskel, brother, George (Shirley) Loeb. Stepmother of Jimmy and Andrea Wallick, and Michelle & Steven Williams, sister-in-law Rhoda Lohre, and many nieces, nephews and grand-nieces and nephews. Services on Friday, May 29 at Riverside Nassau, 12 Noon.

title: Indonesian Students Resume Demonstrations in Capital
description: Students resumed their demonstrations in the capital today, gathering in a holiday mood outside the gates of the Parliament building to reject a new Government timetable for elections next year.

title: In Reversal, Theater Vows to Stage Play That Drew Threats
description: A week after saying it was removing from its fall schedule a play featuring a gay Jesus-like figure who has sex with his apostles, the Manhattan Theater Club reversed course yesterday and said it would stage the play as originally planned.

title: Wealthy Nations Cut Aid to Pakistan Over Nuclear Tests
description: In reactions that followed the relatively mild pattern of responses to nuclear tests conducted by India two weeks ago, Japan, Germany, Canada and Australia joined the United States today in taking action against Pakistan for going ahead with tests of its own.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Scent of Ink'

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CEFALU, LOUIE
description: CEFALU-Louie. 5/29/80-1/2/98. Happy 18th birthday. Our thoughts, prayers, tears and love are with you. We miss you so much. Say hi to grandpa. Mom, Dad, Alex and Grandma

title: Pippen's Added Punch Sends Pacers to the Edge
description: It was late in the rout. And by then, the two stars were resting as comfortably as a couple of retirees on a park bench.

title: Mariners' Big Lefty Part of Yankee Deal?
description: The Yankees possess baseball's best record, but they are looking for more. They have joined a handful of other teams in pursuing Randy Johnson, Seattle's 6-foot-10-inch All-Star pitcher.

title: Intel and Microsoft Face Differing Antitrust Paths
description: Lawyers for the Intel Corporation should be well acquainted with antitrust inquiries by the Federal Trade Commission -- a process different from the one followed in Justice Department antitrust cases -- because the commission has been investigating the microprocessor giant off and on throughout this decade.

title: Money, Fans, Players Keys to the New League
description: Now that NBC and Turner Sports have declared their intentions to form a new pro football league, all they must do is prove that America needs it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMOWITZ, BERNARD
description: HYMOWITZ-Bernard. Beloved husband of Judith and the late Ronnie. Loving father of Ira, Phillip and Fran Lerner; stepfather of Eric, Todd and Jonathan Sorrin; adored grandfather of Adam, Rachel, Samantha, Jason, Michelle, Elana, Joshua, Jacob, Aaron & Daniel; dear brother of Stanley. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 11:30 A.M., Friday.

title: DATA TRANSMISSION NETWORK CONSIDERS POSSIBLE SALE
description: The Data Transmission Network Corporation, an electronic news and information company, has hired Salomon Smith Barney to examine a possible sale of the company or other alternatives to bolster its share value. Options include a stock repurchase, recapitalization, acquisition, sale or merger, the Omaha-based company said yesterday. Its shares rose 56.25 cents yesterday, to $38.5625, in Nasdaq trading, giving the company a market capitalization of $438 million. The move comes two months after Data Transmission rejected an unsolicited bid of $36 to $41 a share from an investor group led by Jerrold Pressman. Data Transmission provides commodity news, quotes and market analysis to 160,000 subscribers in a variety of industries.

title: Starr Seeks Action
description: Moving for a quick resolution in his battle with the White House, the special prosecutor Kenneth W. Starr asked the Supreme Court to rule directly on an appeal of a lower court ruling denying privilege claims and compelling testimony by two of President Clinton's aides.

title: Lures, Not Worms: A Fish Story or Two
description: I am haunted by waters.

title: Sanctions Could Badly Bruise Fragile Pakistan
description: Fear of economic sanctions from the United States did not stop India from testing five nuclear devices two weeks ago, nor did it stop Pakistan from retaliating. Now, having promised to punish both nations, the Clinton Administration is uncertain how much pain it can inflict.

title: United Health To Acquire Humana Inc.
description: The United Healthcare Corporation, one of the nation's largest health insurers, agreed yesterday to buy Humana Inc. for $5.5 billion, further shrinking the number of competitors in the industry and narrowing the choices of managed-care plans for consumers.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Reg Butler

title: South Asian Arms Race: Reviving Dormant Fears of Nuclear War
description: In a matter of weeks, covert nuclear programs in India and Pakistan, rivals who have three times gone to war, have turned into an open nuclear arms race, raising alarms about what comes next -- and where.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, PEARL
description: KLEIN-Pearl. On May 28th, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jack P. Klein. Dear mother of Louise (Earl) Hodin and Anne (Lewis) Rothman. Adored grandmother of Roger, Stephen, Jason, Hilary and Jeffrey. Services today May 29th, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Doctor, Why Do I Keep Dreaming of Argentina?
description: When rush-hour traffic gets him down, Andres Cornejo pulls his taxicab over to the curb and opens his trunk to his collection of Sigmund Freud. His frustrations quickly melt away, he said, as he reads Freud's theories on dreams and the development of the infantile libido.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, EDWARD J.
description: HAMMOND-Edward J. To my esteemed friend and dearest companion. Winston and I miss you and wish you well. Ned Marshall and Winston Hammond

title: TAXI PANEL PASSES MUCH OF PACKAGE SOUGHT BY GIULIANI
description: Handing a major defeat to the taxi industry, the Taxi and Limousine Commission yesterday approved most of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's strict new regulations, including quadrupling insurance requirements, sharply increasing fines for cabbies and making it much easier for them to lose their licenses.

title: Kenneth Starr's P.R. Man
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Emmet Gowin

title: Investors Moved $24.5 Billion Into Stock Funds Last Month
description: United States investors pumped an estimated $24.5 billion into stock mutual funds in April, the highest monthly inflow since September.

title: Life or Death? More Yawns Than Passion
description: WHEN a killer named Eddie Lee Mays went to the Sing Sing electric chair on Aug. 15, 1963, becoming the last man executed by New York State, not a word about his death appeared in this newspaper. Even The Daily News, far more crime-oriented, ran only five short paragraphs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLER, CHAIM
description: SULLER-Chaim, died May 26, age 96, at Beth Israel Hospital. For many years co-editor of the Yiddish Morning Freiheit, journalist and teacher. Survived by his wife, Elsie; daughter, Dina Brey; grandchildren, David, Samantha and Isaac. Services Friday, May 29, 12 o'clock, at the Gramercy Chapels, 2nd Avenue and 10th Street, NY.

title: America Online In a Settlement
description: America Online Inc. agreed today to pay $2.6 million to 44 states to settle complaints that it misled consumers about fees and phone rates.

title: Kenneth Starr's P.R. Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer; No Place for Crybabies
description: The baby-boom generation is now looking down the gun barrel of 50 and worried about what to expect. At its request, I have gone ahead to scout the territory. This is what's up there:

title: Autos' Converters Cut Smog But Add to Global Warming
description: The catalytic converter, an invention that has sharply reduced smog from cars, has now become a significant and growing cause of global warming, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Thompson Partner Joins Harry Winston
description: The head of the De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. account at J. Walter Thompson New York is leaving to join Harry Winston Inc., the diamond and gem retailer in New York, in the new position of global marketing director for retail operations.

title: Open Admissions Cheats Best Students
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STERLING SOFTWARE INC., Dallas, agreed to acquire Mystech Associates Inc., Falls Church, Va., for $25 million in stock.

title: Byars's Task: Tutoring A Successor at Fullback
description: He said he desperately wants for the youngsters to make it. But Jets Coach Bill Parcells still can't give up on the veterans.

title: A Reluctant Editor but Ardent Lover
description: HERE BUT NOT HERE

title: George C. Dade Dies at 85; Fliers Inspired His Museum
description: George C. Dade, who as a boy on Long Island was so enthralled watching the pioneering giants of aviation take off from his front yard that he devoted much of his life to preserving memories of those early pilots and restoring some of their planes, died on Wednesday at a hospital near his home in Glen Head, N.Y. He was 85 and a founder of the Cradle of Aviation Museum at Mitchel Field in Uniondale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZETUNE, BARBARA
description: ZETUNE-Barbara. Of New York, NY. Born January 8, 1942. Died May 17, 1998. Memorial services at Cormaria in Sag Harbor, Long Island, on May 30, 1998 at 10 AM.

title: Image Is Believed to Be the First Of a Planet Beyond Solar System
description: After deciphering digitized pictures made by the Hubble Space Telescope last August, astronomers have reconstructed what they believe to be the first image ever captured of a planet outside our solar system.

title: ING Says Profit Rises 86.5% in Quarter
description: ING Groep N.V., the Dutch banking and insurance company, said yesterday that its profit jumped 86.5 percent in the first quarter, helped by recent acquisitions. ING said its first-quarter profit rose to 1.94 billion Dutch guilders ($966 million) from an adjusted 1.04 billion in the period a year earlier.

title: Amid More Upsets, Pierce Is Booed and Beaten
description: For the players who waited to get onto the courts and for the spectators who huddled beneath umbrellas through a three-hour rain delay today, another inhospitable day unfolded at the French Open. With the second round still incomplete, the tournament has already lost 11 of its 32 seeded players.

title: The U.S. Choice For Venice
description: Ann Hamilton, an installation and performance artist known for her use of beautiful materials, obsessive repetition and frequent references to the body, has been chosen to represent the United States at the next Venice Biennale.

title: The Subcontinent Goes Nuclear
description: Hitching nuclear weapons to the bristling hostility between India and Pakistan has long been a frightening prospect. It became a reality yesterday when Pakistan tested nuclear devices just two weeks after India did the same. The two nations have now achieved a fearful symmetry that, if managed carelessly, could produce a nuclear confrontation. To avoid that deadly result, Pakistan and India, with the help of the United States and other nations, must move immediately to limit their nuclear ambitions.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Re-election Struggle in Panama Could Affect Transfer of Canal
description: The slogan is blunt and emphatic, and it has begun appearing on glossy billboards and as crudely scrawled graffiti: ''No Re-election!'' Having decided to defy 95 years of tradition, President Ernesto Perez Balladares is encountering widespread opposition to his effort to amend the Panamanian Constitution so he can seek a second five-year term.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Arthur F. Mathews, 60, Lawyer And Expert in Securities Crime
description: Arthur F. Mathews, who helped build one of the country's leading legal practices dealing with securities enforcement and white collar crime, died on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 60.

title: Iznik Wares, Even Rarer Than Ming
description: If you were looking for a set of dishes in Constantinople in the 1500's and you went to the equivalent of Tiffany & Company, you would probably have bought Iznik wares, hand-painted plates that were all the rage. In their glory years, Iznik faience wares were as popular as Dutch Delft tiles, at least among the Ottoman sultans and princes.

title: A Private Nightmare In Days Without End
description: In the atmospheric Norwegian thriller ''Insomnia,'' two taciturn detectives arrive in midnight-sun territory to investigate a murder in a remote setting. Fog and endless daylight in northern Norway serve to heighten tensions that already run deep. Early in the film, a taut debut feature directed by Erik Skjold bjaerg, the investigator Jonas Engstrom (Stellan Skarsgard, of ''Breaking the Waves'' and ''Good Will Hunting') becomes complicit in the crime in ways he could not have anticipated, and his discreet paranoia sets the tone for the rest of this enveloping story. Engstrom makes a grievous misstep and spends the rest of the film trying to protect his secret.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Devices That Can Save Your Neck
description: AUTOMOBILE head restraints are good examples of how theory and practice sometimes diverge.

title: Yet Another Century of Faith?; Christianity's Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Clinton Counsel's Brief
description: Following are excerpts from a brief by the White House counsel, Charles F. C. Ruff, unsealed on Wednesday by Judge Norma Holloway Johnson of Federal District Court here, describing the effect that the investigation by the independent counsel's office has had on President Clinton and the White House staff:

title: A Man, a Plan, Ravioli: A Briefcase Gone Astray
description: ''Day at the Beach'' is about a lot of things. It is about love and loss and crime and guilt and youth and ambition. It is about the way comedy turns to tragedy in an instant and alters lives forever. But mostly it is about a man who yearns to make a movie.

title: Who's Happy, Anyway? Not That Many People, If They're Being Honest
description: Are you happy? That blunt little question will always be linked to the birth of cinema verite.

title: A Gantlet-Running Lewinsky Meets With the Investigators
description: In the rare glimpses of Monica S. Lewinsky over the last four months, she has alternately appeared confused, amused, becalmed and beleaguered.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Behind Antics, More Antics

title: Sports of The Times; A Bold New Venture For Moguls?
description: THOSE who know a dreadful blowout when they see one and went to sleep before halftime of the Chicago-Indiana playoff game on Wednesday night missed the grand announcement by Hannah Storm (and simultaneously on CNN): NBC and Turner Sports have decided to turn upfield on the option play and get back into the pro football business both networks were purportedly shut out of in the last National Football League television auction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, WILLIAM J.
description: KEATING-William J., 84. Of East Stroudsburg, PA. died Wednesday. Born in Brooklyn, graduate of Fordham Law School received Doctorate. Director of taxes at Ingersoll-Rand. Survived by wife, Gloria (Pflugfelder); sons, Mark Kenneth, William, Michael Patrick; daughters, Grace Colby Drury, Bridget, Katherine, and Kinnea; and four grandchildren. Services, Saturday, 9:00 AM, St. Matthew's R.C. Church, East Stroudsburg. Burial Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn. Clark Funeral Home, Stroudsburg, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRN, MARJORIE ANN.
description: BYRN-Marjorie Ann. Of Baldwin, N.Y., May 27, 1998. Beloved wife of Francis X. Byrn. Devoted mother of Maureen Gang, Virginia Nielsen, Barbara Farina, Robert Patrick and Thomas Byrn. Adored grandmother of Damien, Tristram, Spencer, Eric, Nicole, Michael and Gregory. Past President of AAUW Nassau County Chapter. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-10PM, at Weigand Bros Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Avenue, Baldwin. Funeral Mass on Saturday 9:45 AM at The Queen of the Most Holy Rosary Church, Roosevelt, New York. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, BEATRICE (BILLIE) JEFFE.
description: POLLACK-Beatrice (Billie) Jeffe. Died on May 24, 1998 in Cypress Creek, FL. Beloved wife of the late Stanley Pollack. Survived by her loving sister, Frieda Sherman of Santa Cruz, CA, brother Perry Jeffe of Santa Fe, NM, and their families.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEARNEY, RAYMOND
description: KEARNEY-Raymond. Of Tampa, FL, on May 6th. Formerly of Woodside and Peekskill. Father of Ray, Pam, Joanne and Dana. Brother of Marge Engelman, Florence and Edward, and the late John, William, Robert and James.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALSBERG, SUSAN J.
description: SALSBERG-Susan J. Beloved daughter of Edgar and Rosalind. Loving sister of John, David and Holly Newman. Aunt of Daniel and Nicholas. Services Monday, June 1st, 10AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend last Friday with an art review of ''Police Pictures: The Photograph as Evidence,'' at the Grey Art Gallery in Greenwich Village, misidentified a man in a Lone Ranger mask standing with J. Edgar Hoover. The picture was lent by the F.B.I., which supplied the identifications. The bureau said yesterday that while the man was not Clayton Moore, one of several actors who have portrayed the Lone Ranger, it had not yet determined his identity.

title: After an Anguished Phone Call, Clinton Penalizes the Pakistanis
description: After a futile midnight effort to stop Pakistan's nuclear tests, President Clinton grimly denounced them today as dangerously destabilizing and imposed penalties that could cost the Pakistanis billions.

title: A Conviction Ruled Unjust Leads to a Redemption
description: In the mug shot taken the day Betty Tyson was arrested in the strangulation death of a businessman, her hair is tangled and standing on end, her eyes sullen and her shoulders slumped. She was not a murderer, Ms. Tyson said then and says now, but she was a heroin addict and prostitute.

title: Jakarta Takes Over Big Bank After Run
description: The Government today took control of Bank Central Asia, one of the nation's largest private banks, after panicked customers withdrew large amounts, forcing the bank to borrow heavily from the Government.

title: Northeastern Surprises Cal
description: The University of California, the Pacific 10 champion, was upset but not eliminated as the national intercollegiate rowing championships began yesterday on the Cooper River in Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DROPS FURTHER. The Japanese currency fell again after Pakistan tested five nuclear bombs, adding to uncertainty in Asia. In New York, the dollar rose to 138.70 yen from 137.40, reaching its highest level since August 1991.

title: A 4-Year-Old Addresses Death
description: Small films sometimes seem more personal on small screens than they do in theaters. When the characters themselves are as small as they are in ''Ponette,'' intimacy becomes all the stronger. Released this week by Fox Lorber, the highly acclaimed French film, directed by Jacques Doillon, is so acutely focused that large-screen settings are more or less beside the point.

title: Young Heavyweight Packing a Mean Jab
description: Michael Grant never had a boxing idol when he was growing up. Never followed the sport that much. Thought he would be a big star in the National Football League.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Dancing Vision

title: India's Choice, and Pakistan's
description: To the rest of the world, Pakistan's decision to set off nuclear tests looks like an unfortunate but inevitable reaction to India's nuclear tests earlier this month. ''We had no choice left to us'' was how Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawiz Sharif, put it yesterday. But Pakistan did have a choice.

title: Iberian Tastes
description: When people think of the world's great cuisines, the food of the Iberian Peninsula does not often come to mind. But few cuisines are as deeply satisfying as Spain's and Portugal's, which are full of lusty, robust flavors. Here are 12 places to sample Spanish and Portuguese foods. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: First Drug Solely for Crohn's Disease Gets Panel's Backing
description: An advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration recommended today approval of the first drug specifically for Crohn's disease, an often debilitating bowel ailment that afflicts some 100,000 Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LENNARD, FLORENCE
description: LENNARD-Florence. In life, you were always there. It's been twelve years since you left-but you are still here. Everlasting love, Jules

title: Death Penalty Jury Is Told That Killer Showed Remorse
description: The first person convicted of capital murder under New York State's current death penalty law expressed an ''enormous amount of remorse'' for killing three people, a psychologist yesterday told a Brooklyn jury that is to decide whether the convicted man should be executed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIMBEL, NICHOLAS
description: GIMBEL-Nicholas. My good friend for more than twenty years. I already miss his wisdom and wit. Condolences to Amy and all of the children. Martin Askowitz

title: Starr Asks Supreme Court to Speed Process For Ruling on President's Privilege Claims
description: Pressing for a quick resolution in his battle with the White House, the independent counsel today asked the Supreme Court to put on an unusually fast track the privilege claims that President Clinton has asserted to block the testimony of two aides in the Lewinsky investigation.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on May 20 referred incorrectly to the United States Naval Academy's plan to change its training in the use of a sextant, which helps plot a ship's course by the angle of stars off the horizon. The Academy said yesterday that midshipmen would still learn how to use the device. But they will now feed its data into a computer to plot a course. A corrective article appears on page A17.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Passion and Reverence'

title: Residential Real Estate; A New Upscale Address: Near the Train Station
description: Betting that convenience to a rail line is an amenity that apartment and house hunters will want, builders in the suburbs are putting up high-priced developments within walking distance of train stations -- or even right next door.

title: Kenneth Starr's P.R. Man
description: To the Editor:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: At first glance there is little about Bellini to set it apart from the dozens of other chic, expensive Italian restaurants on the East Side. The airy white walls and tile floors are attractive but not particularly distinctive, and the menu is familiar to anybody who ever patronized Scarlatti or Lello. No surprise there: the chef is Lello Arpaia, who was chef and owner of those restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANNON, THOMAS F.
description: SHANNON-Thomas F. Sr. suddenly on May 21, 1998, age 66, husband of Martha Mead Shannon of Cape May, NJ (formerly of Manhatten, NY). Also survived by 3 sons- Todd, Christopher & Andrew Shannon, a brother Douglas Shannon & 4 grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a Funeral Mass Saturday 9AM at Our Lady Star of the Sea Church525 Washington Street, Cape May, NJ, Interment private. Blake-Doyle Funeral Home- Collingswood.

title: Explosion Kills A Man Sought In Bomb Case
description: A man who was wanted for questioning in a church bombing in Danville, Ill., was killed in an explosion in his garage this afternoon, the authorities said.

title: TAKING NAMES: A special report.; New Jersey's H.I.V. List: Valuable, and Still Secret
description: Inside a small locked room at the New Jersey Department of Health, a chain-link fence soars to the ceiling, encircling two chairs, a backup computer and a towering main computer. It is called the cage.

title: Showing Why a Rain Forest Matters
description: In a new permanent exhibition off the rotunda, the American Museum of Natural History has a surprise in store for visitors accustomed to its displays of South Sea cultures, vertebrate evolution and, of course, the dinosaurs of awesome splendor. No single category of life, not birds or mammals or reptiles, animates this show. No geographic boundaries or epochs of time restrict its scope.

title: Comedian Phil Hartman Is Shot to Death in His Home
description: Phil Hartman, the versatile comedian known for his roles on ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''Newsradio,'' was shot to death in his home this morning, apparently by his wife, who then took her own life as officers ushered the couple's two children from the house, the police said.

title: Murder Charges Revived in '66 Killing
description: Thirty-two years after Molotov cocktails lighted up a frosty Mississippi night, the authorities here arrested three aging Klansmen today and revived charges against them in the 1966 killing of Vernon F. Dahmer Sr., one of this state's most revered civil rights leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, SAMUEL ROBERTSON.
description: JOHNSON-Samuel Robertson. Of Newton, May 27, 1998. Samuel Robertson Johnson. Born on February 14, 1993. Son of Charlie and Kate (Ross) Johnson. Brother of Teddy Johnson. Grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Rockefeller of Greenwich, CT., Mr. and Mrs. Robertson Lee Johnson of Portland, OR. and the late Henry L. Ross and Dorothy M. Johnson. Attended the Second Church Nursery School Newton. Services will be held in the Trinity Church Copley Square Boston on Saturday, May 30, 9:30 A.M. Followed by a private burial. In lieu of flowers remembrances may be made to the Sam Johnson Fund C/O The Floating Children's Cancer Center at New England Medical Center, 750 Washington Street, Boston, MA. 02111. For information the J.S. Waterman & Sons and Eastman Waring Funeral Service 495 Commonwealth Ave. (Kenmore Square), Boston. (617) 536-4110.

title: Coca-Cola Asks the Dismissal Of Federal Suit Filed by Pepsi
description: Lawyers for the Coca-Cola Company filed a motion yesterday to dismiss a lawsuit brought by Pepsico Inc. earlier this month, in which Pepsi, breathing new fire into the cola wars, contends that Coke unfairly pressed food-service distributors to provide only Coke to restaurants, theater chains, stadiums and other places that serve what the industry calls fountain soft drinks.

title: Call for Investigation Renewed At Service for James Earl Ray
description: A group of people whose alliance would have seemed shocking when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was shot to death 30 years ago gathered today in a small, mostly black church here for a memorial service honoring James Earl Ray, the man who confessed to Dr. King's assassination, and later recanted.

title: Aides Differ on Toll That Starr Inquiry Has on Clinton
description: Since January, when accusations of an affair with a former intern were first leveled against President Clinton, the White House has cultivated an Olympian aura of imperviousness to the ensuing bombardment of questions, bawdy televised jokes and widely publicized prosecutorial suspicions.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Germany Pardons en Masse Thousands Persecuted by Nazis
description: Years after the death of many of its likely beneficiaries, a mass pardon was approved today by the German Parliament for hundreds of thousands of people punished unjustly by Nazi courts, military tribunals and medical panels.

title: Privilege Issue Raised Twice In Civil Case
description: The White House sought to invoke executive privilege on at least two occasions to avoid answering questions in a civil lawsuit brought by a critic of President Clinton, according to a judicial opinion released today.

title: Miami Official Is Arrested In Election Fraud Inquiry
description: A Miami City Commissioner already under Federal indictment on charges of money laundering and mortgage fraud was arrested today on charges of fabricating evidence during a state investigation of the widespread voter fraud that invalidated Miami's city elections last November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, ETHEL F.
description: SIMON-Ethel F. On May 15th. Very much loved wife of Leonard, devoted mother of son, David Jeffrey, and daughter, Judith Fern, cherished grandmother of Alexander Max and Marissa Fawn. An absolutely beautiful person with an army of caring friends and relatives.

title: 3 Democrats In Senate Race Go to Primary
description: State Democratic leaders agreed today to put all three party candidates for Senate -- Charles E. Schumer, Geraldine A. Ferraro and Mark Green -- on the Sept. 15 primary ballot. The decision came after an unexpectedly tense contest that suggested growing support for Mr. Schumer, and some concern about Ms. Ferraro, among party officials.

title: Lilly Announces Stock Buyback
description: Out to rouse some enthusiasm along Wall Street, Eli Lilly & Company announced yesterday that it would buy back $2 billion worth of its stock before year-end and increase revenues by developing new uses for some existing drugs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Haunted by Hope and Regret on Eternal Playback
description: He's Krapp, all right: the white hair, arranged like errant strands of cotton candy; the scarlet nose, evidence of a requited love of the bottle; the shuffling feet, the frantic hands and, of course, the haunted, probing eyes, fixed on that ancient tape recorder and the plastic spools that safeguard the secrets of a solitary life.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about a lawsuit filed by 20 states against the Microsoft Corporation misidentified the antitrust officials who contend that the company's pricing policies for its Office suite of programs leave computer makers with the practical choice of installing the software on all their computers or none. They are the states' attorneys general, not staff members of the Justice Department.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MCI to Sell Internet Unit Amid Chill in Merger Review

title: FIRST HAWAIIAN TO BUY BANCWEST IN STOCK SWAP
description: First Hawaiian Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the BancWest Corporation in a stock swap valued at $971 million. The combined regional bank company, to be known as BancWest, would have $14 billion in deposits and more than 200 branches in five Western states and in Guam and Saipan. First Hawaiian, is the parent company of First Hawaiian Bank, Hawaii's oldest bank, and of Pacific One Bank in the Pacific Northwest. BancWest is the parent company of Bank of the West, California's fifth-largest bank. BancWest is wholly owned by Banque Nationale de Paris, France's second-largest banking company. Under the terms of the deal, Banque Nationale will receive about 25.9 million class A shares of First Hawaiian stock in a tax-free exchange. The deal was announced after the stock market closed; earlier, First Hawaiian shares closed at $37.50, up 75 cents.

title: Head of German Web Sentenced for Pornography
description: A judge in Bavaria sentenced the former head of Compuserve Deutschland to two years in jail on charges of spreading pornography, but suspended the sentence.

title: Fire Kills 200 Animals At Cape May County Zoo
description: More than 200 animals died after the reptile house of the Cape May County Zoo burned to the ground early yesterday morning, zoo officials said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 3 about the indictment of William Hamilton, the teamsters' former political director, misidentified the person who sent a memo in June 1996 requesting that the teamsters contribute $250,000 to state Democratic parties. According to the indictment, the memo was sent by the former finance director of the Clinton-Gore campaign. That person was Laura Hartigan, not Terence McAuliffe. (Mr. McAuliffe was the campaign's former finance chairman.)

title: Businessmen Accused In $115 Million Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors indicted two Brooklyn businessmen yesterday on charges that they carried out a scheme to defraud a bank of $115 million through illegal accounting practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARR, FLORENCE LINCOLN.
description: FARR-Florence Lincoln. Florence Lincoln Farr died on May 26, 1998 at her New York home. Born in New York City in 1897, the daughter of Frederic Walker and Philena Prentice Lincoln, she was the mother of William Rockefeller and Elsie Rockefeller Proxmire McMillin, both of whom have died, and surviving children Frederic Lincoln Rockefeller, Florence Sloan DeVecchi, and Anne Sloan Morrison. She attended Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Connecticut, married William A. Rockefeller in 1918 and following their divorce married George A. Sloan, President of the Cotton Textile Institute, Chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Association and at the time of his death in 1955 President of the International Chamber of Commerce. In 1959 she married H. Bartow Farr, partner in the law firm Wilke Farr & Gallagher. He died in 1972. She served on the Board of the Eastside Settlement House, the Stepney Camp, and the Colony Club. She leaves 21 grandchildren and 32 great grandchildren. Funeral services will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to Miss Porter's School.

title: BankBoston Deal Seen for BankAmerica Securities Unit
description: After weeks of negotiations, the BankBoston Corporation is close to buying BankAmerica Robertson Stephens Inc., a San Francisco securities firm, from the BankAmerica Corporation for about $800 million, executives at the two firms said yesterday.

title: Strong Dollar and Woes Abroad Drop Long Bond Yield to 5.82%
description: Treasury securities rose yesterday, pushing long-term yields to nearly two-month lows, in a rally propelled by financial turmoil in Russia and much of Asia and the rising value of the dollar.

title: Yet Another Century of Faith?; Religions That Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: New Video Releases
description: Oscar and Lucinda

title: Mr. Right Finally Finds A True Love: Plain Dwayne
description: Once upon a time, Hollywood cranked out mediocre romantic comedies about Mr. Right and his best pal, Plain Jane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODIG, RICHARD DIRAN,
description: BODIG-Richard Diran, 75. Died unexpectedly on May 26. Beloved husband of Joyce and loving father of Christian and Paul. A person of rare wit, sensitivity and wisdom, he enriched the world around him. Memorial service at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue, Tuesday, June 2, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to the Viola Da Gamba Society of America, C/O Ken Perlow, 131 South Humphry Avenue, Oak Park, IL. 60302, are appreciated.

title: Explosion Is Detected By U.S. Scientists
description: A lone nuclear signal from deep beneath the earth in Pakistan was detected by the global network of seismometers that track earthquakes and underground atomic tests, American scientists said yesterday.

title: Denmark Cuts Rates In Key Areas
description: Denmark lowered all its key interest rates by 25 basis points yesterday as the krone strengthened after the country's approval on Thursday of a treaty extending the European Union's powers. The repurchase rate and certificate of deposit rates were lowered to 4 percent and the discount, deposit and folio rates were lowered to 3.75 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODIG, RICHARD
description: BODIG-Richard. Aston Magna notes with great sadness the passing of Richard Bodig, a long-time member of its Board. A music lover in the purest and most profound sense, and a consummate gentleman, his contributions to Aston Magna were many and important. His intellect, gentleness, decency and good, common sense will be sorely missed by all who were privileged to know him. Board of Directors Aston Magna Foundation for Music and the Humanities, Inc.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC., a producer of plastics-processing machinery, bought Autojectors Inc., an Indiana manufacturer of injection molding machinery for the medical, electrical and automotive industries. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Tax Reform Spells Relief for Many
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Slump, Ending Worst Month Since October

title: A Big New Name In Accounting
description: Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand L.L.P. said yesterday that the name of their combined company, the world's biggest accounting firm, will be PricewaterhouseCoopers. The new name will take effect on July 1.

title: Man at Airport Is Held In False Bomb Claim
description: A man waiting to board a Continental Airlines jet at Newark International Airport yesterday told the security officials that he had a bomb and a gun in his luggage, but a search of the man's carry-on luggage and of all 66 bags on the flight turned up no weapons or explosives, the authorities said.

title: Commerzbank Says Profits Rose 16.7%
description: Commerzbank A.G., Germany's third-largest publicly traded bank, said yesterday that its first-quarter pretax profit rose 16.7 percent, more than analysts expected, led by gains in interest and commission income. Pretax profit rose to 962 million marks ($539 million) from 824 million marks a year earlier, based on ''very tentative'' first-quarter risk provisions of 300 million marks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a Federal judge's decision on executive privilege misstated the nature of grand jury testimony by Sidney Blumenthal, an adviser to President Clinton. Mr. Blumenthal has publicly said that while he declined to answer questions about his conversations with Hillary Rodham Clinton, he did respond to those about his dealings with journalists.

title: Clinton Meets Delegation From Kosovo Seeking Talks
description: President Clinton met today with ethnic Albanian leaders from the Serbian province of Kosovo who favor a negotiated solution to their conflict with the Serbian Government in Belgrade.

title: Metrocard for Lefties
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Opposes Plan For School Transfers
description: The State Senate has voted to block a proposal by the State Department of Education to allow students to transfer to schools outside their district without the consent of the schools they would transfer to.

title: Shaped by a Painful Past, Secret Service Director Fights Required Testimony
description: Two demons haunt Lewis C. Merletti, the director of the United States Secret Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLIGAN, JOHN PHILIP III
description: GILLIGAN-John Philip III. 67. Died May 23. Survived by his brothers, James of Cambridge, MA., and Mike of Garrison, NY and his 3 nephews, Jonathan, Timothy and Christopher Gilligan. Visiting 13:30PM Saturday, May 30 at Morehead-McLain-Gallaher, 424 West 51st Street. Services Saturday, May 30 at 5PM, Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46 Street.

title: INSIDE
description: White House Deadline

title: McCaughey Ross Fires Manager, Unsettling Campaign
description: Two days after scoring what many Democrats viewed as a major strategic victory at the Democratic State Convention, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, a candidate for governor, fired her campaign manager yesterday, unsettling her campaign as other staffers threatened to walk out the door.

title: Taxi Reform Is Just a Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: The Modern Paper Chase
description: Dear College Senior:

title: Sports of The Times; As Expected, Rodman Does What's Unexpected
description: DENNIS RODMAN, madly tattooed and polychromatically thatched, is often an eyeful, sometimes an earful, but always a handful. For the opponent as well as for his own team, the ever-patient, ever-prodigious Bulls. And in the Eastern Conference playoff finals against Indiana, Rodman has, as expected, been a significant factor, although not always in expected ways, which fits the image.

title: CUNY's New Standards Strengthen Its Degrees; 'Proficiency' Tests?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cone Keeps Cool And Runs Follow For the Yankees
description: David Cone allowed a titanic 406-foot homer to Reggie Jefferson on his fourth pitch of the game last night. So what? Cone stayed calm. He knew, just as everyone else at soggy Yankee Stadium knew, that his pitching opponent, Derek Lowe, would have a difficult time suppressing the Yankees. Every other pitcher does. Why should Lowe be any different?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRISTOL, DOROTHEA T.
description: BRISTOL-Dorothea T. Formerly of Summit, NJ, on May 23, 1998 in Scottsdale, AZ, at 70. Survived by sons, Brian T. of New York, NY; Sanford A. of Summit, NJ; daughters, Pamela W. of Princeton, NJ, Madeline B. Kuckel of Clinton, NJ; sister, Margaret T. McIndoe of Winchester, MA; 7 grandchildren. Memorial service Monday, June 1 at 10 A.M. at Messinger Mortuary Chapel, Scottsdale, AZ. Family suggests contributions to The Union Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue, Schenectady, New York 12305, Planned Parenthood, 5651 N. 7th Street, Phoenix, AZ 85014, or Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower, Phoenix, AZ. 85014.

title: A Spelling Champion for All Jamaicans; 12-Year-Old From Kingston Is a Hero for Winning in Washington
description: Suddenly, Jamaica has a new hero: a 12-year-old girl from Kingston with a winsome smile and steely determination whose David vs. Goliath victory at the National Spelling Bee has enthralled Jamaicans both on the island and in the large immigrant community in New York City.

title: Panicking Over Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Risky Business; A Set Fee for Each Patient Gives Doctors More Control and More of a Financial Stake
description: Even as a new Government-financed study raises questions about an increasingly popular way of paying for health services, many doctors and hospitals in New York City and a number of other big cities are embracing it. And while this form of managed care -- known as capitation -- gives health care providers more control, it also carries with it more financial risk.

title: Mother Arraigned in Starved Baby's Death
description: A 21-year-old mother was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court on charges that she failed to properly nourish her baby daughter, who later died of malnutrition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHRINGER, HAROLD
description: OHRINGER-Harold. The Board of Governers and Members of Brae Burn Country Club record with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Harold Ohringer. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his entire family. Leon Fassler, President Kenneth Auerbach, Secretary

title: Share of Lead Earns Mattiace a Break From His Anxiety
description: Today's superb round of golf lifted Len Mattiace's spirits, if only temporarily.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: LUMBER FALLS 3.5 PERCENT. Prices weakened to the lowest since January 1996 because of sharply reduced demand for American wood products in Asia. July contracts fell $10 per 1,000 board feet, to $272.40.

title: An Experiment in Putting Broadway on Average Americans' TV Screens
description: Faith Daniels moved across the Broadway Theater's darkened stage into a white circle of light, then beamed into the glass eye of a television camera a few feet in front of her. ''Millions of people come through Broadway theaters every year,'' she said just as thunderous pounding erupted from somewhere in the back of the theater. ''Cut,'' the director yelled. ''What is that noise?''

title: Russian Qualifier Sends Defending Champion Home
description: Unable to re-create the wild ride he took to the winner's circle last year as an unsung, unshaven, unseeded surf bum from Brazil, Gustavo Kuerten had his title defense nipped in the bud this afternoon by Marat Safin, a towering Russian who seems to have selected the Terminator and Godzilla as performance role models.

title: Race Track a Victim of Competition From Casinos
description: After the second race today at the Atlantic City Race Course, the noisiest creatures in the grandstand were some sparrows chirping in the rafters. Jack Klein, a 71-year-old carpenter and loyal track patron for a half century, sat alone in the mezzanine, a solitary figure in a sea of orange and yellow seats.

title: Ending an Era, ABC News Chief Relinquishes Control
description: An era ended yesterday, when Roone Arledge, who has reigned over ABC News for 21 years -- longer than any other news executive in television history -- announced he would turn over leadership to the division's president, David Westin, starting on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FONSECA, GONZALO
description: FONSECA-Gonzalo. A memorial for Gonzalo Fonseca, Monday June 1, 6 P.M., at the Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, NY.

title: Japan Airlines Expects A Profit in 1998
description: The Japan Airlines Company, Japan's largest airline, said yesterday that it expected to show a profit in the current fiscal year, after posting wider losses in the second half. The company, the world's sixth-largest airline, indicated a net loss of 114.3 billion yen ($824.3 million) for the six months ended March 31, compared with a loss of 11.8 billion yen a year earlier. The earnings were derived by calculating the difference between the company's first-half and full-year figures. Sales fell 1.5 percent, to 586 billion yen from 595 billion yen.

title: SUHARTO FORTUNE DRAWING NEW FIRE
description: Attacks intensified on the Suharto family today as two of former President Suharto's relatives were forced out of their positions and the new Government announced several measures aimed at curbing the economic favoritism that allowed the family's fortunes to flourish.

title: CUNY's New Standards Strengthen Its Degrees; Large Class Size
description: To the Editor:

title: Jurors in Death Penalty Case Hear of Murderer's Heroism
description: A New York City correction officer yesterday told jurors who are considering whether Darrel K. Harris should be sentenced to death for the murders of three people in a Brooklyn social club that Mr. Harris was once a hero, saving his life by throwing his body over the unconscious officer during a jail riot.

title: Debate Grows Over Efforts To End Parole
description: The fatal shooting of a New York City police officer by a drug dealer on parole this week has intensified the already fierce battle between Democrats and Republicans over ending parole for first-time violent felons.

title: Wake-Up Call: Truisms Of U.S. Policy Totter
description: Several of the hopes and assumptions of the post-cold-war era have been shaken by this month's momentous events in Asia. The collapse of President Suharto's rule in Indonesia and the detonation of nuclear devices by India and Pakistan has forced the rethinking in Washington and other Western capitals of ideas that had come to be policy truisms.

title: State Police Commissioner Quits After 5 Months; Scientist to Replace Him
description: Gov. John G. Rowland announced today that his third police commissioner, John A. Connelly, was resigning and that he intended to replace him with Dr. Henry C. Lee, a leading forensic scientist whose expert testimony helped to acquit O. J. Simpson and William Kennedy Smith.

title: But Who'll Mock the Talk Shows Now?
description: Johnny Carson's famous farewell from the ''Tonight'' show provides the perfect inspiration for the hilarious final episode of ''The Larry Sanders Show,'' whose affection for show business is only surpassed by its satire of all those outsize egos. Among the burning questions for the fictional ''Sanders'' and its last show-within-a-show: who will sing goodbye to Larry as Bette Midler did to Johnny? ''I thought I was your Bette Midler,'' the middle-age rocker Tom Petty complains before leaping into a fistfight with the country singer Clint Black.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about a new book, ''Barbarians Led by Bill Gates: Microsoft From the Inside,'' misattributed a quotation about Mr. Gates. The comment, ''It's hard enough to control Gates, much less your daughter,'' was made by the book's co-author, Jennifer Edstrom, not by her mother, Pam Edstrom, a public relations executive who has worked with Microsoft.

title: F.T.C. Clears Merger Path For Publishers
description: The planned merger of Bantam Doubleday Dell and Random House, which would produce the largest publisher of English-language trade books in the world, can proceed without further investigation by antitrust regulators at the Federal Trade Commission, a commission spokeswoman announced yesterday.

title: Gerber Says Baby Food Was Not Tainted
description: A Federal investigation has determined that jars of Gerber baby food recalled on Wednesday from a Shop-Rite supermarket here were not tampered with, company officials said yesterday.

title: The Hits Just Keep On Coming for the Mets
description: Everyone knew the Mets could pitch and play defense. But on offensive, where they had struggled so often this season, they are suddenly hapless no more. On the contrary, ever since Mike Piazza's arrival from Florida one week ago, this team has looked like a Big Met Machine.

title: Tackling Tobacco
description: Lost in the speculation that Congress might not pass any tobacco legislation this session is the simple fact that it doesn't really matter if a bill is approved or not. If the goal is to hobble Big Tobacco, the states have already proved that they can do the job.

title: About New York; History Moves A Professor To Protest
description: WHILE the trustees of the City University of New York debated the future of remediation on Tuesday, Renate Bridenthal took a stand by getting on her knees. It was not quite an act of surrender, although it had a pleading touch. Ms. Bridenthal, a history professor at Brooklyn College, joined teachers and students blocking the street outside CUNY headquarters to protest what they saw as an attack on the institution, which nurtured her as a student and employed her as an educator.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN SKIDS TO A 7-YEAR LOW. The Japanese currency dropped again on news of record unemployment in Japan. The dollar traded as high as 139.25 yen before settling in New York at 138.90 yen, up from 138.70.

title: City Told to Improve Transit for Disabled
description: A Federal transportation agency has told New York City Transit that its service that provides door-to-door rides to disabled people around the city must be improved.

title: BANKBOSTON IN DEAL FOR BANKAMERICA UNIT
description: Confirming widespread recent rumors, the BankBoston Corporation announced yesterday that it would pay $800 million for the BankAmerica Corporation's securities unit, Robertson Stephens. BankBoston, the second-largest bank in New England, will pay $400 million in cash to BankAmerica and put $400 million in a pool to persuade the firm's partners and key employees to remain after the sale. The pool will consist of $300 million in cash to be paid over three and a half years and $100 million of stock options. Robertson Stephens, which sold itself to BankAmerica last year for $540 million, adds stock underwriting to the corporate financing that BankBoston offers clients. BankAmerica will keep the firm's money-management and debt underwriting businesses.

title: Beliefs; A century ago, in what is now Chisinau, hundreds fell victim to a pogrom. Yesterday, a day of healing, Christians and Jews remembered.
description: Before Kristallnacht, there was Kishinev.

title: Bilingual Education Is Facing Push Toward Abandonment
description: Bilingual education, once widely hailed as a humane and sound method of immigrant assimilation, has fallen into disfavor, disparaged as a bureaucratic boondoggle, even by many of the people it was primarily designed to serve: the nation's increasing Hispanic minority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, RENEE
description: GREENBERG-Renee. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with profound sorrow the death of Renee Greenberg, a very special lady whose life was filled with achievement. We extend our sincere sympathy to her devoted and loving husband, Irving, valued and respected member of the Home's extended family, her children and grandchildren. We hope that your loving memories of Renee will help to ease your sorrow during this time of sadness. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: One of Jefferson's Enigmas, So Finally the F.B.I. Steps In
description: For two centuries, scholars have argued over Thomas Jefferson's views on religion, especially as stated in a famous letter he wrote in 1802. Now the Federal Bureau of Investigation has helped solve that particular puzzle.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I kept seeing kids doing poorly in the upper grades after they had gone through bilingual education. There was no transition to English.''

title: Red Wings Hold Off Late Flurry By Stars
description: Too much too soon almost ruined the party for the Detroit Red Wings and their fans tonight in a loud, crowded Joe Louis Arena. After taking an early four-goal lead and seeing it cut to one, the Wings survived for a 5-3 victory over the Dallas Stars in Game 3 of the Western Conference finals of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

title: Campaign Upheaval
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross fired her campaign manager yesterday, unsettling her campaign for governor and causing some of her staff members to threaten to quit.

title: LEADERS IN INDIA AND IN PAKISTAN TONE DOWN CRISIS
description: A day after Pakistan matched India by setting off its own underground nuclear tests, both nations began talking of new arrangements that would stabilize their rivalry and minimize the risk of war.

title: Martin H. Schrader, 73, Magazine Publisher
description: Martin H. Schrader, a former publisher at three Hearst magazines, died on Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. Mr. Schrader, a resident of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was 73.

title: Ex-Trooper Testifies Against Brawley Plaintiff
description: A former state trooper serving time for robbery and conspiracy to commit murder testified yesterday for the defense in the Tawana Brawley defamation case, saying that Steven A. Pagones had been with other men in the area where Ms. Brawley was on the night she disappeared.

title: In Buying We Trust; The Foundation of U.S. Consumerism Was Laid in the 18th Century
description: ''A penny saved is a penny earned'' and Benjamin Franklin's other homespun exhortations may stir nostalgia for an earlier age when habits of frugality and thrift are thought to have been more deeply ingrained in the American character.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINATRA, FRANCIS ALBERT, PH.D.
description: SINATRA-Francis Albert, Ph.D.; '85 Hon. D. Eng; Stevens Institute of Technology. On this Stevens Alumni weekend, alumni mourn the recent death of Frank, our fellow alumnus, and are thankful for his good works for Stevens. Guys of '53

title: Parade Ground Likely Challenger In Belmont Stakes
description: One week before the Belmont Stakes, nine colts appear ready to challenge Real Quiet in his bid to become the 12th horse to sweep the Triple Crown. The ninth, whose trainer says he is ''leaning strongly'' toward running, is Parade Ground, who has raced five times in New York and who ran third last Sunday in the Peter Pan Stakes.

title: Sanctuary Lost: Hong Kong Can't Hide From Asia's Woes
description: For the last year, as one thriving Asian economy after another caught a chill, this former British colony has seemed like the region's healthiest outpost. Today, though, Hong Kong acknowledged that it had come down with a full-blown case of the Asian economic flu.

title: CASTLE HARLAN SELLS INTEREST IN U.S. SYNTHETIC
description: Castle Harlan Inc. sold its majority interest in the U.S. Synthetic Corporation to investment funds controlled by the Boston-based Bain Capital Inc. for $165 million. Castle Harlan, a New York merchant bank, said U.S. Synthetic, based in Orem, Utah, was a maker of synthetic diamonds used in oil and gas drill bits. Synthetic drill bits have increasingly been replacing traditional tungsten bits in the marketplace. U.S. Synthetic's management will retain a 40 percent stake in the company. Castle Harlan Partners II L.P., a private equity fund managed by Castle Harlan, acquired U.S. Synthetic in February 1997 in a transaction valued at about $60 million.

title: Conviction Set Aside, but in Prison for Life
description: The life sentence, like a hand on his chest, pressed harder at night. When the lights died in the cellblock, the youngest serial killer in Alabama history would discard the murderer's persona that gave him status, tell himself he was innocent, and plan his escapes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DORF, PHIL AND MIKEY
description: DORF-Phil and Mikey. Ever in our hearts, with love and longing. Nathalie and Family

title: An Era Ends at ABC
description: Roone Arledge, who has run ABC News for 21 years, longer than any other chief news executive in television, is stepping down. Page A6.

title: Torre Hurls a Sinker At a Deal for Johnson
description: The possibility of seeing Randy Johnson pitch for the Yankees has seemingly depreciated. Both General Manager Brian Cashman and Manager Joe Torre have expressed doubt about the likelihood and the wisdom of making such a deal with the Seattle Mariners, and the two teams did not speak about Johnson yesterday.

title: Safety in National Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. FILTER ANNOUNCES FULLMAN INTERNATIONAL TAKEOVER
description: The U.S. Filter Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Fullman International Inc. for an undisclosed price, expanding its industrial piping business. U.S. Filter, a provider of water and waste-water-treatment systems, said that the closely held Fullman was one of the largest United States installers of process piping systems, which are used to carry high-purity water, chemicals and gases. Fullman, based in Portland, Ore., has yearly sales of more than $130 million. Fullman will join Kinetics Group Inc., acquired earlier this year, as part of U.S. Filter's industrial products and services group, which is expected to generate about $600 million in annual revenue.

title: Johnson to Call It Quits After Coming Season
description: Pepper Johnson made a retirement announcement today, and he did it with his usual style and sensitivity.

title: CUNY's New Standards Strengthen Its Degrees; Let Parents Be Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, SIMON D.
description: STRAUSS-Simon D. The Board, staff and clients of The Women's Prison Association and Home mourn the passing of a loyal friend who will always be remembered with gratitude and affection. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and love to his wife Janet McCloskey Robbins Strauss, former Board member and past president of WPA. Catherine D. Pradie, President Ann L. Jacobs, Exec Director

title: Gucheng Journal; In China's Countryside, It Is Time to Grow Rich
description: A peasant's life was bleak here 25 years ago toiling on one of the huge communal farms of Mao's China. Roused by a bell often before dawn, commune members gathered to receive work assignments from the team leader to earn points for food. The work was backbreaking. Food was scarce and slogans were plentiful. Luxuries like tea and prerolled cigarettes were reserved for Communist Party cadres.

title: Tax Reform Spells Relief for Many
description: To the Editor:

title: British Dairy Company Ends Takeover Talks
description: Unigate P.L.C., the British dairy company, said yesterday that it had called off talks with Hillsdown Holdings P.L.C. on a possible $:1.59 billion ($2.6 billion) takeover of the British food and home building company.

title: EMERGING COMMUNICATIONS RECEIVES BUYOUT OFFER
description: Emerging Communications said yesterday that it had received a buyout offer of $9.125 a share in cash, about $100 million, from its chairman and executive, Jeffrey Prosser, who plans to take the telecommunications company private. Emerging Communications, based in St. Croix in the United States Virgin Islands, said Mr. Prosser was the controlling stockholder of the company, which owns the Virgin Island Telephone Corporation. The company's shares jumped $1.9375 each, or 27 percent, to $8.9375, on the American Stock Exchange. Emerging Communications was created Dec. 30, when it spun off from Atlantic Tele-Network Inc.

title: High Court Gives Clinton Deadline to Reply to Starr's Motion
description: The Supreme Court ordered the White House today to respond by Monday afternoon to a request by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, to speed up dramatically consideration of privilege claims by President Clinton.

title: Aquariums for Curious
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan's Catch-22
description: Ten days ago, in a long session with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, I found him sobered and deeply anguished by the choices before him.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the New York State Democratic Convention referred incorrectly to the status of Evan A. Davis, a candidate for attorney general. While he removed himself from the balloting, he is trying to petition for a spot in the September primary; he did not withdraw from the race.

title: Taxi Vote's Aftermath
description: After seven hours of impassioned complaints from cabdrivers and owners on Thursday, the Taxi and Limousine Commission retreated into secret session to decide its vote on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new safety rules.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about the arms race between India and Pakistan referred incompletely to the sources of $4 billion in aid to North Korea to end its nuclear weapons program. The major donors included South Korea, the United States and Japan, not the United States alone.

title: Taxi Reform Is Just a Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Del Tredici's Bewildering But Amiable Grab Bag
description: ''The Spider and the Fly,'' David Del Tredici's cantata-like dialogue at the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night, can be amiable in its off-the-wall way, but its prolixity bewilders. Mr. Del Tredici's half-hour exercise for high soprano, baritone and orchestra is the musical equivalent of an overcrowded antiques shop in which profusion has the upper hand over quality control. Offered is the occasional reward for careful pickers, fruitless rummaging for everyone else.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ETTINGER, SIDNEY
description: ETTINGER-Sidney. 2/11/16-5/30/ 86. 12 long, lousy, lonely, longing years. You're still the love of my life. You'll always be my movie star. Your Bride

title: Higher Bid Seen At Belgian Bank
description: ABN Amro Holding N.V. offered today to raise the cash part of its $12.3 billion takeover offer for Generale de Banque if needed to offset a fall in its share price.

title: Santos's Pitching Paces No. 2 Miami
description: Alex Santos allowed only four hits and struck out eight in eight innings as second-seeded Miami began its fifth straight College World Series with a 3-1 victory over No. 7 Long Beach State last night in Omaha.

title: After Accident, Panel Suggests New Rules for Macy's Parade
description: Six months after a woman was seriously injured when a balloon was swept out of control in the Thanksgiving Day parade, a mayoral panel released recommendations yesterday that would restrict the use and size of the balloons, especially in windy conditions, and subject some aspects of the parade to the approval of city agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, RUTH
description: SHEPARD-Ruth. Died peacefully on May 29, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Ralph. Loving sister of Oscar Abeles. Devoted aunt and great-aunt. Dear friend of Sophie Shapiro. Graveside service on Monday 11 A.M., New Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: Barry Goldwater Is Dead at 89; Conservatives' Standardbearer
description: Barry M. Goldwater of Arizona, the recklessly candid Republican Presidential candidate who founded the modern conservative political movement in America, died yesterday at his home in Paradise Valley, a suburb of Phoenix. He was 89.

title: Defendant in Racial Beating Case Seeks Help to Pay Lawyer
description: Saying he was penniless, a white Queens man being retried in the nearly fatal beating of a black man two years ago outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub sought today to get the government to start paying for his lawyer.

title: Filling Summer Full
description: From solstice till equinox, summer lasts only 91 days and a few hours, a little longer if you count from Memorial Day till Labor Day. It seems like so much time. But summer defies perspective. The closer you get the smaller it looks, unlike winter, which looks longer and longer the nearer it comes. From a distance -- from April, say -- summer looks as capacious as hope. This will be the season in which we lose weight, eat well, work out, raise a garden, learn to kayak, submit to Proust, paint the apartment, drive to Glacier, and so on and so on and so on. This will be the season in which time stretches before us like the recesses of space itself, the season in which leisure swells like a slow tomato, until it is round and red and ripe.

title: Council Chides Pakistanis and Indians, Too
description: The Security Council strongly deplored Pakistan's nuclear tests today, but also repeated its criticism of India and urged both nations to stop testing and take steps to reduce the tensions between them.

title: I.M.F. Sending Russia $670 Million to Help Stabilize Ruble
description: Russia received a boost today when the International Monetary Fund said it would disburse $670 million by the end of June. That, along with conditions the I.M.F. placed on the Government, should be enough to stabilize the Russian financial markets, fund officials said.

title: Messinger Lands a Job at Hunter College
description: Six months after her bruising loss in the New York City mayoral race, Ruth W. Messinger, the former Manhattan Borough President, has ended a long and awkwardly public job search by accepting a teaching post at Hunter College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCH, KALMAN
description: ASCH-Kalman. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Linda. Devoted brother of Toby. Adored uncle. Services Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Mon., June 1, 3:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Stroke Club, North Shore Hospital, Manhasset L.I.

title: Fetal Law's Effects
description: To the Editor:

title: After Illness, A Program On Recovery
description: Fans of National Public Radio may recognize the name of Rebecca Perl, a health reporter. In 1995, the year she won a Peabody Award for her coverage of the tobacco industry, she found out she had non-Hodgkins lymphoma. In 1997, after months of chemotherapy and radiation proved unavailing, she went to the University of Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha for a bone marrow transplant.

title: CBS Affiliates To Share Costs For First Time
description: CBS announced an agreement yesterday with its affiliated stations to share in the cost of rights to National Football League games this fall, the first time a network has received direct financial help from affiliates to pay for programming.

title: CUNY's New Standards Strengthen Its Degrees
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Say Assault Preceded Girl's Death
description: A 3-year-old girl who drowned in a swimming pool while her father took hallucinogenic drugs at a party on Sunday had been sexually assaulted before her death, the Camden County Prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Deported Killer Returns to U.S., Kills Brother Of First Victim
description: A Dominican immigrant, convicted for the 1991 slaying of a Brooklyn man and deported last year after serving a prison term, sneaked back into the country and killed his victim's brother, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, JERE
description: DANIEL-Jere. On May 29, 1998. Friend-and-partner of Hara Marano, father of Josh & Sean Daniel, & step-father to Gabe and Daniel Marano. Grandfather of Lily, Daniel and Quincy Daniel. Family and friends will be gathering to say goodbye on Sunday, May 31 at 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1070 Madison Ave. at 81 Street. We will always remember Jere for his kindness, wisdom, support, sense of justice, humanity and his dreams.

title: Journal; Bombing Off Broadway
description: The theater loves a happy ending, especially if it's any variation on the theme ''The show must go on!'' And so it got one this week when Lynne Meadow and Barry Grove, the leaders of Off Broadway's esteemed Manhattan Theater Club, reversed their decision of a week earlier to remove Terrence McNally's ''Corpus Christi'' from their fall schedule.
