Instead of caving in to anonymous threats of violence -- whipped up by reports that Mr. McNally had created a gay Jesus-like hero who has sex (offstage) with his apostles -- Ms. Meadow and Mr. Grove announced that they would do what they should have done in the first place: assert their and Mr. McNally's right to free speech and secure the aid of the city's Police Commissioner in protecting that right, which also extends to the play's law-abiding critics.

title: CUNY's New Standards Strengthen Its Degrees; Bureaucrat's Crutch
description: To the Editor:

title: MARATHON OIL OF HOUSTON TO PURCHASE TARRAGON OIL
description: The Marathon Oil Company, a Houston-based oil and natural gas producer, agreed yesterday to buy Tarragon Oil and Gas Ltd. for about $510 million (United States) in cash and stock. Shareholders of Tarragon, based in Calgary, Alberta, can receive either $14.25 (Canadian) cash or shares of Marathon's parent, the USX-Marathon Group. The bid, which has been approved by Tarragon's board and recommended by a special adviser, Nesbitt Burns Inc., will be voted on by shareholders in August.

title: The Honorable Senator From Arizona
description: By most standards, a defeat like the one Barry Goldwater suffered as the Republican candidate for President in 1964 would be reason enough to retreat forever into the political desert. His home state of Arizona and five Southern states voted for him that year. The rest of the nation, worried about a man who believed that ''extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice,'' and who fought the Civil Rights Act because he thought it was unconstitutional, handed a landslide victory to President Johnson.

title: George Wright, 77, Theater Organist With a Cult Following
description: George Wright, a master theater organist with such a deft touch it was said he could make a mighty Wurlitzer swing when it wasn't actually jitterbugging, died on May 10 at a Los Angeles hospital near his home atop the Hollywood Hills. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDEN, BETSY M.
description: CARDEN-Betsy M. The Brooklyn College community mourns the passing of Professor Emerita of Dance Betsy M. Carden. Her 31 years of teaching and service will be long remembered. Vernon E. Lattin, President Brooklyn College

title: Vote Set for Prayer and Marriage-Penalty Bills
description: House Republicans are beginning a major effort next week to demonstrate a commitment to the religious right, with floor votes scheduled on proposals favoring school prayer and opposing the ''marriage penalty'' in the Federal income tax.

title: Limits on Privilege
description: As a matter of law and in the interest of orderly government, the Supreme Court should grant Kenneth Starr's request for a speedy Supreme Court hearing on President Clinton's claims of executive privilege. As the independent counsel investigating Whitewater and related issues, Mr. Starr has sometimes slighted the need to produce answers rather than multiplying questions. But he cannot be blamed for the White House's strategy of delay through legal appeals based on novel and expansionist claims of privilege. Mr. Starr's bid to leapfrog the appeals court on the question of whether Presidential aides can be compelled to testify exposes the White House's dilatory approach and offers the Supreme Court a chance to further refine the law on such conflicts.

title: Family Plans Lawsuit In Quadriplegic's Death
description: The family of a quadriplegic Atlantic City Boardwalk performer intends to sue the city for $5 million, charging officials with negligently contributing to her death in a February traffic accident, their lawyer said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An activity listing in the Spare Times column of Weekend yesterday for ''Korean Cuisine: A Day of Korean Culture,'' at the Staten Island Children's Museum, misstated the date. The event is to take place from noon to 4:30 P.M. today, not tomorrow.

title: Melancholy Babies: Depression, the Unbearable Darkness of Being
description: Andrew Delbanco, the Levi Professor in the Humanities at Columbia University, delivered the annual William E. Massey Sr. lecture on the History of American Civilization at Harvard University this month. This an excerpt from that talk, ''The Anatomy of American Melancholy,'' which will be published next year by Harvard University Press.

title: Japan Says Unemployment Has Reached Record High
description: Japan's economic distress deepened today as the Government reported the highest unemployment rate on record, bond yields tumbled to new lows and the yen hit a seven-year low, partly on fears that regional instability could send the world's second-largest economy into a tailspin.

title: Philip Carret, Money Manager, Dies at 101
description: Philip L. Carret, a founder of one of the country's first mutual funds and a legendary investor who swapped investment ideas with Warren E. Buffett's father half a century ago, died on Thursday at Mount Vernon Hospital in Mount Vernon, N.Y., where he was recovering from hip surgery. He was 101.

title: Quick-Fix H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Stake in Nikko To Be Bought By Salomon
description: Salomon Smith Barney, the investment bank subsidiary of Travelers Group Inc., is preparing to take a minority stake in the Nikko Securities Company, Japan's third-largest brokerage firm, executives at the Wall Street firm said yesterday.

title: A Non-Pro Wins the Trophy For Master Points in a Year
description: In the early days of the game there were two national organizations, William McKenney's American Bridge League, with roots in auction bridge, and Ely Culbertson's United States Bridge Association. They were merged in 1937, with McKenney in command, and Charles Goren was named the first winner of the McKenney Trophy for winning the most master points in a year. He won seven more times, a record.

title: Defendant In Internet Torture Case Gets 15 Years
description: Ending a trial that gained attention because the victim met the defendant on the Internet, a State Supreme Court judge sentenced Oliver Jovanovic to a minimum of 15 years in prison for kidnapping and sexually abusing a young woman he met in a computer chat room.

title: Study Finds Risks to Patients in Drug Trials
description: Federal investigators said today that patients who participated in clinical trials of new drugs were often exposed to unsafe and unethical practices because no one policed the research to protect their interests.

title: Income and Spending Were Up in April
description: Growth in personal income accelerated in April and consumer spending continued to increase, signs that domestic demand was helping to offset the effect of the Asian crisis on the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, MADELINE HENGGELER
description: MATTHEWS-Madeline Henggeler. On May 28, 1998. Retired from the Hewlett Woodmere U.F. School District and volunteer with the former Track & Field Organization of AAU. Devoted mother of Dr. Peter R. Matthews of Woolrich, PA., and Gail M. Scoby of Golden, CO. Proud grandmother of four grandchildren. Dear sister of William Henggeler and Clara McNamara. Funeral private.

title: Taxi Reform Is Just a Band-Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Joy of Debts: Eastern Europe on a Credit Fling
description: On a recent Saturday, Andrzej Komuda, 41, and his father-in-law, Janusz Lisowski, 69, were on their knees, tape measure in hand, sizing up refrigerators on the sprawling sales floor of the Promenada shopping center here. Rows of television sets flickered in the background as oven doors were opened and shut by picky buyers.

title: Fed's No. 2 Chosen to Lead District of Columbia's Financial Board
description: More than seven years after she headed a panel that warned of a looming fiscal crisis in the District of Columbia, Alice M. Rivlin was selected by President Clinton today as the chairwoman of the District's financial control board.

title: VALLEY NATIONAL AGREES TO ADD WAYNE BANCORP
description: Valley National Bancorp agreed yesterday to acquire Wayne Bancorp Inc., a New Jersey bank holding company, for more than $69 million in stock, based on Thursday's closing price. Valley National's principal unit is Valley National Bank, based in Wayne, N.J., with assets of $5.1 billion and 97 branches in northern New Jersey. Wayne Bancorp is the holding company for Wayne Savings Bank, also based in Wayne, with assets of $272 million and six branch offices. Valley National will exchange 1.1 of its shares for each of Wayne's million shares outstanding. Shares of Wayne Bancorp rose 87.5 cents, to $31.625 on Nasdaq.

title: Philosopher Gamely In Defense Of His Ideas
description: Jacques Derrida, perhaps the world's most famous philosopher -- if not the only famous philosopher -- was eating barbecued chicken with a knife and fork at the Polo Grill. A scholar (who considers Mr. Derrida's work deliberately obscure) warned against asking him to define ''deconstruction,'' the notoriously difficult and widely influential method of inquiry that he invented more than three decades ago. ''Make it your last question,'' the scholar counseled, because it sends deconstructionists into ''paroxysms of rage.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, HARRY
description: SCHWARTZ-Harry. Happy birthday. You are truly missed. Love, Nancy

title: Bears, Pratfalls and Dung, the Classy Stuff
description: They're in a race with Lewis and Clark (who have a two-week head start) to reach the Pacific Ocean. They're abandoned at the outset by most of their team, who decide to go to New Orleans instead (for the food). Leslie Edwards is an aristocrat who travels with a liveried slave and relaxes by the campfire in a gold paisley robe. Bartholomew Hunt is a rude, crude frontiersman who enjoys jokes about animal dung. In ''Almost Heroes,'' a dopey but largely harmless comedy set in 1804, they encounter bears, mentally unbalanced American Indians, white water and a frontier brothel offering assignations with small straw dolls.

title: Sports of The Times; Into the Void: Sporting Life After Jordan
description: ON this final day of veterans minicamp, the Jets' locker room was brisk with movement; players rushing to get out of town, back to the end of their vacations.

title: Giants Ready to Unload Miller in Payroll Purge
description: Monday marks the beginning of the National Football League's annual roster-shaping and payroll-trimming festival. After June 1, salary cap regulations make it advantageous for some teams to dump high-salaried players, and many teams do.

title: Market Falls Again, Ending Worst Month Since October
description: Stocks retreated from early gains and ended lower yesterday, dragged down by weakness in technology issues. The selloff came as concern grew that continued turmoil in Asia could damage corporate profits in the United States.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Tuesday about a recall of defective tubing for dialysis machines misstated the number of Americans who rely on dialysis to remove waste products from their bodies. It is 217,000, not 20,000.

title: New York Man Dies of Injuries After Pushing Boy to Safety
description: A Mount Vernon, N.Y., man who saved an 8-year-old boy from being hit by a runaway car but was unable to avoid the car himself died yesterday, the authorities said.

title: Foreign Affairs; My China For Your Congress
description: Let's get straight to the point: President Clinton has no business, no business whatsoever, going to China now. The Republicans are right. President Clinton is wrong, wrong, wrong. He should stay home. This trip to China is an outrage. A sham. An embarrassment. It should be canceled. Today. Now. Immediately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, FLORENCE
description: LEVINE-Florence. Beloved wife of the late Irving, loving mother of Sari Oxman, Monte, and Henry Levine, cherished grandmother of Sheryl August, Scott and Marci Oxman. Graveside service at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn Long Island at 11 A.M. Monday.

title: Webb Takes Title
description: Vanessa Webb became Duke's first woman collegiate tennis champion yesterday, beating Stanford's Ania Bleszynski, 6-3, 6-4, to win the N.C.A.A. title in South Bend, ind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNAFO, GERTRUDE A.
description: MUNAFO-Gertrude A. (Ret. Texaco Oil). Beloved wife of the late Joseph; loving sister of Edith Cremins and Huldah Williams; dear aunt of many nieces and nephews. She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Mount Holyoke College and received her masters from Columbia University. She was also a fifty year member of The American Chemical Society, volunteer at UNICEF and read for the blind. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Mount Holyoke Scholarship Fund or The Parkinsons Foundation. Funeral services will be held Sunday 7PM at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St). Interment Monday 11AM at Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: U.S. Fears That Calm Talk Is Masking Harsher Reality
description: American intelligence reports indicate that Pakistan may be preparing for more tests of nuclear weapons and missiles, acts likely to provoke an Indian reaction. As a result, Administration officials said they were skeptical of peaceable statements by both nations today because they believe that the calmer rhetoric does not reflect a calmer reality in the region.

title: Field Is Set For Run at Title
description: It will be East versus West today on the Cooper River in Cherry Hill, N.J., with intercollegiate rowing's national championship the prize.

title: Warped Military Justice in Colombia
description: No matter which presidential candidate Colombians choose in elections tomorrow, the new president will take over a government whose powers are tightly constrained. The problem is not just left-wing guerrillas or right-wing paramilitaries. The country's civilian institutions are also being eroded by its own military. One attempt to wrest back civilian control, a reform of the military justice system, is now in congress and is being sabotaged by the armed forces. Its passage is crucial to the cause of protecting human rights and democratic governance.

title: Man Arrested in '92 Parkway Killing
description: The killing sent shock waves through a city already consumed with its alarmingly high crime rate: on Christmas night in 1992, Pamela Mascaro was driving home from dinner with her husband and 3-year-old daughter when she was fatally shot by a driver who fired at her from a car on the Grand Central Parkway in Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUZZO, ANTHONY
description: GUZZO-Anthony, 75. Died May 28, 1998 at Rome Memorial Hospital, Rome, NY. He was born October 8, 1922 to Anthony and Fannie Guzzo in Brooklyn, New York. Would any kin or anyone knowing any next of kin contact the Central New York DSO (collect) at 315336-2300 regarding any special funeral arrangements.

title: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL IN DEAL WITH LINCOLN PROPERTY
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust, the nation's largest apartment owner, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 25 multifamily properties in four states from the Lincoln Property Company for $465 million. Equity will pay cash and operating partnership units for the properties, which have 5,774 units. The agreement also includes assumed debt. Equity Residential is a Chicago-based real estate investment trust controlled by the financier Sam Zell. Late last year, Equity Residential and Lincoln, based in Dallas, formed a venture to develop $1 billion of apartment properties over three years.

title: Bob Patino, 58, Interior Designer Known for Stylish Minimalism
description: Bob Patino, an interior designer known for the quiet sophistication of his design work for homes, stores and restaurants and for his subtle experimentation with materials and textures, died on May 22 at his home in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Sirens, Shouts, Gunshots, All in the Tapping of a Shoe
description: When Savion Glover first exploded onto the stage of the Variety Arts Theater on Wednesday afternoon, he wore a drooping T-shirt and baggy pants. Other dancers in ''Savion Glover Downtown'' were similarly dressed. Indeed, they looked like people who had wandered in off the street. And that was the point, for Mr. Glover wanted to bring the streets into the theater in this new tap show, subtitled ''Live Communication.''

title: Smits and Best Push the Pacers Into a Game 7
description: Backs to the wall. No tomorrow. Do or die. The Indiana Pacers defied the cliches and the Bulls tonight, scrambling for a 92-89 victory over Chicago that forced a seventh game in the four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference finals.

title: St. John's to Talk With Jarvis
description: After completing the first round of interviews with the three candidates for the vacant head basketball coach's position at St. John's, Athletic Director Ed Manetta added another name to the mix and scheduled an interview with George Washington University Coach Mike Jarvis. Manetta, who had Jarvis on his list two years ago but did not interview him, has been in touch with the coach, and George Washington has given permission for St. John's to interview him.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results yesterday misstated the daily number drawn in New York for May 28. It was 112, not 117. A corrected listing appears today on page B4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWENS, VIRGINIA R. (NEE RAEBECK)
description: OWENS-Virginia R. (nee Raebeck). Suddenly on May 28, 1998. Beloved mother of Anne Gilde, Elizabeth Dean, Penelope Adelmann & Johanna Owens. Loving grandmother of Hans, Hannah, Joseph, Virginia, Jenny & William. Dear sister of William Raebeck, Jr. and Arline Wahn. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, New York. Visiting Saturday 11 AM-12:30 PM. Memorial Service at Brooklyn Friends Meeting House, 110 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn on Saturday, June 20th, 1998 at 1 P.M.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Heart Patient Helps Raise Funds for Others
description: WHEN Alan and Sondra Haywood talk about their life these days, they call it ''new normal.'' Mr. Haywood, a strapping man who had a heart transplant 15 months ago, no longer plays football, but he can swim and go speed walking. He wears an alarm watch to remind him to take a battery of pills, but compared with the cumbersome machine that used to help pump his heart, he says that is a minor inconvenience.

title: If You Have to Ask . . .
description: PORTRAIT OF DR. GACHET

title: What X Marks
description: IT'S difficult to reserve a table at Restaurant X for a Saturday night, and for obvious reasons. The food is often wonderful, and the warren of dining rooms, including a beautiful bar where you can order anything from a spoonful of caviar to a root beer float, is flawlessly designed. The profusion of fresh flowers alone is worth the extra phone call it takes to secure a table.

title: At the Casinos
description: Atlantic City Hilton

title: Got You Babe: Cher Reclaims Her History
description: IT took a tragedy, but she's back.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Shareholder Value: Sorting Out the Voices
description: I RECENTLY heard a reporter on one of the TV business shows intone authoritatively that shareowner value was increasingly the watchword on Wall Street.

title: Drama About Power And Yes, It Corrupts
description: IRVING BERLIN wrote a musical about the other ''chosen party giver.'' But the swells of yesteryear would have told you that the real ''hostess with the mostes' '' was not Perle Mesta (the inspiration for ''Call Me Madam'') but Elsa Maxwell.

title: In America, an Upright Aristocrat Learned to Relax
description: THE Windsor chair's stature endures like that of the medieval castle from which its name derives. First sighted about 1715 on the royal grounds at Windsor Castle, near London, the chair was rough hewn and unpainted, fitted with bark-covered stick legs, a plank seat and in all likelihood, spindles at the back. British aristocrats so admired these chairs that they moved some indoors, and over the next 20 years the seat was thinned, the front legs were stripped of bark and eventually curved, the back was eased with a splat, and the entire surface was sealed with coats of chalky green-blue paint.

title: Comparing Notes On Shakespeare Only for the Brave
description: SHAKESPEARE is being celebrated this year with an unusual number of major productions in New York, even for him. By the middle of June, five of his plays will have been done at the Brooklyn Academy of Music alone, including the rarely seen ''Cymbeline,'' opening on Wednesday at the Opera House in a version by the Royal Shakespeare Company, now in residence at BAM.

title: Coexisting and Colliding the American Way
description: EUROPEANS negotiating the maze of townships that make up Greater Pittsburgh might be puzzled to find each with its own police force wearing distinctive uniforms and driving different squad cars. Redundancy multiplied many times would surely be the charge. Think of the wasted resources, the jurisdictional incoherence.

title: The Nation; Pride, Prejudice And Border War Bluster
description: WITH its brassy boardwalk, bar and shopping-mall culture, New Jersey is the ancestral home of the attitudinal T-shirt -- the ones that say things like ''I'm Not as Think as You Drunk I Am'' in blurry letters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, HARRISON OLIVER, JR.
description: BROWN-Harrison Oliver, Jr., M.D. 69. Of Flemington, NJ, on May 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Jean Abel Cramer Brown, M.D. Devoted father of David Littleton Brown and Steven Holloway Brown, M.D. Loving brother of Juluis Bunting Brown. A memorial service will take place Friday, June 19 at 3 PM at the First Presbyterian Church of Westfield in Westfield, NJ. All are invited. Private services were held at the Dooley Colonial Home in Westfield. Please make memorial donations in his name to the Cancer Society of Union Co., 512 Westminster Avenue, Elizabeth, NJ 07208.

title: Don't Tread On My Tax Rate
description: Although Gov. Howard Dean may disagree with Elinor Burkett's article, this old curmudgeon thinks that Act 60 is just about the worst thing that ever came down the pike (Letters, May 10, in response to ''Don't Tread on My Tax Rate,'' April 26). The Governor may choose to believe that we Vermonters are for the most part adjusting to this new system ''in a caring and thoughtful way,'' but I for one, as a tax assessor in Vermont of some 24 years' service, would love to be in good enough physical condition to carry the head pitchfork in a tax revolt marching on Montpelier.

title: Boomer Parents And Little Tyrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VERGNES GEFFNER, JEANNINE
description: VERGNES GEFFNER-Jeannine. Dearest Jeannine. Another year and Poshka now gone. How is Mimi? Happy birthday. All my love, David.

title: Stephanie Woodson and Jin Chang
description: Stephanie Bland Woodson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stephen Woodson 3d of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to Jin James Chang, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jae C. Chang of Kettering, Ohio. The Rev. Amy Richter performed the ceremony at St. Chrysostom's Episcopal Church in Chicago.

title: Love's in the Air
description: Directed by William A. Wellman, with Charles ''Buddy'' Rogers, Richard Arlen and Gary Cooper, WINGS (1927) has two distinct assets as a Hollywood antique. It won the first Best Picture Oscar, in the ballroom ceremony held at the Roosevelt Hotel on Hollywood Boulevard, and the airborne scenes depicting World War I are fine, with a swarm of those marvelous old planes on both sides and some remarkable photography. Otherwise the picture seems rickety. The plot has Rogers and Arlen as two American Army aviator pals in love with the same woman (a fairly subdued Clara Bow). The story does pick up with a twist at the end, but those old planes are what make this picture fly -- Friday at 6 A.M. on American Movie Classics. Howard Thompson

title: Williamsburg
description: To the Editor: Your article about Williamsburg was interesting but missed the point about Colonial Williamsburg: It is a living museum staffed by historical interpreters, not actors merely playing scripted parts. Our children thoroughly enjoyed speaking with Martha Washington about her daily life, the wigmaker about Colonial hair styles and Mr. Randolph's manservant about his concerns for his children, to name only a few. Readers should also realize that Colonial Williamsburg is a foundation whose ''profits'' are used to preserve and maintain a historical area and provide educational programs.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results yesterday misstated numbers for several games in New York and Connecticut for May 29. In New York, the daily number was 735; the Win 4 number was 5148; the Take 5 numbers were 10, 7, 24, 25, 3. In Connecticut, the daily number was 630; the Play 4 number was 5297; the Cash 5 numbers were 4, 8, 19, 26, 27. A corrected listing appears today on page 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCK, DAVID JONATHAN LOUIS
description: LUCK-David Jonathan Louis, 70. On May 23, 1998, scientist, alive in the hearts of the many to whom he generously gave the gift of love and friendship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. A profound loss to his wife and family. To John, a loss of a father, mentor and best friend. Bob Feinberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, EARL TAFT
description: BENNETT-Earl Taft. Born September 21, 1908; Died May 28, 1998. Former New York Times Pressman who proudly ran Press #

title: Seismic Reincarnation of Bay Bridge
description: If the Golden Gate Bridge is the queen of the San Francisco Bay, the Bay Bridge is her humble lady-in-waiting. Painted an industrial gray, and stretching across an unremarkable swath of waterway, it is overshadowed by the warm red hues and spectacular views afforded its famous neighbor to the west.

title: Handling the Difficult Task of Edging
description: MANY homeowners find it difficult to maintain the borders around the patio, driveway and sidewalks. Frequently, the lawn overgrows onto these surfaces, narrowing them and making them look unkempt and uncared for. The usual way to service these areas is with an edger that trims and cuts back the grass to form a neat, defined edge.

title: May 24-30; Russian Economic Woes Set Off Investor Panic
description: Panic swept through Russia's financial markets as foreign investors feared that the ruble would be devalued. Interest rates tripled and the stock market plummeted.

title: Elizabeth Transou, Josh Kernan
description: Elizabeth Howard Transou and Francis Joshua Kernan were married yesterday at Meadowood, a resort in St. Helena, Calif. The Rev. Haywood Holderness, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Garry Shandling Goes Dark
description: It's around 2 on a Wednesday in late April and Garry Shandling is studying the screen of an editing terminal upstairs from what used to be his office at ''The Larry Sanders Show.'' The offices are empty now, furniture upended, ready for storage. ''The Larry Sanders Show,'' a brilliant, lacerating situation comedy about a fictitious late-night talk-show host and the complications, both emotional and professional, of his show-biz life, filmed its last episode, the one Shandling is now editing, a month ago. The key to ''Sanders,'' which completes its sixth season on HBO tonight, has been tension and longing, the way the characters bumped up against one another in their quest for some sort of intangible sense of acceptance and glory. The show was born out of the Leno-Letterman, man-who-would-be-Johnny talk-show wars, and Shandling, a stand-up comedian who had been a guest host for Carson during the mid-80's, saw the backstage whirl as emblematic of larger desires in American culture. ''The whole world is show business now,'' he explains, still concentrating on the editing terminal. ''Everyone wants to be famous. They think being famous will change their life. I'm here to tell them that it doesn't.''

title: Finding Beauty in Everyday Objects From Japan
description: BEFORE the 1870's, the concept of fine art is said not to have existed in Japan. While works of painters, sculptors, basket makers, potters and other artisans were appreciated for quality and esthetics, there was not a conscious hierarchy within the arts. Around 1920, Yanagi Soetsu, a Japanese art theorist and social critic, pioneered such a delineation, coining the term mingei, meaning art of the people.

title: There's More to Planting Than Digging a Hole
description: NOW that the planting season is here, everyone should be proceeding wisely. Those who know what they are doing follow a steady schedule. Reminders may resemble preaching to the choir, but there are many novices about who may be unsure about procedures. For them, here are a few reminders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOFFMAN, ETHAN AND HERB
description: HOFFMAN-Ethan and Herb. Forever in our hearts and minds. How we miss you and love you. Mom, Bob and Caren

title: Mourning Officer Who Was Husband, Hero and Friend
description: Outside the church yesterday, as New York City police officers gathered hours before the funeral of one of their own, it was easy to think of Anthony Mosomillo as just an unlucky policeman killed in the line of duty -- another painful statistic for the Police Department and for a city that boasts a plunging crime rate.

title: TV Journalists Find Yeltsin Drawn to Big Brother Role
description: With a crash on financial markets, floods in Siberia and a miners' protest that blocked the country's main railroad, Russia has had a lot of bad news lately. Too much, according to President Boris N. Yeltsin, who called in the directors of three national television channels this week to complain about negative coverage.

title: Duffers Need Not Apply
description: TO justify spending hours steering dimpled balls into plastic cups, many business people explain that golf is great for building relationships with clients. This reasoning, of course, makes the great untanned masses back at the office suspect that golf is merely a clever excuse for playing hooky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERBERG, CHARLES
description: ZUCKERBERG-Charles. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Alice G. Weaver. Adored grandfather of Jennifer and Kevin Weaver. Dear brother of Beth Schutz and uncle of Roy and Mark Zuckerberg, Jacob Weiss, and Ruth Musher. Service Monday, 2:30 PM at Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hilary Fagan, Albert Dahlberg
description: Hilary Douglas Fagan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Fagan of Newport, R.I., was married yesterday to Albert Andrew Dahlberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert E. Dahlberg of Providence, R.I. The Rev. Alan Neale performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Columba's Chapel in Middletown, R.I.

title: The View From/New Haven; The Abused Urban Tree Finally Gets Some Help
description: IN the absence of human activity, 90 percent of Connecticut would be forest. ''We have inserted ourselves into this forest ecosystem,'' says Fred Borman, Connecticut's Urban Forestry Coordinator. ''People do not give the trees the attention they deserve.''

title: All the Wrong Places
description: MARY BUTTS

title: The World; It's a Test, Not a Weapon. But That's Awfully Close.
description: ON their northern border, high in the Himalayas, India and Pakistan have for years been fighting for position and not much else along a glacier that is virtually uninhabitable. On mountains reaching 20,000 feet, their armies snipe and trade artillery blasts, if the weather allows. By most definitions, it is war, but a small war. Each side loses as many soldiers to altitude sickness as to combat.

title: Sandra Feuerstein, Michael Stanger
description: Sandra Allison Feuerstein, the daughter of Helen Badt of Stuart, Fla., and the late Martin Feuerstein, was married last Monday to Michael David Stanger, the son of Sheila Stanger and Dr. Melvin Stanger of Brooklyn. Rabbi William Lebeau officiated at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Budding Funds' Hidden Benefits
description: A LOT of investors have been reading about something called the ''new fund effect.'' That's the tendency of new funds to outperform their older peers because of -- well, you name it -- better access to initial public offerings, better-motivated managers or better prices on trades.

title: Colossus to Get Sparkling New $30 Million Coat (of Gray)
description: ''These gigantic, suspended rainbow arches of steel and stone are surely evidence of Divine inspiration,'' Robert Moses, then chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, wrote in 1964 for the opening of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

title: Sunday, May 31, 1998: Religion; Fundamental Differences
description: Expect a lively rumble among some champion proselytizers next month, just before the Southern Baptist Convention holds its annual meeting in Salt Lake City. A Baptist battalion of 3,000 front-door missionaries will trawl the streets, trying to convert Mormons to their brand of Christianity -- in the stronghold of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The campaign is called Crossover Salt Lake City.

title: Ms. Clay, Mr. Frelinghuysen
description: Heather Newlin Clay, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Clay of Versailles, Ky., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Nicholas Lawrance Frelinghuysen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Frelinghuysen Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. William McDonald, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ROBERT F.
description: YOUNG-Robert F. Former president and publisher of Family Circle magazine, he was a longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson and Carmel, NY, recently moved to Greensboro, NC. Died May 27, 1998. Cherished husband of Judith, devoted father of Melinda Rosengarten, Julie O'Connor, Steven and Christopher. Beloved brother of Lenore Cerrone and proud grandfather of Caitlin, and Justin; Robbie & Rennie; Kristen, Brianne and Kenneth. Memorial contributions to the Louis August Jonas Foundation, Rhinebeck, NY. A memorial service will be held in June in Manhattan.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1999 Mercury Cougar; After 8 Lives or So, Mercury's Cat Claws Its Way Back
description: THE high-style car is suddenly in fashion. Buyers are lining up for the Volkswagen New Beetle, a retro departure from the look-alike wedges and jellybeans that have dominated auto design for a couple of decades. At the Ford Motor Company, the president of automotive operations, Jacques A. Nasser, is asking designers to come up with cars that have more flair and personality. And Ford has moved its Lincoln-Mercury operations to Southern California, so its staff members can stay abreast of youthful West Coast trends.

title: Amy Dunham and Richard Lyman 3d
description: Amy Ellen Dunham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Burdett Dunham of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Warren Lyman 3d, a son of Elizabeth Rossman of Swampscott, Mass., and Mr. Lyman Jr. of Marblehead, Mass. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: State Plans to Test Fourth Graders in the Arts
description: Within two years, New Jersey's fourth graders will be expected to be able to perform or create a work of art, as well as to critique others' work.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 31, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Assisi Restores Churches And, It Hopes, Popularity
description: THE first disaster to befall Assisi was the earthquake that struck this lovely medieval hilltop in central Italy last fall, causing 11 deaths and serious damage to the magnificent Basilica of St. Francis and other churches associated with one of the Catholic world's most beloved saints.

title: Unraveling the Mystery of the Fork People
description: SUMMERTIME, and the living is hard out here on the East End of Long Island. Wading River is the gateway to the North Fork, and about 10 million tourists will be driving through between now and Labor Day. On weekends, we've learned to stay at home, congratulating ourselves that at least we don't live on the South Fork. Residents down there are pretty much trapped in their homes from May till September, unable to get a car out of the driveway or park it anywhere else if they do.

title: Our Towns; Neighbors Set The Limits Of Hospitality
description: FOR weeks, families in this tract of stout, vinyl-sided houses on Hospitality Way were worried sick. Their cherished neighborhood, still shiny and new, was in trouble.

title: Returning Seals Find Their Coast Is Clear
description: When Capt. John H. Wadsworth was a boy in the 1940's, diners at his family's seaside restaurant here could watch harbor seals resting on rocks along the Niantic River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMASINO, VINCENT
description: TOMASINO-Vincent. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vincent Tomasino, associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1977.

title: A. What Is a Freeholder
description: THE voters lined up along Main Street here for the Memorial Day parade would have deflated county officials anywhere. When questioned about the Hunterdon County Board of Freeholders and the approaching primary race for three seats, Lewis Levi of Raritan Township gave an answer better informed than most: ''Freeholders,'' he said. ''They're like county council.'' Then, asked if he could name any freeholders, he said, with confidence, ''Absolutely not.''

title: PAKISTAN SETS OFF ATOM TEST AGAIN, BUT URGES 'PEACE'
description: Pakistan exploded another nuclear test device today, the Government announced, spurning worldwide criticism and calls for restraint after its nuclear tests two days ago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Amanda Ross, Theodore Farris
description: Amanda Colby Ross, a daughter of Judith N. Ross and Wilbur L. Ross Jr., both of New York, was married yesterday to Theodore Northington Farris, the son of Dr. Mutie Tillich Farris of New York and the late Theodore N. Farris. Mayor Paul F. Rickenbach Jr. of East Hampton, N.Y., officiated at the bridegroom's house there.

title: Updating Capri Pants
description: Capri or bicycle pants, a look from the 1950's, have returned, and this time around, it's the shoe that makes the difference. Capris evolved from acrobats' tights and came into fashion at the end of World War II. Originally worn with Capezio flats, they are being worn today with an eclectic range of footwear: platform clogs and other backless styles, chunky sneakers, delicate evening designs, 40's wedgies and 50's pumps.

title: Long Famous And Now, Kosher, Too
description: Move over, Hebrew National, and make room for Nathan's Famous: the Coney Island icon is going kosher.

title: Chefs Show Off In the East 60's
description: CONTRAPUNTO * [rating: one star]

title: THE GUIDE
description: Photography Show

title: Invitation To Dispute a Settlement
description: THE notices are in the mail, close to six million of them, telling investors about a $1 billion class-action settlement. Advertisements are appearing in business publications, saying: ''If you traded securities on the Nasdaq market between May 1, 1989 and July 17, 1996, please read this summary notice.''

title: Manhattan Meetings: The What, When and Where
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Battery Park, Civic Center, Financial District, South Street Seaport, TriBeCa; third Tuesday of month; next meeting June 16, 5:30 P.M.; Southbridge Towers, Community Room, 90 Beekman Street, near Gold Street. Board Chairwoman: Anne Compoccia. District Manager: Paul Goldstein. (212) 442-5050.

title: Forays to Spots Meriting Only a Mention
description: SEASON or circumstance frequently dictates our investigations into dining spots. Often restaurant size, updating or fireplaces or patios as main attractions preclude a full review. But as these places deserve some kind of mention, we report here on a few of our recent findings.

title: SOAPBOX; A School Bus Lesson
description: ON the day that 6-year-old Emory Grant was killed by his own school bus, his principal and district superintendent appeared on television expressing their pain. Emory's foster mother, who had planned to adopt him, passed out in grief. The city's Board of Education sent in counselors to console heartbroken children who were en route to P.S. 114 in Canarsie, Brooklyn, on the same bus that ran over Emory that morning of May 18. He was a kindergartner who missed his bus after wandering off to buy a piece of candy. Realizing his mistake, he chased after it at close range and was struck by one of its tires as it made a right turn.

title: 'Really Real' Seaside Heights Serves as MTV Summer Set
description: Over the years, this sliver of a beach town has played host to scores of small-time warm-weather events, from high-school proms to monster-truck rallies. But Seaside Heights officially entered the big time last weekend when MTV kicked off its ''Summer Share'' show in a rented beach house on the local boardwalk.

title: Lamb, Succulent With Spices and Figs
description: WHEN I was growing up in England, the traditional dish for a spring Sunday lunch was roast lamb. It was, of course, served well done (the children always fought over who got the crispy bit at the end of the joint -- and very crisp it was, too). The meat was gray and rather dry, and with it fresh mint sauce, peas and new potatoes from the garden were handed around the table. It was one of my favorite meals.

title: Matthew Kahn and Dora Costa
description: Dr. Dora Louisa Costa, an associate professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Dr. Matthew Edwin Kahn, a visiting assistant professor of economics at Harvard University, both in Cambridge, Mass., were married on Friday. The bridegroom's grandfather Harry Kahn, a civil marriage celebrant, officiated at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge.

title: Brooklyn Cinema Burns, 2 Weeks After Premiere
description: Two weeks ago, the 14-screen Linden Boulevard Multiplex Cinemas opened in East New York, Brooklyn, the only movie theater in a long-neglected neighborhood. Late Friday night, the multiplex caught fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, WILLIAMSON
description: DOUGLAS-Williamson. Born in Richmomd, VA, October 12, 1942, died May 29, 1998 in Palm Beach, FL. Internationally renowned painter. Mr. Douglas was a member of the Chelsea Arts Club in London, England. Educated at Andover and the University of North Carolina. Survivors include a son, Christopher Chase Douglas and a daughter, Grey Bean of Mill Valley, CA. For information contact Quattlebaum Funeral Home, 561832-5171.

title: A Strong Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Aliens Take Saks
description: Beginning on Wednesday night, you may do a double take at the Saks Fifth Avenue windows. John Barlett's line of turtlenecks, pants and jackets will be modeled by multicolored, swirly-headed mannequins from another planet that were designed by the artist Kenny Scharf. ''It's the surreal versus the real,'' said Anthony G. Lombardi, corporate director of visual presentation at Saks. ''It's the juxtaposition between something a person is going to wear against a form that's abstract, almost otherworldly.''

title: Where the Stars Loved Laughing at Themselves
description: Roseanne slept with him. David Duchovny certainly behaved as if he wanted to. Sandra Bernhard tried to steal his show while he was on vacation.

title: Hater of Softee Jingle Enjoyed Seeing the Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Scene but Not Heard
description: Frankel is right about the proliferation of delayed leads. The practice has become so pervasive that I have taken to beginning front-page stories two paragaphs down from the top.

title: Travel
description: ''IN truth,'' Stephen Minta protests, ''I've never wanted to follow in anyone's footsteps.'' As a boy, when he sang the carol about Good King Wenceslas, Minta focused on the role of the King's page, summoned outdoors at night to accompany his liege ''through the rude wind's wild lament'' -- ''In his master's steps he trod, / Where the snow lay dinted.'' As Minta reconstructs the story, the two gave Christmas dinner to a serf they saw gathering firewood in the storm and ''then, I suppose, returned home, the King to be a saint and the page to carry on being a page.'' But although this was a ''memorable journey,'' Minta recalls that ''it was hard to believe, at the age of 12, that life held nothing better than the promise of a great man's coattails.''

title: Only Human
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Independent Bookstores Struggle Against the Tide
description: IN Hastings-on-Hudson, two independent booksellers, Deborah Boylan and Rosemary Edelstein, stubbornly ignore the writing on the wall, as does Carol Greenman in Pleasantville and Harold Makanoff in White Plains. Struggling to survive in the growing shadow of large chains like Borders Books and Records and Barnes & Noble, they remain holdouts -- aware of the perils of their profession yet unwilling to give in.

title: Final Link in a Pedestrian Pathway
description: ''I COULD stay here forever, but we finish the job soon the trail opens in June,'' said Fernando Araujo, owner of the Golden Star Painting Company, standing on the deck of the Baltimore truss bridge, which spans the New Croton Reservoir in Yorktown. For two months, Mr. Araujo and 10 others have been painting the 1904 bridge, which once carried the old Putnam Railroad over the water supply for New York City and Westchester.

title: Pass the Popcorn (And the Khakis)
description: NAME-BRAND apparel and independent films. There's not much connection there, really, except you might wear one while watching the other. Still, consider this: Major clothing manufacturers have decided that, in their quest to remain hip with youth, they want to associate with those low-budget films that everyone talks about and almost no one sees.

title: Sunday, May 31, 1998: Art; My 4-Year-Old Better Not Do That
description: Pity the student artist trying to make a splash at the end of the 20th century, when every eye-popping artistic statement has been made (and made again). Still, the show must go on. This spring, the nation's art schools will grant Masters of Fine Arts degrees to some 2,000 students, who need to turn heads with their final projects. A survey of the 1998 crop reveals work that is bold, beautiful and. . . strange. But don't go calling it phony. These projects are not elaborate dodges, says Stephen Goldstine, director of graduate studies at California College of Arts and Crafts, who does concede that some viewers will be left behind for now. Hoping to stay hip, we turned to the artists for personal explanations.

title: Forced Back Into Institution, 9 Men File Suit
description: Nine men who were recently forced from community residences back into state institutions for the developmentally disabled (''As an Institution Empties, Community Fears Force Nine Men Back,'' May 17) have filed a suit in Federal District Court against the Department of Human Services and its Division of Developmental Disabilities.

title: Bustling Queens Library Speaks in Many Tongues
description: At peak times in the Flushing branch of the Queens Borough Public Library, librarians do not even blink if they look up and see 40 people, loaded with books, tapes and CD's, waiting in a line that winds crookedly through the cramped space.

title: Doubleday Takes Wheel And Revs Up the Mets
description: Nelson Doubleday is still in a home-run trot, a baseball lawyer said a week after the Mets acquired Mike Piazza. ''He hit one McGwire distance,'' the lawyer said of Doubleday, ''and he's not going away.''

title: Another View of Plan For Ex-Mental Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: But Who Is He Really?
description: IISABEL PAPAGNO, Gerard Papa, Cynthia Fromer, Khairy Guirgis and Marilynn Garfinkel, like a lot of shrewd people last week, could not be dragged into a critical discussion about Mayor Giuliani. They thought he might be listening, and get sore. I found it very frustrating, because I am trying to figure out how I feel about the Mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROFE, BEATRICE
description: GROFE-Beatrice. Died an untimely death on May 26, 1998 in New York City. Beloved sister, aunt, cousin and friend. Her perception and intelligence was most creative and artistic. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her.

title: Red Sox Make Yankees Look Human
description: Yankees fans are blessed with extraordinary memories and vocal talents, and they greeted Boston's Bret Saberhagen with running commentary on his life before today's game. Helpful fans reviewed every memorable transgression in Saberhagen's 34 years, probably invented a few others, and Saberhagen, honored by their attention as he warmed up in the bullpen, tipped his cap to them.

title: Down-Home Southern Treats and Caviar
description: CORNBREAD and Caviar is both the name of a new Baldwin restaurant and a description of the first bites of a meal there. Warm, crumblely squares of cornbread, paired with caviar-dotted butter, create a positive first impression.

title: Overseas, and Often Overlooked
description: TO some extent, investors are spoiled by the volume of research and analysts' comments on most American stocks. Even relatively small companies may have a clutch of analysts following their stocks, perhaps because they have a promising new product in a hot industry. Investors can weigh the company's results against consensus forecasts and quickly gauge how the company is doing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, JERE
description: DANIEL-Jere. On May 29, 1998. Friend-and-partner of Hara Marano, father of Josh and Sean Daniel, and step-father to Gabe and Daniel Marano. Grandfather of Lily Daniel and Quincy Daniel. Family and friends will be gathering to say goodbye on Sunday, May 31 at 12 noon at Frank E. Campbell, 1070 Madison Ave. at 81 Street. We will always remember Jere for his kindness, wisdom, support, sense of justice, humanity and his dreams.

title: The Real Asian Miracle; Asia Devalued
description: It wasn't long ago that East Asia was eating our lunch. Its stable, government-guided capital markets gave its companies the long time-horizons that ours lacked; perhaps more important, ''Asian values'' gave it an edge.

title: Alison Ambach, Christopher Illick
description: Alison Repass Ambach, the daughter of Lucy and Gordon Ambach of Washington, was married yesterday to Dr. Christopher Dunbar Illick, the son of Selden and Christopher Illick of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Robert Lamar, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's grandmother Mrs. German H. H. Emory in Southport, Conn.

title: It's Time for 'Railroad Roulette'
description: ''GOOD evening ladies and gentlemen and welcome to Railroad Roulette, where you never know when the wheel will stop. I'm your host, Andy Rayle. Now, let's meet our contestants. Maureen Lamb hails from Port Washington. Welcome, Maureen. Doesn't your line get washed out during severe rains?''

title: 72d St. Subway Entry
description: To the Editor:

title: Injured Wings Star Returns To Detroit to Lend Support
description: On his better days, Vladimir Konstantinov is a hockey player again. He competes against his 9-year-old daughter, Anastasia. They play in the driveway. He sits in a wheelchair and manipulates his stick with his best working arm.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Re-using an Industrial Area on Stamford's Fringe
description: FOR three decades, businesses of all sorts have sought out the prestige of tenancy in the imposing office buildings in the heart of this city.

title: The First Exhibit
description: To the Editor:

title: Mountain Skating
description: They look like giant in-line skates, boots with three wheels six inches in diameter that have to be blown up like the tires of a car. Daredevils take them over grass, dirt and ski slopes, sans snow. ''They're like mountain bikes on your legs,'' said Dennis Shafer, president and chief executive of Rollerblade Inc., the Minneapolis-based company that created the skates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIBERGER, WILLIAM W.
description: HEIBERGER-William W. May 30, 1998, in Aventura, FL. We'll miss you, Papa. Your loving family

title: Zeroing In on Creativity In a Nonfiction Course
description: ''I AM not for a minute telling you that this is not tough going,'' Lawrence (Ren) Weschler said, teasing his students at Sarah Lawrence College here. Mr. Weschler, a Pelham resident and staff writer at The New Yorker, teaches a small creative nonfiction course -- part of the college's master's program in writing.

title: The World: Weathering the Storm; The Southeast Asians Did Some Things Right
description: THE ruins of crony banks and businesses built on corruption and special favors litter the devastated economies of Southeast Asia, making it easy to notice what the region's leaders did wrong.

title: 'Power Plays,' Something More Than a Family Affair
description: ''POWER PLAYS'' is the umbrella title for the Manhattan Theater Club's program of three one-act plays, now settling in for an Off Broadway run at the Promenade Theater. Don't be confused by the fact that the Promenade is actually on Broadway (at 76th Street). The technically correct, if geographically inexact designation of ''Power Plays'' as Off Broadway perfectly fits this sometimes uproarious production, which uses language to subvert reason, sanity and peace of mind.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Sidewalk Slabs

title: Insider Sales Don't Always Burn Outsiders in I.P.O.'s
description: IF the cockpit crew dons parachutes before the plane even leaves the gate, prudent passengers may want to avoid the flight. But such logic doesn't necessarily apply to investments in new stock offerings.

title: New Delhi's Leaders Say They Don't Need to Match Tests in 'Competition'
description: India delayed a formal response to Pakistan's latest nuclear test today, but a senior official said India did not regard nuclear testing as a ''competition'' requiring New Delhi to match each move by Pakistan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHLEIFER, NACHIMSON, MAR GARET
description: SCHLEIFER - NACHIMSON - Mar garet, M.D. Your 37th Birthday. Maggie, we miss you so. Your loving family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUBALIN, HERB
description: LUBALIN-Herb. 1918-1981. As long as there are words and pictures his life, his wit, his work exists, though his presence is deeply missed. Rhoda Sparber Lubalin

title: Chess Buddies' Friendly War
description: They sit on the western side of the terrace at Central Park's Chess and Checkers House, on a hill north of the Wollman Rink, near East 64th Street. They are all men, of various ethnic backgrounds and mostly of retirement age. On weekday afternoons, a dozen or so show up, more on weekends. Laughing, cracking jokes and taunting each other, they play what they call ''speed chess,'' in which each player is allotted only a total of five minutes per game to make all his moves.

title: POSTINGS: An Upper East Side 'Terra Cotta Trek'; Colorful Tiles On the Skyline
description: Binoculars and walking shoes would be in order for anyone joining the Terra Cotta Trek of the Upper East Side beginning next Saturday at 1 P.M.

title: Sharon Seitz, Stuart Miller
description: Sharon Germaine Seitz and Stuart Frederic Miller, freelance writers in Manhattan, are to be married this afternoon at the Morris Yacht and Beach Club on City Island in the Bronx. Bart Worden, the assistant leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, is to officiate.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Portraits From Iran

title: Sunday, May 31, 1998: Soccer; We Don't Got Game
description: Less than two weeks before the World Cup brings global glory to soccer, pickup players in New York's own multinational soccer community are feeling oppressed. Nearly every day for two years, a lively gang of Brazilians, Brits, St. Lucians, Libyans and others has gathered in Central Park's North Meadow, one of the last refuges for impromptu pickup soccer games (as opposed to highly structured league contests) left in Manhattan. Next month, the Parks Department is shutting it down for a two-year, $4.6 million renovation, so the pickup guys will have to pick up and take it elsewhere.

title: Intentional Walk Issued to Bonds Yields Unintentional Disbelief
description: Of all the reactions to perhaps the most unusual play of the season, Buck Showalter will long remember the look on his catcher's face.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 31, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Ms. Steinacher, Ensign Provencher
description: Melissa Leigh Steinacher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Steinacher of Ithaca, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ens. Matthew Thomas Provencher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Provencher of Barrington, N.H. The Rev. Ronald E. Gaesser performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Ithaca.

title: A Share for Ms. Invisible
description: Last January, Ted Lauer had just split up with his girlfriend when it was time to send a $2,300 check to cover his summer share in Westhampton. Suddenly single, the Manhattan stockbroker, 28, gambled and bought two shares, hoping that by the summer his love life would improve. In a recent telephone conversation from the house he shares with 45 others, he expressed relief that he had had the foresight to buy the extra share. ''My house has strict girlfriend and guest policies, and I wasn't going to take the chance that if I had a new girlfriend she'd get cut out of the deal,'' he said.

title: Suzanne George, Craig Packer
description: Suzanne Margaret George and Craig William Packer are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Dennis C. Tobin at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Children's Books
description: HOORAY FOR DIFFENDOOFER DAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMOWITZ, BERNARD
description: HYMOWITZ-Bernard. The Staff of Weinstein and Holtzman, Inc, deeply regrets the passing of Bernard Hymowitz, the former President and co-owner of The Company. We extend heartfelt condolences to all the members of his family.

title: An Antitrust Antithesis
description: To the Editor:

title: Opinions Differ On Fire Island Chief
description: Re: ''Debate Engulfs New Fire Island Superintendent'' (May 7).

title: The Return Of Joe Six-Pack
description: I can remember when the President of the United States addressed his constituents as ''my fellow Americans'' or ''my friends'' (On Language: ''The Return of Joe Six-Pack,'' by William Safire, May 3). It saddens me that the currently sitting President has come to think of the average American as ''Joe Six-Pack.''

title: Offering Commuters Fare Cuts and Free Parking
description: Riders on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad out of Bridgeport, Conn., will enjoy lower fares and free parking at the station if a Connecticut proposal to help rejuvenate downtown Bridgeport and reduce traffic on Interstate 95 is approved.

title: In a Solo Turn, a Tempest Over a Famed Tutu
description: IT is easy to love the art of Edgar Degas but harder to feel affection for the man. He might be called the French Impressionist with an attitude problem. Thin, bearded and forever ornery, he spoke of women as lower mammals and insisted they were I.Q.-deficient. He had no known mistresses and never married, explaining with his usual sourness, ''I would have been in mortal misery all my life for fear my wife might say, 'That's a pretty little thing,' after I had finished a picture.''

title: School Spreads Alcohol Policy to Wine Sips in Paris
description: American zero tolerance of student alcohol use collided recently with French joie de vivre. In the Denver area's wealthiest school district, prohibition won.

title: What Shall We Ask of Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Equity Fund Without Any Stock
description: ''WE'RE like a square peg'' in a round hole, John B. Sprow said with a laugh when asked why investors had a hard time understanding his fund. Indeed, it is impossible to fit his fund, Smith Breeden Equity Market Plus, into a clear-cut category.

title: Staying Put and Caring For the Neighborhood
description: IN a world full of fence-sitters, Evelyn Schatz is about as subdued as a whirling cannonball. Friend and foe alike in New Haven have labeled her irrepressible, tyrannical, bumptious, blunt and brassy. In short, she is considered a dogged persuader who gets things done.

title: All Honest Heroes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: May 24-30; Starr Wants Quick Decision
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater Independent Counsel, asked the Supreme Court to rule quickly on whether two of President Clinton's aides must appear before the grand jury investigating the Monica Lewinsky matter. A Federal judge in Washington had ordered the aides to appear, but the White House is appealing the ruling.

title: World Cup Tuneups End With Attack Sputtering
description: The United States soccer team had plenty of chances to defeat Scotland today with a smothering defense and a newly liberated offense, but the American men again had trouble finishing what they began.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIVELSON, SHEILA F.
description: FEIVELSON-Sheila F. 6/1/90. My darling child. Loving, giving, super special. You are with me always. Love you, Mom

title: Ideas & Trends: Leaving America; Ireland, New Promised Land
description: BETWEEN retrieving thrown juice cups and cleaning up crushed cookies, the moms in the mother-toddler group at the Irish Community Center here talk about home. But unlike generations of homesick Irish women before them, many of them aren't just talking. They're going.

title: Juliet Lambert, John Pratt
description: Juliet Ann Lambert, who in June will be resuming the role of Fantine in the Broadway production of ''Les Miserables,'' was married yesterday to John Whalen Pratt, a first vice president at Salomon Smith Barney in New York and the associate director of one of its mutual fund advisory services. The Rev. Marek Chmurski performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of Hope Chapel in West Barnstable, Mass.

title: REELING INDONESIA GETS FISCAL BREAK
description: A top official of the International Monetary Fund said today that the economic situation in Indonesia was far worse than earlier estimated and that the fund would relax its deadlines for the imposition of austerity measures.

title: Woman's Release From Prison May Turn Out to Be Brief
description: Two years ago, Ray Alvarez was leaving the basement of his newsstand on Avenue A when he felt a thunderous blow to his head. He collapsed in a heap on the stairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, FRANK J. (FRANCIS)
description: O'BRIEN-Frank J. (Francis). 65 years, on May 29 from complications after bone surgery. Retired computer consultant (Blue Cross, J.P. Morgan, AIG, AonRe). A gentle man of high culture. Lifelong student of literature, languages, history and music. Amateur actor, playwright and opera buff. Taught drama at the New School Institute for Retired Professionals. For 29 years, beloved husband to Miriam (Myrna), caring stepfather to Lisa, David and the late Daniel Bershtein. Family receiving at their Brooklyn home June 1-5 from 4-7 PM. Contributions may be made to Yale, Class of '54.

title: May 24-30; Viagra for the Poor
description: The Clinton Administration suggested that Medicaid might have to pay for Viagra, the new impotency pill. Federal officials said the Medicaid law seemed to require that states must cover most prescription drugs when they are used for purposes approved by the Food and Drug Administration, as is the case with Viagra.

title: Birdman of Fifth Avenue Reveals His Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: 50-Year Retrospective Of Sculptor's Work
description: ELIZABETH CATLETT models as beautifully as she carves, but it is in the more laborious, subtractive mode that she has done her finest work. Or so it seems from the sculptor's 50-year retrospective, which is on view in the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College here.

title: Lives; Asphalt Optimist
description: The place where I stand is exposed to the weather. In the winter, the north wind whips in over the cornfields, past the Styrofoam cup factory and across the freeway access ramp. It blows the tail of my overcoat askew.

title: Three Homers Give Leiter All the Support He Needs
description: For nearly two months the Mets had to rely on their pitching and defense, and sometimes a little help from the other team's defense, to squeak out victories. Not anymore.

title: Children's Books
description: BALLPARK. Written and illustrated by Elisha Cooper. Greenwillow. $15. (Ages 5 and up) What happens at an old-fashioned, open-to-the-sky ball park on the day of a baseball game? The story, told in small, graceful watercolor illustrations and simple text, begins in the early morning as a groundskeeper rides a red tractor around the infield, and continues through a day when play is interrupted by a cloudburst. Many details of the game, and the experience of going to the ball park, as well as a panorama of fans, players and support staff.

title: Hardship Claim Is Doubted In Bid for SoHo Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects
description: To the Editor:

title: May 24-30; Making Money at Home
description: Even as the tides of free trade, globalized investments and regional currencies are washing over every continent, there are islands of resistance.. In 66 towns and villages in Canada and the United States, people are printing their own money -- from Sand Dollars in Bolinas, Calif., to Mountain Money in Hot Springs, N.C., to Thread City Bread in Willimantic, Conn.

title: In America; The Big Chill
description: On Thursday a Federal judge ruled that the city could not revoke the licenses of newsstand operators without a hearing. The Giuliani administration had tried to establish new rules that would allow it to shut down newsstands without holding a hearing or giving a reason.

title: Clea Simon and Jon Garelick
description: Clea Simon and Jon Sherman Garelick are to be married today by Rabbi Donald Pollock at the Lyman Estate in Waltham, Mass.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Among the films brightening the television screen this week are an improved version of a Broadway play, World War II suspense, a corking thriller and a briny adventure.

title: Dorothy Briley, 63, Children's Book Editor
description: Dorothy Spence Briley, the editor in chief and publisher of Clarion Books and a vice president of the trade and reference division of the Houghton Mifflin Company, died last Sunday at her home in New York City. She was 63.

title: In Hartford, Serious Food and Talk
description: A ONCE mundane space in Hartford's center that used to be a political hangout known as Frank's (now moved elsewhere) has been smartly transformed into Max Downtown, with large windows and high ceilings. This new location for the flagship of the Max mini-conglomerate (with Max Amore in Glastonbury and Max a Mia in Avon) is perfectly situated to its business clientele. The mostly brown decor is invigorated by a vibrant mural on the upper walls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAO, CHIEN YUAN (ERIC), MD.
description: KAO-Chien Yuan (Eric), MD. The administration, faculty, staff and students of the State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn mourn the sudden passing of Chien Yuan (Eric) Kao, MD, Professor of Pharmacology, and an alumnus of the Health Science Center. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his family and friends. Eugene B. Feigelson, MD Interim President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, STEVEN
description: WERNER-Steven. 1898-1998. Died on May 30. Mourned by his beloved wife Klara, children Dr. Andrew Werner and Elaine and granddaughter Andrea. Born in Budapest, Hungary. A man of outstanding intellect who excelled in his profession of mechanical engineering. Came to this country in 1956, during the Hungarian Revolaution, as a refugee and built a successful life. Leaves behind an unfillable void for all of those who knew and loved him. Funeral arrangements are private.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report on May 17 about the use of women's names on apartment buildings misstated the origin of the name Evelyn, at 101 West 78th Street. Though some residents believe the building was named for Evelyn Nesbit, the showgirl who was married to the industrialist Harry K. Thaw, records show that it was named when she was a small child in Pennsylvania. The origin of the name is obscure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINDUS, PROFESSOR MILTON
description: HINDUS-Professor Milton. On Thursday, May 28, of Newton, MA. Husband of Eva (Tenenbaum). Father of Myra Hindus and her partner Barbara Frank of Jamaica Plain, MA. Services at Berlin Chapel, Brandeis University, Waltham, MA, on Tuesday, June 2 at 11 AM. Remembrances may be made to National Women's Committee, PO Box 9110, MS132, Waltham, MA 02254-9110. For information contact the Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNLAP, JACK
description: DUNLAP-Jack. On May 25, 1998. Devoted friend of Jack Metcalf. During his thirty years at the Metropolitan Opera House, he was most recently the Assistant to Chairman Mrs. Louise Humphries. After his retirement, he did volunteer work at several organizations. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd Street, New York, NY 10021, and DOROT, Inc., 171 West 85 Street, NY, NY 10024. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Sports of The Times; No Mercy Even for U.S. World Cup Veterans
description: IN this capital city, there are no guarantees for incumbents. Four years ago, Alexi Lalas was a towering presence on the American soccer team that advanced to an epic game with Brazil on the Fourth of July.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, BARRY
description: KLEIN-Barry. Happy birthday. You are missed more than words can ever say. Love and kisses, Sherry

title: Couples Ignores Migraine and Takes 3d-Round Lead
description: There was a major difference between the way Fred Couples felt today and the way he played.

title: Kimberly Greene, Brewster Jennings
description: Kimberly Jan Greene, the daughter of Carolyn Filiss of Seattle, was married yesterday to Brewster Prentice Jennings, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Jennings of Mill Neck, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Gilbert performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: Q&A/Dannel Malloy; Stamford Offers Prekindergarten at Age 4
description: AS Mayor Dannel Malloy of Stamford sat through the lengthy meetings of the School Improvement Panel at the State Capitol he had an idea. Listening to the data about the importance of early education, he decided to create an opportunity for all 4-year-olds in Stamford to attend prekindergarten. By September, 360 children will be enrolled in the new school readiness program. Every 4-year-old child who lives in Stamford will be eligible, with fees charged on a sliding scale from $5 to $135 a week. According to the Mayor, Stamford will be the first city in the nation to offer a prekindergarten program to all its children. ''What we want to do is guarantee all 4-year-old children in the City of Stamford a prekindergarten experience regardless of their financial circumstances,'' Mr. Malloy said. ''It's the single largest step we can take to resolve disparity with other towns.''

title: Where the Bad Air Comes From
description: WHEN many new residents arrived in Connecticut they thought they were getting away from the noise and pollution of the Big City and that they would be enjoying rural landscapes and picturesque towns. One would be able to throw open a window to take in a deep breath of fresh air. Ah were it but true; unfortunately the state has some of the smoggiest, most unhealthful air in the entire country.

title: With Hardly a Stir, Party Leaves Japan Coalition
description: Japan's four-year-old governing coalition fractured today when the Social Democratic Party formally announced it would quit and strike out on its own.

title: No Big Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Counting Sheep, And Dollar Signs
description: FOR more than two years, Edward Marx, of Cos Cob, Conn., deliberated about buying a mattress and box spring with a $4,500 price tag. Plagued with a bad lower back, he hoped his dream mattress in the Duxiana showroom in Greenwich, Conn., would alleviate his nightly discomfort.

title: Author Distorts Memory of Bums
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Welcome Truce For Jazz Festivals
description: EVER since the Newport Jazz Festival moved to New York in 1972, the idea of a jazz festival in the city has been a sore spot for everybody involved, from the producers to the musicians to the fans. The oldest and best known of these gatherings in New York, George Wein's JVC Jazz Festival, successor to Newport, has traditionally elicited a storm of questions and doubts.

title: Naked City
description: HERB'S PAJAMAS

title: Clambake
description: Leaving Small's Hotel

title: Groups Seek To Control Growing Sprawl
description: MAUREEN MORGAN has renegotiated her relationship with The Road. Previously, Ms. Morgan, now a leader in the campaign to stop expansion of Interstate 287, was a blithe traveler on the road she scarcely noticed. She would climb into her tan Volkswagen, slip into an automatic pilot mode, put her foot on the gas and go.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption on the Backtalk page on Sunday, with an article about the Brooklyn Dodgers, referred incorrectly in some copies to the site of the playoff game in which Bobby Thomson hit a dramatic home run to beat them in 1951. It was the Polo Grounds, not Ebbets Field.

title: Introduction
description: Warren Beatty received mixed reviews from readers turned off by talk of political injustice over four-course meals, but a picture of the star stumping for George McGovern was a hit with two women who both identified themselves as the girl with the lollipop standing beside Beatty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCH, KALMAN
description: ASCH-Kalman. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Linda. Devoted brother of Toby. Adored uncle. Services Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Mon., June 1, 3:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Stroke Club, North Shore Hospital, Manhasset L.I.

title: Lobbyists Barred for a Time at City Hall
description: Police officers barred lobbyists from speaking to City Council members or handing them leaflets on the way into budget negotiations yesterday, but the officers backed off after Speaker Peter F. Vallone protested.

title: Not a Mall, and a Lot Cozier
description: BROADWAY at the corner of Prince Street in SoHo is a boundary between two fashion camps. West lies the familiar, the highly advertised. The khakis of the Banana Republic. The sexy, flower-bedecked extravaganzas masquerading as shoes at D.& G. But east, along Elizabeth, Mulberry and Mott Streets, lies the unknown, the never-advertised, the freshly sprouted -- 25 tiny shops full of clothes, hats, shoes or jewelry. Most have opened in the last two years -- nine last year and five this year -- and two are so new they have just celebrated their one-month anniversaries.

title: Cookbooks
description: When warm weather arrives, most home cooks secretly heave a sigh of relief. The pressure is off. Ambitious culinary schemes are deferred, and gradually unravel completely. That four-course experiment in Gascon cuisine can wait until next fall. In spring and summer, it is a far, far better thing to cook according to whim, tossing together a little of this, a little of that and not setting the bar too high.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: When Britain Really Ruled the Waves
description: THE SAFEGUARD OF THE SEA

title: On Language; Hamlet Enters Whitewater
description: The ghost of a melancholy Dane strode upon the Whitewater stage this month.

title: Boeing Is Still Plodding Despite Being No. 1
description: IT has one of the great global brand names, faces only one competitor, and demand for its product is setting records. So why is Boeing stock still taxiing?

title: Hands Dance, Feet Sing And Bodies Are the Drums
description: TAP is a rambunctious hybrid dance that was born in America from a mixed heritage of African and European dance and musical styles. Tap is distinguished by its rhythms, which transform the dancers into percussive musicians whose feet are their instruments. Through its rhythms, tap can absorb all varieties of music, from Bach to hip-hop, and through its movements, it can embrace all kinds of popular dance steps and gestures. This guarantees that tap will remain fresh and connected to the larger social context.

title: Scene but Not Heard
description: I cannot agree with Frankel's no-nonsense point of view. Is not the point of an opening paragraph to ''grab'' the reader? I enjoy a little creativity, along with the facts about President Clinton, Indonesia, Newt, Frank's death. If I want ''just the facts, ma'am,'' I can watch CNN. I love words. I love learning new ones -- looking up a funky and obscure pearl I can read only in The New York Times. Don't rain on my parade.

title: With Brutality and Bribes, Mexican Suspect Thrived
description: Among the scores of kidnappers operating in Mexico, Daniel Arizmendi Lopez has earned a name as the boldest and most brutal, Mexican officials say, and not only by hacking off hostages' ears to pressure desperate relatives into paying million-dollar ransoms.

title: Amsterdam
description: June is perhaps Amsterdam's best month. The weather is usually sunny and dry. It is warm (or at least mild), and for those who haven't had their fill of culture after trips to the Concertgebouw or the Big Three museums -- the Rijksmuseum, the Van Gogh and the Stedelijk Museum of Modern Art -- there is the bonus of the Holland Festival and its program of music, theater and dance.

title: Smirking Byrd Outpoints Castillo in a 10-Round Snoozer
description: Eliecer Castillo faced down sharks during his escape from Cuba on a leaky homemade rubber raft in 1994. But faced with a smirking Chris Byrd tonight at the Atlantic City Convention Center, he could not escape with a victory in their 10-round heavyweight bout.

title: Habitats/45 Sutton Place South; Penthouse With a Terrace Beats a Weekend Home
description: E. LEE HENNESSEE and her husband, Charles J. Gradante, were shopping for a weekend house. Instead, they bought a penthouse in their Sutton Place South apartment building.

title: QUICK BITE/Lumberton; Wings With Garlic, Wings With Sauce, but Mainly, Wings
description: Dadz has a menu worthy of a Greek diner, but normal customers on normal high-fat diets aren't that interested in variety: they go to Dadz for the wings. At this Burlington County bar -- actually, roadhouse is probably the best word -- Buffalo wings, barbecue wings and garlic wings come out of the kitchen night and day, on plates and in buckets. They are great big wings from great big chickens, plump beyond all reason and suspiciously tender.
