title: Going to Bat for the Home Team
description: MY oldest brother says I need some bats around the house. He's forever sending me brochures and E-mail proclaiming the virtues of bats, those much-feared nocturnal mammals that think they're birds. He uses phrases like ''nature's bug-zappers'' and ''D.D.T. with fur'' to describe them because they eat insects by the ton.

title: Pack Your Bags
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIALKOFF, JACOB
description: FIALKOFF-Jacob. Devoted husband of the late Ethel. Loving father of David and Rosalie Fialkoff, Susan and William Webster. Beloved brother of Ivy. Adored grandfather of Adam, Laura, Stuart. Great-grandfather of Mitchell and Staci. He was a cofounder and past president of Congregation Beth Shalom of Kingsbay. Services Tuesday, June 2, 2:30 PM, at Congregaton Beth Shalom of Kingsbay, 2710 Ave X.

title: Life's Lessons
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends: Shhhhh! The Audience Is Listening.; When Seeing a Movie Is a Pain in the Ear
description: GODZILLA was going about his business in a Times Square theater one afternoon last week when he discovered a murdered infant godzilla and shrieked in anguish (118 decibels). Then he was strafed by fighter jets (105 to 115 decibels for five minutes). Finally, he died (67 decibels).

title: Musical Festival of the Hamptons Offers Stars Under the Stars
description: A CHILDHOOD DREAM has come true for Eleanor Sage Leonard, and with it 10 midsummer days of East End music.

title: May 24-30; Where's the Fire?
description: Fire safety in New York City is a deadly serious business. There have been too many horrific scenes of charred bodies piled up at cramped exits.

title: Banding Together For a Transit Link
description: Italian-food merchants in the Belmont section of the Bronx have banded together with the Bronx Zoo to make it easy for New Yorkers without cars to reach them. Last Saturday was the first run of a 25-seat jitney that travels from the Metro-North Fordham station to the zoo and the shops, groceries and restaurants around Arthur Avenue. The jitney runs hourly every weekend from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., until Nov. 1.

title: Innovations Expand School Studies
description: AS some school districts struggle to meet higher state-mandated standards, other districts are leapfrogging ahead with programs that are more exciting -- and often more rigorous. In the process, the districts are redefining, in many cases, what school is all about.

title: Defending the Swiss
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWEERDT, ARTHUR L.
description: DeWEERDT-Arthur L. Died May 29, 1998, at home. Survived by a friend, Raul Urrejola. He was a retired editor from McGraw Hill in NYC, where he was employed for approximately 40 years. Services were private at the A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, Cliffside Park, NJ.

title: Passion Play Director Asks Fairness for McNally
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Broadway is the one slice that's making money. It has become the tail that wags the dog. ''

title: Mr. Conservative
description: There wasn't much left of the Barry Goldwater I knew when, in 1994, he made his regular appearance at the annual Goldwater Award dinner. That year the prize went to Lady Thatcher. For the convenience of the press, the award was presented in a hotel salon, away from the crowd. The cameras whirred.

title: Anita Pamintuan and Dino Fusco
description: Anita Lacdao Pamintuan, a daughter of Dr. Elvira D. Lacdao-Pamintuan and Dr. Jose C. Pamintuan of Seaford, Del., is to be married today to Dino Fusco, a son of Guglielmo Fusco of Hebron, Conn., and the late Maria Benacquista Fusco. The Rev. Barry J. Langley is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Anthony of Padua in Wilmington, Del.

title: Rosie Jones's 64 Comes Easily
description: Rosie Jones, an eight-time winner in 16 years on the L.P.G.A. Tour, bolted four shots clear of a stalled field with an eight-under-par 64 yesterday in the L.P.G.A. Rochester International.

title: A Top-44 List For All Time
description: Mozart made the cut. So did Bach and Beethoven, Chopin and Coltrane, and Bob Marley. But Sinatra did not, nor did Elvis, nor, for that matter, did the Beatles.

title: At Cannes, Synergy Is a No-Show
description: ''DER Scharon,'' said the note with the flowers. ''Tank you somatc for you traveling to Cannes. A louk forwarh to seeing you leeter -- Harvet.'' Sharon Stone and Harvey Weinstein, the recipient and sender of the bouquet, respectively, sat in Ms. Stone's hotel room marveling at this tiny document as a pure, perfect specimen of Cannes-style miscommunication. That same day, Mr. Weinstein had been profiled by a French film journal that managed to mix him up with Bob Weinstein, his brother and Miramax partner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RETTEW, DANIEL A.
description: RETTEW-Daniel A. Died May 27, 1998 after a mercifully brief struggle with AIDS. Beloved son of Roslyn, brother of Amyjane and Thomas Mark & uncle of Nicholas, Thomas, Eleanor and Devon. Dan will be greatly missed by his family, friends and former colleagues from DANY and from the USVI. Services private. Donations may be made to Open House Nursery School, 203 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

title: Baja Preserves
description: To the Editor: We at the Nature Conservancy were happy to see the articles ''Baja by Land and Sea'' (March 29).

title: Westchester Q&A/Dr. Stuart A. Newman; Drawing a Line in Genetic Engineering
description: DR. STUART A. NEWMAN, a professor of cell biology and anatomy at New York Medical College, wanted to do something controversial to evoke public and scientific debate on the morality of genetic engineering. So Dr. Newman and a colleague filed a patent for a process to make ''chimeras,'' creatures that are part human, part animal.

title: An Ailing Teen-Ager to Sit In the Dugout With His Idol
description: Ray Smith's voice is mellow and high-pitched, and interspersed with a sweet giggle that can melt a room. It is the voice of a 14-year-old boy who has endured three open-heart surgeries, sometimes spending his birthday in the hospital. It is a voice that leaves an impression.

title: Add G.M. Building To Trump Holdings
description: In a deal reminiscent of the high-flying 1980's, Donald Trump and an Indianapolis insurance company have purchased the General Motors Building in midtown Manhattan for $800 million.

title: Jerry Brown Thinks Smaller
description: Jerry brown teeters atop a table in an oakland cafe, his arms akimbo like a jack-in-the-box. Surprise, it's me! It's early on a Saturday morning, and droopy-eyed customers drift past him, bellying up to the counter. But Brown won't be ignored. ''Oakland has been on the verge of greatness for so long, it's time to push it past the verge!'' he shouts as the black table wobbles beneath him.

title: The Salsa Is Hot, but What About the Stock?
description: IN grocery stores and, increasingly, among investors, ''Mexican'' food is hot but real Mexican food is hotter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, ARTHUR
description: FINE-Arthur. October 14, 1902 - May 27, 1998, of Tucson, AZ, formerly of New York City. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 64 years. Adored father of Alice Fine, Joseph Fine & Lucy Rosengarten. Cherished grandfather of Leslie Fine, Dina Davenport, Daniel Rosengarten and the late Ruth and Jonathan Rosengarten. Great grandfather of Mikaila Davenport. A graduate of New York University, he was Past President of M. Fine & Sons Mfg. Co., Inc. in NYC (founded in 1890). He was a Founder and Past President of Temple Israel in Great Neck, NY & former Vice President and Life Trustee of Park Avenue Synagogue in NYC. He was a devoted supporter and honoree of the Jewish Theological Seminary in NYC and the United Jewish Appeal, since the inception of the State of Israel.

title: Around Island, Many Boaters but Few Slips
description: WHEN Hubert Raynor digs for clams this year he will have to increase his harvest to help pay for $350 he has to pay to Southampton Town to dock his boat.

title: Sarah Kidwell, C. S. Borghesani
description: Sarah Elizabeth Kidwell and Christopher Scott Borghesani were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard S. DenUyl Jr., a Congregational minister, officiated at the Allen's Neck Friends Meeting House in South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Look at the Long Term
description: To the Editor:

title: Mirror of the Moment, Perhaps a Mild Panic
description: IT doesn't take a Nostradamus to predict that the next few years will see a flood of shows that honor -- or despair of -- the millennium. An early entry, ''Tick Tick Tick,'' at Real Art Ways in Hartford, is both cryptic and engaging; it is also capable of causing mild panic in viewers.

title: Miss Graham And Mr. Cooper
description: Samantha Anne Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Graham of Holland, Pa., was married yesterday to James Agar Cooper Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cooper Sr. of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Dr. J. Dennis Williams performed the ceremony at Thompson Memorial Presbyterian Church in New Hope, Pa.

title: Moving On, Without Wheels
description: FOR the first time in 15 years, Tommy Schierioth won't be pushing a rolling chair on the Boardwalk this summer. ''I'm in pretty good shape physically, but my eyes are starting to go,'' he explained. ''I've got glaucoma. My life is starting to look like a dirty window.''

title: What Manuscripts May Have to Say About Music
description: WESTERN classical music is based on a rather small number of good ideas, one of the best being notation. Once music could be written down, it could gain in definition. And out of this increased definition sprang what is perhaps the most special feature of music in the West: the extent to which a composition can be particularized to carry, in sound, the signature of its composer. In the challenge and dynamism of a Beethoven symphony, or in the pleasures and suggestions of a piece by Debussy, we hear a person. The hand that held the pen still moves, drawing patterns in our minds.

title: Little Club That Could: Sailing on a No-Frills Approach
description: The sailing squad at Hobart and William Smith tends to think of itself as the provincial, can-do little guy of college sailing: the Green Bay Packers of the blustery, blue-collar Lambeau Field taking on the corporate ownerships and climate-controlled luxury boxes of the typical National Football League megalopolis.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ASTROVE, ANITA FAY
description: ASTROVE-Anita Fay, May 29, 1997. I love you always. Your Bertie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, CONSTANCE KAUFMAN
description: SOLOMON-Constance Kaufman. A leader of several volunteer groups including the Bellevue Hospital Asssociation and the New York Women's Foundation, died at the age of 74 on Friday, May 15, 1998 in Belvedere, CA. from pneumonia and chronic emphysema. Connie remained active until two days before her death. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, Anthony; her brother George Kaufman; her son Adam; her daughter Tracy; her grandchildren Peter and James and two poodles Cobb & Rust. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, June 2 at the New York Historical Society, 2 West 77 St., at 4 PM. Donations should be sent to the New York Women's Foundation.

title: Jeanne McMullin, Henry Labalme
description: Jeanne McMullin and Henry George Labalme were married yesterday atop Mohegan Bluffs on Block Island, R.I. The Rev. Frederick C. Lanz, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Budget Talks Stall as Mayor and Speaker Chase Own Goals
description: Emissaries of the two most powerful officials in New York City government met last week in a private office in City Hall. There, behind glass doors masked by white curtains, they began the pokerlike negotiations over the city's $34 billion budget.

title: Robyn Tarnofsky And Antony Ryan
description: Robyn F. Tarnofsky and Antony L. Ryan, law associates, were married on Monday at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi David Fass officiated.

title: Patient Care An Issue At a Home In Ossining
description: A COMMITTEE of the Board of Legislators wants to know if criticism of an Ossining nursing home is valid or motivated by revenge from a new employees union that cannot get a contract.

title: Neighbors Fight 'City Hall'
description: Yet another upscale restaurant is scheduled to open in TriBeCa soon, this one called City Hall. Owned by Henry Meer, proprietor of the Cub Room in SoHo, the new place was billed in promotional literature as ''a town square for the entire downtown neighborhood,'' with several rooms and a sidewalk cafe.

title: What Shall We Ask of Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: Choice for State's Quarter: Washington's Crossing
description: Emanuel Leutze's classic painting of George Washington crossing the Delaware River on his way back to Trenton in 1776 has been recommended for the back of 700 million quarters to be issued next year to commemorate New Jersey.

title: Backtalk; Uneasy Lies the Crown
description: History tells of an Indian nation of the Plains that judged its greatness by the bravery of its enemies. In simple terms, if you fight only pugs, you are only the best pug. On the other side of the coin, great competition makes great champions.

title: Finding Paths in the Corporate Jungle
description: It was the most important meeting Carmela Guarnera had ever attended. Her consulting firm had been hired to help develop a Walt Disney theme park in South America, and she was on the team assigned to come up with ideas for rides.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM; Fighting to Keep a Touch of Green
description: When Matthew Albert started a community garden, activism was far from his mind. But last month, Mayor Giuliani transferred the land under many of these gardens to housing officials for development.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/The Lower East Side; Reinventing the First Stop for Immigrants
description: THIS summer the Lower East Side, long the first home of immigrants, will mark the centennial of the consolidation of what is now New York City.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Chicago Moves a Road And Adds a Campus
description: The 11-year task of moving Lake Shore Drive in Chicago, completed in 1996, has created a campus for three major museums: the Adler Planetarium and Astronomy Museum, the Field Museum, and the John G. Shedd Aquarium.

title: What Shall We Ask of Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WAGONFELD, YETTA
description: WAGONFELD-Yetta. 7/1/08-5/30/97. We miss you and you will always be in our hearts. Love from, Your children, Sam and Susan and from your grandchildren, Betty, Marjorie, Peter, David, and Joel, and from Hellen

title: Black Jack
description: UNTIL THE LAST

title: Sunday, May 31, 1998; SPECK IMPACT
description: It's no giant asteroid, but on Nov. 17, the Leonid meteoroid shower will pass through the Earth's atmosphere, producing millions of particles ranging from dust-speck size to pebble. *In its path are more than 500 satellites that control everything from military aircraft to television. *The last Leonid storm, in 1966, encountered fewer than 50 military satellites, some built to withstand nuclear attack, but today's birds have fragile mirrors and solar panels. *Satellite owners and experts met in California last month to discuss protective measures; suggestions included positioning the satellites' sensitive sides away from incoming. *Could this mean another cell-phone blackout? Most likely not, says David K. Lynch, an astrophysicist with the Aerospace Corporation. At worst, some TV stations might go away.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the possible effects on technology investments from antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corporation misstated the location of Sand Hill Road, a California center for venture capital firms. It is in Menlo Park, not Palo Alto.

title: Chaim Suller, 96, Editor of a Yiddish Paper
description: Chaim Suller, a longtime editor of The Morning Freiheit, a left-wing Yiddish newspaper in New York, who criticized Soviet policy regarding Jewish culture, died on Tuesday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 96 and lived in the East Village of Manhattan.

title: Islanders Trade Top 1996 Draft Pick
description: The Islanders traded left wing Jean-Pierre Dumont, their 1996 first-round draft pick, to Chicago for center Dmitri Nabokov yesterday. The 21-year-old Nabokov, the 19th overall pick in the 1995 draft, had seven goals and four assists in 25 games with the Blackhawks this season.

title: Who Created Santa?
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Past on Its Sleeve, Tribe Seeks Bonn's Apology
description: Asked where he got his traditional Herero dress hat, Alexander Tjikuzo, 63, answered, ''My grandfather left it to me.''

title: Maria Peznola, Steven Reed
description: Maria MacNeil Peznola and Steven Francis Reed, financial executives in New York, were married yesterday in Marstons Mills, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Allan Page, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the Inn at the Mills.

title: Upgraded Drug Traffic Flourishes on Old Route
description: This week Federal officials in South Florida scored what they believe is their biggest cocaine seizure from a pleasure boat: 4,000 pounds, with a street value of $34 million, found in hidden compartments aboard a 62-foot-long luxury yacht.

title: Making Bulbs That Really Shine
description: When Randy Satin and Larry Merson formed a business that sells lightbulbs to companies in the region, they spent time fielding complaints from customers who said the bulbs blew out prematurely, shattered too easily and had bases that snapped off and stuck to the sockets.

title: Turkey Opens Terminal At Airport in Antalya
description: A new international air terminal has opened in the Turkish resort town of Antalya, where millions of visitors arrive each year for Mediterranean holidays on Turkey's south coast. During summer months, charter flights, mainly from northern European cities, pour into Antalya along with many scheduled flights.

title: Students Lose On Last Issue In Bias Suit
description: In the latest and probably final chapter of a closely watched case testing how far universities must go to accommodate disabled students, a Federal judge ruled on Friday that Boston University did not have to allow liberal arts undergraduates with learning disabilities to substitute other courses for a two-year foreign-language requirement.

title: Taking the Plunge on Casual Day
description: As the weather improves, so does the climate for casual days, those corporately sanctioned breaches of formal office wear. Who wears what on casual day in your office, and does any of the attire make you pine for a bit less latitude in personal style? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@ nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: When Overtime Doesn't Feel So Fine
description: WHEN a winter storm destroyed the Albertson's store where Debra Chard used to work as a deli manager, she called it divine justice. She was relieved to get away from managers who, she said, pushed her to work before and after shifts and demanded that she work long hours with no breaks.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HOTEL

title: Editorial Observer; Nuclear Fear and Narcissism Shake South Asia
description: India and Pakistan could not have asked for a clearer example of the futility of nuclear arms grandstanding than the one they have set themselves. Now that Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has answered India's test blasts with his own, India needs to face a fundamental question. Why did Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee give up the advantages of nuclear ambiguity in favor of an action that has clearly worsened his country's security?

title: Chopsticks and Bun
description: On bad hair days, Helen Dougherty, 30, a computer sales executive, used to toss up her long red mane with a pair of chopsticks. But once compliments started rolling in, she began wearing the style every day.

title: Attacking That Army Of Ants
description: LOOKS like it's going to be a buggy summer,'' said Dr. Michael F. Potter, a professor of urban entomology at the University of Kentucky. ''I'm already getting tons of calls on mosquitoes, and it's a better than average year for fleas.''

title: Three European Cities Offer Discount Cards
description: Travelers to Budapest, Helsinki and London can save money this summer by buying city cards, which provide access to public transportation, admission to tourist sites and discounts on museum and theater tickets.

title: Confidence Runs High for Popular California Senator
description: Barbara Boxer has spent much of her political career defying the odds. When she first ran for the Senate in 1992 after representing the progressive Bay Area in the House of Representatives for 10 years, she was dismissed as too liberal, too parochial, too out of step with voters statewide.

title: Playground Proves Elusive
description: For many people, a stroll along the water is the ultimate tranquilizer. But for parents of preschoolers, it can jangle the nerves. That is why some West Village residents are unhappy that the section of the Hudson River Park planned for their neighborhood does not include a waterfront playground they would consider safe for small children.

title: Aspects of Love: Seven Playwrights on the Sonnets
description: IT seems appropriate that the Acting Company, the classical repertory theater that tours nationally, is celebrating its 25th-anniversary season with an evening of plays and music inspired by Shakespeare. The sonnets, to be exact.

title: In the Region/Long Island; The Last Season for the Last Drive-In Picture Show
description: TWO days ago the three giant screens of the Westbury Drive-in Theater on Brush Hollow Road, dark since last November, came alive for the theater's final season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINATRA, FRANCIS ALBERT, PH.D.
description: SINATRA-Francis Albert, Ph.D.; '85 Hon. D. Eng; Stevens Institute of Technology. On this Stevens Alumni weekend, alumni mourn the recent death of Frank, our fellow alumnus, and are thankful for his good works for Stevens. Guys of '53

title: Sports of The Times; Bird Is Still Trying to Cover Jordan
description: EVEN in retirement, Larry Bird has had his cameo moments on the pro basketball stage that has been Michael Jordan's for almost a decade. Alongside Jordan on the original Dream Team in Barcelona, Spain; in Jordan's hamburger commercials, matching him shot for innovative shot, and with Bugs and Daffy in a supporting role of a cartoon film.

title: The Whit Stillman Rat Pack
description: IT was Christmas break 1969. As Charles Scribner 3d, then a freshman at Princeton, tells it, he was sitting in a room off the grand ballroom of the Plaza Hotel with a freshman from Harvard named Whit Stillman.

title: Photography: Visions by Rudy
description: The gallery owner Julie Saul, who reviewed Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's photographs now hanging in, of all places, the Leica Gallery, must be receiving a lot of bad photography portfolios for review, if, as she states, ''his photos are actually better than much of the stuff sent to me each day for consideration'' (Sunday: ''Visions by Rudy,'' May 10). Is it not enough that we are force-fed the Mayor's quality of life ''vision'' for New York, without being subjected to his frankly boring photographs? A ''point and shoot'' style and a helicopter do not a photographer make.

title: At Disney World, Food That's Not Mickey Mouse
description: TO view the perfectly manicured lawns, the monorail gliding silently overhead, the fountains cascading in syncopated splendor and the perpetually sunny smiles of the Disney employees is to accept that there is a god and his name is Walt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPARBER, JAMES N. BERNSTEIN
description: SPARBER-James N. Bernstein. Died suddenly on May 27, 1998. Adored son of Gloria Bernstein Sparber and the late Dr. Joseph Bernstein. Most beloved brother of Jody Sparber Giordano and Francesca Sparber Harvey. Beloved uncle of four. Precious and darling sweetheart of Joyce Jaffe, always and forever.

title: The Economics Of Intervention; A Prominent but Impolitic Theorist Questions the Worship of Free Markets
description: NO group in America seems more resistant to economic theory than politicians. For them, it is quixotic, and economists who stand on theory are like politicians who cling to principles that don't play well at the polls. So when prominent economists take big jobs in Washington and use them to push theory, the response from their bosses is often skepticism and resistance -- or outright rejection.

title: Battery Park City And Public Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: Her Windmill Arm Keeps On Winning
description: WHO -- Laura Tynio, 17, a 5-foot-6, 135-pound senior at Clifton High School. As a pitcher, Laura has led the Clifton Mustangs varsity softball team to three straight league championships. This year, Clifton won its 12th straight league title under Coach Richard LaDuke, 45, of Stockholm, the winningest softball coach in New Jersey high school history. On Tuesday, when Coach LaDuke won his 400th game in 17 seasons with the Mustangs, Ms. Tynio tied a state record of 51 straight wins. On Thursday, Ms. Tynio set a new record with her 52d, making her season record 27-0 so far. Her total record is 60-1, with a career earned run average of .026, and 624 strikeouts against 85 walks and 111 hits allowed.

title: Q and A
description: Scottish Golf Courses

title: For Artists, Studios Function As Canvases
description: At one time, artists settling on the East End gravitated toward old farmhouses and barns. Now their studios are just as likely to be individual statements, often reflecting their attitudes toward the region's natural features as well as their art.

title: Vacation Reading
description: FICTION & POETRY

title: Plan for Assisted Living Complex Draws Fire
description: AS an alternative to nursing homes, as people live longer, the health-care industry has turned to the building of assisted living housing facilities, particularly on Long Island, where the population continues to age.

title: Colman Rackley, Richard Riddell
description: Colman Laughon Rackley, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles E. Rackley of Washington, was married yesterday to Richard Kane Riddell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Riddell of McLean, Va. The Rev. Stuart A. Kenworthy performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church, Georgetown, in Washington.

title: An Auspicious End to an Era at George Street
description: DURING Gregory S. Hurst's nine seasons as its artistic director, the George Street Playhouse here was a regional theater with a commercial mindset. The production of new plays and musicals owed more to outside producers' contributions than to artistic conviction. For all the theater's lofty claims to searching for the new, it did its best work in traditional restagings of pillars of the popular American theater like ''The Miracle Worker'' and ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' or second viewings of more recent crowd-pleasers like ''Other People's Money.''

title: Jumping Rope Can Be a Mission
description: FOUR years ago, when Janice Harrington took a job as a physical education teacher at Forbes School in Torrington, she figured it would be a snap to start a jump rope team. She had coached double dutch, which uses two counter-rotating ropes, and short rope jumpers for 16 years in Falls Church, Va., and she was accustomed to holding a one-day workshop before picking the team.

title: The Collector
description: Wormholes

title: Follow The Roaring Water
description: THE turns were tight out of Hana, but the views expansive, on Maui's Highway 31. Lush palms and fiery red ginger overhung ''beware of pig'' signs nestled in leafy driveways, and cattle grazed on hilly fields of pale grass stretching to the sea.

title: Irabu's Many Doubters Owe Him an Apology
description: Hideki Irabu deserves an apology or two or three. A hundred. Just think about it. How unfair is it that Irabu's implosion into ineptitude with the Yankees last season was covered with much more zest and vigor than his explosion into ecstasy this season? Do the headline writers who treated one of Irabu's weak batting practice sessions in spring training like a World Series fiasco feel silly? They should.

title: Julia Mayer, Adam Janovic
description: Julia Margaret Mayer, a daughter of Veronica J. McDavid and a stepdaughter of Jack Minc of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Adam Janovic, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Evan Janovic of Manhattan. The Rev. Dougall C. Fraser 3d, a Lutheran pastor, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Pedal to the Metal and Eyes on the Screen
description: Several television specials this year have commemorated the 50th anniversary of Nascar, the stock-car racing organization created in Daytona Beach, Fla., to bring order to what was up to then a chaotic, formless sport. Two of the latest will be shown tonight on TBS, one of a number of channels that now show Nascar's brand of stock-car racing.

title: Opinions Differ On Fire Island Chief
description: Your usually reliable reporter managed to interview all the wrong people. Had she interviewed residents of Fire Island Pines, her story would have been very different. Mr. Dillon's first act as Superintendent was to side publicly with a group opposed to the Pines' building a shore protection project (entirely at community expense) on the ridiculous ground that the Army Corps of Engineers did not know or care how to locate a borrow site so that it would not cause damage to the shoreline they were trying to protect. Then he and his equally uninformed resource manager wanted the project constructed as a squared-off headland rather than tapering it into Park Service property per the engineers' design. Only when Brookhaven Town threatened to sue him if he continued to block the project did Mr. Dillon back down, thereby establishing a pattern later repeated in other areas.

title: Brooke Schmitt, Ray Charles White
description: Elizabeth Brooke Schmitt was married last evening to Ray Charles White. The Rev. Andrew H. Zeman performed the Episcopal ceremony at her mother's farm in Onancock, Va..

title: Poor Conditions Follow Laborers as They Travel North
description: Every July and August, an estimated 45,000 migrant workers arrive in New York State to harvest onions, apples, pumpkins and vegetables.

title: May 24-30; Lyme Disease Vaccine Gets Cautious Push
description: Lyme disease is the most common tick-borne illness in the United States, and its sometimes debilitating symptoms -- arthritis and damage to the nervous system and heart -- underscore the need for a vaccine.

title: An Emerging-Markets Bog: Time to Wade In Again?
description: MAY was a rough month for emerging markets, which are proving once again that they can turn sour on a dime.

title: Bookend
PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: THE FINE PRINT: A close look at the wine and beer lobby; Pentagon Fights Wider Military Sale of Beer and Wine
description: The beer wars between Congress and the Pentagon are heating up again. Only this time, there is a new twist: wine.

title: Van Cliburn Medalist, Pops Season Finale
description: AS part of its 65th anniversary season, South Shore Music will present Valery Kuleshov, a silver medalist at the 1998 Van Cliburn competition.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about student evaluations of college teachers misstated the name of the president of The Harvard Crimson. He is Matthew Granade, not Michael Andrade.

title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects
description: To the Editor:

title: The Groves of 155th Street
description: A CENTURY OF ARTS & LETTERS

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Grace Coughlan, John Connell
description: Grace Elizabeth Coughlan, a daughter of Mrs. Francis Pierce Coughlan Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Coughlan, and John Edward Sparks Connell, the son of Mrs. Edward Sparks Connell of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mr. Connell, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. John Cardinal O'Connor performed the ceremony at the cathedral's main altar.

title: Backtalk; Allowing Games to Be Educational Tools
description: Despising Nike is too easy these days, not that the sneaker bully doesn't deserve it. But the commercialization of adolescent sports, the corruption of higher education and the exploitation of low-paid workers is too huge a mission even for Phil Knight and his talented marketing executives. They needed help to swoosh the world, and they got it eagerly from Michael Jordan, from hundreds of pro athletes, Division I coaches and university presidents. They got it from high school coaches grateful for team uniforms and a little walking around money.

title: Sports of The Times; Jeter Is Still The Torres' 'Little Boy' Shortstop
description: IN his third season as the Yankee shortstop, Derek Jeter is high among the American League leaders in batting, hits, runs, triples and stolen bases. On this Yankee juggernaut of a baseball team, he has been arguably its best player during what has been a dream season so far.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article on May 21 about new enrollment figures for the University of California referred incorrectly to the minority groups that are considered underrepresented in the statewide system. They do not include Asian-Americans. The article also misstated the change in the number of applications received by the university this year from members of underrepresented minorities. There were more, not significantly fewer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, IRVING
description: JAFFE-Irving. On May 29, 1998 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Los Angeles, in his 91st year. Beloved husband of Bertha and loving father of Mark Jaffe and Beth Pressman; grandfather of Kimberly and Lauren Pressman; father-in-law of June Jaffe. Strong, kind, remarkable and hard working, he was formerly a resident of Paterson and Clifton, NJ. Born on the Lower East Side and starting in the midst of the Depression with a single store in the area of Lower Manhattan now known as Tribeca, he built one of the largest auto parts businesses in the metropolitan area. He early recognized the potential development of Tribeca and was active in the real estate business there. Services ''Schoem's Menorah Chapel,'' Route 4, Paramus, NJ, 10:30 AM, Tuesday, June 2. 201-843-9090.

title: Far From the Dues-Paying Demanded by Hollywood
description: NOAH BAUMBACH, the child of two film buffs, grew up on movies -- everything from the innovative French dramas of Jean Renoir and Francois Truffaut to the screwball comedies of Howard Hawks. In his mind, he was always a filmmaker. And by the time Mr. Baumbach was 25, this notion had become a reality, with the release of his sharp-eyed comedy ''Kicking and Screaming,'' which was an art-house hit in 1995.

title: At 31, Realizing Goal of Being Sports Anchor
description: SEAN KIMERLING, 31, the new weekend television sports anchor on ''WB11 News at 10,'' said he awoke in the middle of the night at his home in Croton-on-Hudson not long ago and realized he had been dreaming about his job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, RUTH (NEE CAHN)
description: MARSHALL-Ruth (nee Cahn). On May 27, 1998, age 86, of Mamaroneck, New York. Beloved wife of the late Harold, loving mother of Elizabeth Wachenheim (Edgar Jr.) and Jane M. Burke of Mamaroneck, NY. Grandmother of James and Marcie Burke, sister of the late Joshua Binion Cahn and Alma Schapiro. Memorial service June 7, 1998, 11 AM. For details call 914-698-3962.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 17 about the wildlife of Central Park misstated the year the statue of Shakespeare was erected on the Mall. It was 1872, not 1864. (The statue's pedestal was unveiled in 1864, the 300th anniversary of Shakespeare's birth.)

title: Trail Builders Ease the Way With a Bridge to Nature
description: FORDING a creek in Watchung Reservation will be a lot drier after a team of volunteers spent a recent Sunday there bridge-building. The team, sponsored by the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, built two small bridges and about 70 feet of boardwalk over wetlands.

title: Ninamarie Campo, Trey Flood
description: Ninamarie Campo, a daughter of Joann and Salvatore J. Campo of Randolph, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Cambere Flood, a son of Michele and Robert F. Flood of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. David McDonnell performed the ceremony in the St. Lucy Filippini Chapel at Villa Walsh, a Roman Catholic convent and school in Morristown, N.J.

title: On a Unicorn Hunt in France
description: WHO has not wanted to glimpse a unicorn browsing in Central Park? Or, better still, to have a tame unicorn of his own, following him around in a gilded collar, nudging for tidbits of whatever rare food unicorns eat, admiring itself in a hand mirror? Of all the mythological beasts that prance through heraldry and legend, the intelligent unicorn is the one in whose real-life existence we most want to believe. Symbol of power and benign magic, familiar of kings but only to be tamed by a spotless maiden, the unicorn has been sought and venerated for centuries.

title: A V. Fine Mess
description: BRIDGET JONES'S DIARY

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 21 about the Indonesian opposition misstated the age of Megawati Sukarnoputri, an opposition figure. She is 51, not 50.

title: Merrill Buice, Jonathan Hubbard
description: Merrill Stuart Buice, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Buice 3d of New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan Field Hubbard, a son of Mrs. Charles Joseph Hubbard of Shelburne, Vt., and the late Mr. Hubbard. The Rev. John B. Macnab performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Quinipet, a retreat on Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: Sidewalk Food Vendors Face a New Set of Critics
description: New York City's sidewalk food vendors, soon to be exiled from the financial district and large sections of midtown, will face further peril next month when the city considers requests to bar them from 95 more Manhattan blocks.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about living in Westport, Conn., referred incorrectly to the Old Hill area. It is not a historic district.

title: Offending Words
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Declarations of Independence; The New American Spirit: Divided We Stand
description: MERGER mania may be running amok in the world of commerce, but in the world of civics the opposite seems to be happening. Cities and counties dotting the country are in the grip of secession fever.

title: Commercial Property/Downtown; At the World Trade Center, Things Are Looking Up
description: THE leases were signed, one after another. Bankers Trust took 274,000 square feet, Aon Risk Services 396,000, Oppenheimer Funds 181,000, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield 461,000 and, finally, J&H Marsh & McLennan committed to 361,000 square feet earlier this month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVENKRON, RACHEL
description: LEVENKRON-Rachel June 21, 1904-June 1, 1988 10 years have passed. Our love for you is undiminished. Your Family

title: Artistry on Both Sides of the Shutter
description: WHEN recounting his method of capturing the perfect picture, James J. Kriegsmann, who made a career of celebrity portraits, said he would ''begin always with the eyes.'' A collection of alluring eyes, smiles, dimples and poses, in Mr. Kriegsmann's photographs of famous faces, is on display at the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale.

title: John Wesley Jones, 90, a Retired Diplomat
description: John Wesley Jones, a retired Foreign Service officer, Ambassador to Libya and Peru and a former deputy commandant of the National War College, died on May 20 in his home in Flat Rock, N.C. He was 90.

title: A County Wants Gallery Space, but Not for Galleries
description: The brittle bones of two mastodons, dug up 10,000 years after nature laid them to rest in Bergen County, may soon be uprooted again. The Bergen Museum of Art and Science, where they have been on display for two decades, is threatened with eviction by its landlord, the county government.

title: Iowans Seem All Too Calm About Race for Governor
description: Gerald Rayner, a grain and livestock farmer and registered Democrat from nearby Lone Tree, thinks he likes ''the guy -- his name starts with a V'' in this state's race for governor, but he is not sure he cares enough to make it to the polls on primary day.

title: Elusive Bosnian Serb
description: In the farmlands of eastern Bosnia, a game of cat and mouse is being played out between Radovan Karadzic, the wartime leader of the Bosnian Serbs who has been indicted on war crimes, and troops from the United States, Britain and the Netherlands. He moves from one location to the next, often just ahead of the troops seeking to bring him to trial.

title: Luxurious But Never Lived In
description: In the middle of Manhattan, in the middle of a real estate boom, a luxurious 21-story apartment building stands vacant.

title: Boomer Parents And Little Tyrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Gulf Sheik Is Complex And Critical Ally of U.S.
description: In the wealthy lands that border the Persian Gulf, dollars speak loudly, as they did with an announcement a few weeks ago that the United Arab Emirates would buy 80 American-made F-16 fighters in a $6 billion deal.

title: Katherine Finn, Geoffrey Molson
description: Katherine Brigid Finn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Finn of Marshfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Eric Molson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric H. Molson of Montreal. The Rev. Vincent P. Doolan performed the ceremony at St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Chapel in Marshfield.

title: Capitals Silence Sabres With Assist From Hasek
description: While Dominik Hasek has not been playing his best hockey during the Stanley Cup playoffs, he has given the Buffalo Sabres a chance to win in every game. But his blunder tonight -- when he allowed the Capitals' Joe Juneau to score from 70 feet out late in the game and give Washington a 2-0 lead -- took the life out of the Sabres and their crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPLIK, KENNETH E.
description: KOPLIK-Kenneth E. May 31, 1996. Two years have passed since you left us. You were the laughter in our hearts and the substance of our souls. How blessed we were to have shared your life and your love. Diane, David and Family

title: A Band That Built a Career From the Ground Up
description: EACH member of the Dave Matthews Band tends to recall a moment in the early 1990's when he realized that the group's offbeat blend of jazz-style improvisations over high-revving world-beat rhythms had a good chance of making it big.

title: Bar Fined
description: The owners of a Manhattan bar have agreed to pay an $8,500 fine for serving alcohol to 20-year-old Patrick McNeill, a Fordham University student who became intoxicated and drowned in the East River in February 1997. Mr. McNeill was discovered in New York Harbor seven weeks later.

title: Scene but Not Heard
description: Getting right to the point, I agree 100 percent with Max Frankel that substance should transcend style in news articles (Word & Image: ''Scene but Not Heard,'' May 10).

title: Group Tours
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article, ''Group Tours, Pro and Con'' (Practical Traveler, May 3), reminded me of our Sicily group tour by bus a few years ago, when we almost missed seeing the historical town of Erice.

title: Great Expectations
description: To the Editor:

title: When an Insult Is Coupled With Crime
description: HATE crimes are either increasing, decreasing or staying the same depending on who's talking.

title: May 24-30; Clearing the Air at Casinos
description: Atlantic City is hardly a hotbed of activism, but it could become the next serious battleground in the tobacco wars.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 6/

title: Another Televised Strike Against the Pentagon
description: THE Pentagon is having a rough year on television. First came HBO's ''Pentagon Wars,'' about the billions of dollars wasted by the Defense Department on arms procurement. HBO followed this month with ''A Bright Shining Lie,'' a movie based on the Pulitzer Prize-winning book about the civilian military adviser who blew the whistle on the Pentagon's failed policies in the Vietnam War.

title: A CD Niche Opens on a Big Landscape
description: WHEN Uwe Buschkotter started Largo, a German label specializing in 20th-century music, he was neither a dreamer nor a new-music ideologue. It was 1984, and Mr. Buschkotter, having established himself as a producer of television soundtracks and commercial jingles, wanted to make classical recordings. After releasing a few disks of standard repertory, he realized that by focusing on contemporary works and neglected scores of recent decades, he could find a niche in the fledgling CD market. A few years later, he signed on David Drew, an English musicologist and Kurt Weill specialist, as artistic director.

title: Farmland May Yield to Fairway
description: OF all the initiatives by Suffolk County to protect farmland and pine barrens, none was ever more praised than a program to keep East End farms as farms by buying their development rights.

title: Students Suggest Discipline
description: Tenth through 12th graders at the Teterboro campus of the Bergen County Technical Education Center suggested ways to handle disruptive students.

title: 2d Capital Case In New York Gets Underway
description: Testimony is to begin Monday in the state's second death penalty trial, a case in which a man is accused of killing his estranged wife and her daughter from a previous marriage.

title: Downtown, a Pizza Man Tells Which Way the Wind Blows
description: AT the intersection of ''La Boheme'' and boomtown, just a few blocks east of NoLIta, a pizzeria that has been a Lower East Side gathering place for more than three decades is on the brink. A big pizza chain bought the building it is in and gave notice that its lease, which is up June 15, will not be renewed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EDELMAN, HILDA W.
description: EDELMAN-Hilda W. 20 years. Still with us. Mort, Diana, Robert, Nancy, Alex

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOBRICK, DAVID H.
description: BOBRICK-David H. Beloved husband of the late Mildred. Devoted brother of Mollie Chandross. Loving uncle to many. Graveside services 11 AM, Tuesday, June 2nd, at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, New York.

title: Commencements; Cadets Are Warned of New Threats
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen today urged the 865 graduates of the United States Military Academy to rise to the challenges of a post-cold war world dogged by new tools of war and the longstanding threat of weapons of mass destruction.

title: Presbyterians Devise Plan To Diversify Denomination
description: In response to changing immigration patterns, officials of the Presbyterian Church (USA) have created a plan to help the 2.6 million-member denomination raise the proportion of members who belong to ethnic minority groups by half, to 10 percent by 2005.

title: Sewage Spill
description: A power failure at a Consolidated Edison substation resulted in equipment failures at a Mamaroneck sewage-treatment plant earlier this month. As a result, 250,000 gallons of untreated but diluted sewage spilled into Mamaroneck Harbor and 6 million gallons of partially treated sewage was discharged into Long Island Sound, said Anthony P. Trelewicz, the county's Environmental Facilities Commissioner.

title: Colleen Mara, Colin McLane
description: Colleen Elizabeth Mara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington T. Mara of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Colin McLane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce McLane of Westfield, N.J. Msgr. Donald Prior performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: A New Face Joins Nightlife Icons
description: THE SCENE -- The V.I.P. room of the nightclub Life on Bleecker Street, where a Nightlife Award ceremony was held on Thursday night. The award, chosen by clubgoers and promoters, salutes the ''top pop icon'' in ''nightlife subculture.'' This year's winner? Jocelyne Wildenstein, the estranged wife of Alec Wildenstein, the art dealer with whom she waged a very public divorce battle earlier this year. (She got use of the game ranch in Kenya, he got the family jet.)

title: Corrections
description: A quotation on page 37 of the Arts and Leisure section today, in an article about the Dave Matthews Band, misstates the date of a concert at the Great American Music Hall in San Francisco. It was in 1994, not 1995.

title: Q&A: Dr. Stuart Tauber; In Israel, Medical Help for All People
description: AT Shaare Zedek, one of the Middle East's leading medical centers, compassion transcends ethnic and religious boundaries. Founded in 1902, the 500-bed center in Israel annually treats more than 200,000 patients of diverse backgrounds in an atmosphere of kindness and respect combined with the latest in medical technology.

title: John Paul's Jewish Dilemma
description: According to Paul Elie, I ''look out'' for Pius XII (''John Paul's Jewish Dilemma,'' April 26). More accurately, I look out for truth in a controversy riddled with bias, oversimplification and just plain sloppiness on both sides.

title: Board Terms End Unhappily
description: The letters were brief and to the point. ''I must inform you that Council Member Kenneth Fisher has decided not to reappoint you to membership on Community Board 1,'' Borough President Howard Golden wrote to Marsilia Boyle and John Dereszewski on May 15. ''Therefore, you are not being reappointed.''

title: Lee Rezza and Fritz Michel
description: Leanora Stella Rezza, the daughter of Leanora M. Dezenhall of Cherry Hill, N.J., and Frank D. Rezza of Tavernier, Fla., was married yesterday to Clifford Fredrick Michel, a son of Betsy and Clifford L. Michel of Gladstone, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Timothy J. Mulder performed the ceremony at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Anita Roberts and Alan Teig
description: Anita Roberts and Alan Gilman Teig were married yesterday by the Rev. Martha Neibank at the First Parish Universalist-Unitarian Church in Waltham, Mass.

title: An Odyssey
description: ''GRANT me, Pallas Athena, the wisdom to lead 11-year-olds safely through the ruins of Troy and home to Ithaca,'' I muttered before reciting the invocation to the Muse that begins ''The Odyssey.'' The works of Homer are required reading for the sixth grade students in the Gifted Language Arts Program at the school where I teach. The academic abilities that brought them to my classroom insure that my 11 students will understand ''who ate and otherwise killed who,'' according to Katy's synopsis of ''The Iliad'' and ''The Odyssey.''

title: Pakistan Test Leaves U.S. Out of Ideas and Angered
description: The United States reacted with anger and a sense of frustration to Pakistan's nuclear test today, as Administration officials said they had few ideas about how to stop the arms race in South Asia.

title: A New Sound for Fiesta Time en Cabo De Mayo
description: IF Memorial Day is past, then the Cape May Music Festival, a five-week walk on the lighter side, must be in full swing -- or, this year, full tango. Added to the 20 classical, folk, jazz and brass concerts is the Tango Project, a trio of unlikely bedfellows: a pianist, an accordionist and a violinist whose other life includes commissioning works that she performs at the Library of Congress.

title: The State in Your Pocket
description: For years, Streetwise Maps of Amagansett, N.Y., has been publishing the ''Streetwise,'' ''Transitwise'' and ''Artwise'' series of fold-out maps thin enough to carry in a purse or pocket and plastic-coated to reduce wear and tear. Now the company has discovered the Garden State.

title: FILM; The Making Of a Director The Indirect Way
description: THERE is a certain symmetry in the fact that Eric Schwab's first film as a director, ''Green Fog,'' which he also wrote, will be made in Thailand in the fall. It was in Thailand a decade ago that Mr. Schwab, at the age of 30, began in earnest an unusual apprenticeship with the director Brian De Palma. At that time, Mr. De Palma was filming ''Casualties of War,'' his Vietnam morality play, with Mr. Schwab serving as the second-unit director, supervising scenes that did not require the movie's primary cast members.

title: Jane Donahue, Timothy Kunhardt
description: Jane Elizabeth Donahue and Timothy Woodruff Kunhardt were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church in Point Lookout, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick J. Sullivan performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 17 about Boston Common misstated the period in which most of the houses on Beacon Hill were built. It was the 19th century, not the 18th.

title: Backtalk; N.B.A. Needs To Address Riots In Title Cities
description: In the emergency room in Christ Hospital in Chicago last June 13, four doctors watched the Bulls finish off the Utah Jazz for the National Basketball Association title. The moment the buzzer sounded, the doctors were inundated with the sounds of celebration, Chicago style: they listened not to cheering, but to their beepers chirping simultaneously, alerting them to the first incoming casualties of the Bulls' fifth title in seven years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 18 about polling errors in the 1948 election misstated the placement of a Life magazine photograph and caption calling Thomas E. Dewey ''The Next President.'' They appeared inside the magazine, not on the cover.

title: Late Surge Gives Tigers the Title
description: At the painful pace of 42 strokes to the minute, Princeton outrowed favored Washington over the last quarter of the 2,000 meters yesterday in Camden, N.J., to win the national intercollegiate championship for men's varsity eights. It was the second national title for Tiger athletes this week; the lacrosse team won its championship last Monday.

title: Adventure, With the Kids
description: HAVING adventures and having children are not mutually exclusive. Children sometimes lead the way to adventure, demonstrating to their parents that novelty is exciting, and so is a bit of danger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGE, KNOX MARTHA
description: EGE-Knox Martha. Of NYC died February 16, 1998. Wife of the late Kevin Butler and the late Warren S. Ege. She was the daughter of Federal Judge John C. Knox and Mrs J. Knox. Mrs. Ege attended the Lincoln School in NYC and Sarah Lawrence College. Services private. Memorial contributions may be made to Waynesburg College, Waynesburg, PA., and Mary Hitchkock Pavillion, Dartmouth College, Hanover, N.H.

title: Explorer Scout, 14, Drowns on Trip to a Lake With Police Officers
description: A 14-year-old Boy Scout who was on a day trip with city police officers drowned yesterday in a Staten Island lake, the authorities said.

title: Econ-Icons
description: Two Lucky People Memoirs.

title: Marketplaces Open in Old California Bank Branches
description: VISITORS face temptation each time they walk in the door of the majestic marble-columned Wells Fargo Bank in this Southern California suburb. Customers can withdraw money and then spend it without leaving the lobby.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEYMAN, BELLA
description: HEYMAN-Bella. Dear Mom, we love and miss you terribly. Happy Birthday. Terry and Arty

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, YETTA
description: FELDMAN-Yetta. On May 30, after a valiant battle. Loved by Melvin, her husband of 50 years, and her two adoring children Estey and Ronald, son-in-law Douglas, sister-in-law Ruth, and many others who also loved and respected her. She was a caring, giving, warm, wonderful and thoughtful lady. Services Tuesday, 11 AM, Riverside Chapel, New York City.

title: Uncharted Territory: Bulls Hear the Whispers of Seventh Game
description: Do the Chicago Bulls feel vulnerable? Of course they do, Michael Jordan says. How could they not when 48 more minutes of ball against the stubborn and resilient Indiana Pacers in the United Center on Sunday night will decide the Bulls' season and likely whether this is the end of the Bulls' National Basketball Association dominance as we know it.

title: May 24-30; Court Backs Police In High-Speed Chases
description: Several hundred people die every year as a result of high-speed police chases. A Supreme Court decision has now reduced nearly to the vanishing point the chance that any of their families will be able to collect damages, even for police behavior that is reckless to the point of negligence.

title: New and Noteworthy; A Noteworthy Collection
description: American Pastoral

title: Former Bookstore Next to Whitney Awaits Next Chapter
description: A year ago today, the independent bookstore Books & Company shut its doors for good after a battle with its landlord, the Whitney Museum of American Art. Though sales were slow at the 20-year-old bookstore on Madison Avenue and 74th Street, it enjoyed below-market rent. The museum, saddled with high operating costs and flat attendance, wanted a tenant that could pay more.

title: The World; A Chinese Plot Is Easy to See. Maybe Too Easy.
description: IN politics, as in science, pundits are always on the lookout for a unified theory, preferably a single idea that binds together an otherwise disparate constellation of facts and events. For the seemingly endless stream of revelations that constitutes America's campaign finance scandal, no explanation is as seductively simple -- or sinister -- as the China plot.

title: Leonora Pascarella, Tido Meyerhoff
description: Leonora Martin Pascarella, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Pascarella of Greenwich, Conn., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Tido Volkmar Meyerhoff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Meyerhoff of Lingen, Germany. The Rev. Ronald A. Erbe, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Ms. Brownlee And Mr. Walker
description: Heather Ann Brownlee, the daughter of Eileen R. Brownlee of West Orange, N.J., and John S. Brownlee of Sparta, N.J., was married on Friday to Scott Lee Walker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Walker Jr. of Montville, N.J. The Rev. Ronald W. Johnson performed the ceremony at the Wyoming Presbyterian Church in Millburn, N.J.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON LINE; Little Old, Really Old, New York
description: As any schoolchild knows, modern New York had its beginnings in 1624, when the Dutch established an outpost. So why then is there a Web site called Medieval New York? Didn't the Middle Ages date from 500 to 1500?

title: Essay; Adventures in the Mag Trade
description: ''Do you call this serious work, darling,'' my mother said. It wasn't a question. I knew where she was coming from. I came from there myself.

title: Building A Better Bee
description: It is not just deadly parasitic mites and bad weather that are having a devastating effect on the honeybee colonies (''Building a Better Bee,'' by Karen Wright, May 10). It is also the rampant misuse of pesticides. It would be a shame to put faith in alternative pollinators and not seriously address the underlying sickness: the way we are treating the earth. The bees are the canary in the coal mine.

title: Ideas & Trends; Classes Are Full At Catch-Up U.
description: ALL the brouhaha last week over the dropping of remedial classes at the City University of New York, one of the nation's largest systems, would make many people think that remediation was a multicultural course invented by CUNY professors.

title: In the Race for Governor of California, a Candidate From the Reagan Mold
description: Spend a day with Dan Lungren, the Republican contender for Governor of California, and you will feel transported back to the beach blanket optimism of Frankie Avalon and Annette Funicello.

title: In Boston, a Last Broadcast Bastion Falls
description: FOR classical-music lovers in the United States, FM radio used to be the last bastion of provocative, informative, wonderfully quirky programming. The concerts by your local symphony orchestra may have been boringly bound to 50 favorite pieces from Mozart to Mahler. But at least on the radio you might hear a birthday tribute to Shostakovich; an opera-buff hour with a voice fanatic as host, comparing five sopranos in the same aria, or interviews with composers and live performances of their works.

title: Can't Anybody Here Run This Game?
description: The Commissioners

title: Sunday, May 31, 1998: Questions For:; Dion Hughes
description: Hughes, 29, was one of three people who recently rode the roller coaster at Six Flags Over Georgia 17 hours a day for 61 straight days, a world record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDWATER, BARRY
description: GOLDWATER-Barry. Members of the Circumnavigators Club offer their deepest sympathies. Jeffrey P. Kelly, President

title: Liberties; Monica's Frowny Face
description: Poor little Monica.

title: Affirming Vibrant Freedom of Method
description: Manoucher Yektai

title: What Shall We Ask of Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: Conservation, Close to Home
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's new plan to raise the state gasoline tax to preserve New Jersey's dwindling open space is important in its own right. Yet it is only the latest in a series of nationwide, grass-roots efforts to protect farmland and other open areas from commercial development. This encouraging trend seems, however, to have escaped notice in Washington, where Congress is again threatening to squeeze the Land and Water Conservation Fund, the one Federal program explicitly designed to help states and communities get a grip on suburban sprawl.

title: Classical Brief
description: MOZART: PIANO CONCERTOS NOS. 9, 25

title: For Espresso And Pastries
description: Muddy Waters, a small espresso bar serving granitas, cappuccinos and vanilla lattes, opened a month ago at 669 Vanderbilt Avenue (near Park Place) in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. The owner, Ntozake Lundy, a 27-year-old native of Brooklyn and a St. John's University graduate, once owned a small catering company and a coffee bar named Hot Buttered Soul that was also in Prospect Heights. Muddy Waters sells a variety of pastries, including everything cookies, made with chocolate, coconut and three kinds of nuts. Espressos are $2.25, vanilla lattes $3.50. ALEXANDRA McGINLEY

title: Grand Designs
description: MICHAEL ANANIA did not see the 1971 Broadway production of ''Follies,'' the musical meant to be inhabited by a stageful of legends and pretty-near. He was a sophomore at Boston University that year. ''I never saw it anywhere, and I didn't even know what the show was about,'' he said last month after the opening-night performance at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: Experts Say Pakistan Test Was Either Small or a Failure
description: The global network that tracks earthquakes and underground atomic blasts found only a faint echo from the nuclear test that Pakistan said it conducted yesterday, American experts said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the battle for control of the Marvel Entertainment Group misidentified a Marvel Comics character that visited the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in 1995. It was the Thing, not Iron Man.

title: May 24-30; A Growing Case Against Swiss Banks
description: A long-awaited report sponsored by the Swiss Government confirmed the central bank's complicity in accepting gold looted from Holocaust victims, bolstering allegations by Jewish groups that Switzerland traded in wartime misery. Not only did Swiss bankers ignore the gold's origin, they also considered melting it down to disguise it, the study said.

title: The Animated Mind Behind the Mannequin
description: CHARLES RAY is watching. His gaze may be following you from the big photographic self-portrait called ''Yes,'' from 1990, in which his slightly zoned-out eyes (he was on LSD at the time) seem to wander after you. Maybe it is the ''Self-Portrait'' mannequin of the same year, in which a very stiff Ray likeness wears the artist's favorite sailing outfit (he loves to sail his 40-foot fiberglass sloop out of his home port in Oxnard, Calif.), the eyes just a little wall-eyed, following you across the room. Or maybe it is the eyes of one of the eight naked Ray-like figures that stare out from the onanistic proceedings in his most talked-about sculpture, the 1992 ''Oh! Charley, Charley, Charley . . .''

title: A Chapter Out of Broadway History
description: CONSIDER the pantheon of landmark musicals in the 1950's, a decade when musical theater fulfilled a glorious tradition of mass entertainment, not since rivaled, and hardly attempted except by a brave few who mostly fail.

title: Gardening
description: Reading along in THE INVITING GARDEN: Gardening for the Senses, Mind, and Spirit (Holt, $40), I suddenly came upon this provocative sentence: ''Gardening is not a hobby, and only nongardeners would describe it as such.'' For a writer as genial as Allen Lacy, this qualifies as a shot across the wheelbarrow. ''There is nothing wrong with having hobbies,'' he goes on, ''but most hobbies are intellectually limited and make no reference to the larger world. By contrast, being wholeheartedly involved with gardens is involvement with life itself in the deepest sense.'' Indeed. For could it ever be said about, say, bridge that the way you play a hand has implications for the environment, American cuisine, biological diversity, drug policy and national identity, not to mention the nature of time and the meaning of place? ''A garden, whether we know it or not,'' Lacy writes, ''connects us to the world in many strange and wonderful ways.''

title: Don't Tread On My Tax Rate
description: Dean does not refute Burkett's characterization of Act 60 as a ''centralized, intrusive and redistributive scheme of mind-boggling complexity''; he merely indicates that this characterization should more properly appear on the editorial page. None of us here in Vermont comprehend the distinction.

title: Diana-ana And Other Obsessions
description: CAROL HERSH-WEISS collects, and then some. To enter her sprawling New York City apartment is to venture into the nooks and crannies of her decidedly idiosyncratic mind. Along one wall are 19 pairs of shoes, a small part of a collection of black shoes. Elsewhere are soda bottles bearing forgotten brand names like ''Cheer Up,'' ''Dream'' and ''Just Whistle.'' Hidden in a drawer are thousands of erasers, including one shaped like Ronald Reagan's head.

title: INSIDE
description: Upbeat in California

title: Oldies but Goodies
description: Paging through THE NEW ELEGANT BUT EASY COOKBOOK (Simon & Schuster, $25), a revised version of the 1960 best seller by Marian Burros (a columnist and writer for The New York Times) and Lois Levine (a cooking teacher and author from California), is a little like sifting through a family photo album. Readers may giggle at the sight of recipes for brandied cheese roll and three-ingredient peanut meringues, wax nostalgic over instructions for (updated) pot roast and chocolate angel food cake -- and then find themselves heading to the kitchen, inspired by a dish that looks approachable and appealing. After all, this chatty book's title trumpets ease of preparation, and many of its selections can be assembled ahead of time, then refrigerated or frozen for later cooking. ''Breezy'' barbecued chicken, zesty and tangy, is a cinch to execute, as are the delicious Maryland crab cakes and the braised fennel, lusciously partnered with grated Parmigiano-Reggiano. Brownies are ubiquitous in American cookbooks, but Burros and Levine's rendition, elevated with Grand Marnier, orange zest, coffee extract and pecans, stands out in the crowd. Not everything is such a knockout: curried rice salad, bound with nonfat yogurt and light mayonnaise, is so stodgy it appears to have come straight from Ozzie and Harriet's kitchen. And no matter how good it might taste, no one short of a restaurant pastry chef is likely to tackle an ''easy'' recipe for chocolate cake that spans four pages. Helpfully, the authors include a set of 10 different menus, complete with shopping lists and detailed game plans, along with suggestions for dishes that can be whipped up for, say, ''unexpected guests.'' Here's just the push a reluctant cook might need to turn on the stove and do some entertaining. (P.S. Laugh if you will, but the peanut meringues are addictive.) Tom Sietsema

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: Re Joyce

title: Instant Replay
description: REMOTE FEED

title: DIARY
description: U.S. ECONOMY

title: 48 Hours and 2 Acts of Violence
description: A fatal stabbing and a shooting within a 48-hour period that have been linked to events at two popular dance halls have heightened concerns among some neighborhood leaders about a resurgence of nightlife-related crime.

title: Longer ID Checks Endanger Minor Suspects
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Technology Fit Easily in Schools
description: TECHNOLOGY in the schools frequently resembles presents under a Christmas tree: shiny and bright. But once the new-toy stage passes, machines are all too often relegated to the back of the classroom.

title: Consolidators
description: To the Editor: My wife and I having only just returned from a foreign trip, I want to comment on Betsy Wade's Practical Traveler column, ''Who's Afraid of Consolidators?'' (April 12). For the last 20 years or so I have exclusively used the services of air consolidators for overseas travel. Ms. Wade correctly lists the definite risks and limitations when purchasing tickets through consolidators. But providing one uses common sense and takes into full account the recognizable pitfalls, there is also a manifest reward: the ability to fly to foreign destinations at considerably reduced fare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDBERG, HANS
description: LANDBERG-Hans. The Beverly Bridge Club mourns the sudden death of our dear friend Erik. He was dearly loved and will be missed by the entire Bridge community. A memorial service will be announced.

title: No Country for the Old
description: Hastened to the Grave

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PREISS, ELIAS
description: PREISS-Elias. Ever loved, never forgotten. Theo and Fred

title: May 24-30; U.S. May Have Helped India Hide Nuclear Test Sites
description: An intelligence board will report this week on why the United States failed to foresee this month's nuclear tests by India, which spurred tests in Pakistan and incited what President Clinton calls a ''dangerous arms race.''

title: American Shutout: Chang Is Ousted
description: Out-hit and outgritted by unseeded Francisco Clavet, a spindly Spaniard in a hot pink bandanna, Michael Chang, the only American man left in the French Open, bowed out of the Grand Slam tournament he took by storm in 1989 when he was 17 and almost impervious to the kind of aches and pains that hobbled him today.

title: VIEWPOINT; Why Daimler Would Love New York
description: THE planned merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler is widely heralded as a sign that Germany Inc. is ready to take on the world. A more realistic analysis points to the opposite: that Germany Inc. may have decided that it is better off exporting itself to richer shores.

title: Revival Yes, Parking No
description: Late last year, the city opened a one-stop payment center for people to pay tax bills, parking fines and the like in a vacant factory on 94th Avenue. But there was limited space for parking -- only 50 spots for an estimated 251 employees and 1,200 daily visitors, many of them drivers headed to a Parking Violations Bureau hearing room.

title: Dressed To Finance
description: In support of the arts, civil rights and education, and those fighting homelessness and cancer.

title: Ms. Retzler, Mr. Wigglesworth
description: Laura Retzler and Henry Cowell Wigglesworth were married in Washington yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Georgetown. The Rev. Margaret M. Graham performed the ceremony.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Consolidators
description: To the Editor: I recently contacted Cheap Tickets for the first time, to inquire about flights for a business trip to Helsinki. I was interested in exploring options for fares but would not purchase a ticket without advance seating reservations for the long segments of the trip, a condition I made clear to the agent I spoke with. I was told that I had seat assignments for those segments and was given seat numbers.

title: Sales Tax Lifted
description: In a 13-to-4 vote, the Board of Legislators approved sales tax amnesty on clothing costing less than $500 for the first week of September.

title: Boomer Parents And Little Tyrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, MAY
description: ROSENBERG-May, 95 years. Died on May 26, 1998 in Florida. Former Queen's County and NYS President of Jewish War Veterans Ladies Auxiliary. Loving mother of two, grandmother of five, greatgrandmother of thirteen.

title: Classical Arts Lose Their Stages to Broadway
description: Orchestras, ballet companies and opera companies -- organizations that inspired construction of performing arts centers across America over the last 30 years -- are being displaced from their homes, sometimes for months at a time, by presentations with a different esthetic and a broader popularity: touring Broadway shows.

title: What Happened On Horton Road
description: Kelly ann tinyes's ninth annual 14th-birthday ceremony turned out much like the others.

title: The Soul and Spirit of Hilo
description: I THINK of Hilo, rain or shine, as the unsung hero of the Hawaiian Islands. Residents of the town in eastern Hawaii, known for its abundant rainfall, have retained their spirit through the devastating tsunamis of 1946 and 1960 and the more recent economic struggles of sugar plantation closings. The engines of tourism and economic development raced past Hilo, creating, in a sense, a kipuka -- an oasis of green in a sea of lava. Modest plantation-style homes have yards full of gingers, orchids and other riotous blooms, as well as litchi trees that bulge with fruit during summer. If economic hardship has taken its toll, you won't see evidence of it in downtown Hilo, where the parking meters (once 10 cents an hour and now free) are covered with jaunty flowered cotton covers made by volunteers.

title: Informal Dining With an Ethnic, Latin Beat
description: THE most authentic wave of ethnic restaurants sweeping the Island moves to a Latin beat. The new, 19-seat Port Churasquito, at 73 Main Street in Port Washington (883-8080), is typical. These mostly tiny, family-owned storefronts deliver exceptional value and wholesome interesting dishes.

title: The unicorn at the Metropolitan
description: The seven tapestries known collectively as ''The Hunt of the Unicorn'' are among the most celebrated, and most popular, treasures in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHUSTER, WALLY
description: SCHUSTER-Wally. One year ago today you left us. You're missed and loved so very much. ASCAP paid you a beautiful tribute on May 6 with family & music luminaries. Your legacy will always be remembered as ''How can I help?'' Phoebe, Leonard, John Lewin & great nephews Lee & Jamie Elaine, Peter, Jason & Michael Schuster, and grandchild Maisie

title: POSTINGS: Stevens Tech Restores and Updates Victorian Auditorium; Multimedia Renovation
description: The 1871 Edwin A. Stevens Hall, the first building of the Stevens Institute of Technology's 55-acre campus on the Hudson River in Hoboken, N.J., underwent a renovation in 1994 that upgraded everything except, because of a lack of funds, the landmark's auditorium.

title: Williamsburg
description: To the Editor: The Frugal Traveler column headed ''The Family Plan in Williamsburg'' (May 10) conveyed much of the majesty of the area.

title: Home Depot Victory
description: With yet another round of court proceedings facing them, Home Depot officials are moving ahead with plans to build a super-size home and garden center in Port Chester. Paul D. Sirignano, the company's lawyer in Westchester, said the Atlanta-based retail giant is undeterred by a pending environmental approval process or other requirements by the village, in part because an earlier site plan had been upheld in the courts.

title: Fallen Serb on the Run, Hotly Pursued by NATO
description: In a region of sleepy white stucco farmhouses, leafy hillsides and dusty back roads in eastern Bosnia, a game of cat and mouse is being played out between Radovan Karadzic, who has been indicted on war crimes charges, and special forces from the United States, Britain and the Netherlands, NATO intelligence officers say.

title: At Last, Only Malaysia Has a Bigger Pool
description: Nassau Dives In

title: ON THE MAP; Where Historic Wooden Boats Find Their Last Refuge
description: Small wooden boats shaped commerce and recreation along the New Jersey coast. Now the Maritime Museum of the Toms River Seaport Society is the last refuge for a number of such vessels that once plied Barnegat Bay and nearby waters.

title: Comics
description: One day early this spring I carried a couple of grocery bags filled with ''alternative'' comics to the university where I teach and left them on a bench outside one of the computer labs with a sign that read ''Free!!!'' Although my motives weren't completely selfless (I needed the closet space), they were, by and large, altruistic. I was hoping that my copies of Eightball, Bone, Palestine, Berlin, Artbabe, Cerebus, Dirty Plotte, Minimum Wage, Jimbo, Black Hole, Acme Novelty Company and a dozen other worthy titles would find their way into student backpacks and briefcases, dorm rooms and campus bars and eventually be read. But an hour later I returned to find both paper bags just as full as I'd left them. Meanwhile, a carton of freebie detective novels that somebody else had left nearby was almost depleted. Two hours later, I swung by again. Same thing: no takers. I checked one last time before leaving for home and came upon a film student I recognized just as he was digging through one of the bags. Finally! But as soon as he saw me, he blushed so deeply you would have thought I'd discovered him skulking in a porno shop. Then he sped off down the hall, his chin tucked guiltily into his collar, his eyes averted.

title: Supply-Chain Software: An Industry on a Thrill Ride
