description: CONSIDER this business case: A bunch of small companies introduce software packages that can save corporations millions of dollars in inventory carrying costs. Customers snap up the products, so investors snap up the stocks. Stock prices soar to 10, 20, 50, 100 times earnings.

title: Boomer Parents And Little Tyrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Vice Adm. A. R. Gralla, 85, Hero in Pacific
description: Vice Adm. Arthur Robert Gralla, a veteran of three wars whose combat ribbons told of two crippled warships with some 5,500 sailors and airmen snatched from danger in the Pacific, died on May 22 at the Arleigh Burke Pavilion in McLean, Va. He was 85 and, most recently, a resident of Arlington.

title: More Miles for Meals And Mortgages
description: Four major airlines have announced expansions of their frequent flier programs, involving foreign carriers, restaurants and a mortgage company.

title: Michelle Gengaro And Ali Kokmen
description: Michelle Theresa Gengaro, a daughter of Geraldine and Frank Gengaro of Floral Park, Queens, is to be married today to Ali Tarik Kokmen, the son of Tomoko Kokmen and Dr. Emre Kokmen of Rochester, Minn. The Rev. Robert Allmen, an American Catholic priest, will officiate at the Chateau Briand, a restaurant in Carle Place, N.Y.

title: Life in Des Moines
description: AN OCEAN IN IOWA

title: Whiplash; In Health Care, Be Careful What You Wish For
description: IF there is one national issue emerging from the hodgepodge of political campaigns that will take shape with primary elections in eight states on Tuesday, it is health insurance. Health maintenance organizations have taken over, and voters don't like it. So politicians are promising to do something about it.

title: With Proposed Gas-Tax Boost, a New Push for Self-Service
description: New Jersey was not alone when it banned self-service gasoline in 1949. Many states decided that they did not want to encourage this oil-company innovation, citing safety issues. In 1968, 23 states still had bans; by 1977, with the development of safer pumps, all but New Jersey and Oregon had dropped their objections.

title: Skip Away Sets Record in Winning Mass Cap
description: It was all Skip Away in the 59th running of the Massachusetts Handicap yesterday as he won his sixth straight race and broke the Suffolk Downs record for the mile and one-eighth.

title: The Half-Full-or-Half-Empty Question, About a Park
description: Riverdale-Snediker Street Park is an orphan, and it looks it. Fifteen years ago, the Department of Parks and Recreation decided to stop maintaining the park because, it said, surrounding blocks were losing residents. The park was fenced off and weeds claimed the land.

title: Enjoyable Parks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Capitalist; The Publisher's Curse
description: In book publishing, right now is inevitably the worst time. Publishers are always less profitable than they've ever been, editors always care less about quality work than ever before and writers are always getting more of a raw deal than they once did. The two latest occasions for these laments have been the announcement that Bertelsmann A.G., the German publishing giant, would be acquiring Random House, and the news that Pearson P.L.C., the British conglomerate, would acquire Simon & Schuster's educational divisions.

title: Acceptance of Gay Men and Lesbians Is Growing, Study Says
description: American acceptance of gay men and lesbians has swelled substantially in recent years, as has support for their civil rights, but a majority of the population still disapproves of homosexuality, according to a study released on Friday by the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, an advocacy group based in Washington.

title: Annual Vines: The Slipcovers of the Plant World
description: RARE is the home landscape that has no structural imperfection in need of camouflage. It might be a utilitarian but ugly chain-link fence, a shed in need of new siding or a dead snag of a tree that hasn't yet been removed.

title: Ms. Sweeney And Mr. Scheier
description: Kathleen Marie Sweeney, a daughter of Jean Florig Sweeney of Collegeville, Pa., and the late Eugene J. Sweeney, was married yesterday to David Gustav Garcia Scheier, a son of Karen and Howard Scheier of Fredon, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Martha B. Kriebel, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Trinity Reformed Church in Collegeville.

title: Men on a Mission
description: RUSSELL PRATT knocked on the door of Apartment 18A, delivering a firm, fearless rap that echoed down the dim, graffiti-scarred corridors of the Taft Houses in East Harlem. When the door finally opened a crack, he found himself facing a snarling dog and a leery, unwelcoming glare.

title: Hackley School Is Host to Ensemble
description: THE Wild Ginger Philharmonic is not, as its name might suggest, a melange of aromatic herbs. Rather, the title of this young musicians' orchestra derives from what the dictionary gives as one meaning of ''ginger'': ''high spirit, mettle, pep, vigor.''

title: Scene but Not Heard
description: Scene-setting and anecdotes in news reports have as much or more to do with the national obsession with memoirs, and the personal in everything, as they do with the influence of movies and television. Workshops in ''literary nonfiction'' are the rage in creative-writing programs. Journalism departments offer courses called ''literary journalism.''

title: Where Creation Is Still Under Way
description: THERE is probably nowhere else on the planet where you can see, hear and smell the process of earth's creation as vividly as you can in Volcanoes National Park on the Big Island of Hawaii. At Kilauea, the fiery centerpiece of the 230,000-acre park, Pele, the Hawaiian goddess of volcanoes, is visible in the rising sun, the coils of hard lava and even in the surrounding rain forest. Pele may destroy by fire, but in doing so, she ignites the birth of new life.

title: Elizabeth Mesker, Thomas Vance
description: Elizabeth Alden Mesker and Thomas Gough Vance were married yesterday in St. Louis. The Rev. William Chapman, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Susan and David W. Mesker.

title: Bell Atlantic Tries to Halt Exodus of Workers Retiring Early
description: Caught off guard by the popularity of an early-retirement program, the telephone company that serves New York and New England is negotiating with its union to prevent a crippling exodus of line installers, technicians, clerical workers and other employees this summer, company officials said Friday.

title: In Need of a Maestro
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Johnson's Girls Are on a Roll
description: FIVE unicycling girls were the stars on Thursday at the District 3 Multicultural Fair at P.S. 163 on the Upper West Side. Crystal Pinedo jumped rope on her unicycle; tiny Brittney Green pedaled backward on the ''giraffe,'' a unicycle nearly six feet high. The girls took their bows to thunderous applause, and the admiration shone on the faces of children, teachers and parents.

title: An Unusual Window Into Vanguard
description: IT is the rarest of opportunities. Because of a twist in proxy requirements, investors are getting a look at how two of the biggest names in the mutual fund industry -- John C. Bogle, senior chairman of the Vanguard Group, and John J. Brennan, its chief executive -- invest their money. They can also see how the outside directors who oversee their funds choose among Vanguard's offerings for their own portfolios.

title: May 24-30; Warning About Wall Street
description: New York City's government, struggling to balance its books just two years ago, will end the fiscal year with a surplus of $2 billion. The windfall comes from Wall Street -- and that's the danger, say analysts.

title: Towns Forming Power Companies
description: Several Long Island municipalities have formed their own power companies, saying they can do a better job of reducing electric rates than the Long Island Power Authority and at the same time avoid paying part of the Shoreham debt.

title: Improving on Nature
description: CATS' PAWS AND CATAPULTS

title: Total Baseball
description: Tim MCCarver's Baseball for

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOWE, B.S.
description: LOWE-B.S. 13 years. Love you as always

title: Classical Radio Plays Only To Sweet Tooths
description: CLASSICAL-MUSIC radio stations in the United States were once chock-full of nutty professors, eccentrics whose quirky opinions served to educate and inspire generations of listeners. In the 1950's and 60's in New York, for example, the obsessive Fleetwood, on WNCN, might play a selection four times in a row if he liked, and the outrageous Seymour DeKoven, on WFUV, proselytized fanatically for ''barococo'' music. Far more than purveyors of musical appreciation, they were models of musical devotion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, WALTER
description: SCHWARTZ-Walter. On May 29, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Miriam. Devoted father of Judy and husband Mel Stern and the late Leonard. Cherished grandfather of Lauren and husband Ken Adelson, and David Stern. Loving great-grandfather of Richard and Michael Adelson. A truly special man. He'll be missed. Funeral Tuesday, June 2, 12 noon, Schwartz Bros., Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Boomer Parents And Little Tyrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Time for Annual March of the Snapping Turtle
description: So-called living fossils from the Jurassic period will be available for close-up, personal inspection by the public starting 7 A.M. June 13 in Garrison, N.Y. The occasion is the fourth annual Snapping Turtle Walk on the grounds of Boscobel Restoration on the east bank of the Hudson River opposite West Point.

title: Appearances; Germ Warfare
description: A friend of mine -- beautiful, well traveled and healthy -- fears to take yoga class because the teacher's correcting touch may spread contagion from other students, yet she dares to climb hundreds of feet up vertical rock faces. Her problem is not multiple-personality disorder but exquisite sensitivity to millenarian anxiety, the underlying link joining fear of germs and attraction to high-risk sport.

title: Writing a Happy Ending, Or at Least a Pleasant Pause
description: The seven justices of New Jersey's Supreme Court managed to accomplish a rare feat with their latest -- and possibly last -- ruling in the long-running court battle over the quality of public education for urban schoolchildren.

title: China Jobless Fuel a Growth Industry
description: Sitting in his storefront shop beneath a karaoke bar, surrounded by tall blackboards listing job openings, Fu Xuanrong could be a Government prototype for the new era of worker layoffs, for he embodies the official dream of how redundant workers should cope.

title: The Real Asian Miracle; The World's Biggest Going-Out-of-Business Sale
description: It has been less than 10 years since a Japanese company nobody had ever heard of bought Rockefeller Center, but it might as well be 10 centuries. The fear and loathing of the Asian corporate enterprise seems a thing of the distant past. The financial crash that began in Thailand last July 2 and that is still playing itself out across Asia was the final great clarifying event: in a stroke it explained away a great deal of mystery. American businessmen who had wondered how, say, Thailand kept growing by 8 percent a year, or how South Korea supported five large automobile companies, found themselves gazing into the guts of the busted machine.. . .Oh,so that's how it worked!

title: Homesteaders, Nearly Homeowners; After Hard Work and a Break, a Building Is Almost Theirs
description: Seven years ago, a group of Dominican immigrants, desperate to own their own homes, came across a tumbledown, apparently abandoned apartment house in the Highbridge section of the Bronx. Garbage rose clear to the ceilings. Weeds shot up from the roof. Derelicts came and went, leaving needles, drug vials and waste behind.

title: What Shall We Ask of Immigrants?
description: To the Editor:

title: Remembrance Of Friends Past
description: IN a space no bigger than a three-car garage, a mass of humanity (with luggage) was waiting for a plane that would never come. This was beginning to dawn on us when the China Air personnel appeared to be closing their counters and locking the doors. Welcome to the Guilin, China, airport. Or rather, go away until tomorrow (maybe). Our flight to Hong Kong had been canceled because, we gathered, the plane was fog-bound in Shanghai.

title: Christine Ferrara, Steven Birnbaum
description: Christine Elizabeth Ferrara, a daughter of Joyce T. Ferrara of Sag Harbor, N.Y., and the late Dr. Angelo C. Ferrara, was married yesterday to Steven Brooke Birnbaum, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sidney H. Birnbaum, who lived in Short Hills, N.J. Cantor Henry Weintraub officiated at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: The Ladies Who Lied
description: SISTERHOOD OF SPIES

title: Dr. Lerner, Dr. Angeles
description: Dr. Anna Eleanor Lerner, the daughter of Mimi Lerner and Dr. Harvey Lerner of St. James, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Carmichael Angeles, a son of Dr. Carmen Angeles and Dr. Santos Angeles of Laurel Hollow, N.Y. Harvey Shapiro, a retired justice of the village of Islandia, officiated at Flowerfields, the former John L. Childs house in St. James.

title: Herald Square, Swing District
description: THE portly man struck the golf ball with a stiff swipe, and the sound of metal striking plastic brought to mind green fairways, wind in the trees and money. But the man was not on the seventh hole of some exclusive country club. He was at the New York Golf Center on 35th Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway.

title: Rhonda Edwards, Henry Powell
description: THE last person Rhonda M. Edwards ever expected to marry was Henry J. Powell.

title: Limousine Liberals Sweep Poll
description: Since Feb. 6, Washington limousine and taxi drivers have been able to tell their passengers' political affiliations as soon as they open their mouths. That was when Washington National Airport was officially renamed Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. When a passenger steps into a Town Car to be whisked to the Delta Shuttle and says, ''Take me to Reagan National Airport,'' it's almost a sure bet that the passenger is a Republican. Democrats seem to prefer the more minimalist, more nonpartisan ''Take me to National Airport.''

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Grapes and Vines Wend Path in History
description: HAMPTON COURT, the royal palace 15 miles west of London, has what is called the Great Vine. Mine is less impressive. The royal grape vine was planted by Lancelot (Capability) Brown, a leading English landscape architect of the time, in 1768, while mine went in last year. The Great Vine is the Empire State Building of the species -- it fills a greenhouse the size of a 7-Eleven from a single trunk, drawing its nutrients from a large field left fallow outside the greenhouse for the vine's needs.

title: David J. L. Luck Dies at 69; Pushed Bounds of Cell Biology
description: Dr. David J. L. Luck, a New York educator and biologist who contributed significantly to the field of cell biology, died on May 23 at New York Hospital. He was 69 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Essay on Sidewalk Cafes Was Not Anti-Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday, May 31, 1998; I, HILLARIACI
description: Sylvia McNair, one of the world's pre-eminent sopranos, has commissioned the San Francisco composer Jake Heggie to turn themes of speeches by Hillary Clinton into operatic songs. This improbable idea is a result of a chance meeting between the singer and the First Lady at a music festival in Salzburg, Austria, last summer, which led to a White House performance and an ongoing scrum of mutual admiration. McNair and Heggie make it clear that the so-called Hillary Cycles will be a straight-up celebration of the First Lady's essence and ideas. With the project still in its early stages, McNair is busily gathering up Hillary's speeches. I won't be able to lift huge sections out of them without her permission, she says. But I do hope to select certain sentences.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Bronx Man After He Threatens 2 With Knife
description: A Bronx man who had slashed his former girlfriend across the throat in February returned to her home early yesterday and threatened to kill her and her daughter with a kitchen knife before he was shot and killed by an officer who was responding to the woman's call for help, the police said.

title: HOMELESS HARVEST: A special report.; As Economy Booms, Migrant Workers' Housing Worsens
description: Inside room 39 at the Westwind Motel was an astonishing scene: 10 people bedded down for the night.

title: Will a New Association Give Insurers a Kinder Face?
description: WITH trumpets and drum flourishes, the life insurance industry has rolled out a new organization intended to burnish its soiled reputation and convince Americans that it really is safe to do business with its agents.

title: Geriatric Research
description: The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's Westchester division has received one of the largest grants in its history, a National Institute of Mental Health award of $5 million for research by its Institute of Geriatric Psychiatry.

title: Food; Jam Session
description: Sugar and shape are the only differences between biscuits and scones, though socially, they are worlds apart.

title: In Ridgefield, Farewell to a Family Business
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON resigned as Commander in Chief of the victorious Continental Army, Spain consolidated its conquest of Florida and Mozart composed his Mass in C Minor. And, in Ridgefield, the original Bedient's hardware store opened its doors in a cottage on Main Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 17 about investing in makers of removable computer storage products misidentified the company that is collaborating with the Sony Corporation to develop a high-capacity floppy disk. It is Fujifilm Computer Products, a division of Fuji Photo Film U.S.A.; it is not Fujitsu Ltd.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; REIT's the Big Buyers in a Strong Industrial Market
description: BOLSTERED by a strong economy, New Jersey's industrial sector showed signs of steady improvement over the last year and the forecast is for more of the same through the rest of 1998.

title: Blocking the Gingrich Trick
description: With Congress due back in Washington tomorrow, we find it necessary to send up another warning about a Republican trick to kill the Shays-Meehan campaign-finance legislation and about the prominent Democrats who are foolishly playing along. The threat arises from 119 House members, most of them Democrats who profess support for Shays-Meehan but are sponsoring a separate bill that could kill it off. Their bill would create an independent commission to study the issue and make a recommendation that would be voted up or down in the future. The commission approach, as we have said, is an idea whose time has come and gone. Any lawmaker who genuinely favors reform should oppose the commission as a dangerous diversion.

title: A Peek Into Closets of Queens and Princesses
description: Trompe l'oeil murals by William Kent and ceremonial robes belonging to Queen Mary and George V are among the treasures on view at the newly revamped State Apartments and Ceremonial Dress Collection in Kensington Palace, in London. The rooms reopened this month after a two-year, $5.1 million restoration.

title: Fresh Face to Wake Up 'Good Morning'
description: When Kevin Newman was called into the office of the ABC News president, David Westin, in March, he thought he was going to be admonished for some gaffe he might have made as the news anchor of ''Good Morning America.''

title: Thinking on His Feet
description: A WALK IN THE WOODS

title: Warren Beatty Is Trying to Say Something
description: With white, liberal friends like Warren Beatty, the black underclass needs no racist enemies (''Warren Beatty Is Trying to Say Something,'' by Lynn Hirschberg, May 10). Beatty's apotheosis of gangsta rap as a viable expression of black aspirations parallels his reported advice to Gary Hart to re-enter the 1988 Democratic primaries, after the politically lethal Donna Rice episode.

title: Aircraft Noise Plans Don't Go Far Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Williams, Mr. Schoenfeld
description: Suzanne Lyn Williams, a daughter of Andrea and Dan Raymond Williams of Ridgewood, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Eric William Schoenfeld, a son of Gloria and Herbert Schoenfeld of Massapequa Park, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Applestone is to officiate at the Hermitage, a historic house in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. The Rev. Mike Pulsifer, a Presbyterian minister, is to take part in the service.

title: Correspondence / Reporter in Wonderland; A Darker View of American Politics Through an Irish Looking Glass
description: TALK about political culture shock. A day after votes were counted in the Northern Ireland peace referendum, I flew from Belfast to San Francisco to catch the final week of the California primary campaign. After a month immersed in the low-tech modesty of Irish politics (and writing about it for The New York Times), I was greeted at the airport by an electronic stand-in for the Mayor and chief municipal showboat, Willie Brown Jr. In a message that boomed from above, and over and over, in the international arrivals terminal, Mr. Brown introduced himself and welcomed each and every visitor (and prospective voter) to what he grandly called ''my city.''

title: Avoiding That Sinking Feeling
description: Uncharted waters. That's where United States equity investors found themselves last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, RENEE
description: GREENBERG-Renee. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with profound sorrow the death of Renee Greenberg, a very special lady whose life was filled with achievement. We extend our sincere sympathy to her devoted and loving husband, Irving, valued and respected member of the Home's extended family, her children and grandchildren. We hope that your loving memories of Renee will help to ease your sorrow during this time of sadness. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec. V.P.

title: Hearing Damage
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathryn Williams, Daniel Fitzgerald
description: Kathryn Lea Williams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Williams of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel John Fitzgerald, the son of Daniel Fitzgerald of New Canaan and the late Barbara Fitzgerald. The Rev. Lidabell Lunt Pollard performed the ceremony at the New Canaan Congregational Church.

title: Bracing for the Next Club
description: It would seem difficult for a nightclub deep in a hotel basement on a busy, noisy corner of Broadway to become notorious. But for much of its 13 years, the China Club, at 75th Street, was just that. The major problems, angry residents said, were the many cars roaming for scant parking space, the milling crowds and violence, such as the shooting of two clubgoers in May 1997.

title: Style; It's a Stretch
description: Last week a friend of mine gave a party for her neck. Through the years it had grown worn and thick with the burdens of rubbernecking, bottlenecking and holding her head high. Recently it had developed a crepey wattle, which my friend took as a conspicuous sign that she would either be served up for Thanksgiving dinner or that the A.A.R.P. would soon be leaving its calling card. In the latter case, arthritis, Social Security and early-bird specials would surely follow.

title: Public Relations Firm Helps the Disabled
description: IS helping people with disabilities any way to build a public relations company? Susan and Robert Cole think so. When the Coles started Cole Communications, they did it with the understanding that they would devote a third of their practice to working with organizations serving people with disabilities.

title: Q. & A.
description: Tax Break On Selling A Home

title: Williamsburg
description: To the Editor: As we read and enjoyed the article about Williamsburg, we thought of a future visit with our now 4-year-old child.

title: Trump Buying The Landmark G.M. Building
description: In a deal reminiscent of the high-flying 1980's, Donald Trump and an Indianapolis insurance company have purchased the General Motors Building in midtown Manhattan for $800 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, CHARLES
description: FRANKEL-Charles, 81. Beloved husband of 50 years to Constance. Devoted father of Sherry and Van. Cherished grandfather of Troy, Tara and Daniel. Brother of Margaret and David. Services Monday at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. He was an attorney, loungewear manufacturer, and avid collector of jazz and swing music.

title: The View From/Scarsdale; A Place Where the Jazz, and the Patrons, Are Taken Seriously
description: IT was one day after Frank Sinatra died, and people were clamoring for his music. In the sleek August Restaurant and Lounge, a new jazz club and restaurant here, patrons gathered around little black tables topped with flickering candles and asked for songs he had made famous.

title: New Housing Favors Manhattan In Uneven Pattern
description: CITY COUNCILMAN ARCHIE SPIGNER wanders through the streets of southeast Queens these days and marvels at the scatterburst of new housing that has been or is being built -- even in neighborhoods that were struggling only a decade or so ago.

title: The Reverent And the Less So
description: LAUDA CHAMBER SINGERS, a 45-voice chorus directed by Charles Walker, plans to introduce a new piece at its concert next Sunday. ''Three Solemn Words,'' composed for Passion Week by Michael Hegeman, a doctoral candidate at Princeton Theological Seminary, is to have its premiere in the elegant company of Tallis, Elgar and Palestrina, among others.

title: Beverly Hills 11968
description: PHILISTINES AT THE HEDGEROW

title: Streetscapes/Starrett-Lehigh Building; Time of Change for a Modern Industrial Landmark
description: THE 1932 Starrett-Lehigh Building, considered a landmark of modern industrial architecture, occupies a full block just north of the Chelsea Piers sports complex. Owned by Leona Helmsley, it is up for sale. Potential buyers have submitted sealed bids, and with the decline of New York industry and the resurgence of Chelsea, the building could be reconfigured for office or back-office space.
